column2: Unearthing in Antioch, Syria, of a unique series of mosaic floors which furnish a history of painting from the first to the sixth century after Christ will be announced at the annual meeting of the Archaeological Institute of America at Philadelphia Tuesday by Dr. F. O.

The Maple Leafs took an undisputed lead in the National Hockey League's international division and the Detroit Red Wings broke a fivegame losing streak tonight as they battled overtime to a 1-1 tie before a crowd of 13,200.

After phenomenal development the year before, skiing was curtailed during the past Winter because of the vagaries of the weather. Throughout the nation's snow belt the stage had been set for a great season, with only heavy snowfalls needed to complete a glowing picture and bring delight to thousands of Winter sports devotees.

Announcement. has been made of the engagement of Miss Mary Louise Andrews, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Percy Chester Andrews of this city, to James Lafayette Marks Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Marks of Saltsburg, Pa.
The major problems of the new year, which is just around the corner, may be left to one side for a little while. Prophecy about major problems is a risky, business at best.
A new stage in the Horner-Courtney, KellyNash warfare was begun last week when the Chicago City Council, by a vote of 43 to 4, adopted an ordinance to license the operation of handbooks.
Watertown (N. Y.) High School routed Clearwater High, 48 to 0, in an intersectional holiday gridiron encounter today that saw the invaders score twice before making a first down.

The dominant figure in the game for longer than any one can remember, the New York Athletic Club won both soft-ball .and hard-ball national indoor water-polo championships during the past year to remain supreme in this roughaquatic sport.

Mrs. E.- H. Bartlett's 5-year-old Zevson, who seldom finishes out of the money, recorded his ninth victory of 1937 today in the $2,000 added Christmas Handicap at the Fair Grounds. Top weighted at 113 pounds, Zevson came from behind with a rush in the stretch -and won by a comfortable margin from Mrs. S. Orr's Hope Eternal, who nosed out the Shady Brook Farm's Visigoth in a photo finish for the place.

A long and interesting horse show season reached its height in the fifty-second National in Madison Square Garden in November. It was one of the most successful exhibitions in the long history of the association and one of its best from almost any angle.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Stephanie Jane Maresco, daughter of Mrs. Paul J. Maresco of this place and the late Mr. Maresco of Buenos Aires, Argentina, to John LeFoy Brouwer 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ogden Brouwer Jr. of Montclair.

Mr. and Mrs. Clifford H. Walker gave a tea today at their home in Waban at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Walker, to James Rogers Leech, son of Mrs. James W. Leech of Providence, R. I., and the late Dr. Leech.

Gifts amounting to $6,966,52 came into the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday from 513 contributors, and brought its total in this twentysixth annual appeal to $265,111.28. Despite this evidence that the spirit of Christmas moves the hearts of many persons to take compassion on afflicted men,

The mandates of the undistributed profits surtax in effect disavow the sound reasoning heretofore employed by the courts and the Board of Tax Appeals in respect to the rights of corporations to build up and maintain proper and adequate surpluses.

The distinction of winning the first national A. U. horseshoepitching championship fell to the lot of John Lindmeier of Oak Park, Ill., who captured the crown by defeating Walter W. Lane of Anderson, Ind., 55-37 and 51-18. The final was. staged on rain-soaked courts in Cincinnati.

Members of the New York unit of the Women's Overseas Service League will hold their annual Christmas party at the Soldiers' and Sailors' Club, 283 Lexington Avenue on Tuesday evening. The program will be reminiscent of the 'World War days.

The Samoan Clipper landed here today at 3:57 P. M. [11:27 P. M. Saturday, Eastern standard time], completing the last phase of her flight from Honolulu to the southern terminus of a new ocean airline.

The forum series of lectures and debates of which the Temple Israel Union is sponsor, for the benefit of the Temple Israel Union Summer camp fund for children of the East Side sabbath school, was announced yesterday.

Tris 'Speaker,' former' manager of the Indians and one of baseball's greatest outfielders, announced today he had accepted the .chairmanship of the executive .committee in charge of the annual Tornament conducted by - the -National Semi-Pro Baseball Congre.
By different routes several of the smaller European States are endeavoring to reach the same goal-freedom from obligations that might involve them in the quarrels of their more powerful neighbors.

A grandmother's Christmas duties occupied Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt today. She devotde a large part of the day helping to open packages and to make toys work for her grandchildren, Curtis and Eleanor Dall, at the home of their mother and stepfather, Mr. and Mrs. John Boettiger.

NUMEROUS short operatic works, some of them not performed to date in this country, will be presented by the London Intimate Opera Company, which opens its first American season Jan. 4 at the Little Theatre.

The annual boneftt garden Ieoture sponsored by the Woman's Aueilfef{ of the Brooklyn Botanlo Garden will have for their speaker this year Mrs. Constance Spry of London, England's foremost flower decorator, who will make her first appearance in this country on these occasions.

The Board of Superintendents announced last week that applications for the position of principal at Bay Ridge High School and Wadleigh High School are now being considered. Applications must be filed with Associate Superintendent Jacob Greenberg by Jan. 3. These positions are open to women only.

Sheriff Arthur Quigley of Wayne County said today that he believed two former convicts made the crude and unsuccessful Christmas Eve attempt to extort $3,800 from John L. Bryan, bank cashier, by carrying 3-year-old Donald Bryan, his only son, his wife, a nurse and a grocery clerk from the Bryan home in two automobiles.

Mrs. Louis M. Gillette of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Doris Gillette, to William A. Meyerhoff, son of Mrs. William F. Meyerhoff of Ridgewood, N. J., and the late Mr. Meyerhoff.

Throughout Christmas Day, under gray skies and a steady rain, British troops fought a fierce battle with rebels in the hills of Galilee. One officer of a border regiment and two soldiers were Injured slightly, bringing British casualties since the fight started Thursday to five.

The new steamship Consuelo, which was recently built in England for the transatlantic trade of the Ellerman's Wilson Line, is due to reach New York Tuesday on her maiden crossing, it was announced yesterday. She will proceed to her berth at Seventh Street, Hoboken, where she will be inspected by shippers.

The subdued note upon which Great Britain's financial year ends contrasts strikingly with the high hopes of pronounced activity with which it opened. Everything went well in the first quarter. The expansion of business,

Harold W. Hastings, who was defeated as the Democratic candidate for District Attorney in the last elections by Thomas E. Dewey, enters private practice on Jan. 1 as a member of the newly formed law firm of Hastings Aranow at 84 William Street.

Demands for the blind and indiscriminate cutting of public budgets seldom get anywhere and seldom should get anywhere. Public expenditures are like private investments-some are good, some bad, some pay a profit and some do not. A sensible economy lies in distinguishing between the two and eliminating the bad and unprofitable expenditures.
Race followers at Oriental Park had a dizzy time of it in the first race today when jockeys with the same surname, Fernandez, rode the first three horses.

Mrs. Ashleigh Drake Halliwell of Halliwell Drive, Stamford, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Eleanor Andrews Barrett, to Giles Newton Montgomery, son of the Rev. Dr. George Redington Montgomery and the late Mrs. Montgomery of Stamford.

The New York State Journal of Medicine will carry an editorial in its January issue exhorting physicians to oppose any plan to bring medicine "under the control of a political bureaucracy." The editorial, headed "Organized Medicine Resolves." says:

The housing of Negroes in the cities and towns of this country is described as a "disgrace to any nation" in a message that has been sent to churches by the Department of Race Relations of the Federal Council of Churches, it was announced yesterday. The sixteenth annual Race Relations Sunday will be observed on Feb. 13.

Handicapped by the absence of the injured Cecil Smith, the Texas Rangers' polo team lost an 8-to-7 overtime decision to the Mexican Army riders today, for the Americans' only setback in the threegame series.

The index of French wholesale prices on Dec. 18 stood at 596, compared with 594 a week before and with 593 two weeks earlier. The gold price index of raw materials was 44.7, compared with 44.9 a week before and with 45.2 two weeks before.
Yesterday, and in extreme cases today, should be declared an official holiday as National Recovery From Christmas
Of 1,469 applicants who took the October bar examination, 693 passed, the State Board of Law Examiners announced today, making public the list of the successful applicants.

Senator Byrd, a member of the Finance Committee, who is preparing a plan of his own for government reorganization, warned in a statement today against the proposal in the Administration's reorganization plan to eliminate the office of Controller General.

In the pretty little town of Cahirciveen, County Kerry, this morning Councilmanelect Michael J. Quill of New York married Miss Mollie O'Neill. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Hugh Keane in the Daniel O'Connell Memorial Church.
Carmen A. Battaglia, inventor and jewelry designer, announced here today a novel Christmas gift for mankind-a method of "deshining" trousers.

Still another college went down to defeat last week and the ranks of unbeaten basketball teams in the metropolitan district are now reduced to three. N. Y. U. and C. C. N. Y. came through the week unscathed while L. I. U. was the latest city team to drop from the unbeaten list. Columbia, which was

The Federal Trade Commission has issued an order against the Fox-Weis Company, Philadelphia, a distributor of furs and fur coats, directing it to stop certain practices regarded as unfair methods of competition, the commission announced today.

Shooting under good conditions, the North Jersey Gun Club held its regular competition today. In the first fifty-target event E. Jacobus won the high-gun trophy, W. T. Woodward, Mrs. W. B. Wolf, R. Rhode and J. L. Flagg taking handicap prizes.

After asserting that not abstractions but persons have the most profound influence on individuals, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive, declared in his sermon yesterday morning that "all the great reforms in the Christian church have come from the rediscovery of Jesus."

Discussing the sterility of the special session of Congress in the United States, writers here say that President Roosevelt has found himself between two fires in attempting to offer a compromising tax and a furtherance of his social policy under the unpropitious conditions of the trade setback.

The biennial report of Joseph D. Basson, president of the Moving Picture Machine Operators Union. Local 306, reviews a two-year effort to overcome "the general loss of prestige and public respect which the local had suffered at the hands of prior administrations."

Dr. Lawrason Brown, one of the leading tuberculosis specialists and teachers in the United States, died early today after an illness of several months following an attack of pneumonia last Spring. He was 66 years of age.

Dr. Norris A. Brisco, dean of the New York University School of Retailing, and Mrs. Brisco gave a tea at their home here this afternoon at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Brisco, to David Hamlin of East Bloomfield, N. Y., son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur S. Hamlin, also of Summit.

Miss Frances Cohen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Cohen of New York, was married here this afternoon in Temple Emanu-El to Julius Cinamon. son of Mrs. Joseph Cinamon of this city, and the late Mr. Cinamon. The Rev. Max Zucker

Current pagan ideas and modern persecutors of Christians will go down to defeat like their ancient predecessors, the Rev. Charles O'Connor Sloane predicted. yesterday in a sermon at St.. Patrick's Cathedral.

National banks will be permitted, under an amendment to Regulation F announced today by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, to invest funds of various individual trusts in participation in a common trust fund, provided the amount invested from any one trust does not exceed $25,000, or 10 per cent of the value of the assets of the common trust fund, whichever amount is less.
British troops and airplanes engaged in fighting rebel bands in the hills of Galilee, Northern Palestine, continued to search out the recalcitrants today.

Robert Irwin, charged with firstdegree murder, will never stand trial for the triple slaying of Mrs. Mary Gedeon, her daughter Veronica, and a boarder named Frank Byrnes in the Gedeon home, it was indicated yesterday.

The revised reorganization plan for the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company, now before the Federal District Court, was criticized today by the Bureau of Municipal Research as providing for no increased benefits to the city.

Mrs. Bonnibel Remington Nash, wife of Luther Roberts Nash, vice president of the Stone Webster Engineering Corporation, died yesterday at her residence in the Hotel Lexington. She was born in Norwich, Conn., a daughter of Franklin B. Remington of the wholesale grocery firm of B. F. Thurber Co.
Frank L. Duley, educator and former member of the American Consular Service, died today in the Addison Gilbert Hospital here after two weeks' treatment for a heart ailment. His age was 65.

ADAMS--Purser Elder, on Dec. 25, 1937, formerly lieutenant 308th Infantry, Seventy-seventh Division. Funeral services at the Campbell Funeral Church, Broadway and 66th St., Monday, Dec. 27, 8:30 P. M Interment Tuesday, Arlington Cemetery, Virginia.

A plea for sympathy and prayer for the blindly obedient Japanese people was voiced by Dr. Francis Cho Min Wei, president of Central China College, Wuchang, in outlining a plan of action for American Christians interested in the Far East crisis yesterday morning at Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Tenth Street.

Old Uncle Ned's banjo has gone where the good darkies do not go. Some vandal has cut away the bronze banjo that Uncle Ned held so long on the statue in Highland Park, erected in honor of Stephen Collins Foster.

Represented by teams of four players each, New York University, City College, Columbia, Cornell, Brooklyn College and Yeshiva College will compete in the annual tournament of the Intercollegiate Chess League, beginning at 10 A. M. today at the Manhattan Chess Club in the Hotel Alamac, the scene of the memorable international tournament of 1924. N. Y. U. is the

The appointment of V. A. Nikonoff as Soviet Minister to Norway was announced today. He succeeds Ignati Yakubovitch, who was not mentioned in the announcement and was believed involved in the current "purge" of the Russian diplomatic service.

The American Association for the Advancement of Science, which will open America's annual "Parliament of Science" here tomorrow, will consider far-reaching initial steps aiming to unite the scientists of the world's democratic countries into an articulate body of organized knowledge.

Mr. and Mrs. John A. Waite of Bridgewater, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Belden Waite, to Charles Gilbert Lincoln, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond G. Lincoln of West Hartford.
How many ball games will Bob Feller, rated by some critics as a major disappointment of 1937, win for the Indians in 1938?
Walter D. Hood, for many years a member of the State Board of Education and for nearly thirty years, until he retired last June, principal of the Gilbert School, died yesterday at the age of 65.

The Tariff Commission said today that the Philippine Independence Act, though not likely to change the economic life of the United States, "will undoubtedly play a major part in altering the economy of the Philippines by changing the duty-free status of trade between the two."

The wholesale market was quiet last week as retailers concentrated on the pre-Christmas selling rush. Apparel orders were chiefly for formals at all price ranges, with sheers still leading in popularity.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Marie Louise Smith of this city, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. James Smith 3d of Newark, N. J., and Asheville, N. C., to Louis Sutherland Allen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Leach Allen of New York and Westhampton, L. I.

A sharp advance in the price of hogs last week had relatively little effect on lard futures on the Board of Trade here, although futures moved up, with commission houses buying moderately and packing interests generally on the selling side, hedging against the current make of lard.

The net revenue received by the United States Treasury from the Panama Canal during the fiscal year which ended on June 30, 1937, totaled $13,136,585.23, as compared with $14,531,654.54 in the preceding year, according to the annual report made to the War Department by Governor C. S. Ridley of the Canal Zone.

The financial success of the Cotton Bowl game New Year's Day is assured, its backers reported today, and with Rice and Colorado nearing top condition, it's squarely up to the weather man to provide the perfect setting.
James King Steele, author and lecturer, died last night of a heart attack. His age was 60.

The vote to recommit the Wage-anaHour Bill should be highly reassuring to business. The bill in the form recommended by the House Labor Committee would have caused disruption in many industries. It would have increased unemployment and the relief burden. It would in effect have erected a tariff
Premier George Tatarescu today submitted his Cabinet's resignation to King Carol. His Liberal party lost control of the Chamber of Deputies in last Monday's elections.

Thomas E. Dewey, who will take office as District Attorney next Sunday. announced yesterday that three important assignments in his office would go to three of his chief assistants on the present special rackets prosecution staff.

Service on the I. R. T. subway and elevated lines was halted for two minutes at 2 P. M. yesterday during the funeral services for George H. Pegram, chief engineer for the I. R. T. for thirtytwo years, who died Thursday.
The Auburn Plainsmen will return to Drake Field tomorrow to resume training for their Orange Bowl game with Michigan State in Miami New Year's day.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry Charles Murphy gave a tea yesterday afternoon at their home, 51 Montgomery Place, Brooklyn, for their daughter, Miss Doris Wilson Murphy, who made her debut at the Brooklyn Debutante Ball on Thanksgiving Eve.

Effective Jan. 1, a 5 per cent pay rise will be granted the entire staff of the Hotel Edison, according to announcement by Max J. Kramer, president. This is the second increase declared within the last year.

Dr. William Ernest Graham, expert chemist of the National Research Council laboratories here and well-known for his research work in the tanning and leather industries, died in a hospital Saturday of an injury suffered a week ago. His age was 38.

Mr. and Mrs. D. Leslie Hodgens of 905 East Eighteenth Street, Brooklyn, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Hodgens, to Howard Eldred Stephenson, son of Mrs. Eldred Stephenson of Milwaukee, Wis., and of Grant Thomas Stephenson of Pebble Beach, Calif.

Sharp issue with the theory held in some government circles that an "economy of scarcity" will bring prosperity to agriculture was taken by the agricultural committee of the United States Chamber of Commerce in a report issued today.

Miss Jane Kessler, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George L. Kessler of Brooklyn, has completed plans for her marriage to Ira Kendall Hearn Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ira K. Hearn of Norfolk, Va., which will take place at noon on Jan. 5 in the Bedford Presbyterian Church, Brooklyn. The ceremony will be performed by the Rev. George W. Arms.
William J. Smith, lawyer, died yesterday at his home, 262 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn, after an illness of several months. He was 62 years old.

About 6,000,000 weekly checks will be distributed next year to an estimated total of 930,000 qualified applicants for unemployment insurance benefits in this State, according to forecasts made public last night by the division of placement and unemployment insurance of the State Labor Department.

The Public Welfare Council of Knoxville passed a resolution today asking a Congressional investigation of the purchase of marble and mineral leases in the TVA Norris Dam area by Senator George L. Berry and others.

Uniformed police "volunteers" at the "request" of Mayor S. Davis Wilson continued today a door-to-door canvass in behalf of the Mayor's campaign against a new lease of the city-owned gas works to the United Gas Improvement Company.

Miss Ruth Norma Benjamin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob A. Benjamin of Jackson Heights, Queens, was married there yesterday afternoon at the Jewish Center to Joseph Tropp, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob A. Tropp of Brooklyn.

For the third successive week, prices of cotton made moderate gains last week. This was the first time since last March that cotton prices had moved upward for three weeks in a row. At the close on Friday, prices for active future deliveries on the New York Cotton
Albert Watson, 49 years old, formerly of Philadelphia, who was serving a State prison term of ten to fifteen years, escaped today from State Prison Farm here.

The Josiah Macy Jr. Foundation, established in 1930 by Mrs. Walter G. Ladd with a fund of $5,000,000, issued its first report yesterday, disclosing grants of $806,681 to many universities and agencies for better integration of special branches of medicine and the more effective application of the art of medicine to human welfare.

The French Senate today cut short its Christmas holidays to discuss the budget, during which Finance Minister Georges Bonnet reiterated his confidence in France's economic future, revealing that the influx of gold had brought 10,000,000,000 francs back to the Bank of France's vaults in the last few months.

In all tne rinancial and commercial markets here business this week fell to a minimum, owing to Christmas and the nearness of the year-end. Sentiment, especially in the stock markets, has been marked by a quiet confidence.

C. G. Wright, with 77-13-64, captured first prize in the fifth qualifying round of the twenty-ninth annual Sno Birds' golf tournament at Siwanoy today. Thirty-one were in the starting field, six failing to turn in cards.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Franklin Pritchard of Green Hill Farm, this place, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Pritchard, to M. Gilbert Barnes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Goffe Phipps Barnes of New Haven.

The rush to Lake Placid for Winter sports during the holiday season begins today. Among the activities on the schedule will be public riding on the Olympic bobsled run, skiing at Scotts Cobble Ski Center, and short novice ski trips to Connery Pond and Indian Pass.
A special New Year's Eve "whoopee" service was announced today by the Boston Maine Railroad.

The turnover of currency in Great Britain was never so great as at present. This is evident from a further rise of [Pound]7,361,211 in the Bank of England's circulation to a new high record of ?509,315,646. The largest circulation recorded previously was the
Eight American sea fliers trimmed their nineteen-ton sky clipper today in preparation for the inauguration next Wednesday of a new transpacific airline linking the Antipodes with the United States.
The Irish-Americans, before a crowd of enthusiastic soccer fans at Clark's Field, today defeated the New York Americans by 2 to 1 in an American League match. At half time the home team led, 1-0.
No more homework for school kiddies, says Principal Dale W. Houk. Under his new program at Pittsburgh's Forest Hills Junior High School emphasis will be placed on study instead of recitation.

A shiny pair of G-man handcuffs held greater fascination today than a half-dozen dolls for Buffalo's babein-toyland foundling, still unclaimed eighteen days after she was abandoned on the toy counter in a department store.

The State Department at Washington is seeking assurances that Mexico will slow her "Mexicanization" of industry campaign, which has been extremely harmful to United States companies, as well as other unnamed guarantees of future conduct regarding property of Americans, it was said here today-on excellent authority.
Commercial Christmas tree cutting has grown to proportions of "murderous extravagance" and Dr. L. McDonough Gould, Seattle physician, wants to get up a society to curb it.

Miss Ellen Williams of 50 Riverside Drive has announced the engagament of her ward, Miss Marion Padilla, to Leon-Haritonoff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas B. H. Haritonoff of 39 West Sixty-seventh Street. The announcement was made at a reception held last night at the Haritonoff residence.
In one more week Alabama and California will have written the twenty-third annual chapter into the records of the Tournament of Roses football classic.
Sammy Snead of White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., loomed as the man to beat in the $4,000 Hollywood Beach open golf tournament starting tomorrow.
With Clarence (Buddy) Combs scoring 10 goals on backhand and angled drives, the Red Bank Polo Club today defeated Squadron A of New York, 15 to 10, before a large crowd at the Red Bank Armory.

At a requiem mass in St. Augustine's Church here this morning the Legitimists' new private military formation made its first appearance. This formation, called the Iron Legion, was represented by 120 men in uniform. Its task will be to protect Legitimist demonstrations against interference by Nazis or left-wing sympathizers.
Pennsylvania's relief problem was complicated further today by another sharp increase in unemployment which swelled the rolls beyond the half-million mark.

The New York Americans snapped the Boston Bruins' victory string at five straight games tonight before 13,000 at the Boston Garden. Withstanding one of the most aggressive attacks ever staged on a Boston rink, the invaders emerged with a 3-1 triumph.

Mr. and Mrs. Singer B. Irelan of Forest Hills, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Irelan, to Jack Wells Clarke, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Sydnor Clarke of Forest Hills. The prospective bride was graduated from Kew-Forest School and also attended Sweet Briar College.

" Elektra," the second opera in the Richard Strauss cycle, will be revived at the Metropolitan Opera House on Friday evening, Jan. 7. Rosa Pauly, Hungarian dramatic soprano, who arrives today on the Berengaria, will make her debut at the Metropolitan in the title role.

Miss Josephine Molinari, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Molinari of East Stanwich, Greenwich, was married today in Port Chester, N. Y., to Ingvold Olsen of Riverside, Greenwich. The ceremony was performed in the rectory of the Church of the Holy Rosary by the Rev. Aloysius Trisari.

The marriage of Miss Natalie Bernhard, daughter of Mrs. Hugo Hammer of New York, to Charles D. Brooks, also of this city, took place yesterday noon at the Hotel Elysee. The Rev. Dr. Benjamin A. Tintner performed the ceremony.

With the combined population of the fifteen institutions, including Sing Sing, under the State Department of Correction reaching the 16,000 mark for the first time in history, a census report made public today shows 16,246 offenders in these institutions, or an unprecedented gain of 290 in a month.
New England's Santa Claus of the air made a second trip today "bombing" fifty-five lonely lighthouses and fishermen's shacks from Vinal Haven, Me., to the Cape Cod Canal with Christmas packages.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amounted to $3,636,619,500. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest - bearing discount bills.

Miss Marian Ethel Shaw, daughter of the late Rev. Benjamin J. H. Shaw and Mrs. Shaw of Louth. Lincolnshire, England, and of Massachusetts, was married here to David Lawrence Pierson of this city, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Dodd Pierson of Orange, yesterday at the Hotel Alvord. The Rev. Harry L. Bowlby of East
As usual during the holidays, a number of special theatrical programs for children have been organized in and around the Times Square area. Those on view this week are:

Angna Enters and Martha Graham divided the evening between them last night, as they had done the week before, Miss Enters presenting fourteen numbers from her repertoire at the Alvin, and Miss Graham and her group giving the second of two dance recitals at the Guild, across Fifty-second Street.

The first half of the program offered by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under John Barbirolli at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon concerned itself with the repetition of works already presented at the Thursday and Friday concerts of last week.

Solomon G. Rosenbaum, merchant and philanthropist, who was president of the National Cloak and Suit Company from 1904 until his retirement from business in 1925, died yesterday of heart disease at his residence, the Hotel Dorset, 30 West Fifty-fourth Street, after an illness of three weeks. He was 69 years old.
Mayor E. W. Scott issued a proclamation today urging that every able-bodied citizen "take up arms" to check an epidemic of robberies here.
The Archbishop of Canterbury in a radio address today urged citizens of democratic nations to work as individuals to promote world peace.

The volume of freight moved by truck in November was 9.72 per cent under the volume hauled in the same month last year and 16.94 per cent below the October tonnage of this year, according to the monthly statistics made public here today by the American Trucking Associations, Inc.
The Boerse was closed here yesterday and today. Trading on the four pre-holiday days was relatively active with cheerful sentiment predominating.

A bright Christmas tree that had fascinated the two little children of Mrs. Agnes Collins played a tragic part early yesterday morning in a fire that swept the family's apartment at 322 East Thirty-fourth Street, near First Avenue, and seriously burned Mrs. Collins and the two youngsters.

Endowment of a chair for the study of love in every educational institution in America was advocated by the Rev. Dr. C. Jefferes McCombe, pastor of the Methodist Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street, in his sermon yesterday morning.

Enraged by her continued refusal to marry him, Vincent Franco, 26year-old mechanic, killed Antoinette Imperiale, 22, on a residential street here this afternoon while several dozen persons, strollers and motorists looked on and shuddered at the brutality of the murder.

The Chief Executives of Haiti and the Dominican Republic exchanged Christmastide pledges to avoid war as a means of settling recent border incidents in which thousands of Haitians were reported slain.
Leonard Romagna and Ted Clark were the winning skippers in the frostbite dinghy regatta held on Manhasset Bay today.

The United States Government has accepted the Japanese notes of Dec. 14 and of Dec. 24 as constituting an adequate reply to the American protests on the sinking of the Panay and the three Standard Oil vessels. The incident, therefore, may be considered officially closed.
On the Pepper Amendment (to the Wagner-Steagall Housing Bill) reviving Title I under which government insurance up to $2,500 would be granted for modernizing and repairing homes, adopted, 46 to 22:

Deploring the prospect of renewal of the bitter conflict between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization, Matthew Woll, vice president of the federation, declared in an interview yesterday that the A. F. of L. bore no responsibility for the breakdown of their recent peace negotiations.
When It comes to wild-life restoration, North Carolina has certainly accomplished something during the past year.

Religion is the only force that can revolutionize the world, the Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan, rector of St. James Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

Flora Campbell, actress, who has been playing the leading feminine role in the Broadway play "Many Mansions," underwent an emergency appendicitis operation yesterday afternoon in a Cleveland hospital, according to word received here last night.

Nine new national swimming records were set at a meet today. Ralph Flanagan, Olympic speedster and holder of the American mile, half mile and quarter mile crowns, bettered three marks in a 250-yard sprint over a twenty-yard course in the Miami Biltmore pool.
Morris Barasch, a former banker and insurance broker, died yesterday at his home, 436 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, following a brief illness from heart disease. His age was 59.
Playing spottily the Syracuse Stars skated to a 4-to-2 victory over the New Haven Eagles in an International-American Hockey League game today.

The engagement of Miss Dorothy Thompson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Olaf Thompson of this place, to Lawrence W. Larsen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Larsen of Port Richmond, S. I., has been announced by her parents.

Basketball fans who have been eagerly awaiting the return of Stanford with its famous Hank Luisettl will finally get their wish tonight when the Cardinals meet C. C. N. Y. at Madison Square Garden in one game of a doubleheader.

The indications are for fair weather with little change in temperature today. Tomorrow will be cloudy and somewhat warmer, probably with occasional rain, according to the map charted at the United States Weather Bureau at 7:30 o'clock last night.

The eyes of American skiers will be focused on Sun Valley in the heart of the Sawtooth Mountains of Idaho next Friday and Saturday, when two of the strongest units in the sport, Dartmouth College and the University of Washington, both with impressive records, meet in an intersectional meet.

The United States is not now "running into a major depression," Robert H. Jackson, Assistant Attorney General, asserted in a radio address tonight in which he assailed "monopolists" and "big business," blaming their policies for many of the economic ills of the past and present.
A Christmas tragedy was discovered today when Alpine peasants near the Austrian frontier found the wreckage of a French air liner and three bodies half covered with snow.

A family of three and their two guests were taken to Jamaica Hospital suffering from ptomaine poisoning yesterday after eating a turkey dinner. The meal included spaghetti and tomato sauce, the sauce being prepared from powdered tomatoes. None of the victims is seriously ill.
A Spanish Government communique tonight declared the last centers of. Insurgent resistance in Teruel were in flames and a third citadel captured.

Christmas messages taking President Roosevelt and Mayor La Guardia to task because of their housing policies and chiding Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City for his method of law enforcement were interspersed among Christmas carols at
The Rev. Dr. Christian F. Reisner praised Mayor La Guardialast night for "ignoring the unjust charges" of labor unions against Police Inspector Harry L. Lobdell.

The fourday business week before Christmas was eventless here, with the exception of the new Reich social insurance law, which, like Col. Gen. Hermann Goering's decree prescribing wage payments for holidays, seems designed to compensate industrial employes for privations arising from the rise in the cost of living and the scarcity of necessaries.
A representative field of 130 will start play today in the annual national junior and boys' indoor tennis championships at the Seventh Regiment Armory. The tournament,
Minnie, the singing mouse, ends her first year as a radio performer on Tuesday with $1,000 earned. As a grandmother, she promises to make more

The Atlantic Monthly Press reports that it has already received 100 manuscripts in 'the sixth Atlantic $10,000 Prize Novel Contest, which closes Feb. 1, 1938. The first Atlantic Prize Novel was "Jalna," by Mazo de la Roche. Others have been "Peking Picnic," by Ann

The report of the National Power and Light Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Nov. 30, issued for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $8,911,362 after all expences and charges.

Funeral services for Dr. Isadore Goldstein, ophthalmic surgeon of Mount Sinai Hospital, were held yesterday in Temple B'nai Jeshurun, 257 West Eighty-eighth Street. In his eulogy Rabbi Israel Goldstein called Dr. Goldstein a "true scientist," and praised his teaching and activities in Jewish affairs.
Enrico Venturi, European lightweight champion, will meet Billy Lee of Nevada in the star bout of eight rounds at the St. Nicholas Palace tonight. Venturi is to box

The housing division committee of the seventeenth annual Women's National Exposition of Arts and Industries will occupy the entire main floor of the Grand Central Palace during the week of March 28-April 2, when exhibits of architects, building material companies, contracting builders, landscape architects and operative builders will be shown.

The Minister of Foreign Affairs announces the promulgation of a new set of regulations designed to facilitate the entrance of tourists and all travelers at the port of Callao. The regulations will go into effect immediately permitting passengers to reach the capital forty-five minutes after leaving the ship.

An improvement in the buying of steel is expected in the opening weeks of the New Year, according to the magazine Steel. The review points out that consumers have delayed orders as much as possible, in order to limit inventories, but that they are expected to place orders when the turn of the year is passed.
Sergeant James Huntington of Great Meadows prison announced tonight that two prisoners had escaped from that institution.

Encouraged by reports of excellent skiing. 200 Winter sportsmen and sportswomen, all that could be accommodated because of the limited holiday facilities, left last night on the Saks Fifth Avenue Laurentian Special for the snowy slopes and wooded trails that abound in the popular region extending from Piedmont to Ste. Jovite in Canada.

The government freed 120 Protestant pastors from prison for Christmas. The charges against them will be dropped. The decree was signed by Chancellor Hitler on Christmas Eve and became effective today.

The home of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Machoksy on Searingtown Road, this village, was bare of Christmas joy yesterday, but today the family, consisting of the couple and their six children, sat down to a hot turkey dinner obtained through policemen attached to the Third Precinct at Mineola, who learned that the family had had nothing to eat for three days.
A major penalty cost the New York Rangers a game last night. With Lynn Patrick sitting on the sidelines for five minutes in the second period, the Chicago Black Hawks scored two goals.
Clarence S. Stein, the architect, and his wife, Aline McMahon, the actress, plan a new home at Yorktown Heights, N. Y., where they have purchased an estate of thirtyone acres. The property is on

Allowing for the differences between American and British outlook and tradition, differences more palpable as the two countries become superficially alike, there is an odd similarity between the background and temperament of Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden and President' Roosevelt.
The new liquidity of the banks has conduced to cheerful sentiment in financial circles and it is predicted that the new 1,000,000,000-mark Reich loan will be oversubscribed.

More new industries were acquired and there were more industrial expansions in Los Angeles County in 1937 than in any other year since 1930. More than 13,000 new jobs and the addition of approximately $15,000,000 to payrolls resulted from this development.
Edward S. Lewis of New York, former president of The St. Louis Star, now The Star-Times, died of a heart attack late last night in St. John's Hospital, at the age of 89.

Burgoyne Hamilton, president of the real estate company bearing his name and a leader in the fight against prohibition, died suddenly of coronary thrombosis at 2:30 A. M. yesterday at his Winter residence in the Hotel Ambassador. His age was 55.
Robert W. Bender, 41, publisher of The Juneau (Alaska) Daily Empire and son-in-law of Governor Joseph W. Troy of Alaska, was found dead today in a hotel bathroom.

The list of the motorship Santa Barbara of the Grace Line, due to arrive today from Chile, Peru and Ecuador, includes Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Knox, F. S. Von Stade Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Harold M. Randall, Mr. and Mrs. Jose Ignacio Chopitea and Dr. and Mrs. Gerardo Lozado.
Unemployment insurance will cost employers more after New Year's Day. The tax on payrolls will increase from 2 per cent to a permanent 3 per cent, Social Security Board officials said today.
Paul T. Dowling, executive editor of The Toronto Globe and Mail, died at his Muskoka district home today after a short illness. He would have been 48 years old tomorrow.

From the social point of view of the French people, the year 1937 is not finishing much more favorably than did 1936. From the financial point of view, progress has been accomplished in reducing the budget deficit by means of fresh taxes, higher tariffs and a cut in expenses applied by the government last Summer. Nevertheless,

Miss Ruth Rosenberger, daughter of Mrs. Benjamin Rosenberger of 260 West Seventy-second Street and the late Mr. Rosenberger, was married to Maurice G. Cornell, son of Mrs. Simon Cornell of New Haven, Conn., and the late Mr. Cornell, yesterday afternoon at the Hyde Park Hotel, 25 East Seventy-seventh Street.
BELLER--STERN--Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Stern, 697 West End Ave., announce the marriage of their daughter, Alvin Marie, to Mr. Albert Beller on Dec. 24, 1937.

Joe Louis, world heavyweight champion, is accorded the distinction of the game's No. 1 place in the twelfth annual world ranking of boxers by The Ring Magazine, which will publish the ratings in a copyrighted article in its February issue. The results of a poll of every

Featureless trading prevailed last week in the world's wheat markets. Speculation was restricted greatly by the approaching holidays, and there was nothing in the news to cause operators to take a decided stand on either side.
Holiday season having come around again, the Shuberts have put together their usual operetta, "Three Waltzes," which they feared at the Majestic Saturday evening.

Mayorelect Thomas L. Holling, who early the morning after his election made a surprise tour of City Hall and "found hardly any one at work," announced today that he would remedy the situation on taking office.

Though mortality from the disease has been reduced 25 per cent in the last fifteen years, pneumonia still takes an annual toll of 100,000 lives in the United States, according to statistics made public yesterday by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

Lady Astor, on a visit here today, declared that a great problem before Britain and America was to provide better living conditions for underprivileged children from 2 to 7 years of age. In England, she said, open-air nursery schools were being established.

A series of dramatized exmbits presenting the latest scientific and medical knowledge about cancer, diabetes, heart disease, tuberculosis and other ailments that frequently cause death will be a feature of the New York World's Fair, it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation.

The Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York urged yesterday that the differences between the Postoffice Department and the New York Mail and Newspaper Transportation Company be adjusted, so the pneumatic mail tube which the company operates can continue its forty-year service.
The Bronx Tigers of the Eastern Hockey league held the Baltimore Orioles scoreless for all but the final period tonight, then withstood a last-minute onslaught to win 4 to 3.

The engagement of Miss Ellin Lenahan, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Hugh James Lenahan of the place, to Peter J. Quinn, son of Mrs. Peter J. Quinn of Bloomfield, N. J., and the late Mr. Quinn, has been announced by her parents.
Mr. and Mrs. John Kean Roosevelt gave a dinner last night at their home, 804 Fifth Avenue, for their daughter, Miss Virginia Roosevelt, and later took their guests to a theatre.
A sharp decline in the number of alcoholic cases admitted to Bellevue Hospital over the Christmas week-end as compared with last year was announced last night by hospital officials.
Announcement was made here last night of the death yesterday of heart disease at his Winter residence in Hamilton, Bermuda, of Richard Peabody of 465 Park Avenue.

The long trek that began last July in Central City, Col., and has since included thirteen other towns, brings "A Doll's House" to the Morosco tonight. It is Jed Harris's revival of the Ibsen play, in a new acting version prepared by Thornton Wilder, and with Ruth Gordon, Dennis King, Paul Lukas and Sam Jaffe in the leading roles. Mr. Harris has, of course, also directed.
The bodies of seven inmates were recovered today from one wing of the government insane asylum near:ClermontFerrand, which was destroyed by fire during the night.

Telegrams of condolence from Postmaster General James A. Farley, Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. of New York State, Frank V. Kelly, Democratic leader of Brooklyn, and from many judges and other persons in public life were received yesterday at the home of United States Attorney Leo J. Hickey, at 59 Rutland Road, Brooklyn. where Mr. Hickey died early Saturday.

Twenty-six honor students of the School of Technology at. City College have been elected to Chi Alpha Pi, honorary engineering fraternity, according to an announcement yesterday by Dean Frederick Skene.

Frederick Barber Campbell, prominent lawyer and clubman, of 112 East Seventieth Street, died of a heart attack yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Club, 1 East Sixtieth Street. He was in his seventieth year.

Dr. William W. Brooke, a surgeon and member of a family dating back to the Mayflower, died yesterday at his home, 915 Avenue C, Bayonne, N. J., of a compound fracture of the skull. He had been health officer of Bayonne for twenty years.

Reports of snow in mid-Pacific and "ice and gale conditions" off the California coast today caused Pan American Airways to postpone for twenty-four hours the flight of the China Clipper from Honolulu to Alameda with motion picture films of the U. S. S. Panay bombing.
Defeating A. C. Cass in thirtyseven moves, Frank J. Marshall, champion of the Marshall Chess Club, yesterday gained another point in the club's annual title tournament. By advancing all of

George S. Wheat, vice president and director of the United Aircraft Corporation, died at his estate here today after having apparently recovered from an operation only a few weeks ago. He was 51 years old.

Mr. and Mrs. Auguste Richard and Mrs. Winthrop Ames will give a dinner dance tonight in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis to introduce their daughters, Miss Harriett L. Richard and Miss Catherine H. Ames. Mrs. Alfred C. Chapin will return to the Drake today from Washington, D. C.
Premier Camille Chautemps and his Cabinet checked off one victory today as they worked to stem widespread sit-in strikes for wage and hour adjustments.

Secretary Hull is arranging to devote much of 1938 to the negotiation of trade agreements. The new year, he believes, will prove the most important in this move since the first such agreement was signed with Cuba in 1934.

A program initiated by the Indians themselves to carry through the Blackfeet irrigation project as a means of placing the Blackfeet Tribe on a self-supporting basis has been approved by John Collier, Indian Commissioner, it was announced today.

The total traffic on rapid transit, bus and street railway lines operating within the city limits for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1937, amounted to 3,121,000,000 passengers, according to a report made public yesterday by the Transit Commission. This was an increase of 82,900,000, or 2.7 per cent over the preceding fiscal year.

An additional contribution of $25,000 to the United Hospital Campaign from the Davison Fund, established by John D. Rockefeller Jr., was announced last night by John W. Davis, campaign chairman. A gift of $30,000 from the fund was reported earlier in the campaign.
Stocks irregular in moderately active trading; turnover, 5,723,513 shares. United States Government bonds higher, other issues teady and mixed; transactions, $40,286,025.

Herbert H. Foster of 717 Dixie Lane, this city, has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Elsie Burke Foster, to Stuart Warren Don of Saratoga Springs, N. Y., and Louisville, Ky. Miss Foster is the daughter of the late Mrs. Grace Burke Foster and

In an overtime game which saw both teams strive vainly to tally in a ten-minute extra period, the New York Rovers and the Hershey Bears battled to a 2-to-2 tie in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League engagement at Madison Square Garden yesterday before 13,874 persons.

There was no apparent let-up last week in the European demand for American cash corn, sales being estimated at more than 3,000,000 bushels for the week, and trade views indicate there may be no falling-off in the business until more is known regarding the outcome of the new Argentine crop.

LAST Summer a man I know was riding in a crowded street car. He noticed a sign warning against pickpockets. To comfort himself, he felt of the pocket in which he carried his money. The money was safely there. A few minutes later he left the street car. The crowd was so thick that he had some difficulty in reaching the door, but he did get out at last.

The sixth and last concert of the successful Beethoven series sponsored by the Federal Music Project was given by the Federal Symphony Orchestra, under Joseph Littau, last night at the WPA Theatre of Music. Sydney de Vries, baritone, was the soloist.
Discovery of a new kind of rheumatism which affects the brain and causes one of the commonest forms of insanity was - announced today before the American Association for the Advancement of Science.
Charles Waterbury Clark, who until his retirement five years ago was controller of the National Sugar Refining Company, died Saturday of a heart ailment at the Le Roy Sanitarium. His age was 69.

The wholesale price index on Dec. 15 was 105.5, compared with 105.6 on Dec. 8. In the first eleven months of 1937 Germany's wholesale price index, based on the average of 1913 as 100 ranged between 106.9 on Aug. 11 and 105.2 in the first week of January.

Dr. and Mrs. James Woods Babcock 2d and their debutante daughter, Miss Virginia Ivins Babcock, gave an eggnog party yesterday afternoon at their home, 172 East Seventy-first Street. The guests included the young friends of Miss Babcock.

Production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 28 per cent of capacity for the five working days, unchanged from the two weeks preceding. By the present practice of the American Iron and Steel Institute capacity is taken as that for a full week, but Christmas is as

The Maple Leafs of Toronto increased their international division lead in the National Hockey League with a 3-1 conquest of Detroit's Red Wings in a lightning-fast game before 10,000 spectators tonight.

Coast Guard headquarters here reported today that the freighter Beulah, in distress off the southwestern coast of Vancouver Island for twenty hours, was proceeding into the Strait of Juan de Fuca under her own power. One seaman was reported lost overboard in the battle with a fifty-mile-an-hour gale.
A Duquoin movie fan last night supplied whatever color was needed to give a "Wild West" picture at a local theatre all the tinge of the days of '49.

The gas water-heater division of the Association of Gas Appliance and Equipment Manufacturers will next week launch an enlarged advertising and promotional campaign for the sale of automatic gas water heaters in 1938, according to plans to be made public today by A. P. Brill, president of the Ruud Manufacturing Company, Pittsburgh, and chairman of the division. The campaign,
The Philadelphia Germans and Brookhattans battled to a 2-all tie in their American Soccer League game at Starlight Park yesterday before 5,000 fans. All the goals were made in the first half.

The engagement of Miss Regina Frances O'Connell, daughter of Mrs. George F. O'Connell of 2,977 Valentine Avenue, the Bronx, and Spring Lake, N. J., and the late Mr. O'Connell, to Arthur Edward Cooney,' son of Edward T. Cooney of New York, and the late Mrs. Cooney, has been announced by her mother.
The Brooklyn Jewels scored a 49-to-33 victory over Kate Smith's Original Celtics in an American Basketball League game before 4,000 persons at the Hippodrome last night. Mac Kinsbrunner and

The attention of the securities markets here has been drawn in the last week especially to the financial situation of the government and the prospect of its having to borrow more than 45,000,000,000 francs in 1938, a figure which considerably exceeds the amount officially announced by the Minister of Finance-25,000,000,000 to 30,000,000,000 francs.

Citizens of London poked wary heads out of doors today and heard strange tales of the worst Christmas fog since 1904. The grimy curtain of "pea soup," lifting slowly in most sections, left a trail of dignified police bowled over by motorists, charred debris where firemen fought fires they could not see and millions of raw throats.

William Hartman, 27 years old, a taxicab driver, of 436 East Eightyfifth Street, was arrested at 3 A. M. yesterday and charged with assault and robbery after a hold-up in William Capek's Tavern, 419 East Seventieth Street.

After being out of the world for twenty-five years, three Visitation nuns arrived here from Lima, Peru, yesterday on a Pan American Grace Line plane. None had ever been in an automobile until driven to the airfield to take the plane.

Permanent registration of qualified voters for New York City was advocated by Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, in his last official report to Mayor La Guardia before retirement, which was made public yesterday.

Edwin and Maxine Hilson and the Guaranty Trust Company, as trustee, leased to the Satt Realty Corporation the six-story building at 222-224 Greene Street, between West Third and Fourth Streets, near Washington Square.
The contract is to be let this week for construction at Tanglewood of the $80,000 Berkshire festival music shed to be used by the Berkshire Symphony Orchestra next Summer.

Mrs. Cordelia Campbell, daughter-in-law of a noted Ohio steelmaster, died today of a gunshot wound in the abdomen Received at a family Christmas gathering. Authorities, holding her daughter, Louise Campbell, ordered an inquest tomorrow to determine "whether it was accidental."

America's acceptance of Japan's reply on the Panay incident was received here with unconcealed relief and satisfaction. Secretary of State Cordell Hull's reply did not accept Japan's version of events, but his satisfaction with "the definite and specific steps" taken by the Japanese Government in answer to the United States' demands closes the incident.
Mrs. Marie Prindle Myers Phelps died last night here at the home of her son, Charles H. Phelps Jr., at the age of 67. She was a resident of Fairfield, Conn., and had been active in charitable work.
The body of Anton Bielman, 47 years old, secretary of the chief of police here, was found in his car on a little-used road near the Brigantine golf course today.

The work of reconstructing the Thirty-third Street terminal of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad to accommodate trains on the city's new Sixth Avenue subway as well as those on the interstate line was started at 6 A. M. yesterday. Six hours earlier train service to the terminal was discontinued and the entrances boarded up.

Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Boyle gave a tea at their residence here today at which they announced the engagement of their niece, Miss Maureen T. Guerrero, to Gilbert M. Reischmann, son of Mr. and Mrs. George M. Reischmann of Garden City.

Calling for an alert and openminded public opinion, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, in his annual report yesterday as president of Columbia University, attributed the trend toward authoritarian regimentation and the growth of class warfare to the demand for the same efficiency in government that has been achieved in modern industry.
Several parties were given at homes this afternoon. Mr. and Mrs. George G. Bass, with their daughter, Miss Miriam Bass, and their son, George G. Bass Jr., entertained a company of 150 at tea.
Newton D. Baker, former Secretary of War, will be buried in Lake View Cemetery here, near the graves of John D. Rockefeller and Myron T. Herrick, former Ambassador to France.

Renewed interest of industrial management in profit-sharing plans for employes is indicated by the results of a survey made public yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board. Out of a total

Within a few days after the end of holiday festivities brings the world back to grips with stern reality, the British Broadcasting Corporation will begin a series of programs in Arabic, Spanish and Portuguese that will be far more Importantt to diplomacy than to radio.

HARRY WALLUM, the manager of the old Jersey City team when professional basketball was in its heyday, was desperately in need of another player. He came to Dave MacMillan, playing coach of the old Knickerbockers and now the coach of the University of Minnesota quintet.

The year 1936 should have been one of the most colorful the country has known, for during that year 65,675,080 pounds of chrome yellows, chrome greens and iron blues were produced in the United States and $8,915,006 worth were sold.

Scotland Yard detectives said to night that the Christmas Eve robbery of the country home of Sir Felix Cassel, brother of the Earl of Verulam, netted the thieves jewels valued at $35,000 instead of $250,000, as first announced. Mrs. A. E.

The Agriculture Department of New York State took the lead today in a movement to better the lot of the State's farmers through a program of crop diversification. Holton V. Noyes, Agricultural Commissioner, who has been

Professor Ross F. Tucker, head of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology course in building engineering and construction and a leading construction engineer, died here today at the age of 69. His home was in Great Neck, L. I.

The world has lost sight of the child and what he means, and that is partly what is wrong with the world, the Rev. Dr. William P. Merrill, pastor of the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street, asserted in his sermon yesterday morning.

Despite the general shortage of steel in Germany, the mills report difficulty in selling large shapes. The export market for German steel is quiet and the Belgian steel manufacturers affirm that they are suffering badly from American competition and the chaos in the Far East, but buying by Holland and the Scandinavian countries is satisfactory.
Eight races were sailed today in the weekly dinghy regatta off the Indian Harbor Yacht Club, with Richard Maxwell's Lei carrying off the honors.

Francis Asbury Wilson of 414 West 118th Street, who had been advertising director for several large manufacturers, died yesterday at the home of a daughter in Cos Cob, Conn., after an illness of two months. He was 80 years old.

When the Berengaria enters New York Harbor tomorrow morning three American citizens, two men and a woman, under indictment as connected with a gang of diamond smugglers that has brought millions of dollars' worth of gems into this country during the last two years, will be aboard as passengers, it was learned yesterday.

Charles V. Noel, a Philadelphia banker who made a twenty-fiveyear hobby of being chief of the Narberth Fire Department, died in an ambulance on the way to Bryn Mawr Hospital today from a heart attack while fighting a fire.

Campaigns conducted throughout the United States and Canada by community chest organizations have raised $61,000,000 for the aid of persons in 311 cities in 1938, it was announced yesterday by Charles P. Taft, chairman of the Community Mobilization for Human Needs. Additional results are expected to bring the total to more than $83,000,000.
Otto Loree of Whitestone, L. I., piloted Dolce VII to victory today in the third of the Winter point series of ice boat races sponsored by the Greenwood Lake Ice Boat and Yacht Club.
Announcement-has been made of the engagement of Miss Mary Elizabeth Gaylord, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold B. Gaylord of Green Tree Corner, Chestnut Hill, to Edward T. Stanley of Landsdowne, Pa.

L. F. Sanman won the high-overall cup in the final shoot of the year at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday. The Winged Foot gunner broke 96 out of 100 targets to lead in a small field.
Money market conditions again became tighter during the week, principally by reason of the need for end-of-themonth accommodation and yearend maturities.

Important changes in the State's fiscal practices, designed to make budgetary procedures more effective instruments of control of financial policies and thus achieve "a really balanced budget," were urged in a report made public tonight by the Joint Legislative Committee on State Fiscal Policies.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: At the annual dinner of the Citizens Budget Commission last Monday I said that liberal pay and working conditions for city employes and a sound program of public improvements are jeopardized by waste.

A 27year-old Negro in West Hudson Hospital appeared to be out of danger today with a good chance of recovering after an unusual operation in which a broken-off knife blade that had penetrated his heart was removed. Three stitches were taken in his heart.

Grade B milk at 9 cents a quart will go on sale today in various city markets under an experimental plan worked out in cooperation with Mayor La Guardia, who believes there is too great a spread between the price paid to the farmer and the price charged to the consumer.

A protest against persecution of Jews in Poland was made public yesterday by the American Writers Committee to Aid the Jews of Poland, with headquarters at 103 West Seventy-seventh Street. Condemning particularly the establishment of "ghetto benches" in Polish schools and universities, the protest said anti-Semitism was "a threat to the freedom of cultural development and a blot upon the name of the Polish republic."
The thirty-first annual meeting of the American Association for Labor Legislation will be held here on Tuesday. Wednesday and Thursday.

Violette Moriss, 44-year-old former feminine shotput champion of France and an allround woman athlete, was jailed tonight following a scuffle aboard her houseboat La Mouette, which is anchored in the Seine River, in which an unemployed mechanic, Joseph Lecam, 34, ex-Foreign Legionnaire, was shot to death.

The leading military nations of the world are making extraordinary precautions to protect non-combatants against enemy gas attacks by. air, according to Lieut. Col. Augustin M. Prentiss, chemical warfare expert of the United States Army, writing in the issue of Army Ordnance, to be published tomorrow.

Logic and intellectual honesty demand "acceptance of all the Gospel story or none of it," the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer, pastor of Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, asserted in his sermon yesterday morning.
An average of more than $254 a year for each employee has been spent by the American Rolling Mill Company for plant expansion and improvement since 1929, Charles R. Hook, president, reported today.

Arthur Fiedler, conductor of the Pops and Esplanade concerts of the Boston Symphony Orchestra Players, suggested today that, if "The StarSpangled Banner" is too difficult for singers, it could be made easier for them by changing it from a twelve-note range to one of ten notes.

Mr. and Mrs. Howard Crosby Brokaw of 984 Fifth Avenue and The Chimneys, Oyster Bay, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marguerite Brokaw, to Charles Crocker of New York and Pebble Beach, Calif., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William H. Crocker of San Francisco.

Louis Novis of Great Neck, L. I., was elected president of the Rural Youth of America at the annual meeting yesterday at 80 Van Cortlandt Park South. He succeeded Samuel H. Meisler. The organization, devoted to the economic adjustment of youth, also
The capture of Tsinan, the capital of Shantung province, by a Japanese army was reported today in dispatches reaching Shanghai from North China.

The Neediest Cases Fund rose to $268,901.59 yesterday as 162 contributors sent in gifts totaling $3,790.31. Two days after Christmas it is $2,595.71 short of last year's final total, which provided aid to 479 cases through gifts of $271,497.30.
A. E. Matson, 53 years old, was burned to death here today in a freak accident that puzzled investigators.
The National Maritime Union is seeking to extend its influence on ships at sea and strengthen its organizational activities in oceangoing crews where union members predominate. The Pilot, official

Echoes of Christmas were heard in sermons throughout the city yesterday when members of the clergy urged that there be no spiritual letdown after the festival. The Very Rev. Milo H. Gates, dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, said:

The C. I. O. will seek the protection of the Federal courts in its long-delayed organizing drive in Jersey City, it was announced tonight by Samuel L. Rothbard, chief counsel of the organization in New Jersey.

Researches which have convinced him that children born in March or late February in the United States and countries of similar temperature have the best chance of achieving intellectual distinction were made known yesterday at the University
Two biblical murals, anonymously donated to the Leonia Methodist Episcopal Church, were dedicated at a candlelight service attended by 800 persons this afternoon.

There were twenty-one sailing dinghies out today in the after Christmas regatta of the Larch mont Yacht Club, and Frank Campbell, skillful handler of his Class B craft Felix, not only led in the open racing between B and Class X boats but clearly defeated the others in his class group in the afternoon contests.
Threatened withdrawal of the Grace Line and Panama-Pacific Line luxury liners from the intercoastal run leaves slower and cheaper service in prospect for 1938.

A collision in midstream between the ferryboat Albany, operating between Staten Island and Brooklyn, and an army dredge jarred fifty passengers early today and resulted in the loss of an unoccupied automobile, which went overboard following the shock.

While a vast tide of destruction, battle and destitution is surging across ever-spreading areas in China, preceded and accompanied by a wholesale hegira of the population, it becomes daily clearer that a fundamental struggle is arising between order and anarchy.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Mrs. Alice Dresel Beal of this city, and Balmville, Newburgh, widow of Thaddeus Reynolds Beal, to George Van Santvoord of the Hotchkiss School, Lakeville, Conn.

Gold coins with an estimated value of 1,000,000 francs and nearly 600 years old have been found by masons during the demolition of an old house at Calais. The coins are of the reign of Philippe the Bold and struck ater April 15, 1339.

He whom President Wilson was wont to speak of as America's best public servant and who, returning to private life became one of our greatest citizens, came too early to the end of his remarkable career. His most eloquent voice has been stilled. The ardent and powerful proponent of a league for

Taxable gasoline sales in California in November aggregated 140,281,207 gallons, off from 143,619,000 in October but an increase of 1.9 per cent from November of last year, according to compilations by the State Board of Equalization.

Thirty-six University of Santa Clara football players, coaches, officials and some 250 fans entrained tonight for New Orleans, where the Broncos and the Tigers of Louisiana State will keep their Sugar Bowl date New Year's Day.

Christ would have spent Christmas Day among the unemployed, the poor and the unfortunate were He on earth now, the Rev. John King Benedict, pastor of Centenary Methodist Church, Washington Avenue and 166th Street, the Bronx, declared in his morning sermon yesterday.

Mrs. Grace Packer, 24 years old, and her 3-year-old son, Richard, were found dead yesterday in their four-room apartment on the top floor of 321 West Twenty-first Street, a five-story tenement. Mrs. Packer, according to the police, apparently committed suicide by gas.

Plans to oppose ?? of the National Child Labor Amendment by the New York State Legislature were discussed yesterday at the year's final meeting of the Long Island Chapter, Knights of Columbus, at the Knights of Columbus Institute, 81 Hanson Place, Brooklyn.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 83.2, which compares with 83.9 a week ago, 84.3 two weeks ago, 84.6 three weeks ago and 85.1 four weeks ago.

Major General Douglas MacArthur is maintaining a strict silence regarding his personal plans after his retirement, at the age of 57, from active service in the United States Army effective on the last day of this year. Those closest to him believe
Appointment of City Court Justice Paul M. Livoti as County Clerk of Queens by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of the Second Department was announced yesterday.

Functioning of the new Eastern Ice Yachting Association in the coordination of racing in this section will begin this week at a meeting that is to be called by that body. One of the contests to be taken up will be that for the Rumson Eastern Championship Pennant, the open prize put up last Winter and which never has been raced for.
An improved economic order was advocated as a means of expressing devotion to the ideals of Jesus in a sermon yesterday morning at Union Congregational Church, 115th Street and Eighty-sixth Avenue,

The hardware manufacturing business of Peck Brothers, established in 1856, will be dissolved under a decree last week by Judge Edward A. Daly. Holbrook Bradley, its receiver, will be discharged. Under the stress of the depression the company ceased manufacturing two years ago.

The King broke his vacation at Sandringham tonight to hold a privy council meeting. For some time there was considerable speculation concerning the business that required a meeting on Sunday, particularly when the day followed Christmas Day.
With the city relief rolls rising rapidly the Emergency Relief Bureau has added sixty investigators to its staff and is seeking funds for the employment of 100 more, it was learned last night.
Appointment of City Court Justice Paul M. Livoti as County Clerk of Queens by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of the Second Department was announced yesterday.

The controversial "Philippine mahogany" case hes been reopened by the Federal Trade Commission with a view toward possible issuance of an order barring use of the term for trade purposes, it was learned today.

Cuba's sugar grinding season will start on Jan. 16, next, and terminate on May 31, according to a decree issued by President Federico Laredo Bru today. Preliminary work such as the cutting and hauling may be initiated several days before the opening date.

Thomas J. McGann, vice president and controller of James Talcott, Inc., 225 Fourth Avenue, textile and general factors, died of a heart attack on Sunday at his home, 430 Bainbridge Street, Brooklyn. Mr. McGann was prominent as a Republican and a Roman Catholic layman. His age was 53.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles Dusch and Mr. and Mrs. Warren Joli are neighbors on the second floor of a four-apartment stucco house at 8 First Street here, and when the Duschs' daughter, Annise, was born two months ago the Jolis were almost as happy as the parents.

Based on an affidavit by Benjamin D. Riegel, chairman of the board of the Riegel Paper Corporation of 342 Madison Avenue, New York, that his company could not obtain loans with which to accomplish a contemplated plant expansion in North Carolina, the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to grant an extension of time within which to build a spur to the proposed Riegel plant in North Carolina.

It is now verified that more than 90 per cent of the Arab terrorist gangs at present operating in Palestine are Syrians, all of whom are equipped with rifles and ammunition and receive monthly salaries from a mysterious source.

Operations of the steel industry are scheduled at 19.2 per cent of capacity this week, a new low level and marking the seventeenth consecutive week of decline. The current activity index represents a drop of 4.3 points, or 18.3 per cent, from last week.

A court at Ostrow today appointed a guardian for the property and person of 67-year-old Prince Michael Radziwill, a member of Poland's most powerful and aristocratic family pending the outcome of a suit that the Prince's family has brought to have him declared unfit, on mental grounds, to manage his estates.

In a court session lasting only three minutes, Justice of the Peace Harold Hicock today dismissed proceedings against two members of the German-American Bund charged with violating the Connecticut law which prohibits secular work on the Sabbath.
Eight persons, all Negroes, were lynched in 1937, the Tuskegee Institute Department of Records and Research reported today. The 1936 toll also was eight.
Arturo Toscanini is a great man, but no man is big enough to run past a red traffic light without warning.
Miss Elizabeth Sanderson Haldane, author and only daughter in the extraordinarily gifted family of the late Robert Haldane of Cloanden, died today at the age of 75.

Governor Lehman today invited the newly elected District Attorney of Erie County and the new Mayor of Buffalo to confer with him tomorrow morning on a grand jury request for appointment of a special prosecutor to press a Buffalo city payroll investigation.

The engagement of Miss Mary Hyde Clarke of this city, daughter of Mrs. Beach Cooke and of George Hyde Clarke, both of Cooperstown, N. Y., to Kenneth Henson Paton, has been announced here by her mother.

A Japanese Embassy spokesman, explaining the new regulations for crimes against the Japanese armed forces, said any issue arising over these rules would be between Japan and the third power concerned, because China, no longer in control of the territory covered by the rules, would be unable to fulfill her treaty obligations.

Changes in the Merchant Marine Act of 1936, to make possible the upbuilding of the American merchant marine under private ownership and operation, was recommended in a report of the merchant marine committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, made public today.

Extradition proceedings against Gerardo Machado, former President of Cuba, who was recently arrested on a warrant issued against him in 1934, were dismissed yesterday by Garrett W. Cotter, United States Commissioner, with the approval of Pablo Suarez, Cuban consul general.
Sir Daniel McNabb, surgeon-rearadmiral and former deputy director general of the medical department of the Royal Navy, died today, at the age of 75.
The Democratic members of the new City Council will meet this afternoon at the National Democratic Club and try to agree on a candidate for vice chairman and chairmen of important committees.

Officials of the several United States oil companies operating in Mexico remained here over the week-end trying to work out proposals for a compromise which they might carry back to Mexico City, under which it would be possible to continue operations there.

Mr. and Mrs. Fred E. Linder of Staten Island and Center Lovell, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Agnes Pruyn Linder, to Dr. William Allan Monkhouse, son of Mrs. Bertram L. Monkhouse of Toronto, Ont.
The design has been completed and dies made for the Caldecott Medal which will be struck in bronze and awarded annually for the "most distinguished American picture book for children."

The White House was the scene today of one of the gayest of all the holiday celebrations on its program. Sixty youngsters, guests of the President's grandchildren, joined in the frolic, which began with a marionette show in the East room, and ended there, after supper, with a distribution of gifts to all from the great Christmas tree, which gleamed with snow and silver trimming.
Prices on several grades of pulp have been reduced for the first quarter of 1938, restoring the approximate levels that prevailed in the third quarter of 1937.
One explanation of Germany's capacity to keep up her heavy expenditures is found in tax reports for the first eleven months of this year.

Announcement has been made here by Colonel and Mrs. Robert Schuch von Glickhfelden of Vienna, Austria, of the engagement and appreaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Henriette Charlotte Schuch von Glickhfelden, to Albert Green Walker of Syosset, L. I.

In his campaign Mr. Dewey, sufficiently recommended to the public by his performance as Special Prosecutor, made but a single promise. If he was elected District Attorney he and his staff would do the work of the office and not hire extra lawyers to help them.

From a technical and traffic viewpoint the airlines of the United States in 1937 had the best year of their history, the American Air Transport Association reported today, but from a profits standpoint the year was not good.
Ivor Gurney, poet and musician who was incapacitated by service in France during the World War, died today at the age of 47. It is said that 200 of his songs written before 1911 remain unpublished.

The net profit of the Black Decker Manufacturing Company and subsidiaries for the year ended on Sept. 30 amounted to $1,052,169 after depreciation, interest, Federal income taxes and surtax on undistribute earnings.

Ruth Gordon slammed the door on Ibsen's "A Doll's House" at the Morosco last evening. Although no one was shocked or astounded, a good many people were profoundly impressed, for Miss Gordon is a remarkable actress.
