Not long ago she was standing "Ethan Frome" on its ear with a richly documented and passionate performance.
Premier Camille Chautemps and his aides today conferred with representatives of employers and workers in an effort to end the wave of holiday stay-in strikes.

The files of the Federal Writers Project in Washington are bulging with thousands of manuscripts containing variants of known folk tales and much material perhaps never before collected, the annual convention of the American Folklore Society was told today by Henry Alsberg, national director of the government-sponsored relief organization.

Closer cooperation among the air forces of France, Poland and Rumania will be one of the most important results of the recent European tour of French Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos, political circles here believe.

General Sessions Judge Freschi yesterday postponed until tomorrow pleading on the indictment charging Charles Falci, 54 years old, a Tammany follower of Albert Marinelli, with tampering with the writein vote for Joseph V. McKee, Recovery party candidate for Mayor in 1932.

The WPA Federal Theatre opened its series of holiday dance matinees for children yesterday afternoon at the Forty-ninth Street Theatre. The bill consists of "Folk Dances of All Nations," arranged by Lily Mehlman, with musical arrangements by Alex North:

Amendments to the city's Building Code that were approved by the Board of Aldermen at its meetings of Dec. 14 and 21 were vetoed yesterday by Mayor LaGuardia after he had talked them over with Alfred Rheinstein. who will become Commissioner of Housing and Buildings on Jan. 1.
Charles Fremont Amidon, retired United States District Judge, of Fargo, N. D., and Westport, Conn., died here last night. He was 81 years old.

Higher.Cloud, a 4-year-old gelding that had been left at the post in his last two starts at Saratoga in August, ran like a streak of lightning to take the Palm Beach Purse at Tropical Park today. It was another feature score for Chicago's Mrs. Emil Denemark.

Violent death claimed at least 500 lives as the nation's price for one of its most extensive Christmas celebrations in years. With the double holiday crowding highways, traffic accidents took a toll many times higher than any other cause.

Harold St. L. O'Dougherty, for three and a half years chief assistant to the late United States Attorney Leo J. Hickey in the Eastern District of New York, was sworn in yesterday as his temporary successor. Mr. Hickey died of pneumonia in Holy Family Hospital, Brooklyn, on Christmas Day.
Weston W. Fletcher, for whom sev eral thousand persons in the United States and Canada offered blood transfusions in a fight against a streptococcus viridans infection died today in Grace Hospital.

Disappointment and "profound regret" over the collapse of the recent peace negotiations between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization was expressed yesterday by Justice, the official organ of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, third largest C. I. O. affiliate.

Good generalship prescribes that, before an engagement, it is wise to send out scouts to determine if possible the numbers, emplacements and morale of the enemy; whether there are friendly troops afield and where; and what are the sources of subsistence for forces about to enter hostile territory.
The R.C.A.-Victor Company has put in operation in its plant here a sharethe-work policy to provide a greater spread of employment in "times of stress," it was disclosed today.
Percy D. Stoddard of Oyster Bay and Mineola, counsel for many years for the State Tax Department, was sworn in as Supreme Court justice of the Second District this afternoon at his home here.

Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, announced yesterday that 1,222 court prosecutions under the New York Workmen's Compensation Law were brought by the Department of Labor through State Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. from Jan. 1 to Dec. 1, 1937. Of these, Mr. Andrews said, 1,073 were disposed of, 949 resulting in convictions and 124 being dismissed. The remainder are pending.

Justice Leander B. Faber of the Supreme Court, whose home is in Jamaica, received notice yesterday of his appointment by the Appellate Division in the Second District as an official referee, his term to begin Jan. 1.

The Japanese army is pushing on in the vicinity of Tsinan, Shantung's capital, following its capture at 1:30 yesterday afternoon. Rising Sun flags were placed on all gates of the ancient walled city and the Japanese army advanced three miles west and seized the Tsinan airfield.

With less than 5,000 out of the 70,000 bales certificated stock delivered on first notice day for January contracts, strength in the spot month exerted yesterday a steadying influence on prices on the Cotton Exchange. A holiday in Liverpool tended to curtail business while weakness in the stock market reduced professional support.
The 50,000-watt beam of the Perry Memorial at Put-In-Bay shone tonight over icy Lake Erie in tribute to the late Newton D. Baker, President Wilson's Secretary of War.

Renewed assurances that the Securities and Exchange Commission will strive to purge the securities trades of alleged improper accounting methods were tendered today at the annual meeting of the American Accounting Association by Robert E. Healy, SEC Commissioner. The association is meeting in the Hotel Chalfonte-Haddon Hall here.

The Adjutant General released the following orders today: Hedberg, 1st Lt. George A., having qualified is placed on duty. He is to report immediately to the commanding officer, 14th Inf., for assignment to Co. A.

Albert Morris Bagby gave the 402d Musical Morning in his series yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria. Kirsten Flagstad, soprano, and Emanuel List, basso, both of the Metropolitan Opera Company, and Rudolf Serkin, German pianist, were the artists.

American Airlines, Inc., carried 283,485 passengers during the first eleven months of the year and estimates indicated the total would reach 300,000 by the end of the year, C. R. Smith, president of the company, announced yesterday.

There is reason to believe that the present levels under resale pricemaintenance contracts are not as high as the proponents of the contracts hope eventually to make them, Robert E. Freer, a member of the Federal Trade Commission, told the American Marketing Associtation meeting here today.
Toothaches today upset the Windsors' Riviera holiday. Suffering from an ulcerated jaw, the Duke today called in Dr. Edwin Munziger, a dental graduate of the University of Pennsylvania.

Benjamin Kopf, manager of the Ford Motor Company in Japan, receives hearty praise in all of today's morning newspapers for the purchase of 1,000,000 yen worth of the China Incident bonds as a mark of sympathy with Japan.

Among leases of residential space reported yesterday was the renting by Theodore Komisarjovsky, writer and lecturer, of an apartment in 37 West Seventy-second Street through the Apartment Renting Company, Inc.

The Baltimore Ohio Railroad applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to borrow $8,233,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. Jesse Jones, chairman of the RFC, said recently that his corporation stood ready to make all necessary and reasonable loans to railroads.

Banking institutions were the sellers in three of the Brooklyn realty transactions reported yesterday. The Title Guarantee and Trust Company sold the four-story dwelling on a plot 60 by 100 feet at 262 East Fifty-fifth Street for investment to a client of Hy D. Agar, Inc., brokers.

Soviet authorities hinted that today a submarine expedition to the North Pole was being considered as the next step toward establishing a regular airplane service from Russia over the Pole to the United States.

The second issue of the Treasury's new series of bills was sold today at an average interest rate of 0.101 per cent, compared to an average rate of 0.102 per cent on the first issue of the new series last week, Secretary Morganthau announced today.
Sir Douglas Hazen, former chief justice of New Brunswick, died today of pneumonia at the age of 77. One of two daughters, Mrs. Douglas Macauley of Montreal, arrived yesterday.

If medical students are to become good practitioners they must get away from the "prolonged emphasis" on scientific medicine and cultivate the powers of bedside observation of the patient, according to Dr. Harvey Cushing, noted neurologist.
A Lutheran Hospital room occupied by Miss Flora Campbell, New York actress, who underwent an appendectomy yesterday.

The Imperial Airways plane Centaurus completed the last lap of a survey flight from England to New Zealand this afternoon, arriving from Sydney soon after 3 o'clock. Crossing of the Tasman Sea, almost 1,300 miles, took a little more than nine hours, with the plane flying at an average of 9,000 feet most of the way.
Dan Beddoe, oratorio tenor, dled Sunday in the apartment of his son, Donald Beddoe, at the Fortyfourth Street Hotel. His age was 74.

Albert Eliphalet Mitchell, mechanical engineer and president of the Wyckoff Pipe and Creosoting Company, Inc., 522 Fifth Avenue, die?? Sunday at his home in the Hotel Sherman Square after a brief illness. His age was 82. He had been associated with the Wyckoff company for twenty-nine years.

State Department investigators are working on the theory that "Mr. and Mrs. Donald Louis Robinson," who disappeared mysteriously in Moscow early this month, may have been traveling with another set of fraudulent passports in the name of Mr. and Mrs. Adolph Arnold Rubens of New York and may be the couple who, under the latter names, sailed on the steamer Rex on Oct. 16 and disappeared after reaching Naples on Oct. 23.

The lower East Side, one of Manhattan's major centers of outmoded tenements, probably has witnessed greater activity in the remodeling and improvement of such buildings during recent months than at any other period within the past twenty or thirty years.
Finance Minister Georges Bonnet's statement concerning the nation's finances made a favorable impression in the Senate, so the Bourse held steady today despite a virtually stagnant condition.
Corn was the leader in the grain markets on the Board of Trade here today, advancing as much as 2 1/2 cents a bushel over Friday's close at the extreme.
Max D. Goodman, retired assistant director of Montefiore Hospital, died of a heart ailment in St. Petersburg, Fla., on Saturday at the age of 75. He left for the South last month.

Magistrate William O'Dwyer is slated for appointment to the Kings County Court by Governor Lehman, it was learned yesterday. His name was the only one submitted to the judiciary committee of the Brooklyn Bar Association for the vacancy occasioned by the election of Judge Algeron I. Nova to the Supreme Court bench, and the committee sent back to Albany an "unusually favorable report."

The number of business failures in the United States for the week ended Dec. 23 was 209, compared with 200 in the week preceding and 162 in the same period last year, according to the weekly report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet.
Foreign diplomats today saw in the arrival of the new Soviet Ambassador to China-a soldier rather than a diplomat-indications that closer military relations between China and Russia were in prospect.
A police release today tells of the detention of twenty "Integralistas" [Fascists] and the apprehension of literature and a printing press.

Tentative trade practice rules for the metal-clad door and accessory industry, which has an average sales volume of more than 8,000,000 units, were announced today by the Federal Trade Commission, subject to modification.
The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 22:

Acting to make its own rules conform to those of the Federal Reserve Board, the New York Stock Exchange committee on business conduct has amended regulations relative to dealing in "when-issued" securities and rights not traded on the Exchange.

Leading producers of women's full-fashioned branded hosiery yesterday announced price reductions ranging from 15 cents a dozen on higher priced styles to 50 cents a dozen on the volume 42-gauge numbers.

Princeton University's varsity basketball forces were today deprived of the services of their captain, John H. Vruwink '38. of Albany, N. Y., for at least six weeks, it was anbounced by Coach Ken Fairman. The team's leader and outstandstar was operated on this morning for appendicitis.

Using the same tactics as five men who held up the Downtown Democratic Club at 59 Madison Street on Christmas Eve and escaped with $3,000 collected for the poor of the neighborhood, a policeman "held up" seventeen men in a lunchroom at 239 Grand Street last night and caused the arrest of three men for the robbery.

Dr. Joseph Morton Howell, who was United States Minister to Egypt, 1922-27, died here today at the age of 74. Born in Uniopolis, Ohio, March 17, 1863, Dr. Howell attended the Starling Medical College in Ohio and practiced surgery at Dayton, Ohio from 1885 to 1921.

Methods which promise to yield economical air-conditioned comfort to the average home have been developed through the demand, not of the home owner, but of industry, a divisional meeting of the American Chemical Society was told here today.

Two victories over Manchester City over the Christmas holidays sent Brentford into a 3-point lead in the English Football League today. The Bees followed their 2-0 Christmas Day victory at Manchester with a tight 2-1 decision in London today.

Dr. Ernest Martin Hopkins, president of Dartmouth College, and Mrs. Hopkins have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Hopkins, to John C. Merrill, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard B. Merrill of South Pasadena, Calif.

Mrs. Katherine Jones Whipple, widow of Colonel Charles W. Whipple, U. S. A., died Sunday at her residence, 106 East Thirty-seventh Street, at the age of 82. Born in Plattsburgh, N. Y., she was a descendant of early English, Dutch and Huguenot colonists.

Eight Manhattan properties changed hands yesterday at auction sales in the Vesey Street salesrooms. Among the parcels involved were two large apartment houses on West Eighty-third Street, between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue, which were bought in at separate sales by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, as plaintiff in both instances.

The influence of radio and the drama on current speech will be discussed by leading exponents of this branch of education at the annual convention of the National Association of Teachers of Speech, which opens today in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
Japanese fishermen are ruining Panama's famous Perlas Islands fishing grounds by the use of dynamite, according to a complaint to President Juan D. Arosemena by Panaman fishermen.
The French destroyer Vauquelin today rescued the French freighter Yolande from two Spanish Insurgent cruisers which ordered the freighter to follow them to Insurgent-held Mallorca.
Governor Lehman declared tonight that the effects of the present decline in business would be mitigated by the State Unemployment Insurance Law, under which benefit payments will begin next month.
While Gordie Drillon held first place, there was a scramble during the week for the spots just below the young Toronto Maple Leaf star in the National Hockey League scoring standing.

The Tennessee Valley Authority announced today a new wage and hour schedule for 8,000 skilled and unskilled workers, providing a maximum 40-hour week with overtime pay, and an approximate increase of 5 per cent in wages.

The quotation in yesterday's TIMES from President Butler's report ended with his urging the universities in the nations where democracy still rules to be untiring and emphatic in making plain to general public opinion what contemporary conditions really are and what they may involve.

The official newspaper El Nacional says editorially today that President Lazaro Cardenas is personally responsible for the Interior Department orders to enforce immigration and population laws that are expected to force several thousand Jews to leave Mexico.

The marriage of Miss Marjorie Goddard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Percival S. Goddard of 118 Eightyfourth Street, Brooklyn, to Joseph Victor Leidy, son of Mrs. Joseph Schreiber and of Russell Leidy, all of Philadelphia, took place at noon yesterday in the Church of the Transfiguration. The Rev.

A. W. Sulloway of Harvard, seed,ed second, was among the winners in the third annual invitation intercollegiate squash racquets tourpament at the University Club yesterday. Play in the first round was completed with the exception of one match.
GOVERNORS ISLAND Each of the following Reserve officers, now on active duty with the CCC, is continued on active duty until the date set opposite his name:

Outlining the Federal housing program, Senator Robert. F. Wagner urged last night that government, labor and industry "go forward together in a determined effort to build a better America." He spoke in a radio forum over a network of the National Broadcasting Company.

In the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis last night Mr. and Mrs. Auguste Richard and Mrs. Winthrop Ames gave a dinner dance to introduce their daughters, the Misses Harriett L. Richard and Catherine H. Ames. Mrs. Richard and Mrs. Ames received with the debutantes.

Though the city's fiscal officers expressed serious concern yesterday over the likelihood of a city default on interest payments on its short-term debt soon after the close of the year, Mayor La Guardia still insisted that the city had no budget.

Turpentine firm, 26c: sales 46 barrels; receipts 568 barrels; shipments 1,672 barrels; stock 34,326 barrels. Resin firm; sales 546 barrels; receipts 1,199 barrels; shipments 1,375 barrels; atook 90,037 barrels. Quote: B, D. 4.25 F, G, $5.55; H, $5.70; 1, $5.75: K, $5.90; M, $6.05; N, $6.10; WG. $6.85; WW, X, $7.20.

Incoming trains to this Southern metropolis brought to the city today the vanguard of delegates to the annual conventions of the Amerlean Football Coaches Association and the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

Chinese and foreign art lovers here fear that there may have been a widespread dispersal of the famous Chinese Imperial Treasures, incident upon their removal from Nanking in the face of the Japanese invasion.
Because of low prices and the small crop of coffee, Nicaraguan merchants probably will buy one-third less merchandise from the United States next year compared to 1937 purchases.
Stocks reactionary, closed lower with losses of 1 to 4 points; turnover, 1,361,120 shares. United States Government and Japanese bonds strong, corporate issues lower; transactions, $8,061,000.
School boy sport were put on the same peril basis as academic studies by action today of delegates to the New York State Public High School Athletic Association.

The Associated Marine Workers, a C. I. O. affiliate composed of towboat employes, announced yesterday that it would apply today to the National Labor Relations Board for a port-wide election to determine the labor bargaining agent of towboat employes in New York.

Violet, Dowager Duchess of Rutland, artist, widow of the eighth Duke and mother of the famous beauty, Lady Diana Duff Cooper, wife of the First Lord of the Admiralty, died in London today after an operation for appendicitis.

Miss Janet Oline Hart, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Hornell Hart of this city, was married on Christmas Day to William Diebold Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William Diebold of Weehawken, N. J. The ceremony was performed by the bride's father.

Dr. George Edward Stubbs, 80 years old, dean of Trinity Parish choirmasters, who had served for forty-five years as organist and choirmaster of St. Agnes Chapel, 121 West Ninety-first Street, died late Sunday night in his home, 272 West Ninetieth Street.

Smoke and flames tonight rolled out of three thick-walled medieval buildings where 6,000 persons were reported desperately waiting an Insurgent counter-offensive to rescue them. All three buildings were crumbling under the incessant pounding of government artillery, which had set the upper floors afire.
Benjamin Ackman, former vicepresident and treasurer of Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc., has resigned from that firm and plans to form a real estate brokerage and mortgage financing organization of his own.

Smiling Joe Thomas, Negro, whose heart was closed with three stitches after the removal of a broken knife blade, jumped thirty-five feet out of a window in the rear of Hudson Hospital here tonight and fled like a marathon runner to the meadows, where the police searched for him with floodlights mounted on the tops of nine patrol cars.

As measured by excise tax aollections, radio manufacturing in the first eleven months of 1987 was 6.8 per cent ahead of a year ago, Bond Geddes, executive vice president of the Radio Manufacterers' Association, announced yesterday.
The McCormick Steamship Company denied in a statement today a charge by the Senate Civil Liberties Committee that the company employed "industrial spies." The statement added:

Miss Sarah Elkus, supervisor of the day classes for adults in English and citizenship, will retire from the school system next Monday, it was disclosed yesterday at the Board of Education. The project was founded twenty-two years ago by Miss Elkus.

With allowance for the holiday, the daily average of automobile production was lower last week against a steady seasonal trend, and the adjusted index eased to 89.9 from 91.4. In computing the index, 106.5 was used as the seasonal variation factor. For the week ended Dec. 26, 1936, the number was 96.8.

The north lounge of the Breakers was the setting tonight for a dinner followed by contract bridge given by Mrs. Walter Furman Schuyler. Guests were seated at one long table, decorated with roses and lighted with pink tapers in silver candelabra.

A ruling of the Ministry of the Interior in effect forbids the establishment of new Jewish clothing firms in Berlin. Officially the decree merely provides that permission must be obtained to open new firms, but it has been announced that permission will not be given to Jews.

Enrico Venturi, Italian lightweight, defeated the Piute Indian, Billy Lee of Toronto, in the tenround feature, before 3,000 fans at St. Nicholas Palace last night. Venturi weighed 139 and Lee 136 1/4 pounds.

The will of Robert W. Bingham, Ambassador to Great Britain, filed for probate in Jefferson County Court here today, vests control of the Bingham newspapers, The Courier-Journal and The Louisville Times, in a son, Barry Bingham, who was co-publisher of the papers.

Activity in the Building Department offices yesterday was confined to the Bronx and Queens. In the former borough, architects filed the specifications for two groups of apartment buildings to be built in Riverdale at an estimated cost of $1,750,000.
President Roosevelt and the Budget Bureau have agreed on a reduction of about $124,000,000 in the appropriation for the CCC in the fiscal year 1939 from the $350,000,000 of the current fiscal year.

Six men were sentenced to life imprisonment today for the sensational kidnapping and slaying of wealthy Abel Ayerza in 1932. Five other members of a band convicted of the crime were given prison terms ranging from ten to twenty years. Three were women.

ELEANOR EARLY calls her new travel book "Ports of the Sun,"* and that is just about right. For while New York shivers on a cold and forbidding December morning, the sun is hot in Hamilton, Charlotte Amalie, St. Kitts, Barranquilla and Havana.

A new purge in the Transport Commissariat has been launched with the denunciation of six high officials by name on the familiar charges of treasonable wrecking and the appointment of three new Vice Commissars.

At a time when there are plenty of other problems to engage its attention, events have forced upon the Government the necessity of reconsidering its silver policy. This is because two of the principal commitments which it has made in this field are due to expire at the end of the month.

J. C. Peregoy, general manager of the Great Atlantic and Pacific food stores here, said today that eight of fifty-three units in the city had been closed because of the "burden imposed by payment of the Louisiana chain store tax." The stores closed, he said, employed about twenty clerks and managers.
The Toronto Maple Leafs, leaders in the International Group of the National Hockey League, will oppose the New York-Americans on the Madison Square Garden ice surface tonight.
Visitors to the office of Police Commissioner Valentine will find a new reception clerk in charge of the outside office and office force, it was announced yesterday.

A move to get Soviet officials to standardize conditions going into orders placed here by the Russian Government took shape in the export trade yesterday with the announcement that the Export Managers Club of New York, Inc., is considering seeking an early conference on the subject.

The government today issued a special warning to civil servants to hold their tongues and not to reveal what is going on in government offices. Large placards showing a man with his finger on his lips were placed in all Ministries.

The results of the open seasons on deer in many New England States show that these animals were certainly more numerous this year. Either that or the hunters were better shots and more versed in woodcraft than usual.

Sir Theodore Brinckman, well-known British sportsman, is touring the Argentine with a cricket team that includes several well-known county players. Today the Englishmen won an unofficial test match by two wickets.
Japanese authorities here are frankly uneasy over the tone of the United States note settling the Panay incident. They interpret the wording as a tone of cold disbelief in the Japanese explanation.

Miss Patricia d'Armand Ferguson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Milford Ferguson of 45 East Sixty-sixth Street, was introduced to society yesterday at a luncheon given by her parents in the Corinthian Room of the Pierre.

The Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today that Canada's October production hit a new High point for the second month in succession. The output was 51,853,071 pounds, compared to a September total of 48,045,881 and one of 34,644,498 a year before.

One person was killed and five were injured in an earthquake that shook the towns of Ahuachapan and Atiquizaya near the Guatemalan border last night. Considerable property damage was reported in both towns and the shock disrupted electric light and telegraph services.

The Court of Pardons commuted to life imprisonment today the death sentences imposed on Mrs. Marguerite Fox Dolbow and Norman Driscoll, who were to have died in the electric chair next week for the murder of the woman's husband, Harry, a Salem County farmer.

New York State taxpayers face a combined Federal, State and local debt of $11,875,000,000, or the equivalent of a mortgage of nearly $3,000 on every family in the State, including those on relief, the Joint Legislative Committee on State Fiscal Policies asserted in the second section of its report, made public today.

Julius Rosenwald 2d of Chicago, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lessing J. Rosenwald of Abington, and Miss Julia G. Kaufmann, daughter of Mrs. Alice G. Kaufmann of Elkins Park, Pa., applied for a marriage license here today.

Sir Henry Chilton, the British Ambassador to Spain, who has been functioning at Hendaye, France, on the Spanish frontier, since August, 1936, will go on a vacation immediately, according to the diplomatic correspondent of The Daily Telegraph and will not return because he has already ?? 60 the retirement age.

Frank B. Kellogg, former Secretary of State and Ambassador to Great Britain, was buried today in the Washington Cathedral, where rest the remains of Woodrow Wilson, World War President; Admiral George Dewey, Dr. William Holland Wilmer and others held in honored memory by the nation.

Among the passengers due today from Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria are Lord Howard of Effingham, C. C. Hopegill, British Consul at Seattle; Colonel J. H. J. Phillips, W. N. Tilley, J. Stanley Holmes, M. P.; Mr. and Mrs. John C. Griffin and Miss Margaret Glenn.
The Neediest Cases Fund went over the top yesterday. Contributions of $5,111.28 from 223 donors brought the Fund's total in this twenty-sixth annual appeal to $274,012.87.

Mexico will discuss most-favored-nation treaties with Germany and other nations, according to the Under Secretary for Foreign Affairs, Ramon Beteta, who announced today that a commission on commercial treaties would meet early in January under his direction.
John Sullivan, 277, Ireland, pinned Hans Steinke. 240, Germany, in 36:14 at the Hippodrome last night. A crowd of 4,000 saw Sullivan throw Steinke with a body slam.
Whether the Minister of Justice ought to kiss publicly a convict, and furthermore let himself be photographed doing it, is a question to which the Rightist French press today is devoting much space.
Harry Jacobi, 14 years old, a violin student, has been missing since Oct. 11, it was made known yesterday by his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Jacobi of 1,925 Quentin Road, Brooklyn.

Inclement weather last week and week-end was held accountable by the Police Department yesterday for a sharp rise in accidents, deaths and injured in city traffic as compared with figures covering the corresponding period last year.
Mrs. Robert H. Wood of Essex Fells announced tonight the engagement of her daughter, Miss Natalie Wood, to Henry Nicoll Wightman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Wightman of Upper Montclair.
The United States "liquidated" the Panay incident, Premier Benito Mussolini's newspaper asserted today, because "really nothing can be done against Japan."
The international stock market indices for Dec. 24, with comparisons, are as follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 1927:

Results of the first official count of the unemployed are expected to be available when Congress considers the problem of relief expenditures. John D. Biggers, director of the government's unemployment census, intends to announce his findings on Jan. 3, the day Congress meets.

While, in general, business for the first half of the coming year may fall below the corresponding period of 1937, advertising of some products and in certain classifications is expected to show continuing gains, according to agency executives yesterday.

The opening game of the American and Canadian ice hockey series at the Playland Ice Casino saw Colgate go down to its first defeat of the season at the hands of Brown University by the score of 2 to 1.

Dr. Allen T. Haight, president of the Allenhaight Realty Corporation, announces that he has sold the fee to the middle of the streets in four subdivided sections at Massapequa, L. I., to the Ogantz Realty Corporation and the Lake Ramona Realty Corporation.

The United States gunboat Oahu today sailed up the Yangtze River to start salvage operations on the U.S.S. Panay, sunk by Japanese bombs Dec. 12. Aboard was Lieut. Comdr. Harold Larner, of the Naval Construction Corps, to superintend salvage.
Award of the Pi Lambda Phi Tolerance Medal for 1937 to Newton D. Baker, former Secretary of War, who died Saturday, was announced yesterday at headquarters of the fraternity, 1,440 Broadway.

Joseph N. Francoeur was returned as Liberal member of the Federal Parliament for Lotbiniere tonight in a byelection. The result promises to influence the course of Canadian politics. His independent opponent, Paul Bouchard, had campaigned on the platform "No war, no armaments for Canada, and more autonomy for Quebec."

Tommy Vogt, a promising young golfer from Westport, Conn., tied J. E. Pearman of Bermuda for top honors in the championship flight as play started today in Belmont Manor's annual Christmas tournament. Each had a card of 77.
Before long, plenty of powerful corporation executives are going to be regretting their loud, insistent demands for a revision of the undistributed profits tax.

Sweeping all opposition before them by their brilliant play, two brothers, Clinton R. Stephens and Warren A. Stephens of the Rutgers Badminton Club, held the spotlight in the first Eastern junior badminton championship tournament, which opened yesterday on the courts of the Old Sixty-ninth Badminton Club in the 165th Infantry Armory.
Funeral services for H. Percy Soule, a member of the news staff of THE NEW YORK TIMES for the last thirty years, were held at 8 o'clock last night in the chapel at 187 South Oxford Street, Brooklyn.

Performances of Rimsky-Korsakoff's opera, "The Bumble Bee Prince," were given yesterday morning and afternoon, at the St. James Theatre by Junior Programs, Inc., an organization formed "to select, produce and promote the finest professional programs for children's audiences and bring them to as many children as possible at the lowest cost."

Rejecting numerous amendments which the Democratic minority said would save the county $133,680, the Westchester County Board of Supervisors adopted today a 1938 county budget and fourteen district budgets in substantially the form in which they were submitted a week ago by its Budget and Appropriations Committee.

Responding with vigor to the diplomatic settlement of the bombing and sinking of the American gunboat Panay, Japanese dollar obligations staged yesterday a rally apart from the remainder of the bond list and in comparatively moderate trading advanced 1 to nearly 8 points.

Cinderella is still the screen's fa-. vorite character. Arlene Whalen, who was a Hollywood manicurist until her discovery by Twentieth Century-Fox talent scouts, has been assigned the leading feminine role in Robert Louis Stevenson's "Kidnapped," which will go before the camera next week.

Full use of the old Fort Schuyler Military Reservation at Throgs Neck will pass to the New York State Merchant Marine Academy PARENT under the terms of a lease being prepared by the War Department for submission to Governor Lehman, according to Roderick Stephens, president of the Bronx Board of Trade.

The Guaranty Trust Company, which is trustee for Norfolk Southern Railroad first general mortgage 5 per cent bonds of 1954, announced yesterday in a letter to the bondholders that it was prepared to accept a distribution of securities of the line, after reorganization, as suggested by Judge Luther B. Way of the Federal court in Norfolk, Va. A hearing on the amended plan of reorganization will be conducted in the court on Jan. 4.

Mrs. Chauncey Marshall of 960 Fifth Avenue gave an afternoon reception with dancing yesterday at 1 East Seventy-seventh Street, the private entrance to the entertaining suite of the apartment building, to introduce to society her granddaughter, Miss Nancy Gilmore Marshall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Marshall of 129 East Eighty-second Street.
Although two of this week's evenings are now free of new shows, neither of the entertainments scheduled for tonight has been willing to postpone. Hence a conflict of premieres, as follows:
The Administration's policy after Dec. 31 on purchases of newly mined domestic silver remained in the field of conjecture today as the White House and Treasury withheld definite information.

Richard William Brown of 411 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, was designated by President Roosevelt today to take the March 1 examination for admission to West Point on July 1. The President also named for the examination George Warren Harris Jr., of Albany.

Charitable bequests totaling $50,000 were contained in the will of Albert A. Troescher, filed for probate here today. Mr. Troescher died at his home in Sayville on Sept. 7. A transfer-tax affidavit gave the value of the estate as "more than $100,000."
Police today arrested ten persons charged with bringing counterfeit American money and securities into Italy, where they were exchanged for Italian currency.

The address delivered last night by Robert H. Jackson, Assistant Attorney General, in which he attacked "monopolies," charging profiteering, drew a reply tonight from General Hugh S. Johnson, former NRA Administrator, who declared in a radio address that it was "a blast of defiance to business."
Under exchange control by the Banco do Brazil, decreed on Dec. 23 and in force today, the market opened without, exchange available for any purpose, including imports.

The Transit Commission, the Corporation Counsel and the receiver for the Manhattan Railway Company were charged yesterday with "seeking to destroy the value of the Interborough bonds" by their demands in connection with the application of the I. R. T. receiver to disaffirm its Manhattan elevated
A dance was given last night at Sherry's by Mr. and Mrs. Ward Melville to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Margaret Melville.

Staff reports prepared by the Imperial Headquarters on the Japanese attacks on the gunboat Ladybird and other British craft have now been fully examined by the Foreign, War and navy offices, and it is expected that the Japanese Government's answer to the British note will be given to Ambassador Sir Robert Leslie Craigie today.

THE NEW YORK TIMES editorial calling for "parallel action between the United States and Britain" to "restore order, decency and safety in the world" was hailed by a section of the British press as the best news that has broken during the Christmas recess.

Horton Smith of Chicago and Leonard Dodson, 25-year-old pro from Springfield, Mo., shot a pair of three-under-par 67s today to share a one-stroke lead in the first round of the $4,000 Hollywood open golf tournament.
Georgia O'Keeffe's fourteenth annual exhibition of paintings opened yesterday at An American Place, 509 Madison Avenue, to continue until Feb. 11.

The Westchester Rangers, making their home debut before a capacity attendance at the new Imperial Arena tonight, dropped their first Metropolitan Amateur Hockey League decision, bowing to the Crescent A. C., 2 to 1, as Joe Callahan tallied in the third period to break a 1-1 deadlock.

Army's new athletic policy, limiting the eligibility of athletes to three years of varsity intercollegiate competition, will go into effect at the beginning of the Fall semester on July 1, 1938, it was announced yesterday by Major Gen. William D. Connor, superintendent of the United States Military Academy.

Storm-crippled and listing badly, the Panama freighter Beulah docked here today with one officer missing and another injured. Her first officer, Trygve Bragdo, was swept overboard while the 1,042-ton vessel wallowed in heavy seas near Carmanah Light on the south coast of Vancouver Island yesterday.
The Rev. Gilbert Rumsey Underhill, rector emeritus of St. Mark's Protestant Episcopal Church of Hammonton, died today at Kings Park, L. I., at the age of 87 years.

More than 500 students from colleges throughout the United States came to the Vassar campus. today for the third annual convention of the American Student Union and were greeted by a message from President Roosevelt which declared that "so long as our printing presses, radios and schools are kept free, I do not have any great anxiety about the future success of our democratic system."

Before the arrival here today of Senators Edward R. Burke, Tom Connally, Warren R. Austin and William H. King to investigate the need for increasing the Supreme Court from five members to seven members, Miguel A. Garcia Mendez,
Following a report that Louise Campbell "wanted to die" because a shot from her pistol killed her mother, sheriff's deputies closely guarded her tonight at the Trumbull County jail.

Coming from behind in the home stretch, S. J. Molay's Fire Advance nosed out Mrs. C. C. Winters's Proprietary in a photo finish to win the mile and a sixteenth feature for players at the Fair Grounds today.

A revival of true religion is needed today more than a revival of business, Dean Frank Glenn Lankard of Brothers College of Drew University declared yesterday at the opening of the twentyeighth annual meeting of the National Association of Biblical Instructors. The two-day meeting is being held at Union Theological Seminary, Broadway and 120th Street.

City College's victory over New York University, the defending champion, marked play in the first round of the annual tournament of the Intercollegiate Chess League for possession of the Harold M. Phillips Trophy at the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. William Jay Schieffelin gave a reception yesterday afternoon at their home, 620 Park Avenue, for their debutante granddaughters, Miss Ann Louise Schieffelin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Jay Schieffelin Jr. and Miss Alice D. Osborn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Osborn.
California's Golden Bears moved into Pasadena today, nearing the climax of a gridiron victory parade that started last Fall and moved with clock-like precision to the Rose Bowl.

The report of the El Paso Natural Gas Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Nov. 30, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $1,812,516 after interest, depreciation, amortization, taxes and other charges.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 31,000, including 8,000 directs. The market was mostly 25 cents lower than Friday's average; 25 to 35 cents lower late on butchers, 280 pounds up. Bulk good and choice 150-200 pounds. $8.10-$8.40; 210-240 pounds, $7.75-$8.25; 250-300 pounds, $7.30-$7.80. Most good packing sows, $6.35. $6.65, a few $6.75. Shippers, 5,000; estimated holdover, 1,000.

Mr. and Mrs. Louis Connick of this city and Mr. and Mrs. August Mattern Sartorius of Tenafly, N. J., gave a supper dance last night in the ballroom of the Pierre to introduce to society their daughters, Miss Barbara Joan Connick and Miss Beverly Sartorius.

The greatest of all college basketball double-headers was staged before the greatest of all Madison Square Garden court crowds--18,148 spectators-last night as Stanford defeated City College, 45 to 42, and Minnesota vanquished Long Island University, 56 to 41.

James Congdon, St. George's, won by default from Stuart Cool, Westport B. C.; Harry Bernard, Trinity B. C., defeated J. Cameron Greenleaf Jr., Pomfret, 15-0, 15-4; Aubrey V. Gould, St. George's, defeated Phil Arnold Jr., Gorton High School, 15-3. 15-5; W. D. Twining, St. George's, won by default from David Edgar, Lawrence High School: John I. Merritt, Woodbury Forest. defeated F. Sanford Cutter,

The New York Trust Company announced yesterday the proposed sale at public auction on Jan. 26, by Adrian H. Muller Sons, at 18 Vesey Street, of 10,000 capital shares of no-par value stock of the American Trading Company, Inc., which secure an issue of $50,000 five-year 6 per cent notes of Amtraco Corporation.
The Home Owners Loan Corporation, reviewing its activities for the last year, reported today that delinquencles had been reduced $8,678,140.

The appointment of T. H. Cooper as controller of the Canadian National Railways was announced yesterday by D. C. Grant, financial vice president. Mr. Cooper succeeds J. B. McLaren, who is retiring after forty-five years of service with the company.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Dec. 22: Willard, Comdr. C. L., Dental Corps, when discharged from treatment Naval Hospital, Washington, D. C., to home, relieved all active duty.

The two-story varnish plant of the C. A. Woolsey Paint and Color Company, at 145-53 Colden Street, Jersey City, has been sold to the Columbia Paint and Varnish Works through Ben Schlossberg, Inc., broker, for $20,000 cash.

Judge J. Wallace Leyden of the Bergen County Orphans Court signed today an order granting half of the $300,000 estate of Gustav Pitsch to the Sisters of St. Joseph of Peace, a convent at Englewood Cliffs.
The opening event of the Colony Dances, a subscription series for girls who will be introduced to society in future years, took place last night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton.

Frederick I. Bergen has been nominated as 1938 president of the Crescent Athletic Club. Other officers on the slate, which will be voted on at the club's annual meeting on Jan. 24, are William M. Tomlins, vice president; William E. Warland, treasurer, and Colonel Frederick H. Stevenson, secretary.

The Securities and Exchange Commission reported today odd-lot transactions on the New York Stock Exchange on Friday as follows: Customers' orders to buy, 5,910, for 154,177 shares; customers' orders to sell, 3,960, for 121,250 shares.

Foster Strader, former district manager here of the Railway Audit and Inspection Bureau, appeared yesterday before Abraham S. Wechsler, chief of the Division of Licenses, in the State Building, 80 Center Street, and made a personal plea for a license as a private detective.

This pioneer Winter sports region in the heart of the Adirondacks reverberated with the rollicking cries of skiers and skaters today as Lake Placid provided a vast holiday throng with its best snow and ice conditions in almost two years.

Hy-Grade Covered Button Co, renewal, Charmaine Trading Corp, dresses: Ace Jewelry Co, Max Oberman, embroidery, in 315 W 36th St; A. B. S. Fur Co. Inc; K B Button Co, renewals, in 307 W 36th St; Foremost Undergarment Co. Inc, renewals, in 164 Madison Ave; J. G. White Realty Corp. in 450 7th Ave. broker.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the last three days:

It took the British Association for the Advancement of Science a decade to realize that a biologist, a physicist or chemist is not an anchorite of the laboratory but a responsible member of society. The realization bore fruit at the historic Blackpool meeting of 1936.

Active selling of leading stocks yesterday was attributed mainly to the speech attacking "monopolies" made by Assistant Attorney General Robert H. Jackson on Sunday, but was heightened by the receipt in Wall Street of several reports on the status of new corporation-tax proposals which agreed in all essentials.

The fifth week of the Metropolitan Opera season began last night with a performance of "Tannhaeuser." Last night's capacity audience and houses that are already sold out for several other performances this week indicated that the holiday period would bring the Metropolitan the best business. of the season thus far.

Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President, and Mrs. James Roosevelt Roosevelt, his half sister-inlaw, who are members of the holiday house party at the White House, and Mrs. Hull. wife of the Secretary of State, attended today Mrs. Lawrence Townsend's ninetyeighth musical morning at the Mayflower Hotel.

The Middle Atlantic States Regional Unit of Secondary Schools of the National Catholic Educational Association was formed yesterday at a meeting of more than 400 Catholic educators at the Bishop McDonnell Memorial High School, Classon Avenue and Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn.

Mary Ann Collins, 4 years old, who with a brother, William, 10 months, and their mother, Mrs. Agnes Collins, 36, was severely burned when a short circuit ignited the Christmas tree in their home at 322 East Thirty-fourth Street Sunday, received a blood transfusion yesterday in Bellevue Hospital.
The Mexican Ambassador, Francisco Castillo Najera, conferred today with Sumner Welles, UnderSecretary of State, about plans for speeding construction of the proposed Pan American Highway.
The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company has sold to the Asiatic Petroleum Corporation the old plant of the Vacuum Oil Company on the west shore of the Kill Van Kull in the Constable Hook section of Bayonne.

The city of Niles, Mich., will consider sealed proposals on Jan. 4 for an issue of $330,000 of 3 3/4 per cent bonds for sewer improvement purposes. The issue will be dated Oct. 1, 1937, and will mature serially on Oct. 1, 1940 to 1963.
Increased Federal regulation of forest lands of the nation was recommended today by F. A. Silcox, chief of the Forestry Service of the Agricultural Department, in his annual report.

Orval W. Adams of Salt Lake City announced through the Republican National Committee today that he had declined to serve on the party's program committee because of the "non-partisan character" of his duties as president of the American Bankers Association.

Libraries have been spending their book-buying funds on worth-while non-fiction to such an extent that the public is going to the corner drug store library for the rest of its reading, Ralph R. Shaw of Gary, Ind., charged today.

John Ballantyne, president of . the Manufacturers National Bank and dean of Detroit bankers, died early today following an illness, at first believed minor, after a slight stroke six weeks ago. His age was 69.

The United States Government has decided to maintain a hands-off policy with reference to the showing of motion pictures of the Japanese attack on the United States gunboat Panay, refraining from exercising any censorship, even by suggestion.

Rallying for two goals in the third period, the Brock Hall team of New Haven, Conn., topped the St. Nicholas Hockey Club, 4 to 3, in an exhibition contest at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. It marked the initial contest at the Brooklyn rink since it was remodeled this Winter.

Every seeded player in both divisions came through and few were extended to any considerable degree as the national junior and boys' indoor tennis championships got under way yesterday on the courts of the Seventh Regiment Armory.

A 'cellist of extensive accomplishments played a formidable program last night in Town Hall and was cordially received by an audience which included many of his fellowprofessionals. He was Maurice Eisenberg, who has been in Europe for ten years and who gave on this occasion his first American recital.

Miss Marjorie Jean Carlin, daughter of Colonel and Mrs. Walter Jeffreys Carlin of 35 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, who was introduced to society in that borough on Thanksgiving Eve at the annual debutante ball in the Heights Casino, made her debut here yesterday afternoon at a large tea dance given by her parents in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton.

Changing trends in the financing of American business were viewed as a major factor in the business recession here today as eleven organizations opened their annual session under the auspices of the Allied Social Science Associations.

A plan for the reorganization of the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railway Company which holds the equity of common stockholders to be of no value, was recommended today to the Interstate Commerce Commission by Milo H. Brinkley, examiner.
A measure designed to prevent excessive increases in the rents of tenement dwellers is being prepared for submission to the New York State Legislature, it was learned yesterday.

William H. Andrews, 41 years old, who gave the Ambassador Hotel as his address and said that for the last two years he had been a broker in Toronto, Canada, pleaded guilty yesterday before General Sessions Judge Wallace to a charge of attempted robbery in the third degree. He was remanded to the Tombs for sentence Jan. 10.

Charles Edward Marling, a retired investment broker, brother of the late Alfred Erskine Marling, died yesterday of anemia at his home, 11 East Sixty-eighth Street, after an illness of six months. He was in his seventies.

Miss Carol Louise Wilmot, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Wilmot of Port Chester, N. Y., was martried to Curtis Ronald Andrews, of Henry F. Andrews of Norwich, Conn., and the late Mrs. Andrews, at noon yesterday in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church here.
Miss Madeline Schiffer of Elberon, N. J., and Miss Marjory Hasler of Rumson, N. J., are two more youthful riders who will compete for horsemanship honors in Madison Square Garden next year.

John Edgar Briggs, who had been associated with the marine division of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad and its subsidiaries for more than fifty years, died yesterday in the Marine Hospital at Stapleton, S. I., after a long illness.
There was no solution to the political crisis today following the resignation of Premier George Tatarescu after the publication of official election returns.

The president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company received a salary of $206,250 and director's fees of $4,400 in 1936, making him the highest paid head of any communications company, the Federal Communications Commission reported today.
Mr. and Mrs. H. Edward Manville are leaving today for Phoenix, Ariz. They will sail from the West Coast on Jan. 28 for Honolulu and will return here via the Panama Canal early in April.
Dr. William Edgar Darnall, surgeon and president of the Atlantic City Hospital Association and well-known gynecologist, died' today. He was 68 years old.

Directors of the Holly Sugar Corportion declared yesterday a dividend of $2 a share on the common stock in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of $1.75 a share on the preferred stock, the same as were declared a year ago at this time.
The Ford Motor Company today retained Frederick H. Wood, the New York lawyer who helped kill the NRA, to direct its legal fight against the National Labor Relations Board.

Father Knickerbocker will save $500,000 next year on the cost of lighting the city's streets and public buildings under a series of new contracts with the service companies announced yesterday by Mayor La Guardia.

The isolation of six mysterious chemicals from cells of yeast or living cells of animal tissues, which promise to provide important new clues to the cancer process and possibly may lead to new methods of treatment, was reported here today before the opening sessions of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

Mr. and Mrs. Harry C. Olmstead gave a tea at their home here this afternoon, at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rowena E. Olmstead, to G. John Francis, son of Mr. and Mrs. G. M. Francis of Teaneck, N. J.

Reorders for the cheaper lines of dresses, to retail at $3.98 to about $7.98, were the chief features of the mail requests coming into manufacturers and resident offices here yesterday, they reported.

Elliott Roosevelt, son of President Roosevelt, was appointed president and general manager of the Hearst chain of radio stations, according to an announcement yesterday by Joseph V. Connolly, chairman of the board of directors of Hearst Radio, Inc. Mr. Roosevelt will take over his duties Jan. 1, 1938.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The organization calling itself "Publicity Associates" has favored me with a copy of its letter to THE TIMES, in which, purporting to answer my criticism published in THE TIMES of Dec. 23, it acknowledges and attempts to justify its share in the recent radio broadcast by the Japanese Ambassador on the Panay incident.

THERE is a calm and beatific peace over the holiday streets of the Borough of Manhattan, City of New York, this week. It is not entirely due to the fact that the country, for the moment at any rate, has managed to steer clear of the civilizing effects of aerial bombardment nor is it entirely a remainder of the glow of Christmas. Life has changed for the city this Winter.
Mrs. Delafield Du Bois gave a dinner last night in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador and a theatre party later for her daughter, Miss Theodora Du Bois.

Dr. Charles Huntington Whitman, whose work as head of the English Department at Rutgers University since 1911 had earned him wide recognition in academic circles, died at his home in Highland Park this morning of coronary thrombosis at the age of 64.

It is increasingly evident to observers here that the monetary authorities of the United States are more than pleased with the stabilization fund, the secret workings of which have been criticized by some New York financiers. It appears to have become more than a transitory device.
The office of Prosecutor William Wachenfeld announced today that the county grand jury would reconvene tomorrow to continue the investigation of Newark's municipal affairs.

An anonymous admirer of Mayor La Guardia has purchased for him a twenty-inch wooden figure of the Mayor by Warren Wheelock, noted sculptor and painter, it was announced last night. The figure, done in lignum vitae, an exceptionally hard wood, is one of the displays at the exhibition

Shipping operators in the coastwise and intercoastal trades said yesterday that their vessels had sailed during the last ten days with their heaviest cargoes in many weeks. The ships in some foreign trades, notably African and Australian, also were reported heavily loaded.

Describing himself as an enthusiastic New Dealer and a thorough believer in democracy, Jerome N. Frank was sworn in today as a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission. He said also that he was a believer in the profit system, and that the New Deal was trying to find a way to make it operate intelligently under a democracy.

Charlie Keller, outfielder of the Newark Bears, carried off the individual batting championship of the International League for 1937 with an average of .353, according to the official figures announced yesterday.

Tsinan, the capital of Shantung Province in North China, was voluntarily opened for foreign settlement in 1906. After the opening of the Tientsin-Pukow railway it grew rapidly and was modernized by Western methods and the erection of many new buildings.

Benjamin Newman, 32 years old, of 302 Eighth Street, this city, manager of a four-story, sixteenfamily apartment house at 447 New York Avenue, was sentenced to ninety days in the Hudson County Jail today in default of a $100 fine by Acting Recorder Mervin Herzfeld in police court on a charge of violating the city health ordinance, by failing to provide proper heat for the building.

To operate profitably, department stores must eliminate costly services that have cut net profits and consider the methods practiced by specialty and variety chains, D. F. Kelly, president of The Fair, Chicago, declares in a telegram to THE NEW YORK TIMES, commenting on prospects for 1988.

Professor Edwin Grant Conklin, Princeton biologist and retiring president of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, sounded the keynote at the official opening of America's annual "Parliament of Science" here tonight by calling on the scientists of the democratic countries to "use their utmost influence to see that intellectual freedom does not perish from the earth."

The American Trustee Share Corporation, Jersey City, an investment trust, has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Securities Act of 1933, covering 1,800,000 diversified trust shares, seriesD, to be offered at the market for estimated cash proceeds of $10,170,000. The proceeds will be used for investment.

Aided by a brilliant doublecentury from the bat of Don Bradman, South Australia piled up 429 runs for eight wickets against Queensland's meager 93 in the second day's play of a Sheffield shield cricket match.

Examination Notice Regular leaves of absence shall terminate, and off-tours of duty shall be discontinued, for members below the rank of lieutenant (who are not participating in the examination), in units of the three platoon system, from 8 A. M., and from 9 A. M. in units of the two platoon system, on Wednesday, Dec. 29, 1937, until the return of the candidates from the examination for promotion to lieutenant.

Mr. and Mrs. John D. Butt of 1,373 Dean Street, Brooklyn, gave a luncheon yesterday at the Westbury at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Butt, to J. Warren Mesereau, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jones W. Mesereau of White Plains, N. Y.

Excepting a few miscellaneous cuts which were active, trading was generally slow, Steer beef and lamb cuts were weak to lower; some sales veal and calf were lower; fresh pork cuts sold unevenly. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef prices to be steady to lower; veal and calf steady to weak: lamb sharply higher, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

W. L. Sayre has been appointed district sales manager in the New York district for the Edison General Electric Appliance Company, Inc., of Chicago, it was announced yesterday. John C. Sharp has been named chief engineer.
State Supreme Court Justice O. Byron Brewster of Elizabethtown, said tonight that he would not be the first president of Paul Smith's College of Arts and Sciences.
Robert H. Jackson's radio talk was a remarkable performance, and the more closely it is examined, the more remarkable it becomes.

One hundred and twelve colleges, thirty preparatory schools and fifty-eight high schools will have representatives present this morning when the second annual College and School Service Christmas Conference under auspices of THE NEW YORK TIMES opens at the Hotel Biltmore. Late registrations yesattendance to 720, with 684 reservations for the luncheon at noon.
Miss Carol Smith, daughter of Mrs. Ernest E. Smith of this city, was married this afternoon to August Zinsser Jr., son of Mrs. H. M. Zinsser of New York and August Zinsser of New York.

The central sales depot of His Master's Voice Radio and Gramophone Company, occupying a four-story landmark in Oxford Street. London's chief shopping thorough fare, was destroyed today in the West End's fiercest fire in years.
A storm of criticism broke today around the ears of Don Budge, who lazily permitted Germany's Baron Gottfried von Cramm to beat him, 6-1, 6-3, in an exhibition tennis match.
The Pennsylvania Railroad announced today that arrangements had been made to transport War Admiral, Kentucky Derby winner, from his quarters at Berlin, Md.,

New York Stereotypers Union 1 and New York Electrotypers Union 100 announced yesterday that they had negotiated with the Electrotypers and Stereotypers Association an agreement establishing the fiveday, forty-hour week, Monday to Friday inclusive, effective Jan. 1, 1938.

Mrs. Sophie Arcuri, 24 years old, of Greenbrook Road here, cut the throat of the 5-month-old baby of her landlady this afternoon and placed the body under the infant's Christmas tree, Chief of Police George Kafka reported tonight.

The wedding of Miss Patricia Eleanor O'Callaghan, daughter of Mrs. Thomas A. O'Callaghan of this place, and William Sheperdson Abell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Abell of Chevy Chase, Md., took place this morning in the Immaculate Conception Church here.

Mrs. Edith Carleton Leavitt Round, first president of the Riverside Parent-Teachers Association here and descendant of a Colonial Governor of Massachusetts, died last night at her home at the age of 57.

Deferring to a personal request ot Mayor La Guardia, officials of the Milk Wagon Drivers Union, Local 584 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and Chauffeurs, withheld taking any action on a threatened strike against the four independent milk companies participating in the city's plan to sell bottled Grade B milk at 9 cents a quart until they had conferred with the Mayor this morning at City Hall.

German and Japanese engineers are now constructing in Fushun, Manchuria, a plant to make fuel oil from coal which will make the Japanese Navy entirely independent of foreign supplies. The announcement appeared here today in the Krupp Company's bimonthly journal.

Presenting two new German players, Anneliese Uhlig and Albert Matterstock, and holding the audience in suspense until the end, "Stimme des Blutes" ("Blood Bond"), the Christmas week offering at the Eighty-sixth Street Casino Theatre, is much superior to the average circus film.

The original manuscript of an early choralsymphonic score by Jan Sibelius, the Finnish composer, has disappeared while en route from Europe to Boston, a Boston Symphony Orchestra official disclosed today.

The troubled relations over the killing of a large number of Haitians on Dominican territory which for several weeks threatened open hostilities between Haiti and Santo Domingo now appear to be on the way toward pacification. President Trujillo,

Declaring that Jersey City has been a sort of sanctuary for the preservation of ideal labor-employer relations, and charging that the C. I. O. thrived on violence, disputes and disorders, Mayor Frank Hague made public today a statement in which he gave his reasons for opposing the union's campaign here.

Edmund H. Driggs 3d, 19 years old, a sophomore at Princeton University, was overcome about 11 o'clock yesterday morning by coal gas fumes escaping from a wall ventilator in his room at the Princeton Club, 39 East Thirty-ninth Street, where he was staying as the guest of his father.

Denying published reports of dissension in the American Labor party, Alex Rose said yesterday that he had withdrawn his offer to resign as State executive secretary and would continue in that capacity. Mr. Rose explained that the pressure for his resignation came entirely from his own union and that this now had been withdrawn.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has amended its rules under the Public Utility Holding Company Act relating to officers and directors approved by a Federal court in proceedings under Section 77B of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

Christmas mail delayed by the grounding of the liner President Hoover on Hoishoto Island, near Formosa, was distributed here today. The liner President Grant arrived yesterday with 1,500 sacks of mail taken off the Hoover, which grounded Dec. 10.

Announcement was made yesterday that the inductions of James J. Conroy, former first assistant district attorney, and former County Clerk Thomas J. Towers as justices of the City Court in Queens, to which positions they were elected at the last election, would take place Monday at noon in the court room of Trial Term, Part I, of the City Court.

Mrs. Adam Schaub celebrated her 103d birthday today at her home, 110 Mount Joy Place, by knitting and reading messages from President Roosevelt, Governor Lehman, Cardinal Hayes and officials of New Rochelle. Attributing her longevity to an active life, free from smoking and drinking, she said she still walks to church on Sunday and "can't be bothered with eyeglasses."

In the admittedly "rash" but "tempting" role of a prophet Professor Thomas Reed Powell of the Harvard Law School, delivering his presidential address tonight before the American Political Science Association, weighed the distant effects of the Supreme Court crisis in this sesqui-centennial year of the Constitution's adoption.

An order has been issued by the Securities and Exchange Commission granting an application by the Chicago Stock Exchange to strike from listing and registration the no-parvalue $3 cumulative participating preferred stock of United Chemicals, Inc., of New York City, the delisting having been sought because the Chicago transfer office of the company is being discontinued.
Members of the city Police Department have given $9,645 to the United Hospital campaign, it was announced last night by David H. McAlpin Pyle, president of the United Hospital Fund.

Strong indications that anti-monopoly legislation sponsored by the Administration would have far more united support than any of President Roosevelt's recent proposals appeared evident today in Congressional circles.
Going the way of many football coaches after a disastrous season, Harvey J. Harman, head coach at the University of Pennsylvania, has resigned.

Stockholders of the Republic Steel Corporation have received a letter from the board of directors blaming labor difficulties and repressive legislation for the frustration of "earlier hopes that a common stock dividend would be possible" in 1987.
The number of industrial and commercial failures in the United States in the week ended Dec. 23 were higher in four groups, and were unchanged in the commercial service division, as compared with

Al Reid, 126 3/4 pounds, Bronx, won a close decision over Jack Sharkey Jr., 129 1/2, Union City, N. J., in the main eight-round bout at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn, last night before a capacity crowd.

The leading Bruins pulled 6 points ahead of the second-place Rangers in the American Division of the National Hockey League by outbattling Lester Patrick's youngsters for a 3-2 victory tonight before an overflow crowd of 16,000 at the Boston Garden.

Spanish Insurgent troops tonight stormed the heights dominating Teruel in a determined drive to retake the captured provincial capital and rescue a force of beleaguered comrades. They had orders from Generalissimo Francisco Franco to win back the city, a strategic point on the eastern front, regardless of cost.

Miss Maria Cerra of Hunter College won the women's annual invitation fencing competition after a fence-off with Miss Elizabeth Bruskin of Brooklyn College yesterday on the strips of New York University. Third place went to a...

In accordance with the requirements of the new City Charter, Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx announced yesterday the appointment of that borough's three-man Planning Board, which will assist the City Planning Commission.
The list of the Hamburg-American liner Hamburg, due today from the Channel ports, includes Count Hermann Keyserling, the writer, and the Countess; Karel Kozeluh, tennis player: Otto C.

Business of the General Outdoor Advertising Company in the fourth quarter of 1937 was as good or slightly better than in the same period last year, Alexander L. Bauers, vioe president, said at the special

Wage increases were decreed today by the Province of Quebec Fair Wage Board of all workers whose pay is less than that set by minimumwage ordinances for specific categories and a simultaneous increase of 5 to 10 per cent was ordered in the minimum now legally fixed. The orders will add $26,000,000 a year to the wages of Quebec workers.

A special rogues gallery and an extradition bureau are in the process of formation for the New York World's Fair in 1939 to deal with crooks who prey on. "suckers" at big expositions, Charles P. Sullivan, District Attorney of Queens, announced yesterday.

Gifts totaling $440,200 have been received up to last night by the industry section of the United Hospital Campaign, according to a report by Walter C. Teagle, chairman of the section. The industry section contributions already have exceeded last year's total by $1,000, Mr. Teagle said.

Current business trends, unemployment and the condition of the railroad industry were discussed by President Roosevelt today in conferences with officials and business leaders, including Bernard M. Baruch, Carroll M. Miller, chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, and John Biggers, director of the Unemployment Census.

ADAMS-At Greenwich, Conn., on Monday, Dec. 27, 1937, Percy D., husband of Alice Pinkham Adams, father of Mrs. Lawrence Dalley, Gardner and Demarest Adams, brother of Mabel Adams. Funeral services at Fred D. Knapp Son Memorial Chapel on Thursday, Dec. 30, at 2:30 P. M.

Dean George F. Bateman of the Schools of Engineering of Cooper Union married Miss Mildred S. Wolf, registrar of the Schools of Engineering of the same institution, Monday afternoon in the Church of the Holy Apostles here.

Canada Cement Company, Ltd., and Subsidiaries-Year to Nov. 30: Net income, $1,461,054, equal after preference dividends, to 26 cents each on 600,000 common shares, compared with $717,907 or $3.57 each on common stock in preceding year.

Last year the Legal Aid Society of New York, first of its kind, was sixty years old. It is the parent of nearly a hundred similar societies. In 1936 the combined docket included 250,000 cases. The sixty-first annual report of

George Sauter, painter and winner of a Carnegie Institute medal, died today. He was 71 years old. Born in Rettenbach, Bavaria, George Sauter studied at the Royal Academy, Munich, and when 23 years old went to London. After painting many portraits there, he traveled extensively on the Continent, and in 1895 returned to London.

As a result of the plan of most men's clothing manufacturers and retailers to shorten the regular Spring selling season and lengthen the promotional period on Summer clothing in 1938, both national and local advertising for the latter type will probably reach a new all-time high, advertising agents remarked yesterday.
Both Uldine M. Utley, who first became known as a child evangelist, and her sister, Ovilla, a secretary, obtained marriage licenses at the Municipal Building yesterday and will be married on Friday.
The American Chamber of Commerce met today to study the foreign exchange situation created by decree giving a monopoly to the Banco do Brazil. Pending detailed

The Crystal Garden of the RitzCarlton was the setting last night for a dinner dance at which Miss Martha Scott Clayton, daughter of Mrs. August Zinsser, and Miss Virginia Hoffmann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Hoffmann, were introduced to society.

Officials of the Treasury Department said today that the policy of buying silver from Mexico which has been on a month-to-month basis this year would be continued during January as usual. The government has never made known the exact

After attending night schools for more than ten years, James F. Quinn, a 28-year-old patrolman of the career type-the kind that Mayor La Guardia has in mind for promotion to the magistrates' bench or other high office-has received his reward. It was announced at headquarters yesterday that Quinn was now a ful-fledgedr lawyr.

About 30,000 production men in General Motors plants throughout the United States are to be laid off'immediately, William S. Knudsen, president of the company, announced here today. He also declared that the remaining 205,000 men would be reduced to a three-day 24-hour week because of a decline in sales.
Setting aside a portion of an $804,200 assessment made by Newark against the Household Finance Corporation, the Supreme Court held today that taxation of chattel mortgage loans was improper.

Apartment buildings in various sections of the Bronx led in realty sales activity in that borough yesterday. Joseph B. Miller, as trustee for certificate holders, sold to Joseph Berger, for cash, the six-story apartment house at 1,049 Fox Street. The house, on a plot 100 by 100 feet, contains forty-two suites and 147 rooms.

Although the police and several hundred volunteers searched all last night and until dusk today, they were unable to find '"Smiling Joe" Thomas, Negro, who fled from Hudson Hospital last night and hid in the meadows. A day before his

A committee to study plans for reorganizing the New York City school system with a view to strengthening the vocational division and removing trade courses from the academic schools has been named, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, disclosed Yesterday.

Salt River Project, Agricultural Improvement and Purification District, Arizona, will consider sealed proposals on Jan. 3 for an issue of $3,197,000 of bonds at an interest rate not exceeding 5 per cent. The bonds will be dated Oct. 1, 1937, and will mature serially on Jan. 1, 1948 to 1964.

Healing a breach which the Academy feels will make the 1937 awards the most significant of any since the practice was started, the Screen Actors Guild and the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences have reached a compromise on balloting on the most distinguished performances of the year.

President Roosevelt revealed today that he probably will ask Congress to authorize an enlargement of the naval building program beyond the $564,406,461 earmarked for the fiscal year 1939. Many nations are increasing their armaments, and "despite his every conceivable effort to stop the trend," he said, "facts nevertheless are facts, and the United States must recognize them."

Thousands of Buffalo families, who had groped in the dark with flashlights and candles as a result of a fire which started in a huge generating station in Tonawanda at 9:22 o'clock this morning, had current restored to them at 6:22 o'clock this evening.

A general strike of Paris public service workers was launched at 5:30 A. M. today when subway employes suspended operations on all lines. The strike call embraced workers in gas, electricity and water services also.

An Issue or $5,625,000 in first mortgage bonds, 4 1/2 per cent series due in 1947 and one of $800,000 of serial notes due from 1989 to 1943 of the St. Joseph Railway Light, Heat and Power Company, a total of $6,425,000, will be marketed today by an underwriting group

Startling experiments which reveal that ?? force within the roots of living plants, hitherto believed to be very small, is actually of a gigantic nature, capable of overcoming with ease counter-pressures of 125 pounds to the square inch, the equivalent of a pressure of eight atmospheres, was reported here today before the American Association for the Advancement of Science by Dr. Philip R. White of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Researcn.

There are pitfalls even in the dancing business, 150 teachers declared yesterday as they shuffled around the Florentine Room of the Hotel Park Central and perfected the latest steps with the opening of their third annual two-day convention and Christmas Normal School.

Charles Betts Hillhouse, formerly with the New York Produce Exchange and a member of a New England family whose ancestors came here on the Mayflower, died yesterday morning after a short illness at his home, the Hotel Westbury, 15 East Sixty-ninth Street. His age was 81.
The Japanese reply to Great Britain's note regarding the attacks on the gunboat Ladybird and other British vessels on the Yangtze River was handed to Sir Robert L. Craigie tonight.
Exports of merchandise from the United States exceeded imports by $91,456,000 in November last, and for the first eleven months of the current year exports were $151,670,000 above the import values,

No appreciable progress toward reducing the "fantastic" mortality rate in the millinery industry can be achieved until a $12 a dozen wholesale price and a $1.65 retail price are made the minima for the industry, 0. W. Pearson, director of the Millinery Stabilization Commission, declared yesterday.

The Rev. and Mrs. James Elmer McKee of All Saints' Rectory, Peterborough, N. H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Grace Eugenia McKee, to Samuel Sumner Verbeck, son of Colonel and Mrs. Guido F. Verbeck of the Manlius School, Manlius. N.Y.

After intimating that he might show Broadway his portrayal of Falstaff in "King Henry IV, Part I" for a brief engagement next month, Maurice Evans has changed his mind, and will wait until next season.

The Chicago Board of Trade notified all its members today to postpone trading in September, 1938, grain future contracts "until further notice." Officials indicated the delay was ordered because of a pending decision by the Commodity Exchange Administration on proposed changes in trading regulations.

The engagement of Grand Duchess Kira Kirilowna, daughter of Grand Duke Cyril,. pretender to the Russian throne, to Prince Louis Ferdinand, second son of the former German Crown Prince Friedrich Wilhelm and Crown Princess Cecilie, will be solemnized at a family reunion at Doorn tomorrow.
