Centralization in the State of the collection of taxes for relief purposes and maintenance of local administration of relief were recommended today in the third section of a report prepared by the Joint Legislative Committee on State Fiscal Policies.

Romaine A. Philpot, banker and a descendant of distinguished Englishmen, died on Monday in his home, 2,070 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, after a short illness. In the last few years he had been semiretired.

Mr. and Mrs. Russell Wheeler Strong of this community have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marguerite Davenport Strong, to Dr. J. W. Theodore Suckau, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Cornelius J. Suckau of Berne, Ind.

Committed to peace, individually and as a group, delegates to the annual convention of the American Student Union, which is in session at the Vassar campus here, nevertheless spent the afternoon wrangling about peace.
Menalcus Lankford, former Repretentative and referee in bankruptcy for the United States District Court here since 1933, died at his. home here yesterday.

Members of the New York Stock Exchange were invited. yesterday to appear before the Committee for the Study of the Organization and Administration- of the Exchange. A letter addressed to them said that "if you or any partner of your firm
A short time ago we touched on Southern deer shooting and the fact that hounds were used. Since then we have had a number of letters on this kind of hunting-some "pro" and some very "con."
In completing her series of six Bach piano recitals last night at Town Hall, Rosalyn Tureck is entitled to congratulation on several points. First, courage.

Horace Dodge of Detroit twice ran his 4,300-pound hydroplane Delphine IX over a mile straightaway today, but failed to break any of three water speed records at which he was shooting. He said he would

The Metropolitan Museum of Art announced yesterday the purchase of seven paintings by living American artists, raising to a total of twenty-eight its acquisitions of native art this year. The pictures will be exhibited about the middle of next month.
The St. John's fencing team vanquished Purdue, 9 1/2 to 7 1/2, in a dual meet at the victor's gymnasium yesterday.
A coroner's verdict of "accidental death" and brief, closely guarded funeral services brought reunion today to 28-year-old Louise Campbell and other descendants of James A. Campbell. steelmaster.

Two pickets arrested on Christmas night in front of a Horn Hardart Automat at 115 East Fourteenth Street were each sentenced to sixty daye in the workhouse yesterday by Magistrate Earl A. Smith in Yorkville Court. The magistrate ascertained from fingerprints, which he examined over the objection of defense counsel, Sidney Cohn, that both defendants had previous convictions.

Kentucky's closed claiming rule was changed to a semi-open one and Mondays were dropped from the 1938 calendars of Churchill Downs, Latonia and Keeneland Park at a meeting of the State Racing Commission today.

Thayer St, 42; 75x84.8: for 6-story tenement; David Markbreiter, 280 E 137th St, Bronx, owner; H. Herbert Lilien, architect; cost $150,000. Alterations 46th St, 12 and 14 W; to two 2-story restaurant and stores; Exchange Estates, Inc, 240 Madison Ave, owner; Arthur Weiser, architect: cost $25,000. 102d St, 212-14 E; to two 5-story tenements; Brurum Realty and Const Co, Inc, 121 W 78th St, owner: Charles N. and Selig Whinston, architects; cost $15,000.
The Foreign Policy Association has published "Europe in Crisis," by Vera Micheles Dean, as the first of a new series of pamphlets on international problems affecting the United States. The pamphlet

Mr. and Mrs. Edward Bonnell Hutchings of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjorie Hutchings, to Morton E. Sanborn of Pleasantville, N. Y., son of Mrs. Beatrice P. Sanborn and the late Morton F. Sanborn.
The government's constantly growing bureaucracy is forcing an increasing number of commercial concerns from the central section of the city.

Part of the choral symphonic score-of "Ukko, the Fire Maker," by Jean Sibelius, which was lost in the mails on the way from Germany, was flashed from Berlin by facsimile radio yesterday so that the Boston Symphony Orchestra might present it in a concert on Friday night.

Mrs. Marie Damrosch Wiechmann, widow of Dr. Ferdinand Wiechmann, chemical engineer, a daughter of the late Dr. Leopold Damrosch, and a sister of Waiter and the late Frank Damrosch, died yesterday at her residence, 317 West Eighfy-seventh Street.

At the close of its best year since 1929 from the viewpoint of earnings, the oil industry, with an investment of some $13,000,000,000, faces the prospect of large capital outlays in 1938, W. S. Farish, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, said yesterday in

The wedding of Miss Matilda Carland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank B. Carland of New York, formerly of this place, to Lieutenant Whiteford Carlisle Mauldin, son of Mrs. Whiteford C. Mauldin of Lockesburg, Ark., and the late Mr. Mauldin, took place this afternoon in Grace Episcopal Church here. The Rev.

The Hershey Chocolate Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of 75 cents on the common stock, the same as paid in preceding quarters. Directors also voted the regular quarterly distribution of $1 and an additional dividend of $1 on the convertible preference stock.

Michael E. Reiburn, 44 years old, of 150 Riverside Drive, who, from 1921 to 1927, represented the Washington Heights district in the Legislature as an Assemblyman and a Senator, was sentenced to a term of eighteen months to three years in Sing Sing yesterday by General Sessions Judge Allen.

Although Japan's reply to Great Britain had not been received in London tonight and probably will not be published until tomorrow, there is every evidence that the British Government would like to consider the recent Yangtze "Incident" as closed.

The tenth anniversary of the establishment of the Fred L. Lavanburg Homes, a non-profit-making model tenement at 124-42 Goerck Street and one of the first low-cost housing enterprises in this city, was celebrated last night by 200 tenants at a party in the basement assembly hall of the building.

Shareholders of the Quebeo Powar Company at a special meeting yesterday approved the adoption of a by-law providing for the elimination of an item of $2,045,450 of bond discount, premium and expense and for a corresponding reduction of the stated value of the common took of the company from $13,394,950 to $11,349,500.
In the Fiji Islands, if a man is insuited he frequently commits suicide to wipe out the memory of the shame, the American Anthropological Association was told today.

The report of the joint legislative committee recommending a revision of the State's fiscal policy was long overdue. That we have it now is due almost entirely to intelligent and conscientious fiscal leadership in the Assembly, and in particular to the work of Abbot Low Moffat, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee.

Miss Muriel Leeney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Leeney of this place, was married this afternoon to Ulric R. Jaeger, son of R. Richard Jaeger of Mamaroneck, in the Westchester Country Club here.

Plunging down the steep descent under perfect control, Miss Elizabeth Flanders, Wellesley College senior, captured the downhill race in the college and junior women's ski competition for the Helen Louise Taylor Trophy today.
A resolution adopted by the board of directors of the Jersey City Chamber of Commerce supports "without any reservations" Mayor Hague's course in keeping C. I. O. representatives out of Jersey City.
Contributions from 205 donors came into the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday in the sum of $4,456.60 and increased the total of the Fund for this twenty-sixth annual appeal to $278,469.47.

The lists comprising yesterday's commercial leasing report included a number of contracts for full floors. Amerop Travel Service, Inc., affiliate of the M. E. R. Corporation (Mitteleuropaeisches Reiseburo), general agents for the German State Railways, the Hungarian Government Railways and other transportation organizations, took the entire nineteenth floor in 400 Madlson Avenue, where the service has occupied smaller quarters for a number of years.

General Iwane Matsui, the Japanese commander in the Yangtze area, threatened today to press Japan's attack 1,000 miles into China's interior. Unless the Chinese Government ends "its anti-Japanese policies," he warned, the Japanese forces "may find it necessary" to advance to Hankow and Chungking, temporary capitals, and "may repudiate the National Government of China."

The National Labor Relations Board announced today that it would file with the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals a petition for a decree enforcing the order against the Ford Motor Company after expiration of the ten days allowed to the company to execute it.

I am now convinced that Nikolai Bukharin, former chief editor of the newspaper Izvestia, is among those who have been executed by Joseph Stalin. Although no official announcement of his death has ever been made, there is no doubt in my mind, or in that of any one else who knows the situation in Russia, that he has been killed.

The agreement between the operators of five large taxi fleets and the Transport Workers Union, a C. I. O. affiliate, was ratified yesterday by 5,000 night-shift drivers at an early morning meeting in the St. Nicholas Arena and by 2,200 day shift men in an evening meeting at Transport Workers Hall, 153 West Sixty-fourth Street.
H. Hentz Co. announced yesterday the reopening of their office in Hollywood, Fla:, under the management of John H. Kaplan and Emile Z. Weinberg.

Baroness Shidzue Ishimoto, Japanese feminist, who was among those taken in a police raid on Dec. 13, is still detained in a police station. She is not accused of any offense but is held for questioning in connection

Daily average sales of chain drug stores in November of this year were 2.5 per cent lower than in the corresponding month last year, a survey made by the Department of Commerce showed today. November sales were down 3.8 per cent from October of this year.

Miss Helen Bernhard, 16-year-old titleholder from New York, today advanced to the semi-final round of the national girls' singles indoor tennis tournament at the Longwood Cricket Club by defeating Miss Enid White of Newton. 6-0. 6-4.

Favorites without exception stroked through the opening round today of the fourth annual Sugar Bowl tennis tournament. Three of the top-seeded stars, in eluding Bobby Riggs, the nation's second-ranking player, had to extend themselves to eliminate lesserknown but hard-fighting opponents.
Justice Willis Van Devanter, who retired in June from the Supreme Court of the United States at the age of 78, will sit as a Federal judge in this district next Tuesday, it was learned yesterday.

Coordination of the transportation agencies of the United States to make for greater efficiency and lowered operating expense was urged yesterday by John M. Fitzgerald, vice chairman of the committee on public relations of the Eastern Railroad Presidents' Conference.

The following Reserve officers, recently promoted, are assigned to units of Third Military Area as indicated below: To 310th Infantry (Englewood District)Capt. William Brill, Inf.-Res., 228 45th St., Union City N. J.; Capt. Charles P. Garbarini, Inf.-Res., 34 Prospect St., Jersey City, N. J.: 1st Lt. Arthur E. Szabo Jr., Int.-Res., 40 W. Palisade Ave., Englewood, N. J.
To see the present milk problem in perspective it is necessary to go back not merely to the passage of the Rogers-Allen act in May of this year but beyond that. Under State milk
Modification of Armour Co.'s plan to simplify its capital structure will be asked at the annual meeting of stockholders scheduled for Jan. 28, it was learned today.

When Congress reconvenes next week the stage will be set for the submission of President Roosevelt's fifth budget. Officials of the Treasury Department and the Budget Bureau are now preparing the estimates on which it will be based.

Commissioner Walter M. W. Splawn was chosen today chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission for the year beginning on Jan. 1, the commission announced. He will succeed Commissioner Carroll Miller, who has been

The cost of distributing goods is being reduced by shifting, modifying and even in some instances eliminating the functions performed by the middleman, according to John F. Thomas of Sears, Roebuck Co., Chicago.

William E. Stevenson, New York lawyer, has purchased the property of Mary S. Tisdale and adjoining acreage from Otto Sarrach on Briar Brae Road, in Stamford, Conn., through Kenneth Ives Co. The purchase comprises about thirty-three acres with a remodeled Colonial residence, the main section of which dates back to about 1760.

A report exonerating: two policemen in the fatal shooting of Frank Converse, 18 years bold, while the youth was fleeing arrest on a theft charge, was made public yesterday by District Attorney William C. Dodge after it had been sent to Commissioner Valentine on Monday.

Daily average sales of general merchandise in small towns and rural areas during November were 5 per cent higher in the Far West than for the corresponding month in 1936, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Mrs. Clarence Handley Terhune of this city and Allenhurst, N. J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Mrs. Virginia Terhune Monroe, to Alex Sayles of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Robert Sayles of Montclair, N. J. The marriage will take place on Jan. 6.

Several thousand men and women employed by the Frank G. Shattuck Company in the forty-six Schrafft's restaurants in this city, Newark, White Plains, Boston, Syracuse and Philadelphia and in the Schrafft's candy factories here and in Boston, Wallace Co.'s candy factory in Brooklyn and the Schrafft's Sales Company here received Christmas bonuses, Gerald Shattuck, president, said yesterday.

Charles E. Lauriat, president of Charles E. Lauriat Company, booksellers, and nationally known as a collector of rare books and prints, died suddenly tonight at the Wyman House in Cambridge. He was in his sixtythird year.

California Water Service Company--Twelve months to Nov. 30: Gross corporate income before bond interest and depreciation, $1,225,125, against $1,203,862 in twelve months to Nov. 30, 1936; gross revenues, $2,457,073, against $2,345,090.

Three thousand veterans who packed the basement assembly hall of the 113th Regiment Armory here tonight, pledged themselves to defend Myor Frank Hague's ban on the "C. I. O. and other subversive organizations."

Semi-Final Round-Clinton P. Stephens, Rultgers B. C., defeated Aubrey V. Gould, St. George's, 15-1, 15-2; Warren A. Stephens, Rutgers B. C., defeated Joseph T. Thayer Jr., St. George's 15-4, 15-8. Final-Clinton P. Stephens defeated Warren A. Stephens, 15-12, 15-11.

In a move which would affect thousands of commuters and tourists, the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad proposed tonight to abandon seventy-two stations in Massachusetts, including many in the Summer resort area of Cape Cod.

Ralph Dawson Jr. of Trinity School, ranked eighth, became the first of the seeded players in the current national junior indoor tennis championship competition to fall by the wayside when he succumbed to George Kraft of Erasmus Hall in a third round encounter at the Seventh Regiment Armory yesterday.

Miss Anna M. Troxell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Troxell, was married to John M. Crowley, son of Mrs. Bertha M. Crowley of White Plains, this afternoon on the thirtythird wedding anniversary of her parents.
Stocks continued to weaken and closed nervous with losses of 1 to 5 points in heaviest trading in two months; turnover, 2,381,950 shares.

Maurice Ravel one of the best known French composers, died in a clinic here today at the age of 62. He had been operated upon on Dec. 17 for a brain ailment from which he had been suffering for some years.

Hanya Holm's New York debut at the Mecca Auditorium last night in a group composition of major ditensions called "Trend" served to confirm the impression made by the same work in the Bennington Festival last Summer, that here is a creative talent of the first magnitude to be reckoned with.

The first resume of the weekly reports on trade being furnished to Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau by retail merchants showed a decrease of 7 per cent for the week ended Dec. 18, in comparison with the corresponding week last year, it was learned here yesterday. The next resume,
Five golfers turned the $4,000 Hollywood open into a wild scramble down the homestretch today as they rounded the half-way mark all even at 138, two below par for thirty-six holes.

The Toronto Maple Leafs entrenched themselves more firmly in first place in the international group of the National Hockey League by blanking the New York Americans at Madison Square Garden last night.

Mr. and Mrs. William Halsted Vander Poel of 830 Park Avenue and Oyster Bay, L. I., gave a dinner dance last night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Mary Wendell Vander Poel.

About $200,000 in unemployment relief benefits has been distributed to members of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America in New York City in the last two weeks, it was announced yesterday by Louis Hollander and Joseph Catalanotti, co-managers of the Amalgamated Joint Board in New York.

Puerto Rican Girl. Scouts this afternoon sang Christmas carols on the old sea wall for Mrs. Frederick Brooke of Washington, newly elected head of the Girl Scouts and their first head to visit Puerto Rico.

Land planted to corn and cotton tends to erode more than one hundred times as fast as land planted to -grass and other cover crops, according to experiments now being carried on by the Soil Conservation Service.

To take effect 12 midnight, Dec. 31: PATROLMAN Charles E. Foye, 13th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed June 30, 1909. Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M.. Jan. 1, 1938: LIEUTENANT Peter F. Mathews, from 74th Precinct to Police Academy.

Marion Ave, 2,557 (12-3286): Fordham Construction Corp to Sigmund Sacks, 3,224 Grand Concourse; Installments, 6 per cent: 525,000. Grand Concourse, 1,228 (9-2457); 1,228 Concourse Corp to Moritz Weiss, 973 Tiffany St installments. no interest; $9,900.

Mayor La Guardia made it clear yesterday that in vetoing recent amendments to the city Building Code on Monday he had made an exception of the amendment permitting light steel construction in certain classes of buildings and had signed that provision.

Miss Merri-Hope Hamilton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maylin Hamilton of 170 East Ninety-fourth Street, was introduced to society yesterday afternoon at a reception with dancing given by her parents in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.
The bond market underwent yesterday its widest break in more than a month when investors and traders joined in selling which sent prices off 1 to 6 points.

Glenn Cunningham and Gene Venzke will renew their old rivalry a week from Saturday when the Columbus Council, K. of C., inaugurates the new track season at the old Thirteenth Regiment Armory in Brooklyn. They will meet in the

In announcing prices on its line of silk full-fashioned hosiery for Spring, Gotham Silk Hosiery Company yesterday also offered a new number made from cotton lisle, wholesaling at $7.25 a dozen to retail at $1 a pair. Executives described the number as a plain lisle and declined to discuss details of

The Administration was accused today by Lewis W. Douglas, president-elect of McGill University and former Director of the Budget under Roosevelt, of creating a "vast array of additional vested interests" instead of curbing monopolistic tendencies, which he said had continued to develop through the "excessive paternalistic protection of the late Twenties."

31st St, 140 E, 21x98.9; Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to Suzolt Realty Corp, 317 W 27th St, p m mtg $18,117 bldg loan mtgs $9,400 ($18.50). 40th St, 325 W, 25x98.9; Clarice M. Baright, ref, to Jacob J. Tabolt, 239 W 42d St; foreclosure ($5). 52d St, 127 W, 24.6x100.5; Thos A. Maher to Codi Corp, 115 Bway ($49.50).
No doubt it is the sesquicentennial of the Constitution that makes people today prophesy in 150-year periods.

Norman Alley stepped out of the China Clipper at Pan-American's seaport in Alameda at 10 o'clock this morning with a small zipper bag containing a motion picture of the bombing and sinking of the U. S. gunboat Panay by Japanese airmen on the Yangtze River sixteen days ago.
Four United States cruisers will leave the San Diego-San Pedro area early next week for Sydney, Australia, for the celebration of the 150th anniversary of the Botany Bay settlement in Australia.
An inquest will be held to determine the cause of the death of Cecil Latta, 34-year-old son of a Scottish ship operator, who was found dead in the bed of his Paris bachelor apartment.

Production of crude oil in the United States last week averaged 3,492,600 barrels daily, compared to 3,439,850 in the previous week, an increase of 52,750, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 1,300 barrels more than the calculation of 3,491,300 daily by the Bureau of Mines for December.

A $20a-week porter at the Newark Athletic Club told the police here today he had lost $67,000 in cash from the pocket of a sweater on Friday when he was loading garbage on a truck in the rear of the clubhouse.

Registration of visiting buyers reported in the market during the week ended yesterday was less than in the preceding week and in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the list published in THE TIMES. For the week the arrivals were 295, as against 335 in the previous week and 365 in the same period last year. Buyers reported in town yesterday numbered 193, which compared with 102 recorded a week ago.

Captain Louis Boudreau's long goal from the field and a free throw by Pick Dehner brought Illinois a 33-to-32 overtime triumph over Notre Dame tonight, ending the Irish's latest basketball winning string after nineteen straight vicstories.

In a stormy session of the Federal Court here today, Judge Patrick T. Stone refused to declare a mistrial in the Federal Government's gasoline price-fixing case and lectured attorneys for conduct which he said resembled "a saloon brawl."

Holders of mortgage certificates In four issues for which Daniel W. Blumenthal is trustee will receive, as of Dec. 31, payments on account of principal varying from 2 1/2 to 10 per cent, it was announced yesterday.
Newton D. Baker's belief in man's immortality, expressed only eight days before his death, was read today at funeral services in Trinity Cathedral for President Wilson's Secretary of War.
English hockey had one of its infrequent outbursts of fighting tonight as the Harringay GreyhoundS defeated the Earl's Court Rangers, 4-2, in a National League game.
Mrs. Baldwin D. Spilman entertained tonight with a dinner followed by music and games at her home in honor of her visitor, Mrs. Christopher J. Dunphy of New York.

The Canadiens squared their city championship series with the Maroons for the Kennedy Cup and took second place in the National Hockey League's International Division tonight as they subdued their local rivals, 2 to 0.
James Edward Miles, better known in the literary world of Great Britain and the United States as Hamish Miles, died in Edinburgh yesterday at the age of 43.
Miss Helen Vaughan Kiendl, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Kiendl of Bronxville and this city, was introduced to society last night at a dance given by her parents at Sherry's.

Mortimer H. Chute, 62 years old, of 1,662 East Fifty-first Street, Brooklyn, a member of the December Kings County grand jury, died suddenly of a heart ailment yesterday in the grand jury room of the Central Courts Building, Smith and Schermerhorn Streets, Brooklyn.

Governor Lehman said today that Leo J. Hagerty, District Attorney-elect of Erie County, had agreed to appoint Frank G. Raichle a Deputy District Attorney to act as a special prosecutor in the investigation of municipal affairs in Buffalo.

The undefeated Pete Scalzo, West Side featherweight, kept his record intact last night at the New York Coliseum, the Bronx, where he won the decision over Cristobal Jaramillo, Puerto Rican, in the feature eight-round bout.

Posing as a collector for old clothes for "charitable" organizations, an unknown woman entered yesterday the apartment of Mrs. Helen.Leib at 1,240 Walton Avenue, the Bronx, ordered her into a clothes closet, took a purse from a doorknob in the kitchen and left.

British authorities seized a cargo of bronze fittings and casings aboard a Japanese vessel upon its arrival here today. The cargo was said to have been salvaged from the German cruiser Emden,-sunk near Cocos Island during the World War.

Steel ingot output declined last week when the seasonal trend was steady, and the adjusted index slumped to 35.9, its lowest point in more than three years. The figure for the previous week was 43.6, while for the week ended Dec. 26, 1936, the index stood at 125.7.
Committees for holders of securities of the Seaboard Air Line Railway are to meet here on Jan. 10 to discuss a reorganization for the company, which has been in receivership since 1930.
Hadassah Hamilton Posey, only daughter of Mrs. William C. Posey of Radnor, Pa., and the late Dr. Posey, was married today in St. John's Church, Pembroke, to Dr. Wolfgang Michael of Freiburg, Germany.
The undefeated Dartmouth hockey team scored its fifth straight victory tonight, routing Brown by 5 to 1 in the second game of the intercollegiate ice hockey series at the Playland Ice Casino.

Criticizing the maximum penalties allowed by law as insufficient for the crimes committed, Federal Judge Charles G. Briggle today applied the maximum and sentenced thirty-six men convicted in the dynamiting conspiracy arising out of the Illinois mine union warfare to serve four years each in prison and to pay fines of $20,000 each. Judge briggle previously had denied a new trial for the defendants.

After Jan. 1. Mayor La Guardia, plans to divide his time between the old City Hall downtown and the modern offices he has been ocoupying temporarily in the Empire State Building, it was learned yesterday.

For the first time in the experience of the New York State Labor Relations Board, rival unions seeking certification as the collective bargaining agency for a group of employes have both been repudiated by the employes in an election.

The most important problem facing retailers in 1938 will be the rising costs of operation, Lew Hahn, managing director of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, warned in a statement issued yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Mr. Patterson's attack on the Transit Commission is but the latest of an unending series. As chairman of the Citizens Budget Commission his criticism carries great weight.
The second match between Pierre Etchebaster and Ogden Phipps for the world court tennis championship, scheduled for Saturday, has been indefinitely postponed, it was announced yesterday.
A machine which spots an airplane twenty miles away by the heat thrown off by the plane's motor is nearing perfection, amid great secrecy, at the hands of army engineers.

Emperor Hail Selassie of Ethiopia today sent identical telegrams to the seven States that are bound by the Oslo convention-Belgium, Sweden, Denmark, Norway, The Netherlands, Luxembourg and Finlandprotesting "in the name of my people" against the proposal of The Netherlands that they grant what he termed de jure recognition of the Italian annexation of Ethiopia.

Interesting observations on building conditions in various parts of the country have just been received at the New York offices of the American Institute of Architects from officials of that organization in other States.

The "peace at any price" citizens were denounced here tonight by Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd at the annual dinner of Pi Gamma Mu, national social science society, which awarded to him a key for "distinguished service in the cause of social science and international cooperation and peace" He was honorary president of the society for four years.

Several purchases of apartment buildings on the West Side were included in the Manhattan real estate transactions reported by brokers yesterday. Irving 0. Freedman bought the six-story apartment house at 421 West Twenty-fourth Street, facing London Terrace, and immediately resold the property to Samuel Shack, attorney, who is entering the realty operating field, this being his first purchase.
Herman B. Good, president of Good Brothers Leather Company of Newark, died today after a long illness at his home here. He was 71 years old.
Mrs. Robert R. P. Bradford. 72-year-old social worker well known to the mill employes in the Kensington district, received today the Gimbel award as Philadelphia's "outstanding woman of 1937."
NEWS OF METROPOLITAN REAL ESTATE
In several discussions of proposed changes in the Sherman Anti-Trust Laws, the Attorney General has stressed two recommendations which should be encouraging to business.
The Jewish boycott seems to have been revived since Dr. Hjalmar Schacht's departure from the Ministry of Economics.

The Securities and Exchange Commission since Oct. 1 has been receiving, from twenty of the largest investment trusts, with about one-half of the assets of all such trusts in the country, weekly reports on transactions in securities

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Dec. 27: COLONELS Gruber, E. L. (F. A.), General Staff Corps, three days' leave, Dec. 29. Hunt, C. A. (Inf.), General Staff Corps, four days' leave, Dec. 27.
E.J. O'Connor's Deserter, who lost his first start at the Fair Grounds when he went wide at the stretch turn, came back with a smashing triumph in the mile and 70-yard race for $1,800 players today.

In a scientific announcement of utmost importance for industry, Harvard University physicists reported today the first penetration of the mathematical mystery of the large power vacuum tube, and promised radical improvements in the efficiency of this vital implement of modern electrical progress.

At midnight last night the Dominion of the British Commonwealth known for fifteen years as the Irish Free State ceased to exist and President Eamon de Valera's new State of Eire (or Ireland in English) came into being.

Jay W. Hays, banker and community leader, died of a heart ailment yesterday. He was 55 years old. After working as a clerk for the Central Trust Company he became cashier of the West Town State Bank and vice president of the University State Bank.
The stock market here still was reflecting the holiday inactivity today. Most sections were extremely quiet and slightly weaker. Gilt-edge issues

ADLERBLUM, DAVID (Dec. 23). Estate, more than $10,000. To Henriette Adlerblum, widow, executrix, 35 W. 92d St., life estate in residue, with right to invade the principal at discretion of executor. Meyer Kurz, 9 Woody Lane, Larchmont N. Y. executor.
The discovery of the leprosy bacillus in a wild gray field mouse by the School of Tropical Medicine was revealed today when the school advertised for 2,000 mice to carry on experimentation.

A complete understanding of headaches, fainting spells and epilepsy requires studies that are both medical and psychological, according to a paper delivered yesterday at a meeting of the Association for Research in Nervous and Mental Disease at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
The retiring United States Ambassador and Mrs. William E. Dodd left at noon by automobile for Hamburg, where they will board the liner Washington tonight for New York.

Detective Alfred T. Wing of 88-32 247th Street, Bellerose, L. I., attached to the Fifteenth Detective District, Jamaica, Queens, died of a heart attack yesterday in Mary Immaculate Hospital, Jamaica. He was 55 years old. Mr. Wing had
Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Bald Jr. of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Tilghman Bald, to Clifford Stanton Heinz Jr. of Beverly Hills, Calif.

Thomas E. Dewey, District Attorney-elect of New York County, announced yesterday the appointment of fourteen assistant district attorneys, who will begin their duties when he assumes office Saturday. The appointments indicate that Mr. Dewey will have the youngest staff of any New York City District Attorney in recent decades.

Births in this city for the week ended last Saturday totaled 1,555, the fewest for any week so far this year, it was reported yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner. Nevertheless, the Commissioner expects the total births to reach 102,000 for the full year, an increase over 1936.

The Cunard White Star liner Berengaria arrived yesterday from Europe thirty hours late due, the officers said, to the continuous storms from the mouth of the Channel to the American coast. She only averaged nineteen knots for the voyage.

The marriage of Miss Jane Allen Runyon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarkson Runyon Jr. of 730 Park Avenue and Camp Medamin, Upper St. Regis Lake, N. Y., to Lieutenant Thomas West Hammond Jr., U. S. A., of West Point, N. Y., took place yesterday afternoon in St. James Church.

John's Prep School of Brooklyn vanquished St. Michael's High tonight at basketball, 34 to 23. The victors, who held a lead of 16-13 at half-time, were in front from the beginning. Grubb, Gibbons and McDermott divided scoring honors for St. John's.

FREUDENHEIM, JULIUS (June 27, 1936). Gross assets, $84,697; net, $80,699. To Lea F. Gross, daughter, Benedict J. Freudenheim and Edwin Freudenheim, sons, one-fifth residue outright; Daisy F. Levy, life estate in one-fifth residue; Sol. J. Freudenheim, son, temporary estate in one-fifth residue. Chief assets, jointly

The dollar volume of retail financing of new passenger automobiles decreased almost 20 per cent for November as compared with November of last year, and a decrease of about 3 per cent compared with November, 1935, a preliminary report by the Commerce Department showed today.

The Most Rev. Thomas E. Molloy, Bishop of the Diocese of Brooklyn, presided yesterday in a funeral service for Leo J. Hickey, United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York and a prominent Brooklyn Catholic layman who died of pneumonia Saturday. He was 47 years old.

Dr. Henry Seymour Brown, former superintendent of the church extension board of the Presbytery of Chicago, assumed his new duties today as vice president of Princeton Theological Seminary and director of the $3,000,000 financial campaign recently started by the seminary. Dr. Brown, who resigned from the church extension board last September, comes to Princeton after nineteen years of social service work in Chicago.
The programs of the Philharmonic-Symphony concerts for tomorrow evening, Friday afternoon and Saturday evening have been changed slightly.

Thirteenth annual meeting of the American Catholic Philosophical Association will open at the Hotel Roosevelt this morning at 9 o'clock and continue tomorrow. Dinner at 6:30 P. M. at which speakers will be Bishop Stephen J. Donahue, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, the Rev. Dr. William T. Dillon, Ignatius Smith.

Although he admitted total thefts of $13,591 from the Knickerbocker Club in East Sixty-second Street more than fourteen years ago, John Stevens, 53 years old, an accountant and former cashier of the club, was freed on a suspended sentence yesterday by General Sessions Judge Wallace on a guilty plea to forgery.

17th St. 425 E. 25x92; Amcor Holding Corp (Joseph Braunstein, pres) to A. Gordon. 340 Riverside Dr; prior mtg; $15,100; 3 years, 6%; $6,000. 31st St, 140 E, 21x95; Suzolt Realty Corp (Morris Grodsky, pres) to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank; p m mtg; due on demand; interest as per bond; $18,117. Same property; same to same; building loan; prior mtg, $18,117; due on demand; interest as per bond; 9,400.

Ben Cantwell, veteran Jersey City right-hander who spent part of his time last season with the Giants, and later with the Dodgers, was the most effective pitcher in the International League during the regular 1937 campaign, according to the official figures announced yesterday.

Albert Marinelli, who resigned as New York County Clerk after charges by Thomas E. Dewey, special rackets prosecutor, was named yesterday by Henry Alexander, counsel to Andrew B. Keating, Acting County Clerk, as the official who, while County Clerk,

Twelve crews took part today in the intercollegiate sailing dinghy regattas held at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club here and at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club at Port Washington, L. I. The Massachusetts Institute of Technology won with 49 points, to 42 for Princeton, the runner-up.

Mrs. George Forrest Butterworth will give a dinner tomorrow in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for her granddaughter, Miss Isabel I. Butterworth. Mr. and Mrs. Bertram Winthrop of Boston are at the Ritz Tower.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the last three days:

A. and U. Restaurants, Inc., which has operated the Hollywood Restaurant at 1,600 Broadway for the last eight years, filed yesterday a petition in Federal court seeking permission to reorganize under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act.

Mrs. Emma Ovenshine Harbord, wife of Major Gen. James G. Harbord, U. S. A., retired, chairman of the board of the Radio Corporation of America, left a net estate of $264,792, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. Mrs. Harbord died at their home in Rye. N. Y., on May 29.

The executive committee of the United Licensed Officers Association found Captain John F. Milliken, president of the association, guilty of negligence of duty and of having acted to disrupt the organization, at a meeting on Monday evening at the Downtown Athletic Club, it was disclosed yesterday.

The drastic steps for economy taken by the General Motors Corporation had a depressing effect yesterday on the stock market. Reductions of prices in certain raw materials and parts utilized by the industry have been reported and automotive makers are still anxious to obtain lower priced steel. Hence,

Miss Virginia Marian Wertz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick L. Wertz of this place, was married tonight in Central Presbyterian Church here to Howard Brooks Bosworth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence W. Bosworth of Providence, R. I.
The New York A. C. sextet vanquished the Brooklyn Bruins, 6 to 1, in a New York Amateur Hockey League contest last night at the Brooklyn Ice Palace.

The Drake, twenty-story hotel structure at the northwest corner of Fifty-sixth Street and Park Avenue, was sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms. The Chase National Bank, trustee for the mortgage bondholders, as plaintiff, bought in the building for $1,700,000.

The interest and sinking fund requirements on the Interborough Rapid Transit Oompany first mortgage 5 per cent bonds due Jan. 1 have been ordered paid by Federal Judge John C. Knox in an order signed yesterday.

The marriage of Mrs. Ruth McNamara Work of 1,170 Fifth Avenue, widow of Charles A. Work and daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. John P. McNamara of Richmond, Va., to William H. Crichton Clarke of this city, took place yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride.

Apartment rentals reported by brokers yesterday included one signed by Jacques Grinieff, film producer, for a large suite in the building at 1,160 Fifth Avenue. Pease Elliman, Inc., negotiated the lease.

Ira Grant Hedrick, who designed bridges in the United States, Mexico and Canada, died at his home here today at the age of 69. One of his major works was the Burnside Bridge in Portland, Ore., said to be one of the first lift span bridges with car tracks and automatic trolley connections.

Dr. Carl W. Blegen, field director of the University of Cincinnati's expedition to the site of ancient Troy, announced to the Archaeological Institute of America here today the almost certain discovery of the Scaean Gate, through which, according to Homer, Helen watched the Trojans march out against the Archaean host and her kinsman, Agamemnon.

Belated liquidation by holders of December wheat contracts who did not desire to take delivery of the cash grain, weakness in stocks and a reaction in the Buenos Aires market sent prices down today on the Board of Trade here, with the lowest levels

A general reduction in prices to expand demand and a similar reduction in wages of skilled workers as measures to stimulate recovery were advocated by 0. M. W. Sprague, Harvard economist and president of the American Economic Association, in an address here tonight.

Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 18,000, including 2,000 directs. The market was strong to 10c higher than
On Dec. 31 the interests of the late F. V. R. Reynolds in De Haven Townsend, of Andrew Hazelhurst in Homans Co., of the late. Sidney J. White in E. A. Pierce Co., and of Donald W. Green in

The three-story apartment house at 84-86 Romaine Avenue, Jersey City, was sold by the Hudson City Savings Bank to the Fifteenth Street Corporation. The property contains twelve apartments. J. I. Kislak, Inc., broker, negotiated the sale.

The export duty on scrap iron was reduced from 50 francs to 5 francs a 100 kilograms by the French Government yesterday because the disparity between French and world prices is now negligible and the demand for scrap metal is lower.
Declaring with a first-innings score of 429 for eight wickets, South Australia had a decided advantage at the end of the third day's play in its match against Queensland.

When Stanford and Minnesota were booked to play in the two basketball double-headers at Madison Square Garden this week, the Coast five was the team that figured to be the headliner in both bills. While Minnesota was
Alabama and California went into strict secrecy today to work out ways and means of shoving each other around the Rose Bowl New Year's Day.

The marriage of Miss Harriet Baldwin Westlake, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emory Hammond Westlake of Summit, N. J., to Alexander McFarlan Ackley, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Westervelt Ackley of Rahway, N. J., took place here yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Ascension.

The marriage of Miss Kathleen Regina Daley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Daley of 2,316 Loring Place, the Bronx, to Warren S. Fogel, son of Mrs. Warren S. Fogel, also of the Bronx, and the late Mr. Fogel, took place yesterday morning in the Church of St. Nicholas of Tolentine, the Bronx.

Cuba's import duty on rice was almost doubled by a Presidential decree today because of the heavy losses in customs receipts since last August, when the low tariff was instituted for the rest of the year.

Hugh W. Jackson's Bulwark, recently third to Mucho Gusto and Paradisical in the Christmas Handicap, proved one of the biggest disappointments of the Tropical Park meeting when he finished third in the Naples Purse today. The winner turned up in Mrs. F. M. Grabner's 5-year-old mare Spanish Babe, who ran back to her recent promising effort to take the purse by half a length from Jesse Spencer's Our Willie. Bulwark was five lengths farther behind.
C. W. P. (Pete) Reynolds, coach of the football team which broke Knox College's record losing streak, resigned today to devote full time to a business job. When Reynolds,

The marriage of Mrs. Mary Schnitzius Osborn, daughter of Mrs. Ida B. Schnitzius of Colorado Springs, Col., to David Albert Stretch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert T. Stretch of Trenton, N. J., took place here yesterday afternoon at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen P. Duggan Jr., 211 East Seventyfirst Street.

King Carol of Rumania appointed Octavian Goga, co-leader of the anti-Semitic, proGerman National Christian party, as Premier today, although M. Goga's ticket had failed to obtain even 10 per cent of the ballots in last week's elections for the Chamber of Deputies.

Pleading that "a man can't be at the top all the time-I'm no machine," Don Budge offered today to meet Jack Crawford to make up for a listless showing in an exhibition tennis game he lost to Baron Gottfried von Cramm yesterday.
Dance halls throughout Japan have been ordered to close before April 1 by Admiral Nobumasa Suetsugu, Home Minister, Japanese newspapers reported today.

The young French abstractionist, Jean Helion, is having his third one-man show in New York. It occupies the entrance gallery at the Valentine, 16 East Fifty-seventh Street, and will be current until Jan. 15.

The Elizabeth Town and Country Club scored its fifth consecutive victory in Class B of the Women's New Jersey Squash Racquets Association when it defeated the Short Hills Club today, 3-2. Two defaults contributed to Elizabeth's victory. The Averett sisters,

Joseph D. Tooker, real estate operator and an officer of several New York, Boston and Havana construction and management corporations, died of pneumonia today in his home here. He was 56 years old and had been ill for three days.
Three issues of securities of the Scullin Steel Company were admitted yesterday to listing on the New York Curb Exchange.

The Western Union- Telegraph Company, accused recently in an anti-trust action brought by the United States Attorney General, who also sued the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation and its subsidiaries on the same ground, filed an answer yesterday in Federal Court and asked for dismissal of the suit.

The Commonwealth Gas and Electrio Companies, a subsidiary of the New England Power Assooiation, has been permitted by the Securities and Exchange Commission to pay a dividend of $47,255, or $2.50 a share, on 18,902 shares of preferred stock out of capital or unearned surplus, to avoid payment of the tax that otherwise would be imposed by the undistributed profits levy.

Prince Michael Radziwill today rejected a Polish court's appointment of a guardian for him. The 67year-old Prince declared he considered the guardian, Count Alfred Chlapowski, former Polish Ambassador to France, "incompetent to manage my estate."

Sale of the Shady Nook Nursery property on the Mount Kisco State Road in Armonk, and of several dwellings in various parts of Westchester County, were reported yesterday by Robert E. Hill, Inc., brokers.
TIME and tide, as some alert physicist once noted, wait for no man, and the tide of public opinion seems to be another matter over which mortal man has little, if any, control.
The first sixty-eight railroads to report for November showed a net operating income which was 52.9 per cent lower than the total for November, 1936. Gross revenues declined 10.8 per cent.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today dismissed a complaint against the Pennsylvania Railroad Company by the Master Truckmen of America, Inc., which charged that the railroad had violated Section 6 of the Interstate Commerce Act by

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders, dated Dec. 23: CAPTAINS Goss, N. H., Comdr., Destroyer Squadron 10, to duty as inspector of ordnance in charge, Naval Ammunition Depot, Mare Island, Calif.

Three alleged diamond smugglers, indicted as members of a ring that has been. carrying jewels from Antwerp to the United States for the last fifteen years, were returned yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria to plead today before a Federal Commissioner to the charges on which thirty-one others already have been apprehended.
Pitt's smouldering athletic volcano erupted again today with a prediction by The Sun-Telegraph that Coach John B. (Jock) Sutherland was preparing to resign at the close of next season.

The city's plan to permit independent milk companies to sell bottled Grade B milk from their trucks at market areas at 9 cents a quart appeared to have struck a fatal snag yesterday as officials of the Milk Wagon Drivers Union, Local 584, of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and Chauffeurs, announced they would call a stoppage strike at 5 A. M. today against any participating company found to be violating union contracts.

They probably will not be able to go out today and produce a fullfledged newspaper, but more than 600 aspiring young editors and reporters learned yesterday how it is done, at the second annual College and School Service Christmas Conference of THE NEW YORK TIMES, at the Hotel Biltmore.

Headed by Dr. Thomas Parran, Surgeon General of the United States, more than 400 health officers, representing every State, are supporting the "Fight Infantile Paralysis" campaign, Keith Morgan announced yesterday.

David P. Childs, who with his brother built a chain of 268 grocery stores in Philadelphia, New Jersey and Maryland, hanged himself in his home here last night, Coroner Franklin P. Jackson of Camden County reported today.
High praise of a worthy opponent was given by Coach John Bunn of Stanford, as he addressed the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association at luncheon in the Hotel Lincoln yesterday. Bunn was

The gradual, insidious extension of the claims that Japanese military authority extends even over foreigners possessing extraterritorial rights and living in the International Settlement and French Concession became evident today when spokesmen of the Japanese Army and Embassy discussed a second hand grenade attack on Japanese soldiers.

Avery Brundage, president of the American Olympic Association, last night announced that the first steps toward organizing America's 1940 Olympic campaign will be taken at a meeting called for next week.

The four favored entrants gained quarter-final brackets as play in the second round of the third annual invitation intercollegiate squash racquets tournament was completed on the courts of the University Club yesterday.

Miss Anne Louise Root, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis D. Root of 800 Park Avenue and Southampton, L. I., was married to Thomas Bealle Davis Jr. yesterday morning in the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Fortyeighth Street.

Trailing Harvard's hockey forces, 3 to 0, late in the second period, the Westchester Rangers rallied tonight and with young Frankie Boucher, leading the way with three goals, finished in a 5-to-5 overtime deadlock before 1,200 at the new Imperial Arena.

Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday he had made a New Year's resolution to end the practice of holding daily noon press conferences at which all important crimes, departmental policies and changes have been discussed for forty years.

A dramatic attempt by five members of the French Foreign Legion to desert to Spanish Morocco to join the Insurgent army was disclosed tonight after three were recaptured and one was killed by military police.
IT has long been fashionable to smile at academic scholarship, particularly that brand sponsored by university English Departments. There is some reason for this.

After irregular fluctuations over a 10-point range, prices on the Cotton Exchange ended yesterday with losses of 1 to 6 points. Weakness in the stock market caused scattered liquidation of cotton futures from time to time, but execution of a few price-fixing orders for foreign and domestic mills canceled

City College's varsity fencing schedule, announced yesterday by Professor Walter Williamson, college manager of athletics, lists Princeton University for the first time. A dual meet with the Tigers has been arranged for the Princeton gymnasium on Feb. 26.

THEI CONTESTANTS Brooklyn College-Misses Ruth Engel, Elaine Klepper, Sabina Danziger, Ann Mahler, Hortense Block, Murial Goodman, Judith Randle, Louise Holland, Clara Zillotto, Ruth Greenberg, Elizabeth Bruskin, Diana Kass.

Accounting for both the singles and doubles titles, the Stephens brothers, Clinton P. and Warren A., of the Rutgers Badminton Club, monopolized the competition in the boys' division as the first Eastern junior badminton championships came to a close yesterday on the Old Sixty-ninth Club courts at the 165th Infantry Armory.

With two Queens members absent, thirteen Democratic Councilmen-elect met yesterday in caucus at the National Democratic Club and named Alderman John Cashmore of Brooklyn as the Democratic candidate for vice chairman of the City Council.
Mr. and Mrs. Wilton Lloyd-Smith gave a fancy dress masquerade dance last night in their home at 10 Gracie Square for their daughter, Miss Marne Lloyd-Smith, who made her debut last season.
McGill University skiers lived up to advance predictions by carrying off major jumping honors as the first annual international intercollegiate invitation ski meet opened in subzero weather today.

Columbia University chess players took a slight lead in the annual tournament for the championship of the Intercollegiate Chess League and custody of the Harold M. Phillips Trophy at the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday.

The government mouthpiece, La Nacion, editorially dismisses today as unimportant bitter criticism by the Leftist Opposition press and in Congress as a result of the enforced retirement of Colonel Tobias Barros, chief inspector of artillery, on the ground that he was unfavorable to the Alessandri government.
Glenn S. (Pop) Warner, whose forty-three years of coaching have led him from coast to coast, said today football's defense had stepped too far ahead of the offense.

Mrs. Watson Ziegler gave a supper dance in the Pierre roof garden last night for her debutante daughter, Miss Barbara Ziegler. Miss Ziegler, who received with her mother, wore a pale pink net gown and carried a bouquet of pink camellias. Mrs. Ziegler wore a gown of chartreuse crepe bordered at the hem with gold leaves.
Eastern and Western football stars, priming for the annual charity game here New Year's Day, charged through scrimmages today that are expected to conclude the contact work.

The curtain will fall tonight on Twentieth Century S. C. boxing activities for the year at the Hippodrome. Gunnar Barlund, Finnish puncher, and Alberto Santiago Lovell of Argentina will provide the action in the principal bout of ten rounds, a struggle between two of the most promising of the foreign heavyweights now here.

A reduction from ninety-seven to eleven in the number of civll service exempt positions in the newly organized office of the District Attorney was announced yesterday by Thomas E. Dewey, who will take over that office tomorrow.

Don Budge scored another smashing victory yesterday. The world's greatest amateur tennis player, voted the outstanding individual athlete of the year, was declared winner of the James E. Sullivan Memorial Trophy for 1937. This award annually is given by the Amateur...

Mischa Elman was soloist at the concert given by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, John Barbirolli, conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall, playing the Beethoven violin concerto. Mr. Barbirolli played for the first time in this city the Third Suite of Old Airs...

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Dec. 30.-Although astronomers are often supposed to work with greater precision than most other scientists, approximate methods have a very important place in their studies. The value of these was emphasized by Dr. Henry Norris Russell of Princeton...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30.--A Chinese scholar and his American colleague, poking about a prehistoric lake bed in Shantung Province, have discovered evidence indicating that some 15,000,000 or more years ago the continents of Asia and North America were linked by dry land.

The Annalist reports that prices of commodities drifted downward in the week ended on Wednesday, lowering its index for commodities at wholesale to 84.9 from 85.2 a week before. The new mark, it said, was the lowest since October, 1936.
Retail milk prices throughout the city will be reduced one half cent a quart beginning tomorrow, it was announced last night by officials of Borden's and Sheffield's.

Cloudy weather, followed by rain, with little change in temperature was forecast for today and clearing and colder weather is expected tomorrow, according to the map charted at the United States Weather Bureau at 7:30 o'clock last night.

With both teams scoring a goal apiece in the ten-minute overtime period, the New York Rovers and the Bronx Tigers played to a 4-to-4 deadlock before some 2,200 fans in the New York Coliseum last night.

Former City Chamberlain A. A. Berle Jr. was named yesterday by Mayor La Guardia as chairman of the new City Planning Commission at $15,000 a year. At the same time the Mayor named four other members of the powerful new agency, which begins to function Saturday.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 30.-Leonard Dodson, "forgotten man of golf," defeated his one-time teacher, Horton Smith, by three strokes today in a play-off for top money of $750 in the Hollywood open tournament.
RYE, N. Y., Dec. 30.--Dartmouth remained unbeaten in hockey, gaining its seventh straight triumph of the season by beating Williams tonight, 5 to 3, but the Indians had to come from behind to do it.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Dec. 30.-The request of the C. I. O. for a permit to hold an open-air meeting in Jersey City was refused today by Daniel Casey, Director of Public Safety, on the ground that such a meeting would lead to "riot, disturbances and disorderly assemblage."

The prompt settlement of the strike of the Paris transport and public utility workers is welcomed by nearly all shades of French public opinion. Members of the outgoing Board of Estimate held their last meeting in Mayor La Guardia's office at the Empire State Building yesterday and disposed of a number of minor matters pending on the calendar.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 30.-Mr. and Mrs. J. Jay O'Brien gave a dinner for twenty tonight at Villa Del Sarmiento for Mr. and Mrs. William Paley of New York.

Alfred E. Smith sat back in an armchair, puffed at his first cigar in four days, and waved aside as incompetent, irrelevant and immaterial the question of his retirement from either politics or business activities.

PARIS, Dec. 30.--The Senate Finance Committee this afternoon voted, 18 to 3, against prolongation of the Paris Exposition.

LAC BEAUPORT, Que., Dec. 30 (AP).--Dominating the final slalom and downhill events in below-zero weather, the McGill University Redmen today completed a sweep of the three-day international intercollegiate invitation ski meet at this Winter sports center.

Responsibility for the breakdown of peace negotiations between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization was placed upon the A. F. of L. yesterday by The Advance, official organ of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 30 (AP). --The weather forecast today eased the anxiety of Alabama's football entourage and some 89,000 fans who expect to see the Rose Bowl game New Year's Day. The weather man predicted a sky as fair as it was today.

New York audiences sat silent but tense yesterday through the first showings here of the two motion pictures of the bombing of the United States gunboat Panay. It was the manifestation of deep emotion over an affair already thoroughly aired.

The United States liner American Trader will sail today for Plymouth and London, carrying among her passengers Theodore Cook, Mr. and Mrs. W. H. Myers, John Flaige, Eric Knight, Arthur D. Wright, Miss Melvina Svec, Maurice Leigh and the Rev. and Mrs. W. S. A. Larter.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30.--President and Mrs. Roosevelt gave a Christmas dance tonight, entertaining 400 young people for Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Roosevelt Jr., John Roosevelt and his fiancee, Miss Anne Lindsay Clark of Boston.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30.--Indications that the business recession which began in September is "nearing the bottom" are cited in the monthly survey of business issued tonight by the American Federation of Labor.

Mrs. Evalyn Walsh McLean gave her annual New Year's ball tonight, entertaining at Friendship, her home in Wisconsin Avenue, 1,500, of whom 320 were her guests at dinner preceding the dance.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: I write this letter in the hope that it will come to the attention of the front office of Madison Square Garden because I know that it expresses a complaint and a desire of all New York hockey fans.

Milius, sister, specific jewelry; Babette Fround, niece, Warren and William Milius Jr., nephews, one-third residue each; First Church of Christ Scientist and Thirteenth Church of Christ Scientist, both New York City, $250 each: Laura C. Pinkard, specific jewelry and $1.000; several other bequests. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $24,431. Fertig. Walter Gottesman, attorneys. 45 John St.

The following Reserve officers, recently released for assignment to Third Military Area, is assigned to unit therein as indicated below: To 309th Field Artillery, Newark District: 2d Lt. Oliver H. Cote Jr., 523 West 112th St., New York, N. Y.

The International Petroleum Company, Ltd., has made a contract to buy the surplus crude oil of the Mene Grande Oil Company for a long period, it was announced yesterday. The terms provide for payment to the Mene Grande Company of $25,000,000, which will be repaid through oil deliveries.

Hester St, 55-7, 5-story brick tenement and stores and 7-story brick loft and store building, 46.1x88x irreg; Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank against Herman Dinstelheim; due, $61,489; to plaintiff for $1,000.

Fare reductions becoming effective today on Northwest Airways have increased the company's advance passenger reservations from 30 to 50 per cent on different trips of its extensive routes, Archibald P. Werner, East Coast representative, said yesterday.

American shipyards built 274,012 gross tons of commercial ships and 89,400 displacement tons of naval vessels (362,412 tons in all) last year, representing increases of 24 and 60 per cent respectively, over 1936, according to a survey published by the monthly journal Marine Engineering and Shipping Review.
The Leesburg Citizen has offered $10,000 for the "first quintuplets born within eight miles of Leesburg during 1938." A full page advertisement announcing the offer read:
To the strains of the Army and Navy Band of Englewood, N. J., The New York Stock Exchange bade good-bye yesterday to 1937. Members danced on the floor, played pranks.
It was Auld Lang Syne for the old year and for the old New York, Westchester Boston Railroad at the same time last midnight.

Athenaeum Court, Ltd., a British concern acting as rental agents for apartment hotels in London, has opened an American office headed by E. Colbeck, and has leased space on the fifth floor of the British Empire Building, Rockefeller Center.
Virgino Diaz, treasurer of the international committee here for the relief of Republican Spain, was shot dead on the street today by another Spaniard after an argument.

The confinfant son of Mr. and Mrs. George Strawbridge of Sunset Hill, Villanova, is being christened tomorrow afternoon. The Rev. Richard Gurley, the rector, will perform the ceremony in St. Martin's Church, Radnor, where the infant's parents ev were married.
With most leading commodity markets, both in the United States and abroad, closing at noon, trading in futures was quiet on the local Exchanges yesterday.

Net earnings of $6,266,992 for the year ended on Nov. 30, were reported in a statement issued for publication today by the International Shoe Company. This was after deductions for expenses, depreciation, provision for decline from cost to market at Nov. 30, 1937, in inventory values and purchase commitments, and provision for income taxes.

About 150 relatives and associates in the theatrical world attended yesterday a funeral service for Jean De Koven, 22-year-old New York dancer who was slain in Paris last July and whose body was discovered early this month buried beneath a Paris villa.

A New York dress manufacturer, Joseph Love, Inc., of 1,333 Broadway, has agreed to stop using insignia or tags indicating that children's clothes known as "Princess Elizabeth" dresses have any connection with those worn by the heir to the British throne, according to a Federal Trade Commission stipulation handed down today.

The War Department announced today that the following candidates have been designated for the March 1938, entrance examinations with a view to admission to the Military Academy at West Point: Robert D. Johnson, 704 President Street,
Opening a campaign for re- the election, Senator Claude Pepper today criticized "big business" as "the rotten apples in the business barrel."

Louis Franck, Governor of the National Bank of Belgium, died suddenly today of a heart attack at his chateau here. He was 69. Mr. Franck was to have retired from the governorship after the end of the year.

The issues of the strike of approximately 800 clerks in fifty-seven links of the Whelan Drug Stores chain in this city, Westchester and Long Island will be submitted to the State Board of Mediation on Monday.

A banking group composed of the Bankers Trust Company, Brown Harriman Co., Inc.; Phelps, Fenn Co.; the Northwestern National Bank and Trust Company and Mannheiner-Caldwell, Inc., purchased yesterday a new issue of $360,000 of sewerage disposal system bonds of Minneapolis, Minn.

Britain was not sorry to see the passing of 1937 which had brought many humiliations and disappointments. Troubles had crowded upon her, troubles she was unwilling or unable to cope with, although she was rearming on the most prodigious scale in all her history.

Mr. and Mrs. Richard HOOKer or Longmeadow, near here, and Blandford, Mass., announced this afternoon at their home in Colony Hills the engagement of their younger daughter, Miss Mary Newberry Hooker, to Robert Morris Cavanaugh of Woodbury, N. J., son of mr. and Mrs. Robert Emmett Cavanaugh of Indianapolis.

More than 10,000 persons, it is announced, have cast ballots in the art contest conducted in connection with the Dance International at Rockefeller Center. Visitors to the exhibition of "arts related to the dance" were given blanks on which they might indicate, In one-twothree order, their preferences among the paintings and pieces of sculpture on view.

The indications are for partly cloudy weather preceded by rain and with little change in temperature today. Tomorrow will be generally fair and colder, according to the map charted by the United States Weather Bureau at 7:30 P. M. yesterday.

Open-market rates were unchanged in December but indications of a somewhat easier condition of credit were provided by the progressive cheapening of the rates at which four issues of Treasury bills were awarded.

We noticed in yesterJapan day's headlines that Britasish Are Cool to Tokyo's Author Note. But, as everybody expected, this was followed quite briskly by another headline saying, Britain Accepts Tokyo's New Note.

The chess players representing Brooklyn College defeated New York University by 31/2--1/2 in the fifth and final round at the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday to gain the championship of the Intercollegiate Chess League and custody for a year of the Harold M. Phillips Trophy.

On their own application: To take effect 12 midnight, Dec. 31: CHIEF INSPECTOR-John J. Beery, 19th Division, at $6,000 per annum. Appointed Aug. 12, 1903. ASSISTANT CHIEF INSPECTOR--John A. Lyons, 18th Division, at $4,000 per annum. Appointed Nov. 8, 1909. DEPUTY CHIEF INSPECTOR-Cornelius O'Leary, 17th Division, at $4,000 per annum. Appointed June 8, 1901.

Conditions for the staging of the eighteenth annual Middle Atlantic outdoor speed skating championships at Newburgh, N. Y., today were reported yesterday to be excellent. With four and one-half inches of hard ice on Crystal Lake in the southern section of the city, only a sudden thaw will, impair the program.

Representative O'Connor of New York and Senators Copeland and McCarran joined various Republicans today in attacking Administration spokesmen for asserting that "big business" was on a sit-Jown strike.

August A. Andersson, SwedishAmerican editor, died here last night following a brief illness. His age was 75. Mr. Andersson was editor of Skandia, local Swedish weekly, for seventeen years, and for thirteen years previously had edited a similar publocation in McKeesport, Pa.

The second five-year plan ended today. The third goes into effect tomorrow. For the first time since Josef Stalin launched his series of plans the new one will begin without the preparation of a chart of the whole course well in advance.

The flags of sixty-two foreign nations that have signified their intention of participating in the New York world's fair in Flushing, Queens, were hoisted for the first time, yesterday, on steel flagpoles on a knoll on the fair grounds.
Carl M. Loeb Co. will become Carl M. Loeb, Rhoades Co. on Feb. 1 with the admission of five partners of Rhoades Co., according to an announcement yesterday,

Eager to match their speed against Michigan State's power, the Auburn Plainsmen breezed through a signal drill today and pronounced themselves ready for a supreme effort to give the South its first Orange Bowl football victory tomorrow.

Seven persons were overcome by coal gas about 5 P. M. today in a three-family dwelling at 4,203 Hudson Boulevard, here. One of the tenants, Mrs. -Ellie Schwope, 58 years old, who lives on the top floor, summoned help after she had been awakened by the cries of Joseph Mangino, year-old son of Mrs. Anna Mangino, another tenant.

An American audience today heard for the first time two early choral-symphonic works of the Finnish composer, Jan Sibelius, missing parts for one of which were radioed across the Atlantic to enable the Boston Symphony Orchestra to perform it on schedule.

Francis Parsons, a trustee of Yale University and former vice chairman of the board of directors of the Hartford National Bank and Trust Company, died here yesterday at his home, 27 Forest Street, after a month's illness. He was 66 years old.

Officials admitted today that the French and Polish Governments were discussing the possibility of mass emigration of Jews to Madagascar, but no decision was to be expected in the near future. The statement came in reply to a London report that the two countries had concluded an agreement on the matter.

Notre Dame coupled a brilliant scoring attack with a last-half defense that held Northwestern to 4 points to overcome an early lead and defeat the Wildcat basketball team tonight, 40 to 29. Northwestern set the pace in the first half,

Applicants for the post of executive director of the New Jersey Council, which has $150,000 to advertise New Jersey, will be interviewed by a special committee of the Council at the suggestion of Governor Hoffman, to whom the position has been offered at $15,000 annually.

Bill Miller of Chester, Nova Scotia, defeated his father, Colonel Miller, 4 and 3, today in the thirty-six-hole final round of Belmont Manor's annual Christmas golf tournament. The winner took the lead after the first nine and was never headed.

E. P. Trainer, business manager of Local 38, of the Marine Engineers' Beneficial Association, charged yesterday in a complaint filed with Secretary of Labor Perkins that steamship companies had violated the Federal law which limits the day of a ship's engineer to eight hours.

Football's collegiate headliners of 1937, gathered from practically every section of the country, will pool their individual talents here tomorrow to fight it out in the annual East-West charity game.

Distillers' representatives, intent on getting evidence for court injunctions, vied with bargain-seeking retail customers yesterday in reaching liquor package stores where nationally advertised brands of whiskies were being offered at cut prices in a widespread New Year's Eve price war.

The Bronx Board of Trade went on record yesterday against the proposed law for limiting freight trains to seventy cars which is under consideration by the committee on foreign and interstate commerce of the House of Representatives.

Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe allowed attorneys and others yesterday a little more than one-fourth of what they demanded as final fees for the services they rendered in the bankruptcy and reorganization proceedings of the United Cigar Stores Company of America, consolidated with proceedings as to the Cigar Stores Realty Holdings, Inc.
One squad was gay, the other grim when a couple of psychologistcoaches put their Rice Institute and Colorado football players to bed on the eve of the Cotton Bowl duel.

An earthquake of moderate intensity jarred Mexico City this morning. The Central Observatory estimated the epicenter 250 miles southwest of the capital, probably in the Pacific Ocean.
Increased gas ratet for the Perth Amrboy Gas Light Company were approved today by the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners over the objection of Perth Amboy, Carteret and Woodbridge.

The Neediest Cases Fund closed the old year with total contributions of $290,396.99 recorded in the present appeal, the twenty-sixth annual one since its inception. Gifts of $3,775.50 from ninety-sevendonors brought it to this figure yesterday.
A form of capitalism called "financial capitalism" was blamed today by an economics expert for lack of economic progress in the United States.

William Shapard Dowdell, former president of the New York Cotton Exchange, died of a heart attack today at his home here. His age was 53. He had been ill for several weeks but had gone yesterday to his office in New York.
Mr. and Mrs. William Walter Phelps of Westbury, L. I., and their sons, William W. Phelps Jr., Sheffield Phelps and Irving Phelps, are passing the holiday at the Cloister here.

Mr. and Mrs. Samuel J. Reeves and Miss Elise Reeves of Bryn Mawr, Pa., are at the Ambassador. Mr. and Mrs. John A. B. Smith and Miss Virginia Lee Smith will give a reception and tea tomorrow at their home, 1,170 Fifth Avenue.

Apparently taking their cue from a decision handed down last Tuesday by Vice Chancellor Maja Leon Berry, local authorities caused the arrest this afternoon of three bakery pickets for illegal picketing, that being defined as picketing where ho strike was in progress and business was going on as usual.

Thousands of football fans here to attend tomorrow's Sugar Bowl game between Louisiana State and Santa Clara joined tonight in the pandemonium of New Orleans' welcome to 1938. Fair weather was predicted for the game.

Thousands hurried out of New York yesterday and last night by boat, train, airplane and bus, in a last-minute dash to sunnier or snowier holiday resorts,-while other thousands flocked by "Times Square Specials" to join in the city's merriment.

Ireland begins the new year in orthodox fashion by turning a new leaf. On the fresh page is imprinted the image of a nation developed in the imagination of a leader singularly lacking in the qualities supposed to characterize or appeal to the Irish.

I. R. Stewart was elected chairman of the board of the Anchor Hocking Glass Corporation at a meeting of directors yesterday. I. J. Collins was elected president and William V. Fisher vice president and general manager. Thomas C. Fulton was elected a vice president;

William C. Dodge before leaving his office yesterday as District Attorney to make room today. for his successor, Thomas E. Dewey, said In a statement that "certain people" tried to cast aspersions on his administration in the last four years; quoted the Bible to shove that racketeering had existed since 593 B. C. and prided himself or having been a "humane" prosecutor, rather than a "hard-boiled" one.

OUT of all the fine-or terrible-books published in 1937, here are a dozen, not the dozen, perhaps, that should live on for a long time to come. Each one has its stirring and enduring excellences. They were all written with passion, wit and eloquence.

Frederick James Ingham thinks the song titled "Pennies From Heaven" should be changed to "Dollars From Heaven." Ingham, a Negro boatman plying the Hamilton-Paget Sound rowboat ferry this afternoon, was astonished to find money literally dropping from the skies.

Terrorized by a two-month epidemic of brutal beatings and holdups in the Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, parishioners of the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Rosary celebrated their annual New Year's Eve holy hour services last night one hour earlier than usual and under the protection of a special police detail.

Supreme Court Justice John MaeCrate in Brooklyn yesterday signed an order directing a check-up in six election districts of the Fourth Senatorial District for a place in the State Constitutional Convention contested by Abraham H. Schiff,
With the fires kindled by the debates over a peace program still smoldering, more than 500 delegates of the American Student Union from 150 colleges dispersed from the Vassar campus this evening.

The fifty-fifth annual solemn high mass to be celebrated on New Year's Day "for the spiritual and temporal welfare" of its members will be offered this morning at 11 o'clock in St. Patrick's Cathedral under the auspices of the New York Archdiocesan Union of Holy Name Societies.
A daughter was born here today to Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Tingley Craven Jr. of Brookline at the Baker Memorial Hospital. Mrs. Craven is the former Miss Helen Eck, daughter of the late
The Senate tonight rejected by 224 votes to 73 a bill authorizing the reopening next year of the International Exposition.
There won't be any ice for the first annual Ice Bowl football game tomorrow, but the prospect failed to dim enthusiasm among the cliff dwelling Eskimos of this Bering Strait isle.
A new streamlined ambulance for the Fire Department was delivered yesterday to the shops at 32-03 Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, for final adjustment and equipment.

In spite of the widening split between the A. F. of L. and the C. I. O., a C. I. O. union in this city proposed to an A. F. of L. union yesterday a joint drive to organize some 2,500 workers in the lumber yards of metropolitan New York.

Mayor Frank Hague and Governorelect A. Harry Moore will greet thousands of their constituents tomorrow at their annual "open house" New Year's Day reception at City Hall here. The Public Safety Department Band and Glee Club will entertain arid Senator Moore and Mayor Hague

Owners continued yesterday the rush to file plans for new buildings and alterations in existing ones before the end of the old year. The projects include plans for apartment houses in Manhattan, where' a six-story building to cost $300,000 will be erected at 171-1T7 Seventh Avenue.

Conflict among the Democratic Councilmen-elect over the selection of a City Clerk developed yesterday. It was predicted, however, that the difference of opinion over this matter would not prevent the election of John Cashmore of Brooklyn as vice chairman. The first meeting of the new City Council will be held Monday at noon.

Trading in bonds through the year's final session yesterday was dull and featureless, with leading issues fluctuating irregularly within narrow limits. Reflecting the influence of the pre-holiday atmosphere,

The new City Planning Commission will hold its first organization meeting next week, probably on Thursday, A. A. Berle Jr., chairman of the commission, announced yesterday after an informal meeting of the body in Mr. Berle's office, 70 Pine Street.
