Charges by Stanley Getz, an orphan now 19 years old, that he was treated "like a slave" for ten years by his aunt and uncle, although they were receiving $10 a week from his estate for his support, were upheld today by Surrogate William J. Sheils in a decision filed

Created to provide development facilities for "by-product" ideas and inventions of technicians of the Bell Telephone Laboratories, a large new laboratory at 76 Varick Street will be opened for inspection by representatives of the press at 3 o'clock Monday, it was announced yesterday.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has adopted a rule, designated 11F-1 under the Public Utility Holding Company Act, which provides that any person proposing to submit any reorganization plan to a Federal court for a registered holding company must file first with the commission an application for approval of the plan.
The death rate last November was the lowest for any November in the history of the 17,500,000 industrial policy holders of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, according to a report yesterday.

Professor Einstein has broken to bits the old conception of time, but still the universe seems to men's ears to strike like a great clock when the earth reaches the imaginary fixed point in space that we call January First.

The John Price Jones Corporation announced yesterday that its "index of philanthropy" indicated a substantial increase in the "social dividends" from American business and Industry and in the "standard of giving" for 1937, despite the decline in the business index in the latter part of the year.

Alma Tell, retired stage and screen actress, who died Wednesday night of a heart attack, will be buried here today. She was 39 years old. Born in New York, Miss Tell went on the stage at the age of 16 and played in "Main Street," "Eyes of Youth" and "The House Beautiful."
Twenty-six thousand workers on WPA educational, professional, sewing and white-collar projects in this city were assured of continued employment yesterday when Lieut.

In message to Congress President Roosevelt sees no need for constitutional amendment and looks to courts for progressional interpretations. In message two days later he predicts a balanced budget for 1938.
Frank Eliot Sweetser, a New York lawyer living here, died yesterday at the North Country Hospital, Glen Cove, L. I. He was a member of the law firm of Sweetser, White Co. His age was 56.

Two thousand Winter sports devotees rolled out of Grand Central station last night in three snow trains headed for Northern New York and New England, where they will spend the first two days of the New Year skiing over forest trails and open slopes. Twelve coaches and forty-three Pullmans were used to transport the passengers.

The Sun-Telegraph said today it had learned that the University of Pittsburgh Panthers will play Indiana University's Hoosiers on the gridiron in 1940, probably in the first week of October. The game would mark the first time the teams have met.

For the first time in five years, the average price of real estate bonds showed a decline in 1937, according to the Amott-Baker Real Estate Bond Index, which is based on 200 issues on Eastern properties.
A special commissioner was established in the Rumanian Ministry of Commerce today to enforce the measures against Jews which have been instituted by Premier Octavian Goga.

In a little London hotel Sir James Frazer, author of "The Golden Bough," one of the world's outstanding anthropological studies, will celebrate his eighty-fourth birthday tomorrow in the manner. that pleases him most. His wife said today that he planned to do his usual work.

Corrupt expenditure of $435,000 in connection with the sale of $17,000,000 notes of the Buenos Aires Central Railroad Terminal Company was charged in a bill in equity filed in the Suffolk Superior Court today against the General Investment Corporation of Boston, and a group of its present and former directors, by Frederick S. Burroughs of Sparta, N. J., a stockholder.

The Red Navy was divorced from the Red Army by a government decree announced unexpectedly today. By this decree a new commissariat, called the Commissariat of Naval Affairs, was created, and the Red navy's ships and personnel were a transferred from the Commissariat of Defense which, since its creation on June 20, 1934, has governed both the army and navy.

According to reliable dispatches reaching the border from Irun, Spain, an American and a British war correspondent were killed and an American was wounded today when a Government shell hit their automobile three miles behind the Rebel lines in the Teruel sector. [The Spanish Rebel commander at Irun confirmed the killings, according to The Associated Press.]

Four men who are capable of clearing 6 feet 4 inches or better have entered the handicap running high jump event in the twelfth annual Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, indoor track meet to be held next Saturday night at the Thirteenth Regiment Armory in Brooklyn, it was announced yesterday.

Estate more than $10,000. To Rev. James R. Cassidy, 0. M. I., St. Mary's San Antonio, Texas, $2,000; seven specific bequests; Mae Ward, niece, executrix, 360 95th St., Brooklyn, $1,000 and residue. Jessie E. Nagle. 10 W. 103d St.. executrix.

Pershing Beer Hall is bankrupt. After the war its owner, Mme. Joly, a widow, named her beverage place near the Bois de Boulogne after the United States general to capitalize on the hero worship bestowed on him.

Word has been received here from London of the engagement of Miss Nadia Fortington, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold A. Fortington of Lime Ridge, Poughquag, N. Y., and the Isle of Jethou, Channel Islands, to Charles Graham, Master of Kinnaird, elder son of Lord and Lady Kinnaird of Rossie Priory, Perthshire, Scotland.

The Living Church, Protestant Episcopal weekly organ published in Milwaukee, has included the name of Mayor La Guardia in its annual roll of honor of churchmen rendering "distinguished service" in 1937, it was announced yesterday.

Denouncing the sit-down strike as "a treasonable machination," Judge Harry S. McDevitt in a sweeping opinion today permanently enjoined 25C union members from resort to the sit-down technique at the plant of McNeely Price, leather tanners.

Scoring 313 runs for five wickets, an All-India eleven made a good start today in the third unofficial cricket test match against Lord Tennyson's touring English team. The visitors won the first two games, played at Bombay.

Henry Ford expressed the opinion in a statement on business conditions today that the country was on the verge of greater quantity production, and revealed that he expected to produce a low-priced tractor of unusual design within a rew months.

In the presence of his wife and a few friends, Charles. Poletti, formerly counsel to Governor Lehman, received yesterday the oath of office as a member of the Supreme Court for a fourteen-year term from Chief Justice Frederick E. Crane of the Court of Appeals.

Football enthusiasm surged high tonight as nearly 90,000 persons, largest throng in the history of Rose Bowl warfare, waited impatiently for tomorrow's struggle between the Golden Bears of California and Alabama from the sunny South.

Another suspect among the thirtynine persons indicted for the $2,000,000 long Island real estate swindle known as "Slovak Manor" was arrested early yesterday morning while visiting friends in Brooklyn. He was Maurice Miller, 44 years old, of Moodus, Conn., a farmer.
Thousands of New Yorkers joined in the gay revels staged at leading hotels and restaurants last night to celebrate the passing of 1937 and to welcome the New Year in traditional noisy fashion.

A drive by the Administration to force the elimination from the pending Farm Bill of the McNary-Boileau amendment, which aims to prevent the use for pasturage purposes of lands withdrawn from crop production, was begun today at a conference between Secretary Wallace and Senators Pope and Hatch.

The State Department received today from Consul General Paul R. Jossolyn at Hankow the names of the 158 Americans who were among the 300 foreigners sent by special train to Hong Kong in anticipation of hostilities at Hankow between the Japanese and Chinese.

State Sehatot Lester H. Clee's total net galn in the Hudson Cont Gubernatorial recount today reached 454 out of 44,899 votes retailed. In three districts of Jersey City's tenth Ward,the defeated Roepub lican candidate gained eleven ballots fo the day.

Member trading in round lots for their own account on the New York Stock Exchange went along with the rising price trend in the week ended on Dec. 4, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

More than 100- conventions and exhibitions will be held in New York City in January, according to a list issued yesterday by the Merchants Association. The association described the large number of events scheduled as "one of the most favorable omens that has been observed since the current recession began."

Rice, pickles and bean soup for breakfast; rice, pickles and vegetables for midday dinner, and rice, pickles and vegetables for supper-these were the short and simple menus in the detention prison where Baroness Shidzue Ishimoto was held for a fortnight on suspicion of harboring dangerous or near-dangerous thoughts or because she knew some people who might.

Thomas E. Dewey was sworn in yesterday as the new District Attorney of New York County and the first independent prosecutor in twenty years. One of his first acts in the new year was to witness the swearing in of Mayor La Guardia for a second term in the library of the home of Samuel Seabury, 154 East Sixty-third Street, at 12:01 o'clock this morning.

Keith Morgan, chairman of the Committee for the Celebration of the President's Birthday to Fight Infantile Paralysis, announced yesterday that 1938 would mark the first time in history that the American people have united on a nationwide scale to combat infantile paralysis.

Apparently to eliminate reports that the crash of three Cuban planes at Call Wednesday was due to criminal mechanical tampering with the planes, the secretary of President Alfonso lopez today issued a press bulletin contradicting that theory.

New bond financing during the final week of the year amounted to $9,351,000, as compared with only $3,030,000 in new loans offered in the preceding period. During this week a year ago a total of $71,390,000 in new bonds was placed on the market.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 1,102,000 bales, against 1,054,000 a week ago, 982,000 two weeks ago, 959,000 three weeks ago and 909,000 a year ago; of which American 663,000 bales, against 635,000 a week ago, 559,000 two weeks ago, 538,000 three weeks ago and 341,000 a year ago.

George M. Trautman, president of the American Association, predicted today the league would experience its greatest player turnover in history before the start of the thirty-seventh annual campaign, on April 16.
There is one resolution the trout fishermen should make this morning, and do their best to carry out during the coming year. That is:
For the seventh time, the frostbite dinghy sailors plan today to usher in a New Year with a regatta, to be held on Manhasset Bay, Long Island, where Winter windjamming was started in 1932.

Ogden Ave. (9-2524), w s, 125 ft s of 162d St, 100x90; Ogden Realty Corp to Central Management Corp, 384 E 149th St; mtg $140,000. Zerega. Ave (14-3542), n e cor of Lacombe Ave, 300x218; Del Balso Holding Corp to Del Balso Construction Corp, 220 E 42d St.
The National Collegiate Athletic Association took steps today to "save boxing from disappearing" as a college sport.

The new Estonian Constitution, prepared last August by the National Assembly, becomes effective at midnight. The event will be celebrated all over the Estonian Republic with great civic festivities, military processions, artillery salutes and torchlight parades.

Sir Robert G. Vansittart, strong-willed and forceful Permanent Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs since 1930, was shifted from his post tonight and with the start of the new year will no longer have direct control of the British diplomatic machine.

General Douglas MacArthur's decision to reYnain in the Philippines in control of the destinies of the island's young army with the rank of Field Marshal was made at the behest of President Manuel Quezon, a statement by the latter today revealed.

The Peruvian budget for 1938, which will be published tomorrow by President Oscar Raimundes Benavides, is balanced at 165,545,739 soles. It is the highest recorded in the history of the republic, exceeding the 1937 budget, the previous record, by 11,975.104 soles.

The Federal Government's gasoline price-fixing case recessed today for the week-end after testimony that the average retail price of gasoline in key Midwestern cities in 1935 was lower than the average for, representative cities in other parts of the country.

Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange in December was the slowest for December since 1934. Sales, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, totaled 28,417,970 shares, compared with 29,264,906 in November, and 48,605,047 in December, 1936.

Senator Steiwer asked Attorney General Cummings today to take action to halt the labor boycott against the Oregon lumber industry. Asserting that A. F. of L. unions in California were boycotting Oregon lumber, the Senator, in an open letter to Cummings, declared that this constituted a secondary boycott and was therefore illegal.
Disappointment was apparent among at least some legislators from the western mining sector when they learned tonight of President Roosevelt's proclamation cutting the

Completion of Hampshire House, an apartment hotel at 150 Central Park South, cost $75,000 less than the estimate made last May, Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler was informed yesterday by the trustees of Series C-2 mortgage certificates of the New York Title and Mortgage Company.
The Duke of Windsor's "shadow," Chief Inspector David Storrier of New Scotland Yard, was promoted today to the rank of superintendent in the Metropolitan Police.

A three-judge Federal court granted the Donnelly Garment Company a temporary injunction today against picketing and interference by the International Ladies' Garment Workers in a decision arising from the question of what constitutes a labor dispute.

Dr. and Mrs. Lewis Parke Longnecker have announced the engagement of M their daughter, Miss Ruth Longnecker, to John Mauro French of Framingham, Mass., and Brownsville, Vt., son of Mrs. Charles Stratton French and the late Mr. French.

Columbia University Press is starting the New Year by publishing, on Jan. 10, "The Plough and the Sword; Labor, Land and Property in Fascist Italy," by Carl T. Schmidt. It provides, according to Columbia Press, "some important facts about II Duce's bailiwick that have not hitherto been gathered and analyzed."

Stocks closed year steady and mixed in slowest trading of the month; turnover, 780,115 shares. United States Government bonds slightly higher, other groups firm and mixed in second slowest turnover of year; transactions,
Deep in the northern regions of Quebec, where white men seldom penetrate, twelve surveyors and their two Indian guides were listed as missing tonight.

In observance of New Year's Day, financial and commodity markets the world over, with a few scattered exceptions, will be closed today. Banks, likewise, will be closed. Trading in the major commodity exchanges was halted at noon yesterday, although the principal securities exchanges traded the full session. Business in all markets will be resumed on Monday.

Carrying out the decree of King Farouk's new government, police today occupied camps of the Nationalist Blueshirts throughout the country. The Blueshirts, youth organization of the Wafd [Nationalist] party which the 18-year-old King had removed from power, had vacated during the night.

New securities offered to the public here in December were in somewhat larger volume and more diversified than in the preceding month. State and municipal bond flotations and industrial stock offerings led in their respective fields.

A 3-year-old Negro was suffocated and his sister, 4, was overcome yesterday when, terrified by a smoky fire that started in their apartment on the fifth floor of a tenement house at 200 West 144th Street, they locked themselves in a closet. Firemen found them unconscious. The children were James Jordan, who died, and Jean, who was revived and sent to Harlem Hospital.

A decree effective tomorrow was issued here tonight fixing the foreign exchange rate at 25 pesos to the dollar for both imports and exports. The rate for articles of luxury heretofore had been 24 pesos to the dollar.

New data concerning the planets obtained in two different ways, one by direct observation and the other by theoretical considerations, were presented today to members of the American Astronomical Society, meeting here. at Indiana University.

Admiral Shen Hung-lieh, the Mayor of Tsingtao, his chief of police and all members of the police force have fled from the Shantung Province port, leaving the maintenance of law and order in the damaged city in the hands of 300 foreigners, who are armed only with clubs.
Two hopefuls who learned to play tennis on cement courts in New York gained the final round of the national junior indoor tennis championships at the Seventh Regiment Armory courts yesterday.

A regulation under the safety provisions of the Motor Carrier Act limiting the working hours of drivers of commercial motor vehicles, effective July 1, was announced today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
George Cookman, Yale University carried off the honors in the fourth annual intercollegiate invitation squash racquets tournament at the University Club yesterday when he defeated A. W.
A Spanish Insurgent broadcast from Salamanca tonight announced Generalissimo Francisco Franco's troops had battered their way into Teruel and relieved the Insurgent garrison within the city.
West Virginia and Texas Tech football teams smoothed last-minute wrinkles today for their game in the Sun Bowl tomorrow.

The marriage of Miss Marian Greenlee, daughter of Mrs. Ralph S. Greenlee of Chicago, to Detmar H. Finke, son of Mrs. Mary Berkeley Finke of New York, took place this afternoon in the chapel of St. James Church.

Mrs. Nannie M. McDannald Garritt, for thirty-three years a Presbyterian mission worker in China, died on Tuesday at her home in Green Cove Springs, Fla., according to word received here last night. She was 73 years old.
Miss Hilda R. Hutchinson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Hutchinson, gave a luncheon yesterday in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for Miss. Mary P. Johnston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs.

William Nashman, about 25 years old, of 859 Sixty-first Street, Brooklyn, a clerk employed by a bread company, was robbed of $200 in cash and checks for $400 belonging to the concern, about 9 o'clock last night by two young men who forced him into a vacant lot at Clark Place and Jerome Avenue, 'the Bronx. Neither of the robbers, who appeared to be about 19, was armed.

11:00 A. M.-12:00 M.--Cincinnati Conservatory of Music Concert--WABC. 1:55-4:45 P. M.-Metropolitan Opera: "Don Giovanni," Gina Cigna and Dusolina Giannini, Sopranos; Richard Crooks, Tenor--WJZ. 2:00-4:45 P. M.-Football: Louisiana State-Santa Clara, at Sugar Bowl, New Orleans-WEAF. 2:00-4:45 P. M.-Auburn-Michigan, at Orange Bowl, Miami-WABC (Colorado-Rice, at Cotton Bowl, Dallas, Texas, 4:45-5:45.)

Former Judge William E. Woollard, executive chairmar of the New York State Waterways Association, said today the group would "vigorously oppose" transfer of the New York State barge nal to the Federal Government and the charging of tolls on its commerce.

Sun Power, a Canadian invader in the silks of the Toronto brokersportsman, H. R. Bain, closed his 3-year-old career with a thrilling victory in the Hialeah Purse of one mile at Tropical Park today. Five horses ran in the feature, and a rope thrown across the finish line would have struck every horse.

Cotton-mill activity declined last week. Even with the working-day factor raised to 5.0, the daily average of activity receded more than anticipated seasonally, and the adjusted index eased to 83.7, its lowest point mince the week ended Sept. 29, 1934.

Application by the Chicago Stock Exchange to strike from listing the no par value common stock of the Stutz Motor Car Company of America, Inc., has been granted, the Securities and Exchange Commission stated today. Delisting was sought,
The report of the Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore and subsidiaries for the eleven months ended on Nov. 30, issued yesterday,

Following Berlin's demands for the suppression of German emigre newspapers in Czechoslovakia made in the course of German-Czech negotiations for a press truce, the German Social Democratic party's weekly, Neue Vorwaerts as from ta next week will be published in Paris.

Political developments in Rumama the last few days seem to indicate that King Carol is abandoning constitutional government and establishing himself as a dictatorial ruler. Choosing as Premier the intense nationalist Octavian Goga, leader of the National Christian party-which won but 9 per cent of the

Interest payments totaling 6 1/2 per cent of their investment were made in 1937 to guaranteed mortgage .certificate holders who invested $2,231,000 in the Buchanan, a fifteen-story and penthouse apartment at 160 East Forty-eighth Street,

Judge J. A. Valin, one of the three guardians of the Dionne quintuplets, said today that the children now have an income of $17,000 a year from their investments. On top of this is a large income from royalties and other sources.
An agreement effective tomorrow between the United States and Brazil provides for the reciprocal waiver of passport visa fees for, nonimmigrant nationals of both countries.
The Interstate Commerce Commission today ratified the appointment of Walter Kidde as sole trustee of the property of the New York, Susquehanna Western Railroad Company.
President Roosevelt asked the newspapers today to convey his New Year well wishes to the country and to express his gratitude to those who had sent New Year's greetings to the White House.

A charge that the appointment of Municipal Court Justice Paul Livoti as Queens County Clerk was part of a "political plot" designed to strengthen the power of James C. Sheridan, Queens County Democratic leader,

Endorsement by Senator George W. Norris of a boycott upon silk hosiery was condemned yesterday as more of a blow to American industry than an anti-Japanese move by Earl Constantine, director of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers, and George Urlaub, executive' director of the Throwsters' Research Institute.

Short Skirt, 4-year-old filly from the Sioux City Stable that had won only one race in thirty-three previous starts during 1937, marked up a second victory today when she upset the talent to capture the featured sixth race at the Fair Grounds.

The following foreign service changes since Dec. 18 were announced today by the State Department: David A. Thomasson, Henderson, Ky., clerk in American Legation, Helsinkia, Finland, confirmed as a foreign service officer, unclassified, vice consul of career, and a secretary in the diplomatic service, and assigned to Naples, Italy, as vice consul.

Reorganization trustees of the Prudence Company in Federal bankruptcy proceedings have brought suit in Supreme Court to recover $2,370,000 from twenty-one officials or former officials of the company or their estates and beneficiaries, it was disclosed yesterday.

Lucien G. Berry, retired brigadier general of the United States Army, died at his home here today at the age of 74. He served as brigade adjutant during the Spanish-American War and saw action during the Philippine Insurrection.

The Minneapolis, St. Paul and Sault Ste. Marie Railroad - commonly known as the Soo Line-filed today in Federal Court a petition in bankruptcy. Greatly reduced earnings, increased taxes, labor and other costs and heavy bond maturities in 1938, including a $70,000,000 issue in July, forced the 3,300-mile road to the step, C. T. Jaffray, chairman of the board, said.

Abraham N. Davis, an assistant director of the Trading and Exchange Division of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has resigned to return to private practice of law as a member of the New York firm of McCauley, Spigelberg, Davis Gallagher.

Ninety-one awards for participation in Fall sports have been made by the City College Athletic Association, according to an announcement yesterday by Professor Walter Williamson, college manager of athletics.

Herberl G. Jacobson, doing business as the Herbert Company, 80 Wall Street, New York City, has filed an application for withdrawal of registration as an over-the-counter broker or dealer, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

J. I. Kislak, Inc., broker, announces the sale of several residential parcels in Hudson County, N. J. The three-family house with a two-car garage at 588 Twenty-first Street, West New York, was sold by the Town of Union Building and Loan Association to Concetta Potenti.
The United States liner President carding will arrive today from Hamburg and other European ports. On board is Colonel M.
Three Japanese gendarmes were injured today when a Chinese terrorist hurled five hand grenades in the heart of the International Settlement.

The police placed a member of the Detroit' Purple Gang and his woman friend in the line-up yesterday, ruining the profitable narcotic business he had built up since he came to live quietly in Brooklyn Heights. He was Joseph Fradella and she said she was Billie LeRoy. The police said Fradella is wanted for four murders, kidnapping two policemen and several- other charges.
William Oscar Anderson Jr., former publisher and a political writer, died yesterday in his room at the Hotel Flanders at the age of 51.
Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg declared today in a year-end interview that he was confident Austria would weather both the internal and foreign storms of 1938.

Arturo Toscanini and the new NBC Symphony Orchestra will give a benefit concert on Sunday evening, Feb. 6, in Carnegie Hall on behalf of the Italian Welfare League, it was announced yesterday by the National Broadcasting Company. The concert is not to be broadcast.

New York cheered in the New Year with traditional din and gayety despite a sleet and rain that fell on noisy thousands in Times Square. [Page 1.] Hotels and night clubs were well filled, although the crowds were smaller than last year and spending was curtailed. [Page 2.] Churches throughout the city held midnight services. [Page 2.] Travel to and from the city was heavy. [Page 2.]

Twenty-five Brooklyn patrolmen and detectives and a detachment from the Manhattan Bomb and Alien Squad guarded yesterday the Japanese freighter Nagara Maru, docked at Pier 16 at the foot of Joralemon Street, Brooklyn, and, it was said, would continue to guard the ship until it sails on Monday morning.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John Y. G. Walker of Llewellyn Park, this place, of the engagement of Mr. Walker's daughter, Miss Mabel Burke Walker, to Charles Pendleton Lewis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edison Lewis of Cedarhurst. L. I.

Garland Sevier Ferguson Jr. of North Carolina tomorrow will become chairman of the Federal Trade Commission for the third time. Commissioner Ferguson is not only the first member to hold that office three times but is the oldest member of the commission from point of service, having served more than ten years.

LOVE AND HISSES, based on a story Art Arthur; screen play by Curtis Kenyon and Mr. Arthur: music and lyrics Mack Gordon and Harry Revel, Lew lack and Sidney D. Mitchell: "Power House." by Raymond Scott "The Song," by Norman Zeno an will Irwin: directed by Sidney Lanfield;

The Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company, which last January inaugurated cooperative newspaper advertising, yesterday announced that it would discontinue such advertising allowances to retailers and substitute a liberalizing of its volume rebates at the opening of its Spring lines on Monday.
Quae caussa fuit, consurgere in arma Europamque Asiamque, et foedera solvere furto? Virgil, 70-19, B. C.

In his address on "Science ana Ethics" before the symposium on "Science and Society" at the Indianapolis meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, Professor Edward G. Conklin remarked that "science has flourished under a freedom which it has not created,

To complete its program for standardization of colors in bathroom and kitchen accessories, the housewares buyers group of the National Retail Dry Goods Association yesterday suggested a label to be attached to the articles for identification of the standard colors.

Several transactions in the common stock of General Motors Corporation were included in the summary of reports for November of officers, directors and principal stockholders, made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

W. Somerset Maugham's "The Letter," one of the cultural achievements of early sound which Paramount made in 1929 with the late Jeanne Eagels and Herbert Marshall, is to reach the screen again under the auspices at the same lot with a star unknown here. Isa Miranda,
Mayor S. Davis Wilson was forbidden today by the State Supreme Court to carry out his announced intention of seizing the city-owned gas plant at midnight, on the advent of the new year.

An orchid for every woman and a gardenia for every man, the flowers to be grown by prisoners in the penitentiary - gardens and given to island visitors, was part of the plan Governor Blanton H. Winship announced in a New Year broadcast as a means of exemplifying the island's hospitality.

Miss Cynthia Root, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Root of 114 Clinton Street, Brooklyn, was married last night in the First Presbyterian Church of Brooklyn to Robert S. Carter, son of Mrs. Robert S. Carter of 7 Park Avenue, and the late Mr. Carter, by the Rev. Phillips Packer Elliott.
After he had taken the oath of office yesterday as President of the new City Council, Newbold Morris announced the appointments of six persons on his administrative staff.

Archibald R. Watson, new New York County Clerk, announced yesterday he had requested William B. Herlands, who takes office today as Commissioner of Investigation, to make an audit of the records of the County Clerk's office recently vacated by Albert Marinelli.
Gray Craig, home of Mr. and Mrs. Michael M. Van Beuren in Middletown, was the scene of a New Year's Eve party tonight for about 300 guests.

The Tennessee Valley Authority, with a total investment in its programs of $170,416,718, of which $10,945,062 net is allocated to electricity purposes, showed a net income from sale of electricity for the fiscal year 1937 of $714,622, according to the annual report of TVA, which went to Congress today.

The shrill laughter of more than 100 children from St. Paul's Parochial School broke morning stillness yesterday in the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse at a special screening of two one-reel film fables produced for the entertainment of youngsters by the Julia Ellsworth Ford Foundation of California. Mrs. Ford,

The Securities and Exchange Commission has called a hearing for Jan. 18 to determine whether the common stock, 10 cents par value, of the Chollar Extension Mining Company should be suspended for not- more

Germany, entering the new year, looks back tonight upon the old as a period of steady progress, enhanced national prestige and increased strength. There is no question that today the Third Reich is stronger and counts for more in the world than last year.
Governor Lehman called Supreme Court Justice William F. Dowling of Utica on the telephone today and informed him that he had been appointed to the Appellate Division at Rochester, effective tomorrow.
British courts are preparing for a deluge of divorce cases, as the new act liberalizing divorce laws, which A. P. Herbert almost single-handedly pushed through Parliament, takes effect MAD tomorrow.
Prices of wheat declined around 1 cent a bushel at the extreme on the Board of Trade here today to a new low level- for the May since Nov. 26 on scattered year-end liquidation.
Police Commisisoner Valentine ordered all officers of his department yesterday from the chief inspector down to acting lieutenants to appear in headquarters today "for instruction in their duties."

SIX football games on New Year's Day. There's a business expansion in this era of depression. Everything isn't going to the bowwows, Mr. Ickes. Baseball had a great year. Basketball is setting new records. The football campaign, from any angle, was the best in nearly a decade. Hockey is filling the ice arenas.
The French railways, which have operated under private management for nearly a century, pass under government control at midnight tonight.

Federal authorities filed murder charges today against two amateur crewmen who, they said, ended the pirate reign of Jack Morgan, 28, on the yacht Aafje by tossing him overboard near the Mexican west coast five days after he slew the wealthy owner, Dwight L. Faulding, 49, Santa Barbara hotel man.
ROCHESTER. Dec. minute after the church bells ring in the New Year at the Brighton Reformed Church, the Rev. Anthony Luidens will end the Watch Night services with a wedding service.

In accordance with the Federal Highway Act, Secretary Wallace today allocated $195,000,000 to the States, but in a letter which he sent to the Governors he stated that the alterations might be considered in advance as only tentative.

A new direct radio telegraph channel between New York and Reykjavik, Iceland, will open today at 8:30 A. M., Eastern standard time, with W. A. Winterbotton, vice president of RCA Communications, and the director general of telegraphs of Iceland exchanging greetings.

Samuel L. (Roxy) Rothafel, who died on Jan. 13, 1936, left a net estate of $215,560, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. The entire estate goes to his widow, Mrs. Rosa Rothafel of 25 East Seventy-seventh Street.

Dartmouth, temporarily minus the services of its star, Dick Durrance, today won both cross-country and slalom events in the first day of the intercollegiate ski meet with the University of Washington. Steve Bradley of Dartmouth won from ten opponents in the slalom race in 3 minutes 43.6 seconds for two runs.

The business recession in the United States has put new difficulties in the way of a revised Canadian-American trade treaty or at least in the way of the Domincan Government's defense of it before Parliament, according to observers.

The success of the recitals of the International Dance and of the attendant art exhibits and lectures prompts the comment that here is a medium Which may be availed of not only for the mere joy of it but also for promoting incidentally a folk feeling among people of different nations.

Tne Japanese attack on the British gunboat Ladybird in the Yangtze River, which is the British counterpart of the Panay incident, was virtually closed as an issue tonight with the publication of a note to Japan in which it appeared that Britain had moved almost but not quite on parallel lines with the United States.

Miss Sybil Ewart McCrea, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Lowrain Edward McCrea of Little Linden Farm, Ambler, was married this evening to De Witt Norton McClumpha, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. E. McClumpha of Pittsburgh. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Elbert Bennett at the home of the bride's parents.

Two former winners, J. H. Van Alen of New York and W. C. Wright of Philadelphia, today reached the semi-final round of the Gold Racquet court tennis championship, an annual feature of the holiday season at the Tuxedo Club.

Imports of gold at the Port of New York last month amounted to $2,423,700 and exports amounted to $15,000,000, all of which was sent to France. At San Francisco, shipments of $21,077,300 gold were received, making the total imports for the month at both ports $23,501,000 and the net imports $8,501,000.
Tne securities and Exchange Commission cited today Gerald M. Loeb and Gordon B. Crary, partners in E. F. Hutton Co. of New York, a brokerage firm, and H. Terry Morrison, said to be a floor trader,
Discovery of a new principle of immunology which opens the way for the preparation of effective vaccines against all the virus diseases, from infantile paralysis down to the common cold,
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Dec. 30 unless specified: Asheville, at Manila, Dec. 31. Henderson, at San Francisco. Manley, at Gibraltar, Dec. 31. Pillsbury, at Shanghal, Dec. 31.

Commenting on the approval by the. Securities and Exchange Commission of a voluntary plan of reorganization of the American Water Works and Electric Company, Inc., H. Hobart Porter, chairman of the board of the utility, said yesterday that he found the commission's decision "most satisfactory."
The Securities and Exchange Commission has approved an application by the Cumberland County Power and Light Corporation, a subsidiary of the New England Public Service Company,
Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Dec. 25 totaled 460,,367 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

The administering of oaths to 140 town, city and county officials who will take office tomorrow in Westchester County was completed today. Harold Mercer, County Clerkelect, was the last of the new county officials to be sworn in this afternoon.

Joseph (Smiling Joe) Thomas, Negro, who fled West Hudson Hospital here Monday night after three stitches had been taken in his heart by a surgeon, came smiling back today. He walked into the hospital and apologized for having caused so much worry to the hospital staff and Kearny police.
William Bradford, formerly of New York, an engineer, died of heart disease in his villa near here, where he had lived for ten of the thirty years he was a resident of France. He was 65 years old.

Uldine Utley, who gained nationwide fame as a child evangelist, was married yesterday morning in the Little Church Around the Corner to Eugene Langkop, traveling representative of a shoe manufacturing concern.

The Alabama agricultural experiment station announced today the perfection of a testing machine which will tell whether an egg will produce a chick. Dr. M. J. Funchess, director, who explained that the machine will tell within fifteen hours whether an egg is fertile, said it has a potential value of $17,000,000 to American ??.

The underground pneumatic letter express recently threatened by labor complications will continue operations, at least temporarily, it was learned yesterday, pending negotiations between its private owners and the Postoffice Department. The employes won a five-day week and a nine-hour day.

That Newark porter at $20 a week who pretended to have lost $87,000 out of the pocket of his sweater, advertised a reward of $10,000 and finally acknowledged that his treasure amounted to $83, should be judged indulgently. He bothered the police, but he amused the public.
The Labor Department reported today that there were 4,394 strikes during the first eleven months of 1937, more than twice as many as during all of 1936.

Answering an old charge but one recently repeated by a Madras politician that missionaries are handmaids of imperialism, Bishop Vizagapatam, at a jubilee celebration at the Eucharistic Congress yesterday, said:
Tribute to efforts of employes to obtain traffic for the Baltimore Ohio Railroad was paid by Daniel Willard, president, in his New Year's greeting to the company's forces.

An appeal for "cooperation among the divergent groups of labor," also for a "more cooperative attitude toward both industry and labor" on the part of the government, was made by Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor,

Don Bradman, famous Australian captain, set a new record today. Playing for South Australia against Victoria, he scored 54 of his team's opening day's total of 287 for nine wickets, bringing his aggregate in Sheffield Shield cricket matches to 6,280 runs, six more than the total compiled by Clem Hill.

The Washington Redskins, national professional football champions, announced to day a schedule of three January exhibition games, as follows: .Jan. 16, All Stars at San Francisco; 23, Chicago Bears, Dallas, Texas, and 30, All Stars at Houston, Texas.

The name of the Prudence Company, Inc., defunct New York mortgage investment concern, entered the Merritt Parkway land purchase inquiry today, it was disclosed at the office of Attorney General McLaughlin.
Joseph Sullivan, Past Commander of the Nashua Post, Veterans of Foreign Wars, today boasted a perfect cribbage hand, the first ever dealt in the ten-year existence of the City Cribbage League.

William J. Gray, former president of the National Association of Gardeners and an enthusiastic supporter of the plan to create an International Peace Garden along the Canadian border, died today at his residence, 3.203 S Street. He was 56 years old.

More than 200 guests attended a costume dinner dance at the club here tonight. Among them were many members of society from New York, Boston and Philadelphia. There are many visitors here for the annual gold racquets court tennis championship tournament which got under way today.

Miss Helen Bernhard, 16-year-old New Yorker, defeated Miss Cissy Madden of Boston today to retain her championship with a 3-6, 7-5, 6-3 victory in the final match of the girls' national indoor tennis tournament at Longwood.
Mayor La Guardia expressed an all-inclusive wish for the happiness of New Yorkers during the New Year as he was leaving his temporary offices in the Empire State Building yesterday afternoon.

States in which horse racing is Conducted received $8,850,336 in 1937 as compared to $7,537,170 in 1936, a survey by The Associated Press revealed yesterday. The figures do not include Missouri or Louisiana, where the State has no control over the sport and receives no income. In Texas, where the sport was outlawed, they include the State's share from Sept. 1, 1936, to July 1, 1937.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Dec. 30: COLONEL Bonesteel, C. H., Inf., Ft. Sheridan, Ill., to Hawaiian Dep't, to sail from New York about April 14.

Ridley Watts, until his retirement in 1929 head of the wholesale cotton goods firm of Ridley Watts Co. and one of the leading figures in the textile business in this country, died yesterday at the Beekman Street Hospital after a brief illness. He was 65 years old.

The validity of price-fixing contracts for trade-marked products as provided under the New Jersey Fair Trade Law was upheld here today by Vice Chancellor Alfred A. Stein, who granted a preliminary injunction restraining the Woods Cut Rate Store of East Orange- from selling the products of the Houbigant Sales Corporation of New York at below prices set by the concern on its cosmetics.

Greater efficiency and economy in the management of the hospitals at the Medical Center during 1938, under control of a single governing board which became effective at midnight, was forecast yesterday by officers of Columbia University and Presbyterian Hosptal, which jointly operate most of the facilities at the center.

Because today is New Year s Day all the pastors will preach sermons tomorrow about hopes temporal, international and spiritual for the new year. Many clergymen of Protestant churches, especially those of the Episcopal communion, will call on their congregations to take a "Pledge to the Cross," which is somewhat- like that of the pledge to the flag.' It reads: "

MacSumner Mullin, Wilmington, was appointed a member of the State Athletic Commission for a three-year term today by Governor Richard C. McMullen. He succeeded James L. Luke, commission chairman, whose term expired.
Department store trade here this week was about even with the figures of the corresponding week a year ago, although considerable spottiness continued in evidence, merchants reported here yesterday.

Bernard W. Lynch, president of the . Standard Gas and Electric Company, in a statement reviewing 1937, said yesterday that business everywhere was facing demands for a change. These demands, whether they resulted from economic dislocations or differences in thinking, must be considered and, wherever justified, they must be met, he added.
America's football coaches were told today that the fatality toll taken by the game this year was the lowest since official records were started in 1931.

More than a hundred friends, including persons well known in the world of writing and the stage, attended services held yesterday afternoon in the Church in the Gardens, Ascan Avenue and Greenway North, Forest Hills, for Donald Perry "Don" Marquis, who died at his home, 51 Wendover Road, Forest Hills, on Tuesday morning.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 9,000, including 4,000 directs. The market was 15c-25c higher than Thursday's average; spots up more.

Miss Osmunde Olcott Phillips, daughter of Mrs. Osmund Phillips of 2,316 Avenue J, Brooklyn, and de the late Mr. Phillips, was married In to Aurin Moody Chase Jr., son of Colonel Aurin M. Chase of Hamilton, N. Y., yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Nativity, Farragut Road and Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, by the Rev. Thomas L. Settle.

Few changes were shown in the foreign exchange market yesterday where trading was small and listless. The French franc rose 1/2 point to 3.395-16 cents, but the discount on ninety-day franc futures increased a point to 10 points.

The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System announced today the reappointment of Owen D. Young as a class C director. of the Federal - Reserve Bank of New York for a three-year term ending on Dec. 31, 1940, and the redesignation of Mr. Young as deputy chairman of the New York bank for one year.

The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, the Republic Steel Corporation and the National Tube Company have received an order for 24,000 tons of 12 3/4-inch pipe for construction of an oil pipe line in Colombia.

The government will most likely be called in to arbitrate the deadlock that has resulted from the two conflicting votes of the Seine Department and City of Paris Councils regarding the pay adjustment to be granted to public utilities employes.

Although the holiday spirit restricted business in the stock markets here today, the tendency was firm and most sections advanced. Gilt-edged issues went forward, while among foreign bonds Far Eastern issues improved.
Twelve horses were named today to start in the $5,000 New Year's Handicap at Santa Anita tomorrow, but the name of Seabiscuit was not among them.

A series of events marked Palm Beach's farewell to 1937 tonight. The largest and most brilliant was the dinner dance with which the Everglades Club began its social season. More than 500 members and their guests attended.

Following is a summary, prepared by Hal H. Smith of The New York Times Washington Bureau, of the leading events related to the Federal Government or its activities since the adjournment of the regular seasion of Congress on Aug. 21:

A holiday hockey double-header this afternoon will bring together the New York Rovers and the Baltimore Orioles in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden, starting at 3:15 o'clock. The preliminary contest, to begin at 1:30, will have the Westchester Rangers crossing sticks

Orders were issued today by the Federal Trade Commission directing the National Federation of Builders Supply Associations, its affiliated trade associations and their dealer members and officers, to cease and desist from alleged unlawful practices by which the commission said they had suppressed competition in the sales of building materials and supplies to increase costs to consumers.

A vast market for electrical equipment exists on American farms at present and will provide an outlet for $5,000,000,000 worth of electrical goods in the near future, Ralph C. Cameron, sales manager of household appliances for Kelvinator division of the Nash-Kelvinator Corporation, declared yesterday.

Prestdent Roosevelt tonight lowered the price the Treasury will pay for newly mined domestic silver from 77.57 cents to 64.64 cents an ounce, thus defying the congressional silver group which had demanded maintenance of the higher price.

Among social events of New Year's Eve in this city was the debut of Miss Elizabeth Simpson Kampmann, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Robert Simpson Kampmann, who was introduced at a dinner dance given by her uncle.
The Mercury Theatre is holding an opening this evening, adding to its repertory a revival of Thomas Dekker's "The Shoemaker's Holiday."

FROM the point of view of foreign affairs, the past year was characterized by a number of important developments. Some of these represented a further deterioration of those basic international relationships which underlie the preservation of world peace, while others pointed in the direction of renewed hope for an improvement in the relations among nations. Throughout the year,

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade-State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:
The Federal Power Commission's. reports showed today that production of electric power in the United States was likely to establish a new high annual total in 1937, despite a recession in business.

Rallying strongly in the last four minutes of play, City College's varsity basketball team came from behind at the C. C. N. Y. gymnasium last night to close out the old year with a hard-earned 37-31 victory over a surprisingly strong Wayne University five from Detroit. The Tartars held the Lavender to a 29-27 score in Detroit,last Winter in the first meeting between the two schools, but after C. C. N. Y's

The lowest death rate among mothers in childbirth and among babies under 1 year old, as well as the lowest mortality from typhoid fever and tuberculosis in the history of New York City since records have been kept were achieved during 1937, according to the annual report made yesterday to Mayor La Guardia by Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner.

Night clubs were jammed, to capacity last night, the turnout of New Year's Eve celebrators exceeding the hopes of proprietors. A majority of places had not a single table left after the crowds arrived at about 11:30 P. M. from the theatres and motion picture houses.

The need for State legislation creating local housing authorities under the provisions of the WagnerSteagall act is urged upon the Gov- a ernors of nineteen States in a New Year's letter from Helen Alfred, secretary and executive director of the National Public Housing Conference.

With Cardinal Hayes presiding, New Year's Eve services at St. Patrick's Cathedral last night were attended by more than 3,500 worshipers. Throngs of other persons also participated in similar services at many other Roman Catholic churches and at "watch hour"
Sweeping denials that E. F. Hutton Co. had had "any knowledge or information of any manipulative operation in Auburn stock" were made yesterday by Gerald M. Loeb, a partner.

Which of the new books will you want to read now? Which can wait? As a guide in helping you choose the books for your immediate reading list, you, too, will prefer-as do book lovers throughout the country-the informed and dispassionate reviews in The New York Times Book Review. Among the books reviewed next Sunday:
MEN OF POWER, by Fred Eastman. (Cokesbury, $1.50.) Short biographies of Jefferson, Dickens, Pasteur and Matthew Arnold.

A good deal of holiday optimism is needed to find much encouragement in the fact that down to Dec. 27, 1937, only 922 persons had been killed in motor accidents in New York City. This is thirty-six more deaths than the number due to the same cause during the same period last year.

The New York Rangers conquered the sturdy Bruins of Boston in a sizzling National Hockey League battle at Madison Square Garden last night. The speedy blue-jerseyed skaters built up a 3to-O lead in the first period, but so bitter was the Bruins' counter-attack in the next two sessions that the New Yorkers had all they could do to record a 5-to-3 triumph.

In the final session of the year, a pre-holiday atmosphere prevailed in virtually all of the security and commodity markets. Price movements yesterday were generally without significance, and the volume of business done was small. The stock market held slightly lower throughout the day and closed steady.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Ordinarily I am unmoved to reply to, or comment on, statements and speeches of those officials of the Federal Government whose primary duty seems to be to issue statements and make speeches calculated to arouse sympathy for the policies of the Administration.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today overruled a motion by a protective committee for holders of bonds of the Rock Island, Arkansas Louisiana and Lousiana Arkansas Railroad Companies for a separate consideration by the commission of the reorganization of the Rock Island, Arkansas Louisiana Railroad Company from the other debtors in the pending reorganization proceedings.

The State Banking Department has issued an authorization certificate for the Bankers Commercial Corporation, 270 Madison Avenue, New York City, the department's weekly bulletin announced today. The firm's capital was $3,197,500.

Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman of the Maritime Commission, who will relinquish that post soon to become Ambassador to Great Britain, will return here early next week from a Florida vacation and then leave for a hasty inspection trip to the West Coast.

Investors were active yesterday in the purchase of houses in Manhattan and the Bronx. The North River Savings Bank sold to an investor the five-story apartment house for thirteen families at 18 East 116th Street.

52d St, 62-4 W; A. Ostrovsky to Radio Center, Inc, 64 W 52d St; mtg $111,500, deed dated April 25, 1933. Same property; Radio Center, Inc, Lotty R. Cantor, president, to Manboro Real Estate, Inc, 64 W 52d St; mtg $111.500.
Judge Marcus A. Kavanagh, formerly of Des Moines and Chicago, died of a heart ailment here today at the age of 78. He was a noted jurist and recognized authority on criminology.

John P. Leo, secretary of the New York Athletic Club, denied yesterday that Cadwallader Kelsey of 51 East Sixty-seventh Street was a member of or connected with that club as Kelsey was alleged to have told Assistant District Attorney Lawrence J. McManus last Dec. 6
Miss Grayce Beverly Foster, daughter of Mrs. Walter S. Foster, was married to Douglas Avann of Greenwhich tonight in the Methodist Church at Rye, N. Y. The Rev.

Stocky Edward P. Wells, latest sensation of the crack Dartmouth College ski team, continued his remarkable achievements in the seventeenth annual Lake PIacid Club Sno Birds' college week invitation tournament today as the Indians from Hanover added to their imposing lead in competition for the team honors and the President Harding trophy.

The city's plan to provide cheaper milk to the millions of local consumers received considerable impetus yesterday afternoon when the Market Department announced that a large number of retail grocery stores throughout the city had indicated their intention of selling bottled Grade B milk of some independent companies at 10 cents a quart, beginning Monday morning.

An unofficial check of alien land acquisitions this year shows that sixty-seven applications for permission to purchase property were made by Americans. Authorities did not disclose whether any of the applications were rejected.

The Mountain States Power Company, a subsidiary of the Standard Gas and Electric Company, yesterday filed a petition for reorganization in the United States District Court in Wilmington, Del., under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act, setting forth that it is unable to meet obligations which mature today.

The munitions "boom" that helped make last New Year prosperous for Japan has become a full war boom, and the nation, exalted by a succession of victories in China and happy with prosperity, greeted the holiday with hectic exuberance.

Four employes of the Illinois Central Railroad, who have a combined record of 201 years of service, wilt retire today. They are J. F. Porterfield, general superintendent of transportation, and F. T. Wilbur.
Bobby Riggs of Chicago stroker his way to possession of the silver Sugar Bowl tennis trophy today with a straight-set victory over Joe Hunt of San Francisco, 8-6, 6-1, 6-2.

At a time fixed at one-half a second after midnight today a 6 pound 10 ounce boy was born at Mary Immaculate Hospital, Jamaica, to Mrs. Margaret St. Clair of 85-17 150th Street, Jamaica. The time of the birth was checked with Western Union for accuracy, according to hospital officials.

Dr. Carl Wittke, historian, dean of Oberlin College, assailed the educational authorities of some States today as near-racketeers for their success in forcing Legislatures to "pile up requirements for teacher training."

The long discussion over the advisability of "staggering" apartment leases, so as to avoid the hectic rush and inconveniences incident to the traditional Fall moving day on Oct. 1, appears likely to come to a head next season.

As a result of an anonymous letter threatening destruction of the Japanese freighter Nagara Maru, police and custom guards maintained a close watch yesterday over the freighter and escorted her through the harbor to her pier in Brooklyn.

Any impression that his anti-monopoly campaign was directed against business in general or "big business" in its entirety was challenged by President Roosevelt at his press conference today with a "parable." Objects of the Administration's attack, he implied, were the counterparts of those whom Theodore Roosevelt termed "malefactors of great wealth."
An original map of the Americas made more than three centuries ago was presented to the Department of Geography and History by Julio Gonzalez, secretary to El Salvador's consul general in Hamburg.

Edward Lathrop Ballard, chairman of the executive committee of the Merchants Fire Assurance Corporation of New York and for many years a trustee of the present Riverside Baptist Church, died here yesterday after a long illness. He was 67 years old.

Mrs. Mary. Stamps Bateson Gaillard, wife of William E. G. Gaillard, prominent in the industrial real estate business, died yesterday of pneumonia at her home, 325 East Seventy-ninth Street, at the ago of 55.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "While the volume of business has let down in wool at the year-end, prices are being maintained at the basis established a week ago, with some demand continuing, especially in fine short wools and noils.

Mrs. Janet Grace, wife of Joseph P. Grace of Tullaron, Manhasset, L. I., and New York, died early today at their Winter home here. In ill health for several months, she had come to Aiken only a few weeks

The Rev. Jaime Castilleo, former Professor of Psychology at Fordham University, died on Wednesday night as the result of injuries he received in an automobile accident while on the way from Tampico to Mexico City, according to word received here last night. He was 40 years old.

Daily figures on the number of vehicles which have used the new Lincoln Tunnel between New York and Weehawken, N. J., since it was opened to traffic at 4 A. M. on Dec. 22 were made public yesterday by officials at the Jersey end of the tunnel. The totals follow:
Steadiness characterized trading through yesterday's short session on the Cotton Exchange here and the list ended with a loss of one to a gain of three points.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Shick gave a dinner tonight at their home here at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Elizabeth Shick, to Walter John Bragdon Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bragdon of Pittsburgh.

Canada's budget would have been balanced this year if drought had not struck the prairies, decreasing Canada's agricultural wealth by millions of dollars, Charles Dunning, Finance Minister, said today in his annual economic survey.

General Jan I Christian Smuts in a world broadcast tonight over the League of Nations wireless, as one of the League's founders, declared it "still remains a formidable army able to do battle against militarism and reaction."

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Dec. 29: CAPTAINS Coman, V. K, Newport, R. I., to command Destroyer Squadron 12. Stevens, L. M., Baldwin, L. I., N. Y., to command the Vincennes.
Following is the text of President Roosevelt's proclamation setting a new price for newly mined domestic silver:

Pieces of ancient Central American art, described as "priceless and irreplaceable," were stolen from Harvard University's Peabody Museum this afternoon by a thief who pried open two table show cases, ignoring a burglar alarm which rang as he. worked.

Nathan Straus, Federal Housing Administrator, modified today his previous warning that New Jersey must enact enabling laws "Immediately" so municipalities might participate in the low-cost housing and slum clearance program.
The New Year's Eve performance of Strauss's "Der Rosenkavalier" at the Metropolitan Opera House was attended by an audience which filled every available space in the auditorium.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William I. Frothingham of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Marvin Frothingham, to Henry G. Bradlee Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bradlee of Brookline, Mass.

Realty men and builders will open their offices tomorrow, morning to begin a new year of work under conditions differing in many ways from those which prevailed in their field twelve months ago. New legislation now in force will have a far-reaching effect on real estate trends both in New York and in the nation as a whole.

A NEW YEAR is here. Into it is stepping a fresh young personality, the jeune fille of 1938. She's a well poised individual, knowing full well what she wants. She has ideas of her own in regard to dress-and about life as well.

California defeated Alabama, 13 to 0, before 90,000 spectators in the annual Rose Bowl football game at Pasadena, Calif., yesterday. Vic Bottari made both touchdowns, the first on a 3-yard sprint around right end in the second quarter and the other on a 5-yard gain produced by the-same play in the third period.

So the new jury division of the county clerk's office might continue the work formerly done by the Commissioner of Jurors without interruption, Archibald R. Watson, the new New York County Clerk, swore in yesterday afternoon three officials who are to have charge of the work.

Transfer of the distribution of relief milk at 8 cents a quart from city agencies to independent grocery stores is being urged on the city authorities by grocers with stores in the sections where the milk is sold to the needy, it was learned yesterday.

Gotham's earliest and surest harbinger of Spring, long before groundhogs and their shadows, long before crocuses point their buds up through the snow, long before the robins chirp their tweet tweets, is the National Motor Boat Show.

While the optimistic views expressed early in 1937 by many leaders in the National Lumber Manufacturers Association for a greatly increased demand to care for the expected building activity did not fully materialize, Wilson Compton, executive manager, reports that the year closed with a total lumber consumption of practically twenty-four billion feet as compared with twenty-three billion feet for 1936.

THE opening of the seventyeighth session of Congress, with President Roosevelt de livering his message in person, will be broadcast coast-to-coast tomorrow beginning at 1 P. M. It is expected that Mr. Roosevelt will go on the air at 1:30 o'clock and speak for half an hour. New York outlets will be WEAF, WJZ, WABC, WOR and WQXR.

Thomas E. Le Sueur, rather of Joan Crawford, motion picture actress, died at his home here today of a cerebral hemorrhage on the eve of his seventy-first birthday. He had worked here as a plasterer for nearly thirty years.

FIFTEEN years ago Alice Keating Cheney and her husband, the late Bushnell Cheney, organized the Jitney Players, and in celebration of this fifteenth anniversary,all Jitney Players, past and present, who now number more than two hundred, will give a reunion party this evening at its rehearsal headquarters.
The Berkshires' gayest holiday season in many years will end tomorrow with several entertainments. Today Mrs. George K. Livermore had a luncheon party of 100 at Three Acres, Lenox.

Strengthening of the rank and file forces in the A. F. of L. and the C. I. O. was advocated yesterday by Charles J. Hendley, president of the Teachers Union, as the most effective means of restoring unity in labor's ranks.

At the end of the third quarter of the budget year the government finds itself in the happy position of having spent no more than it anticipated last April and with revenue coming in better than expected.

The second annual Colonial Ball under the auspices of the Sons of the American Revolution, the Continental Guard of the Empire State Society of that organization and the junior members of the D. A. R. will take place on the night of Jan. 22 at the Pierre.

Basketball will swing back to a faster stride this week after a lull during the Christmas vacation and in another week should be booming along on high once more. Two double-headers at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday and Saturday will be the high spots.

WITH more than $5,000,000 worth of United States Government and foreign orders on its books, the Northrop division of the Douglas Aircraft Corporation of Santa Monica, Calif., last week was into the task of completing forty-five A-17-A attack planes. By next Spring,

PRINTS, even exclusive of contemporary work, are now to be seen in considerable abundance about town. Two exhibitions that have most recently become current are those containing Italian Renaissance prints and illustrated books at the Metropolitan (through Feb. 27) and fifteenth century woodcuts, together with miniatures,

BY ACT of Congress 17,000,000 cubic feet of coveted helium are released for world flight today. Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes is reported to be in a receptive mood for orders from foreign powers for the full amount should favorable conditions prevail for its use in lighter-thanair transport.

PARIS.-There are at present 370,000 troops on French soil, exclusive of the colonies, according to the figure given to the Chamber of Deputies by Minister of War Edouard Daladier, who pointed out that on the northeast these soldiers are faced by 1,000,000 Germans and on the southeast by 300,000 Italians.

Conceding that "there is no perfect and complete program for ure bringing about peace in the world at the present moment," Eleanor Roosevelt, in a new book to be released tomorrow, suggests creation of a revamped League of Nations to exert a strict economic boycott and, if this fails, to send a sort of international "police force" against aggressor nations.

Mrs. Payne Whitney's Jungle King topped the list of steeplechase horses for 1937 in the matter of money earned, according to figures announced by the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association. Jungle King won $12,595, only $20 more than Yemasee, owned by Thomas Hitchcock
Insurgent Spain today celebrated the recapture of Teruel, which Insurgent leaders hailed as "one of the most decisive defeats" Inflicted on the government in the 17-months-old civil war.

WHENEVER the film industry is placed upon the pan for its alleged desecration of a highly potential art form, its critics invariably point with scorn at the industry's deliberate mass output of "program pictures," more familiarly known as "B's.' Sincereky,

The decline in THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity has once more been halted. Two gains in its components more than offset four losses for the week ended Dec. 25. It now stands at 84.7, compared with 84.6 for the previous week and 107.1 for the corresponding week a year ago.
The Mexico City observatory reported that six light earthquakes were registered today, most of them coming in the early hours while the city still was celebrating the New Year.

IN the art of the motion picture there is always room at the bottom. That is why it is comparatively simple to pick the year's Best Films, and why practically no one but ourself would attempt to choose, from among the likelier candidates for oblivion, those few choice specimens which,

Playing in Class C of the Charlton L. Becker Golf Trophy tournament, a tin whistle event, T. R. pudel of New York carded a low net 64 for the memorial prize today. Rudel played with J. C. Musser of Akron, Ohio- Howard Phillips of Pinehurst and J. Pryor Williamson of Wilkes Barre.

The rate of commission established by the Long Island Real Estate Board is now 5 per cent on the first $50,000 of the consideration and 21/2 per cent thereafter on the sale of improved property in the First, Second and Fourth Wards of Queens.

The Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association has reported new high records in deposits, total resources and capital funds at the close of 1937, with deposits standing at $1,357,000,000, an increase of $58,402,000 over the record at the close of 1936.

Syracuse University won its fifth straight basketball game tonight, 40 to 32, but only- after a battling Princeton quintet had thrown a real scare into the home camp. Trailing, 21 to 11, at half time, the Tigers came back with a rush that cut the Syracuse lead to 5 points in rough play that resulted in a pair of Orangemen and one Princetonian leaving the contest via the personal foul route.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Richard Drysdale MacLaren of 1,471 East Eighteenth street, Brooklyn, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Geraldine Avis MacLaren, to John Edward Shea Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John Edward Shea, also of Brooklyn.

Federal and State taxes paid by the distilled spirits industry this year will amount to more than $1,000,000,000, with local governments collecting additional taxes of more than $100,000,000, James B. Melick, vice president of SeagramDistillers Corporation, said last week.

Mr. and Mrs. William F. Straukamp of 1,317 Carroll Street, Brooklyn, gave a tea dance yesterday in the Embasy Suite of the Ambassador for- their daughter, Miss Marie Straukamp, who made her debut at the Brooklyn debutante ball on Thanksgiving Eve.

Ravel Memorial Concert, by the Music Hall of the Air Symphony Orchestra under the direction of Erno Rapee; Carlos Salzedo, harpist; Horace Britt, 'cellist, and Georges Barrere, flautist, are the soloists: WJZ, 12:30-1:30 P. M.
Walter E. Turner, who served five terms as Assemblyman from Cumberland County, died at his home today after a long illness at the age of 70.

President Roosevelt devoted much of his time today to the preparation of the message he will read before a joint session of Senate and House Monday afternoon at 1:30, soon after the reassembling of Congress in regular session.

The Neediest Cases Fund for 1937 on the final Sunday of the appeal reached a grand total of $293,569.65 today. The receipt of seventyseven contributions yesterday, aggregating $3,172.66, increased the total for this twenty-sixth annual appeal to that amount.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There are a few matters very pertinent to the Tennessee Valley Authority which may well be added to the article by Arthur Krock in THE TIMES of Dec. 24. The Tennessee Valley Authority Act (H. R. 508i) as presented to the House of Representatives was largely the work
ON the basis of announcements available from many of the world's capitals, notably London and Paris, 1938 seems destined to be the most prolific philatelic calendar period in a decade.
AKE GEORGE.-The first snow Train to Lake George resort will leave Grand Central Station at 11:50 P. M., Jan. 7, arriving at Lake George next morning at 7 o'clock.

As part of the national sesquicentennial program for the celebration of the 150th birthday of the Constitution'of the United States, a series of lectures will be offered at City College in the next few months. by outstanding scholars and authorities, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president.

The engagement of Miss Lucille Finlay Cloud, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Marts Cloud of this place, to John MacDonald Manning, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Tiers Manning, also of Mount Vernon, has been announced by her parents.

HANOVER, N. H.-The recent formation of the Dartmouth Open Slope Region, comprising towns and Winter resorts within twenty-five miles of Dartmouth College, adds a new and large area to New England's facilities for organized skiing.

The annual Madison House ball will take place this year on March 26 in the grand ballroom of the Plaza. A dance committee, composed of members of the junior board, will meet this afternoon at the same hotel to discuss plans for the event.
TO solve one of the most perplexing problems of photography, that of determining correct exposure, many amateurs are now working out intensive practice courses with their exposure meters.

LONDON.-With much of its great income, from endowments, reduced by the passage of the Tithe Act, the Church of England, s seeking to economize by requiring young ministers to remain unmarried for five years or more after they are ordained.
Miss Catherine E. Shanahan, for eight years field secretary of the New York League of Women Voters, has been made municipal research assistant in the New York State Civil Service Department.

The text of John D. Biggers's letter to President Roosevelt telling of the result of the unemployment census was as follows: As administrator of the census of partial employment, unemployment and occupations, I respectfully submit this preliminary report on unemployment as revealed by the voluntary unemployment registration, Nov. 16 to 20, 1937,

An estimated million persons cheered the annual floral display of the Tournament of Roses parade today. The neighboring city of Burbank won the sweepstakes prize in the parade on the 1938 theme of "Playland Fantasies."

As Mayor Joseph F. Loehr, Democrat, started his fourth two-year term in Yonkers today the Republicans strengthened their hold upon the Common Council and the deadlock between the Mayor and the Council over the tentative 1938 gross budget of $16,842,538 continued.

More than thirty civic and taxpayer groups in the Bronx which recently formed an organization known as the Bronx Joint Committee for the purpose of securing immediate action on the easterly approach to the Triborough Bridge,

Because undergraduates at-New York University's School of Commerce,,Accounts and Finance, at Washington Square East, complained of "severe" cuts in their allotted spending money and the high price of bids to the school's senior prom, the co-chairmen of the affair announced yesterday that the bids, priced at $10.50,

A gift of money from an anonymous member of the recently organized Friends of Barnard has made it possible for the fine arts department of Barnard College to extend its museum trips to include week-ends in Boston, Philadelphia and Washington. On these trips,

Indoor gardeners are finding pleasure in planting dish gardens of South African succulents. Although these plants are not cacti, their homes in South Africa are much like the dry and desert abodes of our Amrican cactus group. Like the cacti, they store up moisture to carry them through a long period of drought.

To further instruction and research in the field of air-conditioning, Cornell University will install a new heattransfer laboratory in the Sibley School of Mechanical Engineering. Within the last few years the.offerings in this field have been considerably expanded with the aid of apparatus supplied by Willis H, Carrier, '01, chairman of the Carrier Corporation, and others.

Evidence of the increasing demand and widening tastes of the British reading public was recorded today in an annual analysis of the publishing and bookselling trades, which showed that an all-time high was reached in 1937 with the publication of 71,286 books, an increase of 714 over 1936.
TALE OF BALI. By Vicki Baum. New York: Doubleday. Doran Co. $2.75. NONE of Vicki Baum's previous novels could have prepared one for the departure which "Tale of Bali" represents.

Thomas E. Dewey moved yesterday into the office of the District Attorney of New York County, and found that the chair behind the desk at which Tammany nominees have sat for twenty years was a little too low for his stature.

Secretary of Commerce Daniel C. Roper has not been advised of any "general program by any unit of society throughout the country to conduct a boycott against Japanese goods." "My idea is to develop trade relations and maintain them," he asserted.

Two hundred were present for the traditional annual reception and flagraising marking the formal opening of the season by the Biscayne Bay Yacht Club at the clubhouse in Coconut Grove, Miami, this afternoon.

In contrast to the pageants and court scenes depicted at the Russian Students Ball in past seasons, settings of an old-fashioned Russian village fair have been devised for this year's ball, which will take place on Jan. 14 at the Plaza.
An alert and scrappy West Virginia football team capitalized a secondperiod break today to defeat the Red Raiders of Texas Tech, 7 to 6, in the Sun Bowl classic before 12,500 spectators.

NO part of New York's new Charter. which went into effect on Jan. 1, is more important than that which establishes the City Planning Commission. This commission will not be merely titular or ornamental, as commissions often are. but will be a department of the city Administration, with salaried personnel and chairman-a commission with real power and with permanence of tenure.

A couple of months ago, in discussing trout fishing, we "slipped off the fence" a moment to defend the fairness of the request submitted by several fly fishermen that a mile or so of certain streams be limited to members of the flythrowing fraternity.

The New Year began luckily for the Duke of Windsor, who after dining on New Year's Eve at a Monte Carlo sporting club with the Duchess and the Hon. Reginald Fellowes took a fling at baccarat and won in the neighborhood of 1,000 francs.

FROM a press in Printing House Square. Blackfriars, there issued 150 years ago, on Jan. 1, 1788, the first number of The Times or Daily Universal Register (published for three years running under the second name), which later, simply as The Times, was to become, and long to remain, one of the outstanding newspapers of the world, a masterpiece of journalism.

In the Hotel Pennsylvania Sunday, Jan. 16, will be held the forty first specialty show of the Pekingese Club of America. The exhibition will be open from 10 A. M. until 9 P. M. Herbert L. Mapes of Little Falls, N. J., will judge the show and will call his first class into ring at 11 o'clock.
