THE unexpected death of Miss Lilian Baylis has robbed London musical life of a great personality. It was Lilian Baylis who gave London opera as well as Shakespeare, and it is Lilian Baylis who leaves behind a tradition that has its roots deep in the affection of every Londoner. Oddly enough,
IN no other hobby, not even in stamp collecting, has the demand for instructive written material been so great as that at present observed in relation to photography.

Although control measures have been enforced in close successioneven involving a complete prohibition of the annual flood of New Year's cards in order to conserve wood pulp-Japan is rapidly losing the gold and foreign exchange resources without- which it cannotfight at maximum efficiency.
Of all the major nations the United States has perhaps the brightest and most cheerful tinge to its foreign relations as it gazes out on a troubled world at the beginning of another year.

Professor William P. Maddox of Princeton University will discuss the "Foundations of World Economic Order" on Wednesday at a luncheon conference the New Jersey League of Women Voters will hold at the Kresge Department Store in Newark. Mrs. Leonard H.

Encouraged by the reasoning that retailers have already discounted the current business recession to substantial extent by their liquidation of inventories and curtailment of purchases during the last three months, manufacturers and resident buyers here incline to the view that initial Spring buying activity may prove better than many anticipate-falling under last year to some extent, but comparing very favorably with the 1936 period.

Miss Clarabelle Quick, daughter of Captain and Mrs. Richard Quick of this city, was married to George Baer Connard, son of Mrs. Rolla S. Knapp of Easton, Pa., at noon today in Grace Episcopal Church by the Rev. Charles M. Tubbs.

The ability of the Democratic members of the City Council to elect Alderman John Cashmore of Brooklyn as vice president at the first meeting of the council. tomorrow became more uncertain last night when Councilman-elect William N. Conrad of Queens announced that he intended to nominate Alderman James A. Burke of that borough for the position.

SOME one is always busily "reviving the road" in this country. After loud and spectacular cries that New York is not America, the hero comes dashing in with a list of transconitinental bookings, and a storm of national applause shatters the ingrown circle of Broadway. Few ever pause long enough to take a good, long look at the theatres to be covered by the touring show. If they did.
Modernization of old-law tenements in compliance with the provisions of the Multiple Dwelling Law in many instances is proving profitable to owners, states Missac I Thompson, engineer and realty man.
Robert M. Hankinson, resident manager since 1930 of the Bretton Hall Hotel, 2,350 Broadway, died Friday at St. Elizabeth's Hospital, 689 Fort Washington- Avenue, of pneumonia. He was 53 years old.

Harold Preston, one of the leading members of the bar of Washington, died today at the Seattle General Hospital at the age of 79. He did not regain consciousness after he was stricken with apoplexy Thursday at his home, 712 Thirty-fifth Avenue.

Elliott Roosevelt, son of the Presdent, is to take up his new duties here tomorrow as president and general manager of Hearst Radio, Inc. of 20 East Fifty-seventh Street. As a result of his elevation to this position it is expected that he will move here from Fort Worth, Texas, next month.

A fast-skating squad of New Eng landers, the Boston Olympics, com pleted their sweep of Big Three circles tonight on the Hobey Baker ice by defeating Princeton, 3-2, in a thrilling, action-filled encounter The visitors recently defeated both Yale and Harvard.

The annual report of Sir Frederick Maze, Inspector General for Chinese Maritime Customs, for 1937 reveals an increase of approximately 18,000,000 Chinese dollars over 1936 collections, including import and export duties, the inter-port surtax, tonnage dues, flood relief and the revenue surtax.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial "Wages: The Next Step" you suggest that child labor be handled separately from a general wages and hours measure, and recommend for this purpose enactment of the Wheeler-Johnson bill.

FADE OUT. By Nao??i Jacob. 352 pp. New York: The Macmillan Company. $2.50. IF Naomi Jacob is not one of the most exciting of the minor English novelists, she is at least one of the most reliable and workmanlike.

The ladies' auxiliary of St. Joseph's Day Nursery will give a luncheon, followed by bridge, on Jan. 11 at the Biltmore. Proceeds of the event will go toward the maintenance of the nursery, which is one of the pioneers in the work of daytime care of children whose mothers are employed.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Elsa Voorhees, daughter of Mrs. John D. Jameson of this city and Sugar Hill, N. H., and of Professor J. Dayton Voorhees of Princeton, N. J., to Theodore Spaeth, Hauschka, son of Mrs . Carola Spaeth Hauschka of Princeton, and the late Hugo Hauschka of Vienna, Austria.

FOR its readers real service; for when, with the first page of "Ports of the Sun," you wonder whence comes this peculiarly easy charm, you can turn to the jacket and find out at once. Eleanor Early "knew the islands before the tourists discovered them."

HERE ARE MY LECTURES! By Stephen Leacock. 251 pp. New York: Dodd, Mead Co. $2. PROFESSOR LEACOCK should have retired these humorous lectures when he retired himself, for they were obviously written to be spoken,

Mrs. Carmen T. Calderon de Pinillos of 219 West Eighty-first Street, widow of Maximo de Pinillos, was married to Herbert Sherman Houston, also of this city, yesterday afternoon in the rectory of St. Joseph's Church on Waverly Place by the rector, Mgr. John J. Hickey.

LABORING under the impression that musical shows used to be more numerous, as well as better, this correspondent recently looked up the files for 1927-28. Holy smoke! what a season that was! There were twentythree song carousals that year, which in itself may not be remarkable.
WORK has begun by which 6,400 acres of St. Tammany Parish in Louisiana will be converted into a public playground, a wild-life refuge and game-propagation station.

A study of conditions in Chicago during the years 1935 and 1936 -by the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics showed that current living expenses of non-relief white families with incomes of less than $1,000 were greater than current net income in a majority of the families investigated.

STROUDSBURG, Pa.-A good fall of snow and continued cold weather has assured every one of plenty of Winter sports for the next week or two unless a midwinter thaw should come. Hotels throughout the Poconos are filled for the New Year's week-end parties. There are a number of college groups here.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y.-Tomorrow afternoon an invitation downhill and slalom race at Adirondack Loj, near this village, is expected to attract many of the hundreds of Winter visitors who are remaining at this resort through early January.

THE year 1937 brought little that affected the habits of the average players who form a vast majority of the millions who follow contract bridge. The laws and scoring remained unchanged both in rubber and in tournament or party bridge.

A six-story apartment and hotel building, with garage space below street level, is planned on the southwest corner of Concord Avenue and Craigie Street in Cambridge, Mass., according to Henry J. Moulton, head of the corporation sponsoring the enterprise.

An endowment fund to support the battle against tropical diseases carried on by the School of Tropical Medicine of the University of Puerto Ricounder the direction of Columbia University scientists was urged yesterday in the annual report of Dr. George W. Bachman, director of the school.

Today the Scviet Union embarks on a new FiveYear Plan-its third since Joseph Stalin launched his industrialization program in the Fall of 1928. Again, as in the two preceding plans, the Kremlin is ordering the wheels to turn faster and the men to produce greater quantities than ever before to meet the country's insatiable needs.

Trial of the litigation filed by eighteen Southeastern private utility corporations generating and distributing electricity in the Tennessee basin, to test the constitutionality of the New Deal's Tennessee Valley Authority program, will be resumed here on Monday morning before a three-judge Federal court after a recess since Dec. 22.

Mucho Gusto, the big bay veteran that Ramsey and Coppage bought back from Walter O'Hara for $6,500 before the opening of the Florida season, scored his second straight victory since the sale when he captured the $1,300 winner's share of the E. Phocian Howard Memorial

IN photography, since the advent of the miniature camera, the trend has been toward "angles." The extreme portability of the small camera and the quick changes of position that are possible in locations where the bulk of a view camera would be a deterrent have made this possible.

Plans for a Spring discussion meeting on health problems of the individual will be laid at a conference on Thursday of the department of health of the City Federation of Women's Clubs. Mrs. Jean E. Smalbach of Flushing, chairman of the department, will preside at the session at federation headquarters in the Hotel Astor.
Philadelphia's traditional New Year's day spectacle, the Mummers parade, was postponed today until next Saturday after a wait of nearly three hours for a morning drizzle to end.

WELL,.Mr. Tutt is not coming home, after all. Not this season, anyhow. It seemed that he was about to, because Owen Davis and Arthur Train had finished their play; and Walter Huston, who was to have starred in it, offered only minor objections.

Participating in a nation-wide celebration of the seventy-fifth anniversary of the Emancipation Proclamation, Negroes of New York City will hold a mass meeting at 3 o'clock this afternoon in the auditorium of St. Mark's Methodist Episcopal Church, Edgecombe Avenue at West 136th Street.
A new preparation for treating human, burns, said to have many advantages over preparations heretofore used, is revealed in a patent just granted to a BOston physician, Dr.

Leading families of this Berkshire city were represented in the congregation that filled the old First Congregational Church this morning at 7:30 o'clock for the 122d annual New Year sunrise prayer-meeting. Among them were the Colts, the Joneses, Hulls, Wilsons, Hibbards, Robbinses, Plunketts, Wests and Gamwells.

FURTWAENGLER has been much in evidence these past weeks and his presence here has given rise to a certain amount of talk regarding eventual changes and new "combinations" (as they say in European politics) in the Staatsoper's staff of conductors.

The New York City schools, during 1938, will work toward these objectives: 1. Further differentiation of the courses of study and educational treatment, better to meet the varying capabilities of the children.
The bankruptcy dockets for 1937 were closed in Federal Court with a total of 2,943 entries, or 452 more than were recorded in 1936 and 180 more than in 1935.
The Japanese-sponsored provisional government of North China today started the new year by appointing more than forty new officials, most of them previously obscure individuals.

Percapital costs of the operation and maintenance of general departments of the city governments of the ninety-four cities having a population of more than 100,000 rose from $47.78 in 1935 to $48.83 in 1936, the Bureau of the Census of the Commerce Department reported today.

Pan American Airways' Samoan Clipper, inaugurating commercial air service between New Zealand and the United States, arrived here at 2:30 P. M. [9:30 P. M., Eastern standard time] from Auckland, N. Z.

In a thrilling demonstration of aerial fireworks intermingled with powerful reverse plays and other tricks, the Santa Clara Broncos came out on top by 6 to 0 today in the Sugar Bowl gridiron duel with Louisiana State's Tigers before a crowd of 45,000.

Last week's announcement by General Motors that 30,000 employes would be laid off on Jan. 1 was scarcely needed to show the country the change in the outlook for business from as recently as six months ago.

Mr. and Mrs. John Motley Morehead of this place held a reception here today at their home. The hostess was assisted by Mrs. Livingston Platt, Mrs. Williamson Pell, Mrs. Sheldon Potter, Mrs. William S. Conroy, Mrs. George Hite, Mrs. Basil Harris, Mrs. William W. Peake and Mrs. H. F. G. Wev.

Plants that will grow well, and even thrive, in city apartments during the Winter have been assembled in one of the greenhouses at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Some plants, like begonias, camellias and geraniums, need a certain amount of moisture in the air, such as can be furnished by evaporating pans kept near or on radiators. Others do not need even this assistance.

Sharing honors with commercial farmers in .building New Jersey's reputation as -the "Garden State" are the amateur gardeners, who spend millions on -their hobby annually and form a growing group of clients for the all-embracing New Jersey Extension Service of Rutgers University.

Replying to an appeal from the director of a benevolent society, the Minister of Government has issued a circular to the prefects of all departments informing them that the sale of Irish sweepstake tickets is prohibited and instructing them to adopt measures necessary to enforce strictly Law No. 8126.

Gloria Hyman, 13 years old, of 2,187 Mapes Avenue, the Bronx, was crushed to death last night by a Tremont Avenue trolley before her mother's eyes. The child and her mother had just emerged from the Eighth Avenue subway at Tremont Avenue and the Grand Concourse. Gloria ran ahead,
The forthcoming Seattle Mayoralty election may be the political armageddon of the prolonged labor rivalry along the Pacific Coast between Dave Beck and Harry Bridges.

Mrs. George Edwin Steel of 390 West End Avenue has announced the engagement of her niece, Miss Elizabeth Pearsall Russell, to T. Scudder Winslow Jr., son of Mrs. Thomas Scudder Winslow of 901 Lexington Avenue and the late Dr. Winslow.

Omcials said tonight that the French Government had ordered a virtual embargo on armament shipments to Rumania and Yugoslavia, long France's allies, because of their growing friendship with Italy and Germany.

A steadily increasing interest in the Civilian Conservation Corps, reflected in a mounting pile of applications for admission, was reported today by W. Frank Persons, chief of the Labor Department's employment service.

The first hours of the new year saw a number of dangerous and stubborn fires in New York City. In the East New York section of Brooklyn a man and a woman died because they delayed their escape from a burning house long enough to put on shoes and coats.

At 12:01 yesterday morning, with whistles sounding the arrival of the new year, the Postal Telegraph Company closed its wires in the observation tower at the government quarantine station and turned off the lights.

THE Screen Actors Guild and the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences have finally reached a satisfactory compromise on the manner in which balloting will be conducted to determine the outstanding performance of the year.

The New Year glided in on ice and sleet and snow and although early indications were that these trappings would be retained, the Weather Bureau forecast fair weather with little change in temperature for today. A possibility of colder weather tonight was seen.

William H. Sandland, former Mayor of this city, died in his home this morning of a heart attack. He had been ill for more than a week. He was 69 years old. Mr. Sandland was a member of the State Republican Central Committee for eighteen years, a member of the Republican town committee for twenty years and had been serving as tax commissioner since 1931.

The board of directors of the Merchants Association of New York has authorized support of an amendment to the Multiple Dwelling Law which will permit the application of that part of the new building code providing for the construction of Class 2, fire protected dwellings.

The government of New York began operating yesterday under a new city charter. The 1,500 sections of the old charter formed a thick tome where one could wander for weeks without finding the answer he sought to his question. The new volume has 425 easily digested sections. In clear, concise language it defines the powers of city officials and city departments.
AUTOMOTIVE engineering will move forward on many fronts in the next twelve months. The direction of this technical effort will be conditioned by economic developments to a strong degree.

UNDER holiday influences, there were few features to report for retail trade in the week. Most centers indicated that volume was holding even with last year. The exceptions were where mention was made of the effect of increasing unemployment upon sales.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles Sewall Wing have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cornelia Wing, to John Barr Dolan, son of Associate Justice Arthur Walter Dolan of the Supreme Court and Mrs. Dolan of Boston. The announcement was made at a tea today at the Wing home here.

Mr. and Mrs. George Buckingham Clay of Glenside have announced the engagement of their daughter, Misa Madeline Frances Clay, to Leopold Wood Von Seldeneck, son of Baroness Leopold-A. Von Seldeneck of Elkins Park and of the late Baron Von Seldeneck.
Agriculture Department officials predicted today that the steady economic improvement which farmers have enjoyed for five years has little chance of continuing through 19S8.

A surplus and accumulated earnings from a fund contributed in 1911 for a new gymnasium at Rensselaer Polytechnic Instititute is being used today to construct at a cost of about $325,000 an addition that will increase the facilities for a wide range of sports and recreation by from 70 to 80 per cent, according to Professor Harry A. Van Velsor, head of the Department of Physical Education and Athletics.
The Department of Agriculture said today that a declining American taste for honey threatened the future productivity of the country's fields, gardens and orchards.

Mr. and Mrs. Eugene LIguri Mullaney of 135 East Sixty-sixth Street will give a reception this afternoon at their home for Miss Rita Roberurmuhlen and Robert William Lehrfeld, whose marriage will take place on Saturday in the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola.
Viscount and Viscountess Hailsham's family party for Christmas included Mrs. Quinton Hogg and Neil Hogg.
Albert Jefferson Mayell, a civil engineer who had been associated with the New York Board of Transportation for the last thirty-seven years, died suddenly here today of a heart attack at his home,

With production value more than $90,000,000 in advance of 1936, Canadian mining in 1937 established new records in many fields, according to a preliminary year-end summary compiled by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics.
Along with black for women, it is obviously going to be a great season for monopoly.

A throng of 2,500 persons attended yesterday morning the fiftyfifth annual solemn high mass "for the spiritual and temporal welfare" of the members of the Archdiocesan Union of Holy Name Societies in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

IN America, the musical theatre is either opera or musical comedy. Opera means only the Met; musical comedy is on its last lap. Vaudeville has died a t scurvy death; revue is alarmingly deteriorating, one revue a year. If you still have the desire to write for the musical theatre you must find a new form, one which will work in a new way and yet manage to offend nobody by its newness.

PROVISION for sidewalks along the highways in New York State, at such points as the Superintendent of Public Works deems necessary, seems likely to lead to increased safety for the pedestrian. It follows similar provision in Massachusetts, where some $8,000,000 has been appropriated for such footways.

ENGINEERS have cut shelves around the dizzying sides of "impassable" mountains and sliced through jungles as if they were pie in order to complete 1,200 miles of the projected 3,200mile stretch of the Pan-American Highway passing through Mexico and Central America to the Canal Zone. There are wide gaps,

T. J. Randolph Nicholas of Owings Mills, Md., Sheriff of Baltimore County, sportsman and business man, died today at University Hospital. Born fifty-three years ago on the estate at Owings Mills, occupied for nearly 200 years by the Nicholas family, he was graduated from Calvert Hall College.

Miss Jean Seagrove, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Kay Seagrove of- this place, was married this afternoon to Carl Nicholas Dunn, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Carl Nicholas Dunn of Wilmington, N. C., in the Reformed Church here by the Rev. John H. Powell Jr., the pastor.

The engagement of Miss Jane C. Mammel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin E. Mammel of this place, to Edward C. Mueller of Lockport, Ill., son of Mr. and Mrs. E. G. Mueller of Carlstadt, has been announced by her parents.

Bonds called last week for redemption before their maturity dates were in somewhat smaller volume than in the preceding period. Announcements principally were for parts of municipal and foreign issues and redemption dates in most instances were for future
Beethoven's second symphony was the chief number of last night's popular concert given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under John Barbirolli in Carnegie Hall.

Faced with a reluctance on the part of some relief recipients to apply for benefits under the State Unemployment Insurance Law because the amounts due them in unemployment insurance 'are less than they now receive in home relief,

Mr. and Mrs. Walter 0. Hellwig of Elmhurst, Queens, and Lake Mohawk, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Muriel Kingdon Hellwig, to Dr. George William Herlitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Herlitz of Corona, Queens.

GERMANY'S persistent demand for colonies is being advanced with all kinds of propagandistic methods. Nazi officials frequently make speeches voicing the claims of the Reich; colonial exhibitions recall memories of the days when Togoland, the Cameroons, Southwest Africa and Tanganyika were German possessions.

Mrs. Elizabeth N. Hotch kiss announced at a party which she gave at her home here this afternoon the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Bassett Keyes, to Walter Dimont Rector, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dimont M. Rector of Delanson, N. Y.

Retail trade was stimulated in some sections last week by drastic price reductions as merchants moved to reduce inventories, but in other districts sales were either equal to or below the levels of the final week of 1936. A few instances were reported where the drive to cut stocks had carried so far that store assortments were thinned out and were inadequate to meet public demand.

The black and white ball was held tonight at the Bellevue-Stratford for the benefit of Ward B of the University Hospital. Mrs. George Reath of Whitemarsh was chairman of the committee managing the event.

In a slightly revamped program for Girl Scouts which will be under consideration at the national field staff conference to open on Tuesday at headquarters, 14 West Fortyninth Street, cognizance will be taken of more mature interests which are making an appeal to the girls of senior scouting age-14 to 17 years. Mrs. Paul Rittenhouse.

THE Duke of Windsor is not mentioned in this little fable for adults, except in the author's dedication. Instead Mr. Gibbs starts out with a time-honored sentence: "Once upon a time there was a Young Prince and his people loved him."

An annual problem in many homes is how to keep alive the. plants received as holiday gifts. Often such specimens are not ideal house plants, but correct care will help to maintain any of them in good condition for a fairly long period.
Twenty thousand Moslems prayed today in the mosque of El-Azhar for repose of the soul of Sheikh Farhan es' Saadi, aged Arab leader who was hanged in Palestine in the British drive against terrorists.
THE romantic world of films grows narrower daily. Scenarists no longer excite the imagination by bringing klieg lights to the Congo, the Amazon fo and the hills of Tibet.
John D. Biggers, administrator of the national unemployment census, said in reporting to President Roosevelt that the unemployed "may be divided into two classes."

The slippery condition of highways today curtailed the number of guests at the New Year's receptions, dinners and dances in the North and South Shore society colonies. Invitations to the party which Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. F. McCann had planned to give in the playhouse of their estate, Sunken Orchard, at Oyster Bay, had been recalled late in the week because of the illness of Mrs. McCann in New York.

IN one of his chapters in this book Professor Brownell speaks of the dispersive, pluralistic quality of modern life, of "the multiplicity of reference points"--in short, of the fact that our existences now have not one center but many unrelated centers. Each of us tends.

RADIO a national pastime, devoted to entertainment, current events and education, is divided into such a variety of clasifications that it is more difficult to put a finger on what might be called the ten outstanding broadcasts of the year

NEW YORK CITY will launch tomorrow a new attack on its ever-present traffic problem, this time aimed at the congestion caused by cars parked along the curbs. In ten east-west streets, between Seventeenth and Fifty-fourth, and Third and Ninth Avenues, parking will be entirely prohibited. In addition,

For the second straight year Harry Cooper, English- born golfer, has been named No. 1 player on the 1937 All-American professional squad selected by. Harry Guldahl, national open titleholder, and announced yesterday. In 1936 when Tony Manero was open. champion he also selected Cooper as the top man.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Eleanor Cameron, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm John Cameron of Westerleigh, S. I., to Albert Edwards Case Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert E. Case of Westfield, N. J.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Phyllis Dougherty, daughter of Mrs. Alvin L. Powell of Glen Ridge and of Clarence V. Dougherty of Ridgewood, formerly of Newark, to Donald D. Streit, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Streit of East Orange.

SEVERAL years ago Mrs. Wilder wrote her first story about an extraordinarily lifelike family of five; father, mother and three children-Laura, the irrepressible middle child; Mary, the quieter older sister, and Carrie, the baby.

Two irrepressible Rice Institute sophomores, Ernie Lain and Olie Cordill, unfolded all their cunning to crush Whizzer White and his hitherto unbeaten Colorado mates, 28-14, before 37,000 Cotton Bowl fans today.

For the first time since 1932 the national junior indoor tennis title went to a New York City boy, when Joseph Fishbach of St. John's University yesterday captured the honors in the final at the Seventh Regiment Armory courts.

A manuscript written and signed by the late Laura Bridgman, blind deaf mute, has been received as a New Year's gift by the American Foundation for the Blind, it was announced yesterday. The gift came from Stetson K. Ryan of Hartford, Conn., a trustee of the foundation, who found the manuscript in a secondhand book shop.

More and better training for unemployed young people between the ages of 17 and 21, in vocational high schools, junior colleges and CCC camps, will be a major educational advance in 1938, according. to many of the school and college authorities who have prepared New Year forecasts for THE TIMES.

Japan's basic peace terms are believed to have been confidentially communicated to Dr. Oskar Trautmann, the German Ambassador to China, some days ago. Though drastic, they are less severe than expected, considering the magnitude of the, war and the completeness of General Chiang Kai-shek's military defeat.

A classified ad by President Roosevelt, if he used it to get administration aides, might read like this: Wanted-Several men, or women, with knowledge of diplomacy, labor conditions, transportation or finance willing to work for $8,000 to $17,500 a year.

Major Charles Spencer Hart, Grand Exalted Ruler of the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks, made public yesterday a letter from Gbvernor Lehman, congratulating the organization on its traffic safety program.

THE most significant phe nomenon of 1937 has been not so much the launching of several independent companies but, in the light of experience, -their survival. In order of their initial issues, these are: The Friends of Recorded Music, Musicraft, Gamut and Timely; all devoted to tapping resources untouched by the commercial companies, and likely to remain so.

The Penn A. C. five defeated the Crescent A. C. of Brooklyn in the second extra period today, 35-34, before a holiday crowd of more than 1,500. The victory enabled the Philadelphia clubmen to widen their lead in the Eastern Athletic League race.

The sixteenth annual concert of the Junior League Glee Club, in conjunction with the Yale Glee Club, will take place on Feb. 4 at the league clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street. A private performance of the concert program will be given on Jan. 20

IT is very refreshing to read the first American biography of Claude Achille Debussy. The book is refreshing because of its new approach to the subject, the excellence of its arrangement and the extent of its information, its good writing and sensitive and balanced judgments.

The University of Michigan basketball team broke Toledo's five-game winning streak with a 50-to-38 victory tonight before an overflow crowd of 6,000 fans, largest crowd ever to witness a basketball game in Toledo.
There is still treasure on the Spanish main. This conviction was expressed yesterday by Capt. John D. Craig, deep sea Photographer and co-inventor of the Craig-Nohl diving suit,

FOR the Boy Scouts, as for so many other organizations and individuals, the beginning of a new year is budget-planning time. Sources of income are estimated and balanced against coming expenditures for individual and group scouting activities.

WITH perhaps no other period in European history offering so much drama, not to say melodrama, as the decades between the accession of Henry VIII to the English throne in 1509 and the death of Elizabeth in 1603, it is no wonder that the sixteenth century is irresistibly attractive to historians and biographers.

ALMANAC FOR NEW YORKERS, 1938. Compiled by the workers of the Federal Writers' Project of the Works Progress Administration, New York City. Sponsored by the Guilds' Committee for Federal Writers' Publications. Illustrated. 118 pp. New York: Modern Age Books, Inc. 25 Cents.

THE 19-year American pianist, Ezra Rachlin of Los Angeles, now on his first European tour, created a veritable sensation on his recent appearance at the Milan Conservatory. Local connoisseurs proclaimed him a virtuoso, although the very perfection of his mechanism became at times a blemish when it detracted from the depth or subtlety of his interpretations.

More than 300 photographs by amateur and professional photographers from many parts of the country will go on exhibition tomorrow in the gallery at the offices of Carl Zeiss, Inc., 485 Fifth Avenue, for the fourth annual Zeiss ikon photographic exhibition.

Reinforcement of the pending drive of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. 0. affiliate, for recognition as sole collective bargaining agent for the city's Independent Subway System will be one of the first official concerns of City Councilman Michael J. Quill, international head of the union.

Thomas E. Dewey starts tomorrow his first week as District Attorney of New York County. He will carry into his new office the energy and capacity for swift action which has made his career as special prosecutor so spectacular. But his field will be much larger and more complex.

The revival of road business in apparel lines is hailed by local manufacturers as one of the surprise developments of the last year. This is attributed to the growing volume of retail women's wear sales falling to smaller specialty shops in communities of all sizes.

Mr. and Mrs. Caleb Sipple Layton of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Lee Layton, to William Barnes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thurlow Weed Barnes of Cambridge, Mass., formerly of Albany, N. Y.

Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands today replied to the round robin appeal of Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia to the seven States of the Oslo Convention [Luxembourg, Finland, Norway, Sweden, Denmark, the Netherlands and Belgium] justifying "in view of the importance of maintaining normal diplomatic relations with Italy" the action of her government in proposing that the Oslo convention powers extend recognition to the Italian annexation of Ethiopia.

A larger volume of orders than had previously been anticipated will probably be placed in the New York wholesale market during the next few weeks, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIME by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers. Although there will be relatively little advance purchasing,. retail buyers have been reduced to a point where replenishment is a necessity.

Although December is normally a month of rising share prices, the month just completed proved to be one of the few exceptions to the rule. Measured by THE NEW YORK TIMES index of fifty stocks, the stock market showed last month a net decline of 4.53 points.

With the new year, Japanese armies stand, after six months of fighting, at the crossroads of conquest. Since the incident near Peiping on July 7 they have overrun more than143,000 square miles of Chinese soil-Peiping,

With somewhat the same suddenness that marked its beginning the Paris municipal workers' strike collapsed in the early hours of Thursday morning after a twenty-four-hour tie-up of transport and the reduced functioning of most of the other public services.

Miss Earlene White, president of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs, announced today the appointment of Mrs. Mary T. Denman of Pennsylvania as national legislative chairman, and a steering committee of three,

Already committed to a "fight to the finish" in an attempt to bring about cheaper milk, the Department of Markets, through Commissioner William Fellowes Morgan Jr., will submit a program of proposed ordinances to the City Council at its first meeting at noon tomorrow.

Mrs. Clarence M. Burdick of the Marguerita Apartments, Far Rockaway, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Ruth Burdick, to Donald Foster Grant, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry K. Grant of Cedar Rapids, Iowa.

PINNEHURST, N. C.-The running of the twenty-first annual events of the Pinehurst Field Trial Club will occupy the center of attention atSthis Midmouth resort starting tomorrow and continuing until Thursday. The amateur stakes, including an allage and derby event, will be held the first two days and will be followed by the open events, the freefor-all, the derby and the puppy stakes.

The French Parliament tonight adopted a balanced ordinary budget for 1938. The Chamber of Deputies and Senate agreed on a measure fixing receipts at 54,776,176,392 francs and expenses at 54,739,600,976 francs.

Dr. Jose Castillejo, Professor of Roman Law at the University of Madrid, has been appointed Visiting Carnegie Professor at Columbia University, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president. Dr. Castillejo,
Great Britain moved today to bolster the defenses of her vital Mediterranean route to India and the Orient by dispatching anti-aircraft troops with equipment to Alexandria, Egypt.

STAMPS from both factions In the Spanish conflict again sup ply the bulk of the week's new foreign issues reaching New York. The Loyalists Lave released two miniature sheets the proceeds from which are to be used to provide a refuge for French anti-Fascists.

Mrs. Daniel Howland of East Greenwich; R. I., has announced to friends here the engagement of. her daughter, Miss Katharine Stanley Howland, to. Lieut. Alfred Allen Maybach, U. S. A., son of the late Colonel and Mrs. Alfred A. Maybach.

WITH a record year behind them, airmen will settle down to the business of 1938 with the opening next week in Cleveland of the First National Aeronautic Planning Conference. The conference will be held coincident with the annual meeting of the National Aeronautic Association Jan. 9 to 12,

51 NEGLECTED LYRICS. Edited with Introduction by Tom Boggs. 110 pp. New York: The Macmillan Company. $2. AN anthology containing no more than fifty-one negelected lyrics promises a highly individual collection, and that promise is fulfilled in Mr. Boggs's book.
Joseph A. Glennon, sales manager for E. R. Squibb Sons, 745 Fifth Avenue, New York, died here tonight at his home, 573 South Clinton Street, at. the age of. 61.

A message of good-will expressing congratulations "on the birth of the State of Ireland, December 29, 1937, consequent upon coming into effect of the new Constitution," signed on parchment by nineteen Governors, eighty United States Senators and 206 Representatives, was made public here yesterdav.
Cardinal Hayes was "at. home" for New Year's Day at his residence, 452 Madison Avenue, yesterday afternoon. The Cardinal received his callers standing in front of a lfe-size painting of Pope Pius XI.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Marion Bard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Norwood Bard of this place, to James H. McMahon Jr., son Mrs. James H. McMahon of Bronxville, N. Y., and the late Mr. McMahon.

To carry out its 1938 legislative program covering five main issues, the National Federation of Business and Professional Women has named Mrs. Mary Denman as national legislative chairman. The appointment was announced yesterday as approved by the executive committee, headed by Miss Earlene White of Washington, national president.

Stan Laurel, the comedian who teams with Oliver Hardy in the movies, Was married here early today to Illeana, a Russian singer. He was followed here from Los Angeles by his second wife, in whose divorce suit a final decree was entered there yesterday.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, , which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference. THE TIMES receives a great many more queries than it can publish. It endeavors, therefore, to select those of the greatest general interest.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Ernway Edwards of Evanston of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanore Virginia Edwards, to James F. Devine, son of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Devine of Pelham, N. Y.

According to The Sunday Chronicle, leaders of international Jewry will meet in a village near Geneva this week to devise a "counter-offensive" to anti-Jewish moves in Poland, Rumania, Germany, Hungary and Austria.

Mr. and Mrs. Niels Frode Holch of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, and South Kensington, London, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helga Eleanor Holch, to John Nicholson Daniels of Tendring, Essex, England.

Admiral Hilary P. Jones, one-time commander in chief of the United States Fleet and who distinguished himself as naval adviser and delegate to arms limitation conferences, died at his home here at 7 o'clock tonight after a brief illness. His age was 74.

Charles Clement Wood, president of the Champlain Marine Company, Inc., and the Champlain Realty Company, Inc., and for five years president of the Champlain Valley Council until he retired from that office a few months ago, died yesterday of a heart attack at the age of 40.

Increased emphasis upon guidance services offered junior and senior high school pupils in the New York City school system is noted in the annual report of Dr. Charles M. Smith, director of the Board of Education's division of guidance and placement.

Ways of making more effective cooperation of clubwomen with police in crime prevention-highlighted on the program of the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs-were under consideration by two groups last week. The services of the Woman's Club of Orange, the largest woman's club In the State, were offered to five local police chiefs of the Oranges and Maplewood in their campaign against crime.

A total of $275,000 is being paid in "dividends" each year to members of the Retail Trade Board of Boston, according to a pamphlet being sent to the membership under the signature of P. A. O'Connell, president.

Princeton University in fulfilling its educational responsibilities is endeavoring to develop among undergraduates a more complete understanding of religion and its significance in the secular world, a survey of the religious situation on the campus disclosed today.

THE year 1937 in the American theatre will be remembered, if it is, as the one which gave birth to the American Theatre Council and its first annual convention. For while plays came and went with accustomed precision the oratory of the convention went on forever, or so it seemed to those who heard its flow.

Held to a 17-all tie in the first half, Penn State opened its attack late in the game and defeated Western Reserve, 43 to 34. Reserve started the second half with four substitutes in the line-up, and it was while this team was on the floor that Penn State went ahead to stay.

SENDING a strong signal over the Alaskan Gulf and across the wide expanse of Northern Canada, Alaskan Station K7FBE was picked up in this area recently as the operator called for contacts with American amateurs in the East.

Mr. and Mrs. Royal Dana of 332 East Eighty-fourth Street have announced the engagement of- their daughter, Miss Adelaide Alice Dana, to Robert H. Montross, son of Charles G. Montross of Orange, N. J., and the late Mrs. Montross.

After nearly five years of groping about in a maze of economic theory for an industrial policy most likely to give stability to prices, profits, production and employment, the Roosevelt Administration this week thought it had found the answer.
What President Getulio Vargas will do with the corporative state he set up in the political coup of Nov. 10 is the question confronting Brazil. Dr. Vargas is the regime, and the regime is Dr. Vargas.
TRAVELERS to the West who imagine that the famed "horsiness" of that land is now confined to dude ranches should be informed that California has become one of the more horse-conscious places.
The Montreal Maroons tried a new- bench manager in the person of President Tommy Gorman tonight, but failed to shake out of their slump and dropped a 3-1 decision to the New York Americans.

Now the women are going to have their chance for a new point-scoring trophy in outboard racing. Mrs. George W. Sutton Jr. of Darien and New York, wife of the former president of the American Power Boat Association, yesterday divulged a plan that will meet with high favor.
Clem Dreisewerd, strikeout king of the Piedmont League during the 1937 season, said today that Judge Kenesaw Mountain Landis had declared him a free agent.

To the Radio Editor: May I join in the chorus for a program, on one station at least, that is not dance music after 11 o'clock at night? Those of us who are complaining about this and that must remember the sponsors of programs are still groping around for the greatest

Miss Patricia Wright, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin N. Wright 3d of Corby Beck, North Wales, was married this afternoon to Paul F. Gierasch Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul F. Gierasch of Bay Shore, L. I., in the Church of the Messiah at Gwynedd by the rector, the Rev. William C. Patterson.

Premier Mussolini has declared more than once that the antithesis drawn by some people between fascism and democracy is absurd and that the socalled dictatorships are the world's purest example of democracy.

Members of the police homicide squad expressed gratification last night at the promptness add efficiency with which the staff of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, taking office with the New Year, responded to its first opportunity for a criminal investigation.

On the eve of the convening of Congress the American Labor party called on President Roosevelt yesterday to ignore the demands of "big business" for a balanced budget and to recommend increased relief appropriations to meet the added needs of 'thousands of workers who are being thrown out of employment.

The United Licensed Officers Association warned American ship operators yesterday that curtailment of the powers of licensed officers on their ships by the grant of unusual privileges to their un- j licensed personnel would make the lines responsible for casualties at sea.
After his recent visit to Brussels, President Luis Companys has returned to Catalonia and resumed his position as head of the Catalan Government.

COVERING a period of about thirty years, Mrs. Holmes's novel opens in 1891. when the Rev. Charles Enoch Allender becomes minister of the First Baptist Church of Lebanon, a small but prosperous Western town.

A lease has been signed by Newsreel Theatres, Inc., for the theatre portion of the new two-story building to be erected on the northwest corner of Broadway and Seventysecond Street to replace the old St. Andrew Hotel, Mark Rafalsky Co., Inc., agents announced yesterday.

An indication that Soviet airmen and scientists will establish a scientific camp at the South Pole, as they did at the North Pole, was given today in a fictional article by Mikhail Vodopyanoff, Arctic flier, in Pravda, the Communist party newspaper.

ONE of the distinctive series of chamber performances to be given in New York this season, if the results of the first concert are a sign of what is to come, will Be the program of interpretations of Beethoven's piano and violin sonatas by Adolf Busch, violinist, and Rudolf Serkin, pianist, in Town Hall.

All the theatres report record box-office takings over the Christmas week-end. Queues started to line up early in the morning for the most popular pantomimes, and hundreds of people were content to get standing room.

If it be true that there is in the world a line-up of fascist States vis-a-vis democratic States, then it must be written that in 1937 the fascist States made large advances.. Using war and threats of war to obtain their ends, they have gone ahead while the powers which have popular rule have abstained from war and threats Of war.

Mrs. Joseph F. Negreen has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Madeline Negreen, to Henry C. Kessler Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kessler of York, Pa. The announcement was made yesterday at a dinner given by Miss Negreen's mother at her home in East Forest Hills, Queens.

Claude R. Dietrich of Reading, holder of the Pennsylvania amateur wingshooting championship, with twenty straight fliers from thirty yards rise, led an interstate field of ninety-three gunners today to in the Golden Jubilee Shoot for the historic Reading Sweepstake Cup.

Once again the writer, as chairman of the All-America Selections Council, presents to the readers of THE TIMES. garden page the award winners and the "recommended" varieties among. the annual flower introductions for 1938.

TIME AND THE CONWAYS-Tomorrow evening at the Ritz Theatre. A play by J. B. Priestley, with a cast including Dame Sybil Thorndike, Jessica Tandy, Helena Pickard, Godfrey Kenton, Guy Pelham Boulton, Joan Henley and Christopher Quest, all brought over from London, where the play also is running. It is the first of Mr. Priestley's works to deal with the subject of time.

Prevailing minimum rates of wages now being paid in Westchester County under a contract let on Jan. 27, 1937, for the Delaware water project are substantially lower than the rates for similar work fixed in three contracts awarded by the Board of Water Supply on Nov. 16, 1937, for the same project, it was disclosed yesterday.

THE hot-chestnut venders. long a familiar sight on New York street corners. are on the way out. For years their ranks have been thinning and their returns diminishing. Now a determined drive to clear them off the streets is under way.

The Bush Terminal, occupying the entire waterfront blocks between Forty-first and Forty-third Streets, Brooklyn, is to be modernized at a cost of $400,000, it was announced yesterday by Irving T. Bush, president of the owning company. The work will be in addition to the extensive improvements already started in other portions of the terminal.

BECAUSE the Chinese complained that something in the kerosene they burned in their lamps made the wicks crust, successful application of high-luster enamel to motor cars is now possible, according to technicians in the chemical laboratories at the Ford Rouge plant at Dearborn, Mich. For years,

Cranston Williams, secretarymanager of the Southern Newspaper Publishers Association, said today that "the only definite protection that American publishers can have to prevent arbitrary price-fixing (on paper) by Canadian manufacturers and Americans operating in Canada, cooperating with Canadian politicians, is to develop the Southern pine newsprint industry."
In the last few days Mr. Robert Jackson, the Assistant Attorney General, and Harold L. Ickes, the Secretary of the Interior, have been busily trying to build up a new mythology.

NO sooner are holiday parties at an end along the French Riviera than its citizens begin to prepare for the preLenten carnival. Beginning about the middle of February and ending about March 1, with the burning of King Carnival, this event is the peak attraction of the season.
THE art of Maurice Ravel is artificial, sophisticated, brilliant to a degree, gallant and heroic. He could only live in his art, for his physique was delicate and miniature.

It now develops that for a decade and a half Congress has failed to tax what the United States Supreme Court describes as cohstitutionally taxable stock dividends. In the basic decision (Macomber v. Eisner, 245 U. S. 418) the Supreme Court held in 1920 that a dividend paid in common stock to the holders of common stock is not income within the meaning of the Sixteenth Constitutional Amendment.

Commodities upon which concessions were asked of England by American exporters who filed suggestions with Washington officials in charge of negotiating the reciprocal trade treaty with England make up a cross-section of American industry, according to officials of export-trade organizations. The suggestions, which will be supported later by briefs and by oral testimony before the Committee for Reciprocity Information, cover everything from toys to railroad, locomotives.

The new executive committee of the American Olympic Committee will hold two important meetings this week to organize and make plans for United States participation in the 1940 Oylmpic Games at Tokyo. On Thursday evening the executive group will gather at the New York A. C. to choose ten more

THE Christmas season is always prolific in children's books, and this year the output of them is almost bewildering. Notices of them occupy a greater proportion than ever of the space devoted in the press to the Christmas offerings of our publishers.
Mrs. Ella Bixby Tent 18, Daughters of Union Veterans of the Civil War, will install recently elected officers on Friday evening at its meeting room, 110 East 125th Street.

THE current issue of The Yale University Library Gazette is an all-Shaw number. based upon the Henderson Memorial Collection of his works. The gift of the extensive library of Archibald Henderson. presented last year in memory of his grandfather,

New residences and other buildings erected in Nassau in the Bahama Islands during the past year are reported to represent an aggregate value of more than $1,500,000. A large proportion of the new homes have been built by American residents, many of whom have hitherto rented homes for Winter occupancy. This construction activity has also been supplemented by a marked increase in the purchase of property for early improvement.

The Mexican Government has decided to take a step backward in its wage battle with United States and British petroleum companies. The Federal Labor Board will suspend its decision ordering an increase in oil wages of one-third and fixing a program of operations until the Mexican Supreme Court makes a ruling on the companies' request for a permanent injunction, Gustavo Corona, government member of the Labor Board, said today.

Thomas G. Grace, State director of the Federal Housing Administration, has pledged the cooperation of his department in connection with the seventeenth annual Women's National Exposition of Arts and dustries to be held at the Grand Central Palace from March 28 to April 2.

AS 1938 begins to unfold, and radio manufacturers review the days gone by, they find that within the past two years they have changed their minds twice on the subject of television. First skepticism gave place to apprehension; now fear has been replaced by a firm belief in the future of the new entertainment.

WITH charity for all and malice toward none....No, that's the wrong speech. . . Having donned the ceremonial robes, having placed burnt offerings upon the managing editor's desk and having paid obeisance thrice to Will H. Hays, the department is prepared to announce its Ten Best list of 1937.

THE best gardener in Acy is a Portuguese. The village admits it with humor, and also with some embarrassment. It offends its sense of the fitness of things that French soil should yield thus generously to the blandishments of a foreigner. but there it is.

Food prices are declining after reaching in November their highest peak in years. The downward trend began last month, and government economists predict that the housewife can rely on much lower retail prices for most products in 1938.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Robert H. Williams of this place of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Ruth Ophelia Williams, to John Semple Barton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard G. Barton of New York and Brightwaters, L. I.

Auburn's Plainsmen pushed the Michigan State football team all over the Orange Bowl today, but clicked with just one scoring thrust for a 6-0 victory, the first by a Southern squad in the four years the New Year's game has been played.

" Don Giovanni" made a welcome return to the Metropolitan repertory yesterday afternoon, and a very large audience demonstrated its delight in the proceeding. This was, in fact,. the .most vivid and entertaining interpretation of the work that we remember in years in Broadway's lyric theatre, and it was so despite the presence of but few exceptional voices in the cast.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Broadbridge Nash of Garden City, L. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Valerie Ferry Nash, to Marshall Konopak Skadden, son of Marshall Henry Skadden of Toledo, Ohio, and the late Mrs. Skadden.

The work of the Crippled Children's After Care Committee will be furthered by a luncheon to be held Thursday at the WaldorfAstoria. The special guests will be the Rev. Dr. Milton Steinberg of the Park Avenue Synagogue, who will speak on the play, "The Brothers Ashkenazi," and Maurice Schwartz, who plays the leading role in the production.
Governor and Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman held their annual reception for the public at the Executive Mansion today, but owing to snow and rain, less than two hundred persons attended.

The President's proclamation of Friday night, announcing expiration by time limit of the Silver Purchase decree of December, 1933, and reducing the government's bid price for domestic-mined silver from 77.57 cents an ounce to 64.44, marks at least partial retreat from a discreditable experiment in public finance. It is true,

Patrolman Vincent A. Devine, 32 years old, of 86-13 108th Street, Richmond Hill, Queens, attached to the West Twentieth Street station in Manhattan, shot himself dead in a bar and grill at 1,512 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, at 1 A. M. yesterday, according to the police.
The Quebec Lands and Forests Department tonight announced that a rescue plane had found fifteen surveyors cut off from the world more than a month in Northern Quebec.

TROMKA looks out of his window and sees all the confusion of high buildings, tumbled buildings, lamp-posts, automobiles and the risible "L." Apparently the disordered scene is for him a symbol of the city.

MIAMI, Fla.-National importance attaches to the Miami-Biltmore men's tennis championships, opening at Coral Gables tomorrow and continuing through next Sunday, be cause the new rankings, issued by the United States Lawn Tennis As sociation, will in this touranment have their initial test of the 1938 season.
A preview of "inventions of 1938" is revealed in the 774 patents granted this week by the United States Patent Office. Several are of unusual interest.

Solly Krieger of Brooklyn, N. Y., maintrained his position among the leading challengers for Middleweight Champion Freddie Steele's crown by scoring a three-round technical knockout over George Black, Milwaukee, in the main bout here today.

Arlene Schagen, 3-year-old daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Schagen of 968 East Nineteenth Street, died at 8:30 o'clock in Paterson General Hospital tonight as the result of a pistol accident this afternoon.

World peace in 1938 is dependent in large measure upon the ability of the democratic nations to defend themselves against the encroachment of the "hysterical and brutalized autocracies," Rabbi Jonah B. Wise warned yesterday in his sermon at the Central Synagogue, Central Park West and Fifty-fifth Street.

Republicans gained control of Cincinnati's City Council today, electing James Garfield Stewart for Mayor. He succeeds Russell Wilson, a "charterite" who helped found the city manager plan here and who had served eight years as Mayor.
Mr and Mrs. Jesse L. Parker of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen W. Parker, to George Henry Alexander, son of Mrs. M. H. Alexander, of Rochester, N. Y.

THE maintenance committee of the Air Transport Association will meet in Dallas, Texas, Jan. 13 to 15, to discuss the numerous problems involved in keeping airline planes in the air safely and on schedule. Maintenance of engines, propellers, instruments and other accessories are to be discussed.

Spectators at a dog-racing stadium in England were thrilled recently by the performances of cheetahs 'imported from the Kenya jungles. In their first public appearance at Romford Stadium, one of the animals, matched against greyhounds, covered 355 yards in 15.86 seconds-roughly fifty-five.miles an hour-leaving the- greyhounds virtually at a standstill.:

Ancestor worship such as that practiced by the Japanese and Chinese has appeared in Germany along the Baltic Sea coast, notably in Mecklenburg, which has become the center of extreme Germanism and neopagan experimentation.

Another in the series of entertainments planned in the interests of the Grenfell Association's opera benefit later this month will be a luncheon to be given by Mrs. Stephen Baker, vice chairman of the benefit, tomorrow at her home, 660 Park Avenue, for members of the debutante committee headed by Miss Hilda R. Hutchinson.

Miss Nora Johnston of Surrey, England, one of th four women in the world to hold a diploma from the Belgium School of Carillons, will be presented in a program introducing her portable carillons at the Rutherford, N. J., Woman's Club tomorrow. Presidents of clubs of the forty-sixth district will be guests.

The New York Diet Kitchen Association will be the beneficiary of the matinee performance on Feb. 22 at the Metropolitan Opera House of "Tristan und Isolde" starring Kirsten Flagstad and Lauritz Melchoir.

BESIDES a hangover, the new year has ushered in feverish activity in the night clubs. True, the weak sisters are scheduled to be weeded out soon in keeping with the post-Jan. 1 tradition, but the more hardy have freshened up their presentations, called in the plasterer and carpenter and otherwise expressed confidence in 1938.

Tonnage sales in the grocery inlustry ran ahead of 1986 figures, although net profits were smaller, according to a survey conducted by Paul S. Willis, president of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., and made public yesterday.

Carrying on their custom, established many years ago, Mr.. and Mrs. John Shepard Jr. entertained a. large number of their friends today with cocktails at Casa del Pastor, celebrating his eighty-first birthday, which is tomorrow, and New Year's Day.

The following two games, which were won by Bernard Winkler of Columbia and Jetemiah F. Donovan of Brooklyn in the college tournament at the Manhattan Chess Club are good examples of the play in that competition:
Sixty thousand persons, the largest crowd in the history of Santa Anita racing, saw Gosum, a 16 1 shot generally overlooked by the bettors, win the $5,000 added New Year's Handicap today.

Three properties will be offered at auction this week in the Vesey Street rooms by Henry Brady. Tomorrow he will sell the two-story laundry building at 118-20 East 129th Street in a foreclosure action brought by the Harlem Savings Bank against the Pansor Holding Corporation to satisfy a debt of $30,890 with interest.

The New York Americans will tackle the Maroons of Montreal in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. The battle is an important one for the local skaters, as a victory for the Canadian sextet will interfere considerably with Manager Red Dutton's hopes of ascending in the standing of the international group.

Captain Henry Burke, 71year-old master mariner, has felt the call of the sea again. One of the few remaining master mariners in Nova Scotia, the Lunenburg sea veteran, who sailed out of his native port for the first time fifty-three years ago, will be aboard the four-masted Newfoundland schooner R. R. Govin when she takes on cargo here this month for Great Britain.

A brilliant University of Washington team, scoring at will, thrilled 13,500 shirt sleeved spectators in the Poi Bowl football game today with dazzling runs as it trounced an almost helpless University of Hawaii squad, 53 to 13.

Installation of 'the recently elected officers of the Women's Auxiliary to the 165th Infantry, U. S. A., Inc., will take place on Friday evening at the armory, Twenty-sixth Street and Lexington Avenue. The ceremony will follow the regular monthly meeting.

NOWADAYS, when diplomats write euphemistic notes to whitewash international incidents, the newsreel camera is apt to confound them with the realities before the whole public--at least in the maligned democracies.

A constantly diminishing gross profit margin, due to the necessity for meeting merciless price competition, is the chief source of the millinery trade's current difficulties, according to Charles Rothenberg, president of Chesterfield Hat Co. Inc.

Thirty-three hundred pages and twenty-one pounds of law comprise the administrative code implementing the new city charter which became effective yesterday - remarkable next to its size for the number of people who don't know what's in it. The Mayor doesn't know;

With the variety chains generally indicating they are eliminating Japan as a source of novelty merchandise during the coming year, more intensive visits in other foreign countries by merchandise scouts of the chains will- be made to discover suitable sources of supply.

Intermittent rain, snow, hail and sleet, in addition to the biting cold, hampered the athletes considerably today as more than 200 speedsters vied for championship honors in the eighteenth annual Middle Atlantic outdoor speed skating meet on an improvised eight-lap track on Crystal: Lake.

Few price changes are looked for in the wholesale rug market tomorrow when mills open their Spring rug and carpet lines to the trade. Reductions averaging 5 to 7 per cent were made by the majority of mills last month and they are expected to carry these new prices through the Spring season.

Dr. and Mrs. Warren F. Cook of Waban, Mass., have announced to friends here the engagement' of theft daughter, Miss Carol Clayton Cook, to John Finch, son of Mrs. Wallace Finch of Mount Vernon, N. Y., and the late Rev. Dr. Finch, former pastor of the Chester Hill Methodist EPiscopal Church.

The farmers of the New York City milkshed-in six States, within a 200-mile radius of the metropoliswere scanning the headlines again last week, watching with anxious interest the latest dislocations in the always eccentric machinery of milk distribution and hoping that, whatever happened to the consumers of the city, they as producers would not suffer too much economic pain.

Mr. and Mrs. J. Frank Baldwin Jr. of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catheripe Baldwin, to William Lehner Hoffmann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel R. Hoffmann of South Orange.

DISPENSING with haphazard, trial and error methods of improving the performance of vacuum tubes, Professor Emory L. Chaffee of Cruft Laboratory, Harvard University, has applied a new mathematical analysis, described as "a major scientific development,

The nineteenth annual Aviators Ball, under the auspices of Aviators Post, 743, of the American Legion, will take place on the night of Feb. 18 at the Roosevelt. As in the past, funds derived from the sale of tickets will be donated to the Aviators Welfare and Relief Fund.

In a year-end statement as the Administration prepared to launch a major home-building program, the Home Owners Loan Corporation announced today that its record as mortgage lender, collector and landlord demonstrated that "the American home owner is the world's best risk."

George Washington's wedding anniversary will be observed by the New York City Chapter, Daughters of the American Revolution, of which Mrs. Edward C. Zabriskie is regent, on Thursday afternoon. A reception at 3 P. M. at the Hotel Plaza will have Mrs. William A.

ROFESSIONALLY, in the higher registers, the boss cook is a man. His title is "chef." In the amateur class there are men who cook for the love of the fine art of it. whose pride is the perfection of the performance. who make the process a ritual.

Urging confidence in real estate as an investment, Frank S. O'Hara, president of the Real Estate Association of the State of New York, predicted yesterday that realty activity would increase during 1938. He declared, however,

A livelier twelve-month than in many a year came up with the dawn of 1938 for domestic workers, as drafting of a proposed bill for reduction of working hours revived discussions among the feminine half of the public on the all-absorbing topic of household help.

GUIDED by reports of "murder tactics" in the Spanish conflict, an Air Corps soldier here has devised for army consideration a miniature parachute to guile warplane pilots in delayed parachute jumps during combat, enabling them to drop safely out of range of planes which may pursue them to earth.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Heiss of this place and East Orange gave a dinner today at Little Brook Farm, their home here, at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Elizabeth Heiss, to Carroll Aylsworth Boynton, son of Dr. and Mrs. Perry Sanborn Boynton of New York.
Eamon de Valera looked a serious and solemn, almost disillusioned, man on Wednesday when his new State of Eire came into being.

The University of Toronto hockey team accomplished the first shutout of the current international intercollegiate series at the Playland Casino by blanking the University of Montreal six, 7 to 0, tonight.

Widespread publicity given to television was credited yesterday by radio set manufacturers as one of the reasons for the current Jetdown in their sales. The economic recession has, of course, played the chief part in the downtrend, but manufacturers said that their volume would be considerably better if consumers were not led to believe that they will soon be able to buy television sets, thus leading them to hold off purchases of new radios.
Angelo (Hank) Luisetti staged a spectacular show tonight by scoring 50 points as Stanford routed Duquesne University, 92 to 27, before a sellout crowd of 7,800.
The four important factors to consider in making a sound appraisal, according to Max F. Wolff, vice president of the realty firm of Curtis-Johnson and head of its appraisal department,

The engagement of Miss Elinor Constantinides, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles L. Constantinides of this place, to Harold Thayer, son of Dr. Helen Thayer of Rochester, N. Y., and the late Dr. Herbert Thayer, has been announced by her parents.

The Seventy-fifth Congress, when it meets tomorrow for its second regular session, will assemble in a charged atmosphere. In the thirteen days since the special session adjourned an issue perennial in American life has been brought forth.

An appreciable number of socalled "superior" children pass through the Psychological and Mental Hygienic Clinic at Rutgers University, New Brunswick, N. J., every year, but only a minority falls into the "problem" category.

RECENT exhibitions at the Rhode Island School of esign have included English and Continental china, Japanese color prints, and water-colors and prints from the permanent collection of the museum. Among the new accessions are an eighteenthcentury Gobelin tapestry;

Williawa Sellers Cox, who in 1935 won the intercollegiate yachting championship as the representative of Princeton, today took high honors in the sixth anniversary regatta of the Frostbite Yacht Club.

Hope Eternal, 6-year-old mare belonging to Mrs. S., Orr, today romped to a four-length victory in the $2,000 added New Year's Handicap at the Fair Grounds. Visigoth of the Shadybrook Farm finished second, three lengths ahead of Trouper, carrying the colors of Mlrs. A. R. Smith.

The largest undergraduate scholarship in the history of New Jersey College for Women will be awarded to a student entering in September of this year, when the college will celebrate its twentieth anniversary. The grant, amounting to $800, will be known as the Twentieth Anniversary Scholarship.

Candidates for the Rebecca Elsberg Memorial Scholarship prizes, consisting of .$150 each to a boy and- a girl, are being considered by the school officials, Dr Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools. announced last week.

Group life insurance outstanding at the beginning of 1938 is estimated at $13,900,000,000, which is equivalent to about 38 per cent of the salaries and wages paid out during 1937 by private industry in the United States, according to Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the Equitable Life Assurance Societv.
THE appearance of Curt Sachs's "World History of the Dance" in an excellent English translation constitutes as a matter of course a distinguished event.

Congress is supposed to assemble on Monday in chastened and cooperative mood, fearful of opposing any major Presidential measures because to do so will line up Congress with the "Sixty Families" against "the 120 millions."

Henry Abiah James, prominent member of the Bucks County bar and a former bank president here, who also had served as President of Borough Council and the Doyles-, town Fire Company, died at his home last night at the age of 72. He practiced law here for fortynine years and at one time served as Solicitor of Bucks County.
Brentford retained its first division lead in English football league competition today, although held to a 1-1 draw by the Bolton Wanderers.

The King's man is dead;. long live the King's man," summarizes Rumania's ten days of political surprises. First alarms created by the nomination to the Cabinet of Octavian. Goga and the joint leaders of his party, which had not secured 10 per cent of the votes in the election, are subsiding.
WITH a fortunate facility in looking forward rather than back, the film industry prefers to ignore the past twelve months and discuss 1938 as though its products already were realities.

The building at 202 Avenue A, recently remodeled by John Billovits at a cost of about $20,000, is now fully occupied. The four-room apartments were changed into threeroom suites and oil heat was installed.

The repetition of an entertainment that was a feature of the social season here a decade ago will mark the dinner and musical to be given on the night of Jan. 23 in the grand ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria for the benefit of the Musicians Emergency Fund.

Forrmenrly Lecturer of the Imperial University, Tokyo FOR more than twelve centuries the Japanese people have been divided into four classes--soldiers, farmers. artisans and traders. Their class system was originally borrowed from China but soon became quite un-Chinese in its practical application.

FACING a bright New Year, Onkel Franz Frisch, the field marshal of the St. Louis Cardinal forces in baseball, ran slap-dash into a gathering that included Barrister Leo Bondy, vice president and treasurer of the New York Giants.

The annual benefit theatre party under the auspices of the Woman's Board of the Church Charity Foundation, which for many years has evoked great interest among members of Brooklyn society, will be held this year on Jan. 17. The play chosen is "The Star Wagon" at the Empire Theatre.
Mr. and Mrs. Wilfrid M. Thomson entertained yesterday at a cocktail party at their home on Shippan Point before the New Year's dinner dance at the Stamford Yacht Club.

Newspaper delivery trucks have traversed the streets, avenues and boulevards of the Brownsville section of Brooklyn daily and nightly for a number of years without arousing the suspicion of Patrolman James Norton of the Brownsville precinct.

Announcement has been made by Colonel and Mrs. Clarence T. Starr of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Morris Starr, to John De Groff Talbot, son of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Talbot of Dongan Hills. S. I.

Employment in the United States in mid-November of 7,800,000 to 10,800,000 persons was indicated in the first independent National Unemployment Census ever undertaken by the government, on which a partial report was delivered to President Roosevelt today.

The marriage of Miss Jeanne Danner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Danner of Brooklyn, to Lee C. Brown Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lee C. Brown of Rhinebeck, N. Y., took place yesterday afternoon at the Plymouth Institute, the parish house of the Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims, 57 Orange Street, Brooklyn.

Forty gunners took part in the New Year's Day Handicap over the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday. Champagne prizes were awarded in all classes. The high-over-all entrant was Tracy H. Lewis, who had a card of 88 in Class A.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John F. Anderson of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elin Anderson, to Richard Hartman Haigh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry J. Haigh of Maplewood.

IT is possible that there may be others who, like this reviewer, will be deeply grateful to Mr. Frankau for introducing them to Major Geoffrey McNeill-Moss's absorbingly interesting on-the-spot history of one of the most heroic episodes in the contemporary Spanish war.
WHEN hiking trails and playing fields are frozen tight, recreation-minded persons in the New Area refuse to settle down for a Winter of inactivity.

Harlow Morrell Davis, father of Bette Davis, screen star, died today of a heart attack at his home in Belmont, Mass. His age was 52. Mr. Davis had been connected with the patent office of the United Shoe Machinery Corporation for more than a quarter of a century and since 1935 had been manager of its patent division.

THE Mexican revolution, that unfailing source of literary material for novelists here, has produced one of its most interesting books to date with the publication of Jorge Ferretis's latest novel, Cuando Engorda el Quijote,

THE Philadelphia Orchestra, under Eugene Ormandy, will cover wide territory in its tours this season. In addition to the cities to be covered, the orchestra will participate in three major music festivals, namely, that at Ann Arbor, Mich., May 11-14; the Spring festival of Toronto, Canada, May 16-18, and the Westchester festival, White Plains, N. Y., May 20-21.

Although marine traffic declined sharply at the ports of San Francisco and Oakland in the past few weeks, principally through the withdrawal of the big luxury liners of W. R. Grace Co. and the Panama Pacific Company from intercoastal service,

This being the season for sport writers in general and so-called golf experts in particular to essay the well-nigh impossible task of picking best players for 1937, let it not be said that this department evades the issue by refraining from offering an opinion on the merits of women golfers who made the best records during the past year.
Threatened school deficits reported from eight widely separated States offer a precarious new year prospect for the nation's schools, according to a survey by the American Federation of Teachers.

Ralph Greenleaf, sixteen times holder of the world pocket billiard championship, will meet Andrew Ponzi in a week's match which will start tomorrow afternoon at the Strand Academy. In Ponzi the champion will be facing his most persistent rival over the last few...

The New York Stock Exchange ice hockey team triumphed over the Manhattan Arrows, 3-0, at the Imperial Skating Rink tonight. After a scoreless first period the winners broke into the scoring column twice in the second chapter as Tilley and Harry Sniffen each came through with tallies.

The American farmer, trekking out of the depression, finds himself at this new year in the position of mountain climber who, after steady progress up a long slope, is crossing a dip in the terrain before resuming his climb to still higher ground. At any rate, this is the picture drawn by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics in its annual "Outlook Report."

Interference in business by the Government of the Union of South Africa in attempts to control food production and raise prices in the interest of the farmers has been attended with anything but happy results.

Persons whose suits against New York City were settled during Mayor La Guardia's first administration collected on an average of less than-half as much per case as they collected during the Tammany administrations. since 1929, the annual report of the city's Law Department indicated yesterday.

The first Fusion administration in the city's history to succeed itself in office got under way yesterday when Mayor La Guardia, at ceremonies in the council chamber at City Hall, announced the reappointment of fourteen commissioners and administered the oath of office to a group of new appointees.

Alfred Gratz, insurance executive, died today at his home, 1,828 Spruce Street, at the age of 83. His business interests centered in the Girard Fire Insurance Company and the Mechanics Insurance Company of Philadelphia.

The tide of giving to this fund is still rising. "A single breaker may recede, but the tide is evidently coming in." There is no "recession" in that which is "all mankind's concern" if one may generalize from this instance.
