The amount contributed to date is the largest since 1931 and may even exceed the total for that year.

HOLIDAY stoppages in a number of automotive plants during the week just closed cut production of new cars and trucks to about 45,000 units, as compared with 65,000 in the previous week and 80,000 for the corresponding week a year ago.

Dr. Bernard Sachs, former president of the New York Academy of Medicine and international authority in child neurology, will be 80 years old today. He was born in Baltimore, a son of Joseph and Sophia Baer Sachs, and prepared for his profession at Harvard and the University of Strassburg, Germany.

The opening of the New York World's Fair is now only somewhat more than a year away, and yet, to date, no tangible support for an adequate marine transportation exhibit at the Fair has been forthcoming. New York is probably the world's greatest port; it is certainly, in a commercial sense, the most important gateway to America.

Ten Neediest Cases for which provision only in part can be made out of the Neediest Cases Fund as it stands today are published below They are typical stories of misfortune, selected from many more cases which still are awaiting aid.
Police Commissioner Valentine pledged his high command yesterday to a period of service to the city that would far surpass the "good record" of the last four years.
The lull in holiday operations has given the automobile industry time to reflect on 1938 production.

Mr. and Mrs. Louis D. H. Weld of New Rochelle, N. Y., have announced the engagement of Mrs Weld's daughter, Miss Virginia Ann Hickox, to Eric Adamson, son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Adamsor of Mamaroneck, N. Y.

Thousands of ex-revelers woke up yesterday to find New York on New Year's Day a damp,. cold place. Meanwhile the large hotels calculated their profits on the celebration of the night before and reported that they had entertained nearly as many holiday-makers as last New Year's Eve, which was an extremely good one.

The Toronto Maple Leafs came from behind to defeat the Montreal Canadiens, 6-4, tonight and widen their lead in the International Group of the National Hockey League to five points over the Flying Frenchmen. A New Year's night crowd of 13,500 watched the game.

Mr. and Mrs. Stanton T. Lawrence of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Naomi Lawrence, to Walter Scholla, son of Gustave J. Scholla of Scranton, Pa., and the late Mrs. Scholla.
Gifts totaling $379,273 to the United Hospital Campaign had been received up to last night by the finance section, according to an announcement by F. Abbot Goodhue, division chairman.
FOUR mural paintings, executed under the direction of the Federal Art Project, have been recently finished, approved and installed. Three are in hospitals, the fourth in Public School 164, Brooklyn.
Billy Hearndon, old-time bare fist fighter who turned preacher, died here today at the age of 74. He collapsed after going to the early New Year service at Eastham.

THIS TROUBLED WORLD. By Eleanor Roosevelt. 47 pp. New York: H. C. Kinsey Co. $1. WITHOUT sentimentality or undue optimism, this book presents a publicspirited woman's findings on the subject of peace.

Robert Boutelle Noyes, who has been a coffee grower in Puerto Rico for the last thirty years, died suddenly yesterday of a heart attack in the apartment in the Hotel: Savoy-Plaza which he end his wife had been occupying during a visit here. He was 57 years old.

The marriage of Miss Mary Josephine Cutting, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fulton Cutting of 15 East Eightyeighth Street, New York, and the Wheatley Hills colony here, to Alexander B. McFadden, son of Mrs. Bernon S. Prentice of New York and the late George McFadden, took place at noon today in the Church of the Advent on the Jericho Turnpike. The Rev. Richard Pope,

Sensator Byrd of Virginia coupled a statement today that he would support President Roosevelt's proposed reduction in the Federal appropriation for roads with a demand that at the same time "the extravagances and luxuries of government get the axe, and by a major operation."

A man fleeing with a revolver in his hand from the scene of a murder at Delancey and Cannon Streets shortly before 1 o'clock this morning was shot and seriously wounded by Patrolman Joseph Pigott of the Clinton Street station.

A card party and fashion show under the auspices of the Ladies' Auxiliary of All Hallows Institute will take place next Saturday afternoon in the Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the organization's building fund.
OSLO, Norway's ultra-modern little capital, situated on a beautiful fiord, has no lack of Summer visitors, but as a Winter resort it is almost unknown to tourists.

HANYA HOLM'S presentation of "Trend" at the Mecca Auditorium constitutes not only a red-letter event in the season's activities but also a landmark in the progress of the modern dance toward the development of its own theatre forms. Though,

The induction of eighteen new members into the New York University Chapter of Phi Delta Kappa, national professional educational society, was announced at the university's School of Education yesterday. The initiates were:
The engagement of Miss Helen Dixie Wolfe, daughter of Mrs. Townsend Durant Wolfe of this city and the late Mr. Wolfe, to Donald Patrick Baker of New York has been announced by her mother.
CONCERNING the continued absence of Vladimir Horowitz from the concert stage, European and American, one has heard many explanations.

MONTREAL.-With the ChristMVI mas and New Year's rush over, Montrealers are preparing for their regular skiing expeditions to the Laurentian Mountains on the week-ends. Snow conditions are reported as ideal throughout the North country, with three to four feet the average at most of the popular runs.

Track and field enthusiasts, who have been impatiently awaiting the 1938 indoor season, will have an opportunity to see a plethora of stars in action on Saturday night when Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, will present its twelfth annual meet at the Thirteenth Regiment Armory in Brooklyn.

Japan's invasion of China and increasing war preparations in other parts of the world, notably in Germany and Italy, were cited yesterday by Dr. Harry W. Laidler, executive director of the League for Industrial Democracy, as "the greatest setback to progress during 1937."

Announcement that daily broadcasts in Arabic will begin on Monday from a British station at Daventry to counteract the effects in the Near East and North Africa of anti-British broadcasts from Bari, Italy, is a sign of sustained tension between Italy and Britain.

Deporstation of Harry Bridges, leader of the C. I. O. union in the jurisdictional fight with the A. F. of L. labor forces in the Pacifio Northwest lumber industry, would notend that conflict, in the opinion of Senator Frederick Steiwer, Republican, of Oregon.

Heavyweights undoubtedly will be more active in the new year than has been characteristic of the class since the days of Jack Dempsey but it is to the middleweights and welterweights that will go the distinction of ushering in 1938.
THOSE who confine their reading to much-talked-of books, hot off the press, show the same disregard for values that the savages showed when they traded their gold ornaments for plug hats.

Jack Trammell, hard - hitting Youngstown heavyweight, was held to a draw by Jim Howell of Harlem in the feature bout of ten rounds before 2,000 at the Rockland Palace last night. The result was a distinct surprise, since Trammell was a topheavy favorite over the Harlem fighter.

Despite the recession in many lines of business in the last quarter of the year, the volume of production and trade for the whole year 1937 is estimated to have been about 5 per cent more than in 1936, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reports in its current monthly bulletin.

Two major labor laws enacted by a Democratic Legislature'for Governor Earle's New Deal administration and affecting millions of Pennsylvania workers will be tested next week in the State Supreme Court. Their constitutionality is challenged by industrial interests.

Fearing a "gang war" might result from an influx of policy slip bankers and runners, District Attorney Walter A. Ferris is making a campaign to drive policy slip operators out of Westchester County. Cooperating with him are ninety police chiefs and directors of public safety.

The bullion market here for gold and silver was closed today and it was left to Bombay to show the effect of President Roosevelt's action of last night in slashing the domestic silver price in the United States.

Community building possibilities will be discussed at the convention of the Home and Community Builders National Association in Washington Jan. 11, 12 and 13. "Community building is the key to the solution of the national housing problem." states Don A. Loftus, president of the association.

One result of the continued practice of converting old private residences in Manhattan into multifamily houses has been to create a dearth of desirable single-family dwellings in some parts of the borough.

Pressure for volume will tend to arrow retail mark-ups during the first quarter of this year, but the counter-pressure to show at least a small profit in the face of rising costs will be nearly as great, resulting in pretty much of a standoff, retail executives pointed out during the week.
REAT chutes, tractors and all the devices of this complicated machine age may be applied to logging in other lands, but Australia remains faithful to the bullock team.

THE second opera of the Richard Strauss cycle, "Elektra," will have its revival at the Metropolitan Friday night, after an absence of four years. Rosa Pauly, Hungarian soprano, will make her Metropolitan debut in the title role of this opera.

Foreign correspondents with Generalissimo Francisco Franco's troops tonight mourned the loss of one of their youngest and most popular American companions, 26-year-old Bradish Johnson, who came to Spain only a few weeks ago as a photographer and special correspondent for News Week.

MR. JOSEPH has drawn a picturee of a settlement near Akron, Colo., of a portion of country here referred to as "the flat." The story opens with the arrival in a prairie schooner of Abe and Mollie Turner.

Canisius scored its first basketball victory over Fordham tonight, 34-31, as the college double-header season opened before a crowd of 4,000. Nebraska's speedy team won from Niagara, 43-37, in the first game.
An anti-aircraft shell which is said not to require a direct hit to disable an enemy airplane is described in a patent granted to Mark S. Willing of Mount Holly, Va.

A football team that refused to mention names-California's 1938 Rose Bowl champions-splashed boisterously through the shower baths, running the risk of injury by alumni back-slappers after avoiding casualties on the field today.

ON a plot at the corner of Harbor Road and Lake Drive overlooking the Seawane Golf Club at Hewlett Harbor, L. I., an attractive home of five rooms and two baths is being erected by McMorrow Houses, Inc., for John Alden Stanton of New York.

Children visiting the New York World's Fair in 1939 will find a complete miniature fair of their own, with everything their imaginative minds could wish, according to approved plans announced yesterday.
Two Japanese columns, moving rapidly south to complete the conquest of Shantung Province, are converging on Yenchow, important railway junction near the province's southern border.
ONCE a year King George's Pension Fund for Actors and Actresses arranges a vast matinee which, in the course of a single afternoon, adds some twenty thousand dollars to its resources.
Newspapers editorially assure the American fleet that it will be welcomed with every testimony of gladness and approval within the people's command.

Sixteen steamships will arrive in New York today and land 7,071 passengers, mostly from cruises to Bermuda, the Bahamas and the West Indies. Only two of these vessels are coming from Europe, the Franconia and the Scythia, both of the Cunard White Star Line.

TELEVISION, through opportunities it affords in visual interpretation of sounds, shows promise of being a medium of entertainment and recreation for the partially deaf, according to reports from London of experiments conducted at the Tower House home

Mr. and Mrs. Clarence O. Wood of East Orange have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Margaret Wood, to George B. Walker, son of Francis H. Walker, also of East Orange, and the late Mrs. Walker.

HAVANA, Cuba.-With an unusually large number of visitors already in the island, Cuba is looking forward to an excellent Winter season. The racing meet at Oriental Park, which got under way on Christmas, promises to be a major attraction this year. Operating under the new management of the International Jockey Club, which has made extensive improvements at the oval, the sixty-nine-day meet has been welcomed by fans.

Cruise clothes in the. shops now are enough to give a city person a serious case of wanderlust. The collection of accessories and clothes shown at one shop, which are to be worn in hours of loafing under a warm sun, are gay, fetching, yet eminently practical.

Two former winners, James H. Van Alen of New York and W. C. Wright of Philadelphia, will meet tomorrow in the final round of the annual Gold Racquet court tennis championship, a holiday feature at the Tuxedo Club.
Mr. and Mrs. Welcome W. Bender of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marie Adelaide Bender, to William Austin Tansey Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Tansey of Newark.

Reduction of its operating force by General Motors this week to 205,000 workers, resulting in a lay-of of some 30,000, naturally has caused considerable consternation in the United Automobile Workers' camp.

The collection of the ate V. Everit Macy, a. trustee and benefactor of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, will be sold at auction at the American Art AssociationAnderson Galleries, Inc., on Thursday, Friday and Saturday afternoons.

Three houses in Westchester County have been sold through the brokerage office of Mildred Sanford at Larchmont. They include the dwelling at 19 Barnum Road, Larchmont, purchased by Gilbert J. Moore; the house at 8 Byron Lane,

To millions of citizens Wall Street is remotel, mysterious and foreignsomething hostile to the world of Main Street, peopled by powerful men of wealth who, in its narrow canyons and tall buildings, pursue the slightly sinister business of high finance.
WHEN entire rooms from the homes of early families in America become museum exhibits, our Colonial past is made a visible and living tradition.

Mayor La Guardia vetoed almost one-third of the resolutions and ordinances submitted to him by the old Board of Aldermen during the four years of his first administration, according to figures made public at the Mayor's office yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.-While many New Year's holiday visitors still remain, this resort swings back into its regular Winter entertainment program. Vacationers find various sports and diversions available.

Agencies working among the foreign born are at a loss to determine the reason for the limited number of applications emanating from New York by aliens seeking repatriation under the special 'act of Congress passed last May.

Thanks to a victory over Sir George Thomas in the fifth round, Samuel Reshevsky of New York, the United States champion, overtook Paul Keres in the international masters tournament at the Hastings and St. Leonards Chess Club today and again tied the Estonian for first place.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Hanson Jr. of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marie Cecilia Hanson, to Francis Albert Meixner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anton Meixner of Jersey City.
Mr. and Mrs. Amos J. Vroman of Maplewood have announced the engamement of their daughter, Miss Betty Vroman, to William E. Buckley, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Buckley of Westfield.

Mrs. Anna H. Clarke of 257 Beach 127th Street, Belle Harbor, Queens, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Margaret Mary Clarke, to Thomas F. Keating Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Keating of Brooklyn.

Though sorely troubled by the conflict of armed forces in Spain and China and by the restlessness of totalitarian States, the world has not lost interest in science. Out of the laboratories of Europe and America has come about the only constructive news of the past year. Some of it is great news, recognized as such at the time of its announcement chiefly by workers in chemistry, astronomy, biology and physics.

Committees are being organized here and in Westchester to assist with plans for the ice revue to be given on the night of Jan. 24 at Madison Square Garden for the benefit of the Children' Village at Dobbs Ferry.
The service that the Federal Housing Administration renders by standardizing mortgages is giving greater stability to the mortgage money market, declares Thomas A. Colletan, New Jersey FHA director.
The building firm of Levitt and Sons, with headquarters at Manhassett, L. I., announced yesterday that 1937 was the best year it has experienced since the organization was established in 1929.

What paints are to the artist, or words to the poet, so are plants to the designer of a garden. Of late years garden clubs have been laying great stress upon design, as contrasted with the disordered growing of a collection of plants. Design, however, is but a matter of lifeless lines and curves on paper until it is vitalized and made a thing of living form and color through the medium of growing Plants.

The marriage of Miss Tula Ruth Greenberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Greenberg of Topeka, Kan., to George Francis Friedman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Isidor Friedman of 202 East Thirty-first Street, took place here yesterday in Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street.

Colonel M. Thomas Tchou, former secretary to General Chiang Kaishek, commander of the Chinese military forces, and Chinese representative to the International Labor Conference at Geneva, arrived yes.terday from Europe on the President Harding of the United States Lines to deliver a series of fifty-two lectures. He will spend a week in New York.

The New York City Housing Authority and the New York City Civil Service Commission will cooperate with New York University in offering an eight-week course in public housing management, beginning Monday evening, Jan. 10, it was announced yesterday by Dean Ned H. Dearborn of the university's division of general education.

Jake Schaefer and Welker Cochran will meet for the world 18.2 balkline billiard championship in a 4,200-point match at the Strand Academy, starting on Jan. 10, it was announced yesterday. Both are claimants of the title.
A new music curriculum, offering a greater variety of courses designed to meet the needs of the students more adequately, will be inaugurated at Hunter College in the semester beginning in February.

RADIO will sound "A" for musicians throughout the country, when beginning today, the WABC network introduces a tubular chime designed to vibrate exactly 440 times a second. The chime will be part of the daily time announcements.

Throughout its history the Neediest Cases Fund has made it a fundamental principle that every penny contributed through it must go for the neccessities of life and the permanent rehabili tation of the sufferers for whom. it is given; nothing is wasted on non-essentials or trivialities.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial "Hair-Trigger Accusations" of Dec. 24 charges that the report on industrial espionage of the subcommittee of the Committee on Education and Labor under S. R. 266, of which we are members, was undocumented, carelessly prepared and filled with rash accusations;

With upward of 200 dress firms resenting their Spring lines this veek, a "decisive change in the assect of the industry" will be witnessed, according to Morris Kolhin, executive director of the Afillated Dress Manufacturers, Inc. The openings will represent one of he largest number of new lines to be shown in an "opening week" in recent years.

Masterpieces from the greatest private collections of England went on public view for the first time today at the opening of the great exhibition of seventeenth century European art at Burlington House, the home of the Royal Academy.

Thirteen persons died in New York City on New Year's Day as the result of automobile accidents, police reports showed. Two others had been killed similarly late on New Year's Eve. Ten more succumbed in the suburban area yesterday.

THE year 1937, in one way of looking at it, was just 365 days of impenetrable gloom, one right after the other. Wars and destruction, pirates and taxes, strikes and slumps, tumult and shouting all over the place. Democracy's back to the wall. Civilization cracking up. A terrible year.

Mr. and Mrs. James Jared Tracy gave a reception today at their home in Shaker Heights, at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Tracy, to Webster Sandford, son of Mrs. Joseph Webster Sandford of Plainfield, N. J., and the late Mr. Sandford.

Dartmouth's brilliant band of skiers, whose supremacy in intercollegiate circles for the past three years has not met with a serious challenge, continued to add to its imposing record today when the Indians captured the team prize as the seventeenth annual college invitation meet sponsored by the Lake Placid Club Sno Birds ended.

Acquisition for Philadelphia of "The Ballet Class" by the nineteenth century French artist, Edgar Degas, has been announced by the Commissioners of Fairmount Park. The purchase was made by Joseph E. Widener, chairman of the committee in charge of the Wilstach Collection.
Mr. and Mrs. F. B. Northrup of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice Northrup, to Roger W. Townsend of Orange, son of Mr. and Mrs. S. H. Townsend of Bucklin, Mo.

The establishment and activities of five district health committees in 1937 and the organization of four local reception committees in districts where official health centers are situated to serve as nuclei for permanent bodies are described in the annual report of the Committee

AN unheralded series of stamps has been received from Manchukuo. It was released on Deo. 1 to testify postally that Japan has formally turned over to the Manchukuoan authorities the administrative control of the South

IN Paris before the war, this reviewer met a compatriot who had just come from a German university and who, not especially interested in anything French as French, was yet in avid quest of all the greatness, as well as the beauty, which Paris could show.
East I and West locked grips today in a football struggle that ended in a scoreless tie to the cheers of 58,000 fans.

APEPPERY little man who will be 80 years old on next Tuesday sat at his desk in the Senate Office Building recently and decried the trend of the times. As vitriolic as when President Wilson said of him that he used only half of his mouth when he spoke and that fear might be entertained for an opponent

Pancho Villa, a brown little Indian from Monterrey with a kick in both hands, scored a decisive 10-round victory over Harry Jeffra, world bantamweight champion from Baltimore, in a non-title bout at the Mexico City bull ring today.

Reviewing the various activities of the Federal Housing Administration in New Jersey during 1937, Thomas E. Colleton, State FHA director, finds some evidences of general improvement combined with certain disappointments. Residential sales. he states, fell short of expectations, but the FHA business remained fairly constant and the sharp decline toward the end of the year in new construction was offset by increased activity in the refinancing of mortgages on existing homes.

Personality traits possessed by the ideal teacher, deduced over a period of five years on the basis of firsthand observation of. thousands of applicants for teachers' licenses, were set forth yesterday by Dr. Joseph K. Van Denburg, chairman of the Board of Examiners.

The French Govrnment is deeply disturbed about the turn taken by Rumanian affairs. Warm telegrams have been exchanged by President Albert Lebrun and King Carol, but they are not to be taken at face value.

USE of modern devices to alter the appearance and add to the attractiveness of living quarters in midtown apartment houses is illustrated by the program of improvement which has been undertaken in the Beaux Arts Apartments.

ON Jan. 24 Alfred A. Knopf will publish two books by a new writer, Rex Warner. a young English schoolmaster. Oxford graduate, friend and contemporary of such men as C. Day Lewis, W. H. Auden and Stephen Spender.

Mrs. Jane Shonnard Gates of this city was married to Bertrand Faugeres Bell, son of Mrs. Bertrand F. Bell of 320 East Seventysecond Street and the late Mr. Bell, yesterday afternoon at the home of her mother, Mrs. Joyce Shonnard, at 340 East Seventy-second Street by Supreme Court Justice Charles Poletti. There were no bridal attendants.

With a minimum of scoring but a maximum of thrills the New York Rovers defeated the Baltimore Orioles yesterday in Madison Square Garden before a crowd of 6,500. The final count was 1-0, Al Collings scoring in the second period.

Confident prediction that the Amerlcan educational system would be "greatly improved and enriched" by present keen rivalry between the small collage and the large university was made by Dr. Frank Aydelotte, president of Swarthmore College, in his annual report issued today.
A supper dance was given last night at Sherry's by Dr. and Mrs. Raymond Peter Sullivan to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Katharine Esther Sullivan.

Miss Adelaide Hammond of Cambridge and Sudbury, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Alexander Hammond of Sudbury, was married here at noon today in St. Mark's Church to Edwin G. Johnson of Cambridge, son of John August Johnson and the late Mrs. Johnson. The ceremony was performed in the presence of the immediate families and a few friends by the rector, the Rev. Robert F. Cheney.

Plans for formation of a council composed of various defenders of fair trade laws to devise protective measures against efforts to repeal the Tydings-Miller law at the session of Congress opening on Monday have been proposed and are receiving serious consideration, it was learned here yesterday.

While conceding that the higher price ranges in men's clothing have made relatively better sales progress in recent months than the lowend styles, retail store executives here have become somewhat puzzled by continuous Department of Commerce reports of substantial increases in the higher brackets.

About 250 guests attended a tea lance and reception at Rosemary. Hall, Greenwich, this afternoon. It was given by Miss Caroline RuutzRees, Mrs. George McMurtrie GodLey and Mrs. D. Walter Gibson to introduce Miss Evelyn Glass, laughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Glass of Old Church Road.
The engagement of Miss Josephine K. Herche, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank M. Herche of this place, to Lowell F. Johnson of Butler, N. J., has been announced by her parents.

Alabama's glorious Rose Bowl reoord lost some of its luster today when the Crimson Tide was conquered by California's powerful football team. The score was 13-0. It was the Southern university's first defeat in the five Tournament of Roses gridiron games its teams have played.

Mr. and Mrs. Frank H. Deknatel entertained today with a tea at their home here at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Elizabeth Deknatel, to Herbert Henry Smith Hinman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Platt Hinman of Alhambra, Calif.

Mr. and Mrs. Winchester Britton of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter,, Miss Floyd Tyler Britton, to Donald Edwin Ward of Baltimore. Miss Britton attended Drake Institute. She is a descendant of prominent colonial families of New England, Maryland and Virginia.

As the result of enforced closing, voluntary vacating or demolishing of more than 6,000. "old law" tenement houses in New York during the last four years, the number of occupied old tenement houses has been reduced from more than 66,000 in 1934 to less than 60,000 today,

Assets of Connecticut College total ing $5,099,637 were reported by President Katharine Blunt in her annual statement to the board of trustees which has just been is sued. This represents an increase of $838,450 over last year.
NOT to be outdone by his compatriots, Thomas Moore and, more recently, James Hilton, Mr. Geoffrey Household has embarked

Optimistic predictions of a revival in the building industry during 1938 were voiced yesterday by HerberAbrahams, president of the Ruberold Company, building supplies manufacturers, and Clarence A. Smith 2d, chairman of the committee on public information of the Delaware Chapter of the American Institute of Architects.

If the United States should go to war again, the army expects to mobolize more than twice as quickly as it died in 1917. Colonel Louis Johnson, Assistant Secretary of War, says that if hostilities should start tomorrow 300,000 trained soldiers could be put into the field immediately.

The sociologists must have been somewhat disappointed in the symposium on "Science and Society" arranged by the American Association for the Advancement of Science. Long ago they told us that it is not the fault of science that its discoveries have made it possible to produce more goods than we can consume, and that high explosives and deadly gases were devised for use in peace rather than in war.
Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Bradley Murray and their debutante daughters the Misses Therese and Rosamond Murray, will leave later this month for the Boca Raton Club, Florida, for a stay of several weeks.

The year just ended was a bad one for marriages in the city, judging from the annual figures just made public by Deputy City Clerk Philip A. Hines, In. 1987 the applications for licenses were 29,250, against 30,425 obtained in 1936.
Dartmouth scored a clean sweep in its two-day intercollegiate ski meet with the University of Washington, winning four of five places in the downhill event today, lastof the team contests.

The Debutantes' New Year's Ball, an event of several years' standings took place last night in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. The ball is arranged each Winter similarly to other subscription dances which have a large patronage of debutantes and young men. Occasionally a few young women make their formal debuts at this Party.

THE HISTORY OF MILITARISM: Romance and Reality of a Profession. By Dr. Alfred Vagts. Illustrated. New York: W. W. Norton Co. $4.75. By HOFFMAN NICKERSON ADDITIONS to the small number of books dealing with the sociology of war--that is,

Brown University yachtsmen look forward today toward having one of the most complete headquarters for undergraduate sailing in the East, as work began on the modernization and improvement of the Narragansett Boat Club on the Seekonk River.

PALM BEACH, Fla.-With the holiday rush behind them and the younger set back in school, colonists are turning to the sports and social and cultural activities that follow, with a few variations, the same general pattern each season.

Any misgivings about the internal situation in Germany at the beginning of the new year are wholly offset by a sense of triumph in the international field. There is no doubt that official Germany is feeling quite cocky about this. It is felt that the new Reich is really getting somewhere.

Unaccustomed to having any question raised of the righteousness and wisdom of the doings of its State Government, Connecticut now finds a whole series of investigations being directed at the conduct of the State Highway Department on the Merritt Parkway.

THE Chicago Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Frederick Stock, will present its thirty-third annual Theodore Thomas memorial program this week in Chicago, Ill. The works chosen for performance are Beethoven's overture to "Prometheus," Sixth symphony and Strauss's "Ein Heldenleben."

Plans for a world-wide boycott of Japanese goods by trades unions and cooperatives were adopted by the executive committee of the International Peace Campaign in London on Dec. 15, and the committee voted unanimously to put the boycott into effect yesterday, it was disclosed yesterday by Paul M. Reid, executive secretary of the American League for Peace and Democracy.

The number of retail departments scoring either substantial sales increases or an improved profit showing has-been much smaller in 1937 than in the preceding year, according to estimates in well-informed retail quarters.

Reporting that the sales of fabricated copper and its alloys in the United States last year were the second largest in history, C. Donald Dallas, vice president and treasurer of the Copper and Brass Research Association, and in a yearend review of the industry that the general outlook for 1938 would depend largely on the attitude of the Administration in Washington toward business.
Arriving buyers may register in this Column by telephoning LAckawanna 4-1000.

Mr. and Mrs. J. Robert Wiss of South Orange announced today the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Charlotte Wiss, to Waldron M. Ward Jr. of Summit. The announcement was made at a tea for 100 guests at the Wiss home.

A modern locomotive, operating under its own power on rollers will be a feature of the exhibits in the Railroad Transportation Building which will be erected at the World's Fair by twenty-six Eastern railroads under the sponsorship of the Eastern Presidents Conference, it was announced yesterday as architectural drawings of the building were made public.

Consumption of burlap in the United States in 1937 probably exceeded that of 1986 by about 81,000,000 yards, C. E. Rockstroh Co., estimated. Consumption in 1936 was 785,000,000 yards, and in the first eleven months of 1937 it was 806,000,000 yards.

Production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 19 per cent of capacity, against 28 per cent for the five working days of the preceding week. A large drop is recorded, because while Christmas always has been observed strictly as a steel-mill holiday, New Year's Day has not been, whereas consumers observe both days.
Aggressive, hopeful planning, held in check by wise financial measures, should supply a successful 1938 merchandising formula, according to Mrs. Hortense M. Odlum, president of Bonwit Teller Co.

The mutual savings banks, having experienced a year of progress in 1937, look forward to stability in 1938, Philip A. Benson, president of the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn and first vice president of the American Bankers Association, said in a discussion of the savings outlook, issued yesterday.

J. J. Hackett Jr., secretary of the First Avenue Association, announced yesterday that the group had filed with the Manhattan Bureau of Buildings a demand that the city oust the automobile parking business from the site of the old Consumers Brewery in Sutton Place South,
In his address broadcast tonight on the eve of the opening of Congress, Senator La Follette said the major question before Congress was action to ease unemployment.

Neville Laski, president of the Jewish Board of Deputies, said tonight that neither he nor his associates knew of plans for a meeting of leading Jews from various countries to map a "counter-offensive" against persecutors of Jews in Fascist countries.

Trading in grain futures on the Board of Trade here last week, while 13,310,000 bushels in excess of the preceding week, was less than half of the 248,020,000 bushels sold a year ago, when business was abnormally active for the last week in December.
Convicts-a majority of Alabama's 550 "most worthy" ones-drifted back to prisons today to keep a "word-of-honor" agreement to return from Christmas paroles on time.

While they may differ as to the basic causes of eccentrio markets, experts agree that thinness has magnified minor dips into collapses and tentative recoveries into sharp advances. In Wall Street, thinness means a paucity of interest on either side of the market, with too few orders on the one hand to act

Mrs. Rebecca Rabinowitz, 45 years old, died yesterday at Trinity Hospital, Brooklyn, of injuries suffered in a leap from a window during a fire early Sunday in a three-story frame building at 271. New Jersey Avenue, East New York.

In spite of-the fact that 1937 generally was disappointing to manufacturers. of knitted outerwear, the industry looks forward with renewed optimism this year, according to Iser P. Cohen, president of the Cohen Brothers Corporation.
The official German news agency reported today that Chancellor Adolf Hitler had sent Pope Pius XI his personal and the government's official best wishes for the New Year.

The improvement and modernization of railroad equipment continued at a fast pace in 1937 and the year saw the number of lightweight, streamlined steam and motor-driven trains in service reach the highest total to be attained. The volume of orders for rolling stock placed by the . railroads showed a decline from 1936, however.

Except for a profit-taking reaction on Wednesday, prices on the Boerse this week were firm. Among the favored securities were Reichsbank shares and also those of I. G. Farbenindustrie, Siemens Halske and other electrical. Besides, there was an especially sharp rise in certain lignite stocks.

Peru in 1937 made steady progress and its general prosperity was marred by scarcely a sign of political discontent. In that respect it differed from the closing months of 1936 when the annulment of the Presidential election led to the

If the American reaction were to be checked, there is nothing in Great Britain's position to suggest anything in the nature of an important setback. Even in the event of a large-scale movement of gold from the United States to Europe, a decided stimulus to European trade should be provided.
The publishers of The. Wichita (Kan.) Beacon announced yesterday that they had sent the following telegram to Secretary Ickes "answering criticism of American newspapers":

Racing in New York continued to march on to new high levels in attendance, amount of money distributed to owners and taxes paid to the State last year, as well as accomplishing a number of important reforms for the benefit of the sport, according to the annual report of the State Racing Commission filed yesterday with Secretary of State Edward J. Flynn.

Market prices of government securities at the time of the Treasury's December financing had recovered about one-third of the losses in the early months of the year, according to Vincent H. Herrmann of C. J. Devine Co., Inc., specialists in government securities, in a review of the 1937 market.

Detectives John Deas and G. J. Davis said tonight that $27,000 in jewels was stolen with the purse of Mrs. Clara Austin, a well-known resIdent of Old Greenwich, Conn., killed in an automobile-train crash Saturday.

Eyes were misty, voices husky at The Players, this year half a century in Gramercy Park. Along the bar drifted bits of reminiscence, the first strands of a saga woven round the passing of Don Marquis, poet, playwright and columnist.

After a twelve-day holiday adjournment, the three-member Federal court will convene here tomorrow to hear completion of the Tennessee Valley Authority's defense against eighteen private utilities challenging constitutionality of the Authority's program.

The men who make the rules for college football were here today debating regulations of the game for 1938. Their sessions were held in strict secrecy. William S. Langford, secretary of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's football rules committee, said a complete draft would be ready for announcement "probably some time tomorrow afternoon."

George W. Mason, president of Nash-Kelvinator Corporation, reports that production of cars increased more than 109 per cent in the year ended on Sept. 30, compared with the year before, while refrigerator sales achieved the twenty-third consecutive year of continuously increasing sales.

Even a light upturn in business this year will find the machine tool manufacturers again searching for trained mechanics and compelled to offer long deliveries to their customers, according to Tell Berna,

The Women's Committee of the National Conference of Jews and Christians will discuss "The Future of Religion in America" Wednesday morning at the Hotel McAlpin. Mrs. Andrew J. Noe, president of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs, will preside.

A half-hour memorial broadcast was held last night over the National Broadcasting Company networks in honor of Newton D. Baker, Secretary of War during the world conflict. Tribute was paid to Mr. Baker by speakers talking from Washington, New York, Arizona and Paris.

Cardinal Mundelein tonight called on the Catholic Church to rally behind the working man and urged churchmen, "with a Christian conscience," to rally to the ballot box and vote for those who seek to advance social justice.

With a stop in Los Angeles and a tour of the Hollywood movie lots still on their itinerary, Eastern football stars who played a scoreless tie with the West in the annual New Year's Day charity game left tonight on their return journey.

A number of uncertainties enter into any prediction regarding the prospects of the grocery industry for 1938, Paul S. Willis, president of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., said in a year-end statement.

The Brookhattans went into the lead in the American group, Metropolitan Division, of the American Soccer League yesterday when they defeated the Philadelphia Passons by 5-4 at Starlight Park in ankledeep mud before 5,000 fans.
Mr. and Mrs. Albert L. Pope of this city have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Pope, to Dr. Robert Walker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles P. Walker of New Haven.

The Hayden Planetarium of the American Museum of Natural History announced yesterday that beginning today weekday visitors to the afternoon performances not only will see the wonders of space in the planetarium dome but also will be taken on a "trip through the solar system."
Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, again takes up the defense of the gold standard in an article published in the Journal of German Law.
Humane Society officials moved tonight to end the three-day vigil kept by a mongrel over the body of another dog in a vacant lot here.

The publication of "Helping to End Economic Discrimination," a report on Jewish non-employment prepared by Rabbi J. X. Cohen, chairman of the Commission on Economic Problems of the American Jewish Congress, was announced yesterday by Dr. Stephen S. Wise, president of the American Jewish Congress.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is conceded that any Administration heading the government will always do its best to serve the public. No Administration can be 100 per cent perfect.

January was marked by the beginning of heavy floods in the river valleys of the Middle West, which greatly impeded for the moment steel production and transportation; also, more particularly by the "sitdown strike" at the General Motors plants in Flint, Mich.,

The year 1937 was one of the most difficult in which to operate in his many years of experience in the food business, Joseph Wilshire, chairman of the board of Standard Brands, Inc., says in his annual statement on conditions.

Miss Emma Christina Mann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ellery Wilson Mann, was married here this afternoon at the home of her parents to Henry de Villiers Williams Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Williams of Hempstead.

Petitions aimed at the overthrow of the powerful "Moran faction" of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association were being circulated yesterday by supporters of Ray A. Donovan of the Fourth Avenue police station, Brooklyn, candidate for the presidency.

The most encouraging factor for the development of sound prosperity in 1938 is the sincere effort that business and government are making to cooperate with each other, the result of which will mean solving the problems that have been holding back the development of business, according to Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Chamber of Commerce and president of the International Business Machines Corporation.

Kate Smith's Original Celtics lost twice at the Hippodrome last night, where a crowd of 3,500 persons saw them bow to the Akron (Ohio) Firestones, 52-46, in a game played under collegiate rules, and to the Kingston (N. Y.) Celtics, 46-36, in the regularly scheduled American Basketball League encounter.
The following were the best sellers for the week ended Saturday:
Principal Keeper P. H. Quinlan of Great Meadows Prison at Comstock announced tonight the recapture of two escaped convicts.

Several months ahead of the customary period, Fidelio Brewery will today introduce Bock beer to consumers in the metropolitan area and is making plans for an extensive advertising campaign to promote this innovation. Last year.

William A. Blinn, 54 years old, veteran Chicago newspaper man, died today at his home after a short illness of heart disease. Mr. Blinn, a native of Kentucky, began his newspaper work in Cincinnati, and came to Chicago in 1914. During the war years he was city editor of the old Journal and later was turf writer for the

In the avalanche-ridden district of Lake O'Hara, John Bulyea, young Edmonton skier, was swept to death on Friday and a companion, Bob Hind, also of Edmonton, narrowly escaped the same fate, it became known here today.
Glove importers and manufacturers closed 1937 with a sales volume running somewhat under that of 1936 on a dollar basis, although the first half of the year showed substantial increases.

The appeal of Bishop Manning for funds with which to complete the Sanctuary and Choir in harmony with the present "majestic Nave" of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine should evoke instant response.

Declining industrial operations throughout the country in the latter half of last year cut consumer income so deeply that only in the South and the Southwest were retail sales maintained at levels sharply above 1936, and there were many districts which showed losses in the last few months.

Sudden increases in railroad expenses in 1937 necessitate rate increases if the "new era of railroading" is to be continued, A. D. McDonald, president of the Southern Pacific Company, says in a review of the year.

In wide-world communication, in broadcasting and in the creation of instruments essential not alone for its own use but for the many branches of science and industry as well, the year-end finds radio everywhere more highly regarded than ever before as a dependable public servant,

A combination of "poor political sense and poor business sense,"William J. Cameron of the Ford Motor Company charged tonight, is interfering with America's business progress. He declared in a radio address that the "second-string" business man to whom business is a "springboard to something more congenial" helped to "invent" the New Deal.

Frederick G. Beach, dean of Rochester advertising men and for more than fifty years an employee of The Democrat and Chronicle, died last night at the age of 84. Mr. Beach was advertising manager for more than thirty years, relinquishing that title ten years ago to prepare advertising copy exclusively.

The system of private enterprise under which the United States has developed depends upon the accumulation of savings by persons and corporations and the investment of these savings in industry and commerce, George H. Houston, president of the Baldwin

James C. Ledbetter, in 12 E 88th St; John H. Thompson, in 114 E 71st St; Edward G. Miller Jr, in 169 E 69th St; Elizabeth B. Blair, in 158 W 58th St; M. S. Dave, in 245 W 74th St; Mrs. Cecile Lidz, in 215 W 78th St: Maria Clara Hunerasky, in 230 Riverside Drive; Miss Pearl Lewis, Mrs. Annette Meyer, in 267 W 70th St; Pease Elliman, Inc. brokers.

A General Court Martial will convene here tomorrow to try Brig. Gen. Harold C. Reisinger, Marine Corps, on charges of Irregularities in his personal travel accounts. The court martial originally was ordered for last October, then postponed until December and again to Jan. 3.

Two crew members of the yacht Aafje, survivors with four others of a cruise of murder and terrorism, will be arraigned tomorrow on charges of slaying Jack Morgan, who took charge of the vessel after killing Dwight L. Faulding, the owner.

Automotive taxes collected in 1937 set a record for all time with about $1,550,000,000, or more than the total tax bill of the nation in 1900, according to Baird H. Markham, director of the American Petroleum Industries Committee.
Canada has been more fortunate than the United States from the point of view of business activity, according to Lieut. Col. J. E. McKenna, M. C., chairman of the Montreal Stock Exchange.

No agency in the city government is more likely to leave a permanent impression on the kind and quality of life in our five boroughs than the City Planning Commission. The commission's membership, as announced by Mayor La Guardia, is surety that a good job of work will be done.

The year just closed has seen a high-water mark reached in resale price maintenance legislation, according to Frank L. Weil of Well, Gotshal Manges, counsel for the Retail Dry Goods Association of New York. The Miller-Tydings law enacted by Congress, he said, legalizes such "price fixing" in interstate commerce and forty-two States have enacted such laws.

Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek has given up the premiership to devote all his time to prosecution of the war, the Chinese Government announced today at Chungking, one of China's emergency capitals. This was taken by Chinese circles as an indication of the government's determination to continue resistance.

Total revenue from customers of the electric power and light industry in the United States during 1937 was about $2,200,000,000, compared to $2,044,586,900 in 1936, an increase of 7.6 per cent, according to the Edison Electric Institute.

It is unlikely that Arturo Toscanihi has conducted in this city with more blazing intensity than he exhibited Saturday night when he gave his second concert with the NBC Symphony Orchestra in Radio City.
The Federal Trade Commission has announced hearings for this week in New York City as follows: Fashion Originators Guild of America, Inc., New York, and others-Monday, Jan. 3, 10 A. M., 45 Broadway.
Up to the yearend, German official and private experts described the American business setback as normal reaction in the course of prolonged recovery.

An important Van Dyck, "The Abbe Scaglia Adoring Virgin and Child," has been presented to the National Gallery by Anthony de Rothschild in memory of his great aunt, Louisa Lady de Rothschild, and her daughter, Constance Lady Battersea.

Mr. and .Mrs. Frederick H. Vahtsing of Forest Hills, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Vahlsing, to Henry Frelinghuysen Schenk, son of Mrs. Henry F. Schenk of Flemington, N. J., and the late Mr. Schenk.

Last year witnessed the largest single day's turnover in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange in more than sixteen years. It occurred on March 12, when total transactions amounted to $35,199,200, the largest since Dec. 30, 1920.

Due to the lengthy task of compiling the 600,000 words of Sir Hall Caine's "Life of Christ," Doubleday, Doran has announced that publication of this volume of nearly 1,500 pages, originally scheduled for March, will be postponed until later in the year.

With the old year out of the way the grain trade is commencing to pay attention to the outlook for business in the first half of 1938 with somewhat mixed feelings. The trends of the wheat and corn markets are expected to be influenced to a considerable extent

The Financial News Index of thirty industrial stocks, based on July 1, 1935, as 100, on Dec. 30 stood at 96, compared with 97.5 a week before, 98 a month ago, 124.6 a year ago, the high record of 124.9 on Nov. 18, 1936, and the low record of 41.6 in June, 1932.
Government and Insurgent advices indicated tonight that the critical battle for Teruel still raged with undiminished fury despite earlier Insurgent reports that the city had been captured.

Dividend yields on leading industrial preferred stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose with hardly an interruption in 1937, starting the year at 4.94 per cent and attaining 5.32 per cent in the first week of December.

The steel industry of the United States has found a commercial value for huge annual supplies of blast furnace slag, once a useless by-product for which research has revealed many practical uses, although the available tonnage still exceeds the demand.

Dance International brought to a close last night its five-week exposition, devoted to activities of the dance and related arts, with a huge performance at the Center Theatre in which many of the leaders in the modern dance field collaborated.

Mill activity in the knit-goods industry reached high levels early in 1937 but, like other textiles, suffered from a receding demand in the latter part of the year, and the rate of production fell below that of 1936.
The Community Mobilization for Human Needs, representing the local charitable efforts of the people of the United States, has drafted a proposal to Congress for a new relief program.

Production of Buick cars in 1937 totaled 233,923 units, an increase of 27 per cent over 184,255 cars produced in 1936 and the highest volume attained in ten years, according to Harlow E. Curtice, president of the Buick division of General Motors Corporation.

The division of placement and unemployment insurance of the State Labor Department got its first concrete indication of the extent of joblessness in the metropolitan area yesterday when 140,000 filled-out applications for unemployment insurance benefits cascaded into the division's offices at 342 Madison Avenue.

The efficient manner in which members of the industry met the sudden change in the business situation last year was an outstanding feature of the trade's experience in 1937 and has great significance so far as 1938 is concerned, according to Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc.
Under severe regimentation, the German capital market of 1937 yielded large sums for funding the Reich debt, but little for private investment.

Hopes of approaching stability in world monetary affairs which were evoked toward the end of 1936 by the establishment of the tripartite currency agreement were confounded by the events of the last year.

In the hope of turning "kids on the. road" back to their families and of making up for eighty-five years of neglect of his name, the Hoboes of America started a drive tonight to have memorials erected to the author of "Home, Sweet Home."

Improvement in buyer-seller relationships was an outstanding feature of the year just closed, according to Milton J. Greenebaum, of Felix Lilienthal Co., and president of the Association of Buying Offices.

An old man, rabbi of the Dean Street Temple, Brooklyn, returned to St. John's Hospital yesterday morning with a testimonial penned and illuminated in water-colors by him in token of his gratitude to the institution for saving his life when he was stricken with heart disease last Summer.
The lull of the holiday season In art galleries is to be followed this week by a considerable quickening of activity. Several group shows are on the roster.

Although the Middle West was at first skeptical of reports regarding business recession in the East, their continued repetition and the fact that it is reaching farther West have made the average business man of this section nervous and unwilling to expand operations. Retrenchment in em.

A distinct air of conservatism marks the opinions of the directors of the Merchants Association of New York, which are included in the association's annual symposium of business developments and the outlook for 1938.
Development of new synthetic products was the principal activity in 1937 of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., a survey issued by the company showed.

The statement of the banking firm of J. P. Morgan Co. and its associates, Drexel Co. of Philadelphia, for Dec. 31 shows deposits of $394,997,148, compared with $478,922,407 at the end of 1936. Total resources were $457,111,631, against $550,338,618.

Listed bond values in 1937 moved over the widest range experienced in many years. The combined price average of representative domestic corporate bonds reached the high mark for the year of 90.74 on Jan. 16.

With a background of probably fairly good prices for all farm commodities during at least the first six months of 1938, Chicago trade leaders are inclined to look for some improvement in conditions, to develop shortly after the turn of the year.

The air conditioning industry's biggest year, so far as engineering and commercial activity and increased acceptance by the public are concerned, has been marked by definite characteristics, according to J. J. Donovan, manager of the air conditioning department of the General Electric Company.

Recessions in the light manufacturing industries such as the dress trade are likely to prove temporary due to the flexibility of operation that enables firms in those fields to adjust themselves to conform to changed conditions, according to Morris Kolchin; executive director of the Affiliated Dress Manufacturers, Inc.

Declaring that he was not pessimistic over the outlook for the petroleum industry in 1938, Colonel T. H. Barton, president of the Lion Oil Refining Company of Arkansas, said the demand for petroleum products should suffer as little as any of the essential commodities if the business recession continued.

Gracie Fields beamed the expansive smile that made her fortune and exclaimed, "Oo 'eck, look what I've got now, motherr" as she learned that King George had made her a commander of the Order of the British Empire in the New Year's honors list.

Mrs. Blance Gibbs Cook, wife of Howard Bell Cooks senior partner in Haskins Sells, accountants, died Saturday at her home, 277 Park Avenue, at the age of 56. Also surviving are a son, Howard A., and three daughters, Mrs. Arthur Forester, Miss Blanche Cook and Mrs. Iredell Jenkins of New Orleans.

The total number of pure nickel coins which have been placed in circulation since Switzerland adopted this metal in 1881 is approaching 4,500,000,000 pieces, according to an estimate by the International Nickel Company.

Characterizing the policy of collective security as impossible of realization and likely to lead to war if pursued in active form, Norman Thomas, in an address over station WEVD last night, urged a policy of official neutrality by the United States plus a popular boycott of Japan as a practical means of checkmating her aggression in China.

The nation's first census of the unemployed, which showed that a total of 7,822,912 persons had registered either as totally unemployed while desiring work or as employed on work relief projects, listed New York State as having the largest number of unemployed of any State in the country, according to a supplemental report made public today. by John D. Biggers, director of the special voluntary census.

Activity in the electrical manufacturing industry last year came within 5 per cent of the 1929 peak despite a severe drop in general business during the Fall, W. J. Donald, managing director of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association, said yesterday in a statement prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES.
Callfornia's victorious Golden Bears celebrated today, Alabama wearily headed south and the twenty-third chapter was written into the records of the Rose Bowl football classic.

Miss Anne Lindsay Allen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Porter Allen of Bronxville, N. Y., was married here Saturday to Hugo Herz of New York. The ceremony was performed in Christ Church by Dr. Alexander Griswold Cummins.

George R. Jacobus, president of the Professional Golfers Association, today praised the fourteen-club ruling that went into effect yesterday as a benefit to the amateur golfer and not harmful to the professionals' play.

One of the most disastrous weeks ever experienced by local college basketball teams saw C. C. N. Y. and N. Y. U. toppled from the ranks of the unbeaten, leaving only Columbia, which was idle, with a perfect record.

The Schroder Trust Company, central paying agent here, has been notified by the cash office of foreign credit in Budapest, Hungary, that it will redeem at $8.75 each semi-annual coupons dated Jan. 1 detached -from each $1,000 bond of the following series:

Although the final week of the year brought to Germany no important event in domestic business, sentiment was predominantly optimistic. This feeling was ascribable in part to reports of extremely favorable operations by commercial banks and expectations of dividend increases.
Corporate borrowing in 1937 through the medium of stock offerings reached $446,697,000, the largest volume of stock financing since 1930, when flotations aggregated $730,692,236.

Declaring that 1937 closed in an atmosphere of doubt and concern, Francis E. Frothingham, president of the Investment Bankers Association of America, urged in a yearend statement that the government take immediate steps to relieve the present fears and uncertainties of business.
Imports of black pepper were estimated to have fallen sharply in 1937, and last available figures showed a drop of 4,000,000 pounds in the first nine months.

Billy Foales led his Silver Brook indoor polo team to an 18-to-9 victory over the Governors Island trio today at the Red Bank Armory. The victors made six counters in the first period and added six in the second. Foales was the top scorer with nine goals.
The State Department has begun preparation of a public notice of intention to negotiate a trade agreement with Great Britain.
Despite a sharp recession in sales in the latter half of 1937, production of all types of papers just about equaled the record-breaking year of 1936, according to manufacturers.
A State Police squad under Lieutenant Lord Nelson arrested fifty men on charges of participating a cockfight today, following an early morning raid on a barn in Chautauqua Township.

The "hat trick," ambition of all hockey players, was achieved by young Toe Blake tonight as the Montreal Canadiens defeated the Chicago Black Hawks, 4 to 2, in a hotly contested National League battle before 12,000 fans at the Stadium.

Bishop Thomas E. Molloy of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn announced at vespers yesterday afternoon at St. Rose of Lima's Church, 269 Parkville Avenue, Brooklyn, the launching of a diocesan convert movement to explain Catholicism to non-Catholics.
Mexico is now seeking an entirely new basis for her future relations with the United States and is throwing over the major agreements that have long governed relations between the two countries.
Frederick W. Gardiner has been appointed chief engineer for the receiver of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver, announced yesterday.

A 10 to 20 per cent decline in the sales of men's clothing in industrial centers and a smaller drop in agricultural sections was forecast by William Goldman, president of Cohen, Goldman Co. There is little chance of an improvement in wool prices in 1938 and they will probably fluctuate within a narrow range, he said.

H. Hughart Laughlin, former director of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation and a grandson of one of the company's founders, died yesterday at the age of 59. He was active in the Y. M. C. A. and served on the organization's metropolitan board.
Despite the sharp decline in business activity in the last three months of 1937, the earnings of the oil industry as a whole for the full year were the best since 1929.

Harry Mendel, sports promoter, and two prominent New Jersey business men today offered Joe Louis $100,000 to defend his heavyweight boxing title against Tony Galento, New Jersey champion, in the Atlantic City Auditorium some time during March or April. The Auditorium has a seating capacity of 42,000.

After narrowly missing the Yankee Stadium, a subway kiosk and elevated tracks at 161st Street, Troy W. Newkirk, 40-year-old Negro flier, and Miss Lola Jackson, his flying companion, 30, crashed their tiny plane yesterday

The market for real estate securities in 1937 experienced the phenomenon of a substantially downward price trend in the face of steadily improving operating results and wide-spread instances of increased interest distribution, according to H. R. Amott,

Credit men generally might be quoted as being of the impression that business will return in good order early in the Fall of 1938, according to a statement prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men.
Eight persons were caught in an avalanche this morning on the 6,000-foot Schneeberg, only one and a half hours from here. This afternoon the bodies of four Viennese and one German had been recovered.

Net income of $1,807,162 is reported for the twelve months ended on Nov. 30 by the Central Maine Power Company, compared with $1,650,315 in the calendar year 1936. Operating income was $6,810,627, against $6,617,013.

Prophecy concerning the outlook in the United States perhaps is as hazardous now as at any time in the history of the markets. It is instinctively felt here that the present depression is overdone, but in the general fog hanging over the situation it is almost impossible to see ahead.

The trading rules and contracts on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange are being studied constantly with a view to providing equal possibilities for both buyer and seller and to meet present-day conditions, according to Chandler A. Mackey,
There is substantial ground for sound belief that 1938 will witness wholesome business progress, according to Maurice Rentner, chairman of the Fashion Originators Guild of America, Inc.

Leading communication companies directed efforts principally toward a wider use of services available rather than new construction during 1937, with the result that the improvement of existing plant and facilities served to place the varlous systems in peak condition.

The net proceeds of the performance tomorrow afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House of "Tristan and Isolde" will be used for the maintenance of the Florence Crittenton League, a shelter for young women at 427 West Twentyfirst Street.

During the last year the consumer cooperative movement has been characterized by continued growth in the rural areas and unprecedented growth in cities, according to Flint Garrison, executive vice president of the Consumer Distribution Corporation, which was organized by the late Edward A. Filene to support a group of cooperative department stores.

One reason for the crowding of Sing Sing is suggested in the announcement today that 480 former prisoners were returned to Sing Sing in 1987 for violation of parole, 119 more than were. sent back in 1936.

Exports of scrap iron and steel from the United States last year are estimated to have attained 4,000,000 tons, a new record. This contrasted with exports of about 3,500,000 tons of semi-finished and finished iron and steel products and nearly 1,600,000 tons of iron ore.

Taking a stand against extension of the spoils system, the League of Women Voters announced today that it would fight the McKellar bill, "which would return first, second and third class postmasterships to the patronage lists."

Inventories of raw materials and manufactured goods last year showed a tendency to rise slightly above the bottom figures recorded in 1935 and 1936 but remained measurably below those for every other year back to 1928.

Dictatorial control of the press was denounced yesterday by Carl W. Ackerman, dean of the Columbia University School of Journalism, as a "black plague" threatening world peace. Mr. Ackerman depicted the wide epidemic of censorshin and suppression in a world
The nineteen-ton Samoan Clipper carrying the first Australia-America airmail cargo, arrived here at 4:45 P. M. (10:15 P. M. E. S. T.) from Pago Pago, Samoa.

Soviet citizens will not be permitted to leave the Reich in the future without a special exit visa. Germany is now the only country, excepting Russia herself, which has such a requirement for foreigners but it applies only to Russians.
In an exhibition soccer match at Scots Field today the team representing the Trenton Highlanders defeated a picked eleven of the American League by 2-1.

Seven young persons, all of high school age, were killed tonight in this Northeastern Indiana town as the automobile in which they were riding crashed through crossing gates into the path of a speeding passenger train.

William J. Ford, 51 years old, was found dead of gas poisoning in his apartment here early this morning. The police, who listed the death as accidental, said Ford had prepared to make a pot of tea and had fallen asleep while waiting for the water to boil.

Wilhelmus B. Bryan of Washington, D. C., has announced the marriage of his daughter, Miss Elizabeth Ewing Bryan, to the Rev. William D. Barnes of this city and Salem, Mass. The ceremony was performed yesterday at the home of the bride in Washington by the Rev. W. B. Bryan, brother of the bride, who is a student pastor at Princeton Seminary.
Magistrate Irving Ben Cooper, who was appointed and sworn in by Mayor La Guardia at City Hall on Saturday, succeeds to the unexpired term of former Magistrate Henry H. Curran, now Deputy Mayor.
Farmers are not the only ones interested in soil conservation. The butcher, the baker, the family doctor and the banker are all keeping an eye on this new trend in agriculture.
Dutch financiers believe that the American situation, after a much too violent boom and recession during 1937, is now gradually clearing up, though at a lower level.
Net profits of B. Kuppenheimer Co., Inc., for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 30, amounted to $75,666 after all deductions, compared with $112,078 for the preceding year.

Colonel William H. Patterson, in charge of recruiting headquarters at the Army Building, 39 Whitehall Street, announced yesterday the recruiting service would begin today to enlist 2,350 young, unmarried men for foreign service, the largest such quota in many months.
Ronaid Conrad, 26, of Trappe, shot and killed himself early today near the wreckage of a borrowed automobile he had been driving, Sheriff Samuel Carroll said.

The country's investment trusts since Aug. 14 have gone through a severe contraction in security values reminiscent of that in 1929, but thus far have experienced none of the difficulties encountered when the preliminary 1929 crash was followed by a downward spiral movement for the ensuing three years.
Announcement was made here last night of the death on Saturday of Dr. Louis Miller of 240 West Seventy-fifth Street at his Winter residence in Miami Beach, Fla. He was 55 years old.

A salvage tug pulled the Standard Vacuum oil tanker Toorak undamaged from a reef on the east coast of Cebu Island today, and the British vessel proceeded to the port of Cebu. The 5,627-ton tanker went aground last week.

Declaring the "attempt to forecast economic trends is especially hazardous at this time," David E. Moeser, president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association and treasurer of Conrad Co., Boston, contented himself with expressing several "hopes" for the new year.

Louisiana's drive to attract new industries to the State by easing the burden of taxation resulted last year in a gain of $47,000,000 in industrial enterprises which provided construction jobs for 10,000 workers and will give permanent employment to an estimated 15,000 persons, according to Governor Richard W. Leche.

While the January contract remained unchanged, other active deliveries on the New York Cotton Exchange closed last week with net losses of 2 to 5 points, holidays and year-end influences having restriicted trading.

An outstanding development in the railroad field in 1937 was the construction of a turbine locomotive by the Union Pacific Railroad. This was an extension of research in mechanism of this type by two or three European railroads.

Assailing harmful propaganda and personal bitterness in public life, Cardinal O'Connell today called on members of his church to disregard attempts by government leaders to arraign class against class.

The North Jersey Gun Club's New Year shoot today attracted a good entry. In the first fifty-target event W. M. Frederick won the high-gun trophy, L. S. Rothwell, W. N. Drake, B. E. Finch and F. S. Dean taking the handicap prizes.

Here is the status of President Roosevelt's known legislative program on the eve of the regular session of Congress: Crop Control-Passed by Senate and House and under study by a conference committee seeking to adjust differences.

The "Kansas Flier," Glenn Cunningham, racing under the colors of the New York Curb Exchange, came down the stretch with a burst of speed today to lead a strong field in the featured mile run of the annual Sugar Bowl track carnival in record-breaking time.

The dilemma facing the world today is the decision whether our religion shall be the religion of the state or the worship of Jesus Christ, the Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street, said in his sermon yesterday morning.

Automobile production in the United States this year was the second highest on record, with an output estimated at 4,975,000 units, according to Alfred Reeves, vice president and general manager of the Automobile Manufacturers Association, the high record having been 5,621,715 cars and trucks produced in 1929.

What promised to be the best year for general business since 1929 was witnessed in the Middle West during the first six months of 1937. But the tremendous impetus given to trade in that period by heavy government expenditure and resultant plant

Students and alumni of Kent School, at a special service yesterday morning were urged to carry through life the deep religious beliefs formed at school and to draw from that source the divine power to guide their lives.

The threatened scarcity of longterm municipal financing will tend to sustain the price structure of the municipal bond market, according to Bernard J. Larkin, vice president of Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.

President Anastasio Somoza announced today that all troops had been withdrawn from the Honduras border in accordance with the recent agreement made through the United States, Costa Rica and Venezuela as mediators.

As the demand for steel is a measure of activity in so many of our industrial enterprises, the sharp decline in steel operations in the closing months of 1937 reflected a letdown in general activities, according to Tom M. Girdler,

Decentralized administration of unemployment relief, with the Federal Government making appropriations to the States to be administered by State and local governments in accordance with certain basic standards,

Taking 1937 as a whole, the Dutch market has sold American securities on balance. Its holdings of Americans had assumed too large proportions, owing to an expected further strong increase in American prosperity.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I live with my wife and one child in a three-room, steam-heated apartment, to which I have been accustomed in pre-depression days.

As a result of our great harvest and despite the smaller yield in Canada and Argentina, the world's wheat crop will be the largest since 333-34. But the net amount of grain available showed little change from the previous season.

Although Dekker called it "The Shoemakers' Holiday," the Mercury Theatre has translated it into the Gotham playgoer's holiday by the originality and gusto of the acting. To "Julius Caesar," a terrifying tragedy, now add an uproarious comic strip of Elizabethan fooling.

The Federal Home Loan Bank of New York has paid a semi-annual dividend at the annual rate of 2 per cent on its outstanding capital stock for the six months ended on Dec. 31, it was announced yesterday by George MacDonald, chairman of-the board of directors.

With shipments of automobile tires substantially the same, an increase in the demand for other rubber products caused sales volume in the rubber industry last year to be the best for any year since 1929, according to S. B. Robertson, president of the B. F. Goodrich Company.

Four four-story apartment houses at 56 to 62 La Salle Street, near Amsterdam Avenue, were sold by the Dry Dock Savings Institution to Retlaw Management, Inc., for altering into sixty-four two-room apartments at a cost of $40,000. M.

Lieutenant Ellis V. Brown, for the last fourteen years an officer of the Delaware Hudson Railroad police, died today at the age of 63. He was a native of Harrisburg, Pa., and also served on the Oneonta (N. Y.) police force. He was assistant captain of the D. H. pistol team which took part in many matches.

The year 1938 opens with the food industries of the country somewhat discouraged by small profits, bargain selling and the danger of higher labor costs, but looking forward to sustained volume "with a nice upward trend" during the closing months of the year, according to a statement by Gordon C. Corbaley, president of the American Institute of Food Distribution. Mr. Corbaley said in his forecast:

Factory sales of new Willys cars aggregated more than $30,000,000 in the first twelve months of operations of Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., which began business on Oct. 8, 1936, following reorganization of the predecessor company, David R. Wilson, president, reports.

Public hearings are to be held in five cities of the State on a proposed revision of the Code of Criminal Procedure, recently completed by the Commission on the Administration of Justice, it was announced yesterday by Senator John L. Buckley, chairman of the commission.

While 1937 produced notable records in business activity in Great Britain, the year ends with hesitancy and doubts concerning the future. There is seriousness behind the levity which prompts the remark that business is suffering from Columbus's discovery of America.

In many ways, 1937 has been for England a year of striking contrasts in behavior of the financial as distinct from the business world. Trade, especially domestic, continued to expand in many directions; overt seas business also yielded increasingly satisfactory results.

Industrial disputes of 1937 cost the workers involved a monetary wage loss of more than $140,000,000, according to computations by Gustav R. Stahl, director of the industrial relations department of J. T. Trenholm Co. and formerly chief

Preparation of Spring lines for the expected January influx of buyers occupied the attention of the New York wholesale market last week. Nevertheless, the dress market was unusually active for the time of the year,
Mrs. Alton Brooks Parker has gone to St. Petersburg, Fla., to pass the remainder of the Winter. Mr. and Mrs. Sosthenes Behn will sail Wednesday from Cherbourg and will be at the Plaza for the Winter.
