Members of the guild that knows no fear, the bob-sledders, enjoyed the limelight as the heavy holiday program of ice and snow events here ended today. Despite a driving snowstorm that hampered visibility, five four-man crews thrilled the large crowds huddled along the vantage points of Mount Van Hoevenberg as they engaged in a race from the one-mile mark that officially opened the Olympic run for the season.

Activity in wool-goods mills should pick up somewhat in the next few months, but no real revival is likely until mills begin to produce for the Fall season, Arthur Besse, president of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers forecast in a statement prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The annual service in memory of the Rev. Dr. Archibald R. Mansfield, late superintendent of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York, will be held today at 11:30 A. M. in the Chapel of Our Saviour, 25 South Street.

Friends of Harry C. Hequembourg, Dunkirk philanthropist, received word today of his death at his Winter home in Hialeah, Fla. He was 75 years old. Mr. Hequembourg, former official of the American Locomotive Company, was widely known for his establishment of health camps for tubercular children in this region.

Preaching his first sermon as minister-elect of the Fort Washington Collegiate Reformed Church at Fort Washington Avenue and 181st Street, the Rev. Henry A. Vruwink said yesterday morning that assurance was essential in our lives today if we are to come through this period of general unrest stronger and more firmly resolved that the present and future are ours to be used for good.

Production of steel ingots in 1937 is estimated at 50,250,000 gross tons by Walter S. Tower, executive secretary of the American Iron and Steel Institute, who says that the figure is so close to the 1928 total of 50,325,400 tons as to leave a chance that 1937 will be the second best year for steel output in the history of the industry.

Liquidation of shoe inventories in the last few months of 1937 was so sharp that even in the event of a decline in consumer income in the early part of 1938, the probable rate of consumption still will necessitate an increase from the recent abnormally low levels of shoe production, Merrill A. Watson,

The position of wholesaling was made more secure in 1937 because the high cost of selling direct was vividly illustrated to manufacturers in the period of falling volume and prices, Henry Matter, executive secretary of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute, declared in a statement prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The Syracuse Stars lost a 4-to-2 decision tonight to the Springfield Indians in an International-American League hockey game. The Indians appeared strong and fast, after shaking off a jinx that gave them fourteen straight losses before they recovered to take the Stars for their second victory in a row. Benny Grant, Indian goalie, played in good form.

Counsel for the twenty-nine defendants indicted on Dec. 2 after a lengthy investigation of municipal affairs here will appear before Common Pleas Judge Dallas Flannagan tomorrow, the tentative date he set for the start of their trial. It is probable the trial date will be postponed at their request.

The year 1937 was the- greatest 12 months in port and postal, volume and receipts in its history. Receipts for the year amounted to $12,527,622, almost $1,000,000 more than the 1936 total of $11.590,038.
The new police regulations forbidding parking in ten crosstown streets in the midtown section will become effective at 8 o'clock this morning.
" If our pitching comes through," says Sam Breadon, "look out for a championship St. Louis Cardinal baseball team in 1938."

Breaking 99 out of 100 targets, A. L. Burns captured the high-over-all cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday. Good weather conditions brought out an excellent field, and practically all the scores were high.

Utah's snow-covered mountain ranges, a century-old obstacle to Western progress, are paying new dividends this Winter. Hundreds of visitors are turning the mountains into a vast Winter playground and pouring silver dollars into the pockets of Utah residents.

Alaska Game Commission figures today showed $2,285,710 in furs were shipped from Alaska during 1937, an increase of $379,971.95 over 1936. Frank Dufresne, executive officer, said the gain was due in large measure to the open season on marten. There were 16,969 marten pelts taken, valued at $27.35 each.

Hilary Ewing Howse, Mayor of Nashville, died today in a hospital, less than a month before his seventysecond birthday. More than twenty years of his life had been spent as the city's Chief Executive. An intestinal ailment complicated by pneumonia caused his death.

The mutual savings banks area prepared to serve more efficiently in 1938 the host of persons who find their services in keeping with their needs, Henry Bruere, president of the Bowery Savings Bank, declared in a year-end statement issued yesterday.

The New Haven Eagles helped New England's representatives in the International-American Hockey League make a grand slam in tonight's competition by winning a tight game, 2-1, from the Pittsburgh Hornets.

Congress will reconvene today after a short holiday, which has been used by several members of the Administration for a sudden assault on the "aristocratic anarchists" and the "corporate earls," who now stand accused by them of a conspiracy to create an industrial depression for the purpose of "liquidating the New Deal."

An unwillingness "to pay the price" of solving today's economic problems was characterized as "the blind spot in today's economic confusion" by the Rev. Frank Curtis Williams in a sermon yesterday morning at the First Methodist Episcopal Church, Henry and Clark Streets, Brooklyn.

A court holiday in General and Special Sessions Courts, possibly of two or three days, appeared likely yesterday as District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey and members of his staff worked on the files of cases scheduled for early trial.
The year just closed was one of new records for the American petroleum industry, according to Axtell J. Byles, president of the American Petroleum Institute.

Theodore F. Krug, for more than fifty years a leading business man here, died last night at his home at the age of 84. He was one of the developers and administrators of the Maryland Institute. For half a century he was head of the iron firm of G. Krug Sons. He also was director of the Mercantile Trust Company, the Maryland Casualty Company and was identified with many civic and fraternal organizations.

Alexander Mungle of 91-22 109th Street, Richmond Hill, machinist in the Menlo Park laboratories of the late Thomas A. Edison when the inventor was perfecting the electric light, died yesterday at Long Island College Hospital. He was 88 years old.

Commander Harrison E. Knauss, retired United States Navy officer and twice assistant judge advocate general at Washington, died of a heart ailment in his home here last night. His age was 52. Born in Easton, Pa., Commander Knauss entered the United States Naval Academy in 1903 and,
J. B. Priestley starts talking about "Time and the Conways" this evening at the Ritz Theatre, where his play opens as a transatlantic running-mate of the original production now on view in London.

After registering substantial gains during the first half of the year, advertising volume began to recede during the second six months in line with the business setback and the outlook for 1938 is somewhat unsettled, according to authorities in the field.
While closing on an uncertain note, retail trade achieved gains last year above 1936, indicating that reduction in consumer buying as yet has not paralleled the sharper recession inindustry.

A plea for the injection of new blood in the life-stream of the ministry, now made "sluggish" by the presence of men who are "intellectually incompetent," "deficient in personality" and "lacking in spiritual passion," was voiced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. William Chalmers Covert of Philadelphia in a sermon at the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue at 105th Street.
The City Bank Farmers Trust Company has been appointed registrar for 1,050,000 shares of the commoh stock of the Plymouth Oil Company.

Several influences for increasing industrial purchases of "the beatthe-gun sort" are apparent as the country enters 1938, according to a statement prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by George A. Renard, secretary-treasurer of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.

Despite the business recession, the thousands of workers in the domestio cane sugar refining industry virtually are assured of their jobs for 1938, according to Ellsworth Bunker, chairman of the United States Cane Sugar Refiners Association.

Steel production in January exceeded that of any month since August, 1929; first-quarter output was a record for the period. The subsequent downward movement was the most marked in steel-trade history.

Lack of faith is the cause of "recessions" and "depressions," the Rev. Dr. Walter Theodore Taylor, pastor of Central Baptist Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Ninety-second Street, asserted in his morning sermon yesterday.

In discussing wild-life management as a supplementary farm enterprise, Dr. Ira N. Gabrielson, Chief of the United States Biological Survey, asserts that wild life must be produced on farm lands as well as on public lands if benefits are to be perpetuated. Dr. Gabrielson made this statement in his report to the Secretary of Agriculture on Friday.

Brennon Trexler, 9-year-old son of Mr. and Mrs. George F. Trexler of 836 Morningside Road, was drowned this afternoon when his sled, a Christmas gift, went through the soft ice near the middle of Cole's Pond after a coast from a hill.

In the best racing of the Winter season, George Isdale and Sam Wetherill came through with their Class X craft today to tie for first honors in the dinghy regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club. They led in the open racing with the Class B boats and scored 13 points each.

A step that makes relief immediate and practical for families in dire need, cutting through official red tape, has been taken by the Police Department. During the hours when the regular relief agencies are closed the police in each borough may now furnish cash from a revolving fund established in each borough.
Retail sales of corsets and brassieres rose about 10 per cent in the first half of 1937 and 4 per cent in the last half, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by L. T. Warner,

The world consumption of nickel in all forms during the first ten months of 1937 amounted to about 201,000,000 pounds, an increase of 24 per cent over the corresponding period of 1936, according to Robert C. Stanley, chairman and president of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd.

British retail trade sales in November were 7.1 per cent higher than in November, 1936, compared with an increase of 0.4 per cent in October and an average increase of 7.6 per cent for ten months. There is no evidence yet of rising prices curtailing buying power.

The Boston Bruins, leaders in the American group of the National Hockey League, defeated the Red Wings of Detroit, 4 to 1, tonight, with Gordon Pettinger, former Detroit center recently traded to Boston, setting up the first two goals before 10,000 spectators.

A store of dynamite under the bed might mean uneasy sleep to most people, but to Mrs. J. O. B. Petersen, now in Montreal visiting her mother, Mrs. C. W. Trenholme, it is just one of the things one gets used to.

While Isaac I. Kashdan, titleholder, and Dr. J. Platz adjourned their game in the sixth round, S. S. Cohen took the lead in the annual tournament for the championship of the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday, defeating Oscar Tenner.

Lieut. Col. Roy H. Coles of the Signal corps, United States Army, died this morning at Walter Reed Hospital, in his fiftieth year. Colonel Coles was born in Warren, Ohio, on April 25, 1887; was graduated from West Point in 1909 and served as an officer of infantry until 1916, when he was transferred to the Signal Corps.
The boycott of Japanese goods caused Colon merchants much concern until the pre- Christmas rush cleared the shelves of Japanese merchandise.

The casualty and fire reinsurance industry had a satisfactory year in 1937, characterized by a normal growth in volume of business and an appropriate realization of profits, according to Edgar H. Boles, president of the General Reinsurance Corporation and of the North Star Insurance Company.

Mr. and Mrs. Earle T. Munkenbeck gave a tea yesterday at their home, 790 Carroll Street, Brooklyn, for their daughter, Miss Marjorie Sharp Munkenbeck, who made her debut at the Brooklyn debutante ball on Thanksgiving Eve.

The sharp business recession of the last three months of 1937 brought to an unexpectedly early end the progress toward recovery that had been made ,over several years, Oswald W. Knauth, president of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, commented.

The Continent's sowing of Winter wheat has proceeded under favorable conditions but the area is estimated the same as last year or only slightly higher, and probably this year's 41,000,000 bushels, without Russia, will not be exceeded.

A memorial service for Miss Mary Denniston will be held tonight at 8 o'clock in the James Memorial Chapel of Union Theological Seminary, Broadway and 120th Street. The service will be under the auspices of the Greater New York Federation of Churches.
Joseph Scheer, 54 years old, of 62-86 Forest Avenue, Ridgewood, Queens, a district superintendent of the Department of Sanitation, died of a heart attack yesterday while driving his automobile.

Nathaniel Schmidt, Professor Emeritus of Semitic Languages and Oriental History at Cornell, urged yesterday that our attitude toward the present Sino-Japanese conflict be "one of justice, sympathy and good-will toward both victim and oppressor."

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 83.1, which compares with 83.2 a week ago, 83.9 two weeks ago, 84.3 three weeks ago and 84.6 four weeks ago.
Sporting goods enjoyed one of the most active years in their history in 1937 and sales continued to gain even after other products had started to experience declines, according to manufacturers.

The first nine months of last year brought a gain of 35.5 per cent in this country's foreign trade, James A. Farrell, chairman of the board of the National Foreign Trade Council and former president of the United States Steel Corporation,

Barring some external catastrophe, such as a serious foreign war or an upheaval of nature, 1938 should see the resumption of the forward movement in business, according to Bernard Gimbel, president of Gimbel Brothers, Inc. Mr.

No contrast could be more complete than is presented by the industrial picture at the year-end -of 1937, compared with that at the year-end of 1936. At the present moment prediction, in the marketplace or in the walks of trade, limits itself.

Despite sharp increases in the final quarter of 1937, business failures in the United States fell just short of the 1936 total, reaching 8,973, against 9,185 for 1936, according to a compilation by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

A chemical that combustible experts later identified as one used in making up a powder for curling women's hair straightened that of detectives yesterday afternoon. Lawrence Tanenbaum of 293 East Forty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, brought the chemical to the West Sixty-eighth Street station.

The marriage of Miss Virginia Christensen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry E. Christensen of this city, to Duane Edward Steinle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Steinle, took place yesterday afternoon in St. Mark's Episcopal Church.

A variety of factors in the first half of 1937 caused considerable forward buying of crude foodstuffs by processors who wanted to assure themselves of supplies, C. M. Chester, chairman of the General Foods Corporation, said in a review of business conditions.

Peter Fick of New York, Miss Katherine Rawls of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Miss Dorothy Forbes of Philadelphia-all national swimming champions-bettered three American records in the Miami Biltmore Country Club pool today.

The cosmetics and toilet goods industry, which a year ago looked forward with confidence to continued improvement throughout 1937, found its expectations realized, according to H. L. Brooks, president of the Toilet Goods Association and general manager of Coty, Inc.

John Barbirolli completed his eleventh consecutive week at the head of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall, with Mischa Elman as the violin soloist in the Tchaikovsky concerto.

Roland Ray Conklin, retired capitalist and promoter, died yesterday in the Lenox Hill Hospital of pneumonia at the age of 79. Since 1922 he had not been active in business. In 1924 he sold his large estate, Rosemary Farm, at Huntington, L. I. Recently he had been living at 82 Washington Place.

Lower prices on spices developed in 1937 and the result was an improved demand, according to a report prepared by C. A. Thayer, president of the American Spice Trade Association, who declared that total American needs for spices were more than 150,000,000 pounds.

The fifth annual report of Postmaster General Farley showed today that postal revenues in the year ending June 30, 1937, were the highest in the history of the department. The total was $726,201,109.89.

EVERY one remembers that late in 1936 Chiang Kai-shek, the Chinese Generalissimo, was captured and held prisoner for some weeks by certain Chinese soldiers. And that about six months later Japan began a war that still goes on.

Despite manifestations from time to time in official quarters last year; to the effect that a serious effort would be made to curtail expenditures and reduce the Government's debt, the outstanding interestbearing debt of the United States Government actually increased about $2,993,000,000 in the calendar year 1937.

Cigarette consumption is unaffected by the business recession and the tobacco industry can look forward to another prosperous year, O. H. Chalkley, president of Philip Morris Co., Ltd., declared in a business forecast.
Selwyn Bywater of this city and Greenwich, Conn., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Marjorie Yvonne Bywater, to James Benjamin Adams Jr., son of James B. Adams of Omaha.

Mayor Edward H. Armstrong of Daytona Beach died in a hospital here today as he entered his fifth term as head of that city's government. He was 57 years old. In failing health for some months, the former wholesale grocer and well-known political figure came here for treatment early in December. Physicians performed an operation about a week ago and found him suffering from an inflamed liver and gall bladder.

Work for the jobless provided by the WPA was cited yesterday morning by the Rev. John Paul Jones in a sermon at Union Presbyterian Church, Ridge Boulevard and Eightieth Street, Brooklyn, as a modern example of the practice of "pure religion."

Improvement in the floor coverings industry will depend upon the progress made by the country as a whole in reversing the current recession, Herbert Gutterson, president of the Institute of Carpet Manufacturers of America, Inc., said yesterday.

The Rev. A. J. MacGillivray, former Moderator of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in Canada and a widely known clergyman in the Dominion, died in the Guelph General Hospital yesterday at the age of 70.

The chief reason for the quick failure of most reform movements is that they try to bring about Utopias before people are ready for them, the Rev. Dr. John L. Davis said in a sermon yesterday morning at the Washington Square Methodist Episcopal Church, 133 West Fourth Street.

" A concrete symbol of the church's trusteeship"-new doors that will always remain open-were dedicated at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue and Tenth Street, by the Rev. Dr. Donald B. Aldrich, the rector, before a communion service yesterday morning.
Certification of the Packing House Workers Union, Local No. 5, Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen of North America, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor,
Nine specimens of a rare insect, the "ice bug," have been found near Kamloops at a lower altitude than they were previously known to exist, G. Alan Mail, Dominion entomologist, announced today.

Squaring matters eleven seconds before the close of the third period and capably holding its own in a ten-minute extra session, the University of Montreal gained a 5-all tie with the St. Nicholas Hockey Club at the Brooklyn Ice Palace yesterday.
Bills already introduced indicate that the aviation industry will receive a large share of attention in the new session of Congress.
Yale University will give scholarship and beneficiary aid totaling $1,200,000 during the current school year, it was announced today. Of the undergraduates, 815 will receive $338-784.

The results of a secret investigation purporting to show that the so-called Young-Kolbe-Kirby syndicate of New York recently took steps to place control of the Alleghany Corporation, top holding company of the old Van Sweringen railroad system, in a Bahama corporation for tax-evasion purposes were made public today by the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee, which has been investigating rail financing.

Two thousand Negroes celebrating the seventy-fifth anniversary of the Emancipation Proclamation yesterday at St. Mark's Methodist Episcopal Church, 137th Street and Edgecombe Avenue, were reminded by Hubert T. Delany, municipal tax commissioner,
Even before the clash with England and the United States over the Japanese bombing of neutral vessels, the economic effects of Japan's war with China had become apparent.
The unfinished game between T. H. Tylor of England and Salo Flohr of Czechoslovakia in the fifth round of the international chess masters' tournament was again adjourned after a second session today.
The importance of the market for work shirts as an index of business conditions was emphasized in 1937, according to producers.
The police of Newark and New York are cooperating with Passaic detectives in an attempt to solve a $25,000 jewel robbery that occurred in the home of Dr. Joseph J. Weinberger,

A decline of about 20 per cent in residential construction in the last six months of 1937 wiped out most of the earlier gains in lumber consumption, and the total for the year is estimated at 24,000,000,000 feet, compared with 23,000,000,000 in 1936,
Financial symptoms, observable in Europe, have not yet reached such a pitch of intensity as to indicate that the economic cycle is approaching a descending curve.

Sir Charles Thomas Davis, Permanent UnderSecretary of State for Dominion Affairs, 1925-30, died here yesterday. His brilliant promise as a classical scholar at Oxford was justified by his career as a civil servant once he managed to get himself transferred from the admiralty accounting division in 1897.

The most interesting question as the business year closes is: How is Japan standing up to the strain of war? The answer is that the real strain is still to come, and will not be felt probably until after peace is restored.

The demand for State and municipal bonds exceeded the. supply of new offerings in 1937, according to Louis S. Lebenthal, head of the odd-lot municipal bond firm of Lebenthal Co. In an annual review of the municipal bond market Mr. Lebenthal declared that

Staple cotton goods suffered, in 1937, the sharpest price drop in nearly twenty years, but production reached a record high mark, according to Paul B. Halstead, secretary-treasurer of the Cotton Textile Institute, Inc., who,
In response to the questionnaire sent out by mail in an effort to reach every family in the country for an unemployment census, 7,822,912 persons reported themselves to be totally unemployed.
A new concern, known as Glazo, Inc., headed by Louis W. Halk, has acquired the Glazo manicure preparations and the Elcaya toilet article lines from the Northam Warren Corporation.

On the eve of her eleventh birthday, Josephine Altomare today caused the death of her 39-year-old cousin, Joseph Malizia, through what Albert McDermott, detective sergeant of police, said was the accidental discharge of a rifle.

Dr. William Crocker, director of the Boyce Thompson Institute for Plant Research, Yonkers, N. Y., is the winner of the annual gold medal of the American Institute for his "contribution to knowledge of life processes in plants and for his unique leadership in the organization of plant research," it was announced yesterday.

Thirty-five couples, all wed fifty years or more, rode to the Grand Street Boys Association clubhouse at 106 West Fifty-fifth Street yesterday for the club's second general Golden Wedding party. More than 100 couples had received invitations.

Scattered liquidation by holders of lard futures developed last week on the Board of trade and the near-by deliveries dropped to the lowest prices of the season, while -the cash article touched 7.90 cents a pound, the lowest since August, 1934.

Mrs. Elva R. Evans, widow of the Rev. William P. Evans. former rector of the Church of the Resurrection, Richmond Hill, died Saturday after a short illness in her home in Forest Hills at the age of 82. She was born in Pleasant Valley, N. Y., and resided in Queens for more than thirty-seven years. Two daughters,
Extreme dullness, punctuated by a few ineffectual attempts to raise prices, and ending in a decline to the lowest levels since carly in 1934, characterized the world silver market in 1937.

Fire caused by defective wiring destroyed a Christmas tree and a representation of the Christ child in the manger at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Benedict the Moor, 342 West Fifty-third Street, yesterday afternoon, but a permanent figure of the Madonna,
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The permanent registration of voters advocated by Mr. Blanshard should be seized upon by taxpayers as a means of effecting a great saving.

Imports of gold into the United States exceeded $1,000,000,000 for the fourth successive year, in 1937. Total imports were $1,205698,000, while reported exports were $45,250,000, leaving a net influx of $1,160,448,000, compared with net imports of $1,116,600,000

Money market conditions remained rather tight this week by reason of industrial and commercial requirements for year-end maturities. The call money rate nevertheless was maintained between 2 3/4 and 3 per cent.

The close of 1937 marks the end of a decade of research by the United States Steel Corporation, since Dr. John Johnston left Yale University to establish a central laboratory for the company and its subsidiaries.

The leading mail order companies and shoe chains contested for the largest percentage increase in retail trade last year. Following two successive years in which they led, the three major malt order companies had an average gain of 14.9 per cent for the first eleven months of last year.

For Italy 1937 has been characterized, from the financial viewpoint, by the effort made to begin exploitation of Ethiopia, an effort which has been enormous, owing to the vastness of territory to be developed and the primitive state in which Ethiopia found itself after conquest.

Producers of full-fashioned silk hosiery have experienced no appreciable decline in sales as a result of the growing agitation for a boycott against Japanese products, according to a survey by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Everybody's Thrift Shop will be the beneficiary of a card party and tea on Jan. 25 in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Guests are expected to bring packages of clothing and useful and decorative articles suitable for resale at the shop which is maintained for the benefit of charitable organizations.

Cash income of farmers in the United States during 1937 was the highest since 1929. This was due largely to the unusually high prices which prevailed during-the early part of the season, when the bulk of the new wheat crop in the Winter grain

For manufacturers of sulphur in the United States, 1937 was the second best year in their history, as expension continued in the entire chemical industry. Shipments exceeded 2,400,000 tons, according to preliminary estimates, which was 22 per cent more than the total for 1936 and was 99.3 per cent of the amount shipped in the peak year, 1929, which was 2,437,238 tons.

Six members of a fifteen-man Quebeo Government survey party which was found yesterday in the frozen muskeg country of Northern Quebec after being virtually without food for thirty-nine days were landed safely today at this town on James Bay.
A plea to make Suffolk County highways safe for pedestrians and motorists will be made to every automobile owner in the county as he obtains his new registration plates beginning tomorrow.
An impressive array of guest speakers will give a send-off tomorrow to broadcasts in Arabic with which Great Britain hopes to counteract the effect of unfriendly Italian programs in the Near East.

New York City bank and insurance stock markets in 1937 were not immune from the general downward trend in securities, according to Colonel Oliver J. Troster of Hoit, Rose Troster. Declines of about 32 per cent in leading bank stocks and 24 per cent in insurance stocks were incurred.

As a result of the 18,746,000-bale cotton crop of 1937-an increase of 6,347,000 bales over 1936 and of 769,000 bales over 1926, previous high record--the end-of-the-season carry-over will be much larger.

Democratic chances of controlling the organization of the new City Council decreased further yesterday when a conference of the Democratio Councilmen, which had been scheduled, was called off after it became known that the three Tammany members were balking at voting for John Cashmore of Brooklyn for vice chairman unless they were assured that the other regular Democratic members would vote for the reappointment of Michael J. Cruise as City Clerk.

Mutual fire insurance companies and mutual casualty insurance companies achieved the most successful year in their histories in 1937, according to reports received to date by the American Mutual Alliance from representative major organizations in both fields.

The oil industry made many new operating records last year, according to J. W. Van Dyke, chairman of the Atlantic Refining Company. This he attributed in part to friendly relationships existing between employes of the oil companies and the managements.

The accumulation of huge surpluses during a period of rising prices, largely induced by the buying of these surpluses, and a resultant. drastic decline marked the textile industries in 1937, but at the year-end, by reason of sharp reductions of production and an almost
THIS TROUBLED WORLD, by Eleanor Roosevelt. (Kinsey, $1.) The author analyzes various peace. plans and presents her own ideas on how permanent peace can be brought about.
The principal security and commodity markets of the world will reopen today. Most of the commodity exchanges in the United States began the New Year's holidays at midday on Friday.

Public financing by the railroads in 1937 was in substantial volume, compared with depression levels, although, in conformity with the trend in the securities market, it decreased sharply in the last half of the year. Most of this financing was in the form of equipment trust certificates.

The Rev. Joseph W. Trenz, pastor of Holy Trinity German Catholic Church since 1906, died today after an illness of a year. His age was 75. Father Treitz was born in New York City, Oct. 20, 1862, and was ordained to the priesthood by the late Right Rev. William O'Hara, p Bishop of the diocese of Scranton, in 1886,

In this market the outlook for 1938 is not regarded overoptimistically, because recession in world trade is generally expected -- a development which could have serious consequences for Austria, in view of her small financial reserves.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edward MacPherson Haynes of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Eleanor Haynes, to John Henry Winant Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Winant of Hackensack.
French unemployment is again on the increase. It was 340,000 at the beginning of December, after having fallen to 305,000 in September from 428,000 in January.
The dress manufacturer's estimate of business conditions in 1937 is summed up as "disastrous" by Mortimer Lanzit, executive director of the National Dress Manufacturers Association.

The Pontiao Blue Devils of the Michigan-Ontario Hockey League gave a demonstration yesterday of the sort of game which the amateurs in that circuit play, and the New York Rovers did not -find it exactly to their liking, the guests defeating the hosts. 4 to 3.

Foreign traders view possible developments of the present year with mixed feelings. Concern over events in the Far East and the possible loss of the rich Chinese market on one hand is matched on the other by hopes for a successful conclusion to the Anglo-American trade treaty.
Beginning today the bureau of advice and information of the Charity Organization Society will be known as the contributors information bureau, it was announoed yesterday. Rudolph T.
Within twenty-four hours of the fatal wounding of a 3-year-old child in a similar accident, a 13-year-old Chinese boy seriously wounded himself here today while playing with a loaded pistol.

Interest in the message which President Roosevelt will deliver at 1:30 o'clock tomorrow afternoon, standing before members of Senate and House as the second regular session of the Seventy-fifth Congress begins, rivals in intensity perhaps, that which attended his first message to Congress in 1933.
Costume Jewelry sales in 1937 reached the highest dollar value in six years. according to a special summary prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Carl Rosenberger, president of Cohn Rosenberger, Inc.
The toy and playthings industry closed 1937 with a slight increaseabout 3 per cent over 1936--according to James L. Fri, managing director of the Toy Manufacturers of the U. S. A.
The Neediest Cases Fund received $492 from twenty-seven contributors yesterday, bringing its total for the twenty-sixth annual appeal to $294,061.65.

Nicolas Titulescu, former Foreign Minister of Rumania, who is now ill in Switzerland, today offered Dr. Julius Maniu, president of the National Peasant party, his help in fighting any Fascist tendency of Premier Octavian Goga.

After industrial concerns had experienced improved earnings for the first nine months of 1937, the general business recession later materially altered the results of their operations for the full year. Although many companies in various fields managed to show favorable earnings compared with 1936, indications are that the. total corporate income for last year probably will be less.

Programs aimed at national selfsufficiency in Europe continued in 1937 to broaden the sources from which textile products can be made. The production of a wool-like fiber and its fabrics from casein, derived from milk,

Although final figures of last year's packs of the canning industry are not yet available, the year will undoubtedly prove to be one of the best in the history of the industry from the standpoint of both production and quality, according to O. C. Huffman, president of the Continental Can Company, Inc.

James G. Martin, who at one time controlled the largest cherry orchards of the world in Door County, and who served five terms as Mayor of Sturgeon Bay, died at St. Joseph's Hospital in Milwaukee this afternoon at the age of 74. Mr. Martin, who had been a member of the Chicago Board of Trade,
The Supreme Court may tell the Roosevelt administration tomorrow Whether it may legally aid in financing construction of publiclyowned electric plants that compete with private companies.

A meeting of the Eastern Baseball League's constitution committee at Hazleton at 9 A. M. Wednesday was called tonight by Thomas H. Richardson, president of the circuit, successor to the New York-Pennsylvania League.

" America has three outstanding sins-rationalism, pantheism and materialism," said the Rev. Dr. Ellis B. Burgess, president of the United Lutheran Synod of New York, in his sermon yesterday morning at the Evangelical Lutheran Church of the Advent, Broadway and Ninety-third Street.

German industry was quiet this week. The Trade Research Institute points out that certain branches of industry are not working at full capacity yet and it predicts their expansion in 1938. A strong impression has been made by the Labor Minister's

William P. Smith, 48 years old, of Camden, was killed today when a freight train of the Pennsylvania-Reading Seashore Lines backed over him at Broadway and Bulson Street here, according to the police.

A new streamlined, all-steel ferryboat, with capacity for thirty-six automobiles and constructed to plough through ice readily, has been completed for the Yonkers-Alpine line and will be placed in service on the Hudson River in a few days.

" Although the first half of 1938 may not be quite so good as the corresponding period in 1937, volume for the full year will be as good or better than for the year just closed," Samuel R. Sperans, president of Nathan Straus-Duparquet, Inc., which supplies hotels, restaurants, , said yesterday.

The political and financial anemia from which the American public utilities have been suffering for four years at last has shown signs of abating. But to bring about this amelioration it took a setback in business, acutely swift and severe in its development, to impress on the Administration the necessity for a rapprochement with the private power and light industry.

The advent of automatic electric tuning was the most important radio development of 1937, according to a statement issued by George K. Throckmorton, president of the RCA Manufacturing Company, whc forecasts a great new market for the sale of instruments.

Attacks upon big business, as responsible for the present depression, by Assistant Attorney General Robert H. Jackson in two recent speeches have been accepted by many local Democrats as constituting an attempt to put Mr. Jackson in line for the Democratic nomination for Governor by making him acceptable to the American Labor party, it was learned yesterday.

The number of new magazines introduced in 1937 reached a high record, with major successes also setting a high mark, according to authorities in the field. The chief feature was the phenomenal growth of picture magazines and to a smaller extent of pocket-size digests.

The Rev. Thomas Lester Graham, preaching yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral, urged "a spiritual inventory" to be taken at the New Year by "every one who is making an honest attempt to save his soul."

Predicting a banner year in 1938, Lewis R. Rosenstell, founder of Schenley Distillers Corporation, and chairman of its executive and finance committee, said in a statement prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES that the general gloom concerning economic conditions is unjustified.

An appeal for about $1,000,000 to complete the sanctuary and choir of the. Cathedral of St. John the Divine before the opening- of the World's Fair in 1939 was made yesterday by Bishop William T. Manning in a "report to the public" at the end of his New Year's sermon.

The wholesale price index for France on Dec. 24 was 599, compared with 596 on Dec. 18 and 594 the week before that. Native products stood at 644, compared with 641 and 638; imported products, 517, 514 and 515; foodstuffs, 606, 603 and 600;
As was generally anticipated by close observers of court tennis, James H. Van Alen of New York emerged victorious in the annual gold racquet championship which was concluded at the Tuxedo Club today.

HE current rating of heavyweight fighters has Shufflin' Joe Louis alone in his glory in Group 1 and Tom Farr of Tonypandy paired with Herr Max Schmeling of Hamburg in Group 2. That about covers the top class in the heavyweight realm and recalls the mournful statement of Sir John Falstaff, Knight, delivered long ago in the Boar's Head Tavern, Eastcheap, London, to wit:
In Ireland all ears are cocked to catch British comments on the new Constitution. One question is paramount: How does it strike the British; how will it affect relations between the two countries?

The old year went out quietly last week, as it was expected to do; but not until steel production had receded further to the lowest weekly figure since September, 1934, and not until stock market averages had temporarily touched the year's lowest.

Richard Hurtley, 17 years old, of 170 East Seventy-ninth Street, was reported missing last night by his mother, Mrs. Helen Rhodes. The boy was last seen on Friday morning canoeing near the Rhodes home not far from Darien, Conn.

Preparations are being made in Canton, until recently a city of more than 1,000,000, in South China, to destroy everything of value before the Japanese capture the city in the expected early invasion of Kwangtung Province. [Page 1.]

In the field of taxation the year 1937 was outstanding for at least three things: Corporations were required to prepare and file their first returns under the undistributed profits tax imposed by the Revenue Act of 1936; there was enacted the Revenue Act of 1937 imposing an unprecedented graduated tax upon personal holding companies,
The new national infantile paralysis foundation, now being organized around the celebration of the President's birthday, is going to carry on its fight in a way unique in American medical history.

Five personal assets necessary for significant and happy living were listed as contentment, courage, culture, a cause, and faith, by Rabbi Samuel H. Goldenson yesterday before the congregation in Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at Sixtyfifth Street.

Doug Mann of McGill University won the annual New Year's Day slalom staged by the St. Sauveur Ski Club today. He led a field of sixty-three and negotiated the tricky course in 35 seconds. F. Little of Dartmouth placed first in Class B, finishing in 37 4-5 seconds.

Over the last month comparatively little change has occurred in the general average of stock and bond prices on the London Stock Exchange. The Bankers Magazine index, based on December, 1921, as 100, although calculated at the middle of

Despite the sharp decline in equity values and the recession in trade in the latter half of last year, the total of dividends paid in the year was the largest since 1930, amounting to $4,550,460,671, compared with $4,122,725,360 in the preceding year and $4,982,668,635 in 1930. January,
Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, 11 A. M. "Labor Laws-Real and Rhetorical," Frank Rising, Spencer Miller, Mrs. George A. Wyeth.

J. M. Keynes, noted British economist, whose writings helped inspire President-Roosevelt's "pump-priming efforts," drew a distinction today between the public-works program he was advocating for Britain and that carried out by the New Deal.
Rye developed independent strength on the Board of Trade last week on buying considered as against operations in cash grain, but nothing was heard from the seaboard regarding export sales.

The United States Lawn Tennis Association announced yesterday that it had received 1938 Davis Cup challenges from Canada, Great Britain, Switzerland, India, Yugoslavia, Austria, Rumania, Greece and Czechoslovakia. Many more nations are expected to challenge before the close of entries on Jan. 31.
Charles 0. Pickel, engineer and sanitation inspector during the construction of the Panama Canal, died here today at the age of 59.

More than 36,000,000 wage earners now have Social Security accounts under the old age insurance program; about 21,000,000 workers are employed in jobs covered by the approved unemployment compensation laws of all the States and more than 2,100,000 of the needy-the aged, the blind, and dependent children-are receiving regular allowances from Federal.

The National Maritime Union asked the Maritime Commission yesterday to conduct elections among the unlicensed personnel of its merchant ships to determine the bargaining agency qualified to represent the men in negotiations for labor contracts.

Despite prosperity in this section for the past year as a whole, there is no denying that in the final quarter there has been a slow but gradual recession of business activity-attributed largely to the sharp decline in cotton prices from a level above 13 cents a pound to practically 7 1/2 cents.

The number of new magazines introduced in 1937 reached a high record, with major successes also setting a high mark, according to authorities in the field. The chief feature was the phenomenal growth of picture magazines and to a smaller extent of pocket-size digests.

The Rev. Thomas Lester Graham, preaching yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral, urged "a spiritual inventory" to be taken at the New Year by "every one who is making an honest attempt to save his soul."

Predicting a banner year in 1938, Lewis R. Rosenstell, founder of Schenley Distillers Corporation, and chairman of its executive and finance committee, said in a statement prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES that the general gloom concerning economic conditions is unjustified.

Emphasizing that world prices for cotton are beyond control by any agency, John C. Botts, president of the New York Cotton Exchange, in his year-end review declares that any effective limitation of production or control of prices through which foreign producers may increase their output profitably merely transfers cotton-growing from the United States to other countries.
The Atlantic City Sea Gulls and the Baltimore Orioles played a 3-to-3 tie tonight in a rough Eastern Amateur Hockey League game that saw surprisingly few penalties.

Edward J. Neil, Associated Press correspondent who was wounded critically on Friday in the village of Caudete when a government shell exploded in front of a parked automobile in which he was seated with three other newspaper men, died at noon today in a hospital here.

At almost 5 o'clock this morning the French Chamber of Deputies and the Senate, having finally reached agreement-that is to say, having done some keen horse trading in which for the most part the Senate was successful--closed their session, twenty-nine hours late, on the legal hour of midnight, Dec. 31.
Mohammed Mahmoud Pasha, Egypt's new Premier, confronted by a Wafdist (nationalist) party majority, decided today to prorogue Parliament for one month starting tomorrow.

Manufacturers of pulp and paper face the new year with consider able optimism after setting alltime high marks in both production and shipments in 1937, Orton B. Brown, vice president and a director of the Brown Company, says in his annual statement.

Sheriff Maurice A. FitzGerald of Queens objected yesterday to a story in THE NEW YORK TIMES in which it was intimated that in his appointment of thirty-five subordinates he was defying Mayor La Guardia. Mr. FitzGerald said:
Starting from scratch, Dave Kantrowitz of the home organization won the weekly four-and-a-half-mile road run conducted yesterday by the St. Anselm's A. C.

A plan for the refinancing of six certificated issues of the New York Title and Mortgage Company, in liquidation, approved by Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler, was announced yesterday by Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance.

The decline of [Pound]3,988,515 in the circulation of the Bank of England in the last week marks the customary slowing down after the Christmas spending rush. If it follows the usual course, circulation will continue to decline until well into January.

The Tennessee Valley Authority said in a "Review of Progress" today that it entered the new year well advanced on a unified program of flood control, navigation, power development and agricultural planning.

Dr. Emmet Rixford, a leading San Francisco surgeon, died today in the Peter Bent Brigham Hospital at the age of 72. He was admitted to the hospital Dec. 17. Attaches declined to disclose the cause of death.
San Luis Rey, carrying top weight of 118 pounds, captured the $1,000 six-furlong headliner of today's racing program that ushered in the new Sunday-only meeting here.

Notwithstanding the lately-cabled alarmist American views, the American situation is not considered here as anything analogous to 1929. General opinion is that your depression is temporary, and chiefly due to consumers having

Rising prices, chiefly resulting from higher costs for labor, developed in 1937 in such essential raw materials in the production of industrial chemicals as coal, limestone, salt, sulphur and phosphate rock, and for this reason,

Passenger traffic on the railroads in 1937 was the largest since 1930, J. J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads, said in his review of the year. It was the first full year since 1920 in which passenger fares all over the country were down to pre-war levels.

New paid-in insurance of the New York Life Company during 1937 exceeded that of 1936 by approximately $24,000,000 and was. larger than the total in any of the last five years, according to Alfred L. Aiken, president, who looks forward to a still larger volume in 1938. Mr.

Labor troubles, symptoms of a "buyers' strike," legislative difficulties and international uncertainties last year brought to the stock market its first major recession since the election of President Roosevelt.

While some 24,000 persons sat calmly this afternoon in seats that rotated under the strongest earthquake shock of the many recently registered in Mexico, Matador Liborio Ruiz coolly played and dispatched a fighting black bull.

A further rise in the Pennsylvania relief rolls during the week ended Dec. 25 placed the total number of persons on relief at 556,971, which is nearly 100,000 higher than the total three months earlier. In his report issued today, summarizing the relief situation as of Dec. 25, Karl de Schweinitz,

Unlike a year ago, investment bankers face the coming year with dire concern and much uncertainty as to what the future holds for the new investment market. They look for only a slow revival of corporate financing to even normal volume, and do not hesitate to predict a

Possibility that the public interest in security markets may have permanently diminished has been mentioned by Fred C. Moffatt, president of the New York Curb Exchange, as an explanation for the "stalemate" in which security exchanges found themselves at the end of 1937.

New capital issues here in December amounted to [Pound]17,825,000, against [Pound]20,211,000 a year ago, making a total of [Pound]170,906,000 for the year, compared with [Pound]217,221,000 in 1936. The depression in the stock market resulted in considerable curtailment in financial activity, which was reflected sharply in the reduction of new capital offerings.

The extent to which the people of the United States will prosper in 1938, as well as in the years to come, will depend upon the extent to which individuals and groups of individuals are rewarded for their initiative, ability, thrift and effort, in the opinion of Charles R. Hook,

The Bourse was quiet this week. The decline in Wall Street and the strike in Paris caused some weakness, but toward the end of the week quotations hardened slightly on better reports from Wall Street.

Boulder Dam, not scheduled for completion until next year, has already returned more than $2,000,000 to the Federal Treasury, John C. Page, Commissioner of Reclamation, reported today to Secretary Ickes.

Bruno Landi, young Italian lyric tenor, will make his debut at the Metropolitan Opera next week, singing the role of the duke in the season's first performance of "Rigoletto." Grace Moore will make her first appearance of the season as Mimi in "La Bohbme" and "Die Meistersinger" will return to the active repertoire.

David H. McAlpin Pyle, president of the United Hospital Fund, announced last night that $2,055,655 had been raised to date in the United Hospital Campaign. He said this was the largest sum raised in a fund campaign in the last fifty-eight years.

Three hundred and fifty customs officials and fifty-five doctors and immigration inspectors were kept busy all yesterday from 7 o'clock in the morning until 9 at night examining 7,011 passengers who arrived in New York, mostly from West Indies ports, on sixteen steamships.

Frank Van Dyk, executive director of the Associated Hospital Service of New York, announced last night that H. Lindsley Cummings of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company has become the 100,000th family subscriber to the three-cents-a-day plan for hospital care.

Manufacturers in the United States bought more aluminum in 1937 than in any similar period, despite a recession in the aluminum industry in the closing months, according to George J. Stanley, vice president of the Aluminum Company of America.

Two hours of work by a police emergency squad, called to aid two physicians, appeared last night to have saved the life of a baby born without pulse or respiration at 2,184 Davidson Avenue, the Bronx.
Federal supply contracts amounting to $10,345,355 were awarded in the two weeks ended on Dec. 30 under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Department of Labor announced today.

" To attempt to appraise the trend of American business as we enter 1938 presents the normal difficulties of any forecast, although I believe the circumstances this year are quite unusual in character and, in some respects, very clearly defined," Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the General Motors Corporation, says in his New Year's statement.

Battle lines for what appeared to be a serious conflict between the Progressive Parents Council and the Board of Education were drawn today with threats of a pupils' strike on one hand and court action on the other.
The past year's developments in the American business situation have shown only too painfully how seriously wrong were the predictions of a continued forward movement a year ago.
The employment industry showed great advances in scientific methods of placement in 1937 and should show even greater improvement in 1938, according to Alice M. Wright, head of Wright Personnel.
The weekly survey of mill operations issued by the National Rayon Weavers Association showed operations in the week ended Dec. 25 were influenced by the holiday.
A little girl of our acquaintance wrote at the age of eight a sociologcal drama entitled "Do Mothers Treat Their Husbands Right?"
Holiday travel reached a new peak yesterday, equal if not exceeding the day-before-Christmas rush, as celebrations of the New Year calmed down to the normal beginning of 1938.

For the third consecutive year public utility companies led all other industries in the retirement of bonds before maturity. In 1937 the group showed prepayments of $1,119,477,000 of a total of $2,441,894,000 for all classes of refunding operations.

The "twenty-year cycle" used to be accepted as the economic rule; it covered depression, recovery and the final boom. But the twentyyear period was invariably punctured about midway in the cycle by severe reaction - always coming when recovery was vigorously under way. It interrupted but did not end the "upward curve."
A modest revival in borrowings by the railroads from the government took place toward the close of 1937, when investment markets became unreceptive to new offerings.

Trade practice rules have been promulgated by the Federal Trade Commission for three industries-the popular-priced dress manufacturing industry, the house dress and washfrock manufacturing industry and the toilet brush manufacturing industry.

An unidentified man about 45 years old was stricken with a fatal heart attack at 9 o'clock last night at Fourteenth Street and Broadway. A passer-by summoned an ambulance, but the man died on the way to Columbus Hospital.
" There are so many uncertain and contradictory elements in the present economic situation that the traditional role of New Year business forecaster is a particularly perilous one.
Eleven holiday celebrants were drowned and sixteen others were missing today after an Inland Sea ferry, the Midorimaru, capsized off the coast of Hiroshima prefecture in a violent windstorm.

Copper consumption outside the United States in 1937 reached a record high level of about 1,350,000 tons. In the first eleven months of this year the apparent consumption of the metal abroad amounted to 1,241,000 tons.
Stocks 'declined to around low levels of the year in heavier trading for a week; turnover, 7,897,505 shares. United States Government bonds irregular, other issues lower; transactions, $43,813,500.

Members of the Junior Auxiliary of the Silver Cross Day Nursery will complete plans for the benefit dinner dance to be held Jan. 21 at the Pierre on Thursday afternoon at a meeting in the home of Mrs.

After a highly promising start in 1937, waste materials succumbed to the general influences affecting raw commodities near the close of the second quarter of the year, and both sales and prices slumped sharply, according to the National Association of Waste Material Dealers.
The franc was adversely affected this week by sales of a speculative character, which appeared when strikes again broke out, especially the surprise of stoppage of public services in Paris.

In an attack- on the speech made last week by Secretary Ickes in which "big business" was accused of staging a "sit-down strike," Representative Samuel B. Pettenglll, Democrat, of Indiana, called today for the retirement of the Secretary of Interior from public life.
Having abandoned all hope of luring Robert Donat to Hollywood in face of his contract difficulties with Warners, RKO has assigned Douglas Fairbanks Jr. to "The Son of Monte Cristo."

Furniture manufacturers -are looking to Grand Rapids and Chicago for a concrete idea of what the trend of 1938 business will be. In both cities seasonal openings of Spring merchandise are being held today and buyers from all parts of the country are expected to shop through showrooms for midwinter sales and regular merchandise.

The city's Independent Subway System, during the year ended Dec. 31, 1937, carried nearly 61,500,000 more passengers than in 1936, according to a report made public yesterday by the Board of Transportation.

Spotting their rivals a goal in the first period, the New York Americans waged a gallant uphill struggle to conquer the Montreal Maroons in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.
Government cooperation with business is the need of the hour, Orval W. Adams, president of the American Bankers Association and executive vice president of the Utah

Corn showed a tendency at times last week to assume market leadership on the Board of Trade here, owing to the development of a continued active foreign demand for the cash article on a scale that had not been witnessed in more than ten years.

Mrs. Gunnar Haugh of this city, formerly of New York, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Katharine Haugh, to J. John Hassett Jr., son of J. John Hassett of Elmira, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Hassett.

Responsibility for crime was laid to the "competitive complex of modern culture" by Nathaniel Cantor, Professor of Sociology of the University of Buffalo, in an address last night at. a forum of the Department of Social Philosophy of Cooper Union, Fourth Avenue and Eighth Street.

Miss Marie Kane of Glasgow, Scotland, armed with a letter of introduction to Mayor La Guardia and also letters to twenty-six other Mayors, arrived in New York on the Cunard White Star liner Scythia yesterday afternoon, an emissary of Glasgow's Empire Exhibition, which is to open in May. She will ask the Mayor to attend.

The natives howled, the huskies growled and an Arctic blizzard hid the fun when football came to the land of the midnight sun. The Oogruits (Walruses), coached by Ben Levin, defeated the Airgrits (Reindeer), coached by Ben Chisholm, 7 to 6, in a New Year's Day "ice bowl" game that had everything.

Despite notable forward movements of midsummer, when generous- crops and high prices gave promise of returning prosperity, the Middle West is ending the year in an uncertain attitude. Pall in prices and the dubious condition of sown acreage has been especially depressing to the Wheat Belt.

The recession in business proceeded at a slower rate in December than in the Autumn months and a few signs appeared that it was flattening out, the National City Bank says. in its monthly letter published today.

Spotting their rivals a goal in the first period, the New York Americans waged a gallant uphill struggle to conquer the Montreal Maroons in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.
Government cooperation with business is the need of the hour, Orval W. Adams, president of the American Bankers Association and executive vice president of the Utah

Corn showed a tendency at times last week to assume market leadership on the Board of Trade here, owing to the development of a continued active foreign demand for the cash article on a scale that had not been witnessed in more than ten years.
Veering from measures of restraint to measures of expansion, the credit policy of the Federal Reserve System presented a confused and contradictory picture in 1937.
The railways spent $846,000,000 on equipment, supplies. and materials in 1937, against $761,000,000 in 1936, according to estimates by Railway Age.

In the Supreme Court of the United States the following proceedings were had today: 138--The United States, pet's., v. Pete McGowan, claimant of one Chevrolet coupe, etc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals.

What happens to the accident rate when a holiday falls on a stormy week-end was clearly reflected yesterday when the weekly figures of the Safety Bureau of the Police Department showed an astounding increase over the corresponding weekend of 1937.

A sharp break in Erie Railroad issues, which served to unsettle the market for other secondary rail loans, was a feature of an otherwise dull and routine trading session in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

An application for the probate of the will of Newton D. Baker, filed today in Probate Court, tentatively estimated the value of the estate at $31,000. His wife, Mrs. Elizabeth L. Baker, was named executrix and sole beneficiary. The estate listed personal property and securities as tentatively valued at $15,000, and real estate, consisting of Mr. Baker's Colonial home at $15,000.

James V. Mangano, Kings County Sheriff, announced yesterday that there would be no special deputies' shields distributed from his office during his two-year term because the use of the badges sometimes had been linked to all kinds of rackets.

The Orleans Hotel, well-known ten-story hostelry at the southwest corner of Columbus Avenue and Eightieth Street, facing the American Museum of Natural History, has been purchased for investment by Frank V. Storrs from the Orleans Real Estate Company.

Shipments of all types of hosiery in November were 9,822,303 dozen pairs, compared with 10,894,000 dozen pairs in November, 1936, a decline of 9.4 per cent, according to a report issued yesterday by the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers.

Advertising campaigns by rug manufacturers for the first half of this year will approximate in size those for the corresponding period of 1937, it was reported here yesterday at the official opening of Spring lines. Some companies, however, had not completed their Spring campaigns yesterday but will have details ready shortly.

All reaords for number of bankruptcy petitions filed in the northern distric. of Federal Court were broken in 1937 with a total of 1,442 petitions. The previous record was established in 1936, when the number filed was forty-three fewer, according to the figures revealed by Glen A. Porter, clerk.

In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals today the following proceedings were had: CUSTOMS 4131--United States V. American Engineering Inc. Motion of applt. for leave to print record nune pro tune, granted. 4119--Gridley Maxon Company, et al, v. United States. Dismissed upon motion of applt.
Senator Carter Glass, eldest member of Congress, wil observe his eightieth birthday tomorrow. A year ago he said he wanted to live to be 80, thereby bettering the record "of any of the Glass clan."

The Department of Commerce yesterday issued its revised Check Sheet on Introduction of New Industrial Products, which deals with marketing new products on a scientific basis or in correcting practices on products not moving satisfactorily.

The late Lord Rutherford's last address to a body of scientists was read today at the opening of the silver jubilee session of the Indian Science Congress in the presence of the Viceroy, the Marquess of Linlithgow, and 100 visiting delegates from the British Association for the Advancement of Science.

Charles Frederick Pannell, former president of the New York cloak and suit company of his name, died here yesterday at his residence, 21 Ivanhoe Terrace, at the age of 76. He was born in Columbia, Mo., a son of Professor Frederick Pannell of the University of Missouri.

Frank C. Lynch Jr. of Kansas City, towering Naval Academy athlete, assumed the position of "five striper," or midshipman commander of the regiment, today upon the reassembly after the Christmas vacation. He succeeds John K. Leydon of Philadelphia, who has commanded the regiment since the opening of the school year.

The twelfth Earl of Lindsey died yesterday at the age of 78. A Justice of the Peace in Lincolnshire and formerly a captain in the Northamptonshire Regiment, he went to Australia as aide de camp to Lord Carrington, Governor of New South Wales, and married an Australian, Miss Millicent Cox of Sydney, who died in 1931.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today receipt of the following applications from New York City for registration as broker or dealer in the over-the-counter market (symbols: S, sole proprietor; P, partnership; C, corporation):

A poll of the members of the Senate and House after President Roosevelt had delivered his message today revealed differences of opinion, but for the most part along party lines. A few Republicans approved parts of the address, but in the main Republicans were critical.

Trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad have been authorized by the Interstate Commerce Commission to abandon 15.12 miles of line in Litchfield County, Conn., a part of the railroad extending from Hartford to Salisbury.

A general reduction in loans and in deposits, with resultant decline in total assets, was shown in the statements of condition as of Dec. 31 which were issued yesterday by banks and trust companies. In contrast to the smaller loans and discounts, most of the banks showed larger holdings of United States Government securities and many reported increases in cash and cash items.

The war Department released the following orders, dated Dec. 31: COLONEL Fulton, W. S., Inf., detailed in the Inspector General's Dept., effective June 19. by direction of the President; from Fort Douglas, Utah, to sail from San Francisco about June 23 for the Philippine Dept.
William H. Benedict, a director in the jewelry firm of H. R. Benedict Son, Inc., of New York, died yesterday at the Elizabeth General Hospital following a short illness.

The third issue of bills in the Treasury's current series was sold today at an average interest rate of 0.065 per cent, compared with 0.101 per cent for the issue last week and 0.102 for the first of the offerings in the current series, Secretary Morgenthau announced tonight.
Mgr. Andre du Bois de la Villerabel, titular Archbishop of Melitene who was removed as Archbishop of Rouen in 1936 after a bitter clash with the Vatican, died here today at the age of 73.

Art prizes totaling $1,300 were awarded yesterday at the fortyseventh annual exhibition of the National Association of Women Painters and Sculptors, which will be opened to the public today at the American Fine Arts Galleries, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Asa S. Bushnell assumed office yesterday as "high commissioner" of Eastern college athletics. Under the more formal title. of executive director of the Central Office for Eastern Intercollegiate Athletics, the one-time Princeton graduate manager took charge of the most pretentious movement collegiate sports along the Atlantic seaboard has ever experienced.

Despite declining United States iron and steel indices of recent months, the world demand for these materials has been maintained at a high level, exceeding the 1929 demand, according to statistics for the first eleven months of 1937, made public today by the Metals and Minerals Division of the Department of Commerce.
A tall Southern Methodist basketball team from Texas tonight opened an invasion of the East with a lastminute 31-to-28 victory over Gettysburg College before a crowd of 5,000.

Officers for the coming year will be installed by the Flatbush Real Estate Board at a meeting to be held the evening of Jan. 14 at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn. H. G. McNeill is president. H. John Lynch has been placed in charge of sales at the real estate office of A. Neurad, Inc.

CHASE, LUCIEN B. (Dec. 6). Estate, more than $20,000. To Emma Chase, widow and executrix, 440 Park Ave., residue. GUSTAV, SIMON (Dec. 12). Estate, less than $5,000. To Sadie Gustav, widow, executrix, 716 10th Ave., residue, and two specific bequests.

Miss Arden Beavers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Gaylord Beavers of this place, was introduced to society today at a tea given by her parents in their home here. The debutante received with her parents, her cousin, Miss Joan Earle of Brooklyn, and the Misses Elizabeth Craig of Nashville, Tenn.; Elizabeth Crandell, Edith Young, Elinor Gwinn and Frances Brisler.
Retiring President, National Collegiate Athletic Association, and Commissioner of Athletics, Western Conference

William Francis, who during his sixty-five years as dean's verger at Christ Church, Oxford, became a friend of the original of "Alice in Wonderland" and other members of the Liddell family, died in Oxford today at the age of 97.

Automobile production dropped' sharply last week due to holiday shut-downs in a number of plants. Daily average output showed a marked decline, when a nominal easing was called for seasonally, and the adjusted index slumped to 66.3, its lowest point since the week ended Oct. 12, 1935.

Accounting practices of certain Federal agencies were denounced and the Treasury criticized for failure to conform to the system prescribed by the General Accounting Office in the annual report submitted today by Richard N. Elliott, Acting Controller General.

Wheat fluctuated in an erratic manner on the Board of Trade here today within a range of around 13/4 cents a bushel, prices showing little change at the opening but advancing later in sympathy with Winnipeg and securities, only to weaken when the trade placed a bearish construction on the President's message.

Crosby Ave (15-4167), n w cor of Daniel St, 43x144; Bank of New York Trust Co. to Mike Dorick, 1,888 Bathgate Ave. Carpenter Ave, 3,990 (17-4827): Cape Realty Corp to John Copek Sr, 3,990 Carpenter Ave. 222d St, 844 E (16-4680); Presbyterian Church of Pound Ridge to Paul Messina, 2,166 Crotona Ave.

Among those reported yesterday as having signed contracts for commercial space was Robert L. Kendell, doing business as the Great Eastern Advertising Company, who took-space in the building at 17-23 East Sixtieth Street. The Cross Brown Company, broker, negotiated the lease.

Miss Helen Leigh Fletcher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram Leigh Fletcher of 32 Remsen Street, Brooklyn, was married last night at the home of her parents to Justin Armstrong Stanley, son of Mrs. Walter H. Stanley of Leesburg, Ind., and the late Mr. Stanley, by the Rev. Dr. J. Hillman Hollister of Washington.

Congressional leaders decided upon all possible speed for enactment of the "Big Navy" program in line with the tone of President Roosevelt's message today and at the same time planned to marshal their forces to prevent the Ludlow anti-war referendum proposal from reaching the House floor for consideration next Monday.

Nathan Schneider, 24 years old, of 173 Monroe Street, who was a prisoner in Gouverneur Hospital charged with the killing of Raymond McCormack, 40, who was shot Sunday morning on Cannon Street, near Broome Street, died last night from bullet wounds inflicted by Patrolman Joseph Pigott of the Clinton Street Station.

Stocks closed irregular after moderate gains; turnover, 916,050 shares. United States Government and foreign bonds firm and mixed; Erie Rairload issues fell 1 1/2 to 16 points on default news, other rails weakened; transactions, $5,000,800.

Miss Lizzie, A. J. Stallings's 5-year-old chestnut mare, came fast in the closing stages to carry off top honors in the six-furlong test for 4year-olds and upward which opened today's program at the Fair Grounds. J. Lane's Sadie F. was second, with Coward Coffey's Royal Broom third.
Mrs. Ann C. Bonham von Bonnewitz, wife of Dr. Orlando R. von Bonnewitz of 876 Park Avenue, died yesterday in the Flower Fifth Avenue Hospital after an illness of three months following an operation.

Dr. Charles Russell, president of the State Teachers College, Westfield, Mass., has been appointed curator of the Department of Education of the American Museum of Natural History, F. Trubee Davison, president of the museum, announced yesterday. Dr. Russell succeeds Dr. George H. Sherwood, who died last March.

The report of the Electric Power' and Light Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Oct. 31, issued for publication today, shows a consolidated net income after all expenses and charges, of $9,497,778.
To the honor roll of newspaper men dead in line of duty must be added the names of three men who fell last Friday on the road to Teruel: Richard Sheepshanks, Bradish Johnson and Edward J. Neil.

The possible consequences of the Supreme Court's action today in the case of the Railroad Commission of California v. the Pacific Gas and Electric Company are both political and economic, and very important indeed.
The George Washington University quintet defeated Ohio State tonight, 46-35. The Capital team, victor last week over Minnesota, completely mastered its second Big Ten foe of the season.

Congress was requested today by Attorney General Cummings in his annual report to investigate and revise the anti-trust laws, which he pronounced "inadequate." In detailed support of this recommendation, he turned over the largest section of his annual report to Robert H. Jackson, Assistant Attorney General in charge of antitrust enforcement, who twice recently held "monopolies" responsible for the current recession.

Four German ships were reported today to have been forced ashore in a storm near Melilla, Spanish Morocco. They were the Traunstein of the Bernstein Line, the Boltenhof of the August Bolten Line, the Maritza of the Schuldt Line and the Luise Leonhardt of the Leonhardt-Blumber Line.

Herb Kopf passed a busy day yesterday as he assumed his new duties as football coach at Manhattan College. Familiarizing himself with the routine of the athletic department and receiving the good wishes of many friends, Kopf announced that it was "still too early to form any plans."

Lee Thompson Smith, who was foreman of the "runaway" grand jury which resulted in the Dewey investigation, was appointed yesterday by the Board of Estimate to head its real estate bureau at a salary of $9,500 a year.

Mrs. Virginia Lee Redgate, daughter of Mrs. Henri Hornung of New York, was married to Ashbel Green Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Green of New York and the Old Parsonage, this place, at noon today in the Presbyterian Church here by the Rev. Robert Lawson, the pastor.

A fast-skating sextet from Queens University of Canada overwhelmed the New York Athletic Club hockey team, 6 to 1, at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. Held even in the first period, the Canadians put on the pressure in the second and tallied four goals.

A welterweight battle of eight rounds between Andre Jessurun, Bronx favorite, and Frankie Cinque of Washington Heights features the first boxing card of the year at the New York Coliseum, the Bronx, tonight. The contest will be a return engagement, their previous meeting resulting in a draw.

Bennett Ave, w s, 1,076.5 ft n of 187th St. 159.3x155.10 to Overlook Terr, x246.8x irreg; John D. Rockefeller Jr. to City of New York, given upon condition, however, that said premises shall be used forever for the purposes of a free public park and for no other purposes.

The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today an application of the Duluth, Missabe Iron Range Railway Company to acquire control of the Duluth Iron Range Railroad Company and the Interstate Transfer Railway Company by purchase of stock.

Although leaders of the Grand Rapids Furniture Exposition frankly admit they do not expect as big a market this year as in 1937, attendance on the opening today was gratifying. More than 300 had registere'd tonight for the 121st consecutive semi-annual market, a good registration for the opening day.

The New York Stock ExchangeI suspended yesterday from dealings American Telephone and Telegraph Company ten-year convertible 41/2 per cent debentures, called for redemption; City of Buenas Aires 61/2 per cent Series 2B bonds due July 1, 1955, called for redemption; Brunswick Western Railroad Company first-mortgage 4a, which matured on Jan. 1;
The intention of responsible leaders of the Republican party in the State to remain on as friendly terms as possible
President Roosevelt's message to Congress was broadcast yesterday over about 350 stations in the nation, together with several short-wave stations, enabling a world-wide audience to hear the speech.

After 105 clerks of the State Department of Labor had checked 105,000 applications for unemployment insurance benefits at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Thirty-fourth Street and Park Avenue, yesterday they forwarded to Albany a total of 5,000 notices of unemployment.

Police detectives and plainclothes patrolmen were aroused yesterday by the news that the B. M. T., citing "economy," had not yet renewed police passes and that-the Long Island Railroad, alleging "abuses," had cuts its list from 1,470 to 650.

Three persons were injured in skiing accidents in this area over the holiday week-end as thousands of Winter sports enthusiasts took to trails in the near-by mountains. Those hurt were: Duane Davis, 23, of Boston, fracture of the lower left leg.

The Ford Motor Company petitioned the National Labor Relations Board today to set aside its "cease and desist" order and to grant a rehearing of the NLRB complaint against the company that it had violated the Wagner Act.

A headline appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 30, dealing with Halle Selassie's appeal to the Oslo treaty signatories against the action of The Netherlands in according de facto recognition to the conquest of Ethiopia, was misleading.
