City pigeons flew about the 244th Coast Artillery Armory at 125 West Fourteenth Street as usual yesterday afternoon in search of food. Inside, more highly bred pigeons were placed in small cages, where chey immediately started puffing,

A pretentious exhibition schedule of thirty-three games, which will include six with the St. Louis Cardinals and five with the Dodgers and will call for another swing through Texas and Oklahoma, has been arranged to whip the Yankees into shape for the 1938 baseball campaign, according to an announcement by Business Manager Ed Barrow yesterday.

Columbia University's 500 maintenance employes will enjoy some of the dignity of the institution's academic staff under a new plan announced yesterday at the annual meetings of the university trustees. As of Jan. 1, the salaries and positions of the non-academic employes will be designated according to Hugh standards that apply to professors Afte and instructors.
Virginia Field, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Field of New York and Seattle, Wash., will be married here tomorrow to William Greene Chester, son of J. H. Chester of Seattle.

Two amateur sailors were held without bail today to await grand jury action on charges that they murdered Jack Morgan aboard the yacht Aafje, Christmas Eve, four days after he had slain the wealthy owner, Dwight Faulding of Santa Barbara, and seized possession of the craft.

Athel D. Merrill, clothing merchant and former member of the City Council, died here today following a heart attack. His age was 62. Long prominent in civic, fraternal and business affairs, he was a director of the Association of Commerce, a member of the committee which sponsored the establishment of the city manager form of government here and was one of the first five Councilmen elected under Plan C.

E. I. Rollins Sons, Inc., yesterday purchased an issue of $375,000 of temporary loan notes of Auburn, Me., on a 0.465 per cent interest basis. The notes will be dated Jan 6, and will become due and payable on Nov. 3, 1938.

The annual report of International Match Realization Company Ltd., for the fiscal year ended Oct. 31, shows a surplus of $7,412,904, after two liquidating dividends aggregating $17.50 per share, or $3,026,310.

The decline in the market values of securities in the latter part of 1937 inevitably reduced the liquidating value of investment trust securities, but it is not possible accurately to appraise companies of this character by a short-term performance, according to Floyd B. Odlum, president of the Atlas Corportion.

Mrs. Horace G. Reed, chairman of the membership committee of the Public Education Association, will give a luncheon today at her home, 46 East Eighty-first Street, for a group of women invited to serve with her in a campaign to enlist greater lay interest in the public schools and in the association.
The Navy Department described as serious today the condition of E. P. Gassie, American Embassy clerk wounded in the Dec. 12 sinking of the United States gunboat Panay.

Arnold Bernstein, Jewish shipping operator, who is awaiting judgment on exchange law charges, has transferred his stock in his two lines-the Red Star and the Bernstein-to Marius Boeger, government trustee who was placed in charge when Herr Bernstein was arrested a year ago. He has empowered Herr Boeger to sell the stock if he sees fit.
Total exports of farm implements and equipment in November were valued at $4,567,811, a gain of 63 per cent over the same month of 1936, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Mrs. Desmond Humphreys, who was widely known a generation ago under her pen name Rita, died at Combe Down, near here, Saturday. She was 73 years old. Mrs. Humphreys fell in her bedroom last November and never recovered from the effects.

The flexibility that is essential to the proper working of this country's economic system has been marred by government intervention, but all indications point to "a growing appreciation by government" that this flexibility must be restored if the recover march is to be resumed, Percy S. Straus, president of R. H. Macy and Co., Inc., New York, told shoe men attending the National Shoe Fair today.

The Public Works Administration, in noting today that the Supreme Court decisions upholding the PWA power program opened the way to proceed with sixty-one projects in twenty-three States, said many had been blockaded by litigation.

THE Rangers were gathering for a session of "skull practice" prior to their neighborhood squabble on skates with the star-spangled Americans, and M'sieu Francois Boucher, the most polite gent ever to check another player into the boards, was sitting on a bench just outside M'sieu Lestairre Patrick's boudoir.
Professional football officials snapped up some welcome talent Sixty after the East-West game here New Year's Day.

The Erie Railroad defaulted interest on five bond issues today and reported it was unable to meet current expenses, leading to the expectation that the road might seek reorganization under the Federal Bankruptcy Laws.

The new cruiser Philadelphia sailed today on a trial run which will take it to Cuba, Puerto Rica, Jamaica and Bermuda. The ship is scheduled to return here Feb. 16. The cruise is for the purpose of testing equipment and familiarizing the crew with its operation.

The election of Lisle R. Beardslee as secretary of General Motors Corporation to succeed the late Thomas S. Merrill was announced yesterday by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman. following a meeting of the board of directors. Mr.. Beardslee, who has been assistant secretary of the corporation, will make his headquarters in New York.

Development of 200 acres at Whiteport Lake, Kingston, N. Y., into an all-year resort will be started immediately by the Wall Street Fish and Game Club, a group of New York brokers who acquired the property recently from W. L. Burnett of Newburgh.

After two hearings on the question, an American Arbitration Association board has decided that the Shubert office owes Hugh Sinclair and Valerie Taylor (Mrs. Sinclair) $142.86 and first-class transportation to England.

The six-family apartment house at 571 Eleventh Street, West New York, N. J., has been sold by the Weehawken Trust Company to Bert Newman. Sale was for cash above a $10,800 mortgage. B. F. Kislak, Inc., brokers, negotiated the deal.

An air of deepest mystery hung over City Hall today. City officials gathered in Mayor. Jackson's office, waiting for him to open a package sealed fifty years ago and deposited in city vaults. It was marked: "Not to be opened for fifty years from January, 1888."

Count Hermann Keyserling, German writer and lecturer, who had undertaken a lecture tour in the United States, is understood here to have canceled it "for reasons of health." He had intended to sail aboard the liner Hamburg, which reached New York last Wednesday, and had engaged passage on the ship. He is now in the Black Forest.

The dollar declined sharply in terms of the principal foreign moneys in yesterday's dealings in the foreign exchange market. Great Britain's pound sterling rose to $5.01 1/3, the best price since Dec. 17, and closed at $5.011-16, up 15-16 cents net;

The New York Rovers and the Bronx Tigers battled through seventy minutes of hockey last night, but at the close of the ten-minute overtime session they still were deadlocked at 2-2. A crowd of about 3,000 witnessed the game in Madison Square Garden.

Chief City Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. revealed yesterday that in 1937 there were 715,776 traffic cases tried in the Traffic Courts in Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens, compared to 596,194 in 1936, an increase of 119,582, with a total of $1,226,319 in fines in 1937, an increase of $366,247 over the preceding year.

A doctor selected by parents of a minor to perform an operation becomes the legal representative of the child while it is under anesthesia, the Supreme Court held here today in sustaking the action of Circuit Judge William A. Smith in granting a non-suit in favor of Dr. Henry B. Orton of Newark.

American shipyards started ne new year with 124 vessels of 300,680 gross tons under construction, according to a survey published yesterday by the American Bureau of Shipping. This represents a decrease of fifty-eight in the number of ships but a gain of 39,490 tons during the last twelve months.

Being interested just now in speculations about time, J. B. Priestley has put some of it into a tenderly wistful Play entitled "Time and the Conways," which was put on at the Ritz last evening. This is the first of the three plays Mr. Priestley produced in London earlier in the season, and it is still the most popular one there.

Edgar Snow's "Red Star Over China," published yesterday by Random House, was completely sold out by mid-afternoon. The book, 4,800 copies of which were printed, is an account of the activities of the Chinese Red Army.

By the end of 1938 the number of stores and restaurants offering airconditioning comfort for patrons will have expanded more rapidly than any other types of structures utilizing this modern device, according to those most familiar with the trends of the market.

Turmoil and a deafening tumult were created in Parliament tonight when former Premier Mustafa Nahas Pasha, leader of the nationalist Wafd party, and his partisans prevented Dr. Ahmad Maher, Speaker of the Chamber of Deputies, from reading a decree by 18-year-old King Farouk adjourning Parliament for a month.

The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized today extension of the time of payment of $3,725,207 of loans by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the Pittsburgh West Virginia Railway Company to Dec. 31, 1938. The loan was to mature on Dec. 31. 1937.

Dr. Jerome Trier, in his inaugural address last night as president of the First District Dental Society, at the New York Academy of Medicine, appealed to the .profession to work out its own plan for providing care for the public, and not to wait until the government may feel called upon to take measures in the interest of public health.

The season's third performance of Bellini's "Norma" was given by the Metropolitan Opera Company last night, to open the sixth week, before a large, enthusiastic audience. As in the two previous performances, Gina Cigna sang the title role.
The power and utility program of the New Deal received a decided impetus from the Supreme Court as the justices met today for the first time in the new year.

In a suite at the Madison Hotel last night Miss Sarah Elkus was packing. Just a preliminary packing, this was, and not connected with her projected sailing on Jan. 13 for Rio de Janeiro. For yesterday was her first day in retirement after twenty-two years of teaching and supervising the day classes in English and citizenship, in the city's educational system and mementoes to be tucked away were many.

The Glidden Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the year ended on Oct. 31, a net profit of $2,542,793 after interest, depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges. After dividend requirements on the 41/2 per cent preferred stock, the profit is equivalent to $2.62 each on 799,701 shares of no-par common stock, excluding 1.100 shares held in the treasury.

All Jewish docors and dentists are excluded as of Jan. 1 from "panel" practice under the Compulsory Insurance Law. As ordinary medical practice in Germany is almost entirely paid for by the government insurance association, the great majority of Jewish physicians and dentists will suffer a heavy loss.
The Hamburg American Line this month will launch a 15,000-ton liner for the west coast of South American trade and a 10,000-ton combined passenger and freight motorship for the Australian trade.
Steel operations in the United States are scheduled at 25.6 per cent of capacity this week, compared to 27.4 per cent in the latest full week of operations, beginning on Dec. 13.

The Rev. Odoacre B. Villante, pastor for the last twenty-one years of the Italian Presbyterian church of New Rochelle, died yesterday at his home here after an illness of one month. His age was 62. He was born in Italy and came to this country as a boy.

If a guest has not thrust a knife, fork or spoon into an order of food it may be served again to another customer according to a ruling today by Fritz Dreesen, leader of the economic group in the officially controlled restaurant trade.

The Toronto Leafs entrained tonight for Boston to play the Bruins in a National Hockey League game tomorrow night. Captain Charlie Conacher accompanied the team, but it was doubtful whether the big right winger, injured in a practice session today, would be able to play.

The United States Lines was advised late Sunday night by the master of the American Trader, which sailed for Plymouth and London at 4 P. I Friday, that the purser, Russell Merkel, 31 years old, of Kingston, Pa., was missing.

Steven M. Seisel, who has been manager of the 285 Madison Avenue branch office of H. G. Einstein Co., has been admitted as a general partner. Charles L. Lehman has become associated with the firm as manager of the investment department.

A jury in Kings County Court was directed yesterday by Judge John J. Fitzgerald to acquit Joseph Anglin, 42 years old, of 106 King Street, Brooklyn, of a charge of second-degree assault. According to testimony, Anglin, a striker at the Robins Dry Dock and Repair Company in Brooklyn last Summer was arrested on the complaint of James Dunn, 55, of 68 Second Place, Brooklyn, a non-striker.
Japanese warships in the Yangtse River off Nanking escaped unscathed yesterday when subjected to two Chinese air raids by five planes each time, a Japanese spokesman has announced today.

The Transit Commission filed with the Court of Appeals in Albany yesterday its application for permission to appeal the rulings of the lower courts holding that the appointment of former Mayor James J. Walker as special counsel to the commission had not been properly made.
The Queens Department of Buildings had one of the heaviest days' work in its history yesterday in placing on file the plans for 715 buildings estimated to represent an aggregate cost of $4,865,300.

The Minneapolis, St. Paul Saulte Ste. Marie Railway Company filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission a petition for reorganization similar to that which it filed on Friday with the Federal Court for the District of Minnesota.

Continuous progress in all branches of the chemical and related products industries during 1937, and prospects for an exceptionally good year in 1938 despite recessions during the closing months of 1937, were reported today by C. C. Concannon, chief of the Chemical Division of the Deapartment .of Commerce.

Ralph Greenleaf, world pocket billiard champion, defeated Andrew Ponzi, former titleholder, in the first two blocks of their twelveblock meeting at the Strand Academy yesterday. Greenleaf, whose crown is not at stake, came from behind to win both times.

Abraham H. Schiff, who thought he had lost a seat in the State Constitutional Convention by 368 votes in the November election, found out yesterday that he had won by ninety-four votes when a check-up was made in six election machines in the Fourth Senatorial District in Brooklyn.

Today's major events: A special matinee of "Tristan und Isolde" at the Metropolitan Opera House; opening of season by the London Intimate Opera Company at the Little Theatre tonight; Jussi Bjoerling, Swedish tenor, in recital at the Town Hall tonight,' and Genia Nemenoff and Pierre Luboshutz, two pianos, at Carnegie Hall tonight.

Acting Captain Edward W. Flynn, executive officer of the Juvenile Aid Bureau of the New York Police Department, died yesterday morning at his home, 376 East 205th Street, the Bronx, of heart disease. He was 52 years old.

With the first varsity basketball game of 1938 scheduled for a local court tonight, New York City is in the strange position of starting a year with only one of its teams undefeated. The last of the Mohicans is Columbia, which is scheduled to meet Fordham at the Ram gymnasium tonight.
Thousands of furniture buyers today trudged through miles of exhibits in both the American Furniture Mart and the Merchandise Mart.

To holiday revelers who drank too often and too deeply at the wassail bowl came yesterday a mixed message from medical science of both hope and sympathy, depending chiefly on what form the hangover took.

Reorganization of through service on subway and elevated lines operated in the city was indicated as necessary if the city's opposition to the application by the I. R. T. receiver to disaffirm its Manhattan elevated lease is upheld, in a final brief filed by the Corporation Counsel's office with Federal. Judge Julian W. Mack yesterday.
In sharp contrast to the trend of general

Paulie Walker, veteran Trenton middleweight, last night kept his record for bouts at the St. Nicholas Palace clear of defeat. He added Chuck Woods of Detroit to his list of victims when he won the decision in an eight-round bout.
REPORTS OF ACTIVITIES IN METROPOLITA N REAL ESTATE

Mrs. Mary Hartigan, 60-years old, was killed instantly at 9:30 o'clock yesterday morning when she fell to a rear courtyard from her eighthfloor apartment at 258 Riverside Drive. Patrolman John Duross of West 100th Street station reported that Mrs. Hartigan was standing on a ladder removing Christmas decorations when the ladder slipped and she fell through a window.

The New York Curb Exchange has admitted to listing Allied Products Corporation (Michigan) Class A convertible common shares of $25 par value and common. shares of $10 par value, which were issued, share for share, in exchange of simflar issues of Allied Products Corporation (Illinois) under the plan of reorganization.

All-India today won the third of the unofficial cricket test matches with Lord Tennyson's touring eleven by 93 runs. The first two contests, played at Bombay, resulted in victories for the Englishmen.

A billion is a lot-whether it represents fish, acorns or dollars, but the Wisconsin Conservation Department passed this number in its stride during 1937 by planting no less than 1,096,730,400 fish in the streams of the State.

The total number of unemployed in New York City is between 600,000 and 615,000, according to Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local WPA Administrator, who based his estimate yesterday on a survey the WPA began last April.

To the surprise of practically every one, the Frederick Lonsdale who writes plays is actually staying around here for a while, thus shattering his old habit of taking the next boat home as soon as he lands in New York. What is keeping him here is his new comedy for Gilbert Miller, "Half a Loaf," about which the news is as follows:

Chinese here, official and non-official, consider a Japanese invasion of Kwangtung Province, involving an attack on Canton, only a matter of time and are concentrating their energies on preparations for a conflict.
President which is the Roosevelt's latest expression of faith in democracy had the same heartening effect upon British opinion tonight as his more dramatic speech at Chicago in October.

Ruling women's service on a grand jury illegal, Supreme Court Justice Edward N. Smith today excused two women drawn for service. Mrs. Ruth Kenyon of Adams had filed an exception and was not in court, but Mrs. Lucy C. Mitchell was present.

In sympathy with irregularity in Outside markets, prices on the Cotton Exchange moved uncertainly yesterday over a 12-point range to ind with a gain of 2 to a loss of B points. Holidays in overseas markets curtailed the volume of business, and most operators seemed disposed to await developments in Washington as well as in the genDral trade outlook following the surn of the year.

The battle between Mayor Frank Hague and the C. I. O. organizers continued here today as an attorney for the union ridiculed Jersey City authorities for their "apparent inability to maintain order" and as the Mayor offered "indisputable documentary proof that the Communist, Roger N. Baldwin, is the master mind in planning the C. I. O. attacks."
LETTERS TO A FRIEND, by Winifred Holtby. (Macmillan, $8.50.) Leters written by the late English novelist, covering the period 1920-26.

The Samoan Clipper arrived here today at 1:15 P. M. (6:45 P.. M., E. S. T.) from Kingman Reef, completing a round-trip flight of 8,904' miles which inaugurated a commercial airline linking the United States and Australasia.
Nathaniel Robinson of 840 West End Avenue, who had been associated with the public school system since 1907, died Sunday at the home of friends here of a heart attack at the age of 52.

The Georgia House of Representatives today endorsed "the principles advocated" by President Roosevelt "that our great country may continue to go forward and be the greatest nation with the happiest people on the face of this earth."

Eight men who, until their arrest, were high officials of Soviet Armenia have been shot at Yerevan (formerly Erivan) on multiple treason charges, prominent among which is conspiracy to bring about the secession of Armenia from the SovietUnion.

Comment on the President's message to Congress published by representative newspapers in the nation follows. NEW YORK "When the Trick Fails" From The Herald-Tribune (Ind. Rep.). The calm tone of the President's message is a welcome relief after the Jackson diatribes and the Ickes hysterics.

American professors remaining at Ginling College in Nanking as foreign members of the Refugee Welfare Committee were seriously embarrassed to discover that they had been harboring a deserted Chinese Army colonel and six of his subordinate officers.

The State Corporation Commission announced today that final authorization had been accorded to the Appalachian Electric Power Gompany to sell to the American Gas and Electric Company the Kingsport Utilities, Inc., of Kingsport, Tenn., and the Kentucky and West Virginia Power Company, Inc.

The text of the Supreme Court's unanimous opinion in the Alabama Power Company case, upholding PWA loans to municipalities to construct public power plants follows: (The court also handed down a brief collateral opinion to the same effect in the suit of the Duke Power Company and the Southern Public Utilities Company.)

The National Labor Relations Board announced today it had certified the National Maritime Union as the exclusive bargaining agency for unlicensed personnel on the boats or vessels operated by the Sinclair Navigation Company of New York City.
Shorterm and long range proposals on relief and unemployment will be presented to Senator Byrnes's Committee on Unemployment, which will open its sessions here tomorrow.

Albert T. Bard, vice president of the Reliance Manufacturing Company, has been placed in charge of all manufacturing operations of the company, it was announced yesterday by Herbert Mayer, president. Mr. Bard will be assisted by Sam Manaccus. David Gottlieb and Leon L. Chock, vice presidents, have been placed in charge of the Chicago operations and New York operations, respectively.

Miss Carlotta Joaquina Maury, forme paleontologist for the Brazilian Government and geologist for oil corporations, died today in her home here after an illness of one year. On Thursday she would have been 64 year old.

The Cardinals today announced a thirty-three game Spring training exhibition schedule. Twenty-two games will be played in Florida, after which the club will leave its St. Petersburg training base and make a swing through the Southwest. Fourteen games will be held at St. Petersburg.

The continued slump of industrial, activity is shown in November reports from manufacturers in twenty-five industries analyzed in the National Industrial Conference Board's current service letter made public yesterday.

The time formerly required by automobiles to cross town was reduced about 60 per cent on the -ten midtown streets where the daytime prohibition of week-day parking went into effect yesterday, the police reported.

American Fidelity and Casualty Co., Inc., Richmond, Va.-Net underwriting profits for the first eight months of 1937 amounted to $93,467 against $63,677 for all of 1936, according to S. A. Markel, president. During last year the company has become licensed in adaitional States including New York, Pennsylvania, Michigan, Illinois. California, Oregon, Arizona and' Nevada and is now licensed in twenty-eight States.

Four parcels of land at the northwest corner of Roosevelt Avenue and Prince Street, Flushing, L. I., having a frontage of 100 feet on Roosevelt Avenue and a depth ot approximately 77 feet, have been purchased by the Gulf Oil Corporation, which plans to erect an automobile service station on the site.

Several thousand commuters living in the eastern part of Westchester County had to seek new means of reaching their offices in New York today because of the closing on Jan. 1 of the bankrupt New York, Westchester Boston Railway. Many used automobiles, picking up friends and driving to the Bronx subways, while others traveled on buses and railroads that were new to them.

An offer to drop charges of unfair. labor practices against the management of the, Ford assembly plant here was made todaY by Claude O. Pearcy, counsel for the United Automobile Workers of America, at a National Labor Relations Board hearing on a complaint filed by the union.

Promulgation of the Fair Trade Practice Rules for the popular priced dress manufacturing industry by the Federal Trade Commission marks the beginning of a new administrative procedure in curbing unfair returns, Louis Rubin, executive director of the Popular Priced Dress Manufacturers Group, Inc., and Charles Ballon of the firm of Hartman, Sheridan Tekulsky, counsel to the manufacturers group, said yesterday.

Shore's Mabel Doone, a white and liver pointer bitch owned and handled by Raymond Hoagland of Cartersville, Ga., and New York, placed first today in the amateur all-age stakes of the Pinehurst Field Trial Club.

There seems to be no "recession" for artists like Yehudi Menuhin. His recital at Carnegie Hall last night attracted absolute capacity, with an overflow of 300 personsthe limit under the law-crowding the stage. There was barely room for Ferguson Webster, the gifted accompanist.

Matthew M. Levy, legal adviser to the American Labor party, who on Saturday was selected by Mayor La Guardia to succeed Michael B. McHugh as Municipal Court judge in the Bronx, has been living like a Spartan since his appointment, it was learned yesterday.

Frank E. Gannett, Rochester editor and publisher, has accepted the invitation of General John J. Pershing, chairman of the national antisyphilis committee of the American Social Hygiene Association, to serve as committee chairman for this State, it was announced today by Ray Lyman Wilbur, president of the association.
Paul Redfern, aviator, who vanished on an attempted non-stop flight from Georgia to Rio de Janeiro in 1927, was declared legally dead today on petition of his wife.

It has been suggested, as one explanation of the recent excitement of Assistant Attorney General Robert H. Jackson, that he has got himself confused with Andrew Jackson and is exhibiting the Old Hickory quality.

Trudie Bennett, 17-year-old daughter of Harry Bennett, head of the service department of the Ford Motor Company, has been missing since 3 P. M. yesterday following a series of threats received at the Bennett home, the State police made known early today.

The newspaper Angriff today demanded the suppression of the special privileges of the Catholic church. Occupying one-half of the front page the article. apparently was meant to be the opening gun in an campaign for the disestablishment of the church as prophesied by Hanns Kerl Reich Minister for Church Affairs, in his addresses last Autumn.
Most commodity futures declined in fairly active trading yesterday on the local exchanges. Crude rubber and wool top futures were weak and hide and copper futures advanced slightly.

The ship Coamo of the Porto Rico line in from New York this morning was unexpectedly tied up by what the company alleges is an unauthorized C. I. O. strike called by Fred Small, organizer, who called out the watchmen and clerks.

John A. Dilliard, former president of the State Title and Mortgage Company, which failed in 1933 with more than $60,000,000 in mortgages and mortgage certificates outstanding, lost $1,000,000 in the failure, he testified yesterday at his trial in Federal Court for alleged mail fraud and conspiracy.
Kenneth F. Simpson, New York County Republican Chairman, announced yesterday that Representative Bruce Barton had appointed Isidor Schiff of 154 West Seventieth Street his political secretary.

Joseph P. Delaney, for thirty years a Public Service Commission employee and a trainer of race horses, died today after a short illness at the age of 64. As a horse trainer he was employed by the Whitney stables during the Saratoga Springs season and also trained horses for Representative Parker Corning of Albany.

Warner Brothers announced today the return of James Cagney to the studio on March 14. J. L. Warner and Cagney disclosed that attorneys have been instructed to withdraw the appeal made to the California Supreme Court which followed Cagney's victory in the lower court to abrogate his contract.

Senator A. Harry Moore said today that Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City would not be interested in appointment as United States Senator. Mr. Moore will take the oath as Governor of New Jersey on Jan. 18 and Mr. Hague has been mentioned as his possible successor here.

The New York Trust Company has resigned, effective yesterday, as co-depositary for the Bondholders Committee for the Republic of Colombia, the committee announced yesterday. The bank is a trustee for one of the Colombian bond issues represented by the committee.

Ralph A. McClelland of Scarsdale was elected chairman of the Westchester County Board of Supervisors this afternoon at the board's annual reorganization meeting. He had been Republican majority leader in 1936 and 1937. Frederick G.

STUDENT FAGERPRINT CLASSIFIER, $1,440 a year. Federal Bureau of Investigation, Department of Justice, Washington, D. C. Applications must be on file not later than the following dates: (a) Jan. 24, 1938, if received from States other than those named in (b) below. (b) Jan. 27, 1938, if received from the following States:

The St. John's University junior varsity basketball team routed the Brooklyn College Jayvees, 48 to 20, at De Gray Gymnasium yesterday. Jake Ahearn, with 14 points, excelled for the Redmen, who led at the half, 28 to 9.

Representing a year of research, a catalogue of ninety-five Catholic plays has just been published by the National Service Bureau of the Federal Theatre Project. Chosen primarily for production by project and non-professional groups, the plays listed have either been presented here or abroad or have received unusual critical attention.

Granting of rate increases is not the solution of the nation's railroad problem, although many owners of railroad securities and "others who are not so well informed" seem to think it is, the Interstate Commerce Commission asserted today in its fifty-first annual report.
Import of cement aggregated 53,739,102 pounds, valued at $119,288 in Nomember, compared with 76,208,682 pounds, valued at $178,332, in Nomember, 1936, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Walter Gabell, late president of the Northern Central Trust Company, Philadelphia, was exonerated today, two years after his death, of a charge of embezzling $60,000 of the bank's funds on which he received a suspended sentence following a plea of guilty four years ago.
Eli T. Conner, dean of mining engineers of the anthracite field and nationally known for his work in connection with mining problems, died today in a hospital at the age of 73.

Punch's famous cartoon, "Dropping the Pilot," depicting Bismarck's dismissal by the young Kaiser Wilhelm II, might appropriately be reproduced today to illustrate the dismissal of Mustafa Nahas Pasha, long Premier and head of the predominant Wafd (Nationalist) party, by the 18-year-old King Farouk.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Dec. 31, unless specified: San Diego to San Pedro, Jan 3: Brazos, Dorsey. San Diego to Mare Island, Jan. 3: Cincinnati, Sandpiper. Coco Solo to Panama Bay Area, Jan. 3:

Solly Krieger, Brooklyn middleweight, claimed yesterday that he, and not Fred Apostoli, who meets Champion Freddie Steele in a nontitle bout at Madison Square Garden Friday night, is the foremost challenger in the division.

Although drawn, the twenty-sixth game of the recent world championship match between Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, the victor, and Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, was not without its special points of interest.

Formal transfer of title to some of the additional property at the south end of the Fort Tryon Park improvement from John D. Rockefeller Jr. to the city was filed with the New York County Register yesterday.

Mrs. Lena K. Bechtold of 50 Locust Hill Avenue, Yonkers, prominent in fraternal orders and former Grand Chief of New York State lodges of Pythian Sisters, died today at the age of 74. She was the widow of Louis R. Bechtold.

William Lawrence Calhoun, music teacher, who formerly taught in Missouri and later in New York, died on Friday at St. Vincent's Hospital after a brief illness at the age of 75. He lived at the Twentythird Street Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association, 215 West Twenty-third Street.

Dr. Jacob H. Hollander, Professor of Economics at Johns Hopkins University, today announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Bertha Hutzler Hollander, to Dr. David A. Gershenson of Fairfield, Ill.
New judges were inducted in the superior and lower courts throughout the city yesterday, many of them in ceremonies attended by groups of friends and a few without ceremony.

Operation of electric trains on the Pennsylvania Railroad to Harrisburg is expected to be in effect within two or three weeks, giving the company electric service from New York to the Pennsylvania capital, a distance of about 194 miles.

Secretary Morgenthau denied at his press conference this afternoon that President Roosevelt's message to Congress was in conflict with Mr. Morgenthau's speech in New York Nov. 10, in which he announced the Administration's intention of trying to balance the budget in 1939.

The New Orleans States said today that Governor Richard Leche planned to resign as Chief Executive soon to accept a proposed new Federal judgeship in Louisiana. The newspaper said that an authoritative source reported Mr. Leche planned to retire before the Legislature meets in May.

President Roosevelt's decision to lower the price paid by the government for newly mined domestic silver from 77.57 cents to 64.64 cents an ounce followed an "exhaustive study" of the domestic silver situation by the Treasury, Secretary Morgenthau disclosed at his press conference this afternoon.
THE CRADLE WILL ROCK, a play with music in two parts by Marc Blitzstein. Staged by Orson Welles; presented by Sam H. Grisman, in association with the Mercury Theatre. At the Windsor Theatre.

Contracts for the immediate construction of twelve high-speed tankers, intended primarily as auxiliaries to travel with the United States fleet were signed today by the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey and four shipbuilding concerns.
Secretary Wallace declared here tonight that "it doesn't do either labor or agriculture any good to scare capital; instead, they must all find ways to work together."

Mrs. Newbold L. Herrick entertrained yesterday with a luncheon at La Salle du Bois for Mrs. Gilbert Burdett and Miss Ruth M. Burdett, who will leave tomorrow for Camden, S. C. Luncheon guests of Mrs. H. Seymour Shonnard Jr. at the Trouville were Mrs. John Englis, Mrs. S. Hillen MacSherry, Mrs. Roswell Colt and Miss Josephine MacSherry.

Major events of the week-end were the opening of the new building of the Society of the Four Arts, the informal debut of the Palm Beach Biltmore, formerly the Alba; and the opening of Whitehall and the Sun and Surf and Palm Beach Country Clubs.

The Federal Trade Commission will complete its presentation of evidence against the Fashion Originators Guild of America, Inc., at a hearing tomorrow at 11 A. M. in the commission's offices, 45 Broadway.

Attorney General Cummings is still following hard on the heels of that inveterate enemy of justice, delay. His annual statistical table showing the time required to bring civil cases to trial after joinder of issue has been of great help to the Judicial Conference of senior circuit justices presided over by the Chief Justice.

Even play marked the Sheffield Shield cricket match between Victoria and South Australia today. At the close of the third day South Australia had made 304 and 148. for three wickets, Victoria compiling a first innings' score of 364.
A plan of reorganization for the Hartford Connecticut Western Railroad Company, a subsidiary of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, was filed today with the Interstate Commerce. Commission.
The football rules committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association announced today two changes in playing regulations, both of which will aid the offense.

The Richard B. Harrison Students Memorial, an acting group formed in honor of the late "Lawd" of "The Green Pastures," will give a performance of "Othello" Thursday night at the Y. W. C. A. auditorium, 144 West 138th Street. The cast will consist entirely of Negro players under the direction of William Simmons.

ABBE-Harriet Colgate, on Sunday, Jan. 2, 1938, in her eighty-second year. Funeral services at Chapel of Riverside Church, Tuesday, Jan. 4, at 2 P. M. It is requested that no flowers be sent. AHEARN-James F., Jan. 2, beloved husband of Catherine Ahearn (nee Corcoran) and devoted father of John P., Margaret M., Kathleen and Rita Ahearn.

The New York wholesale dress market was quiet last week, with little demand for merchandise of any type from manufacturers, according to the weekly report issued yesterday by the research and statistical department of the joint board of the Dress and Waistmakers Union.

The estate of Gloria Laura Morgan Vanderbilt, 14-year-old daughter of Mrs. Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt and the late Reginald C. Vanderbilt, was valued at $4,082,255 on Dec. 27, according to an accounting filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday by Thomas B. Gilchrist, her general guardian.

The New Jersey Alumnae Club of the Bennett School in Millbrook, N. Y., will give an invitation subscription dance at the Montclair Golf Club tomorrow after the presentation of "Fol-De-Rol" by the Princeton Triangle Club at the Montclair Theatre.

President Lazaro Cardenas tonight shook up his Cabinet for the first time in more than a year in order to strengthen it and pay political rewards. Efrain Buenrostro, sub-secretary of finance, was made Secretary of National Economy in charge of the oil industry replacing Rafael Sanchez Tapia.

Holders of Chinese Republic 5 per cent bonds of 1925 have been notified that,. under the terms of the amortization plan, 53,007 of the bonds have been drawn for redemption and are payable on or after Jan. 15 at their face value of $50 each at the offices of the Banca Commercials Italiana's agency in New York.

The New York State Labor Relations Board asserted its jurisdiction over the Bank of Yorktown, Thirtyseventh Street and Elighth Avenue, yesterday when it handed down a decision ordering an election among the bank's forty-four employes to determine their collective bargainIng agency.

Officials of the Dollar I4ine announced today from headquarters here that they had abandoned to the under writers the $8,000,000 luxury liner President Hoover which grounded Dec. 19 on a reef off Hashioto Island, near Formosa.
The Pennsylvania Supreme Court today' decided that Goldstein- Levin, a dress manufacturing firm, need not return its plant to Philadelphia from Johnstown. The firm moved to Johnstown last Summer.

The message which President Roasevelt read to Congress yesterday is the message for which a great many middle-of-the-road democrats have been waiting. In it, to be sure, there are certain recommendations whose wisdon may be questioned.
The 124th Field Artillery polo team of Chicago defeated the Cuban Army team, 6 to 4, today in the first game of a series on Camp Columbia field.

That the City Council might intervene in the present milk price controveray was indicated yesterday when Newbold Morris, Council President, informed the body in his opening address that it had power to "make rules for the distribution of milk."

Mr. and Mrs. Henry M. Post will give a dinner dance on Saturday in the Crystal Garden of the RitzCarlton for their niece, Miss Julia Gilbert Post, debutante daughter of Charles Morgan Post. Dr. and Mrs. Fielding Lewis Taylor are expected today at the Carlyle.
Heavy fighting which left Teruel's snowbanked battlefields littered with thousands of dead tonight surged about the strategically located pro vincial capital.
The German Red Cross received a new constitution today limiting its activity and providing that all of its personnel must take a special oath of personal loyalty to Chancellor Adolf Hitler.
A. F. Sangster, American aviation instructor, and Harold Walsh of San Francisco, his mechanic, were killed today in a crash here.
Member lines of the Atlantic Passenger Conference have revised their excursion rates for certain periods of the year for passengers in tourist and third class quarters, it was announced yesterday.

The list of the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria, sailing today for Southampton via Cherbourg, in- from cludes Baron and Baroness Stackleberg, Sir C. M. Barclay-Harvey, W. N. McG. Hogg, third secretary of the British Embassy at Washington; Charles B. Cochran, British theatrical producer, and Mrs. Cochran; Peggy Wood, the Hon. Penelope Dudley Ward and Gladys Hanson, actresses.

Frank F. Kolbe, a member of the original syndicate that purchased the control of the Aklleghany Cor portion, the top holding company of the old Van Sweringen railroad system, said yesterday he had no interest in the Seaboard Company, Ltd.,

It's still Gordon Drillon and the rest of the league, so far as the race for individual scoring honors in the National Hockey League is concerned. The young Toronto Maple Leaf amassed four points during the last week, and stayed out in front by a comfortable margin.

Plans for extensive alterations in the twelve-story apartment house at. 777 West End Avenue, at the southwest corner of Ninety-eighth Street, are due to be filed today by Schwartz Gross, architects, in behalf of the owners, the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

C. Milton Schenk, a Linden school teacher, died today at the Elizabeth General Hospital here following an operation for appendicitis. Born in Bridgeport, Conn., he was a graduate of Battin High School and the Westchester State Teachers College of Pennsylvania.

Sir Henry Imbert-Terry, Baronet, historian, music critic and founder of the Junior Imperial League, died here today at the age of 83. Sir Henry Machu Imbert-Terry, first Baronet, was chairman of the Junior Imperial League from 1906 to 1927, and of the Central Organization Committee of the Unionist party, 1907-17.
The Count of Covadonga, who is ill at the Cuban Association Clinic here, received a blood transfusion tonight.

There was a rushing business yesterday at the office of Charles E. Harnett, Motor Vehicles Commissioner, at the State Office Building. Deputy Commissioner I. J. Brody estimated at the close of the business day that between 4,000 and 5,000 persons had applied on the first day that 1938 license plates were passed over the counter.

A reduction of 1 cent a yard from the last published prices was announced yesterday on denims by two of the leading producers. Cone Export and Commission Company announced a price of 11 cents on its standard 2.20 denims, for deliveries through March, compared with its last announced price of 12 cents, made on Oct. 20.

Free Synagogue House, 40 West Sixty-eighth Street. "Social Economic and Political Backgrounds of Jewish History," Dr. Sidney E. Goldstein, 10:45 A. M.; "Intimate Glimpses of Fascinating Mexico," Rabbi J. X. Cohen, 2:15 P. M.

Daniel E. Osgodby of Piedmont, Calif., assistant director of sales for the Pacific Coast division of the Congoleum-Nairn Company, died here today of a heart attack at the age of 58. Mr. Osgodby was visiting his son-in-law, R. F. Jones, at the Hotel East Orange preparatory to attending the opening today of the floor covering market in New York.
Paul Pidcock thrilled 1,000 hockey fans at Playland Casino tonight as McGill University of Montreal battered the University of Montreal sextet to win, 15 to 1.

Expressing "high appreciation" for the fairness shown by the Federal Trade Commission, James H. Oliver, president of Oliver Brothers, Inc., of 421 Canal Street, said yesterday that the commission's order for the company to cease and desist from alleged violations of the brokerage clause of the RobinsonPatman act, came as no surprise to the company.

The bodies of Edward J. Neil Jr., Associated Press correspondent, and Bradish Johnson, correspondent for the magazines Spur and Newsweek, and the body of Richard Sheepshanks, correspondent for Reuter's [British] news agency, left by motor this morning for Irun, on the French frontier, after a funeral mass at La Seo Cathedral in Saragossa.

President Roosevelt's address to Congress was greeted here with the customary unfavorable reception. The press in headlines emphasizes the President's proposal for increased armaments, -but only two papers comment on it and very briefly at that.

William B. Herlands, sworn in as Commissioner of the new Department of Investigation by Mayor La Guardia at 9:45 A. M. yesterday, immediately started several investigations, including a survey of the New York County Clerk's office which will go thoroughly into the conduct of the office by Albert Marinelli, Tammany district leader who resigned under fire.

A six-year plan providing for sixty-six new schools and 192 replacements to assure adequate schools for New York City was outlined by Dr. John E. Wade, associate superintendent of schools in charge of buildings, last night at a meeting of the delegate assembly of the United Parents Associations at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The stock market here was generally firm today, although business was on a small scale. Gilt-edge issues were well supported, while in a quiet foreign bond section Far Eastern loans did well. Transatlantic stocks were dull for the most part, although little selling was evident.

A triple tie for first place among Samuel Reshevsky, the United States champion; Paul Keres of Estonia and Salo Flohr of Czechoslovakia resulted from today's play in the international masters' tournament at the Hastings and St. Leonards Chess Club.

The new Department of Public Works was without a commissioner yesterday, as none has yet been named, but E. J. McGrew Jr., Deputy Commissioner of the defunct Department of Plant and Structures, stepped into the breach with an elaborate set of temporary

Without deciding the legality of President Roosevelt's theory of a "prudent investment," as a basis in valuing utilities for rate-making purposes, the Supreme Court today returned the cases of the Pacific Gas Electric Company to the lower courts to see if rates prescribed by the California Railroad Commission were confiscatory.

An application of the Santa Fe Trail Transportation Company to acquire control of the Central Arizona Transportation Lines, Inc., and Rio Grande Stages, Inc., from the Santa Fe Trail Stages, Inc., by purchase of capital stock for $150,000, was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Residential building operations continued active in the Bronx yesterday. Among the plans filed were three apartment projects involving a total estimated expenditure of $565,000. In that borough and in Brooklyn several new private dwellings also were projected.
A thorough investigation by the Federal Trade Commission of the Tennessee Valley Authority was proposed in a joint resolution today by Senator Norris, who is known as the "father of the TVA Act."

Mr. and Mrs. George F. Bayle Sr. of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Marie Bayle, to James Henry Minnick of Syracuse, son of Mrs. Rose Minnick of Glens Falls.

Miss Dorothy Rivers of this city, formerly of Chesterfield and Greenville, S. C., daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Geoffrey Rivers of Chesterfield, was married yesterday afternoon to Frank S. Nugent in the City Hall chambers of Mayor Florello H. La Guardia, who performed the ceremony.
The Supreme Court's grant today of a review of lower court decisions upholding the registration provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act in the Electric Bond and Share case,

The House Subcommittee on Taxation, in an effort to aid corporations undergoing financial difficulties, agreed today to apply to them the lower corporate tax rates which it had tentatively decided to apply only to corporations with net incomes of $25,000 or less, in the legislation now being prepared.

All United States and British oil refineries in Tampico were closed today. Among them were those of the Plerce.Sinclair; Dutch Shell, managed by the Mexican Eagle Company, and the Standard Oil of New Jersey subsidiary, Huasteca.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In Friday's financial section were three articles illustrative of a noteworthy trend. For a long time business leaders have been woefully weak in anything resembling leadership. All last Spring and Summer resentment, bitterness, antagonism toward the government and privately expressed invective were rampant.

Trading was only fair to slow on most steer beef. Demand for other classes was fair. Steer cuts sold unevenly. The lamb market was higher. Fresh pork, steady to lower. Other classes steady. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef to be stronger; veal and calf sharply lower; lamb about steady, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.
A change in annual volume rebate schedules was the chief feature of an otherwise colorless trade opening of Spring rugs and carpets here yesterday.

Bryan M. (Bitsy) Grant and the other seeded players won easy first-round matches today at the opening of the annual Miami Biltmore tennis tournament. Grant, seeded second, eliminated Charles Carroll, a local player, 6-1, 6-1, in a style that confirmed expectations he would go to the final.

Almerindo Portfolio, who as City Treasurer is in charge of the revamped Department of Finance, announced yesterday the appointment of William Reid as City Collector and of Andrew J. Galligan as chief of the new bureau of receipts and disbursements.

In addressing the Congress on the state of the Union, present facts and future hazards demand that I speak clearly and earnestly of the causes which underlie events of profound concern to all. In spite of the d termination of this nation for peace, it has become clear that acts and policies of nations in other parts of the world have far-reaching effects not only upon their immediate neighbors, but also on us.

Receipts of revenue by the political parties in 1937 included $1,294,743.57 by the Democratic National Committee and $628,046.98 by the Republican National Committee. Republican expenditures were reported at $632,185.12.

The American Labor party began yesterday a survey of rents in the city, the findings of which will guide the party's representatives in the Legislature and City Council in drafting legislation to aid tenants, Alex Rose, State executive secretary, announced yesterday.

Mrs. Emma C. Havens, wife of Colonel Elmer H. Havens, president of the Bridgeport Library Board and member of the firm of Hunter Havens, Inc., died today at the age of 67. She was a sister of the late Howard Curtis, Connecticut Supreme Court Justice.
A change in annual volume rebate schedules was the chief feature of an otherwise colorless trade opening of Spring rugs and carpets here yesterday.

Bryan M. (Bitsy) Grant and the other seeded players won easy first-round matches today at the opening of the annual Miami Biltmore tennis tournament. Grant, seeded second, eliminated Charles Carroll, a local player, 6-1, 6-1, in a style that confirmed expectations he would go to the final.

Almerindo Portfolio, who as City Treasurer is in charge of the revamped Department of Finance, announced yesterday the appointment of William Reid as City Collector and of Andrew J. Galligan as chief of the new bureau of receipts and disbursements.

In addressing the Congress on the state of the Union, present facts and future hazards demand that I speak clearly and earnestly of the causes which underlie events of profound concern to all. In spite of the d termination of this nation for peace, it has become clear that acts and policies of nations in other parts of the world have far-reaching effects not only upon their immediate neighbors, but also on us.

Receipts of revenue by the political parties in 1937 included $1,294,743.57 by the Democratic National Committee and $628,046.98 by the Republican National Committee. Republican expenditures were reported at $632,185.12.

The American Labor party began yesterday a survey of rents in the city, the findings of which will guide the party's representatives in the Legislature and City Council in drafting legislation to aid tenants, Alex Rose, State executive secretary, announced yesterday.

The first day of business in Wall Street for 1938 failed to produce any sensational rises in stock prices despite the many encouraging pieces of news over the week-end, but generally the financial section was in a happier frame of mind.

Leroy T. Vernon, political editor of The Chicago Daily News and for twentyfive years chief of the newspaper's Washington bureau, died today in his home. He was 59 years old. Mr. Vernon recovered from an attack of pneumonia in November, but later suffered a blood clot in his right leg.

With Sir Jonn C. W. Reith, director general of the British Broadcasting Corporation making his first appearance before the microphone since he introduced Edward's farewell broadcast the night of the abdication, Britain today sent her own version of what is happening in the world

In his first show for two years, Stephen Etnier, a score of whose canvases are on view at the Milch Galleries, has made the most notable advance he has yet achieved between any two exhibitions. His palette has deepened. There is evidence of a new sureness in his work.

Charles H. Hoag, president or the Star Towel Supply Company, Inc., 1,666 Summerfield Street, Brooklyn, died today of a heart ailment at his home at 47 Roxbury Road here after a long illness. His age was 69. Surviving are his widow, Mrs. Sarah Keith Hoag;

Colonel Francois de la Rocque, leader of the Rightist French Social party, today received 10,000 francs damages in a libel action against seventeen newspapers which he charged with her slanderously accusing him of ac- trio cepting government "secret funds."

Patrick J. O'Connor, former member of the Essex County Board of Freeholders and a former State Service Commissioner, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 77 Mount Pleasant Avenue, at the age of 55.

The Court of Errors and Appeals was asked today by Morris Umansky to declare him judge of the North Hudson District Court. A judgment of ouster, returned by a Hudson County jury, was upheld by the Supreme Court and it is from that decision that he is appealing.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has issued an order declaring the West Penn Railways Company, a subsidiary of the American Water Works and Electric Company, not to be a holding company within the meaning of Section 11 (B) (2) of the Public Utility Holding Company

WHEN Winifred Holtby died in 1985 she was still in her thirties and the author of a dozen books, including "Mandoa, Mandoa" and "South Riding." Those who had been her admirers said that with her death England had lost one of its finest novelists. However this may be, there is no doubt that England lost an able and sincere young woman-one who' was representative, in many ways, of the troubled post-war period.

One of Thomas E. Dewey's first acts yesterday as he started his first work day as District Attorney of New York County was to order the removal of the big well-padded leather sofa in the old recreation room attached to his private office, which was used frequently by his predecessor, William C. Dodge.

William C. Chanler, taking over the office of Corporation Counsel from his former chief, Paul Windels, announced yesterday the establishment of two new bureaus in the law department and the appointment of nine Assistant Corporation Counsel.
Contributions amounting to $1,541.25 were received by the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday from fifty-two donors. They brought the total that has been received in the present appeal to $295,602.90.
Steve Dudas, 196, Edgewater, N. J., knocked out Roy (Tiger) Williams, 176 3/4, Chicago Negro, in the fourth round of a scheduled eight-round boxing bout tonight.

More than 500 patrons attending a motion picture show at the Eagle Theatre, 1,852 Third Avenue, near 102d Street, were ordered from the building at 11 o'clock last night because of smoke from a fire in the basement storehouse.

World lead production in November amounted to 172,180 tons, compared with 164,146 in October, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics. Output in the United States was 42,892 tons in November, against 45,112 in October.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 27,000, Including 6,000 directs. The market closed active and around 10c higher than the low time today, or 10 to 15c lower than Friday's average.

Following the recent filing by the Mountain States Power Company of a petition for reorganization under section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act, holders of "substantial total" of the company's first- mortgage bonds have formed a protective committee headed by H. S. Payson,

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Dec. 30: CAPTAIN Helm, J. B., Med. Corps, granted sick leave of three months; to await orders at Washington. D. C. LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS Gorry, W. A., the Raleigh; to Submarine Base, New London, Conn. Sayre, F. N., Receiving Ship at San Francisco: to the Portland as First Lieutenant and Damage Control Officer.

The engagement of Miss Jeannette Morse Genius, daughter of Dr. Richard M. Genius of Winter Park, Fla., to Hugh Ferguson McKean, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur McKean of Orlando, Fla., has been announced here by her father.
President Alberto Enriquez prohibited by executive decree today all forms of gambling in which money or other things of value are risked and winning depends on chance.

James F. Ahearn, former Tammany leader of the old Nineteenth Assembly District in Manhattan and a cousin of the late John F. Ahearn, also a Tammany leader, died Sunday at his home, 54 Carroll Street, City Island, the Bronx, after a short illness. He was 68 years old.

Stanley M. Isaacs, on taking over the office of Borough President of Manhattan yesterday, announced he would urge the City Planning Commission to give early attention to the rehabilitation of large residential areas of the borough.

The price of silver advanced here and in London yesterday when dealings in the metal were resumed for the first time since the announcement on Friday night by President Roosevelt of a reduction in the price to be paid to domestic producers of the metal from 77.57 cents to 64.64 cents.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 27,000, Including 6,000 directs. The market closed active and around 10c higher than the low time today, or 10 to 15c lower than Friday's average.

Following the recent filing by the Mountain States Power Company of a petition for reorganization under section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act, holders of "substantial total" of the company's first- mortgage bonds have formed a protective committee headed by H. S. Payson,

Stanley M. Isaacs, on taking over the office of Borough President of Manhattan yesterday, announced he would urge the City Planning Commission to give early attention to the rehabilitation of large residential areas of the borough.

The price of silver advanced here and in London yesterday when dealings in the metal were resumed for the first time since the announcement on Friday night by President Roosevelt of a reduction in the price to be paid to domestic producers of the metal from 77.57 cents to 64.64 cents.

139th St, 244 W. 17x99.11; William Sills to Railroad Federal Savings Loan Assn, 441 Lexington Ave, due as bond, 6%; $3,500. 112th St. 246-8 E, 37.6x100.11; Concetta Bonfiglio to 246 E 112th St Corp. 24 Lee Ave, Yonkers, N. Y., 5 yrs, 5%; $21,000. 10th St, 270 E, 25x96.4; 270 E 10th St Corp (Chas. Kissel, secy), to Central Savings Bank, pr mtg, 10 yrs, Int per bond, $12,000.

Because there has been almost as much difficulty in filling vacancies in the London police force as in the British Army, future "Bobbies" will be permitted to be an inch shorter than the present towering policemen.
The New York Americans will try once more to snare a victory in their intra-city series with the Rangers, when the teams meet at Madison Square Garden tonight in a National Hockey League game.

Samuel Hulse, 80 years old, a retired fisherman, who lived alone in a small shack on South Ocean Avenue, was found dead today of shock following burns he suffered probably on Sunday, when his clothing became ignited in some manner. Mr. Hulse had succeeded in putting out the fire and in getting into bed, where his body was found.

The nineteenth annual pilgrimage to the grave of former President Theodore Roosevelt, who died Jan. 6, 1919, will be made Thursday when the surviving men and women associates of the late President, who have made the pilgrimage yearly, gather at Youngs Memorial Cemetery, Cove Neck.

Christmas will arrive here on Friday for thousands of Russian and Syrian church members. They observe the day 'according to the Julian church calendar. Tomorrow night there will be numerous Christmas.Eve church services and on Friday morning many services will be held.

Harry I L. Todd, one of the leading members of the Masonic order in California and. postmaster at San Francisco under the Coolidge and Hoover administrations, died of a heart attack in his home here last night at the age of-69.

Additional local and out-of-town banks made public yesterday their statements of condition as of Dec. 31, in anticipation of the calling of such reports by the State and Federal supervisory authorities. Although some variation appeared among the reports the prevailing trend for the last quarter of the year was one of declining loans and deposits and lower total assets.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced $1 a bale yesterday on an increased volume of business that carried the list into new high ground for the movement. In sympathy with the strength in outside markets and a better trade demand, May cotton sold above 8 1/2 cents a pound before meeting a supply of contracts sufficient to halt the rise.

A suit for damages in excess of $1,000,000 and for an accounting was begun yesterday in Federal court for the alleged infringement of patents covering a one-piece razor. The plaintiff, represented by Saul W. Goodman, attorney of 270 Broadway, is the Segal Safety Razor Corporation, and the defendant is the Gillette Safety Razor Company, Inc.

In the fiscal year ended on June 30, 1937, the Federal Communications Commission was instrumental in bringing about reductions in telephone rates which will save subscribers $21,000,000 or more annually, the commission said in its annual report issued today.

The J. J. Newberry Company has sold 1,000 shares of its Series A 5 per cent preferred stock to the Hartford Fire Insurance Company for $101,000 in cash, the proceeds to be used as additional working capital.

An increase of nearly $1,500,000,000 in the value of foreign trade of the United States during the first eleven months of 1937 over the corresponding period of 1936 brought a large measure of activity to the country's principal ports, according to a bulletin issued by the State Department today.
A reorganization plan whereby the Witherbee - Sherman Corporation and its subsidiary, the Port Henry Mining Company, may reorganize has the approval of Federal Judge Frederick H. Bryant.
Paced by the brilliant Phil Viscidi, the Yale Composite team last night won the national junior saber championship, defeating the Fencers club in the final at the Salle d'Armes Henry IV, 5 to 2.

The Insurgent counter- offensive against Teruel has failed. From your correspondent's inquiry on the spot yesterday, it seems certain that the Rebels never reached the city, never made contact with the garrison and refugees in the cellars of Teruel, never captured any Government general staff officers and in short never really menaced the provincial capital, which remains firmly in Government hands.

Given a guarantee by the Chesapeake Ohio Railway, the Erie Railroad could obtain from private bankers the $6,006,000 that it seeks to borrow from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, it was ascertained yesterday in Wall Street. By declining to give this guarantee the C. 0. has blocked the Erie from obtaining the loan from the government.

Of particular interest is the exhibition that opened yesterday at the Macbeth Gallery, 11 East Fiftyseventh Street. For it serves to bring again before us that group of American artists known as "The Eight."

The alms of the new Goga government in Rumania are daily becoming harder to discover. As its anti-Semitic measures multiply, its protestations that nothing really serious is intended increase in the same proportion.

172d St (11-2905), n w cor of Washington Ave, 95x30; Bernard C. McDonald, referee, to Union Dime Savings Bank, 1,065 6th Ave. 173d St (11-2914). s e cor of Washington Ave. 100x30; Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to Modernization Building Corp. 55 W 42d St: mtg $34,000.

Exports of canned crab meat from Japan to the United States during the first ten months of 1937 totaled 194,175 cases, compared with 135,861 cases in the corresponding period of 1936, the Commerce Department reported today.

Fourteen men and one woman were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn as members of a bootleg ring which defrauded the government of about $10,000,000 in taxes in the last three years and poured about 500,000 gallons of illicit whisky into the city annually.
The far-flung nature of Japan's ultimate plans for controlling China and ousting American and European influence is gradually unfolding.

A rapid spread of the sale of grade B milk at 10 cents a quart throughout the city was reported to Mayor La Guardia yesterday by William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Markets. More than 80 per cent of stores retailing milk have reduced the price to 10 cents and the number of stores selling it for 9 cents has also increased, the commissioner said.
California won't repeat as 1938 football champion of the Pacific Coast conference, but watch out for the Golden Bears in 1939, says Coach Leonard (Stub) Allison.
AFTER 1903--WHAT? by Robert Benchley. (Harper, $2.50.) Humorous essays. THE ITALIANS OF NEW YORK, by workers of the Federal Writers Project. (Random House, $2.) A volume in the American Guide Series.

The Rev. Dr. Frank E. Torrey, former mem- M ber of the board of trustees and the board of stewards of the New York Eastern Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, died today after a long illness at the Deaconess Hospital.

A plan to make Iceland's hot springs, near this capital, provide the buildings of the city with natural central heating is now nearing realization. Through borings the capacity of the springs has been increased, so that they can now yield nearly forty gallons of hot water per second.

Richard W. Heurtley Jr., 17 years old, who had been the object of a wide search since he started out from Darien Friday in a 18-foot canoe to paddle to Florida, was picked up today off Rocky Point, L I., by the Coast Guard patrol boat OG-833.
Puerto Rico's Mediation Commission was instructed today by Acting Governor Rafael Menendez Ramos to attempt to end a strike that today paralyzed shipping in all Puerto Rican ports.

Members of the United Licensed Officers Association at a meeting last night at 15 Whitehall Street voted to expel Captain John F. Milliken, president, and Patrick Hagerty, a former member of the executive committee, after the executive committee had submitted a report accusing both men of having tried to disrupt the organization.
Leases for large quarters in buildings in several sections of the city featured the contracts for commercial space reported by brokers yesterday.

Liberalization of the rules governing the course requirements for junior high school principals was recommended yesterday by the Board of Education's law committee, James Marshall, chairman, announced yesterday.

The Motor Vehicle Bureau issued 38,759 passenger automobile license plates for 1938 and 2,518 commercial plates on Monday, the first day of registration for the general public in this city, it was announced yesterday by Charles A. Harnett, Motor Vehicle Commissioner.

The triple tie for first place in the international masters' tournament at the Hastings and St. Leonard's Club was broken today when Salo Flohr of Czechoslovakia dropped behind, due to an unfinished game in which he has a poor position, thereby leaving Samuel Reshevsky, the United States champion, and Paul Keres of Estonia in joint possession of the lead.

A $1,188,000,000 potential credit reserve for domestic home builders or buyers is now available through members of the Federal Home Loan Bank System, it is announced by Preston Delano, governor, at the start of the organization's sixth year.

Announcement was made yesterday of the dismissal of three patrolmen from the Police Department, bringing the total of policemen discharged since Police Commissioner Valentine took office to 196. Two of the men dismissed, Patrolman James F. Crane of the Greenwich Street station and Patrolman

The expense of constructing a deep inland waterway from Montreal to New York City would not be warranted, at least until the St. Lawrence seaway is an accomplished fact, the international joint commission said today in a report filed with the governments of Canada and the United States.

The strong University of Queens hockey team of Kingston, Ont., downed the St. Nicholas Hockey Club, 8 to 3, in the feature game of a double-header at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. In the other, a New York Amateur Hockey Association contest, the Columbia Lions battled to a 1-all tie with the Long Island Falcons.

Edgar Howard Borck, Manhattan College ace, who had been entered in the Columbus 500, one of the featured events on the program of the Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, indoor track meet at the Thirteenth Regiment Armory in Brooklyn on Saturday night, yesterday requested that he be permitted to scratch from that event and be switched to the 800-meter run.

The Bohn Aluminum and Brass Corporation has reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission that sales less discounts for the year ended Dec. 31, 1936, totaled $17,994,879; gross profit, $2,499,780; operating profit, $1,746,535, and net profit, $1,579,901.

Excluding the weekday editions of The New York American, total advertising linage in New York newspapers for December registered a decline of 3.5 per cent, according to compilations based on Media Records yesterday. The linage amounted to 9,843,668, as against 10,207,136 in the like month of 1936.

Internal dissension threatened tonight to split the Wafd (Nationalist) party, already in a ticklish political situation after being ousted by King Farouk from control of the government, so as to strengthen the hand of the young ruler's newly picked Cabinet.

Births in the city for the week ended last Saturday totaled 1,876, an increase over the previous week when there were 1,555 births, the fewest for any week in 1937, according to a report issued yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner.

Mrs. Edythe Walden Andrews, wife of Charles Lee Andrews, special representative of the stock brokerage firm of De Coppett Doremus of 42 Broadway, died yesterday in her home, 44-35 Kissena Boulevard, Flushing, Queens, of heart disease.

Turpentine firm, 26 1/2c; sales 35 barrels; receipts 143 barrels; no shipments; stock 31,899. Resin firm; sales 448; receipts 1,018; shipments 310; stock 72,854. Quote: B, D, $4.15; E. $4.15-.20; F, $5.45; G, $5.50: H, 55.671/2-.70; I. $5.771-.80; K, $6.00; M, $6.20; N, $6.25; WG, $7.05; WW, X, 87.50.
Twelve men and women dog owners were found guilty yesterday in Yorkville Court under a city law charging them with allowing their pets to cause a nuisance in the streets.
The Reconstruction Finance Corporation stood firm today in its refusal to lend $6,006,000 to the Erie Railroad unless the Chesapeake Ohio guaranteed payment.

The Earl of Perth, the British Ambassador, called on Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano yesterday to discuss the situation created by political propaganda activities of Italian and British broadcasting stations. It is understood they agreed that future programs would be limited to music and news, excluding all comment and opinion apt to embitter their relations even further.

The attention paid here to President Roosevelt's message to Congress is a further sign of a reorientation of British foreign policy which may have an important bearing upon developments in Europe. It is hardly an exaggeration to say that the eyes of Great Britain have turned from the European to the American continent.

Representative Lister Hill, New Deal supporter, defeated former Senator J. Thomas Heflin in Alabama's Senatorial primary today, apparently by 2 to 1. With the vote in 1,453 of the State's 2,200 districts tabulated, the count was: Hill 74,034.
Boris Skvirsky, former counselor of the Soviet embassy in Washington, was not arrested, as erroneously reported in the press abroad. He was seen yesterday by Americans at the Foreign Office.

Indefinite and perhaps endless delay in partitioning Palestine was foreshadowed tonight in a new declaration of British Government policy published as a White Paper and signed by Colonial Secretary William G. A. Ormsby-Gore. The White Paper maintains that partition of the Holy Land into three parts "is the best and most hopeful solution of the problem."
A petition has been filed with the Chicago Board of Trade proposing that salaries of officials and employes of the Exchange be limited according to the amount of dues and assessments paid by members.
A member of France's superior war council told an investigating magistrate today that he had warned the army general staff against a Communist plot to overthrow the French government last November.
An agreement reached today by Pennsylvania, New Jersey and New York held forth the possibility of a $50,000 a year saving for bus owners in this State.

An increase of 39 per cent in communication between ships and shore and the development of new equipment to be used in the transmission of messages and the protection of ships in distress last year were reported by Charles J. Pannill, president of the Radiomarine Corporation of America, in a report published yesterday.

Two new playgrounds, one in the Greenpoint area in Brooklyn and the other in Elmhurst, Queens, were opened to the public by the Department of Parks yesterday. These their brought to 361 the total of city playgrounds available, 253 of them having been opened since Robert Moses took office as Parks Commissioner in January, 1934.

The London Intimate Opera Company, which performs musical works of the lighter sort, by English composers of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries, held forth last night in the Little Theatre, the performance being the opening of their New York engagement.
Mrs. Charles G. Allen, for ten years State treasurer of the Women's Christian Temperance Union, died today. She was 67. Survivors are her husband, a sister,
Secretary Swanson late today ordered Brig. Gen. Harold C. Reisinger, paymaster general of the marine corps, to report immediately to the Naval Hospital here to undergo mental examination.

J. Irving Winegrad, 28 years old, of New York City, was acquitted today on a directed verdict by Federal Judge John Boyd Avis of a charge of violating the Mann Act. Winegrad was one of more than sixty persons indicted on vice charges as a result of raids last Fall in New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware.

Mr. and Mrs. Lennox S. Burgoyne of London have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia De Fabeck Burgoyne, to Elliott A. Dingee, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Dingee of Old Greenwhich. Miss Burgoyne attended Sherborne School, Dorset, England, and Miss Broadbent's School in Brussels. She made her debut in 1933.

Refusing to concede defeat even when trailing by three goals, the New York Rangers made a soulstirring comeback to earn a 5-5 tie with their city rivals, the Americans, in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

Owners of rooming houses already are looking forward to increased business during the World's Fair of 1939 and are preparing to place their houses in order to reap the benefit of the influx of visitors.

The authors of the pre-message strategy, which the President endorsed and made effective whether or not he thought of it first, were today frankly delighted over what they conceive to have been its complete success.

The Giants, who are keeping themselves busy these days rearranging their battle lines along the minor league frontier, yesterday announced that they have shifted their Greenwood franchise to Fort Smith, Ark., in the Western Association, a Class C loop.
Loafer, making his second start at the Fair Grounds after winning four out of five at Tanforan, didn't do much loafing once he hit the stretch at the New Orleans oval today.

A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. C. Russell Griffin of 440 East Seventy-eighth Street on Dec. 31 at the Harkness Pavilion. Mrs. Griffin is the former Miss Gertrude B. Taylor. The child will be called Joan.

With grants from the Rockefeller Foundation, the Sir Halley Stewart Trust and the trustees of the estate of the late Lord Leverhulme, the National Institute of Economic and Social Research has been formed for the investigation of the problems of contemporary human society.

Admiral Nobumasa Suetsugu, Minister of Home Affairs, declared today that foreign war supplies reaching China were serving only to prolong the Chinese Japanese war. Admiral Suetsugu, one-time commander of Japan's combined fleet and known as a militant nationalist, recently retired from active naval service to assume a Cabinet post in which he controls the

The elaborate program of skiing events scheduled for the metropolitan area by the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association will start on Sunday with the annual interstate jumps on the slide at Bear Mountain Park.
