Tight coils of picture wire held five members of the household of J. Edward Meyer helpless here this morning and broad strips of adhesive tape sealed their lips, as four armed men ransacked sixteen rooms and fled with cash and gems valued by the police at about $30,000.

According to a Reichsbank statement today, currency circulation had reached 7,478,000,000 marks at the yearend-a record high for the postinflation period. It is more than 500,000,000 marks higher than last year-end and 761,000,000 higher than 1929-1930, the previous prosperity period.
What is to Great Britain a revolutionary decision on the part of an industrial company to pay "child bonuses" to married employes has aroused considerable controversy among Laborites.

The December Federal grand jury in Brooklyn handed up yesterday to Judge Mortimer W. Byers a presentment urging that Harold St. L. O'Dougherty, temporary United States Attorney of Brooklyn, be given the permanent appointment to succeed Leo J. Hickey, who died of pneumonia on Christmas Day.
Provisional Government officials have outlined possible procedures and policies to be followed in the next few months.

One man died of smoke and four persons were burned or overcome last night in a spectacular fire that swept through the upper floors of an old tenement house at 66 Irving Place, on the northeast corner of Eighteenth Street.
The Guarantee Trust Company of Atlantic City cleared last year a profit of $145,000 for the benefit of preferred stockholders, Mayor Charles D. White, president of the company, announced today.

President Justice Pelham St. George Bissell will preside tomorrow morning at the induction of Matthew M. Levy as a Municipal Court justice in the First Bronx District. Mr. Levy, former chairman of the Bronx law committee of the American Labor party, was appointed by Mayor La Guardia to

On the banks of the Irrawaddy River, in Upper Burma, Dr. Hallam L. Movius of Harvard and I have found what may prove to be a prehistoric link between two of Asia's most ancient Stone Age cultures-very primitive stone tools similar to others that have been found both in India and Java.

In his message to Congress on Monday President Roosevelt gave the country a definite outline of the Government's new budget. The Administration has once more abandoned hope of achieving an immediate balance between income and outgo. The budget for the fiscal year beginning next July will show another deficit.

Loans on securities to member firms decreased $28,567,274 in December, it was announced yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. The total of loans at the end of December was $659,219,305, compared to $687,786,579 at the close of November.

The dwelling at 70 Brook Street, Garden City, L. I., has been sold by the New York State Teachers Retirement System to Janet E. Burkhard. Pease Elliman, Inc., in conjunction with M. C. O'Brien, Inc., arranged the sale.

The John Marshall College of Law of Jersey City downed the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy five, 58 to 33, on the losers' court last night. John Killat and Jerry Kelly, scoring eighteen and seventeen points, respectively, set the pace for the Jersey City team.
Edward M. Kimball, veteran of the stage and screen and father of Clara Kimball Young, star of the old silent-film days, died in the Hollywood Hospital today from a stroke suffered on New Year's Day.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick R. Lucken of 294 Third Avenue, who have been married for twenty-four years, are serving today as members of a jury hearing evidence in a $500 breach of contract case in Supreme Court.

Fifteen Berks County full-fashioned hosiery manufacturers today asked the American Federation of Hosiery Workers to agree to a "downward revision of the wage scale which will recognize serious competitive disadvantages of our mills."

United States District Judge Charles B. Davis today canceled a $3,650,000 improvement program of the Wabash Railway Company and suspended quarterly interest payments on underlying bonds and payments of principal on equipment-trust certificates to conserve the railway's cash balance.

Mrs. Carolyn Donavin, widow of Charles S. Donavin, died this morning at her home. A daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. George M. Williams of this city, she was a member of the board of trustees of the Family Welfare Society and a former member of the Junior League of Elizabeth.

The Butlers Staff .Ball will be held in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Commodore on Jan. 12 under the auspices of the Staff Club, a social organization founded and incorporated last year by the butlers of New York City.
President Roosevelt, at a press conference, discussed cooperation between business and government to determine production policies. McCarra He conferred with Joseph P.

A ten foot bronze statue of Woodrow Wilson is for sale here. Eight years ago the Mayor commissioned Sophie Kaminska, Polish sculptress, to make a statue costing $15,000 to be erected in Liberty Square.

Mori's restaurant, a landmark in Greenwich Village, closed its doors at 144 Bleecker Street yesterday after the filing on Monday of a petition in bankruptcy in Federal Court. The restaurant, which survived the prohibition era and the depression, had been at its present address since 1884, when it was founded by Placido Mori.

When his safety belt snapped after a reinforcing rope around it broke, Herbert Wacks, .35 years old, of 523 East Eighty-third Street, plunged to his death on the sidewalk from an eleventh-floor apartment at 7 Gracie Square, where he was cleaning windows yesterday afternoon.

Patrolman Charles H. Wellman was under suspension here today by order of Mayor Joseph Stilz pending a hearing on charges of "conduct unbecoming an officer." The charges grew out of Wellman's testimony at a trial of four men in New York City last month, in which he said motorists received a "break" from New Jersey police if they exhibited cards of the Police and Court Officers Benevolent Association, of which he is president.

The stock market here was quiet and generally firm today, and ' most sections advanced. Gilt-edge issues were in demand; while among the foreign bonds, Brazilian loans fell. Transatlantic stocks opened quietly but a stronger tendency developed in later dealings and United States Steel and International Nickel rose.

Gifts aggregating $968.07 reached the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday from eighty-seven donors, and brought its total for the present appeal to $296,570.97. Two contributions of $100 each were the largest of the day. One of them, made "In Memory of My Father, A. S. M.,"

Trading was slow on the bulk of steer cuts. Demand for other classes was generally fair. The lamb market was strong to higher and other classes mostly unchanged. quality considered. Early trading in kosher meats indicated lamb to be lower and other classes steady to slightly lower, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

The American Federation of Radio Artists, the newly formed American Federation of Labor union covering radio players, singers and announcers, will open negotiations on Friday for contracts with the National Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System, it was learned yesterday.
The Court of a Appeals today upheld the contentions of the Young Men's Christian Association and New York University that the city sales tax does not apply to them.
M. Ducoureau, French consular agent at Irun, Spain, and the three members of his staff have been arrested by Spanish Insurgents in retaliation for the arrest of Major Julian Troncoso,

Seward Park High's quintet suffered its first setback in seven starts when it bowed to Franklin K. Lane High, 30-22, at Lane, in one of many non-tournament contests played by New York City schoolboy fives yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Sewell Parkinson in his letter to THE TIMES asks if I have an affirmative plan of action to end what he calls "the anarchy of industry and of the Administration." I believe that his question evinces social sincerity.

John Lester Perry, new president of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, predicted today that the nation's large steel consumers will buy on a hand-to-mouth basis for the first few months of 1938. He said, too, that he believed business would "pick up soon," but he added, "However, I am not here to forecast."

The city collected almost 90 per cent of its 1937 real estate tax levy, Almerindo Portfolio, City Treasurer, announced yesterday. The record of only 10.22 per cent uncollected on Dec. 31, 1937, was a "most remarkable one" and the equal of any year since the greater city was established in 1898, Mr. Portfolio said.

Appointment John Y. Wall is appointed as an ununiformed fireman with compensation at the rate of $2,000 per annum, for a probationary period of three months, to take effect at 12.01 A. M., Jan. 5. and will be charged to the code noted below. He will report to the Assistant Chief of Department for assignment to duty:
Evan Grey (Parson) Barnard, Western pioneer and brother of George Grey Barnard of New York, noted sculptor, died at his home here today after a three-month illness.

IT is said that back in 1524 an Italian named Verrazzano sailed into what is now New York Harbor and thus, by nearly a hundred years, beat Henry Hudson and his Dutch ship to the promised land. Whether the story is right or not (it is still argued in some circles),

Ashton Wherry Gray, postmaster and former City Councilman, died at a hospital here yesterday after a lingering illness. He was 60 years old. Mr Gray, who had been a member of Governor Henry Carter Stuart's staff,

A son, their second child, was born to Mr. and Mrs. Alvin De Witt Wadsworth Jr. of Norwalk, Conn., on New Year's Day at the Norwalk Hospital. Mrs. Wadsworth is the former Miss Elisabeth Heard. The child, who will be named for his father, is a grandson of Professor and Mrs. James Heard of Norwalk, formerly of Paris, France, and Summit, N. J., and of Dr. and Mrs. Alvin De Witt Wadsworth of Woodscourt, Norwalk.

Playing at the top of his game in the inaugural round of the first open invitation tournament sponsored by the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association, Germain G. Glidden, national amateur champion, yesterday defeated Tommy Byrne, 27-year-old pro of the Downtown A. C.

The State Athletic Commission yesterday rejected a petition by Ed Miller, manager of Freddie Steele, to set the weighing time for the middleweight champion's ten-round non-title bout with Fred Apostoli in Madison Square Garden Friday night for 2 o'clock Friday afternoon, instead of noon, as is customary.

The outstanding statistical fact in the survey of the registration in American universities and colleges for 1937 made by President Walters of the University of Cincinnati is that despite the reduction of one-third in the Federal grants to needy students, there has nevertheless been an increase of 3.6 per cent in the number of full-time students attending these institutions.

Justice Willis Van Devanter, who retired from the Supreme Court last June at the age of 78, will preside in the United States District Court here today at the trial of Earl Frederick Palmer and Garriel Morosi, charged with dealing in securities- stolen from two New York banks.
Three major prisons in Alabama listed as "unreported" today 23 prisoners out of 554 who were granted Christmas paroles on man-to-man agreements that they would return.

More than twenty Japanese bombers, coming in waves, dropped more than a hundred bombs on the Hankow military airfield yesterday afternoon in of the biggest and most spectacular raids by Japanese planes since the outbreak of hostilities.

Art Perry of Rahway was elected honorary captain of Rutgers' 1937 football team, it was announced tonight at the annual all-sports dinner attended by more than 400 athletes, coaches, university officials and sports writers.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Francis Weadock of Greenwich, Conn., and Mayfair House, this city, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Weadock, to John Taynton Davy Spence, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Denbow Spence of Hove, Sussex, England.

Finance Minister Dunning announced today that subscription would open on next Monday for a new issue of $50,000,000 of Canadian National Railways Dominion-guaranteed bonds. The issue will be used to reimburse the government for advances made since 1932 for redemption of debt and for capital expenditures by the road, Mr. Dunning said.

President Roosevelt's message was warmly welcomed in League of Nations quarters which find its analysis of the world situation to be in close accord with that given by General Jan Christiaan Smuts and Joseph A. C. Avenol in their New Year messages and generally "up Geneva's street."

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey started a drive yesterday to speed up prosecutions in General Sessions and Special Sessions with a view to reducing the calendars of cases in those courts and reduce the number of prisoners in the overcrowded Tombs. At his request Judge James G. Wallace of General

Payment of $15,000 to a New York City school pupil by the Board of Education, in settlement of a claim. for damages incurred in a classroom, was announced yesterday by James Marshall, chairman of the board's law committee.

Encouraged by the new United States law that makes helium lifting gas available to foreign countries for the first time, Edward P. Farley, president of the American Zeppelin Transport Corporation, announced yesterday completion of plans to resume airship service between Germany and the United States next June.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Mary Burr Plimpton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Plimpton of Chestnut Hill, this city, to William Wellman Paxton of Boston, son of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Paxton of Montclair, N. J.

Manhattan Estate, $2.500. To Fred Malile and Islam Malfle, nephews, executors. 147 Allen St., equally. BROWN, SARAH (Nov. 28). Estate, more than S10,000. To Ella M. Buxbaum, daughter, executrix, 43 W. 93d St. COHEN, DORA M. (Dec. 27). Estate, more than $20,000. To Bertram Weal Jr., grandson, 120 E. 39th St., $1,000; Jack May, 311 W. 72d St., $1,000 and specific bequest: three specific bequests;

Miss Virginia Gray, daughter of Dudley Gray of West Hartford, has chosen Jan. 21 as the date for her marriage to Richard B. Bulkeley Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard B. Bulkeley of Hartford. The ceremony will take place in St. John's Episcopal Church, West Hartford, and will be followed by a reception at the Hartford Golf Club for relatives and a few intimate friends.

In an effort to direct the attention of the customers to James Cagney's return to the Warner fold with as much emphasis as possible the studio today named "Boy Meets Girl" as the first picture for their prodigal son. With him will be cofeatured Pat O'Brien.

The St. Francis College basketball team defeated St. Peter's of Jersey City, 29-24, on the victors' court in Brooklyn last night. The visitors led, 20-17, at the intermission. The St. Francis freshmen won the preliminary game from the St. Peter's junior varsity, 35-16.

Andre Jessurun, 150 1/4 pounds, Bronx, easily won the decision from Frankie Cinque, 141 1/2, Washington Heights, in the feature bout at the New York Coliseum in the Bronx last night before a crowd of 5,000.

For more than an hour yesterday morning Joseph D. McGoldrick, the new City Controller, inspected the 5,200 birds exhibited at the annual New York Poultry Show in the 244th Coast Artillery Armory, 125 West Fourteenth Street.

An armed thug invaded the Hotel Robert Fulton, 228 West Seventyfirst Street, at 4 A. M. yesterday, held up the night clerk, John Sullivan, and an elevator operator and escaped with $7. At 5 A. M. he entered the Hotel Rutledge, 161 Lexington Avenue, and was holding up the night clerk there when two guests entered the lobby. He fled.

Robert H. Jackson, Assistant Attorney General, declined today to debate Benjamin A. Javits of New York on the part played by monopolies in the current business recession. He said he was scheduled to debate with Wendell L. Willkie, president of the Commonwealth and Southern Power Company, Thursday evening on an NBC radio program and that a debate with Javits would only be a duplication.

" After the Gleaners," by Nellise Child, and 'Sunup to Sundown," by Francis Edwards Faragoh, were selected last night as the prize winners in the play contest of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.

President Roosevelt gave an inkling today of his plans for helping business to end the recession. He would like to make it possible, he asserted at a press conference, for business and industrial leaders to gather around the council table with representatives of government to determine production policies,

Four women and two men were arrested yesterday when. the police charged they created a disturbance while picketing the plant of the Eagle Electric Manufacturing Company at 59 Hall Street, Brooklyn. Those arrested described themselves as Jean Miano, 19 years old, of 482 Gates Avenue;

Charles R. Tuite, for the last twenty-eight years a civic leader of Edgewater, died on Sunday night at the Holy Name Hospital in Teaneck after a brief illness. Mr. Tuite had served for the last fifteen years as secretary of the Board of Health.
Robert L. Kendall, doing business as the Great Eastern Advertising Company, has leased space in the building at 17-23 West Sixtieth Street, not in 17-23 East Sixtieth Street as reported yesterday.
When the State Legislature convenesit will have before it about a score of bills dealing with real estate and prepared under the sponsorship of Martha Byrne, New York County Register.

Assistant Attorney General Robert H. Jackson, believed to be the present first choice of President Roosevelt for the Democratic nomination for Governor, has received a slight preference in time and position among the speakers at the National Committee's Jackson Day dinner at the Hotel Commodore Saturday evening, it became known yesterday, when arrangements for the dinner were made public.

John A. Coakley, general traffic manager of the manufacturing subsidiaries and mining companies of the United States Steel Corporation in the Pittsburgh and Chicago districts, has resigned, effective Jan. 1, and William S. Guy, traffic manager of the Eastern district for

A report drafted by the public relations committee and approved by the executive board of the Westchester County Medical Society was published today in the society's January bulletin and censured the American Medical Association for "not promoting some arrangement to provide competent physicians for the indigent at the expense of the public."

The adoption of charge that there was a concerted nation-wide movement on the part of large employers, with the National Manufacturers Association as the "spearhead," to frustrate the Wagner act and make impossible genuine collective bargaining was made by David J. Saposs, chief economist of the National Labor Relations Board, at a board hearing in the Berkshire Knitting Mills case here today.

Surrogate Foley signed an order yesterday permitting Thomas B. Gilchrist of 14 Wall Street, general guardian of Gloria Laura Morgan Vanderbilt, 14-year-old daughter of Mrs. Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt and the late Reginald C. Vanderbilt,

On the eve of the sending of the annual budget to Congress, well-informed officials predicted it would indicate a $1,000,000,000 deficit. The latest official estimate of the prospective deficit for the current year was $895,245,000. Officials indicated, however, the message tomorrow would revise this figure upward.

A contract for $318,521.67 worth of spare parts of 315 Model R-1830-13 engines, used in P-26A airplanes, was approved today. The material will be purchased from the United Aircraft Corporation, Pratt Whitney division, of East Hartford, Conn. Another contract, amounting to $866,800.59, for 142 Model R-1340-47 engines and spare parts for use on

5th St. 741 E, 34.6x97; Ease Lest to Manufacturers Trust Co.; p m mtg, pr mtg, $33,000; 6 years, 5%; $5,000. 114th St, 244 W, 25x100.11; George S. Loewy to Central Hanover Bank and Trust Co; p m mtg, 5 years, 3% and 4%; $16,500. Madison Ave, 1,834, 25x100; One, Inc (Gussie Schames, president), to N Y Savings Bank; p m mtg, due and etc, as per bond; $8,000.
The Cunard White Star liner Franconia sails tonight on a cruise round the world via the Southern Hemisphere with more than 300 passengers.

Even on bright, sunny days more than one-third of the classrooms in the city's school system are inadequately illuminated, resulting in increased eye-strain and physical fatigue for thousands of children, a Board of Education survey disclosed yesterday.

A copy of THE NEW YORK TIMES dated Oct. 21, 1891, was found today in an iron box in the foundations of Daly's Theatre in Leicester Square which is now being demolished. The newspaper was in an excellent state of preservation, but the copy of The Times of London of the same date, which also was found, had been powdered into fine dust.

Private dwellings, apartment houses and several commercial buildings figured in the realty deals in Manhattan and the Bronx reported by brokers yesterday. The three-story and basement private house at 135 West Eighty-second Street, which occupies a plot 17.6 by 102.2 feet, has been purchased for investment by a client of Porter Co., Real Estate, Inc., from Adele B. Norton.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced tonight that Wendell Forrest Bowers had confessed in Louisville the slaying near Philadelphia of Mrs. Wilma V. Carpenter on Dec. 13.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,436,600 barrels, compared to 3,492,600 in the preceding week, a decline of 56,000, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 54,700 barrels fewer than the calculation of 3,491,300 daily by the Bureau of Mines for December.
In his first home-town appearance in six years, Tony Galento, Orange, N. J., heavyweight, tonight will assist in the return of Harry Mendel as a New Jersey boxing promoter.

A day of excitement over the disappearance of Miss Gertrude Bennett ended this afternoon when her father, Harry H. Bennett, personnel director of the Ford Motor Company, learned that she had eloped to Indiana with a college sweetheart and was married.

Charles D. Millard of Tarrytown was inducted today as Surrogate of Westchester County at ceremonies in the County Court House here. About 200 jurists, attorneys and friends attended the installation ceremony. Speakers extolled Mr. Millard's work at the bar and his long service as Greenburgh Town Supervisor and United States Representative from the Twenty-fifth District.

Numerous luncheon parties were given yesterday in conjunction with the "Around the World Style Show," held in the Caprice Room of the Weylin for the benefit of the Boy Scouts of America. In addition to modern fashions for all occasions,

Temporarily trapping about 200 beano players in American-British Hall, a fire tonight sent twoscore persons to hospitals, nine of them seriously hurt. Nine persons remained in hospitals, suffering from injuries which included broken limbs, burns, bruises and cuts.
Secretary lokes said today that he had "too much respect" for many indictment" of them.

Yachts of assorted sizes, marine Ro engines of huge, unwieldy bulk, and crates of the thousand-and-one accessories and gadgets that go to make up a National Motor Boat Show began going into Grand Central Palace yesterday, there to be painted, polished and spruced up in ship-shape style for Friday night's opening.

Conferences have been arranged by President Roosevelt with Chairmen of the House Appropriations and Naval Affairs Committees, out of which are expected to come the Administration's definite plans for substantial increases in the nation's sea and air defenses.

Morris R. Cohen, who will retire as Professor of Philosophy at the College of the City of New York at the end of the present semester, late this month, after thirty-five years there, has accepted the same professorship at the University of Chicago.

Mayor La Guardia commended Murray W. Stand, former majority leader of the Board of Aldermen, in warm terms yesterday as he gave him an appointment as director of the New York City World's Fair Commission, which has offices in the Empire State Building.

Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told Senator Byrnes's Committee on Relief and Unemployment today that only government intervention could stop the sharp and continued drop in consumer purchasing power, as the indices of production between August and November showed the sharpest rate of decline on record.
In an impressive display of scoring, the Manhattan College basketball team defeated Cathedral College, 52--33, last night in the Manhattan gymnasium before a crowd of 800.
Not content with their local triumphs, the New York Athletic Club anglers are going farther afield for their fishing and have completed plans for their first midwinter Florida Fishing Expedition.

Reginald G. Hammond of the United States Table Tennis Association's ranking committee said today the United States team to defend the Swaythling Cup in London late this month would be selected in St. Louis after the national intercity team

The chapel of the Brick Presbyterian Church at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street was filled yesterday for the final noon service to be held in that church, which was established almost eighty years ago.

Stockholders of the Ritter Dental Manufacturing Company at a special meeting voted yesterday to retire 5,000 shares of 7 per cent cumulative preferred stock at 105 with Treasury funds, reducing the number outstanding to 20,000.
The chauffeur for a member of Governor Earle's Cabinet was hauled on the official carpet today, charged with driving 65 miles an hour and passing-of all cars-the Governor's.
The belief grew among Republican groups today that party leaders Br ultimately would settle upon Judge Arthur H. James of the State Superior Court as their candidate for Governor this year.

Charles C. Franck, who retired on May 1 after forty-one years of service with the New York Life Insurance Company here, died on Sunday in West Hempstead, L. I., at the home of his son, Russell C. Franck,

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Dec. 31: Kilpatrick, Capt. W. K., when discharged from treatment Naval Hospital, Brooklyn, N. Y., to Naval Operations, Washington, D. C. Whelchel, Lt. Comdr. J. E., Washington, D. C., to the McCall and in command when commissioned.

The $300,000 ship model collection of the late Colonel Henry Huddleston Rogers, which he willed to the United States Naval Academy at Annapolis, will be shipped from here to Baltimore Thursday on two large freight cars under care of a special crew, it was learned today.

Dr. David Lvovitch, executive vice president of the World ORT Union, discussed the difficulties confronting European Jews at the annual membership meeting of the American ORT Federation at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night.
The Dartmouth hockey team won its eighth consecutive victory in the Davis Rink tonight, downing a hard-fighting Boston University sextet, 8-4.
Mrs. Anna M. Stephens, widow of Judge Albert M. Stephens of Los Angeles, died last night at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Ralph D. Osborne, in Llewellyn Park, West Orange.
British merchantmen are hurrying from the River Plate in ballast to United States ports on the Gulf of Mexico where heavy cargoes of grain are awaiting shipment to Europe.

Six persons were killed this afternoon when a Luftansa Junkers JU-52 passenger plane crashed at the airport here while landing in a snowstorm. The three-engined plane left Milan at 10:20 this morning for Frankfort and Amsterdam with three members of the crew and three passengers.

President Ignaz Moscicki is confined to his bed at his country estate at Spala. He has been ill for several days and, therefore, the President's traditional New Year reception in Warsaw did not take place this year.

Turkey's strong protest against the League of Nations rules for the Spring elections in the Syrian Sanjak of Alexandretta has caused the Council to put this question on the agenda for the session opening Jan. 17.

A report to the Securities and Exchange Commission showed today that Wallace Groves received aggregate remuneration of $40.429 in the fiscal year ended Aug. 31, 1937, as chairman of Phoenix Securities Corporation and as director of the Auto Car Company, a subsidiary.

In the first match to decide the Women's Metropolitan Class B interclub team squash racquets championship, the Rockaway Hunting Club five defeated the Plainfield (N. J.) team, 4--1, on the courts of the Cosmopolitan Club yesterday.

The four-story apartment house at 1,514 West Eighth Street, Brooklyn, was purchased by the Gervin Corporation, Nathan Bram, president. Purchase was subject to a first mortgage of $50.000. Irving Felsher was the attorney for the seller. Harry Posner represented the buyer. The Maurice J. Abrams Company was the broker in the deal.
Ralph Greenleaf, world champion, yesterday went down to defeat twice in his twelve-block, non-title pocket billiard match at the Strand Billiard Academy against Andrew Ponzi, a former champion.

The receipt of funds totaling $104,662 was announced yesterday by the National Recreation Association of 315 Fourth Avenue. One gift, $50,000 in cash and securities from the Henry Strong Denison Medical Foundation, Inc., of Denver, will be used to establish the Henry Strong Denison Fund for the training of college graduates for professional service in public recreation, the announcement said.

Recent research tends to show that contrary to popular belief, sexual maturity is gained earlier in cooler climates, Colonel Ram Nath Chopra of the Indian Medical Service said today in his presidential address to the physiology section of the Indian Science Congress.

Miss Hope Alden Meade, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Gordon Meade of Sunny Bank, Ambler, was married this afternoon to Bernhard W. Fox, son of Caleb F. Fox Jr., and of Mrs. Fitz Eugene Dixon, both of Elkins Park. The ceremony was performed in St. Thomas Church, Whitemarsh, by the Rev. Nathaniel Groton, the rector.
James E. Quan, president of the National Bank of Greenwich, Conn., from 1917 to 1923, died here yesterday in his home at 30 East Sixtyeighth Street after a long illness. He was 73 years old.
More veterans applied for hospitalization during the fiscal year 1937 than in any year since 1932, the Veterans Administration said today.

Mrs. Mont W. Hyer of Plainfield, formerly of Fanwood, N. J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Elizabeth Hyer, to Leonard Francis Beckers of South Orange, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Gerhardt Beckers.

Louis E. Prina, president of the School Board, said today that if the strike of parents and junior high school pupils here "should assume much greater proportions," a few parents might be taken to court as disorderly persons, "as an example."

Distributors Group, Inc., in its capacity as underwriter of an issue of $4,000,000 of ten-year 4 1/2 per cent debentures of the Celotex Corporation offered to the public last March, has sent to dealers in securities who participated in that financing copies of a letter which reveals the underwriter's opposition to the proposed purchase by Celotex of the Phoenix Securities Corporation's holdings of preference and common stock of the CertainTeed Products Corporation.

McGill University, which hasn't lost a hockey game since 1933, extended its streak in a keen battle with the University of Toronto before a crowd of 1,500 at the Playland Ice Casino tonight, winning, 4 to 2.

President Roosevelt's speech caused in France neither enthusiasm nor disappointment, for nobody in this country expected him to go any further than he did. Papers of the extreme Left urge once more that the democracies unite against fascism. In other quarters there is satisfaction that even though no promises were made it would be impossible for the United States to stay our of any general conflict.

Officials of New Rochelle recommended today the development of a new bus system within the city to serve commuters isolated from transportation systems by the closing of the bankrupt New York, Westchester Boston Railway. The buses would run to stations of other railroads.

Jimmy Lancaster, Wilmington (Del.) lightweight, won a six-round decision over Young Chappie of Albany in the feature event at the Broadway Arena last night before a crowd of 3,000. It was their second meeting at the club within a month, their previous meeting having resulted in a draw.

Canada's imports from the United States increased in the first eight months of the fiscal year 1937-38 to $346,060,460, compared with $251,473,449 for the corresponding period, April 1 to Nov. 30, last year, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.

Seven prominent Philadelphia Summer colonists, together with an association of Philadelphia people holding Summer property, filed tax suits involving $276,000 worth of property against the Jamestown Board of Tax Assessors in Newport Superior Court today.

Behind on his proposed schedule of seeking repeal of a "law a week," Repretentative Bruce Barton of New York offered two measures today as a start and said he would continue the flow of his repealers into the House hopper at the rate of two a week until he catches up.

Because of noisy demonstrations by sympathizers, who booed police witnesses, Magistrate Dreyer in West Side Court had to adjourn from yesterday until 10 A. M. today the trial of nineteen veterans of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade, Spanish Loyalist Army unit, who were arrested on Dec. 22 for mass picketing the F. W. Woolworth Company store at 1,518 Broadway, in Times Square, between Forty-fourth and Fortyfifth Streets.

A survey among American exporters completed yesterday by the Export Managers Club here discloses a wide variety of policies being followed by producers in regard to special sales terms demanded by Soviet Russia in orders placed here.

A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Warren Milne of Cliff House, Bryn Mawr, last Friday at the Lankenau Hospital here. Mrs. Milne is the former Miss Barbara V. Litchfield, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bayard S. Litchfield of Cantitoe Farm, Katonah, N. Y.

The fourteenth annual Newspaper Institute, under the auspices of the North Carolina Press Association and the University of North Caronia, with Duke University cooperating, will open here Jan. 20. The first session will be open to the public.

In the Supreme Court of the United States today, Charles W. Hagen of New York City was admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had: 636-Electric Bond and Share Company, American Gas and Electric Co., et al, petrs., v. Securities and Exchange Commission, et al. Motion to advance sublnitted for the respondents.

Antonio Buscaglia a Nationalist who has sworn to go barefoot until Puerto Rico wins her independence, went on trial today with five other defendants at Ponce, charged with dynamiting the home of the Rev. Nestor J. Aguilera, a Brooklyn-educated priest, last July 6.

The Italian press today makes ample comment on President Roosevelt's message to Congress and prints an adequate summary of it, which is noteworthy because the Chicago speech scarcely was mentioned in the Italian papers. The comment follows the expected lines.

The stock market was strong from the start yesterday and closing prices approximated the best levels of the day with leading issues up 1 to 4 points. Strength in the steel stocks featured the day's trading, but not far behind were the automotive, electrical equipment, metal, tobacco and aviation issues.
Sir George Halsey Perley, a member of three successive Conservative Cabinets, former Canadian High Commissioner in London and Acting Prime Minister, died in his sleep here today at the age of 80.

-James W. Trenchard, last surviving member of the G. A. R. in Cumberland County, died today at the age of 94. He was the uncle of Supreme Court Justice Thomas W. Trenchard, presiding jurist at the trial of Bruno R. Hauptmann, and of Mrs. Elizabeth Trenchard Leaf of Philadelphia.

An investigation to determine if political influence affects motions on litigation in the courts of the city is asked by a special committee on law reform in a report to be submitted to the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York tomorrow.

A sixteen-point legislative program was announced yesterday by the Public Affairs Committee of the Socialist Party. Harry W. Laidler, State Chairman, expressed the hope of the committee that the Legislature would enact laws for the benefit of the workers and farmers of the State and its expecstation that the presence of an American Labor -Party group in the Assembly would stimulate consideration of labor legislation.

Following is the text of the British Government's White Paper, announcing in he form of a dispatch from William G. A. Ormsby-Gore, Colonial Secretary, to Sir Arthur Grenfell Wauchope, High Commissioner in Palestine, the government's intention to send a commission to Palestine to report on the partition plan:
Senator Wagner announced today that President Roosevelt had approved allotments totaling $23,798,601 of WPA funds for non-Federal projects in New York City.

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Miss Denny Prager, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Prager of 260 Riverside Drive, to Glenn Griswold, also of this city, which took place Monday night in the Recorder's Court of the Municipal Building, West New York, N. J. Recorder Louis L. Flaum performed the ceremony, at which Mr. and Mrs. J. B. Wolfe of Weehawken were the witnesses.

Supreme Court Justice William Harman Black ruled yesterday that the State Liquor Control Board to could not interfere with the transmission of orders for wines and liquors by telegraph. telephone or air mail. Previously the board had threatened to cancel the licenses of stores that participated in the taking and filling of such orders.

The report of the Standard Gas and Electric company and subsidiaries, excluding the Deep Rock Oil Corporation and the Beaver Valley Traction Company, both of which are in receivership, for the twelve months ended on Oct. 31, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income after all expenses and charges of $4,149,324.
Daniel Frohman who is 86 years old, was introduced as "the dean of philanthropists" at the annual theatre assembly Christmas party for the guests at the actors fund home here today.

Although consumption of copper in the United States declined matereally in the, last three months of 1937, reflecting the business recession in that period, it approximated 810,000 tons in the year, compared with 764,000 in 1936. In the first eleven months of the year, apparent x domestic consumption was 786,000 tons.

Another double-header, fourth in the series of college basketball attractions, will be presented tonight at Madison Square Garden, with local quintets again pitting their wares against invading teams. In the first contest N. Y. U. will engage Georgetown, to be followed by a meeting of the L. I. U. and Southern Methodist fives.

The Fidelity Union Trust Company of Newark, N. J., reported, as of Dec. 31, deposits of $143,393,689 and total assets of $160,503,954, compared, respectively, with $148,086,054 and $165,559,820 on Dec. 31, 1936.

Miguel Nazar, who was Minister of Public Supply in Santo Domingo during the regime of Rafael Estrella Urena, received twenty days yesterday to arrange to go to some country other than Santo Domingo, where, according to his attorneys, he would be executed as a political offender.

Football coaches from all sections of America hauled out the "O.K." stamp yesterday and applied it to the three major decisions of the National Football Rules Committee in its week-end deliberations at Edgewater Park, Miss.

A case on the result of which is expected to have an important bearing on the Federal Government's program of financial aid for road building was argued in the Supreme Court today when the justices heard discussion of a South Carolina law seeking to limit the weight and width of motor trucks operating in interstate commerce on standard paving.

Mayor S. Davis Wilson collapsed in his office today from what Dr. Maxwell Cherner, a police surgeon, said was an attack of nervous indigestion induced by overwork. He was revived by Dr. Cherner. The Mayor's son, Woodrow, one of his assistants, took his father home.

Inquiry for various lines of dry goods improved moderately yesterday, but on some lines wholesalers and other distributors were awaiting price revisions in line with Monday's action on denims, which were reduced 1 cent a yard.

One of the smokiest minor fires in recent years started at 7:10 o'clock last night in the basement of a two-story store and office building at the southwest corner of Broadway and 125th Street and in the two-hour battle that ensued before it was brought under control two firemen were overcome and several others affected.

Refusal by the Bituminous Coal Commission to supply facts and figures on which it based its price schedules for coal resulted today in an indefinite adjournment of a hearing on protests by the consumers' counsel.

Hearts ousted the Celtics from top place in the Scottish Football League today by turning in a 1-0 victory over Falkirk at Tynecastle Park. The decision gave the Hearts 36 points for the campaign to date, one more than the Celts, but the latter have a game in hand.

Mrs. Mary Tomey, business woman and sister of Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., died of a heart attack at her home here today. Mrs. Tomey was office manager of the A. T. Parker Company, insurance brokers, for more than ten years.

AHEARN--Mary (nee Larkin), suddenly, on Jan. 3, 1938, at the home of Catherine Hyland, 211 8th Ave., Brooklyn, wife of the late Patrick Ahearn, native of Galbally, Tipperary, Ireland, and former resident of. Spring Valley, N. Y.; survived by four sisters, Mrs. Catherine Fox, Mrs. Delia Hogan,

Destruction of the rival pawn formations was the leading motif of the twenty-seventh game of the world championship match between Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris and Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam. the full score of which has reached here from Amsterdam.

J. Dexter Crowell, a partner In the admiralty law firm of Crowell and Rouse, 111 Broadway, died Monday at the Hotel Brittany, 55 East Tenth Street, after a long illness. He was 53 years old. Mr. Crowell was born in Brooklyn and studied at Amherst College and New York Law School.

Howland Wood, curator since 1913 of the Museum of the American Numismatic Society, Broadway and 156th Street, died yesterday of pneumonia in his home at 137-17 Franklin Avenue, Flushing, Queens. He was 60 years old.

Surprise at the absence of onehanded shooting in the metropolitan district was expressed yesterday by Jimmy St. Clair, coach of the Southern Methodist basketball team, as the squad worked out at the West Side Y. M. C. A. shortly after its arrival in New York.

Somewhere there are two members of the Baseball Writers Association who would leave Joe DiMaggio of the New York Yankees off an allstar 1937 baseball team, and there are four writers who would pass up Joe Medwick of the St. Louis Cardinals.

American doctors still are in much demand by the Chinese, says Dr. Norman G. Patterson, who returned from hospital work in China. Dr. Patterson said the hospital at Sutsien, where he was stationed, "is crowded at present with wounded soldiers."

The 1938 Toy Fair will be held from April 25 to May 7 at the Hotel McAlpin and the Toy Centre, 200 Fifth Avenue, it was announced yesterday by H. D. Clark, of the Toy Manufacturers of the U. S. A. and director of the fair.

Two light airplanes, especially equipped for Arctic flying, are being prepared for evacuation of the Soviet scientists from their North Polar ice floe if an icebreaker is unable to reach them by the great northern sea route, it was announced today.

A decree of divorce was granted here today to Mrs. Rebecca. Pollard Van Lennep from William B.Van Lennep of New York. She charged cruelty. Mrs. Van Lennep was formerly Miss Rebecca Pollard of Hialeah, Fla.

Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo approved yesterday the terms for settlement of a stockholders' suit against Bloomingdale Brothers, Inc., by which Samuel J. Bloomingdale's salary is reduced from $75,000 to $25,000 a year and Hiram C. Bloomingadle's pay is cut from $50,000 to $15,000 a year.

On the theory that the unanimous Supreme Court decisions on the Alabama Power and Duke Power cases yesterday cleared the road for construction of sixty-one public power projects at a cost of $146,917,808, the government took steps today for the immediate dissolution of temporary injunctions which so far have blocked these programs in twenty-three States.

Troy W. Newkirk, the 40-year-old Negro aviator who was forced to land his plane -in McCombs Dam Park Sunday, was commended for his good judgment by Magistrate Overton Harris when he appeared in Bronx Magistrate's Court to answer two summonses, charging him with damaging public property and landing a plane on park property without a permit.

The nominating committee of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange announced yesterday that Chandler A. Mackey had been selected to serve for a fourth consecutive term as president of the Exchange. F. Shelton Farr and W. W. Pinney also were nominated to succeed themselves as vice president and treasurer, respectively.

Nat Volpe of New York and Robert Conkling of Teaneck, N. J., were elected captains of the Manhattan varsity basketball team and the 1938 cross-country team, respectively, during the Christmas holidays.

Frederick A. Miller of the H. C. Godman Company, Columbus, Ohio, was elected chairman of the board of directors of the National Boot and Shoe Manufacturers Association at its convention in Chicago yesterday, it was announced at the association's office here last night. Jay O. Ball was re-elected president.

As a challenge to his own industry and others to put more men and money to work now, A. Edward Barit, president of the Hudson Motor Car Company, announced today a new car, the Hudson 112, to compete in the low-priced field.

In a vivid and terrifying map published in our issue of Jan. 3, Dean Ackerman of the Columbia University School of Journalism showed the present spread throughout the world of what he calls "The Black Plague of the Twentieth Century."

Mr. and Mrs. William A. Davidson of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice E. Davidson, to J. G. Graham Batting of Bridgeport, Conn., son of Dr. and Mrs. Harold L. Batting of Chicago.

Book publishers are now extending their fair-trade contracts under the Miller-Tydings law into most of the forty-two States having price maintenance laws on their statute books, and the movement promises to gain headway this year, it was reported here yesterday.

The War Department released the following orders today dated Jan. 3: MAJOR GENERAL Connor, W. D., West Point, N. Y., to home and await retirement. BRIGADIER GENERAL Bishop, P. P., appointed as Major General.
President Anastasio Somoza has abolished the decree requiring that ripe coffee be picked berry by berry instead of stripping the trees.

Senator Adams of Colorado said today the special Senate Committee, of ?ich he is chairman, 'will reopen hearings in its investigation of the wool industry in "about two weeks." The inquiry, he said, would center on methods of marketing wool through dealers in Boston and other large cities.

VOTE for ten. Those are the instructions issued to the enrolled (and paid-up) members of the Baseball Writers Association of America by the Baseball Hall of Fame Elections Committee, consisting of Alexander Cleland, representing the home folks of Cooperstown, N. Y.; Henry P. Edwards of American League headquarters and William E. Brandt of the National League forces.

Mr. and Mrs. Newton Fassett Osmer of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Elizabeth Osmer, to John Thornton MacDonald Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Thornton MacDonald of Belle Haven, Greenwich, Conn.
Walter J. Blankfard of the commission merchant firm of Snyder Blankfard, which was founded by his father, collapsed today in his office and died shortly afterward. He is survived by his widow.

Continued unsettlement in the market for secondary railroad issues, which were paced again by a further precipitate drop in Erie obligations as a result of the default in interest, characterized bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

Apparently to prevent political parties from operating under cover as cultural or like societies, President Getulio Vargas issued a decree today forbidding such groups to function unless fully equipped to carry out their programs. All political discussion by the societies is barred.

London policemen will henceforth loom less majestically on the sight. The present minimum height of 5 feet 9 inches has been cut down by an inch. The main reason is that recruits are almost as hard to find for the Bobbies as for the Tommy Atkinses. To draw men to the army the physical requirements have been made easier, and all sorts of luxuries have been introduced, including chambermaids and waitresses, we believe.

Three bulky packages, containing $25,000 in five, ten and twentydollar bills, vanished Monday night from a locked vault in the basement of the Bensonhurst National Bank, 8,515 Bay Parkway, Brooklyn. The loss became known yesterday morning while the police, mystified by the money's disappearance, were questioning red-eyed and jumpy bank employes at the Bath Beach station.

Ballots were cast in behalf of persons long dead, others dying, and still others in insane asylums in Jersey City in the November gubernatorial election, according to a memorandum filed today with Chief Justice Thomas J. Brogan of the New Jersey Supreme Court.

The Shubert office took exception yesterday to a heading over a paragraph in THE TIMES relating to an arbitration between themselves and Hugh Sinclair and Valerie Taylor. They said that since Mr. and Mrs.

The engagement of Miss Rosamond Hodges, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. John King Hodges, to Stirling S. Adams of this city has been announced by her grandmother, Mrs. Amory G. Hodges of 1,040 Park Avenue. Miss Hodges was graduated from the Chapin School last June.

The publicity department of the Long Island Railroad explained yesterday that the road had reduced this year. the number of passes issued to police detectives and plainclothes patrolmen from 1,470 to 650 because of increased operating expenses and decreased revenue.
By a decree signed by the Minister of National Economy and Finance Greece has consented to import American products to a value of approximately $50,000 in the forthcoming six months.

Mrs. Caspar Whitney has left for Santa Barbara, Calif., where she will pass several weeks. Mr. and Mrs. Crittenden H. Adams of Morristown, N. J., will give a dinner dance for their daughter, Miss Agnes Adams, a debutante of last season, on Friday at the Pierre before the Second Junior Assembly.

Magda de Fontanges, French actress, who arrived on Nov. 8 on the Normandie, was deported yesterday on the steamship Champlain to Havre. She came here while under a twelve-months suspended sentence from the French court for the shooting in Paris of the Count de Chambrun, former French Ambassador to Italy.
Gaunt with hunger and barely able to speak, Arthur Spencer, 53, staggered into a farmhouse this afternoon and gasped that he had been trapped in a near-by woods for almost two days.

With the approval of President Roosevelt, Senator McCarran, sponsor of legisolation to put air transport under the jurisdiction of the I. C. C., is planning to redraft a measure which he has introduced so as to create a separate commission to have charge of all commercial aviation.

The recent strength in the prices of the principal farm products, which was more pronounced yesterday, is giving some encouragement to the security markets. Reflecting increased export demand, prices of grains in Chicago and in other principal markets of the world are displaying the greatest strength in months.

James Charles Bennett, formerly vice president of the Westinghouse Electric -Company, died here this morning of pneumonia. Mr. Bennett, who lived in Stamford, was 69 years old. He was born in Canton, Ohio, and was graduated from high school in Pittsburgh,

Formation of the national floor coverings group of the merchandising division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association was unanimously voted last night at a meeting held in the Hotel Martinique and attended by from 75 to 100 floor coverings buyers.

Herrick Allen, 60 years old, described by the police as an attorney forced by financial reverses to accept home relief, was found dead by hanging last night in the kitchen of an apartment at 596 Riverside Drive, where he occupied a furnished room.

Mrs. Sarah Jesurun Henriquez Maduro, who was known for her philanthropic activities in the West Indies, died on Monday at her home in Curacao, Netherlands West Indies, in her seventy-fifth year, according to word received here yesterday.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Horace Westervelt of A Maplewood of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Evelyn Westervelt, to Joseph Franklin Zeman Jr., E son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Zeman of Islip, L. I.

In the fifth annual report of the Commodity Exchange, Inc., published today, Floyd Y. Keeler, president, stresses the growth in trading volume on the Exchange in 1937. Taken as a whole, the year saw the volume of trading in raw silk, hides, copper, lead and zinc at the highest levels for any year since the inauguration of futures trading in these commodities in this country, Mr. Keeler says.
Sales of cigarettes in cans and the use of metal cigarette wrappers were discontinued in Japan on Jan. 1 by order of the Tobacco Monopoly Board, the Commerce Department was advised today.
Fresh From its finest season in both attendance and spectacular play, the National Football League looks forward to even greater things in 1938.

The brotherhood of eager men who dash to quench fires in remote communities, and who proudly march past Brooklyn's Borough Hall with antique hose carts for their need of civic glory once a year, received a shocking setback yesterday in Coney Island Court. One of their own number was actually convicted of fighting a fire.

A banking group headed by Salomon Bros. Hutzler obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $1,400,000 of home relief and relief project bonds of Buffalo, N. Y., on a bid of 100.279 for 3 1/2s. The bonds, dated Jan. 15, 1938, and maturing serially from Jan. 15, 1939 to 1948, were reoffered at prices to yield from 1.50 to 3.35 per cent, according to maturity.

Charged with having killed his 5-year-old daughter and critically injured his wife by battering them with a hammer, Urban Kaufmann, 30 years old, of 371 East 204th Street, the Bronx, was arrested yesterday after eight policemen overcame him when he walked into the Bronx Park Station with the bloody hammer in his hand.

Another shipment of $5,000,000 of gold to France left here yesterday on the Champlain, it was learned in Wall Street. This made a total of $45,000,000 of the metal sent to that country since Nov. 8. In addition, $5,000,000 of gold was sent to England early in November.

Police will begin tomorrow to pass out summonses to New York motorists who ignore the new ban on parking in ten midtown streets. While patrolmen will continue to use suasion today, police commanders said yesterday the public should not require more than three or four days to learn the new regulations and that summonses would be in order tomorrow.

Inflation talk, which appeared to have its inception in an unbalanced Federal budget and the stressing of the strained world political situation in President Roosevelt's message to Congress yesterday, dominated the world grain markets today and sent wheat prices soaring.

S. R. Fuller Jr., president of the North American Rayon Corporation, said after a conference with President Roosevelt today that he had assured the Chief Executive he was not "a bit worried about the business situation."

The Bureau of New Plays, organized by seven motion-picture companies in 1936 to encourage young playwrights, demanded yesterday that the Dramatists Guild cease its attacks on the bureau, lest it force the bureau to abandon its activities.

The New York Association of the Blind will start today its main appeal of the year for support of its work for the welfare, training, employment and recreation of the blind. Nearly 4,800 blind persons were enrolled by the association last year.

Eight employes of the Ford Motor Company were held for trial today when arraigned in Justice Court on assault charges growing out of a fight at the Ford Rouge plant May 26 in which members of the United Automobile Workers were injured.

George Cardinal Mundelein of Chicago was a luncheon guest of President Roosevelt at the White House today and described his visit as a "social call." He said in explanation that he returned the call President Roosevelt made on, him in Chicazo in October.

National manufacturers should give dealers specific facts and information on the type of local sales management they want stores to Tu have, as it can be one of the most important factors in the sale of products, C. Y. Belknap, executive vice president of Trade-Ways, Inc., yesterday told the luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

President Roosevelt's frankness on cooperation between democratic States found no general approbation in the Austrian press today. The Wiener Zeitung skeptically commented that while the President considers democracy the bulwark of peace, Mussolini is firmly convinced that democracy is outmoded and only the future will show which is right.

Mrs. Charles Henry Hamilton and Miss Josephine C. Kelly entertained with a large cocktail party today at their villa. Mr. and Mrs. J. Terry West entertained at Villa Tramonto with a dinner party. Mr. and Mrs. H. Halpine Smith gave a dinner tonight at their residence.

The number of industrial and commercial failures in the United States in the five days ended Dec. 30 was higher in all five divisions compared with the corresponding period a year ago, according to the weekly report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The detailed comparisons follow:

Frederick F. Umhey and James V. Barry, both of New York City, were appointed today by Governor Lehman as members of the Industrial Council. Mr. Barry succeeds George Meany, president of the New York State Federation of Labor, who resigned, while Mr. Umhey fills the vacancy caused by the death of Jeremiah Ryan.
The Treasury Procurement Division today invited bids on 333,000 yards of textiles. The bids, to be dated Jan. 6 and opened Jan. 13, for complete shipment by March 1, were for the following:

Although relief figures stand at a new low for recent years, Canada is still faced with serious problems of unemployment and dependency, according to "The Relief Outlook in Canada," an annual review prepared by the Welfare Council.

Authorities prepared today to rush provisions to the Waldeck Expedition, searching for the long-missing American aviator, Paul Redfern. The searchers-three men and one woman-were said by their porters to be marooned on Devil's Hole Isle, on the treacherous Cuyuni River, which cuts through the colony's thickest jungle.

George Welwood Murray, 81-year-old New York lawyer, has been honored for his advancement of legal research by the creation of a Columbia Professorship of Legal History in his name, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university.

The bodies of three newspaper men who were killed in Spain started home today in flag-draped coffins. The bodies of Edward J. Neil Jr. of The Associated Press, Bradish Johnson of the magazines Spur and News Week,

The many in today's throng of about 7,000 at Tropical Park who installed Norman W. Church's big Bull Dog colt Sir Oracle an 11-20 favorite in the Melbourne Purse were relieved when the camera decision found their selection a nose winner of the sprint feature.

The Oxford University Press will publish, early in February, the ninth book in the Phaidon Art Series under the title "Art Without Epoch." The volume will contain reproductions of 140 works of painting and sculpture.

Columbia remains the city's only unbeaten basketball team, the alert' Lions taking the measure of Fordham, 40 to 32, before 1,500 persons at -the Ram's gymnasium in the Bronx last night. It was the fourth straight conquest of the season for Coach Paul Mooney's squad, which handed the Maroon its third successive setback.

Prices of commodity futures turned generally higher in moderate activity on the local exchanges yesterday. Fair-sized gains were recorded in hide and rubber futures. In the cash market all the grains, cocoa, lard, tins, rubber and cotton advanced, but refined sugar and silk declined.

The New York University Commerce Bulletin, undergraduate publication of the university's School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance, in collaboration with the People's Medical League, 570 Seventh Avenue, will offer, starting tomorrow, a free Wassermann test to undergraduate and graduate students as the first step in its antivenereal disease campaign, it was learned yesterday.

Pending final action by the Legislature on the proposed amendment that would increase Federal contributions to the State unemployment insurance fund, J. M. Robbins, an administrator of the New York State Bureau of Unemployment Insurance, urged employers yesterday to delay final payments for 1937 which are due by the end of this month.

The League for Political Education yesterday announced plans for expanding its cultural and educational activities. A five-story addition to the Town Hall, 113 West Forty-third Street, the present building, is contemplated, at a cost of nearly $1,300,000.

Senate and House conferees on the Farm Bill overcame one of their greatest difficulties today when they reached a general agreement that the McNary-Boileau amendment was subject to change in conference although it had been adopted in identical language by both the Senate and House.
About 150 men recruited among the unemployed at South Shields are to be sent across the Atlantic this week to bring the liner Leviathan over on her last voyage to the shipbreakers.

Voters of eighty-three municipalities located in twenty-two States during December approved municipal bond issues aggregating only $6,410,470, compared with $65,838,192 bonds approved in November, according to The Daily Bond Buyer.

The annual Wagner matinee cycle at the Metropolitan Opera will begin this season on Thursday, Feb. 3, it was announced yesterday. The six productions will include the usual uncut version of the four works of the "Ring" and the additional operas will be "Tannhaeuser" and "Die Meistersinger."
The Bruins swooped inside of Toronto's wide defense almost at will while overwhelming the visitors by 6-3 tonight before an overflow crowd of 16,000 at the Boston Garden.

Movements of livestock on the Chicago market today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 25,000, including 3,000 directs. Market very uneven, mostly steady to 10c higher than Monday's average, but closed weak on weights 230 pounds up. Top $8.45;

An order directing the liquidation of the Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Company has been signed by Supreme Court Justice George E. Brower in Brooklyn. On Aug. 2, 1933, the company was placed in the custody of the State Insurance Department for rehabilitation.

KINGS COOPEIR, DORA W. (Oct. 8, 1937). Gross assets, $20,940; net, $18,835. To son, Albert Cooper and daughter, Lillis Cooper. one-half of residuary estate each. Chief assets, mortgages. notes, cash and Insurance, $20,940. Robert G. Redlefsen, attorney. 64 Wall St., Manhattan.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Jan. 3, unless specified: At Naval Operating Base: Fanning, Hamilton, J. F. Talbott, Jan. 4; Wyoming. At Pearl Harbor: Lark, Oglala, Pruitt, Preble, Quail, Slcard, Tracy, Whippoora will. San Diego to Pearl Harbor: Memphis, Milwaukee, Trenton. At Panama Bay Area: Mallard, S-42, 44, 45, 46, 47.

Jussi Bjoerling, 26-year-old Swedish tenor, who made his New York debut at the Town Hall last night, was preceded. by raptures and hosannas. A good deal of the advance praise was warranted; some of it was not.

Seventeen scheduled airlines operating in the continental United States in November carried 81,654 passengers and flew 5,311,978 miles. This was a sharp decrease from the figures for the corresponding month in 1936.

The second winner of the Lou Marsh Memorial Trophy, awarded annually to Canada's "outstanding sport competitor," was announced tonight to be Lieut. Marshall Cleland of the Governor-General's Horse Guards, noted rider who scored a long string of victories in Canadian and United States horse shows in 1937.

Two young Newark girls, who recently formed a fast friendship in a reform school, confessed today to the police that they culminated a brief hold-up career with the murder on Dec. 21 of a bus driver in Belleville, N. J., on the outskirts of Newark.

Two openings this evening: At the Playhouse is "The Greatest Show on Earth," a comedy by Vincent Duffey and Irene Alexander, in which, says popular report, the actors take the roles of circus animals looking out at life.

Senator Glass didn't want any fuss made about the anniversary of his birthday yesterday, but so strong and great a public character cannot escape the regard and affection in which not only his colleagues, with and among whom he has fought so sturdily, but most Americans, irrespective of party, hold him.

William O'Dwyer, who rose from a patrolman's post to that of city magistrate, was sworn in yesterday as a Kings County judge by Supreme Court Justice Mitchell May in the Central Court Building, Schermerhorn and Smith Streets, Brooklyn, in the presence of a large group of friends and relatives.

The curtain will rise on the 161st annual session of the Legislature at noon tomorrow with a fair prospect that Governor Lehman will receive a measure of cooperation for his legislative program from the Republicans, who will again control the Assembly this year, while the Democrats continue in control of the Senate.

An unidentified woman about 30 years old caused a lively but brief commotion last night in the WEVD broadcasting studio on the fifteenth floor of the Hotel Claridge by throwing pepper at Arthur Garfield Hays, counsel for the American Civil Liberties Union, while he was attacking Mayor Hague of Jersey City in a broadcast speech dealing with labor policies.

The Transamerica Corporation reported yesterday for 1937 a net profit, subject to audit, of approximately $12,500,000, or $1.12 a share, on the 11,200,000 shares outstanding. This compared with $12,018,861, or 52 cents a share, on 23,181,568 shares, in 1936.
Five seeded players, headed by Bobby Riggs of Chicago and Bryan (Bitsy) Grant of Atlanta, survived the second round of the Miami Biltmore tennis tournament today in matches marked by only one upset.

Still deadlocked over the parliamentary question whether the thirteen Democrats in its membership constitute a majority sufficient to organize, the City Council heard Mayor La Guardia beg for immediate approval of the new city budget yesterday, when the members held their second meeting in City Hall.

Raymond W. Ruddon, vice president and general manager of the Federal Motor Truck Company, has been elected president, succeeding M. L. Pulcher, who resigned. Philip T. Sharples and Cummins Catherwood have been elected members of the board of directors of the Fidelity-Philadelphia Trust Company.

The Travelers Aid Society of New York, Inc., yesterday reported an increase of nearly 10 per cent in the number of persons assisted in 1937. Miss Virginia Murray, executive secretary, said the total of men, women and children aided last year was 52,142, compared with 47,798 in 1936,

Prank C. Ferguson, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, said yesterday in an informal preliminary report that all records for New York-New Jersey vehicular traffic were broken in 1937 on the bridge and tunnel facilities of the Authority.

Counsel for 3,500 New England farmers contributing milk to H. H. Hood Sons, Inc., told a Federal master here today that they had lost $100,000 a month since the Federal Milk Marketing Act took effect.

Senator Carter Glass observed his eightieth birthday today, surrounded by his family and amid a shower of congratulatory messages and floral tributes. The vigorous Virginian, affectionately called the "unreconstructed rebel" by President Roosevelt, had only one complaint:

The financing of domestic railroads has become a monopoly dominated by J. P. Morgan Co. and Kuhn, Loeb Co., Senator Burton K. Wheeler, chairman of the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce, charged before that committee today.
The American Labor party announced tonight its intention to press its own legislative program through its representatives in the Assembly. There are five American Labor party Assemblymen.
Horatio A. Phinney, president of the Arlington Cooperative Bank and of the Symmes Arlington Hospital, died today at the hospital of pneumonia. He was in his seventy-eighth year.

The St. Francis Prep basketball team tightened its hold on first place in the Brooklyn Division of the C. H. S. A. A. by downing St. Michael's High, 26 to 16, on the winners' court yesterday. The victory was the second in as many times out for St. Francis.

After he had mailed a special delivery letter informing his sister that he intended to take his life, John M. Krolick, 45 years old, insurance broker of 297 Washington Street, Hempstead, L. I., committed suicide by hanging yesterday at the Hotel Governor Clinton, Seventh Avenue and Thirty-first Street, where he had rented a room in the forenoon.

Justices of the State Supreme Court at a hearing today criticized the Sinking Fund Consolidation Act, passed by the Legislature last May, to permit Philadelphia to establish a single fund to retire all municipal bonds instead of separate funds for each of forty-four issues.

Witnesses appearing today before a House subcommittee assailed Representative Patman's measure which would prevent manufacturers under certain circumstances from selling their products at retail as "upsetting" the traditional merchandising system of the whole country.

It is possible now to give a considered survey of economic conditions in Ethiopia as they are at the beginning of the Duke of Aosta's viceroyalty after more than eighteen months of Italian occupation.

The Court of Appeals today upheld convictions of nine persons charged with possession of a machine gun found in the house they occupied, in a decision which was considered as upholding the law's constitutionality.

Mr. and Mrs. Paul C. Vogel of this place have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Ruth T. Vogel, to Dr. Charles W. Neuhardt, son of Mrs. AdolphHoehn of Yonkers, N. Y., and the late Charles F. Neuhardt.

At a meeting yesterday of the directors of the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, John L. Turnbull and Charles C. Jordan were elected vice presidents, M. Scovill Martin was appointed trust officer and Crosby T. Smith assistant trust officer. G. Warfield Hobbs 3d was made assistant secretary.

The following units are organized, with home station and district as indicated: 50th Field Artillery (155 How.) RAI, Ithaca, N. Y. (Rochester). 12th Observation Bn. (S. F.) RAI, Jamestown, N. Y. (Buffalo). 17th Engineer Bn. (Hv. Pont. Mtz.), Jamestown, N. Y. (Buffalo). Hq. and Hq. Co First Military Area, NNY, Syracuse. N. Y. (Syracuse).

Congress awaited the reading of the President's budget message tomorrow as a signal for a real start of the session. The Senate was in recess today, but the House, going through the routine of calendar business, gave the Republicans an opportunity to attack the anti-monopoly speeches last week of Secretary Ickes and Robert H. Jackson, Assistant Attorney General.

Salesmen's Union to Get Plan Tonight on Taking Orders for Scotch Whiskies An early truce in the protracted dispute between unionized salesmen of wholesale liquor establishments and their employers over price-cutting which has affected their commissions on Scotch whisky sales, appeared probable last night.
Building projects submitted yesterday included plans for apartment houses in the Bronx to cost $800,000. Plans also were filed for several small homes in Brooklyn. The projects follow:

A national sailing dinghy regatta, along the lines of that to be held in England, will be run at the Larchmont Yacht Club on March 26 and 27. Announcement of it was made yesterday by J. S. Dickerson, chairman of the Larchmont race committee.

Chancellor Hitler will come to Rome in April to return the visit Premier Mussolini paid Germany last year and will remain in Italy for five days or a week. The exact date of his arrival is not known, but it is understood- his program

The University Club,an ornate building which was erected at a cost of about $500,000 before the depression, was sold here today at auction by the city for $40,500. The purchaser was Jacob Miller, one of two operators of the Knights of Columbus Hotel in this city.

A flood of legislation, including about twentyfive "program bills" embodying Governor Lehman's recommendations in his annual message, was introduced at the opening sessions of the Legislature today. Ninety-three bills went into the Senate and there were a countless number on the Assembly side.

Colonel J. H. Bigley, who was a deputy director of the former New Jersey State Emergency Relief Administration, became the first director of the Brooklyn Chapter, American Red Cross, yesterday afternoon. He was introduced to members of the executive committee at a special meeting in the headquarters, 130 Clinton Street.

Counsel for the Federal Trade Commission, in resting its case yesterday against the Fashion Originators Guild of America, Inc., entered into a stipulation with these respondents whereby the total sales volumes of guild members for 1935 were admitted as evidence.

Senator Copeland is planning to introduce within a few days amendments to the National Labor Relations Act designed to provide what he regards as a fairer basis for employer and employee in relationships defined in the legislation and to make responsibility for the carrying out of the act mutual on the part of business and labor.

The American Smelting and Refining Company yesterday advanced the price of copper in the domestic market 1/8 cent a pound to 10.25 cents. The leading producers, however, continue to quote 11 cents for the metal.

Marking the fourth consecutive annual gain, the sales of department stores, dry goods, women's apparel and allied establishments throughout the country showed an increase last year of 5.4 per cent over- 1936, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Controllers Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

The Rev. Martin Niemoeller has sent a message to his Dahlem parish in which he says that the anti-Christian road the German nation is in danger of taking will end in bolshevism. There is, of course, no means of knowing how the message

Harry Smith, 18 years old, of Providence, R. I., was shot and killed by a Darien radio patrolman early today after a wild 70-mile-an-hour chase for four miles of an allegedly stolen auto, when the car crashed against a fence here.

Miss Virginia Field, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Field of this city and Seattle, Wash., was married to William Greene Chester, son of J. H. Chester of Seattle and the late Mrs. Chester, yesterday afternoon in the St. Columba Chapel of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. The ceremony was performed by the dean, the Very Rev. Milo Hudson Gates.

Spokesmen of the crew of the Black Diamond ship Black Falcon, which arrived yesterday from Rotterdam, denied that they had been intoxicated and disorderly on a recent voyage as was charged at a hearing on Dec. 13 before the Senate Commerce Committee.

Beginning today, an inquiry into the organization and operation of the Pennroad Corporation, organized in 1929 with control vested in a voting trust of three members, all of them directors of the Pennsylvania Railroad, the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce sought to show that the corporation was a corporate device adopted by the Pennsylvania to evade the Transportation Act of 1920.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Petitions JACELLEN REALTY CORP., 430 E. 86th St.-Voluntary proceeding under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law listing liabilities of $1,585,962 and assets of $1,841,481. The company owns and operates a 16-story apartment house.

Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., Jan. 6: ACTING CAPTAIN-William C. J. Strutzenberg Jr., from 19th Division, office of chief inspector, to 15th Division. Assignment changed from duty as supervisor of plain - clothes patrolmen to desk duty. Designation as acting captain at $4,500 per annum revoked.

Total advertising linage in Manhattan newspapers in 1937 was 114,246,646, compared with 112,581,679 in 1936, a gain of 1.5 per cent despite the discontinuance of The American, figures compiled from Media Records yesterday showed. Gains were shown in three of five major classifications.

A net profit of $596,318 for the year ended on Oct. 31 was reported by the Lee Rubber and Tire Corporation after expenses, depreciation and taxes, including $17,927 surtax on undistributed income. This is equal to $2.31 a share on 257,465 capital shares outstanding and compares with $563,825 or $2.20 a share on 256,465 shares shown in the preceding fiscal year.

Soviet Russia has already gone far toward building a strong fleet and is now a sea power to be reckoned with, military authorities declared today through an editorial in Krasnaya Evezda, organ of the Red army and navy.
Fifty years ago is a long way back, and then again it doesn't seem so very far after all. President Roosevelt said in his message to Congress on Monday:

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith filed a petition yesterday with Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe asking. permission to resign as co-trustee in reorganization of the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation, which was recently named defendant along with the Western Union Telegraph Company in anti-trust actions- -brought by the United States Attorney General.

Arthur S. Tuttle, formerly State director of the Public Works Administration and widely known engineer, has been named consulting engineer to the WPA here to draft a long-range program for WPA construction projects for the city.

Mrs. Chauncey Clarke Woodworth, widow of the retired manufacturer who had passed many seasons here, and Ernest P. Valle, professionally known as Val Ernie, were married this afternoon in Fort Lauderdale by County Judge Boyd H. Anderson in his chambers. Neither was attended.
