A business and residential property, consisting of two stores and two apartments, at 298 Central Avenue, Jersey City Heights, N. J., was reported yesterday to have been sold by J. I. Kislak, Inc., as brokers, for Antoinette A. Vitalius to 298 Central Avenue Corporation for investment.

Gettysburg displayed a fine brand of basketball to down the strong Lehigh five, 41-25, before a capacity crowd tonight. After a slow start the Bullets shot ahead never to be headed. At half time they were out in front, 24-13.

Miss Mildred Ann Trainer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. Trainer of the Bronx, was married here yesterday morning in the Church of Our Lady of Lourdes, West 142d Street, to Lieutenant John Lawrence Powers, U. S. A., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Lawrence Powers of Worcester, Mass. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Richard Stuart.

Sir Reginald Hoare, British Minister to Bucharest, was instructed today to call the attention of the Rumanian Government "in the friendliest manner" to the interest the British Government feels in its observance of the post-war treaty guaranteeing the rights of minorities.

Plans to make navy aircraft in Hawaii the swiftest and most powerful ever based at the crossroads of the Pacific, by adding forty-two multi-motored, long range patrol and bombing planes in 1938, were announced here tonight by fleet patrol wing officials.

The Manhattan Arrows subdued Sands Point, 3 to 2, in a Metropolitan Amateur Hockey League game at the New Imperial Ice Rink tonight. Bill Moore, Yale captain last season, scored all three goals for the Arrows, after the Sands Pointers had taken a two goal lead early in the opening stanza.

A second half rally led by Bob McDonald, guard, who scored 15 points, gave Cornell a 53-45 decision over Colgate's basketball team tonight. It was Cornell's fourth straight victory and Colgate's second loss in five games.

" EARTH-LORE," by S. J. Shand,* is in the exact sense of the word a fascinating book. It is a little book on big questions of Science, written in simple language (though not for children) by a man who was until recently connected with the University of Stellenbosch, South Africa, and is now Professor of Geology at Columbia.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Daniel J. Barrett of this city and Ridgefield, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rita Angela Barrett, to Armand Francis Macmanus, son of Jose Macmanus of Pelham, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Macmanus.

Qualifying preliminaries for individual junior championship, at New York A. C., Seventh Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, 8 P. M. HOCKEY New York Americans vs. Detroit Red Wings, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and Fiftieth Street .....8:45 P. M. Bronx Tigers vs. Atlantic City Sea GUlls. at New York Coliseum, East 177th Street and Boston Road. Bronx .......8:30 P. M.

Charles Gilbert, 49 years old, a radio engineer, committed suicide by gas yesterday at his home, 3,900 Greystone Avenue, in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. His body was discovered shortly before 4:30 P. M. by the superintendent of the building, who investigated after other tenants had smelled gas.

The marriage ofMrs. Jane Cooper Fleming, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Cooper, to John Millen of Honolulu and California, son of Mrs. John Millen of North Redding, Mass., and the late Mr. Millen of Edinburgh, Scotland, took place yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents at Hampshire House. The ceremony was performed by City Magistrate Overton Harris.

Marjorie Lawrence, dramatic soprano of the Metropolitan Opera, appeared in her first solo program in New York at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon and established herself as a recitalist of distinction. Her singing had depth of feeling, imagination, variety and discriminating intelligence. Her Bruennhilde and Ortrud at the opera have marked her as an artist of sensitivity and temperament, but her impersonations have not provided a full measure of her capacities.

A very great musician and a leader of indisputable authority returned last night to direct the performances of the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall, and the effect of his presence was immediately evident in the performances.
The National Labor Relations Board complimented the newspapers today for their recent handling of labor news.
Eugene du Pont of Greenville, Del., father-in-law of Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., asked the Board of Tax Appeals today to review a Treasury tax assessment of $63,829 for the years 1933 through 1935.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE TIMES quotes Henry Ford in a statement on business conditions as follows: "When we made plenty of the things that people use to live, we were able to make them at low prices and people were able to buy them, and this made work for more men.

William Reid, City Collector, announced yesterday the appointment of a deputy collector for each of the boroughs. He named the civil service men who had held the same positions under the old charter. They are: Manhattan, A. M. Steinert; the Bronx, George Nebgen; Brooklyn, Charles W., Hogan; Queens, Bernard H. Fee, and Richmond, Thomas W. Smith.
The New York State Committee of the Communist party made public yesterday its recommendations for the present Albany session, covering a fifteen-point people's program of "must" legislation.
Two new appointments to the faculty of Princeton Theological Seminary were announced here today, to take effect with the beginning of the second semester later this month. Dr.

Supreme Court Justice -Alfred Frankenthaler dismissed yesterday objections to the proposed reorganization of the Lawyers Title Guaranty Company which had been interposed by the Globe Rutgers Fire Insurance Company, one of the largest stockholders the mortgage company.

The total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined $1,846,891,565 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. Average price a share of all listed stocks on Jan. 3 was $27.53, compared with $28.92 at the beginning In of December.

King Victor Emanuel today gave his consent to the engagement of Prince Ferdinando di Savoia-Genova, Duke of Genoa, to Countess Maria Luigia Alliaga Gandolfi del Conti di Ricaldone, a famous Turinese beauty.
Quiet moves to strengthen the Suez Canal area against any possibility of attack from the air became known today.

With strenuous training ended yesterday, Freddie Steele, middleweight champion, and Fred Apostoli, Pacific Coast contender, will mark time until the gong the opens their 12-round non-title battle at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night.

Senator Lester H. Clee gained twenty-eight additional votes today in the recount of. the Governorship ballots, bringing his total net gain to 549 since the reexamination of the Hudson County ballots began.

Representative May of Kentucky, foe of the Tennessee Valley Authority, inroduced in the House today a resolution proposing an investigation by the Military Affairs Committee into many charges he made against the Authority.

With one more round to be played, Samuel Reshevsky of New York, chess champion of the United States, tonight leads the entire field of ten competitors in the international masters tournament at the Hastings and St. Leonards Club.
The estate of Colonel Edward H. R. Green has paid $17,000,000 in inheritance taxes to the Federal Government, Harry M. Hickey, District Collector of Internal Reyenue, said today.

Conferences today between Acting Governor Mendez Ramos and representatives of shipping companies, the C. I. 0. and the A. F. L. resulted in a temporary impasse but the Governor told both sides that he wanted the ship strike settled promptly. Longshoremen now earning 32 cents an hour want 50 to return temporarily while the C. I. O. demands a closed shop with control of the hiring halls.

Closer cooperation among the governing bodies of boxing and stricter supervision of matchmaking will soon bring the ring sport back to the prosperous plane it once enjoyed. This was the view of prominent figures in the game who attended a luncheon and meeting of the Boxing Writers Association of New York yesterday in Jack Dempsey's Restaurant.
Associate Justice George Sutherland, for more than fifteen years a member of the Supreme Court, notified President Roosevelt today that he would retire from the bench on Jan. 18.

The Fidelity-Philadelphia Trust Company (Philadelphia) in its statement for Dec. 31 showed total deposits of $104,145,512 and total assets of $130,054,619, compared respectively with $106,508,465 and $132,626,437 on Sept. 30 last. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $33,542,325, against $31,213,957; United States Government securities to $15,553,229, against $15,811,812 and loans to $23,096,829, against $23,346,830. Capital and surplus were unchanged at $6,700,000 and $15,000,000 respectively and undivided profits

Hank Johnson scored almost half his team's points to lead the Brooklyn Poly quintet to a 45-40 victory over Wagner at the 101st Signal Battalion Armory in Brooklyn last night. Nine field goals and four from the foul line gave the Poly center 22 points.

Faced with the uncertainty of world conditions and the necessity of putting the army and navy on a sound basis, President Roosevelt, in the budget recommendations submitted to Congress today, called for national defense expenditures for the fiscal year 1939 of about $1,000,000,000.

Continued recodification of the State Banking Law, which was initiated last year, will be pressed by the Banking Deapartment in the present session of the Legislature, it was announced by William R. White, Superintendent of Banks, in his annual report to the Governor and the Legislature, made public here today.
News of his defeat in yesterday's Democratic Senatorial primary was still kept today from former Senator J. Thomas Heflin, ill of pneumonia for two weeks. Dr. N. A. Wheeler described Mr.

Exhibits by the distilled spirits and automotive industries at the 1939 World's Fair were assured yesterday. The General Motors Corporation signed a rental contract for the largest space yet leased by a single private exhibitor, and Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation, announced plans for a joint display by twenty-six distillers under the leadership of the Distilled Spirits Institute.

The Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies will receive a legacy of $5,000 in the will of Harry A. Steinberg, filed for probate in Surrogates' Court yesterday. His residuary estate of undetermined value goes in equal shares to ten charitable institutions to be selected by his executors.

In his biennial message today Governor White startled the Legislature with a recommendation that all homesteads be exempted completely from State, county, district and municipal taxes. He declared that the State's present financial condition, with a surplus of more than $5,000,000 in the treasury, justified such action.

The four American painters who won the fellowships in book illustration, amounting to $2,000 each, awarded recently by the Limited Editions Club have selected the classics of American literature that they will illustrate, George Macy, director of the club, announced yesterday.

Announcement was made yesterday by the National Association of Shirt and Pajama Manufacturers that the industry it represents "will label merchandise pursuant to regulations for the rayon industry as approved by the Federal Trade Commission."

Premier Camille Chautemps, acting as referee in the strike in the Goodrich rubber factory, which broke out Dec. 15 over the dismissal of an electrician, tonight gave a ruling upholding the company's right to dismiss a man over a matter "entirely outside the domain of union labor."

With four members of the LaborRepublican-Fusion bloc breaking away from the leadership of B. Charney Vladeck, the City Council rejected Mayor La Guardia's plea for immediate action on the new city budget yesterday by a vote 18 to 6, with Councilman Howard A. Spellman, Manhattan Democrat, not voting.
Julien J. Schwarz, advertising director of The Albany Times Union, died here early yesterday morning at the home of his sister, Mrs. Leo Goldschmidt, 574 West End Avenue. He was 43 years old.

So much of Paragrapn 3, Special Oraers ??, dated Aug. 26, 1937, as continues 1st Lt. Charles DiSalvo, Ch.-Res., on active duty with the CCC until March 6, 1938, is amended so as to continue him on active duty until Feb. 8, 1938.
Harvard ran its undefeated basketball string to six games tonight,.deeating Tufts, 41-30, and winning the mythical greater Boston chainpionship in the process.
Announcement that the itinerary of the United States warships that will come to Australia provides for a visit only to Sydney has evoked disappointment throughout the Commonwealth.

Dr. Harry H. Fisher, in 115 Central Park W: Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., broker. Benjamin Landsman, in 5 W 86th St; Joseph T. Melling, in 949 West End Ave; George W. Lehr, in 423 W 120th St: Seymour S. Glazon, in 201 W 89th St: Arthur J. Rieser. in 235 W 71st St; Harry Gasarch, in 304 W 89th St; lsabelle A. Esson, in 423 W 120th St; John Condon, in 949 West

Instead of coming to the Martin Beck Theatre on Jan. 24, as had been expected, "Spring Thaw" will pause in Baltimore after Saturday night for four to six weeks, to be devoted to rewriting the first two acts. The weeks scheduled for Philadelphia and Boston-Jan. 10 and 17-are also canceled, and Jose Ruben will go back to "7-11," now slated for early February.

The serving of summonses upon motorists who disobey the new regulations against parking on the ten midtown streets chosen by the Police Department as "express" crosstown routes will not start until the end of this week, Deputy Chief Inspector James J. Sheehy announced yesterday. No specific date was fixed.
Arthur Alfred Holman, veteran actor, producer and director of the theatre department of the Leland Powers School of the Theatre, died here today at his home. He was 52 years of age.

The Rochester and Lake Ontario Water Service Corporation, a subsidiary of the Federal Water Service Corporation, applied yesterday to the Public Service Commission for permission to extend further the maturity of $2,000,000 of the subsidiary's 5 per cent first mortgage bonds.

Every German boy is to be taught the manly art of boxing. Reich Boxing Commissioner Metzner has made an agreement with the Hitler Youth organization whereby he undertakes to provide training for all members of the Hitler Youth, to which all German boys are compelled to belong.

The opening contests of the Long Island division of the Amateur Fencers League of America will be held here on Jan. 17 with the women's junior foils matches, it was announced today by Miss Mildred Stewart, national intercollegiate women's fencing champion and secretary of the division.
The firm of Donoho Co. informed the New York Stock Exchange of a change in name to J. F. Donoho Co. Hana Goldstein, special partner in Schatzkin, Loewi Co., has retired therefrom.

21st St, 233-37 W. 50x98.9; Seelnep Realties Corp, Herman Knepper, president, to Mastan Co, Inc, 350 5th Ave; due and interest as per bond; $4,000. Bleecker St; 371-73, 37.9x61.10; Ida Jacobs to 373 Bleecker St Realty Corp, 342 Madison Ave: p m. prior mtg $44,000, 6 years. 5%: $9,000.

The Mortgage Commission of the State of New York has sold, through the Duross Company, to the 708-12 Greenwich Street Realty Corporation, Louis Syrkin, president, the six-story warehouse building at 708-12 Greenwich Street, between West Tenth and Charles Streets.

The marriage of Miss Clare Killeen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward V. Killeen of 35 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, to William Hamilton Sullivan, son of Frederick B. Sullivan, also of Brooklyn and of Allenhurst, N. J., and the late Mrs. Sullivan, took place here yesterday morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Awards of several contracts for construction and alterations in New York and vicinity were reported yesterday by Brown's Letters, Inc. The proposal of T. B. Campbell, Inc., for the general construction of a new school in the Union Free School District 4 of the Town of Huntington, L. I., at a cost of $177,965, was accepted.

Turpentine, firm, 27c; sales, 22 barrels; receipts, 122 barrels; shipments, 36 barrels; stock, 31.985 barrels. Resin, firm; sales, 112; receipts, 514; no shipments; stock, 73,368. Quote: B. D $4.25; E. $4.50; F $5.50; G. $5.60; H. $5.75; I, $5.85; K, $6.10; M, $6.20; N, $6.25; WG, $7.05; WW and X, $7.50.

Donald Collier, 25-year-old archaeologist and son of John Collier, United States Indian Commissioner, announced yesterday, on his return from South America on the Grace liner Santa Rita, that he had discovered a stone temple of pre-Inca origin on the upper Peruvian coast.

As far as the $9,575,000 naval hospital here is concerned, motor vehicle traffic and not dangers of the sea are the greatest threat to Uncle Sam's sailors. Traffic accidents now cause more deaths than any other kind, says Captain L. W. Johnson, executive officer.

Loading and unloading of all ships in Seattle harbor ceased at noon today in a dispute between the Waterfront Employers Association- of Seattle and the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union.
Mrs. John Nagle, one of the contenders for Charles Vance Millar's $500,000 "stork derby" bequest, last night gave birth to her twelfth child-a girl.

Two books by women newspaper correspondents are announced by Macmillan for Spring publication. Mary Knight, who for five years worked as a reporter in Paris, China, Japan and the United States, tells of her adventures in "On My Own."

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company is prepared to invest $100,000,000 in dwellings in which rentals would be low, Frederick H. Ecker, chairman of the board, said yesterday following the publication of Governor Lehman's message. Mr.

The bitter fight over State relief administration, with political leaders and social workers ranged on opposite sides, resulted today, after many delays, in an announcement by Governor Earle that Karl de Schweinitz would be retained as Secretary of Public Assistance.

A banking group headed by Lehman Brothers won yesterday the award of a new issue of $1,350,000 of State of South Carolina certificates of indebtedness on a bid of 100.479 for 3s. The certificates, dated Jan. 1, 1938, and maturing on Jan. 1, 1939 to 1952, were reoffered at prices to yield from 0.85 to 3.00 per cent, according to maturity. The bankers reported 150 the issue all sold.

Dr. Frank J. Sexton, former baseball coach at Harvard, Brown and Michigan, died suddenly at his home in Brighton last night at the age of 65. Dr. Sexton was one of the great Brown University pitchers of the early Nineties, along with Fred Woodcock, and they with Fred Tenney, late star first baseman and manager of the Boston Nationals, as catcher, had remarkable success against all college teams..

Casa Rosada del Lago was the setting today for a large tea and cocktail party given by Mrs. Peyton J. Van Rensselaer for her house guest, Mrs. Esther Bissett Norment of Washington. The guests included Mr. and Mrs. Jules Vatable, Prince and Princess Balthasar Odescalchi, Mr. and Mrs. Guernsey Curran Jr., Mr. and Mrs.

Peter V. Cacchione, Communist candidate for City Councilman in Brooklyn, who lost by 368 votes in the last election to Abner C. Surpless, Republican, failed to get a complete recount of the ballots cast in a decision handed down yesterday by Supreme Court Justice John MacCrate in Brooklyn.

The principal operating subsidiaries in the American Telephone and Telegraph Company system had a net gain of 41,700 telephones in service in December, it was announced yesterday. This compared with a net gain of 91,500 installations in December, 1936.

A threecornered struggle among the foreign petroleum companies, the Mexican Government and the National Oil Unions was deadlocked today, five days after the companies had petitioned the Federal Labor Board for a temporary injunction against the board's wage ruling.

Accused of operating a scheme whereby more than $50,000 was obtained from various banks in the metropolitan area, four men pleaded guilty yesterday in County Court, Brooklyn, to charges of second-degree forgery and first-degree grand larceny.

The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for Dec. 31 showed that the ratio of the bank's gold reserve to notes in circulation was 123.65 per cent, against 127.33 per cent on Dec. -15.

A young bald eagle, with a wing spread of 7 feet 2 inches and guaranteed to be "militant," was en route today to General Smedley D. Butler, retired commander of the marines, at Newton Square, Pa. E. N. Fogleman, junior

Candid-camera enthusiasts from nearly every State in the Union and ten foreign countries will be represented in the Fourth International Leica Exhibit of Candid Photography to be opened on Saturday in the International Building, 630 Fifth Avenue, following a private opening tomorrow night.

In a further effort to provide relief for taxpayers subject to the capital gains and losses levy, a House subcommittee on taxation today agreed tentatively on legislation to permit carry-overs of capital losses from one year to the following year.

Basketball finally has arrived as a major sport. Paralleling the growth of football in many respects, basketball has awakened nation-wide interest mainly because of (1), the widespread increase in intersectional games;

Mrs. Robert L. Livingston will give a dinner tonight at her home, 1,192 Park Avenue. Rear Admiral and Mrs. Richard E. Byrd have come from Boston to the Biltmore. William Gilman Low and his daughter, Miss Rhoda Low, of Tuxedo Park and Newport, who have been at the Ambassador, have gone to St. Agatha, Canada, for Winter sports.

In an effort to bring about closer relationships between its dealers and the management, Alfred P. part Sloan Jr., chairman of General Motors Corporation, announced yesterday the establishment of a dealerrelations board.

An epidemic of infantile paralysis. confined to Melbourne for some months after its outbreak last June, is now spreading. The total cases in Victoria are now 145 and deaths 79. Last week 57 of 99 cases reported were in country centers.

William H. Wheelock, well-known New York realty man, was named chairman of the board of Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., at meetings of the stockholders and directors of the company yesterday. The office had been vacant since the death of Charles S. Brown in 1935.

179th St, (11-3221), n s 135 east of Loring P1, 35x116: C C Construction Co. Inc, to Elm Ereo Corp, 141 West 179th St. Marion Ave, (12-3284); n e cor of 199th St. 35x98: William H. Austin. ref, to Harlem Savings Bank. Grant Ave. (11-2816); e s 188 s of 170th St, 103x100; Berwyck Realty Corp to 52 E 120th St Corp, 1.475 Broadway.
Two dozen newspaper reporters and a smiling group of police officials turned the tables yesterday on John J. Sullivan, who has headed the detective forces of this city

Under a further improvement in foreign prices, which maintained the relative cheapness of cotton grown in the United States when compared with Indian and other competing growths, quotations on the Cotton Exchange here advanced yesterday to the highest levels since the latter part of September.

Eight ready-to-wear buying offices have organized the Buyer's Guild, Inc., with offices at 225 West Thirty-fourth Street, and will do all their buying hereafter under that name, it was announced yesterday.

The Far Eastern crisis occupied the attention of both sides of the Capitol today when the House approved a Senate bill to tighten restrictions on the photographing, mapping or sketching of American military or naval defenses, and the Senate debated aspects of the Administration's foreign policy.

The Seamen's Church Institute of New York will have an educational booth at the Motor Boat Show, which opens Friday evening at Grand Central Palace. A debutante committee will assist with the displays and in the sales of sailors' handicraft and will act as manikins, wearing typical yachting clothes.
New Jersey's bonded debt stood at $169,501,000 at the half-way mark in the 1937-38 fiscal year, a reduction of $3,500,000 since the year started on July 1, the Controller's office said today.

New lower prices for police uniforms, which give allowance for lower fabric values, were submitted yesterday by the Uniform Manufacturers Exchange, to forestall the movement in the Police Department to establish a cooperative factory. The prices were sent to members and to Commissioner Valentine.

49th St, 249 W. 4-story Hotel Byron, 25x 100.5; City Bank Farmers Trust Co against Lityn Realty Corp; due, $78,763; to plaintiff for $71,000. 9th Ave, 138, 3-story tenement and stores, 16.7x60; Home Owners Loan Corp against Helen A. Eckholdt; due, $8,354; to plaintiff for $500.

Strong support by members of Congress was indicated today for President Roosevelt's request, in his message on the budget, for authority to veto "riders" in appropriation bills without being forced to void the whole measure, including necessary appropriations.
The text of President Roosevelt's message submitting the Federal budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 1938, to Congress follows:

Charles R. Hook, president of the American Rolling Mill Company, in a letter to stockholders explaining the dividend policy of the company last year, which resulted in the omission of the 50-cent payment due on Jan. 15, said that the unexpected recession in business, which prompted the directors' action, evidently was due to the cumulative effect of a number of things.

Twenty-one entries were received at a meeting at the Marshall Chess Club yesterday for the women's championship tournament to be held in this city under the auspices of the National Chess Federation of Chicago concurrently with the men's national tournament, early in April.

The world's outstanding professional tennis stars, Ellsworth Vines and Fred Perry, today named their first ten men's singles ranking for both amateurs and professionals, dating from 1920 through 1937.

Ralph Greenleaf, world champion, and Andrew Ponzi divided blocks in their exhibition pocket billiard match at the Strand Academy yesterday. Ponzi holds a point advantage of 635 to 593 in the six blocks played. Greenleaf scored, 125 to 76, in ten innings, then lost, 125 to 99, in seven innings. High runs were: Greenleaf 39 and 43, Ponzi 42 and 51.

Two women and five men were arrested yesterday on charges of disorderly conduct as the result of mass picketing of the Eagle Electrical Manufacturing Company plant at 59 Hall Street, Brooklyn. Captain William O. Jones of the Classon Avenue Station said that although he had ordered that only forty pickets be allowed nearly 200 pickets surrounded the building.

The Yale Club continued to hold its position at the top of Group I in Class C of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association yesterday by defeating 'the Squash Club, 3-2. It was the unbeaten Eli team's fourth triumph.

Alfred Rinn, 30 years old, of 41 Campbell Avenue, Hackensack, was killed instantly this afternoon after being struck and run over by a loaded twelve-ton milk truck and trailer on Route 4 as he walked from in front of his truck which he had just driven to the side of the road.

Dr. Robert Livingston Schuyler of Columbia University, managing editor of the American Historical Review and author of many studies on American government, will deliver the second in a series of lectures on the Constitution as part of the national sesquicentennial celebration today in the Great Hall of the main building, 139th Street and Convent Avenue.
The British in Pales Government discovered today that caused b it had stirred up a hornet's nest of criticism by its latest declaration of policy on Palestine.

Police seized today thirtybars of gold, valued at $30,000, and $750 in cash from Dr. Emilio Ochoa Yochoa and Gabriel' Marco Villatonga, both Cubans. It is understood the Panama police received a tip from the Havana police in connection with the robbery of the Nunez Bank in Havana.

Motor boat men upset Police Com- v missioner Valentine's no-parking edict yesterday and partly blocked East Forty-seventh Street from s Third to Park Avenues not only for s daylight hours but far into the night. It was for a good cause, however.

The Chinese Government dispatched memorandums today to the United States, Great Britain and France protesting against the proclamation issued Saturday by the Shanghai Municipal Council, the body governing the Shanghai International Settlement, in which the council said any person committing an offense against armed foreign forces in the Settlement would be handed over to the forces concerned.

Bobby Riggs, top-seeded Chicagoan, today played his first match in the Miami Biltmore tennis tournament, defeating Dick McKee, Miami school boy, 6-4, 8-6. Riggs drew a first-round bye and his second-round foe defaulted. His opponent tomorrow will be Martin Buxby, Miami, who eliminated his fellow-townsman, George Pero, 6-1, 6-2.

J. Edgar Hoover reported to Attorney General Cummings today the results of an investigation covering five months into the nation-wide activities of the German-American Bund, an organization headed by Fritz Kuhn of New York.

A son was born here today to Dona Maria, Princess of Asturias, and Prince Juan, heir apparent to the nonexistent throne of Spain. The baby's grandfather, former King Alfonso XIII, and Prince Juan were at the Anglo-American Hospital when the child was born. Mother and child were reported doing well. The baby will have the title of Infante de Espana.

World consumption of coffee dedined 573,553 bags, or 4.8 per cent, in the last half of 1937, compared with the same period in 1936, the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange announced yesterday. Delivseries to consuming channels during the 1937 period were 11,490,276 bags, against 12,063,829 bags in the corresponding 1936 period.
Investors bought several apartment houses in Harlem in deals announced yesterday. The activity in housing properties also extended to Washington Heights and other sections of the city.

A horizontal enlargement of the navy to give it sufficient strength to cope with situations arising out of unsettled world conditions was decided upon today, it became known after a conference at the White House, during which the general situation was discussed by President Roosevelt with House leaders responsible for authorizations and appropriations for the naval forces.

Purses totaling $307,000 will be offered during the twenty-eight-day 1938 race season at the milliondollar Delaware Park track at Stanton, directors of the Delaware Steeplechase and Race Association announced today.

The receivers for the Wabash Railway announced yesterday that an order issued by the Federal court in St. Louis on Tuesday directed them to make no payment on account of the 20 per cent remaining unpaid on interest due on and after May 1 last on first

The heads of two of the island's three major political parties today petitioned Congress and the American people for liberalization of the Puerto Rican Organic Act and for a plebiscite in which the island may decide between statehood and independence as its ultimate status.

In the first ruling on secondary picketing since the Court of Appeals handed down a decision on the subject a month ago, Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman held yesterday that a union could call or threaten to call a strike at establishments supplying the Rand Tea and Coffee Stores, Inc., but could not use "violence or intimidation" to prevent the Rand stores from getting supplies.
The Labor Relations Board today denied the petition of the Ford Motor Company for a rehearing on the board's complaint that the company violated the Wagner Labor Relations Act.

In a reference to an application was felt widely by the Southeastern Greyhound ing inevitably Lines to the Interstate Commerce country. The Commission for approval of the is- branch-banking suance of $2,939,690 of stock made by the State B in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Tues- report accompa day, the company was described as port of the the Southwestern Greyhound Lines. Banks.

A first mortgage loan of $265,000 for ten years at 5 per cent has been arranged by the Paul Ham-mond Company for the M. J. H. Realty Corporation, M. H. Hanover, president, on the new six-story apartment house at 81 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn.

ABBOTT-Frank. Services Walter B. Cooke, Inc., Funeral Home, 117 West 72d, Friday, 12 noon, auspices the Actors' Fund. AHEARN-Mary (nee Larkin), suddenly, on Jan. 3, 1938, at the home of Catherine Hyland, 211 8th Ave., Brooklyn, wife of the late Patrick Ahearn, native of Galbally, Tipperary, Ireland, and former resident of Spring Valley, N. Y.;

Nick Calacione, 27-year-old unemployed bakery worker, stabbed his wife, Theresa, to death in a quarrel yesterday morning and died two and one-half hours later at Long Island College Hospital of injuries suffered when he jumped off the Brooklyn end of Manhattan Bridge.

Five years of depression, recovery and recession are a long time in any State's history, but Governor Lehman could face the Legislature yesterday with evidence that their lessons have not been lost. As the Governor said, we do not know how far the present slump will go, nor what the Federal Government means to do "in carrying the burden of relief."

The United States Biological Survey, in carrying on its wildlife research, has uncovered a number of interesting facts in relation to the abundance fluctuations of certain game, which some characterize as "cycles."

Allerton Ave (16-4440), s w cor of Boston Rd, 163x234; Leo Weil to Bronx Savings Bank, 5 years, 5 per cent; $48,300. St. Georges Crescent (12-3313) e s, 105 ft n of 206th St, 75x100; Gelson Realty Corp to Lauretta K. Reynolds, 189 E. 206th St, 1 year, 5 per cent; $21,500.
With a left hook to the jaw Tony Galento, Orange heavyweight, tonight knocked out Charley Massera, Pittsburgh fighter, in the third of what was to have been a ten-round battle in the Orange Armory.

The Interstate Commerce Commission reported yesterday that 141 Class 1 railways had a net income of $17,194,927 in October, 1937, against $46,585,462 in October, 1936. Statements by individual railroads issued yesterday follow:

Charles Remsen, a retired farmer, died today in the Northern Westchester Hospital here of injuries suffered New Year's Eve when struck by a skidding automobile in New Castle. He was 56 years old and lived in Armonk.

Smashing the chief hope of the amateur contingent, Jack Summers, M. I. T. coach, eliminated Germain G. Glidden, national amateur champion, from the ranks of the competitors in the first open invitation tournament of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association yesterday.

Army won an exciting game from Princeton today, 28 to 26, as the Cadets opened their basketball season. Brinker, high scorer with 13 points, decided the battle with only a few seconds left when his dribble and perfect shot wrested the lead from the Tigers and made the score 27 to 26 in Army's favor.

William E. Dodd, retiring United States Ambassador to Germany, is due to arrive tonight from Berlin on the steamship Washington of the United States Lines. Others coming from the Channel ports are H. M. van Haersma de With, Netherlands Minister to the United States; Miss Mary Agnes Hamilton,

The Cunard White Star liner Franconia sailed last night with 311 passengers on her annual voyage around the world during which she will steam 38,000 miles via Brazil, Capetown, East Africa, India, Siam, Malay States, Australia, New Zealand, across the Pacific to the Hawaiian Islands, California and the Panama Canal and back to New York on May 31.

Patrolman Frank E. Zaccor of the West Thirtieth Street police station was shot and killed at 1:15 A. M. today by one of three robbers with whom he engaged in a pistol battle in McElroy's bar and grill at 30 West Thirty-first Street.
Two teams which did not receive much consideration in early season games now loom as the defenders of Eastern basketball prestige.

The pickets who paraded outside the Horn Hardart Automats for five months were withdrawn at noon yesterday after the strike called against the cafeteria chain by two A. F. of L. unions had ended with an interchange of letters among the management, the unions and the State Mediation Board.

Amsterdam Ave, 423, 188 Realty Corp, Blanche E. Frank, president, to Frederick H. Fleitmann, care of Maurice Mencher, 33 W, 42d St; mtg, $40,000 ($7). Bleecker St, 371-3, 373 Bleecker St Realty Corp, Harry A. Rose, president, to Ida Jacobs, 230 E 173d St; mtg, $44,000 ($15). Same property, Ida Jacobs to Leo Karger, 399 South 5th St, Brooklyn; mtg, $53,000 (50c).

The United Licensed Officers Association, a union of merchant marine deck and engineer officers affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, was divided into two camps yesterday as the result of a meeting of a group on Tuesday night-at which expulsion of Captain John F. Milliken as president was voted.

Today's major events: Boston Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P. M.; "Carmen," Metropolitan Opera House, 8 P. M. Olga Samaroff Stokowski will lecture before members of the Metropolitan Opera Guild on Strauss's "Elektra" this afternoon at the Hotel Pierre.

China's determination to fight Japan to the utmost was exemplified today by the government's decision to strengthen the National Military Council and by renewed activity of the reorganized air force, which is directed by Mme. Chiang Kai-shek.

The maladjustments responsible for the present decline in business have been sufficiently corrected so that a reversal of the trend could occur within sixty days if confidence were restored, A. W. Zelomek, economist of the International Statistical Bureau told the Bridgeport Control

The Martime Investment Corporation, Los Angeles, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 49,800 shares of 60 cent Class A preferred stock and 49,800 shares of 60 cent Class B common, both securities having no stated par value, to be offered in units of one share of preferred and one share of common at $10 a unit.

The New York University freshman basketball team recorded its highest point total in seven games this season in defeating N. Y. U. Washington Square College, 86 to 34, at the University Heights gymnasium yesterday.

Following is the text of Governor Lehman's annual message to the Legislature: This is the sixth year of my administration as Governor of the State of New York. The years since January, 1933, when I first appeared before your honorable bodies have been arduous and exacting.

The engagement has been announced of Miss Margarete Alicia Minske, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Minske of White Plains, N. Y., formerly of Greenwich, Conn., to Humphrey Grant Schroeder of Mount Vernon, N. Y., son of Mr. and Mrs. John G. Schroeder of a East Orange, N. J. Miss Minske attended Columbia University. Mr. Schroeder was graduated from Colgate University.

A small loan exhibition of portraits of noted singers of the Metropolitan Opera is being held in the buffet lounge on the grand tier floor of the Metropolitan Opera House under the auspices of the Metropolitan Opera Guild.

Justice Willis Van Devanter, who retired from the United States Supreme Court last year, at the age of 78, donned his judicial robe again yesterday to preside at the trial of a criminal case in the Federal District Court here.

Premieres of two important choral works will be heard at the concert of the Schola Cantorum, Hugh Ross, conductor, next Wednesday evening at Carnegie Hall. They are the first American performance of "The Mass of Life," by Frederick Delius,

For two days now the Insurgents have been trying to widen the base of their narrow salient pointing toward Teruel. According to today's Government communique, their efforts have been completely in vain.
Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 21,000, including 4,000 directs.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Jan. 3: COMMANDER Jersey, C. C., New York, N. Y., to home, relieved of all active duty. LIEUTENANT COMMANDER Van Bergen, N. B., the Concord, to Bureau of Navigation, Washington. D. C.
The American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions tonight announced that Miss Mary G. Webb, retired missionary, died today in Beirut, Syria. She was 83 years old.
Mrs. Marie Louise Davis Gifford of 290 Park Avenue, widow of Livingston Gifford, New York patent lawyer, died on Tuesday at the Regent Nursing Home here of a heart ailment. Her age was 73.
Unfavorable railroad news depressed prices and stocks closed irregularly lower; turnover, 1,150,840 shares.
Mr. and Mrs. Paul H. Goetz of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eunice M. Goetz, to Donald Hayden Bookhultz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Bookhultz, also of this city.

Mrs. Pauline Creeron, former ballet dancer, died today in the Mount Vernon Hospital of injuries suffered New Year's night when she jumped from a window of her second floor apartment at 504 South Third Avenue here.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Jan. 4: LIEUTENANT COLONELS Peake, A. S. (Inf.), National Guard Bureau, relieved from detail in the National Guard Bureau, Washington, D. C., April 14, and ordered to 22d Infantry, Fort McPherson. Ga.
The Senate delayed a message from the President for nearly an hour today to hold a birthday party for its oldest and smallest member, Carter Glass of Virginia, who was 80 years old yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. John C. Cowan of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Annie Ruth Cowan, to Finley W. Tatum, son of Mrs. Menafee W. Tatum of El Paso, Texas, and the late Mr. Tatum.

Filing of factums before the Supreme Court today by parties interested in next week's reference to that tribunal of recent Alberta banking and newspaper legislation disclosed that the Dominion Government planned not only to upset that legislation but to have the introduction of a social credit system declared illegal in Alberta or any other Canadian Province for all time to come.

One important question before the nation's voters in the campaign of 1936 was this: Do you want the President or Alf M. Landon to fill the inevitable vacancies on the Supreme Court? Since Mr. Roosevelt's re-election two vacancies have occurred, and when he fills the chair of Justice Sutherland--if the Senate

Baron and Baroness Carl Czoernig von Czernhausen have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helene Marie Czoernig von Czernhausen, to Charles Richard Arenschield Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Richard Arenschield of Washington, formerly of this city.

With Captain Jim McKay scoring 23 points, the Regis High School basketball team last night came from behind to overwhelm Fordham Prep, 47-29, for the winners' first victory over the Rose Hill youngsters in eight years.
Scoring two goals in the last two and a half minutes of play, Phillips Andover Academy's hockey team defeated Medford High, 3-1, today.

Although the Board of Estimate upheld Mayor La Guardia this week by voting repeal of the $12,000,000 water rate reduction approved in October by the Board of Aldermen, the movement for "fair water rates" will continue, the Citizens Budget Commission announced yesterday.

The directors of the William S. Merrell Company of Cincinnati, manufacturer of pharmaceutical products, adopted yesterday a resolution approving for submission to its stockholders a plan of reorgan ization whereby, the Vick Chemical Company would acquire all assets of the present Merrell company in exchange for Vick Chemical stock.

A suit to remove the Chase National Bank as trustee for holders of American participating certificates in a $25,000,000 6 per cent made by the Deutsche BankI of Germany was begun yesterday by Ruth Greene, holder of a $1,000 certifi cate, who charged that all certifi- ho cate holders had not agreed to an extension of the note's maturity date.

Judging by the many requests for advance reservations, indications are that a throng of city dwellers will flee to popular snowlands of Upper New York State and New England on the one-day "snow trains" that are to make their season's debut on Sunday.

No budget submitted by President Roosevelt has aroused so little interest or caused so little comment as the document which he sent to Capitol Hill today. This was due largely to the fact that all but one salient point in it had been anticipated.

Four members of the seeded list scored victories last night as the fourth annual Class B invitation squash racquets tourney started at the Union League Club with a field of thirty-two players. It is the strongest entry in the event's history.

Frank Dunne was re-elected president of the New York Security Dealers Association yesterday. Clarence E. Unterberg became first vice president, John J. O'Kane Jr. second vice president and Peter Ross executive secretary.

Two acres in the subdivision of the Estate of Percy A. Rockefeller in Greenwich, Conn., have been sold to Mrs. Alice C. Rowland of Greenwich. With this sale, about twenty-eight acres of the 312-acre tract have been sold, the plots averaging about four acres in size.
All government salaries will be doubled as of Jan. 1, it is announced by Finance Minister Jose Benito Ramirez, to meet the higher cost of living and depreciation of the cordoba.

Estimated retail sales of $40,388,000,000, an increase of 6 1/2 per cent over 1936, represented the largest dollar volume for any year since 1930, Secretary Roper said today in a statement issued with the results of a survey of the merchandise inventories of the country. This 1937 total, he added, was 18 per cent under the 1929 record of $49,115,000,000.

M. Ducoureau, French consular agent at Irun, was still in an Insurgent jail today, and information was still lacking from the Spanish side on the nature of the charges preferred against him and two aides. Four others are reported to have been arrested on like charges.

Arift in the big Socialist union, the Union General de - Trabajadores [General Union of Workers] was settled today in Valencia by the withdrawal of the general secretary, Francisco Largo Caballero, who for some years has-been the union's big boss.

Mrs. Howard A. Scholle will give a luncheon today at her home, 43 Fifth Avenue, for members of St. Hilda's Guild of Grace Church, Broadway and Tenth Street, after the meeting of the sewing class of the organization which will be held at Grace House.

Kings HYMOWITZ, LEBA (March 12, 1936). Gross assets, $9,095; net, $2,343. Chief assets, real estate, $8,000; mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $110; miscellaneous property, $985. Harry Salvan, attorney. 302 Broadway, Manhattan.
Wheat made a strong start and a tame finish today. Prices on the Board of Trade advanced around 11/2 cents a bushel at the opening, with the May at the new highest mark since Nov. 17, but the buying

The Federal Trade Commission today charged the Standard Manufacturers Association, Jacksonville, Fla., and twenty-five member companies manufacturing wooden containers for fruits and vegetables, with combinations and agreements in restraint of trade through the fixing of uniform prices, terms and discounts for their products, and other practices.

At the close of business Tuesday, 50,694 passenger car and 3,171 commercial automobile license plates for 1938 had been issued in New York City, Deputy Commissioner of Motor Vehicles I. J. Brody announced yesterday. This figure was 27,422 short of the mark for the corresponding day of last year, Mr.
Clearly outplayed by Dr. Alexandre Alekhine in the twenty-eighth game of the match for the chess championship of the world, Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam was guilty of three missteps.

Two more top-flight athletes made last-minute entries yesterday in the Columbus Council, K. of C., meet, which will open the indoor track season Saturday night at the old Thirteenth Regiment Armory in Brooklyn.

The' Bishop of Bermuda demonstrated his disapproval of the Duke of Windsor's romance this afternoon. The Bishop walked into a local newspaper office to pay his subscription and saw two photographs of the Duke and Duchess hung up behind the counter by a shop girl admirer.

Harry S. Whitehair, 53 years old, a former insurance broker, of the Kew Gardens Inn, Kew Gardens, Queens, killed himself yesterday in a room in the Hotel Commodore. He shot himself twice in the head with a .22 caliber rifle after writing notes asking that his wife, physician and an undertaker be notified.

Declaring that the majority of strikes in 1936 and 1937 were fought around the issue of collective bargaining and the right of labor to organize, David J. Saposs, chief economist and research director of the National Labor Relations Board, blamed "intransigent" employers today for much of the industrial unrest, which he held was an element responsible for the business recession.
Alarmed at the growth of poor speech in this city, the Board of Examiners presented yesterday a manual citing the most common speaking faults and how they might be corrected.

Vittorio Venturi gained his most important victory since his arrival from Italy a year ago when he outpointed Frankie Blair of Camden, N. J., in the feature ten-round bout at the Hippodrome last night. Scoring almost at will with left hooks that carried plenty of power Venturi won by a wide margin, taking eight of the ten rounds.
Toy balloons containing inflammable gas were banned in Westchester County parks today by Hermann W. Merkel, superintendent of the county park system.

Jesse Owens, brilliant Negro track and field star who had a falling out with the A. A. U. after he had won four gold medals in the last OlympiC Games, said today he would apply for reinstatement as an amateur.
A new $9,900 streamlined ambulance was placed in service at a brief ceremony yesterday at Brooklyn fire headquarters, 365 Jay Street.

LADIES AND GENTLEMEN IN VICTORIAN FICTION, by E. M. Delafield. (Harper, $2.50.) A record of the Victorian domestic scene. I'M GETTING MARRIED, by Jolan Foldes. (Farrar Rinehart, $2.) A romantic novel.

The army mule, long conspicuous in activities at Fort Slocum off here, made his farewell appearance today. Twelve animals, all that remained at the islandfortification in Long Island Sound, were shipped by boat to the mainland and by truck to Camp Dix, N. J.

At the largest post-election public meeting ever to be held in New Jersey, Mayor Frank Hague will offer to the nation tomorrow night a defense of his ban on the C. I. O. in Jersey City as a "Communist-inspired" organization.
Today saw the beginning of official departures from Manila that in the next few months will again place the focus of Philippine affairs in Washington.

The Louisiana State University Athletic Council disapproved today a proposal for an exhibition football game between the Washington Redskins, national professional league champions, and a Louisiana all-star team.

The memory of Edward J. Neil Jr., war correspondent and former sports writer for The Associated Press who died of wounds received in the Spanish war, will be honored, by a medal to be awarded to the boxer who is outstanding in the sport each year.

" Tannhaeuser" was presented at the Metropolitan Opera House last night before a large and responsive audience. The cast was headed by Kirsten Flagstad as Elisabeth, Carl Hartmann as Tannhaeuser, Ludwig Hofmann as the Landgrave Hermann, Dorothee Manski as Venus and Julius Huehn in his first local impersonation of Wolfram.

The United States naval yacht Isabel arrived today to become the new headquarters for Admiral Harry E. Yarnell, commander of the United States Asiatic fleet. His flagship, the Augusta, will sail tomorrow for Manila.

A Federal deficit of $950,000,000 for the fiscal year 1939, despite projected economies of more than half a billion dollars, was forecast by President Roosevelt today in a message transmitting another $7,000,000,000 annual budget.

Mr. Robert Jackson, in the section he contributes to the Attorney General's report, raises questions of the first importance concerning our anti-trust policy. "The most serious obstacle to anti-trust prosecution," he contends, is "the judicial attitude * * * which makes a state of mind an element in every case. * * * The only possible standard which can practically be enforced [is] results."

Formal agreement to the appointments of Joseph P. Kennedy as Ambassador to Great Britain and Hugh R. Wilson as Ambassador to Germany has been received by the State Department from the governments concerned. Public announcement of these and other important changes in the diplomatic service

The American Iron and Steel Institute, whose membership comprises virtually the entire steel industry of the United. States, made public yesterday a statement disputing recent official assertions in Washington that the advances in steel prices have far outrun increased costs and are delaying the start of a housing program and restricting other uses of steel.
Phillips Exeter's hockey team outplayed Dover High School today, winning, 6 to 3. James and William Sloane, Captain Bill Saunders and Dan Stuckey were the chief factors in the winners' scoring.

Colonel M. Robert Guggenheim of New York and Washington and Mrs. Rebecca Pollard van Lennep of Philadelphia and Miami Springs, who was divorced yesterday from William van Lennep of New York and Malbern, Pa., by the Circuit Court at Miami, will be married aboard the Guggenheim yacht, Firenze, here, tomorrow.

Justice Sutherland's resignation following so close that of Justice Van Devanter should remind impatient souls that by the natural process of time new blood has flowed again and again into the Supreme Court. Sometimes the rejuvenation has been gradual. Sometimes it has been quick and general.

Mr. and Mrs. John Wallingford Muir of Chestnut Hill have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice King Muir, to the Rev. Lorenzo Russell Clapp of Germantown, son of Mrs. Walter Nicholas Clapp and the late Rev. Mr. Clapp.

Miss Lily Pons, the opera singer, has been appointed a member of the national women's council of the Committee for the Celebration of the President's Birthday to Fight Infantile Paralysis, it was announced yesterday.
The new year starts with steel production at 25 1/2 per cent of capacity, a moderate gain over week, but with prospects still shrouded in uncertainty, the Iron Age says this week.

BRUCK, THERESA L. (Dec. 19). Estate, less than $10,000. To Alumnae Association of Hunter College, model of the Taj Mahal with class cover and marble pedestal, books and curios not already bequeathed; Eva C. Neiman, 30 East Chester Rd., New Rocheile, N. Y.; Carolyn London, sister-in-law, 210 E. 68th St., and Zilla Coh, niece, executrix, residue equally.

The two three-story apartments at 1,881 and 1,885 West Ninth Street, Brooklyn, which occupy plots of 28 by 100 feet, have been sold by a client of Walter Samuels, Inc., to an investor represented by Sackman-Gilliland Corporation, broker.
With interest centered on the. exploits of newsreel men in the Panay incident, Metro will rush into production, probably early next month, "Too Hot to Handle," with Clark Gable as the star.

Indictments for murder against Mrs. Ethel Strouse Sohl, 20 years old, and Genevieve Owens, 17, for the slaying of William Barhorst, a bus driver, will be sought Friday when the Essex County grand jury convenes, it was announced today by Prosecutor William Wachenfeld.

A copy of the first edition of Bret Harte's "Mliss," in the original wrappers, was bought by Walter M. Hill for $750 last night at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., at the auction of Part 2 of the library of the late Joseph B. Shea of Pittsburgh.

Movements of vessels follow; all dates are Jan. 4 unless specified: Astoria, San Pedro to San Francisco. Badger. at 52d Street, Brooklyn, N. Y., Jan. 5. Brazos, San Pedro to Puget Sound Yard. Bushnell, San Diego to Balboa.
The semi-official bulletin Informazione Diplomatica reported today that ten nations had given formal diplomatic recognition to Italy's conquest of Ethiopia.

Special Order It is ordered that the following members of the uniformed force shall be allowed the time served by them in the Police Department (as indicated below), which shall be included and counted as service in the Fire Department:

The business recession has been responsible for an employment decline since September affecting more than a million wage and salaried workers, the American Federation of Labor announced today. Employment is still above last year's level,

Mrs. J. Chesney's Carl S., far back in the New Year's Handicap, came back today to defeat five other high grade claimers in the mile and a sixteenth feature at the Fair Grounds. After Caravel had set the pace to the top of the stretch, Carl S., 3 to 1 shot, went to the front and under C. Hanauer's guidance finished

Hearing on a petition of the American Newspaper Guild for collective-bargaining elections among the editorial employes in the Washington, Philadelphia and Boston bureaus of The Associated Press opened yesterday before Frank Bloom, examiner for the National Labor Relations Board, in the Woolworth Building.

Democratic leaders in the City Council believed yesterday that they had found a way to tie up the Council's proceedings indefinitely, even if the Labor-Republican-Fusion bloc mustered thirteen votes upon the return today of Councilman Michael J. Quill, who has been abroad.

Joseph Wiener, retired merchant active for forty-three years before 1928 in the novelty jewelry business and former president of the Novelty Jewelers Association, died on Tuesday in his home in the Hotel Salisbury. He was 72 years old.
Phil Cavarretta, 21-year-old youngster of the Chicago Cubs, will start the 1938 training campaign as regular first baseman, forcing Rip Collins to force him from the job if he can.

THE GREATEST SHOW ON EARTH, a play In three acts and twelve scenes by Vincent Duffey and Irene Alexander. Staged by George Somnes; settings by John Root costumes designed by Frank Bevan; produced by Helen G. Bonflis and her misband, Mr. Somnes. At the Playhouse.
Everett James Esselstyn, for many years an attorney in New York and a former vice president of the New York Bible Society, died yesterday at the Midtown Hospital after a short illness.

Puerto Rico increased its purchases from the United States substantially during 1937, according to figures issued yesterday by the Puerto Rican Trade Council, which showed that the island bought American goods valued at $82,750,000 during the first eleven months of the year, a gain of almost $5,000,000, or 6 per cent, over the same period of 1936.

Ecuador's first "Newspaper Men's Day" was celebrated here today in accordance with a decree of President Alberto Enriquez. President Enriquez has restored freedom of the press and, so far, has maintained it.

A mission representing the leading Turkish banks is to visit London to negotiate for British participation in new Turkish industrial and mining schemes. Informal conversations on the subject were begun in Angora during the recent visit of S. O. Waley of the British Treasury and F. H. Nixon of the Export Credits Guarantee Department of the Board of Trade.

The financial community was not particularly surprised or alarmed with the essential features of the President's annual budget message, having been forewarned by recent developments of the trend of government finances.
Miss Vera Van Arsdale, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Van Arsdale of Castile, N. Y., will be married next month to Frederick C. Eaton Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Eaton of Warren, Pa.

In what may prove to be his last annual message to the Legislature, Governor Lehman, reading it in person at a joint session of the Senate and Assembly today, pleaded for governmental policies which would promote closer cooperation between business, labor, the farmer and the consumer.

Faced with the opportunity of rising to a tie for first place in the International Group of the National Hockey League, the New York Americans will oppose the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden tonight. If the Americans win and the Toronto Maple Leafs lose to the Montreal Maroons the local six will deadlock the pace-setting Toronto six.

T. Walter Williams of THE NEW YORK TIMES, only active charter member of the Ship News Reporters Association of New York, was elected president of the association yesterday for a year. He has served thirty-three years as a ship news reporter and this is the fourth time in that period that he has been elected president.

City Physician Ernest A. Casino of Garfield and Fred Larosa, an insurance salesman, were sentenced today to thirty days in the Bergen County jail by Judge A. Demorest Del Mar. They had pleaded guilty to defrauding an insurance companv by faking death certificates.

The Press Photographers Association of New York will open its annual exhibition on the seventh floor of La Maison Frangaise, Rockefeller Center, next Monday. There will be 335 picked photographs in the show, representing the work of fifty-three photographers.

District consuls and officers of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Banking will hold a dinner and meeting tonight in the George Washington Hotel here to discuss plans for the Spring semester of the school. Quentin W. Schwer, chief consul and chairman of membership, will preside.

Wide and conflicting price swings characterized trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Speculative interest again centered in the railroad section, where a modest though broad recover movement ruled the greater part of the day, only to give way to another sharp plunge in values in lat dealings under the leadership of Baltimore Ohio.

The apparel trades were well represented in the lists of commercial rentals submitted yesterday. Considerable activity was reported in the millinery district of the midtown section, and a number of leases for full floors continue to feature the reports.

Tiny Peterson of the Winged Foot team scored the only fall in the dual wrestling meet which the New York A. C. won from Columbia, 20-6, at the N. Y. A. C. last night. Peterson, who holds the national 115-pound championship, threw Ed Obermann in 3:06 with a 5, cradle hold in the 118-pound class. All other matches went to decisions.

The year 1937 saw "the greatest advance in the long experience of humanity's campaign against the menace of cancer," according to a statement made public last night by the American Society for the Control of Cancer at a special dinner meeting of the society and the press at the Harvard Club.

Retail Deliveries Up 9% Retail deliveries showed an increase of 9 per cent for the week ended Jan. 1, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. For the four weeks ended on that date there was a gain of 0.5 per cent over the same period a year ago.

George C. Lucas, executive secretary of the National Publishers Association, told a House subcommittee today that passage of the Patman Bill which contains provisions to prevent manufacturers from selling their products at retail in the localities where retail dealers sold the same products if competition would be lessened thereby,

At almost the eleventh hour the Nazi government refused to allow Leo Blech to go to Prague to conduct a gala performance of "Carmen" at the German Theatre, which is celebrating its fiftieth anniversary. Herr Blech also was not permitted to go to Sweden, where he has been a favorite for years.

Thirty-sixth annual show of the Atlantic Cat Club for the benefit of the Bide-a-Wee Home, Hotel Taft, 10 A. M. to 10 P. M. Continues tomorrow. Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Hogarth's Engravings of Modern Morals," Roberta M. Fansler, 11 A. M.; Egyptian collection (general tour), 2 P. M.
The man who led the movement which resulted in removal of the bodies of 44,000 United States soldiers killed in the World War from Europe to graves in their homeland is dead.

Dr. Emil Heuser has been named research associate and instructor in cellulose chemistry at the Institute of Paper Chemistry, Appleton, Wis., it was announced yesterday. Because of rapidly increasing production facilities for paper, the development of other uses than paper-making for pulps has become more important, the announcement said, adding that advances in this direction have been made in the field of cellulose chemistry.

An accounting of the Treasury's activities in the fiscal year ended June 30, 1937, when, with business conditions improving, receipts rose to $5,294,000,000, or $1,178,000,000 more than in the previous year, was given today by Secretary Morgenthau in his annual report to Congress.

" In view of the rather general agreement that the current recession is now scraping bottom," it appears probable that the expansion in lithographic sales will shortly be resumed, The Lithographers National Association, Inc., stated yesterday in a review of. the year just closed.

The Labor party group of five freshman Assemblymen hailed Governor Lehman's message as liberal and progressive, but held that. it "did not go far enough" in recommendations concerning the unemployment fund and consumer protection.

THERE was a gathering of fistic folk at Dempsey's hostelry yesterday and when Al "Weskit" Weill, the Garden matchmaker, casually mentioned the approaching Steele-Apostoli bout it provided an opening for a little heckling on the question of over-the-weight matches in general and this one in particular.

W. W. Larsen, whose career began in a log cabin and included eight terms as a national Representative, died today. He was 65 years old. At his death he was director of the State Unemployment Compensation Division of the Department of Labor.

Miss Susan Stewart Miles of New York and Philadelphia, who died here on Dec. 12, named seven religious, charitable and public institutions as legatees in her will, filed for probate here yesterday. They will receive $81,000 in specific bequests.

Celebration of President Roosevelt's birthday week in the capital for the benefit of the new National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis will be inaugurated with a benefit performance of "Between the Devil" on Sunday night, Jan. 23, at the National Theatre.

Luis Quintanilla, one of Spain's foremost artists, left Barcelona for New York today with a hundred war drawings he will exhibit at the Pierre Matisse Galleries in February. Senor Quintanilla, who has previously exhibited in America, is one of Loyalist Spain's war heroes.

The new night homicide bureau established by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey to tighten cooperation between the police and the prosecutor functioned swiftly yesterday in recording evidence against a man arrested on a charge of homicide.

The Federal Alcohol Administration today asked Congress, in its annual report, to pass legislation including brewers in the basic permit system along with distillers. The report, submitted by W. S. Alexander, administrator, urged increased
Mrs. Mary Stedman Brown, sister of Captain Giles C. Stedman, hero of mid-Atlantic rescues and holder of the United States Navy cross for heroism, died today after giving birth to a son.

While still seeking a commissioner for the new Department of Public Works, Mayor La Guardia yesterday transplanted David A. Thompson from the Department of Sanitation to the new department, with orders to modernize the office methods inherited from the old Department of Plant and Structures and to introduce uniform practices.

Mr. and Mrs. David H. McAlpin Pyle gave a dinner last night at the American Museum of Natural History in the interest of the institution's ten year development program. Later in the evening motion pictures of Pitcairn Island and its inhabitants taken by Dr. Harry L. Shapiro, associate curator of physical anthropology, were shown.

Robert Rainey Wait of Hudson, manager of the Hudson branch office of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, died at Vassar Hospital here yesterday of a streptococcus infection. His age, was 45. Mr. Wait, a native of Kinderhook, was a member of Hudson American Legion Post, Columbia County Veterans of Foreign Wars, Peekskill Lodge of Elks and the New York Conservation Association.

Seven persons were injured slightly yesterday when fire spread from a fifty-gallon oil tank and swept the first floor of a two-story brick structure used as a factory by the Universal Switchboard Corporation at 50 North Eleventh Street, Brooklyn.

Sharpshooting by Sol Miehoff and Charley Prosser enabled Penn State to defeat Pennsylvania in the opening game at the Palestra tonight, 40 to 28. It was only the fifth victory in the series for the Nittany Lions over the Red and Blue.

Part of a $10,000,000 freight equipment buying program was announced today by the Canadian Pacific Railway. Tenders have been called, officials said, for 2,000 forty-ton steel sheathed box cars, 200 twin-hopper cars of 100,000 pounds capacity, 200 eight-inch steel underframe cars, 200 flat cars and 100 low-side dropend gondola cars.

Warning that unemployment insurance was not a panacea for solving the unemployment relief problem, Arthur J. Altmeyer, chairman of the Socia Security Board, told Senator Byrnes's committee on relief and unemployment today that, even if there were some increase in jobless ness during 1938, the unemployment trust funds of the various States would be adequate to cover all withdrawals.

Two sculpture shows, widely dissimilar, are among the offerings of the present week. At the Comet Gallery, 10 East Fifty-second Street, which came into existence only a short time since, will be found a comprehensive exhibition of work by the Italian Mirco.

Apawamis successfully defended its women's metropolitan Class B interclub squash racquets team championship by defeating the Rockaway Hunting Club by four matches to one in the final on the courts of the Cosmopolitan Club yesterday.

Irving J. Piken has been appointed assistant vice president of the Trust Company of North America. Thomas M. Lynch and Harry A. Grove have formed T. M. Lynch Co., municipal bond brokers, at 52 William St. Edward J. Keresey has formed the Keresey Company to deal in State and municipal bonds at 40 Wall Street.

Amid loud cackling and crowing the grand champions of the annual New York Poultry Show were judged last night in the 244th Coast Artillery Armory, 125 West Fourteenth Street. Showing a prizewinning diminutive Modern Black Red Game Bantam pullet and a hen of the same breed, William W. Hepburn of Pennington, N. J., proved to be the champion exhibitor.

The Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company in a statement to stockholders yesterday reported net earnings from operation in 1937, after providing for expenses, taxes and losses, of $2,363,883. This compared with $2,604,617 reported for 1936.

Funeral services for Joseph Scheer, night borough superintendent in Queens for the Department of Sanitation, who died Sunday at the age of 53, were conducted last night at his home, 62-86 Forest Avenue, Ridgewood, Queens, by the Rev. Thaddeus Tinsley, pastor of the Ridgewood Christian Church.

Miss Mary Watkinson Cole, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward S. Cole of this place, has chosen Feb. 12 for her wedding to William Edward Jordan, son of Dr. and Mrs. Louis E. Jordan of Fairlawn, Cobourg, Ont. The Rev. George C. Vincent will perform the ceremony in the Union Congregational Church here and a small reception at the Cole home will follow.

Traffic on the New Lots Avenue branch of the I. R. T. subway in Brooklyn was tied up for forty minutes yesterday when an unidentified man fell or jumped to his death under an eastbound train at the Junius Street station, Junius Street and Livonia Avenue.

Several public utility companies situated in various parts of the United States issued statements yesterday covering their operations for the twelve months through last November. They showed, for the most part, large gains in gross revenues compared with the preceding twelve months and sizable increases in net income.

A passport photograph of Ruth Marie Rubens of New York was identified today as that of the mysterious "Mrs. Donald L. Robinson" whose disappearance in Moscow last month created an international sensation.

In the Supreme Court of the United States today, Frank Feigenbaum and Samuel B. Burk of New. York were admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had: 163 - Thomas J. Brady, petr., v. Terminal Railroad Association of St. Louis. Argued for both.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A Flanagan of Belle Harbor, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Agnes Flanagan, to Henry Gordon Semple, son of Mrs. John J. Semple of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Semple.

Mrs. Lillian Connally of Atlanta, Ga., said today that her daughter, Miss Anne Connally, was married to Thomas Patton Cheesborough Jr. of Asheville on Monday in Columbia, S. C. Mr. Cheesborough, a native of Asheville, is in the advertising business.

With the problem of promoting housing and small homes again to the fore in Congress, and with new surveys tending to emphasize the continued lack of adequate shelter which the man of modest income can afford, the new year has started with wider discussion than ever before of methods of meeting this need.

Survivors of five days of homicide and terror abroad the yacht Aafje told their stories to a Federal grand jury today. The jury was considering whether to return murder indictments against Robert Horne, 27 years old, and George Spernak, 17, members of the original cruise party of eight.

Banned from competition with Broadway, the theatre presentations at the World's Fair will be imaginative super stage productions, John Golden, theatrical producer and chairman of the advisory board of entertainment for the fair, announced yesterday.

Showing steady improvement in circuit competition, the Bronx Tigers will face off tonight against the Atlantic City Sea Gulls in the first of two Eastern Amateur Hockey League games scheduled within two days for the Tigers. Tonight's contest at the New York Coliseum will start at 8:30 o'clock.

Premier Hepburn announced tonight that he would immediately arrange a conference with the Quebec Government to consider the "serious newsprint situation" with which Ontario and Quebec are confronted as a direct result, he said, of business recession in the United States.

The drive by the city administration to force down the retail price of milk and at the same time to stabilize the milk industry in the city continued yesterday as William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Markets Commissioner, pressed storekeepers for a 9-cent price and the retailers declared that many could not sell at 10 cents and there was little prospect of a 9-cent price.

An "Austrian Evening" was held at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Reynolds, 120 East End Avenue, last night, in honor of Mrs. Ira Nelson Morris, author and wife of the former Minister to Sweden. A feature of the evening was living book reviews, with Drake de Kay as commentator.

Long Island University was a -bit too smooth for the lads from Texas last night as the Blackbirds vanquished Southern Methodist, the Southwest Conference champion, 40 to 29, in the feature attraction at -Madison Square Garden before a gathering of 10,000.

Mrs. Ella Reeve Bloor, 75 years old, was honored yesterday by the women's commission of the Communist party at a luncheon at 132 West Thirty-fourth Street. Mrs. Bloor, better known as Mother Bloor, has just returned from Russia. She said that the only way to fight fascism was to "build a democracy" and she hailed the "democratic success" of the Soviet Union.

Realistic religion, with the laity as well as the clergy participating in "works of mercy" among 'the victims of industrial and political oppression, was suggested yesterday at a conference of three faiths at the Hotel McAlpin as a means of forestalling communism and preserving democracy.

Merle J. Trees, vice president of the Chicago Bridge and Iron Company, and Mrs. Trees have presented to the University of Illinois a collection of oil paintings, some done in the sixteenth century, valued at $150,000.

The democratic countries' propagandistic counteroffensive manifested in the worldwide broadcast in seven languages of President Roosevelt's message to Congress and the British radio system's news broadcasts in foreign languages has caused considerable

Secretary Morgenthau hinted today that he might ask-Congress to change the budget laws in an effort to make revenue forecasting more accurate. He explained in his annual report that present laws required the Treasury to guess business conditions more than a year and a half in advance.

Electric power production declined more than seasonally last week. The adjusted index has eased to 93.4 from 96.9, the revised figure for the previous week. For the week ended Jan. 2, 1936, the index stood at 103.1.

The marriage of Miss Jane Kessler, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George L. Kessler of 1,119 Bergen Street, Brooklyn, to Ira Kendall Hearn Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ira K. Hearn of Norfolk, Va., took place yesterday afternoon in the Bedford Presbyterian Church, Brooklyn. The Rev. George W. Arms performed the ceremony.

A deal in the Greenwich Village section was announced by Samuel K. Beier, attorney, who represented an investor in the purchase from the 373 Bleecker Street Corporation of the two five-story apartment houses at 371-373 Bleecker Street. The buildings were modernized recently and were sold subject

Walter S. Mack Jr., president of the Phoenix Securities Corporation, in commenting yesterday on the opposition of Distributors Group, Inc., to the proposed purchase by the Celotex Corporation from Phoenix of the latter's holdings of Certain-Teed Products Corporation, said that there would not be and there never had been any attempt to force such a purchase through.

Trial of an action brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission to restrain Torr Co., brokers; Ellery W. Mann and others from violating the Securities Act of 1933 and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 was begun yesterday before Federal Judge John M. Woolsey.

" Number-taking" was the chief activity of buyers in the wholesale market here yesterday to attend the Spring dress and sports wear openings. Attendance was reported as well under last year's, with showroom sales revealing an even greater decline.

The budget submitted yesterday by Mr. Roosevelt fills in the details of a financial picture which had already been sketched in broad outline by the President in his message to Congress on Monday. It confirms the fact that another deficit (the ninth in a row) is now anticipated by the Treasury for the new fiscal year which begins next July.

The Regional Plan Association announced yesterday that it was completing for early publication a study embodying new population estimates for the New York region, "looking ahead of 1940, 1950 and 1960."
John K. Northrop, vice president of the Douglas Aircraft Corporation and general manager of the military airplane factory bearing his name, resigned both positions today.
