Charges that the sections of the Guffey Coal Act designed to protect the interests of consumers "have finally been nullified" through refusal of the Bituminous Coal Commission to supply John Carson, Federal consumers' counsel in Washington, with the statistical data used to set the new minimum coal prices, made effective Dec. 16 last, were made here yesterday by Helen Hall, chairman of the Consumers National Federation.

Summit Ave, 916: 2-story frame dwelling, irreg.; Carrie Alexander against Alexander Forrest; due, $14,221; taxes, etc., $430; to plaintiff for $1,000. By B. HOLLANDER SON 226th St, 750-2 E; 50x114; Herbert E. Jefferson, execr., against Edythe Dempewolfe Romeo; due, $9,823; taxes, etc., $1,061; to plaintiff for $500.

With 267,000 applications for unemployment insurance benefits filed throughout the State, officials of the division of placement and unemployment insurance of the State Labor Department took stock yesterday of some of the more common errors made by applicants.

Mrs. Edith G. Van Alst, who had been a member of the Republican County Committee of Queens from the time women received suffrage, died on Tuesday at her home. 30-05 Thirty-first Avenue, Astoria, Queens, at the age of 59.

William J. Harahan, late president of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway, left an estate valued at $321,004.69, all in personal property, probate of the will showed today. The will bequeathed all tangible personal property to Mrs. Elizabeth M. Harahan of New York, the widow, except a ring given to Mr. Harahan's father

After four straight favorites had covered themselves with dust rather than glory, C. S. Bromley's 6-year-old Headin Home rewarded the talent with an easy victory in the featured Bird Road Purse today at Tropical Park. Coupled with S. Levine's Light, Headin Home whirled one mile in 1:38,
The Neediest Cases Fund received $629.55 yesterday from sixtyone contributors, bringing the total amount received in the twenty-sixth annual appeal to $297,200.52.

The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation issued a call today to insured banks not belonging to the Federal Reserve System for reports of their condition as of the close of business on Friday, Dec. 31, 1937.

The National Government, whose leaders have recently been stoutly asserting that there is no slump in British industry, received a rebuff tonight when the Ministry of Labor announced that unemployment had risen by 166,204 in the four weeks ended Dec. 13.
Miss Ethel Vondersmith Combs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Hamm Combs of South Orange, was married this evening to John Ferguson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Webster Ferguson of Montclair.

Represented in twenty branches of intercollegiate sport, Princeton University's athletic fortunes over the course of the calendar year 1937 reached their lowest point of the past five years with an undistinguishd winning percentage of .520, according to figures released today by the University Athletic Association.
The stock market here' was generally active today and improvements were registered in all sections. Gilt-edge issues were in demand. Among the foreign bonds, Far Eastern issues were easier.

Justice John F. Carew of the Supreme Court of the State of New York and Mrs. Carew of this city and Rockville Center, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Blanche Boorum Carew, to John Kenneth Glade, son of the late Mrs. Anna Boyle Glade and the late Herman H. Glade.

Mervin S. Hart, New York investment broker, has been missing from his home in this city since Christmas Eve, police said today. His family consulted the police a week ago and sought assistance in finding him, according to Lieutenant Edward Hughes.

William Kosky of the Long Island Railroad Y. M. C. A. knocked out Salvatore Olivia, unattached, in the final of the- 112-pound Queens County championship at the Ridgewood Grove last night as the annual Kings and Queens Counties A. A. U. boxing tournament got under way. He floored Olivia for the count in 1:39 of the first round with a hard right hook to the jaw.

William C. Bullitt today denied he had been summoned to Washington or would resign as Ambassador to France. Reports have been circulating that the position of Under-Secretary of State had been offered to him.

Captain Franco Ferrari, navigation officer of the Italian liner Rex, sailed on that ship yesterday as passenger, accompanied by his bride, the former Miss Celia Nardone of Westerly, R. I. Officials of the line said the couple met a year ago when Miss Nardone was a passenger on the Rex returning to the United States after studying art in Italy.

Harry H. B. Hurd, for many years manager of the Hotel Taft, died here yesterday at his residence after a long illness at the age of 68. He was born in Oxford, Conn., and was formerly a brick manufacturer and a lumber dealer.
The New York' Rovers defeated the Hershey Bears, 6 to 2, tonight and took undisputed possession of first plabe in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League.

An "orgy of looting, raping and killing" followed the occupation of Hangchow, the Chekiang provincial capital, on Dec. 24, according to a Canadian insurance surveyor who returned to Shanghai yesterday.

The formal presentation and acceptance of a pipe organ, the gift of Dave Hennen Morris, former American Ambassador to Belgium, to City College, will take place today in the Pauline Edwards Theatre of the City College School of Business, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue.

The year 1937 saw a turn from "promises and aspirations" to "definite achievements" in social security in this State, Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the Social Security Board, said yesterday in her annual report.
President Roosevelt sent to Congress his annual budget message and discussed naval expansion plans with officials of the Navy Department and Chairmen of Senate and House Appropriations Committees.

Arturo Toscanini will conduct the NBC Symphony Orchestra in the Beethoven First and Ninth symphonies at the benefit concert to be given in Carnegie Hall Sunday evening, Feb. 6, the National Broadcasting Company announced yesterday. The proceeds will be directed to the Italian Welfare League, Inc.

After displaying moderate strength in the forenoon, the stock market weakened yesterday and closed irregular. The turnover on the Stock Exchange was 1,150,000 shares, compared with 942,000 on Tuesday.

Crown Prince Michael of Rumania, en route to Athens on the destroyer Queen Marie, encountered heavy seas and a blizzard that forced the ship to enter a safe anchorage. [The 16-year-old Crown Prince was transferred safely to the Rumanian steamer Dacia, The Associated Press reported.]

A. memorial service for the Rev. Dr. John McDowell was held yesterday afternoon in the assembly hall of the Presbyterian Building, 156 Fifth Avenue, under the auspices of the Presbyterian Board of National Missions, of which Dr. McDowell, who died Nov. 13, was for many years a secretary.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Jan. 5 unless specified: At Naval Operating Base, Norfolk, Va.: Umpqua, Jan. 6; Fairfax. At San Pedro: Grebe, Neches, New Orleans, Robin. At Mare Island Yard: Narwhal, Sandpiper. Astoria, San Francisco to Puget Sound Yard.

While store executives showed considerable interest in the upturn in the stock market yesterday as a possible forerunner of improving local business, consumer response thus far to January sales events has been only "fair," reports yesterday indicated.

In consonance with a renewal of strength in the outside markets and the absence of any pressure of actual staple, prices on the Cotton Exchange here rose into new high ground again yesterday and ended with gains of 8 to 10 points.

The time lost in defending the PWA power cases, in which the government was upheld this week by the Supreme Court, was deplored today by Secretary Ickes, who cited the fortytwo injunctions filed against the Administration's sixty-one power projects as an instance of the high cost in time and money of legalistic efforts to avoid compliance with the nation's laws.

With his eight months' economic inquiry virtually completed, former Belgian Premier Paul van Zeeland arrived in London tonight to discuss the final details of his report with Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain and Sir Frederick Leith-Ross, economic adviser to the British Government.

A The set strike of cane-cutters on an estate the fact at the east end of the island owned was tall by the Hon. R. Ehrenstein, member for St. Thomas, assumed a serious aspect yesterday when 1,400 canecutters in a hostile demonstration forced the owner to leave the district under armed police protection.

Surrogate James A. Delehanty upheld the validity of the 'six charitable trusts established in the will of Edward West Browning, real estate operator, and at the same time ruled that his adopted daughter, Mrs. Dorothy (Sunshine) Browning Hood of Dunn, N. C., was to receive $25,000 a year until a trust was established..

The capital today cheered the Princess Frederika Luise of Brunswick and her fiance, Crown Prince Paul, when they arrived here this afternoon. The Crown Prince had gone to the border to meet the Princess.

Australia will play in the Davis Cup tennis competition this year and will challenge in the North American zone, it was decided today. In exhibition matches Gene Mako of the United States, who is touring Australia with his doubles partner, Don Budge, leading tennis amateur of the world,

More than 15,000 men and women crowded the huge Jersey City armory tonight in a monster rally which roared its approval of Mayor Frank Hague's stern methods in stopping what he called the "Communist invasion" of the city by the C. I. O. recently.

The 1938 renewal of the world's most famous steeplechase, the Grand National, drew seventy-nine nominations today, including seven Americanowned jumpers. Provided all face the starter at Aintree on March 25, the American standard bearers will be Mrs. Marion Scott's Battleship,

Declaring that he personally had negotiated the terms of the Celotex Corporation's proposed acquisition of a large stock interest in the Certain-teed Products Corporation from the Phoenix Securities Corporation, Bror Dahlberg, president of Celotex, charged yesterday that the bankercritics of the deal were judging

Otis A. Glazebrook Jr. of G. M.-P. Murphy Co. has been elected to succeed the late Grayson M.-P. Murphy as a member and chairman of the Bondholders Protective Committee for Seaboard Air Line Railway Company first and consolidated mortgage 6 per cent bonds.

To the accompaniment of increased trading, the stock market moved steadily higher yesterday and closed strong. Final quotations on many leading issues were at the best levels of the day, and the net gains in many instances ranged from 1 to 6 points.
Colonel and Mrs. Louis Jacques Balsan gave a dinner tonight at their residence for their house guests, the Marquis de Talleyrand and the Viscount Sosthenes de la Rochefoucauld of Paris.

President and Mrs. Roosevelt entertained at dinner tonight in honor of the Vice President and Mrs. Garner. Mrs. Woodrow Wilson, Senator and Mrs. Charles L. McNary, Senator Pat Harrison, Senator and Mrs. Robert M. La Follette Jr. and Senators Alben W. Barkley and Robert F. Wagner headed a list of eighty guests.

The Irish Repertory Players will offer as their next production a revival of G. B. Shaw's "Candida" on Jan. 16 at the Master Institute Theatre, 310 Riverside Drive. Other performances will be scheduled later.

Declaring at the outset that labor troubles in France had broken out again with an intensity that "is dangerous for the prosperity and security of the country," Premier Camille Chautemps issued an appeal today to workers and employers to obey the law.

In an effort to clear up the chaotic situation in which many of the country's great railway systems find themselves, to maintain as solvent roads now on the brink of bankruptcy and to end receiverships involving thousands of miles of trackage, President Roosevelt has asked Joseph B. Eastman of the Interstate Commerce Commission to draft legislation for early presentation to Congress.

The Commissioners of the Port of New York Authority re-elected Frank C. Ferguson of East Orange, N. J., as chairman at the annual meeting yesterday afternoon at the Commerce Building, 111 Eighth Avenue.

The highest extracurricular prize given by the student council of Hunter College for outstanding service in one field of student activity, good service in another field, and continuous service all through college, has been awarded to three seniors.

The new tax bill which is being written by a Ways and Means Subcommittee approached completion in rough draft today with the writing of a section which defines in detail the status for tax-paying purposes of personal corporations. It gives them virtually no relief such as has been promised to other types of corporations.

After three hours of balloting along the somewhat involved lines of proportional representation, ten additional members were added to the executive committee of the American Olympic Committee at the New York Athletic Club last night.

A defense of big business as the agency that has given America the automobile, the telephone and electric power at the world's lowest costs and an appeal for intelligent discussion of the future by government officials and industrial leaders without "catchwords and the nonsense about the sixty ruling families" were made last night by Wendell L. Willkie, president of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, broadcast from Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street.

A small dog of unknown ancestry owes its life to the courage of 57year-old Thomas Kelly of 348 Willis Avenue, the Bronx. Yesterday| morning, when Kelly showed up on his WPA job at the warehouse at the end of East 222d Street, the Bronx, which dead-ends at Eastchester Bay, he noticed the dog marooned on a small island some ten yards offshore.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Althea Crow, daughter of Mrs. Ralph L. Crow of this place and the late Mr. Crow, to Robert F. Reybine, son of Mrs. Alpheus Reybine of New Rochelle and the late Mr. Reybine.

John Hughes Curtis, Norfolk (Va.) ship builder, who fooled Colonel Lindbergh, the Coast Guard and the United States Navy with his false story of having communicated with the kidnappers of the Lindbergh baby, lost his appeal for a pardon today.

In a rough battle of goals and fists the Maroons snapped their five-game losing streak tonight by upsetting the high-scoring Toronto Maple Leafs, 6 to 3. The National Hockey League game was watched by 6,000 fans.

Butter is 8 cents a pound cheaper than it was three weeks ago. It is now selling in most chain stores and independent markets throughout the city for 39 cents a pound, the comparative price list of the City's Consumers' Food Guide showed yesterday.

Continuing today its investigation of the Pennroad Corporation, the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce, which contends that control of Pennroad is exercised by the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, charged that in December, 1929, Pennroad had "window dressed" the Integrity Trust Company of Philadelphia.

Declaring that for each 1 per cent of decline in prices most companies must achieve 2 to 3 per cent more volume if they are not to increase their losses, Dr. Charles Reitell, management engineer, told the Rotary Club of New York yesterday that misunderstanding of this point has been the greatest cause of business difficulty.
The marriage of Mrs. Lynda Hansen Gellatly of Pittsburgh, widow of William Robert Gellatly and daughter of Mrs. John Morrison Hansen of Pittsburgh and the late Mr. Hansen, to Kenneth Taylor Philips,

Prominent Iowans and others announced tonight the formation of "The Economic Policy Committee," designed to align public opinion with Secretary Hull's foreign trade policies. The committee of forty-eight members includes liberals and conservatives and representatives

Steel output in the United States last month was 1,472,241 tons, the smallest total since September, 1934, but production during 1937 was 49,507,766 tons, according to preliminary data of the American Iron and Steel Institute.

Gaining a commanding lead in the first half. Wesleyan's unbeaten basketball team administered a 50-to29 defeat to Yale in Fayerweather Gymnasium tonight. Yale took the lead on a basket by Gallagher, but the sharp shooting of Morningstar and Phelps gradually built a substantial advantage

In a magnificent exhibition, Jack Summers, 44-year-old M. I. T. coach, yesterday defeated Tom Iannicelli, world open squash tennis champion, in a five-game semi-final of the first open invitation tournament sponsored by the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association.
Agents for the Duke of Windsor were reported today to be negotiating for a lease on the pretentious fifty-acre estate of the millionaire inventor, Leon Douglass, near Menlo Park.

The cast of "Between the Devil," which gives one performance in Washington on Jan. 23 for the benefit of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, will donate their services, it was learned yesterday. This being so,

The brilliant concert given by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Serge Koussevitzky conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall was distinguished by the presence and the first public appearance in this city of the Helsinki University Chorus of Finland, which took part in the performances of unknown or unfamiliar works of Sibelius.

Creation of a merchant marine mediation board to settle "serious labor troubles" was urged yesterday by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York in a resolution adopted at its first meeting of the year. The resolution said that the chamber was "deeply concerned with the menace to safety at sea

Additional features of the fiftysixth annual benefit of the Actors Fund on Jan. 23 were announced yesterday by Daniel Frohman as "Rehearse Me Ever," a skit with Alexander Kirkland, Francesca Bruning, Norma Terris, Frank Conroy and Vaughan Glaser, and the "quarrel scene" from "Julius Caesar," with Orson Welles and Martin Gabel.

A parcel consisting of two stores and a brick warehouse in the rear, known as 870 Bergenline Avenue, in the shopping center of Union City, N. J., has been sold by the Hudson Trust Company to J. Israel Co. who for thirty years have operated a painters' supplies business in Guttenberg. The buyer will use the property for business purposes.

The Navy Department contracted today to buy 2,245,000 pounds of copper for $236,829. A $120,804 contract was awarded to the International Minerals and Metals Corporation, New York, for 1,175,000 pounds to be delivered at six navy yards, at prices ranging from 10.17 to 10.64 cents a pound.

The first session of the auction of the art collection of the late V. Everit Macy brought $15,000 yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc. The day's highest price was $1,700, paid by R. M. Chait for a Chun Yao tripod bowl.

The Teruel battle is still being fought in temperature that dropped 4 degrees below zero Fahrenheit last midnight and rose only to 3 degrees above at noon today. Government artillery, placed on Mansueto Heights, two kilometers [about a mile and a quarter] south of Teruel, continued its intensive bombardment, making Teruel a virtual no-man's land.

Federal Judge Mr. Douglas William H. Holly approved today an arrangement under which the supervision of operating and management activities of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation will be turned over to the newly formed Central Service Corporation for an annual fee of $405,215.

All prospects for an early peace between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization appeared shattered last night, despite the position taken by President Roosevelt that continuance of the civil war between the two labor camps was detrimental to the interests of the country, and the assertion to the same effect by the National Labor Relations Board in its report to Congress.

More than 500,000 individual and corporation income tax returns were mailed yesterday to tax-payers by Manhattan's two internal revenue collectors. Although the deadline for payment is March 15, the public was urged to make early payments not only to benefit the government but as a precaution against penalties imposed for late payments.
Salvatore Ossido was put to death in the electric chair at Sing Sing prison tonight for the murder, after criminal assault, of Einer Sporrer,
Gifts in the sum of $402.50 came to the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday from forty-six contributors and increased the total that has been received in the twenty-sixth annual appeal to $297,603.02.

Johnson Ave (13-3416), a e cor of 238th St, 135x93; 3656 Johnson Ave. Inc. to Benab Realty Corp, 153 Center St; mtge, $220,000. Whitlock Ave (10-2741), n e cor of Hunts Point Ave, 150x160 ft: 1000 Whitlock Ave Realty Co, Inc, to Whitpoint Realty Co, Inc. 171 Madison Ave. Decatur Ave (12-3355), e s, 105 ft s of Gun Hill Rd, 50x100; Parak Realty, Inc, to 1938 Realties. Inc. 1,475 B'way.

The first and possibly the largest single appropriation measure to come before Congress was taken up by the House today when it began consideration of the Independent Offices Supply Bill carrying requests for $1,414,818,515 for the expenses of thirty-seven independent establishments during the coming fiscal year.
Crown Prince Michael. returned to Constanta at 10 o'clock this morning on the destroyer .Queen. Marie after the vessel had bucked heavy seas in a snow storm for thirty-six hours in the Black Sea.

Fourteen hospitals will cooperate with the Department of Health in giving courses to physicians in the newest developments in the treatment of pneumonia, according to Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health.

Mrs. Robert R. Livingston entertained with a dinner last night at her home, 1,192 Park Avenue. Among her guests were Mrs. James Roosevelt, Mrs. Charles E. Tracy, Mrs. John Janeway, Miss Alice Weekes, Mrs. George Miller, Mrs.

Reports of business done in last month and year with comparisons with 1936. F. W. Woolworth Sales of the F. W. Woolworth Company for December and 1937 established new monthly and yearly records. The volume last month totaled $47,181,651, an increase of 3.7 per cent over sales of $45,505,958 in December, 1936.
Intensification of the rivalry between the A. F. of L. and the C. I. O. among employes of the Department of Welfare was indicated yesterday as both groups completed plans for membership rallies.

Fear that Jan. 15 may bring a payless payday for 146,000 city employes increased among city officials yesterday as it became apparent that the thirteen Democrats in the City Council were determined not to vote for Mayor La Guardia's new city budget of $589,152,051.

President Roosevelt's new budget ness earmarks a billion dollars as a tenta- will, tive figure for Federal relief of unemployment during the next fiscal year. The President would have this billion spent as other recent billions have been spent: that is,

William E. Dodd retiring United States Ambassador to Germany, who resigned his post two weeks ago after four and a half years of service, declared on his return last night that he doubted if any American envoy who held his ideals of democracy could represent his country successfully among the Germans at the present time.

A plan for combining architeatural harmony with historical interest in the exhibits of the various States and territories at the 1939 World's Fair was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation. It calls for grouping these exhibits according to the three principal cultural influences existing on this continent at the time of George Washington's inauguration as President.

The National Labor Relations Board carried the Ford Motor Company test case of the Wagner act to the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals at Covington, Ky., today, asking that court for an order to enforce its decision against the company.

Hall Paxton, second secretary of the United States Embassy at Nanking and a survivor of the gunboat Panay, arrived here by airplane today to give State Department officials his report of the incident in the Yangtze River. He divided his day between the State Department and the naval hospital, where he took treatment for the shrapnel wounds he suffered.

Jules Barmat, financier extradited from Amsterdam in connection with Belgium's National Bank inquiry into bank practices, died in prison in suburban Brussels today, the Ministry of Justice announced. M. Barmat had been in jail since Dec. 30.

In a surprise speech at the induction ceremonies of the first nonDemocrat ever to occupy -the .Municipal Court bench in the Bronx, Mayor La Guardia yesterday advocated sweeping reforms in the administration of justice in the city's l civil and criminal courts.
Colorful ceremonies of the thirty-fifth "Greek Cross Day" marked the Feast of the Epiphany, symbolizing the baptism of Christ, in this center of the sponge fishing industry today.
Plans for a three-story office, store and showroom building at 412 Fifth Avenue were included in projects submitted yesterday by architects. The cost of the proposed structure was put at $250,000.

By drawing his adjourned game with Isaac I. Kashdan, champion of the Manhattan Chess Club, in 60 moves, Dr. J. Platz tied for first place at 4-2 with S. S. Cohen. dev Kashdan, with 31/2 points out of 4, moved up into third place, with Robert Willman fourth and Arnold S. Denker fifth.
The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today a loan of $8,223,000 by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the Baltimore Ohio Railroad. The funds will be used by the railroad as follows:

Secretary Morgenthau announced this afternoon another offering of ninety-one-day bills in the Treasury's current series, tenders to be received by Federal Reserve Banks or their branches up to 2 P. M., Eastern standard time, on Monday. He declined to discuss financing plans other than to announce the bill offering.

Two leaders in San Francisco's political life-Charles W. Fay and Thomas F. Finn-died today of heart attacks within a few hours of each other, just as funeral services were being conducted for Harry L. Todd, postmaster here under the Coolidge and Hoover Administrations.

A stronger tone in domestic hides has developed this week and has been reflected chiefly in calfskins, on which asking prices have advanced 2 cents since a week ago. Argentine hides also are higher by about 3/4 cent from the last trading basis.
Miss Natalie O. Watts, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Everett Watts, and Morgan Hatton Grace Jr. have completed plans for their marriage, which takes place on Wednesday in St. Bartholomew's Church.

President Roosevelt's naval building plans are explained by the newspaper Kokumin as due to the need to provide domestic employment rather than to international circumstances. The Kokumin asks the intelligent people of the United States to reconsider their policy since it embarrasses Japan to be used as

Chinese circles declared yesterday that Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek had forbidden Governor Han Fu-chu and other Shantung leaders to retreat without further orders, that as a result the Chinese armies in the province had begun advancing northward in an attempt to oust the Japanese from Yenchow, south of Tsinan,

Joseph Auslander, who recently was named to the "chair of poetry" of the Congressional Library, said yesterday that "poets are always turning chaos into cosmos" and that they "need to be wary of formula."

Mr. Roosevelt's reply to Justice Sutherland's letter declaring his intention of retirement is, like his letter to Justice Van Devanter on a similar occasion, pleasant reading. It may be said that retirements so congenial to future rulings of the Supreme Court on his policies put him in good humor, but such is his natural and normal humor.

The earnings. of the twelve Federal Reserve Banks in 1937 were sufficient, after expenses, payment of dividends and other charges, to permit the transfer to surplus of $1,885,000, it was shown in the weekly report of the Reserve System, issued yesterday, which gave effect to a number of year-end adjustments.

J. Burke Wilkinson of the Harvard Club, who was runner-up in the event a year ago, moved into the quarter-final round of the fourth annual Class B invitation squash racquets tournament at the Union League Club yesterday.

Dr. Mary Blanche Kelly, author of "The Well of English" and head of the Department of English Literature at the College of Mount St. Vincent, will be the guest lecturer at the monthly meeting of the Poetry Workshop of Manhattan College this afternoon.
One of the navy's long-range patrol bombing planes vanished at sea last night with seven men aboard, officers revealed today after a fruitless allnight search.
Interest on Capitol Hill centered tonight on the size of Governor Lehman's budget, which will be sent to the Legislature Monday night.

The St. Nicholas Hockey Club began its schedule in the New York Amateur Hockey Association last night by crushing the Columbia Lions. 10 to 2, in the feature game of a double-header at the Brooklyn Ice Palace. In the other test,

The Dartmouth basketball team handed Vermont one of its worst defeats tonight when the Big Green romped to a 60-to-32 victory. Moose Dudis and Joe Cottone began throwing baskets early for the winners, and the score mounted to 35-22 at half-time.

The Interstate Commerce Commission ruled today that the matter of compensation for Walter Kidde, trustee of the New York, Susquehanna Western Railroad Company, and of Ralph E. Lum, as counsel to the present trustee and former trustees of the railroad, be delayed until "a later stage of the proceedings."

Charles E. Arnott, a vice president and director of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company and a defendant in the Federal gasoline case on trial here, testified today that government officials of the NRA Petroleum Code Authority acquiesced in the oil companies' gasoline-buying program in 1935, which is the basis of the charge that they conspired to raise prices.

Henry P. Du Bois, vice president of the American Liberty League in the New York area, committed suicide this morning in the garage on the estate of his father-in-law, William S. Benson, at 181 Pennington Avenue here. Mr. Du Bois had been in poor health for several years, members of the family said. He was 54 years old.

Henry Marquart of Orchard Park, president of the New York State Vegetable Growers Association, said today that farmers in this State are "almost unanimous in opposition" to compulsory crop control and the Wages and Hours Bill.

The first in a series of luncheons for members of La Margherita Society was held yesterday in the Silver Room of the Ambassador. Marchesa Delle Chiuse is president of the organization which furthers Italian Social Welfare work, including aid for mothers and children, and the maintenance of Summer camps for underprivileged children.

The following Marine Corps changes, dated Jan. 3 were announced today: CAPTAINS Munn, J. C., Quantico, Va., to Headquarters, Washington, D. C. Hough, J. F., on arrival in United States about Feb. 1 ordered to Quantico, Va.

The War Department dredge Goethals, newest addition to. the army's fleet and said to be the biggest dredge in the world, on a "shakedown" trip yesterday beat its next largest rival, the Chinook, by fifty yards in a race of three miles down the bay to the dumping grounds three and a quarter miles east southeast of Scotland Lightship.

Dr. Felipe A. Espil, Ambassador to the United States, is being prominently mentioned in political circles as the probable choice for Minister of Foreign Affairs in the Ortiz Cabinet. The most likely competitor for the post is Dr. Julio Roca, who has been Vice President during Agustin P. Justo's administration.

Twenty-four former civil service employes of the District Attorney's office, whose jobs were abolished the first of the year by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, will make a joint demand today on the State Civil Service Commission to compel Mr. Dewey to restore them.

Dr. Vanderhoef M. Disbrow, dean of Ocean County's medical men, died at his home here this afternoon at the age of 80. Dr. Disbrow started his practice in this State fifty-eight years ago and maintained it until last year.

The fencing Liebmann family champion, Bernard Schmetz, has been voted France's No. 1 athlete for 1937. The vote was taken among the leading French sports writers and the winner got an overwhelming majority.

Despite a definite stand on the matter by local coaches, the dizzy one-hand shooting technique that Western and Southern teams have brought into. Madison Square Garden is being adopted by metropolitan collegians. They still don't do it with the lazy grace of a Luisetti or a Stoefen, but that will come in time.

SIR BASIL ZAHAROFF'S enigmatic shadow is silhouetted against more than one page of "Forever Ulysses,"* a racy and sardonic novel that the Book-of-the-Month Club is distributing to its parishioners. It's not a portrait of that eminent merchant of death. There is no Spanish marriage here-indeed, there's considerably less romance than a Ulysses deserves-and no long twilight on the marble beach at Monte Carlo.

Darius Goff, member of one of New England's most prominent mill families, died here today at his home, 1 Homestead Street, in his fortyeighth year. Although in ill health about a year, Mr. Goff had been able to engage in business most of that time.

The Dramatists Guild, at a meeting yesterday of its council at 6 East Thirty-ninth Street, made demands upon the Bureau of New Plays, organized in 1936 by motion picture companies to aid young playwrights.

Stocks advanced briskly in final hour and closed strong and active with gains of 1 to 6 points; turnover, 1,209,840 shares. Rail bonds rebounded with Baltimore Ohio and Erie issues leading with gains of 5 to 9 points; United States Government loans higher; transactions, $8,152,175.

The birthday of President Roosevelt was proclaimed today as a legal holiday in Georgia. Both houses of the Legislature adopted resolutions asking for the holiday and Governor Rivers issued the proclamation.

Despite the sharp decline in rayon yarn deliveries to domestic mills and drastic curtailment of production during the closing months of 1937, the industry's outlook is favorable for the new year, according to the current issue of The Rayon Organon, published yesterday by the Textile Econnnmies Bureau, Inc.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Jan. 4: COMMANDERS Wick, H. C., when discharged from treatment Naval Hospital, Washington, D. C., to duty Bureau Aeronautics, Washington, D. C.

A Federal grand jury today freed Robert Horne, 27 years old, and George Spernak, 19, of guilt in their confessed parts in ending the piratical career of "Mad Jack" Morgan, after five days of terror aboard the yacht Aafje.

Another banner year was experienced by the New York Athletic Club in 1937, it was disclosed yesterday when President Orie R. Kelly and his board of governors accounted for their stewardship in the sixty-ninth annual report to the members of the world's largest athletic club.

The Manhattan office of the Department of Housing and Buildings has reported that 285 plans were filed in 1937 for the construction of 297 buildings at a cost of $60,775,350. This total was $24,685,150 more than the 1936 total, due chiefly to the plans for the $12,500,000 criminal court house and prison to be erected in Centre Street.

Rallying in the fourth quarter after being behind 18-10 at the half, the Seward Park High tossers maintained their unbeaten pace in the Lower Manhattan Division of the P. S. A. L. by downing Textile, 29-24, on the losers' floor yesterday.

The Citizens Union's committee on legislation made public yesterday twenty-three recommendations for the State Legislature to consider during its present session, including the abolition of the State Transit Commission,

In an argument with his 18-year-old daughter, culminated when he made slurring remarks about her church, Charles Schaefer, 49 years old, a checker in the Pennsylvania Railroad freight yards at Second and Henderson Streets, was stabbed to death at 9 o'clock tonight at his home at 14 Paterson Street.

A complete and vigorous reversal of form in the market for secondary railroad obligations was the feature at more active trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The brisk recovery movement in the carrier loans, led by bonds of the Baltimore Ohio and the Erie-heaviest losers earlier in the week-spread well over the rail list and the group, as a whole, more than recovered the ground lost on the preceding day.

Replying to Mayor Frank Hague's charges of "communism" in a broadcast immediately after the Jersey City Mayor's speech on the air, Morris Ernst, counsel to the C. I. O. and the American Civil Liberties Union, called Mayor Hague himself the "greatest radical of our day," because he was "going back on the founding fathers and our Bill of Rights."

Vice Admiral Protogenus Guimaraes died today at the age of 62. He was Minister of the Navy in 1932, when Sao Paulo revolted. Admiral Guimaraes blockaded Santos harbor and bombarded Itapu Fort from the air.
Merville Brown Ray, a portrait painter for sixty years, died at his home here today at the age of 84 after a long illness.

The New York Rangers defeated Chicago for the first time in this National Hockey League season tonight, turning back the Black Hawks, 4 to 1, before a small crowd of 7,000 spectators. The Hawks previously had won three straight from the Les Patrick Club.
Arthur H. Lea, retired publisher, philanthropist and patron of arts, died early today in Chestnut Hill Hospital after an illness of two weeks. He was 78 years old.

The weekly statement of the Bank of France caused lively comment today in financial circles here. Year-end settlements both for private business and for the Treasury were unusually heavy, as the figures indicated, but the item arousing the greatest interest was that of advances by the bank to the Treasury, which increased by 5,000,000,000 francs.

KINGS ARCULARIUS, GRACE C. (March 16, 1937). Gross assets, $5,460; net, $4,905. To sister, Elizabeth A. Winters. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $5,460. Camp and Grier, attorneys, 2 Wall St., Manhattan. BARBER, LAURA H. (May 27, 1937). Gross assets, $24,332: net, $22,515. To Mary Burns and Bridget Nally, $100 each;

Deaths Announced Retired Capt. John R. Gill, formerly a member of Engine Co. 277, residing at 65 Clinton St., White Plains, died Dec. 28. Retired Capt. Edward I. Smith, formerly a member of Engine Co. 203, at 12 Yorkshire Road, Rockville Center, L. I., died Dec. 31. Retired Fireman William McNulty, formerly a member of H. and L. Co. 22 residing at 32 Union Ave., Rutherford, N. J., died Dec. 29.

Argentina has planted 1,035,000 acres of cotton, according to the government's second official estimate of the area sown. This represents a 12 per cent decrease from the total estimated on Dec. 1, there having been considerable losses through drought in the northern provinces where the cotton is grown.

A special decree fixing the salaries and working conditions of journalists was issued today by Special Labor Trustee Ruediger. The preamble says: "The attitude of the German press is determined by National Socialists ideology."

The twenty- seven - acre estate known as Brandywine, on Sleepy Hollow Road, Briarcliff Manor, Westchester, has been sold for a client by Prince Ripley, Inc., to Walker Harden. The main residence on the property is an English Tudor manor house of twenty-two rooms,

Mrs. Sarah Lawes, mother of Warden Lewis E. Lawes of Sing Sing prison, died tonight of a stroke in a local hospital in Elmira, N. Y., after a brief illness at the age of 78. Warden Lawes was at his mother's bedside.

A conference of Jewish organizations in the metropolitan area of New York will be held at 1 o'clock Sunday afternoon, Jan. 16, at the Hotel Astor to discuss the situation of Rumanian Jews and to plan a program of action in their behalf.

Mr. and Mrs. E. Roland Harriman gave the second dinner in a series known as the 1938 "natural science evenings" in behalf of the ten-year development program of the American Museum of Natural History last night at the museum in West Seventy-seventh Street.

The New York Americans tried their hardest to topple the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden last night. For the greater part of the battle it looked as if they would succeed, for they were enjoying a one-goal lead that Hooley Smith gave them in the first period.

On his way to meet President Agustin P. Justo of Argentina at the Brazilian frontier, President Getulio Vargas with his wife and two daughters went by plane today to Porto Alegre. He received military honors and an ovation upon arrival.

Gross income of New York farmers in 1937 totaled $310,450,000, or about $10,000,000 more than in 1936, the State and Federal Agriculture Departments said today in a report which added that because of increases in labor, feed, fertilizer and other costs farmers "fared poorly" on the basis of net income.

TODAY-New England: Increasing cloudiness and slightly colder, with mostly zero temperatures, followed by snow over the central and north portions; cloudy and continued cold, followed by snow, except probably becoming mixed with sleet and rain, with slight rise in temperatures over Sotutheastern Massachusetts and Southern Connecticut.

To engage in their first international match, four or five of the International Class racing sloops on Long Island Sound will be shipped to Bermuda in the Spring. This announcement was made last night at the class meeting and dinner iI the Yale Club, Vanderbilt Avenue and Forty-fourth Street.

Henry Nesbitt, who for the last five years had been custodian of the White House and one of the most popular members of the household staff, died at his home here late yesterday. He was 72 years of age.

City College and N. Y. U. each qualified two fencers for the national individual junior foils championship in the New York district trials last night at the New York A. C. The title event is listed for Feb. 17 at the Greco Fencing Academy.

Ralph Greenleaf and Andrew Ponzi divided the seventh and eighth blocks yesterday in their 12block pocket billiard match at the A. Strand Academy. Greenleaf won, 125 to 115, in 7 innings, and Ponzi triumphed, 125 to 114, in 10 innings. High runs were: Greenleaf 77 and 68; Ponzi, 43 and 42. Each has won four sessions thus far. Ponzi leads in points, 875 to 832.
George Vanderbilt of New York is planning an expedition early next year to Sumatra and the Philippine Islands, on behalf of the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia.
United States Commissioner Edward R. Stanton died of a heart attack tonight in his home here, while listening to speeches at the Mayor Hague rally in Jersey City. He was 85 years old.
Bobby Riggs of Chicago and Bitsy Grant of Atlanta advanced to the semi-finals in separate brackets of the Miami Biltmore tennis tournament today, but the other seeded players were eliminated.

Making the most of the half-point lead he had established in the semifinals yesterday, Samuel Reshevsky of New York, United States champion, today captured first prize in the international tournament of the Hastings and St. Leonards Chess Club when he drew his last game with Paul Keres of Estonia, victor at the recent congress in Semmering.

Unless the weather man puts a blot on the encouraging picture, the multitude of skiers in the East can look forward to enjoying the most favorable running conditions in two years this week-end. Reports from the "Northlands" indicate that snow in generous quantity is to be found practically everywhere.

A further shrinkage of $81,000,000 in the total of their loans and in investments to $7,776,000,000, the lowest level yet reached in the current deflation, was reported for the week ended on Wednesday by member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling: Gold coin and bullion..decreased [Pound]124,000 Reserve in banking dept.,

Two gold chalices and a monstrance, valued at $200, were recovered by police this morning soon after they had been stolen from St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church at Echo Lake. Police said they found them in an automobile that was passing through Guttenburg.
In his opening message to Congress, the President ascribed some of the problems of industry to "the concentration of economic control * * * of other people's money * * * labor * * * and lives."

The disclosure in the statement of the Bank of France yesterday that the French Government had been compelled to increase by 5,000,000,000 francs, roughly $170,000,000, its borrowings from the bank, on which it pays no interest,
The Maritime Commission announced today that it had started an investigation of five pooling agreements between steamship companies in trade between the United States and Euronpean ports.

The closing date in the prize contest for an American composition, sponsored by the Musicians' Committee to Aid Spanish Democracy, is Jan. 15, it was announced by Horace Grenell, chairman. The composition, which must be 10 to 20 minutes long, will be judged by a jury composed of Aaron Copland, Roy Harris, Roger Sessions, Bernard Wagenaar and Alfred Wallenstein.

Official Germany is outraged by the British, and French step in Rumania yesterday in defense of the Jews there, when the two powers reminded Bucharest of their interest in the mi-' norities treaty's observance. Bitter protests appear in National Socialist party organs today and the Government News Service sends out an angry article charging the British Government with hypocrisy.

Thanks to a majority of pawns which he had established on the Queen's side of the board, Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, who lost his world title to Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, succeeded in winning the twenty-ninth game of the recent series.

Archduke Franz Josef of Austria was fined a dollar for overtime parking by Magistrate Louis B. Brodsky in traffic court yesterday. The Archduke was out of town, explained his chauffeur, Carl Kunkel, who appeared for him and pleaded guilty with an explanation that the Archduke is unfamiliar with traffic regulations here.

The Atlantic City Sea Gulls defeated the Bronx Tigers last night, 4 to 2, and moved into second place in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League, displacing the Hershey Bears, who now are in third place with the New York Rovers still settin the pace.

John Allen Capp, founder of the General Electric testing department, died in a hospital here today. He was 67 years old. A native of Germantown, Pa., Mr. Capp entered the service of the company in Lynn, Mass., and forty-four years ago was transferred here.

The report of the National Investors Corporation for its first nine months as a mutualized company formed to combine four companies was issued yesterday. It shows cash income of $989,106 and expenses of $216,201, leaving $772,905 net income.

The Midston House racquet-wielders dropped their first match in six starts in Group II of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association yesterday by bowing to the Bayside Tennis Club, 4 to 1, on the Bayside courts, as the second half of the schedule began.

The War Department issued the following orders today dated Jan. 5; COLONELS Clark, T. A. (Ordnance Dept.), General Staff Corps, relieved from detail as a member of the General Staff Corps, Chicago, Ill.. and ordered to Rock Island Arsenal, Ill.

Despite a sharp rise in bank clear ings in the week ended on Wednesday over those of the previous week, as a result of the check payments incident to the first of the month, the total declined from the corresponding period last year for the eighth consecutive week. All comparisons were on a five-day week basis.

Among the business leases reported yesterday by brokers was a contract involving an entire floor with 20,000 square feet of area. Brick Ballerstein, paper box manufacturers, leased this unit in the Heywood-Wakefield Building, 516 West Thirty-fourth Street, through the Cross Brown Company, broker.

American Gas and Electric Company and Subsidiaries--Twelve months to Nov. 30: Net profit availabel to common shares, $11,471,739, or $2.55 a share, against $9,993,822, or $2.22 a share, for same period yeas before.

The formal opening of the newly organized Manhattan Badminton Club was observed last night at a buffet supper for members and their guests given by the club's officers and board of directors at the clubhouse. 1,280 Fifth Avenue.

Dr. Edward J. Cattell, public speaker, novelist and civic booster, regarded by Philadelphia as one of its most picturesque citizens, died today as he dozed in a chair in his room at the Bankers and Manufacturers Club. He was 81 years old.
The famous "Drake's Drum" which legend says rolls whenever danger threatens England was saved today when fire consumed timbered Buckland Abbey, once the residence of Sir Francis Drake.

The possibility of home-rule legislation which would affect New York City to a great degree at the present session of the Legislature came to the fore today on inspection of the "program" bill introduced in the Senate and -Assembly' to carry out Governor Lehman's recommendations in his message to the Legislature.

Bizet's "Carmen" received its second presentation of the season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, this time with Gertrud Wettergren in the title role. Ezio Pinza was originally billed as the Escamillo but because of his indisposi. tion was replaced by John Brownlee.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, who became known as a relentless prosecutor during his campaign against hardened criminals in the vice and rackets rings, intervened in behalf of a 24-yearold second offender in General Sessions Court yesterday and won for him a two-and-a-half to five-year term in place of a mandatory State prison sentence of ten to twenty years.

A sixteen-foot bronze statue of Henry Hudson in the garb of a sea captain of the early seventeenth century and with steel helmet and sword was mounted yesterday on top of the 100-foot column in Henry Hudson Memorial Park, 227th Street and the Spuyten Duyvil.

Members of four intercollegiate leagues met at the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday and elected Asa S. Bushnell, former Princeton graduate manager and now executive director of the Central Board for Eastern Intercollegiate Athletics, as secretary-treasurer of each group.

Belgium informed the Court of International Justice today that she had dropped the Borchgrave suit against the Spanish Republican Government. Baron Jacques Borchgrave, attache at the Madrid Embassy, was slain while visiting the front in December, 1936.

President Roosevelt discussed automobile production problems with William S. Knudsen of General Motors, received an appeal from Clarence Poe, editor of the Progressive Farmer, for a process ing tax of 2 cents a pound on cotton and, with Mrs. Roosevelt, was host to Vice President and Mrs. Garner and other guests at a State dinner:

Cherry St. 231, Rittenhouse Estates. Inc, B. A. Lipman, president, to Richial Realty Corp, 362 5th Av (83). 24th St. 307-311 E; Howard Carter, executor of George J. Kenny. to Isabel McCaffrey, 219 Central Av, New Rochelle, N.Y.; mtg, 821,000. Cherry St, 231; Metropolitan Savings Bank to Rittenhouse Estates, Inc, 362 5th Av. ($3).

Chairman Copeland said today the Senate Commerce Committee hoped to "re-establish discipline on merchant ships" by labor amendments to the Merchant Marine Act. He said confidential reports of government officials at closed committee sessions confirmed "what we already had heard on lack of discipline."

The 34 West Ninetieth Street Company has sold the nine-story penthouse apartment building at 30 West Ninetieth Street to investors who paid cash over a first mortgage of $254,000. The building, which contains forty-seven apartments in suites of two, three and four rooms, occupies a plot 60 by 100 feet, between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue.

Trading was generally fair. Steer hinds and ribs were unevenly weak to lower but demand improved Veal and calf strong, lamb steady to slightly lower, fresh pork cuts uneven. Kosher lamb sold sharply lower. Trading in other kosher meats was hardly sufficient to quote a market, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Following in the footsteps of his father, Senator Wagner, Assemblyman Robert F. Wagner Jr. started his legislative career today by presenting two measures which would establish a State-wide system of health insurance.

Commonwealth Estates, Inc., has sold the one-story taxpayer on the southwest corner of Commonwealth and Lafayette Avenues, the Bronx, to a client of Philip Poger, attorney. The structure covers a plot 100 by 100 feet, and carries an assessment of $30,000. The buyer paid cash above a mortgage of $22,500

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 29,000, including 6,000 directs. The market was uneven, but steady to 25c lower than Wednesday's average, butchers 250 pounds up showing the most decline. Late sales were 15-25c lower.

Earle Bachman, former advertising manager of The American Mercury, died Wednesday at St. Francis Hospital after a short illness at the age of 51. Mr. Bachman, who had been engaged in the advertising business in New York since 1909, lived at the Orleans Hotel, Columbus Avenue and Eightieth Street.
William Watson, well - known sportsman and clubman of this city, died suddenly early yesterday morning from a heart attack at his hunting lodge at Pinetta, Fla. He was 54 years of age.

An ordinance requiring pet-shop owners to keep a record of each dog handled, in an effort to prevent pet shops from being used as clearing houses for stolen animals, was urged yesterday in a report submitted to the seventy-second annual board meeting of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals at 50 Madison Avenue.

Unless its authenticity is promptly denied, an alleged interview with Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg of Austria printed in The Daily Telegraph of London is destined to cause diplomatic steps by the Reich Government.

Warning that wage reductions in the post-1929 era brought gradual drying up of purchasing power, Douglas G. Woolf, editor of The Textile World, writing in the current issue of that publication, urges textile mills to "resist to the last ditch" any efforts of the minority to reduce wages.

ReusIng to display an "advertisement" of the New York World's Fair on his automobile license plates, Martin McBohin, a former Marine Corps sergeant who fought at Belleau Woods in the World War, placed adhesive tape over the sign on his 1938 tags and was arrested here last night.

Among the several new exnloltions of French art this week, which include those at the DurandRuel, the Valentine, the Pierre Matisse and the Perls, is one in which we are permitted to share a collector's point of view.

Arthur C. Smith, media director of Brown Tarcher, Inc., New York advertising agency, and captain of the Twenty-second. Engineers in France during the World War, died yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Hospital at the age of 51.

Justice Willis Van Devanter, retired member of the United States Supreme Court, sitting in this district as a Federal judge, told attorneys what questions they could not ask of a witness and informed a witness about his rights to refuse to answer.

The United States shipped $83,928,000 more merchandise to Japan, including re-exports, in the first eleven months of 1937 than in the corresponding period of 1936, according to a report today by the Department of Commerce, supplementing total trade figures previously made public. The new figures give imports and exports by countries.

The purchase of Maxwell Anderson's "The Star Wagon" was made today by Zelnick International as a vehicle for Janet Gaynor. The play, which is being given on Broadway, will go before the cameras in the Autumn and will follow an untitled comedy which Miss Gaynor will start next month.
Glenn Frank tonight formally accepted the chairmanship of the Republican committee on program for which he had been selected by the national committee at its recent meeting in St. Louis.

The first habitat group in America of the Okapi, a giraffe-like animal found only in the northeastern part of the Belgian Congo, was opened today in the African Hall of the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia.

Plans for the construction of 429 industrial structures estimated to cost $10,541,419 were approved in the New Jersey ,State Labor Department during 1937, the highest total in seven years, according to a report made yesterday to Labor Commissioner John J. Toohey Jr. of New Jersey, by Acting Deputy Commissioner Michael J. Angel.

A parchment scroll has been awarded to Kenneth Collins, vice president of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., by John W. Davis, chairman of the United Hospitals Campaign, in appreciation of his services during the recent appeal for the ninety-two voluntary hospitals of New York and the Visiting Nurse Association of Brooklyn.

Mrs. Ethel Strouse Sohl, 20 years old, and Genevieve Owens, 17, confessed girl bandits, were named jointly here today in an indictment charging them with the murder of William Darhorst. a bus driver. The indictment was returned by the Essex County grand jury to Common Pleas Judge Daniel Brennan.

The new year failed to check the downward trend of commodity prices, The Annalist says, and declines in prices of livestock, dairy products and food tiems reduced that publication's weekly index of wholesale commodity prices to 84.8 on Wednesday from 85.0 a week before. This is a new low for 1937-38.

The Carnegie Corporation of New York has made contributions totaling $300,000 to two projects for which Princeton University is raising endowment funds, it was announced tonight by Dr. Harold Willis Dodds, president of the university.

A provisional commercial agreement has been arranged between the United States and Chile, the State Department announced today, to take the place of the modus vivendi under which the two countries have been operating since 1931.

Despite the overnight weakness in Wall Street, the stock markets here generally were firm today. Business was slow at first, but little selling occurred and prices improved in late trading. Gilt-edge issues showed small declines, and Far Eastern bonds were easier among the foreign loans.

With attendance of buyers about on a par with the day before, "number-taking" continued to feature the showing of Spring dress and sports wear lines in the market here yesterday. Reports agreed that the larger number of models presented in the openings increased

Thomas A. R. Nelson, head of the trapeze troupe, "The Flying Nelsons," died here of pneumonia last night at the age of 64. Surviving are his widow, who was also a member of the trapeze troupe and worked with her husband for years under "the big top," and a niece, Mrs. Hamilton Fish of Atlanta.

The longshoremen's strike here held tight today for the fourth day, closing all the island's ports. No ships discharged cargo and the steamers Ponce and Coamo of the Porto Rico Line, bound for New York, departed this afternoon with passengers and mail but no outgoing freight.

The combination of inflation talk, strength in securities and a marked broadening in speculative interest in the wheat market advanced the price of wheat today to the highest level since Nov. 1 and, while there was scattered profit-taking on the upturn, most of the advance was held.

Fifteen million acres of petroleum lands in Mexico have been declared national reserves in the past six months and placed under the recently formed National Petroleum Administration, which will exploit them, the official newspaper Nacional declares today.

Investigation by a special House committee of the United States Constitution Sesquicentennial Commission, headed by Representative Bloom of New York, was requested in a resolution introduced today by Representative Charles W. Tobey of New Hampshire.

Wise Prince, veteran sprinter in the silks of Philadelphia's Felix Spatola, made an impressive Winter debut at Tropical Park today when he captured the Winter Haven Purse. The son of Wise Counsellor, with splendid Maryland form to Decommend him, equaled Clotho's sixfurlong track record of 1:10 flat while beating Mrs. Emil Denemark's Higher Cloud, a recent winner, by a length. Eddie Arcaro,

Little by little Wall Street is coming to realize that upon the report of the Carle C. Conway committee and its reception by the New York Stock Exchange and the Securities and Exchange Commission depends the future of security market regulation in this country.
Mrs. Eleanor Brinkerhoff Van Riper Speer, one of this borough's best known women, died today at Hackensack Hospital, where she had been a patient since Sunday. She was 73 years old.

The new firm of Smith, Barney Co. headed the successful banking group yesterday in the auction sale of a new issue of $3,000,000 of veterans welfare bonds of the State of California, receiving the award on a bid of 104.017 for 23/4s. The bonds, dated Jan. 1, 1938, and maturing Feb. 1, 1939 to 1954, were reoffered at prices to yield from $0.50 to 2.35 per cent, according to maturity.

Patrolmen assigned to duty on the com the ten crosstown streets on which parking has been forbidden by the Police Department were instructed yesterday to begin on Monday the serving of summonses to motorists who disobey the new regulations.

William S. Knudsen, president of General Motors Corporation, told the Senate Unemployment and Relief Committee today that although his corporation had experienced in December the most severe decline in business in its history, he felt confident that the recession would be short lived and he was preparing for an upturn in the Spring.

J. Messmore Kendall, president general of the Sons of the American Revolution, denounced Arthur Garfield Hays and Morris Ernst yesterday in an address before members of the New York City chapter of the-D. A. R. at the Hotel Plaza,

League for Political Education, Town Hall, 11 A, M. "Books About to Appear," Edward Weeks. New York Academy of Medicine, 2 East 103d Street. "Treatment of Pneumonia," Rufus Cole, 4:30 P. M.; meeting of the Section of Surgery. Speakers: Hayes E. Martin, Jerome P. Webster, William L. Watson, John M. Hanford, William S. MacComb, William F. MacFee, 8:30 P. M.

Prices on the newest' entry in the low-priced automobile field, the Hudson 112, were made public here today. The base price, which is for the coupe, described, because of its very wide seat, as "three-passenger," is $694.

Most commodity futures closed higher on the Exchanges here yesterday, but the volume of trading generally was off. Raw hide futures registered the best gains, advancing 31 to 38 points. In the cash market wheat, rye, oats, flour, cocoa, butter, lard, cotton and rubber advanced, but eggs, tins, silk and wool tops declined.

While Mayor Hague and his followers were arousing opposition to the C. I. O. in Jersey City tonight a "defiance" meeting of 200 members of C. I. O. textile unions was held at the headquarters here of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.

Detectives and representatives of the Fire Marshal's office were investigating the origin of five separate fires yesterday in East Side buildings in the area bounded by Twentieth and Thirty-second Streets between First and Second Avenues.

Although the British Government Ita last July "accepted in principle" the pre views of the Peel Royal Commission wh that a "tripartite division is the best vie and most hopeful solution" of the Pal- cas estine problem, Great Britain now considers that it "is in no sense committed" to that plan.

The Braille Institute of America, located in Los Angeles, Calif., has arranged with Funk Wagnalls to publish an edition for the blind of Emily Post's "Etiquette." The 877page book will fill eleven volumes when published into the raised letters of braille.

Chandler A. Mackey, president of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, in presenting his yearend report to members at their annual meeting yesterday declared that, in view of bills now pending before Congress which seek to place the organization under the control of the Commodity Exchange Act, the Exchange "has-come to a critical point in its course."

Hardly a week passes that doesn't bring word of some new area being developed for sport fishing, and this week brought several. All of them, of course, are in Southern waters, and some look very promising. We wondered when some enterprising guide was going to do something about the fishing in the vicinity of Grand Bahama,

New authorizations and commitments by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in December amounted to $18,324,281, including $2,283,879 to other governmental agencies, while authorizations aggregating $2,149,771 were canceled or withdrawn, the corporation reported today.

Representative Sumners of Texas, an outspoken critic of President Roosevelt's defeated Court Reorganization Bill, received the backing of the House Judiciary Committee today for appointment to the Supreme Court.

The absence of snow has been a continued annoyance to the members of the Madison Square Boys Club, a group of athletes. For the last month the members have waited impatiently for snow to fall so they could do some skiing on their playground at Twenty-ninth Street and Second Avenue.

Charges that forces led by Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City tampered with the Federal mails were laid before the Postoffice Department today by Morris L. Ernst, special counsel for the Committee for Industrial Organization drive to unionize workers in Jersey City.

The Real Estate Association of the State of New York commended Governor Lehman today for urging the improvement of real estate in his annual message. In a letter to the Governor, Ray Hofferd, this city, executive vice president of the association, expressed the hope that he would urge legislative consideration "at an early date"

The following Coast Guard changes for the week ended Jan. 5 were announced today: Alger, Capt. J. A., selected as commander. Bering Sea Patrol Force, 1938 season, in addition to duties as Western Inspector. Dench, Commander C. H., the Tahoe, designated as commander, International Ice Patrol Force, 1938 season.

A total of 420 new industrial plants were established in Massachusetts and 166 existing plants were substantially expanded during 1937, according to a report issued yesterday on a survey conducted by the Associated Industries of Massachusetts.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On Jan. 9 it will be just sixty years since the amendment to the Constitution enfranchising women was first introduced in the Senate of the United States. Surely it is a date to be remembered.

Mr. and Mrs. Augustus Van Cortlandt Jr. will give a dinner tonight in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for their daughters, the Misses Carolyn and Katherine Van Cortlandt, before the second Junior Assembly, which takes place at the Ritz-Carlton.

After a ninety-minute conference yesterday with coal dealers and union representatives at City Hall, Mayor La Guardia announced that an impending coal strike that threatened to tie up deliveries here had been avoided by an agreement to negotiate for a settlement.

Imports of foreign-made rugs and carpets in the first ten months of last year displaced more than $30,000,000 worth of domestic-made goods in the American market, according to claims made yesterday by the "Made In America Club."

Representative Patman of Texas said today that he would circulate a petition to get his bill providing for government ownership of the Federal Reserve Banks out of the Banking Committee unless early consideration on the floor of the House was granted to it.
The Dartmouth chapter of Theta Chi will dissolve in June. "unless there is an increase in membership," the president of the fraternity, Sidney B. Cardozo of New Rochelle, N. Y., said today.

William Scully, general sales manager; Mathew Fox, assistant to the president, and J. H. Seidelman, who is joining the company under a long-term contract, yesterday were elected vice presidents of Universal Pictures Company, Inc., at a meeting of the board.

Maxwell H. Tretter, Assistant Corporation Counsel, has been assigned to handle the legal work of the New York City Housing Authority. Yvelin Gardner, who has been associated for six years with the firms, has been elected secretary of Porter Co., Real Estate, Inc., and...

John N. Goldsmith, Joseph Pardoll, in 350 E 52d St: Mrs. John D. Kennedy, in 40 El 62d St; William Turnbull, in .111 E 80th St; Douglas L. Elliman Co, brokers. Albert P. Rogers, in 59 W 71st St; Joseph R. Grady, in 360 Central Park West; N. Stone, in 444 Central Park West; Martin E. Popkin, in 685 West End Ave:
Lieut. Col. Henry H. Malven Jr. of the Adjutant General's office died yesterday at Walter Reed Hospital, the War Department announced today.

The "great majority" of the Puerto Rican people wish statehood for the island, not separation from the United States, Governor Winship of Puerto Rico, here to attend the opening of the new Puerto Rican Institute of Tourism in the International Building, Rockefeller Center, said yesterday.

Continuance of a sound fiscal policy by the Venezuelan Government in connection with the public works and service program recently announced by President Lopez Contreras was pledged yesterday by Dr. Manuel R. Egana, director of public credit of that country's Treasury Department, in an address to members and guests of the Pan-American Society.

The Underwriters Trust Company, as trustee, has sold the four-story dwelling at 32-56 Forty-first Street, Long Island City, to an investing client of Riley Realty Company. The house contains twenty apartments.

The mystery of the missing $25,000 from the vault of the Bensonhurst National Bank last Monday was solved late last night with the arrest of a bank employee and a brokerage firm's customers' man, and the unfolding of a plot which turned out to be so intricate and naive that it collapsed of its own weight.

A revolt, against President Jorge Ubico's regime in Guatemala broke out last night, according to reports current in Tapachula, State of Chiapas, Mexico, near the Guatemalan northern frontier and close to the Pacific seacoast.

The Federal Government's interdepartmental study of "hot money" is in the "ice box" for the time being, Secretary Morgenthau said at his press conference today. "They worked out all kinds of plans," he said, "but no one seemed to get a practical answer to the question."

Russians loyal to the Orthodox faith in the face of Soviet anti-religious campaigns crowded into Moscow's few remaining churches tonight for Christmas Eve services according to the pre-revolutionary calendar. [There is thirteen days' difference between the Gregorian calendar and the Julian.]

A decrease of 221 in the number of newspapers published in the United States in 1937, compared with the preceding year, was reported yesterday in the 1938 edition of N. W. Ayer Sons Directory of Newspapers and Periodicals.
The report of the Bank of Canada for the week ended yesterday shows a rise of more than $2,000,000 in Dominion Government deposits and a drop of more than $3,000,000 in those of chartered banks.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt "looked in" tonight on the Velvet Ball-given at the Mayflower Hotel for the benefit of the Children's Lunch Fund. She arrived after the State dinner at the White House in time to rise in her box and personally provide the finale to the tableau of reproductions of gowns worn by the wives of Presidents of the United States.

H. Hobart Porter, president of the American Water Works and Electric Company, has been elected a life trustee of Columbia University, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, announced yesterday. Mr. Porter succeeds Stephen Baker, honorary chairman of the board of directors of the Bank of the Manhattan Company, who resigned recently.

Eight days and nights of midwinter out-of-season yachting excitement will begin this evening at the Grand Central Palace to assure those thousands who have a flair for things nautical and a hankering for vacations afloat that another Summer can't be 'ar off.

Retirement of Justice Sutherland from the Supreme Court will change the seating order of the nine justices for the third time within a year. The Chief Justice presides in the middle, with four associates on either side.

Establishment of official truck, bus and private car register stops nationally in roadside eating places, gasoline and service stations is being projected, and group national advertising is being considered, it was learned here today.

A man whose photograph closely resembled that of Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, fugitive racket chieftain sought by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey and the Federal Government, obtained a passport through the office of former County Clerk Albert Marinelli in the same manner as did the "Robinson-Rubens" couple that disappeared in Moscow, it was learned yesterday.

The first State convention of the Catholic War Veterans held its opening session with a meeting last night at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn. Four hundred persons attended. The principal speakers were Colonel Alexander Anderson, commanding officer of the 165th Infantry, New York National Guard;

Fourteen thousand out of the 15,000 cases of the priceless Peiping palace art treasures have been transported to Chungking, one of the new capitals, and Paochl, an obscure Shansi city about sixty miles west of Sian, according to Han Lih-wu, director of the board trustees for the administration of the British Boxer indemnity refund, who almost single-handedly evacuated

Colonel M. Robert Guggenheim of Washington and New York married Mrs. Rebecca Pollard Van Lennep, member of an old Virginia family, today. The Rev. Elisha King, rector of the Miami Beach Community Church, performed the ceremony before the fireplace in the salon of Colonel Guggenheim's yacht, Firenze, docked here.

For thefirst time in recent Senate history the majority leadership wielded the "big stick" today in an effort to halt a resumption of the filibuster which Southern Senators apparently have decided upon to prevent a vote on the Wagner-Van Nuys Anti-Lynching Bill.

To take effect 8 A. M. Jan. 7: ACTING CAPTAIN-Ambrose J. Haddock, from office of the Second Deputy Police Commissioner to office of the Third Deputy Police Commissioner, assignment to duty in Legal Bureau continued. LIEUTENANTS-Williams J. A. Ford, from 120th Precinct to 9th Division, assignment changed from desk duty to supervisor of patrol in uniform.
The Bureau of Internal Revenue moved before the -Board of Tax Appeals today for leave to be heard on a new claim against the estate of the late Andrew W. Mellon for income taxes in 1931.

E. S. Merritt has been appointed department manager of all glove departments of Marshall Field Co., manufacturing division, it was announced yesterday. The following changes in the piece goods division were also announced: J. A. Rice has been appointed department manager of all silks, rayons and wools, with W. B. Miller as his assistant.

The semi-annual report of the Lehman Corporation for the six months ended on Dec. 31 shows 23.9 per cent of gross assets in cash, receivable items and United States Government securities, representing a value of $14,977,896 at market quotations, equal to $7.20 a share on 2,081,580 shares of stock.

Deals reported yesterday indicated a continuance of the demand for housing properties in the Washington Heights and Harlem sections. Jerome H. Frank, operator, bought the four-story building at 433 West 146th Street from the estate of Charles Lehman.

Miss Grace Allen Toucey, daughter of Mrs. William Hall Headington of 210 East Sixty-eighth Street and the late John M. Toucey, was married yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. James Episcopal Church to Oscar Credelle Turner, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Duncan Turner of Birmingham, Ala.

Crown witnesses from Palestine who claim to have been defrauded by certain officials of Heilbut-Symons Co., Ltd., will be available to give evidence on Jan. 25, it was stated in Bow Street Court today, when hearing of the conspiracy charge against the officials was again adjourned.

A religious edifice rich in historic associations will pass into the hands of wreckers next week to make way for a more imposing modern church. On Jan. 13 workmen will begin to tear away the hallowed and timeworn walls of the old Church of St.
The total of $1,270,000,000 of excess reserves which member banks held on Wednesday was the largest they have had since the May 1 increase in reserve requirements went into effect. It was, in fact,

THERE was some discussion of the relative T merits of Steele and Apostoli and in walked Joe Pearman of the New York A. C. to upset matters. "Who are those fellows?".demanded Joe. "I never heard of them." Since Mr. Pearman is about eight feet highor, at least, looks eight feet high though the estimate may err on the generous side-it is always diplomatic to humor him.

Federal Judge Woolsey, sitting yesterday in trial of the Securities and Exchange Commission's action to enjoin Torr Co., brokers, Ellery W. Mann and others from alleged violation of the Securities Act of 1933 and the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934, said he had seen no evidence of acts of fraud committed by the defendants.

Jeremiah T. Mahoney, who as the Democratic candidate for Mayor last November was overwhelmingly defeated by Fiorello H. La Guardia, last night made a blistering attack on Tammany Hall demanding that it change its name and address because of what the name stood for.

Word that definite assurances of Brazil's intention to observe provisions of the reciprocal trade treaty with this country under which Brazil agreed to allocate sufficient exchange to cover imports from the United States has been given State Department officials by the Brazilian Government, the Merchants Association announced yesterday.

An elderly Negro, who helped make Southern history by taking his place in a jury box to help try a rape case, tonight voted with eleven white men to send two members of his own race to the electric chair on charges of attacking a white girl. The jury reached its verdict in seven minutes.

Mrs. Charles Henry Fargo, the former Miss Gwendolyn Hart, was married to Henry Webster Palmer Jr. this afternoon in the Leslie Lindsay Memoral Chapel of Emmanuel Church by the Rev. Dr. Arthur Lee Kinsolving and the Rev. William E. Gardner.

Mayor La Guardia's announced drive for abolition of the Transit Commission came back into the limelight yesterday with Governor Lehman's announcement at Albany of the appointment of his former counsel, M. Maldwin Fertig, as a member of the Transit Commission.

The Grace Line will start its new service to the West Indies and South America with the sailing of the liner Santa Rosa today. One of the passengers will be Governor Blanton Winship of Puerto Rico, who flew to New York to make the voyage back to San Juan.
