Orson H. Marchant of the firm of Blair Marchant, civil engineers, ended his life with a bullet probably two days ago, according to Dr. Frank J. Wales Medical Examiner of the town of Monroe, where Mr. Marchant's body was found this morning in a wooded section near Lake Zoar. He had been sought since he disappeared three days ago.

1st Lt. Charles H. Robinson Jr., Inf.-Res., 1,301 Florence Ave., Plainfield, N. J., 311th Infantry, is ordered to active duty effective Jan. 9, at headquarters, Third Military Area, 3,400 Raymond-Commerce Building, Newark, N. J., for training. He will revert to an inattive status on Jan. 22.

There were 2,084 daily English language newspapers listed in the United States in 1937, a decrease of 23 as compared with 1936, the N. W. Ayer Son directory for 1938 shows. Weekly papers numbered 10,629, a decrease of 176, and semiweekly 359, a drop of 18.

Arctic experts expressed fear today that the ice floe on which four Soviet explorers have spent almost a- year might be swept into the open sea, where it could be broken to pieces before rescuers reached the scientists.

Appointment of a special Presidential commission to develop a factual basis on which new legislation in the field of the anti-trust laws can be drafted was recommended yesterday by the committee on industrial legislation of the Trade and Commerce Bar Association, according to announcement by Mrs. Lillian L. Poses, administrative secretary of the association.

The final total of State and municipal financing for the year 1937 was $981,452,333, the smallest recorded in five years and substantially lower than last year's total of $1,156,254,317. State and municipal financing for December totaled $93,949,566, as compared with $92,838,321 in December, 1936.

A contract has been signed by the government with the Frederick Snare Corporation of New York, Havana and Lima calling for the expenditure of 21,838,080 soles Lalmost $5,500,0001 for the construction of a new port at Matarani, Southern Peru, and the extension of the existing port works at Callao.

Contending that the degree of latitude allowed the State Liquor Authority in imposing penalties for minor infractions of the State's regulations is so circumscribed that effective enforcement is hindered rather than helped, John J. Daly,

Robert R. Young, chairman of the Alleghany Corporation, announced tonight the election of George A. Tomlinson of Cleveland as president of the corporation, succeeding Charles L. Bradley. Mr. Tomlinson was associated with George A. Ball of Muncie, Ind.,

Through the new Eastern Ice Yachting Association a third challenge was received yesterday for the Rumson Country Eastern Championship Pennant. It was from George E. Ruppert and George J. Gillig, owners of the fast Class A craft Pirate II and Eskimo.

Utilization of the reserve accumulated in the social security fund for low-cost housing and slum clearance was advocated by Stanley M. Isaacs, President of the Borough of Manhattan, at a forum on housing held in City Hall Wednesday night by the Parliament of Community Councils of New York, Inc.

Secretary Morgenthau said today that conditions "as of today" do not require additional relief appropriations. He told reporters that, although President Roosevelt's budget message left open the possibility of asking Congress for more relief money for the current and the next fiscal year, no more money was needed now.

Under a decree that Baldur von Schirach, Hitler Youth leader, announced today all members of the League of German Girls, comprising the vast majority of those from 14 to 21, will have to learn housekeeping,

The buying trend in odd-lot transactions on the New York Stock Exchange continued in the week ended on Jan. 1, with 531,864 shares purchased on balance, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

FOREVER ULYSSES, by C. P. Rodocanachi. (Viking, $2.50.) A satiric novel. AN ENCYCLOPEDIA OF PACIFISM, edited by Aldous Huxley. (Harper, 50 cents.) A topical collection. THE FAMILY OF NATIONS, by Nicholas Murray Butler. (Scribner, $3.) A discussion of its needs and problems.

A move designed to "spread prosperity without placing business in a strait jacket" was made by Senator Vandenberg today when he introduced a resolution for an investigation of profit-sharing with a view to facilitating and encouraging that system throughout the country.

The lay off of 30,000 General Motors workers caused John L. Lewis to break his vacation rest here and plead for higher wages and more security for labor. The C. I. O. leader said the motor company would "probably lay off more, but are just putting out that figure so it will not be so alarming.

Construction has been started and the cornerstone laid for the Amelia Earhart Lighthouse on Howland Island, Dr. Ernest Gruening, director of the Interior Department's Division of Territories and Island Possessions, reported today to Secretary Ickes.

A copy of the first edition of Edward FitzGerald's translation of the "Rubiiyat of Omar Khayyam," with the original wrappers bound in, was bought by James F. Drake, Inc., for $720 last night at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., at the auction of part two of the library of the late Joseph B. Shea of Pittsburgh, Pa.

Gold holdings, as Stated in the subjoined table, represent the item "gold certificates on hand and due from United States Treasury." Title of actual gold in possession of the Federal Reserve was transferred to the United States Government by the law of Jan. 20, 1934.

The United States Senate subcommittee investigation of the question of whether or not the Puerto Rican Supreme Court is in need of more justices is likely to lead to reforms in the court as well as a liberalization of the organic act.

William S. Thiede has been appointed general superintendent of the Bayonne, N. J., plant of the Standard Oil Company. He was formerly assistant general superintendent of the Bayway refinery and will be succeeded in that post by D. L. Ferguson.

Senator Lodge of Massachusetts became today perhaps the first man to fall out of the presiding officer's chair in the Senate. Sitting in the chair temporarily and leaning too far backward, he toppled over with a crash.

A new East-West record for military aircraft was set today when a giant four-motored army bombing plane, known as a "flying fortress," landed here thirteen hours and twenty-seven minutes after take-off from Langley Field, Va., March Field officers announced.

James J. (Gene) Tunney, former heavyweight boxing champion of the world, who since his retirement from the ring has become identified with business and financial organizations, has been elected chairman of the board of the American Distilling Company.

More than 100 persons, representing the Chamber of Commerce, the Catholic clergy, war veterans' organization, the American Federation of Labor and other civic and social groups were on the platform with the speakers. Among them were:

After some talk of moving from Labor Stage, the "Pins and Needles" people have decided to stay where they are, at least through February - this despite pressure from the rank and file of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union who want the show to go to a larger house so that they can all see it.

Indications that the Yankees this year may have another spirited "'holdout war" on their hands such as the one that plagued them during the early days of 1937 were seen yesterday when word was received here from California that Joe DiMaggio was beginning to formulate a pretty good idea of his worth to the world champions next season.

Sir Milne Cheetham, a distinguished British diplomat, died today in Denham at the age of 68. Although he attained the rank of Minister later in his career, his name is associated most closely with Egypt, where he was in sole charge of British interests during the critical period beginning in the World War and extending to the serious outbreaks of 1919.

William H. Wadhams Jr. of 245 East Seventy-second Street has announced the engagement of his sister, Miss Priscilla Reed Wadhams, to Carl Baker Avery, son of Mr. and Mrs. Olin M. Avery of Morganton, N. C.

About thirty men and women associates of the late President Theodore Roosevelt made their nineteenth annual pilgrimage to Youngs memorial cemetery today to mark the day on which he died. Later, the pilgrims motored to Sagamore Hill where they had luncheon with Mrs. Edith Kermit Roosevelt, widow of the former President, who was assisted in receiving by her daughter, Mrs. Richard Derby.

The roads fund revolt against administration suggestions assumed a militant form in the House today when Chairman Cartwright of the Roads !Committee introduced legislation to assure continuance of Federal grants to States for two years more than are specified in current law.
Miss Florence Schenkan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. L. A. Schenkan of this city, was married this evening to Herbert L. Kashmann, son of Mr. and Mrs. I. H. Kashmann of Montclair.

The general level of retail food prices declined in the month ended on Dec. 14, the Bureau of Statistics announced today. The index, based on the 1923-25 average, dropped to 82.6 from 83.6 and compared with 82.9 on Dec. 15, 1936.

Because the efforts of aircraft. designers have been concentrated in recent years on high performance both as to speed and load, many of the modern airplanes cannot be considered safe,. according to Dr. Joseph S. Ames, chairman of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics.

A woman was drowned shortly before 9 o'clock last night when she was trapped in the front of a light truck that plunged through the railing of the wooden bridge at the foot of Flatlands Avenue, at East 107th Street, Canarsie, Brooklyn, and fell into forty feet of water in Fresh Creek below.

An authentic account of daring trickery that resulted in the robbery of mail bags has reached this correspondent from private sources in Yugoslavia. It illustrates amusingly how the pervaiding awe for the police of that country and respect for the all-powerful censorship of the mails could persuade even a trusted servant .of the postal service to hand

The third American airman killed this week in the Chinese air force was identified by the United States Consulate General here today. This flier was Frederick Kreuzberg, German World War aviator, who was naturalized in 1922.

William du Pont Jr., whose interests have extended over flat racing, steeplechasing and breeding for years, was elected a member of the board of stewards yesterday at the annual meeting of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association.

Advertising and production plans for 1938 of Mock, Judson, Voehringer Company, makers of Mojud hosiery, will be based on expectations of "a healthy increase" in sales of 1937, which was the biggest year in the company's history, according to Nathaniel Judson, chairman of the board.

Whole-sale prices dropped slightly in the week ended on Jan. 1 principally because of a further drop in food prices, the Bureau of Statistics announced today. The index, based on the 1926 average as 100 fell to 81.0 from 81.2 and compared with 84.7 a year before.

There's a wider range of vision than usual for a baseball man standing at the annual crossroads. Looking forward, beyond 1938, is baseball's centennial year, - and when you turn around there's a century of baseball history stretching all the way back to the Summer of 1839 and a village green in up-State New York.

The coming establishment of a new National Polytechnical Institute on which the government will spend at least 2,000,000 pesos the first year was announced today by President Lazaro Cardenas in a brief communique.

MANHATTAN BEDELL, JAMES W. (Aug. 5). Estate. $100. To Edith C. Bedell, widow, executrix. BOYD, ADELAIDE I. (Nov. 1). Estate, less than $10,000. To Frances Boyd Sleeper, daughter, Waco, Texas. Elizabeth Day, daughter, executrix, 4 E. 95th St. GRAY, KATHRYN (Nov. 8). Estate, more than $10,000. To Almon Nelson Gray, husband, executor, 118 W. 57th St.

A compilation of major engineering contracts awarded during the year just closed reveals a total of $2,437,623,000, a gain of 4 per cent over the preceding year, according to The Engineering News-Record. The report includes fifty-two weekly reports in 1937, while in 1936 fifty-three were used.

In the glorious old days of the Roman Empire it was customary to brand stigmata fabricensium on the .arms of workers attached to certain factories. The worker could thus be easily identified if he left his job, and the National Labor Relations Act of that day saw to it that he was dragged back.
Allegations of waste and inefficiency are made against the State Highway Department in a report submitted by Robert A. Hurley, Public Works Commissioner, and made public today by Governor Crbss.

The issue of foreign activities in this country for military purposes was raised today by Senator Robert R. Reynolds of North Carolina, who pointed to the parole on Dec. 27 of Adrian Alvarey Hevia from Clinton prison at Dannemora, N. Y., and offered a resolution seeking information covering all such matters.
Clarence (Brick) Owens, for twenty-two years an umpire in the American League, was placed on the voluntary retirement list by President William Harridge today because of poor physical condition.

While 200 detectives searched the city last night for two of the three hold-up men involved in the killing of Patrolman Frank E. Zaccor in a West Thirty-first Street bar and grill early yesterday morning, another patrolman, on special duty in an intensive hunt for a burglar who has been terrorizing homes in the Bronx, was critically wounded by a mysterious assailant at 8:20 P. M.

Norve Williamson's straight-on: poke, after taking Johnny Munro's I pass in the ebbing seconds of tonight's overtime hockey game, gave Queens University a 3-2 victory over Yale before 1,200 enthusiasts in the, New Haven arena.

Traffic through the Welland ship canal and the St. Lawrance canals established new records in 1937, while traffic through the Sault Ste Marie canals was only exceeded in four other years, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today. Total traffic through the canals was 108,458,303 tons, compared with 88,254,459 the previous year.

The Japanese Army's and Navy's combined demands for financing the war in China during the next fiscal ye. will exceed four billion yen, according to a forecast in the newspaper Asahi. This amount tops all previous forecasts, which had not exceeded three billion yen.

Mrs. Marguerite Christian Hellier of 18 Gramercy Park, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Henry Belmonte Christian of Fort Worth, Texas, was married on Monday afternoon in the Broadway Tabernacle Church to Sidney Hosmer of Boston and Marion, Mass., by the Rev. Dr. Allan Knight Chalmers.

In testimony before a subcommittee of the House Appropriations Committee on Dec. 1, made public today, William O. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, emphasized the belief that if the Stock Exchanges were organized properly

Today's major events: "Elektra" and "Gianni Schicchi," Metropolitan Opera House, 8:15 P. M.; Artur Rubinstein, pianist, Carnegie Hall, evening; Ossy Renardy, violinist, Town Hall, evening; WPA New York Civic Orchestra, Federal Music Theatre, evening.

During the week ended Jan. 5 member bank reserve balances increased $88,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from decreases of $61,000,000 in money in circulation, $13,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks and $16,000,000 in non-member deposits

Two physicians accused of drugging holders of insurance policies with medicines that produced symptoms of heart disease; two attorneys, who are alleged to have been advisory conspirators, and an alleged "chaser"

The report by the Iron and Steel Institute, on December's steel production in the United States, makes it possible to round out comparisons for a very remarkable trade year. Production last month was not only smallest of any month since September, 1934, but was actually 71 3/4 per cent below that of March, last year'. high-record month.

A party of United States newspaper publishers today interviewed Premier Mitchell Hepburn of Ontario, presumably to protest a reported plan of the Ontario and Quebec Governments to control newsprint production.

The legislative program of the New York State Conference of Mayors and other municipal officials was presented today to Governor Lehman and the Legislature by Charles Stanton, president of the organization.

Unless otherwise stated, the result of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses and normal Federal income charges, but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings. Figures, in many cases, are subject to final adjustment.
The following statement was read today by W. S. Knudsen, president of General Motors, before the Senate Committee on Unemployment Relief:

Daniel J. Langan, assistant general auditor of the Mortgage Commission Servicing Corporation, a State bureau, was promoted yesterday to be controller of the New York State Mortgage Commission. Mr. Langan will continue, however, to serve as assistant general auditor of the servicing corporation.

Peter Chieffo, who has spent twenty-four of his sixty-three years as custodian of City Hall, had a bad morning yesterday when he was informed that he was dismissed by Edward McGrew, Acting Commissioner of Public Works, but by nightfall his old friend Mayor La Guardia had found another Job for him.

A party of United States newspaper publishers today interviewed Premier Mitchell Hepburn of Ontario, presumably to protest a reported plan of the Ontario and Quebec Governments to control newsprint production.

The legislative program of the New York State Conference of Mayors and other municipal officials was presented today to Governor Lehman and the Legislature by Charles Stanton, president of the organization.

Unless otherwise stated, the result of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses and normal Federal income charges, but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings. Figures, in many cases, are subject to final adjustment.

Miss Mildred Louise Vanderveer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Vanderveer of Forest Hills, Queens, was married to Dr. Edward H. Schwiebert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Schwiebert, also of Forest Hills, last night in the Church in the Gardens, Forest Hills. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John W. Rahill, who was assisted by the Rev. Howard C. Hasbrouck.

ADELSTEIN, ROSA (Sept. 18, 1937). Gross assets, $35,194; net, $22,521. To Michael Addison, Pauline A. Asinof, Gertrude Adelstein, Thomas, Samuel and Sidney Adelstein, children, residue equally, Chier assets, stocks and bonds, $26,583. Alexander, Ash Jones, attorneys, 76 Beaver St.

While the wheat market today was fairly active, there was not the aggressive buying of futures by houses with export connections that was much in evidence yesterday despite reports that 750,000 bushels of domestic hard Winter grain had been sold for shipment abroad.

An English Egyptologist, W. B. Emery, today offered evidence supporting a theory that he had discovered the tomb of Menes, the King whose almost legendary reign is set by Egyptologists at 5,000 to 6,000 years ago.

Led by Nelson McGraw, who scored 10 points, Lincoln School's tossers recorded their fourth victory in as many starts in the northern division of the Metropolitan Athletic Association of Private Schools tournament by topping Fieldston School, 25-18, on the losers' floor yesterday.
Mrs. Anne Gulick Faelten, concert pianist and wife of Reinhold Faelten, Boston pianoforte instructor, died yesterday at her home here, after a long illness at the age of 41.

About 2,000 men and women took part in a picketing demonstration from noon to 1:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon at the home offices of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, which occupies the block bounded by Twenty - third and Twenty-fourth Streets, Madison and Fourth Avenues:
President Maximiliano Hernandez Martinez today approved the appointment of Paul Contreras as Minister to the Insurgent Spanish Government, according to official reports.

Continuing his effort for social accord, Premier Camille Chautemps today issued invitations to the president of the Employers Confederation, C. T. Gignoux, the president of the Labor Federation, Leon Jouhaux, and representatives of the associations
Fordham broke its three-game losing streak by subduing the Seton Hall five, 35-32, before 4,000 spectators in the Orange Armory tonight.
Indoor polo will be resumed tonight after the holiday lapse with the opening games of the season in Metropolitan League competition and new rules in force for the first time.
The Foreign Affairs Ministry announced tonight that it had nominated Secretary of State Cordell Hull of the United States for the Nobel Peace Prize for 1938.

Retailers were encouraged by an unexpected upturn in sales this week, with volume ranging from 2 to 8 per cent higher than in the previous week and 3 to 10 per cent over the corresponding week a year ago, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., declared yesterday in its weekly review. Trade shows, fairs and initial

The Bronx Tigers and the Baltimore Orioles played to a 2-2 overtime tie in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League game last night at the New York Coliseum. It was the fifth deadlock for the Bengals in their last eight starts and their sixth of the season.
Save for two short speeches on Monday, general debate was concluded when the House adjourned today on the Independent Offices Appropriation Bill, introduced yesterday.

Air express shipments handled in New York in December totaled 33,012, a new all-time high and an increase of 12 1/2 per cent over the total of 29,483 for December, 1936, the Railway Express Agency announced yesterday.

Motivated either by overconfidence, born of the belief that more time to get ready is scarcely necessary, or resignation in that it really will make little difference, the Dodgers have decided this year to lop a full week off their customary Spring training routine.

The committee headed by Senator Byrnes is wisely beginning to consider a problem that should have received general consideration many months ago. This is the problem of harmonizing and coordinating our unemployment insurance and our relief programs.

For the purpose of enlarging the Lincoln County Park, Jersey City, by extending it on the south to Communipaw Avenue and on the north to Duncan Avenue, the Hudson County Park Commission has purchased from the Morgan Realty Company two parcels 204 by 1,077 feet on the east shore of the Hackensack River adjoining the south line of Duncan Avenue;

A banking group headed by Brown Harriman Co., Inc., and including Mercantile-Commerce Bank and Trust Company, Kelley, Richardson Co., Inc., and A. M. Snyder Co., submitted the highest bids yesterday for an issue of $950,000 of sewer bonds of Dallas, Texas.
Eight colleges from six States are included in the 1938 football schedule for Union College, according to an announcement today by Professor J. Harold Wittner, director of athletics.

It is heartening to learn that President Cardenas plans to invite a considerable number of exiles to join the faculty of the new National Polytechnic Institute, the establishment of which he has just authorized.

Charles E. Arnott, a vice president of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company and a key defendant in the Federal Government's gasoline price-fixing case, asserted in cross-examination today that the purpose of a 1935 major oil company gasoline buying program was to maintain a place in the industry for small, independent refiners.

Revenues of revenue freight for the week ended Jan. 1 amounted to 457,359 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 3,008 cars, or 0.7 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week;
President Roosevelt shook up the diplomatic corps today when he sent three nominations to the Senate for confirmation, and left the future activities of one career man undisclosed.

A note formally asking information concerning Mrs. Ruth M. Rubens, American woman who disappeared from a large hotel in the heart of Moscow on Dec. 9, a week after the equally strange disappearance of her husband, Adolph A. Rubens, was received by the Soviet Foreign Office today from the United States Embassy here, acting on instructions cabled from Washington.
Surrounded by the gauchos of his native State, President Getullo Vargas this morning greeted more than fifty newspaper reporters following the large ovation he received from the people yesterday.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, made public a letter of protest today which he sent to Joseph B. Eastman of the Interstate Commerce Commission on the scale of maximum hours for the motor carrier industry recently set by the commission.
With a large attendance of younger members of society, the second of the Junior Assemblies for this season took place last night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton.

Manhattan Alterations Center St, 139; to 9-story offices; Haristone Realties, Inc, 475 5th Ave, owner; C. P. Meli, architect; cost, $25,000. Center St, 137; to 9-story offices; Thomas E. Dewey. District Attorney, etc., premises, owner; same architect; cost, $25,000.

Although loser in the recent match with Dr. Alexandre Alekhine for the chess championship of the world, Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam finished strongly by taking the thirtieth and last game of the series, the full score of which has reached here from Rotterdam.

Despondent over the loss of her job as a domestic in a Great Neck home New Year's Day and over the separation of her parents, Miss Mary Foley, 18 years old, jumped from the Cutter Mill Road Viaduct over the Long Island Railroad late Wednesday afternoon and lay in the brush semi-conscious until found this morning.
Thomas J. Watson of New York, president of the International Chamber of Commerce, will give a lecture at Sweet Briar College Thursday evening on the subject of "World Understanding."
With a small radio blaring "Springtime in the Rockies" in his arms, 33year-old Charles Davis leaped three stories to his death today.

A painstaking search of the crowded cubicle that for more than twenty-five years was home to Gabriel Marchand, 76-year-old night watchman and former decorative gardener, yielded $22 in charred bills yesterday, all that firemen could find of $1,000 the elderly Frenchman said had been hidden there when a fire broke out three hours before.

Princeton University's aggressive jayvee hockey squad preserved its undefeated status by turning back Sands Point of the Metropolitan Amateur League tonight, 7 to 1. It was one of the roughest contests staged here this season.

IN the wake of the Stanford and Minnesota basketball invasions of this territory there was a report that the gendarmes were guarding the waterfront to keep local basketball coaches from throwing themselves into various rivers in fits of deep despondency.

The C. I. O. responded to Mayor Frank Hague's big rally in Jersey City last nigh: by filing in Federal court here today a broad injunction suit in which the entire Jersey City situation is made the basis of constitutional issues which may eventually have to be decided by the United States Supreme Court.

Resentment against utilizing the 1938 automobile license plates as a medium for "free advertising" of the World's Fair spread to this city yesterday when more than a dozen purchasers of license plates in the Bronx division of the Motor Vehicle Bureau expressed their determination to blot out the "objectionable" inscription by the application of black paint or adhesive tape.

Foreseeing a continuance of the rise in State expenditures, the New York State Commission for the Revision of the Tax Laws recommended yesterday that existing emergency taxes be made permanent or that some permanent substitutes for them be found.

Imp. Glenn Echo September Sunshine of Dunesk, more familiarly known as Sunny, last night repeated last year's victory by winning highest honors. He was adjudged best cat in the show of the Atlantic Cat Club held in conjunction with the Silver Society.

The Perkin Medal for 1938, one of the high honors in applied chemistry, was presented last night to Dr. Frank J. Tone, president of the Carborundum Company, at a joint meeting of the American Section of the Society of Chemical Industry and the American Chemical Society, held at the Chemists Club, 52 East Forty-first Street.

Complaint in a suit for $150,000 begun in Federal- court on Thursday by E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. against Ferdinand Lundberg and the Vanguard Press, alleging libel in Mr. Lundberg's book "America's Sixty Families," was filed yesterday.

The Dollar Line, one of the principal steamship companies which has received no government aid since cancellation of ocean mail contracts six months ago, became eligible today for an operating differential subsidy.
The manager of a store, in describing the theft of a pair of shoes before the South London Juvenile Court today, asserted an 11-year-old boy said to him:
Formal announcement of the intention to negotiate a reciprocal trade agreement with the United Kingdom was made today by Secretary Hull, under the requirements of the Trade Agreements Act.
The December ball was held tonight in the Barclay Ballroom and was attended by 250 guests.

Three children were killed and their mother was seriously injured early today when dynamite wrecked their home near here. Deputy Sheriff Roy Asher said officers were working on a theory that the blast was the outgrowth of a slaying in 1936. A woman and three men were held for investigation.
Thirty-five fighting ships searched the sea today while 284 planes hunted from the air in an area of 60,000 square miles of the coast here for eight naval fliers lost at sea.

The statement of condition of the Federation Bank and Trust Company as of Dec. 31 last shows resources of $12,891,715, against $12,741,813 on Sept. 30. Deposits were $10,773,649, against $10,634,616, while secured and unsecured loans were $2,260,857, against $2,731,919.

R. Connor, in 399 Park Ave; Warren L. Marks, Daniel Brener, Inc., broker. Marie Kane, in Barbizon Plaza. Simone L. Guiboux, in 415 Central Park West; Lebna Lee, in 522 West End Ave; Alexander Harkavy, in 700 West End Ave; Watson Bennett. Edmund Kohn, Diana Forrest, in 309 W 57th St; Sharp Nassoit Management Corp., broker.

The infant mortality rate is usually regarded by health administrators as an excellent indicator of a community's health. Applying this test, Health Commissioner Rice announces that in this, as in the case of three other causes of death, the best record in the history of the city was attained in 1937.

President Roosevelt conferred with seven Southeastern Governors and was assured of their support of wage and hour legislation in return for his agreement to reexamine the Southern Railroad freight rate structure and

Formation of Consumers Foundation, Inc., a non-profit organization "to promote the consumer interest, with special attention to the needs of low-income families," was announced yesterday by William Trufant Foster, chairman of the organizing. committee and head of the Pollak Foundation for Economic Research, in an interview at the Hotel Astor.

Capt. Lloyd L. Brown. Inf.-Res., 300 south Main St.. Brockport. N. Y., is relieved from assignment to the 1st Division. Each of the following Reserve officers is relieved from his present assignment and is assigned to the lst Division:
Admiral Nobumasa Suetsugu's attack on white domination of the colored peoples was again the subject of a statement by the Foreign Office spokesman today.
Continuing its investigation of the Pennroad Corporation, the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce today called Edsel Ford, president of the Ford Motor Company,

The Rev. Dr. Harry L. Bowlby, general secretary of the Lord's Day Alliance of the United States, will lead a campaign to raise $250,000 in conjunction with the celebration of the Golden Jubilee of the organization. The fund will be used

According to the Grazer Tagespost, there are new aigns of hatred of foreigners in Yugoslavia. Following the expulsion of Hubert Harrison, correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES and Reuters News Agency, Austrians and Germans have been the objects of police attention.

Predicting that the depression so far as production of consumer goods was concerned would be over by March or April, General Robert E. Wood, president of Sears, Roebuck Co., told the Senate Committee on Relief and Unemployment today that his company had decided to "take a licking" and reduce, by an average of 12 per cent, the price of goods produced at higher costs last Fall.
Even though the Theatre Guild's "Wine of Choice" may still be up in the air-and it appears more up in the air than ever-the Guild Theatre, itself, is about to have a tenant.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As editors and journalists who have been following the dispatches of Herbert L. Matthews with admiration for the brilliance with which he has been handling an extremely difficult reporting job, we were distressed by the remarks of Professor Joseph Thorning
Rudolph Seidler, 55 years old, postmaster of Woodcliff Lake, in Bergen County, is in a serious condition at Hackensack Hospital here as the result of a wound in the right temple.

Speaker William B. Bankhead has a new fraternal affiliation. Under Resolution 7,777, introduced by the House parliamentarian, Lewis Deschler, at a turkey luncheon given by the Speaker to members of his office staff, he was elected "master of the honorable order of turkey carvers."
A generally cheerful tone prevailed today on the stock markets here and most sections advanced. Gilt-edge issues improved, but among the foreign loans Far Eastern issues lost ground.

The beating up of British police officers by Japanese soldiers at the frontier of the International Settlement in Shanghai today strengthens the growing feeling in the Foreign Office that President Roosevelt took the right line when he requested

James J. Munro, judge advocate of the Woodhaven, Queens, Post of the Catholic War Veterans, was elected State Commander last night at the closing session of the first State convention of the veterans, held at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn. Mr. Munro served as a captain
A move to release doughnut dunkers from social exile was reported today by the National Inventors' Congress.

Cold weather continues to grip the Balkans. The channel between the islands and the Dalmatian coast is partly frozen--an occurrence without parallel in twenty-five years-while storms have damaged shipping and railroads in the interior are blocked by snowdrifts.

Boxing followers and the critics with whom he worked side by side for so many years paid tribute to the memory of Edward J. Neil Jr., Associated Press war correspondent recently killed in Spain, at Madison Square Garden last night.

101st St, 304 E; Renee Stewart to 1,027 Tiffany St Corp, 448 W 22d St. Madison Ave, 279-293; Murray Hill-Building Co to George McCarroll, 1 Brookdale Ave, New Rochelle, N. Y. (50c). Same property; Ge6rge McCarroll to Murray Hill Building Co, 285 Madison Ave (50c).

The estate of Eugenie Cederholm, who mysteriously disappeared from her home at 338 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn, sometime in 1927 after withdrawing $800 from a bank, has a gross value of $26,274, according to a transfer tax appraisal report filed yesterday in the Surrogate's Court in Brooklyn.
The Chrysler Corporation announced tonight that its automobile plants would reopen Tuesday, returning to work the 55,000 employes who were working when the holiday shutdown began Dec. 23.

Friedrich Wolfgang Adler, secretary of the Labor and Socialist International (Second International) and famous for his role in the World War. today was sentenced to four months' imprisonment for use of a false passport.
Vance L. Bushnell has been appointed second vice president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society in the agency and group departments.
Four Yale students were injured tonight, two critically, as an automobile left a State highway at a curve, skidded 150 feet across a snow-covered field and crashed into the Hockanum River.

Joseph A. Maynard, personal friend of President Roosevelt, collector of the port of Boston and a leading figure for years in the Democratic party here, died of angina pectoris in his home late today. He was 63 years old.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: The current ballyhoo about Sammy Baugh must be slightly confusing to any one who has followed sports for more than ten years. Most sports writers are calling him the greatest forward passer of all time.

At a time when closer cooperation between Government and business is one of the great needs of the hour, Assistant Attorney General Jackson has come forward with a program which he believes should furnish "a common objective." He suggests that the goal of both Government and business should be to achieve
America's designers of pleasure boats unveiled their shiny, white 1938 wares with their gray and buffcolored decks last night before upward of 20,000 spectators who suddenly became ambitious.

Spurred on by prospects of heavy foreign competition, America's track and field athletes may set an even faster pace in 1938 than they did a year ago, when seven world's records were broken by United States standard-bearers.
Forty-five contributions added $468.20 to the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday, and brought the total received in the twenty-sixth annual appeal to $298,001.22.

In the face of widespread reports of business recessions during the month, the Lincoln Motor Company today announced that retail sales of Lincoln-Zephyr cars in December were greater than in December, 1936, when business was forging ahead and production on this car had been doubled.
Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick announced yesterday the appointment of Lewis F. Lang as an assistant deputy controller and Seymour Graubard as law secretary.

Soon after the value of shares of stock began to decline in September, foreign holders of United States domestic securities began selling to the extent that sales resulted in a net movement of capital out of this country amounting to $4,767,000 in

To take effect 8 A. M., Jan. 8. From office of the Second Deputy Police Commissioner to office of Fourth Deputy Police Commissioner, Division of Licenses: DEPUTY INSPECTOR Thomas F. Berkety. ACTING CAPTAIN Benjamin J. King assignment in charge of Investigating Squad continued.
John Laurence Keller, retired Jersey City attorney, of 269 Roseland Avenue, this borough, fell from his bedroom window this morning and was found dead on the lawn of his residence. The county medical
New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $12,

A scathing attack upon the city administration and the Board of Transportation for their failure. to grant real collective bargaining rights to the 5,400 employes of the Independent Subway System was made yesterday by the Transport Workers Union, C. I. 0. affiliate,

The War Department announced today the death yesterday in Walter Reed General Hospital of Colonel George H. Penrose, retired. His age was 76. He was born at Whitehall, N. Y., June 4, 1861, and was graduated from the University of Buffalo, where he received his M. D. degree in 1886.

Bartholomew B. Coyne, attorney, with offices at 270 Broadway, New York, through whose efforts Harry K. Thaw was declared competent and released from a Philadelphia asylum in 1924, died last night of a heart attack in his home here. He was 58 years old.

Eduardo Suarez, Minister of Finance, reached here by airplane at noon today and conferred immediately with President Lazaro Cardenas on the results of the former's trip to Washington and New York regarding silver and petroleum and the attitude of the United States thereon.

A waterfront parcel at Far Rockaway, L. I., was reported yesterday to have passed into new ownership. The property consists of ten brick and stucco one-family houses, a two-story stucco casino with private parking space, and a dock, boathouse and float, as well as a bathing beach, all situated within a plot 500 by 100 feet on the east blockfront of Beach Fifth Street, facing the ocean and Sea Girt Avenue.

Although Lightnin' Norton of Southern Methodist scored 19 points, Temple University had no trouble defeating the Southwest Conference champions, 53-41, in the second game of a double-header before 5,700 fans at the Arena tonight.

A grand jury will be convened at Bridgeport within two weeks to consider primarily the purchases of land by the State Highway Department for the thirty-two miles of Merritt Parkway across Fairfield County from the New York State line.

A call for reports from State banks, trust companies, industrial banks and private bankers was issued today by William R. White, State Superintendent of Banks. The reports, to be made as of Dec. 31, are due within ten days.

The Duke of Windsor, David Lloyd George, Britain's wartime Prime Minister, and Winston Churchill, former British Cabinet Minister, dined together tonight as guests of Maxine Elliott, former American actress.

Mrs. William Hale Harkness Jr., a New York dress designer turned animal collector, brought her second live baby giant panda from the wilds of West China to Hankow Thursday afternoon. Mrs. Harkness arrived here during a Japanese air raid.

The following message was received last night by THE NEW YORK TIMES from President Jorge Ubico of Guatemala: "The President of Guatemala, General Jorge Ubico, categorically denies the news published by the press regarding disturbances in Guatemala.
Influenced by a sharp rise in Indian cotton in Bombay, prices on the Cotton Exchange here moved into new high ground again yesterday. March sold above the 8 1/2 cent

The ominous red placards which appear over all the city when the guillotine has done its work again announced today three more Germans had been executed. They were charged with treason against the State.
Max Schmeling set up training headquarters today for his bout in Berlin Jan. 30 with Ben Foord, former British Empire heavyweight champion.

Three armed bandits held up Peter Casazza, Charles Reali and H. W. Meacham, employes and relatives of Charles Casazza, owner of a liquor store at 1,868 Eightysixth Street, Brooklyn, just as they were about to close the store last and two customers who entered during the hold-up into a wash room, escaped with between $300 and $400.

Rutgers University receives $791,880 from the estate of James Neilson, according to an appraisal filed in Surrogate's Court here today. The amount is the residuary from a gross estate of $935,476 and a net estate of $907,127.

While Mayor La Guardia and his advisers pinned their faith yesterday on the hope that the courts would hold that the 1938 budget would automatically become legal if the Council failed to act on it by Jan. 25, the Democrats controlling thirteen of the Council's twenty-six votes said they would not relinquish their argument that the budget adopted last year was actually the budget for 1938.

The Chase National Bank of New York today brought a $5,000,000 suit in Suffolk County Court against the PrivatBank Aktien Gesellschaft of the Republic of Germany to recover the balance of what is alleged to be a defaulted $4,000,000 loan.

In the Supreme Court of the United States today the following proceedings were had: 397-Duke Power Co. and Southern Public Utilities Co., petrs., v. Greenwood County, et al. Mandate ordered to issue forthwith on motion for the respondents.

Hope St. Clair, New York dancer, and Harry Weiner, her orchestraleader husband, were admitted to probation today by Justice Joseph W. Cox of Federal District Court after pleading guilty to a charge of obtaining a passport by means of an untrue affidavit.

A large housing property in the West Bronx changed hands with the announcement yesterday of the sale of a block front in the Riverdale section. The deal involved Oxford House, an apartment building at 3,656 Johnson Avenue, occupying the block from Oxford Avenue to West 238th Street.
Taxpayers who are receiving their water bills have made numerous inquiries in the last few days to learn why the bills were made out at the old rates, it became known yesterday.

Interior Minister Marx Dormoy today decreed the banning of the Italian newspapers Stamp and Gazetta del Popolo from French territory. The decree, effective today, concerns their "circulation, sale and distribution."

Arnold Bernstein, Jewish shipping magnate, was sentenced to two and a half years in the penitentiary and a fine of 1,000,000 marks today on exchange law charges. If he does not pay the fine fully, he must spend an extra year in the penitentiary, but one year of the sentence is canceled by the period he has been imprisoned since his arrest in January, 1937.
Lafayette triumphed over Albright, 4039, tonight in an exciting game in which Burgess's foul goal in the last eighteen seconds won for the Leopards. Lafayette held a 20-16 edge at half time.
Paul R. Mahony, an authority on foreign trade, died on Thursday of enteric fever in Bombay, India, according to word received here yesterday. He was 61 years old.
German newspaper attacks on Chancellor Schuschnigg and general Austrian politics will be answered in tomorrow's edition of the official Wiener Zeitung.

The magic charm of Trainer Hirsch Jacobs and the powerful riding of Eddie Arcaro again proved an unbeatable combination when Stocks drove up on the outside to gain a photo decision over Paul Codd's Pageboy in the featured Pahokee Purse at Tropical Park today.

Led by John S. Harrison of the Squash Club, four seeded contestants participated in second-round matches last evening in the Union League Club invitation Class B squash racquets tourney and scored victories to enter the quarter-finals.
GIANNI SCHICCHI-Opera in one act in English. Music by Giacomo Puccini; book by Gioachino Forzando. Conductor, Gennaro Papi; stage director, Desire Defrere. Presented at the Metropolitan Opera House.
Benny Leonard, the former lightweight boxing champion, emerged a winner yesterday afternoon in West Side Court. But he won by a decision instead of a knockout.
Among dividend authorizations of $945,100 approved by J. F. T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, in the week ended yesterday, was one affecting the First National Bank of Waverly, N. Y.
Paul Derringer, Cincinnati pitcher, said today he would ask the Reds to trade him to some other club.
Unemployment continued to decline up to last Autumn almost everywhere in the world for the fourth successive year, according to the quarterly figures of the International Labor Office just published.

Dorothy Dayton Jones of The New York Sun staff, one of the best-known women reporters in the city, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital while being given a blood transfusion following an abdominal operation from which she had failed to rally.
Miss Frances M. Curtis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund de Forest Curtis of Villanova, was introduced tonight at a dinner-dance given by her parents at the St. Davids Golf Club.

Over the protests of Miss Jane Daniels of 655 East Eighty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, Magistrate Pinto in the Pennsylvania Avenue Court, Brooklyn, yesterday named a committee of three to visit her home and determine the truth of a charge that she is harboring at least twenty dogs, to the detriment of the neighborhood.

Miss Jane Buckman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Hibbs Buckman of the Orchard, Langhorne, was married this afternoon to Carter Hoodless, son of Mrs. Charles R. Hoodless of Overbrook, and brother of Mrs. George McBrest of New York.

A critical situation in the affairs of United Artists loomed today when it was learned that Samuel Goldwyn, on his return from a Hawaiian vacation upon which he embarks tomorrow, may continue to London, an act that means virtual suspension of United Artists production in Hollywood.

D. F. Kelly, State Street merchant for almost fifty years, will retire as president of The Fair at the annual meeting of stockholders of the company on April 26. He. will be succeeded by C. S. Maginnis, vice president. William Killian, now a merchandise manager, is expected to be named vice president.

The Interstate Commerce Commission, which previously made public total valuations of Class I railroads in connection with its hearings of the railroads' application for an increase of $500,000,000 in freight rates, made public today a breakdown of the valuations by individual railroads.

CAMPBELL, FREDERICK B. (Dec. 26). Estate, more than $50,000. To The Presbyterian Board for Ministerial Relief and Sustentation, Witherspoon Bldg., Philadelphia, Pa., $2,500; Alfred Olsson, 114 Field PI., Bronx, Fanny H. R. Brockington, Box 113, Longwood, Fla., Elise Rosselet, same address, $2,000 each; Hedwig...
The first order granting temporary relief from established minimum coal prices was announced today by the Bituminous Coal Commission in favor of the Providence Gas Company of Providence, R. I.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The volume of business in wool has lessened this week, although prices have been fairly well maintained throughout the list on spot wools. A considerable quantity
Valentine Co., paint and varnish manufacturers, have leased 10,000 square feet of space in the Haviland Building at 11 East Thirty-sixth Street.
The American Olympic Committee cleared the decks for its important organization meeting at the New York Athletic Club today by releasing yesterday the personnel of ten more games committees.

Dr. Tyler Dennett, former president of Williams College and chief of the division of publications and editor of the Department of State, and Sheldon Cheney, author of books dealing with the various arts, have been appointed honorary fellows of Union College.
" The Spectre" has been decided upon as the English title of Maxim Gorki's last novel, according to an announcement from the office of Appleton-Century, who will publish the book this Spring.

An amendment has been filed by the Consolidated Edison Company of New York to its registration state* ment under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $30,000,000 of twentyyear 3 1/2 per cent debentures due in 1958, giving underwriters and allotments as follows:

Another of the thirty-nine persons indicted for grand larceny and conspiracy to defraud in connection with the $2,000,000 Long Island real estate swindle recently uncovered by Attorney General Bennett was arrested yesterday.

Miss Theresa Helburn, director of the Bureau of New Plays, sponsored by motion picture concerns in an effort to uncover new writing talent, accused the Dramatists Guild yesterday of "deliberately misinterpreting or distorting the functions of the bureau, which is not a producing organization and has no intention of becoming one.

Federal Judge Thomas W. Slick today ordered the Auburn Automobile Company, as debtor corporation, to continue to retain possession of all its properties. The order was issued at the close of a hearing on a petition by the company to reorganize under Section 77B of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

Factory sales of American motor vehicles in 1937 are estimated at 5,002,188 cars and trucks by the Automotive Manufacturers Association, surpassing the 5,000,000 mark for the second time in history, exceeded only by 5,621,715 cars and trucks sold in 1929. Sales in 1936 were 4,616,274 units.

In connection with the announcement of "Intention to negotiate" a trade agreement with Great Britain, Secretary Hull issued tonight more than 1,000 products on which the United States will consider granting concessions to the United Kingdom, Newfoundland and the British Colonial Empire.

A large number of colonists attended the first dinner of the season at the Beach Club tonight. In Dr. Edmund Le Roy Dow's party were Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Cudahy, Dr. and Mrs. Daniel J. McCarthy, Mr. and Mrs. Alfred G. Kay, Mrs. Lorenzo E. Woodhouse, Mrs. Theodore Frelinghuysen and Howland Spencer. Mr. and Mrs. Guernsey

After dropping seven straight games, St. Peter's College conquered the Montclair Teachers in a free-scoring contest tonight, 46 to 43. The victors held a lead of 20 to 17 at half-time. Jack Woods featured for St. Peter's with 13 points.
Miss Alice J. Greenway, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Greenway of this city, was married tonight to G. Milton Treadgill, son of Mrs. G. T. Treadgill of Selma, Ala., and the late Mr. Treadgill.
C. E. Denney, president of the Erie Railroad, was reported yesterday to be conferring with bankers here relative to the situation caused by the failure of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway, which controls

Formal announcement of the United States' intention to negotiate a trade agreement with Great Britain was published in morning papers today, but owing to the late hour when Washington dispatches were made public official comment was not immediately forthcoming.

A wholesale grocery company has purchased from the Fulton Bag and Cotton Mills the industrial property at the northwest corner of South First Street and Mythe Avenue, Brooklyn, consisting of an eightstory building and a sixteen-story warehouse adjoining.

The Hollywood Restaurant, 1,600 Broadway, at Forty-eighth Street, one of the first of the more lavish Broadway cabarets, failed to open last night. The Hollywood filed a bankruptcy petition Dec. 26 and, according to Joseph H. Moss, treasurer of the A. S. Restaurants, Inc., the concern operating the place, it "could not go on under the reorganization." About 150 persons lose jobs.
It was officially announced today that no German girl will be admitted to a university until she has served at least twenty-six weeks in the Women's Labor Service or an equivalent organization.
Lawrence Properties announced yesterday that it had bought back one of its former holdings in Lawrence Park, Bronxville, N. Y., after almost fifty years.
Scoring victories on their home courts, the Crescent A. C. and Harvard Club teams last night remained deadlocked for the lead in the Metropolitan League Class C interclub squash tennis competition.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York announced yesterday several promotions of staff members. Norman P. Davis, who has been employed in the division of security loans, was made manager of the security loans department.
The new track season will open tonight when the Columbus Council, K. of C., presents its twelfth annual games at the old Thirteenth Regiment Armory in Brooklyn with a banner card.
The Pratt Institute basketball team downed Dickinson, 45 to 42, on the victors' court in Brooklyn last night. Dick Sherlock tallied 12 points for Pratt, which led, 23 to 16, at the intermission.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reelected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers.

One of the notable factors in the present condition of business in the United States has been the completion or inauguration in 1937 of one of the most widespread eras of construction of new plants that the country ever has seen.

One of the game's veteran professionals, 44-year-old Jack Summers, coach at M. I. T., won the first open invitation tournament held under the auspices of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association when he captured a final round match that lasted only twenty-five minutes at the Downtown A. C. courts yesterday.
Tropical rains threatened today to hinder the rescue of J. T. Waldeck, American explorer, stranded on a rock in the Cuyuni River with his wife and two other men.

Wages and hours legislation, one of the chief features of the Administration's legislative program, seemed to be assured of passage by the present Congress today when President Roosevelt prevailed on the Governors of seven Southeastern States to endorse the measure in return for an understanding of a re-examination of the Southern freight-rate structure and inclusion of a North-South wage differential in whatever labor standards measure is enacted.

Growing opposition was revealed today in both House and Senate to the Administration proposal for creation of a separate commercial aviation commission, with powers similar in some respects to those of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Mao Tse-tung, chairman of the former Chinese Soviet Government, is joining discussions of government officials here on the role-of Communist civil and military leaders in the Central Government and on the general problem of Chinese tactics against Japanese troops in North China areas.
Firm but just is Dr. Joseph K. Van Denburg's position on the subject of the New York dialect. He is the chairman of the Board of

William Loewenstein, who with his brother, Hermann, established the leather importing and exporting firm of Hermann Loewenstein, 26 Ferry Street, forty-five years ago, died yesterday at the Harkness Pavilion of the Medical Center after an illness of seven months. He was 63 years old.

In the last year 5,180 elementary school pupils were changed from slow to normal readers through special techniques prepared by the WPA remedial reading project, Dr. Benjamin B. Greenberg, assistant superintendent, announced yesterday in making public the annual report of this project.

Political onlookers, including many perplexed rank-and-file Democrats in Congress, are awaiting the Administration symposium at thirty-odd Jackson Day dinners tomorrow night for fresh light on President Roosevelt's attitude toward business.

Miss Virginia Catharine, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Catharine of this place, was married this evening to John J. Mueller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Mueller of Montclair, N. J., in the Huguenot Memorial Church here. The Rev. Dr. Willard Soper, the pastor, performed the ceremony.
A new form of store-window advertising for use by bars and taverns will make its appearance shortly in 1,000 such establishments, it was learned here yesterday.
The year-book of the League of Nations on balances of payments, out today, estimates the world's total long-term foreign indebtedness at $35,000,000,000 on the old gold basis at the end of 1936.
Jonkheer H. M. van Haersma de With, the Netherland Minister, Mrs. van Haersma de With and their daughter, Miss Nora van Haersma de With, have come from Washington and are at the Ritz-Carlton.

Philip King, one of Princeton University's greatest athletes and said to have been that university's first paid athletic coach, died today at Emergency Hospital after an operation for an abdominal ailment. He was 65 years old.
Completion of organization-of the Society of Certified Commission Resident Buyers was announced yesterday by Frank Mondshein of the Frank Buying Service, chairman of the board.
The Hofstra College women's basketball team won its second straight game by defeating New York University, 16-13, on the losers' court yesterday.

Mr. Jeremiah T. Mahoney, an insurgent within Tammany, was doubtless prevented last Fall by perturbation over what would happen to the city if he wasn't elected Mayor from uttering his sincere opinion of that ancient philanthropic society.

A feature of the store executives' session of the Mutual Buying Syndicate, to be held next Wednesday, will be a luncheon tendered by Grover Whalen, president of the New York World's Fair of 1989, at the Administration Building on the fair site. A preview of the "World

The $581,285,158 United Corporation, which holds investments ranging from 2 to 26 per cent in the most strongly entrenched utility systems operating in the East, will register with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935, it was learned yesterday.
Changes in the prison wards at Fordham Hospital, the Bronx, were recommended today in an inspection report issued by the State Commission of Correction.

John D. Rockefeller Jr. has become the owner of the old Rockwood Hall Country Club of North Tarrytown, adding it to his large holdings in that village, it was disclosed today when the report of a referee in foreclosure was filed in Supreme Court-here.

The League of Nations got new evidence today of how total totalitarian policy is when Italian pressure forced Carlo, the League's very popular bartender, to renounce his concession because of Italian withdrawal from Geneva.

The colonial dwelling at 71 Brookdale Avenue, New Rochelle, has been sold by Robert Goldman to Morgan Walker. The house contains nine rooms and three baths, and occupies a quarter-acre plot. It is said to have been held at $15,000. H. E. Colwell Sons, Inc., was the broker.

Expenditures during the next fiscal year for river and harbor projects amounting to $100,758,124 for new work, with maintenance fixed at $46,692,585, and a total for exclusive flood control projects of $127,838,810 and maintenance of $5,800 were recommended in the annual report of the chief of army engineers, made today.

William O. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, addressed a dinner meeting at the Hartford Club here this evening of 300 brokers, bankers, institutional purchasers of securities, insurance

The Rev. and Mrs. James E. Gregg of First Church parsonage, Waterbury, Conn., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elise Pumpelly Gregg, to Dr. Emir Allen Gaw of Columbus, Ohio.
Amid academic solemnity and student enthusiasm, McGill University installed today as principal Dr. Lewis W. Douglas, the first citizen of the United States to hold the office.
Kenneth Clinton Walford, a municipal bond trader associated with Kean, Taylor Co., died yesterday at his home, 295 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn, at the age of 38.

New York's virulent attack of surrealism last season isn't likely to be repeated. The subconscious within us (or should it be called the unconscious?) has been churned up only now and then since the memorable exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art. But surrealism,

Cotton-mill activity receded last week. The daily average showed a more than seasonal decline, and the adjusted index fell to 76.4 from 83.7. This is the lowest point touched in more than three years. The figure for the week ended Jan. 2, 1937, was 149.8.

Ralph Greenleaf, pocket billiard champion, twice vanquished Andrew Ponzi, former titleholder, at the Strand Academy yesterday. Greenleaf scored 125 to 58 in eleven innings and 125 to 63 in fifteen frames.
Exchange of checks at the principal clearing houses of the country in 1937 amounted to $333,257,707,239, a gain of 1.9 per cent over the total in 1936, and the largest for a twelvemonth since 1931.

A 42-year-old Bronx dairyman told Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson and a jury yesterday that at a time when his health was so good he could toss 62-pound butter tubs from his truck and lift them into an ice box, he had simulated heart disease so successfully that he was entered as a cardiac case at Sydenham Hospital.
Two gifts to the Commonwealth Fund totaling $8,000,000 by Edward S. Harkness, its president, were revealed yesterday in the annual report of the organization for 1937.
Trailers are becoming increasingly popular and motor cycles are on the wane, according to vehicular statistics for 1937 released yesterday by Michael B. McHugh, County Clerk of the Bronx.

The culttral section of the Canadian Labor Circle, a Jewish fraternal organizazation, and the homes of the president and secretary of the Amalgamated Association of Iron, Steel and Tin Workers, a C. I. 0. affiliate, have been raided by provincial police under the Quebec padlock law.

A suit against the city for $10,050 has been filed in Brooklyn Supreme Court by two fishermen who say that they were unjustly deprived of the proceeds of a "dead whale auction" because city officials ruled that the mammal's body was a health menace.
If there was any lingering doubt that Fred Apostoli, sturdy son of San Francisco, was the best middleweight in America, if not the world, it was dispelled last night in Madison Square Garden.

We had lunch with some ardent anglers yesterday, and by the time the coffee arrived the conversation had covered just about every sport fishing port in Southern waters, with a few side trips to Bermuda and the Pacific.

There was no change with the turn of year in the character or volume of new bond financing and this week brought forth a total of $8,457,000 in new loans, all of which consisted of tax-exempt obligations.
Bryan M. (Bitsy) Grant, Atlanta's mighty tennis mite, reached the Miami Biltmore tournament final today with a fourset marathon victory over Elwood Cooke of Portland, Ore. Grant's.

Shipments of zinc in December amounted to 29,545 tons, compared to 32,676 in November and 59,512 in December, 1936, according to the American Zinc Institute. Production amounted to 51,787 tons, against 49,393 in November and 46,940 in December, 1936. At the end

President Roosevelt, answering a question, suggested today that the newspapers and magazines of the country act to end the "subsidy" which he said they were receiving from the government in the form of second-class mail rates that did not meet the cost of the service.
Raymond Guest, just ending his first year in the office, was again elected president of the United Hunts Racing Association at the annual meeting of that organization yesterday.

Trading generally fair to good. Steer hinds and ribs were weak to slightly lower; lamb steady to lower; veal and calf higher; fresh pork steady. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef to be steady to slightly higher; veal and calf about steady; lamb barely steady with the week's full decline, as reported by the United States Department nf Agriculture.

Captain Charles S. Morris, hero of the steamship Lenape rescue in 1925, New York died here last night while celebrating his golden wedding anniversary. One of the last of the Delaware Bay and river pilots who learned navigation under sail, Captain Morris was 76.

ERIC LINKLATER'S latest buffoon is an amiable, roving tar who finds that you have to leave the celebrated seven seas behind to discover a life of incredible adventure. His new book* is a hilarious odyssey-weren't we speaking of odysseys only yesterday?-through the defenseless English countryside, inadvertently taken by a sentimental young mariner.

The important place which real estate has assumed in the affairs of financial institutions is illustrated by the frequent reference to this form of investment in the annual report of William R. White, Superintendent of Banks, presented this week to Governor Lehman and the State Legislature.
District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey will swear in the officers of the Police Square Club, a Masonic organization, at its annual dinner and dance in the Hotel Astor next Wednesday.

The House leadership mustered all its strength today to defeat the Ludlow resolution in a test vote Monday. The resolution would require a national referendum under some conditions before war was declared.

Joe Louis is taking no chances with his title. The Brown Panther, whose heavyweight crown will be in jeopardy when he enters the ring at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 23 against Nathan Mann, already is looking to his training for the match.
Net assets of the General American Investors Company, Inc., on Dec. 31 amounted to $24,727,698, according to a report issued yesterday. This was equivalent to

C. C. Trueb, assistant general passenger agent of the Pennsylvania Railroad, was elected president of the General Eastern Passenger Agents Association at the annual election in the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.
Members of the executive committee of the National Association of Credit Men in a poll conducted today predicted business this year would be 80 per cent as good as in 1937.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that John L. Cronan of Southboro, Mass., has withdrawn his registration as an over-the-counter broker and dealer and that the commission accordingly had terminated proceedings authorized on Oct. 6 on the question

Members of the New York Stock Exchange were warned by its management yesterday that a contest had arisen in the Celotex Corporation and that, accordingly, they might not give proxies on shares which they held for others without specific instructions.

An appeal for used clothing for men, women and children, and for blankets, has been issued by the Social Service and Tuberculosis Committee of Gouverneur Hospital, through Mrs. George W. Welsh, chairman. In her appeal Mrs.

The marriage of Miss Louise Weld Chase, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Minturn Chase of New Rochelle, N. Y., to John Ireland Howe Baur of this city, son of Mrs. John H. Johnston of Hadlyme, Conn., and of Professor Paul V. C. Baur of New Haven, took place here yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

Taxes paid by employers under the old-age benefit and unemployment insurance titles of the Federal Social Security Act are deductible from income tax payments, Joseph T. Higgins, Collector of Internal Revenue for the Third New York District, announced yesterday.

A message prepared by President Roosevelt as "America's No. 1 stamp collector" will be read by Postmaster General James A. Farley over the NBC-Red network in the RCA Building here late this afternoon, starting a series of weekly broadcasts under the title "Calling All Stamp Collectors."
Miss Mary Isabel Doolittle, member of a family long prominent in Utica, died last night at the home of her brother, Major Julius T. A. Doolittle. She had devoted much of her time to charity.

The second session of the auction of the V. Everit Macy art collection at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., brought $18,595 yesterday afternoon, making the total for the first two sessions $33,595. The sale will end this
Permission to form a chapter of the American Student Union was refused to women students at the University of Rochester today by President Valentine.

Consummation of a reorganization plan authorized by a court order issued Dec. 17, 1937, under which the twenty-two-story Rittenhouse Plaza apartment house, Nineteenth and Walnut Streets, Philadelphia, is transferred to a new corporation was announced yesterday by Albert M. Greenfield Co., Inc., managing agents of the building.

Mayor La Guardia will conduct a forum on "Social Problems in New York City" as a part of the thirtieth anniversary meeting of the Protestant Home Missions Council and the Council of Women for Home' Missions on Tuesday at 3 P. M. in the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church,

The leading producers yesterday advanced the price of lead 10 points in the domestic market. The new price of the American Smelting and Refining Company at New York is 4.85 cents a pound and that of the St. Joseph Lead Company is 4.90 cents here and 4.70 cents at East St. Louis.

The raising of the fund for the endowment of the chair of classics at Princeton is due primarily to the great esteem and affection in which Dean West is so widely held, not only in the United States but in the wider world of letters. He has a visible monument
Market closed lower in quiet trading; turnover, 1,052,720 shares. Bonds irregular; Erie Railroad issues weakened; transactions, $6,988,950.
Weehawken St, 3-5, 44x61.10xirreg; Martin Larson to R. S. Improvement Corp, 271 Madison Ave; p m mtg, pr mtg $37,500, five years. 5 per cent: $4,000.

Fourth-round play in the Metropolitan Badminton Association's men's Class B team tournament this week was marked by the shutout triumphs scored by International House, Downtown. Athletic Club and Yonkers. Other victors were Old Sixty-ninth and Highland.

A hearing has been called for Feb. 2 by the Securities and Exchange Commission on an application by Teck Hughes Gold Mines, Ltd., to withdraw from registration and listing its $1 par value common stock on the New York Curb Exchange.
The Eastern Intercollegiate Association held its annual meeting at the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday and re-elected its slate of officers for another year.

A passenger airplane will take off from here today for Cuzco and will fly from there to Maldonado to blaze a new sky trail over the wilderness regions of the Department of Madre de Dios and thus bring another, remote city within a few hours' flight from Lima.
Owen L. Coon, president of the General Finance Corporatipn of Detroit, in releasing yesterday its annual report said it showed the company's best year of business.

When the NonIntervention Committee meets again Tuesday after the Christmas recess, it will consider a new plan for the withdrawal of foreign "volunteers" from Spain that, according to The London Daily Telegraph, will cost about [Pound]400,000.
Ely K. Selig, clothing manufacturer, died today in his apartments in the RitzCarlton after an illness of a few weeks of a heart ailment.

Charles M. Schmidt, 53 years old, a photo-engraver for THE NEW YORK TIMES, died at 9:15 A. M. yesterday at the Medical Center, where he had been taken several hours earlier from his home, 2,264 Davidson Avenue, the Bronx. Mr.

Fifteen hundred persons, most of them employed on the WPA arts projects, meeting yesterday afternoon under the auspices of the Arts Unions Conference at the Hotel Center, 108 .West Forty-third Street, adopted resolutions urging a 10 per cent increase in employment on the

With their spirits high despite the unfavorable weather in the metropolitan area, 300 skiers departed last night from Grand Central Terminal on three snow trains to spend the week-end testing their "snow ploughs" and "Christianias" on the open slopes and
The Supreme Court acted today to permit Greenwood County, S. C., to begin work at once on its Buzzard Roost power plant.
The St. Joseph Lead Company announced today that its operations at five plants in Missouri would be curtailed, effective Monday, because of reduced demand for lead.
Major Alfred J. Stofer, former newspaper correspondent and second oldest member of the Gridiron Club in point of service, died in his sleep last night. He would have been 82 years old next May.
The Atlantic City Sea Gulls went into a tie with the New York Rovers for first place in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League by tying the Hershey Bears, 1-1, in an overtime battle tonight.
Senator Borah told the Senate today that the Wagner-Van Nuys Anti-Lynching Bill was a compromise with the "vital principles of our dual system of government."

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Jan. 5: CAPTAINS Carter, W. R., the Marblehead, to instruction Naval War College, Newport, R. I. Green, B. H., the Vincennes, to Iona Island, N. Y., as Inspector of Ordnance in Charge, Naval Ammunition Depot.

Professor Edward Charles Cyril Baly, of the Department of Inorganic Chemistry, University of Liverpool, told a distinguished gathering of scientists from Great Britain and India here today that he had succeeded after more than twenty years of research in duplicating nature's fundamental process whereby plants are able to utilize sunlight in making sugars and starches out of water vapor and carbon dioxide in the air.

A $10,000 payroll was taken from the safe of the Koh-I-Noor Company, 47-52 Twenty-seventh Street, Long Island City, yesterday afternoon by two armed men, who forced the company paymaster and eight employes to line up with faces to the wall in a second-floor office.

Representatives of 600 A. F. of L. unions received yesterday official assurance that wage-earners in this State would not be penalized for an employer's failure to pay taxes or file wage reports under the Social Security Act or the State Unemployment Insurance Law.
For the first time since the World War, France granted Germany permission today to establish a consulate in Eastern France, near the recovered provinces of Alsace and Lorraine.

John C. Kelley, who was public prosecutor in the Massie case of 1932, died here today of heart disease. His age was 51. Mr. Kelley, whose brother, Cornelius, is president of Anaconda Copper Company, was taken to a hospital Dec. 26.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward E. Weadock entertained last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza for their niece, Miss Jane Weadock, and John T. D. Spence, whose marriage will take place on Tuesday at Mayfair House.
Major Gen. A. P. D. Telfer-Smollett, commanding British troops at Shanghai, protested yesterday against an attack by Japanese soldiers on two British officers of the Shanghai Municipal Police.

Another in the series of "natural science evenings" in the interests of the ten-year development program of the American Museum of Natural History took place last night at the Museum. Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Watson were hosts for the occasion.

A considerable decline in the number of vehicles using the Lincoln Tunnel between New York and Weehawken was indicated by figures obtained yesterday from the Port of New York Authority. The totals for the last seven days follow:

Jeremiah T. Mahoney, recent Democratic Mayoralty candidate, continued yesterday his attack on Tammany and renewed his demand for a change in name of the Manhattan Democratic organization and for a change in leadership.

A trimotored American Airlines plane, carrying five passengers, a crew of three and 750 pounds of mail, dropped out of a pea soup fog and teeming rain shortly after 3 o'clock this morning to a safe, mudcushioned landing in the Jersey meadows.

A trimotored American Airlines plane, carrying five passengers, a crew of three and 750 pounds of mail, dropped out of a pea soup fog and teeming rain shortly after 3 o'clock this morning to a safe, mudcushioned landing in the Jersey meadows.
The James Monroe and Evander Childs High quintets remained in a deadlock for the lead in the Upper Manhattan-Bronx Division of the P. S. A. L. by recording victories yesterday. It marked the third
Eighteen Mayors in Hautes Alpes Department tendered their resignations today in protest against the shipment of the department's only snowplow to Loyalist Spain.
Pressure against the franc continued strong yesterday as a result of the recent indications of continued government fiscal difficulties and of social unrest.

The marriage of Miss Josephine Catharine Benedict, daughter of Mrs. Henry Harper Benedict of 5 East Seventy-fifth Street and Southampton, L. I., and the late Dr. Benedict, to Dr. James Douglass Sharpe, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Douglass Sharpe, also of this city, took place yesterday at noon in the chantry of St. Thomas Church. The Rev. Dr. Roelif H. Brooks, the rector, performed the ceremony.

Class I railroads employed 1,008,037 persons in December, a decrease of 6.80 per cent from the same month in 1936 and a decline of 4.93 per cent from November, 1937, the Interstate Commerce Commission announced today.

Hamilton College led all the way tonight in defeating the Haverford College basketball team, 48 to 25. The victors' attack, paced by Sophomore Bob Forbush, who garnered 12 points, enabled them repeatedly to break up Haverford's formations.

The ball, the stymie and the Walker Cup team are matters that probably will be discussed or decided at the annual meeting of the United States Golf Association, which is to be held at the WaldorfAstoria today.
