A document described as "Ludendorff's testament" appears in the Ludendorff organ, at the Holy Well of German Power. It is a letter written Nov. 30 when General Ludendorff decided he was about to die. He urged his followers to be true to "the German faith."

Bonds moved irregularly higher in slower trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. More normal conditions were noted in the market for secondary railroad issues, with most of the loans reflecting improvement in sentiment resulting from clarification of the Baltimore Ohio situation.

182d St (11-3112), n e s, 141 ft w of Southern Blvd, 100x81; St. Lawrence- mprovement Co, Inc. to Lillian Most, 123 Elliot PI: mtg $103,950. West Farms Rd (11-3007), w a, at e S of Boone Ave, 101x154' Vyse Boulevard Garage, Inc. to A. D'Angelo Sons, Inc, 3,510 White Plains Ave; mtg S13,500.
Artur Rubinstein, the Polish pianist, made a triumphant return to the local recital platform last night in Carnegie Hall before an audience containing a large number of the city's leading musicians.
Jimmy Thomson and Willie Goggin forged to the front today in the first round of the $5,000 Los Angeles open golf tournament.
Governor Earle today "lifted" for ninety days the driver's license of his 19-year-old son, Hubert. The youth, the Governor's second son, received a summons for speeding in New Jersey on Jan. 2.

Because of the rise of totalitarian States in Europe, the struggle between the church and the State has become so critical as to augur the end of Christianity in its modern concept, the Rev. Dr. Adolf Keller declared yesterday in an address before the monthly luncheon meeting of the Clergy Association of New York at the Aldine Club, 200 Fifth Avenue.

Several parcels of real estate in Flatbush were included in the Brooklyn transactions reported yesterday. The three-story apartment and store building at 1,440 Flatbush Avenue, on a plot 20 by 100 feet, was sold to F. W. Olive, a client of the McInerney-Klinck Realty Company.

Frank J. Martin of MartinHutchinson, Inc., and L. N. Rosenbaum of L. N. Rosenbaum Son were witnesses yesterday at a hearing by the Securities and Exchange Commission on the registration statement of the Puget Sound Distillery, Inc., held before H. Victor Schwimmer, trial examiner, in the New York office of the commission.

The Electrical Manufacturers Association of New York, Inc., paid more than $20,000 in twenty months to Charles A. Eidiitz, acting as impartial chairman for the industry, it was disclosed by testimony given yesterday before John Kirkland Clark, sitting as special master.

Seven indictments returned against Samuel Kendy, 45 years old, a clothing merchant, in December, 1936, in former Assistant District Attorney James J. Wilson's investigation of the so-called municipal garnishee racket, were quashed yesterday by General Sessions Judge Wallace on a motion by Kendy's lawyer.

Bertram Scheuer of this place has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Shirley Rosalind Scheuer, to Ernest Stanley Meyers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Meyers. also of New Rochelle.

Branding communism as a "reversion to a primitive state of society" and the Fascist and Nazi systems as enemies of the "government of law under which individual liberty might flower," William R. Castle, former Under-Secretary of State and United States Ambassador to Japan, addressing a missionary rally last night at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine,

Potatoes, fish and ham today were designated as the principal items of diet for Germans this year by a Food Ministry broadcast. These foods largely will replace bread, butter and other meats which housewives were ordered to use still more sparingly.
BERLIN, Jan. 7.--The buoyant spirit with which 1937 closed was visible in the first week of the new year, which witnessed an active and sharply rising stock market and pronounced firmness in bonds.

John Gruelle, cartoonist and writer, died at his home here today of a heart attack. His age was 57. Survivors include the widow and two sons, Worth and Richard. Mr. Gruelle came here from Norwalk, Conn.

Miss Mary Louise Watters, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Watters of suburban Monkton, was married to Lieutenant Vsevolod Prozenko last night in the Holy Trinity Russian Orthodox Church here by the Rev. Dr. A. Nitikin, the rector.

Twelve hundred pupils of Public School 107, Coward and Croes Avenues, the Bronx, will take part at 2 P. M. Wednesday in a parade to stress the importance of increased safety on the streets, it was announced last night by Uncle Robert. Part of the marchers are to carry banners with the legend "S. O. S." and the explanatory slogan "Stay on Sidewalk."

Invistation have been issued by the Benedicts for their annual ball, to be held at the Elizabeth Town and Country Club on Jan. 28. Patronesses will be Mrs. Horace K. Corbin, Mrs. N. Hillyer Egleston, Mrs. Marion B. Hopkins, Mrs. Richard Krementz, Mrs. Allen F. Myers and Mrs. Frank F. Mountcastle.

A large audience is expected to attend a recital by Lotte Lehmann and Lauritz Melchior of the Metropolitan Opera tomorrow night at Carnegie Hall in aid of the educational department of the Women's Trade Union League.
The Daily Herald today published an interview with King Carol of Rumania in which the monarch declared that the new Goga Ministry is "my government."

Dr. Frank Baldwin Jewett of Brantwood, Short Hills, N. J., an expert in the field of telephone engineering, has been chosen to receive the Washing Award for 1938. L. S. Keith, secretary of the Washington Award Commission,

While the Senate continues consideration of the Wagner-Gavagan Anti-Lynching Bill, with the end of the filibuster which began last week Thursday not yet in sight, the House will lay aside other matters tomorrow to decide whether the Ludlow resolution shall be discharged from committee.

The week's stock market here opened with a sharp advance and remained firm and at times strong, except for Thursday. The upward movement began with bull operations in General Electricity shares on talk of a coming 5 per cent dividend, spread to other electrical, later to chemicals and to all standard industrials excepting potashes.

Mrs. Mabelle Quinn, formerly with the Hancock Realty Company, is with Frances Spencer, Inc., in the rental department. The number of reservations received up to Jan. 8 for the annual dinner of the Real Estate Board of New York on Feb. 5 was greater than on the corresponding date for last year's dinner, according to Jones W. Mersereau, executive vice president of the board.

What is believed to be the first instance of national advertising on sheets with a complete and direct local tie-in will appear for the Pepperell Manufacturing Company in the Feb. 14 issue of a weekly magazine.

Repeating their performances in last Sunday's Inaugural Handicap, San Luis Rey, Jockwell and Whistling Boy ran onetwo-three in the $1,000 six-furlong Ensenada Stake, feature of today's program here. More than 7,000 fans attended.

The St. Nicholas Hockey Club overwhelmed the Brooklyn Bruins, 6 to 0, in a New York Amateur Hockey Association game at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. It was the second league triumph in as many starts for the victors, who now head the circuit standings. Barclay Cooke and Barclay Shepherd each scored two goals for the St. Nicks.

F. B. Masten, a Class A gunner, captured the high-over-all cup in the 100-target shoot at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday, finishing with a card of 99 despite high winds and cold weather.
Condemning British plans for partition of Palestine, an organization of up-State New York Jews tonight demanded a sovereign Jewish State.

A card party under the auspices of the Sanctuary Society of St. Francis de Sales Church will be held Saturday afternoon at the Biltmore for the benefit of the organization's charitable enterprises. Reservations are being made through Mrs. Charles Murray at 1,235 Park Avenue.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 83.2, which compares with 83.1 a week ago, 83.2 two weeks ago, 83.9 three weeks ago and 84.3 four weeks ago.

" The world owes you a living only if you owe the world a life," the Rev. Dr. Paul Scherer, the pastor, said yesterday in his morning sermon at the Evangelical Lutheran Church of the Holy Trinity, Central Park West at Sixty-fifth Street.

Rabbi Abba Hillel Silver of Cleveland has been elected national chairman for 1938 of the United Palestine Appeal, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Stephen S. Wise, whom he succeeds. He will be installed by Rabbi Wise at the National Conference for Palestine to be held in Washington on Jan. 22 and 23.

Reorganization Petitions UNITED UPHOLSTERY CORP., 18 W. 20th St.-Voluntary proceeding under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law listing liabilities of $39,795 and assets of $24,878. Petitions Filed-Against ST. MIHIEL CATERERS, INC., restaurant, 1,287 Lexington Ave., by Standard Wine Liquor Co., Inc., for $90; Standard Food Products Corp., $148; Polo Food Market Inc., $459.

Pitched from their motor cycle as it sideswiped an automobile coming in the opposite direction. Vito A. Rizzo, 23 years old, a Coast Guardsman assigned to a cutter operating from Stapleton, S. I., was killed instantly and George Emmons, 22, also a member of the Coast Guard, was injured critically this evening on Route 4 near here.

Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg and Foreign Minister Guido Schmidt of Austria arrived here with their suite at 9:20 o'clock tonight for the conference of the Rome Protocol States-Italy, Austria and Hungary--which opens tomorrow.

An education board, composed of educators and publicists, was announced yesterday by William S. Paley, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, to plan an evening series of educational radio programs.

The last mass was said yesterday in the little red brick church of St. Andrew's in Duane Street, under the shadow of the Municipal and Federal Buildings, where the first night workers' mass for the printers and newspaper men of Park Row was begun thirty-seven years ago.

The Columbia University Library is preparing an exhibition of eighteenth and nineteenth century books, manuscripts and original drawings from the collection of George Arents, New York book collector, whose tobacco collection was shown in the New York Public Library in the Spring of 1936.

Jimmy Thomson, shooting over par for the first time in the tournament, remained in the lead at the end of the fifty-fourth hole in the seventytwo-hole Los Angeles open today, with a total score of 205.

A revival of "Night of January 16," Ayn Rand's courtroom melodrama, is this week's bill at Werba's Brooklyn Theatre. Another revival in Brooklyn tonight is that of "Oliver Oliver," Paul Osborn's comedy.

While the list of persons among whom the $25,000 Lindbergh reward is to be divided will be revealed today at 2:30 P. M., Governor Hoffman of New Jersey said last night that he himself had not yet made a final decision.

One of the largest crowds at an amateur hockey game in Madison Square Garden this season saw yesterday what was unquestionably the most thrilling contest of the Eastern League race thus far, a battle that never let the fans relax and gave them a surprise finish which was made to order for the local supporters.

The setting up of an "Economic League of Nations" to achieve world peace through world trade was advocated yesterday by Thomas J. Watson and Professor James T. Shotwell in the eleventh international broadcast by the National Peace Conference in America and the League of Nations Society of Canada over a network of the Columbia Broadcasting System.

Miss Barbara Alice Spelman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Leslie A. Spelman of this city, was married here to Dr. Richard Bayliss Schutz of Kansas City, Mo., son of the Rev. and Mrs. Edward G. Schutz of Buffalo, yesterday afternoon in Christ Church Cathedral.

Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt, pioneer feminist leader, observed her seventy-ninth birthday today by entertaining as luncheon guests high officers of the National Committee for the Cause and Cure of War, of which she is honorary chairman.

Columbia turned in two victories during the week to remain the only unbeaten team in metropolitan intercollegiate basketball circles, but the continued fine showing of the Lions was eclipsed in interest by the surprising triumph of St. John's over C. C. N. Y. at Madison Square Garden Saturday night.

Isaac I. Kashdan, champion of the Manhattan Chess Club, yesterday finished his schedule in the annual tournament by drawing with Jack Soudakoff of the Bronx, thereby gaining the additional half point needed to win the first prize with a score of 5 1/2--1 1/2. Kashdan retrained the title for another year, having drawn three of his seven games and won the others.

Mr. and Mrs. Hugh W. Robertson of White Plains and South Norwalk, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah Keith Robertson, to Lyman Emerson Russell, elder son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Russell, White Plains.
The former A. G. Spalding plant in Elkton, Md., has been purchased by the Bailey Dye Works of Philadelphia through the Cross Brown Company, broker.
Frank Campbell, in his Class B one design boat Felix, breezed around again today in the dinghy regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club and clicked off four straight victories in as many class races.

A growing though as yet inarticulate unrest among the German people, primarily as a result of Hitler's anti-church policy, was reported yesterday afternoon by Miss Gordon Holmes, joint managing director of the National Securities Corporation, Ltd., of London, at a tea given in her honor at the Hotel Biltmore by the International Federation of Business and Professional Women.

After conferences with political associates here tomorrow, Gifford Pinchot is expected to announce his candidacy for the Republican nomination for Governor in a statement attacking the policies of the Earle adtministration.

The New Jersey Department of the Veterans of Foreign Wars adopted a resolution here today disavowing support for Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City in his fight with the C. I. O. The resolution pointed out that it is the national policy of the organization to remain neutral in all labor disputes.

Shipping under United States registry through the Suez Canal in the first nine months of 1937 showed an increase in all categories compared with the same period of 1936, according to a report to the Department of Commerce from Port Said.

A LONG in 1929 a youthful Italian of huge but ungainly proportions jumped into pugilistic notoriety by exchanging fouls with the late Billy the Kid Stribling in ring battles overseas. That was Primo Camera, called the Ambling Alp, Da Preem, Little Goody Two-Shoes, Camera Carniv-. orus Horribilis and other less complimentary names.

Between 8,000 and 10,000 United States troops and veteran Philippine Scouts theoretically were fighting off an invading force of 20,000 Filipino reserve soldiers today as the Philippines' greatest war manoeuvres got under way in the provinces of Pampanga and- Tarlac, a short distance north of Manila.
Daniel J. Doherty, National Commander of the American Legion, has come out in opposition to the proposed Ludlow amendment for a referendum on a declaration of war.
Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated at 26 per cent of capacity, against 19 per cent in the preceding week.
Three properties in New Jersey were sold for the Hudson Trust Company by J. I. Kislak, Inc., broker, who disposed of the dwelling at 544-6 Thirty-sixth Street, Union City, to Isidore Harris;

The French wholesale price index on Dec. 31 was 601, compared with 509 and 596 for the previous two weeks. The rise affects native products, whose index was 650, against corrected figures of 646 and 642 for the preceding weeks.

Aaron Cohn, taxicab driver of 851 Tinton Avenue, the Bronx, was a witness yesterday in Felony Court against Olis Dale Miller, 24 years old, of 207 East Seventy-seventh Street, who is alleged to have robbed a passenger in Cohn's taxi Saturday and offered the driver half the loot.

A son, Edward Hull Hardin, was born yesterday in Washington, D. C., to Dr. and Mrs. B. Lauriston Hardin Jr. Mrs. Hardin is the former Miss Dorcas Hull. The infant is the grandson of Mrs. Edward Boltwood Hull of Pittsfield.

Senator Aime Benard, Winnipeg, died here last night after an illness of several months. Born in Henryville, Que., he was a member of the Manitoba Legislature for four terms before being called to the Senate in 1917. He was 64 years old. His appointment to the Senate, given by the Borden government,

Repercussions of the projected reciprocal trade agreement with the United Kingdom on domestic American economy and the probable reaction of the home public are occupying the attention of State Department negotiators as the time draws near for talking with their British colleagues on concrete questions of tariff rates.

Ecuador's Government monopolies on alcohol, tobacco, matches and salt face trouble according to a report to the Minister of Finance by Director General Jaime Chavez. The arbitrary action of the government concerning planting, selling and grading has resulted in planters turning to other crops, hence the monopoly has had to import tobacco.

A crowd of 3,600 persons gave Werner Janssen an ovation tonight when he made his debut as conductor of the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra in his first concert bf the season. Mr. Janssen received five calls for bows at the end of the concert, which he directed without a score.

Morton Kiah Maynard, controller of the General Cable Company, with offices here, died today at his home, 94 Hillair Circle. He was 49 years old and was a former resident of Stratford, Conn., and Rome, N. Y. Mr. Maynard was born in Fair Haven, Vt.,

Fifty-five men, arrested Saturday night in two raids on the C. I. O. United Automobile Workers of America strike headquarters near the Ford assembly plant here, were released late today on bonds of $200 each.
Army Medical Corps officers will examine tomorrow 450 CCC candidates who were selected in the metropolitan area by relief authorities, it was announced yesterday.

The Republican National Committee announced today that Representative Snell of New York, the House Republican leader, would speak over the radio Wednesday on "The State of the Union." The speech will be broadcast from 6:15 to 6:40 P. M., Eastern standard time, by the Columbia Broadcasting Company. Mr.

Instructions from Washington that all WPA workers who are eligible for unemployment insurance be dropped from the work relief rolls will affect "only a handful" of the 130,000 relief workers in this city, WPA officials said last night.
The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, returning to the radio today for the first time since the ordainment of Archbishop Edward Mooney, presented a fourpoint program for the solution of national ills.

Are-stocking of the Irvington House Thrift Shop will take place on Friday at a bridge party and tea in the Grill Room of the Ritz Tower. The committee has arranged that admission to the event will be a bundle of used articles, suitable for resale later in the shop.
Affiliation of two unions of hospital workers with the State, County and Municipal Workers of America was announced last night by Abram Flaxer, national president of the C. I. O. affiliate.

New York table tennis stars tonight beat a St. Louis team in the final of the national intercity table tennis tournament. The teams went into the final with five victories apiece. The New Yorkers scored a decisive 5-to-1 victory to take the crown for the fifth successive year.

Professor Robert M. Yerkes, director of the laboratory of comparative psychobiology of the Yale School of Medicine, who is conducting studies of chimpanzees at New Haven, Conn., and Orange Park, Fla., proposed here today the establishment of a free range chimpanzee colony.

The New Jersey Motor Vehicle Department will open officially its twentyeight stations for compulsory inspection of automobiles tomorrow. More than 1,000,000 State-registered cars will be inspected semi-annually as to their safety at a fee of 50 cents for each test.

The soil erosion control operations of the Soil Conservation Service were expanded during the fiscal year to cover 8,500,000 acres of private land under voluntary cooperative agreements with more than 50,000 landowners, H. H. Bennett, chief of the service, stated in his annual report to Secretary Wallace.

The New Year began, on last week's markets, in what might possibly be called noncommittal fashion. On the whole, the market's course was encouraging. The Erie Railroad defaulted on its interest Monday,
Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Van Santvoord of this city gave a dinner in observance of the fiftieth anniversary of their wedding at the Hendrik Hudson Hotel here today.

The Press Photographers Association of New York opened its third annual exhibition with a preview yesterday afternoon in La Maison Francaise, Rockefeller Center. Mayor La Guardia, the most-photographed celebrity in the show, paid it a visit.

In their annual surveys of world business, both the Reich Statistical Bureau and the Reichskreditbank express the opinion that a revival in the steel industry in the United States is certain because present consumption exceeds output.
An Argentine Army plane carrying the son of Argentina's President and five army officers was reported today to have crashed near the Uruguayan boundary, seriously injuring three of its occupants.

Although the currency circulation of the Bank of England has been declining with unusual rapidity after the big Christmas expansion, last week's decrease of ??12,741,232 was not a record, being exceeded in the corresponding week of 1931. It was,

The spectacular increase in production value of more than $10,000,000, or 35 per cent, over 1936, in British Columbia mining and the advance of $5,000,000 over any previous year in Manitoba stand out as features in 1937 Canadian mining activity, which has been paced, as usual, by the highly productive Ontario and Quebec properties.

The New York Americans defeated the Passon Phillies today; 3 to 2, in a championship game of the American Soccer League. The home team had the better of it in the first half, leading by 2-1 when ends were changed.

Chairmen and committees for its annual ball and entertainment in aid of its fund for needy members, to be held at the Hotel Roosevelt on the eve of Washington's Birthday, were appointed by the New York Society of Teachers of Dancing, Inc., yesterday at its January ing in the Hotel Astor.

Since the turn of the year the world wheat market has developed a decidedly strong undertone, and a considerable part of the recent bearishness which predominated in the grain trade in December has been dissipated as the result of a material broadening in the demand for the cash grain from importing countries.
The German wholesale price index on Dec. 22 was 105.5, unchanged from a week before and compared with 105 in December, 1936, and 103.4 in December, 1935.

Most of the delegates attending the Indian Science Congress left for Madras today after a closing dinner yesterday at which Sir James Jeans, British astronomer, declared a powerful new link had been forged between Indian and British science.
A statement expressing alarm at what was termed "the political juggling with the budget of the city of New York" was issued yesterday by the New York Teachers Guild.

The spirit in which the financial and commercial markets entered the new year is not easy to define with exactitude. Chastened by last year's experience and faced with many obscurities in outlook, the general attitude is one of waiting for something to turn up which will give a definite lead.

Beck St, 845 (10-2710); Louisons Properties, Inc, to Union Square Savings Bank; $21.500. Whitlock Ave, 943 (10-2735): 943 Whitlock Ave Corp to Central Hanover Bank Trust Co, trustee; 5 years, 5 per cent; $24,000. Davidson Ave (11-2862), e s, 233 ft of Tremont Ave, 110x63; Herman Elkowitz to Equitable Life Assurance Society, 393 7th Ave; instalments, 4 1/2 to 5 per cent; $102,500.

Snow plows were at a premium today in the Winter-ridden mountain lands of the French-Spanish border because of the Spanish war. Andorra asked France to clear the snow-filled mountain road into the tiny, semi-independent principality before its food supply was exhausted.

John P. Maham, retired Deputy Collector of United States customs here, died today after a two-weeks' illness. He was 70 years old. Mr. Maham joined the Federal service as a post office clerk and later went to New York City as a deputy controller.

The marriage of Miss Eva Saxe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis L. Saxe, to Robert A. Wile, son of Alfons Wile of New York, took place here this evening at the home of the bride's parents. The Rev. Dr. Henry E. Kagan performed the ceremony.

The Bank of Brazil, lifting the lid on the foreign exchange embargo, will begin to allot coverage on import bills this week. On Dec. 23, when the Brazilian Government declared a foreign exchange monopoly and decreed also an embargo on exchange, the covering of import drafts ceased, resulting thus far in large accumulations in milreis deposits.
Mrs. Timothy A. Leary, wife of Supreme Court Justice Leary, will give a card party and tea next Saturday afternoon in behalf of the Sisters of the Good Shepherd at the Hyde Park Hotel.

The results of the 1937 prize fishing contest held by the East End Surf Fishing Club will be announced on Thursday at the regular dinner meeting of the group to be held at Travelers Tavern, Calverton, L. I. The prizes will be awarded by Charles Altenkirch.

Philadelphia's German-Americans played to a 2-2 tie with the Baltimore S. C. in an American Soccer League game today at O'Donnell Park. The visitors took an early lead when McCahon tallied. Baltimore rallied, and, on goals by Ernst and Monroe, gained a 2-to-1 lead at the intermission.

Eighty-six Princeton undergraduates, including twenty-six residents of New York State, qualified for medals in eight branches of intramural sport last Fall, according to the list released today by William F. Halsey 3d, '38, of Pensacola, Fla., president of the Intramural Athletic Association.

The formal presentations of the New York Film Critics awards for the "bests" of 1937 were made last night via a radio broadcast, during which the local NBC studios, where the presentations were made, were hooked up with Hollywood and Budapest for a verbal distribution of the awards.

The Archbishop of Westminster, the first British prelate to be elevated to the purple in tWenty-seven years. returned to London today as Cardinal Hinsley amid scenes of affectionate enthusiasm rivaling that reserved for royalty.

There will be brought before the House of Representatives today a measure proposing a radical change in the control of the foreign policy of the United States. This is the Ludlow resolution, which would add a new amendment to the Constitution providing that "except in the event of an invasion of the United States or its territorial possessions and attack upon its citizens

Plans for completely modernizing the historic Fulton Fish Market have been developed by BoroughPresident Stanley M. Isaacs of Manhattan and William Fellowes Morgan, Commissioner of Markets, it was announced yesterday by the Borough President.

Cotton prices moved steadily upward again last week to a level approximately 90 to 100 points above the low point touched last Fall. At the close on Saturday, active future deliveries on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net advances for the week of 20 to 24 points.

Henry L. McLaughlin, 61 years old, of 124-15 Fifth Avenue, College Point, Queens, died of a heart attack in St. Fidelis Roman Catholic Church, College Point, yesterday morning. He was stricken as he knelt at the 11:15 mass.

Plans for altering a loft building in the Greenwich Village area at a cost of $50,000 have been announced in connection with the sale of the seven-story structure at 35-37 East Tenth Street by Chantilly Realties. Inc., represented by Samuel Bierman. The building,

Georges Enesco, a composer, conductor and violinist of parts, was heard in the latter two capacities at the concert of the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon. With Mishel Piastro, the concert master, taking Mr. Enesco's place on the podium, Mr. Enesco was the violin soloist in the Bach concerto in A minor and in the Chausson "Pomme."
Rossini's "The Barber of Seville" will be revived at the Metropolitan Opera House on Saturday afternoon, Jan. 22, with Lily Pons, who will sing Rosina, making her first appearance of the season.

Kingsley G. Howe, a retired captain of the British Army, and Mrs. Howe were assaulted early this morning in their fifteenth-floor apartment at the Wyndham Apartment Hotel by an intruder who was found prowling about the rooms at 1:45 A. M.

Long- city, term subsidy. agreements calling for the immediate construction of and pa twenty ocean-going vessels and building preparation of plans for twentythree more have been signed with seven steamship companies by the Maritime Commission, it was announced today.

Members of the Russian Nobility Association, of which Prince Alexis Obolensky is president, will celebrate the Russian New Year Wednesday evening at the Coventry Club, 12 East Sixty-seventh Street. The committee in charge includes Mr. and Mrs. Boris Martinoff, Countess Lamsdorff, Mrs. Alexander Nazaroff, Mrs. Yvonne Poushine and Alexander de Bodisco.

The Colombian Minister to Panama, Jose Vargas, gave a dinner at the Union Club last night for the civil, military and naval authorities of the Canal Zone at which he said that social welfare and collective prosperity can be achieved only by remaining faithful to democratic creeds and institutions.

Dr. Charles J. Turck, secretary of the Board of Christian Education, preaching yesterday at the Fourth Presbyterian Church, West End Avenue and Ninety-first Street, outlined the five fundamental duties of the church if it is to minister effectively to all the needs of mankind.

Six months after the incident at Marco Polo Bridge provided an excuse for the invasion of China, Japanese military authorities are seeking to find a scapegoat for their failure to terminate the war by the year end.

Curiosity is the very A Sign essence of good reportingby the curiosity which will be Night satisfied with nothing less than the facts and the truth. It is therefore with a certain sense of frustration that this column reports three minor items of the New York scene which a timid failure to investigate has magnified into the week's major mysteries.

The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System in an analysis of current business conditions, published in the board's January bulletin, said today that the Federal Reserve index of industrial production appeared to have dropped to a low level of about 83 per cent of the 1923-25 average in December.

The findings in a six-month survey of the city-wide problems confronting the newly established City Planning Commission were forwarded yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission to Mayor La Guardia and Adolph A. Berle Jr., Planning Commission chairman.

Royal W. Robertson, a leader of the bonus marchers who tramped into Washington in 1932 and camped before the Capitol, died last night in the Cedars of Lebanon Hospital. His age was 46. He was a native of Rochester, N. Y. His widow and a daughter survive.
INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 9.--Two railroad crossing accidents brought sudden death to eight persons in Indiana today.

Scoring twice in the last twenty minutes, the Hispanos yesterday defeated the Irish-Americans of Newark, 2 to 1, in their American Soccer League fixture at Commercial Field, Brooklyn. Five minutes after the turn, the Jerseymen took the lead as Sheppell -crossed to J. Pettigrew, who drove into the Hispano cage.

The report of the Bank of France that was given to the public this week made an exceptionally bad impression here by reason of the increase of 5,000,000,000 francs in loans by the bank to the State between Dec. 23 and 30.

The newspaper Tiempo publishes a protest of the Colombian Bondholders' Committee in the United States to the Governor of the State of Antioquia objecting to the law pending in the Assembly reducing freight rates for coffee on the government railway.

Three prizes of $100 each will be awarded by the New York Newspaper Women s Club for outstanding work by New York newspaper women in 1937, it was announced yesterday at the club headquarters, 22 East Thirty-eighth Street.
Luganetz Orelsky, new Soviet Ambassador to China, will present his credentials to President Lin Sen at Chungking on Jan. 18, a Foreign Office spokesman said yesterday.

The net proceeds of the three polo games to be played at Squadron A Armory, Madison Avenue at Ninety-fourth Street, Saturday night, will go to the Girls Friendly Society of the Diocese of New York, which was founded more than fifty years ago by Miss Elizabeth Wisner.

The new year has not begun in France under conditions likely to inspire capital generally with any confidence. The foreign-exchange market, which began the week on an irregular and dull note, was characterized, from Wednesday, by a marked weakening of the franc.

Speculative interest in the grain markets last week was largely concentrated in wheat, in which sales increased more than 55,000,000 bushels from the preceding week, when holiday operations served to curtail trading.
Justice Benjamin N. Cardozo has suffered several "alarming" heart attacks in the past few days and will have to be kept abed for some time, his physician said today.

The Robert E. Lee birthday celebration under the auspices of all Southern organizations in New York will take place Wednesday evening at the Ambassador. The program will be followed by a supper dance in the Embassy suite of the hotel.

Winning twenty games, drawing six and losing only two, Dr. Emanuel Lasker, former chess champion of the world, concluded a memorable exhibition of simultaneous play at the Marshall Chess Club early yesterday morning, after a session lasting seven hours.

A game of chess which two British naval officers began by correspondence nearly twenty-two years ago shortly before one of them died in the battle of Jutland ended tonight when his daughter won the decision with a single move.

Services commemorating the broad church movement in the United States from 1842 to 1882, during which time many Episcopalian congregations settled for themselves the problem of fundamentalism and turned from a literal to a liberal interpretation of Scripture, were held yesterday afternoon at the Episcopal Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue and Tenth Street.

The first week of the year brought stocks the sharpest gains since May, 1933; turnover, 6,050,United States Government and United States Government and foreign bonds irregular, corporation issues generally steadier; transactions, $37,716,000.

The use of the term "good neighbor" by our State Department carries with it implications of "tremendous responsibility," declared the Rev. Dr. Edward A. Odell, secretary for the West Indies of the Board of National Missions of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America, in a sermon yesterday morning at the First Presbyterian Church, Henry Street near Clark Street, Brooklyn.

Dominicans residing here, mostly political exiles, today commented on President Rafael Trujillo's broadcast yesterday, in which he announced his own retirement next August and nominated as his successor Vice President Jacinto B. Peynado.

Church bells rang out and cannon boomed salutes in all garrisons and warships throughout Greece at 11:15 this morning while the Archbishop of Athens, robed in gold cloth, in the presence of high dignitaries and royal guests pronounced Prince Paul,
On a tour of the West Indies, A. R. Larrosa, sub-secretary of the General League of Red Cross Societies, departed for Nicaragua by airplane yesterday. He arrived here from Guatemala last Friday.

The twelfth annual Eastern tournament for contract bridge players will take place at the Park Central Hotel, beginning Feb. 28 and running for a week, it was announced yesterday by George Reith, chairman of the committee.

Blackstone's Beguiler, a black puppy bitch, bred and owned by Leonard J. Buck of Far Hills, N. J., and handled in the ring by Bain Cobb, yesterday captured the cocker spaniel Futurity Stake, leading competition at the first session of the two-day specialty exhibition of the American Spaniel Club.

The outdoor track and field championships of the Intercollegiate A.A. A.A., always a sports high light of the Memorial Day week-end, has been dropped back another week and will be staged on June 3 and 4 this year. This was decided yesterday at a special convention of the oldest of all collegiate sports bodies at the Hotel Roosevelt.

More than thirty exhibitions on the, calendar for the current week indicate that the holiday period of quiet has been left behind and that the season in the New York art world has definitely resumed its activities.
The former Gertrude Bennett, 17, daughter of Harry Bennett of the Ford Motor Company, and her husband, Russell Hughes, 21-year-old dance orchestra drummer, were welcomed home today.

To enforce his proposals of financial and economic assistance to Germany and Italy for the general rehabilitation of world trade, Paul van Zeeland has submitted to Premier Neville Chamberlain the following recommendations:

Labor's Non-Partisan League opposes amendments to the Merchant Marine Act which would apply the principles of the Railway Labor Act to maritime labor disputes, E. L. Oliver, executive vice president of the league, announced today.

The German steamer Dessau arrived today to load the first shipment of helium to be transported from the United States. It will take part of the 17,900,000 cubic feet ordered for the LZ-30, sister ship of the Hindenburg.

League for Political Education, Town Hall, 11 A. M. "Poland Today," Julien Bryan. Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, 11 A. M. "Outlook in France." Mme. Charlotte T. Muret. Women's City Club, 20 West Fiftyfirst Street, 12:30 P. M. "The Home Rule Situation in New York," Laurence Arnold Tanzer.
Miss Luciel Baum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Baum of Atlanta, was married here today to Richard Roger Fleisher of Philadelphia.

Men and women who will examine life's inner meanings, bring themselves under the sway of God's influence and see life through His eyes are needed today, the Rev. Alden Mosshammer declared yesterday at the East Eighty-ninth Street Reformed Church, between Madison and Park Avenues.

Mayor La Guardia gave a definite indication yesterday that he had no intention of remaining at the head of the city government beyond his present term. After referring in an address to the costly program of building sewage disposal plants, which is expected to continue three years after his term expires, he warned his listeners to "be very careful in the selection of my successor."

The Original Celtics swamped the New York Yankees, 58 to 26, in an American League contest and Larry Kelley's All-Stars defeated the Passaic Kenyons, 31 to 26, before a crowd of 2,500 in a professional basketball double-header at the Hippodrome last night.
Mel Harder, pitcher for the Cleveland Indians, took a look at the contract proffered him for 1938 today and indicated he would join the holdout ranks with this comment:

Five young men who, according to the police, have admitted participating in a series of recent holdups in Brooklyn and Manhattan, were booked on charges of assault and robbery at the Fort Hamilton police station in Brooklyn last night after they had been questioned for several hours.
This evening brings the Broadway premiere (postponed from Dec. 29) of "Yr Obedient Husband," wherein Fredric March and Florence Eldridge (Mrs. March) will pretend to be Mr. and Mrs. Richard Steele.

Although buyers' arrivals last week fell about 30 per cent below last year's figure a large influx is expected in the wholesale market during the next two weeks, and the apparel trade is looking forward with optimism to Spring buying.

Harry Kennedy's daily plunge in the Atlantic Ocean-regardless of the temperature-cost him his life yesterday. He was stricken with a heart attack in the surf off. Beach Ninety-first Street, Rockaway Beach, in full view of hundreds of boardwalk strollers bundled in furs and heavy clothing.

Miss Renee Weill, daughter of Mrs. George W. Weill of this city, and the late Mr. Weill, was married yesterday afternoon at the Carlyle to Postmaster Edward Brodstein of Asbury Park, N. J., son of Samuel Brodstein of that place. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Nathan Stern.

The Hershey Bears and Baltimore battled to a 3-3 tie in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League game tonight. The Orioles came from, behind to knot the count in the third period and neither team was able to score in the extra frame.

Four of the season's scheduled cruises to the West Indies have been withdrawn in an adjustment to bring the supply closer to the demand. It was learned yesterday that Raymond Whitcomb, charterers of the French liner Paris for voyages to southern ports on Jan. 28, Feb. 11 and 26 and March 19 had canceled all four.

Although he left the city to escape celebration of his eightieth birthday anniversary, which occurred on Jan. 2, Dr. Bernard Sachs, former president of the Academy of Medicine and international authority in child neurology, discovered on Saturday that he had merely postponed the event. John S. Burke,

Eighteen saddle horses, a cat, a dog and several pigeons were burned to death early yesterday when fire destroyed the stable and barn of the Alley Pond Riding Academy near Little Alley Road and 231st Street, Douglaston, Queens, a short distance from Alley Pond Park.

James Frederick Armstrong, retired secretary of the Sheldon Spring and Axle Company of Wilkes-Barre, Pa., with which he had been associated for thirty-four years, died here last night at his home, 506 West Eighth Street. He was born in Wilkes-Barre sixtytwo years ago.

The Pullman Company, sleeping-car company affiliate of Pullman, Inc., reported today that transportation operations in November resulted in a net deficit of $199,055, contrasted with a net income of $221,047 a year earlier.

The Gospel injunction, "Be not anxious for the morrow" is an impossible one because the anxiety of people is increased by the caprices and conspiracies, decisions and whims of their fellow-men, the Rev. Dr. Rheinhold Niebuhr said in a sermon yesterday morning In the James Memorial Chapel of Union Theological Seminary, Claremont Avenue between 120th and 122d Streets.
Queen Alexandrine was operated on in a Copenhagen hospital this afternoon for an attack of an intestinal ailment similar to attacks she suffered in March, 1935, and last September.

The German Consul here has made two futile efforts to obtain censorship of the film "The Road Back." He first requested the Foreign Ministry to prohibit exhibitions of the film, charging it injured the dignity of the German Government and people.
Today's mothers prefer night clubs and cabarets to the nursery, the Rev. Walter P. Kellenberg declared yesterday at a mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral, preaching on the Feast of the Holy Family.
Tommy Smith, Utica, N. Y., speedster, and Miss Janet Milne, Saranac Lake star, captured the principal titles at today's renewal of the Capital district speed skating championships.

Chinese sources declare the Chinese Government is massing more than 300,000 men for a firm resistance on the whole front between the Tientsin-Pukow railway and the PeipingHankow railway which for several years has been heavily fortified.

Dr. Abraham Henwood, a chemist and teacher, died in Roxborough Memorial Hospital today after a brief illness. He was 66 years old. Dr. Henwood had been Professor of Chemistry at both Drexel Institute and Haverford College and at his death was a member of the science faculty of Central High School here. Born in Philadelphia,

A drawing room meeting in behalf of the Alliance for Guidance of Rural Youth, formerly known as the Southern Woman's Educational Alliance, will be held tomorrow afternoon at the home of Mrs. Richard S. Reynolds, 120 East End Avenue.
The presentation of seventy-eight awards to football and cross-country athletes at New York University was announced yesterday by Albert B. Nixon, graduate manager of athletics.

A movement to buttress national air defense by coordinating activities of every aviation group in the country was put under way here today. Called the first National Aeronautic Planning Conference, a meeting attended by aircraft manufacturers, State and government officials and private flying groups discussed among other topics the problem of the United States catching up with Europe in the field of civilian flying.

Members of the St. Agnes Alumni Association will hold their annual Winter dance Saturday night in the Embassy Suite of the Ambassador. The entertainment committee ineludes Thomas Raby, president of the association;

Eric A. Camman of Peat, Marwick, Mitchell Co. and Frank L. Sweetser of Stevenson, Jordan Harrison will discuss "Standard Costs-When and How to Use the Chief Types" at the meeting of the local chapter of the National Association of Cost Accountants to be held tomorrow night at the Builders Club, 2 Park Avenue.

On the eve of the submission by Governor Lehman of his budget to the Legislature tomorrow evening, the Governor's office tonight made public a statement of the State's net debt as of Jan. 1,showing a reduction in it of about $46,000,000.
The American Veterans Association will hold its sixth annual conference at the Hotel Roosevelt Saturday and Sunday. Some 150 delegates from the East and Midwest are expected to attend.

Severe floods and snowstorms took many lives today in scattered sections of Turkey. Twenty peasants, mostly women, were drowned when the Gediz and Menderes Rivers overflowed in the region east of Smyrna.

Former Governor Charles S. Whitman and Mrs. Whitman will give a dinner for Mrs. Whitman's debutante daughter, Miss Anne S. Grosvenor, in the Persian Room of the Plaza on Feb. 4 before the third and last Junior Assembly of the season.

" No, no," said Justice Van Devanter to a hectoring attorney in the Federal District Court, "you must not call out those questions in that tone of voice. You must treat the witness with courtesy. He is presumably a gentleman."

Hearings will be held tomorrow morning in the Federal Trade Commission's proceeding against H. K. Luger, Inc., of New York, in the Post Office Building in Paterson, N. J., and at 45 Broadway, New York, on Wednesday morning, the commission announced today. William W.
(By Mail)-Girls in China are being trained as spies to ferret out Japanese military secrets.

British imagination is stirred by the unusual character and qualifications of Joseph P. Kennedy, the newly appointed American Ambassador. Private comment plays on the piquant fact that a typical hero of an American success story, selfmade, dynamic, a New Dealer from Wall Street, and a Catholic of Irish ancestry to, boot, will represent his country in the Court of St. James.

Beginning today, activities of the Family Welfare Society of Queens will be carried on through the Charity Organization Society of New York, according to a joint announcement yesterday by Charles G. Meyer, president of the Queens unit, and Walter S. Gifford, president of the Manhattan group.

Lieut. Col. Robert Olds of Longley Field Air Station set a record today for military aircraft in transcontinental flight by piloting a sixteen-ton, four-motored bombing plane from March Field, Calif., here in 11 hours 1 minute, Langley Field officials announced.

A discover of the architecture of the mind at Cornell University's collection of brains of famous persons, revealing that emotions and consciousness originate in a ringshaped structure of four main parts deep in the middle of the brain, was made public today.

Investors in utility securities and in securities in general have been disheartened by the statements concerning the utilities industry contained in President Roosevelt's Jackson Day address, Dr. Hugh S. Magill, president of the American Federation of Investors, said in a statement issued today.

Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Bookshops, Gimbel Brothers, R. H. Macy, Charles Scribner's Sons, John Wanamaker, and Womrath Book Shops and Libraries:

The Scots-Americans conquered the Paterson Caledonians in an American Soccer League match at Scots Field today, 2 to 0. Fisher opened the scoring after fifteen minutes of play. Midway in the second period, Moniz made the final tally.

ALBERT-Rebecca, beloved mother of Jonas, David and Louis. Services Park West Memorial Chapel, 115 West 79th St., Monday, 11 A. M. ARM--David, suddenly, on Friday. Jan. 7, 1938, devoted husband of Sadye (nee Nadler), beloved father of Gilbert and Milton.

Major Gen. Frank R. McCoy, commander of the Secon Corps Area, was guest of honor last night at the Overseas Service League's seventeenth annual dinner, in the George Washington Assembly Room, 3 West Fifty-first Street.

The British freighter Marion Moller was released today after the police and the authorities of the Tokyo fortified zone had investigated charges that the vessel had dropped anchor in a forbidden area at Yokohama.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There are a number of cases in which the principle of proportional representation can be applied with as much benefit to the community as in the election of our City Council. This method can be applied to the election of members of the Legislature.
The mild Winter, which has encouraged hens to "lay their heads off," has forced prices of eggs down approximately 20 per cent in two months, market figures showed today.

Bryan M. (Bitsy) Grant, the Atlanta atom, toppled Bobby Riggs, the nation's No. 2 player, today in five bitterly contested sets, to win the Miami Biltmore tournament for the third time. Grant, ranked fourth nationally, conquered Riggs, 3-6, 6-2, 7-9, 8-6, 6-3, and earned permanent possession of the Colonel Henry L. Doherty Trophy.

Mrs. Courtlandt Godwin will give a tea next Sunday at her home, 125 East Fifty-seventh Street, for the junior members of the Society of Mayflower Descendants. She will be assisted by Mrs. Renwick C. Hurry, Mrs. Pierson Mapes, Mrs. Ira Lawrence Hill and the Misses Alla H. C. Smith, Marjorie Stoddard and Jacqueline Godwin.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9.--A copy of a questionnaire purporting to have been sent out to "party functionaries" by the Central Committee of the Communist party in the United States was made public here today by John P. Frey, president of the Metal Trades Department of the American Federation of Labor.

While a large export business was put through in United States cash corn last week it apparently had little effect on the price of futures. The latter sold at a new high for the movement early in the week, but ran into considerable hedging pressure and profit taking as well as closing spreads with wheat. May corn,
Spanish Government forces, their grip on Teruel tightened by the collapse of Insurgent resistance within the city, threw up stronger defenses today against Insurgent columns pressing on the outside.

The Bourse was unfavorably impressed this week by the social agitation, the fall of the franc and the return of the Bank of France. French securities, especially the renters, became heavy, but with little business transacted.

Senator Burton K. Wheeler of Montana today accused the finance division of the Interstate Commerce Commission of action in connection with loans to railroads that violated "common sense and the spirit of the law."

The weekly shoot of the North Jersey Gun Club drew a good field today. F. A. Landis, Class B entrant, took high gun honors in the first fifty-target event in a shoot-off. A. F. Streelman won in Class A, L. W. Minford in Class C.

Trading in oats futures was relatively light here last week, but there was no material pressure on the market and closing trades yesterday were 1 1/2 to 1 7/8 cents a bushel higher for the week, with the May position at 32 3/4 cents and the July at 30%.

The New York Central Railroad and its controlled Michigan Central, Pittsburgh Lake Erie and Boston and Albany lines have established a world's record in safe-passenger transport, F. E. Williamson, president of the system, announced yesterday.

In its annual report to Congress the Social Security Board listed today as indications of progress in the administration of the Social Security Act the start of old-age benefit and unemployment compensation, the receipt of more than 30,000,000 applications for account numbers from workers and -the enactment of unemployment compensation laws in all the States, the District of Columbia, Alaska and Hawaii.

Twenty-five were injured today, five seriously, when a group of about fifty Hungarian Nazis attacked a group of skiers, mostly Jews, on a hill outside Budapest. A serious clash resulted and large police forces were needed to restore order. Fourteen Nazis were arrested.

Dr. William Clyde De Vane, chairman of the English department at Cornell University, has been appointed dean of Yale College, President Charles Seymou?? of Yale announced today. The appointment will become effective July 1, but the new dean will have a leave of absence for the first term of the next academic year.

A group of women under the leadership of Mrs. Winthrop W. Aldrich is being organized as the Women's Century Fund Committee of the ten-year development program of the American Museum of Natural History.

Mr. and Mrs. Thomas R. Fowler of Hudson View Gardens, Pinehurst Avenue and 183d Street, this city, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elsie Bradley Fowler, to Charles Milton Henderson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ludwig H. Henderson, also of this city.
Welker Cochran and Jake Schaefer, claimants of the world 18.2 balkline billiard championship, will open a week-long match at the Strand Academy this afternoon to decide the issue.

The Federal Trade Commission announced today that it had issued an order prohibiting Harry Weinberg, trading as the Nu-Art Tailoring Company, 818 Broadway, New York, from the use of certain unfair methods of competition in connection with the sale of men's clothing.

Plans for the 1938 campaign for funds of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee will be discussed at St. Louis, Mo., on Sunday, Jan. 23, at a meeting of about 100 Jewish leaders from all parts of the United States and Canada. The 1938 campaign officers will be elected and a quota for the year determined. The 1937 quota was $4,650,000.

FIRST RACE-Purse $400; claiming; 4year-olds and upward; five and a half furlongs. Little V., 110..(F. Fernandez) 5-1 2-1 1-1 Polydee, 102 ......... (Conner) . 8-5 4-5 Donna Tutti, 102 .... (Napier) ...... 1-2 Time-1:123-5. Regusted, Foreign Lady, Fractious, Redwick, Dunora, Diamond Digger and Sheila K. also ran. SECOND RACE-Purse $400; claiming; 4year-olds and up ward: six furlongs.

Senator Austin declared,today on returning from Puerto Rico that the island would constitute an important link between the United States and South America "in confronting the two extremes of fascism and communism now menacing the world."
Passengers due today from Chile, Peru, Ecuador, Colombia and Cuba on the steamship Santa Lucia of the Grace Line include Dr. Angel H. Hildago, Consul General for Ecuador in New York,

With the suspension this week-end of Barbara Stanwyck for refusing to appear in S. K. Lauren's "Distant Fields," evidence was adduced indicating that under its production reorganization RKO will employ stars on the basis of a specified number of films a year rather than keep them on weekly salary.

The Utility Consumers National Policy Committee made public yesterday a memorandum which it had transmitted to President Roosevelt in respect to the recent proposals made to the President by Wendell L. Willkie, president of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation.
The Duke and Duchess of Windsor, looking healthy and happy, returned to Paris tonight from a three-week holiday on the French Riviera.

The New York Rangers extended their dominance over the world champion Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden last night. Striking at the Stanley Cup holders in every period, the local skaters registered a decisive 4-to-1 triumph. Lester Patrick's stick wielders held the edge over the invaders all through the game and experienced comparatively little difficulty beating the champions' defense.

Jackson St, 17, s w cor Madison; Margaret J. Mangan, referee, to City of New York, foreclosure of tax lien. 31st St., 442-454 W; Guaranty Trust Co, trustee, under mortgage, to Joseph Greenberg, 318 Lafayette St, quitclaim, all right, title and interest. Same property; Harry N. Stein, trustee in bankruptcy of Runkel Realty Co, to same ($1).

The Brookhattans retained the lead in the metropolitan division of the American Soccer League when they defeated the St. Mary's Celtics at Starlight Park yesterday by 2 to 1 before 5,500 fans. Brookhattan went ahead in the first few minutes when Joe Boyle tallied on Razzo Carroll's pass.

A conference to mobilize public opinion to prevent discrimination against foreign-born Americans, to press for the traditional right of asylum for political and religious refugees in the United States and to assist alien residents in this country in their efforts to become American citizens was held yesterday afternoon at the Pennsylvania Hotel at the call of the American Committee for Protection of Foreign Born.
A list of 277 books that juvenile delinquents are to be encouraged to read as an aid in reforming them was made public yesterday by Mayor La Guardia.
Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen, Associate Professor at the Catholic University in Washington, said here today that he wished Edmund Franco,

" Why not?" we said to ourselves Saturday night, when it came time for the Toscanini radio concert with the NBC Symphony Orchestra. Often we had thought of a millenial time when the night would be old and the wind cold, and we would not pull our head like a turtle into the overcoat collar and trudge through the blast to the concert hall.

Miss Madeleine W. Smith, president of the Woman's Advisory Board of the Brooklyn Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, will give her annual Spring card party the afternoon of March 12 in the main ballroom of the Hotel St. George in Brooklyn for the benefit of the blind under the care of the association.

The Crescent Athletic Club basketball team turned back the Cathedral College five, 65 to 56, at the victors' gymnasium in Brooklyn yesterday. The triumph was the sixth in eight starts this season for the Half-Mooners.

Mrs. George F. Sullivan of this place gave a tea today in her home at which she announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Janet M. Sullivan, to Robert Holman Craft of New York. Mrs. Norman B. Johnson of East Orange and Miss Lorraine Burroughs of Maplewood assisted at the tea.

Receipt of a $10,000 contribution from Edmund C. Lynch, New York broker, to endow annual commemorative meetings on the anniversary of the first airplane flights of Wilbur and Orville Wright was announced yesterday by the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences, Inc., 30 Rockefeller Plaza.

The record of the profits of the "Big Five" banks in 1937, completed yesterday by the issue of Lloyds Bank returns, reveals the best figures since the peak year of 1929. An appreciable increase was shown by every bank.

An absence of "religious motivation" in modern life has resulted in a sag in morality, a spread of lawlessness and a contempt for organized government, the Rev. Dr. Christopher Jeffares McCombe said in his sermon yesterday morning at the Methodist Episcopal Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, Eightysixth Street at Amsterdam Avenue. Dr. McCombe's subject was "God's Country."
William J. Shroder of Cincinnati was re-elected for his sixth term as president of the Council of Jewish Federations and Welfare Funds at the annual general assembly here today.
Six high ranking members of an Italian aviation mission to China arrived tonight from Shanghai.

The charge that many farmers' cooperatives were underselling the agreed-oh price for fluid milk and cream and a demand for an immediate reduction to meet this competition were contained in a letter made public yesterday from the New York Metropolitan Milk Distributors Bargaining Agency to the Metropolitan Cooperative Milk Producers Bargaining Agency, Inc., with headquarters in Syracuse.
The year just past was a sad one for German films. The Film Chamber has just reported that all three of Berlin's longest runs went to foreign films; two American and one French.

The Mexican press applauded today the revelation yesterday by Secretary of Finance Eduardo Suarez that the United States was supporting the Mexican peso with its stabilization fund and was buying Mexican silver reserves in addition to regular monthly quantities of silver.

John E. Muhifeld, furnished suite of ten rooms in 37 E 38th St; William D. Litt, in 36 E 72d St; Carter Carnegie, in 821 Madison Ave; Alfred J. Nelson, in 155 E 49th St; Douglas L. Elliman Co, brokers.

The confidence in God exhibited by the Wise Men in their Journey to the crib of the Infant Jesus -is the hope which should guide us in life, the Rev. Thomas Barry of the New York Apoatolate Fathers said in a sermon yesterday at a mass in the Roman Catholic Church of the Epiphany, Twenty-first Street and Second Avenue.

A shot fired blindly through a door by the proprietor of a liquor and delicatessen store here at 2 o'clock this morning lodged in the skull of a "toy-gun bandit," and within an hour, after picking up the trail through bloodstains leading from the scene, State troopers arrested the wounded man and his alleged accomplice.
District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey yesterday made his first assignment of an assistant to Felony Court on a Sunday, a practice not followed heretofore by District Attorneys.
Participation by the British Empire in the World's Fair was marked yesterday with exercises at the fair site. The Union Jack was

" Man, His Clothes, His Sports" will be the theme of the display by the Men's Apparel Quality Guild, Inc., at the New York World's Fair of 1939, it is announced today. The i Guild has just signed a contract for 68,538 square feet of space in the exposition's Zone of Production,

More than twenty-five years ago Marcellin Berthelot succeeded in producing carbohydrates with nothing but water vapor, carbon dioxide, ammonia gas and light. Soon after came Professor E. C. C. Baly of the University of Liverpool with still closer simulation of the process whereby plants synthesize some of the food we eat.
LONDON, Jan. 9.--England's bell ringers were aroused today over a proposal to introduce "canned" bell ringers at St. John's Church in Weymouth by installing a gramophone and amplifier in the belfry.

Order was restored today in Bizerta, Tunisia, where six persons were killed and thirty-six injured in riots yesterday. Ten demonstrators have been arrested. While the town is under guard, the market has been reopened. Leading citizens went to the authorities to give assurances of their loyalty and the Governor appealed to the natives to remain calm.
League of Nations circles today indicated that Great Britain and France were resolved to strip the League of its power to impose sanctions in an attempt to regain the cooperation of smaller nations.
The money market here became easier after the end-of-the-month maturities, and this week the call money rate sagged from 2 3/4-3 per cent to 2-2 1/2 per cent.

The four-day search by the navy for a giant patrol plane which vanished with seven men aboard came to a temporary end tonight. There was no official announcement as to whether the hunt would be continued.

The government proposes to build "another Alcatraz" for hard-boiled women convicts. Details have not been disclosed, but informed persons indicated today that the institution would probably be put in Eastern Kentucky or at Braggs, Okla., where officials have already inspected tentative sites.

Colonel Walter Jeffreys Carlin, member of the Board of Education, has been elected a trustee of the Brooklyn Bar Association to fill unexpired term of the late Leo J. Hickey, United States Attorney, it was announced yesterday.

Mme. Luisa Tetrazzini's voice, which thrilled opera lovers of the world beginning over twenty-five years ago, spoke and sang today for the United States by radio. She spoke twelve minutes, partly in Italian and partly in English, recalling her American experiences.

Formation of an advisory committee to guide the United Infants and Children's Wear Association in planning the program for the first annual National Children's Week to be held from Feb. 14 to 20 was announced yesterday by Max H. Zuckerman, executive secretary of the United Infants and Children's Wear Association.
Local British authorities banned unauthorized assemblies or demonstrations today after the police arrested more than sixty Chinese participating in an anti-Japanese procession.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, Secretary Perkins; Dr. Thomas Parran, Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service; Mayor La Guardia of New York City, Katharine F. Lenroot, chief of the Children's Bureau of the Department of Labor,

Mr. and Mrs. Albin Kesley Schoepf gave a tea at their home here this afternoon at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Joy Schoepf, to William Wilmot Boynton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert F. Boynton, also of Scarsdale.

Although the December return of British steel output has not been published yet, it has been announced that production in 1937 amounted to 12,900,000 tons, a rise of 300,000 in the last two years and compared to 9,600,000 in 1929.
Industry in Germany is quiet. The shortage in steel bars and in thick and medium sheets has become more intense, while the exports of heavy iron and steel have declined.

Captain Robert Arnold Vansittart, father of Sir Robert Vansittart, the British Government's chief diplomatic adviser, died yesterday at the age of 86. Captain Vansittart was the only son of the late Colonel Robert Vansittart and Elizabeth H. Vansittart.
Representative Celler of New York said today that he would introduce tomorrow a Constitutional amendment empowering the President to veto single items in a general appropriation bill.

Howard Coburn Foss, president of the Savannah Electric and Power Company and chairman of the Industrial Committee of Savannah, died here early this morning after a heart attack. He had been ill but a brief time. His age was 58.

The Jackson Day dinners held Saturday night throughout the country under the auspices of the Democratic National Committee were very successful financially, according to reports received yesterday by Postmaster General James A. Farley.

A large mission field still exists in the United States, the Rev. Arthur M. Knudsen, divisional secretary of the Board of American Missions of the United Lutheran Church of America, said in a sermon yesterday at St. James Lutheran Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-third Street.
Formation of Labor's Committee for Civilian Relief in China was announced today by Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor.

The Police Department's ban on parking on ten crosstown streets in the midtown area has proved so successful in speeding up traffic, that it will be enforced indefinitely, Inspector Matthew McGrath, commander of the First Traffic Division, declared yesterday.

Henry Llewellyn Daingerfield Lewis, a retired member of the New York Stock Exchange, died here early this morning at his home, Merriefield, of a coronary thrombosis. He was 61 years old. A native of Piedmont, Va., a son of Carter Penn Freeland and J. L.

Snow, swirling eastward, covered most of the Midwest today in what was the heaviest fall of the Winter for many sections. Motor traffic was hampered by slippery roads and poor visibility in the dense storm.

The fifteenth annual show of the Brooklyn Concourse Association of Homing Pigeon Flyers opened yesterday for a two-day stand in the Labor Lyceum Hall, 949 Willoughby Avenue, with nearly 800 birds on display by fanciers from the metropolitan area, Maine, Massachusetts, Connecticut, Pennsylvania and Illinois.

James McC. Clarke of Manchester, Vt., has been elected chairman of The Daily Princetonian, undergraduate newspaper of Princeton University, it was announced today by the publication's retiring head, Frank W. Rounds Jr. of Winchester, Mass.

A total of 1,106 nominations, an increase of 32 over the 1939 list, has been received for the 1940 running of the Belmont Futurity, it was announced yesterday by the Westchester Racing Association. Entries closed on Jan. 3 and there were also nine more nominators than for 1939.

GREENPORT, L. I., Jan. 9.--D. Stanley Corwin, Long Island building contractor, died today at his home, 639 Main Street, after an illness of five months. He was born in Greenport on Dec. 4, 1875, a son of the late Charles and Electa Corwin, and lived here throughout life.

Enactment of emergency legislation authorizing life insurance companies in this State to invest their funds for a limited time and in limited amounts in the construction of low-rent housing is recommended by Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, in his annual report to the Legislature.

Bailey Ave (12-3261), n e cor of Albany Crescent, 153x46; Arvo, Inc, to Vernex Estates, Inc, 551 5th Ave; mtg, $118,000. Davidson Ave (11-2862), e s, 233 ft s of West Tremont Ave, 110x54; Equitable Life Assurance Society to Herman Elkowitz, 54 Audubon Ave.

At various widely scattered points spokesmen of the Democratic party took advantage of Jackson Day to deliver various messages to the country. At Nashville Secretary Ickes returned to his attack upon "the sixty families."

Accustomed as the money market here is to easy conditions in January following year-end demands, the credit position currently is abnormally easy. Much comment, in fact, has been stirred by the market's turning the year without recourse to borrowing from the Bank of England.

With the Ludlow War Referendum petition out of the way for the time being, President Roosevelt moved today to present to Congress recommendations for a horizontal increase in the strength of the navy.
Additions to its $500,000 assembly plant here to permit assembling passenger cars as well as trucks will be completed by General Motors by June, it was announced today.

Steel operations for this week are scheduled at 27.8 per cent of ingot capacity, an increase of 2.2 points, or 8.6 per cent, from the operating rate of 25.6 per cent last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
The international polo series between the 124th Field Artillery Club of Chicago and the Cuban Army team ended today, the visitors taking the final game, 6 to 5.

George S. Van Schaick, vice president of the New York Life Insurance Company and former, State Superintendent of Insurance, has accepted a directorship on the board of the Associated Hospital Service of New York, the 3-centsa-day plan for hospital care, it was announced yesterday.

The Supreme Court of Canada reserved judgment today on the reference to decide whether the Dominion still had power to disallow provincial legislation and Lieutenant Governors had the right to reserve legislation for signification of the Governor General's pleasure.

Parleys in an effort to work out a reciprocity arrangement for the navigation of airplanes over commercial routes in the United States and Canada began here today. State and Commerce Department officials greeted a Canadian commission of eight, headed by V. I. Smart, Deputy Minister of Transport.
Italy has just shown that two can play at the sanctions game. Italy now invokes sanctions against the League of Nations by forcing Carlo to from Geneva.
The Reichsbank's statement as of Jan. 8 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

Management of Oriental Park today announced that Tuesdays and Wednesdays for the next two weeks will be omitted from the racing program so as to give late arriving horses from the United States a better chance to become acclimated.

Fellowships enabling experienced newspaper men from all parts of the United States to study at Harvard University on leave of absence from their papers will be established use der a bequest of about $1,000,000 by Mrs. Agnes Wahl Nieman, widow of the founder of The Milwaukee Journal, specifically "to promote and elevate the standards of journalism in the United States."

New Jersey Title Guarantee and Trust Company sold to the Falo Realty Company, Frank Loos, president, the one-story garage at 321327 Eighteenth Street, West New York. The building occupies a site 85 by 100 feet and has a capacity for storing sixty-five cars.
Homer Bassford, veteran St. Louis newspaper man and at one time city editor of The Kansas City Times, died at a hospital today after a brief illness at the age of 68.

While Mayor La Guardia, Police Commissioner Valentine and five deputy commissioners walked silently yesterday at the head of an inspector's funeral for Patrolman Frank E. Zaccor, who was shot Thursday morning in a midtown tavern robbery, plans were made for a similar funeral for Patrolman Anthony Tornatore, who was fatally wounded Thursday night when he surprised an unidentified prowler in the Bronx.

Notre Dame crushed Canisius, 57 to 33, in the feature game of a basketball double-header tonight after St. Bonaventure had defeated Niagara, 44 to 40. Five thousand spectators taxed the capacity of Broadway Auditorium.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 5: Decreases of $84,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans and $54,000,000 in loans to brokers and dealers in securities;

Indications are noted of a wider interest in the purchase of farm properties, according to Herbert U. Nelson, executive vice president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, who cites the fact that in a cross-section of seventysix sales recently reported to the institute of farm land brokers and managers of the national association, practically one-third were bought for investment purposes.

Defense attorneys prepared tonight to send their final Witness to the stand tomorrow in the Federal Government's gasoline price-fixing trial, which began on Oct. 4. Court attaches predicted the case would go to the jury on Friday or Saturday.

Although 2,265 city day laborers had a payless payday yesterday because of the dispute in the City Council over Mayor La Guardia's 1938 budget, an agreement reached during the afternoon offered bright prospects for adoption of the revised budget at today's meeting of the Council.
Church fund-raising through the use of gambling devices was condemned by the Presbytery of New York yesterday in a strongly worded report asserting that if the church had to resort to
The Senate Interstate Commerce Committee approved today a resolution calling for a searching investigation of the National Bituminous Coal Commission.

Proposed trade practice rules concerning the shrinkage properties of woven cotton yard goods growing out of a general trade practice conference held in New York at the suggestion of the New York Board of Trade were made public today by the Federal Trade Commission.

Eduardo Justo, the younger of President Agustin P. Justo's two sons, and eight others were killed last night when an army plane crashed in Uruguay on its way back to Buenos Aires after a ceremony at Uruguayana, Brazil, where President Justo and President Getulio Dornelles Vargas of Brazil had inaugurated work on a new international bridge across the Uruguay River.
Despite the highly irregular price trend in secondary railroad issues, the main body of bonds yesterday

The Charity Organization Society, which has for more than half a century confined its charitable activities to Manhattan, has undertaken, at the request of the Family Welfare Society of Queens, to include Queens in its territory for a two-year trial period.

Department store sales throughout the United States in December were 2 per cent below those for December, 1936, and the volume for the year was 6 per cent ahead of 1936, the Federal Reserve Bank reported yesterday.

Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. this afternoon confirmed a report from Mexico City that the Treasury Department had agreed to purchase 35,000,000 ounces of silver from the Mexican Government. The agreement was made on Dec. 31, he said, with the purpose of preventing fluctuations in world silver prices.

Twenty thousand persons applied for unemployment insurance in this State yesterday, Paul Sifton, administrator of the division of placement and unemployment insurance in the State Department of Labor, announced last night.

The Neediest Cases Fund reached a total of $299,586.22 yesterday with fifteen additional contributions amounting to $129. Fourteen of these were received by THE NEW YORK TIMES and one was received by the State Charities Aid Association. The list of contributions follows:
A group of Indiana banks bought yesterday an issue of $750,000 of temporary-loan notes of the city of Indianapolis, Ind., on a 1 1/4 per cent interest basis, plus a premium of $46.

Cracksmen ripped open the safe of the Trianon Company, Inc., jewelry shop, at 1,142 Sixth Avenue, some time early yesterday after breaking through the plaster wall of an adjoining luggage shop and escaped with the contents of the safe.
Preeminent, owned by Hal Price Headley, whose Whopper won the last two Hialeah Park Inaugural Handicaps, was assigned top weight of 126 pounds today for the track's 1938 opening feature Wednesday.
With the opening of the new Parliament-session in France tomorrow will begin what some persons, perhaps exaggeratedly, describe as "a final effort to maintain democratic government."

Fearing police action if they followed the example of Martin McBohin and obliterated the World's Fair "ad" on their 1938 automobile license plates, half a dozen motorists registered their protest against the "free advertising" in a different way here today.

Three bronze medals awarded to Captain Alan Villiers, former master of the square-rigged ship Joseph Conrad, and two cadets on that ship's world cruise by the Royal Society- for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, London, have

Major events today: The London Intimate Opera Company opens its second week at the Little Theatre with a new bill tonight; Lotte Lehmann and Lauritz Melchior, Metropolitan Opera singer, at Carnegie Hall tonight; Grischa Shub, violinist, at the Town Hall in the afternoon, and Poldi Mildner, pianist, at the Town Hall in the afternoon.
Midwinter tests of the new National League "dead" ball, with sluggers from three leagues participating, today brought three conclusions: 1. The dead ball has a soggy "whoosh" sound when hit.
