The number of business failures in the United States for the five days ended Jan. 6 was 268, compared with 249 in the preceding fiveday period and 177 for the same period last year, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

A concert for the benefit of the house plan of the City College will be heard at 8:30 P. M. Saturday at the college's Pauline Edwards Theatre, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue. Sponsored by the Faculty Wives Club of the college, the concert will be given by Sidney Sukoenig, pianist;
Following the wind-up of its annual convention, the National Retail Furniture Association announced that a "war chest" is being raised to fight what it characterizes as "fake wholesaling."

Kiyoshi Midzutani, representative of a federation of Japanese exporters and importers, sailed from Panama today for Port au Prince, Haiti, en route to the Dominican Republic. He plans the establishment of a Dominican colony of Japanese cotton planters similar to a colony of twelve families already established in Costa Rica.

President Roosevelt sent a-message to Speaker Bankhead in opposition to the Ludlow resolution, conferred with Secretary Hull and Admiral Leahy on plans for expanding the Navy and announced that tomorrow he would resume his discussions with public utility executives.

A furnished apartment containing thirteen rooms and four baths and occupying an entire floor in 635 Park Avenue has been leased to Hermann Irion, manager of Steinway Sons, by Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc. Other rentals follow: Harvey B. Nevins, in 333 E. 68th St.; Mrs. A. G. Dunnington, in 150 E. 73d St.; Eugene B. Bennett, in 14 E. 75th St.; Douglas L. Eillman Co., Inc., brokers.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Jan. 10.--Eight Puerto Rican Nationalists, accused of an attempt to assassinate United States District Judge Robert A. Cooper, were found guilty today after the refusal of the defense to take part in the selection of jurymen, introduce evidence or cross-examine witnesses had brought their trial to an abrupt close.

James C. Sheridan, Democratic leader of Queens, won out by a narrow margin in a clash in the Democratic executive committee last evening. James A. Roe, leader of the Committee for Democratic Unity, the opposing faction, announced that, despite Mr. Sheridan's invitation to get together for party harmony, the fight would be continued and carried to the full county committee.

An intensive study of ways to improve retail sales promotion in newspaper advertising, window display and internal promotion will be made at the sessions of the sales promotion division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the group's twenty-seventh annual convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania, Jan. 31 to Feb. 4.

Rowland B. Haines of the Columbia University Club, former national amateur squash tennis champion, made his first appearance in the Clyde Martin Memorial tournament at the Yale Club last night and showed to such marked advantage in winning two matches as to win added respect for his punitive treatment of the ball.
Dr. Blanche Colton Williams, head of the Department of English at Hunter College, announced yesterday that applications were now being received for the Helen Gray Cone Fellowship award, 1938-1939.

The first official meeting of Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg and Foreign Minister Guido Schmidt of Austria, Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano of Italy and Foreign Minister Koloman de Kanya of Hungary to deal with the agenda of the conference of Rome Protocol States did not take place until 5 o'clock this afternoon.

Japanese marines attempted yesterday to capture Tiger Island, near the Bocca Tigris forts at the mouth of the Pearl River, but 'were frustrated by alert Chinese who fired on a Japanese cutter towing boats filled with marines, it was disclosed today.

Mrs. Lawrence Townsend celebrated her 100th Musical Morning at the Mayflower today by presenting Gertrude Wettergren, contralto of the Metropolitan Opera, and Ruda Firkusny, Czechoslovakian pianist, who was making his American debut.

The "cross-fire of selfish industrial strife" and an "effective fiveweek strike called by the C. I. O." were given as the basis of a petition to reorganize under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act filed yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court by the Reliance Bronze and Steel Company, Inc., manufacturers of metal doors, windows and frames.
The General Telephone Company reported yesterday a net gain of 1,084 telephones in service in December, as compared with a gain of 1,301 instruments in December, 1936. During the entire year 1937,

Blackstone's Reflector, black cocker spaniel dog owned by Mrs. Leonard J. Buck of Far Hills, N. J., and handled in the ring by Bain Cobb, last night won the title of best in show at the twenty-third specialty fixture of the American Spaniel Club in the ballroom of the Hotel Roosevelt, defeating 275 other spaniels of various types entered in the two-day exhibition.

The Oil Transport corporation, operator of marine craft in the distribution of oil from tankers and refineries to wholesale distributors in ports along the Atlantic Coast, brought suit yesterday in Supreme Court here against seven officers and delegates of the Harbor Towboatmen's Union, claiming $150,000 damages because of a strike called last Tuesday on its barges.

The initial weekly report on traffic accidents for 1938 showed a a marked decline in accidents, deaths and injuries, compared with that of the corresponding period of 1937, it was announced yesterday by Fourth Deputy Police Commissioner Cornelius O'Leary.

The report of the Western Union Telegraph Company for the 'eleven months ended on Nov. 30, issued yesterday, shows a net income after interest, depreciation, Federal income taxes and other expenses and charges of $2,915,489.
Frederick John Mulhaupt, American artist, died tonight at his home here after a long illness. His age was 66. His works have been shown in this country's major exhibitions and in the Paris Salon.

Announcement was made here last night of the death yesterday in Syracuse, N. Y., of Vladimir Dubinsky of 323 West Eighty-third Street, a cellist, who had played with several of the leading American symphony orchestras.
So diligent were the House Democratic leaders in mustering their strength against the Ludlow war referendum resolution today that two members were brought in wheel chairs to vote against the measure.

When a Government plows through several years of hard times and reduces its operating deficit as it goes along that is news. When it does this without shirking its duty toward those of its citizens who are unemployed, sick, disabled or too young or too old to work that is even more important news.

While statisticians have been busy compiling figures showing that new construction permits in New York last year rose sharply as compared with 1936, many have overlooked the continued steady, increase In the amount of money expended for alterations.

Edwin J. Brown of Seattle, president of the National Association of State Racing Commissioners, told Winter convention delegates - today that the American weight system "eliminates a majority of our good jockeys" just when they reach their riding peak.

Fourteen Harvard alumni were named tonight as candidates for five vacancies on the university's board of overseers. The selection was made by the committee on nominations of the Harvard Alumni Association; the five new overseers will be elected this Spring by a postal ballot among graduates.
Elmer J. Maloy, Laborite Mayor, put this city of 22,000, in the heart of the Pittsburgh steel district, on what he termed a C. I. O. union basis today.

The racial issue over which the North and South have long differed drove today a deep cleavage in the Senate leadership when Senator Harrison assailed colleagues with whom he long had worked closely for sponsoring the Wagner Anti-lynching Bill. He spoke with blunt irony

The annual convention of the American Drug Manufacturers Association will be held at White Sulphur-Springs, W. Va., on May 2 to 5, it was announced yesterday by Carson P. Frailey, executive vice president, following a meeting of the directors at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Taxes paid by stockholders on profits made by British corporations before the profits were distributed as dividends cannot be deducted from the income taxes which American citizens must pay, the Supreme Court ruled today in rejecting, 6 to 3, the pleas of Mary Duke Biddle of New York and George E. Elkins of Elkins Park, Pa.

With the galleries packed and numerous standee lining the walls, the City Council continued as one of the best shows in the city -yesterday, appealing in equal degree to the studio audience in City Hall-and the radio audience that listened over WNYC. the city station.
The trade was inclined to place a bullish construction on the Department of Agriculture's report on farm reserves of wheat on Jan. 1 issued after the close of business today.

With Gloria Swanson removed from the starring role in Philip Barry's "Holiday," Columbia today announced that Katharine Hepburn has been borrowed from RKO for the part and will be teamed with Cary Grant, with Joan Bennett scheduled for the character of the younger sister. George Cukor,

Paint was flaking and peeling from her bulkheads, pools of water from leaking steam pipes soaked the sodden pile of her once luxurious carpets and the gray light of a gray day penetrated but dimly the dust-covered portholes of the liner Leviathan yesterday as workmen prepared her for her last voyage.

Warren Danforth Lane, director of transportation for the State Department of Public Service, a former State legislator and a former Seattle Councilman, died today of a heart attack in a Seattle hotel room. His age was 70.
Mrs. Motilal Nehru, widow of Pandit Motilal Nehru, Indian Congressional leader, and mother of Pandit Jawarharlal Nehru, this year's President of Congress, died today at Allahabad.

New York County Clerk Archibald R. Watson has decided to replace Owen M. Kiernan as his second deputy and Mrs. Margaret H. Fay as his third deputy, it was learned yesterday. Andrew B. keating, formerly the first deputy, already has retired.

Governor Lehman submitted tonight to the Legislature a budget of $385,824,459.17, some $15,000,000 less than last year, to cover the operations of the State government for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 1938, and ending June 30, 1939. The budget for the 1937-38 year was $400,969,842.41.

Public welfare costs in Westchester County have reached the "staggering" annual total of $20,806,000 and are increasing at therate of $2,000,000 a year, Supervisor Bert C. McCulloch of Mamaroneck informed the Board of Supervisors here today.

I so many choice, words, Henry Cotton, British open golf champion, today condemned the new stymie rule adopted by the United States Golf Association. The new U. S. G. A. rule eliminates stymies when the nearer ball lies within six inches of the cup.

A payment of $7.86 on each $1,000 bond of the thirteen direct and guaranteed external dollar loans of the Republic of Chile for 1938, payable on and after Feb. 1 at the office of the Schroder Trust Company, was announced yesterday by the Autonomous Institute for the Amortization of the Public Debt of the Republic of Chile.

The Ludlow resolution, providing that a national referendum be taken before the country shall go to war, except in case of invasion, was headed off by the Administration in the House today after a hard battle and by a close vote.

Officials of the Air Ministry said tonight that "technical collaboration" had been established between the Ministry and "corresponding departments in the United States" concerning aviation equipment in general and motors in particular.

Hartley W. Barclay, editor of Mill and ' Factory, called today for amendment of the Wagner Labor Act "to preserve equal rights for all workers and to make the act's collective bargaining provisions really bring industrial democracy."

A talking picture device which films scenes with ultra-violet rays is reported to have been perfected by Osamu Mabuchi, an assistant at Kyoto Imperial University, Japan, the Motion Picture Division of the Department of Commerce reported today.

The new spurt. in the arms race marked by successive American Italian and British announcements of bigger naval programs, caused much gloomy foreboding in the informal talks characterizing, as usual, today's monthly session of the board of the Bank for International Settlements.
The birth of Princess Juliana's child is expected within a few days. Two physicians and a number of nurses have arrived in Soest, where the Queen has also taken up residence.
The American Federation of Labor reported today that its membership had continued to grow through the business recession.

Judge John T. McGovern of New York, one of the authors of the famed "Bulletin 23" issued in 1928 by the Carnegie Foundation condemning proselytingg" of college athletes, modified his stand against athlete-aid in an address at the 18th Annual Testimonial Dinner for Notre Dame's football team tonight.

If it isn't one thing it's another with the game law enforcement agents of the United States Biological Survey, who are now having their hands full with illegal duck trappers in Maryland and Virginia.

The annual women's metropolitan Class B squash racquets championship started yesterday on the courts of the Heights Casino, Brooklyn, and reached the quarter-final round with all but one favorite coming through successfully.

While looking ahead to a renewal of the international cup series with England during the 1939 World's Fair, the United States Polo Association plans to strengthen its tournaments this year by keeping its teams at home.
The anti-religious campaign that was revived during preparations for the first "free" election under the new Soviet Constitution last month has now reached its highest point in many years.

Ninety-five plans for industrial building, representing investments 'totaling $1,516,330, in New York State outside New York City were submitted to the State Department: of Labor in December, and the number was the second largest for any December in thirteen years, Industrial Commissioner. Elmer F. Andrews announced yesterday.

W. Byron Kantack of St. Albans, L. I., and William H. Peck Jr. of Glen Ridge, N. J., members of the Campbell-Ely Law Club, were named winners today of the Scott Club prize at the Harvard Law School for the best brief submitted in the qualifying round of the Ames competition for second-year students.

William Ambrose Taylor Jr., a son of the late William Ambrose and Jessie Stillman Taylor of 988 Fifth Avenue, died yesterday of pneumonia in Kitzbuhel, Austria, while on a European tour with a friend, Newton Coleman of Dublin, N. H. He was 41 years old.

Mrs. Florence Winchester Sargent, widow of Joseph Bradford Sargent, former Mayor-of New Haven, who founded the hardware firm of Sargent Co., of this city and New Britain, one of the largest in the country, died today at her home here frOm a stroke of apoplexy suffered yesterday.

In reporting sales for December the J. C. Penney Company announced yesterday that its volume of business for 1937. aggregating $275,378,771, was the largest annual total in its history. It shows a gain of 6.6 per, cent over the 1936 figure of $258,332,479, the previous record high.
Argentina today defeated Sir Theodore Brinckman's touring English cricket team by 222 runs in the second unofficial test match. The Englishmen won the first encounter by two wickets.
Resident Roosevelt advised Congress today that $983,925,505 of old relief and public works funds were still available.

Jake Schaefer of Chicago and Welker Cochran of San Francisco, claimants of the world 18.2 balkline billiard championship, began a 4,200-point match at the Strand Academy yesterday, with undisputed ownership of the title at stake.

The American Museum of Natural History was visited by 1,781,697 persons during the past year, it was reported last night at the annual meeting of the Board of Trustees of the museum; This is an increase of 12,870 over the previous year.

Little danger of inflation exists in the United States despite the unbalanced budget, Dr. Marcus Nadler, research director of the Institute of International Finance and Professor of Banking and Finance at New York University, last night told the January meeting of the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
The Erie Railroad paid yesterday the interest due on one of the six bond Issues on which interest was defaulted on Jan. 1.

Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan dismissed yesterday contempt of court proceedings against Joseph Varon, who operates a retail liquor store at 90 Nassau Street and who was accused of cutting whisky prices in violation of an injunction obtained by Seagram Distillers Corporation.
A HISTORY OF THE BUSINESS MAN, by Miriam Beard. (Macmillan, $5.) A study of the business man, from the Homeric Age to the present.

PANAMA, Republic of Panama, Jan. 10.--Foreign Minister Jose E. Lefevre repudiated today a statement by the Panaman Minister to Germany, Francisco Villalaz, supporting Germany's claim for the return of her colonies.
The emergency court here sentenced a member of the International Association of Earnest Bible Researchers to four years and his wife to two years in a penitentiary today. The presiding judge

Although the weather man predicted that it would be warmer today and that the snow, if any, would be light, the Department of Sanitation was on the alert last night with its new $4,500,000 snowremoval equipment and the four snow-removal crews that trained at Lake Placid recently.

Because of complaints by commuters that the 1:30 A. M. train from Pennsylvania Station to Port Washington had been losing a quarter of an hour -on account of mail handling, the Long Island Railroad announced last night that mail would not be carried on that train beginning this morning.

G. Arthur Callahan, Joseph A. Cole, James A. Corcoran, Robert H. Cox Jr., J. Chester Cuppia, Horace E. Dunham, James A. Dyer, Harold H. Hart, James J. Hopkins, David U. Page, W. Reitze and Herbert A. Shipman yesterday were nominated for three-year terms as governors of the New York Curb Exchange.

More than 2,000,000 signatures have been obtained to a petition condemning war and the international race to increase armaments, it was announced yesterday at a meeting of the People's Mandate to End War at the home of Mrs. Amos J. Peaslee at 1,067 Fifth Avenue.

THE star-spangled Americans had just come off the ice from what must have been a warm practice session. As they shed their dripping uniforms and ambled into the shower stalls Mervyn the Red Dutton, their manager, sat on a trunk saying things through his clenched teeth. Every so often he placed his left hand gently against his left jaw and held it there for a minute.

The American Smelting and Refining Company advanced yesterday the price of copper in the domestic market from 10.50 cents a pound to 10.625 cents. The leading producers are continuing to quote 11 cents for their metal. Domestic sales on Saturday were 1,418 tons, against 1.994 Friday.

Charles T. Thuman, general agent for the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company in Richmond for eighteen years until he retired last September, died yesterday at his home at the age of 73. Surviving daughter, Aurora, all of White Plains.

Orders received by the General Electric Company in the last quarter of 1937 amounted to $73,997,063, compared with $84,857,181 correspondingly in 1936, a decrease of 13 per cent, Gerard Swope, president, announced yesterday.

The Lime Realty Corporation bought from James H. Coleman the vacant plot on the west side of Twenty-third Street, 250 feet north of Forty-first Avenue, Long Island City. The buyer owns the factory adjoining to the south and in the future will improve the parcel just acquired. The Herbert Callman Company was the broker.

Production in the wool textile industry and consumption of apparel class wools fell to new low levels in November and sales of yarns and fabrics continued in very small volume, according to figures issued yesterday by the National Association of Wool Manufacturers.

The trial date for Mrs. Ethel Strouse Sohl, 20 years old, and Genevieve Owens, 17, confessed hold-up slayers of William Barhorst, a bus driver, was set here today for next Monday when the prisoners were arraigned before Common Pleas Judge Dallas Flannagan on a indictment charging murder. They pleaded not guilty.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10.--The Securities and Exchange Commission issued today an order declaring that the Public Service Corporation of Texas had ceased to be a holding company under the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935.

The condition of Associate Justice Cardozo of the Supreme Court was unchanged, his physician said this evening. No bulletin was issued, it being stated informally that there was "nothing new to say." Dr. John Paul Earnest Jr. is his physician.

The University of Cincinnati today added Heartly (Hunk) Anderson to its football coaching staff as assistant. Acting Athletic Director Charles Mileham announced the appointment of the assistant University of Michigan Coach and former Notre Dame mentor.

Style piracy and other chaotic conditions in the women's ready-towear dress industry prior to the advent of the Fashion Originators Guild of America, Inc., were charged yesterday by Milton C. Weisman, guild counsel, at a hearing before Charles F. Diggs, Federal Trade Commission examiner, at 45 Broadway.

For its third concert of the season the Beethoven Association marshaled a brilliant array of artists in a full and rewarding program last night. They were Erica Morini, Adolf Busch and William Kroll, violinists; Maurice Marechal, 'cellist, and Frank Sheridan and Milton Kaye, pianists.

Nathan Straus, Administrator of the United States Housing Authority, announced today that expert inspection of the Lockfield Garden Apartments in Indianapolis had revealed no structural faults affecting the stability of the building, and only such defects in ceilings, walls and floors, as could be, and were being, corrected, in a few apartments.

Japanese forces landed at Tsingtao yesterday, capturing the city without meeting resistance. They found property of their nationals widely devastated. Other foreigners were permitted to return to their homes. Forces pressed on to capture the Tsingtao-Tsinan Railroad, and others continued the drive on Suchow. [Page 1.]
Danarco, flying the light blue and gold banner of the Toronto-owned Cosgrave Stable, made a show of six other four-year-olds in the Governor's Purse at Tropical Park today.

The vote against consideration of the Ludlow resolution in the House of Representatives yesterday may well mark a historic turning-point in the development of American foreign policy. For this is the first significant setback, during the whole post-war period,

A Northwest Airlines transport plane crashed on a snow-covered peak high in the Bridger Mountains fourteen miles northeast of here late today, carrying to their deaths ten persons listed as being aboard.

El Salvador has made concessions on the importation of champagne in return for France's concessions on the importation of El Salvador's high-grade coffee, according to an agreement extending to Dec. 31, 1938. The two countries established their commercial treaty in 1901.
F. C. Horner, of the staff of the chairman of the board of General Motors Corporation, will address the Women's Traffic Club of Greater New York at the George Washington Hotel tonight.
Woodmere Academy opened its basketball season today with a 23-to-14 victory over the Collegiate School of Manhattan in a Metropolitan A. A. P. S. Southern Division game.

YR OBEDIENT HUSBAND, a "sentimental comedy" in three acts, by Horace Jackson. Settings by Jo Mielzner; staged by John Cromwell; produced by Marwell Productions (Fredric March and Mr. Cromwell). At the Broadhurst Theatre.
With apparel buyers arriving here in large numbers and with curtain and drapery shows -opening, the buying of Spring merchandise was launched yesterday on a fairly extensive scale.
Milton Bode, theatrical manager who produced more than 100 pantomimes, died today at his home. at Mapledurham while on a European tour with near here. He was 78 years old.

The earnings of the Brooklyn Trust Company in 1937 amounted to $611,215, George V. McLaughlin, president of the Brooklyn Trust Company, informed stockholders at their annual meeting, held yesterday morning. This compared with $1,100,888 in 1936.
Assemblyman Middleton, Republican, from the Seventh Assembly District, Manhattan, introduced a bill tonight to allow the courts to grant alimony to a husband in marital disputes.
Marco, a paradox among hermit thrushes who finds his Miami in Manhattan, had ornithologists all atwitter yesterday.

Secretary. Morgenthau announced this afternoon there would be no Treasury financing on Jan. 15 in addition to the current weekly issues of ninety-one-day bills, the proceeds of which will be used to retire maturing nine-month bills.
A wage agreement covering 793 employes in the traffic department was signed yesterday by The Associated Press and the Comercial Telegraphers Union, A. F. of L. affiliate.

The Labor Relations Board certified the National Maritime Union today as exclusive collective bargaining representative for unlicensed personnel on vessels operated by the Southern Pacific Company and the Shepard Steamship Company, both of New York City.
Louis Klein, sugar broker, died Sunday at his home at 50 Rugby Road, Brooklyn, after an illness six months. He was in his eightysixth year and had been in the sugar business for seventy-one years.
The text of Governor Lehman's budget message, sent to the Legislature today, is as follows:

An impressive triumph by John S. Harrison of the Squash Club, topseeded entrant, was overshadowed by the elimination of J. Burke Wilkinson of the Harvard Club, 1937 runner-up, and John Hope Doeg, former national tennis champion,

Shipments of finished steel products by the United States Steel Corporation in December were 489,070 tons, a decline of 98,171 tons from those of November. In December, 1936, the corporation shipped 1,067,365 tons, or 578,295 tons above the total for last December.
Mrs. Dixie Bibb Graves, who entered the Senate last Aug. 19 as an appointee of her husband, Governor Graves of Alabama, relinquished her seat today.

Federal Judge John C. Knox, imposing sentence yesterday upon sixteen defendants recently convicted of racketeering in the city's $75,000,000-a-year fur industry, said he regretted that the anti-trust laws, under which the men were specifically accused, did not carry more severe penalties.

Louisville Gas and Electric Company and Subsidiaries--Twelve months to Nov. 30: Net income, $2,726,072, after interest, amortization, taxes, amortization of flood and rehabilitation expense and other charges, compared with a net of $3,178,393 in the twelve months to Nov. 30, 1936; gross

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 10.--Using the new fourteen-club limit rule of the United States Golf Association for the first time in a local tourney, Leon Sikes of West Palm Beach played brilliantly to win the medal in the qualifying round of the annual Lake Worth golf championship at the Palm Beach Golf Club today with a sub-par round of 33, 35-68.

The Admiralty announced today the appointment of eight rear admirals, three of whom will be placed on the retired list. Those remaining on the active list are Captain Henry R. Moore, chief of staff to the Commander in Chief of the Home Fleet;

The new six - story apartment house at 161 East Eighty-eighth Street passed into new hands yesterday. The structure, completed last Fall and now reported as fully rented, was taken by the Fldbro Corporation as an investment, according to Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., brokers in the deal.

Thousands of automobiles were inspected for driving safety yesterday at twenty-eight inspection stations throughout New Jersey in the first day of the State's campaign to reduce highway casualties through the elimination of motor vehicles' mechanical defects.

Jacques Cartier, whose appearances in the past have been concerned exclusively with dancing, last night returned to New York, after an absence of three years, in a type of performance entirely remote from the field of choreography.

Carnegie Hall was packed to the gunwales last night when the Helsinki University Chorus, which made its New York debut last Thursday evening with the Boston Symphony Orchestra, gave a program under its own director, Martti Turunen, of Finnish "a cappella" music.

Reports of increased year-end sales and new production figures for 1937 were made public here yesterday by the Buick and Pontiac divisions of General Motors Corporation. W. F. Hufstader, general sales manager, reported that sales

Joel Hunt, for five years backfield coach at Louisiana State University and a former Texas A. and M. star, was named head football coach of the University of Georgia tonight, succeeding Harry J. Mehre.

Among the contracts for commercial space reported by brokers yesterday was one for a store in the new apartment building under construction by the Wallenstein Realty Corporation at the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street.

Most commodity futures moved higher yesterday in active trading on the local Exchanges. Rubber futures were particularly strong, advancing 50 to 53 points. In the cash markets rubber, wool tops, silk, cotton, tin, wheat, flour, cocoa, butter and lard advanced, but corn, rye, pork and antimony declined.

General Motors announced a new car in the Cadillac shops today and started a back-to-work parade in the automobile industry which will put about 100,000 workers back on their jobs during the next two or three weeks.
Gifford Pinchot, one of the original Bull Moose leaders and a conservative liberal, today announced his candidacy for the Republican nomination for Governor in the May primaries.

The seventh week of the Metropolitan Opera season began last night with a performance of "Die Walkuere." There were several major changes in cast from presentations of the music-drama earlier in the season.

Kenneth S. Templeton was unanimously reelected today as president of the Chicago Board of Trade. Orrin S. Dowse, vice president of the Stratton Grain Company, was elected second vice president, defeating Parker M. Paine by 571 to 183 votes. Under the rules Barnett

A four-point program for working out a better understanding among the English-speaking democracies, in connection with the Anglo-American trade treaty negotiations, was put forward yesterday by Bernard M. Baruch, financier, influential Democrat and friend of President Roosevelt.
The annual General Assembly Council of Jewish Federations and Welfare Funds ended tonight with a symposium in which belief was expressed that American Jewry was in danger of decimation.

The Planetoid now known as the "Object Reinmuth, "which narrowly missed crashing into the earth recently, may return in a few years, it was reported tonight. The possibility was announced by the Johannesburg Star, which originally published the story of the earth's narrow escape.
Eben Joseph Knowlton, retired manufacturer, died on Sunday at his home, 87 Remsen Street, Brooklyn, after a short illness. He was 93 years old.

Strong criticism of the League of Nations and pessimism about its future were the main features of an address to the Foreign Affairs Commission of the Sejm [Parliament] by Foreign Minister Josef Beck today. He declared that the present international crisis is primarily a League crisis caused by the League's difficulties and failures.

Trading was generally fair. The lamb market was lower; steer cuts steady to lower; fresh pork stronger; other traefa meats mostly steady. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef to be steady to lower, and other classes lower, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

The annual report of F. W. Woolworth Co., Ltd., for 1937, released in London yesterday, shows a net profit of [Pound]4,792,948 after all expenses, directors' and managers' remuneration, depreciation and [Pound]1,697,066 provision for taxation. The net profit in 1936 amounted to [Pound]4,576,315.

The stock market here was quiet in general today but a cheerful tendency prevailed. Gilt-edge issues showed little change,. while foreign loans were undecided for the most part, with Japanese bonds weaker.
James F. O'Leary of The New York Post was elected president of the Association of City Hall Reporters at their annual meeting yesterday in City Hall.
Fifty-nine of the first 200 men on the new eligible list for firemen hold college degrees, it was disclosed yesterday by Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission.

Ercole Buratti, 154 1/2 pounds, of Italy won an unpopular decision over Joe Marsh, 149, of Montreal, last night in the feature eight-round bout before 3,000 spectators at St. Nicholas Palace. The contest was the first in a New York ring for Buratti.

Preliminary distribution of $565,000 of the $2,090,000 raised in the United Hospital Fund campaign was announced yesterday to the fund's executive committee by Gates W. McGarrah, treasurer. The second distribution will be made in June.

The appointment of a central standing committee to promote the coordination of neighborhood agencies dealing with school maladjustment and delinquency was announced yesterday by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools.
Mr. and Mrs. Aksel Wichfeld entertained with a large dinner tonight at their villa for their house guests, Mr. and Mrs. Harold W. Brooks of New York.
The Marquess of Abergavenny, prominent in British hunting circles for over half a century, was killed today when he was thrown from his horse while fox hunting.

The amnesty for common criminals recently approved by Congress along with that for political prisoners was vetoed today by President Federico Laredo Bru. He regarded the measure, which it was predicted, would liberate 80 per cent of the criminals in Cuban jails, as too broad in scope.

An informal agreement has been reached by the Port of New York Authority and the Columbia Amusement Park Company calling for the purchase by the authority of 225,000 square feet of land in Columbia Park, North Bergen, N. J., to be used in connection with the creation of a system of approaches to the new Lincoln Tunnel, it was learned yesterday.

Asserting the basic trouble of business was an attempt by President Roosevelt to blend two irreconcilable economic policies, Dr. Raymond E. Moley, former "braintruster," today advanced a threepoint program of his own for fighting the recession.

Charles G. Weber and Martin N. V. Geib, working in the paper section of the National Bureau of Standards in cooperation with and with the financial support of the Lithographic Technical Foundation, have developed a relatively simple

The Interstate Commerce Commission made public today a valuation report on the property of the Empire Pipeline Company, a unit in the Empire Gas and Fuel Company's system, an affiliate of the Cities Service Company, finding the value of property owned and used for common-carrier purposes to be $4;500,000.

President Roosevelt will resume tomorrow his conferences with public utility executives looking toward a compromise between the government and the utilities which may result in a statement of the administration's policy, and a resumption of utility construction.

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Design: English Decorative Arts," Grace Cornell, 11 A. M.; the collection of Greek art (general tour) noon: motion pictures, 2:30 P. M.; "Color in Dress," Grace Cornell, 3 P. M.; "Egypt: The Ptolemies and Rome," Edwin L. M. Taggart, 4 P. M.

Because it has officially been made a matter of public record, the press of the country has been publishing long lists of persons receiving corporation salaries of more than $15,000 a year. This information is compiled and made public by the Treasury in accordance with Section 148-d of the Revenue Act of 1934.

Grocery sales volume last month was better than either wholesalers or retailers had expected and averaged only about 3 per cent below the volume for the corresponding period of 1936, the American Institute of Food Distribution reported in its weekly survey yesterday.

Finance Minister Dunning announced at noon today that the $50,000,000 of government-guaranteed Canadian National Railway bonds had been subscribed in one hour and fifteen minutes after the books opened.
Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador to the United States, and Arnold

When Birger Ruud, Olympic and world ski jumping champion, arrives here tonight on the Europa of the North German Lloyd Line, he will find that his plans for extensive competition will have to be changed considerably.
J. Tyler Meadows, president of the First. National Exchange Bank of Roanoke, died here today after a four-day illness at the age of 71.

A 15-year-old boy was. knocked down in the Sunnyside yard of the Long Island Railroad last night by contact with an electric wire containifig a charge of 6,000 volts more than in the electric chair at Sing Sing and still lives to tell of his experience.
Statistics showing that Germany's foreign trade has been shifted in recent years from Europe to other continents were made public today by the Department of Commerce.
Benson Brookley Boss, Southern manager for an Eastern manufacturing concern, died yesterday at his home in Guilford at the age of 50. He was a graduate of Dickinson.

The old American colonial style house of twenty-five rooms, known as Hopestill Cottage, at Woodstock, Vt., has been purchased by Mrs. Alfred T. Zoebisch' of Westfield, N. J. The estate of Mary Sanders Clark was the seller.

Purchases of securities in odd lots on the New York Stock Exchange on Saturday continued to exceed sales, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today, with customers' orders to buy numbering 5,609, for 137,641 shares, and customers' orders to sell, 3,712, for 102,088 shares.
With budgets providing for purchases equal to approximately 85 per cent of last year's quotas, a large contingent of out-of-town ready-to-wear buyers arrived in the local markets yesterday.
An issue of $100,000,000 of four months' notes was sold by the State today at an annual interest rate of one-fourth of 1 per cent to eighty-two banks and bond firms.

Criticism of the traffic-control system by Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan was answered yesterday by Police Commissioner Valentine in a statement in which he pointed to the reduction in street accidents here and the lack of funds for creating a standardized set-up and informed the justice that "the traffic problems of a large -city cannot be solved by laymen."
" Holland, Indoors and Outdoors," the exhibition is called that opened yesterday at the Knoedler Galleries, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Lammot du Pont,. president of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., one of the nation's foremost industrialists, told the Senate Committee on Unemployment today that his corporation was planning to spend $38,000,000 on new construction this year despite its estimate of a probable decline of 23 per cent in its sales during the next six months.

Announcement has been made here of the marriage on Thursday in Delrey Beach, Fla., of Mrs. Kathleen Jackson Sterry, daughter of Mrs. Warren B. Nash of 888 Park Avenue and the late Gerard Livingston Jackson, to Frederic Eustis Boyd of Wilton, Conn.
Jimmy Thomson won the second major golf tournament of his career today when he posted a 72-hole score of 273 to walk away with the $7,500 Los Angeles open.

Eighty-four motorists received summonses yesterday for parking in one or another of the ten midtown streets where parking had been banned by the police in an attempt to relieve traffic congestion in mid-Manhattan.

MOSCOW, Jan. 10.--The north polar ice floe on which . Ivan D. Papanin and his three fellow-scientists are making observations now has begun drifting so rapidly into southern waters that the Great Northern Sea Route Administration is obliged to make new plans for their earliest removal.

The Earl of Beauchamp, Lord Hiffe, co-proprietor of The London Daily Telegraph; Sir John Barwick, Lady Napier, Sir William MaxMueller and Lady Max-Mueller are among the passengers arriving today on the North German Lloyd liner Europa.
The government requested a court investigation today of alleged wasting of the assets of the Eastern Utilities Investing Corporation, a subsidiary of the Associated Gas and Electric Company.
Mrs. Collin Ford has announced the marriage of her daughter, Miss. Betty Ford, to Alvin B. Burden, son of Mr. and Mrs. I. Townsend Burden of New York and a grandson of Mrs. Dennis Sheedy of Denver.

Regulation of newsprint production and prices had a large part in a conference today among Premiers Mitchell Hepburn of Ontario and Maurice Duplessis of Quebec and five Quebec and two Ontario Cabinet Ministers.
The Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, Inc., in a statement issued yesterday on the 1938 payment offered on Chilean dollar bonds, reiterated its stand taken in the two previous years by again

The kindergarten department of the Board of Education held its annual conference in memory of the late Luella A. Palmer, former director of kindergartens, at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday. Miss attack as he was walking along 169th Street near his home. He was 41 years old. Mr. Noah, who had been in the postal service for sixteen years, was with the American Expeditionary Force in France. Surviving are his widow,
Although the weather gave no particular encouragement to the matter at hand, the Giants' official family put in a busy session yesterday clearing the decks for the 1938 Spring training campaign.

This evening the opening is of' "Stop-Over," or the saga of the regeneration of an actor. Matt and Sam Taylor wrote it, and heading the acting company are Arthur Byron, Sidney Blackmer and Muriel Kirkland. Worthington Miner directed and the theatre is the Lyceum.

Although the so-called seventytwo-hour period has passed, no note from the Soviet Government relative to the Robinson-Rubens case was received yesterday by the State Department, it was disclosed in Washington last night.

Albert Sarraut, director of French North African affairs, will preside at a meeting of the North African Affairs committee Thursday, which will deal with the situation in Tunisia, which has been aggravated by the recent outbreak of violence in Bizerta.

Two coastwise freighters were in head-on collision at 10 o'clock last night in upper New York Bay, a mile southeast of Robbins Reef Lighthouse. One of them, the Southland, owned by the Norfolk and Washington Steamboat Company had to be beached shortly afterward.

Mrs. Isadore A. Yerxa Farnsworth, a charter member of the Montclair Chapter of the Daughters of the British Empire and of the Upper Montclair Women's Club, died here today at her home, 500 Park Street, after a week's illness.

About 175 new kinds of hardy, seedless grapes, many of them deemed suitable for commercial culture, were developed in experimental work done at the New York Botanical Garden during the past year, it was announced yesterday by Dr. H. A. Gleason, head curator, at the annual meeting of the board of managers, held in the board room of the Guaranty Trust Company, 54 Liberty Street.

Charles Fine Taylor, vice president and general manager of the Lummis Peanut Company, died yesterday at his home here after a brief illness. Born sixty-three years ago in Camden, N. J., he came to Suffolk in played with the New York, Philadelphia, Rochester, Syracuse and Minneapolis Symphony Orchestras. His widow, Ida Dubinsky, survives.

The government has confiscated gold bars valued at $31,000, brought here from Havana by two Cubans, Dr. Ochoa y Ochoa and Dr. Marco Antonio Villalongo, on Jan. 5. It is alleged the men attempted to smuggle uninvoiced gold into the country without paying the fees.
Among those defeated by Samuel Reshevsky, chess champion of the United States and winner of the recent international tournament at Hastings, was W. A. Fairhurst of

ROBERT NATHAN'S new novel* is a warm little book, to my mind far more successful than its immediate predecessor, "The Enchanted Voyage." It is sufficiently typical that one may apply to it "idyllic," "tender" and other adjectives regularly trotted out in reviewing Mr. Nathan's work, but it has at the same time more than usual substance and relevance.

There are several ways of analyzing the vote in the House today on Representative Ludlow's proposal to change our form of government from a representative republic to a pure democracy by submitting the question of declaring war to popular referenda.

The Almoners met yesterday at a luncheon in Sherry's. Mrs. Thomas J. Farrell, president, presided. The Almoners contribute to the support of the New York Foundling Hospital, the Barat Settlement and St. Vincent's Hospital.

Mr. and Mrs. E. L. Winkel returned to their home at 32 Crestmont Avenue here at 1:30 A. M. today and, finding the lights on and the furniture askew, telephoned to the police that their house had been burglarized.
Gustave Von Palm, proprietor of a local art shop and a teacher of art classes here, who claimed to be a baron descended from an Austrian noble family, died at his home in Avon today at the age of 84.

Thousands more came to the Motor Boat Show yesterday, sales managers made additional entries in order books and the flag-bedecked Grand Central Palace on Lexington Avenue continued to wear its nautical air.

The American Radio Telegraphists Association, an affiliate of the Committee for Industrial Organization, charged today before the National Labor Relations Board that the Western Union Telegraph Company had "coerced" employes into paying in more than $500,000 in dues into a company union.

The bomb outrages of last September 11, in which two policemen were killed, were perpetrated by Cagoulards [Hooded Ones], it was definitely asserted by Minister of the Interior Marx Dormoy tonight. Three of the four guilty persons are said to be in custody.

Charles Paddock, formerly the world's speediest runner, who is a member of the Committee of 10,000 of Long Beach, Calif., which has started a warfare on the invasion of petty racketeers there from the North, called at District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey's office yesterday to get some pointers on how to cope witch the racketeers.
Mrs. Wilton Lloyd-Smith gave a reception yesterday afternoon at her home, 10 Gracie Square, for the Rev. John W. Suter Jr., rector of the Church of the Epiphany, and Mrs. Suter.
Bookings and billings of the Mengel Company and its subsidiaries For December and twelve months, and unfilled orders as of Dec. 31, 1937, compare as follows:

Seventeen prisoners who had been in the Tombs since the administration of former District Attorney Dodge, all held on felony indictments, were permitted to plead guilty to reduced charges yesterday in General Sessions, under a policy recently announced by District Attorney Dewey.

A dual power plant unit, using two engines mounted side by side, and both geared to the same propeller, was announced here today by the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, in collaboration with the Menasco Manufacturing Company.

Declaring that the men's clothing industry is facing. "difficult times," Jacob M. Franklin of the Franklin Clothing Company, Woodbine, N. J., and president of the International Association of Clothing Designers, yesterday warned members that

Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 37,000, including 15,000 directs. Market active; 230 pounds down steady to 10 cents higher than Friday's average:

Paul J. Moore, former Congressional Representative from the Eighth New Jersey District, and former chief of the Newark Fire Department, died here tonight in St. Michael's Hospital from the effects of a stroke suffered this afternoon.

Chairman Ashurst of the Judiciary Committee informed the Senate today that hereafter all Presidental nominations for judicial appointments, whether to the Supreme or lower courts, would be open to public hearings.

Elisabeth Rethberg, soprano, and Ezio Pinza, basso, of the Metropolitan Opera Company, and Erica Morini, violinist, were the artists heard at Albert Morris Bagby's 403d Musical Morning yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria. Milton Kaye and Edwin McArthur were the accompanists.
The financial community took in its stride the sale yesterday of $100,000,000 of New York State four-month 0.25 per cent tax-anticipation notes.

Jim Londos, 200, Greece, former world heavyweight wrestling champion, threw John Sullivan, 275, Ireland, with an airplane spin and body slam in the feature exhibition, slated for a finish, at the Hippodrome last night. The time was 36 minutes 29 seconds.

For the second time since the government of Premier Duplessis of Quebec began its anti-Communist drive, provincial police today raided the office of Louis Kon, executive officer of the Friends of the Soviet Union. They seized a truckload of alleged Red books, newspapers and other literature under the "Padlock Law."

Members of the New York Stock Exchange elected yesterday a seven-man nominating committee for 1938 out of a slate of twentyone. The new body is charged with selecting candidates for president, the governing committee and the trustees of the gratuity fund, who will be elected in May.
Before a professional but friendly audience, the American Theatre Council's committee on the apprentice theatre yesterday afternoon unveiled Broadway's newest showcase for acting talent.

William O'Dwyer, who was made a Kings County judge recently, was inducted to that office yesterday morning in the Brooklyn Central Court Building in the presence of several hundred friends and relatives. He was appointed to a place made vacant through the elevation of Judge Algeron I. Nova to the Supreme Court.

Gordon Drillon of the Toronto Maple Leafs managed to pick up enough points in the last week to retain a comfortable lead at the head of the National Hockey League's scorers. Tonight's official statistics give him a total of 27,
In the Supreme Court of the United States today John B. King, Morris Ehrlich, George S. Leisure and William P. McCool of New York were admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had:

An Army airplane from Barksdale Field fell into heavy timber near here tonight, killing its two occupants. They were identified as Lieutenant Frank Thompson of Columbus, Ohio, the pilot; and W. T. Mathews, a non-commissioned officer. Jack Fair, a newspaper
The engagement of Miss Alberta Edwards, daughter of Mrs. Alfred B. Edwards of this place and East Marion, L. I., and the late Mr. Edwards, to George Parker of Brooklyn, was announced today by

The New York Rovers and the Atlantic City Sea Gulls remained tied for the lead in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League race as a result of their 5-5 overtime battle at Madison Square Garden last night before 5,823 fans.

The upward movement in prices on the Cotton Exchange carried all months into new high ground yesterday, with net gains of 9 to 11 points. Stimulated by strong outside markets here and another sharp rise in Bombay, buying broadened under commission house, domestic trade and foreign absorption of contracts.

Stocks advanced to best levels since November and closed higher with gains to 3 points; turnover, 1,827,510 shares. United States Government bonds higher, other groups irregular; transactions, $6,579,175.

It was officially announced today that Col. Gen. Hermann Goering will remain as provisional Economic Minister until the end of the month instead of turning over the Ministry to Walther Funk, the new permanent Economic Minister, on Jan. 15, as originally announced.

Granting of a certificate of public convenience and necessity to All-American Bus Lines, Inc., successor in interest to Ni Sun Lines, Ltd., was recommended to the Interstate Commerce Commission today in a report by Kenneth J. McAuliffe, examiner.

Geo-getown University's basketball team provided an upset here tonight by defeating hitherto unbeaten Temple, 39-22. It was the opering Eastern Conference game for both teams. The Hoyas led at the half, 24-12.

Acting on the suggestion of the party's high command, Republican leaders in the Assembly tonight enlarged the size of the Rules Committee from 15 to 16 members and gave the new place to Assemblyman Minkoff of the Bronx, the American Labor party's leader in the chamber.

About 110 persons will share the $25,000 reward posted by New Jersey for the arrest and conviction of the kidnapper and slayer of the infant Charles A. Lindbergh Jr., under an apportionment of the money announced today by Governor Hoffman.

Fred Apostoli, San Francisco middleweight who knocked out Champion Freddie Steele in a non-title bout last week, will make his next ring appearance in Madison Square Garden on Feb. 4 against Glen Lee, the Nebraska star, who boasts two impressive local victories.
Announcement has been made or the engagement of Miss Marion Stearns Sim, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Alexander Sim of this place, to Walter Le Gare Reid, also nf Westfield.

Eugene G. Grace, president of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, will inform employee of the company and subsidiaries today that the policy of work-sharing that was arranged with employes during the depression is again being applied.

The presence at a Cabinet meeting today of Professor Alexander C. Cuza, Minister Without Portfolio, refuted rumors that he was parting from Premier Octavian Goga because he considered the Premier's anti-Semitism too lukewarm. The Cabinet made preparations for revision of the citizenship of Jews arriving in Rumania after 1920.
Mr. and Mrs. Aksel Wichfeld entertained with a large dinner tonight at their villa for their house guests, Mr. and Mrs. Harold W. Brooks of New York.

David Schenker, counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission, traced the financial activities of several investment trusts today, seeking evidence to prove that close cooperation between them had resulted in several stock transfer deals closed to the minority stockholder.

Foreign correspondents in Shanghai today were working under an "open" Japanese censorship instead of the "blind" regulation to which they had to submit when Japanese censors first were established in cable and radio offices last week.
Kentucky's four race tracks handled a pari-mutuel turnover of $11,954,170 during 1937, the State Racing Commission disclosed in its biennial report to the General Assembly today.

Senator Murray of New York City introduced in the Legislature tonight the "County Bill," companion measure to the Omnibus Bill for New York City agencies not covered in the new city charter. The bill would codify for the new charter laws in the old charter pertaining to county offices.
JERUSALEM, Jan.10.--James Leslie Starkey, a noted British archaeologist, known especially for his excavations in Palestine, was killed this afternoon by a band of armed Arabs.

Miss Theodora Kingsbury gave a supper last night at her home, 1,030 Fifth Avenue, for Miss Natalie O. Watts and Morgan Hatton Grade Jr., whose marriage will take place tomorrow in St. Bartholomew's Church. Guests, several of whom will be members of the bridal party,

Theodore Edson Parker, reported to have been the largest individual stockholder of American Telephone and Telegraph Company at one time, died early today at his home after an illness of five years. His age was 80.
Legislation to authorize a Federal investigation of the sales methods of automobile manufacturers and dealers received the approval of the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce today.

After listening to admonitions of leaders urging economies, the House defeated by a voice vote today an amendment to the Independent Offices Appropriation Bill offered by Representative Johnson of Oklahoma to add $45,000,000 to the appropriation of $226,331,000 proposed for the Civilian Conservation Corps.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I congratulate THE TIMES upon the ability and clarity of its editorials and the fullness and fairness of its news reports on the Japanese aggressions in China. I venture to emphasize a serious factor in the problem to which THE TIMES has referred but which few Americans appear to take into account.

Foreign correspondents in Shanghai today were working under an "open" Japanese censorship instead of the "blind" regulation to which they had to submit when Japanese censors first were established in cable and radio offices last week.

The establishment of the first large consumer-farmer milk cooperative in this area and the further spread of the sale of grade B milk at 10 cents or less a quart were assured yesterday afternoon when Holton V. Noyes, State Commissioner of Agriculture, announced that the application of the Consumer-Farmer Milk Cooperative, Inc., for a license to sell milk would be granted.
Hendrik Willem van Loon has sent his publishers, Simon Schuster, the first installment of a new book, entitled "A History of the Average Man." Mr. van Loon

Members of the Drama League who were subscribers to the organization's dinner last year were guests of Mrs. Samuel Newton yesterday at a tea at her home, 136 East Sixty-fourth Street, at which plans were discussed for the annual dinner to be given on Feb. 20.

Experimentation for improvement in silver fox breeding and breeding in greater quantities with resulting lower prices offer "a golden opportunity" for expansion to the industry, Harry Binn, fur buyer for Arnold Constable Co.,
Mr. and Mrs. Aksel Wichfeld entertained with a large dinner tonight at their villa for their house guests, Mr. and Mrs. Harold W. Brooks of New York.

David Schenker, counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission, traced the financial activities of several investment trusts today, seeking evidence to prove that close cooperation between them had resulted in several stock transfer deals closed to the minority stockholder.

The "preservation and encouragement of orderly processes" is the transcending interest of the United States in China, an interest even greater than the protection of citizens or of trade, Secretary of State Cordell Hull said in a letter to Vice President. John N. Garner, made public today.

A skating party on the lake of the old Oak Ridge Country Club in the town of Eastchester turned to tragedy this afternoon when Robert Grosso, 19 years old, a student, crashed through the ice and was drowned in about ten feet of water. He lived at 162 Lake Avenue, Tuckahoe.
Great Britain notified the United States and France today she would oppose all Japanese demands for permanent changes in the administration of Shanghai's International Settlement.

A construotive national youth program sponsored by the National Aeronautic Association as a stimulus to the aviation industry was developed by a number of delegates today at the opening session of the first National Aeronautic Planning Conference here.

Queen Alexandrine's strong constitution apparently has again saved her life, despite a serious internal operation she underwent yesterday. She slept 'well, according to tonight's communique, her condition is satisfactory and there is no reason for anxiety.
The New York Americans will tackle the Chicago Black Hawks in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. Red Dutton's men are favored to turn back the Westerners,
Deals in city realty announced yesterday principally involved tenement properties in Yorkville and Harlem.

Brig. Gen. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt left yesterday for Miami, where they will board their yacht, the Winchester. Lord Beauchamp, who is arriving today on the Europa, will be at the Waldorf-Astoria.
Eight prominent New Jersey Protestant clergymen took a strong stand against Mayor Frank Hague's restriction of free speech in a statement issued here tonight.

Turpentine firm, 28 1/4c: sales, 114 barrels; receipts, 37 barrels; shipments, 75 barrels; stock, 32,100 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 402; receipts, 404; shipments, 240; stock, 74,450. Quote: B and D, $4.30; E, $4.65; F, $5.60; G. $5.65; H, $5.80; I, $5.90; K, $6.10; M, $6.25; N, $6.35; WG, $7.05; WW and X, $7.50.

The undefeated St. Nicholas Hockey Club of the New York Amateur Hockey Association recorded an easy 9-2 victory over the Long Island Falcons at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. Bob McLernon led the winners with three goals.

The Ranee of Sarawak, a British protectorate in Northwest Borneo, opened an exhibition of her paintings yesterday in the Hotel SherryNetherland. The proceeds of the sale will go to the benefit of the leper colony in Kuching, Sarawak.

The second of this Winter's series of Coffee Dances took place last night at the Cosmopolitan Club. Among the dinner hosts and hostesses who later took their guests to the dance were Mr. and Mrs. William Seward Allen.

Teddy Hart, actor, now appearing in "Room Service" at the Cort Theatre, married Miss Dorothy T. Lubow, writer, of 357 West Fiftyfifth Street, yesterday in the marriage chapel of the Municipal Building.

Paced by Chuck Winston, who made eight field goals for 16 points, a fast Princeton freshman quintet easily turned back the Peddie School, 44-26, tonight in the University Gymnasium for its second victory in three starts this season.

Mrs. Marian Eliza Smith, who, with her husband, Captain Gilbert M. Smith, observed their seventyfourth wedding anniversary last Nov. 7, died today at her home, 67 Amity Street, here, after a long illness. She was 91 years old.

Mrs. Nieman, widow of the founder of The Milwaukee Journal, bequeathed a million dollars to Harvard University "to promote and elevate the standards of journalism in the United States:" How could that object best be realized?

The French franc continued yesterday under heavy pressure in the foreign exchange market and, in spite of official support, it fell 7-16 point to 3.391-16 cents. The weakness of the exchange was also revealed by a further widening of the discounts on forward contracts.
The Imperial Council, in the presence of Emperor Hirohito, will give formal sanction today to the policy adopted yesterday for continuance of the war with 'China.

The Loyalists again today attacked on La Muela Hill, outside Teruel, regaining more positions, according to tonight's communique. [An Insurgent communique quoted by The Associated Press asserted Government troops had been repulsed by heavy machinegun fire in five successive attacks yesterday on La Muela and La Cota Hills.]

Leading land developers and home builders, together with representatives of several large financial institutions will meet at the Hotel Washington, in the national capital, today, tomorrow and Thursday to launch a home-building campaign for the nation.
The National Bank of Greece and the Hellenic Bank Trust Company of New York lost yesterday a second attempt to escape a $25,000,000 accounting action brought

The gross revenues of twenty-five of the largest railroads which have reported for November declined 11.9 per cent in the aggregate from the total for November, 1936. This, with an increase in expenses, resulted in a drop of 51 per cent in the aggregate net operating income.
Eleven players contributed to the winning score as the basketball team of De La Salle Institute defeated Loyola School, 35 to 15, in the winners' gymnasium yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Herbert J. Goodwin of Monroe, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their niece, Miss Madeleine Frances Goodwin of 205 East Seventy-eighth Street, this city, to Lieutenant Arthur Edwin Owen, U.S.N.

Seven charitable, educational and religious institutions will receive sum totaling $74,500 and nine other institutions will share equally in the residuary estate of Annie Miller, it war learned yesterday when her will was filed for probate in the Surrogates' Court.
Officers were elected and tentative dates for horse shows in 1938 were approved at the twenty-first annual meeting of the American Horse Show Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.

Automobile production showed a minor increase last week, but daily average output declined against a rising seasonal trend, and the adjusted index receded to 56.6. This compares with 66.3 for the preceding week, and 100.6 for the week ended Jan. 9. 1936.

Dowager Queen Marie's health is said to have taken a turn for the worse in the last forty-eight hours. She intended to proceed to Merano in Northern Italy today but is still here, attended by several doctors.

The committee for a group of institutional investors holding $81,731,200 of securities of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad Company filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission a plan for reorganization of the railroad which would eliminate the
The international stock market indices for Jan. 8, with comparisons, are as follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 1927:
A new appeal for reduction of speed and for other safeguards to reduce the Winter automobile accident toll, was made today by Charles A. Harnett, Motor Vehicle Commissioner.
According to a report reaching The Times from a reliable source, hundreds of persons lost their lives as the result of an explosion in the Madrid underground railway on Monday night.

The Securities and Exchange Commission refused today to vacate an order it issued on Feb. 10, last, declaring that a registration statement filed under the Securities Act of 1933 by Underwriters Group, Inc., covering the issuance of $1,000,000

The right of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey to abolish the jobs of the twenty-four Civil Service subpoena servers employed by his predecessors has been referred by the State Civil Service Commission to Attorney General Bennett for an opinion, it was announced yesterday by Walter R. Van Wagner, one of the men ousted by Dewey.

Police officials disclosed yesterday that Captain Bernard Dowd, who commanded the detectives working with Thomas. E. Dewey when he was special rackets prosecutor, would command the main office squad operating out of Police Headquarters.
Paul K. Rogers, president and treasurer of the Skinner Chuck Company, plunged to his death today from a window of his private office on the fourth floor of the factory.

Miss Sonja Henie, figure-skating star, will be honored by her country at Washington D. C., on Friday, when the Norwegian Minister will decorate her with the Cross of the Knighthood, first class, of the Order of St. Olav, it was announced yesterday.

Before NRA went haywire--encouraging price-fixing, its codes given the status of acts of Congress, and the mails denied to violators--the government and a large section of industry thought they had worked out an ideal form of cooperation.

Frank Fay, divorced husband of Barbara Stanwyck, actress, won a court order today which gave to him custody of his adopted son, Dion, 5 years old, for seven hours every other Saturday, and permission to visit the child in Miss Stanwyck's home for two hours every Tuesday and Thursday.

COMMERCIAL PAPER Yesterday. Monday. For the best names..... 1% 1% The quotations are for four-six months' paper. Buyers' Total Under Last Year Although the number of visitingbuyers reported in the market during the week ended yesterday was the highest in five months,

It is no more than coincidence that about the time the old Leviathan is almost ready to start on her final voyage to the shipbreakers "the largest peacetime shipbuilding program in the history of the American Merchant Marine" is getting under way.

The Adjutant General released the following orders today: Wetheral, 2d Lt. Charles T., having qualified, is placed on duty. He is to report to the commanding officer, 107th Infantry for assignment to Headquarters Company, Second Battalion.

The Commonwealth Edison Company announced today that the offer to exchange its shares for common stock of the Public Service Company of Northern Illinois under the plan of reorganization would expire on Jan. 17, but that it would be renewed

The hearing in the proceedings against Gerald M. Loeb and Gordon B. Crary, partners in E. F. Hutton Co. of New York, and H. Terry Morrison, a member of the New York Stock Exchange, for alleged manipulative activities in the stock of Auburn Automobile Company, has been postponed by the Securities and Exchange Commission from Jan. 31 to May 23.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Wesley M. Angle of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Angle, to Thomas Thacher Richmond, son of Mr. and Mrs. L. Martin Richmond of Sunninghill, Glen Head, L. I.

An illustration of the operation of Section 11 of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 in effecting simplification of the corporate structure of a holding company system was supplied today by approval by the Securities and Exchange Commission of a voluntary plan

The Senate confirmed today, by a vote of 48 to 15, the nomination of F. Roy Yoke to be Collector of Internal Revenue for West Virginia after a sharp fight between Senators Neely and Holt over patronage in their State.

Martin McBohin, 42-year-old former sergeant of the United States Marine Corps, went over the top to defeat tonight in his first legal offensive to cover with adhesive tape the words "New York World's Fair 1939" on his automobile license plates.

Secretary Hull announced today the intention of the State Department to negotiate a reciprocal trade agreement with Turkey. The negotiations are the twenty-first to be attempted in the administration's program for the restoration of world trade.
Piling up a 24-17 lead in the first half, John Marshall College defeated the Catholic University quintet tonight, 47-34.
A dozen women passengers on an I. R. T. subway train in Brooklyn were badly frightened yesterday afternoon by an intoxicated man who staggered about the car, brandishing a pistol.
Vigorous protests against the budget submitted by Governor Lehman were expressed yesterday by representatives of automobile and petroleum organizations.
The ten bodies of victims of the flaming crash of a Northwest Airlines transport plane in the Bridger Mountains near here yesterday were brought to Bozeman tonight.

A decree appointing Count Rene Doynel de Saint-Quentin Ambassador to Washington was signed by President Albert Lebrun today. His appointment as successor to Georges Bonnet now becomes official, but it is not yet decided when he will leave for the United States.

Two of the world's most celebrated skiers, Birger and Sigmund Ruud, brothers from Kongsberg, Norway, arrived last night aboard the Europa of the North German Lloyd line- to spend the next two months in the snowbelts of this country and Canada.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Jan. 8: LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS Ferris, F. E., the Kane, to Yale University. New Haven, Conn., with Reserve Officers Training Corps.
Allie S. Freed of New York, philanthropist and housing authority, died today at Emergency Hospital after an illness of two weeks. He was 46 years old.
" These Reds are trying to convince the country that I'm a tyrant and a dictator," Mayor Frank Hague shouted, pounding his big desk angrily in an interview with this reporter in City Hall today.

Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek left Hankow today for the Lung-Hai Railway front in North China. His departure evoked keen speculation as to whether the reported decision by the Chinese command to assume the offensive on all fronts would be executed.

After persuading seven Democrats to contribute their votes toward the adoption of. Mayor La Guardia's budget yesterday the Mayor's supporters in the City Council put over a smashing attack on the Democratic opposition which resulted in the selection of B. Charney Vladeck, Labor leader, as majority leader of the Council.

The directors of Best Co. voted yesterday to declare an extra dividend of 50 cents a share on the common stock in addition to the regular quarterly distribution of 62 1/2 cents. Both are payable on Jan. 26 to holders of record of Jan. 21. A year ago the corporation paid

A gray-haired, elderly man walked into THE NEW YORK TIMES office yesterday afternoon and. in a quavering voice told of a "national loss" for which he was responsible. He had lost one of the first of the documents that should have warned George III that eventually it would be representation or revolution in the American Colonies.

How TO SEE ENGLAND, by Edmund Vale. (Dutton, $2.50.) An informal guide book. EDWARD WILSON OF THE ANTARCTIC, by George Seaver. (Dutton, $3.) A biography of the explorer and companion of Scott on his illfated South Polar expedition.

The second official session of the powers of the Rome bloc was held from noon to 2 P. M. today, this concluding the official part of the program, which consisted only of four hours of discussion in all.

President Roosevelt was told today by Aubrey Williams, acting Works Progress Administrator, that since Dec. 1 a total of between 250,000 and 300,000 men had been put on the WPA rolls, bringing the total now on relief approximately to 1,760,000.
The Treasury Procurement Division today announced the following awards of contracts for textiles from bids opened on Jan. 5 for shipment by Jan. 31:
Twelve men were elected to the board of trustees, class of 1941, at the forty-fourth annual meeting of the New York Zoological Society last night in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. They were Harry Payne
Inspector D. H. Craig of the Ontario Fire Marshal's department arrived today to investigate a fire that destroyed the Loretto Convent and Academy last night.
The First Communist daily paper freely to be issued in the area of national government control in th last ten years appeared here today with the publication of the first issue of Hsin Hu Shih Pao.
C. W. Johnston, a pioneer cotton textile manufacturer of the South, retired today as president and treasurer of the Highland Park chain of mills, positions he had held forty-three years.

Fortification of the British West African coast is being planned by the naval authorities here as a means of making safer the alternative sea route from Great Britain to the Far East, should the shorter Mediterranean route be menaced at any time.

Led by Harry F. Wolf of the Montclair A. C., the national champion, eight players gained the remaining brackets in the third round of the Clyde Martin memorial squash tennis tournament at the Yale Club last night.

Alexander S. Webb will continue as the president and treasurer of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals for 1938, with Sydney H. Coleman as executive vice president, according to an announcement yesterday.

Establishment of a special labor court within the magistrates' courts in New York City, which would have jurisdiction over cases involving labor controversies, was advocated in a bill introduced today by Assemblyman Jarema, Democrat, from the Eighth Manhattan District.
The Rev. Joel E. Grubb, pastor of the Second English Lutheran Church of Baltimore, died here last night at the age of 57. He was born in Newport,

President Roosevelt discussed business problems with various officials and industrialists, including Alfred P. Sloan, Ernest P. Weir, Lewis Brown, M. W. Clement and Colby Chester, automobile production with Governor Murphy
The subject of flies, wet or dry, salmon or trout, has always been a controversial one so far as individuals and their beliefs are concerned.
Word was received here last night of the death recently at her home in Columbus, Ohio, of Mrs. Margaret Mackin, widow of Colonel James Mackin of the Confederate Army. Mrs. Mackin, who was 83

The flag officers of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club of Oyster Bay, L. I., were re-elected at the meeting of that organization last night in the New York Yacht Club. They were Van S. Merle-Smith, commodore; Henry H. Anderson, vice commodore, and Philip J. Roosevelt, rear commodore.

About 85 per cent of the Canadian people improved or maintained its economic circumstances in 1937, S. H. Logan, president of the Canadian Bank of Commerce, said today at the annual meeting of shareholders of the bank here.

The influence of the Committee for Industrial Organization was thrown today against the compulsory mediation and arbitration and other labor provisions of the pending bill to amend the Merchant Marine Act of 1936 to carry out recommendations of Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman of the Maritime Commission.

The French Government today instructed its Ambassador at Tokyo to deliver an "energetic protest" against the bombing of a French Catholic mission at Nanning, South China, by Japanese planes on Sunday.

The Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce, which is investigating the financing of domestic railroads, brought the Pittsburgh West Virginia Railroad into the picture today and disclosed that when the Pennroad Corporation acquired control of that road

Frank H. Metcalf, president of the Farr Alpaca Company, died today. He was a director of several banks and a member of the American Military Engineers, the Ancient and Honorable Artillery Company and the Royal Society of Arts in England. He was 69 years old.
Two Southern Senators added their voices today in support of the warning by Senator Harrison yesterday that the Wagner - Van Nuys AntiLynching Bill might split the Democratic party.
There is a "woeful shortage" of trained personnel in the nation's air forces, Major Gen. Frank M. Andrews declared here tonight, and in the event of an early war this would cause serious danger.

Dr. Frederick W. Hochstetter, who came from Germany to America thirty-five years ago and worked for a time with Thomas A. Edison and David Steinmetz, announced today that he had discovered a new process for changing straw and other waste farm products into relatively inexpensive newsprint and synthetic cotton.

The twenty-one-ton Samoan Clipper was forced down at sea today on a South Pacific flight, leaving the fate of her seven crew members in doubt. One unconfirmed report said she had been sighted afloat and another that searchers could not find her.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward Nay Morris have left the Madison and will be for the rest of the Winter at 470 Park Avenue, where they have been joined by their daughter, Mrs. Patrick St. John Stirling of London, the former Miss Eugenia Morris.

William Edwin Hall, president of the Boys Clubs of America, received the 1937 "club of champions" award of the Catholic Youth Organization of the Archdiocese of New York for his services to youth at the annual dinner of the group's board of directors last night at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The Treasury asked bids today on 132 automobiles for the Customs Service, lumping its purchases in accordance with President Roosevelt's request that government departments aid business by placing orders for the remainder of the fiscal year as soon as possible.
A one-man show of oils, watercolors and drawings by John Carroll has opened at the Rehn Galleries, 683 Fifth Avenue. His last previous exhibition was held there in January two-years ago.
