A committee of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association yesterday warned members to prepare for a substantial increase in the introduction of compulsory trade-mark legislation in various State Legislatures during this year.
The Actors Equity Association approved yesterday a report asking for a closed shop for all legitimate theatre performers at the New York World's Fair in 1939.

Buckley Scott Utilities, Inc., with showrooms in Boston, and Buckley Scott, Inc., have been appointed New England distributors for Utica Air Conditioners, according to announcement yesterday by Carl Sawade, general sales manager of Utica Radiator Corporation.

An estimated 1,500 engine and train service employes of the Delaware Hudson Railroad Company have received a wage increase of 44 cents an eight-hour day, retroactive to Oct. 1, Fred L. Hanlon, superintendent, said today.

The first "week" of the 162d annual session of the New Jersey Legislature began and ended here today within the space of a couple of hours, but sufficient transpired during that time to indicate clearly that the Republicans, who have a majority in both houses, are far from agreement among themselves.

Elisha Hanson of Washington, counsel to the American Newspaper Publishers Association, told New York State publishers today that "a constantly growing propaganda machine now operating in Washington * * * may result in the destruction of our democratic form of government."
Reports of annual meetings of banks held here and in other places yesterday at which important changes were made follow. The national banking laws set the secon Tuesday in January for such meetings.
Farm bill conferees took Secretary Wallace's advice today and agreed on a "middle-of-the-road" wheat program.
" Gunga Din," the Rudyard Kipling tale that has been on and off of RKO's schedule for two years, today was set for definite production in the late Spring by Leo Spitz.

Those "child experts" who "measure heads" to tell what is wrong with children and disagree with the city's methods of combating juvenile delinquency were chided yesterday by Mayor La Guardia in an address on the social problems of New York.

LONDON, Jan. 11.--Sir Alliott Verdon-Roe, British aircraft pioneer, forecast today "from experiments I have seen" that aircraft will be propelled by the emission of hot air or gases from a high-pressure tube.

Tribute to the memory of Mme. Curie was paid today by a group of American women headed by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, who presented to Jules Henry, charge d'affaires of France, a specially bound edition of Eve Curie's biography of her mother.

Counsel for the defense in the trial of two physicians, two attorneys and an insurance broker accused of mail fraud in the presentation of claims for disability insurance failed yesterday in an effort to ban evidence obtained by the government by wire-tapping methods.

County chairmen in 2,300 of the nation's 3,000 counties are at work to insure the success of the President's Birthday Celebration on Jan. 29. The proceeds will be used in the nation-wide fight against infantile paralysis.
The annual midwinter dinner of the Berkshire School Alumni Association, sponsored by the Berkshire Club of New York, will be held at the Yale Club Friday evening.

Yesterday was a raw day rather than a blowy one, but the light ten-mile wind blew over a sign in front of the West End Theatre, 382 West 125th Street, causing it to strike Miss Anna Grissen, 25 years old, of 318 West Thirteenth Street. She was attended at Harlem Hospital for an injury to the left shoulder and went home after treatment.

Forty-four 3-year-old trotters, including Elbridge T. Gerry's Dale Hanover, 2:03 1/4, the 2-year-old champion of 1937, were kept eligible for this year's Hambletonian Stake No. 13, for foals of 1935, by the Jan. 1 payment.
The board of directors of the Prudential Insurance Company ofAmerica yesterday elected George E. Potter second vice president. Mr. Potter, who has been promoted

Although unable to preside because he had to remain in Washington, Commodore Chandler Hovey, owner of Rainbow, was re-elected senior flag officer of the Eastern Yacht Club at its annual meeting in the Harvard Club of Boston tonight Vice Commodore B. Devereux Balker, presiding in Commodore Hovey's absence, and Rear Commodore Malcolm W. Greenough also were reelected.

Prompt action by the Legislature in response to Governor Lehman's recommendation for the establishment of State mortgage banks was urged yesterday by Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York.
Henry Armstrong, world featherweight champion, tonight at Madison Square Garden will undertake to accomplish what no other boxer has ever achieved against Enrico Venturi, sturdy Italian lightweight.

Price movements of commodity futures were mixed in fairly active trading on the local markets yesterday. Metals and hide futures were higher, but rubber, silk and coffee futures declined. In the cash market copper, lead, tins, silk and printcloths advanced, while all the grains, cocoa, butter, lard, rubber and wool tops declined.

Mrs. Charles H. C. Pearsall, wife of the president of the Colombian Steamship Company, was installed in absentia as president of the Women's Organization for the Advancement of the American. Merchant Marine yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Commodore. Mrs.

Lord Nuffield, England's Henry Ford, who in August last told steel manufacturers that if they did not reduce prices it would be a strong encouragement to buy steel abroad, reassured them the other day.

Police track dogs today followed a trail from a point near Hebron where the British archaeologist, J. L. Starkey was slain yesterday to a house in the near-by Arab village of Kharas. The owner of the house,

Miss Helen Hilton, 36 years old, principal of Grant Grammar School in Dumont, was released In $500 bail by Prosecutor John J. Breslin Jr. here today on a charge of grand larceny after Henry Genschel of 548 Brandon Place, Cliffside Park, had charged that Miss Hilton stole $30 in marked money during a party held at his home Sunday night.

The Court of Appeals refused today to permit former Mayor Walker of New York City to appeal an Appellate Division ruling holding that his first appointment as special assistant counsel to the New York City Transit Commission was illegal. Mr. Walker's first appointment to the $12,000 a year post has since been rescinded and a new one made.
Pennsylvania State College defeated the Carnegie Tech basketball team, 39 to 33, tonight. Miehoff, Prosser and Corbin did most of the scoring for the visitors.

Harvard College Library announced today that it had bought 2,300 letters written by famous American and English literary figures to William Dean Howells, American novelist who was for many years editor of the Atlantic Monthly.
Two officials were badly battered at the end of the annual Fitchburg High School and St. Bernard's High School basketball game tonight before 1,200. Fitchburg won, 23 to 9.
The Treasury asked new bids today on the construction of a Canal Street postoffice station in New York City.

Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Jerrold Bryce of Old Westbury, L. I., formerly of Lake Forest, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Bryce, to Francis Scott Truesdale, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Truesdale of Road Edge, Westbury.

Returning to this country after several months in Europe, Ralph J. Archer, vice president and manager of the Willys Export Corporation, announced yesterday plans to assemble Willys passenger cars and trucks in several European countries. Mr. Archer,

For the first time since the Left Popular Front was elected, clear evidence of cleavage between the Communists and other parties in this majority group was provided today when the Communist leader, Jacques Duclos, failed by one vote to obtain a clear majority for re-election as a Vice President of the Chamber of Deputies.

The quartet of vocal soloists to participate in the performance of the Beethoven Ninth symphony under Arturo Toscanini's direction Sunday evening, Feb. 6, at Carnegie Hall, are Vina Bovy, soprano; Kerstin Thorborg, contralto; Ezio Pinza, basso, and Jan Peerce, tenor.

United States Commissioner Martin C. Epstein in Brooklyn Federal Court refused yesterday to order the removal of Moe Platt, New York broker and president of the Backbone Gold Mining Company, 30 Broad Street, Manhattan, to the United States District Court in Pittsburgh,
The City-Wide Tenants Council received word yesterday from State Senator Elmer F. Quinn that he would introduce tenants' bills endorsed by the organization in the State Senate this week.

BIRKNER--Isaac, in his eighty-fourth year, husband of Mollie, father of Arthur, Henry, Sidney, Daniel, Bella Bogart and Hattie Lindauer. Funeral from the Park West Memorial Chapel, 79th St and Columbus Ave., Thursday, Jan. 13, at 1 P. M.
Leslie HoreBelisha, the 44-year-old Secretary of State for War, struck another succession of hammer-blows tonight in his relentless campaign to rejuvenate the leadership of the British Army.

In the United States Supreme Court today the following proceedings were had: 293-Edward Lauf, et al., petra., v. E. G. Shinner Co., Inc. Motion for leave to file brief of American Civil Liberties Union, Inc., and International Juridical Association, as amici curiae, submitted in that behalf.

The first auction session yesterday afternoon at the newly organized Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., 742 fifth Avenue, realized $13,232. This was the first of seven auction sessions of the property of the late Mr. and Mrs. Jay F. Carlisle.: The entire contents of their country home, Rosemary, East Islip, L. I., will be sold.

The Board of Tax Appeals used three words today to rule on whether income received as alimony is taxable. "It is not," the board said in a case involving a deficiency assessment against Princess Lida of Thurn and Taxis amounting to $52,393 plus penalties of $13,930.

An essay contest for school children from 12 to 14 years old, sponsored by the Department of New York, Veterans of Foreign Wars, will start this Saturday, it was announced by Norman J. Carey, department patriotic instructor. The subject will be the history of the national anthem. The contest will end on March 31.
The New York University women's swimming team opened its season last night by defeating the Savage School squad, 28-25, in the American Woman's Association pool.

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Whistler and Sargent," Alfred Busselle Jr., 11 A. M.; the collection of paintings (general tour), 2 P. M.; "The Medieval Town and the Cathedral," Margaret B, Freeman, 4 P. M.

Governor Lehman's recent appointment of M. Maldwin Fertig as a member of the Transit Commission was confirmed today by the Senate. While concurring in the appointment, Senator Desmond, Republican, of Orange County, assailed the commission.

At a meeting yesterday of the Cuban Atlantic Sugar Company, directors proposed a repayment of capital to stockholders in the amount of $2.50 a share by reduce tion of the par value of 729,000 shares of outstanding capital stock from $10 to $7.50.

The New York Americans observed Ching Johnson Night last night by advancing from a deadlock with the Montreal Canadiens into undisputed possession of second place in the International Group of the National Hockey League.

Several leases for large quarters in the Park and Fifth Avenue sections featured the contracts for apartment space reported by brokers yesterday. Included was one for a large apartment in 405 Park Avenue, taken by Dietz Edzard, portrait painter, through Douglas Gibbons Co., Inc., in conjunction with Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., brokers.

A sixteen-month search in eight States for a man accused of swindling small investors out of $25,000 in securities in the metropolitan area alone was ended yesterday morning with the arrest of Samuel D. Mussman in a hotel at Ninetyfourth Street and Broadway by agents of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr.

Miss Mary R. Lynch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Lynch of Riverside, Greenwich, was married to Dr. Paul F. Jarrett, son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Jarrett of Stamford, in St. Catherine's Roman Catholic Church, Riverside, this morning.

Support for the trade reciprocity program of the Department of State was urged upon men engaged in transportation in an address last night by Eugene P. Thomas, president of the National Foreign Trade Council, before the annual meeting of the New York Freight Forwarders and Brokers Association.

A combination school and garage adjacent to the Yankee Stadium, intended to relieve overcrowding in classrooms and at the same time provide adequate parking space for baseball fans, has been proposed by. Mayor La Guardia, it was learned yesterday.

A proposal that the clothing industry finance a research study to chart the average sizes of men and youths in the various sections of the country was advanced yesterday by Dr. H. L. Shapiro, associate curator of physical anthropology of the American Museum of Natural History.

So much of paragraph 5, Special Order dated Jan. 5, 1938, as pertains to 1st Lt. Edward Roeder Jr., Inf.-Res., is revoked. 1st Lt. Edward Roeder Jr., F.A.-Res., 472 Gramatan Ave., Mount Vernon, N. Y., recently promoted, is assigned to the 305th Field Artillery, 77th Division.
The position of the Soviet polar party drifting on an ice floe at 1 P. M. today was Lat. 78 degrees 16 minutes N., Long. 10 degrees 15 minutes W.

Bank meetings here today were featured by the action of the directors of the American National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago in voting a special dividend of $2 a share on the common stock, in addition to the regular $2 semi-annual payment.

Herbert Mendelson, the Detroit sportsman whose shiny white Notre Dame, with Clell Perry at the wheel, won both the Gold Cup and President's Cup last Summer, was designated as "the outstanding fig-ure in the motor boat sport during 1937" at the show yesterday in Grand Central Palace.

A clash on the organization set-up of the Consumers Foundation, launched at a meeting here last Saturday as a "non-profit fact-finding foundation to promote the consumer interest" was revealed here yesterday in a communication signed by Donald E. Montgomery, member of the organizing committee of the foundation and consumer counsel of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration, who asserted that a bulletin containing a prospectus of the foundation was "misleading" on several counts.

Nearly $3,000.000 in new construction is involved in the building projects filed yesterday in Queens. Architects submitted specifications for seventeen multi-family dwellings, the estimated cost of which is placed at $2,709,000.
Manhattan's undefeated freshman basketball team won its tenth straight game by vanquishing the strong St. Benedict's Prep five of Newark, N. J., 45 to 40, at the Manhattan gymnasium last night.

Donald Budge, Wimbledon and American tennis champion, arrived here today ill and extremely weak. His physician said he had a slight fever and ordered rest. Budge said the fever was a mild one, which apparently recurs about once a year.

August names, those of J. S. Bach, Purcell, Pergolesf, adorned the program of "chamber operas," or excerpts from dramatic compositions of the eighteenth century, given by the three singers who constitute the London Intimate Opera Company last night in the Little Theatre.

The Swedish Government plans to launch a public works program to maintain purchasing power and prevent unemployment in the event that a depression develops, King Gustaf said today in his speech from the throne, opening Parliament.

Representative men's neckwear manufacturers voiced favor for rayon identification in their industry and felt that such identification might be best accomplished through labeling at a conference yesterday with the associate council of the vendors' relations of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.
Close contests featured the opening round of match play in the annual Lake Worth golf championship over the Palm Beach Golf Club course today.

For what are believed to be strategic reasons connected with recent developments in the world situation, the Royal Navy's intelligence office is being removed from Bermuda to Jamaica. The move is expected to be completed this month.

For the first time in twenty-five years the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association of the New York City Police Department has a new president. He is Patrolman Joseph J. Burkard of Traffic F, assigned to clerical duties at the East Sixtyseventh station.

Maxie Berger, Bronx boxing star, squared accounts with Tommy Rawson of Boston last night at the New York Coliseum, when, before 9,200 fans, he fought his way to the decision in an exciting eight-round bout.

Stockholders of the Glidden Company at their annual meeting on Jan. 20 will vote on a proposal to acquire the assets of the Southern Pine Chemical Company for 34,697 shares of Glidden Company common stock.

The National League's new "dead" ball is a livelier bouncer than one of last year's American League "live" balls. At least that is what twenty-five bounces. from a height of fifteen feet showed in tests conducted by T. S. Schreiber, graduate student at the Johns Hopkins University.

The Record said tonight that 27-year-old George A. Munger "definitely has been picked" to succeed Harvey Harman as head football coach at the University of Pennsylvania. Athletic officials at the university, however, denied that Munger, now freshman coach, has been selected.

The Court of Appeals at Albany ruled yesterday in a five-to-two decision that New York City's 2 per cent sales tax does not apply to receipts of an artist from the sale of reproduction rights to his own works. Judge Irving Hubbs wrote

The increase in steel ingot production last week was greater than anticipated seasonally and the adjusted index advanced to 45.4. This compares with 37.8 for the preceding week and 124.8 for the week ended Jan. 9, 1937.

Unless the United States patterns its monetary system. after that of Sweden, "ultimate disaster will follow," Irving Fisher, Professor Emeritus at Yale University, said yesterday to students of New York University in the School of Education auditorium on Washington Square East.

To a resolution of the Senate, seeking light on certain aspects of American policy in the Far East, Secretary Hull has made a prompt reply, which now takes its place as a significant document in the record.
In an effort to speed its report, the committee for the study of the organization and administration of the New York Stock Exchange heard yesterday the views of five persons.
Judge Emmet Wilson summoned John Montague today to appear in court Friday for an inquiry about his financial affairs.
Evidences of the renewed flight of capital from France became more pronounced in the foreign exchange market yesterday as the franc weakened in both the spot and forward quotations.

La Salle Academy's quintet accounted for its ninth triumph in ten games this season by beating Immaculate High, 40 to 23, in a non-league engagement on the winners' floor yesterday. La Salle scored 26 points in the second half after holding a 2-point lead, 14-12, at the half.

Sir Richard Paget, inventor of a mechanical apparatus which produces words and simple sentences, yesterday demonstrated his artificial voice during a broadcast from London which was heard locally over Station WJZ.

Proceedings against permits held by the American Distilling Company of 135 East Forty-second Street, New York City, of which Gene Tunney is the new chairman of the board, have been ended as the result of the tender and acceptance of a substantial offer in compromise, U. S. Alexander, head of the Federal Alcohol Administration, said today.

As the second day of the State's compulsory automobile inspection was completed this afternoon, officials throughout the State announced that the percentage of cars rejected at the testing stations was substantially less than it was yesterday.

The Publio Service Commission announced yesterday that it had authorized the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., to issue $30,000,000 of twenty-year 3 1/2 per cent debentures. Proceeds of the issue are to be used for plant Improvement and construction in the Edison system.

Secretary Morgenthau complained to Congress today that Richard N. Elliott, Acting Controller General, had been "snapping at the heels" of the Treasury in a manner that exceeded the limits of law and interfered with more important work.

OUT of curiosity I asked a publisher the other day how old he thought the publishing business was. He said, "Do you mean the one I am connected with?" "No," I said, "the publishing business as a whole."

The 1,000,000th visitor to the New York Museum of Science and Industry in the RCA Building, Rockefeller Center, passed through its doors at the Sixth Avenue entrance yesterday at 11 A. M. He was John Crossan, 23 years old, of 77 Liberty Avenue, Mineola, L. I.
The signing of three more contracts for exhibit space at the 1939 World's Fair, two of them for displays connected with travel, was announced yesterday afternoon.
The defense in the Federal Government's gasoline price-fixing case struck at government price exhibits today as its final witness took the stand.
Montreal's Maroons and Canadiens shattered all sccring records for the current National Hockey League season and perhaps a few all-time league marks tonight as the Maroons won, 11-7.

Passengers sailing today on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania include Sir Louis and Lady Beale, Mrs. Richard Norton, Lady Beauchamp, Mr. and Mrs. W. L. Mitchell, J. Milne Barbour, Duncan C. Tait, Miss Tamara Geva, Russian dancer; Arthur S. Vernay, explorer; A. Z. Gardner.

With work ready to begin on the foundations of the new building of the Museum of Modern Art at 11 West Fifty-third Street, final plans were announced yesterday for the structure, which is to be one of the most modern museum edifices in the country.

Capitalization of new stock, companies incorporated in New York State in 1937 totaled $432,691,290, the highest recorded since 1929, Edward J. Flynn, Secretary of State, reported tonight. This was $190,000,000 more than in 1936 and $200,000,000 more than in 1935.

With the formal casting of a single ballot by the secretary, the entire slate of officers as proposed by the nominating committee was elected last night at the annual meeting of the New York Athletic Club at its city-clubhouse.

In his famous essay on old age Cicero makes Cato speak of the 90-year-old Masinissa: "When he begins a march on foot he never mounts a horse; when he sets out on horseback he never dismounts; no rain or cold, however great, can induce him to cover his head;
A plan for cushioning the economic impact of independence on the Philippine Islands has been agreed to in principle, and only the details remain to be worked out, President Roosevelt announced today.

Sid Luckman of Columbia, Sid White of Brooklyn College, Bernard Bloom of New York University and Jerry Stein of- City College were guests of honor yesterday at a luncheon at the Hotel Paramount given by the Metropolitan Council of the junior organization of the B'nai B'rith, international Jewish fraternity, and The New York Jewish News in honor of the local members of the Jewish All-America football team.
The large six-story apartment houes at 1,845 Phelan Place, near Burnside Avenue, in the Bronx, has been sold by the Prudential Insurance Company to Charles Walzer, operator.

Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin appointed James A. O'Gorman yesterday as referee to determine whether Series F-1 guaranteed mortgage certificates of the New York Title and Mortgage Company and the Jenfray bond and mortgage, guaranteed by the State Title and Mortgage Company were legal investments for trust funds on deposit with former New York City chamberlains.

A plea for support in a campaign to replace Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City with a Mayor considered "friendly to unionization" was made tonight by William J. Carney, regional director for the Committee for Industrial Organization.

The market thi for wheat developed - weaker undertone today. The buying was less aggressive and toward the last there was a general selling movement under way on the Board of Trade here by longs who had profits and were disposed to accept them.

Officials of the United Corporation announced yesterday that a special meeting of shareholders had been called for Feb. 1 to act upon a reduction of the company's capital from $197,109,220 to $138,965,099, a decrease of $58,144,121.
An investigation of the State Athletic Commission by a special legislative committee is proposed in a resolution introduced today by Assemblyman Hawkins, Kings Democrat.

Many reservations have been made for an entertainment to be held tomorrow night in La Maisonette Russe of the St. Regis to celebrate the Russian New Year. The event will aid the Russian Children's Welfare Association.

Governor Blanton Winship was taken from the Grace liner Santa Rosa on a stretcher today following a fall in a bathroom on Sunday morning that resulted in a fracture of the left fifth rib. At the military hospital, where Governor Winship was taken, a bulletin this afternoon

Julius Bright, 30 years old, a Negro who was released from the Federal penitentiary at Petersburg, W. Va., only a month ago, was held in $12,500 bail in the Felony Court yesterday after he had pleaded guilty to robbery and Sullivan Law charges.

Mrs. Gladys I. Cragin of 424 East Fifty-second Street won yesterday a verdict of $15,000 from a mixed jury in Supreme Court that heard evidence in her suit for $20,000 damages for malicious prosecution from George G. Zabriskie, her former lawyer, and Mrs. Margaret Stockton, his sister.
Three earmarks for the identification of "intelligent behavior" were described last night by Dr. Ralph Gerard, Professor of Physiology at the University of Chicago.

Leases for store units predominated in the list of commercial rentals submitted yesterday. A number of chain organizations took new space, and restaurants and food stores were among the businesses represented.
The Nassau County grand jury handed up today two indictments charging George E. Smith, former village treasurer of South Floral Park with misappropriation of public funds.

Miss Martha Davidge, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Davidge and a granddaughter of the late John W. Weeks, who was Secretary of War ir. the Harding and Coolidge administrations, was married this afternoon to Mark Sullivan Jr.,

Coat manufacturers are agreeing to discontinue selling at retail, I.A. Hirschmann, vice president of SaksFifth Avenue, said yesterday in commenting on the move of retailers here to combat the practice of producers gelling at retail.

Adelbert Bradley Hall, 62 years old, a former WPA teacher of philosophy, committed suicide at 11:15 A. M. yesterday by inhaling gas in his small furnished apartment at 527 West 148th Street, according to the police.

The Chase National Bank and Biyth Co., Inc., obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $500,000 of road bonds of the State of West Virginia on their bid of 100.01 for $180,000 as 3s and $320,000 as 2 1/4s.

With Dick Hough traversing the 200-yard breast stroke in 2:26.6 to break his own university and pool records, the undefeated Princeton swimming team scored its fourth consecutive triumph tonight, overwhelming Rider College, 51-24, in Brokaw pool.

Mrs. Grace G. Landy, a Broadway musical comedy actress of a generation ago, appearing with three sisters under the name of the Four Merrill Sisters, died yesterday of a heart ailment in the Meadowbrook Hospital, East Hempstead, at the age of 47.
George H. Dresser, who retired as vice presiden of the New England Telephone and Telegraph Company on Aug. 1, 1931, died today at his home in Brookline. He was in his seventysecond year.
Several apartments as well as a number of tenements were listed among the Manhattan properties involved in deals announced yesterday.
The New York University freshman five gained its seventh victory in nine starts by defeating George Washington High School, 43-35, yesterday at the University Heights gymnasium.
The American Smelting and Refining Company advanced yesterday the domestic price of copper 25 points to 10.875 cents a pound. The volume of trading at the new level was considered satisfactory.
The Long Island University basketball team, returning to its home court last night after a three-game stand at Madison Square Garden, crushed the Princeton Seminary quintet, 85 to 17.

STOP-OVER, a play in three acts, by Matt and Sam Taylor. Staged by Worthington Miner; settings by Norris Houghton; produced by Chase Productions, Inc. (William Liebling, Edward E. Cohen and James Stabile. At the Lyceum Theatre.

The Netherland freighter Hannah was torpedoed and sunk today by an unidentified submarine seven miles off Cape San Antonio, reports from Government- held Alicante stated. It was later denied the ship sank. It was the first such incident in more than two months.
The Neediest Cases Fund yesterday exceeded the $300,000 mark, the first time since 1930 that the fund has reached this amount.
Diphtheria took three lives in this city during the week ended last Saturday, it was reported yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner.
Henry Norrington, 26, told at the home of his mother, Mrs. Robert W. Norrington, 7 Edmund Avenue, yesterday of his adventures in traversing 300 miles of treacherous Arctic ice and snow,

The Appellate Division. in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that Edward H. Wilson, trustee of the Brooklyn Bar Association, and Assistant District Attorney John J. Kean of Brooklyn, must pay $29,305 to the estate of Joseph Auditore, millionaire stevedore who died on May 10, 1920.

Miss Jane Weadock, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Francis Weadock of Greenwich, Conn., and this city, was married yesterday afternoon at Mayfair House, this city, to John Taynton Davy Spence, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Denbow Spence of Hove, Sussex, England.

Employment of the Chrysler Corporation throughout the nation returned today to the 55,000 level, which it held before the holiday vacations of production workers, the corporation's spokesman announced here.
Out of something like 15,000 notable Americans in the twenty volumes of the Dictionary of American Biography there is just one native
Whitney Harb, Little Rock automobile distributor, said here tonight he and Miss Helen Hicks, former United States women's golf champion, would be married on Feb. 15 at Garden City, L. I.

The St. Peter's High five of Staten Island received its first setback in eleven starts this season when it bowed to Power Memorial Academy, 26-24, in-a ManhattanRichmond C. H. S. A. A. clash on the winners' floor yesterday.
Miss Audrey Peppe of the Skating Club of New York, one of the leading contenders for the national figure-skating championship, which will be contested in Philadelphia next month, arrived from England

The importance to the retailer of recognition of the consumer's viewpoint was stressed by Mrs. Hortense M. Odlum, president of Bonwit Teller, New York, in an address today at a luncheon meeting of the Advertising Club of Boston, Inc. Mrs.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May the writer be permitted to call attention to certain points in your editorial of Jan. 6, "Wanted: A Trust Policy," which misinterpret- the more constructive current proposals, including Mr. Jackson's, for the strengthening and enforcement of the anti-trust laws?
Isidore Konti, sculptor, whose work adorns public buildings, churches and parks in several States, died in his home here today after a heart attack. He was 75 years old.

A further general advance in the price of cotton carried July contracts on the Cotton Exchange to 8 3/4 cents a pound yesterday, and the list ended with gains of 2 to 6 points or 10 to 30 cents a bale.
The Wisconsin Development AuthorityGovernor La Follette's "Little TVA"--died in the State Supreme Court today.

Miss Elizabeth De A. Bogart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cyril De A. Bogart of Yonkers, N. Y., has completed plans for her marriage to Philip H. Milner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilfrid W. Milner of Hastings-on-Hudson, which will take place Feb. 12 in St. Paul's

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed on the eligible list of holders of licenses for service, as indicated, in junior high schools the names of the following applicants, who have been granted license:
Francis P. Coan, who had been City Attorney here for nineteen years, died this afternoon at his home, 257 David Street, at the age of 55, after an illness of a year and a half.

Colonel Frank Knox suggested tonight a "plain-folks" Republican program which would tell business boldly that it must renounce all "excessive" tariff schedules tending to increase the cost of living, and then would insist that the farm expect no cash bonuses for crop restriction.

The season of annual bank meetings began auspiciously yesterday. Although the various chairmen surveyed a troubled and perplexing economic scene and were, perforce, constrained to take a noncommittal view of earnings prospects for the ensuing year, the atmosphere of the meetings was cordial.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses and normal Federal income charges, but before provision fo: Federal surtax on undistributed earnings. Figures, in many cases, are subject to final adjustment.

Considering the business situation as a whole, the essential need is for the cooperative efforts of management and labor, James H. Perkins, chairman of the board of directors of the National City Bank of New York, said yesterday at the one hundred and twenty-sixth annual meeting of stockholders.

The annual "Who's Who," or roll of honor, compiled by The American Hebrew, names 164 Jews and eleven non-Jews, including President Roosevelt, for notable achievement in 1937 in their professions and for outstanding contributions to local, State and national government, bench and bar, social betterment, education, literature, music, science, the theatre and Palestine welfare.

The charges against Judge, Ferdinand A. Geiger of Milwaukee which Attorney General Cummings has laid before the House Judiciary Committee are to be investigated and are to result also in an investigation of some acts of the Department of Justice itself, it was disclosed today.

A goal by Russ Billman, former Yale star, in the last few seconds of the second period gave the New York Athletic Club a 1-to-0 triumph over the Columbia Lions in a New York Amateur Hockey Association game at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. Charley Sleverd assisted Billman.

Exports of canned tomato sardines from Japan amounted to 1,218,556 cases during the first ten months of 1937, indicating the goal of 1,300,000 cases set at the beginning of the year will not only be reached, but probably surpassed, the Commerce Department reported today.

Argentina has launched an industrialization program and encouraged the establishment of factories to produce much of the finished goods formerly imported, DuWayne G. Clark, assistant commercial attache at Buenos Aires
The postal, telegraph and telephone services of Nicaragua were militarized today by President Anastasio Somoza. The rank of colonel was given to the Director General of Communication..

BORN, MARY TERESA (Dec. 30). Estate, more than $10,000. To St. Mary's Church, Rahway, N. J., chalice as a memorial to Her mother, Mary Ellen Roy; Herbert C. Born, husband, executor, Hotel Vanderbilt, specific jewelry and $1,000; Helen Roy Bursch, sister, executrix, 230 E. 73d St., life estate in $7,500 and residue; St.

Average daily gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,437,100 barrels, compared to 3,436,600 in the preceding week, an increase of 500, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Gains of 7,800 and of 5,150

John Perez, 29 years old, who said he lived at 59 West Eighty-seventh Street, pleaded not guilty but waived examination in the Felony Court yesterday for the action of the grand jury on a charge of burglary of the apartment of Mrs. Benjamin Elgar at 593 Riverside Drive Monday night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11--President Roosevelt opened today the intensive stage of his drive for economic recovery through cooperation between government and industry by conferring for an hour and a half with five major leaders of business.

Five indictments on extortion charges pending against Max D. Krone, former private detective, when General Sessions Judge Nott sentenced him last January to a three-year Sing Sing term on his conviction of extorting about $13,000 from Alfred E. Smith Jr., were quashed yesterday.
With nineteen named for the Inaugural Handicap, racing will get under way tomorrow at Hialeah Park under the auspices of the Miami Jockey Club, headed by Joseph E. Widener.

BARKER, MARY METCALFE PERIN (Sept. 30, 1937). Gross assets, $3,080; net $1,809. To Joseph W. Barker, husband, and Beatrice P. and John P. Barker, children, one-third residue each. Chief assets, miscellaneous property, $1,230. Richard R. Powell, attorney; 516 Kent Hall, Columbia University, New York City.
Secretary Wallace told the Senate Committee on Unemployment today that despite bumper crops a nationwide growth in rural relief needs had been caused by the recent slump in farm prices.

Sir Charles Morgan Webb, British author and economist, arrived here yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania for his third visit to the United States to make a lecture tour through the Middle West and California.
In the United States Court of Claims today the following calendar for Wednesday, Jan. 12, was announced: Call of the January Calendar Rule to show cause why case should not be dismissed:

Japan's Imperial Council, convened only for extraordinary purposes, met yesterday for the first time since 1914, in great secrecy, to determine the nation's future course in China, and a statement on its decision is expected shortly. Previously the Finance Minister had told the Cabinet that the nation could carry on a prolonged war, but only with sacrifices. [Page 1.]

Efforts are being pressed by planning experts and other regional authorities in various parts of the country to bring about official abandonment of proposed subdivisions and street plans in subdivisions which turned out to be little more than promoters' dreams and which never materialized.

Sister Marie Matilde, S. S. J., principal of St. Francis. Xavier Parochial School at 697 Carroll Street, Brooklyn, died yesterday at the convent of St. Francis Xavier. She was born Elizabeth McCarron and before entering religious life she was a public school teacher in Greenpoint. She had taught at St.

Poor Richard published one, and so did-and still does-the Old Farmer, if that is his correct title, and the proprietors of proprietary medicines have worked up good-will by issuing them free, complete with eclipses of the moon and sun, edifying anecdotes, recipes, curious scientific facts and weather predictions for the entire year.
Governor Lehman's $485,000,000 budget seemed to be headed for smoother sailing than any recent budget message submitted to the Legislature.
Declines in the outstanding volume of both bankers' acceptance and commercial paper last month were reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

The stock market here behaved uncertainly for the most part today and, although the tendency was firm at first, several sections had turned easier by the close of the session. Gilt-edge issues were weaker, while among the foreign loans Far Eastern issues lost ground.
Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

THERE was good reason for complaint that Freddie Steele carefully left his middleweight crown at home the night he went out to fight Fred Apostoli in the Garden. Now there is to be another champion in the Garden and his title will not be at stake.

Rallying on the incoming nine, Charles H. Mayo Jr. of Long Beach, former Long Island amateur champion, scored an easy victory in the first-match round of the annual midwinter golf championship over the Miami Country Club course today. He defeated William Reed of Indianapolis, 3 and 2.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11-President and Mrs. Roosevelt held tonight the annual State Reception in honor of the judiciary, headed by the Chief Justice of the United States and the Associate Justices.

Exhibits ranging from patchwork quilts to hammered brass trays, and hand-woven towels and table covers to books which are rated high by publishers, are on view here in one of the most unique collections ever shown in Washington.

Jan Weinberger of Nova Paka, Czechoslovakia, arrived yesterday on the Aquitania with details of an invention under which wool may be spun on the cotton system, and he announced that FelixPfeffer of the St. George Textile Corporation, 1071 Sixth Avenue, will be American agent for the invention.
Hugh Gant and Alva Dewey Hunt, No. 1 pair of fugitives on the United States Department of Justice list, were captured here tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 11.--The Samoan Clipper was three hours out of Page Pago when she reported that she was turning back because of an oil leak in one of her motors. At 3:37 P. M., New York time, when the craft had been retracing her course for fifty minutes, her radio beam signals suddenly ceased and no direct word was received thereafter.

In a move dictated both by humane considerations and a desire to strip the unitariann" Vargas Government of every possible appearance of nazism or fascism, Brazilian authorities have suspended deportation orders that would have returned to Europe 800 to 1,000 Jewish immigrants who are illegally in this country.
Mr. and Mrs. J. Renwick Kerr gave a dinner last night at the Beekman for Mr. and Mrs. Henry O. Tallmadge.

The Nonesuch Press announces that it will resume publication this Winter of limited editions on a scale comparable to that of predepression days. A prospectus entitled "Prelude to Plenty" has been prepared, and copies may be obtained by writing to the American offices of the Nonesuch Press, 551 Fifth Avenue.

Five utility companies filed equity suits in Federal Court yesterday seeking to enjoin the New York State Public Service Commission from enforcing its order of June 22, 1932, which prohibited the plaintiffs from paying certain contracting corporations unless payments were charged against "profit andloss surplus accounts."

Producers and managers belonging to the League of New York Theatres, meeting secretly on Monday afternoon at the league offices, rejected individually the contract proposed by the Theatrical Managers, Agents and Treasurers Union, it was learned yesterday.
The "natural science evenings" being held at the American Museum of Natural History were continued last night with a dinner at which Mrs. Henry P. Davison was hostess.

Miss Claire Lesser, daughter of Mrs. M. Mona Lesser of 915 West End Avenue, was married to Max Stark of Quarry Heights, C. Z., yesterday morning at the Whitehall by the Rev. Dr. William F. Rosenblum of Temple Israel.

The Association of Reform Rabbis, meeting yesterday at the Hotel Taft, re-elected Rabbi Sidney S. Tedesche of Union Temple, Brooklyn, president. All the other officers were likewise unanimously reelected. They are Joshua L. Goldberg, Astoria Jewish Center, vice president;

Despite a scintillating run of 215 by his rival, Welker Cochran of San Francisco turned back Jake Schaefer of Chicago, 320-300, in the fourth block of their 4,200-point meeting for the world's 18.2 balkline billiard championship at the Strand Academy last night.

Russia's much-advertised Supreme Soviet, elected at the first general balloting under the new Constitution on Dec. 12, will convene for the first time in the Kremlin Great Palace tomorrow. The 1,100-odd delegates
C. Troutt's aged bay gelding, Hueu, romped off with the big end of the purse in the feature race at the Fair Grounds today.

Appreciable sales of sheeting, pillowcases and sheets have developed in the last few days in the primary market, where buyers for wholesale houses have been replenishing stocks which have been sharply cut as a result of the good response to January sales staged by retailers.
J. Waddy Tate, elected Mayor of Dallas in 1929 after a campaign marked by his distribution of "hotdog" sandwiches, died today after a brief illness. He was 66 years old.
The American League will have exclusive control of major league baseball's opening date this year and, furthermore, will inaugurate the campaign with a grand flourish on a two-game scale.
The Board of Education today adopted a $1,771,500 economy program to bring the 1938 budget of the public schools into line with a recent State Supreme Court decision banning a tax increase.

The number of commercial and industrial failures in the United States in the five days ended Jan. 6 were higher than for the corresponding period last year in four trade divisions, but showed decline in one, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The detailed comparisons follow:

William W. McLaughlin, former police inspector known as the "Millionaire Cop," lived up to his sobriquet, it was learned yesterday in Surrogate's Court, where an application for counsel fees disclosedthat he had left a gross estate of $1,099,556. He died Oct. 12, 1933.

By a vote of 4 to 3 the Court of Appeals today ordered a new trial for Harry Weiss and Martin Schlossman of New York City, convicted of kidnapping Paul H. Wendel of Trenton, whose last minute "confession" delayed for a few days the execution of Bruno Richard Hauptmann for the kidnapping and slaying of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr.

The period of comparative quiescence in German politics that followed the visit of Viscount Halifax was topped today by an exchange of most conciliatory New Year speeches between Chancellor Adolf Hitler and the diplomatic corps at the usual formal New Year's reception, which, for the convenience of all concerned, was held in Berlin after the holidays.

The sum of 7,012 yen was handed to Ambassador Joseph C. Grew yesterday by the Nichi Nichi, the result of its fund for the Panay sufferers. At the same time 943 yen was handed to Italian Ambassador Giacinto Auriti for Sandro Sandri, Italian killed on the Panay.
Newtown High's strong quintet rang up its eighth victory in as many starts in the Queens Division of the P. S. A. L. yesterday by routing Flushing High, 44--23, at the Flushing Y. M. C. A.

A man who -described himself as Birger Johnsen, 44 years old, of 665 Seventy - first Street, Brooklyn, World War flier and former -stunt flier, barnstormer and pilot for American and foreign companies, was freed yesterday by Magistrate Troy in Brooklyn Felony Court on a charge of violating the Sullivan law.

London surrounded by clusters of captive balloons, enemy airplanes trying to drive through them, striking a cable and crashing to the ground-are we to read of such defenses and hazards in the war to come? The British Army has its "Groups on Balloon Barrages."

Coming through in their matches yesterday, the Midston House and Jackson Heights remained in a deadlock for the lead in the Group I team tournament of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association. Midston House defeated the City A. C. 3 to 2, while Jackson Heights vanquished Bayside by the same score, each match being played on the losers' courts.

David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, third largest C. I. 0. affiliate, with a membership of more than 250,000, assailed last night policies of the C. I. O. and demanded resumption of peace negotiations with the American Federation of Labor.
A late rally yesterday following the news that President Roosevelt had summoned several industrial leaders to a White House conference enabled the stock market to close irregularly higher;

Miss Madeleine Dalton of the Salle d'Armes Vince, national junior champion and former intercollegiate titleholder from Hunter College, annexed premier honors in the annual Mrs. Charles Voorhees open foils competition at the Fencers Club last night. A field of thirtyeight prominent foilswomen competed.

The favorites, paced by top-seeded Bobby Riggs of Chicago, moved into the quarter-finals of the Nautilus Hotel tournament without a casualty today. Riggs required three sets to dispose of Oscar Evans of Miami,

Dr. and Mrs. Louis Mackler of Atlantic City were drowned in Little Gunpowder Creek near here today after their car skidded over a twentyfoot embankment from a snow-covered road and overturned in the icy water.

Plans for the New York "Fight Infantile Paralysis" campaign, which will begin on Monday and continue for two weeks, will be made at a meeting of the executive committee of the women's division for the drive Friday morning at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Douglas Gibbons, chairman of the committee.
The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey announced yesterday a reduction of 1/4 cent a gallon in the tank-car price of heating oil, retroactive to Jan. 1.

Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of New York University, addressed a gathering of 300 educators and religious leaders last night in the library of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, Broadway and 122d Street, which celebrated the start of the second half century of its existence.
Suspension of Italo-American trade treaty negotiations was said today to have resulted from the United States' refusal to grant de facto recognition to the Italian conquest of Ethiopia.
Colonel William B. Gordon, United States Army, retired, died here today. He would have been 85 in May.

Police Commissioner Valentine took unprecedented action yesterday to rid the city of vice and gambling. Apparently dissatisfied with the response to his recent demand for stricter enforcement of the morals laws, he summoned the ranking officers of the department to a conference at Police Headquarters.
Dr. Otto Warburg, president of the Zionist movement from 1911 to 1920, died last night after a two weeks illness. He was in his seventy-ninth year.

The possibility of forming a trade union for Great Britain's 1,500,000 private domestic workers-one of the last groups of unorganized labor hereis being examined by the general council of the trades union congress.

The Duc de Levis Mirepoix, noted French historian, lecturer and author, who arrived here last week for a lecture tour throughout the United States, delivered his first talk on the Middle Ages before the French Institute, 22 East Sixtieth Street, yesterday afternoon on the subject "Tragiques Amours des Princesses au Moyen Age."
The fifth annual festival and ball of the Grand Street Settlement House will be held Friday evening ir. the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Unless Committee for Industrial Organization organizers intervene to break up an understanding reached late today between sugar producers and field and factory laborers, a new wage agreement giving 10 per cent increase to field workers and 5 per cent to factory workers

The German reaction to the Ludlow Amendment defeat in the United States House of Representatives is divided between the arguments that it represents a loss of prestige for democracy and that it demonstrates America intends to draw no line between self-defense and intervention.

Commercial tonnage under construction in the shipyards of the world, exclusive of Russia, totaled 2,900,184 tons at the close of 1937, according to the quarterly report of Lloyd's Register of Shipping, published yesterday.

A prompt and adequate modification of government policy regarding the capital market would make a major contribution to business revival, Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board of the Chase National Bank, told stockholders yesterday at their annual meeting.
A favorable report to the Senate is expected soon on the House bill to make the Saratoga Battlefield a national monument.

Miss Elizabeth Taylor of New Rochelle, N. Y., daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Taylor of Tampa, was married to John Munroe of New York, son of Mrs. Henry W. Munroe, this morning in Peace Memorial Presbyterian Church here by the Rev. Ansley C. Moore. Only relatives were present.
Stocks improved and closed irregularly higher after sagging on profit-taking; turnover, 1,506,260 shares. All groups of bonds irregularly lower; transactions, $6,925,850.
Clark Kohl announced yesterday the change of the firm name to Clark, Kohl Eyman and the admission to partnership of Carl E. Eyman.
To take effect 8 A. M., Jan. 12: LIEUTENANTS-James B. Reilly, from 88th Precinct to 19th Division, Office of Chief Inspector. Assignment to desk duty discontinued.
Representative Patman of Texas today introduced a bill providing heavy penalties for business houses indulging in the giving of "commercial bribes"
The Austrian Legitimists held fifty meetings today throughout the country, all under the slogan "For Austria's independence." There were ten meetings here.

One of the most beloved figures in early American life was the country or village Doctor of the Old School. He has not entirely passed out of the picture in some communities, especially in districts far from the cities.

Foreign Minister Istrate Micescu of Rumania conferred at length today with Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch and other Yugoslav leaders. A communique later said full understanding existed between Yugoslavia and Rumania.

That roar of angry multitudes from across the Hudson is not, after all, a C. I. O. revolution. What happened was that the Mayor and City Manager of Hackensack took their automobiles to the State motor vehicle inspectors and flunked the tests.
Hitting 113 runs for South Australia today in a Sheffield Shield cricket match against Queensland, Don Bradman brought his total of runs in first-class cricket to 17,461. This aggregate equals

The Rev. Dr. Samuel Lane Loomis of Larchmont, N. Y., a Congregational minister for fifty-eight years, died yesterday at his Winter home in Orlando, Fla., according to word received by his son, Henry S. Loomis of 42 Claremont Avenue, Mount Vernon. He was 81 years old.

A severe earthquake shook an unusually wide area of Japan today, sending thousands of frightened Japanese rushing from their homes. A considerable amount of damage was believed to have been done by the shock, which lasted twenty minutes.

Sharp words were exchanged today when a lawyer for the Securities and Exchange Commission questioned a $9,700,000 "good-will" entry in accounting records pertaining to Schoellkopf, Hutton Pomeroy, Inc., an -investment banking concern.
Cardinal Hayes left by train yesterday afternoon from the Pennsylvania Station for Miami on his way to Nassau in the Bahama Islands.
The House voted power to the President today to reduce or eliminate in the interest of economy any appropriation item in a bill passed by Congress without vetoing the whole bill.

Richard Barnes and Charles Wilkes, duo-pianists, came last night from their home in Tampa, Fla., to give their New York debut recital in Steinway Hall. They were greeted by an audience that almost filled the little hall.

The Court of Appeals upheld today the validity of a Nevada divorce, with the restriction that the party obtaining the decree must have a legal residence in that State, and that the other party must appear, either personally or through an attorney, to contest the action.

Captain and Mrs. R. Amcotts Wilson entertained tonight with a dinner at their villa for Colonel and Mrs. Louis Jacques Balsan, Mr. and Mrs. Hermann Oelrichs. Viscount Sosthenes de Rochfoucauld, and Sir Philip Sassoon of London, who has joined the Balsans house party for two days on his way to Nassau.
William W. Nichols, retired attor ney and secretary of the board of trustees of Syracuse University, died in his home here today of a heart attack. He was 65 years old.

" Yr Obedient Husband," in which Fredric March and his wife, Florence Eldridge, came to town Monday night, will close at the Broadhurst next Saturday evening. Eight performances. John Cromwell, who directed, returns to Hollywood today.
The Bituminous Coal Commission lowered today the minimum price on pea coal shipped into New York Harbor by the Carter Coal Company and all other operators in the smokeless district of West Virginia.

The feeling of animosity toward the American Labor party, which has existed under the surface in the ranks of organization Democrats for many months, came out in the Assembly today, when Crawford W. Hawkins of Brooklyn introduced a bill which seemed to be aimed at the Labor group.

Frequent statements that the current recession is only a temporary one, created by top-heavy inventories, and that it is certain to be ended almost immediately, were made yesterday at a symposium on "Building Sales Morale for 1938" at the weekly luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.
The National Labor Relations Board has dismissed the petitions of workers at the plant of the Chase Brass and Copper Company at Waterbury, Conn., for representation by a C. I. O. organization.

Charged with extortion in an alleged attempt to "sell" a job of guard on the city subway, John W. Falter, 46, of 1,703 Washington Avenue, the Bronx, and Frank Hulse, 48, of the Hotel Chesterfield, 130 West Forty-ninth Street, were locked up at police headquarters last night

A committee headed by Herbert Bayard Swope of New York, seeking to prolong the jockey's riding career, offered a resolution to the National Association of State Racing Commissioners today that no horse carry a weight less than 103 pounds.
The familiar charges of criminal wrecking and espionage for a foreign power--in this case Germany--are leveled now at another Soviet Commissariat, that of Finance. Gregory T. Grinko,
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Jan. 10, unless specified: At Naval Operating Base, Norfolk, Jan. 11: Badger, Tattnall. San Pedro to San Diego: Mahan, Jan. 11; Drayton.

The proposed Czechoslovak trade treaty gives little promise of stimulating this country's export trade, but does offer "serious possibilities of playing havoc with a number of our domestic industries which will be affected by any concessions
The United States' refusal to recognize King Victor Emmanuel of Italy as Emperor of Ethiopia has resulted in suspension of the Italo-American negotiations for a commercial treaty.
Among the arrivals from Europe last night on the French liner He de France was the Grand Duchess Marie of Russia, who said she had spent fourteen months in traveling on the Continent and in India.

Increased fares put into effect last July on bus lines operating across the George Washington Bridge between New York and Bergen County, N. J., are "not unreasonable or otherwise unlawful" and proceedings in opposition to them should be discontinued, H. C. Lawton, examiner for the Interstate Commerce Commission, recommended to the commission today.

For the ninth successive year Dr. John A. Harriss has been named president of the Broadway Association. Officers to serve with Dr. Harriss during 1938 are Lawrence L. Strauss, first vice president; S. E. Lester, second vice president; Edwin S. Friendly, third vice president; H. C Crowell, fourth vice president; Frank V. Baldwin, treasurer, and J. B. Vandever,'secretary.
Robert B. Harshe, art authority and director of the Chicago Art Institute, died today. He was 58 years old. He is survived by his son, William Read Harshe of Chicago.

Lotte Lehmann, soprano, and Lauritz Melchior, tenor, both of the Metropolitan Opera Association, were heard in a joint recital last night at Carnegie Hall for the benefit of the Educational Department of the New York Women's Trade Union League.

The following ununiformed firemen, having completed their probationary period of three months satisfactorily, are appointed as firemen, fourth grade, with compensation each at the rate of $2,000 per annum, to take effect as shown below:

The waterfront property at Borden and Review Avenues, Long Island City, located on the main highway which will lead to the new Queens vehicular tunnel to Manhattan, has been purchased by Porcelain Metals, Inc., manufacturers of porcelain signs and store fronts.
Jack Morrissey, 47 years old, of 257 West 115th Street, a former prohibition enforcement officer, was acquitted in one hour yesterday by a General Sessions jury on an attempted extortion indictment.
Poldi Mildner, who appeared In recital at the Town Hall last night, has enough sheer talent to be outstanding among the younger generation of pianists.

Conflicting movements again characterized the trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange with the result that the market closed irregular. Renewed selling in bonds of The Baltimore Ohio and Erie railroads was a feature of the trading in the corporate list.

Penn's basketball team, defending champion, won its first Eastern Intercollegiate League contest tonight, defeating Yale, 42-39, in a thrilling overtime battle. At the end of the regular time the score was deadlocked at 36-all.

Miss Ethel Miller, seeded No. 1, reached the semi-finals of the women's metropolitan Class B squash racquets championship by defeating Mrs. J. K. Crimmins of the Bronxville Field Club, 15-11, 15-10, 15-6, at the Heights Casino yesterday.
France projected two 42,000-ton battleships today to match the rising might of Fascist Italy's sea power.

Two first performances of works either new or unknown to the public of this city, given last night by the Schola Cantorum, Hugh Ross conductor, in Carnegie Hall, had a public reception which connoted a brilliant success.

St. Joseph's Seminary and College at Dunwoodie, N. Y., receives a legacy of $6,000 in the will of John J. Shea, formerly of the New York Railways Corporation, which was offered for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday.

The Cornell Club and Downtown A. C. scored victories last night to clinch the honors in Groups II and III, respectively, in the New York division of the Metropolitan League Class C squash racquets competition.
The Federal Communications Commission today called a conference for Jan. 27 of press association and newspaper representatives to discuss rules and regulations

Goesta Ekman, Swedish actor who appeared with Greta Garbo before she started her Hollywood career, died today. A Continental film star and player of Shakespearean roles, Mr. Ekman had refused Hollywood offers. He was 48 years old.

The first major financing of 1938 and the largest offering since midOctober will reach the market today. A new issue of $30,000,000 of Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., twenty-year 3 1/2 per cent debentures due in 1958 will be offered by a large underwriting group headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc.

Bob Cox set a dazzling pace, figuring in six of the seven goals scored, as the Harvard freshman hockey team routed Andover Academy, 7-0, at the Boston Arena today. It marked the Crimson yearlings' sixth straight victory.
The Rev. Dr. William Burton Farmer, executive secretary of the Board of Pensions and Relief of the Methodist Episcopal Church, died early today at his home in Evanston, Ill. He was 65 years old.

The Home Furnishings Market at the American Furniture Mart entered its final three days today with buyer registrations "equal to or better than any two weeks' market in history, with the exception of those in 1937," officials reported.

The Bethlehem Steel Company this week will announce to its workers through the Bethlehem Review, plant magazine, a renewal of its policy to grant vacations with pay to mill workers as well as office workers for the Summer of 1938.

The City Council has passed the budget and we can now sit back and catch our breaths. The Council has been acting normally. There is nothing to worry about. The scenes at City Hall on Tuesday were indeed a little remindful of the early stages of the French Revolution.

Stone Webster and Blodget, Inc., will offer publicly today 26,180 shares of 5 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock, $100 par value, of the Bausch Lomb Optical Company at $100 a share plus accrued dividends from Jan. 1 to date of delivery.
City Treasurer Almerindo Portfolio issued a warning to stores and shopkeepers that Saturday is the last day on which the sales tax for the last quarter of 1937 may be paid without penalty.

About seventy singers of the Metropolitan Opera Company, in cluding, according to a union spokesman, a number of the stars, voted unanimously last night to authorize the American Guild of Musical Artists to open negotiations with the opera company management for an agreement requiring all singers to belong to the guild.
American Minister, Franklin Mott Gunther, told Premier Octavian Goga today that the United States was deeply concerned over evidences of anti-Semitism in Rumania.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt made a personal appeal today to the women of the- country to enlist in the campaign against infantile paralysis to be started on Monday by the National Foundation, organized to expand the work begun at Warm Springs.

The amended plan of reorganization for the $900,000,000 Standard Gas and Electric Company that was filed in the United States District Court in Wilmington, Del., on Nov. 24 was attacked yesterday on three major points by the Allen committee for the utility's $4 preferred stack.

Jaquin Guias was sentenced to death today in a special treason and espionage court. Guias, who fled to France at the outbreak of the Spanish Civil War in July, 1936, was convicted of having worked there against the interests of the Spanish Government.

CHRISTMAS EVE. Whether or not the traditional snow decked the landscape where this story arose deponent is unable to say. But put the snow in for good measure to garnish the scene. There were holly wreaths in the windows. There were Christmas trees on the lawns and on the happy hearths and the toys and gifts were being set out in colored wrappings tied with red ribbons.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses and normal Federal income charges, but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings. Figures, in many oases, are subject to final adjustment.

Methods of cutting retail store expenses in such fields as deliveries, light and power, insurance, salaries of sales forces, office operation, and credits and collections were suggested last night in a number of reports presented at a meeting of the Metropolitan Controllers Association at the Roger Smith Restaurant.

Howard C. Fletcher, principal naval architect of the construction and repair department of the planning division of the New York Navy Yard in Brooklyn, died Tuesday night of a heart attack at his residence, 8,918 Shore Court, Brooklyn, at the age of 57.

Motor cruiser folks have stepped momentarily out of the limelight at the National Motor Boat Show to give their little brothers of the outboard field a chance. Racing commissions of one kind or another

Asserting that President Roosevelt in his recent message to Congress, did not properly assay the causes of the present recession, and showed no intention of aiding business, Representative Snell in a radio address tonight said that the Administration's attitude actually was not much different from that expressed earlier by Secretary Ickes and Robert H. Jackson, Assistant Attorney General.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 12--A communique issued tonight at the end of the conference of the Rome Protocol States announced the intention of Austria and Hungary to recognize de jure the Insurgent government of General Francisco Franco in Spain following their de facto recognition of it last September.

William N. Schill, a cotton broker who had been a member of the New York Cotton Exchange since 1904, died on Tuesday night at his residence, 812 Park Avenue, after an illness of several weeks. He was born in this city fifty-six years ago and received his education here.

President Roosevelt's expressed willingness to extend preferential trade treatment of the Philippines to 1960 had stimulated Philippine business interests, which have been perplexed and depressed since March by Quezon's idea of early independence.
The question of ratification of the Federal Child Labor Amendment will come to a vote on the floor of the Assembly this year, unless there is a drastic change in the plans of the Republican leaders.
There will be no foundation stone in the new Museum of Modern Art building. This is what one would have expected.

The Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel opened its annual convention in the Hotel Ambassador today with a series of five arbitration hearings on contract disputes between members, about 400 of whom are attending. The meetings will continue through Friday.
The filibuster of Southern Democrats against the Wagner-Van Nuys AntiLynching Bill continued strongly today, a week after its start.

Directors of the Continental Can Company yesterday declared an interim dividend of 50 cents on the common stock, payable Feb. 15 to holders of record Jan. 25. Four quarterly disbursements of 75 cents each were made last year.
Mrs. Lois C. Clinton today obtained a divorce from Frank C. Clinton of Boise, Idaho, on a charge of cruelty. They were married at Reno May 18, 1935, and have one child.

A resolution proposing appointment of a joint legislative committee to investigate the overhead cost of administering public welfare relief in the State was presented to the Senate today by Senator Desmond, Republican, of Orange County.

Ending a deadlock that had existed for the last five months, the Board of Education at its regular meeting yesterday elected Frederic Ernst, a member of the New York City school system since 1903, as Associate Superintendent of Schools.

Paramount today terminated its contract with Major Pictures, makers of the Mae West and Bing Crosby films, an act that culminated a four-year feud between Adolph Zukor, head of Paramount, and Emanuel Cohen, president of Major and former production chief of the Paramount lot.

The Federal undistributed profits tax has halted plant expansion of Wisconsin industries,' diverted several million dollars from factory improvements during the year and caused the unemployment of many men who previously would have been kept on payrolls and paid out of surpluses, accordingg to the Wisconsin Manufacturers Association.

Demolition of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Andrew, landmark at Duane Street and Cardinal Place, where newspaper men from Park Row attended mass for many years during the small hours of the morning, will not start today as planned.
Sales of printcloths yesterday were slightly more than 10,000,000 yards, and this brought the volume for the week to date about 50,000,000 yards.
Mike Latvis tallied nineteen points tonight to pilot Williams to a 36--21 basketball victory over Massachusetts State on the Physical Education Building court.

A petition filed by State Senator Lester H. Clee of Newark for a Supreme Court order setting aside the election of United States Senator A. Harry Moore of Jersey City as Governor of New Jersey and for an order directing a court investigation of the balloting in Hudson County was dismissed today by Chief Justice Thomas J. Brogan.

Magistrate Anthony Savarese freed three young men charged with assault and robbery yesterday in Queens Felony Court when Alois Achec of 70-35 Broadway, paymaster of the James Waldes KohI-Noor Company, 47-52 Twentyseventh Street, Long Island City, Queens, was unable to identify them as the men who stole a $8,200 payroll last Friday.
Michael Gold, who was a Union corporal stationed outside Appomattox Court House when Lee surrendered, died yesterday in United States Veterans Hospital 81, the Bronx, at the age of 91.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Jan. 10: LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS Bain, E. C., the Saratoga, to the Lexington, as GunneryOfficer, April 30.

Although they admit to many differences of opinion in twenty-four years of married life, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick R. Lucken of 294 Third Avenue agreed that John Simon was entitled to recover $146,404 from the Chemical Bank and Trust Company in a verdict recorded yesterday in Supreme Court.
Clark Griffith, president of the Senators, announced today that he's going to let the government decide the home-run merits of big league baseballs.

The Senate Civil Liberties Committee has abandoned further prosecution of officials of the Railway Audit and Inspection Company on charges of contempt. The citations were brought when company officials failed to comply in August with subpoenas directing production of records.

Harried by recent world economic and political events, American export credit men face difficult situations in Asia, Europe and South America, opinions expressed at the regular monthly round table meeting sponsored by the foreign credit interchange bureau of the National Association of Credit Men at the Hotel Pennsylvania disclosed yesterday.

Before 15,000 persons, one of the largest openingday crowds in the history of Hialeah Park, the Miami Jockey Club today began its 46-day meeting with Clocks the winner of the inaugural handicap at 30 to 1. Now owned by the Westerner, L. E. Ogle, and ridden by Ralph Eccard, the former Brookmeade Stable racer scored by a length at the end of the six furlongs which were run in 1:10 2-5 over a fast track.

Influenced by storms of protest which have arisen since 1938 began, the governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange postponed yesterday the application of the schedule of service charges on inactive accounts that became effective on Jan. 3.
George Coleman Gow, Professor Emeritus of Music at Vassar College, died here today. He was 77 years old.

James G. Strong, assistant treasurer of the Home Owners Loan Corporation, who was a Republican member of the House of Representatives from Kansas, 1919-1933, died here last night at the home of his son, George E. Strong. Mr. Strong was 67 years old.
A 4.1 per cent decline in industrial employment in New York in December and a 2.9 per cent decrease in payrolls were reported today by Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner.

American interests here are studying closely the present foreign exchange situation as a result of the exchange monopoly declared by Brazil on Dec. 23, which automatically placed an embargo on exchange coverage for import bills.

A meeting of minds is always helpful-when the minds meet. This applies as much to the current White House conferences between the President and business leaders as to any others. Cooperation is effective where there is cooperation, which usually means concessions on both sides.

Plans for a garden adjoining the building of the New York Historical Society on Central Park West were announced yesterday by Alexander J. Wall, director. The society is adding two wings to its building between Seventy-sixth and Seventyseventh Streets and has bought the adjoining four four-story houses at 7 to 13 West Seventy-sixth Street.

The steady rise in the stock market in the last week and the definitely improved business sentiment have been communicated to the advertising field here and more optimism is noticeable now than at any time in the last four months, agency executives remarked yesterday. Those companies which

Ted Broadribb, English manager of fighters, is scheduled to arrive here Jan. 19 on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria accompanied by Ernie Weiss, Australian middleweight, and Jimmy Vaughan, outstanding challenger for Great Britain's lightweight title.

M. Maldwin Fertig, former counsel to Governor Lehman, assumed office as a member of the Transit Commission yesterday after being sworn in by Presiding Justice Francis Martin of the Appellate Division. He succeeds former Commissioner Leon G. Godley, who resigned on Jan. 1.
John S. Harrison and Edward R. Greeff, both members of the Squash Club, gained the final of the Union League Club's Class B squash racquets tournament yesterday.

Hoboken police and detectives of a private agency were seeking clues yesterday to the disappearance of two oil paintings from the smoking room of the old liner Leviathan, waiting at her pier in Hoboken for a last voyage late this month to the knacker's beach in Scotland.
In a move to speed up expansion of the Royal Air Force, the British airplane manufacturing industry has called in an outsider to act as liaison officer with the Air Ministry.
E. P Lewis, vice president in charge of credit of James Talcott, Inc., was elected executive chairman of the Uptown Credit Group at the meeting held here yesterday.

Extension from sixteen to twenty-six weeks of the maximum period for benefit payments under the State Unemployment Insurance Law may be recommended by the State Labor Department if it finds large numbers of unemployment insurance recipients forced to fall back on relief because the present benefit period is too short to permit a thorough search for new jobs, Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews said last night.

Richard H. Williams, for many years a member of the Tax Commission of New York, died in a hospital here this morning at the age of 74. Ten years ago he became a permanent resident of Palm Beach on his retirement from his position in New York.

George Miller, diminutive sophomore forward from Elmira, scored eight field goals and almost stole the spotlight as his fighting Union College quintet went down to a 47-33 defeat before the dazzling passing attack of N. Y. U. tonight.

Hearing in the reorganization proceedings of the Consolidated Textile Corporation ended yesterday before Peter B. Olney, bankruptcy referee, when attorneys representing interested groups said they had no objection to a plan of reorganization that has been proposed.
Today's major events: "Lohengrin," Metropolitan Opera House, 8 P. M.; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P. M.; Ruda Firkusny, pianist, Town Hall, 3P. M.

Operations in the wheat market on the Board of Trade were restricted today and a good part of the business consisted in buying here against sales in Winnipeg to close spreads. Prices declined early in sympathy with
St. Francis College scored its seventh victory of the season by defeating the Upsala College quintet, 44-11, on the St. Francis court last night.
A proposed deep waterway connecting the St. Lawrence and Hudson Rivers was described to the Board of Army Engineers today as a "political move to get Senatorial votes for the St. Lawrence Seaway."
A young man found dead on Monday in the woods of Villard Hill here was identified today through fingerprints as Fred Lester Acer of 640 West Center Street, Medina, N. Y., police said.

Brig. Gen. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, who have arrived in Biscayne Bay aboard their yacht, Winchester, were guests this afternoon of Joseph E. Widener, president of the Miami Jockey Club, at Hialeah for the opening day of the races.

Union Temple downed the Crescent Athletic Club five, 43 to 38, in the feature game of a double-header at Union Temple, Brooklyn, last night. In the other contest, the Ohrbach A. A. defeated the Lenox Hill A. A., 56 to 46. Eddie Pollack starred for Union Temple, making 10 points.
