Temple University, in a warm-up for Manhattan in New York Friday night, regained its winning stride by disposing of a hard-fighting Muhlenberg quintet at the Arena tonight, 40-23.

Donald Budge, American and Wimbledon tennis champion, today decided, on advice of a physician, to withdrow from the exhibition singles match he had been scheduled to play tomorrow. He has been suffering with a sore throat and fever.

For the joy of knowledge and for the appreciation of the country as a whole, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt this afternoon recommended to the directors of the General Federation of Women's Clubs that they study carefully the needs of their own communities.

Frederick Charles Holmes died last night at his home, 29 Hillcrest Avenue, after an illness of a year. Mr. Holmes, who was in his fifty-fifth year, had been identified with the drug business in Stamford and vicinity for nearly forty years.

In a move to force Mayor Joseph F. Loehr to make reductions in the personal service items of his tentative gross budget of $16,375,471, the Yonkers Common Council submitted to him today a budget, that deprives all city departments, save the health and welfare bureaus, of funds for equipment and supplies during 1938.

Because of frost and snow which have halted all outside work, unemployment in Germany rose 422,000 in December to a total 995,000. This increase is larger than last year's but the total increase for the Winter so far is only 526,000, which is considerably below last year's.

Associates of United States Senator Francis T. Maloney of Connecticut have learned that he plans in the near future to introduce in the Senate a bill for the regulation of the over-the-counter securities market by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Nicholas J. Eberhard, County Clerk of the Bronx from 1934 until last Dec. 31, announced yesterday that he had just received a refund of $1,574, representing State income tax he paid on his salary under protest for. 1934, 1935 and 1936.

Film programs to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools. The list follows:

The National Council of American Importers and Traders will hold a meeting for members at its offices, 45 East Seventeenth Street, at 2:30 P. M. tomorrow. The proposed trade agreement with England will be discussed.

Miss Catherine Wood Campbell, only daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Reck Campbell of this city, was married to Randolph Apperson Hearst, also of Atlanta, son of William Randolph Hearst, the publisher, of San Simeon, Calif., and Mrs. Hearst of New York, here this afternoon in the Sacred Heart Church. The ceremony was performed by the Very Rev. James T. Reilly.
Harry B. Stewart, operating trustee and former president of the Akron, Canton Youngstown Railway Company, died today at the age of 73.

The Rev. John E. Wickham, who for fifteen years was rector of St. Brendan's Roman Catholic Church, Perry Avenue and 207th Street, the Bronx, died yesterday in the Troy Hospital of a heart ailment. He was 58 years old.

A hard-fighting Choate basketball five met its first defeat of the season today when the Yale Freshmen staged a brilliant scoring drive in the closing stages to win, 25-22. Overcoming a one-point lead at the start of the final period, the Yale cubs swept through the home team's defense. Captain Cobb and Wetherill, the latter with 12 points, led the attack. Captain Lee was outstanding for Choate.

An aggressive campaign to promote the value of price maintenance and fair trade laws, to prevent any abuse of them and to educate the public on their advantages, will be launched on Feb. 28 at the Hotel Astor, when announcement of the rebirth of the American Fair Trade League will be made to some 2,000 guests, it was learned here yesterday.

Negotiations looking toward a treaty of friendship, commerce and navigation between Italy and the United States are going forward in the usual course, Secretary Hull said today, commenting on published accounts that the pourparlers have been terminated.
ACTING CAPTAINS-Christian L. Zimmer, from Telegraph Bureau to 3d Division, assigned to duty as supervisor of plain clothes patrolmen. Designation as acting captain revoked.

A supper party was given last night at the Weylin by Mr. and Mrs. Russell A. Alger Jr. of Grosse Pointe, Mich., who are passing several weeks at the hotel. Their guests included the group of young matrons and debutantes who have assisted at the booth of the Seaman's Church Institute of New York at the Motor Boat Show.

The Port of New York Authority joined yesterday with a group of ship lines and coffee importers in requesting the Federal Maritime Commission to continue the practice of permitting eighteen-day free storage of coffee imports on piers in the port of New York.

Declining for the fourth consecutive month, retail prices in December reached the lowest level since Feb. 1, 1937, according to the Fairchild Retail Price Index. Quotations dropped 1.4 per cent during the month, the index now standing at 93.2 compared with 94.5 for the previous month and with 91.7 at the end of December a year ago.
Pierre Shields of Brooklyn has announced the engagement of his niece, Miss Helen Shields of East Orange, N. J., to John Stanley Graves, son of Mrs. George B. Graves and the late Mr. Graves of Albany.

RIGOLETTO-Opera in Italian in three acts. Music by Giuseppe Verdi; book by Piave, adapted from Victor Hugo's drama, "Le Roi s'Amuse." Conductor, Ettore Panizza; stage director, Desire Defrere; chorus master, Fausto Cleva. Presented at the Metropolitan Opera House.

LONDON, Jan. 12--Around the same Cabinet table at 10 Downing Street at which the old Irish Free State was born in 1921. another effort will be begun Monday to settle the differences still outstanding between Britain and Ireland.

Taking its cue from a recommendation made in Mr. Roosevelt's budget message, the House of Representatives has approved a plan which is intended to give the President power to veto individual appropriation items in a bill, without being forced to veto the measure as a whole.

Full penalty for setting up an inherently weak pawn structure by A. R. Thomas of Liverpool was exacted by Paul Keres, brilliant young chess master, representing Estonia, in the recent international tournament at Hastings, where Keres finished in second place, half a point behind Samuel Reshevsky, the United States champion.

The Neediest Cases Fund rose to $300,383.05 yesterday with additional contributions from fifteen donors amounting to $282. The largest sum, $200, came from the Local Code Committee of the Electrical Construction Industry, resulting from fines assessed against members for violations of the Voluntary Code of Fair Competition.
Larry MacPhail, former general manager of the Reds, said today it was unlikely he would accept a similar position with the Dodgers. MacPhail, stopping here on his way to Mexico,

Assistant District Attorney Ralph K. Jacobs of Brooklyn announced yesterday that he has tendered his resignation, effective Feb. 1, to District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan in order to enter the private practice of law. He said he would go into partnership with Albert Blumensteil.

PEIPING, Thrusday, Jan. 13--The landing of a large Japanese force at Tsingtao is believed to be the prelude to an advance along the Tsingtao-Tsinan Railway that will join the force that is advancing toward Tsingtao from Tsinan.

A move has been started to unseat Albert Marinelli as the Tammany leader in the Second Assembly District West, it was indicated yesterday. The drive also will be directed at several other old-time leaders below Fourteenth Street, including Christopher D. Sullivan, Tammany Hall leader and chieftain of the Second Assembly District East, it was said.
In a drastic order issued by the Bureau of Air Commerce the Northwest Airlines was ordered today to "ground" all its fleet of Lockheed H-14 airplanes.
Harold Ralph Day, manager of the booking department of the United States Lines office here since 1929, died today in Purley, Surrey, at the age of 41.

Charging that the thirteen. Democratic members of the City Council were trying to hamstring Mayor La Guardia's bloc, Newbold Morris, President of the Council, issued a statement yesterday taxing the Democrats with having slipped twenty-two significant changes into the temporary rules under which the Council is operating.
Army defeated the Layfayette College basketball team today, 52 to 27. The Cadets piled up a ten-point lead early in the opening half and led at the intermission by 22 to 16.
Baskets by Captain Jack O'Brien and Tom Macioce in the last three minutes of play gave Columbia's undefeated basketball team a 32-28 victory over Princeton in the university gym tonight.
Dr. Wilhelm Frick, Minister of Interior, today issued a series of special regulations increasing the difficulty of changing names. Jews, as before, are forbidden to assume supposed non-Jewish names.
Mrs. Cora L. Fearon, wife of former State Senator George R. Fearon, died today in University Hospital after an operation for a stomach ailment.

Miss Georgie Bicknell Zabriskie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Zabriskie, was married to Walter H. Grimm of St. James, L. I., today at the home here of her parents. The Rev. Edgar L. Cook of Christ Church performed the ceremony.

John L. Lewis, head of the Committee for Industrial Organization; Philip Murray, chairman of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, and Thomas Moses, vice president of the United States Steel Corporation of Delaware, conferred yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore.

Addressing a mass meeting of more than 600 fur manufacturers last night in the Manhattan Opera House, called to resist demands of the International Fur Workers Union, a C. I. O. affiliate, Harry Heitel, president of the American Fur Manufacturers Association,

A settlement was announced in high court here today in an action in which two residents of the United States share a sweepstake prize of $50,000. The plaintiff in the suit is Jose Gomis of Denville, N. J.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There are no Italian troops in Spain. Madrid was captured by Franco in November, 1936. There are no German aviators fighting for Franco. Franco is not a Fascist despite his two signed statements to that effect.

Butlers who serve New York's leading families, personal maids and parlor maids, cooks, chauffeurs and gardeners of country estates danced the fox trot and rhumba in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Commodore last night at the Butlers Staff Ball.

The tenth day of the longshoremen's strike stopping all cargo shipments to and from Puerto Rico ended with Acting Governor Rafael Menendez Ramos saying tonight that an agreement was no nearer, although the mediation commission continued its efforts.
President Roosevelt and Mrs. Roosevelt paid a call at the home of Justice Cardozo this afternoon, not long after a consultation of physicians was held to discuss the condition of the Justice.
Justice Department agents found no violations of Federal laws in their investigation of the AmerikaDeutscher Volkesbund, an official said today.

Stocks eased and closed heavy at irregularly lower levels; turnover, 1,209,800 shares. United States Government and corporate bonds irregular, Japanese issues recovered part of sharp declines; transactions, $7,540,800.

The deaths of the seven occupants of the Samoan Clipper, which, after having conducted survey flights of. the Hawaii-New Zealand route, was in cargo service .on a bimonthly basis when she met disaster, mar a seven-year safety record in the operation of Pan American Airways' big flying boats.

Assuming that December imports of silver were normal, the rise in the adverse balance of British trade during 1937 was about [Pound]92,600,000, according to preliminary details published by the Board of Trade tonight.

Electric power production increased last week. The gain in daily average output ran counter to the normal seasonal tendency, and after adjustment had been made for a rising long-term trend the index moved upward. The figure now stands at 95.7, compared with 93.4 for the previous week and 107.0 for the week ended Jan. 9, 1937.

Real estate men and builders are awaiting with interest the final form of the proposed amendments to the National Housing Act, now before Congress, to see if the legislators retain in the bill the clause calling for payment of "prevailing wages" to workmen on projects coming under the sponsorship of the FHA.

The House today passed an amendment to the Federal Trade Commission Act, which already has passed the Senate, extending the powers of the commission over "unfair" acts and practices in commerce and over deceptive advertising of food, drugs and cosmetics.
Juan de la Cierva, father of the inventor of the autogiro, died last night without knowing that his son and namesake had been killed in an air crash thirteen months ago.
With the development of a mild pneumonic condition at the base of both lungs, doctors attending Governor Blanton Winship today excluded all visitors from the sick room.
Sweeping every bout, the Yale wrestling team blanked Amherst, 36-0, today in Patty Gym. Only Johnny Cranshaw and Bruce Minnick escaped being thrown by their Eli opponents.

Arthur J. McGrail, head of the Richard Healy Company, Worcester, Mass., was elected president of the Specialty Stores Association at the annual meeting of this buying organization held yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria. He succeeds I.

Replying to a spokesman for the League of New York Theatres, the Theatrical Managers, Agents and Treasurers Union yesterday issued a statement denying that the State Labor Relations Board had made any ruling on questions pending between the league and the union.

Canada's political system could not function if provincial Legislatures were to impose censorship on newspapers, Aime Geoffrion, chief counsel for the Dominion Government, told the Supreme Court of Canada today as he argued against validity of three Alberta bills.

Members of the New York Newspaper Women's Club entertained yesterday at tea in honor of metropolitan newspaper publishers and editors and their wives. Miss Miriam Lundy, president of the club, received the guests at the clubrooms in the Midston House, 22 East Thirty-eighth Street.

The Administration moved today to outlaw the methods followed by Democratic campaign committees last year in selling at high prices to corporations souvenir convention books, some of them autographed by President Roosevelt.
TheWar Department released the following orders today dated Jan. 11: BRIGADIER GENERAL Nuttman, L. M., to retirement.

Employers who contribute to the State Unemployment Insurance Fund will start laying the maximum of 3 per cent of their payrolls for all wages paid in 1938, the unemployment insurance division of the Labor Department announced today.

The expected arrival here soon of Y. Megurikami, representative of the Japanese Exporters and Importers Federation, from Costa Rica has caused considerable discussion in commercial and industrial circles.

Representative Kennedy, New York Democrat, urged President Roosevelt today to appoint Senator Wagner to the Supreme Court to succeed Justice Sutherland. Mr. Kennedy suggested Mr. Wagner's name a few months ago after Justice Van Devanter resigned.

The Bureau of Mines reported today that the zinc industry advanced above depression lows in 1937 for the fifth consecutive year. The 1937 output from domestic ores was estimated by the bureau at 550,200 short tons, an increase of 12 per cent over 1936. The bureau said the output was the largest since 1929.
Lisbon authorities today sought to smash what they termed a widespread, foreign-inspired plot to foment revolt within the Portuguese army and navy.

An "intelligent, modernized" system of free enterprise, and not "artificial devices" for recovery, is the solution of the nation's economic ills, Dr. Glenn Frank, chairman of the recently formed Republican policy committee, declared yesterday.
John T. Cochrane, president of the Alabama, Tennessee Northern Railroad and of the Coastal Petroleum Company, died in his home today.

The discussions that the President has been having with utility executives and the leaders in other great businesses are an encouraging sign of a cooperation between business and Government that could lead to rapid recovery.

World production of rayon and rayon staple fiber was estimated yesterday at 1,525,000,000 pounds for 1937, by the E. I. du Pont de Nemours Company. Of this figure, the concern estimated United States production at 325,000,000 pounds.

The New York Rangers will seek to make more firm their hold on second place in the American group of the National Hockey League tonight when they oppose the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden.

The towering hill of the Norge Ski Club at Fox River Grove, III., will command the attention of the skiing world on Sunday, when an open jumping tournament, the first of its kind in this country, is to take place.
The stock market moved indecisively'yesterday and closed irregularly lower. The turnover on the Stock Exchange was 1,209,000 shares, compared with 1,506,000 the day before.

Miss Natalie O. Watts, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Everett Watts of 1,010 Fifth Avenue, was married yesterday afternoon in St. Bartholomew's Church to Morgan Hatton Grace Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Morgan H. Grace of Lismore, Great Neck, L. I.

There is no sound economic reason beyond the nation's control why the United States now should be suffering a serious business depression, Harvey D. Gibson, president of the Manufacturers Trust Company, declared yesterday in his message to stockholders, delivered at the hank's annual meeting.

The Federal grand jury investigating the issuance of passports to Donald L. and Ruth N. Robinson and Adolph A. Rubens through the office of former County Clerk Albert Marinelli continued yesterday its examination of two key figures in the case.

Dr. Emilie J. Hutchinson, head of the department of economics at Barnard College, died early yesterday morning of coronary embolism. She was 60 years old. She had worked late in her office at the college and had retired to her room at Brooks Hall, a college residence hall.

Calvin Verity, executive vice president of the American Rolling Mill Company, announced yesterday the letting of contracts for the construction of four buildings at its plant at Middletown, Ohio, at an estimated cost of $620,000, exclusive of new equipment.
Discovery of the largest star ever reported was described today by Dr. Otto Struve, director of the Yerkes Observatory of the University of Chicago at Williams Bay, Wis.

A heavy bronze tablet bearing Lincoln's Gettysburg Address and. serving as a memorial to Frederick R. Meres, a patriotic worker, was stolen Tuesday night from Mount Morris Park, Madison Avenue and 120th Street.
The Supreme Court today heard arguments in the case of Edward Lauf and the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butchers Workmen, Local 73, against E. G. Shinner Co., Inc., of Milwaukee.

Boxholders for the benefit performance this evening of J. B. Priestley's, "Time and the Conways" at the Ritz Theatre include officers of the Episcopal Actors' Guild of America, the beneficiary. They are George Arliss, president, and the Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray, vice president, warden and chairman of the council.

A judgment for $2,609,366 was awarded yesterday to the Chase National Bank against Gerhard M. Dahl, chairman of the board of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corporation, by Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer.

A lengthy but mild earthquake was experienced over large areas in Western Japan early this morning. The Osaka and Nagoya districts and the island province of Shikoku all felt the shock Reports have yet to be received from the more remote villages, but in the larger towns the damage was slight.

Three Brazilians comprising the Brazilian Highway Expedition, who will hold the distinction of being the only persons to traverse the full route of the 16,182 miles of the Pan American Intercontinental Highway from Rio de Janeiro to New York, will be received at City Hall by Mayor La Guardia at 2:15 tomorrow afternoon.
The Federal Trade Commission today announced that the Johns-Manville Corporation, 22 East Fortieth Street, New York, had agreed to stop certain misleading representations in the sale of products.

A banking group headed by Blyth Co., Inc., purchased yesterday an Issue of $3,197,000 of bonds of the Salt River Project Agricultural Improvement and Purification District, Arizona, on a bid of 97.07 for 4 1/4s. The bonds are dated Oct. 1, 1937, and will mature serially from Jan. 1, 1948 to 1964.

LONDON, Jan. 12--The Board of Trade's figures, for December, published today, are as follows: Total imports, ??94,320,000; exports of British products, [Pound]43,880,000; reexports, [Pound]4,970,000; total exports, [Pound]48,850,000; excess of imports, [Pound]45,470,000.

Yesterday, considering the fact that the snow was flying and the reports from the Southern fishing ports were rather quiet, we decided to see what we could find out about modern fly-tying, so we hunted up Alex Rogan, and found him tying flies for Alex Taylor.

Far Eastern issues fell heavily in a generally uncertain stock market here today. Gilt-edge issues were quiet but firm. Transatlantic stocks were in active demand and U. S. Steel and International Nickel advanced.

Holding what in some respects amounts to their most important conference of the year-at least it seems so to the players-Colonel Jacob Ruppert and Business Manager Ed Barrow yesterday went into executive session on the Yankees' 1938 salary list and presently emerged very well satisfied with their findings.

Harvard University authorities tonight notified the police of the disappearance of Wilbur James Gould, 18, of 327 Central Park West, New York City, who is a sophomore living in the Lowell House. Gould was last seen by the maid who came to clean his room at 10:45 A. M. Sunday.

Joseph J. Weiss, attorney, of 276 Fifth Avenue, who is on trial in Federal court charged with conspiracy to defraud insurance companies, supplied part of an expense fund used to establish a medical record for the presentation of a fraudulent disability claim, Benjamin H. Nelson, Bronx butter and egg merchant, testified yesterday.

The Japanese Foreign Office spokesman announced yesterday that the Japanese Government had not abandoned its hopes for peace and was still awaiting Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's response to its peace terms. He added that a statement on the Imperial Council's decisions on Monday would not be issued for at least several days.

Field Marshal Werner von Blomberg, Reich War Minister, who will be 60 years old in September, today was married to Fraeulein Gruhn of Hanover. She is reported to be in her late twenties. Chancellor Adolf Hitler and

Iso Briselli, Russian-American violinist, returned to the local concert platform last night at Town Hall for his first recital here in ten years. When he was previously heard in this city he was only 15 years of age and had been in America but two seasons.

President Roosevelt announced he would confer next week with forty-six business leaders. He discussed with Senator McAdoo proposed legislation to exempt American coastwise and intercoastal shipping from payment of Panama Canal tolls. With Mrs.
Waiver forms permitting continuance of pay cuts for Jersey City employes were being received today and similar blanks will be mailed to Hudson County employes beginning tomorrow.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey won a smashing electoral victory yesterday in a poll conducted by the general organization of Abraham Lincoln High School, Brooklyn, to determine "the citizen who rendered the greatest service to the City of New York in the year 1937."

If you study the program, you will observe that "Tortilla Flat," which was acted at Henry Miller's last evening, is a play by Jack Kirkland, based on a novel by John Steinbeck. John Steinbeck wrote both the novel and stage versions of "Of Mice and Men."

Exceptions have been filed to the findings of John F. Davidson, Securities and Exchange Commission trial examiner, in the disbarment proceedings against Joseph H. Van Dorn. A date for argument will be set soon.

A sharp break in Japanese dollar loans with a later recovery which wiped out most of the losses or reduced them considerably featured trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Elsewhere in the bond list a generally higher trend was manifested with interest in the Treasury group at a greater pitch since last month.

Mrs. Bennett Clay Jefferson of 1,212 Fifth Avenue, a member of the Clay family of Kentucky and a world traveler, and Alessandro Gagliardini of Rome, a representative of the International Travel Bureau of Italy, obtained a marriage license at the Municipal Building yesterday. Mrs. Jefferson is 66 years old and Mr. Gagliardini is 34.
The Census Bureau reported today that cottonseed crushed in the five months from Aug. 1 to Dec. 31 was 3,609,513 tons, compared with 2,791,836 in the corresponding period in 1936.

The first tombola, luncheon and fashion show of the season held today at the Everglades Club, was largely attended. Mrs. Marie Calhoun's guests there included Mr. and Mrs. Harding, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick R. Sears Jr., Mrs. Glenn Hodges, Mrs. Plankinton Plaut, Mrs. Edward T. Stotesbury, Mrs. Caldwell Olwell, A. Atwater Kent, Philip H. Giddens, Robert H. Hasler and R. Bushnell Hyman.

Hamilton College's basketball team came from behind in the final minutes to conquer Rochester University, 32 to 29, tonight. The game featured tight zone defense playing by both squads. Rochester led, 14-12, at the half.

Mrs. Edward B. Walters, one of the first American women to cross the Atlantic on the later fire-destroyed German. airship Hindenburg, died today at the Nassau Hospital in Mineola after a brief illness. Mrs. Walters lived at 111 Roxbury Road, here. She was in her fifty-seventh year.

A strong solution of sulphuric acid thrown into his face by an unidentified assailant almost in front of his home at 323 West Eighty-third Street last night seriously burned Jack Roum, 34-yearold shirt manufacturer, and blinded him for life.

The flying boat Samoan Clipper plunged into the Pacific in flames, carrying Captain Edwin C. Musick and six associates to death, her floating wreckage indicated today to a United States Navy searching ship.
Major Edward A. Mechling, U.S.A., retired, died in Walter Reed General Hospital this morning. He was in his sixty-second year. He was born at Yankton, S. D., on June 2, 1876.

The Montclair A. C. scored its tenth straight victory of the season last night in the Metropolitan Interclub Class A squash tennis competition. Invading the courts of the Crescent A. C., the New Jersey players vanquished their rivals by the slim margin of 3 to 2.

The National Association of State Racing Commissioners initiated a step toward eventual restriction of early 2-year-old racing today by recommending each track be limited to four juvenile races a week during January, February and March and that two of these be either maiden or claiming events at a claiming price not over $2,500.
On May 21 Professor Otto Schmidt landed with four airplanes on an ice floe near the North Pole and there established a scientific station on which the eyes of the world have been focused.

Oscar J. Bluemner, 70, a modernistic artist whose studies in vermilion were hailed by art critics in New York at a showing there three years ago, committed suicide today at his home here. The body was found by his daughter, Vera.

Plans for organizing independent retailers on a national scale will feature the conference of associations representing such merchants to be held on Jan. 30 at the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the Greater New York Retail Furnishings and Dry Goods Association, it was announced yesterday by Leon Grizer, general secretary.

It was generally agreed last night that one of the most probable causes of the crash of the Samoan Clipper and the loss of life by the seven members of her crew was the sudden ignition of the fuel load when it was jettisoned to make the plane light enough for a normal landing.

So much of paragraph 1, Special Orders 3, dated Jan. 5, 1938, as continues 1st Lt. Joseph J. Phillips Jr., Inf.-Res., on active duty with the CCC until Feb. 6, 1938, is amended so as to continue him on active duty until Feb. 4, 1938 (2d M. A.).

Increasing his lead to 1,800-1,024, Jake Schaefer of Chicago scored a double victory over Welker Cochran of San Francisco yesterday in their 4,200-point battle for the world's 18.2-balkline billiard championship at the Strand Academy.
Retail package deliveries showed an increase of 6 per cent for the week ended Jan. 8, over the same week last year, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service.

The following members of the department having satisfactorily completed the course in the care and operation of motors and pumps used in the department, are designated as motor and pump operators, and they are therefore qualified to be assigned to that duty in their companies or in any company to which they may be transferred, in preference to all other members who have not previously qualified;
TRANSGRESSOR IN THE TROPICS, by Negley Farson. (Harcourt, Brace, $2.50.) Travel and adventure in South America.

Canada's wheat exports in A 1937, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today, were 96,008,341 bushels, or 147,033,189 less than in 1936, while their value, $124,439,579, was $102,474,184 less. The average price was $1.296 a bushel, compared with 93.4 cents in 1936.
Railroad management and labor united today before the Senate Unemployment Committee in favoring an increase in freight and passenger rates to remedy unemployment.

Mr. and Mrs. Mark DeW. Stevenson of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Stevenson, to Cadet Robert Allen Breitweiser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Allen Breitweiser of Sacramento, Calif.
Rosemont, winner of the 1937 Santa Anita Handicap and one of the favorites among the many nominees for the $100,000 added race here March 5, was withdrawn today because of a soft hoof.

January retail trade so far has been better than expected and the outlook justifies "conservative optimism," according to the consensus of store executives attending the semi-annual conference yesterday of the Mutual Buying Syndicate, Inc. The belief was voiced that

Minister of the Interior Marx Dormoy and the Surete Nationale this evening told the press that five members of the Csar [Comite Secret d'Action Revolutionnaire] had been arrested for the murder of the anti-Fascist Italian brothers, Carlo and Salabino Roselli, who were found shot dead in the woods near Bagnoles de d'Orne, a noted health resort, last June 11.
Ten and possibly eleven miners lost their lives today in an explosion and fire which shattered two divisions of the Harwick coal mine.

Members of the yachting department of the New York Athletic Club gathered in the organization's clubhouse at Central Park South and Seventh Avenue last night for their annual election of officers. Dr. L. M. Waugh again was chosen commodore, and L. A. Kissling vice commodore.

Mason Britton, vice chairman of the board of the McGraw-Hill Publishing Company, was yesterday elected chairman of the board of the Advertising Federation of America, succeeding the late E. H. McReynolds, St. Louis, at a meeting of the board at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Mr. Britton, who has long

The Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, in its adoption of a report on "Motion Practice in the Courts" last Thursday had no intention "to reflect upon the integrity of our judges," according to a statement made public yesterday by Winthrop W. Aldrich, president of the organization.

Taking cognizance of a resolution introduced at Albany on Tuesday proposing a special legislative committee investigation of its activities, the State Athletic Commission yeserday responded with a statement which said that it would welcome a general investigation.
Manuel Ledo, a native of Spain, appeared in piano recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. Although hampered somewhat by nervousness, the pianist gave a promising account of himself.
Employing three complete teams, Lawrenceville School routed the Princeton freshman polo team,' 19-7, today in the R. O. T. C. riding hall for its fifth consecutive triumph of the campaign.

SINCE it seems to be ordained by the stars that journalists of this generation shall write books, especially those who have already written one successful book, it is hardly a surprise to learn that Negley Farson is now the author of "Transgressor in the Tropics.'*

After two complainants had withdrawn assault charges against him, Sidney H. Putnam, 58 years old, of 5 Prospect Place, Tudor City, a retired publisher, was discharged yesterday by Magistrate Andrews in the Felony court.

Joseph Schenck 3d of New York won his second-round match in defense of his Lake Worth golf championship at the Palm Beach Golf Club today. He eliminated Ralph Stevens of Evansville, Ind., 2 and 1, and will meet Harold Kaplow of East Orange, N. J., in his semifinal tomorrow.
After two years' investigation of investment trusts, the Securities and Exchange Commission will soon present recommendations to Congress.

Bound and gagged, shot through the temples and their heads battered, the bodies of Mrs. Lenida Waite, 59year-old widow, and a neighborhood friend, Miss Jean Schuelain, 19, were found about 7 o'clock tonight in separate bedrooms on the upper floor of the modest two-story Waite home at 6 Clement Avenue.
The Drew University basketball team defeated Cathedral College, 46-41, tonight for its third victory in five starts. Drew's 21-14 lead at half time was overcome midway

In anticipation of a possible flight of the Chinese Foreign Office and other government departments from Hankow, United States Ambassador Nelson T. Johnson today sent Chinese members of his staff to Chungking to arrange living quarters.

To Dr. Frederick Fuller Russell, brigadier general in the Medical Officers Reserve Corps, United States Army, has been awarded the Buchanan Medal by the Royal Society of London "in recognition of his world-wide services in the development of public health."

At the auction sale last night of the autograph collection of the late Alfred C. Meyer of Chicago at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., Gabriel Wells paid $3,300 for a copy of the thirteenth (emancipation) Amendment to the Constitution.
The purchase by a syndicate of investors of a triangular block in the East Bronx containing seven apartment houses featured realty trading in that borough yesterday.

Students at Seward Park High School, on the lower East Side, took over the school yesterday and expressed, in no uncertain terms, their enjoyment at being teachers, supervisors and administrators-if only for a day.
Changes in the status of minor subsidiaries of the United States

Mrs. Laura Cocheu, wife of Henry B. Cocheu, supervisor of the Long Island District of the State Income Tax Bureau, died yesterday in her home at 395 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn. She was the daughter of Ignatz and Mary Teller Sametz.

The Spanish civil war may not end soon after the battle of Teruel is over-as the American Civil War did not end right after Gettysburg--but whichever side finally withdraws to leave the other in undisputed occupation of the now devastated provincial capital will thereby acknowledge a major military defeat of the importance of Gettysburg.

Mrs. Ernest Frederick Eidlitz gave a tea yesterday at her home, 920 Fifth Avenue, for Mrs. Thomas H. Beardsley, president of the New York Vassar Club, and for the patronesses and committee aides for the Vassar benefit opera performance of "Otello", the afternoon of Jan. 28.

Scoring 20 points in the fourth quarter after being behind, 16-13, at the end of the third, the James Monroe High quintet gained first place in the upper ManhattanBronx Division of the P. S. A. L. by beating Evander Childs, 33-27, on the winners' floor yesterday.
Dr. Alfred Barton Rendle, for many years the keeper of the Department of Botany in the British Museum, died today at Leatherhead at the age of 72.

Mr. and Mrs. David McAlpin Pyle of Hunting Hollow, Far Hills, N. J., are now at Hampshire House, where they will rest for several weeks. Mr. and Mrs. John Barnes Townsend of Radnor, Pa., are at the Madison.

It becomes plainer and plainer that the avowed Surrealists of today can learn a great deal from certain masters who painted hundreds of years ago, knew nothing about Surrealism as an art movement and worked without benefit of Dr. Freud. Indeed, an exhibition such as J. B. Neumann has just opened in his New Art Circle, 509 Madison Avenue, makes most of our contemporary Surrealists look rather pallid.

Turpentine firm, 293c; sales, 32 barrels; receipts, 72 barrels; shipments, 3,422 barrels; stock, 28,750 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 294; receipts, 570; shipments. 2,441; stock, 72,768. Quote: B. D, $4.50; E, $4.90; F, $5.70; G, $5.80; H, $5.90; I, $6; K, $6.20; M, $6.35; N, $6.40; WG, $7.05; WW, X, $7.50.

The directors of the Chase National Bank yesterday elected Charles Cain Jr., Marus E. Conrad and Sheldon R. Green as vice presidents and Edward Bartsch, Frank E. Bremner, John J. Scully and Edwin R. Williams as second vice presidents.

Chairman Smith, Democrat, of South Carolina, said today that the Senate-House Conference Committee trying to agree on a farm bill was "in a mess." He blamed the Department of Agriculture for aggravating discord.

The grim news from the South Pacific in which the navy flashed word to Pan American Airways that it had identified wreckage of the Samoan Clipper, Auckland bound, fourteen miles off Pago Pago, comes with the shock of the well-nigh unbelievable.
Either the 1940 Olympic Games will be held in Japan, or there will be no renewal of the spectacle two years from next Summer, says Avery Brundage, president of the United States Olympic Committee.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has granted applications by the San Francisco Curb Exchange for unlisted trading privileges in the $5par common stock of the Atlas Corporation, now registered on the New York Curb Exchange, and the $1-par, common stock of the Berkey Gay Furniture Company, now registered on the New York Curb and Los Angeles Stock Exchanges and the Chicago Board of Trade.
A scheduled overnight sit-in demonstration of 700 Philadelphia employes of the State Department of Public Assistance was averted today by Governor Earle.

The first session of Russia's "Red Parliament," the Supreme Soviet created under the new Constitution, opened today in the Kremlin Great Palace in the mixture of official solemnity and holiday jocularity with which the Soviet regime often invests its formal occasions.

On the Cunard White Star liner Antonia, sailing today for Plymouth and London, will be Stanley Wilson, Miss Isabelle Patrick, Mrs. Irene Brown, K. D. Lane, Miss Georgina Cope Cooley and Miss Marguerite Eckers.
Metropolitan milk distributors and producers announced tonight that they had drawn up a new and lower price schedule to be paid producers for milk sold in the New York City market.

A bill to amend the vehicle and traffic law to eliminate provisions requiring all automobile license plates to carry World's Fair advertisement during 1939 was introduced today by Assemblyman-Edward S. Moran Jr., Democrat, from Brooklyn.
Exeter's hockey team won from the Northeastern freshmen, 7 to 2, today. The Exonians took the lead when James Sloane caged the puck in the first period, but Urbank soon evened the count.

The Bituminous Coal Commission today issued an order designed to prevent coal operators from impounding moneys derived from sales of coal with the purpose of testing the legality of the Bituminous Coal Act before its final distribution.
Fred Andrew Sawyer, former president of the Citizens National Bank of Waverly, died suddenly of a heart attack at his home here today at the age of 77.

The moderate advance in commodity prices in recent weeks has resulted in a little more confidence as to the future trend. The belief of many purchasing agents in industry is that prices of most commodities have touched bottom for the time being, and they are beginning to replenish depleted inventories.

It was revealed here today that China has entirely defaulted on the final payment of the TsingtaoTsinan railway, the fifteen-year mortgage which the Japanese Government holds having expired late last year.

Grover A. Whalen, president of th World's Fair Corporation, announced yesterday the refusal of the fair to permit an anti-Nazi organization to take space for a "chamber of horrors" exhibit in opposition to the exhibit of Nazi Germany.
The Appellate Division in Brooklyn disbarred yesterday William C. Rindone, attorney, of 1,774 Seventyfourth Street, Brooklyn, on charges brought by the Brooklyn Bar

Japanese fishermen are to be barred from Panaman waters by a decree effective Feb. 1, signed by President J. D. Arosemena and all members of the Cabinet, reserving fishing grounds to Panamans. The decree provides penalties of fines of $1,000 to $1,500 and confiscation of ships and equipment.

Representatives of intercoastal and domestic shipping lines, appearing today before the House Merchant Marine Committee, urged passage of an amendment to the Merchant Marine Act to give the Maritime Commission broad powers over the fixing of rates.

Was he fouled or was he knocked out? Some 12,500 fight fans left Madison Square Garden last night asking this question after Henry Armstrong, the fighting flash from the Pacific Coast who holds the world's featherweight crown, had gained credit for a knockout over Enrico Venturi, agile Italian, in the sixth round of what was to have been the ten-round feature in the Eighth Avenue arena.

So far as New York State is concerned, the recent marriage of Prince Guido Pignatelli and Mrs. Henrietta Hartford, widow of the former head of the Atlantic and Pacific chain stores, is invalid, Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag ruled yesterday.
The Internal Revenue Bureau ruled today that benefits paid by a union to its members while they were on strike were not subject to social security taxes.

John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, and David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, third largest C. I. 0. affiliate, exchanged words yesterday over Mr. Dubinsky's charge that the C. I. O. was responsible for the collapse of peace negotiations with the American Federation of Labor.

Legislation for the abolishment of the office of Mayor in Rochester's city government was approved by the City Council last night and is expected to be submitted to the Legislature for approval this week.

The election of Patrolman Joseph J. Burkard as president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association of the New York City Police Department leaves the faction headed by Joseph P. Moran, executive secretary, in control of the organization.
Governor Hoffman developed a blister on the little finger of his right hand today when he shook hands with 2,662 persons at a farewell reception ir the Executive offices at the State House.

Defiance of a subpoena of the National Labor Relations Board and the charge that the board was partisan to the C. I. O. because of its reported contribution of $500,000 to the 1936 Democratic campaign fund marked the NLRB hearing in the Berkshire Knitting Mills case here today.
The Westchester Rangers triumphed in a metropolitan hockey league contest tonight, defeating the Manhattan Arrows, 5 to 3, in an overtime battle at the New Imperial Ice Rink.

Samuel H. Ditchett, former editor of The Dry Goods Economist and an authority on the merchandising problems of that industry, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home in the Stratford Arms Hotel, 115 West Seventieth Street. He was 82 years old.

The Jewish Conciliation Court of America, Inc., tried and handed down decisions in 118 cases in 1937, according to a report of the executive secretary, Louis Richman, presented yesterday at the seventh annual meeting in Federation Building, 71 West Forty-seventh Street.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 31,000, including 8,000 directs. Weights 210 pounds down were steady to 10c lower than Tuesday's average; others unevenly 10c-25c off, weighty butchers showing the most decline. Bulk 150-220 pounds. $8.25-S8.60; short load, $8.65; 230260 pounds. $7.65-$8.10; 270-300 pounds, $7.15-$7.50. Packing sows steady to 10c lower; bulk, $6.40-$6.75. Shippers, 2,000; estimated hold-over, 4,000.

The high hopes that St. John's holds for the metropolitan intercollegiate basketball championship rocketed a bit farther skyward last night as the Redmen decisively vanquished Fordham, 46 to 33, in the Ram gymnasium before a gathering of 2,500.
Admiral Sir Nelson Ommanney, member of a naval family which has supplied the British fleet with five admirals, died today in Parkstone, Dorset, at the age of 83.

A staff double the size of the present personnel assigned to ungraded classes in the public schools is needed to care for all the children requiring special training, Miss Elizabeth A. Walsh, director of the Bureau for Children With Retarded Mental Development, said yesterday.

The incoming comedy formerly called "The Housemaster" will be offered here as "Bachelor Born" on Monday night, Jan. 24. The producer is Milton Shubert, in association with Ruth Selwyn, and the house is the Broadhurst.

Frank E. Taplin, president of the Pittsburgh West Virginia Railway, members of his family, his friends and associates realized a profit of nearly $13,000,000 when they sold control to the Pennroad Corporation for $37,323,000 in 1929, according to the estimate of the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce.

VATICAN CITY, Jan. 12--Pope Pius today expressed his high approval of Premier Benito Mussolini and his deepest disapproval of Chancellor Adolf Hitler in a long address delivered to sixty-two Bishops and more than 2,000 priests from all parts of Italy who last Sunday received from Mussolini money awards for their contribution to the battle to make Italy independent of wheat imports.

Following eight successive days of improvement prices on the Cotton Exchange eased yesterday to end with losses of 4 to 8 points. In contrast with a lower range of quotations in both Liverpool and Alexandria, the Bombay market opened at the highest marks of the season.
Ghent, "the city of flowers, of fine linen, of wars, and wheat coming up still canals in great barges," is the scene of May Sarton's forthcoming novel, "The Single Hound" (Houghton Mifflin).

Edward J. Finley, 51 years old, of 230 East Forty-eighth Street, an artist, who was the first recipient of a summons for violation of the new rules against parking in the crosstown "express" streets in the midtown zone, paid a $2 fine by proxy in Traffic Court yesterday.
Patrolman Harry Nesbitt, honor member of the Garden City Police Department, died of a heart attack last night in his home here. He was 59 years old.
The Baltimore Orioles of the Eastern Amateur Ice Hockey League blanked the Bronx Tigers, 6-0, tonight. Baltimore out-skated and outpassed the Bronx team, scoring

Five clubs will compete for the championship of the Metropolitan Chess League this season. They will play in Division A with sixteen on a side. Six entries were received for Division B at a meeting held at the Marshall Chess Club yesterday.
Following up the meeting with five industrialists yesterday, President Roosevelt has invited forty-six other business leaders to confer with him a week from today.

After twenty-four years, Senator McAdoo of California, President Wilson's son-in-law and Secretary of the Treasury, parted company today with one of the war time President's policies, the fight over which was one of the most dramatic chapters in the Wilson administration's history.

The Spanish Government has offered to make sufficient dollar exchange available to its citizens to enable them to pay in full commercial debts of $500 or less owing American exporters and to pay 10 per cent on claims above the $500 level; Miles M. Sherover, president of the Hanover Sales Corporation, official trading agency for the Loyalist Government, said last night.

Brokers and agents reported yesterday the rental of entire floors in the midtown district to new tenants. Wearing apparel, textile and millinery concerns formed the bulk of the business organizations listed.

A public hearing on revision of the State's insurance laws in regard to fire, marine, title, mortgage indemnity and mortgage debenture companies will be held next Thursday and Jan. 21 by the Legislative Committee on Revision of the Insurance Law at the National Board of Fire Underwriters Building, 85 John Street.
The German secret political police continue to persecute the Confessional Synods and the Protestant Church, despite the Christmas release of a great majority of imprisoned pastors.

Charles H. Mayo Jr., former Long Island titleholder, advanced to the semi-finals of the annual midwinter amateur golf championship when he won his second-round match over the Miami Country Club course today.
Six peasants were killed, twelve seriously wounded and fifty slightly wounded today as a result of a long feud between Serbian and Mohammedan peasants in the Bosnian town of Omarsika.

With a strike threatening in the textile industry in the north because employers will not accept an arbitration decision granting a 5 1/2 per cent wage increase and the employers' confederation absent from the labor conference he had summoned for

Police Commissioner Valentine continued yesterday his efforts to improve enforcement of the morals laws by assigning ten sergeants eligible to promotion to lieutenant to assist twenty-five picked lieutenants in supervising the work of plainclothes patrols.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12--A new attempt to obtain House approval for legislation regulating minimum wages and maximum hours of work will be made at this session- of Congress, the Labor Committee decided today.

Browning School, at 50 East Sixtysecond Street, founded by the late John F. Browning, where sons of many of New York s prominent families have received their primary education, celebrated last night its fiftieth anniversary at a dinner in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Henry Hubbard Allen of 580 Park Avenue and Huntington, L. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Hubbard Allen, to Richard Hull Fay of Westport, Conn., son of Mrs. Peterson Tompkins of Westport and of Malcolm N. Fay of New York.
Lampeao, bad man of the Northeastern Brazilian hinterland, who was feared by all for his ruthlessness, has died in bed of tuberculosis in the interior of the State of Sergipe.

Announcement of the purchase of the old Vitagraph studio from Warner Brothers and the formation of Standard Pictures Corporation to produce sixteen features a year, budgeted at from $60,000 to $75,000 each, was made today by Charles B. Taylor. B. W. Richards,
Chance Ray, 6-year-old gelded son of Chance Play, turned in his first victory of the Fair Grounds meeting today when he defeated five other players in the mile and 70yard feature.

Although declining to take a position on the advisability or feasibility of wage and hour legislation, the Trade and Commerce Bar Association recommended yesterday that if such legislation is passed it should be administered either by an independent board or by the Federal Trade Commission with added personnel.

Miss Ethel Miller of Apawamis, in a match full of thrills and excitement, defeated Miss Denise O'Brien of the Bronxville Field Club in five games, 15-8, 13-16, 11-15, 15-10, 18-15, to reach the final of the annual women's metropolitan Class B squash racquets championship at the Heights Casino in Brooklyn yesterday.

R. K. Ferguson, president of the St. Regis Paper Company, told stockholders yesterday at their annual meeting in Watertown, N. Y., that the Treasury Department's deficiency tax claim of $3,600,000 in connection with the exchange of the company's holdings of stock in the Niagara Hudson Power Company for stock in the United Corporation in 1931 had been settled for $941,067 with interest.
Edwin C. Musick, captain of the ill-fated Samoan Clipper of Pan American Airways, ended a perfect record of twenty-five years of flying with his first crash.

Former President Hoover will address by radio from California the seventeenth annual luncheon of the Women's National Republican Club at the Hotel Astor on Saturday, Mrs. William Henry Hays, chairman of the luncheon committee, announced yesterday.

A Federal inspector testified in Magistrate A. D. Brandon's court that Pittsburgh high school students were using a narcotic, "worse than marihuana or morphine," that shows no ill effects until the heart and kidneys collapse.

Mayor Frank Hague urged public officials in other cities throughout the country to join his fight against Communism in the C. I. O. in an address tonight at the fiftieth anniversary dinner of the Jersey City Chamber of Commerce.

Andover Academy opened its basketball season today with a 37-33 victory over Tilton Academy. Andover led from the start except for a Tilton surge in the third period which enabled the visitors to end the quarter with a 28-26 lead.

Maintaining its excellent approach to the basket and improving greatly in shooting over its showing against Duke in the opening game, the Naval Academy five defeated the University of Virginia by 36 to 14 today.

The marriage of Miss Virginia Lee Flanders, daughter of Mrs. Annis Chittenden Flanders of 818 Madison Avenue, and of the late Carl S. Flanders, to Walter S. Gurnee took place yesterday afternoon in the chantry of St. Thomas Church. The Rev. Dr. Roelif H.

Colonel Fritz Loeb, director of the raw-material section of the Four-Year Plan, announced to an audience of functionaries and Four-Year-Plan specialists today that Germany was wholly capable of supplying her own gasoline, fuel oil and lubricants.

The program for the Don Marquis memorial entertainment on Jan. 23 at the Ambassador Theatre was announced yesterday to include reminiscences of the late author by Christopher Morley. and Dr. Harry March;. Otis Skinner, Will Geer,

The Bank of Canada reported today a gain of $4,000,000 in deposits of chartered banks in the week ended yesterday and an advance of $5,000,000 to the Dominion Government, the first in several months. Officials said the advance to the government had little significance and was for short duration.

Three additions to the collection of paintings at the Metropolitan Museum of Art will go on view today. Two of them, "Madonna and Child with Saints Philip and Agnes," signed by Donato Bernardo di Giovannl Bragadin, and "Saint Peter Martyr Healing the Leg of a Boy," by Antonio Vivarini, are the gift of the Samuel H. Kress Foundation.

Mrs. Hans George Spitzer, the former Princess Dolly Obolensky, who is chairman of the patronesses, and Miss Barbara Hill, who is co-chairman of the junior committee, are among those who will give parties tonight at the tenth annual Russian Students' Ball in the grand ballroom of the Plaza.

Georges Enesco began his second week as guest conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra with two works new to the ensemble's repertoire, each at least twenty-five years old. The first was "Suite Frangaise" in D by RogerDucasse and the other, "Jeux," by Debussy.

United Air Lines flew a total of 97,578,794 revenue passenger miles and 16,260,000 miles in 1937, the equivalent of 6,500 coast-to-coast trips, W. A. Patterson, president, announced yesterday. The total number of passengers transported during the year was 200,000.

Headed by Harry F. Wolf, the naional champion from the Montlair A. C., seven seeded players gained the quarter-final round of the Clyde Martin Memorial squash tennis tournament at the Yale Club last night.

Member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City have been heavy buyers of securities in the past week, it became apparent yesterday when the condition statement of these institutions as of Wednesday night showed a rise of $80,000,000 in investments, of which $55,000,000 consisted of securities other than government securities.

Mrs. Laura Laurenson Byrne, who had been active in the woman's suffrage movement, died yesterday at the Elizabeth General Hospital at the age of 82. Mrs. Byrne was a descendent of the first Charles Carroll of Colonial Maryland, who was appointed Attorney General by Lord Baltimore in 1688.

A delegation of more than a hundred baseball men, headed by President Will Harridge, attended the preview of the American League's latest sound motion picture, "Batter Up," at the Hotel WaldorfAstoria yesterday and unanmiously voted it the most instructive and entertaining work of its kind.

Additions to the tenant rosters of buildings in the vicinity of Union and Washington Squares were among the commercial rentals listed yesterday. United States Rubber Products, Inc., was the lessee of an entire floor in 147-53 Waverly Place, for use as a bottling plant and for testing essential oils and aromatics. The Cross Brown Company was the broker.

BERSOHN, FANNY (May 12, 1936). Estate, more than $10,000. To Celia Bersohn, daughter, 302 W. 12th St., $1,500, plus income on $6,500 until Jan. 5, 1937, and income on $13,000 thereafter; estate of Ethel Lubinsky, daughter, income of $6,500 from decedent's death until Jan. 5, 1937; Robert Bersohn, 302 W. 12th St., and A. P. Bersohn, executor, 670 West End Ave., brothers, contingent remainders in S13.000.

Stocks moved cautiously on news of collapse of French franc and closed moderately lower; turnover, 971,570 shares. United States Government issues higher, other bonds steady and mixed; transactions, $6,635,700.

A letter by George Washington written during the American Revolution was bought by Walter M. Hill for $3,000 last night at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc,, at the auction of the collection of historical and literary autographs formed by the late Alfred C. Mayer of Chicago.

Sheer fantasy, delightful, gay and altogether captivating, touched the screen yesterday when Walt Disney's long-awaited feature-length cartoon of the Grimm fairy tale, "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs," had its local premiere at the Radio City Music Hall.
Following is the text of the address made by William E. Dodd, former Ambassador to Germany, at the testimonial dinner given to him at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel:

Three more nations signed up yesterday for participation in the New' York World's Fair of 1939. The total is now sixty-two nations and the League of Nations, according to Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation.

F. Barton's Calculator taking command in the closing strides, wound up on top in a photo finish at the end of the six-furlong feature at the Fair Grounds today. It was his first victory in seven starts over the local course.

Eugene Rosedale, the elderly man who walked into the NEW YORK TIMES office on Tuesday to report a "national loss," was happy again yesterday. He disclosed that the petition to George III, dated 1765, which he lost in the subway on Monday, had been restored to his employer, Harry Stone, a bookseller,

Foolish Bear, 84 years old, and Drags Wolf, 75, delegates from the Water Buster clan of the Gros Ventre Indians of North Dakota, arrived in this city last night to receive the Sacred Bundle, prized relic of the tribe, at ceremonies today at the Heye Foundation of the Museum of the American Indian.

1st Ave, 1,334, 27x85; Bertha Rosen to Corn Exchange Bank and Trust Co, as trustee; Henry Schaefer, p m due and interest as per bond: $10,000. 53d St. 52 E, 16x100.5; Manha Realty Corp (H. William Herkstroter, president), to Thos. C. Wayland, 110 E 73d St. p m, prior mtg $35,000, 5 yrs, 4%; $3,000.

For the first time since Sept. 21, last, The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices rose in the week ended on Wednesday, being 84.9, contrasted with 84.7 the week before and 92.7 a year ago. Led by the metals, prices advanced on a wide front.
Mrs. Leonore Miller Wickes, former president for fifteen years of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union of Kings County, died yesterday at her home in Maple Road here. Her age was 65.

The movement for peace between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization gained momentum yesterday when Charles P. Howard, president of the International Typographical Union and secretary of the C. I. O., declared that the members of the I. T. U. favored the reestablishment of unity in the labor movement.

A brilliant new champion was crowned in the annual women's metropolitan Class B squash racquets championship yesterday when Miss Ethel Miller of Apawamis smashed her way to a great fourgame victory over Miss Elinor Best of Bronxville at the Heights Casino. The score was 4-15, 15-11,
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

Featured by traditional ceremonials of the old Russian New Year, a special entertainment was given last night in La Maisonette Russe of the St. Regis for the benefit of the Russian Children's Welfare Association.

Mr. and Mrs. Duane L. Robinson of Watertown have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss I Lois C. Robinson, to Frederick Henry Blake Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick H. Blake of Montclair. N. J.

The Lyrie Art Society at a final lunchon meeting yesterday at the Hotel Plaza voted to disband the fifteen-year-old organization and to use its funds to endew a bed at the Hospital for the Ruptured and cripled.

A legislative investigation of all phases of the Seabury-Berle transit unification plan will be asked in a resolution to be introduced in the Assembly Monday night by Edward S. Moran Jr., Democrat, of Kings. He made a similar move last year, but it failed of passage.

The arrival here of $706,000 gold from India was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The bank reported no exports and no engagements of gold abroad. In London the price of gold again declined, falling to the equivalent of $34.8784 an ounce, compared with $34.8993 on Wednesday.
During the week ended Jan. 12, member bank reserve balances increased $122,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from decreases of $115,000,000 in money in circulation,

The metropolitan racing season will open at the Jamaica course of the Metropolitan Jockey Club April 15 and close at Empire City Oct. 29 for a total of 170 racing days this year. This schedule. which calls for one day less than in 1937,
John S. Harrison of the Squash Club defeated a clubmate. Edward R. Greeff in the final of the Union League Club's Class B squash racquets tournament yesterday. Harrison won in a long five-game match.

In the Supreme Court of the United States today, Thomas W. Palmer and James V. Hayes, both of New York City, were admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had: 301-Guaranty Trust Company of New York, executor, etc., cetr., v. Commissioner of Internal Revenue. Argument continued for both.

Princeton University's "Department of Zoology" received today a request by telegraph for six crickets that chirp in the key of G, these musical mites being needed for what apparently is intended as a Hollywood epic in sound-recording.

A group of leaders of industry, labor and finance has been conferring for some time, with the knowledge of President Roosevelt and at the instance of A. A. Berle Jr., and Rexford G. Tugwell, with a view to reaching an understanding on some of the chief problems confronting the nation.

Net income of the Erie Railroad System for the first eleven months of 1937 amounted o $610,311 after taxes and charges, equal to $1.27 a share on 479,044 shares of 4 per cent non-cumulative first preferred stock. This is compared to $2,017,

The Ford Motor Company, which had rejected two previous peace proposals, was asked today to consider a third plan for settlement of a strike called by the United Automobile Workers of America at its St. Louis assembly plant.

The largest personal contribution ever made in this country for traffic safety work was announced yesterday when the National Safety Council made public a $25,000 contribution to the Automotive Safety Foundation by Alfred P. Sloan, chairman of the board of the General Motors Corporation.

Lwow University, the last to resist the antl-Semitic students' "ghetto" demands, reopened today, after nearly two months, with separate benches allotted to Jews. Professor Kulczynski, the university's president, resigned the day before the ghetto decree was issued.

If most politics is queer, New Jersey politics is queerer. Any day you drop in there you will find the assertion verified. Governor Hoffman, a figure of fun in the hall of curiosities, singing his swan song recites his "record of achievements" and warmly praises Senator Harry Moore, who will succeed him next week. Mr. Loizeaux,

The government continued today to enforce its anti-Semitic measures. Minister of Public Works Alexander Cuza Jr. issued an order that all Jewish doctors employed by sickness insurance companies must immediately be replaced by doctors of the Rumanian race.

Turpentine firm. 30c: sales. 47 barrels; receipts. 53 barrels; shipments, 41 barrels; stock, 28,762 barrels. Resin firm: sales. 90: receipts, 339; shipments, 97; stock, 73,010. Quote-B, D. $4.50; E, $5; F, $5.80; G, $5.85; H, $5.95; I, $6.10; K, $6.20; M, S6.35; N, $6.50; WG, $7.25: WW and X, $7.70.

Engineering construction awards for the current week, with a total of $42,590,000, represent a drop of 3 per cent from the $43,889,000 recorded in the same week of last year, according to The Engineering News-Record.

Steamship lines carrying freight between European ports and New York are divided over a policy of enforcing the new Federal regulation limiting the period of free storage on New York piers to ten days, it was learned yesterday.

Walter Mills Bennet, retired banker, died today after a long illness. His age was 76. Mr. Bennet was former vice president of the Bank of America of New York and vice president of the Consolidated Copper Mines Company.

The modernists' idea of the Creation was upheld emphatically tonight in a 242page report on "Doctrine in the Church of England," issued after more than fourteen years of study by a commission under the chairmanship of the Archbishop of York.

There has been an increase in the number of Britons entitled to call themselves "millionaires." According to statistics issued today, there are 334 persons with annual incomes exceeding ??50,000--which is held to be the minimum figure for millionaires here-as compared to 296 last year.
The Midston House Squash Club continued to set the pace in Group I of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association by sweeping its match with the New York A. C., 5-0, on he Winged Foot courts yesterday.
Horace K. Roberson, Director of Public Safety here, took issue tonight with Mayor Hague's stand on the C.I.O., the first official of Hudson County to do so.
Clear indication that the flying boat Samoan Clipper and her crew of seven were destroyed in a fire and explosion was brought to Pago Pago today by the navy minesweeper Avocet.

This city is within six-tenths of 1 per cent of the statutory debt limit, Raymond Greer, City Controller, told 450 school teachers tonight in urging them to sign waivers which would continue in effect the present 10 per cent pay cut for city employes.

An open breach in the leadership of the Committee for Industrial Organization here led tonight to the resignation of William M. Leader as chairman of the Philadelphia C. I. O. Council. A few moments later, however, Mr. Leader, who is assistant director of welfare of Philadelphia, received a vote of confidence and reconsidered his resignation.

The world-famous Netherlands airplane designer and yachtsman, Anthony Fokker, added materially to the 1938 optimism in pleasure boating yesterday at the National Motor Boat Show in Grand Central Palace.
Opposition to some of the proposed amendments to the Merchant Marine Act of 1936 wan voiced today at hearings before the House Merchant Marine Committee.

Ruda Firkusny, 25-year-old Czech pianist, successfully held the attention of the audience which attended his New York debut recital given in Town Hall yesterday afternoon. This he accomplished through a facile, often glamorous, technique and pleasing quality of tone, rather than by means of pronounced gifts as interpreter.

Amazed Senators heard today that a clever clerk in the Interior Deapartment who set up -a "dummy" CCC camp defrauded the government out of about $84,000 through voucher forgeries, and escaped detection for almost four years.

Lumber production Increased sharply last week and the index advanced to 48.9, with the seasonal factor checking the extent of the rise. This compares with 48.6 for the previous week and 68.2 for the week ended Jan. 9, 1937.

Reductions of 2 to 6 cents in coarse denier viscose process rayon weaving yarns were announced last night by the E. I. du Pont de Nemours Company's rayon department, and it was believed competing producers would make similar reductions in the next few days.

Dr. Ulysses P. Hedrick, who retires tomorrow as director of the State Agricultural Experiment Station in Geneva, was elected honorary president of the State Horticultural Society today. The honor came as a surprise to Dr. Hedrick, who had been asked to be in the assembly hall at Edgerton Park at 2 o'clock to "answer some questions."

Harry A. Gretton, supervisor of vocal music in the West Orange public schools, died here tonight in his home. He was 52 years old. Mr. Gretton, born in Brockport, N. Y., studied at the Ithaca Conservatory of Music and Columbia University.

Donna Fox of the Bronx, whose injury in 1936 prevented him from serving as captain of the No. 1 four-man bobsled team representing the United States in the Winter Olympics of that year at GarmischPartenkirchen, will sail for Germany on the Europa of the North German Lloyd line tonight on a dual mission.
Holding a 15-8 advantage at the intermission, the Abraham Lincoln High quintet downed the Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute freshmen, 24 to 16, on the winners' court yesterday.

The basketball teams of Long Island University and Manhattan College will strive to uphold the prestige of the metropolitan court realm tonight when the sixth doubleheader of the season at Madison Square Garden brings together the Blackbirds and De Paul in the first game and the Jaspers and Temple in the other.

The second Junior League dinner dance for this season will take place next Thursday at the clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street. Miss Frances Rousmaniere heads the dance committee, which includes Mrs. E. Bonner Bowring, Mrs.

The fifth anniversary of Hitler's ascension to power in Germany was made the occasion of an anti-Nazi meeting last night in the Manhattan Opera House, Thirty-fourth Street and Eighth Avenue, under the auspices of the Joint Boycott Council of the American Jewish Congress and the Jewish Labor Committee.
Arrangements have been made for the sale of a New York Curb Exchange membership at $17,500, an increase of $500 over the last previous sale.

Considering the obvious indebtedness of Messrs. Ickes and Jackson to "America's 60 Families," by Ferdinand Lundberg, it is instructive to read the inquiry into the accuracy of that book published in the current issue of The Annalist. The article confines itself to various statements in the volume that can be checked by reference to public records or official figures.

Mrs. E. J. Selby Tanner of Wilton, Conn., and her daughter, Miss M. Selby Tanner, gave a dinner dance last night in the Crystal Garden of the Ritz-Carlton for Miss Silvia Gould, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kingdon Gould, and Charles Dabney Thomson, whose marriage will take place this afternoon at the home of her parents.
Frank B. Hughes, electrical contracting engineer who directed installation of electricity when the Capitol was rebuilt after the 1911 fire, died today on his fiftieth birthday.

Movementm of livestock on the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 30,000, including 8,500 directs. Weights downward from 210 pounds 10-15 cents lower than Wednesday's average, others 15-25 cents off; bulk 150-210 pounds, $8.15-$8.50; top, $8.50; 220-260 pounds, $7.50-$8.15; 270-325 pounds, $7-57.40; packing sows, 10-15 cents lower; bulk. $6.25$6.40; lightweights. $6.50-$6.60; shippers, 2,000; estimated holdover, 5,000.

The metropolitan milk distributors ratified here yesterday the new and lower price schedule to be paid producers for milk sold in this area, which was adopted in Syracuse Wednesday at a conference of representatives of distributors and producers.
Sonja Henie stood beneath the picture of Norway's King on the only piece of Norwegian territory in the United States to receive a decoration from her sovereign today.

Day Court Builders, Inc., a client of David Jaret Company, brokers, bought the three-story dwelling at 1,763 Union Street, Brooklyn, for cash above a first mortgage from Harry Marcus. The house accommodates two families, and stands on a plot 20 by 100 feet.

There was one day early in The the week when the good peoWild pie of New York must have Waves wondered whether their new City Council was elected by proportional representation or by proportional microphonization.

The philosophy and achievements of Benjamin Franklin were reviewed yesterday by A. E. Giegengack, Public Printer of the United States, at a luncheon to honor the memory of Franklin at the Advertising Club.

War Admiral, the 1937 triple crown winner and number one horse in American racing, was run a handy half-mile over the Hialeah Park course today in 0:48 3-5. This was the fastest the colt has been sent thus far in a careful preparation Trainer George Conway has set for the Riddle champion to make his appearance in the $50,000 Widener Challenge Cup here on March 5.

Announcement of another issue in the current series of ninety-one-day bills was made today by the Secretary of the Treasury. Tenders for bills in the approximate amount of $50,000,000 will be received by. Federal Reserve Banks or their branches up to 2 P. M., Eastern standard time, Monday.

A comprehensive schedule of snow trains has been arranged to transport hundreds of Winter sports fans to popular skiing rendezvous this week-end, as favorable snow conditions resulted in a wide demand for accommodations yesterday. Last week only two of the many trains carded left for the snowlands.

The Hotel, Restaurant and Cafeteria Employes Organization Committee, an American Federation of Labor affiliate, was rejected as the collective-bargaining agent of the employes of Shanty Shops, Inc., by a vote of 280 to 64 in an election conducted by the State Labor Relations Board, it was announced yesterday.

The class of January, 1938, at Hunter College has selected Gertrude Goller, former member of the executive board of the Student Council, as the best executive, the most respected and the senior who did most for the college.

State Department, evidently irritated at the long delay of the Soviet authorities in giving news of the whereabouts of Mrs. Ruth Marie Rubens, alias Mrs. Donald L. Robinson, who disappeared in Moscow several weeks ago, pressed the Russian Foreign Office again today for information.

Net operating earnings of the Bankers Trust Company in 1937 were $7,369,114, compared with $7,326,847 in 1936, S. Sloan Colt, president, informed shareholders of the bank at their annual meeting held at noon yesterday.

Miss. last A Nancy Benedict Harrison, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Jones Harrison of this city, has chosen the afternoon of Feb. 12 for her marriage to Eugene Franklin O'Connor 3d, son of Judge and Mrs. Eugene F. O'Connor Jr. of Garden City, L. I.

Former Kaiser Wilhelm has expressed a wish to attend the wedding of his favorite grandson, Prince Ludwig Ferdinand of Prussia, whose betrothal to Grandduchess Kira of Russia was announced here a fortnight ago.
Attorney General Cummings has goten around to suggest an amendment ?? the Corrupt Practices Act which wouldd seemingly make it illegal for a National political party to repair its

Several luncheon parties will be given today in the foyer restaurant of the Metropolitan Opera House preceding the benefit matinee of "Die Meistersinger." Patients in twenty-seven municipal hospitals and homes, who will be provided with music, occupational therapy and other services through the New York City Visiting Committee and the Hospital Music Committee of the State Charities Aid Association, will be beneficiaries.
Frank Lynch, veteran newspaper man and member of the editorial staff of The Rochester Democrat and Chronicle, died here today after several weeks' illness. His age was 58.

Former United States Senator and Mrs. Hamilton F. Kean of Green Lane Farm here and 25 East Thirtyseventh Street, New York, observed their fiftieth wedding anniversary yesterday with a party at their New York residence.
The Insurgent cruisers Canarias and Baleares were seen to enter Ceuta from the west this evening, while the cruiser Almirante Cervera arrived at Algeciras from the same direction.

Trading was fairly active to slow in local markets yesterday. Steer hinds and ribs and some steer cuts were stronger; veal and calf were weak, lamb steady, fresh pork slightly uneven. Kosher business was confined largely to lamb at lower prices, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Miss Martha Catherine McGowin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Willis Marion McGowin of Chapman, near here, was married tonight at the home of her parents to Assemblyman MacNeil Mitchell, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Henry Mitchell of New York and Salisbury, Conn. The Rev. Arnold Simonson of Brewton performed the ceremony.

The French franc, hammered by a new and severe flight of capital, yesterday broke away from its official control and fell to 3.23 cents, a loss of more than 15 points from its quotation of the previous day. But later it recovered to 3.283/4 cents to show a net loss of 9?? points.

An exposure of the complicated steps taken by Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer to establish and control a brewery in Yonkers used first for illegal and later for legal brewing, while hiding his identity behind other men's names, was contained in a law suit filed here by Schultz's widow, Mrs. Frances Flegenheimer, and revealed today.
Anthony J. Siracusa Jr., City Solicitor of Atlantic City and former Speaker of the New Jersey Assembly, died of leukemia today at Jefferson Hospital here. He was 43 years old.
Retaliating somewhat for two earlier defeats this season, a women's'metropolitan squash racquets team defeated a men's side, 3 to 2, at the Junior League courts yesterday.
