Sir Frederick Whyte, formerly president of the Indian Legislative Assembly and later political adviser to the National Government of China, has been appointed director general of the English-Speaking Union of the British Empire.

Establishment of the Virginia Randolph Fund, said to be "the first permanent endowment fund of a general nature ever created to carry the name of a member of the Negro race," toward which Southern Negroes already have contributed more than $9,000, was announced here last night at the annual meeting of the Southern Education Foundation.

Unrest among the Insurgent forces in neighboring towns is evinced by the desertion of scores of troops and carabineers daily. It is reported that about fifty artillerymen attached to the Punta Carnero and Tarifa batteries disappeared Tuesday night after having bribed coastal watchmen, who escaped with them.
Mrs. Ellen W. Cheney Lambert, wife of Dr. Alexander Lambert, New York physician, died of a heart attack yesterday at her home, 43 East Seventy-second Street, at the age of 74.
Half cakes and souffles, similar to the sweets consumed in Germany, will no longer be made with hens eggs but with "viking eggs," which are made from fish.

Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's armies fighting in Shantung Province were reported today to have killed 2,000 Japanese in desperate but unsuccessful resistance at Tsining, Southwestern Shantung Province.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Suzanne Trott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. J. Howard Trott of Quickswood, Pitts Bay,Bermuda, to John Webber Hornburg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Hornburg of Minnetonka Beach, Minn.
The Federal Government's handling of the crime situation in Washington was assailed today by Senator McKellar of Tennessee in opposing the Wagner-Van Nuys Anti-Lynching Bill.

The New York Athletic Club skaters scored a 7-2 success over the Long Island Falcons in a New York Amateur Hockey Association game at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. The victory enabled the Winged Footers to remain undefeated and go into a tie for first place with the St. Nicholas Hockey Club.

John 19 W. Hanes of New York, who, while a partner of Charles D. Barney Co., was appointed a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission for the term ending on June 5, 1940, to succeed J. D. Ross, will begin his duties as a member of the commission tomorrow, it was stated today at the SEC.

Plans were announced here today by Julius Vinik of Jersey City, president of the Suburban Apartment Corporation, owner and builder of an eighteen dwelling unit nearing completion in Clinton Place, for acquiring the property at West Jersey Street and DeHart Place as a site for three modern apartment buildings.

In the presence of a gathering of fanciers that crowded the offices of the American Kennel Club yesterday afternoon, Mrs. Milton S. Erlanger of New York City and Elberon, N. J., received a check for $250 and a framed certificate. This engraved paper recounted that Mrs. Erlanger's black standard poodle,

During intimate Presidential councils, in which the make-up of the Democratic party after 1940 has been the subject of discussion, the Southern wing has often been attacked for "reactionary" tendencies.

Delmar G. Roos has been appointed vice president and chief engineer of Willys-Overland Motors, Inc. The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company has been appointed transfer agent for 341,911 shares ot $1 par common stock and option warrants of the Permutit company.

Members of the staff of the Jones Children's Center of the Children's Aid Society at 405 East Seventythird Street will attend a meeting at the branch today at which the methods and facilities now available for the control of syphilis will be outlined by Dr. Daniel F. Crowley of the office of Health Commissioner John L. Rice.

A seriou clash between the Austrian official youth organization and the illegal Nazis occurred near Vienna's western railway station tonight when forty Italian Fascist students were welcomed by members of the Fatherland Front on their arrival as guests of the government.

Botany Consolidated Mills, Inc., issues have been suspended from dealings on the New York Stock Exchange. They were Class A stock, $50 par value; ten-year 6 1/2 per cent sinking fund gold bonds due in 1934 and certificates of deposit for the bonds.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Thomas Jefferson has frequently been mentioned with admiration by New Dealers, although I believe never accurately or fully quoted; and, indeed, I have been unable to find in his writings a quotation in favor of their policies. Recently the President mentioned him as waging battles for those things permanently good-battles for the basic morals of democracy.

Miss Maribel Vinson, former women's national amateur figureskating champion, returned to this city yesterday from Ontario and announced that her "Gay Blades" ice-skating troupe closed its season there last Saturday.

The Rev. Frederick Cecil Powell of the Episcopal Church of St. John the Evangelist in Bowdoin Street, West End, for many years head of the Cowley Fathers in the United States, and one of the most widely known clergymen in the State,

The registration parade was resumed yesterday when the $715,000,000 Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation announced it had officially conformed with the provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 by registering with the Securities and Exchange Commission as a public utility holding company.

No one has ever bowled a book quite like this one* down what Mr. Tennyson called the ringing grooves of change. Miss Beard--daughter of the illustrious historian Charles A. Beard--has done for the business man what Hendrick Willem van Loon attempted to do for the arts.

FranK B. Noyes, one of the rounders of The Associated Press and its president through the last thirtyeight eventful years, told his fellow directors yesterday that he would not accept re-election at the expiration of his present term in April. He is president of The Washington (D. C.) Star.

House leaders will probably respond to President Roosevelt's request for the power to veto or reduce items in appropriation bills, by reviving as a matter of policy the authority granted alike to former President Hoover and to Mr. Roosevelt in the midst of the depression to impound such parts of appropriations as the Executive did not wish to expend.

4th St, 399 E, Metropolitan Savings Bank to Sonia Robinson, Holland Hotel, 42d St and 9th Ave ($2). 126th St, 238 E. Charles W. Paris to Alice F. King, 2.073 E 21st St, Brooklyn, half interest ($2.50). 99th St, 104 W, Louise Mazzochi to Tarascon Realty Corp, 11 John St ($1). 125th St, 29-33 E, Herlim Realty Corp, David Kopit, president, to Cay Building Corp, 81 E 125th St, correction deed.

Acting quickly on its promise to frame a new immigration law to straighten out Brazil's complicated foreigner problem, the Vargas government today set up a commission to study the subject and to recommend new legislation.
A buoyant tone in the market for United States Government obligations and local traction issues featured yesterday's relatively quiet trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange.
The Supreme Soviet, now holding in the Kremlin its first session since its creation, is being treated in the Soivet press as the biggest possible news-as a great event in human history.

David S. Garland, for many years editor-in-chief of The New York Law Review and of The United States Law Review, died yesterday morning at his residence, 80 Winthrop Street, Brooklyn, after a long illness. He was 72 years old.

Declaring that it was his opinion the recession was "largely mental," and expressing confidence that 1938 would be a good year for his company, Frank Denny, advertising director of the Cadillac division of General Motors, revealed details yesterday of the new low-priced Cadillac to automobile editors and dealers in the New York area.

An increase of more than 35 per cent in WPA health service to city school children was made possible yesterday when Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, received word from Washington that President Roosevelt had authorized an appropriation of $852,038 to carry the WPA medical and nursing project through June 30, the end of the Federal fiscal year.
President Roosevelt conferred with Charles Edison, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, on naval construction matters and entertained the diplomatic corps at the annual state dinner.

Bank clearings of the twenty-two leading cities throughout the United States declined 17.4 per cent during the week ending on Wednesday to a total of $4,912,502,000 from $5,945,371,000 for the corresponding week of 1937, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The indications are for generally fair and moderately cold weather today followed by snow or rain tonight. Tomorrow will be cloudy and colder, probably preceded in early morning by rain or snow, according to the map charted at the United States Weather Bureau at 7:30 o'clock last night.

The work done by the office in arranging and presenting facts for use in the control of a business has become of as great importance as the actual production or distribution operations of the concerns, Walter F. Titus, vice president of the International Business Machines Corporation, declared last night at a dinner of the New York Office Appliance Managers Association at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Captain William Denny Brereton, U. S. N., and Mrs. Brereton of Washington have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Hyde Brereton, to Robert Dwight Swezey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Dwight Swezey of Newtonville, Mass.

A strong probability of a revival of some proportions In the capital market was indicated today by the filing of a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 by the Appalachian Electric Power Company covering a $67,000,000 security flotation, including $57,000,

Wrecking crews were busy yesterday erecting a heavy wooden scaffold across the sidewalk at the northwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street, and busy New Yorkers, despite their habitual hurry, paused to gaze up less casually than usual at the tall spire of the old Brick Presbyterian so Church there.

Based on allegations by Attorney General Bennett that "there is indicated the existence of fraudulent practices on a huge scale," an order requiring the three top officers of Campagnoli Co. of 41 Broad Street, dealers in securities, to appear on next Friday in Supreme Court for examination was issued yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Richard P. Lydon.

Acting Governor Menendez Ramos late today declared a state of emergency in Puerto Rico and appointed a price commission of three to regulate the prices of all necessaries. Itemized in the proclamation as necessaries, in accordance with a law passed last year, are food, medicines, wearing apparel, bedding, household goods and building materials.

By getting the coming State Constitutional Convention to authorize the use of city bonds for payment of the entire purchase price of privately operated rapid transit lines the city may be able to achieve transit unification at the lowest possible price and at an interest rate of only 3 per cent, Transit Commissioner Reuben L. Haskell declared yesterday.

The Essex County grand jury, which is investigating Newark's administration, reported in two presentments today that it had found no evidence to support criminal complaints in its inquiry into the operation of the city's insurance fund and bureau of motors.

Police Commissioner Valentine's drive to cleanse the city of vice and gambling includes the punch-board racket, it was revealed yesterday in Jefferson Market Court when a salesman for a-Fifth Avenue manufacturing company was held in $500 bail for hearing Jan. 25 on a charge of conducting a lottery.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed-Against PIETRO CAZZOLA, grocer, 2,400 Arthur Ave., by I. Haber, Inc., for $106: Western Sausage Co., $97; Ronzoni Macaroni Co., $104; M. De Rosa, Inc., $58: Mossalina Products Corp., $76; G. Rossano Bro., Inc., $97. Petitions Filed-By LOU LAWRENCE BARENKOPF, salesman, 1,741 Monroe Ave.-Liabilities $863, no assets.
Representatives of the American Theatre Council and the League of New York Theatres will meet at a dinner tonight at the Hotel Astor to discuss certain features of the Council program.

Albert Ottinger, former State Attorney General, former assistant United States district attorney and Republican candidate for Governor in 1928 who was defeated by Franklin D. Roosevelt, died yesterday at his home, 23 West Seventy-third Street. He was 59 years old.

Sale of 15,000 heavy native steers for export at 15 cents. a premium of 1/2 cent over the domestic quotation, has marked relatively quiet trading in hides this week. Prices have continued strong, and frequent bids from tanners for substantial quantities at slight concessions under packers' prices have been declined, it was reported yesterday.

The Interstate Commerce Commission granted today an application made by Governors of six New England States for authority to intervene in the "civil war" case in which nine Southeastern Governors seek lower freight rates for the South.
Activities in Real Estate

Otto Strippel, treasurer of the Central Savings Bank, has also been elected vice president, Charles G. Edwards, president, announced yesterday. Other promotions include Henry Vogeler, from assistant secretary to assistant vice president; August Sidler, from secretary to secretary and -assistant treasurer;

The sound separating Graham Land from Alexander I land in the Antarctic, whose discovery was the principal geographical achievement of the expedition led by John Rymill, will be known as King George VI Sound by the King's permission, it was announced tonight.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, said tonight he believed that leaders, "chafing under autocratic restraint" within the Committee for Industrial Organization, "will win the fight within the dual movement for a united labor movement."

The further rise of $120,000,000 in member bank excess reserves to a total of $1,390,000,000 shown in this week's Federal Reserve statement means that the reduction in excess reserves resulting from the final increase of member bank reserve requirements, last May 1, has been virtually canceled for the moment.

Governor Hoffman of New Jersey came to Pennsylvania today to be held up, and was disappointed. It was done with a practiced flourish as the Governor rode in an ancient tallyho drawn by four horses along Old Coventry Road Cheltenham Township.
The Bureau of Internal Revenue warned yesterday that Federal unemployment insurance taxes for 1937 must be paid by employers of eight or more persons in covered industries on or before Jan. 31 and

The Hamburg-American liner Deutschland will arrive today from Germany and Channel ports. Among her passengers are Franz Schneiderhan, Colonel George Henry Barnett, Miss Auguste Beutner, Professor Ernst Matthias, L. E. Dodd, Major Laurence A. Leech, H. C. Querner and Kurt Lindener.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France, issued today, shows the following changes, in francs:

The Federal Communications Commission voted Tuesday to make a broad investigation into the rates of the country's major telegraph, radio and cable companies, it was announced today. Commissioner T. A. M. Craven did not concur.

Two boys, one 13 years old and the other 14, were held as juvenile delinquents last night after they were said by Assistant Fire Marshal Martin Siegel to have confessed that in the last three years they had set 100 or more fires in various parts of Manhattan.

Princeton University has received from the estate of the late Professor Leroy W. McCay, '77, a bequest of $50,000 for the creation of two graduate fellowships in chemistry, it was announced today at the Winter meeting of the board of trustees.

In an effort to curtail consumption of raw cotton, the Japanese Ministry of Commerce has announced that effective Feb. 1 all cotton yarn used in the manufacture of goods for domestic consumption must be mixed with 30 per cent staple fiber, according to cable advices from Tokyo made public today by the Department of Commerce.

Senator Robert M. La Follette of Wisconsin and Amos R. E. Pinchot, anti-New Deal liberal, took opposite sides last night in Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street, on the question whether the Federal Government should increase or decrease its expenditures to combat the recession and produce a balanced budget.

The largest star in the universe so far to be reported, the discovery of which was announced by Dr. Otto Struve and his associates at the Yerkes Observatory of the University of Chicago, is not the wellknown visible star Epsilon Aurigae, which can be seen with the naked eye, but the invisible "ghost" companion of this star, it was revealed yesterday by Dr. Struve in an interview over the telephone.

George A. Munger, freshman coach and graduate in the class of '33, today was appointed head coach of the University of Pennsylvania football- squad. With the promotion of the 28year-old former Penn player the university returned to graduate coaching.

Colonel Edward H. R. Green, son of the late Hetty Green, assembled at his estate in Massachusetts two radio broadcasting stations, a whaling ship, set in concrete, machinery for smashing the atom, a "fog dispeller" and a blimp, as well as radio direction-finding equipment and workshops, witnesses testified yesterday at a hearing on his $40,000,000 estate.

Attribute to Lorade Taft as a "beloved apostle of beauty" from Dr. John H. Finely of the THE NEW YORK TIMES was read here last night at a memorial banquet following the unveiling of a portrait bust of Taft at the University of Illinois by the Illinois Art Extention committee.

Saryell Prentice, a partner in the New York Stock Exchange firm of Prentice Bradt, and F. E. Mayer have taken over the majority common stock interest and the management of the Reynolds Investing Company, Inc., it was announced yesterday. Mr. Prentice succeeds R. S. Reynolds as president and Mr. Mayer succeeds C. K. Reynolds as vice president. Clayton Davis has been made secretary and Walter A. Galvin, treasurer.

An all-North final was reached in the annual Lake Worth golf championship at the Palm Beach Golf Club today when Harold Kaplow of East Orange, N. J., and Jack Ryerson of Cooperstown, N. Y., former Yale star, won their semi-final matches.

Charles P. Taft of Cincinnati, chairman of the National Citizens Committee of the Community Mobilization for Human Needs, testifying before the Senate Unemployment Committee today, said that great confusion existed as to the wisest relief policies and' he proposed that a single unified program be drawn up to be shared by the Federal, State and local governments.

Labor's initial program in the new City Council will consist of two comprehensive bills, one dealing with the city's labor policy and the second outlining a ten-year program of low-cost housing to provide modern dwellings for 200,000 families, it was learned at City Hall yesterday.

William J. Carney, C. I. O. regional director for New Jersey, made a sweeping denial today of charges by Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City that the C. I. O. in New Jersey was under Communist leadership or that its attempted "invasion" of Jersey City was inspired by Communists.

The State Legislature this year has two chances to strike at the evil of child labor. One way is to reconsider last year's action and adopt the pending Child Labor Amendment. The other way was indicated by Governor Lehman in his annual message when he said:

Production of pianos in the United States during 1937 totaled 106,009 units, an increase of 17.32 per cent over 1936, L. P. Bull, president of the National Piano Manufacturers Association, announced today.

COTTRELL, JOSEPHINE A. (Dec. 16 1937). Gross assets, $14,270: net, $8,832. To daughters, Hazel M., Edna A. and Helen J. Cottrell, one-third of residuary estate each. Chief assets, real estate, $9,000; mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, ?5,145; miscellaneous property, $125. George H. Boyce, attorney, 188 Montague St.

Those who will benefit to any great extent from the revisions of the capital gains tax being proposed by the Congressional committee studying taxation are largely quite wealthy people, Jackson Martindell, president of Fiduciary Counsel, in Inc., said yesterday in an interview. "Such revisions," he declared,
Dr. Arthur Soper Armstrong of 103 East Sixty-fifth Street died yesterday at his home, 8 Henderson Place, Manhattan, after a short illness. He would have been 60 years old today.

Mayor Joseph F. Loehr vetoed tonight the Yonkers budget as sent to him by the Common Council. The Republican majority in the Council had cut $807,000 from the $16,375,000 budget, which the Mayor, a Democrat, had drawn up.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Jan. 13, unless specified: Antares, Quantico to Naval Operating Base, Norfolk. Bagley, Norfolk Yard to Naval Operating Base, Norfolk. Bridge, at Shanghai. Gannett, Panama Bay to Coco Solo. Jarvis, at San Pedro, Jan. 12. Northampton, at San Pedro, Jan. 12.

The House today took up the second large appropriation bill for the next fiscal year, that for the Treasury and Postoffice Departments, which carries total proposed expenditures of $1,515,552,286. Critics of the Administration attacked the measure, Representative Taber of New York declaring his belief that "an intensive drive" could reduce government expenditures by 20 per cent.

The anti-Communist organization "We Americans," recently organized by George U. Harvey, Borough President of Queens, yesterday was disavowed by spokesmen for two war veterans' associations listed as sponsors and warmly defended by two others.
Dr. Eugene McEvers Van Ness, a former member of the staff here of the late Dr. William Osler and prominent for many years in medical, sports and social circles, died last night at his home.

Miss Lillian de Curtoni, daughter of Count Francis de Curtoni of Austria, was buried this morning at Laurelwood Cemetery. Miss de Curtoni gave the money for the erection of the new oratory school at Rockhill.

A banking group headed by Brown Harriman Co., Inc., received yesterday the award of a new issue of $2,000,000 of public works bonds of Rochester, N. Y., on a bid of 100.0599 for 1.70s. The bonds, to be dated Feb. 1, 1938, and maturing serially from Feb. 1, 1940 to 1948, were reoffered at prices to yield from 0.70 to 1.85 per cent, according to maturity.
Hash, says young America, is a favorite meat; spinach a favorite vegetable, ice cream by far the most preferable dessert, and bananas the best-liked fruit.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has granted an application of the New York Stock Exchange to strike from listing and registration the unstamped ten-year 4 1/4 per cent debentures due on Aug. 1, 1946, of the Adams Express' Company because, as a result of an exchange, the number outstanding is so small as to make further dealing in them on the Exchange inadvisable.

Clarence Doan, 43 years old, a constable of Frenchtown, was wounded fatally by a shotgun blast today as he attempted to persuade a disabled World War veteran to go to Phillipsburg for a periodical medical examination.

A plan to break the jam of clogged used-car inventories and thus aid general business by putting men and money back to work in the automobile field was proposed by A. Edward Barit, president of the Hudson Motor Car Company, at a luncheon he gave yesterday at the Hotel Astor to some fifty business representatives and automobile editors of newspapers of this and other cities.

Because of the widespread operation of bingo games, Samuel J. Foley, District Attorney of the Bronx, announced yesterday that he would arrest and prosecute operators of bingo as violators of the lottery law.

The cost of carrying newspapers at preferential postal rates, cited recently by President Roosevelt as one cause for the postal deficit, was minimized today by Representative Engel of Michigan in a speech containing figures showing the great burden placed on the postal service by handling the Administration's free mails.

William Benjamin Shearn, who introduced grapefruit and "fruit lunch" to Great Britain, died today at the age of 65. Mr. Shearn, who had many connections in the United States, was the first president of the English Unit of Florists Telegraph Delivery Association.
Vice Admiral James Farquharson Leys, retired naval officer, died of pneumonia last night at the Naval Hospital here after a brief illness. He was 70 years old.
The New York Central System announced yesterday the discontinuance of several passenger trains and the merging of others, beginning Tuesday.

To take effect 8 A. M., Jan. 14. Assigned to duty as Supervisor of Plain Clothes Patrolmen: ACTING LIEUTENANT' - Harry P. McCann, from 18th Division, 14th Deteclive District to Office of Police Commissioner. Designation as Acting Lieutenant revoked.

The War Department issued the following orders dated Jan. 12: LIEUTENANT COLONELS McNarney, J. T., Air Corps, from Langley Field, Va., to headquarters Sixth Corps Area, Chicago, Ill. Holmes, F. M., Finance Department, retired from active service Jan. 31.

Applications for State unemployment insurance benefits reached a total of 425,700 last night as 20,700 persons here and up-State filed for weekly payments of $7 to $15. No estimate of the percentage of eligibles among those who have applied to date was obtainable at the offices of the division of placement and unemployment insurance of the State Labor Department:
President and Mrs. Roosevelt tonight gave the annual state dinner in honor of the diplomatic corps, entertaining the envoys of fifty-one countries.

The Maple Leafs stretched their International lead in the National Hockey League race to 4 points tonight as they downed the Maroons, 3 to 2, before 11,000. Pep Kelly, after being banished for a minor and a misconduct offense in the second period, came back in the third frame to count the winning goal with less than five minutes to go.
Four leading Chinese diplomats today held a "council of war" that was said to concern a plan to seek Russian and British aid in the conflict against Japan.

TWO strangers were encountered yesterday. One was tall and hefty and the other was short and compact. The tall, hefty :fellow was Tom Haggerty, coach of the De Paul basketball team, that is scheduled to play L. I. U. at the Garden this evening. The short chap said his name was Kieran Crowley and he was a guard on the De Paul team.

Six indictments which were returned against Morris Glaser, 53 years old, in December, 1936, in the investigation by the New York County grand jury into the so-called garnishee racket, in which city employes were the victims, were quashed yesterday by General Sessions Judge Bohan on the motion of Glaser's lawyer, A. S. Cutler.

Federal Judge Fred L. Wham ordered sixty-six members of the Progressive Mine Workers of America and seven locals of the union today to pay $117,000 for damages caused by a long strike at a coal mine near Freeburg, Ill.

Text of former Ambassador Dodd's speech is on Page 4. A warning that civilization as we know it is in grave danger unless Germany, Italy and Japan are checked by the democracies was given last night by William E. Dodd, former Ambassador to Germany, in an address at a testimonial dinner given for him by 200 friends at the Hotel WaldorfAstoria.

The ?? institute sent a letter yesterday to the Committee for Reciprocity Information, an agency of the State Department in Washington, urging that the Canadian tariff on Pennsylvania anthracite be removed in the new trade agreement to be negotiated with Great Britain.

David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, is the man whom Chairman John D. M. Hamilton of the Republican National Committee, in 1936, charged with being a Communist supporter. Mr. Hamilton thought at that time that it was "an affront to the voters of America" to put Mr. Dubinsky's name on the list of Democratic candidates for Presidential electors.
The yacht Sea Cloud, belonging to United States Ambassador Joseph E. Davies, was damaged in the harbor here today when rammed by the yacht Verda, whose owner is stated to be an American named Vering.
Fight skeet shooting was introuced on Long Island tonight as )rty-three contestants participated an invitation fifty-shot competion on the grounds of the Crescent
The government tobacco monopoly has fixed the retail price of leading American cigarettes at 18 cents a package. A smokers' strike was S threatened recently because of the high cost of tobacco.

Negotiations for the leasing of a property in the Times Square area at an aggregate rental of more than $1,000,000 were completed yesterday. The deal involves the five-story building at the southwest corner of Broadway and Forty-eighth Street, which has been taken by the McGinnis Restaurant, Stanley P. McGinnis, president.

The board of directors of The Associated Press at its meeting here has adopted the following resolution by a rising vote respecting the late Edward J. Neil Jr., foreign correspondent of The Associated Press:

A 25 per cent increase in the sales force of Manning, Maxwell Moore, Inc., manufacturers of valves, gauges, safety valves and control instruments for industrial plants, was announced yesterday by William P. Bradbury, general sales manager. The move, Mr.

A score of educational, regligious and charitable institutions will divide more than $1,000,000 of cash be quests under the will of Arthur H. Lesa, retired publisher, art patron an Id philanthropist, who died last week in his seventy-ninth year. The will was filed for probate at Norristown today.

12:30-1:30 P. M.-Daniel C. Roper, Secretary of Commerce, Speaking on Farm and Home Hour-WJZ. 2:00-3:00 P. M.-Music Appreciation Hour, Dr. Walter Damrosch, Conductor-WEAF. WJZ. 3:00-3:30 P. M.-United States Marine Band Concert-WABC. 5:15-6:15 P. M.-Temple Emanu-EI Services-WHN. 8:00-9:00 P. M.-Lucille Manners, Soprano; Ross Graham, Baritone; Revelers Quartet: Bourdon Orchestra-WEAF.

Directors of the Fidelity Union Trust Company, Newark, N. J., voted yesterday to retire $250,000 in preferred stock, it was announced by J. H. Bacheller, president. This is the fifth partial retirement since the original amount of $7,000,000 was issued in 1934, and reduces the preferred stock outstanding to $3,250,000.

Long-range bidding for the services of Don Budge, as a professional, continued yesterday despite the general belief that America's Davis Cup ace has no thought of leaving amateur ranks 'his year, according to The Associated Press.

New capitalization rates for fixing the taxable value of New York City real estate for 1932, 1933 and 1934 were used yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo in fixing the assessment for the Happiness Candy Store property on Forty-second Street, east of Broadway. The court ruled that 1932 rentals should be capitalized at 5 per cent; 1933 rentals at 5 1/4 per cent and 1934 rentals at 5 1/2 per cent.

The metallic reserves of the Bank of Mexico rose considerably this week, from 38.64 per cent to 39.25 per cent, according to the bank's statement, issued today. The reserves now are almost 2 per cent above the low record of 37.60 per cent on Dec. 24.
New light is thrown on the Japanese Imperial Council's.decision of Tuesday by information from highly reliable sources.

Columbia University received portraits of Dr. Herbert E. Hawkes, dean of Columbia College and Professor of Mathematics, and Dr. Cassius J. Keyser, Adrian Professor Emeritus of Mathematics, at an unveiling ceremony yesterday afternoon in Philosophy Hall. The paintings were accepted by President Nicholas Murray Butler in behalf of the university.

Denunciations of fascism and anti-Semitism and appeals to women to play a leading part in building a world free from hate and insecurity marked the addresses today at the silver jubilee celebration of the National Federation of Temple Sisterhoods, which have 55,000 members.

The Navy Department has recommended to President Roosevelt that Congress be asked for authorization to build war vessels in excess of the limits of the existing VinsonTrammell law, it was indicated today by Admiral W. D. Leahy, Chief of Naval Operations. It was presumed that this recommendation would be the basis of the naval message which the President is expected to send to Congress within a few days.

A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Frederick L. Kane of 730 Park Avenue on Monday at the Doctors Hospital. Mrs. Kane is the former Miss Mary G. McGovern, daughter of Mrs. Patrick McGovern of the Plaza. The child will be named Robert Leo.

There was no singing of songs or blaring of bands when 500 troops of the First Division and forty-four army officers embarked upon the battleship Arkansas at the Brooklyn Army Base yesterday afternoon on one pf the first overseas expeditions since the World War.

W. W. Wachtel, vice president of Calvert Distillers Corporation since 1936, was yesterday elected president of the corporation, it was announced last night at a dinner at the St. Regis Hotel attended by executives of the company present in the city for a sales and management conference. E. M.

Two petitions were added today to the voluminous records of the 77-B Receivership of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, causing Federal Judge Holly to set aside Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday of next week for hearing those on file.

Frank Moore of Mamaroneck, N. Y., shot a six-under-par 67 today to win Dizzy Dean's golf tournament and Dizzy himself was so busy acting as host he didn't go to the postoffice to find out whether the Cardinals have slashed his salary. Dizzy declined to talk about the new contract.

The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders, dated Jan. 11: CAPTAINS Benson, H. H. J., detached from command of the Holland; to command the Reina Mercedes. Morrison, C. H., Army War College, Fort Humphreys, D. C., to Bureau of Navigation, Navy Department.
For the first time in his judicial career, Justice Willis Van Devanter, retired member of the United States Supreme Court, addressed jurors yesterday as "Ladies and gentlemen of the jury."
Fifty years ago a 16-year-old girl, timid, yet unafraid, faced a group of twenty-seven boys and girlssome of them older than the young teacher-at Public School 23, Brooklyn.

Judge Carl Foster in Superior Court today ordered a grand jury summoned for Jan. 25 to make an exhaustive investigation into expenditure of $6,000,000 by John A. MacDonald, State Highway Commissioner, for rights of way for the Merritt Parkway.

League for Political Education, Town Hall, 11 A. M. "Can Europe Be Saved?" S. K. Rateliffe. Luncheon of the Pan American Society, India House, 1 Hanover Square, 12:30 P. M. William Dawson, American Minister to Uruguay, guest of honor.

The State Automobile Association voted today to oppose that part of Governor Lehman's budget relating to continuance of the "so-called emeragency" gasoline tax. The action came at a meeting of the officers and directors of the group here.
John A. Lawson, member of the New Haven and Meriden nines of 1 the historic Connecticut Baseball League for several seasons, and of several other New England teams,

As with human babies, cutting teeth is painful for baby giant pandas, said Mrs. Ruth Harkness, American explorer and big-game hunter, on her arrival here this morning from Hong Kong with her fretful panda cub. She captured the animal in the Szechvan hinterland.

United States naval authorities announced today that efforts to salvage the United States gun-boat Panay, sunk by Japanese bombs in the Yangtze River Dec. 12, had been abandoned after the ship's safe and official papers had been recovered by divers.

The Board of Examiners recommends that license as teacher-in-training in day secondary schools other than junior high schools,. in the subjects indicated, be issued to the following applicants, who have met the eligibility and examination requirements therefor:

Endorsement by Dr. Charles E. Irwin, surgeon-in-chief of the Georgia Warm Springs Foundation's center for the after-treatment of infantile paralysis, of the new National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis was made public yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Hearn Waters Streat of 1,165 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lucille Streat, to J. Francis Bartoccini, son of Mr. and Mrs. Astolfo Bartoccini of New Rochelle.
The Bronx Tigers and the Hershey Bears will clash tonight in an Eastern Hockey League game at the New, York Coliseum at 8:30 o'clock. It will be the only home contest of the week for the Bengals.

News of the conference schuled for next Monday between Ireland and Britain, particularly when it was linked with partition as one of the subjects for discussion, created a major political sensation here today. In this capital of the loyal province of Ulster there was real apprehension when the news first broke.

M. Cordero Reyes, Nicaraguan Minister of Foreign Affairs, announced last night that he had sent a message to Koht Halvdan, Norwegian Minister of Foreign Affairs, requesting that Cordell Hull, United States Secretary of State, be awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for 1938.

Isadore Frank, 51 years old, a poultry dealer, who for nineteen years had operated his market at 561 Blake Avenue in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, was shot to death early last night as he stopped his automobile in front of his home at 733 Alabama Avenue, a short distance from the store.

The Dominion Bureau of Statistics issued a review of employment today showing that 1937 saw a monthly average of 1,085,831 persons employed, an average gain of 106,090 over 1936 and the highest average since 1929. The bureau, basing its 1937 averages on eleven months, said there was also an estimated gain of 493 in the number of employers, bringing the total to 10,210.
Former President Herbert Hoover will sail from New York for Belgium Feb. 8 to revisit the scene of his labors as director of a relief commission which fed 10,000,000 persons during the World War.

Young Bobby Riggs of Chicago, back in the form that won him No. 2 national ranking, defeated Wilmer Hines of Hollywood, Calif., 6-2, 6-3, in the quarter-finals of the Nautilus tennis tournament today.

TODAY-New England: Clear, except snow flurries over the north, with slightly higher temperatures, though continuing below freezing over the central and northern portions throughout the day, but with slight thawing temperatures over the south.

The following members of the department shall be directed to report to the Motor and Pump Operators' School at 1 P. M. on the dates specified above their names (except on March 22 they will report at 10:30 A. M.): Group 1, Platoon 2-Jan. 21 and 27, Feb. 2, 8, 14, 25, March 4, 10, 16, 22.

The city's mechanized army of snow fighters had its first real skirmish yesterday and last night as about 33,000 regulars and volunteers, operating with snow shovels, snow loaders, crosswalk plows, hoses and flushing machines and trucks, removed a fall of snow that averaged less than two inches in midtown and over three inches in the outer boroughs.

Physicians announced this afternoon that today's X-rays showed Governor Blanton Winship had five broken ribs instead of one. When the first pictures were taken a bulletin explained that the Governor was suffering too much pain from his fall aboard a steamship to permit a thorough examination.

By THOMAS F. BURCHILL 5th St, 430 E; 5-story brick tenement and stores, 25x96.2; Dry Dock Savings Institution against Esther Feig; due, $18,401; to plaintiff for $1,000. By JOSEPH P. DAY 7th Ave, 2,208; 5-story brick tenement and stores, 25x75; S. Philip Goodhart against Goodname Realty Corp; due, $24,616; taxes, etc, $400: to plaintiff for $1,000.

The Social Security Board announced today grants totaling $13,191,600 for public assistance programs in seven States. The grants, for the quarter beginning Jan. 1 (except Pennsylvania, where they were for the period from Oct. 1 to Dec. 31, 1937), included:

The outcome of the Budapest conversation among the Rome protocol powers [Austria, Hungary and Italy] suggests to German official quarters that those powers are determined to coordinate their political and economic aims still more and to bring Germany directly into line with such a Central European development.

First trace of the gold and jade archaeological treasures stolen from the Peabody Museum of Harvard, Dec. 31, was obtained by Massachusetts State Police today when pieces were recovered in Hartford and in New York. University officials,

Mrs. Rose Frankel of Brooklyn received full and indefinite custody of her 12-year-old son, Howard, and the father, Julius Frankel of Linden, was severely reprimanded in a decree announced today by Advisory Master Dougal Herr in Chancery Court.

The Theatre Guild's official "Wine of Choice" bulletin for today confirms the report that that play, now in Pittsburgh, will be idle next week, reopening in Baltimore on Jan. 24 for a week. Thereafter: Wilmington, Jan. 31; Princeton, Feb. 1; Hartford, Feb. 2; New Haven, Feb. 3-5. At Pittsburgh's Nixon on Wednesday afternoon it played to capacity, plus standees.

Charles Edward Stahl, president of the Arcturus Radio Tube Company of Newark, died of pneumonia today at his home, 502 Grove Street. Born in Chicago fifty-four yearn ago, Mr. Stahl was graduated from Northwestern University, where he was Phi Beta Kappa, in 1903.

The legality of the apportionment made by Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey of the $25,000 reward offered by that State for the arrest and conviction of the kidnappers of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr. was questioned yesterday by New York County Clerk Archibald R. Watson in an editorial published in The New York Law Journal, of which he is editor.

Mrs. Mary Faltermeier, 55 years old, who died today in Orange Memorial Hospital of burns suffered in one of four blazes yesterday in a house at 17 Winfield Street, deliberately set the fires which cost her life, according to the verdict of Dr. George P. Olcott Jr., assistant medical examiner.

The defense rested today in the trial of sixteen major oil companies and thirty-seven individuals on charges of conspiracy to fix MidWestern gasoline prices. James Miller, New York accountant, the last defense witness, testified that major oil companies'

Announcement has been made of the engagement and approaching marriage of Miss Jane Dahl, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George V. Dahl of this city, to Russell W. R. Powell Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. R. W. R. Powell of New York.

Twenty-three students have been appointed to the new editorial board of the Manhattan College Quadrangle, student weekly newspaper, it was announced yesterday. The chief editors and managers are David Lawrence, editor in Chief; James F. McDonald, managing editor; Daniel C. Furst and Joseph T. Gushue, spots editors;

Excelling with his brilliant work around and on the greens, Charles H. Mayo Jr. of Long Beach, former Long Island amateur champion, registered an easy triumph in the semi-final round of the annual mid-Winter golf championship at the Miami Country Club today, overwhelming Sid Salomon Jr. of St. Louis, 6 and 5.

Mr. and Mrs. J. Randall Creel will give a dinner tonight in the Persian Room of the Plaza for Miss Marguerite Brokaw and Charles Crocker, whose marriage will take place on Jan. 27 at the home of Miss Brokaw's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Howard C. Brokaw, at 984 Fifth Avenue.

Wall St. Riding Club Party Feb. 4 The Wall Street Riding Club will hold its annual gymkhana and dance this year on Feb. 4 at 32 West Sixty-seventh Street, it was announced yesterday. Trophies have been donated by persons in the banking and brokerage fields. Miss Alice Chapman of the National City Bank is chairman of the committee on arrangements. Jesse Gordon of Kuhn Loeb Co. is president of the club.

Public Administrator James F. Egan in his annual report shows that his office in the year 1937 brought in revenue totaling $75,373 and, after actual budgetary costs of $42,545, showed a profit of $32,828 for the year. Mr. Egan's post is one of the sixty-five deleted by Mayor La Guardia from the 1938 budget.

Erection of the steel superstructure of the West Side express highway from Canal Street south to Duane Street will be started on Jan. 24, Stanley M. Isaacs, Borough President of Manhattan, announced yesterday.

The Court of appealss has reversed the convicon of Irving Sacks of New York P ??ty under sections of the banking ??W relating to making of loans without authorization from the Late Superintendent of Banks, B ??d also on a charge of conspiring Pith Samuel M. Morton of New ork to make such loans.

The stock markets here were in a hesitant mood today owing to uncertainty over the French situation. Gilt-edge issues had a good tone and foreign bonds generally were better. Transatlantic shares lost ground, reflecting overnight weakness in Wall Street, and United States Steel and International Nickel had a setback.
Boston was selected for the midsummer conference of the National Association of State Racing Commissioners at the conclusion of the annual Winter meeting today. The date will be designated later.

Three one-act plays will be presented by the All Souls Play Shop tonight in Fellowship Hall, All Souls Unitarian Church, Lexington Avenue and Eightieth Street. The pieces are "The Perfect Ending," featuring Miss Lillian Hillman of the Lighthouse Players;

Staging another evening comeback, Welker Cochran, who is introduced daily at the Strand Academy as world 18.2 balkline billiard champion, last night defeated Jake Schaefer, 395 to 300, in ten innings after dropping the afternoon block, 300 to 257, in seven frames in their challenge match.

In contrast with the precipitous decline in the final quarter of 1937, business in the Pittsburgh district improved on a broad front in the first week of 1938, according to the Bureau of Business Research of the University of Pittsburgh.

The election of Leonard Ginsberg, vice president and general manager of the Hearn Department Stores, Inc., as president of Hearn's was announced yesterday by Maurice Levin. Mr. Levin, who has been president of Hearn's, becomes chairman of the board and will continue active in the company's affairs.

Testifying yesterday in response to the charges of the Federal Trade Commission that the Fashion Originators Guild of America, Inc., had been guilty of restraint of trade, Albert M. Post, executive director of that organization, cited several instances in which guild members refused to sell merchandise to retailers who would not "cooperate with them" in preventing the sale of "copied designs."

Frank Herbert Briggs, a member of the board of trustees of Bates College, died here today at the Alexander Hamilton Hotel at the age of 80. Mr. Briggs, a native of Auburn, Me., was graduated from Bates College and was until his retirement several years ago active in government service in Washington.

Rather than be made idle by the complete closing of the plant, the employes of Gar Wood Industries, Inc., voted today-to accept sharp pay cuts. The pay of unskilled workers will be cut by 20 per cent, while that of the skilled employes will be reduced 5 to 10 per cent.

With this country producing more than it consumes, there is no economic or legal justification for any proposal to stop exports of scrap iron and scrap steel, according to Michael V. Bonomo of New York, president of the Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel.

A family feud of long standing, involving the murdered Mrs. Lenida Waite of Elmont and a relative whose name was withheld, was being investigated by Nassau County detectives today as the most promising clue to the murder yesterday of Mrs. Waite and a girl neighbor.

News of Prime Minister Eamon de Valera's forthcoming conference in London with the British Government was read and discussed in this part of Ireland today in a singular mood of hopefulness, revealing a desire for friendship with Britain.

President Roosevelt this morning received and this evening acclaimed a proffer of the General Federation of Women's Clubs to originate a mass movement intended to counteract the constriction of the nation's purse strings due to the "recession."

The present is not the time to impose additional taxes, Secretary Morgenthau has told members of Congress in testimony made public today. This and other views of the Treasury Department chief went into the official records with publication of statements he gave before a House Appropriations subcommittee on Dec. 8 during private studies of the Treasury's Appropriation Bill.

France's second Popular Front Cabinet, led by Camille Chautemps, who suc??eeded Leon Blum last June, has ??rumbled to pieces and with it has ??one the unity of the Popular Front of Radical Socialists, Socialists and Communists elected triumphantly n May, 1936.
Fifteen contributors added a total of $254 yesterday to the Neediest Cases Fund, bringing the total received in the twenty-sixth annual appeal to $300,637.05.
$6,150 Is Withheld Pending an Explanation of Foal Claimed by Victim of Armstrong

Salaries in excess of $15,000 paid in 1936 by newspapers published in New York City are listed in the following report prepared by Editor and Publisher. Salaries of $50,000 and more are eliminated from the C list as having been previously publisted: e
Mme. supplies needs Chiang Kai-shek, wife of China's Generalissimo, came to Hong Kong today by airplane from Hankow, China's temporary capital.

The Free Kindergarten Society of Brooklyn will be the beneficiary of a supper dance to be known as a "Five O'Clock Frolic," tomorrow in the ballroom of the Pierre. Mrs. Frederic R. Sanborn heads the group in charge of the arrangements for the benefit.

The cry of "Track!" will reverberate through the "northlands" this week-end, for thousands of skiers plan to flee the city confines by automobile and train to enjoy what promises to be the best snow conditions for downhill and trail running in the East for the past two years.

Those anglers who had planned to do some Florida fishing this week and then postponed their trip are going to be wild when they learn that no less than eighty sailfish were taken by anglers on six chartered boats off Stuart, Fla., on Wednesday.

Miss Eleanor Louise Hunter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Wentz Hunter of Rosemont, was married this afternoon to Paul Eugene Casey, son of Mrs. Thomas Casey of Park Hill, Yonkers, N. Y., and of the late Mr. Casey.

Declaring that government and business are united on the desirability of prompt action to stimulate recovery, Ward Melville, president of the Melville Shoe Company, yesterday expressed optimism over prospects for an improvement in retail business during the Summer months.

The United States Attorney's office introduced a new technique yesterday in the presentation of evidence obtained over tapped telephone wires. For the first time in the history of procedure here, a jury in Federal Court heard phonographic records of voices talking over tapped wires.

Showing a willingness to gamble at every turn--a characteristic that was sadly lacking in their make-up on their previous visits to this city-the world champion Red Wings came close to conquering the Rangers in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

7th Ave, 911-17; to 12-story and penthouse apartment house and store; Dry Dock Savings Institution, 742 Lexington Ave, owner; Louis S. Weeks, architect; cost, $225,000. 58th St, 330 to 334 E: to three 5-story tenements; same owner and architect; cost. $7,500. 43d St, 328 W; to 5-story tenement; Joseph

Continuing its investigation of the Pennroad Corporation the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce charged today that on July 16, 1929, Kuhn, Loeb Co. of New York began to sell Pennroad stock short and as a result made a profit of $2,700,000,

Plans for apartment houses on sites near the Grand Concourse were announced yesterday in connection with sales of properties in Echo Place and East 179th Street. In both projects the proposed buildings will replace dwellings.

A small item in yesterday's news from Washington throws a long shadow. "It was made clear at the State Department," said one of our dispatches, "that the American policy of non-recognition of the Italian conquest of Ethiopia remains unchanged."

So much of Paragraph 6, Special Orders 204. dated Sept. 2, 1937, as continues Capt. Earle E. Ewing, Inf.-Res., on active duty with the CCC until March 24, 1938, is amended so as to continue him on active duty until Feb. 12, 1938. Capt. Earle E. Ewing, Inf.-Res., having reported at this headquarters in compliance with Paragraph 3, Special Orders 284, Headquarters Ninth Corps Area, Presidio of San Francisco, Calif.,

Congress continued to study today at a secret session a plan for large purchases for the army and navy in accordance with President Arturo Alessandri's urgent message. In spite of the bolt of Left Wing members. from the Chamber of Deputies yesterday in an attempt to prevent a quorum,

Captain Heywood Walter Seton-Karr, explorer and artist, died in Paddington today at the age of 78. More than 200 museums in various parts of the world house collections of prehistoric implements found by him in Somaliland, Egypt and India.

Mr. and Mrs. M. Reed Machtley of Altoona, Pa., have announced to friends here the engagement of their niece, Miss Ethel J. Glasgow of Philadelphia, to Dr. Franklin E. Abel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank E. Abel of Yonkers, N. Y.

Despite extreme weakness in French exchange rates and an easier stock market, relative strength in Liverpool, Alexandria and Bombay sustained prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and the list ended unchanged to 4 points higher. Final trading in the January delivery before the expiration at noon today held the spot month within a narrow range as consumers fixed prices.
Moses Fox, president of G. Fox Co. and for many years a leading New England merchant, died today at his home, 1,040 Prospect Avenue, at the age of 87. Death was due to cerebral thrombosis.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey assigned two assistant district attorneys in his rackets bureau yesterday to an investigation of the throwing of sulphuric acid early Wednesday night into the face of Jack Roum, 34 years old, a shirt manufacturer, in the street near his home at 323 West Eighty-third Street. The victim,

The sudden indisposition of Rose Pauly, who had been expected to make her first appearance here as Ortrud in last night's performance by the Metropolitan of "Lohengrin," necessitated the appearance of Marjorie Lawrence in this part. Miss Lawrence had shown before last night her capacities as dramatic interpreter of the character.
Marion Davies was only a shadow on a movie screen to Clark Alvord, hard-rock miner of the Nevada hills, but he bequeathed to her the bulk of his small estate and named her one of its executors.

Dartmouth's basketball team defeated Providence College tonight, 39-28. The Green led from the start. With three minutes to go in the last period the referees were called upon to quell a free-for-all fight among members of both teams and resulted in Leo Ploski leaving the game with a blackened eye.

Many reservations have been made for the card party and tea for the benefit of the Sisters of the Good Shepherd to be given tomorrow afternoon by Mrs. Timothy A. Leary, wife of Supreme Court Justice Leary, at the Hyde Park Hotel.

THE LADY AND THE PANDA, by Ruth Harkness. (Garrick Evans, $2,60.) Adventure in China in quest of the giant panda, VICTORIAN CRITICS OF DEMOCRACY, by Benjamin E. Lippincott, (University of Minnesota Press, $3,75.) An analysis of arguments against democracy made by Carlyle, Ruskin, Arnold and others.

A men's fashion show was the closing event of the annual convention of the International Association of Clothing Designers at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night. Twenty-five young men modeled the clothes on a runway in the grand ballroom before an audience of more than 1,000 persons.

The report for 1937 of the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, to be made public today, shows net earnings of $28,216,026 before deduction for flood casualty loss, or $2.82 each on the combined 10,000,000 shares of common and Class B common stocks outstanding.

Leases for several large apartments were reported yesterday by brokers and agents. Mrs. Arthur Fowler and Mrs. Grafton Payne took a furnished penthouse suite of fifteen rooms and six baths in 580 Park Avenue, through Douglas L. Eliman Co., Inc.,

The French Popular Front, the union of Socialists, Radical Socialists and Communists, whose second Cabinet fell from power early this morning, had been in control of the government since June 4, 1936, when Leon Blum became the nation's first Socialist Premier. succeeded Albert Sarraut.

James Cagney and Grand National today signed papers abrogating their contract and the actor will report at Warners on Monday with "Boy Meets Girl," scheduled to go into production within a few days. Cagney relieved Grand National of all obligations under the agreement

Four representatives of the Fencers Club were among the eight New York district fencers to qualify for the semi-finals of the national junior epee championship tournament in eliminations at the New York A. C. last night.

The fair trade practice rules recently promulgated by the Federal Trade Commission for the popularpriced dress industry were approved by the Popular Priced Dress Manufacturers Group at a meeting last night at the Hotel McAlpin, but criticism was expressed of the inclusion in the rules of a fiber identification requirement.

Six New Bedford fishermen escaped from their sinking ship, the William S., in a blinding snowstorm in Nantucket Sound early today and rowed several miles before reaching haven in a Coast Guard station at Cos Cata, Nantucket Island.

Bendix Rome Appliances, Inc., will spend $1,000,000 in its 1938 advertising campaign, with a major portion of this budget being expended in the first four months of this year, Judson S. Sayre, vice president in charge of sales, announced yesterday.

The Marine Corps announced the following changes dated Jan. 10: LIEUTENANT COLONEL Winans, R., Fourth Marines, Shanghai, to Department of the Pacific, via the Chaumont, sailing Manila about Feb. 25. MAJORS Jones, B. G., from headquarters Marine Corps to duty Bureau of Ordnance, Navy Department, Washington.

The magic touch of Charley Kurtsinger apparently converted the selling plater, Pageboy, into a sort of War Admiral today, for the gelded son of The Porter surprised many persons by beating highly fancied stake horses in the featured Winter Haven Purse at Hialeah Park. Pageboy,
Professor Otto H. Warburg, eminent physiologist, Nobel Prize winner and director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, begs his friends here and abroad to be assured of his continued good health.

Frank P. Losey, 21, a student at Brown University, was believed critically injured this afternoon when he fell three stories from a loft in the Delta Tau Delta fraternity house. He was sent to the Rhode Island Hospital. It was feared the youth's back was broken.
Circuit Court Judge V. Claude Palmer, sitting as a Supreme Court Commissioner, held today that the classification of silicosis as an occupational disease did not bar a common law action for remedy.

The United States imported $487,406,000 more gold in 1937 than in the preceding year, the Department of Commerce announced today. Exports of gold increased to $46,020,000 in 1937 from $27,534,000 in 1936.
Mrs. Dodge Sloane entertained tonight with a dinner at Concha Marina, where Mrs. Frank Crocker of New York arrived today to be her guest.
Mrs. Herbert Gouverneur Ogden of New Milford, Conn., has announced to friends and relatives here the engagement of her daughter, Miss Glady Gouverneur Ogden, to Warren Jay Vinton of Washington. D. C.

France tonight is preparing to make an appeal to the United States and Britain, based on the three-power monetary accord, for assistance in checking the fall of the franc, which has been the signal for today's political crisis.

The New York Stock Exchange membership of Theodore V. D. Berdell has been transferred to Jacob Schonfeld at H. Hentz Co., that of Edward H. White Jr. to Francis X. Deery of Deery White and that of the late Alpheus C. Beane to John L. Julian of Fenner Beane.

Three american light cruisers will attend The ceremonies at the opening of he new British naval base at Singaore Feb. 14, the Navy Department announced today. Officials said that he visit would be made at the initation of the British Government.

A new decree bringing admission to the medical profession in line with the Nuremberg anti-Jewish laws provides that henceforth only such persons may be admitted as doctors or dentists who are of German or cognate blood.

Mrs. Margaret Green Dargan, an editor of House Garden magazine and an authority on decoration, was married here this morning to Colonel Frederick L. Devereux at the bridegroom's home in the presence of immediate relatives of the couple. They were attended by Miss Elizabeth Clark Devereux and Frederick L. Devereux Jr., children of Colonel Devereux by his former marriage.

Irwin Witty, N. Y. U. center, shot a basket from the corner of the court tonight with seconds to go to give his team a 43-42 victory over the Colgate quintet in an exciting game. Colgate appeared to have the game won, 42-41, until Witty sank the shot.

Two years ago Raymond Prisco, who has a lengthy criminal record and numerous aliases, was within twenty-four hours of being released from the Chenango County Jail, Norwich, N. Y., where he was serving a six-month sentence for violating the immigration laws.

Crime, the business recession and the "breakdown" of democracy were attributed to "the liquor traffic" by speakers at a meeting yesterday of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union in the Hotel McAlpin.

With the foreign exchange market in Paris closed, dealings in the franc here yesterday were less active than they had been on Thursday. The exchange rallied 5 1/3 points to 3.33 7/2 cents, thereby recovering more than half of its net loss in the previous day.

General Hugh S. Johnson will be the speaker at the annual banquet of the National Retail Dry Goods Association on the evening of Feb. 3 in the Hotel Pennsylvania, it was announced yesterday. His appearance will climax the five-day convention of the association, which begins Jan. 31.

Failure of a Senate committee to contact Lewis R. Glavis, former chief of the Interior Department's Investigation Service, caused postponement today of an inquiry into wire-tapping within the department.

N. E. Tarble has been appointed general sales manager of the James Barclay Company, a subsidiary of Hiram Walker-Gooderham Worts, Ltd. Mr. Tarble had been with the parent company as division manager for eight western States since March, 1936.

More than 200 entries will compete in seventeen horsemanship events at the annual midwinter riding competition today at the Kenilworth Riding Club in Rye. Children representing twenty-two schools from New York City, Connecticut, Massachusetts and Westchester County will ride, according to the announcement by Frank J. Carroll, manager of the club.
Stocks closed fractionally higher; turnover, 845,900 shares. United States Government bonds higher, Japanese issues strong, other groups irregularly lower; transactions, $6,997,325.

Training for his second American ring engagement and his first indoor effort here, Tommy Farr, Great Britain's heavyweight champion, yesterday went through a brisk drill at his Summit (N. J.) camp. He boxed seven rounds against three sparring partners.

Changes of ownership involving houses in Manhattan and the Bronx were announced yesterday. The Broadway Savings Bank sold to Reuben Coblens the five-story apartment house for nineteen families at 515 West 134th Street. The building occupies a plot 39.2 by 99.11 feet and is assessed at $43,000.

Miss Marguerite Hagner, daughter of Mrs. Randall Hagner, was married today to F. Moran McConihe, son of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm McConihe, all of Washington. The Rev. Oliver Hart of St. John's Church officiated.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14.-The Senate became involved in a complicated parliamentary situation late today after Southern Senators, continuing their filibuster against the Wagner-Van Nuys Anti-Lynching Bill, had warned that they would force record votes on amendments calculated to bring the racial issue to the fore.

Nicaragua received today its first shipment of armored cars, tanks, anti-aircraft guns, bomb throwers and artillery. President Anastasio Somoza believes that in two or three years Nicaragua will have a small but complete modern army.

The West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company and subsidiaries, for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, reported yesterday a net profit of $2,882,011 after depreciation, depletion, interest, loss on securities sold, provision for loss on miscellaneous investments,

While the total number of accidents, injuries and fatalities due to highway accidents in the city rose during 1937 over the previous year, the number of child fatalities (under 16 years of age) dropped during 1937 to the lowest figure in sixteen years.
A resolution proposing legislation to forbid the posting of political advertising along highways was adopted today by the State Association of County Highway Superintendents.

One sentence. in the telegram we received from Stuart, Fla., the other day spoke volumes. It indicated that sportsmen are recognizing the fact that the same thing can happen to our game fish that happened to the bison, and with even less excuse.

Harry L. Vibbard, Professor of Organ in the College of Fine Arts, Syracuse University, died this noon at his home after an illness of two months. He was 67 years old. Born in Limestone, N. Y., Professor Vibbard was graduated from Syracuse University in 1898 and two years later became a member of the Colleze of Fine Arts faculty.
The Most Rev. Yu Pin, Roman Catholic Bishop of Nanking, China, will celebrate tomorrow the 11 A. M. mass in the Roman Catholic Church of Notre Dame, Morningside Drive and 114th Street.

Sixty-six members of an alleged liquor ring, the leaders of which are said to have directed the operation of thirteen or more stills and the distribution of more than 650,000 gallons of alcohol, using a "prominent hotel" here as their headquarters, were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury.

Mr. and Mrs. J. Randall Creel gave a large dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza for Miss Marguerite Brokaw, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard C. Brokaw, and Charles Crocker whose marriage will take place on Jan. 27 at the home of the prospective bride's parents, 984 Fifth Avenue.

Special attention is being paid by business concerns to preliminary training of prospective salesmen and to the development of improved technique on the part of the regular sales force, according to a study of policies affecting salesmen published yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.
Michael V. Bonomo of New York was reelected president of the Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel at the closing session of its convention here today.

About 300 persons connected with the world of Broadway attended a luncheon at the Astor Hotel yesterday in honor of Louis Sobol, chronicler of their activities, in recognition of his work in enlisting support for the New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities.
Insurgent bombing planes today were reported to have destroyed an entire train bringing up government reinforcements to the Teruel front in Eastern Spain.

With the passing of the old St. Andrews Hotel, at the northwest corner of Broadway and Seventysecond Street, which is being demolished to make way for a new taxpayer building, former occupants of stores in the hostelry have been forced to seek new quarters.

Last February when the Bird brothers' gang robbed the Lorain Street Bank of $18,866, Miss Mary Probala, 28, ran into a washroom and stayed. When three robbers entered today she followed her original impulsebut saved the bank $30.000 in cash.

An official of the Federal Trade Commission said today there had been a decided increase of interest in an established form of government-business cooperation, the trade agreement conference to eliminate unfair trade practices. Such agreements now govern nearly 200 industries.

While 250 diners waited for their Friday evening fish and sea food, fifty-three waiters, bus boys and kitchen workers employed at the Oyster Bay, on Eighth Avenue between Forty-second and Forty-third Streets, walked out on strike at 6:30 o'clock last night in protest against the dismissal or a cook on New Year's Eve.

Queens University won its first home game in the International Intercollegiate Hockey League tonight, defeating the University of Montreal, 8--4. The winners netted six in the initial period and two in the final.

Colonel Edward H. R. Green, son of Hetty Green, had a gross estate of more than $40,000,000 when he died at Lake Placid in June, 1936, according to the first formal appraisal to be made public, which was introduced in evidence yesterday at a hearing in the Hotel Roosevelt before John S. Flannery, special master for the United States Supreme Court.

A foreign trade zone in the Greenville district of Jersey City, between the Black Tom and the Fairmont areas, was predicted today by Wilbur Tietjen, chief engineer of the American Foreign Trade Zones, Inc. Mr.

After he had held a Brooklyn housewife in $500 bail for the Court of Special Sessions on a charge of permitting her home to be used for gambling, Magistrate Solomon in the Flatbush court yesterday remarked: "I am happy to hold this woman and I hope that she is convicted."
The stock market did little more than mark time yesterday. Prices fluctuated within narrow limits and finished irregularly higher, although the gains in most instances amounted only to fractions.
China will continue to meet promptly the service on her foreign and internal loans, Premier and Finance Minister H. H. King announced here yesterday.
Charles Alfred Scoville, former assistant cashier of the East River Savings Bank of New York, died today at his home, 13 Hillside Avenue, at the age of 68.

Extension of the State Unemployment Insurance Law to include within its coverage between 150,000 and 200,000 persons whose salaries of more than $3,000 have heretofore prohibited them from receiving any benefits was advocated in a bill introduced today by Senator Dunnigan of the Bronx, majority leader. A companion measure was submitted in the lower house by Assemblyman Killgrew, Manhattan Democrat.

Although all classifications declined last month, the drop in total newspaper advertising was smaller than in November, according to Media Records measurements of fifty-two cities. With linage amounting to 122,295,404, the decline was 6.5 per cent in December, as against 9.3 per cent in November.

An order requiring Samuel D. Goldie and Samuel Mussman, securities dealers, to appear with all records of their dealings for examnation in Supreme Court next Friday was issued yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Richard P. Lydon, on the complaint of Attorney General Bennett.

Renewed lively discussion In certain sections of the Swedish and German press concerning the highly strategical importance of the Aaland Archipelago-the entrance to the Gulf of Bothnia between Finland and Sweden-in the event of a Russo-German war is annoying official Finnish circles.

Central Park West, 221-6, 152.2x175 x irreg; trust mtg pursuant to the terms of plan of reorganization; Alden Hotel Corp, Manfred Messner, pres., to president and directors of the Manhattan Co, 40 Wall St. trustee, due Feb 7, 1957, 3 per cent to 5 per-cent: bond issue. $2,599,200. Ave D, 78. 20.6x100; Sara Giberstone to Wendel Foundation (a corp), 45 Wall St. p m, 3 years, 5 per cent; $1,500. 8th Ave. 681-5, 60x100;

The killing of Isadore Frank, wealthy poultry dealer, in front of his home at 733 Alabama Avenue, in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, Thursday night was definitely termed a hold-up murder yesterday by police and Assistant District Attorney William E. McCarthy. Two men were being sought.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: The controversy over the foul blow in the recent Steele-Apostoli bout shows the need for a revision of the no-foul rule in New York. The intelligent action of Referee Donovan appears to have been contrary to the rules but his decision to halt the bout until Steele recovered was a sensible move.

Accused of appropriating $2,555 of church funds for his own use and falsifying records, Alexander Flandreau, 50 years old, a bookkeeper employed by the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island, with offices at 170 Remsen Street, Brooklyn, was arrested last night on a charge of grand larceny. He was held in Brooklyn police headquarters.

The past year marked a renaissance in tennis which should continue throughout 1938. The winning of the Davis Cup, emblematic of the international team championship, proved a stimulus which should have far-reaching effects upon the game for several years to come.
Announcement has been made to friends here of the engagement of Miss Jean Underworth North, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Thompson North of Glendon, Harrington Sound, Bermuda, to E. Coghlin Gibbons.

Legislative activities of the General Federation of Women's Clubs will remain in status quo until May, it was indicated today at the session of the board of directors at headquarters here, due to the impending expiration of the administration of Mrs. Robert A. Campbell Lawson of Tulsa.

The Real Estate Board of Newark will hold the first dinner meeting of the year on Thursday, Jan. 20, in the Newark Athletic Club. E. Morgan Barradale, assistant general manager of the Port of New York Authority, will be guest speaker. Joel L. Schlesinger will preside.

Max H. Schwartzer, Bertha Beckwith, Nathan Schwartzer, in 333 Central Park West; William Beck, in 945 West End Ave; Edwin M. Hartley, in 250 W 24th St; Miriam Gzibeck, in 157 W 73d St; Seymour Schainoug, in 215 W 91st St; Byrne Bow-man, Inc., broker.

Despite no-parking rules, the traffic situation in New York City remains acute. Suppose we think of it in terms of people rather than of vehicles. The Fifth Avenue Coach Company furnishes some illuminating figures.

The applications necessary for accomplishment of the merger of eight subsidiaries of the Cleveland, Cincinnati, Chicago St. Louis, or Big Four Railroad, into the parent company, plans for which were announced about a month ago by the New York Central, were filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission by the New York Central and the Bie Four.
The Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to borrow $1,000,000 for six months at 3 per cent from the First National Bank of New York.

The Harvard Club and the Crescent A. C. remained tied for first place in the Metropolitan League Class C squash tennis competition as a result of triumphs yesterday. The Harvard aggregation defeated the City A. C., 5-0, while the Crescents subdued the Yale Club, 4-1. The Columbia Club recorded a 3-to-2 triumph over the Bayside T. C., and the Princeton Club turned back the New York A. C., 3-2, in other matches.

In the face of the industrial recession, radio stations affiliated with the National, Columbia and Mutual Broadcasting Systems have contracted for the employment of more than 1,000 additional musicians and for an increase in the stations' musical wage budgets of $2,000,000 a year, Joseph N. Weber, president of the American Federation of Musicians, announced last night.

Practical arrangements intended to simplify aeronautical relations between this country and Canada have been worked out by the conference of experts which has been meeting here this week. The recommendations which will be presented to the two governments cover these subjects:

The history-making trial of litigation between eighteen private utility corporations and the Tennessee Valley Authority will end when counsel complete arguments tomorrow before a three-judge court which has been hearing the case since Nov. 15.

Daily average sales of general merchandise in small towns and rural areas for December were about 3 per cent below December, 1936, when rural sales were the largest on record, according to estimates of the Department of Commerce, made public today.

Establishment of a standard form of contract for the sale of rayon and silk greige goods is the principal objective of a new trade association to be formed by selling with agents for mills making such fabrics, it was learned yesterday.

Thomas Bayley Russum, superintendent of the New Jersey New York Railroad until that line merged with the Erie, died today in the Elizabeth General Hospital, where he was taken Tuesday following a fall. His age was 89.

Trial of a $1,049,978 suit brought by the reorganization trustees of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway against Speyer Co. and W. J. Seligman Co. and Edward M. Brown, former chairman of the board of the road, is scheduled to begin on Monday in Supreme Court before Justice Louis A. Valente.

General Sessions Judge John J. Freschi in a ruling yesterday indicated his belief that the Appellate Division's recent appointment of Archibald P. Watson, former Corporation Counsel, as County Clerk of New York had not been invalidated by the fact that he already was a member of a lunacy commission, appointed to examine Robert Irwin, sculptor, in the so-called triple Gedeon murder.

The Shanghai customs administration today issued figures showing an increase in exports during 1937, despite nearly six months of hostilities between China and Japan, compared with the preceding year.

Details of bank loans, of recent changes in minor subsidiaries and of the current status of newsprint arrangements between subsidiaries are recorded in a report filed by the International Paper Company with the Securities and Exchange Commission and made public yesterday at the New York Stock Exchange.

Members of society from both sides of the East River joined last night at a dinner dance in the Starlight Roof of the WaldorfAstoria for the benefit of the Speedwell Society. Inspired by the large number of debutantes in this year's group whose families have long been identified with Brooklyn society,
James Fergusson McElhone, veteran newspaper man of Washington and New York, died yesterday at his home, 415 West 115th Street, after a brief illness. He was 71 years old.

John W. Hanes, formerly a partner in Charles D. Barney Co. of New York and the first member of a Stock Exchange firm to be appointed to the Securities and Exchange Commission, began his duties as a commissioner today.

A future of economic progress was predicted for the South by political and business leaders here today at the dedication of the first unit of a $9,000,000 pulp mill as part of exercises marking "Florida Industries Day."
