The old Astoria Silk Works in Long Island City, a one-story building containing about 35,000 square feet of area, has been sold by the creditors to the Metropolitan Electric Company, manufacturers of switch boxes and metal specialties, through the C. Grant Keck Organization, broker.

We should be grateful to William E. Dodd for his courageous speech yesterday and to THE NEW YORK TIMES for reporting it in full. Such utterances are needed to awaken the country to the situation today, to our responsibility under it, and to the need of prompt, vigorous and whole-hearted cooperation with right-minded nations.

Several hundred Winter sports d enthusiasts, weighed down with unwieldy kits and elongated hickory runners, left by snow trains from Grand Central Terminal last night for popular skiing centers in the northlands.

While some stores managed to beat last- year's figures, the average of department store trade here showed a decline for the week. The showing, however, was better than anticipated earlier and for the half month ending today sales are not expected to show more than a drop

Dr. R. Thomas Alexander, chairman of New College since the establishment of the experimental teacher-training division of Columbia University six years ago, will leave his post on June 1, it was announced yesterday, to give his full time to the department of normal school education of Teachers College, with which he has been affiliated.

Rocks of refined copper in the United States, exclusive of those at consumer plants and warehouses, at the end of December amounted to 259,908 tons, compared to 221,676 at the close of November, an increase of 38,232 tons, according to the Copper Institute.
Former Representative Clement C. Dickinson, a Democrat, died here today at the age of 88 years. He saw Jefferson Davis inaugurated President of the Confederacy in 1862.
William P. Wood, prominent in the textile business for more than twenty-five years, died today at his home at the age of 73. He had been retired since 1926.

Ray Born, former Atlantic County UnderSheriff; Louis Kissel, described as a confidential aide and bodyguard of Enoch L. Johnson, Atlantic County Treasurer and Republican leader, and Leo J. Levy, former private investigator in the Atlantic City Mayor's office, were indicted by a Federal grand jury here today on charges of conspiracy to violate the Mann Act.

Wholesale priced declined again in the week ended on Jan. 8, the Bureau of Labor Statistics has announced. The index, based on the 1926 average, fell to 80.8 from 81.0 on Jan. 1, and compared with 85.2 on Jan. 9, 1937. A sharp drop in the market prices of foods was said to be largely responsible.
Herman Elsas, a leader in the paper industry for many years, died yesterday afternoon in his office, 11 West Forty-second Street. Mr. Elsas, who was 73 years old, lived at 610 Park Avenue.

If news from Paris is being watched with keen interest in this country, it is not only because of the important role which French business plays in the world economic situation and the traditional friendship of Americans for the French people.

After Stanley M. Isaacs, Borough President of Manhattan, had reported that the plans for the unfinished sections of the East Side Drive needed further study, the Board of Estimate voted yesterday to refer the project to the City Planning Commission, which will hold hearings on it before submitting its report.

A collection of miniature china, glass, silver and furniture brought $3,295 yesterday at the Parks-Bernet Galleries, Inc., at a session of the auction of the property of the late Mr. and Mrs. Jay F. Carlisle from their country home, Rosemary, at East Islip, L. I. To date the sale has brought $97,359.50. The buyer of the miniature items was Ruby Ross Wood.

An all-star combination of registered A. A. U. basketball players will tour South American countries during February and March, with sixteen games being contested under the supervision of the governing court body of Brazil, it was announced yesterday.

A delegation representing industry, finance and labor spent an hour with President Roosevelt this morning and told him that the New Deal's policy must be crystallized and the nation assured of its intentions.

Owing to a marked shortage of beef, which began to be felt early this week, the government has ordered cattle dealers to keep a reserve corresponding to 3 per cent of the total slaughtered in the previous six months.

The Neediest Cases Fund reached $300,904.05 yesterday with the addition of $267, contributed by fifteen donors. A gift of $100 from an anonymous contributor who signed merely as "J. A.," was the largest in the group.

Cruising into the home stretch after a merry but fatiguing week for all hands as well as for the 100,000 or more spectators, the National Motor Boat Show will close its doors for 1938 tonight at 10:30 in Grand Central Palace.

President Roosevelt indicated today that abolition of all holding companies was his ultimate objective, adding taht it mattered not whether they existed in the public utility or other fields or whether they were top or intermediate concerns.

In a telegram sent today from Miami Beach, Fla., Thomas A. Brogan of Yonkers branded as "ridiculous" the charges made in a Supreme Court suit here that he and others had defrauded the widow of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer of a Yonkers brewery.

President Leon Cortes Castro today denied a report from Managua which stated that there was a secession movement under way in the Province of Guancaste. President Cortes said that there is much political activity in Guancaste because of the coming elections, which are not proscribed in Costa Rica.
Government scientists made a little correaction in the age of the ocean today. They say it is anywhere from 140,000,000 to 340,000,000 years older than had been estimated.

TOWARD A WORLD CHRISTIAN FELLOWSHIP, by Kenneth Scott Latourette. (Edward W. Hazen Foundation, 50 cents.) This is the fifth volume in the series of "Hazen Books on Religion," the purpose of which is to present in compact and inexpensive form a number of the "best available interpretations of the Christian philosophy as a guide to Christian living today."

The New York Public Library will offer an unusual opportunity to see some of the world's earliest and rarest illustrated books in a show which will be opened today and continue through March. The collection has been arranged in the main exhibition room of the building at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

Mrs. Sophie Herman, widow of Bernard Herman and for many years a social worker in New York, died yesterday at the Marsailles Hotel after a six months' illness at the age of 67. Mrs. Herman was active in the Harlem Hebrew Day and Night Nursery, the Babette Marcus Society and the Ladies League of the Hebrew National Orphan's Home.

Retail prices of meats have dropped from 4 to 25 per cent since the early part of December, fruits have gone down about 20 per cent since the holidays and vegetables have declined 10 per cent in the came period, according to reports of chain-store prices yesterday.

An invitation to "become the guest" of the people of New York was presented yesterday by Magistrate Solomon, in the Flatbush Court, ,Brooklyn, to Earle Pickerel, 34 years old, in the form of a sentence of four months in jail.

The gold Morris medal of the Royal Astronomical Society has been awarded to Dr. William Hammond Wright, director of Lick Observatory, for his studies of the spectra of gaseous nebulae and novae and for his work on the photography of planets in light of different colors.

President Roosevelt today received a frank appeal from a group representing industry, labor and finance that he enunciate as soon as practicable a "policy of government" and, in the interest of speedy economic recovery, put an end to apparently conflicting statements of some administration spokesmen on questions affecting the national welfare.

Objections to the railroads' request for a 15 per cent increase in freight rates were filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission by business interests from Missouri, Indiana, Illinois, Ohio, Michigan, Tennessee and Pennsylvania. It has been estimated the proposed increase would yield the railroads $460.000.000 annually.

The Fascist Powers are easily pleased with the Danubian States these days. Italy boasts that a "great diplomatic triumph" was won at Budapest this week in the conversations with the representatives of Austria and of Hungary; and Germany, though not present at the conference, displays its "satisfaction" with the results.

Rallying in the fourth quarter, Regis High School conquered the Brooklyn Cathedral Prep five, 2724, in a non-league contest on the losers' court yesterday. It marked the sixth straight triumph and the eleventh in twelve starts this season for Regis.

B. Charney Vladeck, chosen as majority leader of the City Council by the Labor-Republican-Fusion coalition Tuesday, established his office at City Hall yesterday in the room formerly used by Alderman Frank A. Cunningham, chairman of the Aldermanic finance committee.

The Greek freighter Aspasia sent out an S 0 S early this morning reporting that her chief officer and one other member of the crew had been lost overboard when the bridge was washed away. An earlier report stated that the ship was leaking badly in the bunkers and engine room.

John J. Campbell, 28 years old, of 244 Monroe Street died of head injuries received early this morning while being arrested with his father George Campbell, 48, on charges of disorderly conduct. The son fell to the street and struck his head while Patrolman James McCabe of the Clinton Street station was attempting to take him into custody.

Bolstered by heavy foreign buying, the machine tool index, compiled by the National Machine Tool Builders Association, reached 142.7 last month, a rise of 10 per cent compared with November, the assoelation announced yesterday.

The generous personal contribution of $25,000 by Alfred P. Sloan, announced this week, to set up traffic safety awards as a tangible expression of "his high personal regard for Paul G. Hoffman, president of the Automotive Safety Foundation, and for Mr. Hoffman's safety activities over a period of years" is aimed in the right direaction.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, incorporated in Delaware, and its domestic affiliates announced yesterday that they would put into effect immediately a reduction of 15;000 barrels daily in the amount of crude oil to be run through their stills.

There are three closings tonight, one on Broadway and two the property of the Federal Theatre Project. "Yr Obedient Husband," which arrived at the Broadhurst on Monday, goes at the end of eight performances. (Apparently Mr. March and his family can take it.

Today's major events: "La Boheme," afternoon, "Otello," evening, Metropolitan Opera House; Philharmonic-Symphony Youth Concert, Carnegie Hall, 11 A. M.; Josef Lhevinne, pianist, Carnegie Hall, afternoon; Alexander Culbertson, violinist, Carnegie Hall, evening;

Declaring that the brutal method of the defendant in robbing a woman left him "no alternative," County Judge James M. Barrett yesterday sentenced Edward Sienkiewicz, 30 years old, of 2,927 Coddington Avenue, the Bronx, to a jail term of ten to thirty years for first-degree robbery.
Helen Hayes's recreational and experimental debut as a Shakespearean actress with Portia as her role, made at today's special matinee performance in the Erlanger Theatre, proved to be a happy event.

Mrs. H. Torriente's Swap, heavily played favorite as the result of two previous easy victories, came through as expected today in the mile-and-seventy-yard feature at the Fair Grounds. Much as in his other races, the 5-year-old son of Boot to Boot came from off the pace and drew

The marriage took place today at the Norwegian Legation of Miss Alice King Gade, daughter of the former Norwegian Minister to Brazil, F. Herman Gade, and his American wife, the former Alice Garfield King of Chicago, to Egil Holmbo, Norwegian vice consul at Reykjavik.

Adams Express Company ten-year 4 1/4 per cent unstamped debentures, due in 1946, have been stricken from the listing and registration on the New York Stock Exchange. The Stock Exchange has received notice of changes in the collateral deposited under the El Paso Southwestern Railroad Company first and refunding mortgage.

Charles E. Lester, former president of Hartwell Lester, Inc., 21 West Street, wholesale coal dealers, died Wednesday in Lakeland, Fla., of pneumonia, according to word received here yesterday. He had lived there for about eight years. His age was 66.

William Dawson, newly appointed United States Minister to Uruguay, yesterday praised Uruguay as "having much in common with the United States in culture, politically and in tradition" in an informal address at a luncheon given in his honor by the Pan-American Society at the India House, 1 Hanover Square.
Japanese announced today their forces in Shantung Province had driven through strategic Tsining southward toward the Lung-Hai Railway and had occupied Tangchiakuo.

The National Federation of Temple Sisterhoods closer a two-day silver jubilee convention today with a meeting of the national executive board, and a board luncheon at which Mrs. Leon L. Watters of New York, president of the sisterhoods, spoke informally.
The National Revenue Deapartment reported today that Canada's domestic exports for the first nine months of the fiscal year 1937-38 amounted to $854,364,470, compared with $815,821,725 in the
The new nine-story headquarters building of the Liberty Mutual Insurance Company, occupying a block of frontage at 175 Berkeley Street in Boston, Mass., was opened on Thursday.
Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Jan. 8 amounted to 552,314 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

Admiral William Oswald Story, who served forty-one years in the Royal Navy before retiring, died today at his residence. He was 78 years old. A navy man from the days of sailing ships, Admiral Story retired on promotion to rear admiral in 1912.

An agreement calling for a permanent 5-cent bus fare in this city has been reached with the Third Avenue Railway System, it was announced today by Mayor Denton Pearsall Jr. The arrangement requires the city to cancel each year about $2,000 of the income and franchise taxes collected from the company, but will not affect real estate taxes or a special 1 per cent levy on income for home relief, it was said.

Several small residential properties changed hands in the Brooklyn realty deals announced yesterday. Fay Feinberg bought the threestory brick building at 370 Avenue U, on the corner of East First Street, from Salvatore Ruvollo for cash above a mortgage of $22,500 held by the Brooklyn Savings Bank. There are four apartments and four stores in the structure.

The Atlantic Seaboard Corporation of Wilmington, Del., and the Huntington Gas Company, Charleston, W. Va., registered today with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Public Utility Holding Company Act. Both companies are subsidiaries of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation, which registered yesterday with the SEC.
On the complaint of detectives guarding the Duke and Duchess of Windsor, French police arrested today a man accused of attempting to penetrate into the Windsors' apartments at the Hotel Meurice here.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals only $5,188,757, as compared with the revised total of $16,539,800 for this week. Loans of one State and forty-eight municipalities will be up for award.
Helen Strickland, whose name for more than sixty years was wellknown on the American stage, died on Thursday night in Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 75 years old.

A wage contract covering about 3,000 of the unlicensed personnel employed on seventy-two vessels of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey was signed by the company yesterday afternoon with the National Maritime Union. The contract will become effective on April 1 and remain in effect one year.

The annual Junior League cabaret dinner dance, held tonight in the Bellevue-Stratford ballroom, was attended by more than 500 subscribers. The proceeds from the event will go to the Children's Heart Hosipital.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The editorials published in THE NEW YORE TIMES of Jan. 8 and 9 raise one of the most important questions relating to the entire problem of social security and the possibilities under the present Social Security Act.

The United Corporation showed in its annual report for 1937, made public yesterday, a net income of $10,692,598, an increase of $422,740 over 1936, and consolidated cash income of $11,293,241, a gain of $337,633.

Arthur N. Bloch of Speyer Co. was unanimously elected president of the Corporation Bond Traders Club of New York at the annual dinner and meeting of the organization last night at the Hotel Roosevplt.

Following is the portion of the text of the Ways and Means Subcommittee's report which deals with the undistributed profits tax: On the basis of the facts, your subcommittee believes that the principle of the undistributed profits tax is sound and should be retained.

The Erie Railroad informed the New York Stock Exchange yesterday of more defaults on its obliga tions. Defaults in interest on six of its bond issues, aggregating $122,000,000 of principal, were disclosed in the Erie's statement to the Exchange.

The Department of Agriculture reported today that farm wages had been reduced about 8.5 per cent in three months, or more than twice the average seasonal amount of recent years. Rates for work by the day without board ranged on Jan. 1 from $3 in California to 80 cents in South Carolina and averaged $1.61 for the country.

The flotation of $30,000,000 of Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., 3 1/2 per cent debentures lifted the total of new bond financing this week to $42,981,000, the largest volume for any period since the week ended Oct. 8, last year, when $113,224,300 in new issues wer placed on the market.

Whitaker Ray, well-known theatre man, who for many years was associated with the Erlanger interests and Jed Harris, died yesterday morning at the Cumberland Hospital in Brooklyn, of a heart attack. He had been ill for only a few ley hours, his friends said. He was 55 years old.

Mrs. Dorothy Crowell Addis, widow of John Stanley Addis, treasurer of the State of Connecticut, died yesterday at New Milford, Conn., after a long illness, according to word received here. She was 40 years old.

Wide price reductions in January clearances helped retail sales this week, but volume was held to an average of 2 to 5 per cent above the preceding week and 2 to 6 per cent over the same week last year, according to the weekly review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

William Donner Roosevelt, 5year-old grandson of President and Mrs. Roosevelt, took charge of his grandmother's welcome to the city today. Mrs. Roosevelt came here to address a meeting of women's clubs on the United City Charity campaign.

THE appointment of a new head football coach at Penn certainly stirred up interest. From the college football standpoint, Penn is in the big league. Head coach at Franklin Field is a big job. So there was a lot of wondering going on in intercollegiate circles and suddenly the name of the new Penn coach was hurled on the air. It was hard to catch at first.

The committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange has addressed to the presidents of all corporations having securities listed on the Exchange a letter advising them of its requirements as to the treatment of inventories in their annual and interim reports.

Justice Willis Van Devanter, recently retired member of the United States Supreme Court, who is sitting now in Federal District Court here, departed yesterday from the usual procedure of other judges in this district.

King Levinsky's "roundhouse right" served him well as he made his Chicago debut as a wrestler .tonight. Before 2,000 fans at Marigold Gardens, Levinsky defeated Pat Murphy of Chicago in 1 minute 8 seconds of a half-hour time-limit affair.

The death of Captain Nikolai Evdokimoff, claimant of the world's record for high parachute jumps-26,575 feetwas announced today. The cause of his death was not stated. Evdokimoff was credited with having made 324 leaps.
The Fordham swimming team scored its first victory of the season yesterday by defeating Brooklyn College in the Fordham pool, 52-19. It was the second meeting of the two schools.

Charles P. Howard, president of the International Typographical Union, denied tonight in a telegram to John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, that he had changed his attitude in opposing certain actions of the American Federation of Labor. Mr. Howard is secretary of the C. I. O.
With Harry Frost setting the pace with a pair of goals in the middle period, the Hershey Bears defeated the Bronx Tigers last night at the New-York Coliseum before about 2,500 fans.

Mrs. Evelyn Pengle, 27 years old, of 412 East 145th Street, the Bronx, who, with two Long Beach policemen, was convicted of extortion, was placed on probation yesterday for fifteen years on condition that she never visit this city during that time.

Formation of the largest union of college teachers in the country was announced yesterday by Professor Edwin Berry Burgum of New York University, first president of the new organization. To be known as the New York College Teachers Union, it numbers among its members more than 750 teachers of the major colleges in the metropolitan area.

Charging that the Chamberlain government in allowing the country to "drift toward a cataclysmic war," Herbert Morrison today announced plan's for an intensive "peace and security" drive by the Labor party.

Representatives of dozens of Bronx fraternal and religious groups which were operating bingo for charitable causes visited or telephoned Samuel J. Foley, District Attorney of the Bronx, yesterday to learn if they could complete games which were already advertised and for which prizes had been purchased.

The United States in 1937 drank [Pound]l,000,000 worth more of British spirits than in the previous year, the Board of Trade estimates showed today. Exports of whisky and gin to the United States in 1937 were valued at [Pound]6,562,104, compared with [Pound]5,322,735 in 1936.

Councilman Hugh Quinn of Queens, storm center in the fight for control over the City Council, maintained an open mind yesterday on the matter of casting his vote for the election of Councilman James A. Burke as vice chairman, while the civic pressure on him to do so increased substantially.

Since the town became convinced of the seriousness with which John Barrymore is viewing his revived career, assignments are being thrust upon him at every hand. Today Metro engaged him for the role of Louis XV in Norma Shearer's "Marie Antoinette."
John Golden's production of the Rachel Crothers comedy "Susan and God," in which Gertrude Lawrence is currently starred at the Plymouth Theatre, will be published by Random House next Monday.

Federal Judge Patrick T. Stone today freed one more defendant in the Federal Government's gasoline price-fixing case after all testimony was completed. He granted a motion for a directed verdict of acquittal for James F. Nagle of Tulsa, Okla., branch office manager of the Skelly Oil Company.

Continuing the response of the Fashion Originators Guild of America, Inc., to the charges of restraint of trade brought by the Federal Trade Commission, Albert M. Post, executive director of the guild organization, denied yesterday that its program limited the

Tentative agreement by representatives of the Governors of five Eastern States to join in combating a Southern freight rate differential, which has been asked of the Interstate Commerce Commission by eight Southern States, was reached yesterday afternoon at a conference in the office of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., 80 Centre Street.

The Council of Reich Representations of Jews in Germany, representing all Jewish organizations, has just addressed to the Reich Government an urgent appeal against further restrictions on Jewish economic activities, which threaten to throw the remaining Jewish population in Germany upon public charity.

The most serious obstacle against a prompt resumption of business recovery is the existence of overlarge inventories of materials and finished goods in the warehouses of thousands of factories and dealers throughout the country, according to the current business bulletin of the Cleveland Trust Company, which is edited by Leonard P. Ayres, vice president.

Marcel Hubert, French 'cellist, familiar to American concertgoers since his debut here four seasons ago, was heard again last night at Town Hall. He played a program that displayed impartially his virtues and shortcomings as musician and instrumentalist.

The National Rifle Association gave first place to William Woodring of Alton, Ill., in its annual ratings today. The other ratings in their order were: Willis Kenyon, Marshalltown, Iowa; Dr. Russell Gardner, Troy, Ohio; William Patriquin, Ernest, Pa.; H. D. Allyn, Springfield, Mass.; Charles Hamby, Atlanta; Edward Brown, Alton, Ill.; O. E. Crockett, Logansport, Ind.; Marshall Grosskopf, Marion, Wis.; Merle Israelson, Akron, Ohio; Bernard Selby, Newark, Ohio.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The movement of wool has been slow, both at the Eastern seaboard markets and in the West. Some ber fine and half-blood worsted wools have changed hands at about steady rates.
The Chorus Equity Association, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, won its first contract yesterday in its campaign to organize night club chorus girls.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Eunice Leah Levy, daughter of Mr. Alfred A. Levy of this city, to J. Philip Magill, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip R. Magill, also of Bridgeport. Miss Levy is a graduate of the Fannie A. Smith School here and the Philadelphia Institute of Technology. Mr.

What is a street? Business men in the garment-trade area want more non-parking streets. In this they differ from business men in the shopping centers, who are inclined to look askance at parking restrictions.
The weekly bulletin of the State Banking Department announced today receipt of an application from the Lemoyne Finance Company of Syracuse to transact business as a licensed tender.

The interesting Lawrenceville School trio, making its first appearanoe of the season here, is one of the features of the triple indoor polo bill tonight at Squadron A Armory in Manhattan. Lawrenceville, which has dominated interscholastie ranks in recent years, will meet the Cheshire Academy riders in the second match of the attractive card.

Harvard started defense of its Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming Association championship by defeating Pennsylvania in the Hutchinson Pool tonight, 57-18, and also wiped out three records for the tank.
Joe DiMaggio headed eastward today on what he described as a pleasure trip, but he is expected to visit Colonel Jacob Ruppert for a verbal tussle over his 1938 baseball contract.

Dr. Clement Burbank Shaw, vocalist and lecturer on opera, died here yesterday at Polyclinic Hospital after a long illness. He was 80 years old. Born at Creston, Ohio, Dr. Shaw was educated at Baldwin-Wallace College.
Three of China's once important military leaders have been retired from army commands, according to Chinese reports. They are Generals Yen Hsi-shan, Han Fu-chu and Feng Yu-hsiang.

The grave words of warning that the French are hearing from all sides are not too grave to describe their situation. France is again the nerve center of Europe and the crucial point of interrogation in a forest of question marks.
Member trading in round lots for their own accounts on the New York

A Manhattan College five that played with more fury than finesse carried mighty Temple all the way in a stirring battle at Madison Square Garden last night before losing, 45 to 38, before a crowd of 7,500.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey announced the appointment yesterday as an assistant district attorney of Louis A. Pagnucco, 32 years old, for the last seven years an official interpreter for the Court of General Sessions in the Italian, Spanish and French languages. Mr.

The report of the Northern States Power Company of Delaware and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Nov. 30, issued yesterday, shows a net income after expenses and charges, of $6,161,438, comparing with a net of $5,153,897 in the twelve months to Nov. 30, 1936.

Miss Dorothy Dawson Page, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Randolph Page of 127 East Sixty-second Street, was married to Andrew Gibson Curry of Hartsdale, N. Y., son of Mrs. Rufus Curry of Windsor, N. S., and the late Mr. Curry, yesterday afternoon in the home of her parents.

The engagement of Miss Mary Elizabeth Whitlock to Edward Sanderson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Spalding Sanderson of Waterbury, Conn., has been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. W. Melvin Whitlock of 77 Park Avenue.

Accused of operating a policy ring with an annual income of $1,500,000, Louis Weber, 39-year-old "policy king," and thirteen others were arraigned yesterday in Special Sessions Court, Brooklyn. They pleaded not guilty and Weber was held in $5,000 bail and the others in $1.000 bail each for trial Feb. 14.

Those of us who used to be children can learn a little about the puzzling creatures who have taken our places if we will give attention to the results of a survey just completed by the Boys Athletic League. For one thing, they like spinach.

Dr. Frederick C. Ferry, president of Hamilton College, at Clinton, N. Y., told 400 graduates last night at the seventieth annual dinner of the Alumni Association of New York at the Hotel Pennsylvania that Hamilton will profit by the current return to the humanities in college curricula, and asserted that the college had never undertaken vocational or-experimental "plans" of education. William M. Bristol Jr., chairman of the gymnasium campaign, announced that $253,932 gymnasium fund.

Definite and permanent abandonment of the policy of guaranteeing prices on rayon yarns was predicted yesterday after the announcement on Thursday by E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. of a new list on coarse deniers and discontinuance
Mr. and Mrs. William Wallis of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gayle Wallis, to Lauriston Adams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Everett Adams of Springfield and Adams, Mass.

A report recommending the complete revision and codification of the internal revenue laws, with special emphasis on changes in the present method of taxing corporations and investment profits, was presented today to the Ways and Means Committee by its subcommittee on taxation.

Although quotations for cotton in Bombay closed yesterday at the highest figures of the movement, a combination of commission-house profit-taking and hedging by spot interests carried prices on the Cotton Exchange here off 7 to 8 points.

With the approval of Bishop Benjamin M. Washburn of the Newark Episcopal Diocese, but with the disapproval of seven of the nine vestrymen, the Rev. William C. Kernan, rector of Trinity Church here, gave Roger N. Baldwin the opportunity of expressing his opinion of Mayor Hague at a special meeting in the parish hall tonight.

Controversy began today over an Anglican Church commission's lengthy report on religious doctrine, issued yesterday, which sets forth that one may reconcile the biblical account of the world's creation with evolutionary theories and that the Bible need not be taken as the judge of historical or scientific investigation in any field.

With high runs of 210 and 330 featuring his performance, Jake Schaefer yesterday defeated Welker Cochran in the ninth and tenth blocks of their 18.2 balkline billiard match at the Strand Academy and practically clinched the world title.

President Roosevelt, who called those newspaper men "softies" who complained of sleeping in heatless and leaking tourist cabins during a cold and wet overnight stop with him last Fall at Lake Crescent, Wash., carried the joke a step further today.

The Nassau County police clamped a lid of secrecy tonight on a day of intensified activity in the investigation of the murder of Mrs. Celinda Waite and a girl neighbor, in Elmont, L. I., last Wednesday night.
John Montague got into a legal sand trap today that cost him the right to use his adopted name.

United States exports of raw cotton to Japan in the five months ended on Dec. 31 were only 120,000 bales, valued at $6,897,000, compared with 781,000 bales, valued at $51,540,000, in the same period of 1936, the Deapartment of Commerce announced today.
Buoyancy in United States Government obligations and a fresh sinking spell in secondary and defaulted railroad issues were the outstanding features in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

Wayne Sabin of Hollywood, Calif., reached the final round of the Nautilus tennis tournament today with a victory over Frank Kovacs of Oakland, Calif., as officials here for the United States Lawn Tennis Association's annual meeting tomorrow looked on. The score was 6-3, 3-6, 6-0, 6-4.

John M. Allison, United States Consul at Nanking, has protested to the Japanese Embassy there against continued looting by Japanese soldiers in the former Chinese capital, he reported to the State Department today.

Cold and hungry and tired of dodging police, Chester L. Bassett, 34, a chauffeur, was on his way back to Waterloo, N. Y., tonight to face trial for the murder of his father, James Bassett, 72, in the burning of a farmhouse at Lyons, N. Y., on Tuesday.

A special memorial service commemorating the birthdays of Jacob H. Schiff and Felix M. Warburg, bankers and philanthropists, was held last night in the synagogue of the Jacob H. Schiff Center, 2,510 Valentine Avenue, the Bronx.

Severin Winterscheidt, 34 years old, of 64 Himrod Street, Brooklyn, a lieutenant of Fritz Kuhn in the Nazi movement centering around the German American League, was sentenced yesterday by Magistrate Peter Abeles to serve thirty days in jail for indecent exposure in the Pennsylvania Station.

I MET MY LOVE AGAIN, from Allene Corliss's novel, "Summer Lightning"; screen play by David Hertz; directed by Arthur Ripley and Joshua Logan; a Walter Wanger production; released by United Artists. At the Roxy.
Wall Street was wholly unprepared for the President's declaration yesterday in his press conference against "all" holding companies.

C. W. Kellogg, president of Edison Electric Institute and chairman of the board of Engineers Public Service Company, last night took issue with President Roosevelt on the latter's statement that "600,000,000 of holding company capital controls a $13,000,000,000 public utility industry," according to The Associated Press.

While women leaders mapped plans yesterday for their part in the forthcoming campaign to establish a new national foundation to combat infantile paralysis, Keith Morgan, head of the. Committee for the President's Birthday, charged New York City was "an absolute disgrace" in its inability to treat properly 30,000 known victims of the disease.

The entire slate of officers and directors of the Saratoga Racing Association has been re-elected for the coming year, it was announced yesterday. At the election of officers, held in New York City, George H. Bull was retained as president, F. S. von Stade as vice president and John A. Morris as secretarytreasurer.

Robert J. Keller, retired importer of dyestuffs and other chemicals, died yesterday at his home at 55 Ox Bow Lane here after a lingering illness. His age was 77. He was formerly president of the Geigy Company, Inc., with offices in New York and numerous other American cities, and had long lived in New York City.

With only twenty-four of the forty-two members present, the Republican State Committee voted 14 to 10 today to request the Legislature to make an immediate and thorough investigation of the 1937 Gubernatorial election in Hudson County.

Puffing the pipe of peace with their "dear uncles" the white men, Foolish Bear and Drags Wolf, two venerable elders of the Water Busters clan of the Gros Ventres Indians, reclaimed yesterday from the Museum of the American Indian the long-missing Sacred Bundle of Thunderbird skulls of their clan. As a result the hope of rain was strong again in North Dakota.

Covering twenty-nine holes in one over par, Charles H. Mayo Jr. of Long Beach, former Long Island amateur champion, overwhelmed John Cummings of Memphis, Tenn., 9 and 7, in the thirty-six hole final round for the annual midwinter golf championship at the Miami Country Club today.

Charles E. Mitchell, former chairman of the National City Bank of New York, heard his counsel describe him before the Supreme Court today as a man who "spent $30,000,000 during the panic of 1929 to stem the tide and protect the stockholders."

The Banco do Brasil and the American Chamber of Commerce have concluded an exchange agreement by which the bank, recognizing the United States as Brazil's best customer, puts that country in a position on the foreign exchange slate second to no other nation.

Cooperation with President Roosevelt "to marshal the full force of American business to insure recovery" was urged yesterday in a joint statement by David E. Moeser, president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, and Lew Hahn, general manager of the organization. The association has a membership of 5,800 retail stores throughout the country, having an annual sales volume in excess of $4,500,000,000.

CEHROMITE TEXTILE PRINTING CO., Inc., 252 W. 64th St.-Voluntary proceeding under Section 77B of the Bankruptcy Law, listing liabilities of $42,716 and assets of $15,815. IVANHOE ESTATES, INC., Operating the New Tumble Inn, 22 Holls Terrace, Yonkers-Voluntary -proceeding under Section 77B of the Bankruptcy Law, listing liabilities of $48,074 and assets of $59,578.

The ever growing popularity of skiing and Alpine Winter sunshine has led to the formation at Lausanne of a Swiss committee under Samuel Campiche with the aim of establishing a university in the high Alps.

An erect, gray-haired man walked about thoughtfully yesterday in the bare corridors and anterooms of the old Brick Presbyterian Church at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street and silently watched wrecking crews building a scaffold around the time-worn walls of the edifice.

Acting Governor Menendez Ramos today shifted the scene of the negotiations in the longshoremen's strike representatives and labor leaders parted as widely separated as ever. Significantly, however, the negotiations were not terminated.

With few exceptions, prices of commodity futures turned downward yesterday on the local exchanges. In the cash markets cocoa and wool tops moved higher, while wheat, corn, rye, oats, coffee, eggs, lard, tin, cotton and rubber were lower.

Although Germain G. Glidden, national amateur champion, advanced after a five-game match, two of the other seeded players were not so fortunate in their opening tests yesterday in the New York State squash racquets championship.

Captain Harry K. Savage of 97 South Elliott Place, Brooklyn, vice president of the Trend Realty Company, 331 Madison Avenue, died yesterday at St. Clair Hospital after a short illness at the age of 59.

John Stone Allen of 1,506 Union Street, formerly managing editor of The Schenectady Union-Star, died today in Ellis Hospital of pneumonia. He was 62 years old. Mr. Allen was to have had the leading role created by George M. Cohan in New York in "Ah, Wilderness," by Eugene O'Neill,

The marriage of Miss Henriette Charlotte Schuech von Glickhfelden, daughter of Colonel and Mrs. Robert Schuech von Glickhfelden of Vienna, to Albert Green Walker of this city and Syosset, L. I., took place yesterday afternoon at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Jarvis Cromwell, 159 East Sixty-first Street.

Harnet Corporation, Michael Harnstein, president, sold to the Feinet Corporation the twentyfamily apartment at 17-19 Van Reypen Street, Jersey City. The building occupies a plot 50 by 100 feet and was sold subject to a $51,500 mortgage.

The Peoples National Bank of Brooklyn announced yesterday a cash dividend of 75 cents a share on the common stock and a stock dividend of 61/4 per cent, both payable on Feb. 1 to shareholders of record of Jan. 11.

Less new legislation is being offered in this session of Congress than a year ago. Records disclosed today that only 216 bills have been introduced in the House since the session began Jan. 3, and 671 since the special session began Nov. 15.
Don Budge and Gene Mako of Cali doubles tennis title, today were defeated by Australia's Adrian Quist and Jack Bromwich, 6-0, 2-6, 7-5 6-2.

Charles Golden, 36 years old, of 127 Second Avenue, and Giuseppe Poggi, 18, of 224 East 103d Street, were freed of homicide charges yesterday by Magistrate Alexander Brough in Homicide Court. The police testified that neither was responsible for fatal motor accidents in which they were involved.

Insertion into the Independent Offices Appropriation Bill by Representative Woodrum of Virginia of what amounted to an "item veto" authorization for President Roosevelt raised a stormy sequel today when Mr. Woodrum's fellow Democrats started a movement to override him.

A severe reprimand was sent today by the Federal Communications Commission to the National Broadcasting Company for its broadcast Dec. 12 of the "Adam and Eve" feature by Mae West and Don Ameche, and another part of the same program in which the ventriloquist's dummy "Charlie McCarthy" played opposite Miss West.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles Suydam Cutting will give a dinner and dance tonight at the Essex Fox Hounds Club, Peapack, N. J., for the Hon. and Mrs. Michael S. Scott and Mr. and Mrs. Eads Johnson. Mr. and Mrs. Martin von Dehn will sail today on the Georgic to pass the rest of the Winter in Nassau.

DIE MEISTERSINGER--Opera in German in three acts and four scenes. Book and music by Richard Wagner. Conductor, Artur Bodanzky: stage director, Leopold Sachse. Presented at the Metropolitan Opera House.

At the tea hour this afternoon at the Everglades Club, John Charles Thomas sang on a special broadcast for the benefit of Good Samaritan Hospital, for which a drive for funds is now under way. Hugh Dillman, club president, was master of ceremonies.

Lawrenceville School gained its second hockey victory in as many starts today in Baker Rink, defeating the Peddie School sextet in a one-sided contest, 9-0. Lawrenceville scored in all three periods. Doug Bournique, Red and Black center, led the attack with five goals.
Flags on all State public buildings were ordered placed at half-staff today by Governor Lehman in honor of Albert Ottinger, former Attorney General of New York State, who died in New York Thursday.

A The birdie deuce on the thirty-eighth hole gave Jack Ryerson of. Cooperstown, N. Y., the annual Lake Worth golf championship at the Palm Beach Golf Club today. He defeated Harold Kaplow of East Orange, N. J.

Preliminary reports from ninety-two Class I railroads, representing 83.3 per cent of total operating revenues, show that in December they had estimated operating revenues amounting to $249,534,013, compared to $310,257,528 in the same month of

Pleas of not guilty on charges of first-degree murder were entered in General Sessions yesterday by counsel for Andrew Lunse, 23 years old, and Richard Delaney, 25, suspects in the shooting of Patrolman Frank E. Zaccor on Jan. 6 during a hold-up in McElroy's bar and grill in West Thirty-first Street.

Retail prices of "Old Grand Dad" and "Old Taylor" brand bottled-in-bond bourbon whiskies of the National Distillers Corporation will be reduced to $3.64 a quart locally as a result of reductions in wholesale prices announced yesterday by the company.

Governors Hoffman of New Jersey and Earle of Pennsylvania were the principal speakers and guests tonight at a banquet here held in connection with the dedication of the new toll bridge over the Delaware River between this city and Phillipsburg, N. J.

If it were just another double star, Epsilon Aurigae, the object of a fine study made by Dr. Otto Struve, director of Yerkes Observatory, and his associates, Drs. Kuiper and Stroemgren, would never have shared the front page with the war in China or the conferences which the President is holding with business men.
The Rev. H. Norman Sibley, the recently installed pastor of the University Heights Presbyterian Church, 181st Street and University Avenue, the Bronx, has received the gift of a Hanukkah candelabra.

The Rev. E. Humphrey Walz was installed last night as its pastor in the Second Presbyterian Church, Central Park West and Ninetysixth Street. Mr. Walz came from the pastorate of the Presbyterian Church, Oceanside, L. I.

Miss Isabelle Kirkpatrick Marckwald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Hunt Marckwald of this place, and Daniel Bushnell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Davis Bushnell of Montclair, N. J., were married here this afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church by the Rev. C. Malcolm Douglas, rector.

Miss Virginia Peugnet, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ramsey Peugnet of this place, was married to Morss d'Isay Lippincott, son of Mrs. J. Evans Lippincott of Cincinnati, this afternoon at the home of her parents. Mgr. Arthur J. Scanlan, rector of St. Joseph's Seminary in Dunwoodie, Yonkers.

Abolition of special "blue ribbon" juries on the grounds that such bodies are particularly chosen to be convicting juries and as such are not "capable of giving a fair trial in all cases," was advocated in the fourth annual report of the Judicial Council of the State of New York to the Legislature, made public here today by Leonard S. Saxe, executive secretary.
Exports of gold last week were valued at $5,000,552, all but $525 of which went to France, the Department of Commerce announced today.

Hector C. Bywater, the well-informed naval correspondent of The Daily Telegraph, states tonight that the report that Japan is building a group of superbattleships which will be the largest in the world is now confirmed.

The Ford Motor Company announced today that 10,000 employes laid off Dec. 23 would be returned to work Monday. During the lay-off period, the company announced that fewer than 25,000 of the 87,000 normally employed at the Dearborn plant were idle.
The Department of Agriculture called today for a reorganization of the nation's produce markets, crithcizing them as inefficient and the cause of unnecessarily high retail prices.

The Park Association of New York City, Inc., protested yesterday to Mayor La Guardia against two park encroachments planned by the Board of Education. The association objects, in a letter to the Mayor, dated Jan. 13, to the park sites chosen for the new building for Public School 33 in Chelsea Park and the auditorium for the new Benjamin Franklin High School. 309 East 108th Street.
Holmes Onderdonk, vice president of the Chicago Tribune Building Corporation and manager of The Tribune's real estate, died tonight in Passavant Hospital of pneumonia. He was 59 years old.

President Roosevelt was represented by Senators today as opposed to moves on their part to advance candidates for the Supreme Court vacancy, caused by retirement of Associate Justice Sutherland. Senators said that the President had indicated that he would be in no haste in making the selection, and that geographical considerations would prevail.

The collection of ancient Chinese sculptures formed by Edwin D. Krenn of Chicago, who for a number of years was associated with the late Mrs. Edith Rockefeller McCormick as her counselor in the purchase of art, brought $8,705 last night at auction at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc.

The current trend toward State legisolation regulating certain phases of business activity and conflicting with Federal regulations in the same fields, was criticized today by James F. Hoge, counsel of the Proprietary Association, in an address at the annual convention of the Pennsylvania Newspaper Publishers Association.

Three members of the Brazilian Highway Commission left a set of thirty-two maps for Mayor La Guardia at City Hall yesterday, showing the route of the 16,000-mile Pan American Intercontinental Highway from Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, to New York.

The statement of condition of the Discount Corporation of New York at Dec. 31, issued yesterday, showed total assets of $98,418,728, compared with $74,513,748 on Sept. 30, last. The corporation reported acceptance discounts of $5,567,874, against $4,877,903 a year before; United States Government security holdings of $89,319,073, against $66,365,083,

Miss Marion Martin, former Maine Senator and now assistant to the chairman of the Republican National Committee, made a plea yesterday afternoon for the reorganization of Republican clubs. She addressed more than 100 Republican club women in the auditorium of the Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street.

Praising the role of motion pictures in the development of adult education in this country, Dr. NichIolas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, declared yesterday that they can be made important instruments in the molding of public opinion.

James A. Dingivan, vice president of Arnold Constable Co., was elected president of the Stores Mutual Protective Association at the annual meeting of the organization held yesterday in the Empire State Club. He succeeds Harold W. Garton, vice president of Lord Taylor.

Led by Bill Rector, who registered 25 points, Trinity School's quintet scored its second straight triumph in the Eastern Private Schools League by crushing Horace Mann School for Boys, 42-26, on the winners' floor yesterday.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 1,106,000 bales, against 927,000 a year ago, of which American 681,000 bales, against 364,000 a year ago. Imports of all kinds 87,000 bales, against 83,000 a year ago, of which American 43,000, against 50,000.
Operations of Hiram Walker-Gooderham Worts, Ltd., and subsidiaries in the three months ended on Nov. 30 resulted in a net profit of $2,250,996 after depreciation, interest and Federal income taxes.

Without opinion, the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court affirmed unanimously yesterday a decision of Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler in a test case giving mortgage certificate holders a preference over other creditors of mortgage guarantee companies now being liquidated.

A new playground, to serve the children of picnic groups, will be opened to the public today in the picnic grove of Alley Pond Park, Douglaston, Queens. The playground may be reached by the Grand Central Parkway.

The marriage of Miss Charlotte Tholens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Tholens of Syracuse, to Richard Degenhardt, son of Mrs. Elsa Degenhardt, also of Syracuse, and the late Henry Degenhardt, took place here tonight.

Two horses in the large string of Hirsch Jacobs, who has saddled more winners than any other trainer for the past five years, loom as the favorites in the Fort Dallas Park Handicap, which will feature the first Saturday program at Hialeah Park.
The ter Dartmouth Hockey team blanked Williams tonight, 5-0, for its tenth victory in eleven starts. This was the visitors' second defeat by the Big Green this season.

Annual conference of the American Veterans Association begins this morning at the Hotel Roosevelt at 10 o'clock and continues tomorrow. League for Political Education, the Town Hall, 11 A. M. "A Plea for Aristocratic Government," Salvador de Marariaga.

Transatiantio steamship lines agreed yesterday to permit the storage of imports on their piers beyond the ten-day limit established by the Federal Maritime Commission, on condition that storage payment be made by the persons responsible for the cargoes.

About eleven years ago Martin (Red) Ritter, ragged but likable, clogged on the sidewalks for theatregoers' pennies. One night Julius Tannen, master of ceremonies in the "Vanities," saw Ritter and led him into the Earl Carrol Theatre. There the boy made an impromptu "hit" and was showered with coins.

Twelve of the fifteen competitors in the preliminary trials of the annual tournament for the Hazel Allen Trophy and the women's championship of the National Chess Federation started play in the opening round at the Marshall Chess Club last night.

Because the police had been unable to locate complainants against two Negroes on hold-up charges, General Sessions Judge Wallace yesterday discharged the defendants, Bennie Brown, 27 years old, homeless, and Joseph Semley, 27, of 255 West 114th Street.
Two prominent Chinese who were suspected of aiding Japanese efforts to administer the Shanghai area were shot and seriously wounded today by Chinese terrorists, who escaped.
The directors of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company declared today dividends of 25 per cent in stock on the $40,000,000 of common stock outstanding and $1 in cash.

William Alexander, who served for fifty-eight years as secretary of the Equitable Life Assurance Socity of the United States, left a net estate of $385,213, according to a transfer-tax appraisal filed yesterday. Mr. Alexander died last March 25.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

The Chinese, unwilling to yield despite the military reverses they have suffered, want the war pushed and plan to wage savage guerrilla warfare along the Japanese lines of communication, a survey of opinion in Hankow, China's de facto capital, indicated. Observers believed prolonged hostilities were likely.

Mrs. William L. Mellon Jr., testified today in a suit for divorce that her husband told her two years ago he "was going away, and going away alone." The former Miss Grace Rowley said that twice she went to her husband's T-Bar Lazy Ranch at Yavapai, Ariz., and added:

A subsidence of dust storms in the Southwest and weakness in foreign markets led to fairly general selling of wheat futures today and at no time were prices on the Board of Trade as high as yesterday's finish. Many who bought yesterday went out of their holdings on the way down.

Almost 500 athletes, headed by one Olympic champion and five national titleholders, will compete tonight in the annual indoor track meet of the 165th Infantry at the armory at Lexington Avenue and Twenty-sixth Street. Four new trophies have attracted the finest entry in the history of the meet.
Mrs. t M. Bulley, widow of Reginald Hargreaves Bulley, a steel company executive, died today at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Charles C. Trump of Merion.

Frederick J. Brack, adjutant of the New York Department of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, denied yesterday that he had joined with Roy P. Monahan, State commander of the Disabled American Veterans, in labeling as political the anti-communistic organization "We Americans," sponsored by George U. Harvey, borough president of Queens.

The French I Government asked today, "because of unforeseen circumstances," that the League of Nations Council meeting, scheduled to open on Monday, be postponed until Jan. 26. The request was supported by the United Kingdom and, though all of the Council members have not yet agreed, the postponement is almost certain to be granted.

To the tune of "Auld Lang Syne" sung by students and alumnae of Hunter College, the cornerstone of the 65-year-old college building on Sixty-eighth Street and Park Avenue was removed and opened yesterday, completing demolition of the structure that was condemned after a fire two years ago.

LEWIS CARROLL'S "Hunting of the Snark" is hard to keep out of mind in reading Ruth Harkness's story of her astonishing adventures in capturing the first giant panda to enter American-or any other known-captivity. Her books is breezy, lively and entertaining. Among other things it beautifully debunks quite a lot of the big-game-and-a-book-to-come explorer's art.

The contract between S. S. Kresge, chairman, and the S. S. Kresge Company, providing for the payment of $3,500,000 by Mr. Kresge and the return to him of 200,000 common shares of the company held as security, was completed last month, according to a report to the New York Stock Exchange

The cost of the election of the City Council by proportional representation and the counting of the ballots was put at $701,682 by the Board of Elections in its annual report issued yesterday. Upon estimates of the Elections Board, the Board of Estimate had appropriated $869,790 for the proportional representation election.

Three of a gang which carried on a campaign of hold-ups of horserace bookmakers and vice-resort owners in this city were convicted yesterday of first-degree robbery in General Sessions. Judge Cornelius F. Collins remanded the trio to the Tombs for sentence Jan. 27.

Convinced that the Chinese Government will not discuss peace on the basis of the terms submitted through Dr. Oskar Trautmann, the German Ambassador, the Cabinet held a special session yesterday at which, it is understood, a decision was taken to develop measures looking to a protracted struggle.

The length of the Henry Hudson Parkway that skirts the very edge of the Hudson River between the George Washington Bridge and Dyckman Street will be opened to one-way southbound vehicular traffic at noon today.

Although the volume of trading was affected by the French crisis and the end of the account today, prices in the stock markets here generally held firm. Gilt-edge issues were better and Chinese bonds recovered sharply.

The St. John's University fencing team recorded its third victory in four matches yesterday, defeating Wagner College, 14 to 3, at DeGray gymnasium in Brooklyn. St. John's made a clean sweep of the nine contests in the foil division as Dan Alagna, Murray Kornfeld and Robert Grogan each won their three bouts.

A. L. J. L. Mailman, trading as the Pal Blade Company, Plattsburg, N. Y., have agreed to stop using the word "Florsheim" as a brand or trade name for their razor blades so as to imply that such blades are manufractured by or for the Finrsheim

A reorganization plan looking to the resumption of dividend payments on one large certificate issue sponsored by the Fred F. French interests was revealed yesterday. At the same time it was learned that recapitalization programs to put other large issues of the same company on a new footing were being considered.
Prosecutor John J. Breslin of Bergen County announced today he would take steps immediately to prosecute theatre managements which operated a "bank night" or any other form of lottery after Monday.

Facing the fact that as a result of this morning's resignation of the Chautemps Cabinet the choice must be made between Finance Minister Georges Bonnet and Vice Premier Leon Blum for Premier, President Albert Lebrun today turned first to the former.

A requiem mass for the Rev. John E. Wickham, pastor of St. Brendan's Roman Catholic Church, who died Wednesday, will be celebrated in the church, Perry Avenue and 207th Street, the Bronx, today at 10 A. M.
An English judge refused today to order the flogging of 53-year-old James Hynes, a confessed American robber. Hynes was sentenced to twelve years' imprisonment.
ExPremier Mustapha Nahas Pasha today claimed damages of 5 cents (1 piastre) from a youth who attempted to assassinate him last November.

The St. Louis Cardinal baseball club opened its annual salary sideshow, featuring the one and only Dizzy Dean, today. For the first time in a number of years there was a note of seriousness in the ballyhoo. "Ol' Diz"

Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board of the Chase National Bank, an unexpected witness before the Senate Committee on Relief and Unemployment today, declared that government policies had contributed to bring the business recession, "which was a great surprise to many people."

Annual church unity Sunday will be observed throughout the Christian world tomorrow. In all churches prayers will be offered for the reunion of Christendom. In Roman Catholic parishes the official period to pray for unity will begin Tuesday, which in their ecclesiastical calendar is the Feast of St. Peter's Chair in Rome, and it will continue until Jan. 25, which is the Feast of the Conversion of St. Paul.

The Gordon international medal, first competed for in 1884, returned today to the United States after a year's stay in Canada. The visitors, led by John Anderson, Grand National Curling Club president, triumphed by 228-145 over rinks representing the Canadian branch of the Royal Caledonia Curling Club.

Hans Dieckhoff, the German Ambassador, protested to Secretary Hull today against a speech made by former Ambassador William E. Dodd in New York last night and the Secretary replied that the right of free speech was still guaranteed to citizens of the United States.

Formation of special classes for slow learners in the New York City high schools was announced yesterday by Frederic Ernst, recently appointed Associate Superintendent of Schools. Starting Feb. 1, 25,000 graduates of Grade 8B will undergo standardized reading and intelligence tests to determine their learning ability.

An annual event of the Russian New Year season here--the Russian Students' Ball--took place last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza, drawing an attendance of several hundred persons, including many members of the former Russian nobility.
Formation of the New York Stock Exchange firm of Hunnewell Co. by E. Mauran Beals Jr., Willis P. Beal and Hollis Hunnewell will be considered by the commitee on quotations and commissions on Jan. 27.

92d St, 316-8 E. 6-story brick tenement and stores, 50x100.8; Beskay Realty Corp against 316-18 E 92d St Realty Corp, due, $5,932, taxes, etc, $2,500; subject to mortgage of $48,000: to plaintiff for $49,000.

The Italian liner Conte di Savoia is leaving today for European ports. Bound for the Mediterranean, this liner will have as passengers, Dr. Joel Pressman, accompanied by his wife, Claudette Colbert, film actress: the Marquis de Talleyrand; Archduke and Archduchess Franz Josef of Austria; Thomas L. Chadbourne and Dr. and Mrs. F. B. Jewett. Others listed include Mr.

While employes in three departments worked last night to speed through the payrolls, it became apparent that for many city employes today will be a payless payday, in that their checks will be deferred until Monday.

Brown Harriman Co., Inc., received yesterday the award of a new issue of $200,000 of county house and bridge bonds of Greene County, N. Y., on a bid of 100.6599 for 2.20s. The bonds, dated Jan. 1, 1938, and maturing serially from Jan. 1, 1939, to 1958, were reoffered at prices to yield from 0.50 to 2.25 per cent, according to maturity.

Deposits in mutual savings banks in New York State amounted on Dec. 31 to $5,289,589,813, an increase of $46,691,898 in 1937, it was announded yesterday by the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York.

A New Jersey estate whose sheltered grounds still offer reminders of the fact that at one time it was owned and occupied by Joseph Bonaparte, brother of Napoleon, has been placed on the market. The 242-acre property, known as Bonaparte Park, fronts on the Delaware River at the mouth of Crosswicks Creek, near Bordentown.

Two former prize-winners at the Carnegie International in Pittsburgh are among the exhibitions of the week-Hipolito Hidalgo de Caviedes, at the Reinhardt Galleries, 730 Fifth Avenue, and Max Beckmann at the Buchholz, 3 West Forty-sixth Street.

Iron and steel exports of the United States to Netherlands India amounted to 38,542 tons, exclusive of scrap, in the first eleven months of 1937, compared with 8,309 tons in the same period of 1936, according to a report from Batavia made public today by the Department of Commerce.

Rudy Dusek, Omaha grappler, threw Bill Sledge of Houston at the Twenty-second Engineers Armory last night. Dusek subdued his rival in 23:50 with a leg lock before 3,000 fans. The weights were 220 for the winner and 216 for his victim.

Miss Silvia Annunziata Gould, a great-granddaughter of the late Jay Gould, was married yesterday afternoon to Charles Dabney Thomson, member of a prominent Cincinnati family, in the apartment of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Kingdon Gould, 160 East Seventy-second Street.

John Van Buren Thayer, Wall Street's oldest active banker, will celebrate today his eighty-sixth birthday and the commencement of his sixty-seventh year of service with the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company.

Mrs. Alison Reynolds Wheelwright of 17 East Ninety-seventh Street, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Fulchar Reynolds of Cleveland, was married to Charles Louis Flaccus Jr. of this city yesterday afternoon in the chapel of Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Philip C. Jones.

Announcement was made yesterday of the marriage on Thursday in the Municipal Building of Mrs. Dorothy Benjamin McQuade. daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Henry Benjamin of 229 East Seventy-ninth Street, to George von Lar of London and this city.

Mrs. Alison Reynolds Wheelwright of 17 East Ninety-seventh Street, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Fulchar Reynolds of Cleveland, was married to Charles Louis Flaccus Jr. of this city yesterday afternoon in the chapel of Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Philip C. Jones.

Announcement was made yesterday of the marriage on Thursday in the Municipal Building of Mrs. Dorothy Benjamin McQuade. daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Henry Benjamin of 229 East Seventy-ninth Street, to George von Lar of London and this city.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses and normal Federal income charges, but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed 1 earnings. Figures, in many cases, are subject to final adjustment.
The engagement has been announced of Miss Jo Marie D'Amato, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Boventuro D'Amato of this place, to Edwin A. Urban, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Urban of Flushing.

Benjamin H. Nelson, Bronx butter and egg merchant, who pleaded guilty to filing false claims for disability with insurance companies, and then took the witness stand to testify against other defendants on trial, admitted yesterday that neither Joseph J. Weiss nor Martin Gross knew that he had entered Suydenham Hospital in 1934 to prepare fake history of heart disease.

A group of army and navy officers paid tribute to Lieut. Gen. Robert Lee Bullard, retired, at a private dinner last night at the Hotel Astor. The dinner commemorated the General's seventy-seventh birthday, which is today.

The New York State outdoor speed skating championship for the Governor Lehman Trophy will be held today over the six-lap track at Sackett Lake, Monticello, N. Y. More than 400 speedsters are expected to compete.

Bonds called last week for redemption before maturity again were in small volume and consisted principally of small lots of municipal and foreign obligations. Except for a few small amounts of issues called for January, the new prepayments were for payment in future months.

Without ceremony and without any scramble of motorists determined to be the "first through" the thoroughfare, the lower-level drive of the new Henry Hudson Parkway, between Dyckman Street and the George Washington Bridge, was opened as a southbound, water-edge driveway yesterday at noon.

THIS is a story that is still in the nebulous region between fancy and fact, with enough leaning to the latter to be discerned in its larger outlines. It seems that the air-conditioning of Carnegie Hall is being seriously considered.

A wide variety of topics pertaining to real estate will be discussed at the second annual allday conference of the Metropolitan Association of Real Estate Boards to be held at the Hotel Commodore on Jan. 27.

Prices on real state are holding firmly throughout the country, with a reasonable amount of activity, despite the recession of the last few months, which had an adverse effect upon buying and building, the National Association of Real Estate Boards in its thirtieth semiannual survey of realty conditions.

AFTER several months of meetings, the President's Interdepartmental Committee has made its report to Mr. Roosevelt. He, in turn, called in Representative Clarence Lea of California, chairman of the House Committee on Interstate Commerce,

THE many precision gauges used in making the two Ford V-8s for 1938 brought to a total of 83,100 the different types of gauges designed by the Ford Motor Company since the first days of the famous Model T, a recent announcement from Dearborn stated.

Alden D. Stanton has been elected controller of the Corporation of Trinity Church, one of the largest realty taxpayers in the city. The vast holdings are made up chiefly of land which once comprised a "farm" in lower Manhattan which was granted to Trinity by Queen Anne in 1705.
The educational and recreational programs at Bucknell University have been complemented recently by the installation of a modern motion-picture projector and sound equipment of standard theatre size.

Officials of the Salvation Army announced yesterday the organization's international youth crusade would be started tomorrow. In the words of General Evangeline Booth, the crusade is intended to "save the youth of the world from the dark abyss of Godless materialism and to awaken in it a spirit of selfsacrifice to meet the ever-increasing needs for zealous and unselfish service to God and man."

ONLY an incorrigible optimist would deny that in the final analysis Europe's feverish building of short-wave and highpower radio facilities is a part of the general preparation for war, reports Cesar Saerchinger, former European director of the Columbia Broadcasting System, in a discussion of radio as a political instrument, in Foreign Affairs.

Waging a sparkling, aggressive battle, the splendidly mounted Boulder Brook riders galloped to a 23-to13 triumph over Squadron C in their Metropolitan Indoor Polo League senior division match at the latter's armory in Brooklyn last night.

Preservation of the small forest of Joshua trees on the Mojave Desert, twenty miles east of Lancaster, was assured today when the Board of Supervisors agreed to put enough money in the county budget to buy, at a cost of $20 an acre, 640 acres of the ground where the trees stand.
Husbands who insist that their wives quit working the moment they get married are non-thinking cavemen, Dr. James L. McConaughy, president of Wesleyan University, said today.

MISS FARMER was very positive: "I've come to the conclusion that the legitimate theatre is the only medium for acting and the repertory group is the only kind of theatre which can produce good acting."

A government communique reported today that fifty Insurgents were blown up when a mine exploded in Terol, Madrid suburb. The explosion was followed by a brisk skirmish, the announcement said, but positions of the opposing forces were unchanged.

John L. Lewis, head of the Committee for Industrial Organization, and Myron C. Taylor, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation; conferred this week, it was learned today, on new wage and hour agreements for steel workers.

Following a dull and irregular start, the stock market rallied briskly yesterday and closed with net gains of 1 to 3 points. It appeared to turn on the news that President Roosevelt had conferred with military and naval heads.

Miss Edith Louise Baker, daughter of Mrs. William Hogg Baker of this place and the late Mr. Baker, was married here this afternoon in St. Luke's Church to Jameson Gilbert Campaign, son of Mr. and Mrs. Curtis Campaigne, also of Montclair.

The French franc was less disturbed yesterday by the Cabinet crisis in Paris and registered an advance of 1 point to close at 3.34 7/8 cents. Trading on the local market, however, was at a minimum. This slight recovery brought the decline for the week to 4 5/8 points.

IF your ambition is to parade a baby leopard up and down Fifth Avenue this book won't help you in the slightest degree to attain your desire. But if you are moved by the reasonable wish to domesticate fish or birds or tamable beasts in health and happiness-even if under

Miss Theodora Lyons Morris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Morris of New York and this place, was married this afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church here to Edwin Colby Walton of New York, son of H. M. Walton of Wellesley, Mass.. and the late Mrs. Walton.

An appeal for at least $100,00O to continue the work of the New York Urban League and to extend its educational and social activities was made last week at a dinner meeting marking the twentieth anniversary of the organization at the Roger Smith Restaurant, 40 East FortY-first Street.

BROADCASTING recently from London, under what he termed a most liberating title, "As I See It." H. G. Wells, novelist, said what he was thinking about as he faced the microphone was "a great number of listeners, some alone, some in groups, in all sorts of rooms and places, all round the world."

HOLLYWOOD'S airy contempt for the phenomena of the material world has become so deeply imbedded of late that there would probably be only mild interest in the movie colony if Samuel Goldwyn should announce a "Doomsday," with studio-created grave-rising, terrestrial dissolution and Benny Goodman shaking 'em up as Gabriel.

Examiners attached to the regional office of the National Labor Relations Board have formed a "Disreputable Order of Examiners for the Prevention of Attorneys" to battle collectively against the "oppressive" actions of the board's legal staff, it became known yesterday.

An eight-point peace policy for the United States was suggested yesterday by former President Herbert Hoover in a speech to the members of the Women's National Republican Club at its seventeenth annual luncheon at the Hotel Astor.

Realty conditions in Bergen County, N. J., during the past year were materially better than at any previous time since the advent of the depression, declares Alexander Summer, head of the Teaneck firm bearing his name.
THE Toledo Museum of Art in its official publication, Museum News, calls attention to the Hogarth "Portrait of Joseph Porter," a recent gift from Edward Drummond Libbey.

Children generally are getting their growth faster than before the war, men now stop growing at 20 when they used to stop at 25 and the human race seems to be growing taller, according to a long report on "Physique and Health," by Dr. C. Wroczynski, published in the current Bulletin of the Health Organization of the League of Nations.

The outstanding discovery in physics in 1937 was the "X" particle, credit going to Dr. Beth H. Neddermeyer and Dr. Carl D. Anderson of Professor Millikan's crew of young cosmic-ray experts in Pasadena and to Drs. Stevenson and Street of Harvard.
A FOUR-YEAR-OLD personal feud between rival producers was culminated the other day when Adolph Zukor, chief of Paramount, canceled his company's contract with Emanuel Cohen's Major Pictures unit.

The proposals for self-regulation of the over-the-counter security business as presented recently by William O. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, will be a subject of much serious consideration by the board of governors of the Investment Bankers Association of America at its mid-Winter meeting to be held over next week-end at Absecon, N. J.

One of the outstanding entertainments of this Winter is scheduled for the night of Jan. 28, when the fifth annual "Night in Poland" ball will be given in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the Kosciuszko Foundation in this city.

Reading for pleasure is the favorite hobby of New York City adults, with listening to the radio and going to movies close runners-up, according to the results of a survey made public yesterday by the Board of Education's WPA adult education program.

MUSIC composed to accompany a film came into its own recently when Serge Koussevitzky offered Prokofieff's orchestral suite, "Lieutenant Kije," written for a Soviet film of that name, on a program of the Boston Symphony Orchestra. The significance of the event lies in the fact that this was one of the few times that cinema music had invaded the sacred confines of the concert hall.
Muhlenberg College has become one of the first small liberal arts colleges in the county to extend its educational facilities to high school students by means of radio.
Trainer George Conway had Samuel D. Riddle's champion, War Admiral, out for a gallop today. The bay son of Man o' War was as playful as a kitten and was only asked to travel at a slow gait.
Federal legislation will be discussed by three speakers before the Connecticut League of Woman Voters this week. They are Miss Marguerite Owen, Washington representative of the TVA;
Louis Forant, former vice president, has been nominated unanimously to succeed Vincent Gerbino as president of the Valley Stream Business Men's Association, it was announced today.
Following is Herbert Hoover's speech by radio to the Women's Nationa Republican Club here, delivered at a luncheon meeting of the club's Far Western members at San Francisco:

The marriage of Miss Beulah Ter Bush, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David A. Ter Bush of Schenectady, N. Y., to Terry Stewart Hinkle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Terry Hinkle of this city, took place here yesterday afternoon in the Chapel of St. Saviour, Cathedral of St. John the Divine. The ceremony was performed by the dean, the Rev. Milo H. Gates, in the presence of the two families.

It developed yesterday that there can be three kinds of interest in coins of the realm. First, there is the ordinary interest in intrinsic value; second, there is the collector's interest in rare varieties, and third, there is the patriot's interest in the subject matter of the coin itself.

Electricity replaced steam today on an eighty-three-mile route of the Pennsylvania Railroad between Paoli, Pa., and Harrisburg. A party of railroad officials waited in Philadelphia to board the Metropolitan Express, arriving from New York at 10:05 A. M.,

In public statements and legal opinions, Stanley Reed, named to the United States Supreme Court has always argued for a liberal in terpretation of the Constitution Speaking before the New York State Bar Association on Jan. 25, 1936. he said:

Members of the Maryland Society of New York held their annual dinner dance last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza. H. Dudley Bierau headed the dance committee and his aides were Dr. Edward McPherson Armstrong, Edgar A.
Jack Bromwich defeated Don Budge, Wimbledon and American national singles tennis champion, 6-8, 6-1, 6-3, today and Adrian Quist overwhelmed Gene Mako of California in straight sets, 6-4, 6-2, 6-3.
Captain William Herbert Ellis of 179 East Seventy-ninth Street, naval expert and retired shipping broker, died yesterday-in Lenox Hill Hospital after a brief illness. He was 60 years old.
