An effort to ascertain how many of the 9,000 living graduates of Vassar College are residing in or around New York has been rewarded recently by the large number of alumnae who have lent their efforts to the New York Vassar Club's benefit opera performance.

Aside from the rich, fine-flavored nuts it bears, the hardy, long-lived black walnut (Juglans nigra) is a most desirable ornamental treefor shade, for planting along driveways or roadsides, or as a single specimen in the yard.

A serious picture of chaotic conditions among the personnel of the merchant marine, with a breakdown of discipline attended by violations of law, disrespect for officers and insults to passengers, is contained in a record published today of executive joint hearings of the Senate Commerce and Labor Committees.

NINETY years ago--the date is a little uncertain-a magic word rang across the Plaza at San Francisco and was heard in every city and hamlet in the world. A garrulous man unleashed the fateful word "gold" and so destroyed one empire and started another.

With the resignation of the Chautemps Cabinet at 5 o'clock on Friday morning came to an end that strange alliance of Radicals, Socialists and Communists which has governed France for the past eighteen months under the name of the Popular Front.

A BULLET IN THE BALLET. By Caryl Brahms and S. J. Simon. 269 pp. New York: Published for The Crime Club, Inc., by Doubleday, Doran Co. S2. NEVER, it is safe to say, has any detective, either in fiction or in real life.

The spacious quarters of the Ways and Means Committee in the new House Office Building have lately been the scene of feverish activity. There a handful of legislators, revenue experts and legislative draftsmen have been meeting daily on a new tax bill.

A new development in health and physical education which has eliminated the formal compulsory classes and put required physical education on a semi-voluntary basis has proved successful at the Pennsylvania State College.

Mrs. Ludmila Kuchar Foxlee, who from 1921 to 1937 was a social worker at Ellis Island, was honored yesterday at a luncheon of the National Institute of Immigrant Welfare in the Town Hall Club, 123 West Fortythird Street. Mrs. Foxlee is now the chairman of the institute's committee on Ellis Island interests.

The National Tuberculosis Association and New York University will cooperate in conducting an Institute for the Training of Tuberculosis Workers at the offices of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association, 386 Fourth Avenue, it was announced yesterday

Seven out of thirty-six sections of local department stores scored gains in advertising linage during December, according to the monthly breakdown issued by Media Records. Toilet goods and drugs had the largest increase.

Lessons in courtesy will be given, beginning tomorrow, in schools in Brooklyn and Queens as part of the program of the Junior Inspectors Club, a citywide organization of more than 87,000 children, of which the Department of Sanitation is 'sponsor and which is directed by a WPA staff of counselors.

The visit of United States cruisers to Singapore on Feb. 14 perturbs the Japanese press which, since the fighting began, closely watches Anglo-American relations. The event is interpreted as revealing the hardening of the American attitude toward the Far Eastern situation.

Challenged by the existence of Intolerance, racial bias and misunderstandings in the classroom, educational authorities in New York City have mapped out a campaign to uproot these tensions and help develop a more sympathetic relationship among the diverse minority groups.

After the Park Association of New York City, Inc., had protested that Chelsea Park would be encroached upon if P. S. 33 were built on its site, the Public Education Association recommended yesterday that the building be placed opposite the Dark.

Retail sales showed many losses from 1937 last week and, despite increases in some districts, averaged about 4 per cent off. Price reductions, notably on sheets and other domestics, helped sales, and in a few instances men's clothing was a leader for the same reason.

The $4,500,000 task of turning old Princeton into a "square town" after long years as a mushrooming adjunct of its main street, of rehabilitating it by restoring some of its eighteenth century charm, of accomplishing on a comparatively modest scale what was done in Williamsburg, Va., is well under way.

If somewhere in this city today a bridegroom and his best man are a bit more self-conscious than usual, it won't be Harry Galensky's fault. "Please don't take those suits," Mr. Galensky pleaded with two hold-up men who entered his establishment.
Harvard rallied brilliantly in the closing minutes to repulse Princeton, 33-25, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League basketball game before 1,500 wildly excited fans tonight.

The undefeated Savage School girls' basketball team won its fourth game of the season by overwhelming Upsala today, 28-5. The New Yorkers passing attack completely eclipsed the Vikings' offensive. Marie Tully was high scorer with six points. Aileen Nelson played well for Upsala.
Mr. and Mrs. A. Curtis Brown have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Beatrice Brown, to Victor John Adey Horton, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. J. Horton of Bognor Regis.

Miss Patarcia Preston, daughter of Mrs. Harold G. Cutler of Beacon Street, this city, and Seven Pines, Wenham, was married this afternoon to Farley Wilder Wheelwright, son of Mrs. Wilder Wheelwright of Boston and W. Bond Wheelwright of Chicago.

A GAIN the tide turns toward Florida Many-hued, it rolls onward as if A Drawn by a bewitching tropical moon that had stirred mortals in the frozen North to rebel, in a great wave of migration, against the buffetings and lashings of Winter.
It's gotten to be old stuff, government troops say, to see a deserting Insurgent make his way across noman's land on the Andalusian front.

The junior at the Worcester Polytechnic Institute who displays the most ability in developing and presenting an engineering-economic plan will receive an award of $100 this Spring, according to an announcement made today.

A MAGNIFICENT work, unjustly buried. Such is the inescapable impression on hearing Italo Montemezzi's revised "Hellera," his early romantic opera twice broadcast from the Rome studio some days ago, with the American soprano Franca Somigli as protagonist.

Herbert Bird, 22-year-old son of Clarence W. Bird, a vice president of the Corn Exchange Bank, New York, accidentally shot and critically wounded himself late last night in the home of his parents at Castle Heights here. He is at St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains.

ON next Wednesday General Motors Corporation will open a new Diesel engine factory in Detroit, a plant equipped with special precision machinery which is expected to bring a degree of accuracy hitherto unknown to the manufacture of power plants of the oil-burning type.

Four months of operation of the plan of giving consumers factual data on merchandise have been a "complete success," according to George- P. Gable, president of the William F. Gable Company Department Store, Altoona, Pa., credited with being the first department store to put this plan into effect on a 100 per cent store-wide basis.

When the German police call In Dr. W. Specht to help them solve a murder mystery they are probably just a little astonished to see him spraying a liquid from an atomizer on carpets, table cloths, draperies, woodwork in the room where the crime was committed,

SWING, conceived in shanties and honky-tonks of New Orleans, will tonight invade the sanctum of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society at Carnegie Hall. Where have stood Toscanini, -Walter, Beecham, there will stand Maestro Benny Goodman, king of swing, and concert debutant.
DAVID LLOYD GEORGE will spend his seventy-fifth birthday, tomorrow under the palms at Cap d'Antibes in the front of the bluest of blue seas. He is on holiday, or at any rate that is the theory of it.

Marriages, divorces, births and deaths are on the increase in Great Britain. The statistical Blue Book issued today by the Board of Trade disclosed that marriages reached the biggest total since 1923.

The "Minnesota Man" which Professor A. E. Jenks described before the National Academy of Sciences a few years ago as the earliest human fossil ever found in the United States is handled none too gently by Dr. Ales Hrdlicka of the Smithsonian Institution.

Rowland B. Haines of the Columbia University Club, former national squash tennis champion and now ranked sixth in the amateur list, was the victim of one of the major reversals of the current season yesterday in the Clyde Martin memorial invitation tournament at the Yale Club.
Miscellaneous manufacturing operations in New England have not shown much
Free fertilizer is being distributed to native agriculturalists by the Netherland Indian Government in order to increase the production of rice, the Department of Commerce has been advised.

Liberal newspapers here publish as well founded the report of-the early departure for Rome of Mgr. Juan Manuel Gonzales Arbaleaz, Archbishop Coadjutor of Bogota. It is rumored he will become Colombia's first Cardinal and the third in South America.

Miss Mary Melville Clow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Clow Jr. of Lake Forest, Ill., was married this afternoon to Mario Braggiotti, concert pianist, of New York. The ceremony was performed in the Clow home by the Rev. Herbert E. Prince of Lake Forest's Church of the Holy Spirit.

Lenox R. Lohr, president of the National Broadcasting Company, which was reprimanded by the Federal Communications Commission for broadcasting an "Adam and Eve" feature by Mae West and Don Ameche on Dec. 12, issued a statement yesterday defending his company.

A good many Americans find themselves new yachtsmen of sorts this morning. They came to the Motor Boat Show, they saw and the salesmen conquered them. The thirty-third annual exposition ended its run at Grand Central Palace last night, ended it in a to-do of excitement among buyers and optimism for 1938 among exhibitors.
Colgate came from behind tonight to defeat Fordham, 41 to 40, with Captain Pick Turevon of the home team scoring the winning point on a foul with eleven seconds to go.
A Separate department for the study of chemical engineering has been created by the trustees of Lafayette College and is expected to open classes in September.

The second annual interfraternity week-end at Brown University will close tomorrow after attracting nearly 400 couples for the interfraternity ball of last night and a round of chapter house parties. Winter sports outings took place this afternoon, ending with informal suppers tonight.

More than 110,000 of the 285,000 persons who have applied for unemployment insurance benefits in the metropolitan district since Jan. 1 have been interviewed for job placement purposes, it was announced last night at the- offices of the division of placement and unemployment insurance of the State Labor Department.

At the luncheon meeting of the Middle Atlantic Region of the American Rock Garden Society to be held at the Hotel McAlpin, New York City, on Wednesday, A. C. Plander of the staff of the New York Botanical Garden, will lecture on rock garden construction.
Eighteen thousand persons attended the twenty-fourth annual ball and entertainment of the Uniformed Firemen's Association of Greater New York last night in Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON. - Uncle Sam's navy doctors do not care for term "punch drunk." They admit it is colorful and "scarcely requires elucidation," but say it tends to encumber nosological nomenclature.

Garden City's 5-to-O triumph over Manhattan in a men's Class A match featured an active week of competition in the Metropolitan Badminton Association's team tournaments, which are entering their final stages. The victory, Garden City's fourth in as many starts, kept the Long Islanders at the head of the standings in their division.

PINEHURST, N. C.--Golf, tennis, shooting, diversified activities with horses and a bridge tournament will oocupy the attention of the cottage residents and visitors to this Midsouth resort during the remainder of the month.

Twenty-one seniors at the Phillips Exeter Academy were elected to membership in the Cum Laude Society, national honorary scholastic society, at the first election of the year, held yesterday. They are as follows:
Steady progress in the liquidation of assets of title and mortgage firms was noted yesterday in a report issued by the Title and Mortgage Liquidation Bureau of the State Insurance Department.
In an effort to promote extensive private ownership of contemporary American art, a new organization not for profit has been formed by a group of New York art lovers.

The Rev. George Chalmers Richmond, a retired clergyman who had been outspoken as a minister of several denominations, died of a heart attack last night in a drug store in Northeast Philadelphia. He was 72 years old.

THE JESTER'S REIGN. By Boyne Grainger. 318 pp. New York: Carrick Evans. $2.50. FROM the journal of Mr. Roger Ergo-who may or may not have had some thing to do with the events narrated in this history--comes an account of a conversation in Central Park.
So far as any explanation is possible at all of what has lain behind the conclaves of the uppermost circles in Japan in the last week it is that Japan is searching its soul.

A convincing object lesson of the fact that builders in Queens are looking forward to an active year in home construction was presented yesterday in the announcement of the sale by the Cord Meyer Development Company of a tract of eighty-two lots in Forest Hills on

President Roosevelt's choice of a new Justice for the Supreme Court will command widespread respect. Mr. Stanley Reed is young in years, rich in experience, well equipped for the responsibilities of the great office for which he has been nominated.

The Hackensack realty firm of Chas. H. Borg, Inc., reports the sale of the plot at the southeast corner of Main Street and Knapp Place, Hackensack, to the Daphil Corporation for the Second Reformed Protestant Dutch Church of Hackensack. It has a frontage of 104 feet on Main Street and 140 feet on Knapp Place.

The eight-story office building at 91-93 Fifth Avenue and the abutting four-story building at 6 East Seventeenth Street will be sold under foreclosure in the Vesey Street rooms on Wednesday by B. Hollander Son.

A mob of fifty persons today wrecked and set fire to the Church of Christ, one of the oldest religious structures in North America, destroying the interior with its priceless paintings, relics and carvings.

The Atlanta district council of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union adopted a resolution today proposing that salaries of Southern Congressmen be reduced 20 per cent because of sectional differences in living expenses.
THE Seymours were a merry family, thought by their author and themselves to be typical of America. but far less sober and responsible than the average.

THREE hundred years ago China was invaded by the Manchus. The Chinese dynasty of Ming (13681644) was driven out of power and retreated west into Szechwan. This far-interior province was their last stand. Again an invading army is driving the pure Chinese before it, and again these Chinese are retreating to the solitude of the impregnable mountains of Western China.
NADIA BOULANGER, the eminent French musician and pedagogue, will give two courses in music at Radcliffe College, Cambridge, Mass., this season.
JOE PENNER is the favorite radio entertainer of both boys and girls, according to a survey conducted by the Boys Athletic League of New York. Eddie Cantor is second.

A valuable collection of rare books, manuscripts and original drawings of the last two centuries, Lent by George Arents, New York book collector, are on view for the first time in the exhibition room of the Rare Book Department in Low Memorial Library, Columbia University. The exhibition will continue through Feb. .15.

Whatever led to the killing of Mr. Leslie Starkey, the archaeologist, he has attained a kind of immortality that is accorded martyrs. The bandits have but enlarged and extended his fame. The ancient Lachish which he has helped to recover will be remembered along with Jerusalem-and as long as the words which the potsherds preserve.

The vast program of adult education and nursery schools, developed over the last four years by the WPA in "partnership" with State and local school officials, is having pervasive and permanent effects on American education. Not only has it already reduced the vast burden
AFTER A six years' absence from the repertoire, the Metropolitan will offer a revival or Rossini's "The Barber of Seville" Saturday afternoon.
Mr. and Mrs. Harry D. Kehoe of Astoria, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathryn E. Kehoe, to William H. Seitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry G. Seitz of Woodside, Queens.
A courageous Kent School hockey team today was defeated by a powerful Yale freshman sextet, 4--0. Hazen led the attack on the Kent goal with two tallies.

FLANKED by powerful Ameri can stations to right and left, Britain's short-wave transmitter on 9.58 megacycles is being heard in the United States from 12:20 until 1:15 P. M., sending programs to Arabs in Palestine, North Africa and Arabia.

All but one of the components of THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity advanced for the week ended Jan. 8, and the index moved upward 2 1/2 points to 80.8. The figure for the previous week was 78.3. A year ago the index stood at 105.6.

Senator Byrd filed a minority report today upon the Omnibus Governmental Reorganization Bill, assailing the provisions for reorganization of the civil service and the government accounting service, and delegating authority to the President to regroup and consolidate independent agencies.

YOUNG English girls may be even more stage-struck and romantic than our own movie-mad maidens. Sally, the daughter of a country parson, has the conventional qualifications of the poor but honest heroine, in addition to her background.

Bee-keeping is next to impossible in the Rockies. Bears are the reason. To cope with them the University of California and the United States, Department of Agriculture have resorted to electricity. Sturdy fences with four charged wires on insulators surround the hives.

A group of four concerns selling nitrogenfixing bacteria, a commercial inoculant for promoting the growth of leguminous plants, was found by the Federal Trade Commission to have violated the Robinson-Patman Act by quoting discriminatory prices to certain customers, the commission announced today.

The Princeton University board of trustees completed this week a significant chapter in the eighty-one year history of endowed professorships here with the elevation of present faculty members to two of the three specially funded chairs brought into being during the last few months.

FOR the third successive year, New York was beaten by Philadelphia in a team-of twelve match last week. Represented by one of the strongest combinations that could be assembled from local tournament players, the New York team finished 1,560 points behind.

The difficulties besetting an established church in a political democracy have never been shown more clearly than in the extraordinary report on "Doctrine in the Church of England," published by the commission headed by the Archbishop of York this week after fifteen years of study.
THERE is little that distinguishes this book except its careful log of our wartime "Brittany patrol" and the evident sincerity of its author.

TAKE any quiet residential street in any middle-class section of any American city and you will find there just such people as figure in "The Wax Apple." Although Miss Ward's particular setting happens to be Chicago. it might equally as well have been a dozen other places.

A NEW television system combining the scanning disk and the cathode ray tube, designed to permit finer textured images as well as secret or semi-secret transmission, is revealed in a patent (No. 2,104,862) awarded to Francois C. P. Henroteau of Ottawa, Ont.

WASHINGTON. - Comely and platinum-blonde Mrs. Helen Coolidge Woodring, wife of the Secretary of War, is ready to make an amusing little confession. It came out the other day as she sat, feet tucked under, on the stool in front of her black marble fireplace, discussing some of the "wrong ideas" which she finds that a lot of people nave about the War Department.
WHILE the production forces of the industry idled along this week at an output rate of approximately 61,000 units, the Society of Automotive Engineers gathered here for one of its liveliest sessions.
Retail trade this week was not so good as in the first week of the year, but the first half of January was above a year ago. Employment in the district this month is virtually unchanged.
CHINA AT WORK. By Rudolf P. Hommel. Mustrated. 368 pp. New York: Published for the Bucks County Historical Society of Doylestown. Pa., by the John Day Company. $5.

Speed to Spare, a cast-off of the A. G. Vanderbilt Stable, splashed through the mud to win the $5,000 San Felipe Handicap at Santa Anita Park today. Thirty-one thousand fans saw the 5-year-old black gelding, owned by Mr. and Mrs. E. S. Moore of the Circle M Ranch, Sheridan, Wyo., score easily over Mr. Blaze and Woodberry, who finished in that order.

Solicitor General Stanley Reed, who never has served as a judge, can point to many precedents for going on the Supreme Court without previous judicial experience. Twenty-eight of the seventy-six men who have sat on the tribunal since it first met in 1790 have done so without having been judges before.
Ivan Brown and Bob. Washbond,- Olympic two-man bobsled champions, set a new mile record of 1 minute 16.51 seconds today in the Adirondack A. A. U. championships on the Mount Van.Hoevenberg run.
Government experts hope to solve another fish mystery this year-to locate the place where shrimp go when they leave Gulf coastal waters.

Thousands of city employes remained unpaid yesterday as Mayor La Guardia, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick and Robert Lee Tudor and Michael J. Cruise, the two Democrats who are amicably sharing the office of City Clerk, signed the 1938 budget.

ON both sides of the Atlantic the forthcoming Anglo-American trade agreement has been endowed with vast potentialities. Some hope it will lead to increasing team-work between Britain and the United States in stabilizing currencies, reviving trade and thus reinforcing peace.

QUIETER, static-free auto radios are promised by the invention of a "static dissipator," described in a patent (No. 2,104,800) just granted to Levi R. Grandy and Harry C. Doane of the Buick Motor Car Company, Flint, Mich.

Korean youth will, in the future, have the opportunity for military service in the Japanese imperial forces. Plans for voluntary service were approved by the War Office today after Governor-General Ninami obtained the Emperor's sanction.

Scoring eight points out of a possible ten in a double-round chess masters tournament, Jose R. Capablanca of Havana and former world champion, today captured first prize at the Salons Caissa on the Rue de Presbourg.

Harrison R. (Playboy) McCready's unsuccessful attempt to break a $150,000 trust fund established for his wife and 8-year-old daughter will cost him $8,516.90 Judge McNaugher ruled in Common Pleas Court.

The first in a series of entertainments to be held under the auspices of the junior division of the Greater New York campaign of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee will take place tonight at the Havana-Madrid, 1,650 Broadway.
The report on trade barriers which ex-Premier Paul Van Zeeland of Belgium is now putting in final shape will be a notable adventure in statesmanship.

Confronted with fingerprints, the hold-up man who had described himself to the police as Martin (Red) Ritter who danced eleven years ago in Earl Carroll's "Vanitiess" admitted when arraigned yesterday in the Felony Court on four charges resulting from a daylight robbery in which $698 was obtrained, that he was not the former dancer but his brother.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In "Topics of The Times" of Dec. 15 figures were published indicating the level of illiteracy of the population of pre-revolutionary Russia as well as of the Soviet Union.

Production records for 1937 were announced last week by Dome Mines, a leading producer in the Porcupine district, and by Sullivan Consolidated in Dubuisson Township, Quebec, and from the Consolidated Mining and Smelter Plant at Trail, B. C., came reports for nine months indicating that volume was running well in advance of the figure for 1936.
American volunteers started the year by helping to beat back a sharp Rebel attack north of Teruel, and now they are out of the lines- healthy, happy, full of fight and with only ten casualties.

Following a legislative inquiry into charges that members of the Legislature "could be bought," a resolve was introduced in the House today which would call for a sweeping investigation of "the administration of justice in any part of the Commonwealth" and "the manner and fashion in which laws have been enacted."

John Anton Kutak of 128 East Thirty-fourth Street, who was taking an engineering course at the Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute and was a former president of its Evening Students Organization, died Friday in the French Hospital at the age of 26.

France's New Deal, representing the program of the Popular Front which won the last parliamentary elections in May of 1936, ha?? brought Paris a most difficult governmental crisis. The French capital is used to shifts in Cabinets, but seldom has the attendant political situation presented more difficulties.
Another extensive estate on the North Shore of Long Island has just gone the way of many of its neighbors to provide room for expanding residential communities.

Army beat Williams at basketball with a thrilling rally in the final minutes today, 38 to 33. The game was fast and cleanly played throughout, the Purple gaining an early lead and setting the pace at the intermission, 26 to 20.

KATHRYN WORTH has a gracious poetic manner, a delicate ear for prosody, and a fine architectonic sense when it comes to building a poem. We are not so sure, on the other hand, that she is a born poet.

The White House door is open to all our citizens who come offering to help eradicate the evils that flow from undue concentration of economic power or unfair business practices-who offer to do all that is possible by cooperative endeavor and to aid in corrective and helpful legislation where necessary.

A slight but unmistakable fall in the flood tide of British prosperity has revived agitation for a public works program to block off another "vicious cycle" of deflation like that which followed 1929.

Historic Barnum School was ruined in a two-alarm fire early today. The damage was estimated at $125,000. Four firemen were injured. The 800 pupils will be transferred to the Staples and Beardsley Schools.

The initial United States victory in the international curling competition history was scored today when sixteen rinks representing the Grand National Curling Club of America posted a 208-148 triumph over a British Empire squad to take test-match honors.

A luncheon honoring Mrs. Leo Sulzberger, president for three terms, and the forty-fourth annual meeting of the New York Section of the National Council of Jewish Women will be combined in a single program scheduled for Wednesday at the Waldorf-Astoria.

A definite turning point in the history of the Committee for Industrial Organization is approaching as its militant, underlying unit, the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, prepares to negotiate its second labor contract with the nation's leading producer.

Two young music students whose training has been financed by the Haarlem Philharmonic Society will sing for their sponsors for the first time at the annual breakfast of the organization on Thursday at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Mrs. Carl T. Klug of this place has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Betty Klug, to Laurence B. Field, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry H. Field of Shaker Heights. The prospective bride, a daughter of the late Mr. Klug, was graduated from the Cleveland School of Art and from Western Reserve University.

The trend of retail sales has been mixed; Pittsburgh stores reported a gain over early 1937 of 10 per cent, but at Cleveland a reduction of 8 per cent was indicated. Clearance sales have been reasonably successful.
Mrs. Mary C. Bradford, for tweleve years State superintendent of public instruction, and former president of the National Education Association, died here today. Her age was 75.

The New York Smith College Club, which has awarded scholarships to more than fifty girls during the last ten years, has arranged to augment its fund for this work with a benefit matinee performance of "The Barber of Seville" on Feb.

Black cotton hosiery may become the vogue among undergraduates at Georgian Court College. Japan's invasion of China has nothing to do with the proposed "boycott." In fact, Japan may place all responsibility on a spelling bee- if the silkworms complain.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert William Sloan of Fortyfort, Pa., have announced the engagement of their niece, Miss Janet Hailer, daughter of the late Thomas Haller, to Robert Arthur Hubbard, son of Mrs. Sidney Rheinstein of 941 Park Avenue, New York.

It is not by mere chance that the opening paragraph of the communique issued at the end of the Budapest conference between the Rome protocol signatories deals almost exclusively with Germany and the Rome-Berlin axis.
A RARE opportunity offers it self just now to our conTemporary poets. This discovery is announced by Allan C. Bailey. writing in The Radio Times.
LETTERS FROM ICELAND. By W. H. Auden and Louis MacNeice. Illustrated. 269 pp. New York: Random House $3. POEMS. By Louis MacNeice. 115 pp. New York: Random House. $2.50.

Capturing eight of the nine events, the Rutgers swimming team defeated New York University, 57 to 18, before 1,500 persons in the Rutgers pool today. Julius Calitri, the only first-place winner for the Violet, defeated Ken MacWhinney, Scarlet veteran, by inches in the 100-yard free style event.
An eighth of all bank deposits are in banks owned by holding companies whose elimination President Roosevelt favors.

Bobby Riggs of Chicago reached the final round of the Nautilus tennis tournament today and will meet Mayne Sabin of Hollywood, Calif., tomorrow. Young Riggs, the country's topranking player while Don Budge is abroad,

The influence of the press, radio and newsreel films in molding public opinion and spreading propaganda was discussed yesterday by representatives of each field before a gathering of history, civics and economics teachers. Speakers for the last two industries defended their endeavors, but the press delegate admitted there were grounds for criticism of newspapers.

Paul Raphael Montford, Australian sculptor, died here today at the age of 69. Mr. Montford was the son of a sculptor, Horace Montford, and studied under his father before entering the Royal Academy schools at the age of 19.

RETAIL trade for the country probably ran 3 or 4 per cent under a year ago for the week, but in several major centers sales were reported as running well ahead of expectations. It was indicated further that the sharp markdowns taken by stores in their special offerings had pushed up volume substantially.

Horace L. Mann, president of the Buffalo Niagara Electric Corporation, announced today a $5,000,000 expansion program for this city. Buffalo recently was completely cut off from electric power for a six-hour period by a disabled power plant.
Colgate University will start the experiment of offering a cultural course in mathematics next semester, on the theory that few know how the field of mathematics has expanded through the ages.
Check clearings for the Poughkeepsie Clearing House Association for the week ended on Jan. 12 totaled $3,196,644, compared with $3,439,395 last week and with $3,261,666 for the same week in 1937.

CROWDS like those that invade department stores on bargain day have been turning out during the past week for the Press Photographers Show at the Maison Francaise and the Leica exhibit in the International Building, both in Rockefeller Center.
SUCCEEDING the late L. Earle Rowe as director of the Museum of Rhode Island School of Design, Dr. Alexander Dorner, former director of the Landes Museum, Hanover, Germany, has taken up his duties.

WASHINGTON.-With great clippers of the air quickening communication between many foreign countries and the United States, the job of keeping out alien insect pests is bigger today than ever before for the Federal foreign-plant quarantine force.
THERE are sharp divisions in the work of Gifford Beal, whose recent paintings are being exhibited (until Feb. 5) at Kraushaar's.
Playing in a gale before a crowd of 60,000, Wales today defeated England, 14-8, in the first international rugby match of the season.

Waving the tricolor flag of Ireland [formerly the Irish Free State], a crowd of enthusiastic Irish men and women swept through the police guard at Euston Station tonight when the train carrying Prime Minister Eamon de Valera, bespectacled and smiling, at the head of his delegation to the conference on BritishIrish problems, steamed into the station.

To the Art Editor: THERE have appeared recently in the art columns of THE TIMES several stimulating letters dealing with photography and art criticism. Though the question is of intense interest to the worker in photography, it cannot fail to be of almost equal interest to the intelligent layman.

JACK JONES'S autobiography is one more emphatic illustration that life can be infinitely more amazing, romantic, varied and unpredictable than fiction. Mr. Jones's life would have borne being set down in book form had it been only this. But it is more.

A COMPREHENSIVE program for the development of aviation, civil and military, in the United States was outlined by delegates to the first national aeronautic planning conference held here last week in conjunotion with the annual convention of the National Aeronautic Association.

Displaying a fast-passing attack and a smart man-to-man defense throughout, the St. John's University five hung up its eighth victory of the season tonight, defeating Niagara, 54--29, in the De Gray gymnasium in Brooklyn.
RADIO performances by the Boy Scouts are increasing in number and scope. Songs, talks, skits and award presentations are on the programs offered by Scout broadcasters from coast to coast.

At what period of their lives do the great poets, inventors, scientists make their finest contributions? In their early manhood, most of us will agree. Though we argue from impressionistie judgments, illustrative cases, and, If we are really studious and just a little critical, from averages, we happen to be right. But how far right?

After taking only three innings to beat Welker Cochran in yesterday afternoon's session for the world's 18.2 balkline billiard crown at the Strand Academy, Jake Schaefer went into the doldrums last night and Cochran captured the twelfth block, 382 to 300, in ten frames. Jake's afternoon margin was 300 to 200.

THE key to Uncle Sam's 1938 stamp-issuing program, details of which are eagerly awaited by collectors, is in the hands of President Roosevelt. The Postoffice Department will submit a memorandum of suggestions and recommendations to the White House within a week or ten days and the President will study it in the light of his own ideas.
Taking two of the four singles matches and sweeping the doubles, the Seventh Regiment tennis team defeated Columbia's varsity court men, 4 to 2, yesterday at the Seventh Regiment Armory.
Lord Burghley, member of the International Olympic Committee, said tonight that the question of holding the Olympic games in Tokyo in 1940 is "creating widespread concern."

The government appealed to the Supreme Court today in an effort to compel the Mackay Radio and Telegraph Company to reinstate five employes of its San Francisco office who are members of the American Radio Telegraphists Association. The petition was signed by Solicitor General Stanley Reed.

WHENEVER a public aspersion is cast upon the eating of pie, loyal Americans spring to its defense. A recent report that attributed the poor showing of a team of athletes to their pie-eating met with prompt protest in letters to the editor.

Though we hear a good deal about hormones these days, the thymus gland, which probably produces one of them, has been strangely neglected. Dr. L. G. Rowntree of Philadelphia, the most active student of the gland in this country, says that from ancient times down "its function has remained a riddle."

THE latest Gallic invader is Lucien Adrion, whose paintings at the French Galleries (through January) reveal gayety and sunny mood. Adrion can handle crowds, suggest movement, give pleasant vistaed distances through the arch of a Seine Bridge, and, in general, evoke a very French spirit in his work. Construction is occasionally reminiscent of Sisley. It is cheerful painting.

MISS BEARD looked into the condition of history as it dealt with the business man and found that though she had come into the research libraries so late, she had practically the run of the field. She hald hit on a road into the past that, surprisingly was little traveled,

In its forty-ninth year--and a gratifying state of vitality and expansion - the Women's University Club officially established itself yesterday in its new quarters, on the second floor of the Hotel Biltmore.

Real estate in Dutchess County continues to show activity, following an exceptionally busy Fall season, states the Elizabeth Putnam Conklin Agency. The firm reports that it recently arranged sales of properties in the county valued at $117,000.

Robert C. Morris, an official of the Bankers Trust Company, was this week elected a trustee of Drew University. The trustees also advanced three faculty members in rank and confirmed awarding the contract for the $500,000 Rose Memorial Library to the Turner Construction Company.

The Bagby Music Lovers Foundation, Inc., which aids indigent and aged musicians and their dependents, will benefit from a gala concert arranged by Albert Morris Bagby and an auxiliary committee for the afternoon of Jan. 31 in the grand ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria.

An interesting alteration project has just been carried out at 232-8 East Fifty-second Street, involving three old four-story tenements owned by W. A. Smadbeck, Inc. Under plans drawn by F. P. Platt Bro., architects, the outmoded structures were combined
HEALTH authorities throughout the world are taking cognizance of the increase of international air travel with different steps to prevent the spread of illness from one country to another.

LAKE PLACID.-Under the auspices of the Skating Club of Lake Placid and the "Sno Birds" of the Lake Placid Club, the first Eastern amateur figure skating championship will be held at the Olympic Arena here next Saturday and Sunday.

THERE it goes again. More quarrels over money. The unpaid war debts still cause international bickering. The French Cabinet is always falling heavily over a question of national finance. There are stout old codgers in heavily upholstered chairs in staid clubs hereabout who can be put into an apoplectic fury over any mention of the 59-cent dollar.

Miss Vesta Culbertson and Robert F. Carr Jr., were married this afternoon in St. Chrysostom's by the church rector, the Rev. Dudley Stark. The bride was given in marriage by her father. Craig Culbertson of New York.

Miss Clara Sylvia Guthrie, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. William Norman Guthrie of Stamford, formerly of New York, was married in her parents' home this morning to Robert Leet Patterson of Shields, Pa.
The Chamber of Commerce of the Jnited States reprimanded the Administration today for "the recent tendency to assail business and blame it for the recession."

The Greek freighter Aspasia, which sent out an S 0 S early yesterday morning after seas had washed her bridge away and carried two members of the crew to death, was believed to be proceeding on her journey yesterday after withdrawing the call for immediate aid.

The marriage of Miss Ruth Whiting Cook, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Mason Cook of Park Hill, this place, to John Tyrrell Cheney Jr., son of John T. Cheney of New York and the late Mrs. Cheney, took place here tonight in St. Andrews Memorial Church.

Paddy Reilly, business agent of the Humane Society of New York, left for Detroit last night on a business trip. Ordinarily such a prosaic event would not have warranted the attendance of a farewell delegation of friends and photographers, but Paddy happens to be a hero-a canine hero-so he received a gala send-off.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Jan. 12, aggregated $7,643,000,000, or 24 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week, which included only five business days, and 19 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.

The dwelling at 347 Summit Avenue, Mount Vernon, containing seven rooms and three baths, been purchased by John S. Conway r from the Home Savings Bank of c White Plains. Chauncey B. Griffen and Harriet Portman were the brokers.

The Federal Surplus Commodities Corportion announced today that it Would begin on Monday the purchase of storage apples in Western New York and has established a pride of 75 cents a bushel, f.o.b. cars, for late Winter Varieties, grade United States 1, 2.5-inch minimum.

Manuel Azana, President of the third of Spain controlled by government forces, declared last week that the capture of Teruel "had changed the face" of the Spanish civil war. And, unlike many official statements coming from either side in "Europe's undeclared war,"
STROUDSBURG, Pa.--A continued snowfall in the Poconos has made this season, so far, one of the best for Winter sports that these mountains have had in several years.

One appointment to the Rutgers University board of trustees, and five resignations and nine appointments to the university staff were announced today following the quarterly meeting of the trustees at Atlantic City last night.

The President's birthday celebration has benefited the Georgia Warm Spring Foundation, Inc., to the extent of $1,350,030 since the first birthday ball held in 1934, it was announced yesterday by Keith Morgan, national treasurer of the birthday celebrations.

An attempt to settle the serious international problem created by the difficulties of United States and British petroleum companies operating in Mexico will be made personally by President Lazaro Cardenas.

Although it may not be considered the best play at cards to lead with your ace of trumps, the Giants somehow have found the system not to be a bad one when it comes to signing ball players in- the Spring.
NO matter how dull or in consequential the year's activities in the auction rooms may be, the "American Book-Prices Current." as inevitable as the weather, makes its annual round.

The season's second children's concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra was given yesterday morning at Carnegie Hall under the direction of Rudolph Ganz, pianist-composer, president of the Chicago Musical College and former leader of the St. Louis Symphony.

Claudette Colbert, motion-picture actress, sailed yesterday with her husband, Dr. Joel Pressman, for a vacation in Switzerland. Leaving on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia, Miss Colbert said it would be her first vacation in eight years.
M, A. Shipman, president of the National Bronx Bank, in his annual report to stockholders, said that total resources as of Dec. 31, 1937, amounted to $8,917,008 and total deposits were $7,807,918.

WHAT appears to be the first sit-down strike on the part of a producer is in progress at United Artists. As a result of feeling engendered by the collapse of negotiations for the purchase of the concern by Samuel Goldwyn and Alexander Korda,

Rockland County's new community enterprise, known as the "Dutch Gardens," which is to be officially presented with appropriate dedication ceremonies early next Spring, is not merely a remarkable achievement horticulturally, but includes many radical departures from the standardized pattern for projects of this type.

Even play masked the second day of the Sheffield Shield cricket match between Queensland and Victoria. Replying to the visiting team's total of 396, the Queenslanders had obtained 164 runs for the loss of four wickets when play closed till Monday.

A sitting of one hour for a sketch by Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt, wearing her inaugural gown, and "more time if I may have it" is the program outlined yesterday by Edmund Strudwick, 27-year-old art student, who will begin work on a portrait of the wife of President Roosevelt in Washington tomorrow afternoon.
THE news this morning is that Labor Stage presently is to woo the spoken drama again, as opposed to the musical drama, and with help from none other than "Dead End's" Sidney Kingsley.
The Williams hockey team recorded a 7-6 victory over New Hampshire today. Wells tallied three times in the third period to decide the issue.
LOUIS XVI AND MARIE AN TOINETTE BEFORE THE REVOLUTION. By Nesta H. Webster. Illustrated. 319 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $3.75.

The eighty-fifth annual meeting of the American Society of Civil Engineers will open here. Wednesday and will continue for four days at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street. About 1,200 civil engineers from the United States and Canada are expected to attend.
Robert H. Jackson of Jamestown, Assistant United States Attorney General, continued the Administration's renewed drive on the holding companies in an address before the City Club here today.
UNEXPECTED, for one thing, the Dutch exhibition at Knoedler's must be called. It is common knowledge that the seventeenth was Holland's great century; almost, in art, her alpha and omega.

Application was made today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for the merging of four railroads into the Toledo Ohio Central Railroad Company, in furtherance of consolidation plans previously announced by the New York Central,
Exeter's basketball team continued its winning streak by defeating the Harvard freshmen, 42 to 25, today. Leading, 21 to 12, at half time, the Exonians went on a scoring drive in the second period.

Miss Sarah P. Taylor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Lincoln Taylor of this city, will be married to Dr. Edgar Buell Butler, son of Dr. and Mrs. William Nelson Butler of West Hartford, on Feb. 5 in Trinity Episcopal Church here.

President Roosevelt's statement at the end of last week favoring the elimination of all holding companies of every sort, startled Wall Street. But on further study of his remarks financial observers concluded that he did not acutally have in mind corporations of that type which are integral parts of the industrial organization to which they belong.
The New York Rangers and their city rivals, the Americans, will collide for the fourth time this season when the teams engage in a National Hockey League game tonight at Madison Square Garden.

Considerable activity is reported in the low-cost homes developments known as "Cottage Homes" in New Rochelle and Rye, Westchester County, reports the Cottage Homes Corporation, builders, a subsidiary of the Haring Blumenthal Realty Corporation.

A bridge party will be held Friday at the Bronxville Women's Club by the Commonwealth Chapter, Daughters of the British Empire of Bronxville, for the benefit of the Victoria Home for Aged British Men and Women in Ossining.
THIS book should be set beside Coulton's "Chaucer and His England" and Davis's "Life on a Medieval Barony." Mr. Bennett will be remembered in connection with "The Pastons and Their England."
Cutting four strokes off par young Jimmy Demaret of Houston, Texas, moved into the lead of the $3,000 Bing Crosby golf tournament at the halfway mark today.
The Dartmouth Student Speakers Bureau has been opened as a campus innovation. The bureau, which will charge no dues, will help students to get speaking engagements and arrange lecture trip details.

MIAMI, Fla.-Observance of President Roosevelt's birthday on Jan. 29 will mark the climax of a fortnight of interesting events throughout the greater Miami area, introduced today by the opening of the third annual Metropolitan Miami fishing

Grover Whalen will be the guest of honor at a large luncheon to be given tomorrow under the auspices of the Arts and Interests Committee of the New York Junior League at the league clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street. Mr. Whalen,

Publication of a news bulletin and the creation of a department of family life were announced yesterday by Mrs. Andrew J. Noe, president of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs. The bulletin will be mailed early this week.
The Parke-Bernet Galleries ended their first sale yesterday afternoon and the sum realized, $140,409, was the highest total of any sale since the art auction season opened last September.
IN an adjoining column J. B. Priestley, author of the current "Time and the Conways," takes issue with this department's first night assertion that he "writes down to the theatre."

Counsel for the Ford Motor Company said that "every one" of the 600 or 700 employes of the St. Louis assembly plant would be called as a witness in the company's defense against charges of unfair labor practices at a National Labor Relations Board hearing.

The student editors of The Yale Daily News, The Harvard Crimson and The Daily Princetonian are charting the agenda for their third annual press conference, which will be held here with the Yale men as hosts April 22-23.
Employing a swift short-passing attack, the Brooklyn College basketball team scored a 40-35 victory over Seton Hall last night before a crowd of 1,000 in the winners' gymnasium.

Seven University of Virginia students were injured early today when their automobile overturned on a curve at Piney River. Edward Clopton, 23, of Chevy Chase, Md., and Torrmy Kurtz, 21, of Fort Myers, Fla., were critically hurt.

Wendell L. Willkie, president of the $1,167,848,000 Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, offered yesterday to break up the vast holding concern by selling its entire Southeastern utility properties to the Federal Government.

A radio "Middletown" with a 10,000 population is being sought as the laboratory for Princeton University's radio research project. Such a town, in a rural setting and representing varying social groups, would supply the perfect community setting, the project directors believe in which to study

Chinese reports today insisted the tide of battle in Shantung Province had swung in favor of the Chinese defenders. Spurred to new activity by the presence of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, they declared the Chinese not only had stopped the Japanese advance but had recovered ten miles.
DURING the last week aviation ran a gantlet of the tragic loss of the Samoan Clipper with Captain Edwin C. Musick and his crew of six near Pago Pago, the crash of an airliner in Montana,
THIS brief swift tale of a marine disaster-comparable to that which overtook the Vestris or the Morro Castle of recent memory--starts off with a bang.
Gustav Kilian and Heinz Vopel, German riders, won their ninth straight six-day international bike race tonight with a one-lap lead over Jimmy Walthour and Al Crossley.

A novel radio static-resisting shell or "blister," developed on United Air Lines' flying laboratory as. a part of that company's program to effect a complete reduction of static interference, has proved successful in exhaustive tests, J. R. Cunningham, director of communications, disclosed yesterday.

The opera "La Boheme," which emerges more and more as the freshest, the loveliest and most tender music Puccini wrote for the stage, delighted an immense audience yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House.
On the recommendation of President Corson of Dickinson College, the trustees have voted to extend social security to non-academic members of the college staff through a private insurance association.

Members of the Woman's Board of the Church Charity Foundation of Long Island have taken over the performance of "The Star Wagon" tomorrow night at the Empire Theatre for the benefit of their charitable enterprises.
THE OUTLAW OF EAGLE'S NEST. By Peter Field. 276 pp. New York: William Morrow Co. $2. AS one of the characters in the tale remarks, the place should have been called "Nickerson's Hole."

The United States cruiser Marblehead prepared today to proceed quickly from Tsingtao to Chefoo on the north coast of the Shantung peninsula, for protection of American lives and property from possible danger from disorders.

Dartmouth defeated Yale in two sports tonight. The Indians triumphed by 49 to 27 in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League contest after they had achieved a 6-to-2 victory over the Elis in an International Intercollegiate Ice Hockey League fray.
SOME details regarding Sweden's promised Emanuel Swedenborg commemorative mentioned in these columns last week were made public yesterday by the Swedenborg Commemorative Committee in New York.

Princeton University's well balanced swimming forces preserved their undefeated status today by submerging the Columbia natators, 54 to 21, for their fifth consecutive triumph of the campaign and a step in the right direction in the Eastern Intercollegiate Association.

Continued buoyancy in the market for United States Government obligations was the feature of the week-end trading session in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange. Treasury issues scored net gains ranging from 1-32 to 14-32 of a point on a turnover of $406,175, the largest volume for a two-hour trading period in almost three months.

George R. Ramer, head of the accounting firm of George F. Ramer Co., died today at the Presbyterian Hospital after an illness of a week. He was 60 years old and had lived in Chicago for thirty-three years.

The plot 236 East Thirty-fourth Street, adjoining the entrance to the Pennsylvania Station, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, has been leased by Newsreel Theatres, Inc. It contains a one-story building,
HERE is storytelling for storytelling's sake. Dana Breed has written a dramatic novel based on that note of elemental suspense known in the pulp field as "who gets shot when."

A score of rare antique clocks and watches have been added to the James Arthur Collection of Timepieces last year, Dr. Daniel W. Hering, curator, announced yesterday in his annual report to Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase of New York University.

More than 1,500 persons yesterday morning attended a mass of requiem for the Rev. John E. Wickham, former superior of the New York Apostolate, a mission band, and pastor of the Catholic Church of St. Brendan, the Bronx, for fifteen years.

A reduction in the price of milk and cream becomes effective today in the metropolitan area. A drop of a half cent a quart for milk and one cent for half pints of cream was announced yesterday by the Borden Company and Sheffield Farms Company, Inc., which supply the bulk of this market, and the independents are expected to follow.
FROM Negley Farson's exciting "Way of a Transgressor" one gathered that his motto was "Life is made for living." He used potent ink to set down his impressions of himself his roving and ranging.

Charles F. Noyes, head of the realty firm bearing his name and who materially increased his investments in the downtown insurance district last year, gave further evidence of his confidence in the future of New York City real estate by announcing yesterday that he has awarded contracts for the erection of four new buildings on properties in his ownership.

THE author of the two long short stories contained in this book is a native of Kazan, Russia. She comes of a cultured family engaged in the arts. and before the revolution she contributed stories and verse to Russian periodicals.

Expanding opportunities for women in business and the increasing number of women desiring "careers" make it obligatory upon women's colleges, in the opinion of President James L. Meader of Russell Sage College, to provide specialized training of professional rank.
Mrs. Baldwin D. Spilman entertained tonight with a dinner, followed by music and cards, at her villa in honor of her house guests, Mr. and Mrs. Amory S. Carhart of Warrenton, Va.

The cast for "The Cradle Song," by Gregaria and Maria Sierra, which will be presented at the College of New Rochelle as the annual mid-year play, was announced here yesterday by Miss Viola Laemmle, president of the dramatic society, following the try-outs.

While Tokyo's Imperial Council obviously decided upon two lines of action, dependent on whether the Hankow regime accepts or rejects the minimum peace terms that Japan is prepared to offer, it is significant that the only important military activity consists of clearing up the Chinese remnants in Shantung Province and pushing southward to cut the Lung-Hai Railway beyond Tsining and join the northern and southern forces along the Tientsin-Pukow Railway.
PLYMOUTH, N. H.-It's all "Ski hell!" and "Track!" in these Pemigewasset intervales, and the deer, once so wary of hungry Indians, are even warier of white men on their first skis.

Curtailment of dues payments to the United Automobile Workers of America as the result of decreased employment in automobile plants throughout the country has put a burden on the union the extent of which its leaders refuse to reveal.

The university of Rochester installed its Sibley Musical Library this week in its new building. The library was founded soon after the turn of the century by Hiram W. Sibley, whose father founded the Western Union Company.

Tracy H. Lewis was the principal winner at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday. He began his good work by taking the high-over-all cup with a card of 98. Captain J. B. Grier, a visitor, also had 98 but shot for targets only.

George W. Colley, who is 17 years old and has admitted doing pretty well as a hold-up man in other places, found the New York police too much for him early yesterday. He had just arrived in town, and started the hold-up of a gasoline station, when he found a policeman chasing him.

Creation of a permanent legislative council which would work between sessions to prepare a comprehensive program for presentation at each regular session of the Legislature will be urged in a bill to be presented Monday by Senator Desmond, Orange County Republican, and Assemblyman Parsons, Onondaga Republican.

THERE is fairly general agreement that the President is embarked on what is substantially a new course for the nation. Mr. Roosevelt is seeking increased centralization and regimentation of American life. The question arises whether his aims and ideas suit the psychology of the country.

If the Senate confirms the nomination of 53-year-old Stanley Reed to succeed 75-year-old Justice George Sutherland the average age of Supreme Court members, will be lowered a little more than two years. Now a shade over 69, it would drop to 66 2-3.

A group of House Republicans, which at no time exceeded twenty, fought the silver purchase clause in the Treasury-Postoffice Appropriation Bill so strongly today that consideration of the bill had to be carried over until Monday, thereby disrupting the majority leader's schedule.

Robert C. Chapdelaine, president of the American Federation of Labor Seamen's Union, 21,420, was arrested yesterday on charges of assault and robbery. It was alleged that on Friday he and three aides raided the offices of David E. Grange and Joseph Arras.
Signs pointed to a possible ending next week under an "armed truce" of the parliamentary snarl in the Senate caused by the filibuster against the Wagner-Van Nuys anti-lynching bill.

A brilliant spectacle will be unfolded on the ice of the Madison Square Garden arena on the night of Jan. 24 when an elaborate ice revue will be presented by Miss Sonja Henie and her Hollywood Ice Ballet as a benefit for the Children's Village of Dobbs Ferry, N. Y.

Dotted along the shores of New York's rivers, bays and coves and on adjacent waterways reached by Manhattan skippers on their weekend and vacation cruises are more than two hundred yacht clubs, most of which have been holding their annual elections during the past month.

Consumption of crude rubber by manufacturers in the United States last year amounted to 542,947 long tons, compared with 575,000 in 1936, according to the Rubber Manufacturers Association. Consumption in December was estimated at 29,160 tons, against 33,984 in November and 49,754 in December, 1936.

After winning first prize in the international tournament at Hastings, Samuel Reshevsky of this city, champion of the United States, is resting on his laurels, but will give a number of exhibitions of his skill before leaving England.

In the first application of its kind to be filed under the Holding Company Act, the Washington and Suburban Companies of Boston, a registered holding company, asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for authority to relinquish its control over its local operating subsidiaries,
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt has accepted the invitation of the Women's National Press Club to attend its Stunt Party Dinner, which will be given this year on the night of March 5.

Edith Hamilton, iii a preface to her translation of "The Trojan Women" by Euripides, writes of it as "the greatest piece of anti-war literature there is in the world." It was written 2,350 years ago, and nothing since, "no description or denunciation of war's terrors and futilities * * *ranks with it."
The long tie-up for several San Francisco lumber coasters has ended with the sailing of the Lumberman and the W. R. Chamberlain from this port.

Reflecting what is described as a growing student interest in the subject, a new elective course in religious orientation will be offered by the University of Pennsylvania with the opening of the second semester next month.

Wearing her mother's wedding gown of ivory satin and duchess and rose point lace, Miss Virginia Brown Ostby, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Erling Cornelius Ostby of this ctiy, was married here at noon today in the Central Congregational Church to S. B. Dick Speer of the Goshen Plantation, Augusta, Ga. son of Mr .and Mrs. Joseph McKnight Speer of Augusta and Pittsburh.

Only about 200 taxi drivers responded yesterday to the strike call issued by the Greater New York Hackmen's and Taxi Drivers Union. About 700 members of the union, purporting to act for 10,000 drivers, voted approval of the strike at a meeting in Germania Hall,
Although the co-eds comprise less than 2 per cent of the student body at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, they are taking a vigorous part in the extra-curricular activities.
Educators, public officials and other leaders gathered yesterday to pay tribute to Miss Isabel A. Ennis, a school teacher for fifty years.

Isolation is a word of academic meaning and the United States and Great Britain must stand together at the forefront of the world fight for liberty and freedom, John Bassett, president of The Gazette, Montreal, told members of the Canadian Society of New York last night at the thirty-eighth annual dinner at the Hotel Biltmore.

The graduating class of Brooklyn College held its senior promenade last night at the Hotel St. Moritz. More than 200 seniors and members of the faculty attended the dinner dance which climaxed a week of senior social activities.
The general economic position in Japan is "quite normal," according to a year-end report by the Bank of Japan received by cable by Shoichiro Kobayashi, New York representative of the bank.

THE French woolen manufacturers seem to have been more preoccupied with color this Spring than with weave. Apparently they said to themselves: "Why let the silk people have a monopoly of color? Let's show them what we can do."

FRANK JEWETT MATHER once remarked that Whistler "did a small thing amazingly well," and added: "His fastidious and reticent art, a thing of whispers and raised eyelids, is charming, just that and nothing more."

As 1938 begins to unfold, the noted English novelist who wrote "The Outline of History" and "The Shape of Things to Come," among a large number of outstanding literary works, is moved to peer into the next half-century and give his "guess" as to the way life will be lived by the common man in 1988.

Accompanying a slight pick-up in factory operations, trade this week continued at a high level in the Sixth Federal Reserve District. Retail sales were estimated by a group of leading stores from 2 to 4 per cent above a year ago, and wholesale business was from 4 to 6 per cent higher.

Judging from the large subscription for the dinner dance to be held Friday at the Pierre under the auspices of the Junior Auxiliary of the Silver Cross Day Nursery the funds for carrying on the work of that organization will be augmented greatly.
Less money is required now to fill the housewife's market basket than for many months. The current food index is lower than it has been since 1935 and retail prices conform to the fact.

LONDON.-So concerned is the British Government over the danger of air raids that plans for the huge new building which will house the Air Ministry and other now "homeless" departments have been completely revised to give maximum protection against bombs.

A feud of many years' standing between the Mendez and Davila families brought fresh trouble today when the two families clashed in the house of the Davilas. Eight of the group are now in the hospital suffering from wounds by machetes and clubs.

PERSONAL APPEARANCE: New York's Mayor La Guardia last week visited an exhibition of photographs held by the Press Photographers Association. Out of 335 entries, the Mayor appeared in seven, more than any other person.

Elisha Hanson, counsel for the American Newspaper Publishers Association, declared here tonight that world conditions were such that "thinking men in the United States should pause to consider whether the loss of the liberties that have been sustained by the people of other countries during recent years are likely to be sustained by the people of the United States."

That running phenomenon from Indiana, Don Lash, turned in another of his magnificent performances last night as the Hoosier Iron Man ripped off a 9:11 two miles on the flat 165th Regiment Armory floor at the annual indoor track and field games of the Sixty-ninth Regiment A. A. A capacity crowd of 3,500 attended.

Appointment of Stanley F. Reed to the Supreme Court will not change him from being a regular dirt farmer, his friends in this Northeastern Kentucky town of 8,000 said today. They pointed out that only last week-end he came "back home" to arrange for the sale of the burley tobacco crop grown on his 300-acre Mason County farm.
Mrs. Jennie Marie Sheldon, trustee of Deerfield Academy, president of the Pocumtuck Valley Memorial Association and former teacher of natural history, died today at the age of 85.

To raise funds for the relief of civilian sufferers in war-torn China, an exhibition of early Chinese art treasures, lent by American collectors, will be opened at the Arden Gallery, 460 Park Avenue, on Feb. 2.

A FRIQUE (Alexander Whitkin of South Africa) has come back to the Rainbow Room with mimicry and impressions pfd. of celebrities and anonymities of these and other shores. His repertoire is not wholly free of the stock subjects for mimics-Eddie Cantor, for instance-and he's morn at home when having fun with those who owe allegiance to the House of Windsor.
The session of the League of Nations Council was definitely postponed today to Jan. 26. No member objected to the French Government's request to this end.

Mrs. Edith Mae Cummings, a Detroit real estate broker, was shot and killed this morning on a farm twenty-five miles west of here. Mrs. Julia Barker, a former business associate, surrendered in the office of Prosecutor Duncan C. McCrea, who said that she first related that she had killed Mrs. Cummings in selfdefense but, in a later statement, repudiated this.

A luncheon in conjunction with a card party and fashion show has been arranged by members of the ladies auxiliary of St. Agnes Seminary for next Saturday afternoon at the Biltmore for the benefit of their four-year scholarship fund.

THOUGH no one can complain that there is a lack of recording of Brahms's 'Academic" festival overture, its companion piece, the so-called "Tragic" overture (Op. 81) has failed to arouse much interest in program makers.
Frank L. Pasdeloup, treasurer of the American Bowling Congress for the last thirty-five years, died today of a heart attack. His age was 71.
A store and the second floor in the building at 340 Main Street, Hackensack, N. J., have been leased by Printmasters, printers and engravers, from Hyman Clement Plager through Rusch Boyd, Inc.
IF you like hunting prints, if you are an enthusiastic follower of hounds or, even. a plain hacker in the country or in town parks, you will be delighted with "Sporting Print."
France has no intention of breaking the London naval treaty of March, 1936, by building capital ships exceeding 35,000 tons, the Navy Ministry declared in a communique tonight.

According to the report submitted last Friday to the House Ways and Means Committee by the Subcommittee on Taxation upon recommendations in respect to the forthcoming Revenue Act of 1938, both the undistributed profits tax and the tax upon capital gains will be sought to be retained in principle.
Observing their twenty-fifth wedding anniversary, Mr. and Mrs. Leo F. Krussrman were hosts this weekend to seventy-five guests at their home in Rose Hills Gardens, this city.

Miss Deborah Kallen, founder of the School of the Parents Association in Jerusalem, arrived last week on the Conte di Savoia of the Italian Line to lecture in this country on the school's development and to exhibit examples of work done by the students. While here she will also try to raise funds to found a secondary school.

A total of $8,224,370 in sales tax returns for the last quarter of 1937 had been received from 60,761 taxpayers up to closing time of the City Collector's offices yesterday, City Treasurer Almerindo Portfolio announced.
Dr. James w. Tupper or Lafayette College will deliver the first of three Sunday evening lectures at Centenary Junior College tomorrow at 7:15 o'clock in Whitney Hall.

In report on the "System of Grants - in - Aid of Scientific Research" which is issued by the American Society for the Control of Cancer and endorsed by its executive committee, Dr. James Ewing of the Memorial Hospital, New York, one of the leading authorities on cancer, indicts the present method of financially aiding scientists who are trying to solve the cancer problem.

The first step toward a court test of the State Labor Relations Board's jurisdiction over bank employes was taken yesterday when attorneys for the Bank of Yorktown, 568 Eighth Avenue, applied in Supreme Court for an injunction restraining the SLRB from conducting an election among the bank's forty-four employes.

A man identified by police through papers in his pockets as Bert C. Sellen, 63-year-old proprietor and owner of Kan-Ya-Ta Inn, at Skaneateles, N. Y., died of a heart attack at noon yesterday at the entrance to the pier at Canal and West Streets, where he was scheduled to sail for Miami. Papers in his pockets indicated he was an important member of a Masonic organisation police said.
James F. McKinney, who has been treasurer and a director of the Palisades Trust and Guaranty Company here since its founding in 1902, became its president today. He will continue as treasurer also.

IT is with mixed feelings that one considers the fact that Uday Shan - Kar's performance to morrow evening at Carnegie Hall is to be his farewell appearance in New York before his retirement from professional dancing.

Mrs. James Roosevelt will be guest of honor at the annual benefit bridge of the Alumnae Association of St. Elizabeth Academy, Convent, N. J., which will take place Saturday afternoon at the Hotel Plaza. There will be a fashion show of styles for southern and Summer wear.
Students and faculty at Wheaton are constantly seeking new ways to be useful to Norton and the adjoining towns, with the Y. W. C. A. the most active of the undergraduate organizations.

Premier Mussolini has contracted to deliver in Germany this year a minimum of 30,000 Italian farm laborers. Signor Angelini, chief of the Fascist Farm Laborers Association, proudly proclaims in Lavoro Fascita that the contract is another example of the "far-seeing policy of the leaders of the two nations."

To the Radio Editor: Many of the letters which have recently appeared in this column have indicated the true sentiment of radio listeners as regards the ever-increasing annoyance of commercial announcements being "wedged in" between fine programs in a manner so repulsive to good taste as to mar the enjoyment which the presentation affords.

In a move to bring to a "showdown" the legality of the plan to set maximum trade-in allowances under fair trade contracts in this State on old radios offered in part payment on new sets, letters were sent yesterday to wholesale radio distributors here citing opinions in favor of the plan from Senator Miller,
The Toronto Maple Leafs and Chicago Black Hawks played a 4-4 draw in a National Hockey League engagement tonight while more than 11,000 fans looked on.

Dave Clark, Detroit stable-mate of Joe Louis, won the decision over husky George Brothers of Harlem in the feature bout of ten rounds at the Rockland Palace last night. A crowd of 3,000 saw Clark outbox Brothers in every round. Clark weighed 172 3/4 pounds and Brothers 172 1/4.
One of the problems of the midWinter season, when days are short and hours of sunshine are few, is how to keep in good condition the plants that are being grown in the house.

ROSENDALE, N. Y.-This little Ulster County village, famed as a Summer resort, will take its place next Sunday among the ski capitals of the East when the Telemark Ski Club plays host to twenty-five of the nation's outstanding ski jumpers.
AARON BURR was at once an ironical and romantic figure. Although highly intelligent and cultured, he was nevertheless dominated by restless energy and a sense of the dramatic.
Our first long Arctic flight by moonlight in search of Sigismund Levaneffsky and five companions who disappeared on Aug. 13 on a transpolar flight, has just been accomplished.
RALEIGH, N. C.-To add Interest to motoring, North Carolina is making it easy for vacationists to find the more outstanding points of historic interest in the State.
More sensible study habits for the forthcoming mid-year examination period is to be prevalent on the Skidmore College campus, according to a survey recently conducted by The Skidmore News.

Horace K. Roberson, Director of Public Safety, who permitted Roger N. Baldwin, director of the American Civil Liberties Union, to attack Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City and defend the C. I. O.'s right to free speech last night in a parish house here without interference by the police, was ousted from his post at a special meeting of the City Commission today and transferred to the position of Director of Public Affairs.

Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch of Yugoslavia today had a series of conferences with Nazi officials, including Col. Gen. Hermann Goering. He also talked with Foreign Minister Constantin von Neurath, whose June visit to Belgrade Premier Stoyadinovitch is returning.

William E. Dodd, former American Ambassador to Germany, has received a host of letters and telegrams praising his speech in New York Thursday in which he criticized aspects of the national Socialist regime in Germany, he said today.
SEBASTIAN BACH, THE BOY FROM THURINGIA. By Opal Wheeler and Sybil Dencher. Illustrated by Mary Greenwalt. 126 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton Co., Inc. $2.

Franc quotations fluctuated wildly today in jumps of 1/2 franc to the pound in an unusually active foreign exchange market and at one time slumped to 152 3/4 to the pound before the British Exchange Control authorities got a grip on dealings.
FOR the subject of this narrative poem Padraic Colum has turned to the tales of the traditional kings of Ireland. Many of these kings we know to be historical personages, but their stories,
Sandra Neil, 22 years old, died early yesterday morning, in Bellevue Hospital, after drinking a disinfectant. She had spent months of fruitless search for work, it was learned.

A strike by 245 printers closed down Portland's three daily newspapers today, throwing out of work 8,734 full and part-time employes and cutting off a weekly payroll of about $84,000. Most activity closed at 1 P. M.

Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Boardman of 57 East Eightieth Street and Cold Spring Harbor, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Christina Whitehouse Boardman, to Julian Gerard Buckley of New York.

The new World Headquarters Building of International Business Machines Corporation, 590 Madison Avenue, will be dedicated "to the cause of world peace through world trade" next Tuesday, according to an announcement yesterday.

Japan's takings of American and other cotton may be reduced substantially this year as the result of an order issued by the Ministry of Commerce requiring that all cotton yarns used in the manufacture of fabrics for domestic consumption be mixed with 30 per cent rayon staple fiber, cotton traders here said yesterday.

To prevent the distributive trades from sinking further into "sheriff red," manufacturers must, through distribution engineering, eliminate waste, cut unnecessary steps in their selling and marketing processes and revise their financial arrangements with outlets, Guede Coghlan, distribution engineer, Lincoln Building, said yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia will be a speaker at the dedication of the new Uptown Branch Y. W. C. A., 301 East Kingsbridge Road, the Bronx, today at 4 P. M. Mrs. Cleveland E. Dodge, president of the board of the city Y. W. C. A., will preside. Speakers will include the Rev. Robert A. Ritchie,

Delegates from various parts of the country will attend the national conference of Camp Fire Girls Executives which will open tomorrow at the Barbizon Plaza, Fiftyeighth Street and Sixth Avenue, and continue through Saturday. There wil be morning, afternoon and evening sessions.

Senator George Norris, father of the Tennessee Valley Authority, charged today that "utility company influence" brought about defeat of a provision in the original act that would have made possible carrying out a suggestion today by Wendell wrinkle, president of Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, that the government buy up all private companies in the area.

A between the North and the South exploded in the Civil War a wisp of a woman. Harriet Beecher Stowe, the wife of a college professor. mailed the first chapter of a novel to an anti-slavery weekly in Washington called The National Era.
