When Gifford Pinchot, undaunted by his seventy-two years and two broken ribs, stalked out of his Pike County retreat this week to reveal his plans for seeking a third term as Governor, he accentuated the troubles of Pennsylvanian Republican leaders.
Japan's Immutable policy regarding the situatton in China was announced today at noon in the form of a statemet agreed upon by the Cabinet and Imperial headquarters.

Considering the fanfares and trumpets with which this week's Rome-bloc conference at Budapest as heralded from Rome, its results are extremely meager. It is hardly an exaggeration to say that the City of Seven Mountains labored and gave birth to a ridiculous mouse.

The Ways and Means subcommittee's report recommending extensive changes of the Federal revenue laws is only a forerunner of a broad program of basic tax revision to be concerned principally with the integration of Federal and State taxes and the elimination of tax-exempt

THE GARDENER MIND. By Margaret Haley. Foreword by Stephen Vincent Benet. Yale Series of Younger Poets. 76 pp. New Haven Yale University Press. $2. IF Miss Haley has her head in the clouds, she has her feet in good garden loam, and is not ashamed of the fact.

MID-JANUARY marks the peak of the Winter cruise season, with thousands of New Yorkers seeking gayety and relaxation beneath tropical skies. From now until the season theoretically ends on April 30, more than 240 regular and special sea trips will be taking the vacationists down toward the blue Caribbean.
Government economists, in attempting a thorough analysis of the current business recession, have devoted considerable attention to factors which distinguish it from the slump of 1929.

Discussions of "The Importance of the Movies" by speakers active in various branches of the motionpicture industry will take place at the opening of the four-day fourteenth annual conference of the National Board of Review Of Motion Pictures Thursday afternoon in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Leslie MacMitchell, George Washington High School star, turned in what is probably the fastest mile ever recorded by a schoolboy on a flat track last night when he captured the special invitation one-mile run at the thirty-third annual Stuyvesant High School indoor interscholastic track and field meet at the 102d Engineers Armory.

Edward Miffern Devereux, for more than twenty years treasurer of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad Company and prominent in railroad and financial circles in New York, Philadelphia, Chicago and Baltimore, died today at the Union Memorial Hospital here from a second heart attack following an attack he suffered in New York Thursday.

Miss Gertrude Elizabeth Dally, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Addison Broune Daily Jr. of Pittsburgh, was married to Adrian Mitford Massie of Bronxville, N. Y., at noon yesterday in the Chapel of St. Martin of Tours in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Ben Howe, chairman of the City Fusion party, announces that the formation of similar City Fusion parties up-State and in cities outside New York State is in prospect. Mr. Howe will speak in Buffalo at the first meeting of the City Fusion party there tomorrow.

The Jewish War Veterans of the United States were investigating last night a "misunderstanding" involving a scheduled meeting between Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx and Isador J. Gennett, member of the Morris Krumholtz Post of the J. W. V., who created a stir in Berlin several weeks ago by placing a wreath on the tomb of the Unknown Soldier.

With a thought for the improvement of City Hall Park in time for the opening of the World's Fair next year, the board of directors of the City Hall Park Association.adopted a resolution yesterday advocating demolition of the old County Court House north of City Hall and deploring the delay in razing the vacant old Post Office Building at the south.

Those men who are really interested in wildlife conservation and restoration should certainly plan to attend the Third Annual North American Wildlife Conference, which is to be held in Baltimore on Feb. 14 to 17. Plans are nearing completion for the presentation of the latest research developments and problems in the field of wildlife restoration.
Scoring in every period, the University of Toronto sextet beat the University of Montreal, 6--1, today in an International Intercollegiate League game.

Retail sales in local department and specialty stores during the past week in most instances failed to meet figures for the corresponding week of last year, but a few of the more aggressive merchants with wise advertising and merchandising

Colonel Walter Jeffreys Carlin, member of the Board of Education and chairman of its finance committee, was guest of honor last night of the Cathedral Club at the thirty-eighth annual dinner held at the Columbus Club, 1 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn.

The appointments of Captain Carl Steineke as master of the Hamburg-American liner Deutschland and of George Cusset as chief engineer of the French liner Normandie were announced yesterday at the offices of the lines.

Ten thousand vocational high school students were placed in jobs last year, according to Dr. J. Edward Mayman, guidance director. Despite the recession, the schools have not experienced difficulty in placing students in jobs, he said.

Although job-seeking Columbia University men graduates found 1937 a "banner year," with three times as many calls from employers as in 1936 and a choice of their own jobs for the first time in a decade, the business recession augurs poor prospects for the Class of 1938, according to Robert F. Moore, Columbia secretary of appointments.
Wholesalers and jobbers generally throughout the Ninth District reported business brisk during the past week although retailers differed somewhat in their reports.

While the average of department store trade here fell below that for the corresponding week last year, the decline was not particularly sharp, and estimates indicated that sales for the half-month ended yesterday will be about 2 per cent
Three men were painfully burned shortly after noon yesterday when the motor boat Margareta was destroyed by fire after the gasoline tank exploded.
The Chrysler Corporation, asserting that high demurrage was charged it by railroads for holding freight cars over which, owing to a sitdown strike in its plants, it had no control,

The Council of the League of Nations meets in the next fortnight for its onehundredth session in no mood to Celebrate. It is in a greater quandary on what to do about this occasion than on what to do about the main questions on the agenda.
Ted Ellenwood, Fort Johnson, N. Y. star, took an early lead today in the Eastern States speed skating championships, winning one event and placing third in another for a total of 40 points.

The Netherlands was awaiting today the sound of guns that would announce the birth of an heir to the throne at Soestdyk Palace. The event was expected momentarily, and all was in readiness to spread the news.

Final honors among the field trial retrievers and springer spaniels for the season of 1937 were distributed last week with the award of the Field and Stream Challenge Cups, presented by Eltinge F. Warner, publisher of the magazine.

Van Lingle Mungo, Brooklyn's temperamental fireball artist, took time but today to announce he "is not worrying" about his, future connections. Reports of a brewing Cubs-Dodger deal for the Flatbush team's mound ace notwithstanding, Mungo shifted shifted a hefty quid of tobacco to one side of his mouth and remarked: "I'll...

A belated seasonal increase in Spring buying was reported by wholesalers here this week. The gain of 5 per cent over last week was the first substantial improvement in some time, and put the dollar volume for the week 3 per cent over a year ago.
Taking a commanding lead early in the first period, the Blair Academy basketball team easily defeated Poly Prep today, 44 to 24, in the winners' first Eastern Private Schools League contest.
Funds are needed immediately for civilian relief, medicine and food in the Shanghai area, the China Famine Relief, U. S. A., Inc., anounces. Its offices are located at 105 East Twenty-second Street.

Under the Atlantic Ocean there possibly lies a hypothetical "lost continent of Appalachia." Geologists have speculated about it and for good reasons. The Appalachian range of mountains is composed in part of a vast amount of sediment which drifted from the east.

A Vocational Guidance Conference under the direction of a student committee of seven upper-class women has been planned for the women of Swarthmore College. The conference, the first of its kind to be held at the college, will take place Feb. 11-12.

Members of a junior committee for the annual Blue Ridge Ball to be held at the Plaza on Jan. 28 will meet tomorrow at the home of their chairman, Mrs. Whitney Stone, 136 East Sixty-fourth Street, to discuss plans for the event.
The Japanese decision to prosecute the undeclared war in China, while not unexpected here, was received through press dispatches at the State Department with gravity and apprehension.

James J. Braddock hits the comeback trail Friday night. The former heavyweight champion of the world returns to action in a struggle against Tommy Farr, Great Britain's leader of the unlimited weight class, in Madison Square Garden. They are to battle ten rounds-or less-in a bout that will be of unusual importance to both.

Approval of a bill to authorize the establishment of life insurance departments by savings banks, introduced in the Legislature by a Democratic Senator and a Republican Assemblyman, was announced yesterday by Samuel Null, acting chairman of the legislative committee of the American Labor party.

A musical event of much interest to members of society, including many patrons of music, is the invitation concert to be given by the St. Cecilia Club on Tuesday night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
MR. SHIEL'S story begins as a detective mystery, continues as a cosmic fantasy, and ends as political parable.

Stanley Forman Reed, who has been nominated to be a justice of the United States Supreme Court, is a tall, scholarly appearing Kentuckian now in his fifty-third year. He was unknown nationally until 1929, when he came to Washington at the behest of President Hoover to become general counsel for the Federal Farm Board.

This city's financial affairs became more complex today when the seven Republicans controlling the Common Council refused to attend the special session called by Mayor Joseph F. Loehr, a Democrat, in an effort to reopen the budget.

The statement of Wendell L. Willkie, president the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, here yesterday on the President's holding company stand follows: The President's statement yesterday points inevitably to two conclusions:

NEW JERSEY'S experiment with compulsory testing of all automobiles, which got under way last week, will be watched with great interest. A system of inspection covering brakes, lights, windshield wipers, vision, visibility of license plates and other factors important for safety has already disclosed a surprisingly high percentage of vehicles lacking in one or more of these particulars.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Ten years ago a proposal to enlarge the United States Navy would have found me in bitter opposition. Today I am finding grim satisfaction in the proposals of the President for a supremely powerful navy,
IT is indeed fortunate for our understanding of the greatest poet in English of our generation. perhaps the poet whom posterity will judge to be

A tea will be given on Wednesday at the headquarters of the New York Chapter, American Red Cross, 315 Lexington Avenue, for the Gray Ladies of the chapter's hospital services. Mrs. William A. Roshholz, director of hospital service, and Mrs. William Royce Ray, assistant director, will be the hostesses.

A lower range of quotations in both Liverpool and Bombay caused a slight decline in prices on the Cotton Exchange here in early trading yesterday, but limited hedging operations and a strong stock martet steadied the list, Which gained 2 to 3 points.
A supper was given last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis by Miss Elizabeth Low for Miss Paula Farrelly and her fiance, William Morris.
THE more Bruce Lockhart writes about his adventures the more one sees what a canny and reticent Scot he is. At the age of 50 he has now completed four volumes of memoirs: "British Agent."
The New York World's Fair expects to "disclose the whole story of modern scientific research," Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation, said yesterday.
Although some of the dry goods items on which mills normally name prices for Fall early in January will not be priced this month, some others will be opened this week, it was reported yesterday.
Proposed legislation will have the major share of the attention of the sixty-fifth convention of the Long Island Federation of Women's Clubs, which will be held at the Hotel Pennsylvania on Friday.

To complement the lessons in the positive benefits of good government and community adjustment which visiting lecturers bring to the campus under its sponsorship, the Wellesley Student Forum is this year providing an opportunity for students to view the results of social delinquency.

Although the Palestine Arab High Committee has been declared illegal by the Palestine Government and some of its members have been exiled, while others have escaped from the country, the committee, consisting of escaped members, is now functioning at Damascus, Syria.

A Survey conducted among about 500 freshmen at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute shows stamp collecting to be by far the most popular hobby. Ninety-eight of the students listed it as their sole hobby, or included it among others.

Lawrenceville School's remarkable indoor polo team added another triumph to its list last night when the New Jersey schoolboys made their first appearance of the season in New York and downed Cheshire Academy of Connecticut, 9 to 1, in the Squadron A Armory.

Syracuse flashed great form tonight to turn back Michigan State in an intersectional basketball battle, 59 to 46. State, victorious in six of its eight previous games, trailed most of the way as Bob Stewart, Syracuse forward, led a second-half drive with 14 points.

The first pay day of 1938 passed today, with none of the 19,000 city employes receiving their salary warrants. They faced the likelihood of an indefinite wait, as the City Council must first approve a budget for 1938 and enact a tax program to provide more than $8,000,000 in new revenue.
The National Socialist Year Book for 1938 publishes the thirteen commandments for National Socialist party comrades as follows:

MISS KATHARINE LENROOT, head of the Children's Bureau, will call to order tomorrow a conference the purpose of which is to find ways and means of waging succesaful war against the needless loss of life in childbirth-an enemy that grows more dangerous as the United States grows older.

THE picture or a new United States merchant marine fleet, hitherto presented in vague and controversial details, is now definitely emerging. We begin to see what the ships will look like, and trace the ocean highways over which they will steam.

Marmaduke Burr wrignt, Iormer New York State Assemblyman who paid his funeral expenses ten years ago when told by doctors that he had but a few weeks to live, died of a complication of diseases last night in his home at 10 Rich Avenue. He was 77 years old.

Edward Gunersen, 30 years old, of 62 Second Street, Secaucus, N. J., and his wife Mary, aged 31, are dead as the result of a skidding accident on Route 25 near Old Post Road, in Raritan Township, near here, today.
Members of the military mission, which leaves for Europe Tuesday to study the purchase of material for the army and navy, received final instructions from the Government today.

NINE days hence and the Empire Theatre will have rounded out its forty-fifth year as amusement purveyor to the haute monde. Steeped in tradition, gray with theatrical history, fragrant with the memories of great climaxes, of poignant partings, of thunderous cheers, its calendar jeweled with the names of stage magni?coes of almost half a century, the Empire remains the last living monument of the theatre of the mauve decade.

Historical and contemporary events of the time when the Madison House was founded forty years ago were dramatized by the young people of the lower East Side settlement house at 226 Madison Street for a birthday celebration last night.

Miss Janet Bromley, daughter of John Bromley of Chestnut Hill, was married this afternoon to William Pepper Watts, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Miller Watts of Elkins Park. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Malcolm Peabody in St. Paul's Church, Chestnut Hill.
Retail sales in the Twelfth District continued sluggish last week and volume was smaller than at this
I HAD heard the first perform ance of "Bolero" as a ballet with Ida Rubinstein, as the work had been commissioned by her for her season at the Paris Opera.
For ten years, over week-ends and on holidays, a band of nature lovers has patrolled the Palisades Interstate Park, voluntarily keeping a vigil for those who would destroy its beauties.

The Edith Haggin de Long star ruby, said by experts to be the finest and largest gem of its kind, will be exhibited today in the Morgan. Hall in the American Museum of Natural History, according to an announcement yesterday.
Colonial styles of architecture will continue, for several years, at least, to be the most popular for fine suburban homes, is the prediction of many of the leading architects of Westchester County.

The gross mortgage insurance business done by the FHA during 1937 amounted to $650,000,000, bringing the total amount of business handled by the administration since its inception to more than $2,000,000,000, Administrator Stewart McDonald announced yesterday.

Progress in slum clearance and methods of promoting better housing by taking advantage of recent Federal legislation will be outlined at the seventh annual meeting of the National Public Housing Conference on Friday.

Under the auspices of local chapters of the United Daughters of the Confederacy, the New York Southern Society and other Southern organizations in New York and the surrounding vicinities, the Robert E. Lee birthday celebration will be held Wednesday night at the Ambassador.

THIS account of her childhood and youth ancestry and outlook, by Evelyn Scott, is informative and interesting, if followed by easy stages. Read at a sitting, "Background in Tennessee" drones and becomes confusing.

Herbert O. (Fritz) Crisler, Princeton University's football coach, today spiked the' rumor that he has signed a contract to transfer his sphere of activities to the University of Michigan and asserted that he has not yet been "formally invited" to fill a position at the midwestern institution.

Nomination of Solicitor General Stanley Reed for the Supreme Court drew expressions of approval from many Senators of both major parties today. Democratic Leader Barkley said the nomination was "a fitting climax to a distinguished career."

THE Winter havens in the Caribbean bowl do more than charm the traveler by offering him metaphorical food on a figurative silver platter for purposes of nourishing his perhaps metaphysical mind and heart.

Announcement was made yesterday by the Gdynia America Line that the company had signed a contract for the largest pier area in Hoboken, N. J., giving to the Polish line the most extensive docking facilities available on the New Jersey side of the Hudson.

Foreigners who came into Brazil on tourists' passports and visas good only for six months but who remained here against the immigration law are subject to orders to leave the country within sixty days, according to a police communique issued today.

AS foreshadowed in theme columns some months ago, Italy is combining Italian Somaliland, Eritrea and Ethiopia (philately's Abyssinia) politically. The three become Italian East Africa, and some details regarding this new government's first stamps are now available.

With an expenditure of $100,000,000 during 1937, the United States is in the forefront of industrial research, declares Dr. William A. Hamor, assistant director of the Mellon Institute of Industrial Research, in a world survey submitted to the American Chemical Society.

Chicago Corporation-As of Dec. 31: Net assets at quoted market values for stock and bonds and with controlled corporation carried at ledger value amounted to $31,156,007, equal to $53.11 a share on 586,600 shares of convertible preference stock and to 51 cents each on 3,303,341 shares of common stock.
THE main trend of travel being southward, the amateur photographer who is able to break away for a Winter vacation finds himself faced with opportunity.

Invitations have been sent out for the marriage of Miss Eliabeth A. Tweedy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Leslie Tweedy of London, to Wilbert T. Mendell, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Marlin Mendell of Redwood City, Calif., which will take place here on the afternoon of Jan. 25 in the Church
Much interest is being evidenced in the luncheon and buffet supper to be held Jan. 23 in the Cottage at Hampshire House -to mark the eighth anniversary of the founding of the Lots For Little Shop.
Dr. Courtland Yardley White, chief bacteriologist in the City Bureau of Health since 1910, died of a heart attack last night at his home here. He was 64 years old.

Building permits filed in Mount Vernon, Westchester County, fell from $2,106,260 in 1936 to $619,150 during 1937, points out Harry D. Cole, broker. The reason for this decline, he says, is because 1936 witnessed the filing of plans for the $950,000 Chester Crest apartments, and addition to the library costing $300,000, and another plan for $290,000, which was not consummated due to the lack of satisfactory financing.
The show of optimism that came to the stock market with the turn of the year enabled THE NEW YORK TIMES index of fifty stocks to es tablish a succession of new highs in the first nine trading days.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, in a decision made public yesterday, declared that in its opinion a question of law was involved and the Court of Appeals ought to review the suit of the Federal Government and others to recover $2,842,616 from nine member banks of the New York Clearing House to complete the payment of depositors in the closed Harriman National Bank and Trust Company.
Julius M. Goldstein, who learned the cigar trade in New York, came up-State for his health, built a factory, became Republican leader and was Oneida's first elected Mayor, died today. His age was 83.

Close to 5,000 home furnishings buyers will visit the city this week to scan Spring lines of furniture and lamps at seasonal trade shows opening tomorrow. Furniture manufacturers, who will display Spring and Summer furniture in the New York Furniture Exchange Building, expect 3,000 buyers here during the week, the first of their two-week annual show.
Mr. and Mrs. Arrigo Righi of 449 Park Avenue and Smithtown Branch, L. I., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Righi's daughter, Mrs. Dickson Smith, to Ernest Scott Adams of Houston, Texas.

The United. States Lawn Tennis Association moved today to curb excessive payments to amateurs under the heading of traveling expenses, a practice Chairman Louis J. Carruthers. of. the amateur rule committee said had led to numerous abuses.

Nassau County police announced today that they were looking for John Reobitsch, known as John Reo, for questioning in connection with the killing of Mrs. Celinda Waite and Miss Jeannette Schuellain in Elmont, L. I., last Wednesday night. Miss Schuellain, who was 19 years old, and Mrs. Waite, a widow of 59, were found shot in the Elmont home by George Waite, Mrs. Waite's son.

The American Institute of Steel Construction, 200 Madison Avenue, announced yesterday that it was extending an invitation to students of engineering and architecture in recognized technical schools of the United States and its possessions to participate in a competition to design an urban elevated highway.

New York University undergraduates will start their two-week period of final examinations for the first semester tomorrow coincident with the registration for the second term, which will start in early February, it was announced yesterday by Henry G. Arnsdorf, registrar.

Japanese industrial interests have approached American business men for a $50,000,000 credit for the purchase of machinery. The money would be spent in Manchukuo, where the army is said to have abandoned its ideas of State socialism. [Page 1.]
J. Charles Snyder, 74 years old, president of the Ulster County Board of Elections, died here Thursday at the home of his son, Frederick. Funeral services were held today.
Unemployment shows no evidence of decrease and relief conditions in rural dirtricts have reached acute proportions. Prices of farm products have declined.

China's resistance has not been broken by more than six months of military reverses. On the contrary, pressure of the invader's advance, ruthless methods of warfare and evident plan to dominate the whole country have helped to harden the determination of the Chinese Government and people not to yield.

The newest addition to the facilities of Pembroke College in Brown University, is a field house which was officially opened at a tea held yesterday in honor of the alumnae attending the annual meeting of the Council of the Brown University Alumnae Association over the weekend.

James Graham, vice president of Realty Associates, Inc., of Brooklyn, announced yesterday that a branch office of Realty Associates will be opened tomorrow in the Queensboro Theatre Building at Queens Boulevard and Fifty-seventh Avenue, Elmhurst.

Arrangements for the inauguration of an airline following the routes previously flown in Central and North China by the China National Aviation Corporation- a joint SinoAmerican enterprise in which Pan American Airways holds a minority interest- are now being made in Shanghai, Tientsin and Peiping by a newly formed Japanese company.
As is his invariable custom Josef Lhevinne provided the large gathering of admirers at his recital in Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon with a brilliant display of expert pianism.

AMONG native sources of inspiration for decorative motifs the most American of all are the Indians. Closely related, of course, are the ancient Aztecs and Incas, but the art of the first-named remains separate and distinctive.

Plans for the systematic mobilization of the largest possible number of women consumers of the country in alignment with the proposal presented to President Roosevelt on Thursday and approved by him, occupied the final session this morning of the annual board meeting of the General-Federation of Women's Clubs.

IN nothing are peoples so divided as in their sense of humor, and no division between the American and English peoples is harder to define than this. When the proposed National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis will have provide the adequate sinews of war against the paralytic plague and divested its virus of the mystery that shrouds the power to maim and kill, the skill of two New York women doctors will be perpetuated in the annals of science.

The senior class of Manhattan College voted last week to make available a four-year scholarship to a member of the Negro race who wishes to receive a college education. The award, which amounts to $1,000, will be the gift of the members of the class of 1938 to their college.

Eugene R. Smith, civil engineer, died last night after a long illness at his home -here at the age of 79. Mr. Smith was formerly president of the Islip School Board, president and director of the First National Bank of Islip and director of the Bay Shore First National Bank.

American and English period furniture, English silver, porcelains, Barye bronze statuettes from the collection of the late William Fayal Clarke, tapestries, oriental and Aubusson rugs, antique textiles, paintings, drawings and other objects will be sold at auction at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Friday and Saturday afternoons.

So far the Spring millinery is decidedly less extreme than it has been. Le Monnier's show follows the prevailing influence often stressing pretty hats. Tailleur felts are usually simple; they are brimmed, and the crowns are often pieced in modernistic Patterns.

Harry Albert Braham, conductor and composer, and the first husband of the late Lillian Russell, the actress, died Thursday at his home, 45 Argyle Road, Brooklyn, after a brief illness. He was 78 years old.

Edwin S. Bettelheim, retired owner and publisher of The Dramatic News and Times, died early yesterday of a heart attack in the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, which he entered as a patient the night before. He was 75 years old. His residence was the Hotel Lincoln.

The Pennsylvania Railroad began electric train service over its newly electrified line between this city and Harrisburg today without formal ceremony but with such a shrieking of whistles that thousands of persons telephoned inquiries.

THE four American painters who won the fellowships in book illustration recently awarded by The Limited Editions Club have selected the classics of American literature which they will illustrate.

Despite the opposition of the Socialists, Communists and even without the entire support of the Radical Socialists, Georges Bonnet this evening informed President Albert Lebrun he would try to form a Ministry tomorrow.

The powerful International Federation of Trades Unions today flatly rejected the offer of the Soviet trades unions to join forces when it was confronted with a list of Russian demands that included action in the United States, Canada and South America.

Coroner Edward E. Smith today blamed despondency over marital troubles for the suicide of Joseph C. Timberlake, 31, of Columbus and St. Petersburg, Fla., member of a socially prominent army family and former West Point athlete.

Intensive sales campaigns will be launched next month by producors of consumers' durable goods, such as automobiles, refrigerators, radios and electrical appliances, which have been harder hit by the current recession than have other consumer items, manufacturers said here yesterday.
Russia today suspended all commercial payments to Italy in what diplomatic circles said was a disagreement over delivery of Soviet oil to the Italian Navy.

Many reservations have been made for the dinner and supper dance for the benefit of the Child Placing and Adoption Committee of the State Charities Aid Association which will mark the formal opening Tuesday of the new La Salle Tropicale of Le Coq Rouge.
The Stevens Tech basketball squad defeated Haverford, 40-38, in a thrilling game at the Tech gymnasium tonight. Israel, high scorer, starred for Stevens, collecting 17 points in fourteen minutes.

Columbia's varsity wrestlers beat Syracause today, 15 1/2 to 12 1/2, in a hardfought match that saw three bouts go into overtime. In the last match, the 165-pound bout, Muldoon of Columbia pinned Sheldon to give the visitors their winning points.

Several famous musicians as well as men and women of prominence in society will participate in the entertainment to be given in the grand ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria next Sunday night in behalf of the Musicians Emergency Fund.
LAST Sunday night alumni of the MacDowell Colony of Peterboro met in this city for a reunion and celebration. Among them were workers in all of the fine arts, including many musicians.

A bright new accessory applied here or there can pep up one's Winter wardrobe no end. Officers and members of the First Reserve Aero Squadron Club will give a dinner dance on the night of Jan. 29 in the Silver Room of the Ambassador. Net proceeds will augment the organization's hospital fund for the use of former air service men. Colonel E. Garnsey Brownell is the founder and president of the club.
THE eighteenth loan exhibition in a series presenting work by Old Masters opened Jan. 7 at the Detroit Institute of Arts, to remain current until Feb. 20.

The Light Blue colors of New York City's last unbeaten basketball team trailed in defeat tonight when Columbia bowed to Cornell, 45 to 43. This Eastern Intercollegiate League game was a slam-bang affair in which the visitors came back late in the second period to tie and then take a brief lead,
Attorneys for eighteen private utilities assailing the Tennessee Valley Authority and counsel for the TVA summarized two months of testimony today for the benefit of a three-member Federal court.

FAR away from the hurly burly of fashion shows, where products are paraded before an eager public, the designers of silk fabrics operate. Many of the studios, if they can be dignified by that name, are in the upper stories of midtown loft buildings.

The Department of Botany at Barnard College is trying to give the students that take the elementary course in botany more than a mere knowledge of the names of plants, Dr. Edmund W. Sinnott, head of the department, announced yesterday.

IT is a peculiarity of English musical life that while Handel's "Messiah" is performed in the North before the Christmas holidays, its London performances have usually taken place after the Christmas festivities.

Capital friends learned tonight that Mrs. Lucile Flanagan, a secretary in the office of James Roosevelt, was married on Christmas Eve to Edmund V. Lewis of New York. The ceremony was performed at Alexandria, Va.
Miss Doris Farr, dean of girls at the Thomas A. Edison Junior High School here, died today in the Orange Memorial Hospital after an illness of several months. She was 32 years old.
THE Walter W. Naumburg Foundation will hold its fourteenth annual auditions for pianists, violinists, 'cellists and vocalists in March and April.

HERBERT L. MATTHEWS happens to be a NEW YORK TIMES correspondent in Spain, and therefore a reviewer for this newspaper would like to think that he is an honest observer and a good and gifted reporter.

The wheat market made a firm start and a rather tame finish today advancing about 3/4 cent a bushel early in sympathy with relative' firmness in Liverpool and on continued reports of dry weather and dust storms in the Southwest, but there was no snap to the buying and later fairly general selling developed when prices in Winnipeg started to ease.

For all the acrimonious speech-making that ushered out the old year, the Roosevelt Administration today is more vitally interested in business recovery from the current slump than in anything else, and the surprise conferences of "economic royalists" and others with President Roosevelt during the past week have served to throw a dramatic spotlight on the new campaign.

Miss Florence Payne, a descendant of Dolly Madison, and a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Eugene Payne of Madison, N. C., was married yesterday afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church of Brooklyn to Joseph P. Minetree 4th, son of Mrs. Joseph P. Minetree of Brooklyn Heights and the late Mr. Minetree. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Phillips Packer Elliot.

The new Amherst College Infirmary is nearing completion and will be ready for occupancy in February. Designed in modified Georgian style to harmonize with other recent buildings, it is located on the southeast corner of the campus, near Hitchcock Field, and commands a view of the Holyoke Range.

Princeton's wrestling team scored a 16-to-12 triumph over Penn State today. It was the first home defeat for the Lions in seven years. Charley Toll, 225-pound Tiger football player, clinched the meet for the visitors when he gained a referee's decision over Ernest Bortz in the final bout.

Stanley Forman Reed, Solicitor General of the United States since 1935, was named by President Roosevelt today as associate justice of the Supreme Court to fill the vacancy which will exist whenJustice Sutherland retires next Tuesday. The Solicitor General was 53 years old on Dec. 31.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.-A program of sports and other entertainment is combining with the beach and boardwalk to provide diversion for Atlantic City's Winter visitors.

Minister of Labor Gheorghe Cuza announced today that the Socialist trade unions would be dissolved in the near future and would be replaced by corporations similar to those already existing in various European countries.

Corinto, from the stable of Mrs. Emil Denemark of Chicago, who last Winter scored heavily in Florida racing, easily captured the Fort Dallas Park Handicap at Hialeah Park, before 10,000 persons today.

The thirty-ninth reunion dinner of the Society of the Genessee will be held at 7 o'clock tomorrow evening in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Frank E. Gannett, president of the society, will preside, and the speakers will include Dr. Jacob Gould Schurman, former president of Cornell University, and Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Chamber of Commerce.
At home for the first time in seven weeks owing to English cup games and postponed matches, the Wolverhampton Wanderers thrilled a crowd of 57,000 soccer fans today by defeating Arsenal, 3-1.

THE tradition that writing scholars shall fill at least some of the diplomatic posts at the disposal of the American Government has never been wholly abandoned, and the Roosevelt Administration has observed the tradition in several of its appointments.

More than $407,500,000 in contracts for all types of construction work throughout metropolitan New York were awarded during 1937, reports the F. W. Dodge Corporation. This exceeds the value of awards in 1936 by nearly $89,000,000.

Tribute will be paid to the life and work of Marie Sklodowska Curie, co-discoverer of radium and foremost woman scientist of her time, on Thursday, at 8 P. M., in a memorial program at Columbia University's Harkness Academic Theatre, 535 West 114th Street.

An original Hunter College faculty-student operetta, with libretto by Professor Pearl C. Wilson of the Classics Department and music by Professor Charles W. Hughes of the Music Department; will be presented five times in the week of Feb. 14 at the Little Theatre of the Bronx division.

The appointment of Charles David Gibbons as assistant treasurer of the United States Lines Company was announced yesterday by John M. Franklin, president. Mr. Gibbons will assume his new duties tomorrow.

The report of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its twenty-five principal operating subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Nov. 30, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income after all expenses and charges of $191,324,911.

James Jay Kann, C. Kenneth Baxter and Arthur F. Shettle were authorized today by the Interstate Commerce Commission to act as a protective committee for holders of about $100,000,000 principal amount of securities of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company.

Vic Ronchetti, Chicago youth, snatched a commanding lead at the Ten Thousand Lakes skating meet today in the opening events of the two-day program. Two world records were bettered and one tied.

The number and dollar volume of Manhattan real estate sales as shown by recorded transfers during 1937 showed a marked increase over 1936, due to the large gains registered during the early part of last year, according to figures compiled by the Real Estate Board of New York.

With interest recently focused by President Roosevelt on the need of an annual income of $100,000,000,000 for the country, a timely study of National Income and Capital Formation for the period from 1919 to 1935 by Simon Kuznets has been issued by the National Bureau of Economic Research, 1,819 Broadway.
Stocks advanced vigorously, with armament shares up 1 to 3 points; turnover, 737,810 shares. United States Government issues higher; other bonds steady and quiet; transactions, $3,806,175.
The city of Chattanooga, which is seeking TVA power, lost in the Tennessee Supreme Court today an effort to revoke the franchise of the Tennessee Electric Power Company.

Llewellyn Legge, who served twenty-one years as chief protector of the Division of Fish and Game in the State Conservation Department, died at his home today at the age of 69. He was tricken with a heart attack.

A blanket indictment of the relations of American employers with their employes was made by Edwin S. Smith, one of the three members of the National Labor Relations Board, in an address here last night.

FROM present indications, Africa's travel paths will be well trodden this season, for converts to jungle trails and uncharted forests appear to be increasing. Among unusual and diversified experiences offered Western tourists headed for Africa are
Retail store sales volume since Jan. 1 has been somewhat better than anticipated, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers.
Although Captain Alan McFarland scored eighteen points, the Navy lost its first game of the season to Pennsylvania at the Palestra tonight, 47 to 36, before 7,000 spectators.

Merwin K. Hart, president of the New York State Economic Council, declared today that, unless Amerida awoke, "the United States is going communistic under what in later years will be recognized to have been the leadership of the President of the United States."

THE tradition that writing scholars shall fill at least some of the diplomatic posts at the disposal of the American Government has never been wholly abandoned, and the Roosevelt Administration has observed the tradition in several of its appointments.

More than $407,500,000 in contracts for all types of construction work throughout metropolitan New York were awarded during 1937, reports the F. W. Dodge Corporation. This exceeds the value of awards in 1936 by nearly $89,000,000.

Tribute will be paid to the life and work of Marie Sklodowska Curie, co-discoverer of radium and foremost woman scientist of her time, on Thursday, at 8 P. M., in a memorial program at Columbia University's Harkness Academic Theatre, 535 West 114th Street.

Those attending the luncheon given today at the Wellington by Mrs. Eugene W. Barbier of Bala for her greatniece, Miss Charlotte Louise Gregg, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Pierce Gregg of Edgewater Park Were the Misses Elizabeth A.
More than one person in the course of the last few days may have found himself wondering if Mr. Roosevelt perchance has invented

The reorganization managers of the Lawyers Mortgage Company announced yesterday that more than 7,000 holders of mortgages and certificates exceeding $55,000,000 in face value had filed assents to the plan of reorganization approved by Judge Frankenthaler of. the New York Supreme Court last September.
Miss Pauline Louise du Pont was married today to Alfred C. Harrison 3d, New York attorney, in Christ's Episcopal Church in Christiana Hundred.
One million persons have gone sight-seeing in the skies under the personal guidance of Miss Maude Bennot, director of the Adler Planetarium and Astronomical Museum of Chicago.

The United States spent $100,000,000 on industrial research during 1937, according to a world survey reported to the American Chemical Society by Dr. William A. Hamor, assistant director of the Mellon Institute for Industrial Research in Pittsburgh.

The tenth annual school science fair of the American Institute will be held from May 8 to 12 at Education Hall in the American Museum of Natural History, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, announced last week.

THE vogue of Victoria. started by Strachey. has not spent itself. It gathers momentum. People read about an era and become familiar with its events and personalities. They wish to continue their reading. This book appeals to the Victorian public. nor will there be disappointment. It says things.

Americans of foreign ancestry could do a great service to world peace by uniting in an expression of the benefits of democracy they have had here Rabbi Jonah B. Wise declared yesterday in his sermon at the Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.

Miss Elizabeth Adelaide Turney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Lyman Turney of Yonkers, was married here yesterday afternoon in the Park Avenue Presbyterian Church to Lowell Whittemore of Framingham, Mass., son of Mrs. Horace Alan Whittemore of Brookline, Mass., and the late Mr.

BROADCASTS on the way to Europe do not chug along the surface of the ocean but bounce like a rubber ball, the National Geographic Society points out in commenting on the wonders of radio in abolishing geographical barriers.

Establishment of the Amelia Earhart fund to aid in the campaign for the adoption of the proposed equal rights amendment to the Constitution was announced today by the National Woman's party in the current issue of Equal Rights, its official magazine.

The Cenacle House of Retreats at Lake Ronkonkoma, L. I., will be the beneficiary of a bridge party and dance on Jan. 28 at the Columbus Club, 1 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn. Members of the committee in charge will meet on Friday to complete plans for the event.

Five hundred persons, passengers on a Manhattan-bound train of the Interborough subway, were stranded in the Clark Street East River tube shortly after 9 o'clock last night when water from a leak in a main halted all traffic.
Clues offered by a railroad gateman and three women turned the search for Wilbur James Gould, missing Harvard honor student, to New York State tonight.

Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, 11 A. M. "Problems of the 1938 Session," James J. Wadsworth. League for Political Education, Town Hall, 11 A. M. "Shall Man or the State Survive?" Dr. Ruth Alexander.

Champion Yu Go Han of Orchard Hill, bred, owned and shown in the ring by Mrs. Richard S. Quigley of Lock Haven, Pa., won the title of best in show over 139 other dogs at the roof garden of the Hotel Pennsylvania last night in the final event of the forty-first specialty show of the Pekingese Club of America.

The political crisis in which France has become involved with unexpected suddenness is overshadowing the financial markets here, which, however, show no disposition to lay undue stress on the French situation.

Entering its third major phase, the New York World's Fair 1939 has signed the first contract in its $50,000,000 concessions program, it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair. The fair's 1,000 concessions, ranging from bootblack stands to a 5,000-seat extravaganza restaurant and intra-mural bus system,
Two prominent interior decorators agreed today that the interior of a home should match the hostess who presides over it. They are here for the convention of the American Institute of Decorators.

Eight hundred youthful members of the CCC, residents of New York and New Jersey, arrived here this morning from the West Coast on three special trains for discharge or transfer to camps in the Second Corps Area early this week.

Plans for remodeling the old Mitchell house, a landmark in Flushing, L. I., have been announced in connection with the sale of the property by the Letab Manor Building to Clarence W. Brazer, architect, through Benjamin Rubenfeld, broker. Erected in 1780,

Former Premier Nicolas Jorga has protested against Premier Octavian Goga's planned dissolution of Parliament in a newspaper article, calling it a revolutionary procedure. He insisted that the elected Parliament be convoked.

The New York Rovers demonstrated to the satisfaction of their most ardent admirers yesterday that they never say die. Before a crowd of 14,247 partisans, the largest attendance drawn to an amateur hockey game at Madison Square Garden thus far this season,

Thirty-nine baggage porters and ticket sellers employed at the Kieff railway station are on trial here charged with sabotage. News of this trial was not published in any newspaper, but was printed seriously today in Crocodile, a satirical bi-monthly to which the first complaints were made.

Purchases of foreign exchange for cash and delivery, which this week weighed on the franc, had the effect of decreasing the volume of funds available on the money market. Notwithstanding this circumstance, the market narrowed relatively little.
The Rev. Thomas Burns, one of the most beloved ministers in Scotland, noted for his work in behalf of the blind, died yesterday at the age of 84.

Intolerance and racial prejudice are evidences of immature adulthood, the Rev. W. Dyer Blair said yesterday in his sermon at the North New York Congregational Church, 143d Street near Willis Avenue, the Bronx. Mr. Blair made a plea for a Christian spirit sensitive to the needs and feelings of others.

A gathering of 250 Rumanian Jews, meeting yesterday at the Hotel Astor and representing some sixty Jewish organizations in this country, appealed to King Carol to end discrimination against Jews in Rumania.

E. H. (Ted) Hunter, long recognized as one of the nation's most talented skiers, thrilled a large crowd today in winning the exacting downhill and slalom races as a formidable field competed at Pico Peak, Vermont's newest development for followers of wooden runners and steel edges.

The American Superpower Corporation has reported total assets of $26,827,425 at the close of 1937, including investments of $24,887,855 at year-end market values and $1,315,285 in cash. A year before total assets on the same basis were $46,698,312, including $2,167,728 in cash.

" Excessive poverty, unbridled capitalism and religious intolerance hinder democracy's progress in this country," declared Assistant Dean George E. Payne of New York University's School of Education in a New Year's message to the student body issued yesterday through the university's Interfaith Council.

A joint report on methods to protect the flood zones extending for about 650 miles along the Ohio River from future power shortages in time of flood was made public today by the Public Service Commission of Kentucky and the Federal Power Commission.

Jake Schaefer of Chicago became the undisputed world 18.2 balkline billiard champion last night when he concluded his match at the Strand Academy with Welker Cochran of San Francisco, annexing the final block, 300 to 98.

Cotton prices moved irregularly last week, and after advancing to the best levels since December, quotations receded somewhat near the end of the week. Final prices on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net advances for the week of 2 to 5 points.

To the honors already showered upon Joe DiMaggio this Winter was added one more yesterday when the New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers Association announced it has chosen the Yankees' new homerun king to receive the Player-ofthe-Year award at the chapter's fifteenth annual dinner at the Hotel Commodore on Jan. 30.

In the face of rising national and State public indebtedness, with corollary efforts to meet the mounting cost of government, Nebraska today stands out as the only State with no income tax, no general sales tax and no cigarette tax-and yet has no public debt.

The business recession will be discussed at the next dinner of the Economic Club of New York, to be held in the Hotel Astor on Feb. 2, it was announced yesterday by R. E. Ely, director of the club. Dr. O. M.

A detachment of an Italian Alpine regiment was held pending an investigation today when it was found near Bourg-SaintMaurice in French territory. The Italians said they had been lost in a snowstorm while on frontier patrol.

To the initials P. Q. for personality quotient and I. Q. for intelligence quotient should be added another, S. Q. for spiritual quotient, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, said in his sermon yesterday.

In "Semele's Bar Mitzvah," a melodrama which opened at the downtown National Theatre last night, none of the usual ingredients is omitted. True love, false love, murder, false accusation, madness--they are all there. The author, Harry Kalmanowitch, gets in some amusing comedy relief, served up by the madcap Yetta Zwerling and the inimitably eccentric Leo Fuchs.

Fifteen hundred men will be added this year to the payroll of the Rock-ola Manufacturing Corporation, partly to cooperate with President Roosevelt for the relief of unemployment and partly because the company has had a phenomenal expansion since its

Major Gen. William N. Haskell, commander of New York National Guard, has just approved a schedule of encampments for 21,000 State Guardsmen, made public today, for field training during the coming season in Camp Smith, Peekskill, and other training grounds.

Hotel Commodore (Bowman-Biltmore Hotels Corporation)--Twelve months ended Dec. 31: Net profit, $212,494, before amortization and provision for income taxes, compared with a net profit of $127,483 for the twelve months ended Dec. 31, 1936.1

Dean Israel Harding Noe startled a large congregation at St. Mary's Episcopal Cathedral today with a declaration that the church needs to offer living proof of man's immortality to bring doubters to its services.

Pressure of cash corn for sale on the Board of Trade made itself felt in the futures market last week. While country offerings for deferred shipment t were small, there was no aggressive bidding for the grain at interior points for shipment to ports on the Gulf of Mexico,

The Merchants Association of New York announced yesterday that it had officially approved those parts of the Copeland-Bland bills now pending in Congress that were designed "to end or abrogate the almost endless labor difficulties which have interfered with the operation of steamships in recent months."
Rabbi Judah H. Levenberg, formerly chief rabbi for a group of ten orthodox Jewish congregations in New Haven, died on Saturday in Brooklyn at the age of 58.

The Red Wings and the Maroons battled to an overtime tie in a National Hockey League game before 8,000 tonight, their second deadlock in as many nights. The score was 1-1 and both goals and most of the action came in the first period.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, Governor Herbert H. Lehman and Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia are among the honorary patrons of the all-star entertainment and fashion revue in behalf of the Israel Orphan Asylum which will take place the night of March 19 in Madison Square Garden.

The menacing problem of unemployment will be peacefully and constructively solved- only when our national leaders begin to be sufficiently concerned about the plight of their fellow human beings, Rabbi Samuel H. Goldenson said in a sermon yesterday morning at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street.

The Chicago Bears rallied in the last half today to defeat a group of AllStars, 19 to 10, before 6,000 fans. Trailing 0 to 3, the result of Tillie Manton's 44-yard second-period place kick, the Bears returned to the field in the third period and rushed over a touchdown, then climaxed the assault with two more in the final quarter.

Tommy Smith of Utica, N. Y., and Miss Janet Milne of Saranac Lake today captured the Eastern States senior speed skating titles to repeat their triumphs of last week in the capital district championships at Albany.

Twenty-two-year old Joe Bree of Tuckahoe, N. Y., captured the New York State outdoor speed skating championship today on Sackett Lake, where some 200 of the outstanding Eastern racers competed for the senior men's, women's and intermediate boys' titles.

The course of last week's domestic markets may again be described as negatively favorable. Stock market averages moved up 3 points, although losing part of the gain before the week-end. At Wednesday's best figure, they were nearly 14 points above Nov. 24, the lowest reached in the season's downward reaction.

A plea for sharpening the ideals of right and wrong and a greater certainty concerning the existence and nature of moral standards was made yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of the Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive, in his morning sermon.

Herman Krech has been elected president of the Foreign Exchange Brokers Association to succeed the Charles D. Blauvelt. Other officers elected for the ensuing year are Oscar Peterson, vice president; Bernard J. Snow, secretary, and Frank F. Fabri, treasurer. The new governors are Mr. Fabri, M. I. Katz and Robert L. Root.

The lowest temperature for the Winter was reached at 1 o'clock yesterday morning when the thermometer dropped to 16 degrees. Although there was a rebound to 35 degrees at 8 P. M. the average for the day was 5 degrees below normal.
The executive committee of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations today elected Mrs. Leon L. Watters of New York to the board of governors of the Hebrew Union College here.

This week's stock market opened with some profit-taking sales, but the undertone was firm and a substantial demand for electricals, banks and minor industrials developed. On Tuesday, Wednesday and Friday, purchases for foreign accounts were observed, and these transactions caused some irregular advances, particularly in Siemens Halske and the Reichsbank.

Mrs. Bernard M. Baruch, wife of the financier, close friend of presidents and Democratic party adviser, died last night at her home, 1,055 Fifth Avenue, at the age of 65. She was stricken with pneumonia last Tuesday. Mr. Baruch was with her when she died.

Secretary Ickes made public today a report showing that the Public Works Administration, in its slum clearance and low-rent housing program, had completed thirteen projects at an average cost of $979 per room. The figures were gathered by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

Mr. nd Mrs. Harry S. Bandell of this ity have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kay Sandell, to Edward J. Steiner, son f Mr. and Mrs. Julius Steiner of Ford City. The wedding will take lace in June.

Rivalry I between two factions in the Mexican labor movement finally broke into the open with the start at midnight last night of a twenty-fourhour general strike intended to paralyze the entire State of Veracruz.

Mrs. Roosevelt is near the end of her fifth year Tireless in the White House. But the records show that most of the time she has literally been out of the White House. Rough computations reveal that she has already checked off 200,000 miles of travel.

A series of explosions following a fire in the boiler room of Pathe Exchange, Inc., East Bound Brook, seriously damaged a twostory warehouse here this morning and destroyed a large quantity of motion-picture film.

Olav Aasen, capable performer of the Staten Island Ski Club, accounted for an excellent exhibition today to carry off the top honors in the Class A division of the annual Westchester County ski jumping tournament held on the Norswift Ski Club's Silver Lake Park hill.

PART of the night-life in Bradenton, Fla., is strolling down the street as far as Dizzy Dean's filling station and watching the illuminated sign representing a baseball pitcher going through the motions of whipping a ball over the plate. Unless OF Dizz comes to terms with the Cardinals, he probably will change the sign to make it show a baseball pitcher turning the handle of a filling-station gas pump through the season of 1938.

Convicted criminally of libeling President Rafael Trujillo of the Dominican Republic, in his Spanish book, "The Misdeeds of the Bandit Trujillo," Francisco Girona, the author, must serve three months in jail or pay a $100 fine. His counsel, Manuel Benitez Flores, hopes for a reversal on appeal which was taken yesterday.

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 29 per cent of the capacity, up 3 points in a week and 10 points in a fortnight, from the low point. The trade has no confidence, however, that the apparent revival will hold because late last year some orders were received for replenishment of stocks,
Dean Detton, formerly a claimant to the world's heavyweight wrestling championship, will trade grips with Sammy Stein in the feature exhibition, slated for a finish, at the Hippodrome tonight.

Lanz of Salzburg, Austrian Imports, in 66 5th Ave. through Culver, Hollyday Co and the Harold C. Samuels Co, brokers. Bilt-Craft Shoe Corp, store at 13 W 36th st; Russell B. Corey, broker. Maximilian Olay, new lease, and Walbrooke Welling, renewals, in 170 5th Ave: Cagle Button Corp. renewal in 108 W 8th St; J. D. Robilotto Co, broker.

The National Jewish Hospital at Denver, pioneer institution for the free care of tuberculosis patients on a national non-sectarian basis, held its annual meeting all day yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel,

Despite the refusal of the Pennsylvania Federation of Labor yesterday to purge itself of C. I. O. unions and its stand in behalf of a reconciliation between craft and industrial union heads, Philadelphia labor leaders today envisioned little hope of an early peace among the warring elements here.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In a letter appearing in THE TIMES recently the generally well-informed Arthur Krock rightly took Emil Ludwig to task for making it appear that President Roosevelt was the most surprised of men when he heard himself nominated in the 1920 Democratic National Convention for Vice President. Mr.

Tommy Farr put in a full day's work today for his ten-round bout with James J. Braddock, whom he meets at Madison Square Garden on Friday night. The Welsh heavyweight, in addition to sparring six rounds, did eight miles on the road and considerable bag punching and calisthenics.
A controversy has arisen between lay teachers and religious teachers over the acquisition of the Liceum San Luis in Santa Ana by the Marist Fathers.

A general strike was called in Pampanga Province today in protest against the arrest of 129 "lie down" strikers in a government-owned stone quarry. Sugar workers in the province already were on strike, demanding a wage increase from 30 to 40 cents a ton to 50 cents a ton for cane field work.

Dr. Ruis H. Debayle, 73, eminent surgeon of Leon, Nicaragua, was expected to die last night from diabetes. Congress, before its recess for a few days, believing that the death of the savant was imminent, had passed resolutions that in case of his death national mourning would be declared, that he would be buried with the honors awarded a President and that his body would be interred in the famous Leon Cathedral.

Although official circles are reticent it is generally expected in foreign military circles here, following Japan's announcement of her "immutable policy" toward China, that an intensive military campaign would shortly be launched on several fronts.
George F. Talbot, former Chief Justice of the Nevada Supreme Court, died today of injuries suffered last night in a fall on a downtown street. His age was 79.

A legislative inquiry into the laws governing installment-selling contracts is demanded by City Court Judge Robert J. Summers, who champions the cause of those who lose both their money and the articles purchased when they fail to meet the time payments required in sales agreements.

How a family of five on New York City relief can eat wisely and well on a daily budget of only $1.25 is attested by three well-balanced nutritious meals on view at the annual nutrition exhibit at Teachers College, Columbia University.

The St. Nicholas Hockey Club routed the New York Amateur Hockey Association All-Stars, 12 to 4, in the feature game of a doubleheader at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. In the other contest, the New York Sporting Club downed the Parkwood Ramblers, 2-1, in a Brooklyn-Long Island Hockey League meeting.

With Congress preparing this week to consider the Naval Appropriations Bill, two Senators tonight went on the air, one to urge the need of a strong navy and the other to oppose an enlarged naval program.

The annual election of officers of the New York Safe Deposit Association will be held on Wednesday evening in the Hotel Taft. William C. Orton and William "Cliff" Orton Jr. have become associated with Moore Schley to conduct an unlisted trading department. The firm of William C. Orton Co., organized in 1914, was dissolved last week.

The welfare of minorities is more than ever dependent on the maintenance of democratic ideals in countries where these prevail and in their establishment in other nations, the executive committee of the American Jewish Committee asserted in its report at the committee's thirty-first annual meeting yesterday in the Hotel Astor.

The Transport Workers Union, C. I. 0. affiliate, headed by Coupcilman Michael J. Quill, is planning an active drive here and in Albany for legislation to provide for employes of the Independent Subway System the right of collective bargaining through labor organizations or their own choosing, it was learned yesterday.

One hockey championship already is the property of the New York Rangers. Shutting out the Americans, 4 to 0, at Madison Square Garden last night, Lester Patrick's blue-jerseyed band of athletes clinched the city title, an honor which carried with it the first leg on the William J. Macbeth Memorial Trophy.
Ann Cooper Hewitt Gay returned her diamond engagement ring today to her husband, Ronald Gay, from whom she has separated, and announced that she would move immediately to end their marriage.

Time has ceased to be for the Brick Church at Fifth Avenue and Thirtyseventh Street. The clock was taken down last week from its slender spire. The wrecker is at work, and in a few days or weeks this comely tabernacle where God has dwelt with men in multitudes, this sacred monument of mortals, will be "as the glory of the grass"
The New York Americans, titleholders, eliminated the Brooklyn First Germans from the National Cup competition at Starlight Park yesterday before 5,OOO soccer fans. The score was 4--2.

The four-family flat at 148-48A West Twenty-eighth Street, Bay??nne, N. J., was sold by the Fifth Yard Savings Bank to John F. and Lillian Moran through the Julius Rose Agency, brokers, who also old the taxpayer at 169 Broadway, Bayonne, for Esther Cohen to Raynond J. Cuddy.

Congress will enter tomorrow the third week of its session with the Senate still debating the Anti-Lynching Bill, as other legislation piles up, and with the House hoping to dispose of the Treasury-Postoffice and the Naval Appropriation Bills before the end of the week.

The Rev. Dr. Frederic S. Flemng, rector of Trinity Church, New Cork, and Mrs. Fleming of 1 Lexngton Avenue have announced the Engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Louise Fleming, to Eugene Joseph McVoy, son of Mrs. Forunato Jerace of Rome, Italy, and Chicago, and of the late Eugene J. McVoy of Chicago.

The unemployment insurance division of the Labor Department announced today that more than 16,000 unemployed persons stood in jeopardy of losing rights to insurance benefits because they failed to supply full and accurate information in their applications.

Mohandas K. Gandhi, in virtual seclusion at Shegaon, in the inland province of Berar, announced today he would remain there until he had recovered his health. The Nationalist leader is afflicted with heart disease and high blood pressure.

Earl B. Clark, former major league baseball player, and a companion were killed in an automobile-street car collision early today. Clark, formerly with the Boston Braves, St. Louis Cardinals and St. Louis Browns, died instantly.

Extremist attacks upon big business as responsible for the current recession can bring nothing but a further loss of confidence and should be supplanted by fair-minded analysis and recognition of industry's willingness to cooperate, Henry H. Heimann,
Using the report of the Senate Commerce and Labor Committees to support his charges, Mayor Hague made another attack on the C. I. O. tonight, this time on the organization's maritime union.

With strike leaders charging the steamship companies with a "sit down" to provoke government intervention and the company representatives alleging that longshoremen walked out in violation of a verbal agreement to continue wage negotiations, Puerto Rico enters tomorrow the third week of an absolute cargo tie-up, during which not a single pound of freight has been discharged from or loaded on a steamer.

Elizabeth Anna. wife of the late William and beloved mother of Edith and Mabel Allen, Lillian Alexander, Edna Sturken and Florence Whiting. Funeral services at her late residence. 1,120 Garden St., Hoboken, N. J., on Tuesday evening. Jan. 18, at 8 o'clock. Interment Wednesday, 10 A. M., Fairview Cemetery.

Religion is "sick" because people have found other things that they believe to be more important, and because religion is "sick," society is also ailing, the Rev. Dr. Raymond C. Knox, chaplain of Columbia University, said yesterday in his sermon at St. Paul's Chapel on the university campus.

The Montclair Athletic Club was ousted from first place in the New Jersey Class C division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association for the first time this season when it lost to the Englewood Field Club today, 4-1. The winners now share the lead with the Essex Club, which scored a 4-1 victory over Short Hills at Newark.

Miss Jane Dick Newell, daughter of Mrs. Daniel Edwards Newell of Wilkes-Barre, and Austin King Howard, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Aldred Howard of Binghamton, N. Y., were married here today in Kingston Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Ebenezer Flack.

Miss Madeline Agnes Foster, daughter of Mrs. George W. Foster and the late Mr. Foster of this ??ace, was wed to Hugh J. Devore ??., son of Mr. and Mrs. Devore of ??ewark, yesterday in Our Lady of ??e Valley Church, Orange. The ??remony was performed by the Fostor,

It becomes increasingly clear that the Administration is flirting with two irreconcilable economic programs. On the one hand, there are the vehement and remarkably similar attacks on "monopoly" by Secretary Ickes and Assistant Attorney General Jackson, followed by threats of a new trust-busting campaign and by the President's declaration two days ago that he is Opposed to holding companies of any kind.

A case against E. Frederics, Inc., 235 East Forty-fifth Street, New York, for alleged price-fixing in the sale of apparatus and supplies for use in hair and scalp treatments has been closed because the Tydings-Miller Act, passed last August, permits the practices complained of, the Federal Trade Commission announced today.

A priest who lost his brother i Spain's civil war will say th prayers at the burial services fo Edward J. Neil, Associated Pres war correspondent, who died c shell wounds received on the Terue front New Year's Eve.
Comparatively little interest is being taken in the oats, rye and soy bean markets at present, and a considerable part of the trade in oats was of a local character.

Miss Patty Berg of Minneapolis, defending champion, today won the Augusta women's golf tournament by a margin of 14 strokes over her nearest competitor. Her total was 311. The Minneapolis girl defeated a field of seven women wno hold more-than-sectional titles.

Payion Brickley, left guard on the Pennsylvania varsity basketball earn, was in the university hospital today with a concussion of the rain as the result of a pile-up inder the basket which occurred luring last night's 47-36 victory over Navy at the Palestra.

Assistant United States Attorney John C. Walsh will seek to have vacated in the Maricopa County Court at Phoenix, Ariz,, this morning a writ of habeas corpus obtained by Boies Heed, fugitive co-defendant of William J. Graham and James C. McKay, politically powerful promoters of Reno, Nev.,

About $75,000 will be spent on an alteration project in Greenwich Village as the result of the sale by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank of the two five-story buildings at 9 and 11 Morton Street, running through the block to 51-55 Seventh Avenue South. The houses were bought by the Eleven Morton Street Corporation through Schimmer, Kerner Feder, brokers.

A backdraft caused by a fire that spread through four stores on East Fordham Road near Marion Avenue, the Bronx, at 5:30 o'clock last night blew in part of the roof of one of the stores and blew out the plate-glass window of another, the glass narrowly missing a group of firemen arriving to fight the blaze.

Asserting that the peak of the pneumonia curve for the year occurs between the middle of January and the middle of February, Dr. Charles H. Goodrich, president of the Medical Society of the State of New York, yesterday warned those suffering from colds to obtain prompt medical attention.
The home of Albert Ottinger at 25 West Seventy-fifth Street was filled to overflowing yesterday afternoon as friends and associates of the Republican leader gathered at a funeral service for him.

A State gasoline tax of 4 cents a gallon amounted to $21,032,270 in 1937, but almost $1,500,000 was refunded to those, mostly farmer, who made affidavit that the fuel was used elsewhere than on the public roads. Collections and refunds set new high records.

The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, in the second of a new series of radio addresses, proposed today "a voluntary regulation of production, or rationalization of industry, as the means to the end of annual wages for massproduction industrial workers."

Those of us who are unduly depressed as we view the political state of the world today may merely have lost our perspective. It is, at any rate, both consoling and stimulating to read the latest prophecy of that prince of prophets, H. G. Wells.

Forty-eight of the outstanding book publishers of this country made public yesterday a signed declaration of their intention not to attend the International Congress of Book Publishers when it moves this year, by customary rotation, from London to Leipzig.

A summary of transactions in equity securities by officers, directors and principal stockholders in November, which included also several reports for earlier months, was made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Miss Katherine Rawls of Fort Lauderdale, outstanding woman athlete and holder of twenty-four swimming records, raced 200 yards today in 2 minutes 19 seconds to better the national free style record for the distance by 2.16 seconds.
Harry E. Hull, former member of Congress and former Commissioner General of Immigration, died at his home here today after an illness of about two weeks. He was 73 years old.
Miss Emily L. Penrose, a cousin of the late Senator Boies Penrose, Pennsylvania Republican leader, died today at her apartment in Germantown at the age of 79.

A National Society for the Legalization of Euthanasia, commonly known as "mercy killing," has been formed here, it was announced yesterday. Among the directors of the society, subscribing to the belief that, with adequate safeguards, it should be made legal to allow incurable sufferers to choose immediate death rather than await it in agony, are the following:

The Old Sixty-ninth Badminton Club and the Central Badminton Club's first team were triumphant in men's Class A matches played over the week-end as part of the Metropolitan Badminton Association's team tournament.

Despite cold weather and snow the North Jersey Gun Club's weekly shoot today attracted a good field. t A. F. Streelman was high gun in the first 50-target event. A. B. Blood led in Class B, F. S. Dean in Class C.

The supply of moisture over a large part of the Winter Wheat Belt is far from satisfactory. Precipitation for more than four years has been less than normal, and the subsoil reserve has been depleted until the grain trade and the government are apprehensvie to the outcome of the corp.

" Bublitchki," the new musical comedy presented at the Public Theatre on Saturday night, is not such a vehicle as this reviewer hopes some one, some day, will write for Molly Picon, but it stands up well among the Second Avenue offerings and does give her a number of opportunities to show what a delightful comedienne she is.
Teams representing Brookline, Mass., and the Caledonia Club of New York won their way tonight to the finals of the Paterson Memorial Cup curling competition. Finals will be staged tomorrow morning.

Those who follow their own desires soon come to look on all moral decencies and social codes as oldfashioned, narrow-minded Puritanism, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of Christ Methodist Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, said yesterday.
Chinese reported a counterblow at the Japanese west and southwest of Lake Tai, which endangered their position at Wuhu and Nanking. They also reported an advance in Shantung against Yenchow.

The possibility of a new basic agreement between the Actors Equity Association and Broadway's theatrical managers is near, as the result of talks at a dinner held last Friday night at the Hotel Astor by the League of New York Theatres and the American Theatre Council, it was learned yesterday.

Christ's power to change the lives of men rests not on their belief in Christian teachings and ideals but on their belief in Christ himself, Bishop William T. Manning said yesterday in a sermon at the Ascension Memorial Church, 251 West Forty-third Street.

Mayor La Guardia made public yesterday a letter he has sent Major Charles Spencer Hart, Grand Exalted Ruler of the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks, congratulating the organization for the traffic safety campaign it is conducting on a nation-wide basis.

Miss Gertrude Watson, member of an old and distinguished Buffalo family and a Summer resident of Pittsfield for forty-six years, died last night of pneumonia at Onata Farm, where she had been an invalid since last May, when she suffered a paralytic stroke. She was 79 years old.

Acting under the orders of leaders in both houses, the Legislature will return to work tomorrow night to begin the third week of the 1938 session. It is expected that during the week the legislators, especially those in the Democratic-controlled upper house, will take their first definite step in the enactment of many important measures.
Dr. Cyrus Adler, president of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, announced yesterday that Mrs. Felix M. Warburg had been elected a director of the institution and of its library corporation.

The New York Civil Liberties Committee announced yesterday it was prepared to renew its efforts to have the State Legislature enact laws abolishing the "third-degree" method in the treatment of prisoners. Bills drafted by the committee provide for the immediate arraignment of arrested persons before a magistrate and complete records of all interviews with prisoners by the police.

The industrial recession has been accompanied by a sharp drop in the enthusiasm of workers to exercise their collective bargaining rights through the American Federation of Labor or the Committee for Industrial Organization, an analysis of the record of National Labor Relations Board elections and case settlements in this region indicated yesterday.
Columbia's basketball team finally met defeat on Saturday night, and as a result there is not a single unbeaten college in the metropolitan district.

Bandits last night took possession of the car of Irwin I. Altschuler, president of the Illinois Central Bank and Trust Company, in front of the Standard Club in The Loop.
