They forced the chauffeur to drive several blocks while they took a $1,600 fur coat, a $250 string of pearls and a $175 wrist watch from Mrs. Altschuler and $125 from Mr. Altschuler. They dropped the pearls as they leaped from the car.

With the aid of WPA grants the United States Public Health Service in 1935-36 made a house-to-house canvass of 800,000 families, comprising 2,800,000 persons, in eighty-four cities. The results are incorporated in a report of the highest social importance.

The decline of [Pound]10,443,346 in the circulation of the Bank of England in the week covered by the bank's last report makes the total decline for the three weeks since Christmas [Pound]27,183,000, which is [Pound]8,114,000 greater than the decrease in the same period last year.

Debutante and junior committees have been formed to aid with the plans for the bridge party and tea to be held in behalf of Everybody's Thrift Shop on Jan. 25 at the Plaza. Miss Millicent Bowring is a member of the debutante group, of which Miss Catharine Rogers is chairman. They are assisted by the Misses Helen Michalis, Lois Burchell, Ruth Auchincloss, Edith Sawin and Ruth Burchell.

Christianity is the most practical religion in the world today, the Rev. Dr. Raymond B. Drukker said 4 yesterday morning in a sermon at the East Eighty-ninth Street Reformed Church, between Park and Madison Avenues.

The National Institute of Health of the United States Public Health Service made public today a preliminary report on the results of a "national health inventory," the "most comprehensive and widest in scope ever taken in the United States," made during the past two years by the Public Health Service in conjunction with a $4,000,000 grant of the Works Progress Administration.

A 59-year-old man who was related by marriage to Mrs. Celinda Waite, one of the victims of the double murder at Elmont, L. I., last Wednesday, was found living in a furnished room here yesterday, as Nassau County detectives were preparing to open a widespread search for him in the Middle West and in Florida.

The Independent Committee for Protection of Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad Company Bondholders pleads with the Interstate Commerce Commission in a plan of reorganization, filed with the commission and made public today,

Stocks of lard have started to increase as the result of larger receipts of hogs. The accumulation in local cold storage warehouses in two weeks has aggregated 6,737,000 pounds, with total holdings of 27,866,000 pounds, compared with 85,849,000 a year ago.

The German wholesale price index on Jan. 5 stood at 105.6, against 105.5 on Dec. 22. For the full year 1937 Germany's wholesale price index, based on the average of 1913 as 100, ranged between 106.9 on Aug. 11 and 105.2 in the first week of January.

Major John A. Warner, a child piano prodigy who grew up to become superintendent of New York's State Police, made one of his rare concert appearances today. The police director was guest soloist with the Albany Federal WPA orchestra, presenting Franck's "Symphonic Variations for Pianoforte and Orchestra."

Finishing one-two in the slalom racing, Warren Gammons and John Senn today led Union College to the championship in the first annual New York State invitation college ski meet held in South Corinth in the Lower Adirondacks.

Boris Shumiatsky, chief of the Soviet motionpicture industry, has been quietly removed after two years of growing criticism of Soviet films. for their insufficient quantity, poor quality and wasteful methods of production. However,
More skiing, skating and coasting than the North Shore communities have had for many years occupied both the older and younger members of society and their house guests today and last night.

On the eve of what may be the most important Anglo-Irish conference for years, the continued separation of Ulster from the rest of Ireland loomed tonight as almost the last serious obstacle to reconciliation between Britain and the newly named State of Eire (Ireland).

While wheat futures advanced last week to new high levels since late in October, there was little evidence of a general broadening in speculative interest, and the export business, which had been the backbone of the market for some time, fell off materially.

Hamilton Terrace, 40; Gertrude Cohen, referee, to Home Owners Loan Corp, foreclosure. 16th St, 331 E; Central Savinge Bank to Clara Leitner, 370 Bedford Ave, Brooklyn ($30). 48th St, 426-8 W; Marie J. Bower to Ricka Mamaroneck Corp, 3,341 Reservoir Oval. all right, title and interest; mtg, 20,000 ($2.50).

Counsel for eighteen private utilities and for the Tennessee Valley Authority today were awaiting an early decision from a three-judge Federal court on the suit in which the utilities have sought to invalidate the act creating the TVA.

Swimmers of St. Francis Prep dominated the spotlight in the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association individual championships conducted by the Columbus Council, K. of C., at the Columbus Club in Brooklyn yesterday and raced to victory in five of the eight events.

Birger Ruud of Norway, Olympic skiing champion in 1932 and 1936, made two spectacular jumps of 172 and 181 feet before a crowd of approximately 20,000 today to carry off Class A honors in the Norge Ski Club's annual international tournament held near Cary, Ill.

Allan Clark and Egbert Moxham Jr. were the winners today among the seventeen frostbite dinghies whose crews braved the chill though moderate westerly wind to sail five races in the regular Sunday regatta on Manhasset Bay.

Washington's Redskins, National professional football champions, defeated the Pacific Coast All-Stars, 14 to 13, today in a game played in an almost continuous downpour of rain. Five thousand spectators huddled under umbrellas and improvised shelter as the players slipped over the muddy field.

Miss Helen Headley Goble, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. harry H. Goble of this city, was married this afternoon at the home of her parents to Robert Gordon Planck, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon C. Planck of Irvington.
W. F. Herman, publisher of The Windsor (Ontario) Daily Star, died here last night after an operation. He came to Southern California last month.

The St. Mary's Celtics and the Brooklyn Hispanos, both of the American Soccer League, played to a 1-1 overtime tie at Commercial Field yesterday in the competition for the National Challenge Trophy of the United States Football Association.

New York City spent $835,113,704 in 1937, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick reported yesterday. Its revenues for the year were $1,398,131,057, of which $783,431,057 represented receipts from real estate and other taxes, State school aid, dock rents and other varied sources.
Hesitancy appears to be the keynote of the steel market, with buyers delaying purchases until more definite indications of the future appear, according to the magazine Steel this week.

Mr. and Mrs. James B. Forgan of this place announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Forgan, to G. Bronson Farnam, son of Mrs. George Bronson Farnam of New Haven, Conn., at a party today in their home. Mr. Farnam's mother came to Chicago for the event.

Reports were circulating today among city officials that the budget deadlock between Joseph F. Loehr, Democratic Mayor of Yonkers, and the Republican majority in the Common Council would be ended with a compromise.

Following the futile attempts of Georges Bonnet to organize a government today, Leon Blum, describing what he was doing as "audacious," tonight was trying to form a Cabinet which would include, in addition to the members of the Popular Front, representatives of all parties "attached to democracy."
Portland newspaper reporters appealed today to the Multnomah Typographical Union to mediate its demands and end the printers' strike which closed the city's three newspapers yesterday.

Edwin Morris Capps, one-time Mayor and harbor engineer of San Diego, died at his home here today at the age of 77. Mr. Capps settled in San Diego in 1886. He was city engineer of San Diego, 1892-99, and Mayor, 1899-1901.

Mayor La Guardia, in good spirits after admitting he had "read in the papers that I was cross" on Saturday, spoke briefly yesterday at the dedication of the new uptown branch of the Young Women's Christian Association , 301 East Kingsbridge Road, near Fordham Road, the Bronx.

This country's views of the situation in the United States are divided, although the opinion prevails that politics is confusing greatly the economic issues and that planned economy in the United States has turned out to be a failure.

Samuel Ross Limerick, former assistant general superintendent of the Baldwin Locomotive Works, died of a heart attack at his home here today at the age of 57. He joined the Baldwin company, after attending the public schools, and was connected with it for more than thirty years.
James Roosevelt, son and secretary of the President, who came from Washington yesterday to visit his 5-year-old daughter, Sarah, ill at his home here, returned by train to the capital tonight.
The Jersey Reds captured the American Professional Basketball League first-half championship for the second straight year today by .defeating the New York Jewels, 27 to 20.

The season's first "Lucia di Lammermoor" and the return to the company of Karin Branzell and Eide Norena will mark the ninth week of the Metropolitan Opera's program next week. The full schedule for the week follows:

Announcement has teen made by Mrs. Nathaniel F. Glidden of this place of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Tapp Bird, to Gerard Piel, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Piel of New York and Salisbury, Conn.

Some slowing down of Great Britain's foreign trade is indicated by the figures for December. The month's imports increased 12.9 per cent compared with an expansion of 21.4 per cent for the year while December's exports increased 8.3 per cent against the year's 18.4.
Speculative interest in wheat futures was somewhat larger last week, due to the development of a minor crop scare in the Southwest caused by reports of dust storms.

The Toronto Maple Leafs, leaders of the National Hockey League's international division, staged a five-goal scoring burst in the third period tonight to route the Chicago Black Hawks, 7 to 2, before 15,561 spectators, the largest crowd to see a hockey game here in three years.
Foreign importers in this Japanesedominated trade gateway to China are pressing for action from their governments because of fear that duty-free Japanese goods will wreck their markets.

Harry Goldstein, the Trinity Club's national champion, advanced to the second round of the Eastern open A. A. U. one-wall handball championship by defeating Pat D'Orsi of the National A. C. at the Trinity Club, Brooklyn, yesterday.

Davidson Ave (11-203), w s, 145 ft s of 190th St, 75x100; Max Nisnewitz to Jerrose Estates, Inc. 521 Ave, mtge $109,827. Washington Ave (11-2915). c s. 258 ft s of 174th St. 41x109; Mayer Lublin to Sadie Lublin, 1,700 Washington Ave. Houghton Ave. 2,260 (14-3694): Philip Heinrich to Mary F. McCandless, 2,118 Hermany Ave.

A 76-year-old father and four children, the youngest 6 years old, were burned to death here last night when flames swept the two-story frame house in which they were sleeping. The mother was out shopping and chatting with friends when the tragedy occurred.

President Oscar Raimundes Benavides today inaugurated the 2,500,000-sole railroad bridge "Carrion," spanning Verrugas canyon in the Rimac Valley, one of Peru's natural wonder spots. It is located 85 kilometers inland from Lima.

Mona Rani, assisted by her Hindu musicians, gave her only recital of the season at the Guild Theatre last night. The program was made up in the main of dances that have been seen in her performances of other seasons, with the addition of three titles that do not appear on earlier programs.
James Boyd, formerly assistant Eastern district manager, has been appointed. Eastern district manager of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, according to announcement yesterday.

Tentative plans of United States High Commissioner Paul V. McNutt to visit Shanghai for a conference with Admiral Harry E. Yarnell, commander of the Asiatic Fleet, await President Roosevelt's approval, the Commissioner's office said today.

Thousands of skiers came to the Berkshire uplands by special snow trains and automobiles for the week-end of Winter sports. Conditions were ideal in Pittsfield State Forest, on Warner Mountain at Great Barrington and on Greylock in Northern Berkshire.

Paced by Nat Frankel, who tallied fourteen points, the Brooklyn Visitations turned back the Original Celtics, 36 to 29, in an American Basketball League game at the Hippodrome last night. A crowd of 3,000 witnessed the contest, which was marked by forty-six personal fouls.

The determination of the State Labor Relations Board to avoid interference in the stability of contracts honestly entered into by an employer and his employes was affirmed in two decisions made public yesterday.

The Boston Bruins ended the first half of the National Hockey League's fortyeight-game campaign with a hardearned 1-0 victory over the Canadiens tonight before an overflow crowd of 16,000 at the Boston Garden.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Mary Louise Hanby, daughter of Mrs. Louis Lee Hanby of this city, to John Thompson Marshall of Glen Ridge, N. J., son of Mr. and Mrs. S. Furman Marshall of Langhorne, Pa.

Slammin' Sam Snead walked away with the $3,000 Bing Crosby golf tournament today for the second straight year. The long hitter from White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., had a thirtysix-hole score of 139, set a new course record of 67, 5 under par, on the final round today, and pocketed most of the money put up by the movie star.

Mr. Bridge, nd Mrs. John Shreve Wise Jr. of allentown have announced the enagement of their daughter, Miss Tlorence Adele Wise, to Howard Earthwaite Smith, son of Mr. and Irs. Karl Garthwaite Smith of south Orange, N. J..
Newspaper comment endorses the government's statement on its China policy without marked enthusiasm and without adding anything significant to the familiar arguments.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,071,155,500. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

L. C. Haines of New York captured now gross by one stroke in the eighteen-hole medal play handicap competitionn of the Winter Golf Leaguee of Advertising Interests at :he Palm Beach Golf Club today with 42, 41-83. More than 100 mempers of the organization are here for its thirty-first annual championship, which will start tomorrow.

For two days now Barcelona has been in an almost constant state of alarm for there have been five rebel air raids since yesterday morning. The attacks all have been concentrated on the outer section of the city where the factories are located. On the whole, however, the damage has not been great or were many persons killed.

Hillman-Curl has signed a contract with Johannes Steel for his biography of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, former Minister of Economics of the German Government. The biography will be published next Fall. Mr. Steel is also the author of "Escape to the Present," which Farrar Rinehart published last September.

Although some of the compositions brought forward by Gaspar Cassado, the eminent Spanish 'cellist, at his recital in Town Hall yesterday afternoon, were unworthy the effort expended upon them, even the least inspired of them was lifted to the heights by the unswerving excellence of the artist's performances.

Harold R. Atteridge, one of the most prolific of Broadway librettists, who provided the book and lyrics for more than two score Shubert productions, died Saturday morning at his home in Lynbrook, L. I., of cirrhosis of the liver after an illness of five months. he was 51 years old.
The season during which muskrat may be trapped opens Thursday in twenty counties throughout the State and continues until March 20, the Conservation Department announced today.

Former Supreme Court Justice Arthur S. Tompkins is being treated for shock at Nyack Hospital, where he has been a patient since Jan. 4. Dr. G. F. Blauvelt, chief of the hospital staff, said tonight that the former jurist's condition was critical.
R. U. Knox won the eighth and last qualifying round of the Siwanoy Country Club's twenty-ninth annual Sno Birds' golf tournament by posting 98-18-82 today. Although his score was bettered by

Detailed returns show that Great Britain's steel output in December aggregated 1,103,800 tons, against 1,178,300 in November and 1,019,200 in December, 1936. Iron production last month was 783,800, the largest since 1918 and comparing with 762,300 in November and 671,400 in December, 1936.

Vic Ronchetti of Chicago today won the men's championship of the Ten Thousand Lakes skating meet, during which four outdoor world marks were bettered. Ronchetti scored 130 points in the two-day event to take the Governor Elmer Benson Trophy. Frank Stack of Sudbury, Ont., was second with 100.
Philip Murray, chairman of the C. I. 0. Steel Workers' Organizing Committee, declared today that he was "hopeful" of renewing labor contracts in the steel industry.

190th St, 75x100; Max Nisnewitz to Jerrose Estates, Inc. 521 5th Ave, mtge $109,827. Washington Ave (11-2915). e s. 258 it s of 174th St. 41x109; Mayer Lublin to Sadie Lublin, 1,700 Washington Ave. Houghton Ave 2,260 (14-3694): Philip Heinrich to Mary F. McCandless, 2,118 Hermany Ave.

The Rev. Moses Richardson Lovell, pastor of the Second Congregational Church here, at this morning's service announced his acceptance of the call to the Central Congregational Church of Brooklyn, where the late Rev. Dr. S. Parkes Cadman was and minister for thirty-five years.

Even before the resignation of Premier Chautemps the Cabinet crisis in France was the center of financial interest here, and contributed, with tighter money, to the indecision and weakness on the Boerse.

Peace between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization must be concluded without delay if the trade union movement is to escape disintegration and restrictive legislation, Max Zaritsky, president of the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers International Union, declared yesterday in demanding resumption of peace negotiations between the warring camps.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the ave .ge for 1926, was 83.9, which compares with 83.2 a week ago, 83.1 two weeks ago, 83.2 three weeks ago and 83.9 four weeks.

It is several since John Steuart Curry held his last show in New York, although work by him has, or course, been included in large group exhibitions. Special interest, therefore, attaches to his current solo appearance at the Walker Galleries, 108 East Fifty-seventh Street, where may be seen six recent oils and some water-colors and drawings, together with one older canvas. "Early Morning Roundup," which was done in 1934.

George T. Keating of Plainfield, N. J., one of the first Conrad collectors in the United States, has given his collection to the Yale Library. The collection contains every issue of the first English and American editions of Conrad's works, the periodicals in which his stories and articles appeared, and all of the volumes and pamphlets written about him.
Minor outbreaks of violence that flared up Saturday night in the strike of taxicab drivers belonging to the Greater New York Hackmen's and Taxi Drivers Union were not repeated yesterday.

Bobby Riggs of Chicago won the Nautilus tennis tournament today, defeating Wayne Sabin of Hollywood, Calif., 7-5, 8-6, 6-1, in the final. Both played a deep-court game. Sabin gave the spectators the impression of being "overtennised," and Riggs, except for being caught flatfooted by several smart returns, was master throughout.

In our first Arctic search by moonlight for Sigismund Levaneffsky and his five Russian companions, which was reported briefly yesterday, we covered 1,425 miles in temperatures ranging to 51 degrees below zero Fahrenheit.

An 850-foot miniature railway built on the Vincent Astors' St. George's estate, Ferry Reach, for carrying guests from the boat-house to the residence had a trial run yesterday under the direction of the chief engineer of the Bermuda Railway, H. Kitchen.

The Rev. Dr. Wilbert W. White, founder and president of the Biblical Seminary, 235 East Forty-ninth Street, observed quietly yesterday his seventy-fifth birthday. This evening Dr. White will be guest at a testimonial dinner at the seminary. About 200 will attend.

From all parts of Connecticut, New York and New Jersey the letters have been coming in with various opinions on the matter of the fly versus the worm fisherman, and although it isn't the season for it, it might be a good idea to get some of these things straightened out before Spring.

Mayor Frank Hague announced here today that he had written a letter informing Prosecutor Daniel T. O'Regan that forty Republicans, hired as special deputy superintendents of election to police the polls of Hudson County during the November Gubernatorial election, had criminal records.

Fire Commisisoner John J. McElligott played host yesterday afternoon to fire chiefs of the leading cities of the nation who will attend the annual meeting of the International Association of Fire Chiefs this week at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Mr. McElligott took the visiting firemen for a ride.
The writer of these lines, whose principal occupation it is to report performances of symphony and opera, is much interested in jazz and other forms of American popular music. He thinks,

The French wholesale price index on Jan. 8 was 808, compared with 601 and 599, respectively, in the previous two weeks. The rise was most noticeable in imported products at 527, Compared with 515 and 517, respecUtively, while native products in- A creased again to 654 from 650 and 645. Foodstuffs were 622, against 615 and 608; industrial materials 697, against 591 and 593.

The proposed amendments to the Real Property Law transferring all functions and documents pertaining to real estate, which now are filed in the County Clerk's Office, to the Register's Office, which has the custody of all title records,

The cotton market here last week was somewhat quiet, with prices fluctuating narrowly. Early in the week contracts were scarce and a fair trade demand, coupled with firmness in spots and the goods markets, caused a moderate advance, but this was checked by a recession in stocks and easier foreign markets.

The annual report of the Adams xpress Company for 1937, pubshed yesterday, revealed a further intraction in portfolio, with oneird fewer corporations reprented than in 1936. Drastic changes investments were made last War.

Young persons who contemplate marriage were urged yesterday by Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, to proceed with prayer and common sense. He warned against the over-idealization of "falling in love" and named forbearance as the one quality that preserves the happiness of wedded couples after the first flush of love in its superficial aspects has wornoff.

Ross C. Lyons of Indianapolis has been elected chairman of The Princeton Tiger, campus humor magazine, it was announced today by the publication's retiring head, Albert M. Barbieri of Richmond Hill, Queens.

It is learned from a reliable source that during the past year more than f1,250,000 has passed from the British-owned Rio Tinto Company in London-a company that owns valuable copper and pyrites-producing mines in the south of Spain-to General
Buyers in the wholesale market last week to view new apparelines began to place orders for Spring merchandise, although action is still running under last year in most lines.

The financial markets in The Netherlands began the year in a somewhat better mood than they had finished 1937. This is accounted for mainly by psychological influences, as actual economic conditions have not improved.

The Hon. Patrick Bellew and the Hon. Mrs. Bellew, who is the daughter of Lord Decies, will arrive this week on the Bremen and will be at the Plaza. Mrs. John G. Winant and Miss Constance P. Winant have come from Concord, N. H., to the Drake.

Miss Josephine Simpson Logan, daughter of Mrs. Samuel Simpson Logan of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia, has completed plans for her marriage on Feb. 19 to John Leonard Merrill Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John Leonard Merrill of Greenwich, Conn.

Rallying in the last five minutes, the Crescent Athletic Club five downed the New York Athletic flub, 39 to 36, in an Eastern Athetic Club Basketball League game at the Winged Foot gymnasium yesterday. The setback was the firstt in three tournament contests or the New York A. C.

The Jewish Board of Deputies, spokesman for 300,000 British Jews, today called on the British Government to solve he future of Palestine by making at a "Jewish dominion within the British Commonwealth of Nations."

The fresh frano crisis which happened this week, forcing the government to resign, was not altogether unexpected in financial circles. It was the consequence of rapid evolution in the political situation.

Curtis Stevens, Olympic star, piloted his bobsled team to a narrow victory today in the Adirondack A. A. U. four-man mile championship on the Mount Van Hoevenberg run. His total time for the four heats was 4 minutes 40.34 seconds, the last being made in 1:09.76, the best of the day.

Roger Fawcett broke 100 straight targets for the high-over-all cup in the New York A. C. shoot yesterday. It was the Winged Foot gunner's second perfect string of the season at the Travers Island traps.
Amicably but firmly Miriam Hopkins has withdrawn from "Wine of Choice," the S. N. Behrman play which closed in Pittsburgh last Saturday night for revisions, and reopens next Monday in Baltimore.

Miss Josephine Simpson Logan, daughter of Mrs. Samuel Simpson Logan of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia, has completed plans for her marriage on Feb. 19 to John Leonard Merrill Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John Leonard Merrill of Greenwich, Conn.

Rallying in the last five minutes, the Crescent Athletic Club five downed the New York Athletic flub, 39 to 36, in an Eastern Athetic Club Basketball League game at the Winged Foot gymnasium yesterday. The setback was the firstt in three tournament contests or the New York A. C.

The Jewish Board of Deputies, spokesman for 300,000 British Jews, today called on the British Government to solve he future of Palestine by making at a "Jewish dominion within the British Commonwealth of Nations."

The fresh frano crisis which happened this week, forcing the government to resign, was not altogether unexpected in financial circles. It was the consequence of rapid evolution in the political situation.

Four Catholic women who were in Christ Church here yesterday when fifty Communist youths attacked and burned it were released by the police this morning after having passed the night in jail under arrest, but thirteen Catholic men were still being held because none of the police would take the responsibility for having ordered their arrest.
A strike of 20,000 workers for higher wages and shorter hours closed most of the leading Swedish hotels today. The workers walked out in the early morning after the collapse of mediation efforts.

John M. Horan, oldest active railroad employs in the United States, will be 100 years old next Sunday and he still is on the job every day. On April 17 he will have completed eighty-three years of service for the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad Company, his first and only employer.

The Board of Trade's index of wholesale prices in December, based on 1930 as 100, was 107.6, compared with 108.5 in November and 100.8 in December, 1936, a gain of 6 3/4 per cent over the latter. For the whole year, the average of prices was higher than 1936 by 15.1 per cent;
While brilliant sunshine bathed Cannes, where the Duke of Windsor is now staying, driving rain today swept the battlements of deserted Fort Belvedere, the Duke's last home in England.

Senator Copeland, chairman o the Senate Committee on Commerce, it was announced yesterday, has designated Robert Daru, former special counsel to the committee, to make a report on certain serious conditions in the American merchant marine, partly relating to the narcotic traffic.

Dr. Edward P. Swift, one of the incorporators of the Village of Pleasantville and a well-known homeopathic physician who had practiced for more than fifty years in New York and Westchester, died here yesterday at his home, 25 Halsted Place, after an illness of three weeks.

The government's biennial census of manufactures, which will get under way Jan. 25 with the mailing of schedules to manufacturers, will include inventory information for the first time, the Department of Commerce announced today.
The first meeting of the new merchandising division of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers will be held on Jan. 25 in the Le Perroquet suite of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Dr. Jan de Groot, Crown Princess Juliana's physician, told the press this afternoon that there was no definite indication that her expected child would be born tonight. The event may still be a few days hence, he said. Dr. de Groot left Soestdyk Palace this evening to pass the night at a house near by.

Mr. and Mrs. James Bryan McCormack of this place have announced the engagement of their niece, Miss Gertrude Benjamin, to Dr. James Peter Warbasse Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Warbasse of Brooklyn and Penzance Point. Woods Hole. Mass.

The Bethlehem Hungarians defeated the Irish-Americans today by 5-3 in the first round proper of the National Challenge Cup competition of the U. S. F. A. At half time the rivals were deadlocked at 1-1.
Gales which had buffeted the British Isles with hurricane force at times over the week-end subsided appreciably tonight, leaving at least ten persons dead and widespread property damage.

Industry in he first half of January is reported ?? be less active, but, with the exeption of textiles, the decline was confined to the outdoor branches. The number of unemployed in Deember increased by 422,000, of which 222,000 were in the building industries.

Charity funds distributed through the New York Community Trust in 1937 reached a new high total of $207,899. In 1936 the total was $200,794. Institutions which benefited rose to forty-seven last year from twenty-nine in the previous year.

With the wind-up today of the first of the two series of Winter dinghy races at the Larchmont Yacht Club, Frank Campbell, with his Class B boat Felix, and Harry Hall, with his Class X craft Wow, sailed by Dick Hill, topped all the others.

New York City's policemen are to be trained in marksmanship by one of the nation's crack pistol shots. The new instructor assigned to the police pistol range at headquarters starting today is Patrolman Adolph P. Shuber, formerly of Motor Cycle Squad 1.

Ralph Emerson, legislative representative of the maritime unions affiliated with the Committee for Industrial Organization, in a statement today asserted that the Senate Commerce Committee, which yesterday made public testimony before joint hearings of the Commerce and Labor Committees of the Senate, looking to maritime law changes, no longer made any pretense of impartiality.

A total of 128 supply contracts valued at $10,174,590 were let by eleven Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act in the week ended on Jan. 13, the Labor Department has announced.

The administrative committee of the Zionist Organization of America, meeting yesterday at the Hotel Astor, adopted a resolution condemning "unauthorized political activities designed to create the false impression that the Jewish people reject any proposal for a Jewish State."
President Alberto Enriquez today issued a decree requiring a pre-nuptial medical certificate which may be issued by any licensed physician.

Eighteenyear-old Kung Teh-chen, seventyseventh lineal descendant of Confucius, announced his intentions today to pay an early visit to America during his tour abroad. He said he was considering the possibility of entering an American university.

The invasion of China by the Japanese has made the Chinese people "open-minded to the work of Christian missionaries and more responsible to the Christian gospel than ever before," Dr. E. Stanley Jones, Methodist Episcopal Church missionary to India,

The campaign to obtain contributions for the new National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis will be launched on a nation-wide basis today. In New York a city-wide women's division led by Mrs. Douglas Gibbons will recruit supporters in homes and public places. In this division will be "musketeers,"

Stocks advanced for second consecutive week to best levels since November; turnover, 7,098,850 shares. United States Government issues higher, corporation bonds steadier, Japanese loans up; transactions, $38,485,025.

About 400 delegates are expected to attend a 2-day conference on Better Care for Mothers and Babies, to be opened here tomorrow by Secretary Perkins. The conference will be under auspices of the Children's Bureau of the Department of Labor.

James Talcott, Inc., has been appointed factor for the Excella Hosiery Mills, Inc., Stanfield, N. C. Members of the Association of Gas Appliance and Equipment Manufacturers will feature a wide variety of exhibits at the fifth International Heating and Ventilating Exhibit opening in the Grand Central Palace next Monday.

David S. Polland, New York State titleholder and winner of the American Chess Federation tournament at Chicago, sustained his first defeat yesterday in the annual competition for the championship of the Marshall Chess Club. His opponent was Fred Reinfeld.

Meyer B. Solmson, former managing editor of The Morning Telegraph, died yesterday of a heart attack at his residence, the Hotel Chalfonte, 200 West Seventieth Street. He was born in Pine Bluff, Ark., fifty-seven years ago.

Georges Enesco was heard again as violin virtuoso and as conductor of the Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. It is hard to praise too highly his musicianship and creative conviction in all that he interprets.

Capitalism stands in need of "a larger religious view of creation that will realize development, larger than profit alone and as broad as life itself," the Rev. Frank Curtis Williams declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the First Methodist Episcopal Church, Henry and Clark Streets, Brooklyn.

Father Rupert A. Meyer, Bavaria's most widely known Catholic pulpit orator, was rearrested today for disobeying a secret police order not to appear in the pulpit. He was arrested last July and sentenced to six months' imprisonment, which he did not serve, since he was an officer in the war and lost a leg.

Billy Foales's Silver Brook trio won the 112th Field Artillery's six-goal indoor polo tournament today at the Red Bank Armory by defeating the defending home forces, 13-12. The losers finished strongly, staging a five-goal rally.

The Daily Mail today reported the Americanborn Countess of Carrick is suing for a divorce from the Irish Earl of Carrick, a frequent golfing companion of the Duke of Windsor. The Countess formerly was Mrs. Marion C. Edwards, daughter of Daniel C. Donoghue of Philadelphia.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles Lewis Terry of Remsenburg, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Martha Rogers Terry, to Dr. Everett Leonard Phelps, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Phelps of Detroit.

For outstanding work in airline maintenance during 1937 D. H. Ingalls, superintendent of that branch of American Airlines, was awarded yesterday the highest honors of the Airlines Engineers and Maintenance Conference under the sponsorship of the Air Transport Association, it was announced here.

The Baltimore Orioles recorded a 6-1 Eastern Hockey League victory over the Bronx Tigers tonight despite outstanding work by Marsh, the visiting goalie. The game was a free-scoring affair, with Baltimore doing most of the tallying, but the Bronx sextet threatened often.

John F. Borden, member of the law firm of Parsons, Labretque Borden of this place and son of Mayor F. C. Borden Jr. of Bradley Beach, died today at his home at Bradley Beach following an illness of several months. His age was 32.

The engagement has been announced of Miss Helen Gay Rand, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. LeRoy Henry Rand of 1,326 President SMITH Street, Brooklyn, and Stony Creek, Conn., to Dr. Sidney Edward Lenke, son of Mrs. Melchior Lenke of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Lenke.

Attention in this observation post--one of the best in Europe-focuses today on three events, all related in the eyes of these steady-going buffer people to the capital question of their existence as an independent State.

Two stories of more than program substance have been placed on Metro's February schedule. The first will be Erich Maria Remarque's "Three Comrades," in the leading roles of which will be Robert Young as Lenz and Margaret Sullavan as Patricia, in addition to the previously announced casting of Robert Taylor as Erich.

IT seems to me that Gilbert Seldes's new book is not a little on the futile side. I regret to say so because I remember his previous book, "Mainland," as a stimulating and far from futile piece of work. But this latest tome-"Your Money and Your Life"*--makes me wonder.

The world is crowded with false prophets, fake priests and foolish people, the Rev. Dr. William H. Rogers, pastor of the First Baptist Church, Broadway and Seventy-ninth Street, said in his sermon last night.
Methods of deriving revenue from the Westchester County parks and parkways, at the expense especially of New York City motorists, were considered here today by the county Board of Supervisors.

The Save the Children Fund distribute approximately 60,000 school and library books last year in isolated counties in Tennessee, Kentucky and other Southern States, it was announced last night at the annual meeting and dinner of the fund, held at the Town Hall Club, in West Forty-third Street.

The passenger list of the HollandAmerica liner Volendam due today from Channel ports, a includes Prince and Princess Wolff H. von Stolberg, Coenraad V. Bos, Dutch pianist; John F. Stern, Mr. and Mrs. John C. Tapp and Ralph Murphv.
Outfielder Joe Medwick of the St. Louis Cardinals said today he had reluctantly joined the early season baseball hold-outs despite his club's voluntary offer of a rise in pay.
Guy Guerin de Font-Joyeuse, vice president of the Paris dressmaking establishment of Marcel Rochas, Inc., and manager of the New York branch at 32 East Sixtyseventh Street,

Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange contracted yesterday to small proportions and prices ended with losses of 2 to 4 points. A decline in Bombay for the third successive session furnished the first definite trend toward wider differences in several weeks, but after a slightly lower opening the market here steaded and held within unusually narrow limits throughout.

The first father and son ever executed in Massachusetts, an Italian immigrant candymaker and his American-born son, went to the electric chair within a few minutes of each other early today for the "torch slaying" of a stranger they selected as the victim of an "insurance plot."

Alex Dow, president of the Detroit Edison Company, writing in the utility's annual report for 1937, issued for publication today, says the Detroit Edison Company does not expect to be troubled by any requirements of the "prudent investment" theory of valuation for

Courts are without power to enjoin elections ordered by the State Labor Relations Board because such orders are not a final determination of a dispute between employer and employee, Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin ruled yesterday in dismissing injunction proceedings brought by Wallach's, Inc., retail clothing stores, against the board.

Street fights in which at least seven were killed and twenty-five wounded took place today in Orizaba, State of Veracruz, as Mexico's radical labor federation, the Mexican Confederation of Labor (C. T. M.) sought to break the power of the more conservative unions of the Regional Confederation of Mexican Workers (C. R. O. M.).

With criticism for any "secret dealings by constituted authority in charge of a public interest," Circuit Judge Paul D. Barns impaneled a special grand jury today to investigate the city administration.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Jan. 15, unless specified: San Diego to Pearl Harbor Yard, Jan. 17, Barry, Childs, Gilmer, Hopkins, Williamson. At San Pedro, Chandler, Kalmia, Richmond, Vincennes. Balboa to Panama Bay Area, Jan. 17, Charleston, S-45.

Dr. Thomas Rowe Price, for thirtyseven years surgeon for the Western Maryland Railroad, died at his home at Glyndon yesterday at the age of 72. He was graduated from the Maryland University Medical School in 1891.

Add to the list of vanishing Americans the law-maker who has to borrow a boiled shirt and hire a high hat for White House functions. Tonight being the eve of the annual Presrdential reception for members of Congress, this reporter went out and measured the starched shirt situation.

At both the National Arts Club in Gramercy Park and the Salmagundi Club, 47 Fifth Avenue, large annual exhibitions of work by members are now in progress. The former will remain current until Feb. 4, the latter until Jan. 29.

CARISIUS, IDA (May 28). Estate. about $900. To William Vollman, executor, 1,608 Second Ave. GOLDSTEIN, ISADOR (Dec. 23). Estate, less than $10,000. To Phyllis Ann Goldstein, 275 Central Park West, residue in trust, parts of principal at varying ages, Jacob Goldstein, brother, 316 Weaver St., Larchmont, N. Y., Emanuel Goldstein, 210 W. 70th St., and Guaranty Trust Co., 140 Broadway, executors.
Price reductions on coarse denier rayon yarns, in line with those made by E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. last week, were announced yesterday by American Viscose Cororation, effective Jan. 14.
The European steel cartel met here today. Although no communique was issued it was learned that one of the principal questions discussed affects the market for United States steel here.

President Roosevelt approved the recommendations of the Marine Corps Selection Board today for the promotion of twelve majors to the rank of lieutenant colonel, as vacancies occur. He also approved recommendations that thirteen other majors be put on the retention lists for one year.

Mrs. Roosevelt indorsed today the "wise spending" campaign of the General Federation of Women's Clubs "up to a point," which she defined as application of the plan to those who could well afford to buy needed and desired articles.

One of the controversial Jehovah's Witnesses cases, in which children of members of the cult have run afoul of school authorities for refusing to salute the United States flag on religious grounds, may go before the Supreme Court of the United States, it appeared here tonight.

George E. Roberts, vice president of the National City Bank, will collaborate in the work of the banking seminar of the Columbia University School of Business in the Spring session, beginning on Feb. 2, and will take sole charge of an evening seminar in contemporary banking problems beginning next September, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Benjamin H. Beckhart, Associate Professor of Banking.

A jury of nine men and three women was rebuked for "lack of intelligence" by County Judge John J. Fitzgerald in Brooklyn yesterday after returning a- verdict of not guilty against Frank Milazzi, 44 years old, of 212 Stone Avenue, Brooklyn, accused of possessing two loaded revolvers.

By the time the President was interrupted at his press conference the other day during his attack on holding companies with a question implying that there might be some useful ones, he was well warmed up.
Hsu Sieh-ying, China's Ambassador to Japan, is being summoned to China from Tokyo and is expected to arrive here within a week, the Foreign Office spokesman announced today.

ONE reason why the Rangers are doing a little better than all right for themselves on ice this season is that the Two-Gun Terror from Thornbury, Ont., Cecil Dillon, has his eye on the target again. Gordon Drillon of the whirling Maple Leafs is topping the league in scoring points, but Sharpshooter Cecil is tied for second place with Sylvanus Apps, who skates with Drillon on the Toronto front.

A program by which the members of every fire- department in the country will receive vocational education in scientific fire-fighting and through it reduce the nation's loss of lives and property was adopted yesterday by the executive board of the International Association of Fire Chiefs at Its annual meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Production of knitted underwear, other than glove silk and rayon, amounted to 1,178,897 dozen garments in November, 1937, compared with 1,478,851 dozen in October and 1,905,302 dozen in November, 1936, according to figures just issued by the Bureau of the Census.

Leaving nothing to chance, Chairman John J. Phelan and Dr. William H. Walker of the State Athletic Commission yesterday visited the training camp of Tommy Farr in Summit, N. J., and found the heavyweight champion of Great Britain in excellent shape for the ten-round battle with James J. Braddock, former world champion, in Madison Square Garden Friday night.
Men's chains and other stores which last week introduced more drastic price cuts on shirts, reported yesterday that the new offerings attracted considerable consumer response.
They have punished the head of the Soviet film industry, among other sins, for turning Jim Hawkins, the hero of "Treasure

Trial of a suit brought by the trustees of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway (the Frisco Line) to recover $10,506,090 from the banking firms of Speyer Co. and J. W. Seligman Co. and a number of individuals got under way yesterday in Supreme Court.

Mrs. 46. Caroline Frost Pond, who would have been 100 in July, died today at her home, at 168 Serpentine Road, here. Her husband, the late Benjamin Franklin Pond, had been one of the Forty-niners in the California gold rush and had been master of a ship between San Francisco and Australia.

The New York Rangers will skate against the only team in the National Hockey League that they have not yet defeated this season when they oppose the Canadiens of Montreal at Madison Square Garden tonight.

The International Executive Board of the United Automobile Workers Union conceivably opened a path tonight to renewal of negotiations with General Motors Corporation by formally assenting to the corporation's "wildcat strike" clause in any agreement.
Asserting that the courts "as they are now operated in the field of traffic regulation" cannot be relied on for "any great assistance in accident prevention,"

John Middleton, a former city surveyor who was vice president and trustee of the East New York Savings Bank, 2,644 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, died yesterday at the age of 74 at his home, 1,390 Union Avenue, Brooklyn.

A bill calling for self-regulation of the over-the-counter market under supervision of the Securities and Exchange Commission, which has the backing of the Administration, was introduced in the Senate today by Senator Maloney of Connecticut and will be pressed for passage in the present session of Congress.

Utility and financial circles were generally agreed yesterday that, under the given circumstances, Wendell L. Willkie, president of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, had made the only move possible in publicly offering to sell the entire Southeastern utility properties of his holding company system to the Federal Government at a price to be fixed by a three-man board of arbitration.

In view of the "steadily deteriorating international situation," Jacob Gould Schurman, former president of Cornell University who served as Ambassador to Germany and Minister to China, called last night for support of the President's policy of strengthening the national defense, and for adoption by the United States of the ideal of the "strong man armed."

The Long Island University basketball team crushed a highly rated Niagara combination at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium last night by a score of 57-30. The visitors held the Long Islanders in check during the first five minutes of play, taking a 5-to-3 lead over the home team.

The Transport Workers Union, C. I. 0. affiliate, clashed yesterday with the Municipal Transit Workers Union, an A. F. of L. organization, at a conference with officials of the State Labor Relations Board on the petition filed with the board by the C. I. O. union for certification as the collective bargaining agency for employes of the cityowned independent subway system.

Dr. William Schuyler Colfax, great-grandson of General William Schuyler Colfax, who was captain of George Washington's bodyguard during the Revolutionary War, died today at his home here after an illness of several months at the age of 71. He was a former Mayor of Pompton Lakes.
Substantial reductions in Dankrobbery insurance rates were made effective yesterday, the National Bureau of Casualty and Surety Underwriters announced.

The American Bankers Association will hold its annual convention this year in Houston, Texas, Nov. 14 to 17, inclusive, according to an announcement yesterday by Dr. Harold Stonier, executive manager of the association.

The number of business failures in the United States for the week ended Jan. 13 was 265, against 268 in the previous five-day week and 186 in the corresponding week last year, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

In the long controversy between the Roosevelt Administration and the public utilities industry, a controversy which has done more than anything else to disturb the relations between Government and business, there has been one interlude during which real hope of an early peace prevailed.

E. P. SAN FRANCISCO, Marsh, Federal labor conciliator, said tonight he did not expect immediate settlement of a dispute over wages, hours and arbitration which led to a strike last Saturday of 245 printers and the closing of Portland's three daily newspapers.

Members of the National Association of Shirt and Pajama Manufacturers were urged yesterday by the organization to consider the feasiability of registering their trademarks in those states in which they are now operating.

Under the combined influence of official support and short-covering, the French franc rallied further here yesterday and a mild "squeeze" developed in francs for delivery today. Activity in the market was light, however, and the prevailing view among bankers was that the quotations did not mean much.

The Park Association of New York City wrote yesterday to Ellsworth B. Buck, chairman of the building and sites committee of the Board of Education, that it was gratified by his assurance last Saturday that the board planned no auditorium on park filled land in the East River for the new Benjamin Franklin High School, 309 East 108th Street.

122d St, 129 W, 19.3x100.11; Annie Nefscher to Josephine Donsbach, 129 W 122d St; p m, installment 5%; $2,500. Northern Ave, 55-63, 100x100; Rosmol Realty Corp (Joe Slonimsky, pres) to Wadswalt Holding Corp, 543 W 146th St; p m; pr mtg, $120,000; installments, 6%; $12,000.
Army authorities sent 100 additional troops and constabulary to strike-harassed Pampanga Province today as the situation in the sugar fields and mills became what they termed "more menacing."

Wholesale dry goods buyers arrived here yesterday in larger numbers than at this period a year ago, and will place more orders, but the quantities will be smaller, they said. The majority will confine their purchases of current goods to sixty days ahead, and some will not buy more than thirty days ahead on most items.

Undismayed either by the recent successes of aggressor States or by the powerful support in this country for a policy of isolation, the Thirteenth Annual Conference on the Cause and Cure of War convenes in Washington today.
Congress received a veto message from President Roosevelt today, disapproving a bill to raise pay rates for part-time chairmen and charwomen in the Postoffice Deapartment.
Dr. Walter G. Gonzales of this city died at St. Mary's Hospital here today of pneumonia at the age of 39. He was a staff physician of the hospital.

The Metropolitan Opera Guild will sponsor a junior matinee performance of "Carmen" at the Metropolitan Opera House on Friday, March 4. The performance is intended for young people between the ages of 12 and 18.

Reporters quartered in a hotel near Soestdyk, some of whom have been awaiting the birth of Juliana's child for a fortnight, can get nothing from court officials beyond, "Nothing can be said about her Royal Highness except that she is in perfect health."

A merger of the Rumanian Liberals of Dinu Bratianu and the Liberal dissidents of George Bratianu was effected today at a luncheon and joint meeting. Many Liberal leaders, including former Premier George Tatarescu, spoke, stressing the reconstruction of a united Liberal front.
Stocks drifted downward closing lower with utilities weakest; turnover, 933,680 shares. United States Government obligations irregularly higher; other bonds lower; transactions, $7,042,425.

Louis H. Tabach, 1,060 Broad Street, Newark, N. J., trading as Longwear Hosiery Company, Certified Hosiery Company and Canary Hosiery Company, has been directed by an order of the Federal Trade Commission to cease and desist from certain unfair methods of competition. the commission announced today.

Miss Helen Sullivan, 26 years old, of 73 Tonnele Avenue, this city, who continued on duty as telephone operator at Hotel Plaza, this city, on Dec. 29 during a fire that burned close to her switchboard, died today in the Medical Center.

The General Public Service Corporation reports a market value of assets of $6,882,408 at the close of 1937, equal after allowance for debentures to $83.55 a share on 22,530 preferred shares, compared with $10,244,727, equal to $210.46 a share on 24,920 preferred shares and to $3.55 a share on 669,886 common shares in 1936.

China's opium addicts no longer will be able to evade military service on the ground they are unfitted to fight. The government today ordered all able-bodied men of conscription age addicted to opium to undergo an intensive period of treatment to break the habit.

Debrisstrewn flood waters rose over lowlying farm lands today in the wake of a week-end Atlantic storm which killed thirty-three persons. Police along the normally placid Thames River were warned of extreme high tides as a result of the storms.

A salute by the guns of Cabanas Fortress at 3 o'clock this afternoon announced the arrival of the gunboat Patria with the bodies of seven Cubans killed in the crash of three planes near Call, Colombia, Dec. 29, during the Columbus good-will flight.

Benjamin Nelson, Bronx butter and egg merchant, who has been the government's principal witness in the trial of two physicians, two lawyers and an insurance broker, all accused of mail fraud in an alleged conspiracy to defraud insurance companies by filing claims for faked disability, admitted yesterday when questioned by Lloyd Paul Stryker, defense counsel, that he had been receiving. $50 a week and his hotel expenses from the government since pleading guilty.

Senate approval of the promotion of two army officers to major general and brigadier general, respectively, brought the first of several important changes in the army high command in prospect for this year, officials said today.

Captain Bruce R. Ware, 2d, U. S. N., retired, whose gun crew on the Mongolia fired the first shot for the United States in the World War and disabled a German submarine on April 12, 1917, died yesterday at Naval Hospital.

ONE-THIRD OF A NATION, a Living Newspaper edition (fifth of the series) about housing. Prepared by Arthur Arent and based on research compiled by the editorial staff of the Living Newspaper. Staged by Lem Ward; setting by Howard Bay; music by Lee Wainer: lighting by Moe Hack; produced by Philip Barber as an offering of the Federal Theatre Project. At the Adelphi Theatre.

Diplomatic missions took under advisement a Government offer to guarantee transfer of about 4,000 political refugees from embassies and legations to new concentration centers. A joint diplomatic meeting probably will be held in a few days to consider the proposal.
The Neediest Cases Fund received contributions aggregating $129 from ten contributors yesterday. They brought the total that has been received from the twenty-sixth annual appeal to $301,151.05.

Benny Goodman glorified swing music at Carnegie Hall on Sunday evening, and some of those who heard him were bored. The great majority of Mr. Goodman's audience, however, vibrated in unison with the master's clarinet, and in fact did everything except dance down the sawdust trail and get prayed over by this musical Billy Sunday.
Isidor Achron, who was heard here last month as piano soloist with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in his own concerto, gave a solo recital of the music of others at the Town Hall last night.

A prediction that this business depression will be of short duration and that 1938 "will show a resumption of the upward trend of economic activity" was made-today by N. H. Engle, assistant director in charge of research and statistics, of the Commerce Department's Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce.

United States Savings Bonds, otherwise known as the Treasury's "Baby Bonds," were purchased in 1937 by 490,000 persons in the aggregate maturity value of $635,419,200, the Treasury announced today. This was an average daily sale of bonds in the amount of $2,090,200 maturity value.

Disappointed House leaders gave up late this evening their attempts to complete work on the $1,515,000,000 Treasury-Postoffice Appropriation Bill after concerted action by a nonpartisan group had inserted five amendments in the postoffice section adding $2,326,000 to the total.

An amendment to the by-laws of the Board of Higher Education peremitting the American Student Union, an undergraduate organization, to obtain recognition in all the city colleges in which it is organized, was adopted last night by the board at a meeting at the City College School of Business, Twentythird Street and Lexington Avenue.

The Pennsylvania Railroad for the eleven months ended on Nov. 30, 1937, reports net income of $26,743,401, after taxes and charges, equal to $2.03 a share on 13,167,696 shares of capital stock. This compares with $33,730,691, or $2.56 a share, for the corresponding period in 1936.

Appearances are being maintained in the French political crisis, but underneath there is steadily increasing tension as one after another of the Presidential choices for the premiership gives up in the face of opposition.

The annual report of the Equity Corporation for 1937 shows net assets equal to $4,833.61 for each $1,000 of assumed debentures, and to $48.81 a share of convertible preferred stock, at the end of the year, compared with $9,668.09 for the debentures, $107.76 for the preferred stock and $3.12 a common share at the end of 1936.

The Association of City Hall Reporters, composed of newspaper men assigned to the City Hall "beat," gave a dinner last night to the incoming city administration at Cavanagh's, Twenty-third Street and Eighth Avenue. About forty persons attended.
Colonel Frank St. John Sidway, lawyer and National Guard leader, died this morning in his home of a heart attack. He was 68 years old.

Pennsylvania farmers have entered 2,626,600 acres of cropland in the 1937 soil conservation and improvement program of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration, according to J. Hansell French, a member of the State Agricultural Conservation Committee.

Governors of Southern States went on record today, in messages read to the Senate, against lynching, pledged their efforts to avert the crime and condemned the pending Anti-Lynching Bill. Their statements were read by Senator Kenneth McKellar of Tennessee.

The Hartford Connecticut Trust Company, which bought the assets of the closed East Hampton Bank and Trust Company of East Hampton, reopened the institution today as a branch bank to conduct commerical, trust, safe deposit and savings departments.

R. E. Leigh Co., renting agents for the Chrysler Building since it was opened, has been dissolved and its business henceforth will be handied by a new firm at the same address to be known as the Hudhattan Corporation, it was announced yesterday.

Miss Elsa Maxwell gave a large supper last night in the Perroquet Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria for Cole Porter, the song writer, who was thrown from his horse last Fall and suffered compound fractures of both legs.
A Start toward Italian colonization of Ethiopia was made today. One hundred and five heads of families, all from the region of Apuria, left Brindisi aboard the liner Adria for East Africa.

Bob Pastor, 185, of New York City, won by a technical knockout over Hans Haverlick of Austria tonight when a heavyweight bout was stopped because of a bad cut over Haverlick's eye. The battle was the first for Pastor since he was defeated two months ago by Nathan Mann of New Haven in New York.

An order directing the Scandore Paper Box Company of Brooklyn to end interference with the self-organization of its employes and to reinstate two allegedly discharged for union activities was issued today by the National Labor Relations Board.

No plan for reorganization of the Pierce-Arrow Motor Car Corporation will be submitted until the current trend of business is stabilized. That was the decision reached after a hearing before Federal Judge John Knight this afternoon.

Today's major events: The New York Women's Symphony Orchestra, directed by Antonia Brico, tonight at Carnegie Hall; Ruth Luty, pianist, at Town Hall in the afternoon, and Raya Garbousova, 'cellist, at Town Hall in the evening.

Mayor F. H. LaGuardia told the Senate Committee on Unemployment today that New York City would bear up to $40,000,000 of the cost of WPA projects during 1938 if the Federal Government gave jobs to the same percentage of employables in his city as it accorded to the various States.

A survey of 110 leading industrial corporations by the American Federation of Investors, Inc., discloses that more than 86 per cent of the stockholders of record in these companies in 1937 owned not more than 100 shares of stock each, the federation announced today.

Several leases for quarters in the garment center were included in the contracts for commercial space reported by brokers yesterday. Among them was one for an entire floor at 101 West Twenty-eighth Street taken by the Button and Novelty Workers Union Local 132, which will use the space for meetings and executive offices.

The marriage of Miss Mildred I. Freygang to Dr. Harold G. Campbell of Flushing, city superintendent of schools, will take place within a few weeks. Miss Freygang, who is assistant principal of Thomas Jefferson High School, Brooklyn, has tendered her resignation, to become effective on Jan. 31. Her home is in Manhattan.
Weeping at the separation from her husband, the exiled Empress Quizzero Menen of Ethiopia left for Jerusalem today to recuperate from an unusually bad English Winter.

An irresistible desire for the air that sweeps onto the Boardwalk at Coney Island brought Herman Finkelstein, 22 years old, of 643 West Ninety-eighth Street, Brooklyn, before Magistrate Joseph D'Andrea in Coney Island Court yesterday.

Representative Cummings of Colorado laid today he expected the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to make a $15,000,000 stabilization loan to peg the price of scoured wool at about 81 cents a pound and "end the wool industry's jitters."

Much must be forgiven to Senator Bailey, talking against time and the Anti-Lynching Bill, but he exceeds his license when he is irreverent to a benign public character and instructor. Friday he quoted from the "sourcebook of our Secretary of the Interior" an interesting passage about the addiction of the wealthy to the bath.

Miss Mildred Stewart of Hempstead, women's intercollegiate foils champion last year while at Hunter College, led in the Long Island qualifying round for the national junior fencing championship tonight in Calkin's gymnasium at Hofstra College. Miss Stewart won all four of her matches.

Lord Stanley, Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State for India, and Lady Stanley are leaving for the United States this week. Lord Stanley has been ill recently, and his doctors have ordered him to take a few weeks' holiday.

Offering will be made today through investment dealers of a new issue of $2,000,000 of Manufacturers' Finance Company, Baltimore, series A collateral trust 4 1/2 per cent notes. The issue, dated Oct. 1, 1937, and maturing on Oct. 1, 1942, will be priced at par and accrued interest.

Opening and dedication of the World Headquarters Building of the International Business Machines Corporation, 590 Madison Avenue, 10 A. M. to 10 P. M. Dedication ceremonies, 11:15 A. M. Speakers: Mrs. August Belmont, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, Thomas J. Watson.

Most classes of bonds suffered a sinking spell yesterday in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. There was little change in the volume of transactions from last week--the turnover in all bonds amounting to $7,042,425, against $6,997,325 on last Friday--but the course of

Pitt scored a basketball victory tonight over Carnegie Tech, 50 to 33, before 3,000 spectators. The game not only sent the Panthers into the lead for the City title but marked thei winning debut in the Eastern intercollegiate conference, in which they entered a three-way deadlock with Penn State and Georgetown, all with spotless records.
Final oral argument on the demand of the railroads for a 15 per cent increase in freight rates was set today by the Interstate Commerce Commission for Jan. 31 at its offices here.
ABBOTT -- Fanny, beloved mother of Victor, Elias and Elizabeth. Services Wednesday, 11:30 A. M., at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.
Andre A. Zhdanoff, chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee of the Soviet Congress, today urged that the Foreign Office should act with more determination toward Japan and Manchukuo.

A plan for the reorganization of the Chicago, Indianapolis Louisville Railway (Monon) which finds the stock of the railroad valueless and asks the Interstate Commerce Commission to condition further control of the line by the Southern Railway and the Louisville Nashville on their supplying funds for a necessary program of improvements, was made public today by the I. C. C.

No longer is forestry development concerned with trees alone. Today the agencies interested in promoting forestry are giving considerable thought and provision to the various forms of wildlife that will populat these forests.

Snow, general throughout the metropolitan area and in Central and Western New York State, brought out this city's first line of snow defense yesterday. More than 8,000 regular workers of the Department of Sanitation were working at snow removal yesterday, a force that was reduced to about 6,000 late last night.

George Edings Chisholm, retired New York real estate man and member of prominent New York and Southern families, died yesterday at his home at 320 South Street here after a four-year illness. His age was 79.

Miss Alice Lenore Cornell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hubert Varian Cornell of West Hartford, became the bride of Irving Seymour Copeland, son of Mrs. Woodford J. Copeland of Elmira, N. Y., and Coral Gables, Fla., Saturday at the Farmington Country Club.

Sixty-eight alumni and friends of New York University's School of Law will be made members of the school's chapter of Theta Sigma Lambda, honorary law society, at its twenty-fifth anniversary celebration tomorrow at the Hotel Astor.

A League of Nations health commission was detained in this South China metropolis today as a result of the disruption of railroad service by Japanese air raids. The health experts had been sent out by Geneva to help China organize preventive measures against the epidemics and plagues expected to develop as soon as Winter is over.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said today she would attend funeral serv- A ices in New York tomorrow for Mrs. Bernard M. Baruch, wife of the financier, who died Sunday of pneumonia. To do so, the President's wife canceled an address to the National Conference on Better Care A for Mothers and Babies and an engagement to attend a luncheon planned in her honor by Mrs. William Bankhead, wife of the Speaker of the House.
Thousands of Egyptians from the provinces tonight began pouring into gaily lighted Cairo for the celebration Thursday of the wedding of their boy King, Farouk.

The Harford Agricultural and Breeders Association has increased the value of its most important stake races for the April 15-30 race meeting, it was announced today. The added money for the Chesapeake Stakes, mile and a sixteenth event for 3-year-olds, was boosted from $7,500 to $15,000.

Posters announcing that prices quoted are guaranteed against dedine made their appearance at the New York Furniture Exchange, Inc., yesterday when 500 manufacturers of all types of furniture put Spring lines on display. Quotations were unchanged from Fall. Producers who displayed the signs said they considered the move the last step necessary to dispel fears of hesitant buyers.

Renata J. Elacqua, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Elacqua of East Boston, was married today to Andrew J. Torrielli of Watertown, Mass., instructor in languages at the Fordham University Graduate School in New York. The Rev. Patrick J. McCarthy performed the ceremony at the Church of the Star of the Sea, East Boston.

Thomas W. Lamont and S. Parker Gilbert, partners in J. P. Morgan Co., were re-elected trustees of the Academy of Political Science for three-year terms at the annual meeting of the corporation of the academy at its headquarters at Columbia University.

Rain curtailed play today in the Sheffield Shield cricket match between Queensland and Victoria. Replying to Victoria's total of 396, the home team had made 171 runs for five wickets when play was halted.

President Roosevelt continued his efforts today to provide a basis for a joint government and business program of cooperation for recovery. He called for a White House conference on Friday of the most representative group of automobile manufacturers who have met here since the code-drafting days of the NRA.

An intensive drive to solicit the city's trade and industry in support of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis was announced yesterday, as thousands of volunteer workers started the foundation's nation-wide campaign for funds to combat the disease.

Through Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board here, the NLRB in Washington made known yesterday a decision which for the first time is directed against the activities of an individual serving in an advisory capacity to business and industrial corporations in helping them avoid the provisions of the National Labor Relations Act.

The Dominion Bureau of Statistics, reviewing Canada's $459,713,646 export trade with the United States in 1937, reports large gains in sale of Canadian goods admitted across the line at lowered rates of duty under the 1935 Canada-United States trade agreement.
Repeal of the undistributed profits tax and the capital gains levy was urged today before the Ways and Means Committee by M. L. Seidman, representing the New York Board of Trade.

Efforts to avert a strike of garage employes were begun yesterday by the State Mediation Board at a conference of representatives of employers and employes held in the State Office Building, 80 Center Street.

The cancellation of all its FeldCrawford price-maintenance contracts controlling the resale price at which its domestic products can be sold in metropolitan liquor package stores was announced here last night by the National Distillers Products Corporation in answer to an alleged boycott of its products by organized retail groups.

Miss Annette Hall McIntire, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Reed McIntire of Ardmore, has completed plans for her marriage on Feb. 4 to Harold Beckler Pough, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis H. Pough of St. Louis.

Willie Hoppe defeated Jay Bozeman in the first two blocks of their 600-point exhibition three-cushion match at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy yesterday. Hoppe took the afternoon test, 50-41, in fifty innings, having a high run of 10, as compared with Bozeman's 7.

John R. Longo revealed here tonight that he had received a letter from Mgr. John A. Ryan of the Catholic University of America, in Washington, in which Mgr. Ryan declared civil rights and civil liberties, and not the question whether the American Civil Liberties Union is communistic, are the real issues in the Jersey City controversy.

Louis M. Boas, prominent in theatrical and amusement enterprises for more two than thirty years, died suddenly tonight at his home, 4 Fairbanks Street, Brookline. He had worked at his office today with A. Dolphus Burroughs, his partner of twenty years.
Projects for the construction of eight apartment houses near Brighton Beach and in the Flatbush district, costing $1,175,000, were filed yesterday with the Department of Buildings in Brooklyn.

With a dozen or more United States Senators expected to be among the spectators, A. Harry Moore, Jersey City Democrat, will be inducted into office here tomorrow as Governor of New Jersey for the third time.

The member lines of the Atlantic Passenger Conference will transport teachers and professors of the United States and Canada making transatlantic voyages on sabbatical leaves at 20 per cent below the regular fares, it was announced yesterday.

An appropriation of $553,266,494 for the naval establishment during the fiscal year ending June 30, 1939, was recommended to the House today by its Appropriations Committee in reporting the annual Navy Supply Bill.
Twenty-four women started play today in the eighth annual New Jersey squash racquets tournament at the Short Hills Club, with Mrs. Ary J. Lamme Jr. of Apawamis gaining the quarter-finals.
Mr. and Mrs. William West of Montclair, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughters, Miss Mildred West to Scott Martin Long Jr. and Miss Edith Frances West to James Cummin Westfall.

Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets, as reported today by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 26,000, including 7,000 directs. Lights and underweights, fully 10 to 15 cents higher than Friday's average; 200 pounds up., 15 to 35 cents higher; top, $8.70;

A sharp gain in the number of licensed pilots and aircraft during the last calendar year was reported today by the Bureau of Air Commerce. There were 7,681 pilots and 9,152 airplanes last Jan. 1, against 15,952 pilots and 7,424 airplanes or Jan. 1, 1937.

The doctrine of German racialism was formally incorporated in the Third Reich's official policy today, when Dr. Wilhelm Frick, Minister of Interior, proclaimed the principle that the treatment of German racial comrades abroad is not merely a domestic matter of the States in which they live but an international problem wherein Germany has a vital interest.

Owing to a decreased domestic and export demand for woolen manufactures, the Japanese Woolen Goods Manufacturers Association recently decided to increase restrictions on production of wool manufactures to 60 per cent of capacity, said a report to the Department of Commerce from Tokyo made public today.

Brig. Gen. Sherwood Cheney, a former White House aide, said today that the famous "I do not choose to run" statement of Calvin Coolidge was made because the late President knew he was suffering from a heart ailment.

A fierce northeast blizzard that whipped Boston and Southern New England today caused two deaths and scores of accidents, delayed transportation and piled up from five to eightt inches of snow, bringing the Winter's total snowfall to more than three times that of last seasion.

In pronouncing sentence upon two Long Beach policemen who were found guilty of extortion, Bronx County Judge James M. Barrett yesterday opposed the extension of judicial authority as "dangerous" and deplored the "agitation" in legal circles to allow a prisoner to waive jury trial in non-capital criminal cases.

The hard-hitting Paul brothers of Richdale, Alberta, tonight scored victories at the National Sporting Club. Danny Paul outpointed Tom Casey, Irish heavyweight, in a six-rounder, while Packy Paul won from Jim McKenzie, Scotland, when the Scottish heavyweight was disqualified in the third round of a scheduled sixrounder, for persistent holding.

Fireman first grade John J. Bergen, Engine Co. 28, Jan. 15. Funeral will take place from his late residence, 2.888 Grand Concourse, Bronx, at 10:15 A. M. today. Interment at Calvary Cemetery. Retired Lieutenant Hugh L. Kelly, formerly a member of Engine Co. 245, residing 466 72d St., Brooklyn, Jan. 14.

Commander Paul Reis, Naval Attache of the Brazilian Embassy, announced tonight the Brazilian'Government had signed two contracts in New York for the purchase of electrical equipment and boilers to be installed on the three destroyers now under construction in a Brazilian navy yard.

Foundations have been completed for the new apartment house at 955 Fifth Avenue, between Seventysixth and Seventy-seventh Streets, and construction work will proceed at once in order that the seventeenstory and penthouse building may be ready for Fall occupancy, according to Douglas L. Elliman Co., agents.

A sign that Great Britain means business in her reply to Italian propaganda was seen when the British Broadcasting Corporation disclosed tonight that it had ordered two new [Pound]10,000 short-wave transmitters to handle the Arabic news program.

An unusually large crowd visited in the region around Dartmouth College at Hanover, N. H., last Saturday and Sunday and found excellent skiing conditions, according to word received yesterday from Johnny Piani, head of the Dartmouth Cooperative Society. Many trails were lighted for night skiing.

The New York Maritime Council, which comprises nine unions affiliated with the C. I. O., appealed last night to members of the rival International Longshoremen's Association to repudiate a threat by their leaders to tie up the operations of lumber yards at which C. I. O. Union men are employed.

Overriding a plea by Assemblyman Fred W. De Voe of Middlesex County, floor leader of the Democratic minority, that action be deferred until next week, the House tonight, on the eve of Governor-elect A. Harry Moore's inauguration, adopted a resolution authorizing an investigation of last November's Gubernatorial balloting in Hudson County, in which the incoming Executive, a Democrat, resides.
Sweden's Foreign Minister, Richard Sandler, today told Parliament that Sweden never would participate in any military action or sanctions by the League of Nations.
