Form held up well in the New York State squash racquets championship at the Downtown A. C. yesterday as the two top-seededH men, Germain G. Glidden, the national champion from the Harvard Club, and Stanley Galowin, N. Y.

The Twenty-third Street Association will hold its monthly meeting tomorrow at the Aldine Club, 200 Fifth Avenue. A report on the new parking regulations will be made by E H. Sameth and a preliminary report on housing and neighborhood planning will be presented by Charles E. Lane Jr.

Thugs in Harlem have been holding up subpoena servers from the District Attorney's office with such frequency lately that District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey announced yesterday he had arranged to have a patrolman assigned to each of them in the future to aid in serving grand jury and court subpoenas on tenement residents there.

The estate of Benjamin L. M. Bates, New York Stock Exchange member and owner of the Murray Hill Hotel, who died on Dec. 13, 1935, was worth $6,045,678 on Nov. 30, 1937, according to an intermediate accounting filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday.

An effort to organize physicians and dentists in the employ of the Department of Health into chapters of Local 67 of the State, County and Municipal Workers of America has begun, it became known yesterday.

Associate Justice George Sutherland, who retires from the Supreme Court tomorrow after more than fifteen years' service, and Solicitor General Stanley Reed, who has been nominated to succeed Justice Sutherland upon the bench, faced each other in the court chamber today.

A beauty clinic is to be established at the Goddard Neighborhood Center at Thirty-fourth Street and First Avenue, it was announced yesterday. This will include a series of free classes In personal rehabilitation for the members of the various women's clubs at the center.

Cincinnati Street Railway--Year ended Dec. 31, 1937: Net income (compiled from company's monthly reports), $224,932, after charges and Federal income taxes, equal to 47 cents a share on outstanding capital stock, compared with $367,905, or 77 cents a share in 1936.

We can't forget Benjamin Franklin's birthday, even though this is not a quinquennial anniversary. He was born 232 years ago. There is no divination of statistics-even Ellsworth Huntington's statistics giving the child born in the early months of the year a maximum chance of coming into famethat could account for his amazingly versatile achievements.

A survey of United States coffee consumption for 1937, compiled by George Gordon Paton, statistician of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, shows that distribution of the green product to roasting channels dropped 30,067,303 pounds, or 1.75 per cent, in 1937.

Federal intermediate credit banks, operating on a 2 per cent discount rate, paid franchise taxes to the United States Government amounting to $741,274 in 1937, according to an announcement today by George M. Brennan, Intermediate Credit Commissioner of the Farm Credit Administration.

Paced by Ray O'Neil, who tallied seventeen points, the St. Simon Stock basketball team overwhelmed the Inimaculata High School quintet, 55 to 31, at the former's gymnasium yesterday. The victors held a 27-23 lead at half-time.

Informed persons said today the Argentine sanitary pact had not been considered by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee during the present session of Congress. Their comment was prompted by publication in the Congressional Record of a resolution in which the National Grange expressed opposition to ratification of the convention.

The eluding crisp Treasury Procurement Division today announced the following awards of contracts for textiles for delivery by March 1 from bias opened Jan. 13: 623-T-Type A chambray, fancy, ten-yard length or over, Wennonah Cotton Mills Company, 2,400 yards; fancy chambray or plaid, Camperdown Company, Inc., 30,000 yards;

The United States has about 3,065,000 miles of highway, or about onethird of the total highway mileage of the world, which is around 9,687,000 miles, according to a world highway survey made public today by the Automotive-Aeronautics Trade Division of the Department of Commerce.

Expansion of Federal aid provisions to include more and better medical care for those unable otherwise to obtain it was foreshadowed in a message from President Roosevelt and an address made by Secretary Perkins at the opening this morning of a two-day Conference on Better Care for Mothers and Babies called by the Children's Bureau.
Arthur D. MacMillan, assistant to the president of the Junior College of Connecticut for the last two years, died today. He was 53 years old.
President Roosevelt enrolled today as "Founder No. 1" of the new national foundation he organized to combat infantile paralysis-but he had to borrow a dollar to pay for his certificate.
A campaign to raise $400,000 for Kent School was inaugurated last night at the first meeting of the school's building fund committee at the Columbia University Club, 4 West Forty-third Street.

A stay-in strike that paralyzed the Atha Works of the Crucible Steel Company of America here became a walkout of uncertain strength just before midnight tonight when, assured by authorities that strikebreakers would not take their places and that picketing would be permitted, the strikers evacuated the company property without violence or disorder.

A strong bromide for "Archibaldo" today enabled the Buenos Aires Zoo to reopen. The sedative put "Archibaldo" to sleep after the young rhinoceros, newly arrived from Africa, went on a rampage, repeatedly charging his fence and finally breaking his horn.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art has received as a gift from Harry Payne Bingham the important painting by Rubens of "Venus and Adonis," which has been on loan in the museum since 1920. Announcement of the gift was made yesterday at the annual meeting of the Fellows of the Corporation of the Metropolitan.

Miss Mollie Porter Cullum, daughter of Mrs. James Barton Cullum of River Edge Farms, Pittsburgh, has chosen twelve attendants for her marriage on Feb. 26 at the Indian Creek Country Club to Charles Freeman Shelden of New York.

Fred Lester Acer, Columbia University student, who was found dead a week ago in a wooded section of Dobbs Ferry, committed suicide while emotionally upset, Assistant District Attorney Elbert T. Gallagher of Westchester County declared here today at the close of his investigation.

The sixteen major oil companies on trial here with thirty-six of their executives for conspiring to raise the price of gasoline in ten Central States in 1935-36 were charged today with having made $70,000,000 illicitly by their operations, in the closing address to the jury by John Henry Lewin, special assistant to the Attorney General.

The cornerstone of New York City's exhibition building at the New York World's Fair, 1939, one of the most important structures in the exposition group, will be laid at 12:30 o'clock tomorrow afternoon. It will be one of the permanent structures of the Fair, and will serve a dual purpose.

Unfilled orders on the books of the Glenn L. Martin Company, aircraft construction, exceed $17,500,000, the largest total in the company's history, Mr. Martin announced today at a meeting of the board of directors.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals heard argument yesterday on the petition of the Consolidated Edison Company and its affiliates for the annulment of an order to signed on Nov. 10 by the National Labor Relations Board directing the reinstatement of six discharged employes.

Orienta Point Estates, Inc., a syndicate of which Irving Feldman is president, has purchased the Lascaris estate in Orienta Point, Mamaroneck, Westchester. The tract contains about 200,000 square feet, with frontages on Bleecker Avenue, Rushmore Avenue, Walton Avenue and Forest Avenue.
Mrs. Charles H. Cassavant, the window of the secretary to George B. Cortelyou, Secretary of the Treasury in the Theodore Roosevelt administration, died on Saturday at the age of 76.

Major Ernest Edward Austen, keeper of the Deapartment of Entomology of the British Museum from 1927 to 1932 and one of the world's foremost authorities on the tsetse fly, the bite of which causes sleeping sickness, died here yesterday at the age of 70.

A move to draft a new plan bf reorganization for the Abitibi Power and Paper Company, Ltd., a move probably to be made by the liquidator, is regarded as likely in financial circles following the rejection by the courts of proposed sale of the assets.

The stock market here began the new account today and, considering the hectic political situation in France, the tone of most groups was satisfactory. Gilt-edge issues were in demand, but among the foreign bonds Far Eastern loans failed to maintain their recent gains. Transatlantic stocks were cheerful, taking their cue from the week-end strength in Wall Street.

Capt. Terence J. Smith is relieved from present assignment as assistant deputy chief of staff, CCC, and is appointed as assistant to the CCC executive. Capt. Robert H. Christie is relieved from his present assignment as assistant deputy chief of staff, CCC, and is appointed as assistant to the CCC executive, in addition to his other duties.

A national organization designed to promote housing construction in at least 100 "key" cities throughout the country has just been formed with the cooperation of more than a score of well-known realty men, including several New Yorkers.

Dean Dettor, 226, Salt Lake City, former claimant of the heavyweight wrestling title, was credited with a victory over Sammy Stein, 226, Bronx, in the feature finish exhibition at the Hippodrome last night when the latter landed outside the ring on an attempted flying tackle and injured his shoulder.

The Greater New York Hackmen's and Taxi Drivers Union voted yesterday at a meeting at Germania Hall, Sixteenth Street and Third Avenue, to continue the strike that it called against several taxicab companies three days ago.
C. I. O. unions, representing an estimated 22,000 members, will plan a central labor council similar to the A. F. L. central trades and labor body here this month, it was announced today.

Rockwell Kent, the artist, entered suit yesterday in Supreme Court to recover $25,000 from Covici, Friede, Inc., for the alleged unauthorized sale of the right to reproduce his illustrations for the J. U. Nicolson version of Chaucer's "Canterbury Tales" to the Garden City Publishing Company, Inc.

Equaling par on the second nine, R. Murray Purves of Boston anneed the qualifying medal in the thirty-first annual championship of the Winter Golf League of Advertising Interests at the Palm Beach Golf Club today.
Richmond Hill High, the defending team champion, has entered a strong squad in the P. S. A. L. swimming championships, it was announced yesterday by Coach Fred Hoffman.

The first full week of racing at the Miami Jockey Club's picturesque Hialeah Park opened today with another big crowd in attendance and with the form players keenly disappointed when all eight favorites lost.

French Canada tonight for a second time sustained the Dominion Government's policy of increasing defenses by electing Alderman J. A. Bonnier as member of the Federal Parliament for St. Henry, a Montreal constituency, in opposition to former Mayor Camillien Houde, who had campaigned on a "noarmament" platform.

PRINCIPAL PLANT PHYSIOLOGIST, $5,600 a year, Bureau of Plant Industry, Department of Agriculture. Applications must lie on file with the U. S. Civil Service Commission at Washington, D. C., not later than Feb. 17, if received from Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Montana, Nevada. New Mexico, Oregon, Utah, Washington, Wyoming, and not later than Feb. 14 from all other States.
Clarence Oswald Douden, Brooklyn pharmacist, died Sunday at his home, 1,193 Gates Avenue, Brooklyn, after an illness of ten days. He was 77 years old.

Two entire buildings in Brooklyn and a third in Jamaica have been leased by Abraham Straus, Inc., Brooklyn department store, the former for use as a furniture warehouse and distribution center and the latter as a merchandising outlet in the Queens territory.

A $70,000 damage suit for injuries allegedly suffered during a Fourth of July fireworks display at the Nautilus Beach Club, Nassau County, L. I., has been filed in Brooklyn Supreme Court against the International Fireworks Company, the Island Park Association, Inc.;

Many persons prominent in society attended Albert Morris Bagby's 404th Musical Morning, the conclud- c ing concert of the series for this season, which was given yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria. The artists were Rose Pauly, soprano, and Giovanni Martinelli, tenor, both of the Metropolitan Opera, and Mischa Elman, violinist.

An appeal to President Roosevelt today by Governor Earle of Pennsylvania, for Federal action to break up alleged monopolistic practices among anthracite producers started a Department of Justice investigation to determine the applicability of antitrust statutes to meet the situation.

Sessions of the merchandising division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the organization's twenty-seventh annual convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania, Jan. 31 to Feb. 4, will be featured by discussions of Federal Trade Commission fiber identification regulations and of the problems to be met in maintaining volume and profits in 1938. The program of the division includes nine sessions covering every major store division.
Representatives of Canadian business, which in the last month has keenly felt the effects of the recession in the United States, heard a prediction today by Arthur A. Ballantine,

In an effort to eliminate excessive waste and cost in the milk industry, a conference has been called for 1:30 o'clock this afternoon in the offices of the Department of Markets, 139 Center Street. All branches of the industry and the consumer will be represented.

Dr. Mary E. Woolley, chairman of the department of international justice and good will of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, will speak at 7 o'clock tomorrow night at the Amber Lantern, 150-24 Northern Boulevard, Flushing, Queens, at a dinner of the Flushing Peace Society; Dr.
One Senate committee prepared today to investigate the. Labor Relations Board and another voted to cut down its appropriation for next year.

The National Jewish Hospital at Denver closed its thirty-eighth annual meeting yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel with a medical conference on tuberculosis at which papers on the disease and its treatment were read by Dr. Charles J. had Kaufman; medical director; Dr. sales Harry Wessler, chief of staff, tuberculosis division,
The international stock market indices for Jan. 15, with comparisons, are as follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 1927:
Mrs. Emily Frances Doll, one of the last survivors of the great Indian mutiny of 1857, died on Saturday in her home at Much Hadham, Heathford-shire, at the age of 85.

Net earnings in 1937 of Walter E. Heller Co., finance company and factor of Chicago and New York, amounted to $476,075 after interest, provision for bad-debt losses, Federal income taxes and $34,000 provision for surtax on undistributed profits, according to the annual report of Walter E. Heller, president. In 1936 the company earned $353,327 after similar deductions, including surtax charges.

Mace Ave (16-4424), s s, 25 ft w of Barker Ave, 100x100; Henry Reiss to Ogdis Realty Corp, 2,015 University Ave; mtg, $8,500. Rochambeau Ave (12-3335), e s, 116 ft n of 206th St, 33x100; Underhill Realty Corp to Henry H. Schooler, 1,334 Herschel St.

Federal Judge John C. Knox, who last week imposed sentences upon a group of defendants who had pleaded guilty or had been convicted of violating the Sherman Anti-Trust Law in the city's $75,000,000-a-year fur dressing industry, imposed additional sentences yesterday, bringing the total number to more than eighty.

The reappointments of Holton V. Noyes as Commissioner of the State Department of Agriculture and Markets and Dr. William J. Tiffany as Commissioner of the State Department of Mental Hygiene were submitted tonight to the Senate by Governor Lehman for confirmation.

Specific recommendations for increasing radio's services in the field of education through programs that would dramatize the process of learning, give the American radio audience a comprehensive picture of the nation at work and provide a testing ground for development of new ideas in the whole field of education were made yesterday by the newly formed Columbia Broadcasting System Adult Education Board at its initial meeting at CBS headquartersm 485 Madison Avenue.

The late Colonel E. H. R. Green, son of Hetty Green, considered the old Waldorf-Astoria as his home until the building was torn down in 1929, his family physician, Dr. Henry S. Pascal, testified yesterday at a hearing on the $40,000,000 Green estate before John S. Flannery, United States Supreme Court special master, in the Roosevelt Hotel.

The youngest coach in the metropolitan district is turning in the best coaching job of the year. In the won-and-lost column Manhattan College may not rank with some of the other quintets in town, but that the Jaspers have the most aggressive and most improved team in New York is a personal triumph for Neil Cohalan.

The board of trustees of the American Medical Association, which controls the destinies of organized medicine in America, has adopted a resolution calling for the working out of a series of definite plans by the various component bodies of the association whereby adequate medical care may be brought within the reach of all the people.

Because there are "too many lawyers in the law and too much law in lawyers," former Assistant District Attorney James J. Wilson advocated yesterday the substitution of one layman for one of the three lawyer-judges of the Court of Special Sessions.

Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan set the stage for a lively battle over the status of Councilman John Cashmore as vice chairman of the City Council yesterday, when he signed an application for a show cause order which, if honored, would have the practical effect of tying up the Council's proceedings until that issue is decided next Monday.

A few hours before expiration of his term at midnight, Governor Hoffman granted the request of Governor Olin D. Johnson of South Carolina for extradition of Floyd Mix, 19 years old, a chain-gang fugitive.

The Ellen Lambert Murphy Memorial Community Center was dedicated tonight before 500 residents. The center was made possible by gifts of Governor Francis P. Murphy, native of Winchester, in memory of his mother. The Rev. George T. Carl, pastor of the Federated Church, was in charge.

The stock market was unable to work up much enthusiasm yesterday. Pressure on utility issues, notably those of holding companies, operated as a drag on the market. Even the prominence given the rearmament topic, preliminary to President Roosevelt's forthcoming message to Congress, failed to rally rearmament stocks.

Sleepy tourists were politely but firmly ousted from their hotels without their morning coffee throughout Sweden as a result of a general lockout comprising all licensed hotels, cafes and restaurants today. Even ferryboats and dining cars were affected.

The Rt. Rev. Ernest Neville Lovett, Bishop of Salisbury, today asked the churches in villages and market towns in the Counties of Dorset and Wiltshire to pray for relief from an outbreak of hoof and mouth disease.

Publishers, business leaders and advertising experts were called upon tonight by Will H. Hays, "czar" of the movie industry, to "tell us more of what's right with America." He contended that this was important in view of the fact that "we have heard so much so long about what's wrong with America."

Striking longshoremen late today rejected an offer by steamship representatives of a base pay of 40 cents an hour. Thirty-two cents was the prevailing rate up to the end of December. The new offer was 3 cents an hour more than the best previous offer made during two weeks' negotiations.

The two-family dwelling at 42 McAdoo Avenue, Jersey City, N. J., was sold by the Wood-Ridge Trust Company, George Young, president, to Bridget Cummings, who will occupy one of the apartments. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.

After an occupancy of thirty-five years by the United Cigar Stores as a retail unit, the one-story building occupying triangular plot on the southwest corner of Seventh Avenue South and Christopher Street has been sold by that concern to a client of Louis Lorence, attorney.

Charles E. Denney, president of the Erie Railroad, indicated today there were no developments in the financial dilemma threatening the Erie with bankruptcy. The road's directors presumably will file a petition for Federal trusteeship unless they can find a way to meet interest payments of almost $2,000,000 overdue since Jan. 1.

An interesting contrast of philosophy among the members of the Supreme Court appeared today in two opinions, concurring as to conclusions, on the question whether a Presidential veto is constitutional when a bill is returned within the ten-day limit to a branch of Congress while that house is in recess.

General John J. Pershing, Dr. Ray Lyman Wilbur and Dr. Thomas G. Parran, members of the National Anti-Syphilis Committee, will call the attention of the American people to the need for control of syphilis in a broadcast Feb. 2 at 10:45 P. M. over the combined networks of the National Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System.

Dr. Frank J. O'Brien, director of the Bureau of Child Guidance of the Board of Education, has been unanimously elected to the scientific administration committee of the National Committee for Mental Hygiene, it was announced yesterday at the Board of Education.

Mrs. Frank E. Hale was installed yesterday afternoon at the Spencer Memorial Presbyterian Church, Clinton and Remsen Streets, Brooklyn, as president of the Protestant Big Sister Council of Brooklyn. She succeeded Mrs. Marshall Elliott Stewart.

Louis B. Glavis told a Senate hearing today that, as director of the Bureau of Investigation of the Interior Department. working directly under Secretary Ickes, he had tapped department telephones and taken down conversations in shorthand and by recording machines.

A week-old strike at the Franklin Sugar. Refining Company was ended today with a union victory in a collective bargaining election, conducted by the National Labor Relations Board, in which the Sugar Workers Union, an American Federation of Labor affiliate, polled 364votes to 249 against it.

Mrs. H. Courtlandt Van Voorhis has come from Boston to the St. Regis. Mr. and Mrs. J. Spencer Weed and Miss Janet Weed are at the Waldorf-Astoria for the remainder of the season. Mrs. Emerson Howe of Washington is at the Ritz-Carlton.

George Bernard Shaw recalls his early days as a London newspaper man in the fiftieth anniversary issue of The London Star, on which he wrote musical criticism under the name of "Corno di Basseti." He tells how he left the paper over the protests of "Tay Pay" O'Connor, its founder, because a rival offered him $25 a week instead of the $10 he was receiving.

Mrs. Fanshawe Lindsley gave a luncheon yesterday in the Louis Sherry Room at Sherry's for Mrs. John Jacob Astor, Mrs. Cruger Fowler and Miss Angela Fowler. Miss Elizabeth Pearsall Russell, t whose engagement to T. Scudder Winslow Jr. has been announced, was guest of honor at a luncheon given by Miss Thayer Gibbons at Trouville.
THE MOON IS MAKING, by Storm Jameson. (Macmillan, $2.50.) A novel laid in a Yorkshire fishing village. THE HONEYSUCKLE AND THE BEE, by Sir John Squire. (Dutton, $3.) Reminiscences of an editor.

Inconsistencies in the long-distance F intrastate rates of the Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania and the interstate charges of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company were eliminated today in a ruling by the Pennsylvania Utility Commission.

A marine engineer and a stoker, both employed by the Fire Department, were severely burned shortly after 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon when they were caught in a backdraft from the furnace of the municipal fireboat John J. Harvey, berthed at its Battery Park pier.

Eugenio, Cardinal Pacelli, Papal Secretary of State, today received Admiral Shingiro Yamamota, Japanese Catholic leader. They remained in conversation for more than half an hour. Later Admiral Yamamota also called on Cardinal Pizzardo, until recently Secretary of the Congregation for Extraordinary Ecclesiastical Affairs, and Mgrs. Tardini and Montini,

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Jan. 15: LIEUTENANT COLONEL Ward, O., F. A., Ft. Benning, Ga., detailed as a member of the General Staff Corps and ordered to Washington, D. C. MAJORS Peabody, P. E. (Inf.), General Staff Corps, seven days' leave, Jan. 17.

It was a great pleasure to listen yesterday afternoon to Gertrude Pitzinger, mezzo-soprano; who then made her first appearance in New York in Town Hall. She is a singer of exceptional gifts and individuality. The voice is very unusual, a big voice-and in this offering a rather amusing contrast to the slight stature of the singer-also a voice of a wide range of color as well as sonority.

Better weather today onabled Insurgent troops to carry out a surprise thrust from Celadas, ten miles north of Teruel, with complete success. Muleton and Altos de Celdas were captured, along with 1,500 prisoners and a Government artillery battery.

Judge and Mrs. W. Calvin Chesnut of Baltimore have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Maxwell Carroll Chesnut, to Wilson King Barnes, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. James Upshur Barnes of Pocomoke City,
Prices on Spring and Summer lines of both lamps and shades were down an average of 10 per cent compared with last season, at the opening of the New York Lamp Show at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday.

Harry F. Wolf of the Montclair A. C., national amateur champion, and F. Barry Ryan Jr. of the Short Hills Club, fourth in the ranking, gained the final round of the Clyde Martin memorial squash tennis tournament at the Yale Club last night.

The Beverly National Bank bought yesterday an issue of $300,000 of temporary-loan notes of Beverly, Mass., on a 0.18 per cent interest basis. The notes will be dated Jan. 17, and will be payable on Nov. 4, 1938.

Looking remarkably fit and weighing four pounds less than when he discharged his final blast into the reeling Giants last October, Joe DiMagglo, wonder player of the Yankees, swept into New York yesterday after attending a luncheon in his honor in Philadelphia earlier in the day.
The first February production of Scribner will be "Moments of Memory," by the Hon. Herbert Asquith, son of England's wartime Premier, the late Herbert H. Asquith, Earl of Oxford and Asquith.

The Pennywise Cruise Ball, benefiting a flower-distributing charity, of which Mrs. Ruth G. K. Strawbridge is general chairman, will be held in the Bellevue-Stratford ballroom on Feb. 4. More than 120 young women and men will particinate in the revue.

Three men were sent to jail for two days yesterday by Magistrate H. Stanley Renaud in West Side Court, after th - pleaded guilty to smoking in the subway. Fifteen others paid fines of $3 each. Those jailed when they failed to pay the fines were James Spellman, 40 years old, of 514 West 177th Street; Harry Ahl, 63, of 1,456 Wilkins Avenue, the Bronx, and Giovanni Galeto, 50, of 1,424 Sixty-fourth Street, Brooklyn.

Highly satisfactory attendance and buying activity were reported yesterday by corset manufacturers displaying new Spring lines at hotels or in local showrooms. Display rooms were crowded in spite of unfavorable weather, and orders placed were generally larger and more numerous than had been expected. A marked spirit of optimism pervaded the market;
A special commission. has. been appointed by the Turkish Government to study the problem of reducing the high cost of living and to make practical proposals to that end.

A son, their second child, was born to Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Ottley of Locust Valley on Saturday at the Doctors Hospital, this city. Mrs. Ottley is the former Miss Gladys H. Graham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Graham of Oyster Bay and Palm Beech. The child will be named Philip Graham.

St. Timothy's League, Inc., has taken over the performance the evening of Jan. 27 of "Bachelor Born" by Ian Hay, with Ian Keith and an English cast, which will open on Jan. 24 at the Broadhurst Theatre.

86th St, 50 W; 4-story dwelling, 25x102.2; president and directors of the Manhattan Co, against Peter L. Elder; due, $75.387: taxes, etc., $1,560; to plaintiff for $40,000. By EDWIN J. McDONALD 107th St. 307 W, 19x100;

Caravel, a neglected outsider running in the silks of Jack Carter Jr., gained his first victory of 1938 in the mile - and- seventy- yard race which topped the Fair Grounds card today. In two previous starts this year, Caravel had run second and out of the money.
The Pan American Union said today the Presidents of all twenty Latin-American republics had joined with President Roosevelt in issuing proclamations for observance of Pan-American Day on April 14.

Arrested at Santa Anita race track while betting part of the $50,000 ransom, Peter Anders, 30-year-old Northwest logger, confessed tonight the kidnapping and slaying of wealthy Charles S. Ross of Chicago. He confessed also that he had killed his confederate in the crime, Atwood Gray.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 12; increases of $41,000,000 in holdings of United States Government direct obligations and $68,000,000 in "other securities"

In the Supreme Court of the United States today Nathan W. Math of New York. Jacob A. Freeman and Ralph W. Crolly of Brooklyn. N. Y., were admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had: 143--The United States, petr., v. Helen J. Steven, adrx., et al. On writ of cert. to the First Circuit Court of Appeals.

John Reovitch, a stocky little 59-year-old man who is said to have a suicidal complex, continued tonight to deny, after more than twenty-four hours of questioning by Nassau officials, that he had any knowledge of the double murder at Elmont, L. I., last Wednesday afternoon.
In a hard-fought game the Lehigh basketball team tonight beat Muhlenberg, 43 to 42, before 2,500 persons. Lehigh trailed by 28-23 at half time.

Holding that the use of a sound truck was "a form of picketing not peaceable" Vice Chancellor James M. Fielder In Jersey City yesterday found six members of The Bayonne Times unit of the Hudson County Newspaper Guild in contempt of court for violating an injunction banning its use in their dispute with the publisher.

With Billy Rose returning to Broadway tonight as proprietor of the Casa Manana, the former French Casino, and producer of its first show, "Let's Play Fair!" Mr. Rose and the Chorus Equity Association were in a deadlock yesterday over working conditions for the girls in the cast.

Written for The Associated Press. The year just opening should be an unusually interesting one in golf, with international competition playing an important part. Teams of British and American amateurs will meet for the Walker Cup at historic St. Andrews,

Miss Virginia Randolph of Greenwich, Conn., has completed plans for her marriage to Herman Henry Ridder of St. Paul, Minn., and this city, which will take place on the afternoon of Feb. 11 in the Jade Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.

The Hershey Bears defeated the New York Rovers, 3 to 2, last night in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden before 6,132 spectators, but they required a ten-minute overtime session to turn the trick.
Automobile production increased more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index jumped to 68.3 from 56.6. The figure for the week ended Jan. 16, 1937, was 95.8.
The Senate Appropriations Committee agreed today to elimination of the "item veto" power for the President which the House had written into the Appropriation Bill for Independent Offices.

The 150 leading magazine advertisers for 1937 spent $101,554,745 in such media, a 12.13 per cent increase over the expenditures for the 150 leaders in the preceding year, according to an Advertising Age compilation yesterday, based on figures of Publishers Information Bureau.
Dr. Milan Stoyadinovitch, Premier of Yugoslavia, officially ended his visit to Berlin tonight, when he was the guest of Chancellor Adolf Hitler at a State banquet.

President Roosevelt conferred with Governor Earle of Pennsylvania and others on the coal situation, discussed the legislative program with Congressional leaders and arranged to confer with automobile manufacturers on Friday on business cooperation.

Senator Minton of Indiana expressed opposition today to a proposal that the government purchase subsidiaries of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation which distribute power in the Tennessee Valley region.
Joseph J. Hammer was re-elected president of the New York Pharmaceutical Federal Credit Union last night at the organization's second annual meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
The ghost of the age-old enmity between the North and South of Ireland reared its head just as was expected at the very start of the Anglo-Irish conference at 10 Downing Street today.

Formation of a coalition of 100,000 maritime workers, drawn from all the ports of the nation, pledged to national unity and economic and political action, moved a step nearer today as their delegates opened business sessions here.

The trust department of the Pennsylyania Company for Insurance on Lives and Granting Annuities. trustee for the Erie Railroad's Series NN equipment trust certificates, announced yesterday that the management of the Erie had advised that the payment of $247,000 due on Jan. 15 had been deferred.

The tragedy of Maximilian and Carlotta, long contemplated by the industry during serious moments, has been placed on Warners' Summer schedule as a possible vehicle for Paul Muni. The studio purchased Bertita Harding's "The Phantom Crown" last year and Wolfgang Reinhardt and Aeneas Mackenzie have been assigned to draft the screen play with William Dieterle directing.
The Columbia Grammar School basketball team registered its seventh triumph in nine starts by vanquishing the New York Friends School, 40 to 22, on the loser's floor yesterday.

The Rev. Seward Hiltner of Union Theological Seminary, secretary of the committee on religion and medicine of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, will speak at 3 o'clock Friday afternoon at the annual tea of the Women's Committee of the Associated Clinic of Brooklyn.

The State department objected today to one phase of a double-barrelied legislative program advocated by Pacific Coast interests to encourage maintenance of a fast intercoastal merchant fleet. Secretary Hull, in a letter and through a spokesman, advised the Senate Internceanic Canals

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Unless it is still in a state of stunned insensibility, American business must have read into President Roosevelt's anti-holding company ukase the deathknell of its long-cherished hope of reaching a friendly understanding with the New Deal government.

Panzer College of East Orange, N. J., triumphed over Manhattan College of Staten Island, 51 to 39, yesterday at the losers' gymnasium. Herman Knupple, 6-foot 6-inch center, tallied 14 points in 'the first half to give the visitors a 30-to-19 advantage.
The Ford Motor Company presented today its first peace offer to the United Automobile Workers of America since the union called a strike at the assembly plant here last Nov. 24.

Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Vail Brokaw were hosts to a large group for cocktails today at their villa. Mr. and Mrs. J. Jay O'Brien entertained with a large dinner tonight at Villa del Sarmiento. Mr. and Mrs. Harold Fitzgerald gave a dinner at their home. Mr.

Service on the Eighth Avenue line of the Independent Subway System was disrupted for fifteen minutes yesterday afternoon when a young man committed suicide by leaping in front of a northbound train just as it was pulling into the station at Fifty-ninth Street and Columbus Circle.

Many basic faults exist in the city's school-building program, resulting in poorly designed and educationally unsound structures, a commission of five architects, appointed more than a year ago by the Board of Education, reported yesterday. Even buildings now under construction were found faulty:

Toronto's big three, headed by Gordie Drillon, took command of the National Hockey League scoring situation again last week. Their domination threatened by Cecil Dillon of the New York Rangers, they went on a scoring splurge during the week which ended with Sunday's games, and collected a total of 14 points.
In a rough, bitterly waged battle of eight rounds last night before some 2,500 fans at the St. Nicholas Palace, Vincenzo Dell' Orto, Italian featherweight, and Al Reid of the Bronx fought to a draw.
The American Institute of Steel Construction has invited students of engineering and architecture in recognized technical schools to take part in a competition to design an urban elevated highway.

The wheat market fluctuated today in an erratic manner, within a range of around 1 cent a bushel. An early advance on the Board of Trade, induced by buying on relative firmness in Liverpool and dry weather in, the Southwest was not mainstained.

The new corporation tax provisions as recommended by the Ways and Means Subcommittee constitute for the most part a very substantial improvement over the present law. They remove the worst features of the undistributed profits tax.

The sale of general admission tickets, priced at fifty-five cents, for the Hollywood Ice Revue headed by Miss Sonja Henie, opened yesterday at Madison Square Garden, where the ice carnival will be staged from Monday to Friday next week. Three thousand tickets for each of the five performances were placed on sale.

A young man who told the police that he suddenly realized while walking along a Washington street that he was James Gould, an 18-year-old Harvard College student, was under treatment tonight for amnesia.

Annual reports of changes in the First Avenue district will be made by L. Gordon Hamersley, president, and other officers of the First Avenue Association at its annual meeting and luncheon tomorrow in Woodstock Tower, 320 East Fortysecond Street.
The bipartisan movement to eliminate the Child Labor Amendment as a source of worry on Capitol Hill made its appearance tonight as the Legislature convened for its third week of the session.

STORM JAMESON'S "The Moon Is Making" seems to me much the sort of novel Emily Bronte could have written had she not been Emily Bronte-had she lived in the twentieth century, borne children of her own, read the Wessex tales of Hardy and grasped the portent of Labor governments in London.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt attended Mrs. Lawrence Townsend's musicale this morning at the Mayflower Hotel, entertaining in her box Senora Felipe Espil, wife of the Ambassador of Argentina;

Mr. and Mrs. H. Russell Burbank of 19 Grace Court, Brooklyn, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Burbank, to Charles Stokes Lowry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank C. Lowry of Montclair, N. J.

Japanese rushed reinforcements today to Hangchow, capital of Chekiang Province, in an effort to halt a strong Chinese counter-attack. This development came as the Chinese reported they were pushing back the invaders on the northern, central and Yangtze Valley fronts.
Representatives 6f sixty foreign trade organizations and chambers of commerce met yesterday at India House to discuss plans for this year's observance of Foreign Trade Week, to be held May 16 to 21.

Richard Bennett's withdrawal from "On Borrowed Time" is now definite, and so is the show's postponement. It is understood that Dudley Digges, already mentioned as Mr. Bennett's successor, or Walter Huston may go into the play, which will be idle until Jan. 31.

Stanley Hasrato, 165, New York, scored his second technical knockout over Frank Zamaris, 178, Orange, tonight in a scheduled tenround boxing bout. Referee Whitey Healey stopped the contest at the end of the fourth after a head butt opened a deep cut on' Zamaris's right eyelid.

Duke Ernst von Hohenberg, younger son of the assassinated Archduke Francis Ferdinand, broke an illuminated sign bearing a swastika here last night, causing considerable excitement in Pan-German circles.

The broadcast of next Saturday afternoon's performance of "The Barber of Seville" from the Metropolitan Opera House will be transmitted to the children's ward of St. Vincent's Hospital with a marionette visualization, it was learned yesterday.

The versatile Allan Tolmich, the "one-man track team" from Wayne University, yesterday filed entry in two events in the annual Millrose A. A. games at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 5. The sprinter-hurdler from Detroit notified Fred Schmertz, chairman of the games committee, he had accepted invitations to compete in both the 60-yard sprint and the 60yard high hurdles.

Leander W. Faber, son of former Supreme Court Justice Leander B. Faber, was released in $2,500 bail yesterday in Queens County Court after he had pleaded not guilty to a three-count grand larceny indictment charging that he appropriated some $50,000 collected as a receiver in Supreme Court actions involving apartment houses.
Mayor Frank Hague of this city turned down today an offer to become United States Senator as successor of A. Harry Moore, who will become Governor of New Jersey tomorrow for the third time.

Steel operations this week are scheduled at 29.8 per cent of capacity, compared to 27.8 per cent last week, a gain of two points, or 7.2 per cent, the American Iron and Steel Institute reports. It is the third consecutive weekly gain, for a total of 10.6 points, or 55 per cent.

Frankie Klick, California lightweight veteran, returns to the local ring wars tonight at the New Ybrk Coliseum in the Bronx, where he will battle Johnny Bellus, hard-hit ting New Haven youngster, in the eight-round feature.

The Treasury sold $50,130,000 of ninetyone-day bills today at an average interest rate of 0.111 per cent on a discount basis, compared with 0.097 per cent for the issue sold last week, Roswell Magill, Acting Secretary of the Treasury, announced tonight.

Thomas W. Lamont emphatically denied here today that capital had "gone on strike" to cause the present business recession. He suggested that it would be nearer the truth to say that capital had been "locked out."

Dollar volume of retail food sales last week dropped 3 to 4 per cent below the average for a year ago, the American Institute of Food Distribution, Inc., reported yesterday in its weekly summary of conditions in the grocery business.

RETAIL CLASSIFIED BY OFFICE O. Abel, 1,441 Bway CINCINNATI-Dunlop's Clothes Shop; E. W. Wise, ready-to-wear. DENVER--Neusteter Co.; Miss P. Handler, better dresses: Miss M. Davis, dresses; Mrs. M. Morrison, sportswear. OMAHA-Nebraska Clothing Co.; L. S. Sternberg, dresses, coats; Miss D. Payne, ready-to-wear. PITTSBURGH-Boyd's, Inc.; Mrs. L. Rothschild, better dresses; S. Schwartz, coats, suits, furs.

Fred J. Catania, 34 years old, assistant cashier of the Bensonhurst National Bank in Brooklyn, and Attilio Galardi, 31, a brokerage house employee, accused of evolving a fantastic scheme whereby they stole $25,000 from the bank's vault on Jan. 3, pleaded guilty yesterday in County Court, Brooklyn, before Judge Peter J. Brancato. They were remanded for sentence on Jan. 31.

" Father's Malachy's Miracle" moved last evening from the St. James to the Guild Theatre. But unlike the spiriting from Edinburgh to Bass Rock of the Garden of Eden Casino-the same forming the theme of the play-Brian Doherty's comedy did not arrive intact.
Gordon H. Cilley, retired newspaper editor and advertising executive, died of a coronary occlusion today at his home at Paoli in his sixtyfourth year. He had been ill about six months.

Senator William H. Dieterich issued a formal announcement tonight of his candidacy for renomination in the Illinois Democratic primary on April 12. His statement was sent from Washington for publication here tomoorow.

To Dr. Annie Jump Cannon and Dr. Cecilia Payne Gaposchkin, members of the staff of the Harvard astronomical observatory, have been voted titled appointments without time limit, by the Harvard corporation with the approval of the university's board of overseers.

C. S. Newhall, formerly president of the Pennsylvania Company for Insurances on Lives and Granting Annuities of Philadelphia, was elected yesterday chairman of the board and William Fulton Kurtz, heretofore executive vice president, was elected president, it was announced here, following a meeting of the directors in Philadelphia.

State Policeman C. V. Maine said today that G. Hall Roosevelt, brother of the President's wife, paid a $100 fine imposed on the driver of Mrs. Roosevelt's car for exceeding the Maryland. forty-five-mile-an-hour speed limit. Mrs. Roosevelt was not in the car at the time.

Circuit Judge John Biggs and District Judges William Clark and Philip Forman, sitting as a Federal Statutory Court, began here today hearing argument on an appeal filed by the Port of New York Authority for an injunction restraining the Interstate Commerce Commission from enforcing an order lifting Motor Carrier Act exemptions from truckmen operating between New York and Newark, Elizabeth and Perth Amboy.

Premier Prince Fumimaro Konoye today was reported to have told Japanese political leaders frankly that the undeclared war against China was becoming increasingly grave. Domei, Japanese news agency, said that Premier Konoye informed leading members of both Houses of Parliament that failures to bring

The Community Power and Light Company has filed an application with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Public Holding Company Act of 1935 for a report on a plan of recapitalization to simplify its capital structure, adjust arrearages in preferred stock dividends and reduce dividend requirements on such stock.

The benefits of one of the most satisfactory underwriting experiences in several years were offset for the United States Fidelity and Guaranty Company in 1937 by a sharp depreciation in its investments, its annual t report issued today disclosed.

The United States Government would look with disfavor on any proposal entailing the extension of credits to Japanese interests for the purchase of industrial machinery or for any related purpose, it was declared in an official quarter today.
A shortage of fruit and vegetables was threatened tonight for Pittsburgh and communities within a 100-mile radius as efforts to settle quickly a strike of approximately 500 produce handlers failed.

Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer ruled yesterday that distillers were not legally obligated to proceed against all retailers who cut prices on trade-marked brands of liquor in violation of Feld-Crawford Fair Trade Act agreements.

The two-family dwelling at 1,134 Halsey Street, Brooklyn, was sold by Mrs. R. Stein to an investing clien of Edward Ford, broker in the deal, who states that the purchaser plans to make extensive improvements to the property.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Walter Hamilton Hughes of Upper Montclair, N. J., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Grace Hughes, to Henry Barker Fernald Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Barker Fernald, also of Upper Montclair.

William Henry Walker, cartoonist and painter, who as president of the Flushing Hospital and Dispensary for twenty-two years was instrumental in its growth and development, died yesterday in his home at 144-85 Sanford Avenue, Flushing, after a long illness. He was 66 years old.

The Society of Mayflower Descendants in the State of New York and the junior members of the organization will give an informal reception Saturday afternoon at Mayflower House, 120 East Seventyfirst Street.

Out of the wreck of the Leftist Popular Front majority elected with acclamation a year and a half ago, Camille Chautemps salvaged tonight a purely Radical Socialist Cabinet with a promise of Socialist support.

J. Edgar Hoover, chief of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, arrived here by airplane tonight with Peter Anders, whom he had quoted as confessing the Kidnap-killing of Charles S. Ross, elderly retired manufacturer of Chicago.

Estate, less than $10,000. To Grace F. Bickell, widow, executrix, 1,928 University Ave., Bronx. ELLIOTT, CHARLES ROBERT (Nov. 16). Estate, more than $10,000. To Lillian G. Elliott, widow, executrix, 2 E. 86th St. EPSTEIN, MATILDA (Jan. 11). Estate, less than $5,000. To Isaac Epstein, husband, 127 W. 96th St., petitioner.

Led by Bob Smith, who scored two goals, the Brooklyn Bruins defeated the Long Island Falcons, 3-2, in a New York Amateur Hockey Association game at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. The Cataracts conquered the Monarchs, 1-0, in a Brooklyn-Long Island League preliminary encounter.

When the thirty-first annual Millrose meet is held at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 5, track followers will see an unusual spectacle with two pairs of twins-Elmer and Delmer Brown and Wayne and Blaine Rideout-running as a relay team.

So much of paragraph 2, Special Orders 276, dated Nov. 29, 1937. as continues Capt. Paul J. Latzer, Inf.-Res., on active duty with the CCC until June 17, 1938. is amended so as to continue him on active duty until Feb. 2, 1938. Leave of absence for eighteen days, effective on or about Jan. 15, 1938, to terminate not later than Feb. 2, 1938, is granted Capt. Paul J. Latzer.

Yesterday afternoon's Town Hall debutante was Ruth Luty, pianist, a native of St. Louis. She played a program that started with a transcription of a Bach "Arioso," wandering no farther from nineteenthcentury romanticism than. Ibert, Dohnanyi and Debussy.
Joseph Henry McLean, Superintendent of Police of this city from 1927 to 1936, died today at Waterbury Hospital of a blood clot on the brain. He was 62 years old.

In Northern Ireland, where political divisions follow religious lines and there is hardly any issue save determination to resist union with Catholic Ireland (Eire), the Craigavon government is launching an electoral campaign that is ostensibly designed to permit Ulster again to express its already wellknown aversion to being ruled from Dublin.

Refinery production of gold and silver in the United States was larger in 1937 than in 1936 and closely appreached the output in 1915, the year of largest production, the Bureau of Mines reported today.

Weakness in foreign markets and reports of light snowfall in the more Eastern sections of Nebraska sent wheat prices down around 1 1/4 cents a bushel in the early trading on the Board of Trade here today, but there was no snap to the selling and later short covering developed on dust storms in Northwestern Kansas and Southwestern Nebraska and a rally followed.

Two goals decidedly of the freak variety helped the Rangers defeat the Canadiens of Montreal in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. A shot by Neil Colville that took a haphazard bound over Goalie Wilf Cude's stick gave the New Yorkers a 1-0 advantage in the second period.
Alfred E. Ells, special partner, has become a general partner in the New York Stock Exchange firm of Redmond Co.

Viscount and Viscountess Astor left Miami today as guests of former Governor James M. Cox of Ohio aboard his houseboat, Willowemoc, for a few days of fishing among the South Florida keys. They came from Delray Beach where they are visiting.

Tom Somerville's 39, 39-78 was good enough to lead the first day's qualifiers in the Miami Biltmore amateur golf tournament today. With the favorites swinging into action tomorrow, the final day for qualifying, Somerville appears to have a little chance of being medalist.

Eighty-fifth annual meeting of the American Society of Civil Engineers will open at 10 A. M. at 29 West Thirty-ninth Street and continue all week. League for Political Education, Town Hall, 11 A. M. "The Future of Our Political Parties," Stanley High.

The special committee now studying a plan of reorganization of the administrative set-up of the New York Stock Exchange still has considerable work to accomplish before preparing a draft of its report.

Maritime Commission officials confirmed today reports that Arthur B. Poole would represent the commission as a director of the Dollar Line Steamship Company. The appointment is understood to be a part of an agreement under which the company will receive an operating subsidy.
Senator Ellender set today what was believed to be a record for recent years when he completed the fourth day of his speech in the Senate against the Wagner-Van Nuys Anti-Lynching Bill.

President Roosevelt and members of his Cabinet joined with leaders in business and education yesterday to emphasize "World Peace Through World Trade," the keynote at ceremonies dedicating the world headquarters building of the International Business Machines Corporation.
The "Century of American Landscape Painting, 1800-1900" opened with a preview yesterday afternoon at the Whitney Museum, 10 West Eighth Street. The exhibition, open

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick rejected yesterday the payroll of the City Clerk's office on the ground that it was certified by Robert Lee Tudor, whose election to the post by the thirteen Democrats of the City Council is under dispute. The delayed payroll was submitted in the afternoon.

The Westchester County Medical Society adopted unanimously tonight a resolution urging its parent organizations, the New York State Medical Society and the American Medical Association, to act as sponsors of a plan to provide adequate free medical attention for the indigent and place physicians instead of politicians in charge of the work.
An Increase in French imports amounting to 65 per cent compared with the preceding year was the principal feature of 1937 trade figures issued today.

Woodrow Wilson often used to say of some public man that he was like the equestrian who "mounted his horse and rode off in all directions." When this miracle is performed by a statesman it is frequently deliberate, as in Washington these days.

The C. I. O. strike against the Atha plant of the Crucible Steel Company here ended this afternoon with the members of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee gaining two minor concessions and failing to achieve a major one.

Turpentine firm, 30 1/2c; sales 93 barrels; receipts 195 barrels; shipments 126 barrels; stock 28,555 barrels. Resin firm; sales 320: receipts 859; shipments 379; stock 72,621. Quote: B. D, $5; E. $5.20; F, $5.95; G, $6; H, $6.15; I. $6.20; K, $6.25; M, $6.40; N, $6.50; WG, $7.40; WW, X, $7.80.

Mrs. Katherine C. Tailer filed suit today for a divorce from James B. Tailer of New York City. She charged cruelty. It was the second time for each in a Reno divorce suit. Mrs. Taller was divorced from Alexander Hamilton Dec. 26, 1935. Mr. Tailer was divorced July 9, 1936, by Mrs. Barbara Register Tailer.

Seventeen students and lay brother teachers are known to have met their deaths in a fire which broke out in the College of the Sacred Heart here early this morning and raged with such fury that means of escape were cut off.
The expulsion of all alien Jews from Ecuador except those engaged in farming was decreed today by the Provisional Military Government of Colonel Alberto Enriquez.

Hearings to determine the facts and discover the causes of alleged discrimination in industry against middle-aged workers will begin this morning at the State Office Building, it was announced yesterday by Assemblyman James J. Wadsworth, chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Discrimination in Employment of Middle-Aged.
The New York Curb Exchange was notified yesterday that the reorganization plan of the Northern Texas Electric Company had been confiscated by a Federal court in Massachusetts.

The second day of the Anglo-Irish conference was so satisfactory to both sides today that the preliminary stage can be ended tomorrow and the three interrelated questions of finance, trade and defense can be handed to experts Thursday.
John R. Mauff, former vice president and secretary of the Chicago Board of Trade, died here yesterday at the age of 66 in his home.

John W. Worth, since 1904 organist and choirmaster of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Advocate, Washington Avenue and 180th Street, the Bronx, died Monday night of a heart attack at his home, 412 East 187th Street, after a long period of poor health.

Sanction has been granted the Brattleboro, Vt., Outing Club to stage an "open class" event in conjunction with the national ski jumping championships scheduled for the organization's 60-meter hill on Feb. 19-20.

The resignation of Midshipman Arthur Franks Jr., quarterback of the Naval Academy football team, was accepted today by Claude A. Swanson, Secretary of the Navy. Franks, who lives in Harrisburg, Ill., submitted his resignation from the academy to enter business with his father. He was in the junior class.

The administration policy of non-invocation of the Neutrality Act is unaltered by the action of the Japanese and Chinese Governments in mutually withdrawing their Ambassadors, President Roosevelt indicated today.
Governor Frank Murphy today named a committee of seven for study of objectionable practices in connection with installment selling, with a view to obtaining recommendations for legislative remedies.
Miss Marion Turpie, golfer, said today she and Harry McNaughton, the "bottle" of Phil Baker's radio program, were going to be married. Miss Turpie is divorced from Robert Lake of Long Island.
William H. Bamford, this community's first chief of police, died yesterday at his home, 231 Mount Pleasant Avenue, after a long Illness. His age was 78.

A small man with a bald head walked up to the teller's window of the Coney Island branch of the Brooklyn Trust Company yesterday and asked Albert Johasmeyer to cash an American Express Company travelers' check for $50.

The Regional Plan Association, Inc., made public yesterday estimates that New York City will have a population of 9,384,000 and the New York region 16,379,000 in 1960 if discernible present trends continue.

Dr. Hermann Feit, dermatologist, author of a number of works on dermatology and member of the faculty of the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, died at his home, 521 Park Avenue last night after being ill a year. He was 47 years old.

Wilbur James Gould, 18-year-old Harvard honor student, whose disappearance from Cambridge, Mass., on Jan. 9 led to a nation-wide search for him, returned to his home at 327 Central Park West yesterday from Washington, where he was found Monday night.

At noon tomorrow forty-one Spanish Loyalist officers will come to the middle of the International Bridge here, where they will meet and be exchanged for forty-one Insurgent officers under a recent prisoner-exchange agreement.
After nearly thirty-six hours of uninterrupted questioning, John Reo, a metal lathe worker, confessed early today that last Wednesday he shot and killed Mrs. Celinda Waite,

The library of the late Mrs. Jay F. Carlisle was sold at two auction sessions yesterday at the ParkeBernet Galleries, Inc., for a total of $18,663. The library, with the art property of Mr. and Mrs. Carlisle sold at the same galleries last week, yielded a grand total of $159,073.
Harry Black, theatre manager here, received word today of the death in Hollywood of his brother, Maurice Black, motion picture actor, who was 46 years old. Death was due to pneumonia.

Through the theft of a wallet today from Sir Henry Chilton, recently returned British Ambassador to Spain, it became known tonight that the Duke of Windsor had successfully interceded on behalf of a former Spanish diplomat, Don Xavier de Bermejillo, who was imprisoned in Madrid by the Spanish Government.

Public offering will be made today by a banking group headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., and Bonbright Co., Inc., of a new issue of $9,000,000 of Consumers Power Company first mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds due on Nov. 1, 1967.

The United States Lines announced last night that the prevalence of hoof and mouth disease in the Jersey Isles had caused the canceliation of arrangements for the transport of cattle as transatlantic freight in its ships.

Rudolph Reimer, Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization of the New York District and Commissioner of the New York Port Authority, was re-elected president for the fifth year of the Brooklyn Children's Aid Society, 72 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn, yesterday.

Farida Zulficar, who will become Egypt's second Queen since Cleopatra on Thursday, completed her pre-nuptial arrangements today. The 16year-old bride-to-be had her fortyfive-gown trousseau packed and sent to Koubbeh Palace, where she and young King Farouk will live after their marriage.

Thirty-two exempt jobs that existed in the old Department of Plant and Structures, Tenement House Department and the buildings departments-and public works bureaus under the various Borough Presidents have been eliminated by the Civil Service Commission and if the commissioners of the new Departments of Public Works and Housing and Buildings wish to fill such jobs, they must do so by competitive examination.

The Rev. Martin Niemoeller, Confessional Church leader, will be tried here before an emergency court Feb. 7. He has been imprisoned since last July 1. The charge is sedition and the case has been prepared laboriously by a staff of investigators and assistant State's attorneys. Every possible available argument and every bit of testimony are expected to be used.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses moved today, in a bill sent here, to establish a New York City parkway authority. It would supersede the Henry Hudson Parkway Authority and the Marine Parkway Authority and would have jurisdiction over other toll roads and bridges planned in a broad development of the Rockaways.

The Norwegian glaciers are shrinking in size at such a rate that, if the trend continues, glaciers and snowfields will disappear from Norway just as they did for a period after the last great Ice Age, when forests spread over the Dovre range.

An order suspending effectiveness of a registration statement filed under the Securities Act of 1933 by the Trenton Valley Distillers Corporation has been issued by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The dispute over dates between Wilmington, Del., and Atlantic City was settled yesterday in favor of the Wilmington exhibition, which will hold its show May 19, 20 and 21, the dates originally requested. This was announced following a meeting of the executive committee of the American Horse Show Association, which, at the same time, assigned May 10 to 14 to Atlantic City.

A number of private and multifamily dwellings were reported yesterday as having changed hands in the Bronx. Among them was the five-story apartment house on a in plot 75 by 100 feet at 2,065 Walton Avenue, which was purchased by a client of Samuel Mejansky.

Witnesses for the railroads, trucking companies and a group of manufacturers, and one publisher appeared today before the Ways and Means Committee to oppose not only the present undistributed profits tax but the tax in the modified form suggested by the committee's subcommittee on taxation.

Philip Weinstein of 146 Central Park West, a retired manufacturer of women's coats who had been a generous financial supporter and zealous worker for many Jewish philanthropies, died Monday night of a heart attack in Miami, Fla., according to word received here by his brother, Max Weinstein, president of Russeks, Fifth Avenue. Born in Russia sixty-eight years ago, he had lived here since boyhood.

Portland's citizens, without newspapers for nearly four days, remained virtually unaware today of what was going on in the world. Representatives of The Oregonian, The Journal and The News-Telegram, and spokesmen for the International Typographical Union reported no progress toward settlement of a wage and hour dispute which stopped publication of the three papers on Saturday.

The C. I. O. steering committee for Hudson County held a rally here tonight in Labor Lyceum at which more than 500 persons cheered the denunciation of "Hagueism." The C. I. 0. was forced to meet here, leaders charged, because they were unable to rent a hall in Jersey City.

Recent actions by the United States Department of Agriculture in re-establishing the Cuban sugar import quota and by sugar shippers in continuing the quota granted in the world markets to Cuban producers should tend to stabilize the sugar markets. William C.

Lester F. Scott, national executive of the Camp Fire Girls, Inc., asked yesterday for an increase of 80,000 in the number of girls attending the organization's 150 nonprofit camps. He spoke at the biennial conference of seventy-five local executives from all parts of the country at the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel.
The "Adam and Eve" radio broadcast Dec. 12, which resulted in protests and brought a rebuke of the National Broadcasting Company, had a new aftermath today, a copyright infringement suit.

The bodies of the seven Cuban good-will fliers who were killed Dec. 29 near Cali, Colombia, were placed in the army mausoleum in Colon Cemetery this afternoon with military honors. Cuba's Cross of Honor and the Carlos Manuel de Cespedes Order, the nation's highest decorations, posthumously conferred on the aviators,

Many luncheon parties were given yesterday in conjunction with the fashion show entitled "I'd Rather Be Tyrolean Style Revue," which was held during the luncheon hour in the Caprice Room of the Weylin for the benefit of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association.
Verdi's popular "II Trovatore" was presented by the Metropolitan Opera Association at the Mosque Theatre here tonight before a large and appreciative audience.
A Japanese act against two British sailors and one United States seaman for which Vice Admiral Soemu Toyoda of Japan quickly apologized was disclosed today.

United States Senator A. Harry Moore, inaugurated today for an unprecedented third term as Governor of New Jersey, strongly backed the labor stand of Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City both by declaration and by appointing to his vacated seat in the Senate Mayor Hague's legal adviser, John Milton of Jersey City.
A fleet of eighteen bombing planes, a fighting wing of the United States Navy, droned high over the Pacific sea lanes tonight, bearing 127 officers and men on a non-stop flight to Honolulu.

Miss Anita J. Fernandez, superintendent of the Brooklyn Home for Children at 141 South Third Street, with which she had been associated for twenty-eight years, died Monday in the Wyckoff Heights Hospital. She was born in Brooklyn

President Roosevelt modified today to some extent the stand he took less than a week ago demanding abolition of all holding companies. In answer to a request at his press conferencestoday for his exact position he declared that it would be silly to attempt to give a dictionary definition of a holding company at this time.

Francis Russell Hart, president of the United Fruit Company for the last five years and prominently identified with the Boston banking field for three decades, died today of a heart attack in his home here. He was 70 years old.

Export of Canadian newsprint to the United States has slowed down to such an extent that pulp cutters in camps in Northern Ontario are being dismissed, Peter Heenan, Ontario's Minister of Lands and Forests, said today.

Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 37,000, including 7,000 direct. Market 10 to 15 cents lower than Monday's average on weights downward from 210 pounds; others 15 to 25 cents lower.

Building plans filed in the Borough of Queens yesterday included the specifications for one group of ten apartments to be constructed in Corona in the immediate vicinity of the World's Fair grounds at a cost of $2,875,000, and three others in Forest Hills at an estimated expenditure of $375,000.
Three New York artists, two of them women, today won the three prizes in the Worcester Art Museum's third biennial exhibition of Americas Painting of Today. Awards were made at a press preview.

Dr. Luis Bossano was named Foreign Minister today following the resignation of Carlos Manuel Larrea, the only member of the Cabinet of Federico Paez retained after the ousting of the dictator's government by the army.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Jan. 15: REAR ADMIRAL Allen, W. H., detached as member of General Board, Navy Department, Washington, D. C., about Feb. 26, to duty an Commandant 6th Naval District, and additional duty as Commandant Navy Yard, Charleston, S. C., and Commandant 7th and 8th Naval Districts.

The coldest weather in nearly two years froze New York yesterday and sent the mercury down to 5 degrees above zero at 8:45 A. M. A zero reading was expected by Weather Bureau officials early this morning, but they promised slowly rising temperatures and fair skies later today.

The rivalry of contending groups for control of the United Licensed Officers Association, a unit of the American Federation of Labor consisting of licensed merchant marine officers, was the cause yesterday of two legal actions.

The subscription series of After Dinner Dances for young married couples and former debutantes will be continued this season with two parties, the first of which will take place on Jan. 29 in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. The second dance will be on March 26.

Secretary Wallace of the Department of Agriculture joined representatives of industry today in arguments to the Interstate Commerce Commission that the railroads would lose revenue if the 15 per cent freight rate increase for which they have asked was granted to them.

Receiving 81 per cent of a record vote, in addition to being the only one to receive the necessary 75 per cent, Grover Cleveland Alexander, famous National League pitcher for a score of years, became the latest diamond immortal to have his name added to baseball's Hall of Fame at Cooperstown, N. Y.

New York University and Columbia each qualified two men in the New York district preliminary rounds of the national junior saber championship, held on the strips of the New York Athletic Club last night. Jack Gorlin and James Castello were the Violet survivors, while John Anspacher and Bruce Wallis of the Lions remained in the running as a field of thirty-one was reduced to eight qualifiers.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James A. Horgan of Brooklyn of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Mary Horgan, to Walter Chapman Jones Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter C. Jones, also of Brooklyn.

B. Frank Finney, for forty-four years an insurance broker in Greenwich, died in his home here this morning at the age of 78. Mr. Finney resigned in February, 1934, as president of B. Frank Finney, Inc., the agency which he started in 1892 and which was one of the largest in the State.

Dr. and Mrs. F. E. Requa of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eugenie Louise Requa, to Harry Douglass Hough Jr., son of Mrs. Hough of Trenton and the late Mr. Hough. The wedding will take place Feb. 6 at the Requa home. The Rev. Samuel Steinmentz, rector of St. Michael's Episcopal Church, Trenton, will perform the ceremony.

The number of commercial and industrial failures in the United States for the week ended Jan. 13 were higher in three trade divisions compared with the same week last year and were at the same level in the other two divisions, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The detailed comparison follows:

Closer relationships with the better wholesale outlets were urged upon dry goods manufacturers by E. B. Weiss, vice president of the Grey Advertising Agency, at the opening session yesterday of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute's annual convention at the New Yorker Hotel, which was attended about equally by wholesalers and manufacturers.

Architects, builders, manufacturers and casualty experts have joined hands in a program to develop a new safety code designed to reduce losses from accidents in the construction industry. One reason for their joint effort is the realization that injuries in this field remain a serious problem despite the smaller amount of building operations undertaken in recent years.

The Men's Neckwear Manufacturers' Association of New York, representing about 35 per cent of the industry and including many of the large and middle-sized producers, adopted a resolution last night agreeing to affix labels to all neckwear containing rayon, in line with the Federal Trade Commission's rayon labeling rules.
Rival labor unions whose clash yesterday at Orizaba, Veracruz, caused at least eight deaths, appeared today to have ignored the plea of President Lazaro Cardenas that they "unite for the revolution."
Dodge Concern Shows

Archibald R. Watson, County Clerk of New York County, announced late yesterday the appointment of James McGurrin and Hyman W. Gamso as deputy county clerks at $6,500 and $5,000 a year, respectively. Additional appointments probably will be announced within the coming week, Mr. Watson said.

Playing brilliantly, Mrs. Ary J. Lamme Jr. of Apawamis, defending champion, and Miss Cecile Bowes of Philadelphia, seeded No. 1 and 2 respectively, advanced to the final round of the eighth annual New Jersey State squash recquets championship on the courts of the Short Hills Club today.

Retired Capt. William H. D'Oller, formerly a member of Engine 228. residing at 1,603 Tenth Ave., Brooklyn, died Jan. 9. Retired Fireman Martin C. Hager, formerly a member of Engine 277, residing at 72-45 Seventy-third St., Glendale, Queens, died Jan. 15.

Henry A. Koelsch Jr., until recently assistant vice president of the National City Bank of New York, in charge of the company's English branches, died today as the result of throat wounds received last night. Mr. Koelsch, who was 48 years old, had been in ill health for some time and last night his family found him dying on the bathroom floor.
The text of the Court of Appeals decision in the closed shop case of the New York Rapid Transit Corporation and other defendants was as follows:

Frankie Klick, veteran California lightweight, took the decision over Felix Garcia, Puerto Rican, in their eight-round battle at the New York Coliseum, in the Bronx, last night. A crowd of about 8,000 saw the battle and cheered the award of Referee Jack Goodman and Judges Jack Denning and Charles Devlin.

Nothing could more dramatically illustrate the vacillation and confusion in the economic thinking of our public officials than the news that the Department of Justice, on the plea of Governor Earle of Pennsylvania, has begun an investigation to determine whether the anthracite companies are engaged in monopolistic practices and whether they can be sued under the anti-trust laws.

A "plan of action," dependent on increased Federal participation in a proposed national campaign to reduce deaths at childbirth, was presented today to President Roosevelt at the end of the two-day conference on better Care for Mothers and Babies called by Miss Katharine Lenroot, chief of the Children's Bureau of the Department of Labor.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,476,900 barrels, compared to 3,437,100 in the preceding week, an increase of 39,800, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 70,100

It is a very gratifying sign when the representatives of both major political parties can combine, as they have in the New York State Legislature, to act to wipe out child labor. Following the suggestion of Governor Lehman in his annual message, Assemblyman Moffat, Republican, and Senator Nunan, Democrat, have introduced in their respective bodies resolutions memorializing Congress to enact the Wheeler-Johnson hill.

Benny Bennett, veteran box-office attache at Madison Square Garden, last night was the guest of honor at a Capitol Hotel dinner given by coworkers in recognition of his thirty years of service with the organization. Colonel John R. Kilpatrick, Garden president; Ted Deglin, public relations chief; A. C.

Paolino Gerli, vice president of E. Gerli Co., was chosen a governor of the Commodity Exchange, Inc., to represent the silk group on the Exchange at the annual election held yesterday. Mr. Gerli is head of the International Silk Guild and was president of the Silk Association of America before it became the National Federation of Textiles.

An alert St. Nicholas Club team from New York won the rubber contest of its three-game hockey series with Princeton tonight by edging out the collegians, 3-2, in a loosely played contest staged on the Baker Memorial Rink before some 400 spectators.

Clarence Michel testified yesterday in Supreme Court that he could recall no occasion in the course of his eleven years of service as a director of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway (the Frisco Line) on which any director had opposed a policy suggested by Edward N.

Night deliveries wherever possible in streets ordinarily crowded with automobiles in the daytime were recommended yesterday by John T. Gibala, one of the engineers assigned to the traffic division of the Police Department, as one means of helping to ease the traffic problem between Fourteenth and Fifty-ninth Streets, from Third to Ninth Avenues.

Wesleyan's basketball team won its sixth game in seven starts this season when it outclassed Trinity by a score of 56 to 31 tonight. The game was close for the first five minutes, then Wesleyan took a long lead and scored easily. Phelps and Sonstroem were the stars.

All divisions of the infants' and children's wear industry, with the exception of snowsuits and knitwear, showed slight increases in sales volume for 1937, according to Max H. Zuckerman, executive secretary of the United Infants and Children's Wear Association.

Within four days of receiving the claim for [Pound]1,000,000, their share in the total loss of the 20,000-ton liner President Hoover, the London insurance market today decided to pay it, and checks will be collected immediately from the companies and syndicates that underwrote the risk.

Dr. Edward Cargill Ehlers of Essex Fells died yesterday afternoon of a heart attack while being driven in his automobile to Mountainside Hospital after he had collapsed while waiting in line to have his car tested by State inspectors.

Frank E. Burmester, for sixteen years manager of the banqueting and catering department of Delmonico's at the peak of its fame, died last night in St. Elizabeth's Hospital here at the age of 68. He had organized the catering department of the Waldorf-Astoria when it was opened in New York in 1893, the year of his arrival from Europe.

The famous Oberammergau Passion Play will be produced again in 1940, according to an announcement today by the Passion Play committee, which adds that all foreign rumors of abolition or changes in the play are thus refuted.
