Come this March, Broadway should be seeing Miss Ethel Barrymore as Adeline, aged 101 and a forthright grandmother, in "Whiteoaks." For Victor Payne-Jennings, a London manager, is over here with that idea in mind, and the plan has advanced so far as mentioning a few names.
Mrs. Mildred Blount Morrow obtained a divorce here today from Frank J. Morrow, on charges of cruelty. Mrs. Morrow will resume her former name. A property settlement was entered in the records.

Blanking the Yale Club, 5 to 0, the Harvard Club team won the Class B championship in Group I of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association yesterday. Harvard completed its season without a defeat in six team matches.

Temple's basketball team scored twice from the floor in the final minute of play tonight to defeat West Virginia's Mountaineers, 34 to 31, in a thrilling Eastern Intercollegiate Conference battle. West Virginia's Don Meranda and Harry Lothes brought a crowd of 3,000 to its feet as each registered a free throw to put the Mountaineers into the lead, 31 to 30, with a little more than a minute of play remaining.
Negotiations are under way between Walt Disney and Lily Pons for the diva to become the voice of Snow White in the French version of "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs." Miss Pons and Roy

Coincident with the 1937 annual report of the Detroit Edison Company, Harry A. Snow, controller, announced today that an $18,000,000 construction and replacement program, the largest since the depression of the last decade, would be undertaken this year by the company.

A proposal to limit New York schoolboys to one sport a season was made yesterday at the monthly meeting of the High School Games Committee of the P. S. A. L. at the Hotel Astor. The move is expected to meet a favorable reception. It is designed not only to limit the tax on a boy's time and energy but also to give other candidates a chance to become a member of a team.

Captain Veikko (Pick) Turevon led Colgate's basketball team to a 4942 victory over Niagara tonight. He dropped in seven baskets and two fouls for 16 points and played an outstanding defensive game. Davies was the best all-around player for the visitors.

The advisory committee for the holders of the insured first mortgage certificates of the Conveyancers Title Insurance and Mortgage Company, in a communication to the holders of the certificates, proposes a tentative reorganization plan for the company

The Thomas Jefferson High basketball team of Brooklyn, playing on its home court, defeated De Witt Clinton from the Bronx, 24 to 22, yesterday. Clinton last year defeated Jefferson in the city semifinal and went on to win the P. S. A. L. crown. Jefferson was ahead, 11 to 10, at half time in this nonleague encounter.

Through a coordinated and everincreasing use of the Municipal Art Committee, the schools, parks and playgrounds and cultural and social agencies, "an atmosphere of artistic enjoyment and community life can be fully attained in New York City," Mrs. Henry Breckinridge,

ONCE again the reminiscencers (or should it be "reminiscers"?) have been so hard at it that we have to consider several at the same time in order to make even a show of keeping up with the procession. Here are three among the recent volumes: one by Bruce Lockhart, a Scot; one by Joseph Mitchell, an American; one by the English poet and editor Sir John Squire.

Two workmen at Sagersta Bruk, one of Sweden's largest steel works, have been arrested for spying and are stated to have confessed that they- had been in communication with the Soviet Embassy in Stockholm with a view to selling the plant's secret process for manufacturing rustless steel, called "Seco."

Short-term borrowing featured both actual awards and announcements of future sales yesterday by various counties and municipalities. Officials of Fall River, Mass., awarded to Leavitt Co. an issue of $1,000,000 of temporary loan notes on a 0.582 per cent interest basis. The notes will be dated Jan. 20, and will become payable on Nov. 8, 1938.

James J. Braddock, former world's heavyweight champion, went through a six-round sparring drill during a busy training day yesterday at his quarters in Pompton Lakes, N. J., and impressed the veteran manager, Dan Morgan, so much that he unhesitatingly picked him to beat Tommy Farr Friday night in Madison Square Garden.

County Judge William O'Dwyer of Brooklyn announced that he would sit in open court every Friday at 2 P. M. to hear applications for clemency for defendants scheduled to be sentenced during the following week.

President Roosevelt said today that some progress had been made in recent conferences with business, industrial and labor leaders on plans for ending the business recession, but that no formula had so far been evolved.

The opening of raw-fur prices for 1938 indicate that quotations on rabbit skins have been stabilized and should continue firm and with an upward tendency, Joseph Brickner, president of the American Rabbit Dealers Association, declared last night at the organization's annual dinner meeting at the Fur Merchants Club, 333 Seventh Avenue.

Advertising agencies handling automotive accounts are devoting a considerable portion of their time to evolving promotional plans for moving used cars, stocks of which are now holding up the sale of new cars, agency executives said here yesterday.

Boys generally are more courteous than girls and children from tenement districts are more polite than those from fashionable apartmenthouse neighborhoods, according to a questionnaire survey just completed among New York City school children by the Union Inspectors Club, sponsored by the Department of Sanitation and directed by the WPA.

Because of the success of a twoyear experiment in teaching French to seventh and eighth grade pupils, the study of foreign languages will be introduced in ten elementary schools of this city next month, Dr. Theodore Huebener, assistant director of foreign languages, announced yesterday.

A Federal District Court took control today of the historic Erie Railroad under Section 77 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. The road, reporting that it expected to be unable to meet approximately $10,000,000 of debts due between Jan. 1 and March 1, sought the action as a way out of its dilemma.

Harvard defeated Brown, 10 to 2, in a hockey game tonight. Joseph Patrick and Francis Harding led the Crimson attack with three goals each. Harvard tallied three goals in the first period and four in the second, then was held to a 3-to-2 margin in the final period.

Closing basketball activities until after the mid-year examinations, Lehigh University tonight defeated Upsala College, 54--32. Paced by Earl Russell, the Engineers' diminutive forward, Lehigh opened the scoring and remained in front all the way. At half-time the count was 30--14.

A resolution dealing with a pastorate-maintenance fund, one point of which provides for the establishment of a minimum salary for pastors of $1,500 annually and manse or its equivalent, was adopted yesterday by ministers and church elders of the Westchester Presbytery at their midwinter meeting at the Presbyterian Building, 156 Fifth Avenue.

In its ninth Yorkville purchase duringthe pasttwo years, the Rimsovo Corporation, Burt Franklin, president, has purchased the two four-story tenements at 315 and 317 East Seventy-eighth Street, on a plot 50 by 100.2 feet. Last week Mr. Franklin reported the purchase by his corporation of the houses at 330-32 East Eighty-fifth Street from the Central Savings Bank.

William Picune of North Bergen, aviator and stunt flier, was cleared of a charge of causing death by airplane when Assistant Prosecutor Sydney Sher recommended in Second District Criminal Court here today that the charge be dropped.

Burgess Meredith, acting president of Actors Equity, announced yesterday that the union would waive its demand for pay for actors appearing in next Sunday night's performance of "Between the Devil" at the National Theatre, Washington. Equity's action,

LET'S PLAY FAIR! a musical comedy in twenty-two scenes and two acts; book by Billy Rose; lyrics by Mr. Rose and Ted Fetter; music by Ned Lehak and Dana Suesse; staged by John Murray Anderson; costumes and settings by Raoul Pene du Bois; featured in the cast are Oscar Shaw, Morton Downey, Wini Shaw, Tom Patricola, Doctor Rockwell and Sally Rand; produced by Mr. Rose. At the Casa Manana, formerly the French Casino.

Phillips Exeter's hockey team routed the University of New Hampshire freshmen today, winning 10 to 2. The Exonians opened up in the third period and scored six goals, while the freshmen saved a shutout by scoring their two goals.

Electric Power and Light Corporation and Subsidiaries-Twelve months to Nov. 30: Net income after all expenses and charges, $9,905,143, compared to a net of $7,915,766 in the twelve months to Nov. 30, 1936; gross revenues for the period were $109,103,010, against $94,715,648 in the preceding comparable period.

Steel ingot production increased slightly more than seasonally last week and the adjusted index moved up to 46.7 from 45.4. The figure for the week ended Jan. 16, 1937, was 124.8. According to the estimate of THE NEW YORK TIMES, the industry operated at 29 per cent of capacity, compared with 26 per cent for the previous week and 80 per cent for the corresponding week last year.

Imports of Danish "Smoerrebroed" boomed today as a lockout of 20,000 hotel and restaurant employes continued throughout Sweden. Supplies of the popular open-top fish and meat sandwiches were rushed from Copenhagen restaurants by air mail to supply hungry office workers in Stockholm.

The prospects for world peace in a world at present far from peaceful were discussed with hope but lack of confidence at today's opening session of the National Conference on the Cause and Cure of War.

The Bondholders Committee for 616 Madison Avenue Apartment Hotel Building has sent to the holders of certificates of deposit for the first-mortgage serial 6 1/2 per cent bonds dated Oct. 1, 1923, a notice of termination of the deposit agreement on Jan. 31, 1938.

The American Smelting and Refining Company lowered yesterday the price of copper in the domestic market to 9.75 cents a pound from 9.875 cents. The leading producers continued to quote 11 cents for the metal in the domestic market. Abroad prices ranged from 10.70 tb 10.825 cents, compared with 10.52 to 10.81 cents on Monday.

Member schools of the far flung Pacifio Coast Conference pledged cooperation today and predicted long strides would be taken in the move toward meeting a ticklish problem--the subsidization of college athletics.

For the first time in three years the Title Guarantee and Trust Company had a net operating profit in 1937, George McAneny, chairman of the board, informed shareholders at their annual meeting yesterday.

The Harringay Racers lengthened their lead in the National Hockey League tonight by playing a 2-2 tie with Earl's Court Rangers. The Racers now have a seven - point advantage over the Rangers and Wembley Monarchs.

For the third year in a row, Stanley Galowin, sensational young player of New York University, has reached the final round of the New York State squash racquets championship. He triumphed yesterday in a hard-fought semi-final at the Downtown A. C., defeating G. Huntington Hartford 2d of the Harvard Club.

Walter K. Porzer has resigned as general director of Associated Wool Industries to resume his practice as marketing counsel under the firm name of Walter K. Porzer Associates. Associated Wool Industries will continue its activities under the direction of the executive committee.

Spanish Insurgent authorities announced today their artillery had isolated Government troops at Teruel, except for a small corridor leading from the strategically important provincial capital to Valencia.

Among the leases for large commercial quarters reported by brokers yesterday was one for the main floor and basement, comprising approximately 22,000 square feet of space, in the building at 257 West Seventeenth Street, which was taken by H. Lemberger, Inc., paper box manufacturers.

The report of the Brooklyn Manhattan Transit System, including the Brooklyn and Queens Transit System, for the six months ended on Dec. 31, issued yesterday, shows a net income after all expenses and charges of $689,082. This was equal to $2.76 a share on the company's outstanding $6 preferred stock, and is compared to a net of $2,523,177. or $2.41 a common share, after full preferred dividends. in the six months to Dec. 31, 1936.

Governor Earle announced tonight, after a conference with coal operators, representatives of the United Mine Workers of America and members of his Anthracite Coal Industry Commission, that he would request the Federal Government to assume ownership of Pennsylvania's anthracite industry.

Dr. Herman Leonard Pass, canon residentiary of Chichester Cathedral, and a noted Hebraist, formerly at Cambridge University, died in Eastbourne today at the age of 62. He was brought up in the Jewish faith and after taking his degree at Cambridge was appointed to catalogue Hebrew papyri collected by Dr. Charles Taylor.
The stock market here was irregular in general today and most sections closed slightly weaker. Gilt-edge issues attracted a good demand, but the best prices of the day were not maintained.

Favorites survived the first-round competition in the fourteenth annual Dixie tennis tournament today as only one seeded player was extended. Bobby Riggs of Chicago, topseeded and co-favorite with Bryan M. (Bitsy) Grant of Atlanta,
Stocks sagged on selling of Erie Railroad and liquor issues and closed slightly lower in smallest trading of year; turnover, 779,060 shares.

The Securities and Exchange Commission heard testimony today on an application by the New York Stock Exchange to delist the capital stock of the Mother Lode Coalition Mines Company, which operates in Alaska. There are 2,500,000 shares of the stock, of which Kennecott Copper owns about 660,000.

Fred Desapio's field goal in the last five seconds of play enabled the Jersey City Teachers to score a 21to-20 victory over St. Peter's College tonight. The losers held an advantage of 15-11 at half time. Desapio tallied seven points to top the scorers.

H. E. Galvin, executive vice president of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce, issued a statement yesterday replying to the implication contained in a decision of the National Labor Relations Board that the chamber, through a member of its staff, advocated evasion of the National Labor Relations Act.

Benjamin Nelson, Bronx butter and egg merchant, who has been the government's star witness at the trial of five men accused of taking part in a conspiracy to swindle insurance companies by the presentation of false claims for disability, admitted yesterday in Federal Court before Judge Robert P. Patterson that Dr. Maximilian Goldstein, one of the defendants, had had no conversation with him about any conspiracy of that kind.
President and Mrs. Roosevelt held the annual Congressional reception tonight in honor of the Senate and House of Representatives. More that 1,000 guests were present.

A definite decision to go ahead with an attempt to reorganize the Democratic party in New York County by ousting some of the more important leaders In Tammany was reached last night at a meeting at the Columbus Civic Club, 277 Grand Street.
Pedro Guevara, former Philippine Resident Commissioner at Washington, died today while appearing as a lawyer in a case before the Philippine Supreme Court. Death was attributed to a heart attack.

" Old Man Recession," in the form of an emaciated, top-hatted dummy, was buried yesterday under the 90-foot pile which started foundation work on the $750,000 exhibit building of Gas Industries, Inc., at the World's Fair grounds in Flushing Meadow Park.

Democratic members of the City Council won their fight for a court determination on the claim of Councilman John Cashmore to be Vice Chairman after a stormy three-hour meeting yesterday in City Hall, at which leaders of the Mayor's bloc roundly criticized Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan for issuing an order staying the Council's proceedings.

A spirited rally in the second half carried the La Salle Academy basketball team to a 23-to-20 triumph over the St. Ann's quintet in a Manhattan - Richmond Division, Catholic High Schools Athletic Association, contest on the losing five's court yesterday.

For the first time in almost 112 years, the property at 78 Avenue D has changed ownership. The Cross Brown Company yesterday announced the sale of this parcel for the Wendel Foundation to Sara Giberstone.

A comprehensive drive against manufacturers and wholesalers selling at retail who have not paid the city sales tax is now under way, it was learned yesterday. Confirmation was obtained from Marks Lewis, deputy treasurer in the sales tax division of the city government, who said that a crew of close to 100 accountants is engaged this week in checking up the books of coat and suit manufacturers.

Willie Hoppe and Jay Bozeman divided the third and fourth blocks of their 600-point exhibition-threecushion match at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy yesterday. Bozeman scored in the afternoon, 50--28, in thirty-seven innings, each having a high run of 6.

Fundamentalists who, led by the late Rev. Dr. J. Gresham Machen, seceded in 1936 from the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America were enjoined today from calling their organization the Presbyterian Church of America.

The late Colonel Edward H. R. Green, millionaire son of Hetty Green, shunned New York City from 1933 until his death three years later, fearing that he would be haled to court in a stockholders' suit against the directors of the Chase National Bank,
Charles O. Beaman, former principal in the public schools here, died today at his home at the age of 56. Illness had forced him to retire from the Eastview Avenue Junior High School last November.

Rear Admiral Henry V. Butler, commandant of the Sixth Naval District, will retire on April 1, upon reaching the age of 64, and Major Gen. Harry E. Knight will retire soon, according to official announcements.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry K. Harding entertained tonight with a dinner at their villa for a group that included Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Huntington, Mr. and Mrs. T. Suffern Tailer, Mrs. Dodge Sloane, Mrs. Frank Crocker, Captain Alastair Mackintosh and Arthur Cooley.

Nine contributors added $83 yesterday to the Neediest Cases Fund. These additions brought the total received in the twenty-sixth annual appeal to $301,234.05. The gifts received yesterday were as follows:

Enrico Venturi's suspension by the New York State Athletic Commission was increased to 120 days yesterday at the conclusion of an investigation by the commission into the bout against Henry Armstrong last Wednesday in Madison Square Garden, in which the Italian lightweight was counted out in the sixth round while claiming a disabling foul.
President Roosevelt is scheduled to open the twentieth anniversary week of the Boy Scouts of America in a nationwide broadcast from the White House on Feb. 7 at 6:45 P. M., over WEAF's network.

ABBOTT-Fanny, beloved mother of Victor, Elias and Elizabeth. Services Wednesday, 11:30 A. M., at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. arid Amsterdam Ave. AMSTERDAM-Moritz, 438 Sterling St.. Brooklyn, beloved husband of Fannie, devoted father of Isador S., Bernard, Anna, Sam and Augusta: dear brother and grandfather. Funeral Wednesday noon.

It was confirmed tonight on information from Washington that the Soviet Government had reported the arrest at Sverdlovsk of a man traveling as "Donald G. Robinson" and the arrest a few days later in Moscow of a woman traveling as "Mrs. Robinson,"

Mrs. John A. Goodwin, in 7 Park Ave; Joan Baker, Gladys Otey, in 783 Madison Ave; Ralph Heaton, in 16 E 82d St; Helen Wiegand and Madeline Harrington, through Talman Blgelow, Inc., in 42 Park Ave; Pay on McL. Merrill Co, Inc. broker. Errol Flynn, in Hotel Savoy-Plaza, 5th Ave and 59th St. Ogden M. Field, in 370 Riverside Dr; Leonard J. Beck, Inc. broker.

Capel Tilt, president of the Tilt Grain Company and long a prominent figure in the grain trade here, died at his home early today at the age of 66. Born in Listowel, Ont., where he attended public school, Mr. Tilt entered the grain business with James Carruthers Co., Montreal grain merchants, when he was only 20 years old.

Two books on Macmillan's Spring list are related in an interesting way. The murder around which the mystery centers in Catherine Meadow's forthcoming book, "Friday Market," is factually treated in the biography of the English criminal lawyer, Sir Henry Curtis-Bennett, whose life story is told in "King's Counsel," published recently.

The little red school house of song and story was ordinarily badly lighted, badly heated and insanitary. Its classes were conducted by an underpaid teacher who was lucky if he or she could keep one jump ahead of the more advanced students.

Clipper Smith, who guided Villanova College to an undefeated football season last Fall, is finding the accomplishment has its disadvantages. Now he can't get enough opponents to complete next Fall's schedule.

A few years ago Justice Cardozo, then Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals of the State of New York, speaking at a commencement, raised the question as to the choice which young people should make of the "values."

The defending champion and the medalist-Charles H. Jennings of Miami and R. Murray Purves of Boston-chalked up easy victories in the first round of match play in the thirty-first annual championship of the Winter Golf League of Advertising Interests at the Palm Beach Golf Club today.

Reductions in prices on knitting yarns to levels below those announced last week by other producers were made yesterday by Industrial Rayon Corporation, and traders predicted that the new lows would be met generally in the market.

Despite the fact that Long Island University has been beaten three times, the Blackbirds have been piling up a sensational scoring record, even higher than their mark in early games last season. In thirteen contests thus far, they have tallied 830 points, almost 64 per contest.

The Midston Club squash racquets team gained undisputed possession of first place in the race for honors among Group I teams in the Eastern Squash Racquets Association yesterday when it scored a clean sweep over the Jackson Heights team on the latter's courts.
Princeton University's freshman hockey forces rang up their third straight triumph in five starts by overwhelming an undermanned Hun School team, 10-1, today at the Hobey Baker Rink.

More hopeful than at any time since the Federal tax of 10 per cent on cosmetics was levied, the toilet goods industry is preparing to make a strong effort for repeal of the tax at the present session of Congress, it was learned here yesterday.

Plans have been completed by Miss Jean McCallum Cameron, niece of Mr. and Mrs. William McCallum of 465 Park Avenue and daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Donald Cameron of Portland, Ore., for her marriage to Stephen Hotchkiss Hartshorn, son of Dr. and Mrs. Winfred Morgan Hartshorn of this city, on the afternoon of Feb. 25 in the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street.

The vital statistics for the week ended last Saturday were generally favorable, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, reported yesterday. Deaths in the city totaled 1,478, giving a general death rate of 10.3.

Robert S. Brown, vice president and treasurer of the G. M. Basford Company, advertising agents, 60 East Forty-second Street, New York, died here last night in his home after three days' illness of grippe. His age was 51.

The recital of Raya Garbousova, 'cellist, given last night at Town Hall, was one of mixed pleasure. Her previous appearances have marked her as an instrumentalist of extraordinary technical capacity and a musician of abundant temperament which, however, is misdirected by an uncertain sense of style.

The market for railroad bonds was severely shaken yesterday by the decision of the Erie to file for reorganization under the Federal Bankruptcy Act. Losses of 1 to 7 1/2 points net in the Eries prompted selling over a broad list of other rail issues, with the result that the price average for that group dropped 1.06 points on the day.

The passenger list of the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria, arriving today from Southampton via Cherbourg, includes Alexander Brailowsky, Russian pianist; Artur Schnabel, Austrian pianist; Hans Christian Ericksen, president of the Dania Lodge, recently knighted by the King of Denmark; Karen Branzell, Metropolitan Opera contralto; Dr. Bernard Joseph, legal adviser of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, and the Duchess of Leeds.

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Miss Alice Bredin O'Hara, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. John O'Hara of this city, to Charles Lynde Babcock 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Babcock Jr. of 18 Montgomery Place, Brooklyn, which took place on Nov. 1 in the Municipal Building, this city. First Deputy City Clerk Philip A. Hines performed the ceremony.

Trenchard Emlen Newbold, a chain manufacturer and member of a prominent Philadelphia family, died at his suite in the Belgravia today, sixteen hours after suffering a stroke, one of several during the last ten years. His age was 61.

Expenditures of millions of dollars for emergency conservation work have never been subjected to a "proper audit," according to a report by investigators of the Interior Department, which tells in detail of the embezzlement of more than $84,000 by Reno E. Stiteley, a former $2,300-per-year voucher clerk in the National Parks Service.

John D. Rockefeller Jr. announced yesterday that he had authorized the completion of Rockefeller Center by the construction of three more structures as "evidence of continuing faith in the future of American business," and urged an expansion of building by private business and industry to meet the unemployment problem.
Senator Smith, Democrat, of South Carolina, reported agreement today by a Senate-House conference committee on the cotton sections of the ever-normal-granary Farm Bill.
The statement issued by David E. Lilienthal, director of the Tennessee Valley Authority, in reply to Wendell L. Willkie, reads as follows:

Mrs. Joel Ellis Fisher gave a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Henry Darlington, Mr. and Mrs. Joel Ellis Fisher Jr., the Rev. and Mrs. Gilbert S. B. Darlington, Mrs. John D. Little of Atlanta, Mrs. Charles Herbert Jones, Rene E. Hoguet, Alexander D. Marks and Irving Giffin.

The outstanding advantage of the 1,000,000-volt X-ray machine at Presbyterian Hospital is the elimination of damage to the skin, according to Dr. Francis Carter Wood, director of the Crocker Institute for Cancer Research, in his annual report to President Nicholas Murray Butler of Columbia University.
The five-story apartment house at 210 Central Avenue, corner of Center Street, in Orange, N. J. has been purchased by David S. Meister of New York through James Felt Co., brokers.

BELL, JEANETTE (Feb. 10, 1936). Gross assets, $421,010; net, $380.781. To Isaac Bell, son, personal effects and 50 per cent of residue; Norah Richards, daughter, personal effects and 25 per cent of residue; Henrietta d'Aramon, daughter, 25 per cent; six specific bequests. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $270,687.

Centuries by C. L. Badcock and Don Bradman featured South Australia's second innings today in its Sheffield Shield cricket match against New South Wales. After a poor first innings total of 187, South Australia made 330 runs for eight wickets at the second attempt. New South Wales's opening innings netted 295.
Seventeen persons were injured, one seriously, at 7:30 A. M. yesterday at the intersection of Forty-first Street, Forty-eighth Avenue and Greenpoint Avenue, L. I. City.

Five more members of the extraordinary grand jury, summoned to appear in criminal Superior Court a week from today to investigate the Merritt Parkway land purchases, were selected at the opening of court this morning by Judge Foster to replace five who had been excused.
Movements of vessels follow. All dates are Jan. 17 unless specified: At San Diego, Chandler, Kanawha. At La Haina Area, Lark, Oglala, Preble, Pruitt, Quail, Sicard, Tanager, Tracy.

A widening of the tax base to include the man of "small or moderate means" was advocated yesterday by Mark Graves, State Commissioner of Finance and Taxation, at a joint luncheon of the Queensboro Chamber of Commerce and the Queens Rotary Club in the chamber's dining hall, Long Island City.

A judgment for $632,109 was entered yesterday against the Mansfeld Aktiengesellschaft fur Bergbau and Huttenbetrieb (Mansfeld Mining and Smelting Company) of Eisleben, Germany, by the New York Trust Company as co-trustee under an indenture dated May 1, 1926.

Patrolman William Reilly of the Oak Street Station, while off duty yesterday, went into a downtown luggage store to shop and walked into a hold-up. Two armed men bound him with five others in the store, took his service revolver from him and remarked that if they thought he was a policeman they would kill him. Reilly was not in uniform.

The New Orleans Cotton Exchange yesterday revised its by-laws to allow associate memberships. The plan is designed to open services of the Exchange to a larger body of manufacturers, merchants, farmers, traders and others connected with the cotton industry.
A threegoal drive by the Boston Bruins late in the final period gave the National Hockey League American division leaders a 5-1 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks tonight.

The General Tire and Rubber Company showed for the year ended on Nov. 30 a net profit of $808,913 after all charges, provision for Federal income taxes and surtax on undistributed earnings, according to the annual report sent yesterday to stockholders by W. O'Neil, president.
Charles Kingsley Fankhauser Jr., assistant manager of the Associated Industries of Cleveland for the last ten years, died today at St. Luke's Hospital after a heart attack. He was 36.
Repetition of last year's long and tempestuous hearing on the resolution for ratification of the Child Labor Amendment will be averted this year, it was indicated today.

Mementoes of old New York, which were given to the Museum of the City of New York during 1937 and which add a few more pages to the history of the city as depicted in this institution, will go on special exhibition today.
Mr. and Mrs. Frank L. Dedrick of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen M. Dedrick of New York, to S. Stephen Marvin of Butler, Pa.
Chinese and Japanese forces were reported fighting today along the Yangtze River near where the United States gunboat Panay was sunk by the Japanese a month ago.

The Ambrosian Society, the alumnae literary association of the College of Mount St. Vincent, is sponscoring a lecture by Miss Helen C. White, a Catholic educator and writer, to be held in the Cardinal Hayes Auditorium on Wednesday evening of next week at 8:15 o'clock. She will talk on "A Modern Looks at the Middle Ages."

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, who, as a special rackets prosecutor, obtained the conviction of Charles (Lucky) Lucania and eight of his henchmen on charges of compulsory prostitution, told six judges of the Court of Appeals today that "the case never can be retried," adding:

Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation and president of the International Chamber of Commerce, said yesterday that he was not interested in arranging credits in this country for the purchase by the Japanese of American machinery.

To take effect 8 A. M., Jan. 19: SERGEANTS--Alvin B. Touchette, from 47th Precinct, to 45th Precinct; Henry T. Wade, from 75th Precinct, to 104th Precinct; Daniel J. Carroll, from 104th Precinct, to 75th Precinct.

Miss Gertrude Ruth Roos, daughter of Mrs. John S. Bizel of this city, was married to Dr. Harry L. Chasserot, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Chasserot of New Rochelle, this afternoon in the Church of Blessed Sacrament. The Most Rev. Mgr. Bartholomew J. Eustace, Bishop-elect of the Camden (N. J.) Diocese, officiated. The ceremony was followed by a small reception at the Bizel home.
In the midst of the government-sponsored campaign to increase the consumption of milk, the British Medical Association, representing 37,000 physicians, has issued a public warning

The closed shop part of the contract between the New York Rapid Transit Corporation and three other subsidiaries of the B. M. T. system and the Transport Workers Union of America was upheld by the Court of Appeals today.

Slingin' Samuel Adrian Baugh punctured the publicity bubble surrounding his alleged $25,000 salary demand today by announcing he probably would sign a three-year contract with the Washington Redskins within a few days.

The Maritime Commission stated today that its technical experts were designing two additional types of ships for the Merchant Marine construction program, one to be larger and faster than the design already approved.

Lieutenant Kelley B. Lemmon of Fort Omaha, Neb., member of the United States Army, got locked in the vestry of the Church of the Redeemer with his best man last night. The bride, Djenane Mackellar, was to walk down the aisle in a few moments.

The German Atlantic Cable Company, which failed to pay on its $4,000,000-bond issue under the German law of June 9, 1933, forbidding the use of foreign exchange for such payments, must meet its obligations to bondholders, Supreme Court Justice John MacCrate ruled yesterday in Brooklyn in awarding a summary judgment to two bondholders, Louis J. Goodman and Bernard Douglis.

Dr. Paul de Kruif, writer on research in the field of medicine and bacteriology, predicted further advances toward the prevention of infantile paralysis yesterday in a brief analysis of current investigations into the causes of this disease.

The First Boston Corporation, investment bankers, reported yesterday for 1937 a net loss of $2,484,004 after taxes, charges, depreciation and adjustment of book value of securities to year-end market values. In addition, a provision of $525,000 was made for contingencies, making a deficit of $3,009,004 for the year.

Penn State won its seventh straight basketball game today, defeating Bucknell, 33 to 20. The Nittany Lions were not extended at any stage and led at half time, 19 to 5. Reserves played all except a few minutes of the second half.

The Baltimore Ohio Railroad announced yesterday that it was about to accept the delivery of the fourth of the 3,600-horsepower Diesel-electric locomotives built for it by the Electro-Motive Corporation, a subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation. The B. O.

The Dunnigan-Killgrew bill, amending the be State unemployment insurance law As to include within its benefits 150, 000 to 200,000 workers receiving salaries of more than $3,000 a year, is slated for rapid passage through the Republican-controlled Assembly, it was learned today.

Stockholders of the Celotex Corporation approved yesterday in Chicago the acquisition from the Phoenix Securities Corporation of 9,496 preference and 109,360 common shares of the Certain-teed Products Corporation, it was announced here last night.

Lord and Lady Mountbatten, who are arriving tomorrow on the Bremen, will be at the St. Regis before going to Palm Beach. Mr. and Mrs. George Vanderbilt, who have been in South Carolina, are expected today at the WaldorfAstoria. They will leave soon for Honolulu.

Joe DiMaggio, the American League's reigning home run monarch, who arrived in town Monday for a social visit, will not know what salary the Yankees plan to offer him for 1938 until all the other contracts are mailed to the world champions the latter part of the week.
The Federal Reserve Bank- of New York reported yesterday that its net earnings in 1937 were $3,544,000, compared with $3,699,000 in 1936.
Organized liquor package store groups and the National Distillers Products Corporation appeared deadlocked here yesterday in the controversy over an alleged boycott against the company's products.

Chancer, 5-year-old gelded son of Chance Play owned by P. Andolino, scored a surprise victory today when he defeated seven other players in the six-furlong feature at the Fair Grounds. Making his first start at the New Orleans oval after winning only

Great importance is being attached to a statement by Foreign Minister Rickard Sandler which seems to indicate that Sweden has accepted The Netherlands' proposal to accord at least de facto recognition to the Italian conquest of Ethiopia.

For nearly eight hundred years Leipzig has been celebrated for its fairs. For two hundred years it has been one of the world's great book-publishing centers. It is so no longer. Its presses still rumble, but few persons outside of Germany, unless they happen to be interested in the pathology of dictatorships, care what they print.

Dr. Frank Bacon Hancock, former medical adviser to University of Pennsylvania athletic teams and himself a member of varsity crews in his undergraduate days, died at Allenwood today after a long illness. He was 65.

A reward of $1,000 for information concerning Arthur Fried, 32-yearold sand and gravel company executive, who disappeared Dec. 4, was offered today by relatives here. The offer ended seven weeks of silence by his family, during which no information was given on the source of a $200,000 ransom note that authorities declared they had seen.

The High Command of the Soviet dictatorship suddenly called off the purge within the Communist party today. It issued a series of peremptory orders to the entire party organization throughout the country to reinstate thousands who had been expelled from the party and to restore their jobs to all who had been dismissed as a result of their exnulsion.

Elections today to the editorial board of The Argus, the Wesleyan University semi-weekly student publication, had the following results: Editor in chief, William G. Fash of Hackensack, N. J.; managing editor, Edward C. Grumshaw of Montclair, N. J.; business manager,

Selling activities of a company should not be confined merely to the sales force but should be extended to include the entire personnel of an organization, K. N. Merritt, general sales manager of the Railway Express Agency yesterday told the weekly luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Mr. and Mrs. Solomon Simon of 450 West End Avenue last night celebrated the sixtieth anniversary of their marriage at a dinner and reception given at their home. Of the many congratulatory messages they received one was a letter from President Roosevelt extending his "hearty congratulations" and his "best wishes for your welfare and happiness."

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Jan. 17: MAJOR GENERAL Knight, H. E., Washington, D. C., to home and await retirement. COLONELS Burtt, W. B., Inf., Ft. Williams, Me., to home and await retirement. Coates, C. E., Inf., Hawaii, to Organized Reserves, Boston, Mass.

Virtually all elements in Brazil seem to be engaged in a mass campaign to overcome the impression abroad that the new unitariann" regime of President Getulio Vargas is linked physically with the dictatorships of Europe.

Today's major events: "Gianni Schicchi" and "Elektra," Metropolitan Opera House, evening; "Sleeping Beauty," Juilliard School of Music, evening; Albert-Leveque, pianist, and Rene Le Roy, flutist, Town Hall, afternoon; Frances Moyer, pianist, Town Hall, evening; Madrigal Singers, Federal Music Theatre, evening.

Four methods have been recommended by the Corset and Brassiere Association of America for furnishing information as to fibre content as required by the Federal Trade Commission regulations for the rayon industry, it was announced yesterday by Samuel Blumberg, general counsel.

General Ludjan Zeligowski, conqueror of Vilna and one of the late Marshal Joseph Pilsudski's few personal friends, has been removed from the presidency of the Sejm's war committee for criticizing a government decree making Marshal Edward Smigly-Rydz the first citizen of the republic, next to the President.

An increase in the volume of contracts on the Cotton Exchange yesterday brought a decline of 7 to 9 points. A decline in Bombay widened the spread with the domestic market and led to arbitrage selling here while commission-house liquidation in the March position added to the supply of contracts.

Procedure that involved the holding of court in a parked automobile resulted yesterday in the return to New York of Boies Heed, one of five defendants scheduled for trial in Federal court next Monday on charges of mail fraud in the socalled Graham-McKay case.

Incorporated Investors reported yesterday that its net resources were $47,659,549 at the close of 1937, equal to $15.90 a share on 2,996,694 capital shares, compared with $77,305,950, or $25.77 a share on 3,000,000 shares, at the close of 1936.

A supper dance last night marked the formal opening of La Salle Tropicale, new supper rooms of the Coq Rouge. The party was arranged as a benefit for the Child Placing and Adoption Committee of the State Charities Aid Association.

The first yearracer ever to carry the colors of Mrs. Duval Headley won at Hialeah Park today when her Sparta captured the 4 o'clock race, which featured the program. Young Duval is the trainer of the stable of Hal Price Headley, and last year handled Menow, the champion 2-yearold.

Rhode Island, with 6.4 per cent, had the highest proportion of totally unemployed, and Iowa, with 2.4 per cent of its estimated 1937 population reporting ?? totally unemplayed, had the lowest proportion of jobless, according to figures presented today by John D. Biggers, Administrator of the National Unemployment Census.

Despite the Opposition's protest, the Rumanian Parliament elected Dec. 20 was dissolved tonight by royal decree before it had assembled to show Premier Octavian Goga that he enjoyed the support of only about 9 per cent of the Deputies.
It looks as if most of the anglers who haven't left for Florida will be crowded around the tables at the Long Island fishermen's dinner tonight at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Giovanni Martinelli will be guest of honor tonight at a dinner to be given by the Metropolitan Opera Club in the club's rooms in the Metropolitan Opera House. About ninety active and honorary members of the club will pay tribute to Mr. Martinelli in observance of his twenty-fifth anniversary as a member of the Metropolitan artistic personnel.

Seventy-nine pictures submitted by Princeton University undergraduates and residents of the town of Princeton were placed on display this afternoon as the Princeton Camera Club opened its Winter exhibition in Murray-Dodge Hall on the university campus.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE NEW YORK TIMES in an editorial, "The Sixty-Headed Hydra," commented approvingly on a purported factual analysis of the statistical bases of my book "America's 60 Families"-an analysis which appears in The Annalist of Jan. 14.

Several major public utility holding companies have taken steps recently to comply with the provisions of Section 13 of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 by the creation of subsidiary service corporations to take over duties now performed by the parent companies.

Failure to capture enough second places cost Fordham's swimming team a dual meet with Villanova in the Fordham pool yesterday afternoon. The visiting Wildcats, by finishing first and second in the 200-yard breast stroke, virtually clinched an ultimate 37-34 victory.

Ninety-five out of 110 needlework factories in the island were closed today as a result of the shipping strike with 66,000 workers unemployed, according to the Chamber of Commerce. Some 15,000 needleworkers temporarily have work cleaning up orders on hand, but these will be exhausted this week, the chamber said.

The House took up today the regular annual Naval Appropriation Bill with the probability that it would be passed speedily and substantially as reported by committee. Such opposition as is to be voiced to the Administration's defense program, it was indicated, may be reserved for the additional naval' construction to be recommended in the special message President Roosevelt plans to send to Congress.

The New College basketball team defeated the Columbia College of Pharmacy quintet, 37 to 30, last night at Thompson Gymnasium. Hubert Schulze, center, who played at end for the Columbia eleven last season, was the winner's high scorer with six field goals and one free throw for 13 points.

The economy program of the House leadership suffered a setback today in its first real test of the session, when members voted overwhelmingly to increase sums in the Treasury-Postoffice Appropriation Bill.

With $5,550,000 already raised in the first joint appeal of the New York and Brooklyn Jewish Federations, Governor Lehman urged last night renewed efforts to achieve the goal of $6,250,000 in the final two weeks of a campaign to raise funds for 116 affiliated social welfare and medical agencies.

In generous mood, the New York Women's Symphony Orchestra set seven compositions and four soloists before its audience at Carnegie Hall last night. Since the soloists appeared together in the Vivaldi-Bach A minor Concerto for four harpsichords, this work was the piece de resistance of the evening.
Members of the Roosevelt family apparently like to go about without cash. When the President enrolled on Monday

Daniel Allen Payne, president for the last twenty years of the Lynchburg Trust and Savings Bank, a member of the board of overseers of Sweetbriar College and a leader in society and church circles, died this afternoon at the age of 64, after an illness of several weeks.

The Senate clerk called the name of Governor A. Harry Moore of New Jersey at roll call today, for Mr. Moore remained officially a member of the Senate. He was inaugurated yesterday for the third term as Governor of New Jersey.

Major Lawrence C. Brower, commanding air officer of the Twentyseventh Division, New York National Guard, will lead a squadron of airplanes from Miller Field, Staten Island, to Albany today to invite Governor Lehman and Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr.
Asserting that a hearse is not the "place for advertising," an undertaker today painted out the World's Fair lettering on his 1938 license plates.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The comments in your editorial "The Nation's Health" should give much food for thought to every one. While the American Medical Association is opposed to any radical change in the present methods of medical practice, there is a large body of medical opinion that some change is not only imminent but is wholly desirable.

No formal hearings by the Assembly Ways and Means Committee on the Governor's budget will be held this year. Instead, the committee will hold "open house" Tuesday and hear, informally, any one who has any thing to say.

The echoes of a hot verbal battle between legislative leaders on the one hand and representatives of Park Commissioner Moses and the World's Fair corporation on the other were heard in the Capitol today.

The former $1,500 selling plater Rollin Home, who surprised the bettors by running second in the Inaugural Handicap, showed today at Hialeah Park that his previous performance was no flash in the pan by taking the feature in the easiest sort of fashion.
James W. Van Meter, internationally known chemist and inventor and developer of various ore and chlorine treatment processes, died here last night of a heart attack. He was 67 years old.

The largest local basketball crowd of the season, approximately 3,500, saw Notre Dame defeat the University of Pittsburgh tonight, 51 to 41. The Irish led, 24 to 16, at the half and managed to halt a threatening rally by the Panthers which whittled their margin to 36--34 at one point.

A client of J. A. O'Sullivan, Inc., broker, has purchased for occupancy the one-family dwelling at 2,249 West Sixth Street, Brooklyn, from Ellen Purdy. The house occupies a corner plot and contains six rooms, with a garage at the rear.
J. F. T. O'Connor will resign tomor-': row as Controller of the Currency, it was learned authoritatively today. Friends indicated that he might announce soon his candidacy for Governor of California.
Possibility of the sale of American plumbing fixtures and housefurnishings in Guatemala City, in connection with a plan to construct a number of small or medium-sized homes,

Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, proposed yesterday that the State eventually assume the entire expenses of the municipal educational system as a means of relieving this city of a budgetary item now amounting to nearly $90,000,000 annually.

Two exhibitions open today at the New School for Social Research One, consisting of works by members of the art faculty of the school, will occupy the third floor gallery and the other, a one-man show of oils and water-colors by Crawford Gillis, a young Southern artist, may be seen in the fifth floor gallery. Both exhibitions will continue into February.

To Dr. Thomas C. Poulter, director of the Research Foundation of Armour Institute of Technology, was: presented tonight a Congressional medal for "scientific accomplishment unequaled in polar exploration." The presentation was made by Charles G. Dawes, former Vice President, at a banquet.

A total of $148,525 has been raised in the $200,000 1938 budget campaign of the Young Women's Christian Association of New York City, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Raymond Chauncey, chairman of the drive.

THE legend is that the last muttered words of Johann Wolfgang von Goethe, the great German poet and philosopher, were "More light! More light!" There is no doubt that more light is needed in a great many dark places, but it's carrying a great thought to extremes when a hockey goalie turns himself into a small edition of a pillar of fire by night on ice.

THE TYRANNY OF WORDS, by Stuart Chase. (Harcourt, Brace, $2.50.) An investigation of the meaning and quality of verbal symbols. JAPAN DEFIES THE WORLD, by James A. B. Scherer. (Bobbs-Merrill, $2.50.) A discussion of the Far Eastern crisis.

Close matches featured the second round of the annual championship of the Winter Golf League of Advertising Interests at the Palm Beach Golf Club today. In the only extra-hole match of the day, Robert H. Lansdell of Hackensack, N. J., eliminated R. Murray Purves of Boston, 1921 and 1922 titleholder and winner of the qualifying medal on Monday at the nineteenth.

Charged with disorderly conduct because they staged a "sit-down" in a drug store where the proprietor said there was no labor trouble, eight members of the Retail Cigar and Accessories Employes Union, Local 1,115B, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, were fined $10 each yesterday in West Side Court by Magistrate 1. Stanley Renaud. They paid the fines.

Albert Foerster, Nazi leader in Danzig, delivered a speech here today which is regarded as proof that Colonel Josef Beck, Polish Foreign Minister, secured a pledge from Chancellor Hitler that no attempt would be made in the near future to take Danzig into the Reich.

The Bureau of Agricultural Economics forecast today that prices of hogs would advance in the next few months. Factors indicating an advance, it said, were an expected reduction in hog marketing and the relatively small storage holding of pork and lard.

Italian school children will henceforth say grace before their midday meal, which is taken in school, according to this formula: "Il Duce, I thank you for what you give me to make me grow healthy and strong.

Plans for "vertical" fair trade agreements, binding wholesalers to sell tu retailers at established prices, were considered yesterday by the board of directors of the National Association of Tobacco Distributors, Inc., at the opening of the organization's annual convention in- the Hotel Commodore.

Baldur von Sehirach, Reich youth leader, announced a program today to make German girls more beautiful. All those between 18 and 21 will be compelled to join an organization known as "Work, Beauty and Faith."

Princeton University's industrial relations section, a part of the Department of Economics and Social Institutions, has received an anonymous gift of $60,000 for the furtherance of its research projects, Dr. Harold Willis Dodds, president of the university, announced tonight.

Permanent world peace is to be had, if at all, only at the price of reparation for sins committed in the past, and fair dealing now and in the future will not suffice to avert the curse. of war, Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt, founder of the Conference for the Cause and Cure of War,

Assailing "an unwarranted high cost of dying," Assemblyman Muccigrosso, Bronx Laborite, introduced a bill today permitting the creation of municipal funeral authorities in large cities. The average funeral costs the low-salaried class at least $300, Mr. Muccigrosso said:

After attending a large rally at Madison Square Garden last night flying squads of Communist adherents surged into Times Square among the theatre crowds at about 11:30 o'clock last night and staged a mass demonstration in front of three Whelan drug stores where a strike has been declared by a C. I. O. union.

Friends of the late Don Marquis, author and playwright, will hold a "Don Marquis Night" on Sunday at 9 P. M. in the Ambassador Theatre. Christopher Morley will be master of ceremonies and the speakers will include Otis Skinner, Samuel Forrest and Walter Hampden.

A three-month workhouse term was imposed in Special Sessions yesterday on Nicholas M. Zymaris, 46 years old, of 360 West Fifteenth Street, who pleaded guilty recently to posing as a physician and writing prescriptions in violation of the State Education Law.

Mrs. Grace Rowley Mellon, 29, received a divorce today from William L. Mellon Jr., 30, son of the chairman of the board of the Gulf Oil Corporation. The couple eloped to Wellsburg, W. Va., in 1929. A year later, to the day, the families planned a society wedding.

A new signature of William Shakespeare has been authenticated after nineteen months of critical and scientific examination in the University of Utah's Shakespeare laboratory, according to Professor B. Roland Lewis, who has spent years studying documents of the English dramatist in this country and in England.

Miss Dorothy M. McGee and Miss Marian S. Gray gave a luncheon yesterday at the Coq Rogue for Miss Viola Winmill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Winmill, whose engagement to Randolph G. Duffey of Warrenton, Va., has been announced.
Insurgent air raiders roved up and down Spain's east coast yesterday and Tuesday, bombed Valencia four times and sub??jected Barcelona to its most punishing bombardment of the war.

Operations last year of the Liggett Myers Tobacco Company resulted in a net income of $21,375,560 after deductions for interest, depreciation, Federal income taxes, Federal surtax on undistributed profits and $778,000 flood loss. After dividend requirements on the 7 per cent preferred stock,

William T. Kemper, financier and chairman of Missouri's new Social Security Commission, died this morning at the University of Kansas Hospital, where he was taken two days before Christmas. He was 71 years old.

Adding further laurels to his list, Germain G. Glidden, national amateur champion, won the New York State squash racquets championship yesterday at the Downtown A. C. Thwarting the bid of 20-year-old Stanley Galowin, N. Y. U. senior, who is regarded as one of the finest young players in the game, Glidden carried off the final in four games, 15-5, 12-15, 17-15, and 15-11.

Cornell opened its hockey season on Beebe Lake today and bowed to a speedy Colgate sextet, 2-1, in an exciting game played in near-zero weather. The Red Raiders piled up a two goal lead by scoring once in each of the first two periods and checked the Big Red's late attack.
Charles Burnham, who brought to New York from England the first production of "The Mikado," died in his home here today at the age of 85 after a heart attack. His widow survives.

BRADLEY, EDSON (June 20, 1935). Nonresident. Gross assets, $511,698; net, $299,048. To Title Guarantee and Trust Co., $3,000 in trust, income for improvement, care and preservation of specific cemetery plots; Mrs. Henry B. Shaw, life income of $600 yearly in monthly installments of $50 each; daughter, Julie Fay Shipman, residuary estate. Chief assets,
Attorney General Cummings has ordered the government's investigation of the newsprint industry transferred from the Justice Department to the Federal Trade Commission.
New automobile passenger car parkways on each side of the Hudsen River and new highway developments north and west from Albany were recommended today by Mayor John Boyd Thacher.

Max D. Brill, a founder of Brill Brothers, a men's clothing firm, died yesterday of a heart ailment in his home at 15 East Sixty-ninth Street. Mr. Brill, who was 72 years old, had retired from business in 1930.

Despite a moderate rally in the final hour, led by steel, motor and aviation issues, and some of the electrical and rails, the stock market closed lower again yesterday. Leading issues finished the day with losses of fractions to 1 point, and a few stocks were down 2 to 3 points.

Bishop Charles W. 'Burns of the Boston area of the Methodist Episcopal Church died in a hotel here today of a heart ailment at the age of 63. He came here from Boston ten days ago to speak at special church services, but was prevented from doing so by his illness.

Capt. Christopher E. Mulrain, Inf.-Res., 66 Laurel Ave., Irvington, N. J., is ordered to active duty, effective Jan. 16, at Fort Wadsworth, N. Y., for training. Capt. Mulrain will rank from Jan. 16 and will revert to an inactive status on Jan. 29.

The city Park Department will conduct an ice-skating carnival for Manhattan tomorrow night on the conservatory lake, opposite Seventy-fourth Street and Fifth Avenue, in Central Park. Medals will be awarded to those coming in first, second and third in fifteen events.

A local union that transfers its allegiance from the American Federation of Labor to the Committee for Industrial Organization, changing its name in the process, does not thereby forfeit its rights under contracts made with employers before the shift, Supreme Court Justice Peter Schmuck ruled yesterday. As a C. I. O.

Net assets of the Massachusetts Investors Trust at the close of 1937 stood at $97,678,290, equal to $18.64 a share on 5,240,684 shares, compared to $128,107,247, or $28.87 a share on 4,437,839 shares, the year before. Distribution to shareholders was $5,426,845, against $4,311,521 in 1936.

Daily average sales for chain grocery stores for December, 1937, were about the same in dollar volume as of December, 1936, according to the preliminary estimates of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce, Department of Commerce.
Mrs. William Voigt, who served with the French Red Cross in 1915 and 1916 and was decorated by the French Government, died in her home here last night. She was 75 years old.

An East Side property that has been in the ownership of one family for ninety years changed hands yesterday when the estate of Edith M. K. Wetmore sold to the 37 St. Marks Place Corporation the building containing offices and a motion picture theatre at 133 Second Avenue, northwest corner of St. Marks Place. It was acquired in 1848 by Eugene Keteltas, an attorney, and has remained in the family up to the present deal.

Mrs. William C. Mudgett was hostess at a luncheon yesterday at the Pine Needles in honor of Mrs. Mortimer G. Nichols of New York, Mrs Kenneth B. Trousdell of Yorktown Heights, N. Y.. and Mrs. Edwin Blodgett of Point Chatauqua, N. Y. Members of the Sandhill

Max Gate House, which Thomas Hardy designed and built for himself on a hill overlooking Dorchester and where he died in 1928, is to be auctioned. Hardy's first published work, contributed to Chambers Journal in March, 1865, was an unsigned half-humorous essay entitled, "How I Built Myself A House"

Joseph A. McInerney, recently elected president of the Building Trades Department of the American Federation of Labor, was honored by more than 1,500 friends and associates last night at a testimonial dinner at the Hotel Astor.

The outcome of the President's conference with the automobile manufacturers tomorrow will be awaited with unusual interest. Some of the preliminary announcements are puzzling. Thus the President is represented as believing that "high-pressure salesmanship" and "too liberal credit"

Kosciuszko Foundation scholarships for art study in Poland next Summer have been awarded to Eleanor Lust Eising of 2 West Sixty-seventh Street and Bernard Perlin of 76 Treacy Avenue, Newark, it was announced yesterday.

An investing client of J. B. Wolfe, Inc., broker, has purchased from the Mayflower Building and Loan Association the sixteen-family apartment at 271-73 Williams Avenue, Hasbrouck Heights, N. J. The house is on a plot 50 by 125 feet, sand is divided into fourteen suites of three rooms and two of two rooms. Fiedler, Inc., acted as cobroker in the deal.

A large section of the town of Haskell, N. J., specifically 540 acres, has been sold by the E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., which manufaotured munitions there during the World War, to the recently formed Haskell Improvement Company, Inc.

By direction of the Conference on Better Care for Mothers and Babies, which closed yesterday a two-day session here, Miss Katherine Lenroot, chief of the Children's Bureau, began this morning the organization of a continuing committee to carry on the work of advancing and coordinating public health activities along the lines indicated by the conference discussions.

Willie Hoppe increased his advantage over Jay Bozeman in the threecushion match at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy by scoring twice yesterday. Hoppe prevailed 50 to 35 in 38 innings and 50 to 33 in 34 chapters. Hoppe leads, 5 blocks to 1.

Equaling the P. S. A.. L. record as he defeated the defending 220-yard free-style champion, Jerry Levin, 15-year-old Abraham Lincoln High School star, yesterday furnished the feature of the preliminaries for tomorrow night's annual city P. S. A. L. senior high school swimming championships in the Columbia University pool.

Clinton Tyler Wood of Gilbert Elliott Co. was elected yesterday president of the Association of Bond Brokers of the New York Stock Exchange. Charles M. Newcombe was chosen vice president, Maurice A. Gilmartin Jr. of Charles E. Quincey Co., secretary, and George Douglass Debevoise of Struthers Dean. treasurer.
Prices on Fall blanket lines made by Cannon Mills showed reductions of from 5 to 20 per cent from last year's openings, detailed lists made available yesterday showed.

If you happen to be in the neighborhood of Orlando, Fla., within the next month or so, and are going to fish for black bass, try your luck in Lake Eola or Lake Lucerne. You may be fortunate enough to catch Elmer, the tagged bass, and get $81 for doing it.

The German Commission of the Air Ministry, appointed to investigate the disastrous explosion and fire that destroyed the dirigible Hindenburg, last May, reported today, agreeing in substance with the American commission, but emphasizing the "possibility" of sabotage.
Using reserves most of the way, Manhattan's basketball team coasted to a 53-to-29 triumph over the Savage School of Physical Education at the Manhattan gymnasium last night.

An association of fifty food store owners lost a court fight today to prevent the picketing of its stores because of the refusal of their individual owners to close on Wednesday afternoons, Saturday evenings and Sundays, in cooperation with other merchants' associations.

Approximately $5,206,400, or about 94 per cent, of the first mortgage 7 1/2 per cent bonds of the Manati Sugar Company has been exchanged or deposited under the plan of reorganization approved by the court, according to a letter sent yesterday to the company's security holders.

Massachusetts State defeated the Amherst five, 37-35, tonight. Trailing 26-16 at the half, State spurted and Captain Czelusniak's field goal in the last fifteen seconds broke a 35-35 tie. Fred Riel led the scorers with 16 points, followed by his team-mate Demben with 10.

President Roosevelt conferred with members of his Business Advisory Council on cooperation between government and business and discussed flood control problems with Governors of the six New England States.

T. O. M. Sopwith, who twice failed to win the America's Cup with his Endeavours, and Charles R. Fairey, who has desired for a number of years to attempt to lift the old trophy, are to match their sailing wits against each other in races to be held by the royal yacht clubs in England, Scotland and Ireland. Each has extensive airplane interests.

More than 400 persons, many of them prominent in the sports and newspaper fields, attended a funeral service yesterday morning at the Roman Catholic Church of the Guardian Angel, West Twenty-first Street and Tenth Avenue, for Edward J. Neil Jr.,

" The Sleeping Beauty," a "lyriccomedy opera in three acts," the libretto by John Erskine, the music by Beryl Rubinstein, received its first performance by a cast of Juilliard pupils, with Albert Stoessel conducting, last night in the Juilliard School of Music.

Fred S. Munson, 50, emerged unscathed from three motor accidents in as many hours. A hit-run driver struck his car last night as it emerged from Rigby freight yards. On his way home, after reporting the mishap to State police, Mr. Munson parked on the Rigby overpass in search of evidence to identify the hit-run driver.

Relief and welfare officials told the SeNate Committee on Relief and Un- products from any employment today that, contrary to the general impression that unemployment insurance would take a big load off the relief budgets in the States, the existence of the insurance funds would not lessen relief expenses perceptibly, but would tend to increase them.

The plan for a permanent organization of world scientists recently approved by the American Association for the Advancement of Science has received the support of Dr. Thorvald Madsen, for many years president of the League of Nations Health Committee, who is endeavoring to arrange a conference of scientists of all the democratic countries at Geneva.

The Dartmouth Club last night scored its first victory in Group II of the New York Division of the Metropolitan League Class C squash racquets tournament by defeating Williams, 5 to 0. The match closed the schedule for Williams without a victory. Dartmouth has one match left to play with Heights Casino.

Thomas E. Dewey, District Attorney of New York County, completing his argument against the appeal of Charles (Lucky) Lucania and five of his henchmen from compulsory prostitution convictions, said today that there was no evidence in the case which would warrant a reversal of the convictions by the Court of Appeals.

The Municipal Civil Service Commission was directed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan to regrade candidates for appointment as social investigators so as to eliminate favoritism allegedly shown to employes of the Emergency Relief bureau in evaluating experience.

The garden and patios of Vine dodge formed the setting today for the of the month's largest social events when Mr. and Mrs. Homer lawyer entertained with tea and cocktails. Mrs. James H. Kennedy and Mrs. Frank Vernon Skiff asisted.

Police were stationed around a new international bridge below Niagara Falls today to keep people from walking across it. The bridge was created by nature almost overnight at the foot of the Falls by ice forming from the spray.

George Andrew Martin, 48 years old, editor of The Rockefeller Center Weekly, committed suicide yesterday afternoon in the kitchen of his apartment at 360 East Fiftyfifth Street, according to the police.
With retailers pledged to cooperate in the sale of National Distillers products, reinstatement of all FeldCrawford price protection contracts

Boxes for Moriz Rosenthal's Chopin recital in Carnegie Hall on Saturday night have been taken over by St. Faith's House, Tarrytown, an institution for unwed mothers. Mrs. Peter S. Paine is chairman of the committee for the benefit.

The provision of large numbers of small dwellings in this country is dependent upon the cooperation of every section of the building industry toward lowering costs, according to leaders in that field who spoke at a meeting of the Executives Club of the International Association of Sales Executives in the Hotel Biltmore yesterday.

Leading stocks reduced losses to fractions at the close after receding 1 to 2 points; turnover, 998,851 shares. United States Government issues irregular, rail bonds lower, foreign loans higher; transactions, $8,390,900.

A blanket first mortgage for $26,000 has been given by the Kramshon Realty Corporation, Charles M. Hiesiger, attorney, to the Kings Highway Savings Bank on the seven dwellings at 2,508. 2,514. 2,518, 2,524 2,526, 2,331 and 2,333 E 23d St. Brooklyn. The mortgage bears interest at 6% and provides for the release of any of the properties upon payment of a specified amount. It runs for one year.

President Roosevelt, reaffirming his support of legislation for extension of the Civil Service system, said today that establishment. of a sound personnel program was "one of the most important constructive steps in the improvement of government administration today."

The American Smelting and Refining. Company yesterday lowered the price of copper in the domestic market to 10.50 cents a pound from 10.75 cents. The drop was owing to a further decline in purchases by domestic consumers.

Army's undefeated basketball team won a free-scoring game from Brown today, 56 to 42. The Cadets led at the half, 25 to 12, and maintained their advantage. Platt, big forward, starred for the visitors, scoring 25 points.

A resolution calling upon Mayor La Guardia to "put an end to all unlawful picketing and to all acts of pickets that tend to.a breach of the peace and injury to property owners and merchants of this city"

Miss Cecile Bowes of the Cynwyd Club, Philadelphia, became the new squash racquets champion of New Jersey when she defeated Mrs. Ary J. Lamme Jr. of Apawamis, the defending champion, in a fast, hard-fought match on the courts of the Short Hills Club today. The score was 15-6, 15-10, 10-15, 15-8.

Displaying a brilliant second half offensive after trailing, 15 to 13, at half time, the Williams College basketball team earned a 38-to27 victory over Northeastern tonight in the Lasell gymnasium before a capacity crowd.

Fear of a food shortage In Puerto Rico is likely to be the factor that will in the next few days determine the course, if not the outcome, of the longshoremen's strike. Since the strike began three weeks ago each Wednesday has been looked upon as a crucial day.

Tuesday's formally announced insolvency of the Erie Railroad-not unexpected, in view of unwillingness of the Chesapeake Ohio, which controls it, to guarantee Erie borrowings from the RFC-adds another chapter to a checkered history;

A compilation of security issues sold by electric and gas utilities in 1935, 1936 and 1937 was made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. It showed that the aggregate over the period was $3,115,413,686, of which $2,732,093,951 was in bonds and the remainder in debentures, notes and preferred and common stocks.

The navy strengthened Hawaii's aerial defense today by landing eighteen more of its long-range patrol bombing planes on Pearl Harbor after a non-stop flight in record time from San Diego, Calif., 2,570 miles away.

Representative Barton, Republican, of New York, recalling his "repeal a law a day" campaign platform, proposed today that Congress repeal the Silver Purchase Act and liquidate the export-import banks.

Joseph D. McGoldrick, City Controller, invited bankers yesterday to submit bids tomorrow for a total of $22,500,000 of New York City short-term securities. The financing, which is of routine character, will consist of $10,000,000 of bond anticipation notes, maturing in ninety days; $7,500,000 of special

A decline was registered last week in electric power production. Daily average output eased more than seasonally, running counter to the normal long-term trend, and the adjusted index receded to 94.8 from 95.7. The figure for the week ended Jan. 16, 1937, was 107.6.

Governor Lehman declared at the annual dinner of the State Agricultural Society tonight that "every protection which the State legitimately can provide" should be given to the product of the farmers to assure it reaching the consumer "at a fair and reasonable price."

Peddie School's quintet, defending champion, scored its second straight success in the Eastern Private Schools League yesterday, defeating the Horace Mann School for Boys, 35 to 25, on the losers' court. Bill Bleicher, making fifteen points, the result of six field and three foul goals, led the attack for. Peddle, which held an 18-15 advantage at the half.
Gustav Max Martin, twice attace at the German consulate here, who had been in the German foreign diplomatic service for the last thirty years, died at St. Petersburg, Fla., today.

Partial default by the Government of Haiti on its amortization of the 1922 loan arranged in the United States was announced today by the State Department after a series of discussions between the two governments.

Counsel for fourteen seamen convicted of conspiracy and endeavor to revolt aboard the governmentowned freighter Algic at Montevideo, Uruguay, last Sept. 10 told the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals today that the Wagner act gave them the right of "concerted action".

Reports yesterday from London that the world wheat production this year would reach a record figure and that "a return to the catastrophic 'wheat purchasing power' figures of the early Thirties in the overseas countries is inevitable" were characterized here as "visionary or plainly ridiculous."
A strong finish enabled Navy to defeat Gettysburg today, 36 to 31, in one of the keenest games of basketball seen here in many seasons. A goal from the floor by

The growing dependence upon income from investments for bank earnings was emphasized yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders of the Guaranty Trust Company. In a report to assembled stockholders William C. Potter,

A $5 a day fine against every member who fails to report for picket duty was voted last night by the Wine, Liquor And Distillery Workers Union Local 20244, On strike against almost all the wineries in the city.

Princeton's basketball forces snapped a string of six consecutive setbacks in the university gymnasium tonight and by the comfortable margin of 34-25 repulsed Yale in the first 1938 game of one of the country's traditional court rivalries.

Captain John Binks, former commander of the White Star liners Olympic and Majestic, arrived here yesterday on the Berengaria of the Cunard White Star Line to command the Leviathan on her final voyage to England, where she is to be broken up.

The National Coal Association proposed to the Interstate Commerce Commission today a revision of railroad rates on the basis of "prudent investment," as President Roosevelt has suggested for utility rates.
Five leaders of the New York Society for Ethical Culture issued a statement yesterday denouncing Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City for refustig to give the C. I. 0. a permit for a public meeting.

The Securities and Exchange Commission issued today an order declaring unnecessary a declaration by the Mission Oil Company regarding the issue and sale by the Commerce Trust Company of Kansas City, Mo., to the stockholders of the oil company, of $911,865 principal amount of trustee certificates of beneficial interest in a like amount of unsecured 4 per cent promissory notes of the Southwestern Development Company maturing on July 1.
The marriage of Miss Geraldine Carmer, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Phillips Carmer of this city, to Major Delman F. Weingarth of Sydney, Australia, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John

The Duchess of Leeds, who arrived on the Berengaria, has joined her brother-in-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Jones of Philadelphia, at the Waldorf-Astoria. All will leave later for Palm Beach. Mr. and Mrs. Richard Southgate of Washington are at the Savoy-Plaza.

Although lower foreign quotations carried prices on the Cotton Exchange off a few points in early trading yesterday, the market developed resistance around 8% cents a pound for July and a brisk recover left the list with net gains of 5 to 6 points.

The city's unencumbered margin of debt-incurring power as of Jan. 1 was $81,194,449, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick announced yesterday. This margin, available for new city improvements, compares with $235,886,533 in January, 1937, and $256,547,728 in January, 1936.

At a time when delegations ot Dusiress men are visiting Washington for Lhe purpose of discussing national probems with the President, and when the outcome of these conversations is still matter of some doubt, it is interesting to have the comment of a shrewd European observer regarding the present situation in this country.

Glenn Cunningham has forwarded his entry for the special invitation mile at the Grover Cleveland-Osceola Club games in the Seventh Regiment Armory on. Saturday night. Included among his opponents will be Lou Burns of Manhattan, Joe Alexander of Philadelphia, W. Dow Jenkins, Jay Funston, Joe Pay and Ernie Federoff.
Sales of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation in 1937, including spare parts and equipment, approximated $4,750,000, against $2,014,638 in 1936, Robert E. Gross, president, reported today.

Dr. W. W. Mattson said today that Federal agents had taken William Mattson Jr., 16, and Muriel Mattson, 14, away from their home here, but whether to San Francisco to view Peter Anders or elsewhere he did not disclose.

Charles Prescott Rees, vice president in charge of mining and a director of the Vanadium Corporation of America, with which he had been associated since 1925, died here today of pneumonia at his home, 299 Lee Avenue, at the age of 60.

French naval circles today put forward the possibility of a conference of United States, British and French naval experts for revision of the 1936 London Naval Treaty to allow construction of battleships of more than 35,000 tons.

The government's weekly report of crop conditions was issued yesterday as follows: In Minnesota, parts of the lake region and the eastern Ohio Valley and in most States eastward a light to moderate snow cover protected Winter grains during the week.

The American share in the loss of the Dollar liner President Hoover, which went aground on an island near Formosa early in December, will be paid in f ull today when the American Marine Insurance Syndicate delivers a check for $2,500,000 to the Maritime Commission in Washington.
