Irving Fineman's new novel, "Dr. Addams," will be published by Covici, Friede in April. Its basic theme is the relation of the scientist to the society he serves. Mr. Fineman turned to writing seven years ago, when his "This Pure Young Man" won a $7,500 prize in a first-novel contest.

Ranee of Pudukota, in Hotel Savoy-Plaza. Arthur Whitney, William N. Enstrom, Vicomte de la Rochefoucauld, A. H. Johnson, William V. Griffin, in Hampshire House, 150 Central Park South; Douglas L. Elliman Co, Inc. agents. Mrs. Camille C. gwen, through Frederick Zittell Sons, in 27 W. 55th St; Max Michelson, in 65 Central Park West; Potter. Hamilton Co. Inc. broker.

Leroy W. Baldwin, president, told stockholders of the Empire Trust Company yesterday at their annual meeting that the company's earnings, profits and recoveries for 1937 amounted to $771,916 before adjustments, and that this was equal to $2.20 a share.

A bill to permit the garageing of tenants' automobiles in the basements of apartment houses was introduced today by Senator Crawford and Assemblyman Middleton, both of New York. A memorandum accompanying it by declared that it was drawn by Harold Riegelman, counsel to the Multiple Dwelling Law Committee;

Carl A. Glaser, 39 years old, of 1,709 Second Avenue, Manhattan, who pleaded guilty on Nov. 22 to a charge of grand larceny, was sentenced yesterday by County Judge John J. Fitzgerald in Brooklyn to serve ten to twenty years in Sing Sing. In March, 1936, Glaser obtrained $7,000 worth of railroad

The training grind for James J. Braddock ended yesterday before a distinguished group at his Pompton Lakes, N. J., quarters. Joe Louis, his successor as heavyweight champion, and Joe DiMaggio, Yankee outfield star, were among those watching the workout. Until he enters the ring at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night to fight Tommy Farr, the British Empire heavyweight titleholder, Braddock will enjoy comparative leisure.

Officials tonight listed fortyseven persons dead from the swift fire that trapped students and teachers in the College of the Sacred Heart early yesterday. Twenty-two charred bodies lay in the morgue of this small Quebec town and another in the hospital mortuary, but only four were officially identified.

The State Supreme Court today suspended Hyman Brodsky, attorney and counselor at law, of Bayonne, N. J., for one year "and until further orders." The court found Brodsky guilty of unprofessional conduct.

Any terms for the restoration of peace between China and Japan must conform to China's fundamental determination to maintain her sovereign rights and territorial and administrative integrity, a statement issued last night in the name of the National Government of China declares.

Authoritative sources reported tonight that the American tanker Nantucket Chief had been captured by two Spanish Insurgent gunboats off Barcelona Tuesday. These sources declared the capture took place while the American tanker was attempting to run Insurgent Generalissimo Francisco
The Senate Committee on Public Lands and Surveys will resume tomorrow its investigation of the fitness of Ebert K. Burlew to be Assistant Secretary of the Interior.

The centennial of the first public demonstration of the telegraph invented by Samuel F. B. Morse will be observed Sunday night in the auditorium of the Washington Square Branch of New York University.

A joint Congressional committee agreed today to apply acreage and marketing controls on corn, under the ever-normal granary program, only in the "commercial corn area." Chairman Smith of the Senate Agriculture Committee said that this would limit controls to "the corn belt."

New and modernized radiotelephone and beacon equipment for the principal air routes of the country was indicated yesterday when Admiral Luke McNamee, president of Federal Telegraph, Newark, N. J., announced that orders for forty-two aviation combination radiotelephone and radio range beacon transmitters had been received from the Bureau of Air Commerce.

The AngloIrish negotiations ended their first phase today in an atmosphere of friendliness almost incredible to those who remembered the bad feeling between London and Dublin only a few years ago. Prime Minister Eamon de Valera will return home tomorrow conscious of the tasks ahead but,

Two compositions of Randall Thompson, strikingly contrasted in mood and style, were the features of the concert given last night at the Federal Music Theatre by the Madrigal Singers under the direction of Lehman Engel. They were "Americana," the texts taken from the regular section of the American Mercury of the same name, and "The Peaceable Kingdom,"

When Joe Louis defends his world heavyweight title against Max Schmeling of Germany, the former champion, under the terms of their contract which provide for an undetermined June date, the battleground will be Detroit, unless present plans collapse.

The earth, which recently missed a collision with a planetoid by a narrow margin, will have another celestial visitor today when Eros, a minor planet, will approach within 19,900,000 miles of the globe.

BARUCH, ANNIE GRIFFEN (Jan. 16). Estate, more than $20,000. To Bernard M. Baruch, husband, executor, 1,055 5th Ave., personal effects not bequeathed, and life estate in one-half residue; Renee Baruch Samstag, 399 Park Ave.; Isabel Wilcox Baruch, 1,055 5th Ave.; Bernard Mannes Baruch Jr., Huntington, L. I., children, specific personalty, one-sixth residue each, equal remainders in $75,000 and equal remainders in their father's trust: Cecil Griffen, brother, Flushing,

Hank Johnson's field goal in the last fifteen seconds broke a tie and gave the Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute varsity five a 40-to-38 decision over New York Cathedral College at the 101st Signal Battalion Armory in Brooklyn last night.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, in a transatlantic telephone conversation yesterday with Sir Walter Citrine, general secretary of the British Trades Union Congress and president of the International Federation of
The Junior League Glee Club, in combination with the Yale Glee Club, will give a private concert tonight at the Chapin School. Students of the school and members of the faculty will comprise the

Dr. E. Benjamin Ramsdell, retired New York physician and former medical officer for twenty years of the New York City Fire Department, died of a heart attack early this evening in his home here. His age was 81.

The annual report of the National League for American Citizenship was presented last night at a dinner given by Mrs. Vincent Astor to James L. Houghteling, Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization. at Mrs. Astor's home.

Movements of livestock on Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 29,000, including 11,000 directs. Market uneven, strong to 10c higher than Tuesday's average. Top $8.70; bulk good and choice, 150-210 pounds, 58.40-.65: 220250 pounds, $7.75-$8.25; 260-325 pounds, $7.10-.65: bulk good sows. $6.40-.65; few lightweights, $6.75 or better. Shippers, 3,000; estimated holdover, 2,000.

Mrs. J. A. Nix's Hermone, a disappointment since winning two straight early in December, came from far back today to win the mile and a sixteenth feature at the Fair Grounds in a photo finish with Mrs. L. Hartrick's Sleep Along.

Senate investigators asserted today that a stock transaction between the Pennsylvania Railroad Company and the Pennroad Corporation in 1931 violated Federal law. They submitted evidence to the Senate's committee investigating railroad finances, which, they contended,

Individual investors' holdings of United States Steel Corporation common stock aggregated 6,563,397 shares, or 75.40 per cent of the total number of shares outstanding on Dec. 31, the company reported yesterday. This is compared to 74.19 per cent on Sept. 30. On Dec. 31,

Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan said yesterday that he would not undertake any reprisals against the City Councilmen who criticized his action last Monday in signing an order which acted as a stay on the Council's proceedings.
Professor William Kenneth Boyd, who had occupied the Chair of History at Trinity College and its successor, Duke University, since 1906, died here today at the age of 68.

Declaring that business cannot flourish when it is constantly facing attack. Percy H. Johnston, chairman of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, in his message to shareholders at their 115th annual meeting yesterday afternoon, defended the record of big business, criticized certain policies of the government and asserted that the future was "fraught with uncertainty."

If John D. Rockefeller Jr. had announced that he proposed to give a rear's employment to all the heads of familiess in Butte, Mont., the announcenent would have been bigger news han his decision to complete three ?ew units at Rockefeller Center.

A huge world wheat surplus for 1938 is forecast by the secretariat of the Wheat Advisory Committee. The report, dealing with the international wheat situation, some 30,000,000 above the record was made public today by the secretariat, which originated from the world wheat agreement of 1933.

In the light of recent developments in Rumania, James G. McDonald yesterday warned members of the New York section of the National Council of Jewish Women that forces were at work that might speedily precipitate a situation for

Albert-Leveque, pianist, and Rene Le Roy, flutist, appeared in joint recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon in a program devoted to Bach. The artists were heard together in Sonatas No. 5 and 6. Mr. Le Roy's solo contribution was a sonata, and Mr. Albert-Leveque's consisted of excerpts from "The Well-Tempered Clavichord"

Ludlow St. 182; Harry Nieberg to J. Y. Realty Corp, 177 Ludlow St ($4.50). Washington St. 765: Adelheid Halterman to Minnie Bottjer, 717 Flatbush Ave, Brooklyn, and John Bottjer, 402 Ocean Ave, Brooklyn, quitclaim. Same property; Martin Bottjer to same, quitclaim. Same property; Meta Seemever to same.

Values of a long list of railroad issues suffered further substantial declines in bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The market for rail loans appeared unable to stem the tide of liquidation which has persisted since the fall of the Erie into bankruptcy.
The latent tension in the political situation has increased since last night to an extent difficult to understand abroad in view of an apparently trivial cause.

Prospects for a final matcn- oetween Bobby Riggs of Chicago, America's second ranking tennis player, and Bryan M. (Bitsy) Grant of Atlanta appeared likely today as they led the field of seeded players into the quarter-finals of the fourteenth annual Dixie tennis tournament.
Samuel D. Riddle's War Admiral is training too fast and is coming to hand too rapidly. The brown son of Man o' War was out for exercise today at Hialeah Park and really did run.

An appeal from an interlocutory injunction holding illegal a plan to consolidate the Alleghany Corporation and the Chesapeake Corporation of the Van Sweringen railroad empire was dismissed today by the Court of Appeals.

Baseball's "new dealer" took change of the fortunes of the Brooklyn club yesterday. Leland Stanford (Larry) MacPhail, the man who pulled the Cincinnati Reds out of the "red," was elected executive vice president of the Dodgers, "with full and complete authority over the operation of the club, including all its minor league activities."

Ruland Thompson, 40 years old, a salesman who lived at the Tudor Hotel, 304 East Forty-second Street, was found dead at 5:30 P. M. yesterday at the bottom of a dumbwaiter shaft in a five-story apartment house at 200 West Eightyfirst Street, at Amsterdam Avenue.

The late Colonel Edward H. R. Green, son of Hetty Green, maintrained a private fleet of seventeen pleasure boats, ranging from his $800,000 yacht United States to speedboats, houseboats and even a private gondola kept on his Florida island, it was testified yesterday at a hearing on his $40,000,000 estate.

Patrolman William F. Allmendinger, who had been cited three times for meritorious conduct since his appointment to the Police Department in 1913, committed suicide about 11:10 A. M. yesterday by shooting himself through the right temple in the men's wash room at the Manhattan end of the Brooklyn Bridge.
Mr. and Mrs. Roswell Miller of 9 East Ninetieth Street have announced the engagement of their eldest daughter, Miss Louise Carnegie Miller, to J. F. Gordon Thomson of Edinburgh, Scotland.

Shortly before Governor Lawrence W. Cramer's departure on Monday for Washington to discuss budgetary requirements for the coming fiscal year he transmitted a letter to the chairman of the Municipal Council deploring the action of members of the Legislature who sought payment for their attendance at meetings by introducing a bill appropriating funds to defray the expenses.
A. C. Compton's High Landmark, a 4-year-old chestnut, captured the featured $1,200 La Manda purse at Santa Anita Park today, moving into an early lead and never relinquishing it.

An armed clash between British and Japanese forces at Tientsin was narrowly averted yesterday afternoon, British officials said today, when Japanese Army officers at Tientsin demanded that Chinese within the British Concession be handed over to them.

Three of the nation's undefeated football teams in 1937, Pittsburgh, Albright and Villanova, will play Temple here next Fall. The Temple schedule, announced today, lists Pitt, Albright, Texas Christian and Georgetown as new opponents.

John Geaney, a retired church decorator, died here today at the home of a daughter, Mrs. Theresa McCullough of 16 Yale Place. Born in Cork City, Ireland, seventy-six years ago, he had lived in the United States for forty years.

Vice President Garner started today to enforce the Senate rules rigidly in an effort to make filibustering more difficult, but the ancient custom of Senatorial courtesy operated before the session ended to undo the presiding officer's work in part.

A United States Embassy request to interview Mrs. Marie Rubens, identified as an American citizen held on suspicion of espionage, was understood tonight to have been passed on to the secret political police.

The report of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Dec. 31, issued yesterday, shows a net income, after all expenses and charges, of $24,531,606.

The policies of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System should be directed toward the same objectives as those of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the strengthening of the banking system, Lewis E. Pierson, chairman of the Irving Trust Company,

Members of the Palestine Lighthouse in Aid of the Blind will celebrate the success of their recent theatre benefit with a tea tomorrow at the apartment of Mrs. Arthur M. Lamport in the Lombardy. The play taken over for the benefit on Jan. 11 was "The Three Waltzes."
A motorist awaited sentence today on a drunken driving charge after a City Court jury established a precedent by convicting him on the "scientific evidence" of a young doctor.

The entire government slate of Commissars was unanimously elected, as had been expected, at today's closing session of the Supreme Soviet. The names were presented by Premier Vyacheslaff Molotoff, who had been commissioned to submit a new Ministry for approval by the Supreme Soviet. The Deputies cheered and applauded each nominee.

A hard task confronts the New York Americans tonight at Madison Square Garden, where Red Dutton's men will face the Toronto Maple Leafs in a National Hockey League skirmish. The Star Spangled crew will seek to surpass the outstanding scoring line in league circles and a sextet that has not been downed on the Garden ice this season.

Timothy A. Kenney, a director and vice president of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation and an official in a number of companies in this large utility system, died yesterday after a long illness at the age of 56.

Aacording to a transfer tax appraisal filed in Surrogate's Court here today, Mrs. Anne Henry Phipps, who died at Westbury on Oct. 24, 1934, left a gross estate of $16,481,781. Deductions total $1,740,314, leaving a net estate of $14,741,467.

Julius Streicher's newspaper, Der Stuermer, was seized throughout Germany today for attacking a government bureau. A complaint was made by the Exchange Control Administration, which was bitterly criticized for granting foreign exchange to Jews so they could attend Jewish educational institutions in Switzerland.

Dr. Augustin Castellanos of Havana today described before the opening sessions of the seventh annual congress of the Pan American Medical Association a method for injecting a radioopaque substance into the veins of a child that enables a physician to obtain "striking radiographs"

Morris S. Tremaine, controller of the State of New York, told the Ways and Means Committee today that in his opinion the nation's antiquated tax system destroyed opportunity for labor, reduced revenues and was responsible in a large measure for "practically all of our sorrows and shortcomings."

Revived activity at United Artists in spite of Samuel Goldwyn's sitdown strike was foreseen today in the return of Edwara Small to the UA production ranks and the announcement by Walter Wanger that he will launch three pictures by the middle of March. Small,
Thomas George Tickler, jam manufacturer, whose product was so well known to millions of Tommies during the World War that they composed ditties in praise of it, died today at the age of 86.

The New York Stock Exchange is reminding its members of the service maintained by its secretariat to facilitate mergers and reorganizations of firms because many members are ignorant of its' existence, despite the fact that it was established more than two years ago.

The Harvard jayvee basketball team turned back Andover Academy, 2928, in a seesaw battle today. Andover led, 18-13, at the half and Harvard went ahead, 24--21, at the end of the third period. With the score tied at 27-all, White put Harvard in the lead, 29--27.
Lafayette recorded a 38-27 victory over the Haverford College basketball team tonight. Led by Captain Vernon, the Maroon got off to an early lead and was never in danger.

Larry Gains, Toronto Negro heavyweight, today claimed the British Empire heavyweight boxing championship held by Tommy Farr. Gains, a former titleholder, asserts his recent successes entitle him to important matches and he has written the British Board of Boxing Control stating he should be recognized as empire champion.

Harry Reese Whitcraft, a former newspaper editor and advertising executive, died of pneumonia today at Graduate Hospital. He was 66. Born in Pennsylvania, he had worked as a reporter on The Philadelphia Times, The Public Ledger and The Press and as night editor of The North American.

With the dedication today of a new factory for Diesel engine production and the largest laboratory in the world devoted solely to the study of Diesel problems, General Motors Corporation disclosed plans for undertaking the mass production and sale of small, light weight, twocycle oil-burning engines for all purposes.

Alfred Walter Hanson, producer of the popular British Broadcasting Corporation program, "In Town Tonight," was found hanging last night from the stairs in his home. He would have been 52 years old today.

Oh, wouldn't I like to catch him, Wherever he may be. Oh, wouldn't I like to punch his pumpkin head, That fellow who looks like me! This ditty is known as the "double's lament" and for George Bernard Shaw it is feelingly meant; it comes from Cap' Russell and augurs a tussle, for Russell's his double and he's looking for trouble.

The bewildering state of the anti-trust laws and the confused outlook of some business groups as a consequence of the year-old RobinsonPatman act, latest of the anti-trust laws, is discussed by business,

The statement of the National Surety Corporation, wholly owned by the Commercial Investment Trust Corporation, as of Dec. 31 shows total admitted assets of $20,477,232, including $2,323,856 cash. The capital stock of the corporation is $2,500,000 and its surplus $6,861,770.

A special meeting of the stockholders of the White Rock Mineral Springs Company has been called for Feb. 1 to act on a proposal to reduce the authorized preferred stock to 12,308 shares from 20,000 and the capital represented by the common stock to $1,000,000. Richard C. Harrison, president, said the change would increase the surplus of the corporation by $3,950,000.

A New York representative, H. J. Kowal of Utica, led a strong field in the qualifying round of the annual Miami Biltmore invitation golf tournament today. Despite a lapse in his play on the second nine, Kowal, with 32, 39-71, equaled the amateur course record established in 1933 by Johnny Goodman, present national amateur champion.

At a reception given last night at the Waldorf-Astoria by Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Toby of Far Rockaway, Queens, to celebrate the twenty-fifth anniversary of their marriage, announcement was made of the engagement of Miss Ruth Hecht to Allan Hannan Toby, son of the hosts.
Mr. and Mrs. Cecil H. Trowbridge of Milford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Louise Trowbridge, to O. Thomas Rylander, son of Mr. and Mrs. O. W. Rylander of Milford.
Thomas J. Hogan, former Long Beach Supervisor and City Treasurer, died in the New York Hospital last night after a year of failing health and a fortnight's serious illness of stomach ulcers.

Prospects of much needed moisture being received in the dry sections of the Winter wheat belt led today to fairly general selling of futures by operators who recently were good buyers on reports of dust storms in Western Nebraska, Kansas and Oklahoma.

Biting cold weather continued yesterday for the second consecutive day to chill New Yorkers as the mercury rose and fell between a low reading of 7 degrees above zero and a high of 29. Cloudy weather with little change in temperature and probably with light snowfall was forecast for today.

Vito Maroantonio, president of the International Labor Defense, made public here yesterday a letter he has written to Senator Copeland attacking his action as chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee in permitting publication of the records of executive sessions of the Senate Commerce and Labor Committees dealing with maritime labor.

The problem of where to get something to eat grew more difficult today as proprietors of Stockholm cafes, beer halls and smaller hotels joined the larger establishments in a sympathetic lockout. Two or three hotels that are not members of the employers' federation remained open and did a land-office business.

Yale's swimmers defeated Wesleyan, 57-18, tonight. The Blue placed first in seven events. Don Davis of Wesleyan won the 220-yard free style in 2:211-10 to set a new Wesleyan record. The former record was 2:218-10. Danforth scored 87.17 points in the dive.
In financial, national defense and general social policies the new Cabinet of Premier

Declaring that the only possible standards for consumer goods are those based on minimum requirements, Howard W. Dickinson, advertising and marketing consultant, yesterday said that the "products we know best through advertising are vastly above the minimums which would be established."
Leases of offices and showroom space in buildings in the midtown section of Manhattan featured business rentals yesterday. The activity also showed a good demand for stores.

ACHER-Agnes, on Jan. 18, 1938, beloved sister of Mrs. Helen Ladley. Mrs. Irene Smith, Anna and James McCave. Funeral from her residence, 601 West 174th St., Friday, 8:30 A. M. Requiem Mass 9 A. M., Incarnation Church. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery.

One of the largest artificial outdoor ice-skating rinks in the United States will be available to New Yorkers next Winter if present plans to transform the Polo Grounds into a mammoth playground for Winter sports enthusiasts materialize.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company will not oppose adoption of bills now pending in the New York State Legislature which would enable savings banks to issue life insurance. Leroy A. Lincoln, president, made known his company's stand in a letter to Henry Bruere,
Octavian Goga, Rumania's new Premier, declared in an audience granted to this writer today that he was going to conclude treaties of friendship with both Germany and Italy.

Federal Judge John P. Nields ruled today against Irence du Pont who sought a refund of $161,017 paid as a deficiency tax and interest on his 1932 income. Mr. du Pont based his suit on a reported loss by the sale of 16,000 shares of Rubber Securities Company stock to two trusts of his children.

The opinion was expressed two days ago in this space that any new legislation against holding companies would probably not extend much beyond the banking area of the field, despite the President's previous indication that he wants to abolish them all.
Edward W. Bates of The New York Herald Tribune was elected president of the Legislative Correspondents Association today for the year 1938. Mr. Bates succeeds Paul H. King of the United Press.

In a unanimous decision the Appellate Division in Brooklyn dismissed yesterday the petition of the Joint Committee on the County Clerk asking the court to reconaider its appointment of Paul Livoti as Queens County Clerk and to dedare it void on the ground that it was "a clear and flagrant

The stock market here was generally quiet today, with prices in most sections somewhat weaker. Gilt-edge issues lost ground. Among the foreign bonds, Far Eastern loans were easier, but Brazilian securities were in demand.

Dr. Bernard Joseph, legal adviser to the Jewish Agency for Palestine, arrived yesterday from Jerusalem on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria to attend the National Conference for Palestine in Washington on Saturday.

OHIO-Cloudy with slowly rising temperature Thursday followed by rain in south and rain or snow in north Thursday night and Friday. KENTUCKY-Cloudy with slowly rising temperatures, followed by rain Thursday afternoon and night and on Friday. TENNESSEE--Rain Thursday and probably Friday and colder Friday afternoon and night.

The Southern Wood Panel Flooring Company has bought from the F. F. Property Corporation the three-story factory and one-story warehouse at 442-48 East 148th Street. The flooring business is operated by Osinoff Brothers, who intend to alter the buildings and occupy them. J. Clarence Davies,

Great Britain was cheered today by reports of slightly increased activity in two departments of national life that everybody has been worrying about--building and babies. It has been feared that a decline in the construction industry was a sure sign of a bad time ahead,

It will be Mr. Brady's Playhouse that receives "June Night on Feb. 9, with Ray Parker in a leading role and with Dorothy Hinckley also in the company. This means a conflict in premieres, what with "On Borrowed Time" now set back to that date because of a cast change, Dudley Digges having decided definitely to take the leading role.

Robert McWade, character actor of stage and screen, finished late today his final scenes in the Civil War drama, "Benefits Forgot," which is being filmed on a Culver City studio lot, and then slumped to his death.

The Hotchkiss hockey team defeated Kent, 3-0, in a hard-fought game today for its second victory of the season. Captain Johnson's spectacular saves in the last period averted several Kent scoring threats. Halsey scored two goals for Hotchkiss while Gardiner was credited with three assists.

For the second time within six months all Cgypt is en fete. Only half a year ago the Valley f the Nile outdid itself in celebraion of the investiture of the boy king, Farouk. But the manifestaions of ostentatious rejoicing on he eve of Farouk's wedding make ne wandering through the streets f Cairo tonight wonder whether his is the Egypt of today or the and of the Pharaohs of 3,000 years go.

Mrs. Anna K. Maplesden, widow of the Rev. Raymond Maplesden, died in her home, 438 West 116th Street, Monday night. She was 85 years old. Mrs. Maplesden came to Nebraska in 1866 with her parents from Copenhagen.

Strong opposition to the Schwartzwald bill, introduced in Albany, which would levy an annual license tax of $10 to $550 a store on chain stores was voiced yesterday by the Merchants Association in letters sent to legislative leaders.

The Rev. Dr. Charles S. Macfarland, secretary emeritus of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, suggested last night the formation of a "board of strategy," composed of leading Christian bodies with Jews in a consultative capacity, to stem in this country religious and racial hostility, mainly anti-Semitism.

Equipped with an automobile and several motor scooters aboard, for the convenience of guests ashore, the Moana, yacht of William B. Leeds, arrived here from Cat Cay this afternoon. Guests of Mr. and Mrs.
Syracuse for the third straight year defeated Pennsylvania at the Palestra tonight, scoring, 42 to 39, in a game before 3,500 fans.

John Ferguson, Republican Superin. tendent of the Hudson County Bureau of Elections, who recently declared that "only the presence of the State militia could insure an honest election in Hudson County,"

Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden has inherited an annuity of [Pound]5,000 and his wife a lump sum of [Pound]150,000 under the will of Mrs. Eden's father, Sir Gervase Beckett, who died Aug. 24. The salary of the Foreign Secretary is [Pound]5,000, without entertainment allowances except when traveling abroad or playing host to the heads of foreign States in London.

Fordham University's eleven will meet Rice in New York on Nov. 4, 1939, it was announced yesterday by Graduate Manager Jack Coffey. This will be the first meeting between the two schools on the gridiron. The field for the engagement has not been selected.

G. Thomas Cartier, vice president in charge of operations of the Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania and the Diamond State (Delaware) Telephone Company, died in Bryn Mawr Hospital today of injuries received when he was struck by an automobile at Devon last Friday night. He was 47 years old. His home was in Wayne.

Robert E. Wood, president of Sears, Roebuck Co., has been elected a director of Selected American Shares, Inc., succeeding James O. McKinsey, deceased. The annual meeting of the Interstate Power Company, Delaware, scheduled for last Tuesday, was postponed thirty days.

Mr. and Mrs. Harold Stuart Chase of Las Terrasas, Hope Rank Park, this city, and Detroit, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Dempsey Chase, to George Mercer Nairne of Meikleour House, Perthshire, Scotland.

A prompt and thorough investigation and study of the difficulties that have arisen in the enforcement of the Feld-Crawford Fair Trade Act was recommended yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag in a decision awarding to the Calvert Distillers Corporation and Seagram Distillers Corporation permanent injunctions restraining the Nussbaum Liquor Store, Inc.,

Maritime unions affiliated with the C. I. O. scored three victories and the American Federation of Labor one, in elections on American ships supervised by the National Labor Relations Board, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the board.

A plea for cooperation between business and government was voiced here tonight at the annual midwinter dinner of the Illinois Bankers Association by Philip A. Benson, first vice president of the American Bankers.

The United States steamer Effingham arrived in St. George's Harbor this morning severely damaged by gales, in which two seamen were lost overboard Friday. The freighter was on her way from Galveston, Texas, to Havre, France.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Jan. 18 unless specified: Boston Yard to sea, Jan. 19: Cassin, Mugford. Falcon, at New London. Kewaydin, Dahlgren to Washington Yard, Jan. 19.

Colonel Cornelis de Witt Willcox of the United States Army died in a hospital today of pneumonia. He was 76 years old. He taught at the United States Military Academy from 1910 until his retirement in 1925.

A demand that Great Britain cooperate with the United States and seek a "friendly understanding" with Germany to meet the present world confusion was made today by the Archbishop of Canterbury, presiding at the opening session of the Upper House Convocation at Canterbury, the governing clerical body of the most important section of the Anglican Church.

Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer granted yesterday a temporary injunction restraining the Celotex Corporation from buying 9,496 shares of preference and 109,360 shares of common stock of the Certain-teed Products Corporation from the Phoenix Securities Corporation.

Fred E. Beal, labor organizer, was arrested here early this morning after being sought for eight years in connection with the killing of Police Chief O. F. Aderholt of Gastonia, N. C., in 1929. A hearing on extradition will take place next Wednesday and Beal will fight it.

Yale, through the board of control of the athletic association of the university, today awarded insignia to 136 members of five teams. Thirty-three major Y awards were made, 31 going to the varsity football squad. The listed included Halfback Al Wilson, who was missing from the climax games because of injuries, but who starred in contests equally exacting.

Asked by President Lebrun to resume office less than a week after the fall of his Cabinet on Jan. 14 through the resignation of the nine. Socialist members, Premier Camille Chautemps remarked: "The circle has been completed." The political situation,

Dr. George W. Field, an authority on soil conservation work, died tonight at a sanitarium where he had been a patient for eight years. He was 74 years old. Dr. Field was widely known for establishment of the Sharon (Mass.) perimental biological farm.

Russell Duane, a widely known attorney and civic leader, died of pneumonia early today at his home in Villanova. Illness had prevented his engaging in the active practice of law for about a year. He was 71.

Consuls General from eighteen Latin American republics were guests of honor yesterday at the twenty-sixth annual meeting of the Pan American Society at India House, 1 Hanover Square. John L. Merrill, president of the organization, who presided, was re-elected for the eleventh time.
New York's metropolitan area in the next twenty years will grow a good deal more slowly than was anticipated half a dozen years

Failure of the Roosevelt Administration to indicate clearly in which direction "it is going" was criticized by Raymond Moley, former "brain years truster," in an address at the dinner of the New York Furniture Exchange at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night.

Evidence that Speyer Co., private bankers, made a profit in excess of $160,000 in the stock of the Chicago, -Rock Island Pacific Railway at about the time the firm was acquiring control of the road for the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway (the Frisco Line) was presented yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente.

The re-establishment of a cabinet in France and the lifting of restrictions upon dealings in foreign exchange there yesterday helped the franc in the foreign exchange market but, in view of the still existing uncertainties the currency did not rally very far.

The flow of steel business is so irregular that no definite upward trend is yet indicated, according to Iron Age, which says that operations of mills and furnaces at many plants are intermittent and that facilities are shut down one week to await an accumulation of orders and then started up for another week to fill them.
A rather low average volume of production can be expected in the first half of this year, with an improvement in the second half largely dependent upon a gain in the construction industry,
Thirty lots in Westminster Ridge, White Plains, N. Y., have been sold by the Westminster Ridge Corporation to a client of David F. Birch, broker. The Buyer plans to develop the lots.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Jan. 17: Butler, Rear Admiral H. V., Commandant 6th Naval District, Charleston, S. C., on March 7, ordered home, relieved all active duty. Eggert, Capt. E. F., Washington, D. C., on June 30, to home, relieved all active duty.

In the belief that the measure would help save thousands of lives each year, the Maternity Center Association will campaign in support of the Twoney-Newell bill, requiring blood tests of women about to became mothers, it was announced yesterday at the organization's twentieth anniversity meeting.

Education to arouse the public conscience to combat discrimination against workers over 40 years old, rather than any compulsory legislation, was the only remedy offered to the Joint Legislative Committee on Discrimination in Employment of the Middle-Aged at a public hearing yesterday in the State Building, 80 Centre Street.

Completion of inventory-taking at the end of this month by retailers will see large numbers of buyers in the market here clamoring for merchandise, with difficulty experienced in obtaining goods, Arthur J. McGrail, president of the Specialty Stores Association,

George A. Glendon Jr. yesterday received a judgment for $7,812, plus interest from 1932, against the city for his services in stenographically reporting the removal proceedings against Mayor James J. Walker before Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt.
Charlie is bound to come soon Conacher, injured captain of the Toronto Maple Leafs and former leading scorer of the National Hockey League, announced his retirement from the sport today.

A 16-year-old boy was shot dead by a detective during the robbery of a liquor store last night at 4,064 Broadway, between 171st and 172d Streets. A confederate, who escaped, was believed to have been wounded, and a general alarm was sent out for his arrest.

The text of the statement presented to President Roosevelt today by the Business Advisory Council and read to him by W. Averill Harriman, its chairman, was as follows: We are keenly appreciative, Mr. President, of this opportunity to discuss with you the matters which affect the business situation and therefore the economic welfare of the people of the country.

Ludlow St. 182, 25x87.6; J. Y. Realty Corp. (Joseph Yavarkowsky, president), to Harry Nieberg, 141 Ludlow St; p m mtg, 3 yrs 5%; $3,500. Morton St, 9-11, 49.7x102x irreg; 11 Morton St. Corp. (Max Minskoff, treasurer), to David Schor and another, 239 W 145th St; pr mtg $88,893, 3 years, 6% $8,500.

In a move toward a self-contained national economy for Mexico, President Lazaro Cardenas issued today an-executive decree raising customs duties between 100 and 200 per cent on most major articles of import from the United States, with some rates being increased 400 per cent.

Discovery of footprints in sandstone, so human in appearance that they might have been made by one of the earliest ancestors of man, was announced here today by Dr. Wilbur G. Burroughs, head of the Department of Geology at Berea College.

Under authority of a resolution adopted by the Assembly Monday night, Speaker Herbert J. Paseoe will appoint tomorrow five members to investigate allegations of ballot frauds in Hudson County at the gubernatorial election last November.

Stanley M. Isaacs, president of the Borough of Manhattan, filed yesterday the plans for the new Appellate Division court house, a seven-story structure to occupy a plot 167 by 135 feet on Park Avenue, between Thirty-ninth and Fortieth Streets. Joseph H. Friedlander, architect who prepared the plans, estimated the cost at $3,000,000. The present court house is at Madison Avenue and Twenty-sixth Street.

Fortynine members of his Business Advisory Council were told by President Roosevelt today that simple machinery for formulating governmental policy to reconcile the interests of all elements of the national economy was the object of a search by himself and the Administration.

The Baltimore Orioles of the Eastern Amateur Ice Hockey League defeated the New York Rovers, 5-3, tonight in an overtime match featured by a first-period fist fight. Pike, New York center, and Marshall, Oriole defense man, started the fight, in which other players joined. They were sent to the penalty box for five minutes.

With every member in the starting line-up scoring at least six points, the St. John's University quintet chalked up its ninth victory of the season when it downed Seton Hall College, 58 to 29, for the tenth successive time since 1924 before a large crowd in the De Gray Gymnasium last night.

A, touch of Summer came to the Board of Education headquarters yesterday afternoon. School officials, defiant of the freezing weather, voted to establish a course in the florist trade for vocational pupils.

The Federal Trade Commission today issued a complaint against the H. C. Brill Company, Inc., Newark, N. J., manufacturer of bakers' supplies and other food products, charging violation of the Robinson-Patman Act through allowance

Governor Moore says in his third inaugural address: "My ambition now and my determination alike are to serve, not individual interests nor groups nor classes nor parties, but all the people of the whole State as their Governor."
Talk developed in the Senate late today of an effort to block the seating of John Milton as Senator from New Jersey, but several members predicted that he would be seated without difficulty.

Manida St (10-2777B), e s, 150 ft s of Viele Ave, 200x100 ft; Irving Wenig to National Safety Bank Trust Co; installments, 6 per cent; $18,000. East Bay Ave (10-2772G), n w s at n e s of Halleck St. 75x100; Gustav Wolff to Joseph L. Pascal, 229 W 105th St; 4 per cent; $10,000.

Leaders in philanthropic and publio relations groups joined yesterday in the campaign of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, which is enlisting 1,000,000 founder members in this area -for a nationwide fight against the spread of this disease.

The three-story apartment building at 46-09 Forty-eighth Avenue, Woodside, Queens, on a plot 20 by 100 feet, has been sold by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to a client of James C. McCormick, broker. There are five apartments and one store in the house.

Hershey increased its lead in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League by defeating the Bronx Tigers, 8 to 2, tonight. Hershey got away to a slow start, but tallied three goals in one minute and 28 seconds as the first period ended. The Graboski brothers scored five of the Bears' points.
Demands for a clarification of the objectives of the administration's foreign policy may be expected if debate in the House today on the regular naval appropriation can be taken as a criterion.

A new $300,000 dispensary for Greenpoint Hospital, Kingsland Avenue and Jackson Street, Brooklyn, will be opened for use this afternoon at 3:30 o'clock with ceremonies at which Mayor La Guardia, Dr. S. S. Goldwater. Commissioner of Hospitals; Dr. Charles H. Goodrich, president of the New York State Medical Society, and Dr. Thurston Welton, president of the Greenpoint Hospital Medical Board, are expected.

DAY 9th St, 719-21 E; 6-story brick -tenement and stores, 50x92.3; Dry Dock Savings Institution against Isidore Weisburd: due, $39,013; taxes, etc, $289; to plaintiff for $1,000.

Miss Kate H. Lloyd, sister of the late Governor Henry Lloyd and a granddaughter of Governor Edward Lloyd, died last night at her home in Cambridge, Md. Miss Lloyd was the daughter of the late Daniel and Kitty Lloyd. She was 88 years old.

Film programs to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools. The list follows:

Lord Mountbatten, cousin of King George VI, and Lady Mountbatten, the Earl and Countess of Rosse, Viscount and Viscountess of Weymouth, Colonel Sir Henry George Lyons and Lady Lyons, Sir Henry Noel Bunbury, the Hon. Patrick and Mrs. Bellew,

Lawrenceville's undefeated polo team rang up its seventh consecutive victory today when the Princeton varsity found the going too rough, bowing by 20 to 8. The school trio proved superior in stick work and team play. Bob Osmun and Mather, alternating at No. 1, were high scorers for the Laurentians, while Captain Eisner led the Tigers.

Orchids and camellias were features of the flowers on exhibit at the monthly meeting of the Horticultural Society of New York yesterday at the headquarters, 598 Madison Avenue. Nearly 200 persons visited the display.

The latest 1,000,000,000-mark public government loan, for which subscription closed yesterday, has been so well oversubscribed that the government has decided to raise it to 1,200,000,000 marks in order to meet "the urgent demands for additional Treasury bills."

The vagaries of popular tastes in residential architecture over a long period may be understood more readily by a study of 100 house-plan books of Europe and America, dating from 1570 to 1890, which are now on display in Avery Library of Columbia University.

Senator Schwartz of Wyoming said today that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, cooperating with wool producers and dealers, was completing plans to set up a $10,000,000 corporation to peg at 81 cents a pound the Boston delivered price of scoured wool.
Bob Feller, 19-year-old pitching ace, said tonight he had returned unsigned his 1938 contract to the Cleveland Indians for "minor adjustments."

Miss Louise MacCracken, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Henry MacCracken, was married yesterday afternoon to Robert Groves Olmsted of this city in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin,

Mrs. Christian R. Holmes gave a dinner last night at the American Museum of Natural History as one in a series being held in the interest of the institution's ten-year development program. Later the guests were conducted through various halls now under construction and through the department of preparation where the mounting of animals is done.

Opposition to proposals permitting the FHA to insure 90 per cent mortgages and to revive Title I of the National Housing Act allowing the Administration to insure loans for modernization and repairs was expressed yesterday by Charles E. Lane Jr., real estate man and chairman of the housing committee of the Twenty-third Street Association.

Counsel for the defense in the trial of four former officers of the defunct State Title and Mortgage Company charged yesterday that the indictment against his clients was "one not based on mail fraud, but on persecution,"

Headed by the peerless Harry Wolf, the country's outstanding squash tennis star, the Montclair Athletic Club continued to dominate the race for honors among the Class A teams of the Metropolitan Association yesterday as it kept its record for the season unblemished.

The thinning ranks of unbeaten college basketball teams in the East lost another member last night when the George Washington University five, which had been victorious in its first six starts, lost to Long Island University, 35-25, at the. Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium before a capacity aroung of 1,000.

Surpassing merchants' expectations, sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decrease of only 0.6 per cent for the two weeks ended Jan. 15, compared with the corresponding weeks of last year, according to figures issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
The War Department joined the State Department today in opposing legislation to exempt American vessels engaged in intercoastal trade from paying Panama Canal tolls.

Charles A. Miller, president of the Savings Banks Trust Company for three years, was elected yesterday to the new post of chairman of the board. His advancement followed the annual meeting of the trust company at its offices, 14 Wall Street. August Ihlefeld Jr.,
BY JOSEPH P. DAY Decatur Ave, 2,975, 2-story frame dwelling, 40x110; Manufacturers Trust Co against Anna L. Lynch, due, $3,417; subject to first mortgage of $12,100; to plaintiff for $15,553.

Price movements of commodity futures were mixed in moderate activity on the local Exchanges yesterday. In the cash market rubber, cotton. eggs and butter advanced, but all the grains, cocs, raw sugar, lard, tin wool tops and copper declined.

Calling a person a "scab" does not constitute disorderly conduct, but the use of the epithet "dirty rat" does, Magistrate David L. Malbin held yesterday in Bay Ridge Court, Brooklyn, when he dismissed two charges of disorderly conduct against a former striking employe of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle and gave another a suspended sentence.

Mayor La Guardia laid the cornerstone yesterday of the city's exhibition building for the New York World's Fair in the presence of most of the other important city officials. A dozen salamanders filled with red hot coals surrounded the speakers and a gathering of 200 persons but had a negligible effect on the chilly air. Speeches necessarily were brief,

Rapid improvement in earnings of corporations in 1935 and the increased revenues resulting to the government were shown today in a tabulation from statistics of income for that year made public by the Treasury Department.

The creation of a Federal Department of Public Works as a new separate branch of the government was urged by leading engineers at the eighty-fifth annual meeting of the American Society of Civil Engineers, which opened yesterday at the Engineering Societies 'Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

Spanish Government sources said today that the renewed Insurgent drive in the Teruel sector had dwindled to a series of "feeler attacks" after the Insurgents suffered heavy losses in a night offensive. Dispatches from Salamanca, the Insurgent capital,

With automobile registration estimated at a new high record of 29,650,000 units as of Jan. 1, the market for replacement tire sales has been broadened in the last year, according to S. B. Robertson, president of the B. F. Goodrich Company.

The Rev. Albert C. McGaw, a retired Presbyterian missionary, died in Lahore, India, on Sunday. Mr. McGaw, who began his career as a missionary in India in 1894, retired because of ill health in 1930. His age was 72.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has given its counsel permission to examine the records of the New York Stock Exchange to determine whether further testimony should be taken in the W. E. Hutton Co. stock-manipulation case. The purpose will be to test the accuracy of previous testimony, officials said.

Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Goya's 'Caprices' and 'Disasters,' " Roberta M. Fansler, 11 A. M.; "American Furniture: The Age of Mahogany," Ethelwyn Bradish, noon; Far Eastern art (general tour) 2 P. M.
Fung Kwok Keung, who is also Joseph Rinehart, a 19-year-old American-born Oriental, looked on his native New York yesterday after many years' absence and found it good, but very, very bewildering.

ONE of the chief troubles with the world today, says Stuart Chase in his new book called "The Tyranny of Words," * is that people don't know what they are talking about. This is not supposed to be funny; it is meant literally. People who talk and write sooner or later get around to abstract words-pacifism, unity, the working class, the soul, freedom, free speech, fascism, democracy, and so on.

Christy R. Bohnsack, program director of WNYC, was dismissed from service yesterday by Acting Commissioner of Public Works Edward J. McGrew Jr. following a hearing on charges before Assistant Commissioner Davis A. Thompson.

An autopsy report to police headquarters yesterday on Ruland Thompson, 40 years old, of 304 East Forty-second Street, whose body was found at the bottom of a dumbwaiter shaft at 200 West Eightyfirst Street early Wednesday night, said the death was "definitely no homicide."

The National Labor Relations Board today certified that the Newspaper Guild of New York had been selected as bargaining representative by a majority of commercial employes of News Syndicate Company, Inc.,
A serious error was made in the count of the proportional representation ballots for the election of Manhattan's members of the City Council. it developed yesterday.

A poets' dinner at which Dr. Henry Goddard Leach received a medal and Robert Nathan, author of "Winter in April," sold a poem a few minutes after he had read it aloud, was held last night by the Poetry Society of America at the Hotel Biltmore.
Admiral the Earl of Cork and Orrery is promoted to Admiral of the Fleet, the Admiralty announced tonight, succeeding Sir Frederick L. Field, who retires from the active list tomorrow.
Imposition of sanctions against Japan was demanded tonight by the National Council of Labor, the highest coordinating body in the British Socialist and trade union movement.

The United States Embassy announced today that two Spanish Insurgent warships had escorted the American tanker Nantucket Chief to Generalissimo Francisco Franco's air and naval base at Palma, Majorca.

Steadier employment and more stable prices to consumers in 1938 than in 1937 as a possible result of trade pacts about to be negotiated between the United States and other nations, such as Great Britain and Argentina, were predicted yesterday by Floyd Y. Keeler upon his re-election to a third term as president of the Commodity Exchange, Inc.

The lastplace Red Wings scored two goals in the last 71 seconds of play tonight to defeat the Black Hawks, 4 to 2, for their first home victory in the National Hockey League since they beat the same club on Nov. 25.

There is no great gulf between the objectives of government and industry, Tom M. Girdler, chairman of the Republic Steel Corporation, declared at a testimonial dinner meeting of the Lehigh Club of New York at the Murray Hill Hotel last night, and with both cooperating in good-will he hopes for the greatest expansion and development "that the human race has yet known."
The Securities and Exchange Commission has revoked the resignation of Virgil E. Walker, Rochester, N. Y., as a dealer in the over-the-counter market. It instituted proceedings

Playing against A. E. Santasiere in the eighth round of the annual tournament of the Marshall Chess Club yesterday, Frank J. Marshall, the titleholder, was held to a draw in a well-played game. Marshall, the only undefeated entrant,

The largest collection of ancient Egyptian coins probably ever offered an auction in this country had its first day's session yesterday in the offices of Stacks, coin dealers, 32 West Forty-sixth Street.
The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders dated Jan. 18.

Dr. Julius Maniu, Rumania's foremost democratic leader and the president of the National Peasant party, in a long interview with the writer today made a strongly worded declaration denouncing Premier Octavian Goga's "sham government" but affirming his loyalty to the monarchy.

The Coast Guard announced the following changes for the week endea Jan. 19: Lt. F. A. Erickson, detached Miami Air Station; to San Diego Air Station. Lt. W. A. Burton, detached St. Petersburg Air Station; to aviation office the Spencer.
Miss Harriet Dryden Jones, until recently associate head of the Baldwin School, Bryn Mawr, Pa., and well known in Eastern educational circles, died here last night.

Bishop James M. Maxon of the Episcopal Diocese of Tennessee took "painful" cognizance today of the Very Rev. Israel Harding Noe's fast to attain immortality and ordered his immediate removal as dean of St. Mary's Cathedral.

Mark A. Cadwell of the Great Northern Hotel, for thirty-one years secretary of the New York State Hotel Association and for more than a quarter of a century holder of the same executive position with the New York City Hotel Associatio, died yesterday in Lenox Hill. Hospital of a heart attack.

An explanation of "the great importance which the undistributed profits tax has assumed in the quarrel between business and government" was made yesterday in Harpers Magazine by Maurice Werthelm, investment banker and former principal financial backer of The Nation as a liberal weekly.

Printers of Portland's three daily newspapers voted tonight to accept a new proposition from the publishers, thus ending a strike which closed down The Oregonian, Journal and News-Telegram on Saturday. The publishers offered a new proposal on wages and arbitration to the Multnomah Typographical Union.

Dr. Frank T. Hypps Frank T. Hypps, B. S., A. M., Ph. D., of the teaching staff of the Wharton School of Finance and Commerce, University of Pennsylvania, will become director of research of Brown Tarcher, advertising agency, on Feb. 1.
Business activity in the Pittsburgh district last week declined nearly as much as it rose in the preceding week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.
The problem of protecting vacant buildings, particularly old tenements, from trespassers and vandals has been occupying the attention of real estate interests recently.
A drop of almost $8,000,000 in deposits by chartered banks was shown today in the Bank of Canada's report for the week ended yesterday. Dominion Government deposits gained around $1,500,000.

Today's major events: "Walkuere," Metropolitan Opera House, evening; Lambros Callimahos, flutist, Carnegie Hall, evening; Maurice Ames, Town Hall, evening; Federal Opera Chorus and Greenwic: Orchestra, Federal Music Theatre, evening; Pasquier Trio, Washington Irving High School, evening.

Mrs. Mary Hinman Abel, wife of Dr. John J. Abel of Johns Hopkins Medical School, died today at her home here at the age of 87. Mrs. Abel had long been active in Baltimore charitable and educational work. She was the first editor

President Roosevelt's search for a recovery formula was extended today to the ranks of "small" business men and to groups whose economic philosophy is supposed to differ from that of the more, widely known leaders of industry, labor and finance with whom he has talked.
Harry F. Wolf, national amateur squash tennis champion, last night added the Clyde Martin Memorial Trophy to his list of conquests for the season.

Under the auspices of the Ministers of Government and Industry, the third national convention of labor unions opened tonight at Cali. Seven hundred delegates were in attendance, including a group from Mexico.

As alert as if he had a full night's sleep, 78-year-old Justice Willis Van Devanter, until recently a member of the United States' Supreme Court, appeared on time yesterday in Federal Court, where he is now sitting, although he had waited all Wednesday night for a jury to reach a verdict.

Reports have been received here that Paris is perturbed over the possibility that Germany may take advantage of French political troubles by launching a coup against that country. It can be said, however, that such a project would be, in fact,

Filling a vacancy that has existed since last September, the Board of Superintendents, at a special meeting yesterday afternoon, nominated Arthur Bowie,- principal of P. S. 206, Brooklyn, as assistant superintendent of schools.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Since I am a traveling secretary of a world organization, I am a frequent passenger on American ships and therefore much interested in the problem of safety at sea.

Plants operating 58 per cent of the full-fashioned hosiery equipment in the United States have converted only slightly over 1 per cent of their equipment to production of lisle and rayon hosiery since the movement for an anti-Japanese boycott of silk products began in October, a survey by the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers has shown, the association announced last night.

Clinton C. Johnson, formerly assistant secretary of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, was appointed manager of the foreign department yesterday. Claudius D. Duncan, formerly manager of the Waldorf-Astoria office, was appointed assistant vice president.

Mr. and Mrs. Clinton L. Babcock of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Ann Babcock, to Richard Elwood Harris, son of Mrs. Albert W. Harris and the late Mr. Harris of Newark.
Odd-lot purchases on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Jan. 15 exceeded sales by 365,291 shares, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

THAT man is here again, meaning Jersey James Braddock, the fellow who came out of the Slough of Despond to scale the heights of pugilism. Though a plain, honest and ordinarily amiable gent in what might be called civil life, he always was a puzzle as a pugilist and, hovering around the 200-pound mark, he is now a bigger puzzle than ever before.

While more than 200 theological students carried out furnishings, fire swept through the upper floor of two wings of the old rectory building on the campus of St. Charles Borromeo Seminary in Overbrook tonight.

The annual report of the United States and Foreign Securities Corporation for 1937 was issued yesterday. It showed indicated net assets of $30,850,588 at the close of the year, equivalent to about $146 a share on the first preferred stock, compared with $56,635,893, or $269.69 a share, at the close of 1936.

Movies escaped Federal control probably by coming along before the radio, but the government might do well to "drop the film industry a hint" to become "a force for publie good" by cooperating with the movement to provide educational films for school use, Herbert S. Walsh told a conference of the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures here yesterday.

Beer parlors joined cafes and restaurants in a Stockholm hotel shutdown today, and there was no sign of an early end to the fight between the employers' federation and workers who are demanding more pay and fewer working hours.

Engineering construction awards this week registered a rise of 9 per cent over the same week of last year, with a total of $47,669,000, as compared with $43,941,000 in 1937, according to The Engineering News Record.
The Pittsburgh Baseball Club announced tonight the sale of Pitcher Jim Weaver to the St. Louis Browns of the American League in a straight cash deal. The sum involved was not disclosed.
With more than 1,000,000 units sold in 1937, an extensive national advertising campaign for I. E. S. Better Sight lamps will be launched next month, the budget exceeding $150,000.

The St. Nicholas Hockey Club broke a deadlock with the New York A. C. skaters and gained undisputed possession of first place in the New York Amateur Hockey Association by downing the Winged Footers, 11 to 2, in the feature game of a double-header at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night.

Twelve Smith College alumnae were recently elected to alumnae membership in Phi Beta Kappa. To be eligible for this distinction an alumna must have been out of Smith at least ten years, must have a Ph. D. degree and must have a professional rank or be engaged in important research.
H. J. Kowal of Utica, N. Y., shattered the amateur course record with 34, 35-69 in winning his firstround match in the annual Miami Biltmore invitation golf tournament today. Kowal, who yesterday

The preliminary construction budget of the Standard Gas and Electric Company system for 1938 will total approximately $31,392,000, according to an announcement yesterday by Bernard W. Lynch, president.

Most of the judicial shackles which have restricted the movements of 13-year-old Gloria Laura Morgan Vanderbilt since 1934 when she was the central figure in a legal battle between her mother, Mrs. Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt, and her aunt, Mrs. Harry Payne Whitney, were removed yesterday in a new decree signed by Supreme Court Justice Timothy A. Leary.

Bathgate Ave (11-2914), w s. 180 n of 172d St. 80x120; Gertrude Weg to Dollar Savings Bank: extends mtg to Jan. 19, 1943, at 4 1/2 per cent; $25,000. Walton Ave (9-2472) n e cor of 165th St, 36x100; Charbro Realty Co to Chatham Investing Co, 11 Park P1; extends mtg to be paid in installments as per bond at 8 per cent: $12,000.
President Roosevelt today acceded to the request of J. F. T. O'Connor that he be relieved of his duties as Controller of the Currency, but asked that he remain in the post until April 1.
Pulling into a lead as the field entered the last furlong, Mr. Blaze moved forward and won the $1,500 Van Nuys Purse at Santa Anita Park today.

Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente ruled yesterday that R. H. Macy Co. could present, in defense of a charge that it was illegally cutting prices on Philco radios, facts tending to show that the price-fixing agreement made under the Feld-Crawford Fair Trade Act was widely flouted by other retailers.

Assertions that the Securities and Exchange Commission possesses power virtually to remodel the public utility map of the country through the "death sentence" and other "control sections" of the Public Holding Company Act were made in a brief

The Kolisch String Quartet begins its series of four chamber concerts of music by Beethoven and Schoenberg this evening in the auditorium of the education department of New York University, 41 West Fourth Street.

Nine-year-old Vivian and 7-year-old Alma Herring of Secaucus, N. J., asked the Supreme Court today to review State court decisions upholding their expulsion from public schools because they would not salute the American flag nor take the oath of allegiance, because of religious beliefs.
During the week ended Jan. 19 member bank reserve balances increased $26,000,000. Additions to member

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine ordered late yesterday an investigation of the police patrol system in the neighborhood of Fifth Avenue and the West Fifties as the result of the burglary of a dress shop at 7 West Fifty-sixth Street, from which clothing valued at $5,500 was stolen.
Reflecting further weakness in the price of copper abroad, the leading producers yesterday lowered their quotations for the metal in the domestic market from 11 to 10.5 cents a pound.
Music from Debussy's opera, "Pelleas et Melisande," will be broadcast over the WOR-Mutual network beginning at 10:30 o'clock tonight, with Dr. Laird Waller conducting.

All the New York Americans could get in the National Hockey League game with the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden last night was a 1-to-1 tie, but the outcome was a mighty satisfactory one to the star-spangled sextet.
For her wedding gown yesterday . the King of Egypt's bride rejoiced in a creation by Worth of Paris. During a thousand

The city and the Board of Transportation were accused of maintaining a labor spy system and otherwise interfering with the organizing right of employes on the city's Independent Subway System in a complaint filed with the State Labor Relations Board yesterday

Members of the vast Eastern ski army, whose numbers grow with each snowfall, can look forward to enjoying another pleasant week-end of running starting tomorrow, providing, of course, that the elements do not put a damper on the present outlook.

Duke Ernst Hohenberg, son of the murdered Archduke Francis Ferdinand, who the other day smashed an illuminated display sign carrying a swastika, appeared at the German legation today and presented his apologies to Ambassador Franz von Papen,

The Pan American Trust Company, which began business on Jan. 2, 1937, made a profit in its first year of operation and doubled its deposits, John B. Glenn, president, said in his annual report to shareholders, made public yesterday.

Jake Schaefer and Welker Cochran will return to their billiard battles next Monday when the former opens the defense of his 28.2 balkline title in a 3,500-point match at the Strand Academy. The men will play fourteen blocks, meeting twice daily throughout the week and including Sunday.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

King Farouk, the world's youngest ruling monarch, reigning in one of the world's most ancient countries, affixed his signature at 11 o'clock this morning to two copies of a parchment document constituting a contract of marriage to 16-year-old Farida Zulficar, and thereby she became Egypt's new Queen.
Mrs. Margaret Schwitzer Sayre, daughter of Mrs. Lydia Schwitzer of East Orange, was married this morning at the home of her cousin, Mrs. Harry Schott of this city, to Joseph A. Nash of Brooklyn.

At a hearing today before the Securities and Exchange Commission the Philadelphia Stock Exchange sought unlisted trading privileges in the common stock of the Atlas Corporation and the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation, now registered and listed on the New York Stock Exchange and the New York Curb Exchange respectively.
Henry F. Lutz, State director of parks and secretary of the State Council of Parks, died unexpectedly tonight at the Albany Club.
Disclosure of a plot to bomb the Japanese liner Hiye Maru caused the vessel to be moved hastily this afternoon from her moorings at the Great Northern dock here.

The town of Greenwich was restrained today by Superior Court injunction from enforcing an order that former Justice Townsend Scudder of the Supreme Court in New York must dispose of all but ten of seventy- cocker spaniels on his Round Hill estate by Feb. 1.

Deputy Mayor Henry H. Curran aligned himself with those who condemn the expression "and/or" in legal documents yesterday when he protested against the phrase as a part of five resolutions on the Board of Estimate calendar.
The Rev. Clifford Rowe, pastor of the Olivet Baptist Church of Trenton, died early yesterday in his apartment in the church building of a heart attack. He was 33 years old.

Chinese semi-official reports today stated that Japanese sailors, about 200 strong, attempted a landing yesterday at Yuling, on the south coast of Hainan Island, supported by a bombardment from three Japanese warships and several airplanes, but that they were repulsed after a four-hour engagement by Chinese troops.

Lord Stanley of Knowsley Hall, Lancashire, England, son of the Ear' of Derby, and Lady Stanley are expected to arrive next Wednesday on the Aquitania. They will be at the St. Regis before going to Palm Beach.

More than 400 members of the National Society of New England Women, including delegates from various sections of those States, enthusiastically applauded a denunciation of the Roosevelt Administration yesterday by Governor George D. Aiken of Vermont.

Payrolls for twenty-six Councilmen and the sixty employes of the City Clerk were finally certified last evening by former Deputy City Clerk Philip Hines and Robert Lee Tudor, whose status as City Clerk and Clerk of the Council is in dispute.

Robert M. (Bobbie) Fitzmaurice, executive officer and personal friend of the last three Governors of New York, President Roosevelt, Alfred E. Smith and Governor Lehman, died late today in St. Peter's Hospital of pneumonia after an illness of two days. He was 65 years old.

Five trips to the recently opened State motor vehicle inspection station here before his automobile was officially approved was a little too much for Earl Grove of 17 Evergreen Avenue, Neptune City, N. J. Mr. Grove,
A client of the Colonial Realty Company, Inc., has purchased for occupancy the two-family brick dwelling, on a plot 20 by 100 feet, at 1,916 Seventy-first Street, Brooklyn, from Michael A. Iulo.
Although ever on the alert to defend the new regime of President Getulio Vargas against outside criticism, the Brazilian people maintain among themselves a completely acquiescent attitude toward it.

Columbia University held a memorial meeting for the late Marie Sklodowska Curie, co-discoverer of radium and one of the foremost Sales scientists of the twentieth century, in the Harkness Academic Theatre at Columbia last night.
The State Democratic Executive Committee rejected today a resolution to oust J. B. Hodges as chairman for statements interpreted as critical of President Roosevelt's policies.
Reuters (British news agency) reported today that two Russian border guards had been killed in a clash with an Estonian patrol. Estonian advices,

Governor George H. Earle of Pennsylvania will be a speaker at the interstate conference of independent retailers' associations to be held under the auspices. of the Greater New York Retail Furnishings and Dry Goods Association, Inc., at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria on Sunday, Jan. 30.

Former New York Supreme Court Justice Arthur S. Tompkins died at the Nyack Hospital today as the result of a diabetic infection. He was 72 years old and had been a patient at the hospital since Jan. 4.

Clarification and amendment of the Robinson-Patman Act to permit manufacturers to offer, and the service distributor to receive, "adequate" remuneration for the services the distributor is equipped to render were urged yesterday by Joseph Kolodny, executive director, at the annual convention of the National Association of Tobacco Distributors, Inc., In the Hotel Commodore.

Stockholders of the Valspar Corporation will vote on Feb. 18 in Wilmington, Del., on a plan for readjustment of the debt and capital structure, it was announced yesterday by Thurlow J. Campbell, president.

The Metropolitan Opera's second "Manon" of the season last night was the occasion of the second appearance of Grace Moore, who, of course, took the title role. With Sydney Rayner as the Des Grieux, Massenet's valentine passions and perfumed chivalry were served in uneven though generally adequate measure.

G. E. Stechert Co., importers and dealers in new and second-hand books and periodicals, owners of the eight-story building at 31 East Tenth Street, have purchased the adjoining seven-story structure at 35-37 East Tenth Street.
If enthusiasm is to be considered evidence of a good time, about 200 anglers spent a pleasant evening at the dinner of the Long Island Anglers, held at the Hotel Pennsylvania Wednesday night.

Two subornation of perjury indictments, returned last April 13 against H. Lee Kanner, a lawyer, in connection with Supreme Court testimony in a $20,000 automobile accident suit, were dismissed yesterday by General Sessions Judge George L. Donnellan.

Injections of synthetic vitamin B1, directly into the spinal canal, has proved of value in a large number of different types of nervous disorders, the seventh annual congress of the Pan-American Medical Association was told here today by Dr. Elias Lincoln Stern of New York.

Colonel and Mrs. Louis Jacques Balsan, gave a dinner tonight at their villa, where the Marquis Melchior de Polignac is a guest. Milton W. Holden was host at his residence at a dinner for Winthrop W. Aldrich of New York.
Captain Henry A. F. Young, former New York broker and a veteran of the Spanish-American War, died here today at his home after a long illness. He was 66 years old.

Chandler A. Mackey, president of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, was re-elected to that position by an unanimous vote of the members of the Exchange at the annual election held yesterday. This was his fourth election as president.

After eluding capture for two months and scorning repeated attempts by kind-hearted persons to lure him back to the warmth and comfort of civilized life, Projy, a magnificent russet chow, lay last night in compartment 26 of the stray ward at the shelter of the Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, Avenue A and Twentyfourth Street, and viewed all comers with a skeptical eye.

A drop of 19.2 per cent in construction employment throughout the State for the period running from the middle of November to the middle of December was reported here today in a statement issued by Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews. Payrolls dropped 17.5 per cent and manhours 21.2 per cent.

The charges that Italy is in arrears on her payments to Moscow, made there to justify the suspension of all Russian commercial payments to Italy, drew a reply from the Italian Government today in the form of a communique saying that the converse was true, Russia owing Italy some tens of millions of lire.

Mrs. Johanna Von Meyer, 86 years old, of 358 West Thirty-eighth Street, who had been living alone in a tworoom tenement flat before being taken to Bellevue Hospital on Wednesday, died yesterday morning, leaving an estate estimated at between $200,000 and $300,000.

Although continuing rain and snow have mired roads and flooded streams, greatly impeding all Japanese troop movements and keeping the Japanese air forces immobilized, nevertheless-even according to Chinese admissions-Japanese armies were making important advances today toward Suchow, strategic junction of the Tientain-Pukow and Lung-Hai railways.
To give the nation the best possible transportation system, the railroads should be permitted to retain under their control decision as to matters of judgment and practical detail, M. W.

The Roman Catholic Church of St. Andrew, landmark at Duane Street and Cardinal Place, where the night workers' mass was born just after the turn of the century and where newspaper men from Park Row for years attended services during the small hours of the morning, was turned over yesterday to a wrecking crew.
George Howard Harris, assistant superintendent of the American-La France Foamite Company, died suddenly yesterday in Elmira Hospital at the age of 57.
