Lewisohn, in 7 Gracie So; Mrs. Garrard Comly, in 42 E 78th St; William P. Tanner, Mabel Fiske Hilcken, in The Buchanan, 160 E 48th St; Pease Elliman, Inc, broker.

The Census Bureau reported to day that the cotton spinning industry operated during December at 92 per cent of capacity, on a single shift basis, compared with 105.2 per cent during November last year, and 134.5 per cent during December, 1936.

The marriage of Miss Jane Caryl Anderson, daughter of Mrs. Percy Edward Anderson of Westport, to Charles Henschel Conland, son of Henry Holton Conland, publisher of The Hartford Courant, and Mrs. Conland of Hartford, Conn., will take place next Thursday afternoon at the Holy Trinity Church in Westport.

The national A. A. U. championship in ice hockey at Boston on Feb. 25, 26 and 27 probably will determine whether or not the United States will be represented in this sport in the 1940 Olympics, it was announced yesterday by Frederick W. Rubien, chairman of the national committee and secretary of the A. O. C.

Sing Chung-wan, one of the first students sent to the United States in 1876 by the Dowager Empress, died today. He was 76 years old. He studied at the Worcester (Mass.) Polytechnic Institute and later played a prominent role in the Westernization of China.

Funeral services for Roscoe C. Lawrence of 700 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn, an insurance broker, who died on Tuesday, were conducted last night in the Fairchild Chapel, 86 Lefferts Place, by the Rev. Charles W. Roeder, pastor of Flatlands Reformed Church.

A sweeping program of communications development looking toward the establishment of new routes linking China with lands to the west and south is being rapidly pushed to conclusion by the Chinese Government. In developing new highways,

Evidence continues to pile up to show that there was once a man named William Shakespeare, that he could not spell but that he was quite a hand at writing plays. From Salt Lake City comes news that Professor B. Roland Lewis, a specialist in Shakespeare documents, has discovered and verified a heretofore unknown Shakespearean signature--the seventh of which

The bad post actor, Higher Cloud, one of the fleetest horses in the stable of Mrs. Emil Denemark, was on his good behavior today and not only won the featured Homestead Purse, but did so in the fastest time thus far of the meeting.
With a sharp recovery in Liverpool, prices on the Cotton Exchange improved again yesterday to end with gains of 3 to 5 points.

Breaking two precedents, William L. Monro, re-elected president of the American Tariff League at its fifty-third annual meeting yesterday in the Union League Club, advocated a two-column tariff system based on "low wage" and "high wage" countries, and praised Secretary of State Hull and his staff for the absence of any political influence in working out reciprocal trade agreements.

Seventy-five delegates to the biennial conference of local- executives of the Camp Fire Girls, meeting at the Barbizon Plaza Hotel, voted last night to recommend to the National Council of the organization that married women be barred from executive positions.

Members of the Society of Pennsylvania Women gave a reception yesterday- at Sherry's for the benefit of the Girls Service League of New York and for the scholarship fund maintained by the society at the Pennsylvania College for Women in Pittsburgh.

The Rev. Walter H. Cambridge, rector emeritus of the Church of St. Matthew, San Mateo, and a leader in Episcopal Church circles for many years, died at Colombo, Ceylon, while on a world tour, his former parishioners learned by cable yesterday.
Wesley Ferrell, the Washington pitcher, served notice today he is out to recapture the baseball players' golf championship he won in 1936.
Offices of American film companies in Poland will be closed and the importation of American films will be discontinued if the new Polish levy is imposed on foreign films.
Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

Oliver St, 45, 5-story brick tenement stores, 25x100x, irreg; Isidor Friend, trustee, against John A. Garone; due, $15,516. taxes, etc. $1,069; to 103 Attorney St Corp for $500. By THOMAS 3. LUNNEY Park Ave. 3,540. 2-story frame dwelling, 15x150: Home Owners Loan Corp against Ray Wolkowltz; due, $5,099; to plaintiff for $500.

Work on the filling in of a boat basin in Flushing Bay, adjoining the site of the World's Fair of 1939, was held up yesterday by a stoppage of employes of the Michael J. Torpey Contracting Company of 50-07 Forty-ninth Street, Long Island City.
George Kafandaris, one-time Greek Premier and Minister of Finance, has been arrested at his Athens home and interned on the Island of Zante, according to reliable reports reaching here.

A statement expressing his regret over errors in a list of thirty-nine deputies of the Hudson County Bureau of Elections who were alleged to have had criminal records was made today in behalf of Mayor Frank Hague, who last Monday in a letter to Prosecutor Daniel T. O'Regan requested investigation of the cases.

Barney Hassett's field goal in the second overtime period of three minutes gave the Manhattan Prep quintet a 22-to-20 triumph over Mount St. Michael High in a BronxWestchester C. H. S. A. A. clash on the losers' court yesterday.

Bank clearings of the principal cities throughout the country for the week ended on Wednesday totaled $5,214,937,000, as compared with $6,564,780,000 for the corresponding week a year ago, ace ling to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

ACKERMAN, HARRY (Nov. 28, 1936). Gross assets, $40,861; net, $34,606. To Samuel Ackerman, Beatrice Prcmmac. Alice Greene, Saul B., Laurence J. and Harmon Ackerman, equal interests in residuary estate; four charities share in $1,800 and to persons varying cash bequests. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $20,200. Laurence J. Ackerman. attorney, 123 William St.
The Portland cement industry produced 7,044,000 barrels last month. It shipped 4,780,000 barrels from the mills and had 24,899,000 barrels in stock at the end of the month.

President Roosevelt discussed the political situation with Senator Guffey and Postmaster General Farley, business conditions in the automobile industry with Governor Murphy of Michigan, and Maritime Commission affairs with Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman.

Herbert M. Kopf, recently named head coach of football at Manhattan College, also has been appointed director of athletics for three years, it was announced yesterday by Brother Patrick, F. S. C., president of the college.

World economic cooperation, as a war cure, was advocated by speakers before today's session of the Conference on the Cause and Cure of War, an organization of eleven associations representing 7,000,000 women throughout the country.
Distribution of State unemployment insurance checks to 250,000 persons among the 499,000 who have applied since Jan. 1 was forecast yesterday by Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews.

The appointment of Selden W. Ostrom as president of the New Rochelle Federal Savings and Loan Association was announced today. He had been vice president and manager for four years and succeeds John F. Mahaffey, retired.
Giusto Saiz of 74 Borcher Avenue, Yonkers, a certified public accountant with office at 274 Madison Avenue, died on Wednesday night in Midtown Hospital after a long illness. He was 53 years old.

Neil Petree, who resigned as president of James McCreery Co. on Jan. 3 to become president of Barker Brothers of Los Angeles, was guest of honor at a farewell dinner given by a group of newspaper and department-store executives in the Empire State Club yesterday.

THE PRODIGAL PARENTS, by Sinclair Lewis. (Doubleday, Doran, $2.50.) A novel about the revolt of parents against the revolt of youth. THE SWORD AND THE ROSE, by A. W. Smith. (Little, Brown, $2.50.) A novel about the British Army.

MANHATTAN ELLIOTT, HOWARD A. (Nov. 30). Estate, $7,500. To Katherine Elliott, widow, petitioner, 425 West 23d St. FREEMAN, HENRIETTA TAYLOR (Jan. 8). Estate, more than $10,000. To Emma Ewing, niece, Claremont, N. H., real property valued at $3,000; one specific bequest; Rowland G. Freeman, husband, 103 E. 75th St., residue, executor.

The Japanese Ambassador to France, Yotaro Sugimura, has been booked as the principal attraction on the card of jiu-jitsu matches scheduled to be held Jan. 29 at the Franco-Japanese Jiu-Jitsu Club here.

Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., Jan. 21: PATROLMEN Andrew T. F. Browne, 61st Precinct, assignment to duty as attendant discontinued. From precincts indicated to Borough Headquarters Squad, Manhattan, assigned to duty in Warrant Squad:

A new national "council" such as President Roosevelt has suggested-to consist of perhaps two dozen spokesmen of varied economic interestsmight be a useful thing to have or it might be a step taken in the wrong direction.

Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, outlined today a set of standards for bankers and urged their whole-hearted support of the F. D. I. C.'s "efforts to strengthen and so to preserve" the banking system.

Eli Whitney, who walked to Yale College in 1789 from a Westboro (Mass.) farm and three years later invented the cotton gin, was eulogized today by Joseph W. Roe of Yale University as outstanding inventor of the institution.

Sufficient support appeared in the market for some of the more volatile railroad bonds yesterday to check, at least temporarily, the precipitate decline which has marked those issues in recent trading.

Mayor La Guardia said yesterday in Greenpoint that the "real challenge to the genius of American statesmanship today is to solve the paradox of want in a land of plenty." He spoke at the dedication of a dispensary for Greenpoint Hospital, Skillman and Kingsland Avenues, Brooklyn.
The Catholic Club of the City of New York, at its annual meeting last night at its clubrooms at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, elected T. Louis A. Britt president.
The campaign against Jews in the controlled Mexican press has been permitted to continue despite official assurances that the campaign would end. The newspaper Novedades

Federal Judge Patrick T. Stone released four more individual defendants in the government's gasoline price-fixing case today, reducing to thirty-two the number of oil company executives and officials still on trial.

Declines of 1/2 to 1 cent in domestic hides and 1 cent in Argentine frigorificos have developed in the last few days as tanners found that, After a slow but steady increase in their sales until last week, buying by shoe manufacturers has dropped off fairly sharply.

Promotions Announced The following lieutenants are promoted to the rank of captain, with compensation each at the rate of $4,500 per annum, to take effect as of 12:01 A. M. Jan. 1, and shall be charged to the Code noted below. They will report to the-Assistant Chief of Depart-, ment for assignment to duty:

The advertising of the 1939 World's Fair on this year's automobile license plates in New York State received the endorsement last night of the Central Trades and Labor Council, on the ground that the fair would create work and that Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation, had appointed a labor group to see that proper labor standards were observed.

Two former agents of the Freyn Engineering Company received a judgment approximating $500,000 today when the Circuit Court ruled that the company must pay to them commissions and interest on contracts they obtained with the Soviet Russian Government.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France, issued today, shows the following changes, in francs:

Seeking a review of the indictments returned against them by the Essex County Grand Jury after a Supreme Court Commissioner's investigation of Newark's municipal affairs, Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein and other present and former city officials charged in the Supreme Court here today that the true bills were found because of "popular clamor and demand" and were "not the result of legal evidence."
Miss Sonja Henie, figure-skating and motion-picture star who will be featured in the ice revue at Madison Square Garden next week, is scheduled to arrive in New York tomorrow morning.

Following a cruise along the Atlantic Coast from Baltimore at 165 miles an hour with forty-eight men and women aboard, the new Martin "ocean transport" dipped in salute over mid-Manhattan late yesterday afternoon and without a tremor in its huge hull landed in an icecleared channel in Jamaica Bay off Floyd Bennett Field.
President Getulio Vargas returned here today after a two weeks' stay in Rio Grande do Sul, his native State, and was received with a great ovation despite a protest by him.

Representative Ed V. Izac of California advocated today a $300,000,000 interoceanic canal over Nicaraguan territory. A bill he introduced would authorize an initial appropriation of $10,000,000 for the project and give the Treasury authority to issue up to $300,000,000 in bonds for construction and maintenance.

George Timothy Sullivan, assistant general merchandise manager of the Abraham Straus department store in Brooklyn and the store's oldest employee in years of service, died yesterday a' his home, 2,111 Albemarle Terrace, Brooklyn, after an illness of about three months.

Vought, Campbell, Ward Co have placed a mortgage loan of $250,000 for ten years on the apartment house at 763 Eastern Parkway for the Ten Ten Lincoln Place Corp with the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn.

Dr. Hans Albert Einstein, son of the noted physicist, will sail today on the steamship American Banker of the United States Lines. Others listed for this liner, bound for London, include R. F. Thomas, James C. Gustaveson, Jacob Hefter, Mr. and Mrs. George Bauer, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Thorold, Miss Marion Dixon, Mrs. Mabel E. McGrain and Miss M. J. Gordon.

A. S. Wechsler of the State Division of Licenses announced yesterday that the application of Foster Strader of 230 Park Avenue for a license -as a private detective had been denied for a second time. Mr.

Great Britain's annual Royal Air Force display at Hendon, which since 1929 has drawn technicians from all over the world and provided huge sums for charity, is to be abandoned because military flying has become too dangerous as a spectacle.

1st Lt. Joseph M. Gross, Med.-Res., 238 Barrett St., Brooklyn, N. Y., 77th Div., is ordered to active duty, effective Jan. 19, at Ft. Hamilton, New York, for training. He will revert to an inactive status on Feb. 1.

SINCLAIR LEWIS'S "The Prodigal Parents"* is a rather feeble retort to Sinclair Lewis's "Main Street." And not, I am sorry to say, much more. In his new-novel Mr. Lewis looks again at the revolt of the young against the ways of their elders. Now, he will have none of it.

A courier from Westchester County galloped into town on a lathery horse this week to report that the hinterland is considering retaliatory measures against the bridge tolls imposed by Mr. Moses and the sales tax imposed by Mayor La Guardia. Westchester thinks we are probably pro-British, anyhow.
An application by the Norfolk Portsmouth Belt Line Railroad Company for authority to issue at par a promissory note for $450,000 was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Penniless and broken by age and illness, Dolores Tellez-Giron y Domine, daughter of the last Duke of Osuna and member of a once fabulously rich Spanish family, today entered a home for aged and destitute working women.

Headed by D. E. Ralston, general sales manager for Oldsmobile, a group of sales executives from the factory at Lansing, Mich., will conduct an all-day meeting at Essex House today to discuss plans for new and used car merchandising activities in the Atlantic region.

A disclosure that the Pennroad Corporation lost heavily on investments made partly for the benefit of the Pennsylvania Railroad drew sharp criticism today from Senator Truman of Missouri, acting chairman of the Senate committee investigating railroad finances.

Members of the United States basketball team, slated to sail for a South American playing tour on Jan. 29 aboard the Munson liner Southern Cross, were named yesterday by the A. A. U. Eight players and a manager-coach will make the trip.

A group of snow fence producers and their trade association, the United Fence Manufacturers Association of Burlington, N. J., are charged with violation of the Federal Trade Commission Act and the RobinsonPatman Act in a complaint filed by the Federal Trade Commission, it was announced today.
Edward J. Reilly, well-known criminal lawyer and chief defense counsel at the trial of Bruno Richard Hauptman -for the kidnapping and slaying of Charles A.

William R. White. State Superintendent of Banking, was the recipient yesterday of the distinguished service award key and scroll given annually by the Young Men's Board of Trade to a young man, not more than 35 years old, "who has made the greatest contribution to the community."

An indication of how strongly one section--and that not the least important--of British public opinion feels on the value of an agreement with Germany was seen today when the Bishops of the Canterbury Convocation adopted unanimously a resolution favoring a "friendly understanding" between the two nations despite their expressed concern over Nazi treatment of their "fellow Christians."

An increase was registered in lumber production last week, when a nominal decline was anticipated seasonally, and the adjusted index advanced to 53.1 from 48.9. The index stood at 69.9 for the week ended Jan. 16, 1937.
The reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City continued to make susbtantial purchases of securities, particularly United States Government securities, in the last week.

An investigation has been started to ascertain whether there are heirs in the United States of a wealthy Armenian who died recently at Constant. The Armenian, Artin Mitragosian, who was more than 80 years old, had no family.

Price cutting on domestic brands of National Distillers Products Corporation continued through yesterday despite announcement by both the company and organized retail liquor package stores that their differences had been composed and resale price schedules re-established under Feld-Crawford Act contracts.

World production of rayon in 1937 totaled 1,725,000,000 pounds, setting a new record and comparing with a total of 1,305,000,000 pounds in 1936, according to figures issued yesterday by The Rayon Organon, published by the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc. Japan again led the world in total output, with the United States ranking second.

The leasing by Jack Dempsey of the property at 1,619 Broadway, between Forty-ninth and Fiftieth Streets, for a new bar and restaurant was announced yesterday. This will be the third unit in the Dempsey chain of restaurants.

Speaker Herbert J. Pascoe named today four Republicans and one Democrat to constitute the committee authorIzed by the Assembly to investigate Hudson County balloting at the Gubernatorial election last November.
District Attorney Dewey announced yesterday the appointment of Miss Florence Kelley, 25 years old, of 216 East Sixteenth Street, as a law assistant in his office.

President and Mrs. Roosevelt gave tonight the annual state dinner in honor of the Judiciary, entertaining eighty-six guests headed by the Chief Justice and Mrs. Hughes. The other honor guests were Justice and Mrs. Stone, Justice and Mrs. Roberts, Justice and Mrs. Black, Justice and Mrs. Sutherland and the Attorney General and Mrs. Cummings.
George N. Wallace of New Rochelle, N. Y., who for years has been a prominent racing skipper on Long Island Sound and in ocean contests, last night was made commodore of the Cruising Club of America.

After knocking at the door his last two times out, Miss L. C. White's Buster Boy came through with a victory today when he took the measure of nine other sprinters in the six-furlong allowance race at the Fair Grounds.

The notorious undistributed profits tax seems to be definitely on its way out. The report of the Ways and Means subcommittee abolishes it for the great mass of corporations in all but a nominal form; members of the Senate Finance Committee have indicated that they are still more strongly opposed to it.

President Roosevelt is exploring the political situation in States where difficulties and factional conflicts exist with the aim of strengthening his and party for the primary and regular elections this year.
In the city of Barcelona there is a wide avenue, parked in the center, as THE TIMES correspondent, Mr. Lawrence A. Fernsworth, describes it,

Demand for wool goods this week was generally spotty, but sales were somewhat better than in the preceding two weeks and the belief was general that a pick-up would occur soon, according to the weekly report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service.
Marie Wilson was named by Warner Brothers today for the leading role in the Sam and Della Spewack play "Boy Meets Girl" after a bitter fight which involved several studio factions.

Japanese stocks of manufactured and semi-manufactured goods for export increased substantially during the last few months of 1937 and supplies of imported raw materials and partly manufactured goods declined sharply,

Colby M. Chester, president of the General Foods Company and chairman of the National Association of Manufacturers, testified before the Senate Commission on Unemployment today that two-thirds of forty representative manufacturers and sixteen additional food companies who replied to a questionnaire expected a definite upturn in business during 1938.

Mrs. Pauline Titze, 52 years old, Wife of Theodore Titze, restaurant owner, was found dead from gas yesterday afternoon in the kitchen of their apartment, 156 East Fiftysecond Street. She was found with her head resting on a gas range of which four jets were open.

Lord Louis Mountbatten, who last visited the United States in 1924, when he came here with the then Prince of Wales, arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen en route to Jamaica, where he will play polo with the Hurlingham Club in four games in February.
It took a Senate Judiciary subcommittee just two minutes today to agree unanimously upon a favorable report on the nomination of Solicitor General Stanley Reed to be a Supreme Court justice.
A turn in the trend of wholesale prices in the week ended on Jan. 15 caused a slight increase in the index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, it was announced today.
Mrs. Wat Tyler Cluverius, wife of Rear Admiral Cluverius, commandant of the Fourth Naval District, died today at the Naval Hospital at the age of 62. She was the former Hannah Walker Sampson,
The Association of Foreign Press Correspondents gave a luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Lombardy for Pierre Denoyer, American correspondent of Le Petit Parisien of Paris, who is returning to the head

Chinese military officials notified foreign shipping companies today of the closing of the boom at the entrance of the harbor for the second time in a month following the breakdown of negotiations with ship owners over the amount of "squeeze" to be paid on vessels entering the port.

The Freeport Sulphur Company reported yesterday for the year 1937 a consolidated net income of $2,703,742 after taxes and charges. This is equivalent, after provision for preferred dividends, to $3.30 a share on the 796,381 shares of outstanding common stock and is compared to $2,009,784, or $2.43 a share, earned the year before.

Edward N. Brown, former chairman of the board of the St. LouisSan Francisco Railway (the Frisco Line), testified yesterday in Supreme Court that he had informed none of his fellow-directors of an arrangement which he had made with Speyer Co., private bankers, for acquisition of a substantial stock interest in the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway until virtually all the stock had been acquired.

Fifty Sanitation Department employes will complete their course of training in the use of new snowremoval equipment today at Floyd Bennett Airport and in Van Cortlandt Park, bringing the squad of specially trained men to 224.

It is now final that Katharine Hepburn is out of the cast of "Jane Eyre." In her place the Theatre Guild will hire another actress, the whole thing being scheduled for next month, as far as can be seen at the moment.

Steps to end direct selling of men's wear by wholesalers to consumers in this area were taken yesterday when the Associated Men's Wear Retailers of New York appointed a committee to draw up a contract for .submission to manufacturers.

An outline of the work done by his department in preparation for reciprocal trade agreements with other nations, was given by Dr. Irving H. Taylor, head of the automotive division of the United States Department of Commerce, in an address before the regular luncheon meeting of the Overseas Automotive Club, at the Hotel Lincoln yesterday.
David Pearce of London obtained an acquittal of a house-breaking charge at Croydon today by demonstrating how he could "fake" fingerprints.

Thirty members of Phi Epsilon Philocal fraternity at Rensselacr Polytechnic Institute here, hastily donned clothes and fled in nearzero weather early today when fire swept their three-story fraternity house. The greatest loss.
The six-acre estate of former Senator W. Warren Barbour, in Rumson, N. J., has been sold to the Ward Avenue Company for investment through William H. Hintelmann, broker.
Mari Sandoz, author of "Slogum House" and the winner of the Atlantic non-fiction prize two years ago with "Old Jules," arrived in New York yesterday for a few days' visit. She goes from here
For fifteen hair-raising minutes an experimental Short-Mayo pickabackk" flying boat, carrying a four-engined seaplane locked on its back, tonight made its first flight over Rochester, its birthplace.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Jan. 19: COLONELS Longino, O. H., C. A. C., Gen. Staff Corps, relieved from detail as member Gen. Staff Corps and assignment to Gen. Staff, from Panama Canal Dep't to 69th Coast Artillery. Ft. Crockett, Texas.

Mrs. Leonard B. McKitterick of New York gave a dinner dance to 200 at Patio Moresque tonight honoring Mr. and Mrs. Charles Cotesworth Thomas, who start Saturday on a West Indies cruise, and Mrs. Frank J. Bruen of New York and Miami Beach who will join Mr. Bruen in Havana next week.

The Paramount Building and Loan Association has sold the twofamily residence at 91 Sheridan Street, Irvington, N. J., to Joseph Burke. The house contains eleven room and two baths and stands on a plot 42 by 100 feet.

In time of trouble the unofficial American mind is inclined to propose national advisory committees of private citizens to aid the government. During the World War this idea materialized, but necessarily in official form, and advisory duties became plenary authority in the instances of the War Industries Board and the War Finance Corporation.
Mrs. Edythe Sterling Hammond has arrived in Reno to establish residence preparatory to filing a divorce suit against Ogden H. Hammond Jr., son of the former Ambassador to Spain.
Count Aime de Fleuriau, 'who had served as Ambassador to London for nine years, died in a hospital in Ismailia, Egypt, after having been taken ill on shipboard while on his way to Cairo.
The following reports on the condition of near-by lakes were made yesterday to W. F. Crosby, secretary of the Eastern Ice Yachting Association, and submitted to THE

Spinnakers, including the tent-like parachutes, will not have to be lowered to the decks of New York Yacht Club vessels hereafter during sailing jibes. That was decided in a rule change approved last night at a meeting of that organization held in its clubhouse at 37 West Forty-fourth Street.

Dr. Charles Wesley Day, retired physician and brother of the late William A. Day, former president and later chairman of the board of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, died of a heart ailment Wednesday at his residence at the Hotel Earle after a short illness. His age was 89.
Joseph P. Kennedy, the new American Ambassador to the Court of St. James, will sail for his post Feb. 9 on the Washington, it was announced today at the offices of the Maritime Commission.

Several hours after a 16-year-old boy had been shot to death by detectives as he attempted to rob a liquor store at 4,064 Broadway, the police of the Wadsworth Avenue station yesterday arrested George Relihan, 19, of 616 West 207th Street and accused him of having been an accomplice of the dead youth.

Miss Emily T. Minor, retired Presbyterian missionary, died on Wednesday at the Overton Nursing Home, 583 Riverside Drive, after a short illness. Miss Minor lived at 447 Fort Washington Avenue. Her age was 80.
The feud between the Orthodox Church and the Stoyadinovitch Cabinet over the concordat the latter concluded with the Vatican has ended, apparently with a clear victory for the former.

The State Railroad Commission today ordered all oil fields in Texas shut down for the next six Sundays. The allowable for the other six days of the week was not changed. Currently it is slightly above 1,400,000 barrels daily and will increase owing to completion of wells.

Owners rushing to get their projects on record filed yesterday plans for new buildings to cost millions. Most of the heavy filing was done in Queens, where hundreds of dwellings and tenement houses will be erected.
Japanese Army headquarters in North China were formally moved to Peiping from Tientsin today when General Hisaichi Terauchi, commander of the Japanese forces, arrived and opened the offices.
The first important break in the long period of quiet in steel has developed with the release by Buick Division of General Motors Corporation of orders for substantial flat-rolled steel-tonnage.
The third performance of the season of Wagner's "Siegfried" was seen yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House by a large and enthusiastic audience.

About fifty members of the Banton Boys, who were assistant district attorneys when Joab H. Banton was prosecutor from 1922 to 1929, honored their former chief last night at their annual dinner in Cavanagh's Restaurant in Twenty-third Street.

Gifts and bequests totaling $508,125 received by the New York Medical College and Flower Hospital during 1937 were reported at the annual meeting of the trustees last evening at the hospital 105th Street and Fifth Avenue.

New reductions in viscose process weaving yarns, amounting to 5 cents a pound and bringing the net reduction within a week to 9 cents in the case of 150 denier numbers, were announced last night by American Viscose Corporation, and it was believed other producers would follow immediately. The move, which took the weaving trade by surprise,

In a report to General John J. Pershing, chairman of the national anti - syphilis committee of the American Social Hygiene Association, Charles H. Babcock, executive chairman of the campaign, disclosed yesterday that advance subscriptions in the campaign amounted to $98,000. The goal is $500,000.
Canadian and United States racquet players divided honors in four matches today in the first round of the Canadian championship. Two New Yorkers and two Montrealers prevailed.

The conflict of strike conferees continued today before a conciliation commission, with the chairman making a plea that the steamship companies, if possible, raise their base wage to 50 cents and that strikers lower their demands to that level. There was no response from either group of negotiators.

MANNEQUIN, 'based on the Katharine Brush story, "Marry for Money," screen play by Lawrence Hazard; music and lyrics by Edward Ward, Bob Wright and Chet Forrest; directed by Frank Borzage; produced by Joseph L. Manklewicz for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. At the Capitol.

A prediction that free business enterprise would be destroyed if the higher trend of taxes and the increase of governmental regulation continued was made today by John W. O'Leary, chairman of the executive committee of the United States Chamber of Commerce.
Leases of entire floors to manufacturing concerns and of retail stores in Fifth and Madison Avenues to apparel shops formed the bulk of business rentals reported yesterday.

The pace of buying operations continued to improve in the women's apparel markets during the last few days and all indications are that the volume of orders actually written will show a sharp rise over last week.
An automobile which struck six children saying good-night after a coasting party, killed three of them and injured three others, one critically.

A thorough investigation of the facts and circumstances surrounding the trial and conviction of Fred E. Beal in Charlotte, N. C., before Governor Hurley makes up his mind whether to surrender Beal to the North Carolina authorities, was requested today by George E. Roewer, counsel for Beal.

Hugh John Devore, former Notre Dame football captain and for the past three years head freshman coach and assistant varsity coach and scout at Fordham University under Sleepy Jim Crowley, today was named head varsity coach of football at Providence College.

The House showed its dissatisfaction with the present officer personnel situation in the navy when it overrode its Naval and Appropriations Committees today and voted an amendment to the annual Navy Appropriation Bill designed to stop all selections and promotions of officers for one year.
The Canadian hockey players touring Europe as the Sudbury Wolves today defeated St. Moritz, 5-1. Glen Sutherland, Percy Allen, Red Chipman, Jimmy Russell and Fat McReavy scored the Canadian goals.
Alfred W. Wattenberg, retired New York stock broker, died at his home here today after a heart attack at the age of 71. He was born in St. Louis.

Earie A. S. Hopping of New York, internationally known polo player, today married Mrs. Charlotte Hanna of New York and California, who flew to Manila a week ago. The couple have gone to the Philippines Summer capital at Baguio.
Another of the "natural science evenings" being conducted by the American Museum of Natural History in the interest of its ten-year development program took place last night. Mr. and Mrs. Rufus L.
One convict was wounded fatally, two others shot down by- guards and five captured when eight State Prison inmates attempted to go over the wall under cover of fog tonight.

John W. Owens, editor of The Baltimore Sun since 1927, has been made editor-in-chief of The Sun and The Evening Sun. Mr. Owens announced today that Hamilton Owens, editor of The Evening Sun since 1922, will become editor of The Sun.

Two Bronx residential properties have been purchased by clients of Albert Pfeifer, broker. Albert Klauss bought for occupancy the house at 3,697 Secor Avenue, on a plot 30 by 95 feet, from an institution which recently completed extensive alterations to the property.
Philip Warner, director of ship visiting for the Seamen's Church Institute of New York, died of a heart attack yesterday at the institute's headquarters, 25 South Street.

Short-term borrowing continued to feature State and municipal financing yesterday, both in respect to actual awards made and announcements of future sales. Except for a few issues of serial bonds of small amounts, the new sales are confined to note issues maturing in less than one year.

Markets for wheat showed a firmer undertone today. Removal of hedges against export sales of around 500,000 bushels of Canadian grain, including that for deferred shipment, and insufficient rains in Kansas, resulted in an upturn of around 1 cent a bushel on the Board of Trade here and 2 cents at Winnipeg, but profit-taking developed on the upturn and part of the gain was lost.

A revised code of the State insurance laws, which is the subject of study of a joint legislative committee, was generally approved yesterday morning at a hearing of the committee on the clauses dealing with marine and fire insurance.

Princeton's football forces, 150 strong, meeting at the Nassau Tavern tonight, were advised by Head Coach Fritz Crisler to report for practice in the Spring "so we can get some idea of what we will have for next season."

Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, will not retain the position in the event that it becomes a salaried one in accordance with present reorganization plans, it was disclosed yesterday. Mr. Gay has been president three years.

Miss Brunhilde A. C. Grassi, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Otto Joseph Anthony Grassi of 350. East Fifty-seventh Street, New York, formerly of Scarsdale, was married to Kenneth Edmund Ryan of New York this afternoon at Cedarlane, the home here of the bride's grandmother, Mrs. Hector Grassi.

Further expansion of world economic activity took place last year, according to the survey of international economic conditions in the annual review and forecast number of The Annalist, issued today. Industrial activity continued to increase, and attained new records;

Abolition of all performance bonds on city contracts, a rich source of revenue to political insurance brokers in past years, is provided in a new set of rules governing city contracts introduced yesterday in the Board of Estimate by Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick. Adoption of the rules at the next meeting is expected.

49th St, 533 W, 25x100.5; Harry B. Shapiro to Alex R. Wilson, Mt. Kisco, N Y, execr Clara A. Baab, p m, due July 20, 1938, 4 1/2%: $2.750. 159th St, 549 W. 15.3x99.11; Louis Dembo to Marine Midland Trust Co, trustee, 5 yrs, 5%; $4,500. 187th St, 515 W. 87.6x94.7: Temley Realty Co (Anita Greene, pres) to Cortland Savings Bank at Cortland, N Y, p m, 5 yrs, 3%, to 5%; $97,500.

The French franc bobbed about erratically in the foreign exchange market yesterday but finished with a net loss of 1 7/8 points at 3.34 1/4 cents. In the course of the day it fell as low as 3.29 7/8 cents and sold as high as 3.36 1/2 cents.

An unbiased newspaper is essential to our democratic system, and "if we can sustain a truly free and truly responsible press, democracy will survive even against the bellowing of dictators. and the intrigues of those who are willing to play the dictator's game because that course happens to serve their immediate selfish aims,"

Keith S. McHugh, assistant vice president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, was elected yesterday a vice president of the company. Mr. McHugh has served the Bell System in various capacities more than nineteen years.

In an old cave concealed in Wisconsin's north woods, a former lumberjack, Peter Anders, directed Federal agents last night to the bodies of Charles S. Ross, Chicago kidnapping victim, and James Atwood Gray, an accomplice in the abduction.

An organization of traveling salesmen opposed an increase in railroad rates before the Interstate Commerce Commission today. Opposition was voiced also by meat packers, industrialists, brewers, the National Coal Commission and Representatives of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

Dr. Oliver Wendell Holmes said of his now famous paper on "The Contagiousness of Puerperal Fever" that he did not know that he would ever again have so good an opportunity of being useful as was granted him by the raising of the question which produced the essay.

Decision to discontinue private wire connections with all out-oftown firms was announced yesterday by Frazer Jelke, senior partner in Frazier Jelke Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange. In the future, he said,

Judge Florence Allen of Cincinnati, of the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals, announced today that a decision would be given tomorrow afternoon in the suit filed by eighteen private utilities against the Tennessee Valley Authority.

Dr. John Kunkel Small, director of research and curator of the New York Botanical Gardens, died yesterday at his home, 301 East 207th Street, the Bronx, at the age of 68. Death was caused by heart disease.
A Republican move to force action on the "county bill," sent up to the Legislature by the La Guardia administration, became known tonight.

Benny Friedman, star football player at the University of Michigan and now coach at the College of the City of New York, was on record today as "definitely interested" in the job of head coach at the University of Oregon. He said so in a letter to Athletic Manager Anson Cornell.

Bobby Riggs of Chicago, America's second ranking tennis player, defeated Elwood Cooke, Portland, Ore., in a hard three-set match today to remain in the running for the Dixie championship. Riggs, first-seeded player, defeated Cooke 6--4, 3--6, 6--4.

Robert Moses, Commissioner of Parks, in a statement yesterday blamed the architects employed by the New York State World's Fair Commission for elaborating the plans under which $1,000,000 would be added to the construction cost of the permanent water amphitheatre, part of the State's exhibit at the World's Fair.
The latest March of Time newsreel, entitled "Inside Nazi Germany--1938," was put on view here last night by the Embassy Newsreel Theatre with a screen foreword that it was done "fearlessly."
General Liu Hsiang, chairman of Szechwan Province, died here today of stomach ulcers, from which he had been suffering for a long time. He was 48 years old.

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed on the eligible list of holders of license for service as teacher of general science in junior high schools, as of Jan. 18. 1938, the names of the following applicants, who have been granted said license;

Ambassador Bullitt, who will receive the degree of Doctor, honors causa, from the University at Nancy, left Paris today for a four-day visit on arrival there at 5:40 P. M. During his stay he will be the guest of the prefecture and will receive military honors, and be feted by the municipality.
Huge Insurgent bombers from nearby Mediterranean island bases today struck again with death and terror at the large Spanish Government seaport cities of Barcelona, Valencia and Tarragona.

Stocks strengthened moderately in final hour and closed slightly higher; turnover, $818,310 shares. United States Government bonds irregular; other issues steadier but less active; transactions, $6,811,675.
Howard S. Kennedy, former president of Cluett, Peabody Co., shirt and collar manufacturers, died tonight in a hospital here after an operation. His age was 79.

Lieut. Col Dale F. McDonald of the 17th Infantry was found shot to death today on a lonely road half a mile from Fort Leavenworth. Circumstances of the shooting are being investigated by army officers and Federal agents.

Evidence that drastic age limits are imposed by the Municipal City Service Commission, and to a lesser degree by the State Civil Service Commission, was given by many witnesses yesterday to the Joint Legislative Committee on Discrimination in Employment of the Middle Aged at the second of a threeday public hearing in the State Office Building.

The fight against infantile paralysis needs funds for its support because it is a "luxury disease," Basil O'Connor, chairman. of the New York drive of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, declared yesterday at a meeting at the. Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
The Treasury today invited tenders for an issue of approximately $50,000,000 of ninety-one-day bills to be sold on the usual discount basis to the highest bidders.

An organization of traveling salesmen opposed an increase in railroad rates before the Interstate Commerce Commission today. Opposition was voiced also by meat packers, industrialists, brewers, the National Coal Commission and Representatives of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.
The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that hearings on application filed under the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 would be held as follows:
Elimination of the defending champion featured the semi-final round in the thirty-first annual championship of the Winter Golf League of Advertising Interests at the Palm Beach Golf Club today.
Compton Mackenzie, author whose projected book on the life and abdication of the Duke of Windsor was canceled, won a libel action today against The Leader, a weekly paper.

Declaring that the combined prestige of retail store, wholesaler and manufacturer which is obtainable for national brands outweighs any other selling force, C. B. Larrabee, managing editor of Printer's Ink, told the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute at its convention yesterday that nationally advertised brands possess nine other specific advantages over private brands.

The revised National Housing Act, which President Roosevelt has listed among primary recovery efforts, neared completion today when Senate and House conferees reached a quick solution of differences, and cleared the way for presentation of their report to the House tomorrow.

Presiding Justice Francis Martir of the Appellate Division, First Department, urged a limitation of the number of law schools and law students to eliminate the "ambulance chasing" and similar types of lawyers at the first session yesterday of the sixty-first annual meeting of the New York State Bar Association at the City ??ar Association.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Jan. 19 unless specified: At Naval Operating Base, Norfolk: Acushnet, Vega, Jan. 20.

An acknowledgement that Detroit is making a determined bid to land the proposed Joe Louis-Max Schmeling world heavyweight championship battle came yesterday from Promoter Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century S. C., who has the champion and challenger signed to contracts for the bout.

The internationally famous scientific weekly Nature has been excluded from German libraries because of what the Reich Ministry of Education calls "unprecedented and base attacks against Germen science and the National Socialistic State," it was learned today.

Private capital and private enterprise must be enlisted in the work of slum clearance and housing construction for families of low income if far-reaching results are to be achieved in this field, in the opinion of Alfred Rheinstein, Commissioner of Housing and Buildings.
Arresting Pennsylvanians may become a national pastime for obliging policemen. Pennsylvania has asked for it, and the replies of other States were pouring in today, promising cooperation.

Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, said today that he hoped for early approval of a reorganization plan for the Union Trust Company of Cleveland under which the RFC will provide $17,000,000.

Campagnolli Co., Inc., stock brokers, were ordered yesterday to appear at 11 A. M. on Feb. 7 before John F. Davidson, trial examiner for the Securities and Exchange Commission, to show cause why their license to act as brokerdealers should not be revoked.

Miss Margaret Fanning entertained with a luncheon yesterday in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for Miss Doris Laidlaw, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander H. Laidlaw whose marriage to William E. Dillmeier will take place on Feb. 9 in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral.
The Marine Corps announced the following changes for the week ended Jan. 17:

A nivelty on the program of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Georges Enesco last night in Carnegie Hall, was an early symphony of Franz Peter Schubert, heard for the first time at these coucerts.

United States Ambassador Josephus Daniels today expressed to officials of the Mexican Government "both great surprise and regret" that Mexico had raised her tariffs yesterday from 100 to 200 per cent on major articles of import from the United States.

The proposed "third basket" providing for a special tax on closely held corporations, the undistributed profits tax and the capital gains levies were assailed today by witnesses appearing before the Ways and Means Committee.

A warning to Americans against fascism and a defense of President Roosevelt's use of "brain-trusters" in his Administration were voiced here today by Secretary Ickes in an address before the Association of American Colleges.

Twenty below zero, but the game must go on. The Mille Roche, Ont., hockey team came here to meet Clarkson College in a St. Lawrence Intermediate League match. Early in the game the Canadian goalie froze a foot, and, handicapped by a lack of reserves, a spectator was pressed into service.

Willie Hoppe and Jay Bozeman divided the seventh and eighth blocks yesterday in their 12-block three-cushion match at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy. Hoppe won in the afternoon, 50 to 45 in 43 innings, and Bozeman triumphed at night, 50 to 29 in 45 frames. Hoppe leads, 6 to 2, in the match, which is being contested on the block basis.

Continental Insurance Company--As of Dec. 31, total assets, at convention values, amounted to $86,037,746, compared with $104,436,414 at the end of 1936. Net surplus was $51,759,596 against $71,826,432. Bonds and stocks, based on valuations approved by National Association of Insurance Commissions, are carried at $77,068,188, compared with $96,276,785 on Dec. 31, 1936.

The more or less burning question whether Joe DiMaggio will embellish the sports pages for the next month or so with a stirring holdout siege or quickly accept terms should be answered within the next few hours.

Mrs. Jessie R. Doremus, widow of Robert P. Doremus, a former member of the New York Stock Exchange, left a net estate of $999,866 when she died Sept. 20, 1936, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. Most of the estate was invested in stocks and bonds.

Attorneys for the defense and for the government summed up yesterday at the trial of John J. Dilliard, former president of the State Title and Mortgage Company and Max N. Koven, Edmund J. Donegan and George B. Skiffington, vice presidents, accused of mail fraud and conspiracy in the sale of the company's guaranteed mortgages and mortgage certificates.

The Moore Drop Forging Company has asked for sealed offers for the sale to it of its Class A shares in an amount sufficient to exhaust the sum of $53,451 now in the sinking fund. Shares so offered will be purchased on Feb. 18 at prices not exceding $75 a share.

Mrs. Richard B. Ayer of Glen Cove, L. I., gave a dinner last night in the Sert Room of the WaldorfAstoria for Mr. and Mrs. W. Roosevelt Thompson, Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Ryle, Miss Edna Brokaw, George Cook and Harry Brauer.

Fenton Ave (16-4476), w. s, 377 ft s of Allerton Ave, 30x100; Brim Realty Corp to Brim Ideal Homes, Inc, 391 E 149th St. Broadway (12-3269-3269a), e s, 423 ft n e of 234th St. 150x306: John J. Ryan, referee, to William S. OGutwillig, 40 E 88th St.
Senorita Maria Eugenia Castro, daughter of the Costa Rican Minister and Senora Ricardo Castro Beeche, was married this afternoon in St. Patrick's Church to Oscar Rodriguez of Costa Rica.

The Annalist index of business activity closed the year at the lowest level since November, 1934, according to the annual survey of domestic business conditions in the annual review and forecast number of The Annalist.
The flag-draped coffin of Edward J. Neil, Associated Press war correspondent who was killed by a shell in Spain, tonight rested at the family home.

Mrs. Lucy Wortham James, who in 1924 gave $400,000 for the establishment of a woman's clinic at Johns Hopkins Hospital, died yesterday at her residence, 39 East Seventy-ninth Street. She was 56 years old.
Navy Office authorities issued today a "complete denial of rumors that Japan is building or is planning to build super-warships.

James Roosevelt, son and secretary of President Roosevelt, defended his father against "dictatorship" charges last night in a plea for support of the President's plan to reorganize the executive branch of the Federal Government, which he described as the next major legislation to be put before Congress.
Stocks of whisky at the end of December amounted to 452,402,662 tax gallons, 77,935,506 tax gallons more than at the end of December, 1936, the Alcohol Tax Unit announced today.

The speech against the Wagner-Van Nuys Anti-Lynching Bill which he began six days ago was concluded late today by Senator Ellender. He set a record of twenty-seven hours and forty-five minutes continuous occupancy of the floor, aided by interruptions and quorum calls.

Mark Eidlitz Son, general contractors, have obtained the contract for alterantions to the building at 11 West Forty-eighth Street, the first floor and basement of which will be occupied by the Irving Trust Company. Plans for the work were prepared by Voorhees, Gmelin Walker, architects.

Not a single Communist is now in jail for political activity in the United States and no case involving a Communist for political activity or belief is in the American courts, according to a survey made public yesterday by the American Civil Liberties Union.

Hope for encouragement of private enterprise in the United States such as would be of "economic importance" both to the American nation and to the rest of the world was expressed today by Edwin Fisher, chairman of Barclays Bank, Limited, in his annual address to stockholders.

Mrs. Jessie R. Doremus, widow of Robert P. Doremus, a former member of the New York Stock Exchange, left a net estate of $999,866 when she died Sept. 20, 1936, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. Most of the estate was invested in stocks and bonds.

Attorneys for the defense and for the government summed up yesterday at the trial of John J. Dilliard, former president of the State Title and Mortgage Company and Max N. Koven, Edmund J. Donegan and George B. Skiffington, vice presidents, accused of mail fraud and conspiracy in the sale of the company's guaranteed mortgages and mortgage certificates.

The Moore Drop Forging Company has asked for sealed offers for the sale to it of its Class A shares in an amount sufficient to exhaust the sum of $53,451 now in the sinking fund. Shares so offered will be purchased on Feb. 18 at prices not exceding $75 a share.

Mrs. Richard B. Ayer of Glen Cove, L. I., gave a dinner last night in the Sert Room of the WaldorfAstoria for Mr. and Mrs. W. Roosevelt Thompson, Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Ryle, Miss Edna Brokaw, George Cook and Harry Brauer.
Plans for one great united Protestant Church of England in which Anglicans and Nonconformists would become members of one "visible society" were issued by religious leaders tonight.

Plans for a nation-wide gas refrigeration selling campaign larger in scope than any previously sponsored by the American Gas Association refrigeration committee were adopted yesterday at a meeting of the committee at association headquarters in the Graybar Building.
Eva Le Gallienne should be coming back to the Broadway stage next season in an American adaptation of Marcel Maurette's "Madame Capet." Or, at least, that is what she is telling associates.

ANOTHER impending outburst of basketball at the Garden brought this on. It began with a backfire. Doc Barrett, the veteran Columbia trainer with the imposing shock of white hair, raised his eyebrows and his voice and tossed a backward blast at some Mellows who went through here some weeks ago.

The Egyptian Government how made public the design of three steamps which will be released Wednesday in connection with the International Cotton Congress to be opened at Cairo on that date. Illustrated is a native girl gathering cotton.

President Roosevelt's plans discussed this week at conferences with business leaders of the country will be talked about by some of the pastors in their sermons tomorrow. In liturgical churches there will be a pre-celebration of the Feast of the Conversion of St. Paul, which is next Tuesday.

Henry F. Lutz of New York, director of the Division of State Parks, Conservation Department, and secretary of the State Council of Parks, died early today at the Albany Club of a heart attack induced by influenza. He was 56 years old.

A sharp stoppage and then reversal of the heavy flow of gold into this country occurred in the fourth quarter of 1937, according to a summary of gold and silver movements last year made public today by the Treasury.
Lloyd's reported today that the British steamer Pencarrow, 4,841 tons, was drifting in the Atlantic after battling heavy gales, but had not asked for aid. The ship, bound for St.

The Erie Railroad recently supplied the Interstate Commerce Commission and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation with a statement estimating its net income in 1938 at $2,121,904, provided the I. C. C.

Dr. Hirsch Messman, confessed member of a ring of physicians and attorneys who allegedly drugged and coached holders of insurance policies to show symptoms of heart disease, testified yesterday as a government witness at the trial of five of his co-defendants, accused of using the mails to swindle insurance companies, before Federal Judge Patterson and a jury.
The report of Selected American Shares, Inc., for 1937 shows net income of $424,419, against $340,826 in 1936, and net profit of $142,019 on sales of investments, against $2,065472 in 1936.

British and Canadian seamen who had been brought to New York to serve as the crew of the liner Leviathan on her final transatlantic trip to a Scottish shipyard where she is to be broken up, decided yesterday
Cecilia De Mille, daughter of producer and Mrs. Cecil B. De Mille of Hollywood, tonight was married to Joseph W. Harper, California

The Sunshine Mining Company showed a net profit for 1937 of $5,401,457, according to the preliminary statement made public yesterday. These earnings are after deductions for depreciation, Federal and State income taxes and,

The two top seeded teams in the fourteenth annual Dixie tennis tournament advanced to the doubles final today. Bobby Riggs of Chicago and Wayne Sabin of Los Angeles reached the title match with a victory over Martin Buxby of Miami and Charles Harris of West Palm Beach, 6--4, 6-2, 6--4.
A treatment for the common cold and sinus infections, said to be swift and efficient, was announced tonight by the New England Medical Center.

Sales in commercial printing plants of New York City in December, 1937, showed a decline from sales in the same month of 1936, marking the fourth consecutive monthly decrease, according to a report issued yesterday by the New York Employing Printers Association, Inc.

As a result of "detective" work in the print room of the New York Library, the 400-year-old binding of a rare book has given up some unique data about the manner in which printed pictures were colored in the early days of printing.

A behindthe-scenes campaign to lay aside the Wagner-Van Nuys AntiLynching Bill was started today after Senator Barkley, the majority leader, had issued what amounted to an ultimatum backed by an announcement that night sessions would be employed next week to break the filibuster.

A peace so: program for 1988 embracing the principles of collective security as a basis for the nation's foreign policy, was adopted today at the closing session of the thirteenth conference on the cause and cure of war.

The marriage of Miss Irene Wynkoop, niece of Miss Caroline Wynkoop of this city, to Robert E. Kennedy of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. G. Kennedy of Rhinebeck, took place this afternoon in the Union College memorial chapel. The Rev. Edwin D. Hardin, uncle of the bride and pastor of the Congregational Church in Massena, officiated.

Sales of copper were negotiated yesterday at 10.20 to 10.375 cents a pound c. i. f., European base ports. Although no transactions at less than 10.20 cents could be confirmed, it is understood that final bids for the metal were not better than 10.10 cents.
Stocks closed lower in less active trading; turnover, 791,410 shares. Bonds irregular, United States Government issues lower; trans actions, $7,149,700.

Lloyd Brown and Wes Ferrell, a pair of pitchers, tied today for medal honors in the baseball players' third annual championship golf tournament. A third. Dizzy Dean, who said he had bet $1,000 against $20,000 he would win, didn't, even qualify for the top flight.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: During the last few months we have been reading articles in the newspapers pertaining to the stand taken by trade union locals, consumers' organizations and professional groups in endorsing a boycott of silk hosiery, undergarments and clothing as a weapon against Japan's aggression in China.

McClarty Harbison of the Dunk-Harbison Company has been elected by the governing board as president of the Los Angeles Stock Exchange for his sixth consecutive term. The board also elevated Sidney H. Ellis Jr. of S. H., Ellis, Inc., to first vice

The Securities and Exchange Commission granted today applications by the New York Curb Exchange for unlisted trading privileges in twelve bond or debenture issues and denied similar applications seeking the same privileges in seven others.

D. W. McLenegan, assistant commercial engineer of the General Electric air conditioning department, has been named manager of the General Electric Air Conditioning Institute, it was announced yesterday by J. J. Donovan, department manager.

If the United States Army is seeking "iron men" for recruits, it had better reconsider the case of Frank Earus, 24 - years old, a former weaver of Chelsea, Mass., who was turned down by recruiting officers for a slight disability affecting his hearing.
President Roosevelt conferred with representatives of the automotive industry on elimination of maladjustments and abuses; discussed new tax legislation with Chairman Doughton of the House

Twelve nations, including the United States and Canada, have entered the world and European ice hockey championships Feb. 11-20 inclusive. The United States is regarded as most threatening to Canada's grip on the world title.
The amended Housing Bill as redrafted in conference was adopted today by the House without a record vote after debate which lasted less than half an hour.
Profits of Swift Co., meat packers, for the first two months of the fiscal year which began on Nov. 1,

M. W. Ostrovsky, Soviet Minister to Rumania, took formal leave of King Carol today and disclosed tonight that he would have no successor. He was recalled two week ago. His announcement lent color to reports that Russia was displeased at the anti-Semitism and Fascist tendencies of the new government of Premier Octavian Goga.

A testimonial dinner was given in honor of Julian W. Curtiss, for twenty-five years a member of the Greenwich Board of Education and for twelve years its chairman, at the Greenwich Country Club tonight attended by 300 persons.

The 1938 sugar crop in Cuba was fixed officially at 2,950,000 long tons on a decree of President Federico Laredobru today. According to the decree, producers will be able to export 1,418,174 tons of the new crop, which together with the 309,889 tons now on hand from former crops will complete

Miss Elisabeth F. Raymond, daughter of Mrs. John Sherman Raymond of 380 Riverside Drive and the late Mr. Raymond, was married yesterday afternoon in the Riverside Church to Frank H. Heiss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Heiss of Meridian, Miss., by the Rev. Frank Oliver Hall.
Oliver Cabana Jr., industrialist, civic figure and philanthropist, died this morning at his home on Delaware Avenue. He was 72 years old. Death followed a long illness of a complication of diseases.

The Administration's regret that Mexico has felt itself obliged to raise international trade barriers at a time when many other nations find they can profitably lower them was expressed by Secretary of State Cordel' Hull today, referring to the Mexican decree made public on Wednesday. He added, however,

Miss Celia Randolph Robinson, daughter of Mrs. J. Randolph Robinson and the late Mr. Robinson, has completed plans for her marriage to Julian Peabody, which will take place on Feb. 8 at Mount Pleasant, the home of the prospective bride's aunt, Mrs. Ferdinand W. Roebling, in Paget, Bermuda.

More than 500 persons are expected at the bridge and fashion show this afternoon on the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of Seton Hospital. The revue will feature Winter sports clothes and cruise attire.
Robert Grant 3d of New York, defending titleholder, today reached the semi-finals of the Canadian racquets championship with a 15-3, 15-0, 15-0, victory over his clubmate, D. F. Davis.

President Roosevelt's objective of industrial self-regulation for national recover won apparent acceptance by the automotive industry during a prolonged White House conference today in which manufacturers and sales financing company

L. H. Mercer has been appointed director of wholesale relations of Johnson Johnson. He will continue as director of the Red Cross Products division. E. G. Gerbic has been named assistant director of Red Cross Products in addition to his duties as director of the rollcotton division.

Fresh pork business improved slightly; steer, veal and lamb still slow. Cow, bull and calf were mostly unchanged; other classes were weak, and some sales sharply lower. All kosher meats opened weak with some sales beef sharply lower, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Three preliminary-round matches opened the New Jersey State squash tennis championship at the Short hills Club tonight. A field of thirty-five players is seeking the title now held by National Champion Harry W. Wolf.

The French liner Lafayette will rail today for Plymouth and Havre. Passengers will be Lord Dudley Marley, Mr. and Mrs. Vladimir Palic, Judge and Mrs. A. A. Bruneau, Leon Rothschild, James Bemant, Mr. and Mrs. E. Daltroff, M. P. Labourdette, Jacques Reboud, Mr. and Mrs. Pierre Denoyer, Melville M. S. Fagan, A. St. George Huntington, Edmond Buron, Mr.
Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks 1,141,000 bales, against 1,106,000 a week ago, 1,108,000 two weeks ago, 1,102,000 three weeks ago and 916,000 a year ago;

Two-yearold Geoffrey Knight, whose case appeared hopeless a week ago, has his heart washed twice daily--and a fighting chance to live. Lying in Guy's Hospital, the little blue-eyed son of a Dover miner is puzzled by the parade of surgeons past his cot.

No partner in a brokerage firm belonging to a national securities exchange may guarantee the account of a customer, according to a ruling handed down by the Federal Reserve Board which was made public yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange.

Arnold Futter, in 56 W 65th St, Apartment Locating Bureau, broker. Mrs. John Baldwin, Mme. Yvonne De Saint Cyr, Terence Philip, Mrs. Donald Arthur, in Hampshire House, 150 Central Park South; Douglas L. Elliman Co, Inc, broker.

The New York State Bankers Association will hold its annual midwinter meeting here on next Monday, it was announced yesterday. Morning and afternoon sessions will be held at the Federal Reserve Bank, 33 Liberty Street, and the bankers attending, who are expected to number about four hundred, will be the guests of the officers and directors of the Reserve Bank at luncheon in the bank's dining room.
Queens deals announced yesterday included several apartments as well as industrial properties in various parts of the borough.
