Victor Gelineau, director and chief engineer of the New Jersey State Board of Commerce and Navigation, died of a heart attack today in the Pennsylvania Station in New York while he was returning to his home here from Washington, D. C. He was 52 years old today.

The Swarthmore Phoenix, college weekly, has chosen as editor in chief for the coming year James Wilson, '39, of Louisville, succeeding Kermit Gordon, '38. David Olds, '39, of Pittsburgh, will be managing editor and Joan Woollcott, '39, will serve as feature editor.
The New York Stock Exchange has received a proposal to dissolve the member firm of Harrison Peterson on Feb. 3 and to create

WPA expenditures in this city from the establishment of the Federal relief agency in August, 1935, to Dec. 31, 1937, totaled $478,635,781, according to a recapitulation made public yesterday by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, Local Works Progress Administrator.

Dr. Pontus H. Conradson, oil chemist, died today at the age of 86. A native of Sweden, Dr. Conradson was best known for his method of determining the carbon factor in lubricating oils, a standard in general use by oil refineries today.

In the current annual number of The Annalist, which summarizes the developments of 1937 and attempts to gauge the outlook for the year ahead in many different lines of economic activity, one article of particular interest is that of Lionel Robbins of the London School of Economics.

Dr. Emanuel Lasker, former chess champion of the world, encountered keen opposition against six experts who composed consulting teams in a two-game simultaneous exhibition concluded at the Hotel Alamac early yesterday morning.

Moving with the deliberation of two great chess masters, each of whom seems to hold a profound respect for the other, Colonel Jacob Ruppert, owner of the Yankees, and his latest diamond luminary, Joe DiMaggio, went into their first salary huddle yesterday and emerged with what might be termed a "perfunctory draw."
Mrs. Mary Mulqueen, for many years prominent in educational and philanthropic activities in New York, died of a heart attack Thursday at her home, 10 Park Avenue.

The quintets representing the Barnard School for Boys and Woodmere Academy continued to show the way in their respective divisions of the Metropolitan Athletic Association of Private Schools tournament by scoring victories yesterday.
With the cooperation of the New York State Department of Education, vocational courses in the city school system are to be revised and brought up to date, Morris E. Siegel, director of evening and

An attack on "destructionist tactics" practiced by influential leaders of the Actors Equity Association was made yesterday by officials of the Screen Actors Guild, largest of the actor unions, in the first open split between the organized legitimate stage performers and motion-picture players.

Commercial Paper Yesterday.Thursday. For the best names ...... 1% 1% The quotations are for four-six months' paper. Sales Here Gain Over 1937 Retail trade here continued to make a good comparative showing this week. Department store sales on the average, executives estimated, ran about 1 to 2 per cent above the corresponding week last year.

A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Francis H. Horan of 166 East Ninety-sixth Street on Wednesday at the Lenox Hill Hospital. Mrs. Horan, a former assistant corporatibn counsel of the City of New York. is the former Miss Elizabeth

Net assets of $33,402,126 at the close of 1937 were reported yesterday by the Tri-Continental Corporation. This was equivalent to $3,193.31 for each $1,000 of bank loans and debentures, to $152.84 a share of preferred stock and to $3.26 a share on the common stock.

Close bidding marked the sale yesterday of $22,500,000 of short-term obligations of New York City which resulted in their disposal by the city at the lowest rate ever obtained for similar maturities and a comparable amount.

A 2-year-old child, Theresa Lindley, boarded in the home of Mrs. Jennie Angrosina at 451 Pelton Avenue, West New Brighton, S. I., died of strangulation yesterday when a piece of the skin of an orange she was eating became lodged in her throat.
Charles Leo (Gabby) Hartnett, ready to start his seventeenth season with the Cubs, signed two contracts for 1938 today--one as a player and one as a coach.

At about 4 o'clock yesterday morning an automobile driven by Stanley Super of 1,213 William Street, Hewlett, L. I., was in collision with a car driven by Harris Ther of 1,355 Sterling Place, Brooklyn, at the intersection of Fulton Street and Nostrand Avenue in the Bedford section of Brooklyn.

Princeton's varsity basketball forces tonight gave their best performance of the season in the university gymnasium and before 1,200 incredulous spectators overwhelmed a highly touted University of North Carolina team, 53-32, in the second court meeting of the two institutions.

The Queens County grand jury cleared yesterday William Klein, 49 years old, a B. M. T. motorman, of 160-13 North Conduit Boulevard, South Ozone Park, Queens, of a charge of criminal negligence resulting from the death Sept. 10, 1937, of Mrs. Susanna Bittel, 75, whose marriage on Thanksgiving Day, 1934, to John Bittel, then 26, attracted much attention at the time.
Queen's University defeated the Dartmouth sextet from Hanover, N. H., 9-1, tonight in their International Intercollegiate League game.
Queens took the lead again yesterday in plans for new buildings. The largest project in the borough provides for eleven six-story tenements in Elmhurst to cost $2,365,000.

On his own application: To take effect 12 midnight, Jan. 21. Patrolman William H. Croughan, 105th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Oct, 28, 1912. Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., Jan. 22. Sergeant Richard R. Siegert Jr., from 1st Precinct to 6th Division, designated as acting lieutenant, and assigned to clerical duty.

With many relief recipients confused as to their status under the State Unemployment Insurance Law, Paul Sifton, administrator of the division of placement and unemployment insurance, pointed out last night that it was
Maurice Ames, mezzo-soprano of Boston, who made her local debut two seasons ago, appeared in recital last night at Town Hall before an audience whose number was obviously affected by the bad weather.

Federal funds earmarked for low rent housing projects reached the $158,995,000 mark today. Nathan Straus, administrator of the United States Housing Authority, made the announcement in approving $12,350,000 for four areas.

Deploring "name-calling" and bitterness in politics, Governor Wilbur L. Cross of Connecticut declared last night that "never should a man who is at the head of a government slam either labor or capital." Governor Cross spoke at the annual dinner of the men's groups of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-third Street.

" Tell the readers of THE NEW YORK TIMES that you have talked with Rumania's most ferocious antiSemite and that you found him a pleasant old gentleman of 80 who wishes no harm to any one and wants only this - that every single Jew shall pack up his baggage and leave Rumania," Professor Alexander Cuza declared.

Led by Neil Sullivan and Donald Strachan of Philadelphia, both former national amateur champions, ranking squash racquets players of the United States and Canada started out tonight in the ninth annual Atlantic Coast. championship on the Haddon Hall courts.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Jan. 20: COLONELS Brant, G. C., appointment as brigadier general and as a wing commander terminated; ordered from Langley Field, Va., and assigned as commandant, Air Corps Technical School, Chanute Field, Rantoul, Ill., March 1.
The power of a State Legislature to levy a gross receipts tax on the business of a newspaper was upheld in a three-judge Federal decision here yesterday.
Colonel Clifford Larue Lutkins, big-game hunter and traveler, died in a hospital here last night after a short illness at the age of 72.

With cold weather reviving demand for Winter merchandise and consumer interest in special promotions undiminished, retail sales this week increased 1 to 4 per cent over the preceding week and 2 to 8 per cent over the same week last year, according to the weekly review

Mother Mary Augustine, first dean of the College of New Rochelle and formerly superior of the Ursuline Nuns, died today at the college at the age of 75. She was the sister of Mother Irene, founder of the college, who died three years ago.

Station WOR confirmed yesterday the report of The Brooklyn Tablet that it had refused Father Charles E. Coughlin permission to broadcast over its networks under the terms of a new policy which prohibits "controversial subjects or religious broadcasts on a commercial basis."

Edward Strumn, 42-year-old World War veteran, was found dead early yesterday morning in the bathroom of his home, 516 Chauncey Street, Brooklyn. A rubber tube from the kitchen gas range was in his mouth.

Reno E. Stiteley, former chief of the voucher unit of the National Parks Service, whose confessed embezzlement of more than $84,000 of emergency conservation works funds has been the subject of investigation by the Senate Committee on Public Lands for ten days, was sentenced today to imprisonment for from six to twelve years and to pay a fine of $36,000.
The Polish censor has banned films of the Japanese airplane attack or the United States gunboat Panay on the ground that they might arouse unfriendly sentiment against a friendly nation.

Mrs. Nellie L. Sullivan, first Democratic National Committee woman from Massachusetts and deputy collector of Internal Revenue attached to the Boston office, died this morning at the home of her sister, Mrs. John M. Leary, 344 Highland Avenue, after a three-month illness. She was 70 years old.

The factional fight for control of the United Licensed Officers Association, a union of merchant marine deck and engineer officers affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, was taken yesterday to Supreme Court when Richard O. Patterson, who claims

After hearing arguments from spokesmen for the American Federation of Labor, the Committee for Industrial Organization and the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, the National Labor Relations Board took under advisement today a decision on

Joint committees of American and Brazilian business men have been formed, the State Department announced today, to study the operation of the reciprocal trade agreement between the two countries and to report to their respective governments.

Resolutions urging manufacturers to set up price schedules under the fair trade acts stipulating the levels below which tobacco products should not be sold at wholesale, and also recommending extension of contracts establishing retail prices on branded lines were adopted yesterday at the convention of the National Association of Tobacco Distributors in the Hotel Commodore.

Mrs. Fannie Vedder Flynn, widow of Fireman Jim Flynn, the boxer, who once knocked out Jack Dempsey, died on Thursday in her home at 4,722 Eleventh Avenue, Brooklyn, after a long illness. She was 50 years old.

Municipa ACCOUNTANT, Grade 2 (amended notice). (Certification will be also made from the resulting eligible list to fill vacancies under the new title of junior accountant at $1,800 to $2,400 per annum.)

A battle for the leadership of the Metropolitan Indoor Polo League is the feature of tonight's twin bill at Squadron A Armory, Manhattan. The New York Athletio Club, victims of an upset at the hands of Squadron A last week, will face the undefeated Evergreen Farms team in an effort to climb back into the lead.

The Southern Railway desires to substitute common stock of no par value for its present $100 par value shares because recent values have made the designated par value "misleading," according to a letter written to the Interstate Commerce Commission by S. R. Prince, general counsel of the railroad, on file with the commission.

Naval officers here gave their second dance of the Winter season at the training station tonight for more than 300 guests, most of whom came from many dinner parties. Among those entertaining were Captain G. S. Hathaway and other officers of the hospital staff; Colonel

Formation of the Federated Retailers Buying Corporation as a central buying agency for merchandise in the 5 cent to $1 price field was announced yesterday by H. G. Flanagan of the H. G. Flanagan Buying Corporation.

Though Carnegie Hall is no place for a flea circus, its range of adaptability is now conclusively proven by having housed a "jam session" last week and the flute recital of Lambros Callimahos last night.

A jury which has been hearing evidence for the last two months in the mail-fraud conspiracy trial of four former officials of the State Title and Mortgage Company was locked up at 12:15 A. M. today after deliberating nearly eleven hours.

Net operating earnings of the Cleveland Trust Company of Cleveland, Ohio, in 1937 were $2,345,000, compared to $2,451,000 in 1936, Harris Creech, president, says in his annual report to shareholders. Total net income, including recoveries, was about $3,611,000, before transfer to surplus and reserves, compared to $3,386,000 in 1936.

An industrial council for C. I. O. unions in this city was set up last night by representatives of C. I. O. affiliates, with a combined membership in the metropolitan district of 500,000. A provisional constitution for the new council, which will be similar in function to the A. F.

The Interstate Commerce Commission decided today a five-year-old controversy between the Port of New Orleans and the Port of New York in favor of the northern trade centre. The Commission's ruling destroyed the rate advantage of New Orleans as an export point for automobiles.

W. R. Grace Co. announced yesterday that it will withdraw from the burlap and bag importing business, liquidating all outstanding contracts under the supervision of F. H. Rhoden, who will shortly announce his plans for carrying on the business.

Charles H. Mayo Jr. of Long Beach, L. I., won his second-round match in the annual Miami Biltmore invitation golf tournament today by an overwhelming margin. Another Empire State representative, H. J. Kowal of Utica, winner of the qualifying medal, also advanced to the semi-finals.

Although Robert Cloyes of Cornell won both sprint free-style events, the Pennsylvania varsity swimming team defeated the Ithacans in Hutchinson Pool today, 47-28. This was the first time since 1913 a Cornell team has met the Red and Blue in the tank.

All three defending individual titleholders went down to defeat and the battle for the team crown ended in a triple tie in the annual city P. S. A. L. senior high school swimming championships contested before a capacity crowd in the Columbia University pool last night.

Mrs. Susie Palmer Stewart, the wife of Dr. Francis E. Stewart, physician, who formerly practiced here, died Thursday night at their home in Germantown, Pa., after a brief illness. Her age was 77. Her first two husbands, Franklin D. R. Millar and Edward Linnell, died.

Mrs. Kate Rice Gaither, mother of Rice Gaither of the Sunday department of THE NEW YORK TIMES, died yesterday in New Orleans. She was 67 years old. A native of Florence, Ala., she was married to Julian O. Gaither on Dec. 25, 1886.
Selection of Robert H. Jackson as Solicitor General of the United States, which was tentatively agreed upon when Stanley Reed was nominated to the Supreme Court,

General Ivan Outst T. Spirin of the Red Air Force departed tonight for Paris to lay Soviet aviation records for 1937 before the General Conference of the International Federation of Aeronautics and in particular to claim

The Seventh Pan-American Medical Congress, which opened here Jan. 19, closed late this afternoon. Dr. Jose Arce of Buenos Aires, Argentina, was unanimously elected president of the Pan-American Medical Association.

Rolling up record figures for both exports and imports during December, National Socialist Germany was able to close 1937 with the biggest foreign trade gains of any large industrial country except the United States and such smaller countries as Belgium and Czechoslovakia.
Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

Mr. and Mrs. Abram I. Elkus entertained with a supper dance last night in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for Mr. and Mrs. Jefferson Penn of Reidsville, N. C., after taking their guests to a theatre. Others in the party were Mr. and Mrs. Henry Lee Norris, Dr.
The Brooklyn College basketball team overwhelmed an alumnus quintet, 51 to 29, at the new Brooklyn College gymnasium last night.
Two items out of popular literature, with life imitating fiction, were recorded in our paper yesterday. Like a page from Charles

Another assassination calculated to strike terror in the hearts of any and all Chinese who would cooperate with the Japanese, even indirectly, to establish normal conditions in Chinese areas surrounding Shanghai foreign settlements was carried out at the border
Premier Mussolini's newspaper, II Popolo d'Italia, extolled today the performance of Italian troops in the capture of Santander, Spain, last August.
The knowing fish buyer who buys his fish by their feel and odor now has science on his side with a new electrical device developed by the Bureau of Fisheries.

Representatives of student, women's and foreign relations groups called yesterday on United States Ambassador Nelson T. Johnson to present a letter expressing apprehension over the reports that Japan was seeking a $50,000,000 credit in America.

The Rev. Dr. Frederick C. Grant, dean and president of Seabury Western Theological Seminary, Evanston, announced today that he would resign his post to accept the Edward Robinson Chair of Biblical Theology at Union Theological Seminary,

The United States Supreme Court will soon have an opportunity to decide for the first time whether a worker can be discharged if he refuses to join a labor union with which his employer has signed a closed shop contract.

Twenty thousand Japanese cavalrymen and artillerymen were reported today to be moving to the southern Shantung Province front to bolster an offensive that has been virtually stalled by sleet, snow and fierce Chinese resistance.

The British Professional Soccer Players Union, whose members entertain millions of football fans, are demanding that their minimum wages be raised from [Pound]4 to [Pound]5 a week and the maximum from [Pound]8 to [Pound]9.

Henry Armstrong, world featherweight champion, made it twentyeight knockouts out of twenty-nine of his last professional fights tonight when he added the name of Frankie Castillo, Los Angeles, to the list in the third round of a scheduled ten-round overweight bout. Armstrong weighed 129,

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Dizzy Dean is back in the headlines again. The St. Louis Cardinals have offered Dean a $10,000 contract for 1938. Last year Dean received about $25,000, but he did not have a very good season.

The Maritime Commission received today from Johnson Higgins, marine insurance brokers of New York City, remittances aggregating $2,850,000, representing collections made by the brokers for insurance on the liner President Hoover, wrecked recently on an island near Formosa.
The Foreign Office has instructed Sir Robert L. Craigie, British Ambassador to Japan, to investigate recurring reports that Japan is building or planning battleships of 43,000 tons.

Methodical burglars working with an acetylene torch and two gas tanks early today entered Rahway's new $90,000 postoffice, burned their way into a large safe and escaped with $48,424, of which $47,322 was in stamps and $1,102 in cash.

An appeal to the Supreme Court in the TVA case will be taken as soon as possible, Wendell L. Willkie, president of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, said today when word was received of the decision at Chattanooga.

A second "Tea Week" will be launched on Monday by the Tea Bureau, as part of its current advertising campaign to increase volume in this country. The initial effort during the week of Nov. 28, 1937, brought into the bureau a great variety of detailed reports

A wage and working agreement affecting 2,000 unlicensed marine workers on forty-six ships of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Co., Inc., was signed yesterday afternoon by officials of the concern and negotiators for the National Maritime Union.

Glenn Cunningham's mile debut of the indoor season will feature the Grover Cleveland-Osceola Club track games at the Seventh Regiment Armory tonight. The mile king will run his first board race at eight furlongs after preliminary trials along 800-meter and 1,000yard routes.
The Rev. Dr. Dinsdale Young, one of the most eminent Methodist ministers in Great Britain, died of jaundice today in his home at Richmond at the age of 76.

Lloyd's reported today that the 8,235-ton Brazilian passenger steamer Bage and the 4,968-ton Norwegian motor vessel Brattdal had been damaged badly in a collision off the German port of Cuxhaven, at the mouth of the Elbe River.

A guaranteed weekly wage of $14 for all women and minors employed in the laundry industry in this city was recommended to Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner, yesterday by the laundry minimum wage board, the first board to report under the new State Minimum Wage Law.

Senator Edward R. Burke of Nebraska, one of the Democratic leaders in the successful Congressional fight against President Roosevelt's Supreme Court bill last year, warned the New York State Bar Association at the Waldorf-Astoria

More than passing interest has been aroused by the resolution introduced recently in Congress by Senator Sheppard of Texas calling for an amendment to the Constitution making every homestead exempt from taxation up to $5,000 of its value when occupied by the owner or his dependents.

H. C. Orton, chairman of a committee for holders of preferred stock of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad, and E. A. Pierce of E. A. Pierce Co. have been elected directors of the railroad. Frederick H. Ecker,

Egypt's jubilation over the royal marriage yesterday continued today with undiminished zeal. Friday being the Moslem Sabbath served to prolong the holiday. Singing and dancing in the streets continued, with trolleys, buses and cars crowded to the limit.

The Westport Badminton Club captured the Metropolitan Badminton Association's women's Class A team title for the fifth consecutive year by defeating the Central Badminton Club, 4 to 1, in the championship play-off on the courts of the Manhattan Badminton Club last night.

John D. Biggers, Administrator of the Unemployment Census, told the Senate Unemployment Committee today that the rebound from the recession would be sharp and that it might bring with it problems of a too rapid recovery.

One hundred and fifty residents of Westchester County attended tonight the annual Robert Burns dinner given by Clan Stewart, White Plains unit of the Order of Scottish Clans. The dinner was held at the Hotel Roger Smith here. John B. T. Lambert of Yonkers was toastmaster.

In a fire started when she accidentally overturned the coal stove, spilling live coals on a pile of papers on the floor, Mrs. J. Dicklan, 67 years old, a widow, was burned to death at 9:35 o'clock last night in the ground floor apartment

The first five railroads to report for December showed an aggregate drop of 67.2 per cent in net operating income for the month. The result reflected in part the fact that in December, 1936, the Southern Pacific and the Chesapeake Ohio, two of the companies included in the compilation, had exceptionally high earnings.

Commodore George V. Smith was re-elected to head the American Yacht Club at its annual meeting. The other officers for this year are Dave H. Morris Jr., vice commodore; Ralph P. Manny, rear commodore; Charles Eldredge, treasurer;

Owen D. Young, chairman of the board of the General Electric Company, was designated today by the Federal Reserve Board as chairman and Federal Reserve agent for the Federal Reserve Bank of New York for the remainder of the year. Mr.
Professor William Henry Pickering died Monday at Mandeville Observatory, where he had lived for three decades. He was buried in Mandeville. His age was 79.
The market for railroad issues again was the focus of attention in bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of carded gray goods as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

The marriage of Miss Louise Ann Christison, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Christison of Methuen, Mass., to Allison Fuller Kelsey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Kelsey of Montclair, N. J., took place here yesterday afternoon in the Central Presbyterian Church. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. Theodore C. Speers.

A powerful bomb fashioned for an asserted attempt to blow up the Japanese liner Hiye Maru was found under a Seattle pier today and police began investigating reported ramifications of the unsuccessful plot.
The place of women in politics was emphasized in three addresses yesterday morning at the sixty-fifth convention of the Long Island Federation of Women's Clubs at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

As church bells tolled his age, 38, the body of Edward J. Neil Jr., Associated Press war correspondent who was killed in Spain, was taken today to a last resting place in a snow-covered, hillside cemetery.

Both Manhattan and Long Island University, which of recent weeks have been turning in fine jobs on the court, will attempt to vanquish Pennsylvania foes tonight when the Jaspers meet St. Thomas of Scranton and the Blackbirds encounter Duquesne of Pittsburgh

Criticizing American schools and colleges for "failing so miserably to give students an adequate liberal education," Professor Mortimer J. Adler of the University of Chicago denied yesterday in a speech before teh National Board of Review of Motion Pictures that the film industry had any educational responsibilities.

After holding steady and dull in the earlier trading yesterday, the stock market weakened in the last hour and leading issues closed with net losses of fractions to 2 points and a few lost more than that.

The work of hoisting a 52-foot wooden mast to the top of the 400foot building at 1,450 Broadway, at Forty-first Street, to serve as the support for an ultra-short-wave radio aerial over which WOR programs are to be broadcast simultaneously on 7.5 to 10-meter waves, was begun yesterday.

Milton A. Rauh, for many years a manufacturer of leather goods in New York, died yesterday after a long illness at his home, 911 Park Avenue. He was 58 years old. Mr. Rauh was born here and attended Hotchkiss School before entering the business of his father, S. Rauh Co., 642 Sixth Avenue.

Houghton Mifflin has announced two literary fellowships for 1938. These will be awarded to promising writers who are in need of financial assistance to complete projected books and will carry an award of $1,000 in addition to subsequent royalties.

Dr. Marie L. Chard, a member of she board of trustees of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children and former head of the institution's surgical department, died on Thursday at her home, 320 East Fifty-seventh Street. She was 70 years old.
Lady Federal, eighth in her previous start after winning two straight, refused to quit today and as the result won the mile and a sixteenth race for players which headed the Fair Grounds card.

MANHATTAN BRILL, MAX D. (Jan. 19). Estate, more than $20,000. To Madeline Brill, 15 E. 69th St.; Ruth B. Kugelman, Derry Brusk, Abington, Pa.; Dorothy B. Steckler, executrix, 68 E. 86th St.; Alice B. Aub, executrix, 4,057 Beechwood Ave., Cincinnati, Ohio, and D. Dudley Brill, executor, 755 Park Ave., children, specific paintings and residue equally.

The Interstate Commerce Commission heard meat packers from Chicago and representatives of livestock producers assert today that the proposed 15 per cent increase in railroad freight rates would reduce the purchasing power of livestock farmers and thus delay business recovery.
Memorial meeting of the American Association of Teachers of French in honor of Professor Alexander Guy Holborn Spiers, Harkness Auditorium of Columbia University, 11 A. M.

The oil conspiracy case which has been on trial before Federal Judge Patrick T. Stone here since Oct. 4, with a total cost to both sides of about $3,000,000, was submitted to the jury at 1:33 this afternoon.
Death benefit claims totaling 1,452 were filed in 1937 with the State Department of Labor under the Workmen's Compensation Law, it was announced today by Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner.

Exception is taken in the current issue of Editor Publisher to many of Ferdinand Lundberg's allegations concerning the wickedness of the press and its control by financial interests in his book, "America's 60 Families."

A group of women fliers is scheduled to join today with pilots from the National Guard, navy, Coast Guard, police and airlines in an "air demonstration against infantile paralysis," to aid the fundraising campaign of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

The National Public Housing Conference at its annual meeting here yesterday reported that despite appalling slum conditions in cities throughout the country and even with the great legislative gains made this year, the public housing idea still was in the "propaganda" stage.

Registering its sixth victory in as many league engagements, the St. Francis Prep quintet tightened its grip on first place in the Brooklyn division of the C. H. S. A. A. championship race by downing Bishop Loughlin Memorial High, 17-10, on the loser's court last night.

R. Reed Wills, for more than thirty years prominent in Maryland civic and political life, died Wednesday at his home, Bel Alton, at the age of 80. For fifteen years he was president of the Southern Maryland Bank of La Plata and had been State tobacco inspector.

PEOPLE often enjoy reading other people's mail. In ordinary life-and without permission-to do this is apt to be dishonorable. In the letters-to-the-editor column it is usually informing. And in the best volumes of published correspondence, written by the illustious, the indiscreet and the notorious, it is frequently downright entertaining.
Emile Cohl, who is credited here with having invented the animated cartoon, forerunner of Walt Disney's productions, died today in obscurity.
New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals only $12,865,525, to be represented by fifty-four municipalities. This compares with the revised total of $33,843,757 for this week.

The Kentucky House of Representatives adopted unanimously today a resolution commending Captain Robert J. Foster of Newark, N. J., for his "kindly, sympathetic and courageous" deeds during the Ohio River flood a year ago.
Will Dyson, Australian cartoonist and for many years staff cartoonist of The London Daily Herald, died of a heart attack in Chelsea today at the age of 55.
Gardiner Lathrop, former general solicitor for the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railroad, died today in Milwaukee, where he had made his home for several years. He was 87 years old.

Since an opportunity to watch Sonja Henie pirouette on ice is justification in itself for any film's existence, Twentieth Century-Fox is to be doubly thanked this morning for adding an ingenious script and a sheaf of engaging supporting players to its skating star's latest picture. "Happy Landing,"

Despite daylong appeals by trade union officials, longshoremen at Middlesborough, Yorkshire, refused tonight to load the 10,421-ton Japanese steamer Haruna Maru with iron and steel cargo as a protest against Japan's policy in the Far East.

After a detailed computation of touches scored and sustained, Mrs. Dolly Funke of the Greco Fencing Academy was declared winner of the women's invitation foils competition at the Salle d'Armes Vince last night. With her clubmate,
Following is the text of the Federal court's decision on the Tennessee Valley Authority: In the District Court of the United States for the Eastern District of Tennessee, Northern Division.

The Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company, Springfield, Mass., in its statement for 1937 reports a gain of $36,998,391 in insurance, bringing the total to $1,911,059,101. Admitted assets amounted the to $609,688,369, a gain of $37,575,412.
A wage difference of 10 cents an hour today prevented a settlement of the longshoremen's strike here, Luis Villaronga, chairman of the Mediation Board. reported.

Tomorrow will be the eightieth birthday of Beatrice Webb (Lady Passfield), tireless investigator of social problems, who forms with her husband, Sidney Webb (Lord Passfield), one of the most famous literary partnerships in England.

The Board of Higher Education has granted to Dr. William A. Boylan president of Brooklyn College, a three-month leave of absence to recuperate from a prolonged attack of neuritis, his secretary, Miss Margaret M. Effrige, announced yesterday. Professor Mario E. Cosenza,

A two-way metamorphosis is taking place in the Rhineland. In Belgium businessmen traveling to Germany say that business is better than last year. In this region superficial evidence bears out that report.

The first Allison tuna caught off Miami this year, and a record fish for the Miami Rod and Reel Club, was taken last week by Don C. Kipplinger of Omaha, Neb., who was fishing with Captain W. W. Howd aboard the Dawn. The fish tipped the scales at 144 pounds, 56 pounds better than the record club fish.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

The preparation of three new sulphur compounds, which tests on mice have shown to be from five to thirty times as good as sufanilamide for combating bacterial infection, is announced in the current issue of Public Health Reports, published weekly by the United States Public Health Service.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Daniel W. Farnsworth of this place of the marriage on Nov. 6 in Rockville, Md., of their daughter, Miss Frances Farnsworth, to Francis Murray Jaeckel, son of Mrs. Ethel Tracy Jaeckel of New York and Major H. Francis Jaeckel Jr., of New York and Westchester.

The effect of the Robinson-Patman act and the Miller-Tydings act will eventually be a leveling off of prices at which goods may be bought from manufacturers, and of the prices at which they are sold at retail, according to views developed in a symposium at the closing session of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute's convention at the New Yorker Hotel yesterday.

Today's major events: "Barber of Seville," afternoon; "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci," evening, Metropolitan Opera House; Mischa Elman, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 3 P. M.; Moriz Rosenthal, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 P. M.;

Downtown business properties changed hands in deals announced yesterday. The Bankers Trust Company sold to an investing client of Isidore Ehrman, attorney, the building on a lot 32 by 70 feet at 171 Perry Street in the heart of the new
Thomas Rossiter Barnum, Yale historian, dictionary contributor and curator of a special edition of Yale memorabilia, died last night at his home here after a brief illness.
The mechanized Cavalry Brigade at Fort Knox, Ky., will probably be expanded to a division, the first mechansized division in American military history.
Japanese business men expect valuable advantages from the reduction of Chinese tariffs effected by the Peiping provisional government.

The United States had in 1937 a favorable balance of about $250,000,000 in its foreign trade, experts of the Department of Commerce reported today. This is more than twice as large as the $100,000,000 predicted about a month ago by Secretary Roper.

Wheat futures declined 7/8 to 1 3/8 cents a bushel today on the Board of Trade here. A feature of the market was the selling of wheat against purchases of corn by local operators which disclosed a lack of support in wheat and some stop loss orders were uncovered on the way down.

Scoring three goals in each period, the hard-skating New York Rovers overwhelmed the Bronx Tigers by a score of 9 to 2 last night at the New York Coliseum in an intracity game in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League race.

Several residential properties were included in Westchester deals reported yesterday. The six-story apartment known as The Dorset, at 1,465 Midland Avenue, Bronxville, was bought and quickly resold by

Charles S. Ross, kidnap victim of Peter Anders, logger and confessed bank robber and murderer, was not shot to death, but was killed by a blow on his head that shattered his skull, according to J. Edgar Hoover, chief of the Federal Bureau of Investigation of the Department of Justice.

Fred Ferry defeated Ellsworth Vines last night in the fifth match of their professional tennis tour, 6-3, 6-2. Perry's victory left him trailing Vines by a single match, 3 to 2. Vines and Walter Senior beat Perry and Berkeley Bell, 9-7, 6-2, in doubles.

Mr. and Mrs. C. E. Rood of this city have announced the engagement of their daughters Miss Hazel Rood, to William R. Weems of Atlanta. Miss Rood was graduated in 1935 from the Juilliard School of Music in New York, where she is now taking a post graduate course. Mr.

Five Moro outlaws were killed and ten wounded in a day-long battle between Philippine soldiers and Moros at Paudak Fort at Tajaya in Lanao Province today. Four soldiers were wounded, one seriously.
Japan's basic peace terms, as communicated to China through the German Ambassador, Dr. Oskar Trautmann, were listed today in the Diet by Foreign Minister Koki Hirota as follows:

Picturing the South as the country's last great economic frontier and urging the press of this region to measure up to its responsibility of power during a new era of unprecedented Southern development, John Temple Graves 2d

The Securities and Exchange Commission has issued an order making effective a declaration by American Water Works and Electric Company covering the issue and sale in connection with a bank credit of $6,000,000 of its 3 1/2 per cent promissory notes of which $3,000,000 are to be dated on or before Jan. 26, and $3,000,000 on or before July 15.

Mrs. J. Francis A. Clark has come from Wrentham House, her villa in Newport, and is at the Pierre for several weeks. The Earl and Countess of Rosse and Viscount and Viscountess Weymouth of London, who arrived on the Bremen, are at the Ambassador.

Movements of vessels follow; all dates are Jan. 20 unless specified: Algorma, San Pedro to San Diego. California, San Francisco to San Pedro. Charleston, at Balboa. Cormorant, Kitty Hawk to Washington Yard, via Yorktown.

Pearl St; Alfred E. Smith to Catherine A. Smith, his wife, 820 5th Ave; quitclaim. Cherry St, 172; Elsa Egger to Katherina Welsch. 521 E 84th St; mtgs $2,500 and $7,400 held by grantee. 11th Ave, 582; George W. Hunt. referee, to Teachers Building Loan Assn, 103 Park Ave; foreclosure ($4.50).
After two weeks of feuding following Barbara Stanwyck's refusal to appear in "Distant Fields," a rebellion that caused her to be suspended, the actress and RKO today signed a peace pact and the star

One-year contracts were signed today by the American Newspaper Guild and the two Chicago Hearst newspapers, The Evening American and The Herald and Examiner, averting a threatened strike over employe dismissals.
The Procurement Division of the Treasury Department rejected today for the seventh time offers to purchase the site of the old Newark, N. J., Postoffice at Raymond Boulevard and Broad Street.

Henry Kistemaeckers, novelist, playwright and president of the French Society of Authors, died today at the age of 65. Born in Belgium, he was naturalized here in 1900 after his first literary successes in Paris.

A plea in morning newspapers by Gaetano Fafarella, State conservation officer of game, that something be done to save the lives of 5,000 wild ducks starving along the South Shore, brought prompt results. Henry Faxon, a retired banker,

Mrs. Sophie Marsh Gondran, a philanthropist, died on Thursday in her home at 135 Central Park West after an illness of four months. She was 78 years old. Mrs. Gondran gave the building at 73 Horatio Street to the Winfield Day Nursery and also contributed generously to child adoption work.
Salary squabbles of the DiMaggios became a unanimous family affair today. All three DiMaggio brothers are baseball holdouts.

Firmness in mining stocks and gilt-edge issues stood out in the generally steady stock markets here today. Buying of gilt-edge securities found the market somewhat short. War loans and defense bonds advanced.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deduction for operating expenses and normal Federal income charges, but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings. Figures, in many cases, are subject to final adjustment.
The Callahan Zinc-Lead Company announced yesterday that it had received sufficient subscriptions to its recent stock offering to enable it to exercise the option to purchase Livengood Placers, Inc.

Following confiscation of the regular issue of Julius Streicher's Nazi newspaper, Der Stuermer, on Wednesday, the police seized today a special number devoted to "racial pollution" and demanding the death penalty for Jews who are found guilty of being intimate with "Aryan" women.

Organization of a new division of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, the fourth to be inaugurated in the group's quarter century history, will be announced today with the formation of a Bankers Division to consist of mortgage loan departments of banks and trust companies. H. R. Templeton,

A "guilty plea" to charges of discrimination in the city civil service against middle-aged job seekers, a defense of that policy, and an announcement that some age maximums would be lowered still further, were among Mayor La Guardia's contributions yesterday to data

Major W. L. Ray, former United States Army officer who was supervisor of the Federal alcohol tax unit in New Jersey and Delaware, died last night at the age of 59 after a heart attack at his home here.

Burrell Memorial Hall, in the newly furnished basement of the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, will be dedicated on Tuesday at 8:15 P. M. The hall is named for the Rev. Dr. David James Burrell, who was pastor of the church from 1891 until his death in 1926.

While total internal revenue of the Federal Government increased by $963,893,249 in the last half of the calendar year 1937, over the corresponding period of 1936, effects of the business recession were discerned in a drop of $7,133,303 in documentary and stamp taxes, the Bureau of Internal Revenue reported today.
Fraternities have a rightful place on the campuses of American colleges, the American Association of Colleges declared by resolution today in the final session of its annual meeting.
Burglars invaded Earl Baldwin's country home, Astley Hall, today and were reported to have stolen the former Prime Minister's valuable collection of old coins.
Tourists in Bermuda in 1937 exceeded all records with a total of 83,092, representing a 3 per cent increase over 1936. Arrivals from the United States on ships of regular services were 55,687.

Police of suburban Dearborn arrested 352 members of the United Automobile Workers of America who attempted to distribute union literature at the gates of the Ford Motor Company's River Rouge plant today.

The total number of vehicles of all classifications that used the Triborough Bridge last year was 11,171,956, or an average of 30,608 a day, it was disclosed by the annual report of the Triborough Bridge Authority for the year ended Dec. 31, made public yesterday.

An all-Mozart program was presented by the Federal Opera Chorus and the Greenwich Orchestra last night at the WPA Theatre of Music. The assisting artists were Milton Kaye, pianist; Margaret Stevenson, soprano; Marian French, contralto; William T. Mitchell, tenor. and Attilio D'Amico. baritone.

Investigating magistrates who have been interrogating residents of Teruel one by one during the last fortnight have accumulated evidence execution of at least 3,000 persons because of their Leftist or labor
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the last three days:

Mrs. Lucius Pond Ordway entertained tonight with a dinner at her residence on Panyan Road, having as her guests Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Fatio, Mr. and Mrs. J. Jay O'Brien, Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Waterbury, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Bayard Swope, Mr. and Mrs. Aksel Wichfeld, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick M. Alger Jr., Mrs. Frank L. Crocker, Mrs. Glendenning Frazer, Mrs. Wesson Seyburn, Mrs. Dodge

A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Tell C. Schreiber Jr. of 155 East Seventy-third Street on Thursday at the Leroy Sanitarium. Mrs. Schrelber is the former Miss Pamela D. Prime, daughter of Mrs. R. Shaw-Kennedy Coleman of this city and William A. Primo Jr. of Cedarhurst, L, I.

Webster Ave (11-3142, w s. 162 ft n of 179th St, 62x100; Etmasol Realty Corp to Cornelius J. Smyth, 22 E 40th St, trustee; extends mtg to Jan. 15, 1943, at 5 per cent; $73,500. Tiebout Ave (11-3143), s e cor of 184th St, 113x64xirreg: Remlok Leasing Corp to Manufacturers Trust Co: installments, 4 to 4?? per cent: $33,000.

GOVERNORS ISLAND Capt. Carlyle Morris, Med.-Res., Spring St. and Lake Ave., Metuchen, N. J., 27th Station Hospital, is ordered to active duty, effective Jan. 19, at Raritan Arsenal, N. J., for training. He will revert to inactive status on Feb. 1. Ensign George J. Quick, C.-V. U.S.N.R., now on active duty with CCC Co. 3264c, Camp S-113, Camden, N. Y., is continued on active duty until July 24, 1938.

Harris Tomashoff, druggist, store in building under construction at southeast corner of Madison Ave and 35th St; Walter Samuels, Inc, brokers. Simor. Kernberg, department store, store at southeast corner of 2d A and 102d St; Samuel Levy, broker.

Four Americans were detained by the police today for alleged connection with a "poolroom game." They gave their names as Morris H. Simmons, 61 years old, of June Street, Worcester, Mass.; Edward Rogers, Los
The New York World's Fair Corporation announced yesterday a schedule of dates for filing applications for twenty-three different subdivisions of its $50,000,000 concessions program.

A net decrease of about 300,000 in employment and a drop of $15,800,000 in weekly payrolls in December, as compared to November, were reported by Secretary Perkins today, on the basis of the Labor Department's monthly survey of employment and payrolls.

On behalf of certain independent holders of debentures of the Utilities Power and Light Company, a new plan for reorganization of the utility has been submitted to the Securities and Exchange Commission, according to an announcement in Chicago yesterday by Robert N. Golding, counsel for a group of debenture holders.
The action of the conferees on the Housing Bill in rejecting Senator Lodge's "prevailing-wage" amendment is extremely encouraging.

A long putt for a par 4 on the thirteenth gave Max B. Kaesche of Ridgewood, N. J., his winning margin and enabled him to capture the thirty-first annual championship of the Winter Golf League of Advertising Interests at the Palm Beach Golf Club today.

Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan's order staying the City Council from further attempts to organize was attacked yesterday as an unconstitutional judicial invasion of the rights of legislative bodies. The attack was made by Corporation Counsel William C.

The Indiana Democratic Committee today accepted the resignation of Thomas D. Taggart as National Committeeman and unanimously elected Frank McHale, Indianapolis and Logansport lawyer, to succeed him. Mr. Taggart,

A strike of laborers at the plant of the Tampa Shipbuilding and Engineering Company held up today the drydocking of Commodore W. K. Vanderbilt's $3,000,000 yacht Alva, brought here from Miami for repairs. Union spokesmen said the strikers wanted an increase in wages from 25 to 40 cents an hour for an eight-hour day.

George C. Johnson, chairman of the Lakewood Township Committee; Ira A. Schulman, attorney for the Lakewood Hotel Association, and William H. Styer, vice president of the Lakewood Chamber of Commerce, were arrested in Lakewood tonight and brought here for arraignment on charges of conspiracy
An army airplane crashed and burned near here today, killing its two occupants, Lieutenants Lewis E. Countway and Earle T. McArthur, both stationed at Fort Bragg.

Henry Kraver, a former New York newsboy, who became a business leader here, died today at the age of 78. With savings accumulated from a $50-a-month store clerk's job, Mr. Kraver rose to the presidency of a distillery and a brewery before prohibition.

Three-yearolds that are preparing for the $20,000 added Flamingo will have their first stake opportunity of the meeting in the $5,000 added Hialeah Stakes, the Miami Jockey Club's feature race tomorrow.

The girls' basketball team of the Savage School of Physical Education defeated the Brooklyn College sextet, 27 to 15, at the losers' gymnasium in Brooklyn last night. Miss Helen Smith, Savage's captain, captured high-scoring honors with thirteen points. The victors led, 11-10, at the half.

Four directors of the Narragansett Racing Association, backed by six investment houses in New York, Philadelphia and Buffalo, tonight joined in a move to oust Walter E. O'Hara as president and managing director of the association.

The body of 11-year-old Theodore Scherny of 116-33 Sutphin Boulevard, Jamaica, Queens, was recovered by police yesterday from beneath four feet of refuse in a dump in Baisley Park, Jamaica, into which he had fallen while playing.

Dr. and Mrs. Rufus Cole of Cohomong Wood, Mount Kisco, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth A., Cole to William G. F. Botzow, son of Mrs. F. Alexander Krause of Orange, N. J., and the late Hermann E. Botzow.

Stuyvesant St. 21, 28.9x82xtrreg: Stuyvesant Development, Inc (David Hollander, pres), to Josephine Klein, 145 W 23d St; pr mtg $18,500, installments, 6% $3,600. 7th St, 61 E, 25x97.6; Mary Zimmerman, formerly Mary Berkowitz, to Savings

Mrs. Cora Pynchon Mallory, widow of Henry Rogers Mallory and mother of Clifford Day Mallory, both outstanding maritime figures, died here today of pneumonia at her home, Bonnie Cliff, Byram Shore. Her age was 84.

Members of the board of governors of the Investment Bankers Association of America opened their annual midwinter meeting tonight at the Seaview Golf Club, Absecon, near here. About forty-five bankers from all sections of the country are expected to attend.
A compromise "ever normal granary" farm program will be ready for final Congressional action next week, House and Senate conferees predicted today.

Miss Janice Edith Dolan, daughter of State Senator and Mrs. William A. Dolan of this place, was married here this morning in St. Joseph's Church to Philip J. Kelly, son of Mrs. Mary Kelly of Stanhope. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Michael J. Donnelly, who also celebrated the nuptial mass.

Mrs. Fanny Platt Dukinfield, widow of Charles Dukinfield, former president of the Liverpool Cotton Exchange, died yesterday in her home at Great Meols, Cheshire, England, according to word received by her son, John P. Dukinfield, noted herbalist, of Huntington Station, L. I. A native of Cheshire, she was about 83 years old.

Although the Jockey Club at its annual meeting set April 15 as the opening date for the metropolitan racing season, Edward P. Kilroe, president of the Metropolitan Jockey Club, which runs the Jamaica course, listed to inaugurate the season here, announced yesterday he had rejected the date because it falls on Good Friday. Accordingly,
The Neediest Cases Fund reached a total of $301,370.62 yesterday with the addition of eight more gifts. These contributions totaled $49.62.

The annual meeting of shareholders of the Interborough Rapid Transit, scheduled for yesterday, was postponed until April 21 because of a lack of a quorum. This marks the fifth postponement of the meeting for the same reason.

Fifty-two of 466 companies covered in a survey of the status of operations in the period from Dec. 15 to 25 were operating at peak level, while 120 of the companies were operating at less than 50 per cent of their 1937 peaks, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday.
Price fluctuations on the local Cotton Exchange yesterday were confined to an unusually narrow range, with closing quotations at a loss of 4 to a gain of 2 points.

Cotton mill activity was unchanged last week when a nominal increase was seasonal, and the adjusted index eased to 90.1 from 90.6, the revised figure for the previous week. , The index stood at 140.9 for the week ended Jan. 16, 1937.

Harry H. Schaffer, commanderin-chief of the Jewish War Veterans of the United States, issued a statement yesterday through national headquarters at 276 Fifth Avenue disavowing any endorsement of "We Americans,"
The Netherland East Indies Government announces that it is taking more stringent measures against Japanese fishing boats in territorial waters in order to ascertain their real purpose.
Tennessee Valley Authority competition with private power companies was upheld as "lawful" by a three-judge Federal court here today.

Fred E. Beal, labor leader, awaiting a hearing Tuesday on charges of being a fugitive from justice in North Carolina, was released from the local jail when $5,000 bonds with double surety were furnished by Professor Albert Coolidge of Harvard College and Miss Jessica Henderson of Wayland. Both furnished surety on real estate.

Witnesses before the Ways and Means Committee today continued attacks on the proposed new section to the Internal Revenue Act which would put special surtaxes under some conditions on closely held and "family" corporations with net incomes above $50,000, the so-called "third basket."

Nineteen nations already have filed their challenges for 1938 Davis Cup competition, the United States Lawn Tennis Association announced yesterday through The Associated Press. Entries do not close until Jan. 31.
The National Labor Relations Board told the Supreme Court today that it had power "to compel withdrawal of recognition from company-dominated unions."

For the second consecutive week corporate borrowing led in the volume of new bond financing, accounting for all except $600,000 of the total of $11,600,000 in new issues placed on the market this week.

Miss Mary Joyce, the Alaskan "musher" who drove a dog team 1,000 miles from Juneau to Fairbanks two years ago, arrived here yesterday and talked alternately of the grandeur of Alaska and the impressiveness of New York.

The battle of Teruel was still being fought today immediately outside the town as the Insurgents strive to extend their encircling movement a little each day until their left and right wings meet and occupy all the dominating heights forming a ring around their devastated and virtually deserted objective.

President Roosevelt will not interfere in the Illinois differences over the Senatorial nominee, it became known today following a brief talk between Governor Horner and the President, who earlier in the week had discussed the complicated

-Solicitor General Stanley Reed, nominee to the Supreme Court, tonight read his first "decision" in a mock trial of the type of industrial dispute on which he may soon rule from the nation's highest tribunal.

Samuel Scovil, who celebrated his eightieth birthday last September, was elected chairman of the board of the Society for Savings Bank, largest mutual bank in the Middle West, today when John H. Dexter, having completed fifty years of Cleveland banking, declined reelection.
Throngs of gayly dressed Winter sports enthusiasts carrying skis and packs and intent upon playing in the snow over the week-end departed from the city last night on snow trains.

Postoffice Department officials disclosed today that postal inspectors from Philadelphia and Washington were investigating recent charges of the American Civil Liberties Union that there had been tampering with the mail at Jersey City, N. J.

Ramon Cota, 36 years old, convicted of killing his wife, Emily, 46, at their home in near-by Hamilton Township on June 14, 1936, was put to death in the electric chair at the State Prison here tonight.

General Sessions Judge Collins yesterday ordered that thirty-nine men and women who recently were Indicted by the New York grand jury on conspiracy charges growing out of the alleged $1,500,000 fraudulent sale of lots in "Slovak Manor," L. I., be called for trial on Feb. 4.

A number of small dwellings were included in the Brooklyn realty transactions announced by brokers yesterday. The two-family house at 1,753 East Tenth Street was sold by the Godfrey Investing Corporation

The Metropolitan Chapter of the New York Central Veterans' Association will hold its annual dinner in the Hotel Commodore on Wednesday. P. E. Crowley, former president of the New York Central Railroad, will be among the guests of honor. Frederick L. Wheeler, president of the chapter, will be chairman.

The marriage of Miss Sally Ann Duggan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Pierce Duggan of this city and Stamford, Conn., to Alfred White Weld of 129 East Sixtyninth Street, took place here yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin of the Union Theological Seminary performed the ceremony.
Tommy Farr's ten-round defeat at the hands of Jimmy Braddock in New York stunned British fight fans this morning, and complaints about his low punching brought derisive hoots.
By JAMES P. DAWSON
A pair of New Yorkers, Paul Runyan and Jimmy Hines, and a California "dark horse" today dominated a field of 230 golfers competing in the first round of the $3,000 Pasadena open tournament.

William B. Loftus, sports editor of The Evening News, sports promoter and Democratic leader, died at his home here today at the age of 42. He was a candidate for Mayor two years ago, losing by a margin of 92. For a dozen years he was secretary to the late Mayor Daniel L. Hart, who died in office in 1933.
Quotations for all types of loans were carried forward without change in a market that was quiet and confined to routine requirements.

Senior Week at Hunter College will begin this evening with a dance at the St. Moritz, which will open a series of activities including a dinner, theatre party and tea. About 500 seniors will participate in the social events. About 160 students and their escorts are expected to attend the prom tonight in the Sky Gardens

Prices of most commodity futures held steady in subdued activity on the local markets yesterday. Cocoa, copper and raw hide futures, however, were exceptions, closing sharply lower. In the cash market silk and wool tops advanced, but wheat, rye, oats, coffee, cocoa, butter, eggs, lard, tins, cotton and rubber declined.
Dr. James F. Michel, president of the First National Bank of Farmingdale and oldest alumnus of Syracuse University in Nassau County, died this morning at the age of 75 after an illness of six months.

A novel system of examination insurance with the added inducement of scholastic "hot tips" was the hope held out today to Providence College students as they racked their brains at their midyear tests.

The fourth performance this season of Wagner's "Die Walkuere," given at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, was the ocassion of the debut of a talented young conductor, Erich Leinsdorf. Although but 26 years old,
At the American Folk Art Gallery, 118 West Thirteenth Street, an exhibition of American genre is being held. Interest in genre painting itself may be called universal.

Although the Court of Errors and Appeals, New Jersey's highest tribunal, has upheld the constitutionality of the law creating the Milk Control Board, the act was challenged anew in the Supreme Court today by the Reck
The sudden and sharp increases in customs duties announced by the Mexican Government on many important articles imported chiefly from the United States raise anew the disquieting question:

Led by George Knupple, who made 17 points, the Panzer College quintet downed New College, 53 to 29, at the Thompson gymnasium of Teachers College, Columbia, last night. The winners held an 18-14 lead at the intermission.

Louis Johuson, Assistant Secretary of War, addressing a dinner meeting of the annual convention of the -New York National Guard Association in the Hotel Astor last night, declared that if the United States were compelled to go to war "tomorrow" it was doubtful
James J. Braddock weighed 199 1/2 pounds and Tommy Farr 207 for their contest in Madison Square Garden last night. The referee was Johnny McAvoy and the judges were Charley Lynch and George Lecron.
A more embittered and resentful boxer rarely has been seen than the Tommy Farr who stormed into his dressing room after losing to James J. Braddock last night.

Abolition of the present system of Lunacy Commissions in New York City on the grounds that their principal function is to provide patronage for political organizations, is advocated in a bill introduced in the Senate today by Thomas C. Desmond, Orange County Republican.

Henry Goldsmith of Orange, N. J., connected with the firm of Bowman, Foster Wurzburger, Inc., jewelers, at 373 Fifth Avenue, New York, died of a heart attack last night at the Senator Hotel here. His age was 70. His widow, three daughters and two. sons survive.

The presentation of awards to eighteen executives "for best work during the past year" featured the annual dinner of the Camp Fire Girls National Conference of Executives last night at the BarbizonPlaza Hotel. Lester F. Scott, executive director of the organization, made the awards before a gathering of 250 persons.

A detective of the Union City police force, who for weeks had waited in ambush to thwart an anticipated robbery of a chain grocery store here, paid with his life this morning when he failed to "get his man."

Details of Premier Mussolini's North African war machine were disclosed today with the publication of a decree of last July that doubled the military forces in Libya by creating an additional army corps for service there.

A team of twelve members of the Scarsdale Woman's Club matched memories with a similar number from the Town Club of Scarsdale, a men's organization, in a spelling bee tonight at the clubhouse of the former here and lost.
The decision of the three-judge Federal court at Chattanooga yesterday marks an important milestone in the long controversy over TVA.

In his twenty-nine years as a judge of the Supreme Court Arthur S. Tompkins enjoyed general respect and confidence. He was impartial and he was fearless. Governors appreciated his qualities and sent him to other counties to investigate graft or preside at important trials.

Jay N. Bozeman defeated Willie Hoppe, 50 to 35, in 37 innings, in the ninth block of their 12-block three-cushion match at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy yesterday. The victor had a high run of 9, the loser 4. Hoppe still leads, 6 blocks to 3.

Net assets of Insuranshares Certificates, Inc., at the close of 1937 were $4,564,276, equivalent to $5.94 a share, as compared to $6,519,939, or $7.70 a share, at the end of 1936. Unrealized depreciation was $1,555,037, the annual report shows.

The Harvard Club and the Crescent A. C. remained in a tie for the league leadership in the Metropolitan Interclub Association Class C squash tennis series last night, each team registering its ninth triumph in ten starts this season.

Revisions of the State insurance laws governing title and mortgage insurance companies, which are being considered by a joint committee of the State Senate and Assembly, were submitted yesterday to executives of those companies at a hearing of the committee in the offices of the New York Board of Fire Underwriters, 85 John Street.
Federal Judge Phillip Forman told eightynine men and women receiving final citizenship papers today that if they had ideas for "improving the government" it was their duty to promulgate them.
The high credit rating of New York City's obligations was reaffirmed yesterday with the city's first sale in the open market this year of a block of $22,500,000 of short-term securities.

By capturing the 400-yard relay test, the final one on the program, the St. Francis College swimming team remained undefeated in intercollegiate competition by downing Villanova, 34 to 32, in a dual meet in the Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, pool in Brooklyn last night.

Luis Quintanilla, Spanish artist, who temporarily gave up his painting to fight for the Loyalist forces after Insurgents had destroyed most of his life's work, arrived here yesterday morning on the French liner Lafayette with some 100 war drawings. He predicted that

Mrs. Frank A. Vanderlip will preside at a dinner in commemoration of the 250th anniversary of the birth of Emanuel Swedenborg to be held on Wednesday in the Hotel Delmonico, Park Avenue and Fiftyninth Street. She is a member of the local Swedenborgian Church.

Mrs. Mary Merrill Bentley, widow of Edward M. Bentley, New York attorney, died here today of pneumonia at her home, 232 Broadway. She was 84 years old. Mrs. Bentley was born in Mobile, Ala., the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Ford Merrill. Surviving are her son, Edward F., counsel of the village of Lawrence, and three grandchildren.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "Rather more progress appears to have been made this week toward establishing a new trading basis for wool. The market appears to be steadier here and this condition undoubtedly has been helped materially by the stronger position of

WPA nutrition experts and visiting housekeepers, trained in the experimental kitchens of the Deapartment of Welfare, added their suggestions yesterday to the long list of sample menus drawn up for the benefit of relief families faced
A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Emil Menlo of 18 West Seventieth Street on Thursday at the Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital. Mrs. Menlo is the former Miss Marie Dinkelspeil,

Debutantes of former years and many young married couples gathered in the Grand Ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton last night for the second of this season's Friday Assemblies. Besides young matrons and single girls, a limited number of young bachelors are on the subscription list for these dances, which are patterned after the Junior and Knickerbocker Assemblies.
Frank J. Loesch, 85-year-old crime fighter, has resigned the presidency of the Chicago Crime Commission after ten years as head of the agency he created.

The Naval Appropriation Bill carrying $553,266,494 for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1939, and provisions for beginning the construction of twenty-vessels, including two battleships, was passed by the House today and sent tb the Senate without

A damp slushy snow mixed with rain, which later turned completely to rain, yesterday gave New York one of its most dismal days this Winter. Even the Weather Bureau--unofficially-admitted that it was dismal and discouragingly announced that rain or snow would probably continue throughout today and tomorrow.

For a week the Senate has held up action on an amendment to the Federal Trade Commission Act extending the authority of the commission over "unfair" competition in commerce because of a dispute which today showed no signs of early settlement.

Edward N. Brown, former chairman of the board of the St. LouisSan Francisco Railway (the Frisco Line), was questioned yesterday at length in the Supreme Court about a memorandum in his handwriting concerning the purchase by the Frisco Line in 1926 of a block of stock of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway at a cost of $10,506,000.

The practical value of national parks and monuments was attested, and conservation of these natural resources characterized as a "thrifty investment" of steadily increasing importance, at today's final session of the conference on national parks called by the American Planning and Civic Association.

Lew Hahn, manager and treasurer of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, and Chester Leasure and Robert W. Belcher of the United States Chamber of Commerce will be the speakers at the meeting today of the New York State Commercial Secretaries Conference in the Chamber of Commerce of New York State Building, 65 Liberty Street.

In the twenty-second annual metropolitan bowling championships, which end at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy tonight, the George Washington Hotel team is leading in the five-man Class A event with a total of 3,217.
Soviet arrested authorities refused today to permit United States Embassy officials to visit Mrs. Ruth Marie Rubens until after they have finished questioning her.

Showing a smoothly functioning passing attack, the Princeton hockey team defeated Yale tonight, 6 to 3. A gathering of 2,000 saw the teams collide in the game, an encounter in both the Quadrangular League and the International Intercollegiate League.

C. P. Rossberg, secretary of the Outboard, Marine and Manufacturing Company, has been elected a director, succeeding E. F. McDonald Jr. Stanley N. Muirhead has been elected president of Zonolite Company.

STIFFENING of finance terms for automobiles purchased on time payment plans, a matter which was discussed by leaders of the industry and President Roosevelt at Washington this week, is not a new topic in the automobile business.

I'D RATHER BE RIGHT, a musical comedy by George B. Kaufman andl Moss Hart, with lyrics by Lorenz Hart. 124 pp. New York: Random House. $2. BY this time it must be unnecessary to announce that "I'd Rather Be Right" is the play whose leading character is an American statesman named Franklin Delano Roosevelt. A statesman who will

The best piece of news in months for the general run of Soviet citizens was the decision last. Tuesday by the central committee of the Communist party, under Joseph Stalin's leadership, ordering a halt on indiscriminate removals from their jobs of people excommunicated from the party in the Soviet Union.

Annual conference of the New York State Chiropractic Society, Hotel Commodore, 9:30 A. M. Speakers: H. Ernest Warren, Dr. K. Ligeros, Benjamin A. Sauer, S. Goldschmidt, 0. M. Brees, Lyndon E. Lee, William H. Werner.

Defeating the Hispanos by 4-1 in the replay of their National Challenge Cup tie at Celtic Park in Brooklyn yesterday, the St. Mary's Celtics qualified for the third round, in which they will meet Baltimore a week from today. The Hispanos started brilliantly enough, when Ruddy opened the scoring. Aitken soon tallied, however, and the half ended with the score 1-1.

More than 500 persons crowded into the home of Arthur S. Tompkins, State Supreme Court Justice, 1906-1935, today to attend his funeral services. Those who attended included all of the Supreme Court Justices from the Ninth Judicial District, members of the Appellate Division of which he had been a member, and leaders of Rockland County.

A significant aspect of the generally greater Cuban air traffic of 1937 was the enlarged volume of merchandise transported by airplanes, according to a report to the Department of Commerce from Havana and made public today.
General Francisco Franco's second great counter- offensive against Teruel has been going full blast for three days now and the issue is still in doubt.

Governor Lehman, legislative leaders and heads of State departments will be among those at funeral services for Henry F. Lutz, director of State Parks since 1926, in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, 316 East Eighty-eighth Street, tomorrow morning. Mr.
The revived Montreal Maroons, now a much stronger team than when they started the current National Hockey League campaign, will engage the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of New York University, and Dr. Henry Noble MacCracken, president of Vassar College, will be guests - of honor at the annual luncheon of the Vassar Club, which will be held on Saturday on the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Thomas H. Beardsley,
Three armed and masked men raided a downtown wholesale e jewelry establishment today and escaped with jewelry estimated to be worth $40,000.

" Black light," or ultra-violet rays, is the latest "tool" which may aid the dyer in producing attractively dyed fabrics of two, three and more color effects, it is revealed in a patent just granted here to Harvey A. Schwartz of Cleveland, Ohio.

Lieut. Col. Joseph W. Farrell died in Passaic General Hospital today of a heart attack at the age of 61. Colonel Farrell, who was employed in the purchasing agent's office at the Passaic plant of Raybestos-Manhattan, Inc., was grand marshal of the Memorial Day parade in Passaic.

IN an effort to improve the product of RKO-Radio, Leo Spitz, the president and head of production there, is formulating plans for future operations on the basis of a method which Hollywood has always contended would never work. Releasing schedules
Progress in driving out and mopping up Chinese irregulars operating as isolated units in a considerable area of Pootung, west and south of Shanghai, was claimed yesterday by Japanese spokesmen.

One hundred and fifty delegates, representing fifty-nine classes and sixty-three of the seventy-seven Smith Clubs throughout the country, will attend the annual midWinter meeting of the Smith College Alumnae Council to be held Feb. 18, 19 and 20.

A severe magnetic storm, starting at 12:30 A. M., Eastern standard time today, completely disrupted shortwave radio transmission and greatly disturbed all magnetic elements. The storm was reported to the Coast and Geodetic Survey by Albert K. Ludy, observer in charge of its Cheltenham Magnetic Observatory in Maryland.

BARROW-JANDORF-Mr. and Mrs. Everett S. Shelt announce the marriage of her daughter, Ruth L. Jandorf, to Mr. Morton Barrow of Napanoch, Jan. 16. BLAU-GARMISE-Mr. and Mrs. Anshel Garmise of 60 West 87th St., New York, announce the marriage of their daughter, Gilda, to Moe Blau (Cookie Bowers). on Jan. 18, 1938, at Miami Beach, Fla. California Papers please, copy.

More than 500 delegates and visitors from 200 cities of the United States and Canada are expected at the fifteenth triennial convention of the National Council of Jewish Women, which will open with a reception here tomorrow night.
Johnny Hutchinson, 1263/4, Philadelphia, defeated Frankie Terranova, 131, Bronx, in the featured eight-round bout last night at the Ridgewood Grove before a crowd of 3,500.

The north side of Thirty-fourth Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, has "re-established its claim of having a greater volume of women pedestrians than any other retail shopping center in Manhattan," according to William L. Morris, chairman of the stores group in the rental conditions committee of the management division of the Real Estate Board of New York, who made public yesterday the results of a two-day pedestrian traffic count of sixty-two retail shopping locations.

Designed to acquaint architects, engineers and others interested in building ventures with the provisions of the new city building code, a new course will be offered by the New York University School of Architecture and Allied Arts next term.

Public forums to enlighten the people on the issues to be presented at the Constitutional Convention were urged yesterday on the members of the New York Commercial Secretaries conference at the State Chamber of Commerce, 65 Liberty Street.

To the Drama Editor: I have just returned from a three months' stay in Russia, and thought you might be interested in hearing of the conditions there, and of the new plays produced for the Twentieth Celebration.

Miss Mary Hobart Duel, daughter of Mrs. Arthur E. Duel of this place and the late Dr. Duel, was married at noon today to William A. S. Dollard of New York, son of William G. Dollard and the late Mrs. Dollard.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Tuttle Stevens of Westhampton Beach, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Sophia Stevens, to John Millens Burt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Millens Burt of Forest Hills, Queens.

After a lapse of more than two years, events have again focused national attention on the Federal power policy and its application to both operating and holding companies in the public utility industry.
Apprenticeship of six months or more in the field is to be required of students of architecture and landscape architecture for degrees from the Harvard Graduate School of Design.

About seventy-five sick children, patients at St. Vincent's Hospital, as well as a number of adult patients and their friends, were enabled to witness a realistic performance of the opera, "The Barber of Seville," with the roles sung by the cast of the Metropolitan Opera Company yesterday afternoon.

MANY lively and entertaining narratives of adventures in little-known lands have been written, but few as lively or as entertaining as Lawrence Griswold's account of "Tombs. Travel and Trouble." The tombs are the least

Handsome Henry Picard of Hershey, Pa., fired the lowest round of the tournament today to take the lead in the $3,000 Pasadena open at the halfway point of the golf competition with a total score of 136.

The highest ideals of ensemble playing were realized by Adolph Busch and Rudolf Serkin at the second of their joint recitals devoted to the Beethoven violin sonatas given in Town Hall last night Such perfect give and take, unanimity of approach and complete comprehension as marked their performances can be encountered but on the rarest occasions in a life-time of concertgoing.

Two parts of the report of the Joint Committee on Maladjustment and Delinquency in the New York City Schools have appeared and the third part, containing the recommendations of the committee, will be published this week.

A new building at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center to provide low-priced private hospital service for persons of moderate means was urged' yesterday by Dr. Willard C. Rappleye, dean of the Columbia University School of Medicine, as one of five pressing needs of the Center.

Daring, if not original, is the attempt of the highest officials of Rumania to throw off responsibility for their country's Jewish nationals. By defamation and mendacity, now a tried technique, they represent a section of their population as alien, undesirable and a threat to the nation, in order to divert attention from their own brutal attacks upon them. King Carol,

MANY of the galleries have lately exhibited work by sculptors. The pessimist asks: Why bother? What driver keeps the sculptor at work? The technical demands are overwhelming; sculpture is the most complex of arts.
