SHORT-WAVE Station WEIIN of the Bowdoin-Kent's Island Ex pedition was logged recently sending a special program from the expedition's island camp near the Bay of Fundy, the water strip between New Brunswick and Nova Scotia where seas often rise or drop 50 feet with each ebb or flow of the tide.

Glenn Cuningham's specialty, the mile run, feature of the Grover Cleveland-Osceola track meet at the Seventh Regiment Armory last night, developed into a one-sided affair for the transplanted Kansan, who hardly extended himself to triumph as he negotiated the distance in 4:20.1.

BEYOND HORIZONS. By Lincoln Ellsworth. Svo. New York: Doubleday, Doran Co. $3.50. The autobiography of the polar explorer. MONEY POWERS OF EUROPE IN THE NINETEENTH AND TWENTIETH CENTURIES. By Paul H. Emden. 8vo. New York: D. Appleton-Century Comp.any. $3.50.

The 3-year-old champion of 1937, Samuel D. Riddle's War Admiral, with high weight' up, staged a sensational six-furlong trial at Hialeah Park today. He stepped the distance in 1:132-5, with the exercise boy holding him under stout restraint.

The annual card party for the benefit of the Walter Scott Free Industrial School for Crippled Children and the Lulu Thorley Lyons Home for Crippled and Delicate Children will be held the afternoon of Jan. 31 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the Junior League of the two institutions.

IN Germany, as in most countries of the world, a majority of the important books is published in the Fall, in the months before Christmas. German publishers have always expected to sell 90 per cent of their books within Germany and

Chancellor Hitler, opening here today an exhibition of models of the structures that he has built or intends to build, announced that for the first time since the building of the medieval cathedrals he was creating a truly great architecture.

Deploring the spread of terrorism and violence throughout the world, Rabbi Louis I. Newman, at Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eightythird Street, warned yesterday that the democratic nations must devise a technique to defend themselves against those countries which resort to force.

Establishment of a new College of Nursing was announced today by the administration of Temple University. Miss Beatrice Ritter, recently director of nurses at Hahnemann Hospital, has been chosen as head of the school, which will begin functioning with the reopening of the second semester on Feb. 9.
The lure of a place on Uncle Sam's payroll seems to be increasing. Last year the Civil Service Commission examined 843,000 applicants for government jobs, compared with 261,068 in 1932.

THAT brilliantly perspicacious book about Great Britain--"England. the Unknown Isle" (E. P. Dutton Co. S2)--created a great deal of discussion when it first appeared in 1931. It is the work of a young

Yustin Sirutis, Brooklyn heavyweight, stopped Oscar (King Kong) Matthews of Louisiana in the third round of a scheduled ten-round feature bout at the Rockland Palace last night. Claiming an injury to his right wrist, Matthews failed to answer the bell for the fourth round.

The Chicago North Western Railroad is inquiring for three locomotives of the 4-6-4 type, according to Railway Age. The Argentine State Railways contemplate buying from 250 to 500 box cars. The United States Navy Department is seeking bids for five flat cars of fifty tons capacity and one of 100 tons capacity.

WHEN, a number of years ago, I reviewed the first two novels of Gerhard Bohlmann for THE NEW YORK TIMES, I began with these words: "Germany has a great novelist, but she does not yet know him." I want to repeat this

Sachems of the Eastern Baseball League will meet in New York Jan. 30 to arrange the 1938 season schedule, Thomas H. Richardson, league president, announced today. Representatives will attend a dinner of the New York Baseball Writers Association.
State officials headed by Governor and Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman, as well as more than 400 friends attended the funeral of Robert M. (Bobby) Fitzmaurice at St. Mary's Church in this city today.

Prices of grains fluctuated in an erratic and aimless manner today on the Board of Trade, with local short covering largely responsible for an advance of 3/4 to 1 cent a bushel in wheat and 1/8 to % cent in rye, while corn was 1/8 to 1/4 cent lower. Oats finished unchanged to 1/8 cent lower while soy beans were 1/8 cent a bushel higher.

The board of governors of the Investment Bankers Association, at its midwinter meeting at the Seaview Golf Club, Absecon, tonight went on record in favor of the regulation of the over-the-counter securities business, but urged a modification of the Maloney bill.

Cosmio rays are super X-rays in their penetrating power. X-rays when turned on the eggs of the fruit fly, Drosophila, jolt the genes, units of heredity, so that new kinds of flies are hatched which are permanent new species. What, then, are the cosmic rays doing to life? Is it possible that they may account for the hundreds of thousands of species of plants and animals on earth ?

THE lingua franca of international commerce in the Far East, now interrupted by the war between Japan and China, lacks printed vocabulary and grammar, and its syntax, if it has one, has thus far escaped the theses of higher scholarship.

Modification of the definition of a fireproof multiple dwelling to encourage the erection of the so-called "fire-protected" type of building is suggested by the Merchants Assoelation in a communication addressed to the legislative leaders at Albany. The association urges

Retail sales continued somewhat below last year, but showed a little improvement over earlier days of the month. Cautious buying on the part of consumers was reflected in wholesale figures. Weather in most sections has been favorable, both for urban activity and agricultural operations.

Andover Academy's basketball team scored an easy victory over the Northeastern freshmen today, 38-19. Pete Dudan, stellar Andover forward, tallied almost at will, running up 17 points, almost half his team's total. Next in the scoring column for the victors was Mayo, fast center, who accounted for 10 markers.

Responding to an inquiry made by Governor Lehman, President Roosevelt has given assurances that flood-control projects in the Southern Tier counties will be pressed this year. Preliminary work for two dams is practically complete, the President said in a letter released for publication by the Governor.

Mme. Leon Blum, wife of the former Premier, died tonight after an illness of several days. Her husband and other members of the family were at her bedside. She fell ill shortly before the Chautemps Cabinet resigned and grew worse while her husband was being asked by President Lebrun to form a new government, which he failed to do.

The government, seeking the conviction of William J. Graham, James C. McKay and others in a $2,500,000 swindle, ran into their second difficulty in a week, it was disclosed yesterday, with the disappearance of a former Reno, Nev., detective sergeant who was to be an important witness.

TWO bills recently presented in the House of Representatives in Washington have a close bearing upon the future of the Federal Music Project and the other art projects of PWA, and one of them looks toward the establishment in our government of a permanent Bureau of Fine Arts.

News from Washington of the appointment of a mixed BrazilianAmerican trade committee was received here gladly. The press emphasized the story and American interests are rejoicing, believing that through such a body measures will be put into operation to effect a greater commercial interchange.
Semi-annual commencement exercises of Hunter College will be held on Wednesday at 10:30 A. M. at Carnegie Hall. Approximately 500 seniors will receive bachelors' degrees.

The work of the Dominican Sisters of the Sick Poor in administering to the destitute sick in their homes will be benefited by a card party to be held on Friday afternoon at the Plaza under the auspices of the Friends of the Sick Poor.

The Williams basketball team defeated an invading McGill five tonight in Lasell Gymnasium, 4127, with Captain Mike Latvis leading the Purple scorers with ten points and Shipley the Canadians with six field goals.

A pledge that the open door would be maintained in China and that the country would not become a second Manchukuo was given by Foreign Minister Hirota of Japan in an address to the Diet in Tokyo yesterday. He insisted, however, that a government friendly to Japan must be installed and indicated China must cooperate against Russia and in other matters. [Page 1.]
New York's taxpayers spend about $5,000,000 annually to transport their children to and from school, a survey by the State Board of Regents has revealed.
AMOST astonishing vehicle, one of the marvels of the age in which we live, yet the mod ern automobile is still a long way from being the perfection that engineers see as the future possiability.

Aid to save the legitimate theatre from bankruptcy through removal of the 10 per cent admission tax and imposition of a severe penalty tax on ticket speculators were asked of the Ways and Means Committee today by William A. Brady, New York producer, and two other officials representing theatrical organizations.

INQUIRY at the Bureau of Engraving and Printing last week brought an explanation of the unusual richness of the coloring of the Constitution Sesquicentennial 3-cent commemorative released on Sept. 17 and the Puerto Rico "Possessions" 3-cent issued on Nov. 25.

Predicting that retailers will run into a delivery jam within a few weeks, Mortimer Lanzit, executive director of the National Dress Manufacturers Association, declared yesterday that a change in tempo on the part of the retailer and buying offices is "vitally necessary."

Closing powerfully through the stretch when he appeared beaten, Lawrin from the Woolford farm of H. M. Wolf today captured the $6,290 Hialeah stakes so decisively that he gained sharply as a candidate for the $20,000 added Flamingo, to be run next month.

Peace between the Orthodox Church and the government of Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch has proved a difficult matter in spite of the recent official announcement that the concordat with the Vatican would be dropped.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry John Gucker of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Gloria Gucker, to Richard A. Hoefer Jr. of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Hoefer of Chicago.
Dr. Hugo Eckener, veteran Zeppelin commander, expressed determination today to complete Germany's newest giant Zeppelin by April and start its maiden voyage to the United States late the next month.

Wesleyan defeated Yale at a ski meet on the Talmon River course today, scoring 189.3 to 185.8. In the down hill event, the finishing times were as follows: Aiken, Yale, 51 seconds; Blandin, Yale, 52; Van Dusen, Wesleyan, 62; Phelps, Yale, 65; Krementz, Wesleyan, 67; Hyde, Yale, 69.

Spokesmen for the Committee for International Organization and for industry will appear on the same platform to discuss the business recession at the 123d annual dinner of the Economie Club of New York at the Hotel Astor on the evening of Wednesday, Feb. 9. Paul D. Cravath, attorney, is president of the club.

Malcolm W. Starr gave a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for Miss Leonie Williams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel P. Williams Jr. of Waterbury and Madison, Conn., and John Ogden White, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Howard White of Waterbury, whose marriage will take place Feb. 11 in Waterbury.

WASHINGTON.-As post-graduate and special students in civilian institutions, officers of the United States Army are covering a wide front, the National Defense Act having authorized the assignment of 2 per cent of the commissioned strength to courses in schools, hospitals and industrial plants.

The American Civil Liberties Union announced yesterday that it had begun a survey of more than 1,000 cities of 10,000 population or more to determine the relative standing of American cities in the practice of civil liberties. The organization has sent a questionnaire to public officials and others familiar with conditions.
The Coast Guard cutter Cayuga today went to the assistance of the Gloucester fishing schooner Ruth and Margaret, reported in difficulties about 110 miles east by south of Boston.

With discovery of a technical error in the House amendment, the Wheeler-Lea proposal for increasing the powers of the Federal Trade Commission was forced into conference, and. advertisers, agencies, publishers and others expressed the hope yesterday that three changes they have suggested will be incorporated in the conference bill.
In the slowest trading since Dec. 11, the stock market moved narrowly yesterday and closed irregularly lower.

Ben Jonson's satire comedy "Volpone, or the Fox" will be presented at the Westminster Theatre on Tuesday by Anmer Hall, who gave London Eugene O'Neill's trilogy "Mourning Becomes Electra," now in a larger home at the New Theatre. The original text will be used, though

Local teams once again demonstrated their superiority over outof-town rivals by winning three of the five contests at the third and final series of scholastic basketball programs at Madison Square Garden yesterday. A crowd of 3,500 was present when the first game got under way snortly before noon.
While there was some evidence of

In what was easily the most exciting game of the season, Evergreen Farms recorded its third straight victory in the Metropolitan indoor Polo League last night, defeating the New York Athletic Club, 15 to 14.

Columbia will meet Tulane University of New Orleans in football here on Nov. 18, 1939, it was announced yesterday by Reynolds S. Benson, manager of athletics. The contest will mark the first meeting of the institutions on the gridiron.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman, in an address before 1,000 lawyers at the sixty-first annual dinner of the New fork State Bar Association in the Waldorf-Astoria last night, warned the public to be on guard against Fascist and Communist dictatorships as menaces to the American democratic system.

The result of the government's anti-trust suit against major oil companies and individual defendants at Madison marked today a milestone in the Administration's "trust-busting" drive, according to officials. At the Justice Department officials described the Madison case as "probably the most important antitrust action since the 'sugar trust' and certainly the biggest oil company case since dissolution of the Standard Oil Company in 1911."

PETERBOROUGH, N. H.-Any list of boons brought by the Great Ski Fever should include the birth of beautiful friendships between competing resorts. The old the-view-is-muchfiner-from-our-front-porch" attitude is -gone or, at least, suppressed. Towns like to get together with other towns and the largest of all get-togethers has occurred recently around Peterborough.

Two dances will be held in Westchester County next Saturday night in celebration of the President's birthday. The largest will take place at the County Center here and will feature two dance bands composed of Westchester residents. Harold N. Grattan is chairman of this benefit ball.

More than three hundred attended the Palm Beach Biltmore's opening dance of the season tonight. Among those entertaining were Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Dillman, Mr. and Mrs. John Holliday Perry, Dr. and Mrs. Maitland Alexander, Mr. and Mrs. Guernsey Curran Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Bailey, Mr. and Mrs. Charles P. Hidden, Winthrop W. Aldrich, William Theodore Hoops, George F. Downs and Frank W. Gay.

COLD clear Winter nights are favored by Scout astronomers. Then they turn out to watch the wheeling stars and to draw the constellations. This is the season when the greatest number of first magnitude stars are visible to the naked eye.

Morris Abromowitz, founder and patron of a number of Jewish religious and charitable organizations in this city, died of heart disease Friday afternoon at his home, 920 Riverside Drive, in his seventy-second year. Mr. Abromowitz was in the

THE New York Historical Society, one of the city's oldest institutionsthe second oldest of its kind in the United States-and encrusted with Knickerbocker traditions, is modernizing itself and doing it on a liberal scale.

The text of Foreign Minister Koki Hirota's speech at the seventy-third session of the Parliament in Tokyo yesterday, as made public her, by the Consulate General of Japan, follows: The attitude of the Japanese Government toward the present affair has been clearly set forth in their statements made public from time to time in the past.

When the snow flies egg prices usually go up. Hens lay less in cold weather and stocks of eggs fall off. This year so far has been an exception. The most recent in a series of 2-cent-a-dozen drops occurred last week.

In view of the nation-wide unemployment situation, Colonel Villiam H. Patterson, in charge of army recruiting in New York, New Jersey and Delaware, commended the regular army yesterday as an ally in the government's campaign to assist the great mass of the jobless.

In a solemn ceremony this afternoon Ambassador William C. Bullitt received an honorary doctorate degree from the University of Nancy. Earlier the American Ambassador attended a- military parade in the medieval Place Stanislas and later made a speech at a luncheon in the Town Hall.
To The Radio Editor: Le me add a voice to the chorus crying for music other than jazz late at night. There used to be a delightful period of slumber music at 11 o'clock. I wonder why it was given up.

The Loomis School basketball team defeated Taft tonight by 36 to 14. Randy Morse starred for the Maroon quintet, scoring eleven points. O'Malley of Loomis and Merrell of Taft were next with seven apiece.
Despite two scoring surges in the second half, the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute basketball squad tonight lost its fourth consecutive game of the season to Stevens Tech, 32 to 30.

The report of the Great Northern Iron Ore Properties for 1937, published yesterday, showed a consolidated net profit of $1,256,428 after expenses, Federal income taxes, depreciation, depletion, provision for Federal surtax on undistributed profits and minority interest charges.

A wave of economy that threatens to end elaborate and expensive ceremonies and a greater family solidarity are the only visible effects in Tokyo homes of the ChineseJapanese war, according to Mrs. Haruko Ichikawa, Japanese author.

Three victorious campaigns have led Japan to the threshold of a far more difficult task. The declaration of policy issued here on Sunday defines her aim as the establishment of a new regime with which she can cooperate in the rejuvenation of China.

EVERY year Stuart Chase has a new enthusiasm; every year some country, sight, invention or book sets his hair on fire. Out comes a new volume, bubbling with excitement, demanding that something be done, calling on us to scrap all our previous ideas on that subject, including those Mr. Chase was himself rooting for last year, if we are to be saved from imminent disaster.

IN these days of complacency at facts accomplished, with so much written on the progress of aviation, there is a natural inclinaLion to minimize the early efforts of the comparatively small group of pioneers-far-seeing operators, pilots and others, who envisaged the possibilities of air transport and worked to bring about the successful results, now admittedly attained.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of-Miss Dorothy Lindsay Robbins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Robbins of this place, to Lewis E. Pudney of New York, son of Mrs. Earl H. Pudney of Atlanta, Ga., and the late Mr. Pudney.
The field in the sixteenth annual New Jersey squash tennis championship was cut to sixteen at the Short Hills Club today, with all favorites surviving.

Clearly demonstrating that it did not need the five goals received by handicap, the Squadron C firststring indoor polo team galloped to a 19-to-6 victory over the First Division in a Metropolitan League The senior division match at Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn last night.

DURING the revolution archives were smuggled out of Russia. Boxes that had been locked for many a long year were opened and their contents examined. One of them has yielded treasure trove. Here is a book that contributes new material to history and provides also a rare banquet of full-flavored dainties for the public as a whole. Never, it is safe to say,

In commemoration of the seventyfifth anniversary of the Emancipation Proclamation, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, 69 Fifth Avenue, announced yesterday the opening of a "new crusade for liberty," under the direction of Mrs. Daisy E. Lampkin, field secretary.

Miss Mary Elizabeth Brayton, daughter of Mrs. William Lawton Slade Brayton of Fall River and the late Mr. Brayton, was married to W. Wittredge Katzenbach, son of Mrs. L. Emery Katzenbach of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Mr. Katzenbach, this afternoon in the First Congregational Church of

Since 1931 the number of libraries for the blind important enough to require the services of one or more fulltime attendants has increased from fifteen to twenty-seven, Herbert Putnam, librarian of Congress, recently revealed.

Ballots and letters showing that more than 98.5 per cent of business executives who voted in a poll conducted by the McGraw-Hill Publishing Company desire revision of the undistributed profits tax, the capital gains tax and surtaxes on large personal incomes were forwarded yesterday to members of the House of Representatives.

THAT singular anomaly, the lady novelist. who was never completely demolished by Ko-Ko's raillerv anyway. has reared her head again. Maria Edgeworth. one of the most popular writers of the nineteenth century. went into a decline shortly after Gilbert's antic executioner had included her kind in his little list.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I read with amazement an excerpt from a recent biography by Emil Ludwig in which he makes the statement that Theodore Roosevelt was kept from the battlefields of France by (and I quote Mr. Ludwig's own words) the "ancient enmity of Woodrow Wilson."

Waking up after an inexcusably long sleep, the United States provided for the preservation of records and documents relating to the Government. A beautiful building was built to hold them. The Third Annual Report of the Archivist of the United States has just appeared. The reader of it gets an inkling

Retail trade continued very spotty and averaged about 7 per cent below the like 1937 week, with sharp variations reported by different types of stores. In general, stores catering to the upper middle class made the best showing, their sales declines holding around 3 per cent.

Paintings depicting American pioneer and sporting life in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries will be sold at auction at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Thursday evening. Included will be examples of the work of A. F. Tait, George Durrie, Louis Maurer, William Tylee Ranney, Samuel Colman, Edward Savage, Frederic Remington, and others.

Retail trade was spotty last week, with gains registered in some large cities, including New York, but substantial losses developed in other sections--notably in areas like Texas, where trade had showed gains over several months of declines for the country as a whole. Industrial areas registered occasional small gains over a year ago, with sales frequently stimulated by drastic price cuts.

WHEN fashion experts saw the midseason collections, they were all struck by the fact that prints, even for the Spring models, were conspicuous by their absence. Some houses used a few of them; many, including Vionnet, not one.

The American Museum of Health for which Park Comnissioner Robert Moses has set aside a twentyacre tract on Wards Island is rapidly taking shape. Plans' for the museum have so progressed that its sponsors confidently predict that it will outrank eventually the only other institution of its kind in the world, the Health Museum at Dresden. Germany.

Hank Leiber, Giants' outfielder, joined the hold-out ranks for the third consecutive year when he returned his contract unsigned today. Leiber said he was not satisfied with the terms. Earl Grace, who caught for the Philadelphia Nationals last season, said he had not decided whether he would play this season.

Encouraged by the hearty support which Governor Lehman has offered to the program to put a more effective State system of landtitle registration into operation, the advocates of amendments to the Torrens law have begun a new effort to press their proposals in the State Legislature.
The Labor Bureau's general index of manufacturing employment in December, given out last week, compares with preceding months and years as follows, with the average of 1923-25 as 100:

Stocks closed steady, at irregularly lower levels, in the smallest trading since Dec. 11; turnover, 405,290 shares. United States Government and other bonds generally lower in quiet trading; transactions, $4,064,825.
The Clarkson College hockey team defeated Cornell, 10--0, tonight. Clarkson completely outplayed the Cornellians throughout and scored almost at will.

Thornton Wilder's first full-length original play, "Our Town," had its premiere here tonight in McCarter Theatre before a capacity audience. Produced and staged by Jed Harris, the new Wilder vehicle has Frank Craven as its featured player, returned to the stage after an absence of two years.
The French Government has asked a local auctioneer to hold up the sale of a letter supposed to be from Napoleon III to Wilhelm I of Germany announcing the surrender of Sedan.
Alton Truman Terrel of Orange, Conn., a leading Ansonia, Conn., industrialist and financier, died on Friday of a heart attack in the Hotel Vanderbilt. He was 65 years old.

Trade shows in the home furnishings field here last week drew exceptionally heavy attendance from buyers and a moderate amount of buying and developed increased confidence in furniture and lamp prices.

Another "brick" church is passing in the demolition of the red brick edifice of the Church of St. Andrew at Duane Street and Cardinal Place, but happily another is to rise in its place and a more spacious one. The wrecking has been begun, but the erection of the new building is already proceeding and there is to be no interruption of the services.

Among the 355 guests of the Knights of Rhythm Supper Club in the Hotel Warwick ballroom tonight were Mr. and Mrs. George Draper Lewis of Chestnut Hill, with their daughter, Miss Betty Lewis, and her fiance, William R. Nichols of New York, and Mr. and Mrs. Luther Kellogg, also of New York.

THERE is an off-chance. just a chance, that "The Wild Goose Chase" will be remembered as a turning point for the literature of our day, for it successfully revolts 'against the methods of photographic realism and yet defends itself against the stigma of escapism. But whether it be praised or damned, whether it be remembered or forgotten, it proves that novelty still lies within the reach of novelists.
Mrs. George E. A. Reinburg, widow of Lieut. Col. Reinburg, formerly of the United States Air Service, who at his death in Hangchow, China, in 1936, was an aeronautics adviser to Mme. Chiang

Paul Waner, the left-handed Pittsburgh outfielder, and Jack Russell, former American League pitcher, will meet tomorrow for the baseball players golf championship. Both survived two eighteen-hole rounds today. Waner, set up as

The Hudson River Navigation Corporation, which operates passenger and freight steamboats on the Hudson River, petitioned the Federal Court yesterday for permission to reorganize under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act. It did not submit a plan.

Retail sales in local department and specialty stores were "reasonably satisfactory" during the week, and the public responded well to promotions on staple items. Luxury items, on the other hand, were dull. Men's and women's wear was reported reasonably good for this season, especially on popularly priced merchandise.

Utility and Industrial Corporation--Net assets as of Dec. 31: $2,017,309, based on market or estimated values, equal to $3 a share on 673,381 shares of $1.50 dividend convertible preferred stock, compared with $4,823,617, or $7.16 a share on the same stock, at the end of 1936.

The Grand Street Settlement at 283 Rivington Street yesterday opened its senior floor as a recreation center for boys and girls between the ages of 16 and 21. The fitting out of the floor was done with money obtained from the Nathan Hofheimer Foundation, according to Leonard Rothschild, president of the settlement.

The Dollar Line, assured of six months' subsidy aggregating roughly $8,000 a day, is now enjoying a "comeback." The first task is to restore to traffic the four liners laid up in the bay, some of them since September. They are the Presidents Cleveland, Wilson, Lincoln and Hayes.

To prepare Roman Catholic laymen to speak on the doctrines of their church, an Institute of Religious Discussion Groups is being formed here by the National Catholic Alumni Federation, with the active cooperation of high officials of the Archdiocese of New York.
MODERN MUSIC, the periodical of The League of Composers, contains an article, "Manifesto-The Composers Organize." It makes known the fact of a

Returned from a tour that began last Spring, Mischa Elman was greeted by a large house when he appeared in recital yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. He had been to the Orient and left just before the bombs started to fall; played in Europe from England to Turkey and ranged the concert halls from South to North Africa.

LONDON-Increased use of the public health services provided for British mothers and their children is one of the chief objectives of the "Keep Fit" campaign recently launched by Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain.
The annual auction of the season's fur catch from Greenland will be held at Copenhagen on Feb. 17, according to a report to the Department of Commerce from that city made public today.

Members of the District Attorneys Association of the State of New York have a problem on their hands. Their treasury is overloaded with money ($621) and they feel they ought to get that currency into circulation. Their problem is how to do it.

James C. Deering, who had been connected with city departments for more than thirty-five years, beginning with the old Board of Public Improvements, died Friday at his home, 106 West Ninety-second Street, at the age of 62.

Four members of Phi Rho Pi, Manhattan College fraternity, have been selected as officers of the Jasper Press Club for the coming semester. The other office holder is a member of Beta Sigma fraternity.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE NEW YORK TIMES published not long ago an article, "Library's Growth Traced From 1693," which gave a clear picture of the remarkable growth and progress of the libraries throughout this country and how they are being used by the people.

A jury of nine men and three women, after being out for twentysix hours, returned yesterday afternoon a verdict of guilty of conspiracy to use the mails to defraud against John A. Dilliard, former president; Edmund J. Donegan, former vice president and treasurer, and Max. N. Koven, former vice president, of the State Title and Mortgage Company.

Joe McCluskey, outstanding runner and twice a member of American Olympic teams, last night received the annual award of the New York Athletic Club Veterans Association at the yearly dinner in the club rooms.

A daily total of 1,608,870,000 gallons of sewage and sewage effluents is discharged into the waterways of the metropolitan district, the Interstate Sanitation Commission disclosed in a report to the Governors of New York and New Jersey made public yesterday.
WASHINGTON.-A recent $300,000 grant from the WPA will enable the Geological Survey during the next twelve months to speed up its topographical survey work in many parts of the country.

EVERY minute of the' day giant vacuum tubes silently electrify the ether, stirring powerful waves of spoken words and music that wash around the globe. A countless audience listens in. Twenty-nine years ago today it was different; dots and dashes, not melodies, pulsed in space. Radio belonged to the sea.

Southern exporters of bright leaf tobacco L are seeking new outlets for the product in view of the elimination of some of the more profitable markets. Traveling salesmen are developing a new demand in South and Central America and are being sent into the Asiatic field, including India, notwithstanding that country's large native supply.

A meeting of alumni advisers of the nineteen national fraternity chapters at Brown University will be called soon by Dean Edgar J. Lanpher to consider methods for "revitalizing" the Greek letter houses.

After a search of more than four years, Alexander Lawrence, 40 years old, was arrested yesterday at his home, 511 West 151st Street, on charges of grand larceny in connection with the operation of an alleged bucket shop. Lawrence, who

The stormy days when the League of Nations question was under consideration in the Senate are recalled by the determined filibuster which Southern Senators, aided by a few of their Northern colleagues, have been conducting against the Wagner-Van Nuys Anti-Lynching Bill.
Today Carroll Club-Athletic association program. Sports movies and fencing exhibition. Monday Athena Club of Freeport-Music department meeting, 2:15 P. M. Presbyterian Church parish house.
In a thrill-packed game, which had its greatest drama in the final thirty seconds, Dartmouth's basketball team defeated Penn, 43-38, tonight before almost 3,000 spectators.

William J. Brown, meter foreman for the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, who completed fifty-one years of service with that company last November, died of pneumonia Friday at his home, 562 West 113th Street, after a week's illness. He was 68 years old.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, tc., which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference. THE TIMES receives a great many more queries than it can publish. It endeavors, therefore,
Retail trade here made another good comparative showing last week, with the average of department store sales put at 1 to 2 per cent above the same week of 1937.

Henry Lindsley Brush, descendant of one of the earliest families of Greenwich, died today in Stamford, Conn., where he had made his home with his sister, Miss Emily I. Brush, for the last ten years. His age was 81.

About $12,000 worth of the $47,322 in postage stamps stolen yesterday by yeggmen who blew open a safe in the Rahway Postoffice were worthless to the robbers, Postmaster Martin F. Getting announced today. Among the loot was a large number of pre-canceled stamps, usable only by Rahway industries holding permits.

Proof that manufacturers cultivating export trade have drawn substantial dividends in the way of active foreign demand during the present recession is furnished by the National Foreign Trade Council from a survey completed here yesterday.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- More than the usual number of fishing craft will ride out to the indigo waters of the Gulf Stream daily during the next three weeks for the fourth annual Silver Sail Fish Derby, which began Tuesday and continues until Feb. 13.

Raising the question of whether the wholesale tobacco industry should sponsor a uniform national mark-up, or whether it is preferable to concentrate upon unfair practices acts setting mark-ups in accord with conditions in each State, Joseph Kolodny, secretary of the National Association of Tobacco Dealers and head of the Jersey City Tobacco Company, declared yesterday the adoption of the former policy may bring about sharp conflicts with the State laws now in effect.

THE problem of whether the pictures should fit the room or the room the pictures (if they are distinguished) is once more handled with taste and intelligence in an exhibition at the Decorators Picture Gallery, 554 Madison Avenue.

Retail trade in the Sixth Federal Reserve District this week was maintained at approximately the same level as the corresponding period a year ago. Department store sales were slightly above the same time in 1937. The increase, however, was offset by slightly decreased demands in other stores.

ABRAMOWITZ-Morris. The United Hebrew Community of New York (Adath Israel) announces with sincere regret the loss of its beloved President, Morris Abramowitz of 920 Riverside Drive, New York City. Officers, Directors and members are requested to attend funeral services today, 12 noon sharp, at Riverside Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., and at 12:30 at the United Hebrew Community of New York at 201 East BroadWay, New York City.

The welfare of American college women who have used their scientific training under the propulsion of a keen sense of humanity's needs to penetrate the lives of millions in the Far East is proving a matter of grave concern to their fellow-alumnae.

The Brooklyn College basketball team defeated the Hampton Institute of Virginia, 46 to 31, in a spectacular game before a capacity crowd at the winners' new gymnasium last night. The contest marked the first time an all-Negro college quintet met a metropolitan college outfit.

" Pickets of Jewish shops perform a national duty and cannot be blamed for it," a judge in the Tczew court said yesterday in sentencing a Jewish woman to fourteen days in jail and a fifty-zloty fine, for "abusing" a picket.

First steps were taken yesterda to obtain a city college for Staten Island at a conference of twentyfive men and women in the Staten Island Club, 356 St. Mark's Place, St. George, S. I. The conferees.

The Park Department ran off last night with the athletic meet sponsored by the Mayor's Committee on Municipal Athletic Activities in the 102d Engineers Armory, 168th Street near Broadway. William W. Cohen, chairman of the committee, was in charge.

Germany's treatment of the religious issue was denounced and defended at the Foreign Policy Association's luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Astor. About 500 persons attended, and obeyed the chairman's admonition to show "courtesy and fair play" to both sides.

William G. Roberts, superintendent of Bayonne Hospital since 1928, died of a heart attack last night at his home at the age of 69. Mr. Roberts, who lived here fortyfive years, long had been prominent in fraternal and civic affairs.
Much interest is being shown at Dartmouth in the student speakers bureau, which has been in operation for a little over a week as an experiment.

Frank R. Kelly, captain of the American skeet team, and Carl L. Schweinler, a West Orange entry, are heavy favorites to retain their Eastern open two-man skeet championship at the Loantaka Field Club tomorrow as a result of their sensational shooting in the 20-gauge event today.
University of Pittsburgh students are debating the "catch" in the preferred, free date-making service offered by the Pitt News.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Anson Getman of New York and Albany of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gertrude Getman, to William Gray Moody, son of Mrs. Elizabeth Gray Moody of Brookline, Mass. Miss Getman was graduated from the Albany Girls Academy and attended Smith College.

Representatives of major consumer cooperative associations have voted to form a national wholesale cooperative for the distribution of clothing to be known as Consumers Wholesale Clothiers, Inc., it was announced yesterday following a meeting at Columbus, Ohio.

The Salvation Army reported yesterday that last week's near-zero weather not only had overtaxed the capacity of its shelters for the homeless but had placed a severe strain on the already overloaded case budget carried by its departments directly concerned with relief of suffering-notably the Family Welfare Bureau.

Spokesmen for the iron and steel industry told the Senate Unemployment Committee today that there were indications of an upturn in their business and declared that the industry's price advances in the last two years had not outrun increased production costs.

Temple University put on a fast second-half drive that downed La Salle at convention Hall tonight in the secand game of a double-header, 37 o 22. A. crowd of 8,327 saw the Owls hold the Explorers to 7 points in the last half while they piled up 20.
The tomb of a Second Dynasty noble, sealed since funeral rites 5,100 years ago, was reported today to have been found by W. B. Emery.
A semiofficial source reported tonight that the Reichstag would be summoned to meet Jan. 30, the fifth anniversary of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's seizure of power, in the Kroll Opera House.

The Dante Alighieri Society of New York, a chanter of the Societa Nazlonale Dante Alighieri of Rome, will give a tea dance on Jan. 30 at the Ambassador to raise funds for the support of the free schools established throughout the city by the chapter.

The American Institute of Electrial Engineers will hold its annual Winter convention for five days, beginning tomorrow, at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street. More than 1,500 members from all parts of the country are expected to attend.

Polish imports of raw cotton in November amounted to 7,164 metric tons valued at $2,216,430, of which 4,538 metric tons valued at $1,018,970 were from the United States, according to a report from Warsaw made public today by the Department of Commerce.

A course of three lectures on flower arrangement will be initiated by the Junior League at its clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street, on Feb. 1, when Mrs. Henry Rennell will speak on "The Importance of Backgrounds in Flower Design."

WASHINGTON-The chances are that the New York plane which swings down on the Washington airport just before dusk of an evening when a formal Cabinet dinner or reception is scheduled at the White House will be carrying a tall, fair woman, with blue eyes.

Dr. and Mrs. Charles Augustus Simpson of this city announced today the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Anne Simpson, to Dr. Paul Kiernan, son of Mrs. Vladimir Vasa and the late Dr. Paul Kiernan,

The Department of Geology at Bryn Mawr College is preparing to attack with renewed vigor geological problems presented by the area embracing Southeastern Pennsylvania and Northern Delaware, included in the "Piedmont Province."

Barriers erected many years ago under the rigid practice of the Supreme Court will presumably bar Stanley Reed, the new justice, from participating in the decisions on two or three vitally important New Deal cases and perhaps in the judicial settlement of two-thirds of the suits the court will hear debated during his first week on the nation's highest bench.

The third week of the water-front strike tying up the entire island ended today with a complete impasse. Pessimism dominated the company representatives, government officials and the public generally following the dashing of too optimistic hopes yesterday that a settlement was likely to be reached this week.

Capturing seven of the nine events, Dartmouth's swimming team today turned back Pennsylvania's squad, 50 to 25. Arthur Ostrander of Dartmouth took the 220-yard free style in 2:21 and the 440 free style in 5:13.2.
One final thrust of ill luck was the lot of the liner Leviathan yesterday as she lay at her Hoboken pier preparing for the last adventure of a career spotted with misfortune.

Sixteen major Midwest oil companies and thirty executives charged with criminal conspiracy to raise and fix gasoline prices during 1935 and 1936 were convicted today in Federal court here at the end of a trial which began Oct. 4.

Dr. Otto Struve, director of Yerkes Observatory, and his colleagues, Drs. Gerald P. Kuiper and Bengt Stroemgren, are sure that they have correctly estimated the size of the colossal dark component of the binary star, Epsilon Aurigae.

The West Sixty-third Street Community House, formerly known as the Riverside Day Nursery, will be the beneficiary of a Smorgasbord party next Friday night at the Pagano Studio, 11 East Fifty-first Street. There will be tables for bridge, backgammon and other games. The organization at 149
The Tennessee Valley Authority, victorious over eighteen private utilities in a test of its constitution ality, promised cooperation today in speeding the case to the United States Supreme Court.

A diminutive citizen from India, swarthy-faced, wearing a pert blue overseas cap, stirred the assemblage of women to the Conference on the Cause and Cure of War in Washington last night with a plea for universal vegetarianism as a program for world peace.

The new tax laws of the Roosevelt administration were an important depressive feature of a defective governmental and credit policy which, together with inherently unstable business conditions, combined to bring about the recent recession in the recovery movement, Drs. Gerhard Colm and Fritz Lehmann, economists, conclude in a statistical study of the effects of. New Deal fiscal policy made public yesterday.

Current from high tension lines of the Jersey Central Power and Light Company will be cut in on the distribution lines of the Rural Electric Company, a cooperative project of the Rural Electricfication Administration. at a ceremony to be held next Saturday at Marlboro. The ceremony was to have been held today, but was postponed.

The Young Men's. Republican Clubs of Westchester County, assembled here today for their annual convention, adopted a platform advocating legalization of pari-mutuel betting at recognized race tracks and a general sales tax on all retail sales, excepting food and prescription medicines, the money from the tax to be used entirely for relief and welfare.

The modern Olympic Games, revived in 1896 by a Frenchman, Baron Pierre de Coubertin, who felt that international competition in sport would serve international understanding and friendship, have once more been caught up in the whirl of international politics and, ironically enough, war.

THE recent gift of $25,000 by Alfred P. Sloan Jr. to the Automotive Safety Foundation, establishing twenty fellowships for a year's study of traffic problems, followed by the report just issued by Paul G. Hoffman, president of the foundation, setting
Elmer Thompson, secretary of the Automobile Club of America, said yesterday that his organization favored a hearing on the reimposition of the emergency gasoline taxes. In view of the stand taken

SNOW scenes with a distinct metropolitan flavor are sought by many of the city's photographers as soon as the area receives its first white coat. For. snow photography, with its limitless possibilities for softly beautiful effects, is an event to look forward to, and many cameramen began checking over their shutters and film packs with the arrival of cold weather.

Emerson (Spike) Nelson, line coach at Louisiana State University for six years. today was named head football coach at Mississippi State College. C. R. (Dudy) Noble, veteran member of the coaching staff here, was oppointed athletic director.

Southern Senators agreed today to continue their speech-making against the Anti-Lynching Bill next week. Senator Connally of Texas said after a caucus of the group that opposition speeches would continue until it was demonstrated that the measure could not pass.

Apathy toward the consumers' protective label, demonstrated in an informal survey made by members of the Consumers League, the League of Women Shoppers and the Women's Trade Union League, will be reported to the National Cloak and Suit Recovery Board meeting tomorrow and Tuesday.

The following foreign service changes since Jan. 15 were announced today by the State Department: Avra M. Warren of Ellicott City, Md., foreign service inspector, assigned to the Department of State. Waldo E. Bailey of Jackson, Miss., vice consul at Lyon, France, assigned as vice consul at Nairobi, Kenya, East Africa.

Through "credits for reconstructive aid" assigned by the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, many industries and occupations have been opened to Jews in Poland, according to a report on this work in 100 Polish towns and cities made public yesterday by the committee.

Robert H. Jackson, assistant attorney general, today returned the documents of the Chrysler Corporation and its financing affiliate, the Commercial Credit Company, which were used in a recent Federal grand jury investigation of automobile financing methods.

Mrs. R. W. Gallagher, wife of a vice president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, christened a 4,500,000-gallon tanker with her husband's name as it was launched today at the Bethlehem shipbuilding plant at Sparrows Point.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Zaydee Dejonge, daughter of Mrs. Max Emil Dejonge of this place and the late Mr. Dejonge, to Mason Dix Harris, son of Mrs. Thaddeus William Harris and the late Mr. Harris.

Union College swimmers broke three college records, won six first places and lost only two events, yet, because R. P. I. was able to tie for first place in the 50-yard dash, the Engineers defeated the Dutchmen, 38 to 37, today in the closest meet between them in half a century.

IN its recently closed contest for a translation of Wagner's "Siegfried" the Richard Wagner Society received 205 manuscripts from thirty-six States and seven foreign countries. The entries are being read by a committee of judges consisting of Leopold Stokowski, Fritz Reiner, Lawrence

On the basis of statements of twenty-three out of the thirty-nine Federal savings and loan associations in the metropolitan area, aggregate assets of -these -institutions increased 9 per cent in 1937, according to the association's publicity committee.

Man's desire to protect his interest in trees is about as old as government, for the. Greeks had tree laws Which the Romans adopted and amplified, and many of the Justinian Code's precepts on the subject are still repeated in modern courts of law.

Recommendations on almost every major problem growing out of current affairs were included in the semi-annual survey of a committee on social justice made public yesterday on behalf of the Rabbinical Assembly of America, national organization of conservative rabbis.

Instead of a lull following the Motor Boat Show, the skippers and navigators seem busier than ever. Not only are scores of yachtsmen involved as instructors and lecturers in the free navigation courses in the various units of the United States Power Squadrons,

Mr. and Mrs. Robert Livingston Clarkson of Callendar House, Bayville, L. I., will depart Saturday for Rio de Janeiro and Buenos Aires. Mr. and Mrs. John F. B. Mitchell and the Misses Mary B. and Agnes H. Mitchell are at the Westbury for the Winter.
Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York' Stock Exchange follow: Tomorrow Atlantic Refining Co. Chicago Yellow Cab Co., Inc. Manhattan Shirt Co.

The Boston Bruins, American group leaders in the National Hockey League, rolled up their biggest score of the season and gave the Toronto Maple Leafs their worst beating tonight as they whipped the international section pace-setters, 9 to 1, before 14,500 fans.

Three men who share an apartment at 2,339 Prospect Avenue, the Bronx, reported to the police last night that they had been held up in their home by two armed men who entered at the dinner hour and escaped later over the roof.

WHEN the radio showmen, who by short-wave use all the world as a stage, find a New York hit such as "You Can't Take It With You" failing in the London theatre they realize they cannot hope to entertain the world with the same program. In fact,the broadcasters have relayed samples of some of America's most popular radio'performances to Europe, and over there they "failed to see the joke."

Dr. William A. Dixon, a resident of Passaic for almost a half century, died at his home today after a brief illness. He was 85 years old. Dr. Dixon, a native of New York City, practiced dentistry there until his retirement twelve years ago.

The dictum that Americans who live abroad do so at their own risk and with the definite understanding that they will receive no protection from the United States should the nation in which they live become embroiled in war should be permanent American policy, Oswald Garrison Villard asserted yesterday at the National Republican Club, 54 West Fortieth Street.
A new demand for gold in the Orient was reported today by the Department of Commerce on the basis of advices from Singapore.

Italian Legations throughout Latin America are calling the attention of local sociologists and writers to the San Remo literary prize for the best work on the best method of combating communism. The prize carries a cash reward of 50,000 lire.

The third week of this session of the Legislature has closed without a single issue developing on which the two major parties are in real disagreement. If the current trend is followed, legislative leaders said today, the session would be the shortest and most harmonious in many years.
Wayne Sabin, sixth in the national ranking last year, blasted Bryan M. (Bitsy) Grant of Atlanta, fourthranking player and a member of the Davis Cup team, from the Dixie tennis championship today.

FROM a study of the past year in the theatre, three facts chiefly emerge. Conclusions may follow. The facts are: (??) The theatre has made serious attempts to reorganize itself. (2) Plays of real intelligence and qualm ity have found a public to support them. (3) There has been a wave of popularity for affable flippancythat is, for flippancy that is neither satirical nor "daring" but as harmless as a charade in a country house.

" Are you going to the opera?" is a question heard many times during the past week at Vassar College dinner tables, on the ski slopes of Sunset Hill and on the shore of the lake where students chat as they put on and take off skates.
Robert Grant 3d and J. R. Leonard, both of New York, will meet tomorrow for the Canadian men's singles racquets championship now held by the former.

The annual dinner of the Swiss Society of New York was attended by 450 persons last night at the Hotel Plaza. Irving Weber, president of the society, presided. Marc Peter, Swiss Minister to the United States, was the guest of honor.

Moses J. Freund, a retired linen importer, for many years a member of Freund, Freund Co., died yesterday at his residence, 139 West Eighty-second Street, after an illness of seven months. He was 71 years old.

For the first time in a century mocratic domination of the New York City legislative field finds elf challenged by a group of men who are well aware of their rights d extremely vigilant in exercising system.

A benefit bridge will be given by Manhattan Chapter, National Society, Daughters of the American Revolution, Friday afternoon in the Blue Room of the Hotel McAlpin. Miss Eunice Palmer Otis is head of the arrangements committee and Miss Jane H. Bull is vice chairman of the committee.

Among recent accessions to the Fort Ticonderoga Museum is the punch bowl of Sir William Johnson, a dish of Chinese Lowestoft, Famille Rose, dating from 1750. Given by Mrs. Willet C. Ely, it has been put in a case with the Philip Schuyler punch bowl. With it is a book from Sir William's library, "Thought on Civil Libert," London, 1765.

Two domestic employes will describe the conditions under which they work at an experience meeting on the proposed legislation for household workers on Wednesday at 3:30 P. M. at the Women's City Club, 20 West Fifty-first Street. Mrs. Emily Sims Marconnier, chairman of the club's committee on industry, will introduce them as a nursery governess and a general houseworker, and they will speak without further identification for the protection of their jobs.

The address of Governor Lehman before the State Bar Association at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, New York City, last night follows: To the vast majority of the people of our country both fascism and communism are abhorrent. They logically see no vital difference between them.

IN a few weeks now the British Government will be calling for volunteers to man the new balloon barrage, or "stockade" as it has more recently been called, which is to provide London with some means of defense against raiding aircraft.
The Men's Glee Club of Bucknell University will leave Feb. 6 on a sevenday concert tour. They will go first to Washington, D. C., where they will spend two days. The next three days will be

Admiral Sir Allan Frederic Everett, who in 1918 and 1919 commanded the fourth light cruiser squadron with the Grand Fleet and from 1919 to 1921 the eighth light cruiser squadron in North America, died today at the age of 69.

Discussions are in progress for the acquisition by the United Fruit Company of the Munson Steamship Line's properties in the West Indies, its pier properties in Boston and the steamship Munargo, according to reports from Boston yesterday. The price under
Deputy Mayor Curran has brought down his foot hard on that peculiarly noxious reptile in the fair garden of our English tongue-
A survey now being conducted by the Save the Children Fund, Inc., 1 Madison Avenue, has indicated the Immediate need of proper food, shoes, warm clothing and other welfare help by children

The Hershey Bears increased their lead in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League tonight, defeating Baltimore, 3 to 2. Demarco's goal in the first period gave the Orioles a lead they held until Blinco tallied in the second period and deadlocked the score.

An almost universal policy on the part of shoe manufacturers of restricting their purchases to immediate needs was attributed in the market last week to fear of general business, rather than to internal conditions within the shoe industry.

It is an established fact that a dyed-in-the-wool angler will travel a thousand miles or more to meet the Spring-run salmon, and we've known men to travel almost that far just to catch trout on a favorite stream. Yesterday a friend of ours dropped by to announce that he was off on

The marriage of Miss Genevieve Dayton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen H. Dayton of West Chester, Pa., to the Rev. Dr. Charles Stedman Macfarland, clergyman, author and peace leader of Mountain Lakes, N. J., took place here

SPECIAL trains to the South go out in extra sections these Winter days, and at regular intervals several hundred travelers, with friends seeing them off, gather at the Pennsylvania station for the ceremonies of departure.

Asserting that technological advances in the art of steel making have induced greater employment rather than reducing the number of jobs, Walter S. Tower, executive secretary of the American Iron and Steel Institute, which comprises virtually the entire steel industry of the United States, told a group of Pennsylvania manufacturers last week that "bigness" was essential in modern steel production.

Prominent members of society and the musical world will assemble tonight in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for a "musical soiree" arranged by Mrs. Vincent Astor and several of her friends to assist the Musicians Emergency Fund in providing employment and rehabilitation for musicians out of work and in need. An unusual Sunday evening's diversion is forecast.

A "faculty" of twenty-seven, including twenty-two managers, was announced today for the Cardinals' baseball school at Winter Haven, Fla., Feb. 21 to March 19. Vice President Branch Rickey will direct activities at the school, held primarily to correct weaknesses in

Vieente Lombardo Toledano, general secretary of the Mexican Laborers Confederation, commonly known as the C. T. M., issued a statement to foreign correspondents today urging foreign oil companies to leave Mexico since they were unwilling to submit to "the laws of the country."
A survey of Wilson College campus organizations reveals that seven groups with a total enrollment of nearly 300 are interested in music in some form, although the college gives no degree in music.

Representative J. Parnell Thomas, Republican, of New Jersey, expressed belief today that the Administration was spending $5,000,000 annually to maintain "the largest staff of paid propagandists known to American government."

If the ultraselect group of the world's most important babies has been pondering anything except where the next feeding is coming from, a good deal of thought has been given in imperial and royal nurseries to a recruit from the Netherlands.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The letter of Jacques W. Redway on sloppy speech published in THE TIMES last Sunday is one which might well be addressed to the newspapers of the country-or at least those which publish "funnies" for children.

Paced by Lee Creede, sprint ace, who had a hand in setting two new pool records, Williams College defeated Massachusetts State, 57-20, tonight in the State pool. Creede won the 50-yard free style event in the record time of 0:24.5 and swam the first leg on the 400-yard relay four that set a 3:43.7 mark.

EMORY is a notorious trickster, yet, after cudgeling it soundly, I can recall no more joyous picture than "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs," which the Walt Disney cartoon factory has delivered to the crowded doors of the Radio City Music Hall. It is so delightful, so

Miss Sonja Henie, figure skating star whose Hollywood Ice revue opens at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night, arrived from Cleveland yesterday. Between sips of orange juice at a cocktail party in her honor at the Madison Square Garden Club she

The New Jersey League of Women Voters will hold a State-wide conference on "State Issues Before the 1938 Legislature" Wednesday at the Beechwood Hotel in' Summit. Mrs. Leonard H. Robbins, State president, will preside.

Miss Virginia Gray, daughter of Dudley Gray of this city, was married to Richard Beaumaris Bulkeley Jr. yesterday afternoon in St. John's Episcopal Church here. The ceremony was performed by the Very Rev. Walter H. Gray and the Rev. William T. Hooner.

THE problem of writing a book about music for laymen remains a difficult one. To what extent shall the writer attempt to explain laws of rhythm, melody. harmony, tempo, accent, form. etc.? Or shall he insist purely upon the expressive character of the music. and by

Many native Southerners now residing in this city and a large group of their friends are planning supper parties for the annual Blue Ridge Ball, to be given Friday night in the main ballroom of the Plaza. The ball was established some years ago to raise funds for the support of the
James J. Braddock, boxing's miracle man, was $19,942 richer yesterday after his surprising tenround victory over Tommy Farr in Madison Square Garden on Friday night. With that quiet confidence
The evolution of transportation from its most primitive foot travel to interplanetary rocket-ships of the future will be presented in moving episodes at the New York World's Fair, 1939.

Attention -is centered upon the business man in these days of White House conferences with industrial leaders. Who is the business man What is his place in American life? An attempt to answer these questions is made in the. following article. The author is a Washington observer in close touch with business men throughout the country.

SYNCHRONOUSLY with the Whitney Exhibition of Ameri can Landscape of the nineteenth century, the Frazier Gallery has opened an exhibition (to be reviewed later) of paintings of the Hudson River School, including pictures by Cole, Doughty, Church, Sully and a score of others.

ONE experiences a genuine thrill in looking over the Spring woolens this season. We refer now to those designed and woven in America. Three things strike one immediately: First, the beauty of color; second, the numbers of ensemble woolens, and, third, the presence of many sheers that are almost as light as crepes.

Today a busy country pauses for a few minutes to listen by radio to a few tributes paid to Samuel F. B. Morse. It was 100 years ago that, after six years of thinking, experimenting and starving, he produced his first successful experimental telegraph.

Congress passed a law today limiting the profits of merchants to not more than twenty per cent. Because of the instability of the Nicaraguan monetary unit, the cordoba, many merchants are speculating. in exchange and increasing the price of merchandise more than 100 per cent.

Viscount Swinton, the 45-year-old Air Minister, is the center of a political storm over the government's rearmament program. There is insistent clamor for his removal in favor of some greater "hustler," and Winston Churchill, Air Minister from 1918 to 1921, has many backers for the post.

Wesleyan added another to its string of basketball victories tonight, defeating Massachusetts State College, 57 to 29. Phelps was high scorer for Wesleyan with 15 points, and Bembers led Massachusetts State with 9. The guarding of Sonstroem and Nelson was a feature.

Madonna House which furthers an extensive recreational and vocational program for underprivileged adults and children in a crowded district of the city will be aided by a card party and dance to be held the night of Feb. 3 at the WaldorfAstoria. Alfred J. Talley is chairman and Arthur J. W. Hilley, treasurer, of the civic committee that is sponsoring the benefit. Miss Mary Ross Farley heads the ladies committee for the event.

The annual card party under the auspices of the Educational Auxiliary of the Leake and Watts Orphan House will take place the A afternoon of Feb. 16 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Paul R. Hartmann is chairman and E Mrs. Robert H. Sellers vice chairman of the benefit committee.

MY EARS ARE BRENT. By Joseph Mitchell. Illustrated by photographs. 284 pp. New York: Sheridan House. $2.50. MR. MITCHELL is a sort of Stephen Crane of this generation's newspaper city rooms; a somber athlete with an exceptional writing talent who finds Harlem and the lower East Side the most interesting localities in town.

CALIFORNIA, with fifty-three broadcasting stations, leads all States in the number of such transmitters, according to a report of the Federal Communications Commission. New York is second with fortynine and Texas is third with fortyseven. Next in line is Pennsylvania, with thirty-seven. Illinois has thirty-one.

Enlarging its original plan of advocating peace through armaments and man power, the Women's Patriotic Conference on National Defense has broadened its objectives to include the defense of American social and civic ideals. The change of program is announced by the chairman, Mrs.
The son of the President of the United States has lately spent several days in Massachusetts in quest of a candidate for Governor of the State.

Mr. and Mrs. H. Enton Adelson (nee Mimi Lasdon), Deal. N. J., announce the birth of a son, Louis F..Adelson 2d, Monday, Jan. 17, Fitkin Hospital, Neptune, N. J. BLANCO-Mr. and Mrs. Frank, announce birth of a daughter, Jan. 21, 1938, at Polyclinic Hospital. Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Cohen announce birth of a daughter, Janet Frances, Jan. 19, Jewish Hospital, Brooklyn.

The Montreal Canadiens, breaking loose from a two-week slump; crushed the New York Americans, 4-0, tonight and stepped into second place in the National Hockey League's international group, a point ahead of the Americans.

FROM January through April, this year, the 150th anniversary of the founding of Australia will be celebrated in Sydney, the premier city, and in New South Wales, the Mother State. B. S. B. Stevens, the Premier of

YANKEE BOOKSELLER. The Reminiscences of Charles E. Goodspeed. Illustrated. 325 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $3.75. "NOW, I said, I can do what I always wanted to do: I can try bookselling." But when Charles E. Goodspeed made this exultant remark to himself in the late Nineties he hadn't come into a fortune or been favored by any benison of security.

Paced by Miss Hildegarde Gross, who scored nine field goals for a total of 18 points, the New College girls' basketball combination defeated Teachers College, 49 to 21, yesterday at Thompson Gymnasium. The winners took the lead at the outset and never were in danger.

Recent- events suggest that the armed forces of Paraguay are roughly equally divided between the followers of Colonel Rafael Franco, who was overthrown last August, and those who are willing to cooperate with the civilians and politicians who ruled the country before and during the Chaco war.

Trial of the government's suit to dissolve the Aluminum Company of America as a billion dollar trust, under the Sherman Act, cannot get under way before April 4, Federal Judge John C. Knox said last week when attorneys for both sides appeared before him for a determination of a date.

The Milwaukee municipal government is proudly nearing the point where it will be free of all bonded indebtedness. Controller William H. Wendt estimates that the point will be reached by Jan. 1, 1943. At that time, he says, the city's amortization fund, set up in 1923 to wipe out Milwaukee's bonded debt, will have grown

Miss Cathryn W. Popple, daughter of Bruce Popple of Binghamton, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Popple, was married this morning to Edwin Francis McLaughlin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles V. McLaughlin of Pittsfield, Mass. The Rev. Philip J.

Resolutions calling for the general betterment of conditions in Harlem through State and city legislation were adopted last night by the Harlem Legislative Committee after a six-hur conference attended by about five hundred residents of the community.

Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo has ordered an election to determine whether the members of Local 102 of the Hod Carriers Union, which Norman Redwood headed when he was murdered last February, wish to amalgamate with Local 45 of the same international union.

At the annual meeting of the Westchester County Bar Association here on the night of Feb. 4 the nominating committee will recommend the re-election of eight present officers and the election of Frank J. Lamb and Arthur D. Brennan as directors, the committee has announced.

Miss Mary Stacy Lakin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert C. Kakin of Lake Avenue, Greenwich, was married to George Geoffrey Hoffman of Pleasantville, N. Y., at the home of the bride this afternoon by the Rev. Frank Ritter Shumway of Rochester, N. Y., brother-in-law of the bride.
The capture of Peter Anders in the abduction of Charles S. Ross left unsolved only two of 114 kidnapping committed since the passage of the Federal "Lindbergh act" in June, 1932.

THIS is a promise: a Friday night tentatively set for early February will find The One Act Play Magazine coming out from behind its covers and moving onto the stage of the Bayes Theatre as The One-Act Repertory Theatre.

A new collegiate skyscraper will receive its first students next week when Fenn College in Cleveland begins to move into its twenty-twostory building. Erected as one of the most elaborate clubhouses in the country, the $2,000,000 structure, which has never been occupied, was recently purchased by the college from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation at one-fourth of its original cost.

CALLING the present total mileage of divided lane highways in the United States entirely inadequate, the American Automobile Association urged last week that this type of construction be widely extended and called on motorists to see that diversion of road money by the States be ended, so that funds can be provided for more building of this type.

Rallying on the closing holes, Charles H. Mayo Jr. of Long Beach, former Long Island amateur chainpion, advanced to the final of the annual Miami Biltmore golf tournament today. He eliminated Earl Christiansen, Miami policeman, up.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange were 5 to 10 points lower yesterday under liquidation of Bombay straddles and hedging operations by spot interests.
The Bureau of Agricultural Economics reported today that British India ha' sustained greater losses in international trade in cotton this season than any other producing country.

Thomas E. Dewey, District Attorney of New York, observed last week an increasing number of instances which, in his opinion, illustrated an increased efficiency of operation of his office through a more rapid disposition of cases than district attorneys in the past had been able to achieve.

Going right to the spot where history has been made and recreating it through a recital program is a plan used by the Indiana University Foundation to arouse Hoosiers to the historical significance of their communities.

Two hundred and fifty years ago Emanuel Swedenborg was born. Swedes will celebrate the event and remind the world of its debt to an extraordinary figure, a strange mixture of scientist and mystic, engineer and theologian. Only Leonardo was his peer in versatility, in the ability to probe a problem at one piercing glance and suggest a cogent solution. In these days,

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Jan. 20: CAPTAINS Gaddis, W. P., Newport R. I., to 12th Naval District, San Francisco, Calif., in May. Soule. C. C. Jr., Boston, Mass., to Navy Yard, Boston, Mass., as captain of the yard.

An economy book service has been established by the Y. M. C. A. at the University of Vermont. The exchange will handle second-hand textbooks. Standard prices will be set up and the established price level will eliminate "scalping," a bit of business manoeuvring whereby a flush student could buy in books cheap from needy students and sell at a profit to needy students.

The Columbia University School of Architecture will meet a "changing emphasis in the teaching of architectural design" with a new series of professional evening courses on the planning and construction of buildings, to be given during the Spring session,

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Oakley Sherwood, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick William Dunton Sherwood of Great Neck, L. I., to Martin Vincent Callagy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin F. Callagy of this city, took place yesterday morning in the Church of the Blessed Sacrament, West Seventyfirst Street.

As far as Larry S. MacPhail is concerned, the Dodgers may be called "the daffiness boys" or anything else "just as long as they're called something." "It's the silent treatment that's bad," the new general manager of the Dodgers said today.

Belief that the business recession is approaching bottom is universal among industrial purchasing executives, according to the monthly report of the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.
EASTWARD SWEEPS THE CURRENT. A Saga of the Polynesian Seafarers. By Alida Sims Malkus. With illustrations by Dan Sweeney. 394 pp. Philadelphia, Pa.: The John C. Winston Company. $2.

King and Queen appeared publicly together for the first time in Egypt's history today when King Farouk and his bride, Farida, reviewed a parade of Boy Scouts, Girl Scouts and athletes from the balcony of Abdin Palace.

Any public official who hopes for immortality through the medium of a portrait displayed on the walls of a city, State or Federal building may have his wish gratified through the WPA Federal Art Project, it became known yesterday.

An appeal for continued support of the Jewish colonization movement in Palestine in a time of renewed persecution of Jews in Rumania, Germany and Poland was voiced in Washington tonight by speakers before the National Conference for Palestine, meeting in observance of the completion of twenty years of Jewish settlement in the Holy Land.

Presidential approval of a project for indexing part of the national census of 1920 was announced yesterday by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator. An appropriation of $2,250,000 to finance the project for six months was granted.
Two spectacular second-half rallies made for a great show at Madison Square Garden last night as a gathering of 7,650 thrilled to the seventh of the college basketball double-headers.
Andrew Furuseth, president of the International Seamen's Union since 1908, died in a nursing home in this city today after a year's illness, at the age of 84.

President Roosevelt last week studied American business. His interest stemmed from the twin aims of his administration-recovery and reformfor the two had come into conflict. In hope of reconciling them, he sought the views of representatives of finance and industry.

A CLOUD of mystery surrounds the fate of the "Charlie Chan" series of detective stories as a result of Warner Oland's indefinite suspension by Twentieth Century-Fox last Tuesday after the actor's fourth refusal within a week to complete "Charlie Chain at the Ringside."
The thirteenth annual military ball and pageant of the Veterans of Foreign Wars of the United States, Department of New York, will take place on Feb. 18 at the Astor.
HEIL, DORA (Dec. 5). Estate, approximately S16,000. To Dorothy Gorges, niece; Harold Gorges. nephew, 1 West 85th St., one-half residue each. Paul and Anna Gorges, 1 West 85th St., executors.

President Roosevelt's message on national defense, which will probably be sent to Congress Monday or Tuesday, is expected to precipitate the most far-reaching changes in our national defense structure since the signing of the Washington Naval Treaty in 1922.
