A one-week course in flower gardening, designed to be of special interest to owners of small home gardens and to those who are planning new homes, will be given at the New Jersey College of Agriculture, Rutgers University, New Brunswick, beginning Friday.

Declines in inventories ranging up to 28.6 per cent were noted for thirty out of sixty-four divisions of local department stores at the end of December, in comparison with the same period a year ago, according to the monthly survey issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Hundreds of friends and political associates of Senator Alben W. Barkley, majority leader of the chamber, paid tribute to him at a testimonial dinner here tonight.

" The country is faced with ten to fifteen more years of spending for relief or the crash of the capitalist system," Governor Earle declared here today, adding that continued Federal expenditures for this purpose during the next few years might add $10,000,000,000 to the national debt.

The merchandising efficiency of independent retail stores is gradually but steadily improving, largely because of the entry of many former chain-store employes into the independent field, according to Henry S. Sommers of G. Sommers Co., St. Paul, Minn., who was re-elected last week to the presidency of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute. Declaring that chain-store

An individual medley race of 150 yards will feature the open A. A. U. swimming meet which the Women's Swimming Association of New York will hold in its seventy-five-foot pool at 204 East Seventy-seventh Street this afternoon. Five events are on the program, which will get under way at 2:45 o'clock.

If the country recovers to the extent predicted in some quarters, there will be no need for the abandonments of railroads sometimes recommended, an editorial in the current issue of Railway Age asserts. The publication discusses the probable effects on the railways of an increase of $100,000,000,000 in the national income.
The Pan American Airways' troublebeset China Clipper returned to Cabrillo Beach late today, after it made a start for Alameda, Calif., the base from which it departed late yesterday for Honolulu.

THE FAMILY OF NATIONS, ITS NEED AND ITS PROBLEMS. Essays and Addresses. By Nicholas Murray Butler. 400 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $3. By WILLIAM MacDONALD MOST of the thirty-one -addresses or articles in this volume, all but one of them delivered or published during the past four years in this country or Europe, have a common theme.

The Middle Atlantic Division of the Student Peace Federation, of which Sister Rose de Lima of St. Elizabeth's College is director, this week elected William Matison of Fordham University as president of the group.

Since American gardeners have been learning things about the rhododendrons they have also learned a bit about the heaths and heathers, and now these good small shrubs are appearing in increasing numbers. They will remain to become beloved and prosper only if the right type is chosen for the region; otherwise discouragement must follow.

A service station planned especially for trucks with a hotel for drivers and a unique "signal service" for fleet owners, the first of its kind in the East, has just been opened by Mayflower Stations, Inc., at Mianus, Conn. Drivers will be able to rest at the station's hotel, which is a 150-year-old Colonial house modernized and refurnished, with sleeping quarters, showers and recreation room provided.

Defeating Amherst, 41 to 23, for its sixth straight triumph before a capacity crowd in the academy gymnasium, the unbeaten Army basketball team set the pace as the cadets won two of three varsity athletic contests this afternoon.
Six University of Georgia psychology students who gave up sleep for 100 hours in the cause of science were pronounced "in a good state of health" today at the end of their ordeal.

Retail trade in the Fifth District was above a year ago in both the first and second weeks of January and the same trend was unofficially reported this week. The gain this week will approximate 5 per cent. Wholesale trade in the district is better than in December, and the Spring outlook is more encouraging.

ETIQUETTE: The Department of Sanitation recently sponsored a survey of ideas of politeness among New York City school children. Last week results were announced. There was some dissent from custom. Joseph Terry McCaddon, retired circus man, died on Friday at the home of his son, Joseph T. McCaddon Jr., at Great Neck, L. I., after a brief illness. His age was 78. Mr. McCaddon, who was born in

Thomas E. Grady, rate and traffic consultant, said today that he had offered to cancel his contract with the city of Miami "if, in the opinion of the City Commission, I have become an obstacle to a satisfactory settlement" of rate litigation.

BEFORE Langston Hughes left for war-torn Madrid he fin ished the libretto of an opera for the composer William Grant Still. Today that opera is well on its way toward completion (it was begun as soon as Still finished his new symphony in G minor, lately introduced by Leopold Stokowski and the Philadelphia Orchestra).
The police here were without a clue today to the identity of a thug who shot and killed Detective Arthur Materka yesterday in a holdup in the National grocery store at 4,100 Hudson Boulevard.

More than 200,000 men and women have registered in 35,000 classes maintained by the WPA Adult Education Program of the Board of Education in this city since its inception two years ago, Gustav A. Stumpf, administrator of the project, disclosed in his annual report.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The recent resolution of the American Association for the Advancement of Science concerning the creation of a world organization of national scientific societies is a great step forward toward the goal of a universal organization of science such as I proposed seven years ago.

SEED collecting is an inexpensive hobby which affords excuse for rambling by stream or lake, or in field, meadow or woods. In the city one extends the quest for curious and interesting specimens to street vendor carts and in curio shops.

Friendship between the United States and Great Britain was the theme of the second annual Colonial Ball held last night at the Pierre under the auspices of the junior members of the Daughters of the American Revolution and members of the Continental Guard, Sons of the American Revolution.

The Dartmouth freshmen sextet won a fast game from Exeter today, 6 to 4. The school team forged ahead in the first period when Bill Wood shot a pair of goals, but Dartmouth took the lead on Campbell's second goal late in the third period and clinched the decision with one by Meloon at the 13:40 mark, having a total of three goals for the frame.

A suit attacking the validity of the New York City budget, with its appropriation of $682,412,923 for 1938 and $335,282,601 for the first six months of 1939, was filed in Supreme Court yesterday a few minutes before the noon closing hour.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Is it not possible that the present automobile slump is caused by the body designers? There has been increasing mechanical efficiency, and with it increasing bodily discomfort.

Miss Mabel H. Rydahl, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chamello S. Rydahl of Detroit, was married last night to Dr. J. William Maller, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William Maller, at the home of the bridegroom, 1,000 Grand Concourse, the Bronx. The Rev. Dr. Henry Schorr performed the ceremony.

Phosphorus is now shipped in tank cars. That bald statement means nothing to the man in the street, but much to the chemist. For phosphorus is an element which catches fire merely when exposed to air. Tame it and it becomes useful. In fact it is a necessity in industry, medicine, agriculture, war.
Clarence R. Wise, secretary of the manufacturing committee of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, died yesterday at Overlook Hospital after a short illness. He was 43 years old.

Mrs. Charles Gordon Smith of Scarsdale, daughter of Representative Hampton P. Fulmer of South Carolina, admitted today that she was "the world's worst speller," but insisted that her husband, manager of the State Insurance Fund, was good and should have been adjudged individual winner of a team spelling bee between the Scarsdale Town Club and the Scarsdale Woman's Club here last night.
Steadiness in the spot quotation but further weakness in the forward rate characterized the French franc in yesterday's dealings in foreign exchange. As is usual on a Saturday, the market was quiet.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will open a Model Legislature made up of 2,000 youth delegates from all parts of the State at City College over the coming week-end. Aubrey Williams and Mrs. Eleanor Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, will be other speakers during the session.

IN his novel "Boom Town," which Alfred A. Knopf will publish on February 7. Jack O'Connor tells the story of the life and death of an Arizona mine town. The background should be a familiar one to him, for he is an Arizonian by birth. and one of his ,grandfathers was a prospector and the other was a rancher. Mr. O'Connor himself

The attitude of the government toward industry has settled down temporarily to this: Business groups who come to see the President by invitation, or by their own suggestion, are expected to answer the question, "What can government do for you ?"

AN agreement of the Los An geles Board of Supervisors to buy as the nucleus of a county park a tract on which stands a small forest of Joshua trees is the most recent development in California's half-dozen treesaving campaigns.

Winter, with its sudden fierce gales in the North Sea and English Channel, is a season of hard work for the cable ships of the British Postoffice. Rough seas exert unusual strain on the 240 submarine cables--containing some 25,000 miles of wire and covering a distance of 5,000 nautical miles--for which the postoffice is responsible.

With increasing interest in radio production as an extra-curricular activity, nearly 200 students at Cornell University are receiving training in the scientific and technical phases of radio. In the School of Electrical Engineering forty juniors are registered in the basic course in electronics and twenty-one men have elected the senior option in communications.

TWENTY hours and twelve minutes after porpoising off the bay at San Diego, Calif., last week eighteen of the United States Navy's newest patrol bombers began settling down on Pearl Harbor, Honolulu. Although the navy considered the flight a routine delivery of new aircraft, observers noted

Reporting widespread support among manufacturers in the coat and suit industry for the elimination of retail sales by wholesalers to consumers, I. A. Hirschmann, vice president of Saks-Fifth Avenue, said yesterday the campaign will now be extended to other industries, including dresses, furs, children's wear and furniture.
Twelve new courses, several of which have been included by undergraduate request or alumnae recommendation, are to be added to the two-year curriculum offered at Stoneleigh College for young women.

A NEW process for finishing cars--called "porcelainizing"-was recently introduced in New York by Porcelainize, a company with offices at 726 Eleventh Avenue. The new process, which is a chemical one and is accomplished without heat, is said to produce a surface on automobiles comparable to that produced in the annealing of porcelain.
The price tendency was generally lower but the trading pace was slightly accellerated in the bond section on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

Dismissal of the 201st member of the Police Department to be dropped during the commissionership of Lewis J. Valentine was disclosed yesterday in the regular departmental orders.

Henry A. Soffer, first member of the American Labor Party named to the bench, took the oath of office yesterday morning in the Rockaway Beach Magistrate's Court in the presence of Mayor La Guardia, Samuel Seabury and many officials and citizens of Queens County.

The marriage of Miss Edith Margareta Hagen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin A. Hagen of Brooklyn; to Dr. Clifton E. Benson of Bremerton, Wash., son of the Rev. and Mrs. B. A. Benson of Mason City, Iowa, took place yesterday afternoon in Zion Norwegian Lutheran Church, Brooklyn.

Sixteen corporations and thirty individuals were final defendants in the anti-trust trial which started Oct. 4. Originally there were twenty-three oil companies, three trade publications and forty-six individuals but the number was reduced by directed verdicts as the trial progressed..

There is universal speculation in Peiping over whether the new tariff established by the provisional government and which is considerably lower than the former rates, will be extended to all parts of China now under control of the Japanese Army.

A plea for closer cooperation -between veterans of the National Guard and its active regiments to counteract subversive elements was made yesterday at the close of the two-day annual convention of the National Guard Association of the State of New York in the Hotel Astor.

Residential colleges are "miniature commonwealths," loyal to the principles of democracy, where "the art of living together is regarded as one of the liberal arts, and therefore an integral part of college training,"

Invention within twenty-five to fifty years of movies that can be "felt" and "smelled" as well as seen and heard, and of "time machines" that will shatter all privacy by projecting themselves into the past and present, was predicted yesterday by Robert Edmond Jones, stage and color designer, in an address at the final session of the conference of the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures.

LINCOLN ELLSWORTH does not fit into any category of explorers; he is unique. He is one of two American polar explorers who have contributed heavily of their own funds to finance their expeditions; the other is a woman. Like most explorers he is not deficient in ego; and, like others of the breed, he has his sentimental side.

Mr. and Mrs. Harold Fowler Sperry of this city today announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Eliot Sperry, to Melville Edward Hitchcock, son of Mrs. Melville Hitchcock and the late Mr. Hitchcock of El Paso, Texas.

Fourteen government agencies awarded 108 supply contracts valued at $5,383,531 in the week ended on Jan. 20 under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Department of Labor, has announced. Of the total, $1,657,310 was for indefinite amounts based on last year's purchases and for delivery, if, when, and where needed.
FOR the past year I have been reading articles in the drama section of THE TIMES on "What's wrong with the theatre?" I also have observed that most of these articles have been written by producers.

The final examination period at the College of William and Mary will begin Monday, Jan. 31, and will close on Feb. 8. The second semester, beginning Feb. 11, will offer E a few changes in administration and curriculum.

Congress should not sacrifice local initiative and responsibility in drafting national planning legislation, Chairman Arthur E. Morgan of the Tennessee Valley Authority said today. In a statement sent to the House, Rivers and Harbors Committee,. Mr. Morgan added:

Restmnts of this community will gather Wednesday evening at the staon of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad to witness the veiling of a bronze tablet comemorating the arrival 100 years go of the first train of the old orris Essex line.

In an analysis of the passenger traffic report recently issued by the metropolitan division of the State Transit Commission for the year ended July 1, 1937, Joseph E. Kean, secretary of the Central Mercantile District, states that the figures show that 339,962,330 passengers used the subway, tube and elevated trains in that area during the year.

Miss Mary Howard, daughter of Mrs. Abner Updegraff Howard of this place and the late Mr. Howard, was married here this afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church to Dr. William Weir Fitzgerald, son of Dr. and Mrs. Fred Jesse ComfortFitzgerald, also of Yonkers, by the Rev. Wendell Prime Keeler.
Judge Edwin O. Lewis of Fourth House, Overbrook, has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Eleanor Lord Lewis, to Adkins Lowell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dwight E. Lowell of Mermont, Bryn Mawr.
Some 1,200 New York Rover rooters traveled 150-odd miles today to lend their favorite hockey team moral and verbal support in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League game with Atlantic City.

New national intercollegiate records were created by Princeton swimmers today in the 150-yard back-stroke and the 300-yard medley relay as Old Nassau's undefeated forces literally swamped Cornell, 54-21, for their sixth straight one-sided triumph.

The Richmond Hill Rifle Club of Long Island maintained its lead at the end of the second day's shooting in the team competition for the third annual middle-Atlantic indoor rifle championships today as a new individual leader arose at the Essex Troop Armory.

The members of the special Senate committee to investigate unemployment and relief, after three weeks of public hearings and access to data submitted from many sources, have gained considerable information concerning the causes of the present business recession and proposals to cure it.

As a result of the sales activity in Alden Estates, a new community rising on sixty-eight acres on King Street, Port Chester, Westchester County, the developers have expanded their plans to provide for the erection of between 100 and 120 concrete masonry houses there during 1938, according to John W. Fries, general manager.
Governor Earle looked hopefully this week at his latest prescription for curing the ills of his most "perplexing" patient, the anthracite industry.

Cornell tonight sent Yale deep into the Intercollegiate Basketball League cellar, scoring by 42 to 37 before 500 spectators in the Payne Whitney Gymnasium. It was the Elis' sixth straight set-back this season.

Details of the President's Birthday Ball planned for next Saturday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel were announced yesterday by Basil O'Connor, general chairman of the New York committee for the national celebration.

WASHINGTON.-How would a Cabinet hostess go about interviewing a Cabinet hostess? This was the question put to Mrs. Claude A. Swanson, petite, vivacious and blue-eyed wife of the Secretary of the Navy, as she sat in the drawing room of her home in R Street early on a Winter evening.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Carolyn Wear, daughter of Colonel and Mrs. David Walker Wear of the Astor and Binghamton, N. Y., to John Sutherland Mitchell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel K. Mitchell of Wilkes-Barre, Pa.

SNOW lies deep over the north country, and skiers by hundreds crowd the small towns. On the practice slope outside almost any town, from the eastern foothills of the White Mountains, across Vermont to the Adirondacks, skitow engines are chug-chugging, ropes revolving, strong arms ready to grasp them and be pulled up to the summit of a gleaming, white expanse-a wide, steep open pasture, spotted here and there, perhaps, with groups of pointed spruces.
THE rains are over in Guatemala and from the blue sky cross which the tumbled white clouds travel the bright sunlight falls on the mountain masses of this little republic.

About half the automobiles registered in New York City had 1938 license plates by yesterday afternoon, Motor Vehicle Commissioner Charles Harnett announced at the close of the business day. He warned motorists they had only six and a half days left in which to get new plates, and urged mailing of

Penn State took undisputed possession of first place in the Eastern Basketball Conference tonight by upsetting Georgetown before 5,000, 42-23. Sol Miehoff, the victors' cocaptain, led the scoring with 17 points to maintain his position as the league's leading scorer.

With rather unusual unanimity expert opinion, in or out of the field of practical industry,-has expressed itself of late to effect that the business reaction has virtually run its course. None of the published comments assumes that rapid recovery will at once ensue; they differ as to the date for important trade revival, and frequently condition its occurrence on the course of policies at Washington.

Flower growers who live along the seacoast complain that they cannot grow as many varieties of plants as those living where the soil is rich. So, in making up their orders for seeds, it perhaps will interest them to learn that the plants dealt with here will thrive in poor soil.
Dr. Frank P. Graves, State Commissioner of Education, ordered today that Edward W. Cooke, who was recently removed as principal of Hornell High School, be reinstated.

Adoption of a 1938 program centering on "Woman's Work" and aimed at equality with men in the field of employment and wages was announced yesterday by Miss Mary Van Kleeck as chairman of the advisory committee on research of the Women's Charter Group.

WITH the new highway to Mexico City, now in its second year of use, already increasing Winter travel across the border by 50 per cent, motorists skimming south are reminded of what awaits them when that route is eventually extended

Mrs. Jeannette Brookings Tuttle, first vice president and honorary historian of New York State Chapter, Daughters of 1812, died here today at the age of 73 in her home at 5 Sage Terrace, after a lengthy illness. She was the widow of George Fuller Tuttle, Plattsburg, N. Y., banker.

With five of its components higher, THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity has advanced to 82.0 for the week ended Jan. 15. This compares with 81.2 (revised) for the previous week and 105.2 for the corresponding week a year ago.

Counsel for the National Labor Relations Board and the United Automobile Workers of America tentatively closed their case today at a hearing into Ford Motor Company labor practices in its St. Louis Assembly plant.

Miss Victoire Baughman Conley, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles H. Conley of Guilford, this place, was married in St. John's Church here this afternoon to Richard Bulen Griffin of Washington, son of Mrs. Paul Bastedo and of the late George F. Griffin of New York and Chicago. The Rev. William H.

Soviet Russia was pictured as a peaceful nation, a bulwark against those who Would do violence to world peace, but for different reasons by two speakers yesterday at a luncheon of the American-Russian Institute in the Hdtel Biltmore.

Mr. and Mrs. George Sawyer of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Sawyer, to Edward L. Stasse, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Stasse of East Orange. Miss Sawyer is a graduate of Middlebury College. Her fiance, who is a graduate of Wesleyan University, is attending the Harvard University Law School.

Captain Charles Morrison Austin, United States Navy, and Mrs. Austin gave a reception today at their home here at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Elizabeth Austin, to Dr. Joseph Wilson Johnson Jr., eldest son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph W. Johnson of Chattanooga, Tenn.
Displaying a smoother and more powerful attack, the University of Toronto defeated Dartmouth, 9-4, today, in an International Intercollegiate League hockey game.

More than 1,600 representatives of the International Business Machines Corporation and its affiliates from the United States and twentyone foreign countries will attend the annual world business congress of the company which opens here tomorrow.
Sixty one persons (the largest number in five years) paid taxes on net incomes of $1,000,000 or more last year, the Treasury disclosed today.

Legislation affecting household employes, pending at Albany, will be discussed by members of the Women's City Club Wednesday afternoon at the club, 20 West Fiftyfirst Street. Speakers will include a general houseworker, governesses and employers.

Through a decree-law promulgated today the citizenship of Rumania's 1,000,000 Jews is questioned. Its drastic conditions are so formulated that it will be extremely difficult for any Jew to establish citizenship rights.

Scores were high at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday despite the adverse conditions. Only eighteen gunners reported. A. L. Burns captured the highover-all cup by breaking 98 out of 100 clays. He added a leg on the

Squash racquets still holds the spotlight in women's sports this week, for tomorrow a large entry of contestants will begin competition for the New York singles championship on the courts of the Rockaway Hunting Club, Cedarhurst, L. I.
The Rev. Israel Harding Noe held to his program of absolute abstinence today despite the physical ravages of a three-week fast undertaken in search of a pure spiritual existence.

Most manufacturing operations in New England have not increased from the low level of December. There has been some improvement in the demand for cotton' goods, mostly in the cheaper grades. The local wool market continues very dull, with prices steady. Women's wear mills are taking some orders and doing enough business to sustain parttime operations.

Judge William H. Byrnes Jr. ruled today that Edward Powell must go to jail if he fails to support his 66-year-old father, even at the expense of supporting his son. Powell told the judge he was unable to pay the court-ordered $6 a month to his aged father because his 21-year-old son was out of work and he had to help the youth.

Zevson, 6-year-old owned by Coward and Coffey, made it four out of six victories at the Fair Grounds race track today when he led home a big field in the $2,500 added Russell E. Stone Memorial Handicap.

The Society of Architects and Engineers of the Board of Education adopted a resolution yesterday branding the recent report of the special architectural commission which attacked the design and construction of school buildings as

TRADE results appeared to turn more uneven in the week but without much change on the average. Sales in the industrial regions are, of course, less favorable than in the big cities, while volume in the farm districts and small near-by towns makes about the best comparison.

NOBODY but a European could have written, or would have tried to write. a book with the special qualities of Gabor Vaszary's "Monpti.' Almost plotless, a simple but sophisticated story of young love and poverty in Paris, it has that

Clearings of the Westchester County Clearing House Association amounted to $3,584,335 for the week ended on Jan. 19, compared with $3,790,937 for the preceding week, and with $2,821,766 for the corresponding week last year.
The first warrant to be issued in the cases of 916 members of the U. A. W. A., arrested since Dec. 9 at gates of the Ford Motor Company was signed today by a justice of the peace of Dearborn.

Bids on seventy-seven issues of securities of municipalities, counties and school districts in thirty-one States, aggregating $5,616,100 in principal amount, were called for today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. The announcement said the bids would be opened on Feb. 10.

The Krupp Works, reputedly the world's greatest armament company, reports for the year ended Sept. 30, 1937, assets of 575,234,000 marks, compared with only 389,174,000 marks in 1932-33, the year Chancellor Adolf Hitler obtained power.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Jan. 19, aggregated $8,290,000,000, or 9 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week and 18 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.

The annual authors' luncheon of the Southern Women's National Democratic Organization will be held on Jan. 29 in the Jade Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. An innovation this year will be the presentation of an award to the author of what is considered by the organization the most distinguished book by a Southerner during the past year.

MUCH has been recently and wisely written about the differences of dramatic taste imposed by three thousand miles of sea-water and by widely separated racial cultures. I do not purpose to add to that debate. None the less; during a brief

MURDER BY PRESCRIPTION. By Jonathan Stayge. 289 pp. New York: Published for The Crime Club, Inc., by Doubleday, Doran Co. $2. EUTHANASIA is a word that completely stumps little Dawn Westlake un til her father, Dr. Westlake, explains that it means what is often called "mercy killing."

Mr. and Mrs. J. Paul Cranston of Wilmington and Rehoboth Beach, Del., have announced the engagement of Mr. Cranston's daughter, Miss Jean Cranston, to J. Jay Hodupp Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Hodupp of New York.

FOR several years the little Princess Theatre in Thirtyninth Street was shabby and deserted. Once a charming playhouse where gay and amusing things lightened the evening, it was falling apart. Broadway was through with it. You would scarcely recognize it as a theatre when you hurried along the street.

About twelve hours after he had been seen shoveling snow in front of his fifteen-room home at 28 Melrose Place here, Frederic Ellsworth Kip, 76-year-oldwealthy retired oil and textile executive, was found dead in his garage shortly after 9 A. M. today.

HIROHITO. Son of Heaven, divine in the eyes of Japanese, remote from men and the world, has recently been forced into the limelight by the war of his country on China. Less than two weeks ago he attended a meeting of the Imperial Council in Tokyo,

All the girls of Georgian Court College will be wearing black cotton stockings when they appear for classes Monday and they will continue that form of "mourning" for a month because their spelling team. lost in a contest with a team from St. Peter's College, a boys' school of Jersey City.

What happens every time in French political history has this week happened again. Within less than two years of the general national election, which returned a big Left majority, there has been sufficient reaction within and without Parliament to necessitate transference of leadership from the Left to what really is the Center.

The Vilanova Wildcats chalked up their sixteenth basketball victory by defeating Pennsylvania Military College, 56 to 38, before a large crowd tonight. Villanova's performance stamped it as the best college team to play in Chester in many years.

The Transport Workers Union, a C. I. O. affiliate, lost the first round in its fight for recognition as sole collective bargaining agent for employes on the city's Independent Subway System when the State Labor Relations Board ruled yesterday that its jurisdiction did not extend to the city subway.

The 1936 census of the population of France reveals a total of 41,906,000 persons in that country, compared with 41,835,000 in 1931 and 27,349,000 in 1801, according to statistics recently made available in Paris and reported to the Department of Commerce by the office of the United States Commercial Attache in Paris.

A thorough grounding in government and economics will be required of every student graduating from Muhlenberg College, the trustees decided this week in approving a recommendation made by Dr. Levering Tyson. new president.
The Federal Trade Commission announced today that it would hold hearings in the following matters on the days indicated in New York in the coming week.
THE SYRIAN DESERT: Caravans, Travel and Exploration. By Christina Phelps Grant. With illustrations and maps. 410 pp. New York: The Macmillan Company. $5.

LAKE PLACID.-Colder weather Lat this resort during the past week has increased the thickness of the ice on Mirror and Placid Lakes to twenty inches or more and it is now a common sight to see automobiles and horses pulling lines of skiers across the frozen surface. The lake is also used as

Citing the fact that the tax load is the most serious burden borne by real estate in New York City, as well as in other parts of the country, Robert H. Armstrong of the firm of Armstrong Armstrong makes the suggestion that the Mayor and other city authorities invite into a general conference realty owners and rent payers for the purpose of discussing means toward easing and equalizing the tax burden. Such a step,

PRONOUNCED 90 per cent complete last week, the Douglas Aircrafts Corporation's forty-passenger, four-engined DC-4 transport will make her maiden flight in late April or early May, officials of the Santa Monica factory have announced.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Hilda L. Perlmutter, daughter of Mrs. Max Perlmutter of this city and the late Mr. Perlmutter, to Dr. Philip Levine, son of Morris Levine of Brooklyn. Miss Perlmutter was graduated from the New Jersey Law School and is an attorney in this city. Dr.

RECESSION or no recession, Hollywood is in the throes of a million dollar mania. Every lot schedules several million-dollar epics. Such conditions are bound to develop a bumper crop of geniuses-for no one is a genius, according to the Hollywood maxim,

Viscount Craigavon, the tall, stern and outspoken Ulster Scot who has governed Northern Ireland as Prime Minister for seventeen years, told the writer this week that he saw no chance for any solution of the Irish question that would satisfy both sides.
To the Music editor: I would like to take issue with you about several things you said in your review of Goodman's swing concert in Carnegie Hall Sunday night last.

CONTRARY: "Quite contrary to the views apparently held in some quarters, the entire business community has, according to my observation, made the most strenuous efforts to maintain the improvement that marked 1936 and early 1937."-Thomas W. Lamont.

Having already named Joe DiMaggio as the recipient of their player-of-the-year prize at their fifteenth annual dinner at the Hotel Commodore next Sunday night , the members of the New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers Association yesterday completed arrangements for the second half of their yearly award program.

Three more Germans accused of treason went to the guillotine this morning. Two of them were convicted by the People's Tribunal on charges of "preparing an enterprise of high treason" and treason to the State. No details were available,

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Jan. 21: COLONEL Keller, F., Cav., General Staff Corps, relieved from detail as a member of the General Staff Corps, and assigned to the 1st Cav. Division, Ft. Bliss, Texas. LIEUTENANT COLONELS

Four Swiss and Austrian plague prevention experts arrived here yesterday Berislav Borcic, League of Nations health representative in China, to initiate another phase of the League's extensive work against epidemics, which is just being launched.

The Silver Room of the Ambassador will be the setting on Saturday night for a dinner dance to be given by officers and members of the Dyer, First Reserve Aero Squadron Club. Colonel Walter G. Kilner, who will fly from Langley Field, Va., to attend the party; Dick Merrill, Jack Lambie and James Blackstone Taylor Jr. will be guests of honor.

One should not be deceived by the vote of 502 to 1 for the new Chautemps government which it received when it first faced the Chamber of Deputies Friday night. All that meant was that the Cabinet will get a chance. The mere fact that Communists and the Center voted together indicates the weakness of the government's position. It hails itself as promising to carry out the Popular Front

The conference last week between President Roosevelt and automobile manufacturers and installment finance company executives centered upon a business practice Which has produced an economic giant-installment selling.

R. G. Field, director of the Bureau of Marine Inspection and Navigation, has suspended the licenses of seven former members of the crew of the Panama-Pacific liner California, according to a decision of Jan. 13, made public today.

Representatives of fruit and vegetable organizations expressed before the Interstate Commerce Commission today opposition to the railroads' application for a 15 per cent increase in freight rates.

Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Ritchie of Flushing, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathleen Helen Ritchie, to Gregory Arnold Lee, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph T. Lee, also of Flushing. Miss Ritchie was graduated from St. Agnes Academy, College Point, and from the College of New Rochelle. Her fiance,

The building industry of New York will honor Alfred Rheinstein, new Commissioner of Housing and Buildings, at a testimonial luncheon to be held under the auspices of the New York Building Congress on Wednesday at the Hotel Commodore.

The reading program in general education, assigned for students of Lehigh University who express a desire to broaden their interests beyond ordinary course instruction, will begin for freshmen with the opening of the second semester, Feb. 3.
If the AngloIrish conference of this week leads to nothing else it will at least be a landmark in that it has brought common sense back to Anglo-Irish relations.
Senator Herring advocated today the establishment of censorship over radio programs. He said he was preparing a bill, "to clean up the radio," because abuse of

A mass of requiem was celebrated yesterday at the Church of St. Paul the Apostle, Columbus Avenue and Sixtieth Street, for Bradish Johnson Jr., 26-year-old foreign correspondent for Spur and News-Week Magazines, who was killed by a shell on Dec. 31 while covering the Insurgent front near Teruel, Spain.

The following WPA Federal Art Project exhibitions are on view this week: Institute of Family Service, 2,250 Fifth Avenue-6 children's paintings, 6 pieces of wood sculpture, 5 easel paintings, 25 graphic prints.
Home buying interest in and around Bernardsville, N. J., has been maintained to a larger degree than usual at this time of the year, according to Ellsworth Dobbs, broker. He reports the purchase by

Charles H. Abrams, counsel to the American Federation of Housing Authorities, will give a series of twelve lectures on real estate topics on successive Tuesdays, beginning Feb. 1, at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.

Contemporary public affairs, Including proposals to obtain permanent peace, uniform divorce laws and the humanization of deportation will be under consideration by the National Council of Jewish Women, whose fifteenth triennial convention opens at Pittsburgh today. It will continue through Friday, with meetings at the William Penn Hotel.

Having gone abroad last Summer to help the United States team to defend the international chess championship at Stockholm, Samuel Reshevsky, national champion, is due to return here during the first week of February, according to advices just received from

Whisperings heard from the Senate, and some outspoken expressions by the Finance Committee for the elimination of the tax upon corporate undistributed profits from the forthcoming revenue legislation, restores a degree of hopefulness for the repeal of this generally distasteful form of taxation.

The metropolitan district will be the scene of two of the three championships sponsored annually by the New York State Golf Association this year as a result of action taken at yesterday's annual meeting of the executive committee of the association at the Yale Club.
Thirty-five thousand persons saw the 12-1 shot Minulus win the $5,000 added Santa Susana Stakes for 3-year-old fillies at Santa Anita Park today. They bet $1,037,437 on the eight races.

MARSHAL BADOGLIO'S contribution to the history of the war in Ethiopia waged by the Fascist government of Italy is a plain soldier's book and nevertheless a masterpiece of the printer's art sumptuously illustrated.

The Navy basketball team won its fourth straight game on the home floor by defeating Western Maryland, 50 to 26, today. The Middies, who led by 24 to 12 at the end of the first half, kept the count close to a 2-to-1 ratio at every stage.

For five days this week Portland's 310,000 people were practically cut off from the world outside, so far as newspapers were concerned. Virtually the only news in the city was supplied by gossip and radio broadcasts. From Saturday afternoon

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.-The President's Birthday Ball and the Winter Cabaret of the Charity League highlight the entertainment program here during the next two weeks.

Mrs. Royder Rothermel, Regent of Walter Hines Page Chapter of the D. A. R., will be hostess at the American Women's Club Thursday at the annual meeting for election of officers and selection of delegates to attend the D. A. R. Congress in Washington.

Despite continued heavy demand for merchandise of practically all types in rural sections of the entire Northwest, retail trade here and in other metropolitan centers of the Ninth Federal Reserve District remained slow during the week. Temperatures above 30 in the last seven days caused a slump in the cities. Unemployment, too, had a tendency to affect business in the larger cities.

Andrew Furuseth was praised by labor leaders here today. "Mr. Furuseth was one of the outstanding labor leaders in the United States," said Secretary Perkins. "During his long and useful career he was of invaluable service in improving working conditions of the men who go to sea." William Green, president of the A. F. of L., said:

CECIL B. DE MILLE, an alumnus of the "theatre of wood," as he quaintly describes the stage, a pioneer in the silent films who added new laurels to his already enviable reputation in the loquacious period of the "theatre of celluloid," finds the "theatre of the air" the most captivating phase of his career as a producer.

AMONG the twenty-five or more exhibitions that fell to the lot of this reviewer last week, and that continue through the present week or longer as indicated, were three unusual print shows. One of these was the annual showing of "One Hundred Prints" selected from an earlier exhibition by the American Society of Etchers in November, and now current at the Grand Central (Vanderbilt Avenue) Galleries.

COMPLAINTS having been made that the theatres do not advertise their correct curtain times, this department has asked every box office man what time his play begins. These are the official findings; they are introduced as evidence on which the playgoer can base his personal findings. This department cannot guarantee that the curtains will rise at the specified time nor that the audience will be ready when the actors are.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Taylor Pendleton, daughter of Mrs. Arthur Thomas Pendleton of this city and the late Mr. Pendleton, to Archibald Gracie Ogden of Boston, son of Mrs. Archibald Gracie Ogden of Elizabeth and the late Mr. Ogden, took place here this afternoon in St. John's Church.

Thieves who dallied to commit vandalism late Friday night or early yesterday morning obtained silver ecclesiastical articles valued at $1,000 and six bottles of whisky left over from a silver-wedding ceremony after breaking into the Concourse Center of Israel, 2,323 Grand Concourse, north of 183d Street, the Bronx.

Figures issued by the Commonwealth statistician show that employment is now back to the predepression level. At the end of 1937 only 8.2 per cent of the trade unionists were unemployed, the lowest since August, 1927, when 6.7 per cent were idle.

The Massachusetts Racing Commission today granted licenses to the Eastern Racing Association, Inc., to conduct horse races at Suffolk Downs, Boston, and to the Agawam Racing and Breeders Association, Inc., to operate at Agawam Park, Agawam.

The furniture, tapestries, silver, rugs and other objects of art mentioned yesterday at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries realized $22,745, bringing the total for the two-day sale to $34,982.50.

Stephen A. McDonald, who has been associated with the Joseph P. Day organization for many years, has been made manager of the auction sales division. He has recently been in charge of the sales promotion department and manager of the New Jersey division of the private sales department.

Etta Lhevinoff, 11-year-old German violinist, will give her first American concert at the Heckscher Theatre on Feb. 20 to help her family establish a new home in this country. Etta and her mother and her father, a once prosperous surgeon, are almost penniless. Relatives have provided for them here since they fled Germanylast Spring to escape a concentration camp.

New York City schools of the future are to have greater recreational and playground facilities. Ellsworth B. Buck, chairman of the Board of Education's buildings and sites committee, announced yesterday. Wherever possible, new schools are to be located near existing parks.

Two organizations clashed last night in a fight for jurisdiction over Broadway theatrical press agents, with the result that Charles Washburn, agent for George Abbott's production of "Brother Rat," and Henry Senber, agent for the Mercury Theatre's productions of "Julius Caesar" and "A Shoemaker's Holiday," resigned their jobs.

The American Construction Council has issued an invitation to all organizations and individuals who are interested directly or indirectly in the construction industry to participate in a national construction forum in this city on March 17 and 18.

In the quiet seclusion of Downing Street two men have been talking things over. One of them is a British Conservative, Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain. The other is an Irish republican, President Eamon de Valera, who twenty years ago was pursued by Britain as a rebel and thrown into prison.

MEXICO CITY.-With the sixyear plan of President Cardenas half way toward completion, foreign interests in Mexico are wondering anxiously what the future holds for them. Is foreign capital to be allowed to stay and cooperate in the great scheme of social transformation, or has the time come when the Mexican Government feels strong enough to carry through its plans without outside help? Large interests are at stake

The man known as Peter Anders-his real name is John Henry Seadlund-onetime lumberman who has confessed the kidnapping of Charles S. Ross and the murder of Mr. Ross and his own accomplice, James Atwood kn Gray, arrived in Chicago tonight by plane from St. Paul, Minn.
French and Japanese today -ran into new difficulties when French policemen refused to permit three truckloads of armed Japanese soldiers to pass through the French Concession.

Mrs. David M. Willard, champion of the Women's Chess Club of New York, and Miss Mathilda Harmath were again winners in the second round of the women's national championship preliminaries for the Hazel Allen Trophy at the Marshall Chess Club yesterday.

Additional reductions of 75 cents to $1 a suit will be made in the price of men's Fall clothing when lines are officially opened some time in April, according to manufacturers here yesterday. These new quotations are based on the assumption that suitings prices, to be named around March 15, will probably show substantial reductions below the last official list for Spring goods.

The promotion of Captain Peter Lagaay from command of the liner Volendam to the cruise liner Rotterdam was announced yesterday by F. Ra. Wierdsma, general manager of the Holland-America Line in New York. The promotion resulted from the assignment of Captain Johannes

IN conjunction with the Mac Dowell Colony League of Southem California, which is spon soring the third annual MacDowell Radio Festival, Georges Enesco and the Philharmonic-Symphony will present the distinguished American composer's symphonic poem "Lancelot and Elaine" as the opening work on this afternoon's program.

Miss Alice Mildred Carter and Philip Boyer Jr., both members of families long identified with the social and cultural life of this country, were married here this afternoon in Trinity Church by the Rev. Dr. Arthur Lee Kinsolving.

FOR a number of years America has been having alternate floods and droughts; surplus crops and crop shortages; excess materials and not enough houses; wage disputes and stock market gyrations; hunger and waste.

Buyers' arrivals in the wholesale market were heavy last week, and mail orders were correspondingly lower, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Co., resident buyers.

Artur Schnabel, pianist, will give his first American recital of the season Wednesday evening at Carnegie Hall. His appearance will be the fifth event in the Hurok Carnegie Hall series. Mr. Schnabel will play two toccatas of Bach, in C minor and D major; the Weber Fourth sonata

Almost one-third of the freshman registrations at Williams this year are in advanced courses, according to a report which reveals a broad liberalization of the first-year curriculum in the last four years.

When the Republican party leaders gather here Jan. 29 for their annual powwow and "love feast" banquet, and to do their slate-making for this year's State campaign, former Governor Landon will be only a sideline adviser and spectator.

The action of the stock market last week mirrored the perplexity, rather than gloom, that exists currently in trading circles over the chances for an early recovery in business. Trading was dull and prices drifted lower.

With retail sales throughout the country faring much better than was anticipated when initial Spring buying budgets were set up several weeks ago, the prospects for an upward revision in the near future of these budgets brightened last week, merchandising executives agreed here yesterday.

OF all the excellent and varied fare offered in Victor's special release of a few weeks back, nothing could be more welcome than the album containing Beethoven's Fourteenth quartet, in C sharp minor, Op. 131 (M-369). It is played by the ensemble organized by Adolf Busch, the same that supplied us with the Sixteenth quartet, Op. 135, a few months ago.

Purchase of about 2,500 acres of land in New Jersey, on which the American Telephone and Telegraph Company will construct its latest and most efficient type of transoceanic radio telephone receiving system, was announced yesterday.

Idlehour, country residence built by the late William K. Vanderbilt more than a third of a century ago at Oakdale, in Suffolk County, has been purchased by the Royal Fraternity of Master Metaphysicians and will be occupied by that organization as a retreat for study and rest. THE Scala opera season had its usual brilliant opening on the night of St. Stephen's with an elaborate new mounting of "Mefistofele"-a deviation from the traditional Verdi inaugural. It seems the idea was to combine spectacle with another homage to a historic milestone of Italy's lyric Ottocento. In any case, the choice of the familiar and faded Boito work reiterates the managerial conservatism here.

IN an old-fashioned dining room on the ground floor of the United States Capitol a group of Senators is gathered. From the vaulted ceiling depends a massive crystal chandelier, iridescent in the large gilt mirrors on the walls. Napery is laid with service plates, polished silver and carafes.

The State of Nebraska is giving the rest of the country a good example of avoiding in greater degree than any other State the evil effects of overtaxation. Nebraska alone has no income tax, no sales tax, no luxury tax. Its debt-free State Government levies nothing to pay interest on bonds because Nebraska's Constitution prohibits State bonds. On a thirty-six-acre tract fronting on Ashford Avenue, Sprain Road and Sprain Brook, in Ardsley, Westchester County, the Sprain Brook Manor Realty Company is planning to erect a group of 200 residences in the low-price field.

The volume of bonds called last week for payment before maturity continued small, the announcements being confined for the most part to redemptions of parts of municipal and foreign issues, continuing the trend of recent weeks.

Continued apartment house building in several New York boroughs has prevented the slump since the start of the year in various types of building products, such as boilers, radiators, kitchen and toilet equipment, etc., from being more serious, executives of building supply companies reported yesterday.

Rainy weather slowed business in the Eleventh Federal Reserve District during the week. Retailers advertised price reduction sales, but response was limited. Retail volume was slightly. below a year ago.

In celebration of the tenth anniversary of the founding of the McIntire School of Dramatic Art, the Virginia Players, the dramatic organization of the University of Virginia, will present "Julius Caesar" in modern dress on Feb. 2, 3 and 4 at the Minor Hall Theatre.

Important policies dealing with the future relations of the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization will be-adopted at the meetings of the Federation's Executive Council beginning in Miami on Monday, anil the convention of the United Mine Workers, which will be called to order in this city on Tuesday.

Having captured the world 18.2 balkline billiard title in a recent challenge match with Welker Cochran, Jake Schaefer will risk his 28.2 balkline championship against the same rival this week at the Strand Academy.

PINEHURST, N. C.-The most prominent social affair on the midseason program of this midsouth resort is the second annual Pinehurst midsouthern bridge tournament, which will' be held at the Carolina Hotel next Fridav and Saturday.

Fifty thousand students in American secondary schools, including two New York public high schools, have undertaken a course in propaganda analysis which calls for intensive scrutiny of newspapers, advertising, newsreels and radio in order to understand "numerous conflicts within our society."

The statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for Jan. 15 showed that the gold reserve ratio to notes in circulation was 123.84 per cent against 123.65 per cent on Dec. 31. In the fortnight the reserve ratio of gold to notes and sight liabilities rose to 87.43 per cent from 86.87 per cent.

William H. Friedman, a commissioner of the Authority for the new East River tunnel to Queens, warned yesterday that rising labor costs might force temporary or permanent cessation of work on the tube. Unless future contracts are based on present prices, he said, the project may be abandoned.
