Until dancing is eliminated from the annual President's birthday balls, the Clovis Ministerial Alliance intends to regard the whole business as "demoralizing."

Roger Turner of Boston and Miss Katherine Durbrow of Upper Montclair, N. J., tonight captured the men's and women's senior singles titles in the first annual Eastern amateur figure skating championship.
The annual report of Schoellkopf, Hutton Pomeroy, Inc., for 1937 shows total assets of $3,905,807 at the year-end, compared with $6,544,798 at the close of 1936.

Formation of a committee to raise an endowment fund of $7,000,000 to expand the facilities of Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken has been announced by Robert C. Stanley, chairman of the Stevens board of trustees. Mr. Stanley is chairman of the board of International Nickel Company of Canada.

A "Pioneers' Ball" will be given next Saturday night in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria to mark the eighty-eighth anniversary celebration of the St. John the Baptist Society of New York, which is said to be the oldest Frenchspeaking organization in the country.

FIFTY-ONE blind students had the first of a series of twelve contract bridge lessons Monday night at the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind at 172 East Ninety-sixth Street, with William E. McKenney and Alex M. Sobel as instructors and Sir Derrick J. Wernher as a guest speaker

Detective Captain Marshall C. Scrafford disclosed today that he was investigating the possibility that Rolphe Forsyth, who drowned in an unsuccessful attempt to blow up the Japanese liner Hiye Maru, left behind him a hidden dynamite cache.

An active Spring season for Long Island real estate is predicted by John H. Morris, president of the Long Island Real Estate Board, who expresses the opinion that there is every indication that Congress will accede to the wishes of business regarding the "correction" of the present tax schedules.

Although the United States has lodged formal protests through Ambassador Joseph C. Grew-in Tokyo, looting of American property by Japanese soldiers in Nanking continues, the State Department learned today from John M. Allison, American

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A period of great opportunity presents itself at this time of business recession, which I hope American business leaders will not fail to grasp. This opportunity is to place the operations of this process we call civilization on a workable basis.

HYPNOTIC POWER. By Colin Bennett. 158 pp. New YoTk: E. P. Dutton Co. $1.50. THIS is the third attempt of London authors within the last eight months to take the American public in their laps and to tell it all the mysteries and marvels of hypnotism.
Mexicans out of work in the United States and other countries who want to come home have little chance of doing so on governmentmoney.

Dr. Mary R. Lakeman of Swampscott, Mass., former president of the Association of Women in Public Health, has been appointed Northeastern Regional Director for the Women's Field Army of the American Society for the Conttol of Cancer. The announcement was made

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In a thoughtful and penetrating article on America as a field for regimentation, in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine of Jan. 16, James Truslow Adams deals with the frontier and frontier individualism in a manner that has become traditional with this generation of historians, especially east of the Hudson River.

IF the United States Senate follows the example set last week by the House of Representatives it will be good news for the law-abiding motor carriers of the country. The House, in the Independent Offices Appropriation Bill, approved an increase in the amount allowed to the Bureau of Motor Carriers of the Interstate Commerce Commission of more than $1,000,000 above last year's appropriation of $2,450,000. Hitherto, in the in-

IT is by his expert appreciations of musical compositions and performances that Ernest Newman has won his reputation. but one cannot help wishing at times that he had made literature his main concern instead. Occasionally his function

In an Eastern Private Schools Athletic League basketball game, Irving School routed Poly Prep, 23-11, today. Irving's strong defense held Poly to only one goal from the floor. Sherry and Allen starred, scoring 10 and 9 points respectively.

A listener, fascinated by the noble and audacious experiment made by the National Broadcasting Company in the engagement of Mr. Toscanini and the engagement of a brand new symphony orchestra to carry out his purposes, sometimes wishes to be in two places at once.
Of the 693 patents granted this week by the United States Patent Office the following are among those which attract interest for their ingenious and unusual angles:

More than three hundred exhibits depicting the latest devices in heating and ventilating facilities will be displayed in the fifth International Heating and Ventilating Exposition, opening tomorrow in the Grand Central Palace, Lexington Avenue and Forty-sixth Street, continuing through Friday night.

Three players from Philadelphia and one from Boston gained the semi-final round of the Atlantic Coast squash racquets championship today on the Haddon Hall courts, the seeding standing up to perfection.

One must go back to Napoleon to appraise the power and consequent responsibility given to General Marie Gustave Gamelin under the three new decrees coordinating national defense that Edouard Daladier, Vice- Premier and Minister of National Defense, announced yesterday.
The big event of the week was the wedding of Maggy Rouff's daughter to Viscomte Gerard de Dancourt. The bride wore an utterly simple gown in heavy mat white crepe.

Forty-three organizations affillated during the year will receive certificates from the Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations at the eighteenth annual convention on Wednesday at the Hotel Astor. Presentation will be made by Mrs. Isaac Gilman, president.

A strike of the Building Service Employes International Union against the fourteen-story apartment house at 152 East Ninetyfourth Street yesterday afternoon was quickly minimized by the management, who explained that the structure was equipped with two automatic elevators and an automatic oil-burner and that it virtually "managed itself" in the absence of service help.

Samuel Steckenberg and Abraham M. Fynke, trading as Colonial Ribbon Mills, 95 Madison Avenue, New York, have been ordered by the Federal Trade Commission to stop representing through use of the word "mills" that they are manufacturers or owners or operators of the mills that produce the products that they sell, the commission announced today.

WITH the annual Wagner matinee cycle virtually sold out, although it is almost a fortnight away, the management of the Metropolitan Opera is turning its attention to a series devoted to "Der Ring des Nibelungen" for the evening customers. Such a series has been
A sector of organized labor arranged today to challenge the right of John Milton of New Jersey to sit in the Senate.

With indoor seed sowing time just around the corner-in fact, already here for a few things, and for some extra-ambitious souls-the gardener checks up on his equipment and methods for starting seedling plants. While it is quite true that

BAUMAN-TACHNA-Mr. and Mrs. Max Tachna announce the engagement of their daughter, Ruth Candace. to Mr. Paul Bauman, son of Mr. and Mrs. M. S. Bauman. BERLAND-SPECTOR-Mr. Isidore Spector announces the engagement of his daughter, Jean, to Mr. Seymour Berland, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Berland.

Walter E. O'Hara, charging that a "hostile group" was attempting to seize control of the Narragansett race track, tonight appealed directly to stockholders to retain him as president and managing director.

WASHINGTON. --A million men who worked on the harvests last Fall are in cities, towns and villages this Winter. They are the army of field workers who follow the crops seasonally. Many were included in the unemployment census; some are on temporary Winter jobs; all await the stirring

The fourth annual Virginia Cotillion, a revival of the old Alexandria Assemblies held at Gadsby's Tavern, will take place at the George Mason Hotel here on Feb. 4. Members of society in Northern Virginia, Washington and Baltimore are subscribing to the event, at which several cotillion figures of decades ago will be danced by debutantes of the season and their escorts.

While reports of plant reopening and re-employment were given wide publicity, they indicate a less than seasonal expansion from the yearend contraction. Auto parts plants are reported to be working two or three days a week with only 50 per cent of the force required last year:

German penetration of Southeastern Europepolitically and economically-continues to make impressive headway. Just how much of this progress must be credited to an astute foreign policy and to what extent it has been facilitated by national evolutions and new policy orientations in those areas suggest a subject for profitable cogitation.

Four United States Army officers were killed tonight when their automobile crashed into a tree after a blowout. The dead were Captain Stuart M. Bevans, Captain George C. Ehrhardt, First Lieut. Milton A. Acklen and First Lieut. Henry B. Crosswell.

Miss Barbara Bain Colton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Harding Colton of 927 Madison Avenue, formerly of Stamford and Darien, Conn., was married to Walter Edward Schwab, son of Mrs. Henry Schwab of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Schwab, yesterday noon in the Church of the Transfiguration.

The defendants in the anti-trust trial ended here today were charged with conspiring to raise and fix Midwestern gasoline prices to jobbers (wholesalers) in 1935 and 1936 by a program of buying gasoline from independent refiners at progressively increasing prices.

IF I WERE YOU-Tomorrow evening at the Mansfield Theatre. A play by Benn W. Levy and Paul Hervey-Fox, deriving its idea from the late Thorne Smith's "Turnabout." Constance Cummings, Bernard Lee, Betty Field, J. Malcolm Dunn and Marie de Becker are in it.

THE publication of a new novel by Sinclair Lewis is still front-page literary news, but for several years past the news has been disappointing. It has never been more so than in the case of "The Prodigal Parents." If "It Can't Happen Here" was mediocre as a piece of creative writing,
Members of Le Theatre des Quatre Saisons have been asked to conduct a special diction course in French at Barnard College by Professor Frederic G. Hoffherr, head of the department.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, yesterday assailed the Industrial council for C. I. O. unions organized here on Friday night by representatives of C. I. O. affiliates. In a statement made public by Matthew Woll, vice president of the A. F. of L., Mr. Green declared that the organization of the C. I. O. council as a rival to the A. F. of L.

INTEREST has been revived recently in old whisky bottles and flasks. It is not today's bottles on which the eyes of the true collector are fixed; he seeks, rather, quaint "Jenny Lind" calabashes, rare "Booz" bottles, "Success to the Railroad" flasks and other specimens of early American craftsmanship, all of them long innocent of alcoholic content.

New records were established in the export of base metals from Canada in 1937, with sales of nickel, copper, lead and zinc reaching an all-time high of $146,914,300 in the twelve months ended in November, compared with $98,532,000 in the corresponding period a year before, according to compilations here.

A sunny Winter day behind the Teruel lines. Soldiers splashing in mountain streams, taking advantage of the sunny weather to bathe. A week ago, fighting in subzero weather, the cold was killing many of them.

" The Barber of Seville" returned to the Metropolitan repertory yesterday afternoon, and one of the largest audiences of the season delighted in the captivating opera. Public curiosity was keen concerning John Charles Thomas's first appearance here as Figaro.

The firm of Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., has been appointed agent for the Valeray Real Estate Company, Inc.; the Rayvale Realty Corporation and the Beauvais Realty Corporation, representing out-of-town interests. Among the properties owned by these corportions are approximately sixty buildings.

Miss Catherine Rita McCafferty, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Felix McCafferty of Brooklyn, will be married to Milton Francis Chartrand, son of Mr. and Mrs. Enos F. Chartrand, also of Brooklyn, next Sunday in the Holy Innocents Roman Catholic Church, Brooklyn.

The season of annual bank meetings, which came to a close last week, revealed a further growth in the trend among banks to make available details of their earnings and operations which a few years ago were commonly kept secret.

The girls' basketball team representing Hofstra College of N. Y. U. scored a 33-to-7 victory over the Upsala College women tonight in Calkin's gymnasium. The triumph was the third in four starts. Miss Louise Edelmann led the scorers with six field goals and a free toss for thirteen points.

Mrs. Franklin Delano Roosevelt, as principal speaker, will formally open the New York State Model Legislature of the American Youth Congress in the Great Hall of City College, 139th Street and Convent Avenue, next Friday evening.

Mexico will be the next State to Adopt a Nazi dictatorship, Lord Marley, chief Opposition whip in the House of Lords, declared last night before sailing on the French liner Lafayette after spending several months on a lecture tour in the United States and Canada.

C. Brewer Smith of this place has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Barbara Smith, to James MacKenzie Lister of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter S. Lister of Cleveland. The prospective bride was graduated in 1934 from Wellesley College. Mr. Lister is an alumnus of Harvard College, class of '29, and of the School of Architecture of Cornell University.

Eugene H. Lehman, president of the Westchester Branch of the Hudson River Conservation Society, made public today a nine-point program for beautifying the Hudson River, which he has sent in the form of a letter to Senator Erastus Corning, chairman of the Hudson Valley Survey Commission.

Heads mem of most of the diplomatic missions here and a few American officials were entertained at dinner at the Carlton Hotel tonight by the Secretary of State and' Mrs. Cordell Hull. The following were guests:

As this correspondent was returning to Saragossa late last night in an automobile with a French journalist, Antoine Boucher, and a Swiss photographer, Erich Tilgenkamp, we saw a small car, about 300 feet ahead, blown off the road by two explosions in rapid succession.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I was very much interested in the article by Assistant Secretary of State Sayre in THE TIMES Magazine. Some of the statements were,enlightening, but after reading the whole article I was somewhat confused about certain phases of the subject.

SEVERAL conclusions are likely to be reached by those who visit the exhibition of American landscape painting (18001900), which opened last week at the Whitney Museum-as well-considered and revealing an exhibition as has ever been put on there;

Miss Catharine Filor Lewis, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Orville N. Lewis of this place, was married here this evening in the Central Presbyterian Church to John Russell Wendt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Wendt of Pearl River. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Charles Ackerman.

The old home of Captain Joshua Edwards, one of Long Island's famous whaling captains, at Amagansett, has been purchased by Mrs. Merck Sheldon of this city. According to the brokers, Douglas Gibbons Co., she is planning to restore the old homestead, which has been vacant for several years, for occupancy and will give the property the name of "Whale-Off Farm."

DETAILS regarding a projected Peruvian series of historical and pictorial interest have been received from the South American Republic. Two portraits new to philately's gallery are' included among the designs.

The recent political upheaval in which President Getulio Vargas solidified and extended his personal control of Brazil has left a force in the country with which he or his successors may well have to deal in the future.

Members of the Little Mothers Aid Association will give a luncheon on Feb. 2 in the Assembly Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria, and later the group will attend a theatrical performance. The organization, which

Out of the conferences with industrialists and financiers with which President Roosevelt is now absorbed will arise, he hopes, not merely a cooperative effort to banish depression and welcome home the prodigal, prosperity, but the beginning of a new economic order for the nation. R. G.

Mail from far away places-Tasmania, the Tonga Islands, Pitcairn Island to which the Bounty mutineers fled, Mauritius Island, Norfolk Island, Northern Borneo and Southern Rhodesia-is received regularly by a faculty member at the Pennsylvania State College.

DORIS HUMPHREY and Charles Weidman and their company will, give their final New York performance of the season tonight at the Guild Theatre, when they will present two new group compositions for the first time.
High officials of the Methodist Episcopal Church today conducted funeral services at Copley Church for the Rev. Charles Wesley Burns, Methodist Episcopal Bishop for the Boston district.

Senator McKellar of Tennessee advocated today a ban on appointment of high-salaried officials' of independent agencies without approval of the Senate. He offered an amendment to the 'Appropriation Bill for operation of such agencies which would prohibit the use of

The navy has, as yet, no definite plans to increase the size of its new battleships: beyond the 35,000-ton limitation agreed upon among the United States, Great Britain and France at the London treaty of 1936.

MUMMERS and their miming are turning German cities into festive centers as the annual carnival season gets under way. Not only in Mainz, Cologne and Munich, where this Winter entertainment reaches extravagant proportions, but in hundreds of hamlets and mountain towns, staid citizens have thrown their caps over the moon and gone dancing in street and weinstube.

An unusual plan of informal adult education for New York housewives through reading and discussion groups is to have the aid of the New York and Brooklyn publie libraries, the Brooklyn Museum and a grant of $5,000 from the Carnegie Corporation during the coming year.

Kenneth C. Hogate and William B. Stitt will be candidates for Village Trustee in the March election here, according to nominations announced by the Scarsdale Non-Partisan Citizens' Committee. Mr. Hogate, a Republican, is president of Dow, Jones Co., publishers of The Wall Street Journal, and Mr. Stitt, a Democrat, is a New York attornev.
More than 300 hounds, representing thirty-four hunts, will be exhibited at the annual New York hound show, which will be given next Friday in the Squadron A Armory. The event will be held

A HUNDRED and fifty years ago a poet was born whom mankind throughout the Western World has acclaimed as an immortal. The interest in George Gordon Byron is cumulative; more is written about him today than ever before.

Senator Byrd said today that "we have tried spending ourselves into prosperity and it doesn't work." In a radio address the Virginian asserted: "Building an artificial prosperity upon a foundation of debt is as dangerous as building a house upon the sands."

Arsenal's reputation as one of soccer's great money teams reached a new high today. The famous Gunners, pitted against the Wolverhampton Wanderers in the feature of English Cup fourthround games, emerged with a lucky 2-1 victory on the ground where last week they retired beaten, 3-1, in a league battle.
Representative Maverick of Texas called upon "big business" tonight to respect its "freedom," which he described as "the greatest in the world."

It was officially announced today that the Czechoslovak Government intended to recognize the Spanish Insurgent regime de facto by sending a diplomatic agent to Insurgent territory, thus following the British example.

THE WILD GOOSE CHASE, by Rex Warner. (Knopf, $2.75.) An allegorical novel. TOMORROW'S BREAD, by Beatrice Bisno. (Liveright, $2.50.) The Edwin Wolf Prize Novel. MONPTI, by Gabor Vaszary. (Knopf, $2.50.) A light novel laid in Paris.

The German wholesale price index on Jan. 12stood at 105.5, against 105.6 on Jan. 5. The index for the cost of living in December was 124.8, which was only a half of a percentage point above that for December, 1936.

Twelve-year-old Howard Frankel was back in the home of his mother, Mrs. Rose Frankel, at 2,018 Voorhies Avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, after one more attempt to return to the place he has known as "home" for nearly five years.

Annual wage increases of $700,000 for workers in the children's and house dress industry of New York are stipulated in a new agreement negotiated by Local 91 of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union and the Industrial Association of Juvenile Apparel Manufacturers.

The China Clipper, far behind schedule because of manoeuvring incidental to a clogged fuel line, returned to her Alameda base today from San Pedro and was made ready for a take-off for Honolulu tomorrow, three days late.

Frederick B. Snite Jr., infantile paralysis victim, who has been confined in a metal "lung" nearly two years, is scheduled to speak tomorrow night on an international radio broadcast in behalf of his fellowsufferers.

The Rev. James F. Kane caught an alleged thief on Saturday evening in the Church of St. Francis de Sales, 135 East Ninety-sixth Street, after, the priest charged, he had watched him take forty cents from the poor box at the Shrine of St. Joseph.

The initial effort in organizing a movement for the construction of a "youth center" to serve 30,000 on the lower East Side took place yesterday afternoon at a conference of 200 East Side young people, between the ages of 16 and 25, who met in the Grand Street Playhouse to plan their campaign.
More than a score of new exhibitions, including museum events, group shows and one-man attractions, are added to the calendar with announcements for the present week.

Authoritative sources in the National Assembly reported today that they understood that Commonwealth President Manuel Quezon had offered the Standard-Vacuum Oil Company a contract to explore and develop potential oil fields in the Philippines.

Unless there is a united church and the competitive rivalry resulting in futile and unreasonable denominational cleavages is done away with, there can be no more great victories for the church, the Rev. Dr. Eugene C. Carder, the associate pastor, said yesterday in his morning sermon at the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.
The Baltimore Orioles scored early and set up an almost impregnable defense tonight to defeat the Bronx Tigers, 2 to 1, in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League game.

Frank R. Kelly, American skeet team captain, and Carl L. Schweinler of West Orange successfully defended their Eastern open two-man skeet championship through a day of sennational shooting at the Loantaka Club today.

Dishes from many lands were served by the Gourmet Society yesterday at an "International Dinner" in the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn. Consonant with the foreign flavor of the affair was the society's first trip across the East River-an expedition devoted to a study of table manners in distant lands and remarkable for the fact that Emily Post spilled her Swedish lingenberries and spent most of the three hours with her elbows on the table.
Slingin' Sam Baugh and bulky George Smith of the Washington Redskins strapped a 13-0 defeat on the Chicago Bears in a muddy professional football game today.
A new club for boys and youths, aged 15 to 22, in which every member is at least a director and there are no dues, was in operation yesterday, in its four-story clubhouse at 411 West 134th Street.

Sixty artists picketed the Pennsylvania Museum of Art today, but their aim was to urge the public to visit the show they were picketing. They apparently succeeded in stimulating attendance. Their complaint, in connection with the exhibit of 150 WPA paintings arranged by Miss Mary Curran, a project supervisor, and Fiske Kimball, director of the museum, was that WPA shows were held much too infrequently.

The following were the best sellers for the week ended Saturday: NEW YORK Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Bookshops, Gimbel Brothers, R. H. Macy, Charles Scribner's Sons, John Wanamaker and Womrath Book Shops and Libraries:

The current business situation here contains conflicting factors which make for some uncertainty concerning the future. The moderate recession is more noticeable in consumers' goods industries than in capital goods lines, but in no direction has there been any really serious setback.

Rabbi Jonah B. Wise of New York was elected chairman of the 1938 fund raising campaign in the United States and Canada for the relief and reconstruction of Jews overseas at a meeting today of the Plan and Scope Committee of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee. The national quota was set at $5,100,000.

The uncertain outlook in France and the international steel cartel's price cuts, which German opinion opposed, were bear influences on this week's markets and active subscribing to the Reich loan, although in itself a favorable factor, checked trading in stocks. which declined slightly.

Simpson St (11-2974), ws, 77 ft n of Home St, 100x100; 1,211-15 Simpson St, Inc. to Harry Molodinoff, 795 Garden St; mtg, $107,000. Tremont Ave (11-2867), s w cor of Grand Ave, 92x59; Katherine J. McGovern to Benjamin Milstein, 158 Bush St.

Senate Majority Leader Alben W. Barkley today formally announced his candidacy for re-election to the Senate. The announcement followed a big testimonial dinner given in his honor Saturday during which Marvin H. McIntyre, secretary to President Roosevelt, read a letter from the President praising Mr.

Bob Feller, young Cleveland strikeout king, said today he had reached an agreement with the Indians on his 1938 contract. Feller returned 'the first contract mailed to him last week with the explanation he was "not a holdout," but wanted to have several minor details adlusted.

Joseph Brown of Philadelphia, former Temple University boxing captain and for a short time a professional light-heavyweight, has been named instructor in boxing at Princeton University, It was announced today by Dr. Wilbur H. York.
The bodies of four United States Army officers who were killed in an automobile accident Saturday will be brought to Manila for funeral services Tuesday.

Representatives of Puerto Rico's business, industrial and professional organizations today made an urgent appeal to President Roosevelt for his prompt intervention to end the waterfront strike, which they term a blockade more effective than warfare, endangering the very economic life of the island.

The foreign exchange market was extremely nervous as the week drew to a close. Not only did a huge demand for foreign currencies cause an appreciable rise in quotations for cash and delivery, but at times there was a disparity between quotations here and abroad.

Dr. Henry H. Donaldson, noted neurologist, who for thirty-two years had directed neurological research at the Wistar Institute, an auxiliary division of the University of Pennsylvania, died of pneumonia today at his home in West Philadelphia at the age of 80.

The need for moral and spiritual power in the world of today was stressed by the Rev. Dr. Frederick F. Shannon, pastor of the Central Church of Chicago, in his sermon yesterday at the sixtieth anniversary service of Grace Methodist Episcopal Church, Seventh Avenue and St. John's Place, Brooklyn. Dr. Shannon was pastor of the church from 1904 to 1910.

Liquidation developed in January lard contracts last week and prices fell to about 80 cents under the May delivery, the largest discount prevailing at this time of the year since 1920, when the spread approximated $1 a hundred pounds.

The ninth concert of the New Friends of Music season at the Town Hall yesterday had elements of distinction that placed it among the finest this organization has presented. There were two Mozart chamber works which, because they require wind instruments, are rarely heard, and there was Schumann's "Dichterliebe" cycle which is not often sung in full in the course of a season of public concerts.

A plea to American Jewry to align itself with the friends of democracy and not with those elements of "special economic interest" which in other lands fostered the rise to power of non-democratic and anti-Semitic groups was delivered today by Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, before the National Conference of the United Palestine Appeal.

Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch returned from Berlin today and was welcomed by members of the Cabinet and other officials.. The Yugoslav press stresses that all rumors that Yugoslavia will join the antiComintern pact or recognize General Francisco Franco's Rebel Spanish Government de jure are absolutely unfounded.

Harriet Thompson, formerly with Pease Elliman, Inc., has opened a real estate office at 52 Vanderbilt Avenue. Samuel Fiske Pierson now is associated with his father, Samuel N., in a larger realty office at 65 Broad Street, Stamford, Conn.
William J. Cameron of the Ford Motor Company declared in a radio address tonight that legislation aimed at "big" industry would strike "small" industry also. The two, he said, could not be separated.

The Hawaiian Islands, shaken last night by the "worst earthquake in eleven years," found today that minor damage, such as the breaking of crockery and the falling of plaster, had been done throughout the islands.

Charles C. Read, 71 years old, New Jersey Superintendent of Weights and Measures, was overcome by carbon monoxide fumes this morning in a garage at the rear of his home at 1,019 Wesley Avenue here. A physician and four policemen worked over him for nearly an hour with an inhalator before he was revived.

Walter Hampden, Otis Skinner, Christopher Morley and several hundred other people who remember Don Marquis fondly, met last night at the Ambassador Theatre for an informal benefit, the proceeds of which will go to the estate of the late humorist and playwright.

The board of governors of the Investment Bankers Association closed its midwinter meeting at the Seaview Golf Club, Absecon, near here, today, and many left for New York to attend a session of the Investment Bankers Conference in the Waldorf-Astoria tomorrow.

The constitution of the new Chautemps Cabinet was received with satisfaction in financial circles because at the end of last week there were possibilities of a Socialist ministry coming into power, with the participation of Communists who would have brought in important changes affecting the general economic and monetary policies and also the foreign policy.

By its actions the Bourse showed this week that it was not fully reassured as to the duration of the tenure of the new government. The tendency at the beginning of the week was favorable to the rentes and French securities, with foreign stocks heavy.

A field of broken mush ice that drifted out across the course during the final race failed to stop the large fleet of Frostbite dinghies that raced on Manhasset Bay today, but it made them do some fancy dodging to get across the finish line.

Christmas business brought an increase of 12.9 per cent in employment and 10 per cent in payrolls last month in retail stores in New York State, Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner, announced today.

Making one of his rare benefit appearances, George M. Cohan stopped the show last evening at the Imperial Treatre, where the Actors Fund of America gave its fiftysixth annual entertainment before a crowded house. The receipts are expected to be announced today.
Stocks lower, erasing gains of the preceding week; turnover, 4,726,601 shares. United States Government and foreign issues irregular; rail bonds sharply lower; transactions, $42,271,150.

Raymond Ketcham and Casper G. Lennertz are with Campbell, Phelps Co. Levin R. Marshall has been admitted to general partnership in Cohu Brothers. Horace E. Hoffman and Leonard L. Maher have formed Hoffman Maher to transact a brokerage business specializing in government securities at 40 Wall Street.
Aubrey Wells and his Keene Valley Mountaineers broke the single heat United States record for the mile on the Mount Van Hoevenberg run today to win the Lithgow Osborne four-man bobsled trophy.

The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 77.2 on Jan. 19, compared with 77.8 a fortnight before, 77.2 on Dec. 15 and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

Scoring twice in the final half, the Philadelphia German-Americans defeated the Brooklyn Hispanos, 3-2, in an American Soccer League game today. George Newchek made the deciding goal on a pass from Dick Henry.

" The tragic inconsistency" of rejecting the doctrine of racialism as practiced by Germany, Poland and Rumania and accepting the same doctrine in reference to the Jews in Palestine was condemned yesterday morning by Dr. Samuel H. Goldenson in his sermon at Temple Emanuel-El, Fifth Avenue at Sixtyfifth Street.
The singer Paul Robeson and his wife arrived in Barcelona today for a ten-day visit to Loyalist Spain, during which they hope to go to Madrid and to Teruel. Mr.

The automobile brake service station at 4,546-48 Hudson Boulevard, corner of Forty-second Street, Union City, N. J., has been sold by the New Jersey Title Guarantee and Trust Company to Max D. Emerman, tenant for the last seven years. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broke.

The money market here remained narrow this week by reason of the recent exports of capital and the fact that the greater part of the funds available was used for continuing forward transactions in foreign exchanges.

Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin R. Kittredge Jr. have left the SavoyPlaza to visit Mr. Kittredge's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin R. Kittredge, at Dean Hall Plantation, Oakley, S. C. They will go later to Mexico. Mrs. Walton Ferguson of the Berkshire has gone to her Winter home in Camden, S. C.
Another move northward is made by the Aeolian Company, which has leased about half of the former Chickering Building at 27-29 West Fifty-seventh Street from the Phipps Estates.

The Nicaraguan team selected to compete in the Central American Olympic Games in Panama includes five executives and managers, a masseur, a cook, two stewards, eighteen baseball players, twelve basketball stars, twelve track and field men and four swimmers.

Released twice from the death house in Sing Sing while awaiting execution, Michael Alex, 27 years old, of 1,944 First Avenue, a former East Side gangster, found himself in the shadow of the electric chair again yesterday as he faced charges in two murders.

The cotton market here was only moderately active last week. Early in the week uncertainty concerning the fate of the Farm Control Bill in Congress, discussion of the recession in trade, the unsettled political situation in France and the wars in Spain and China tended to depress prices.

Scientific discovery has verified one of the most amazing miracles narrated in the Old Testamentthe stopping of the sun in the heavens as told in the Book of Joshuathe Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer, the pastor, said yesterday morning in his sermon at the Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Taking advantage of the unusual lull in Anglo - German recriminations, a group of bankers in the City of London has been making new efforts in the past few days to extend British credits and other economic help to Germany.

In announcing its opposition to the Norris and Mansfield bills for the creation of regional power authorities the Merchants Association of New York proposed yesterday the establishment of a national 1 planning agency on a permanent basis to replace the present temporary National Resources Committee.

State Department officials are compiling indemnity charges to be forwarded to Japan as a result of the sinking of the gunboat Panay on the Yangtze River in December. The indemnity to be asked is expected to total between $1,000,000 and $1,500,000, it was learned.
A battalion of American volunteers in the Spanish civil war was reported today to have wiped out two squadrons of Generalissimo Francisco Franco's Moorish cavalry on the Teruel front.

Appointment of John J. McGinty of Bay City, Mich., as national director of the Young Democratic Clubs of America, was announced today, along with the naming of sixteen regional directors and the following national officers:

AT the center of the stage and in the limelight sits the solemn Hirohito, Japan's incarnate god, veiled so that profane eyes may not offend. Spaced at discreet intervals about him are members of his government, the Minister of War and the Minister of Marine nearest his right and his left hand, respectively.

Optimism tempered with caution has characterized action in the wholesale market since the Spring openings. Buyers were in town in good number last week to view Spring lines, and although volume of orders was under last year's in most fields many stores will send buyers on second trips to the market within a month.

Gee's Restaurant, Inc, two stores at 404-6 W. 14th St.; Lillian Michell, store at 19 8th Ave; Van Vliet Place, brokers. John J. Casano, in 100 5th Ave; Marc Hermelin, attorney, in 274 Madison Ave; Scientific Diathermy Corp, in 200 W. 34th St; H. H. Dress Co, in 40 W 27th St; Carstens, Linnekin Wilson, brokers.

Eddie Wares, rookie forward, playing his second game with Detroit's Red Wings, accounted for the winning goal for the second successive time tonight to give the home team a 3-2 National Hockey League victory over the New York Americans before 9,750 spectators.

Before the Business Advisory Council meeting at the White House last week, there was a regular anti-administration rebellion among the fifty business leaders friendly to the New Deal who compose the council. More than forty of them determined to resign if the President did not retract the "sixty families"
Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 30 per cent of capacity, up 1 point in the week and up 11 points from the recent low level in the last week of December.

Miss Nancy Hancock, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Boyd Hancock of Paris, Ky., has chosen Feb. 28 for her marriage to Douglas Farley Cox Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Cox of Llewellyn Park, West Orange. The ceremony will take place in the Presbyterian Church at Paris.
The list of the Hamburg-American motor ship St. Louis due tonight from the Channel ports, includes Dr. Richard Bottler, attach of the German Consulate General in New York;
Beginning today, the Charity Organization Society will increase food allowances 41/2 per cent for all families with children. This will add $4,800 a year to the expenses of the agency.
A prediction that the American Labor party will not nominate a candidate for the Presidency in 1940, but will be able to dictate the choice by holding the balance of power, was made last night by B.

Four hundred executives of industry, finance, utilities, railroads, steamship lines and other transportation interests will convene Wednesday at the Hotel Warwick in Philadelphia for a two-day meeting of the Atlantic States Shippers Advisory Board.

With her first "red duster"-the British merchant marine ensignflapping idly from her stern staff, a smaller American flag flying from the cross-tree of her bobbed foremast, and a wisp of rusty smoke drifting from her forward funnel, the Leviathan still lay at her Hoboken berth yesterday.
Nils Ele of Norway, one of the world's most versatile skiers, gave a remarkable exhibition of control in his second effort to annex premier honors in the Telemark Ski Club's invitation jump today.

Outside interest in the oats market on the Board of Trade last week was small, and no sales of the July or September deliveries were reported on Thursday or yesterday. The May closed with a gain of /s8 cent in the week at 32 cents a bushel.

Jesus' greatest contribution to social history was the discovery of the common people, the Rev. John Walter Houck, pastor of Pilgrim Congregational Church, Grand Concourse at 175th Street, the Bronx, declared in his sermon there yesterday morning.

For the fourth consecutive year Dr. John R. Huffman, Assistant Professor of Engineering at New York University and a representative of the New York A. C., defeated Jose R. de Capriles of Salle Santelli in the final round to carry off the national three-weapon fencing championship on the strips of the Fencers Club yesterday. The score was 10-5.

Goals by Frank Donnelly and Gino Genchi in the third period enabled the Brooklyn Bruins to down the Columbia Lions, 4 to 3, in a New York Amateur Hockey Association game at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night.

The Reich's debt, omitting undisclosed bill liabilities, was reported this week for November last, at 17,655,000,000 marks, against 15,245,000,000 in November, 1936. At the same time the Reich's foreign debt amounted to 1,359,000,000 marks, against 1,459,000,000 a year before.

Jimmy Thomson of Shawnee-onDelaware, Pa., banged his way into the lead of the $3,000 Pasadena open golf competition today. He and Byron Nelson sailed through the third round of the tournament with cards of 64, seven strokes under par for the Brookside course.
There was no material change last week in the outlook for the Winter wheat crop. Parts of Northern Kansas, Nebraska and Oklahoma received some moisture but too little to be of appreciable benefit.

Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott announced yesterday that the fire loss for New York City during 1937 was the lowest in twentythree years. It was $5,978,267, a decrease of $1,745,363 from 1936. The per capital loss for the year was 84.4 cents, compared to $1.05 for 1936.

The funeral of Mrs. Cora Pynchon Mallory, widow of Henry Rogers Mallory, was largely attended at her home, Bonnie Cliff, Byram Shore, this afternoon. The simple service was conducted by the Rev. Albert J. M. Wilson, rector of Christ Episcopal Church, Greenwhich.

Intensive bombing by airplanes on both sides marked the war in Spain yesterday. A Loyalist squadron made a retaliatory raid on Seville. It war reported the previous attack on Salamanca had caused 225 deaths and that barracks housing German volunteers had been destroyed.

Dr. Otto Leyton, specialist in diabetes, died here yesterday at the age of 64. Originally named Ottawa Frankau, he assumed the name of Leyton by deed poll in 1915. Dr. Leyton was physician to the London Hospital.

With the loan of William Dieterle to Walter Wanger to direct "The River Is Blue," with Madeleine Carroll and Henry Fonda, Warners have postponed their contemplated filming of "The Patriot," the story of Maximilian and Carlotta, to which Dieterle was assigned last week. The Wanger work is scheduled to start by midFebruary, an incident that will launch Wanger's second year of his ten-year contract with United Artists.

By working ceaselessly during all his spare time, Georges Enesco has completed a new score in time to conduct it in his final Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra concert this season at Carnegie Hall next Sunday. The music was handed to the copyist sheet by sheet. Mr. Enesco has dedicated the score, his third orchestral "Suite Villageoise," in D major, to the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra.

The body of Andrew Furuseth, 83-yearold president of the International Seamen's Union, lay in state from noon to 3 P. M. today in the government auditorium. Associates in the labor movement and government officials who had known "The Old Viking" during the many years he had championed the cause of American seamen, filed past the bier in final tribute.

When an audience leaves a dance recital laughing gayly, as Doris Humphrey's and Charles Weidman's audience left the Guild Theatre last night, that is news. As if deliberately to prove that the modern dance is not necessarily devoted to solemnity, both dancers ostentatiously snubbed the tragic muse and went in for unabashed hilarity.
Jesus was the great liberal of all time, the Rev. Dr. Minot Simons said yesterday morning in his sermon at the All Souls Unitarian Church, Lexington Avenue and Eightieth Street.

The Garden City Casino and the Westport Club kept their slates clean in the Metropolitan Badminton Association's Men's Class A team tournament over the weekend. The Long Islanders, setting the. pace in the division, turned back the New York Badminton Club, 5 to 0, for their fifth straight victory, while Westport registered its fourth triumph in a row by van quishing the Central first team, 3 to 2.

Brookhattan of the American Soccer League eliminated the Hatikvoh S. C. from the National Challenge Cup competition in their first-round contest at Starlight Park in the Bronx yesterday, 4 to 1. A crowd of 5,000 enjoyed the game, which was well played considering the muddy field.

The Scots-Americans and the Passon Phillies played to a 2-2 tie in an American Soccer League championship fixture at Scots Field today. The first half was scoreless. B. Aitken was credited with the Scots' two tallies, while Murphy and Doran shot a goal apiece for the Passon Phillies.

Local industries increasingly complain that the concentration of capital and labor for the four-year plan has begun to operate detrimentally. It is reported that Western municipalities have made representations in this sense to the Ministry of Economics.

Andrew Furuseth, who died on Siturday at the age of 84, was a labor leader who earned and deserved the respect of employers. From men who followed the sea before the mast he had something like reverence. Not even his bitterest opponents could justly accuse him of a single selfish personal motive.

Moe Frankel's one-handed shot with six seconds to play gave the Jersey Reds a 34-to-32 triumph over the New York Celtics in the American Basketball League game that featured a triple-header before 3,000 at the Hippodrome last night. In the afternoon the Celtics beat the Reds, 33 to 17, at Union City, N. J.
The Frigidaire division of General Motors Sales Corporation is moving ahead its 1938 advertising schedule and on Feb. 22 will Launch a year's campaign in newspapers, magazines, outdoor and radio.

Rumanian business is virtually at a standstill as a result of panic among Jewish merchants and general uncertainty in the country under the new nationalistic, antiSemitic regime of Premier Octavian Goga, it became apparent today.

Governors of oil-producing States, or their representatives, will open a three-day conference here tomorrow for a general review of the oil situation. The conference was called by Governor E. W. Marland of Oklahoma. Governor Carl E. Bailey of Arkansas is the official host.

Dr. John R. Huffman, Wallace Goldsmith, Samuel T. Stewart, Leo Nunes and Nickolas Muray, New York A. C.; Norman Armitage and Hugh Alessandroni, Fencers Club; E. A. Berumen, James Flynn, Rudolph Ozol, Norman Lewis, Migel de Capriles, Jose de Capriles, Anthony Orsi, Kevis Kapner and Albert Ferro, Salle Santelli.

The outlook for the Winter cereal crops of Germany is reported to be fairly good, although in some places damage has been caused by floods. The Reich's net importation of wheat in 1937 was 1,219,000 tons, against 26,000 in 1936.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. announced today that they would award six post-doctorate and eighteen post-graduate fellowships at eighteen colleges and universities for the academic year 1938-39 to encourage research in chemistry.

A $180,000,000 program of public works and educational, recreational and white-collar activities to be carried on in this city with relief labor has been drafted by Mayor La Guardia and Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, it became known yesterday.

The Seagrave Corporation of Columbus, Ohio, manufacturers of motor fire fighting equipment, was exonerated today by the National Labor Relations Board through dismissal of charges by the United Automobile Workers of America that it had resorted to unfair labor practices.
Those who realize the difficulties that Dr. Ellice McDonald, director of the Biochemical Foundation, had to overcome in carrying out his methods of cancer research will rejoice that the

Former Governor George White, chairman of the Democratic National Committee in 1920, announced today that he would enter the Democratic primary for the nomination for Senator to succeed Robert J. Bulkley. He was a candidate four years ago and lost to Senator Donahey.

The revolutionary left wing group of Socialists gained a victory over Leon Blum's adherents in the Socialist Federation of the Seine District tonight, when they obtained a majority on the commission that will draft resolutions of policy for the federation's congress.

John O. Seys, vice president of the Chicago Cubs and one of the oldest executives active in baseball, died tonight of pneumonia after a week's illness. His age was 66. He had been in an oxygen tent at Edgewater Hospital since last Thursday.

To perpetuate the memory of Dr. Oliver Perkins Terry, for many years head of the student health service at Purdue University, his widow has given the university $30,000, it was announced today by President Edward C. Elliott.

ALL-AMERICA TEAM 60-Meter Run-Ben Johnson, Columbia University. 100-Meter Run-Perrin Walker. New York A. C 200-Meter Run-Jack Weiershauser, Olympic Club. San Francisco. 400-Meter Run-Ray Malott, Olympic Club, San Francisco. 600-Meter Run-Edward O'Brien, Syracuse University. 800-Meter Run-John Woodruff, University of Pittsburgh.

Although the Chinese Communists are cooperating with the government against Japan, General Peng Teh-Huai, vice commander of the Eighth Army, said in an interview at Nanking that they still sought an agrarian revolution.

Tommy Clement, last year's. ski captain at Williams College, competing for the Amateur Ski Club, took the honors in the second annual New York City Interclub ski meet today on the Bromley run. He won both the downhill and slalom tests.

George H. Reppert Jr. of Montclair, N. J., has been elected business manager of The Daily Princetonian, Princeton University newspaper, it was announced today by Frank W. Rounds Jr. of Winchester, Mass., retiring chairman of the publication.

While the stimulation of exports of American agricultural products to the United Kingdom resulting from a satisfactory reciprocal trade agreement with Great Britain is "the crux of the trade agreement problem," many obstacles stand in the way of concluding the negotiations, according to the current report of the Foreign Policy Association.

Bright sunny skies and moderate temperatures brought a touch of Spring to the city yesterday, luring many motorists to the road and many walkers to the parks. It was the first full day of above-freezing weather since Jan. 7.

The national champion, Harry F. Wolf of the Montclair A. C., seventime winner here, and Rowland B. Haines of the Columbia University Club, who has held the title three times, reached the semi-final of the sixteenth annual New Jersey squash tennis tourney at the Short Hills Club today.

The proposed consolidation of Locals 102 and 45 of the International Hod Carriers, Building and Common Laborers Union of America was voted down by members of Local 102 in an election yesterday afternoon at Germania Hall, 160 Third Avenue, held by direction of Supreme Court Justice Salvatore Cotillo.

President James B. Conant of Harvard University, in his annual report to the Board of Overseers, calls attention to an "evident danger" in the unemployment of university men in this country. "It seems evident," he writes, "that we are in danger of reaching the condition already so acute on the continent of Europe where the problem of unemployment in the learned professions demands attention even in countries racked by political and economic troubles.

More than 20,000 Negroes have joined the Communist party and others will join "when 2,000,000 cotton-picking Negroes are put on the economic scrap heap," the Rev. Dr. Mark A. Dawber, secretary of the Protestant Home Missions Council, declared in a sermon yesterday at the Metropolitan Temple Methodist Episcopal Church, Seventh Avenue and Thirteenth Street.

Jamshed D. Engineer of India is an engineer. He received his degree last year from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute at Troy, N. Y., were he was known as Jamshed D. Mistry. He said he adopted his new name because in India, "Mistry" means "engineer."

A temporary break at least in the Senate filibuster against the Anti-Lynching Bill was predicted today by leaders on Capitol Hill. The House last week passed the housing measure as it came from conference, and it is expected that the Senate leadership will ask for its consideration tomorrow under the special privilege rule governing conference measures.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 83.4, which compares with 83.9 a week ago, 83.2 two weeks ago, 83.1 three weeks ago and 83.2 four weeks ago.

Nine explosions, one minute apart, wrecked the interior of the du Pont synthetic rubber plant here today, resulting in the death of two workmen and the serious injury of another. The body of one of the victims had not been found tonight. The loss to the company was estimated at $400,000.

The general wholesale price averages in France of imported products and industrial materials could not be calculated for the week ended on Jan. 15 because of the closing of the foreign exchange market and the absence of prices for precious metals.

A youth suspected of eleven gasoline station robberies since Jan. 8 was in custody here today after an early morning capture by a private detective sixty pounds lighter and eight and a half inches shorter.

Not all of the 79,000 oil wells in Texas were closed today in compliance with the Railroad Commission's order to shut down on Sundays. Score of special permits to keep wells on reduced production to prevent them from being killed by water encroachment were hurriedly granted by the commission.

It is by this time no secret that the organization Democrats in the City Council are in a minority. There are, at most, thirteen of them. Counting Chairman Newbold Morris, who in case of a tie casts the deciding vote, there are fourteen non-organization Democrats and Fusionists. But apparently the clubhouse Councilmen will leave no stone unturned to defeat the desires of the electorate.

Dr. Emanuel Lasker, former world champion, yesterday was adjudged the winner of his adjourned exhibition game against consulting opponents at the Manhattan Chess Club. The decision, made by Isaac I. Kashdan after an analysis of the position,

The Phoenix Mutual Life Insurance Company had $644,629,000 insurance in force at the close of last year, Arthur M. Collens, president, announced yesterday. This was a gain of $34,130,000 over the insurance in force on Dec. 31, 1936, and ii a new high record.

One hundred years ago tonight Samuel Finley Breese Morse stood before a group of distinguished Americans in New York University on Washington Square and pressed the key of a strange instrument that made monotonous. clicking sounds. Over ten miles of wire flashed this strange message: "Attention, the Universe! By Kingdoms, Right Wheel!"

An enthusiastic audience of more than 1,200 persons packed Veronica's Veil Auditorium here this afternoon to see the closing performance of "The Seal of Confession," a religious play written by Mgr. F. G. Holweck and presented by the Veronica's Veil Players.

The directors of the Sun Oil Company have adopted a program of plant expansion and development involving about $11,000,000 in capital expenditures in 1938, J. Howard Pew, president, announced yesterday. Virtually all expenditures will be made at the company's principal refineries at Marcus Hook, Pa., and Toledo, Ohio.

In a series of concerts which have impressed the public always the more with his profound musicianship and orchestral control Georges Enesco has seldom equaled the effect of the concert he gave yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall with the New York PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra. When Mr.
Announcement is made today by the American Viscose Corporation that 'it is readjusting its' acetate yarn prices to conform with the current lower market quotations, effective immediately.

All the boxes and seats taken over for the ice revue tonight at Madison Square Garden for the benefit of the Children's Village have been sold. The event will feature Sonja Henie and a Hollywood ballet of skaters.

The New York police force was asked yesterday to take part in a search for an antique cherrywood desk stolen from the home of Minnie A. Thomas at 34 Circular Street, Saratoga, N. Y. The police at Saratoga asked the police here to make a search of antique shops throughout the city.
The New York Rangers were slow getting started in their National Hockey League game with the Montreal Maroons at Madison Square Garden last night.

Plans have been completed for the wedding of Miss Alice Schroder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Schroder of East Orange, to Alexander J. Geiges, also of East Orange. The ceremony will take place the evening of Feb. 5 in Bethel Presbyterian Church here with the pastor, the Rev. Alexander Macauley, officiating.

The establishment of an American record at the new distance of 150 yards for the medley swim featured an aquatic carnival at the Women's Swimming Association pool yesterday. The record-maker was Miss Helene Rains, 13-year-old star of the W. S. A., who turned is a neat 1:56.3 to post new short course figures.

Paul Waner, outfielder of the Pirates and southpaw golf champion, today won the annual baseball players' golf tournament. Playing a par game, Waner defeated Jack Russell, veteran American League pitcher, released by Detroit last Fall, 6 and 5, in the final match.

The President's eagerness to have the Ludlow War Referendum Bill defeated was described as "proof of the first dangerous trend away from democracy in the Roosevelt administration" in a speech here tonight by Norman Thomas, Socialist leader.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,070,985,500. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.
Money continues extraordinarily easy here and this condition should obtain for the time being, although the current quarter will witness the usual heavy movement of tax funds.

The Maritime Commission, of which Joseph B. Kennedy has been chairman, reiterated today that "chaotic labor conditions" prevailed in the shipping industry. In a report submitted to Congress by Joseph P. Kennedy as chairman, and dealing with its activities during the year ended Oct. 25, the commission said:

New paid-for business of forty companies having 82 per cent of the total life insurance outstanding in all United States legal reserve concerns at the close of 1937 amounted to $8,991,807,000, against $8,651,636,000 on Dec. 31, 1936,
The Class I railroads placed on the rails last year 75,058 freight cars which they bought or manufactured or rebuilt in their own shops, according to the Association of American Railroads.

Social implications, possibly more far reaching even than the evidently important economic ones, lie behind the announcement on Wednesday by General Motors Corporation of its entry into mass production in the Diesel engine field.

Michael L. Igoe, former Representative at Large and now Federal District Attorney in Chicago, has decided to run for the Senate. His announcement will be made soon. Mr. Igoe sent word of his decision today to down-State leaders, who for several months have been urging him to enter the Democratic primary on April 12.

A number of important decisions will have to be made concerning the future course of radio broadcasting in the United States, which require development of a soundly based public policy, T. A. M. Craven, member of the Federal Communications Commission, said in a report on "the social and economic aspects of radio broadcasting," published today.

Alexander P. Gest, a retired official of the Pennsylvania Railroad, died yesterday at his home here in his eighty-fifth year. A native of this city, he joined the railroad as a surveyor's chainman after his graduation from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in 1874.

Harry Davis Ives, a retired architect who was associated for many years with McKim, Mead White, died at his home here today after a long illness. His age was 75. Owing to his illness, he had not followed his usual custom of late years of spending the Winter in Somerset, Bermuda.

Pages of history were turned back to the middle of the eighteenth century on the stage of the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria last evening when "A Night in the Palace of Prince Esterhazy" was presented by members of society and a group of distinguished musicians.
